title: Kurtz & Tarlow
description: Kurtz & Tarlow is going to be doing advertising for LJN Toys of New York, whose major offerings are Rough Riders, toy four-wheel-drive vehicles, and Whip-It, a puzzle. Don Kurtz, president, said that the billings, which were $2 million when handled in-house, could soar to $6 million during the coming year. Advertising placement, he said, will be handled by Ed Libov Associates.

title: Chevron Will Finance A New Moyers Series
description: A new television series, ''Creativity With Bill Moyers,'' presented by WNET-TV, Channel 13, for distribution on the Public Broadcasting Service, has received a $3.5 million grant from Chevron U.S.A.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Ogilvy & Mather has decided to put its West Coast operation - Los Angeles and San Francisco - under the leadership of a single person, Hal Riney, who has been named to the new position of executive vice president-west and also to the overall board.

title: French Banks Lower Prime
description: Three French banks said today that they were lowering their basic, or prime, lending rate to 15.9 percent from 17 percent, effective tomorrow.

title: TRIPLING OF COSTS IS CITED IN A REACTOR PROJECT
description: A company that contracted to supply 11 steam generators to the Clinch River Breeder Reactor project for $57 million has renegotiated its agreement to supply just two, but at nearly triple the original price for all 11, a Congressional investigator said today.

title: Court of Appeals Clears Way For Carolina Integration Plan
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today cleared the way for the Secretary of Education to approve a proposed consent decree that would establish a desegregation plan for North Carolina's university system.

title: Commuters in Jersey Face Fare Rise Today
description: Commuters boarding N.J. Transit trains tomorrow morning will have to pay an average of 25 percent more to ride the line. Riders also will find 17 trains dropped and 30 stations closed.

title: Shifts in Top Posts Are Set by Tampax
description: Edwin H. Shutt, 53 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Tampax Inc., a manufacturer of tampons. As president, he succeeds E. Russell Sprague, 65, who was named to the vacant post of chairman and continues as chief executive officer of the Lake Success, L.I., corporation.

title: Around the World; More Poles Applying For Asylum in Austria
description: Poles are applying for temporary asylum in Austria pending permanent resettlement elsewhere at the rate of about 200 a day, or double the number registered earlier this month, the spokesman for a committee for migration said today.

title: C.D. Futures Trades Cleared
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission authorized the New York Futures Exchange today to trade futures contracts on 90-day bank certificates of deposit. Trading would be limited to $1 million certificates.

title: The Buck Stops at a $1 Fare
description: It's a ploy, of course, yet deadly serious. Transit Chairman Ravitch does not want to charge $1 a token for New York's subways and buses nor raise commuter tickets by 50 percent. And Governor Carey, Mayor Koch and the Legislature don't want such a steep and damaging increase for still-inadequate service. But all they've done to keep New York's transit lifeline solvent is to dither.

title: CITINATIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRUST reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
WINFIELDS REQUIRED TO REMOVE HORSES
description: Malcolm and Nigel Winfield must remove their horses from the grounds at Belmont Park following the refusal yesterday of a State Supreme Court justice to grant an injunction that would have delayed the eviction. But the most valuable of the Winfield horses, Proud Appeal, might be unaffected by the action and could race as soon as Friday.

title: TWO TOP PARTIES SEEM DEADLOCKED IN ISRAELI RETURNS
description: Projections based on partial returns from Israel's general election yesterday showed the two major parties in a close, inconclusive race that appeared to provide Prime Minister Menachem Begin with a chance to form a government based on a slim majority in Parliament.

title: Steel Dumping Indictments
description: A Federal grand jury investigating charges of steel dumping by Mitsui & Company Ltd. of Japan today indicted a California steel company, its president, and a Mitsui salesman on charges of defrauding the United States Customs Service.

title: DIGITAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-After $21,867 net loss from discontinued operations and $1,723 net gain on the disposal of discontinued operations. C-Including $25,707 net income from discontinued operations and $131,528 net tax credit...B-Results for the previous yr have be restated to conform to the current presentation; shr earnings h been adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock splits on Jan 4, 1981 an June 11, 1981

title: DINNER ON THE RUN AT ENGINE CO. 35
description: Robert A. Stewart, a freelance writer, has written several articles about firefighters. By ROBERT A. STEWART

title: Edward Ball, Financier, Wills Estate to Crippled Children
description: Edward Ball, the financier who directed the growth of the Alfred I. duPont trust to a $2 billion empire, left the bulk of his $75 million estate to the crippled children of Florida.

title: Summer in the Woods
description: A friend in the country with a woodlot at his disposal points out that even in the summer all this stored-up sunshine does him good. His woodpile helps to keep him fed because the rich soil underneath is the best place to dig fishing worms; and every June he sets up a small tent in the woods at the edge of a field, where, surrounded by ggose-foot, bull thistle and fir trees, he can spend the full-moon nights and other moments when the spirit moves.

title: INTELLIGENCE AGENCY WILL ABOLISH OFFICE PROVIDING PRESS DATA
description: The Central Intelligence Agency will abolish its Office of Public Affairs effective tomorrow, an agency spokesman said today.

title: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 23
WINE TALK
description: HEALDSBURG, Calif. THE quality of California wine has risen drastically in recent years, as every devotee knows by now, and certain bottlings have vanquished the competition from France and other countries in blind tastings. No longer need California producers be considered laggards in the quality sweepstakes, but it is also true that they have been more successful with some grape varieties than others.

title: RAM RAMIREZ, JAZZ PIANIST
description: THE value of the solo piano series at Carnegie Recital Hall that has become an annual feature of what is now the Kool Jazz Festival has rarely been made more pointedly evident than it was at the recital by Ram Ramirez on Monday.

title: The City; Transit Report
description: A southbound No. 1 IRT train from 242d Street was taken out of service at 225th Street at 8:10 A.M. because of equipment problems, causing delays of up to 15 minutes.

title: BEHESHTI FUNERAL DRAWS BIG
description: CROWD

title: STATE U.'S COLLEGES PRESSED TO BROADEN CURRICULUMS IN AN AGE OF
description: TECHNOLOGY By RONALD SMOTHERS

title: Boxing Notebook
description: Holmes Alternative In Unclear Picture By MICHAEL KATZ

title: AFFABLE HAND AT IRISH HELM
description: During the recent parliamentary election campaign, Garret FitzGerald was at a rally one day in the pretty little coastal town of Bray, about to speak to an expectant crowd of supporters. The politician introducing him described him as a man born and bred in Bray and at that point, before the audience had a chance to cheer and clap, Mr. FitzGerald interrupted.

title: IN WASHINGTON
description: Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser of Australia at the White House. New York is among U.S. cities he will tour. Page A6.

title: TOWNER PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
CLARENCE D. KING
description: Clarence D. King, a civic leader and real estate broker in Harlem, died Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 93 years old and lived in Harlem.

title: THE Fi.Y.
description: ALONG with the rest of the city I celebrated another quiet fiscal New Year's Eve last night. No fireworks, no champagne -same restraint I'd displayed on the state's fiscal New Year's Eve, end of March. A friend who was joining me happened to mention that he was really looking forward to ''the new fiscal year.''

title: REAGAN AIDES SAY 'SHORT LIST' OF CANDIDATES FOR COURT IS READY
description: White House and Justice Department officials have produced a ''tentative short list'' of possible nominees for the Supreme Court and plan to interview some candidates before making a recommendation to President Reagan, Administration officials said today.

title: NEW PHASE IN DISPUTE ON SALT
description: The subject was salt and the issue was voluntarily reducing its presence in foods.

title: TV: WILDLIFE OF AFRICA
description: TONIGHT'S special on CBS-TV at 8 o'clock carries what must be the year's longest title, ''Lights! Action! Africa! The Fascinating Adventures of Wildlife Photographers Alan & Joan Root.'' For a change, that adjective fascinating happens to be on target. Produced and written by Mr. Root for Britain's Survival Anglia Ltd., this thoroughly absorbing profile explains and demonstrates some of the techniques used to get those extraordinary sequences that regularly pop up in animal films.

title: METHOD IN TAKING INTERVIEWS FOR POLL
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from June 22 through June 27 with 1,433 adults around the United States.

title: ROBBERY COMPLAINTS IN CITY SHOW FIRST DROP SINCE 1978
description: After declaring an all-out war on robbery three months ago, the New York City Police Department announced yesterday that for the first time since 1978 there had been a drop in the number of complaints involving robberies on city streets or in stores and businesses.

title: The City; Man, 33, Is Victim Of Knifing Attack
description: A 33-year-old man was listed by the police as the latest victim of a series of knifing attacks on men in various parks in Manhattan. The man, Santos Ortiz of 69 West 38th Street, walked into the emergency room at Beth Israel Hospital shortly before 4 A.M. yesterday with a deep cut across his neck, the police said.

title: UNINSPIRED FIRST NAME IS JUST TOO MUCH
description: THERE was a 13th-century minnesinger named Walther von der Vogelweide - what a name for a poet, a poem in itself! I was jealously contemplating it one day, thinking bleakly of my own bald, prosaic, easily forgotten name, when this couplet came to me: My name looks mighty plain beside a Walther von der Vogelweide.

title: Ashland Oil Unit Joins Saudi Venture
description: An Ashland Oil Inc. unit is entering a joint venture to build an oil refinery at Yanbu, Saudi Arabia, Ashland Oil announced yesterday.

title: Around the World; New Delhi Takes Control Of a State Government
description: The Indian state of Assam, where more than 290 people have died in outbreaks of violence directed against immigrants,today was put under direct presidential rule from New Delhi, the Government said.

title: News Analysis
description: In an instant, the bomb explosion that killed Ayatollah Mohammed Beheshti and 73 other high-ranking members of Iran's ruling party Sunday night changed the face of the nation's turbulent postrevolu@tionary politics.

title: LONDON: WHAT'S UP THIS SEASON
description: LONDON HATTERS here are delighted by the unexpected burst of interest in hats. A walk through Harrods and Harvey Nichols, London's leading department stores, revealed crowds of women literally fighting over the meager supply of headgear in departments denuded by the Royal Ascot, which ended June 21.

title: Q&A
description: Q. There are books from the 19th century that refer to ''perry,'' the pear equivalent of apple cider, and speak in glowing, almost rhapsodic terms. Perry seems to have been as or more popular than cider then. Why did the enthusiasm for perry disappear and is perry to be found at all today? Pear enthusiasts are almost as common as apple freaks, so why can't we go on to the cider equivalent?

title: METS' OWNERSHIP IS FRUSTRATED BY STRIKE
description: Nelson Doubleday and Fred Wilpon remember it well: Tom Seaver retired Alex Trevino on a grounder to shortstop for the final out, and the Cincinnati Reds completed a three-game sweep of the Mets. That was three weeks ago tomorrow night, and since then nobody has gone to bat in the major leagues in New York.

title: The Region; 2 Teen-Agers Held In Yacht Club Fire
description: Two teen-agers have been arrested and accused of setting a fire that destroyed the Sea Cliff Yacht Club on the edge of Long Island Sound last August, the police said.

title: Around the World; Atlanta Mothers' Group Files Financial Report
description: Overdue financial reports filed today by a group run by mothers of some of the 28 young blacks slain in Atlanta over the last two years indicate that the committee raised $39,000 in its first six months.

title: TAUNTERS' VICTIM DIED IN SUBWAY AFTER CALL HOME
description: A man who died after he was stripped and chased onto the tracks in a Times Square subway station by a mob of jeering youths and vagrants has been identified as a 26-year-old resident of Torrington, Conn., who was on his way to Washington, D.C., for a job interview.

title: NORTHROP GETTING BIG SWISS ORDER
description: In an unusual contract in which the sale of tactical fighter planes is tied to Swiss use of American marketing expertise, Swiss defense officials said today that the Government would buy $335 million of the Northrop Corporation's F-5E Tiger II.

title: JEWISH GROUPS VOCE SATISFACTION AT TRIAL OUTCOME
description: Heads of American Jewish organizations expressed quiet satisfaction yesterday with the outcome of the Dusseldorf war crimes trial.

title: Careers; Computer Graphics' Many Uses
description: JUST as the automobile gave people new mobility, the use of computer graphics is giving engineers, draftsmen, designers, architects and others new flexibility.

title: Topic; VERBAL ENEMIES; Shades of Red
description: Explaining his concern about four Communists in Socialist France's new 43-person Cabinet, Secretary of State Haig said last week that ''it's simply a fact of life that Communist regimes, whether they are closely aligned with Moscow or not, pursue policies which are not consistent with those of the Western family of nations.''

title: CLAMBAKE RITUAL FOR CITY-DWELLERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Bryan Miller is a freelance food writer who lives in Connecticut. By BRYAN MILLER

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: PEOPLE are surrounding themselves with ever-increasing sources of radiation - from such consumer items as CB radios, microwave ovens, smoke detectors and sunlamps to environmental sources like communication towers, high-tension electrical lines and nuclear-power plants.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY) reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
VAUXHALL MOTORS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Vauxhall is the British subsidiary of General Motors Corp

title: 1,400 SANITATION WORKERS STRIKE IN NORTH JERSEY
description: Garbage carting workers walked off their jobs tonight after rejecting a final contract offer two hours before their strike deadline.

title: Irving Abramowitz, Chairman Of California Health Concern
description: Dr. Irving Abramowitz, board chairman, chief executive officer, director and founder of Berkeley Bio-Medical Inc., died here Sunday.

title: COAL UNIT OF CONOCO IN VENTURE
description: The Consolidation Coal Company, a subsidiary of Conoco Inc., announced yesterday that it had agreed to form a joint venture with Rheinische Braunkohlenwerke A.G., a major West German mining company generally known as Rheinbraun, to develop up to five new coal mines in southwestern Pennsylvania. The deal includes a long-term sales agreement.

title: U.S. Clock Gains a Second
description: The nation's official clock worked overtime tonight to get back in synchronization with Earth.

title: The Region; Denial of Medicaid For Boy Reversed
description: TRENTON (UPI) - A state appeals court rebuked the Department of Human Services for practicing ''push button government'' in denying Medicaid funds to pay for a breathing device for a boy with severe respiratory problems.

title: GRIFFIN PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-Including $2,682,693 credit from the sale of oil and gas properties

title: LAB THAT TESTS CHILDREN'S BLOOD IS CLOSING IN CITY
description: A medical laboratory in New York City that conducts tests to determine whether newborn infants have inherited congenital diseases will be closed by the state tomorrow, according to the State Health Commissioner. All future blood samples from newborn infants will have to be sent to Albany for analysis.

title: Hitachi Leader Named
description: Katsushige Mita, 57, has been appointed president of Hitachi Ltd. of Japan. He succeeds Hirokichi Yoshiyama, 69, who moved into the vacant slot of chairman of the electronics and electrical equipment company, whose base is in Tokyo.

title: MAYOR BACKS A CHALLENGER IN COUNCIL BID
description: Mayor Koch came out yesterday against the first politician on a list of City Council members he wants to see defeated. He endorsed Noach Dear, the 27-year-old district manager of a community board, who is challenging the incumbent, Susan B. Alter, for the Democratic nomination in the Borough Park-Bensonhurt section of Brooklyn.

title: U.S. BEGINS INVESTIGATION INTO MOUNTAIN OF GARBAGE
description: Richard Brown can remember when a brook trickled through a valley on the old Moyer's farm here. Now that valley has grown into a mountain, and it has cast a shadow over the lives of his family and neighbors.

title: MEYER, FRED, INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 23
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.9 million for the latest period and $662,000 for the previous period

title: Blast of M.I.S.L. Gets Joe Fink of the Fever
description: The Baltimore Blast of the Major Indoor Soccer League announced today the acquisition of Joe Fink, the highscoring forward of the Philadelphia Fever.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt MEMOIRS OF AN ANTI-SEMITE. A Novel in Five Stories. By Gregor von Rezzori. Translated from the German by the author and Joachim Neugroschel. 287 pages. Viking. $13.95.

title: O'NEILL READY TO REJOIN BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives, says he is hardly done fighting the battle of the budget, despite the severe defeat of last week, and is, in fact, planning at least two rear-guard tactics to confront President Reagan again, possibly in renewed voting on the floor of the House.

title: DUMPING ON DUMPS
description: To the Editor:

title: 49 Horses Are Killed In 2 Illinois Track Fires
description: Fires at two northern Illinois harness tracks killed 49 horses early today. Thirty-three horses were killed and six persons received minor injuries in a fire at Balmoral Park in Crete, south of Chicago.

title: PRICE DROPS FORECAST
description: President Reagan today ordered an end to four years of import quotas for shoes. The White House said the action both strengthened the Administration's commitment to free trade and paved the way for lower retail shoe prices.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 1, 1981
description: International A close election in Israel was indicated by projections based on early returns. They showed the two major parties in a tight race that appeared to provide Prime Minister Menachem Begin with a chance to form a new Government based on a slim parliamentary majority. (Page A1, Column 6.) The siege of Zahle ended in Lebanon as Christian militiamen were replaced by Government policemen. The transfer brought the end of a 91-day siege by Syrian troops. (A1:4-5.)

title: COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-No yr ago comparable figures are available because the compan was incorporated on Apr 1, 1980

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
CLEAN AIR ACT: A BAROMETER OF CHANGES
description: The Clean Air Act, supposedly scheduled for mere ''fine tuning'' by Congress this year, is turning into a closely watched, hotly contested proving ground for President Reagan's broad effort to change the nature of Federal regulation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article Saturday about a Supreme Court decision on military pensions included a misplaced sentence describing criticism from lawyers familiar with divorce cases. The criticism actually referred to a procedure under which a divorced military spouse could obtain a court order to garnish pension benefits to satisfy an unpaid alimony or child support obligation.

title: M.T.A. LIMITS SALES OF TOKENS
description: As of last night, the sale of subway tokens was limited to two to each customer, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced. The limit was imposed, according to an authority spokesman, to ''head off the possibility of hoarding'' by subway riders prior to an expected fare rise in the next few days.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: If you are a professional chef for a good many years, it takes a certain amount of time to get into ''modern'' cooking techniques. And I put that word in quotation marks because I am referring to pressure cookers that have been around, in this country, at least for several decades. There are many reasons why it took me a spell to get into attempting to cook with a pressure cooker.

title: Rates Post Modest Increase; 7-Year Notes Up to 14.07%
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday, as securities dealers sought to attract more buyers for the heavy supply of notes and bonds in the Treasury and corporate markets.

title: 3 Bombs Explode in Naples
description: Bombs exploded last night at three police stations here, and a new leftist terrorist group calling itself the People's Liberation Movement said it was responsible.

title: Are Peonies Poisonous?
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In ''Don't Throw Those Bouquets, Cook Them'' (June 24), the author, Carolyn Jabs, mentions that peonies ''can be sampled without fear.'' Coincidentally, two days ago I read that peonies, especially the flowers, are extremely poisonous - sometimes fatal - I read this in ''The Herb Book'' by John Lust, published by Bantam.

title: Willard L. Kauth, 82, Founder Of the Boys' Athletic League
description: Willard L. Kauth, founder and executive director emeritus of the Boys' Athletic League and co-founder of the Girls Vacation Fund, New York City organizatons that maintain country camps for underprivileged children, died Sunday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 82 years old and lived in Tuckahoe, N.Y.

title: CLAUSEN AND THE POOR
description: .2,2WASHINGTON - An important issue facing the World Bank's new president, A.W. Clausen, is the future level of programs serving the poorest countries and poorest people in the developing world.

title: COPPER MINE OFFER STUDIED
description: The Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company said it was ocnsidering buying the Cities Service Company's copper operation in Arizona, which is worth an estimated $300 million.

title: MILLION COLLEGE STUDENTS FACE 'NEEDS TEST' ON FUTURE LOANS
description: An estimated million or more college students will have to prove genuine financial need in order to qualify for federally guaranteed loans in future school years.

title: Unclaimed Lotto Stub Is Worth $2.9 Million
description: An unclaimed Lotto ticket purchased at a Manhattan liquor store last week may be worth nearly $3 million, state lottery officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. HARSHLY ATTACKS O.A.U.'S CRITICISM OF ITS POLICIES ON SOUTH AFRICA AND NAMIBIA
description: The Reagan Administration assailed African leaders today for having criticized American policy toward South Africa and Namibia and for having failed to condemn Libya's activities on the continent.

title: A.M.C. RETOOLING FOR NEW CAR LINE
description: The American Motors Corporation said that it would begin retooling its Lakefront plant at Kenosha, Wis., in August to prepare for production of a new line of front-wheel-drive cars designed by Renault, its French partner, and scheduled for introduction in 1982.

title: CHILE FAILS TO BLOCK AMERICAN'S ELECTION IN O.A.S. RIGHTS JOB
description: The American lawyer who heads the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights has been elected to a second term despite an attack on him and the commission's work by the Chilean Government.

title: THE INSPIRATIONS OF A GLOBAL COOK
description: WHENEVER he is invited to eat at Colette Rossant's, Calvin Trillin has written, his wife, Alice, ''is often forced to grab me by the jacket two or three times to keep me from breaking into a steady, uncharacteristic trot'' in the direction of the Rossants' home in Greenwich Village. Her cooking, Mr. Trillin says, ''is so far above frozen food that I have always suspected she may not keep ice cubes.''

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Hammermill-Icahn Pact
description: The Hammermill Paper Company said today that it had reached an agreement to buy for $36 a share the 782,100 Hammermill shares held or controlled by Carl C. Icahn, who waged a proxy fight against Hammermill management a year ago. Under the agreement, Mr. Icahn will not buy any Hammermill shares or attempt a proxy fight against the company's management for eight years. Hammermill also agreed to purchase for $36 a share the 82,600 Hammermill shares held by Bayswater Realty and Investment Trust, of which Mr. Icahn is chairman.

title: Around the World; Canadian Postal Workers Strike for Maternity Pay
description: Some 23,000 Canadian postal workers began their fourth strike in the last seven years today with fully-paid maternity leave as a major issue.

title: People
description: * David A. Rogovin elected president of Maslow, Gold & Rothschild Advertising, Boston.

title: Stocks Continue to Retreat
description: Stocks continued to give ground yesterday in a session that failed to produce any fireworks on the takeover front - the main source of Wall Street's excitement in recent sessions.

title: IN ITALY, A DEEP CHANGE
description: The Italians have two opinions about the new Government of Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini, the secretary of the small Republican Party. The first is that it's business-as-usual and will last maybe six months; the second is that it represents the start of a long tide, of a deep change in the country's political life.

title: Abitibi-Price Modernization
description: Abitibi-Price Inc., the world's largest newsprint producer, announced two capital projects totaling $266.7 million toward the company's ''strategic plan of modernizing.''

title: STSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Advertising
description: Philip H. Dougherty Marsteller Strategy Selection

title: 3 Indicted in Election Case
description: Three men, including a county Democratic Party chairman, have been indicted on charges stemming from an alleged attempt to rig the local party primary in June 1980, Federal officials say. The latest indictments brought to 25 the number of people charged in the case, which involved a failed attempt to re-elect Sheriff Roy Lee of Dillon County. Those charged yesterday were Alan H. Schafer, the party chairman, Ralph Lane, who was Mr. Lee's campaign manager, and William P. Jones, a deputy sheriff.

title: TURKS PLANNING A CONSTITUTION
description: The military junta today announced plans to form a constituent assembly to prepare a new constitution and a law governing political parties and elections to pave the way for a freely elected civilian administration.

title: MASSACHUSETTS, NO BUDGET PREPARED, CUTS TAX TODAY
description: Neither Massachusetts nor Boston officials have been able to agree on budget cuts needed to deal with a votermandated tax reduction that will take effect tomorrow with the start of a new fiscal year.

title: LIBYA LOWERS OIL PRICE A SLIM $1.10
description: Libya, the world's highest-priced oil producer, informed its oil customers yesterday that it had lowered the price of its crude to $39.90 a barrel, from $41 - an indication that it can no longer hold out against the downward price pressure of the world oil glut.

title: Around the World; Tanzanian Troops End 2 1/2-Year Stay in Uganda
description: Tanzanian troops who helped overthrow Ugandan dictator Idi Amin completed their withdrawal from Uganda today.

title: The U.N. Today; July 1, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Development Program Governing Council - 11 A.M.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: B-After net losses of $658,260 for the qr and $747,422 for the yr on the sale of property

title: JOSEPH HELLER IN DISPUTE WITH SIMON & SCHUSTER
description: SIMON AND SCHUSTER published Joseph Heller's ''Catch-22'' (1961) and ''Good as Gold'' (1979) and they have a contract for another, asyet-uncompleted, novel. Meanwhile, though, the author and the publisher have had a falling out that has ended up in arbitration.

title: LEADING INDICATORS DROP 1.8%
description: The Government reported yesterday that the index of leading economic indicators, which is designed to forecast future economic trends, dropped by 1.8 percent in May, confirming a widespread belief among economists that the economy's growth has slowed.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 20.00 20.00 12.00 DISCOUNT RATE * 14.00 14.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 18.54 18.55 9.47 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.32 13.92 8.01 6-MO. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: COYOTE POISON BAN FACES REVIEW
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it was considering lifting the ban on the use of a highly toxic chemical to kill coyotes and other animals that prey on sheep and young cattle.

title: State and 2d Doctors' Insurer Agree to Delay Rate Increase
description: The State's Department of Insurance and the Medical Malpractice Insurance Association agreed yesterday to postpone, until Oct. 1, the company's request for a 69 percent increase in malpractice-premium rates.

title: LUKENS STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 13
JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Notes On People; Tiny Tim Still Finds Life Beautiful
description: He is traveling now with something called ''Roy Radin's Vaudeville Show,'' making one-night stands in smaller towns around the country, but Tiny Tim, the falsetto singer who rose to fame in the 1960's on ''Tiptoe Through the Tulips,'' has lost none of his feeling that life is beautiful.

title: Connors, Down by 2 Sets, Rallies to Defeat Amritraj
description: They were ready to bury Jimmy Connors at Wimbledon today, but he left the center court a five-set winner over Vijay Amritraj of India and with a spot in the semifinals against Bjorn Borg.

title: BLAKE EDWARD'S 'S.O.B.,' A FARCE
description: ''S. O. B.,'' Blake Edwards's newest, most manic, most bitter farce, is about the Hollywood you didn't see in the screen adaptation of Nathanael West's ''Day of the Locust.'' It's not about the smalltime failures, hustlers and nuts living on the sleazy fringes of the movie industry.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BRANDT, IN MOSCOW, CALLS FOR MEETING OF REAGAN AND BREZHNEV
description: The former West German Chancellor, Willy Brandt, used a Kremlin banquet in his honor tonight to urge an early summit meeting between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, who has made no public reference to such a meeting since suggesting one in a speech to the Soviet Communist Party Congress four months ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Cultural Revolution, which lasted from May 1966 to October 1976, was responsible for the most severe setback and heaviest losses suffered by the party, the state and the people since the founding of the People's Republic.

title: THE U.S.-CANADA POWER BOND
description: Canada and the United States, which have two of the world's most closely connected economies, are being drawn even closer together in the energy field these days by rapidly growing new links in electricity.

title: Index; International
description: Salvadoran city is shaken by surprise rebel raid A2 Around the World A5 Mitterrand upholds the Camp David agreements A9 Bush praises President Marcos and pledges U.S. support A13 Government/Politics Mountain of garbage in Pennsylvania leads to Federal inquiry A14 Clean Air Act provides focus for Reagan regulation reform A16 E.P.A. to study lifting ban on chemical to kill coyotes A22 Midtown rally held to push final E.R.A. drive B2 New York Senate passes a bill on guardians for cult members B4 Governor Carey vetoed a bill on joint child custody in divorces B4 Living Section Food A portrait of artists at lunch C1

title: Sale of Islanders' Stock Delayed by Court Order
description: Justice Douglas Young of State Supreme Court issued today a stay of tomorrow's planned sale of minority stock in the New York Islanders. He also called for a hearing Monday.

title: JOE ALBANY STORY, A JAZZMAN'S BIOGRAPHY
description: JOE ALBANY is not one of the giant figures of jazz, not the person whom jazz films normally focus on. The series at the Carnegie Hall Cinema during the Kool Jazz Festival indicates the general tenor of jazz films. There are generalized ones - ''Jammin' the Blues,'' the great Gjon Mili mood piece of the 40's; ''The Last of the Blue Devils,'' which deals with jazz in Kansas City, and ''Jazz on a Summer's Day,'' which reports on the Newport Jazz Festival when it was actually in Rhode Island and before it had been sold to a cigarette company.

title: Economic Scene; Business's Schizoid View
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN has scored a stunning triumph on the Federal budget. In the process he has put together an apparently unbeatable combination of Republicans and Democratic conservatives, has recaptured the political momentum that swept him into the White House, and is now virtually certain to get the tax bill he wants from Congress. His command over economic policy seems complete.

title: NUMEX CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
BEST BUYS
description: AS the summer season gets under way in New Jersey, we can expect lower prices for many fruits and vegetables. Meanwhile, vegetables such as cucumbers, peppers, broccoli and celery, which are between seasons, are still high.

title: Poll Shows Americans Are Evenly Divided on Strike
description: Those Americans who care about the major league baseball strike are evenly divided on whether the owners or the players are right, but one American in three doesn't care or has no opinion, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Companies
description: Dennis C. Stanfill, chairman of 20th Century-Fox, resigned, asserting that his employment contract had been ''materially breached'' by the company. The resignation was apparently a result of a dispute on management policy with Marvin Davis, the company's new owner. (Page D1.)

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: It may be that for most people there is little need for creativity in outdoor cooking. Undeniably, a lamb chop brushed with oil and sprinkled with rosemary and broiled over the embers of wood or charcoal is marvelous enough.

title: ATTEMPT TO LIMIT COURTS IS ASSAILED
description: A bipartisan group of 12 Senators today deplored attempts by conservative legislators to limit the role of Federal courts, saying a result would be to ''radically alter our basic constitutional framework.''

title: IRISH PARLIAMENT CHOOSES FITZGERALD AS NEW PRIME MINISTER
description: Garret FitzGerald, a former economics professor who served four years as Foreign Minister, was chosen today by the newly elected Parliament to be Ireland's seventh Prime Minister.

title: THE GOOD ECONOMIC SENSE OF AN 'ALL SAVERS' BILL
description: To the Editor:

title: MITTERRAND UPHOLDS CAMP DAVID AGREEMENTS
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France today reiterated his full backing of the Middle East peace accords reached at Camp David, apparently dealing a severe blow to Western Europe's hopes of an independent Middle East peace initiative of its own.

title: A NIGHT TO BENEFIT COLLEAGUES
description: JAZZ musicians played a different kind of benefit at Carnegie Hall on Monday - a four-hour benefit for the jazz community, to start a fund on which musicians who need small sums, such as $200 or $300, can draw. They raised $35,000.

title: Adelaide Schulkind Frank, 83; Lent Funds to Social Activists
description: Adelaide Schulkind Frank, founder and director of the League for Mutual Aid that for 50 years provided interest-free loans to young socialists, labor organizers and other activists in causes she deemed important, died last Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83 years old.

title: LIGHT CREAM: HARDER TO FIND
description: When it comes to buying cream these days, one style fits all. Until a few years ago, it was relatively easy to find light cream as well as heavy cream in most markets. And medium cream was once widely available. But now, light cream has virtually disappeared from the dairy case.

title: BALLET: ROYAL TROUP'S U.S. PREMIERE ON MACMILLAN'S 'ISADORA'
description: ''ISADORA,'' a three-hour highly theatrical ballet by Kenneth MacMillan, is a deliberate distortion of Isadora Duncan's life and art, and nothing would be easier than falling into the trap of being outraged by it.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Medicaid yesterday misidentified a Congressman who withdrew a proposal to place a ceiling of 7 1/2 percent on increases in Federal spending for the program. He was Representative James T. Broyhill, Re- publican of North Carolina.

title: Notes On People; Snepp Clears C.I.A. Hurdle With New Screenplay
description: After his royalties were seized by court order for his book ''Decent Interval,'' Frank Snepp, a former Central Intelligence Agency analyst who wrote the book without agency clearance, decided to use a different approach for his next project.

title: FACTORY ORDERS UP
description: New orders for manufactured goods rose six-tenths of 1 percent in May compared with April after falling in April, the Commerce Department reported today. The report said manufacturers' shipments also rose in May.

title: HAIG PLANS TO ATTEND MEETING IN BAHAMAS ON CARIBBEAN HELP
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. will confer with the foreign ministers of Canada, Mexico and Venezuela in the Bahamas July 11 on a joint approach to a largescale economic plan for the Caribbean area being developed by the Reagan Administration.

title: BASEBALL TALKS SET TODAY
description: As baseball's striking players and club owners wrangled in the background over the paychecks of several players, their negotiators agreed yesterday to renew their efforts to settle the strike. It has lasted 19 days, forced cancellation of 237 games and brought the owners $8.4 million in insurance payments.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Shr earnings reflects a 3-for-2 stock split effective Mar 23

title: EXCERPTS FROM RESOLUTION ON HISTORY OF MAO'S CONTRIBUTIONS AND MISTAKES
description: Following are excerpts from the resolution on ''certain questions in the history of our party'' adopted by the Communist Party Central Committee, as made public today in English by the New China News Agency: Before the People's Republic

title: Around the World; Police in Capital Seek Source of Shooting Hoax
description: The Washington Star WASHINGTON, June 30 - The District of Columbia police are searching for a mysterious telephone caller who caused local television stations last night to broadcast erroneous reports that Mayor Marion Barry Jr. had been shot on the front lawn of his home in Southeast Washington.

title: Topic; Banished
description: From time to time, we revise and extend our list of verbal enemies, expressions that warrant exile because they are overused or wrongly used. Today we nominate one of each.

title: Errico Found in Contempt of Grand Jury
description: Con Errico, the former jockey convicted last year of racketeering in connection with a race-fixing scheme at New York tracks in the mid-1970's, refused yesterday to answer questions before a Federal grand jury. He was immediately found in contempt of court and ordered to jail beginning Friday morning.

title: The Region; Merlino Signs Jersey Budget
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Acting Gov. Joseph P. Merlino yesterday signed a $5.691 billion budget for fiscal 1982, after chopping $11.3 million from the plan approved by the Legislature.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $200,000 for the qr and $430,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss after tax credits of $68,000 for the qr and $407,000 for the 9 mos

title: AMADAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-Including $32,000 extraordinary income; shr earnings and shr outstndg give effect to the senior preferred stock divd of $27, which came due during the period

title: U.S.-India Talks Scheduled
description: Assistant Secretary of State James Malone will confer with Indian officials July 14-15 on the supply of uranium to India's Tarapur nuclear power plant, an American Embassy official said today.

title: Around the World; Premature Florida Infant Is Helped by Air Force
description: A baby girl born three months prematurely was making progress today in her battle for life, fought in part by a hospital team that enlisted the help of the Air Force to get the child proper care.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Yr-ago results have been adjusted to reflect a business combina treated as a pooling of interests; shrs outstndg have been adju to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split, effective June 11, 1980 and f assumed conversion of outstndg convertible bonds issued in Apr

title: Bondage and the Safety Net
description: Last year, Ronald Reagan missed the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Not this year. In his address, the President was eloquent and committed when, for instance, he condemned the ''disturbing reoccurrence of bigotry and violence.'' But there was more eloquence than commitment in his grand promise: ''Just as the emancipation freed black people 118 years ago, today we need to declare an economic emancipation.''

title: Union Dissident Wins Bulletin Board Appeal
description: Unions must allow their members to post material on union bulletin boards that is critical of the local or national labor organization, a Federal appeals court has ordered.

title: MR. REAGAN'S $3 BILLION PAKISTANI MISTAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: 42D ST. PLAN WOULD ADD TOWERS, THEATERS AND 'BRIGHT LIGHTS'
description: Detailed architectural plans for the redevelopment of 42d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue call for an enlargement of the former Times Tower as a ''civic sculpture'' and a variety of ''bright lights'' and ''supersign'' special effects.

title: News Analysis
description: Quietly, without any dramatic overruling of prior decisions, the Supreme Court has changed the law on sex discrimination to make distinctions based on sex easier to justify and more likely to survive legal challenges.

title: PEKING ASSESSMENT ASSERTS MAO MADE ERRORS AS LEADER
description: The Chinese Communist Party said today that Mao Zedong, the man who led it to power and ruled China for 27 years, had been a brilliant revolutionary who turned into a blundering national leader.

title: JOSEPH H. BILLINGS
description: Joseph H. Billings, a former partner of Cowen & Company, a brokerage firm, died Friday at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: Shoppers Get $1 Bills Marked as 'Evidence'
description: Shoppers at a supermarket in this Westchester County community may have been surprised when $1 bills they received as change at the cash register had ''evidence'' stamped on them in red letters.

title: EX-NEW YORKER GETS LIFE FOR CRIMES IN NAZI CAMP
description: West Germany's last major Nazi war crimes trial, which spanned five and a half years, ended today with the conviction of eight former guards of the Maidanek camp, including a former resident of Maspeth, Queens.

title: WHEN AN ADULT'S PARENT REMARRIES
A PORTRAIT OF THE ARTISTS AT LUNCH
description: THE painter Raeford Liles's favorite lunch is a steak fillet, boned and pounded thin and fried in his electric skillet -he has no stove - with zucchini. ''I don't even put the steak on a plate,'' he said. ''I eat it right out of the skillet. Then I go back to the canvas.''

title: TRAFFIC LIGHTS WITH A PERILOUS SAFETY MARGIN
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S OFFICIAL: A CARRIAGE RIDE COSTS MORE
description: Horse owners and horse lovers, who are sometimes not the same people, each got a little something from the City Council yesterday. The owners got more money for their animals' labor through a bill that nearly doubles the hourly rates of horse-drawn carriages. And those wanting better treatment of horses, including a limit on labor, got that through a separate bill that received committee approval. That measure also requires all horses to be licensed, at an annual cost of $25.

title: STANFILL OUT AS CHIEF OF FOX FILM
description: Dennis C. Stanfill, who for 12 years headed the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, one of the nation's largest and best-known entertainment companies, resigned late today as chairman and chief executive officer, apparently over differences with Marvin Davis, the Denver oil millionaire who is Fox's new owner.

title: INDISPENSABLE THRIFTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Barge Shipping Resumes Around Collapsed Span
description: Barges began inching past a collapsed 500-ton bridge span today, but officials predicted that it would be at least five days before they could clean up the wreckage that backed up river traffic.

title: Stock Offer to English Is Valued at $300,000
description: George Nicholau, the arbitrator in disputes arising from the new right-of-first-refusal arrangement involving basketball free agents, placed a $300,000 value yesterday on the stock option offer the Seattle SuperSonics have made to Alex English, the Denver Nuggets' free agent.

title: GIVE BIKE RIDERS THEIR SHARE OF THE ROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: ILLINOIS TRANSIT PACT REMAINS ELUSIVE IN ASSEMBLY'S LAST HOURS
description: After a month of arguing, Mayor Jane M. Byrne of Chicago and Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois remained at loggerheads yesterday on a proposal to save the cash-starved Regional Transit Authority. The Illinois General Assembly met yesterday and early this morning but agreement on a plan proved elusive. The Legislature was scheduled to adjourn at 12:01 A.M. today, but continued to meet. The rules of the Legislature require a vote of 60 percent of the members to pass a fiscal measure such as a transit agreement after the midnight deadline for the end of the session.

title: TINKER KNOWN FOR GIVING PRODUCERS A FREE HAND
description: In 1970, Grant Tinker left his post at 20th Century-Fox to form a company to produce his wife's television series, ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show.'' CBS-TV had bought 24 episodes, and, as usual in the television business, the risks were high.

title: BY THIS WEEKEND
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that increases in New York City subway and bus fares to 75 cents would be approved tomorrow.

title: N.A.A.C.P. DELEGATES DISCUSS STRATEGIES TO SAVE CIVIL RIGHTS GAINS
description: Unswayed by President Reagan's appeal to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday to join his ''coalition for change,'' delegates attending the civil rights group's convention here today met to find ways to stem what they view as a growing national conservatism as reflected in the President's policies.

title: HESS'S SUCCESS IN MERGER DEFIES CRITICS
description: When Hess's Inc., a well-known Pennsylvania department-store chain, announced about two years ago that it was merging with a developer of shopping centers, retailers raised a few eyebrows.

title: Woolworth Nears Mexican Accord
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company said it had reached a tentative agreement with Banco Nacional de Mexico to sell 51 percent of its Mexican subsidiary for about $30.6 million, permitting a long-delayed expansion of its 24-store retail operation in Mexico.

title: No Headline
description: Times Official's Son Killed

title: Textile Imports Up
description: The Government said today that imports of textile and apparel products rose 13 percent in May from April.

title: BUSH PLEGES U.S. SUPPORT FOR THE PHILIPPINES
description: Vice President Bush raised a toast to President Ferdinand E. Marcos today on the inauguration of his new six-year term and pledged full United States commitment and support to this country and its non-Communist neighbors.

title: Phone Rate Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday denied a petition by the three major television networks to stay rate increases for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that went into effect Sunday. The networks are challenging the legality of the new rates' effective date and say they need extra time to decide whether to negotiate alternative national wire-leasing.

title: Corco Bankruptcy Plan Approved
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said that a Federal Bankruptcy Court judge had approved a plan to release the company from more than three years of operation under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: 'American Decoy' Show At Museum of Folk Art
description: ''The American Decoy: Folk Sculpture From the Collection of Mr. and Mrs. Donal C. O'Brien'' will open on Sept. 3 at the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 16.710 percent was set at its weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper, compared with a 16.497 percent rate last week.

title: POLL INDICATES TURN TOWARD OPTIMISM ON NATION'S FUTURE
description: Shaking off the national pessimism that affected the country in 1979 and 1980, the American public again thinks the United States will be better off in the future than it is now, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: The Region; Nassau Loses Bid For 2 in Jail Cells
description: ALBANY (UPI) - Despite a recent United States Supreme Court ruling, New York's prison watchdog agency denied a request from Nassau County to house more than one inmate to a cell.

title: About Real Estate; EAST 25TH ST. LOFT IS TURNED INTO A COMMERCIAL CO-OP
description: Originally it was thought that the 12-story loft building at 118 East 25th Street would go the way of so many other loft buildings - residential. There was all the more reason to think so because the entity in charge by 1979 was Helmsley-Spear Loft Sales Inc., whose name speaks for itself.

title: News Analysis
description: For the last week, New York City's 1982 budget and its financial plan for the following three years have been held hostage amid the wrangling over a mass-transit package in Albany. Whether or not it proves successful, the budget ploy, which has the city's approval, is already raising questions about the possible harm that could be inflicted upon New York's fiscal reputation. Today is the first day of the 1982 fiscal year, and it began without the necessary imprimatur of the city's principal monitor, the Financial Control Board. The Control Board must certify the new financial plan, but all it has produced in the last seven days is a good deal of behind-thescenes maneuvering, delays of scheduled meetings and no action of significance.

title: Justice Aide's Move Studied
description: The Justice Department is reviewing a meeting between its No.3 official and the chief lawyer for the indicted McDonnell Douglas Corporation, a department spokesman said today.

title: CAREY VETOES A BILL REQUIRING COURTS TO WEIGH JOINT CUSTODY IN DIVORCES
description: Governor Carey vetoed legislation today that would have required judges to consider granting joint custody of children in divorce cases if even one parent requested it.

title: SOME ISRAELIS VOTED FOR 'LESSER EVIL'
description: ''There isn't anyone to vote for; I simply have to vote for the lesser evil,'' said 47-year-old Esther Mandler of west Jerusalem.

title: Foxboro Board Grants Patriots a 2d Hearing
description: The three-man Board of Selectmen voted unanimously tonight to reconsider its decision barring the New England Patriots from starting a Monday night National Football League game Sept. 21 at the usual 9 P.M. time.

title: IN BATTLE OF AMPLIFIERS, THE AUDIENCE IS THE LOSER
description: THE electric guitar became an accepted jazz instrument during the early 40's, and at first it blended easily with other instruments. Early electric guitarists kept their amplifiers turned down and played sparse chords or terse, horn-like lines. They wouldn't have dreamed of trying to overpower the saxophones and brass, and most of them played softly enough to hear the bass, which was the foundation of the traditional jazz ensemble.

title: Washington; THE DEMOCRATIC DILEMMA
description: The Democrats limped out of Washington for the Fourth of July recess, wounded in the Battle of the Budget by the Republicans and by the defection of some of their own troops. Speaker Tip O'Neill is concerned but not dejected.

title: The City; Sweatshop Inquiry Leads to 9 Arrests
description: Six men and three women were arrested by the New York State Attorney General's office for reportedly engaging in sweatshop practices in New York City's garment industry.

title: Shell Set to Drill Off Georges Bank
description: The Shell Oil Company said that it expected to begin drilling a $24 million test well in the Georges Bank fishing area area off the coast of New England by the end of July.

title: Egypt's Nuclear Safeguards
description: An agreement to insure that nuclear materials supplied to Egypt will be used solely for peaceful purposes will be submitted for approval to the executive body of the International Atomic Energy Agency in September, the organization said today. Egypt initialed the accord yesterday to accept safeguards, including check by inspectors, on all nuclear material it possesses.

title: About New York
description: Rudolph Henry sees the New York City subway system as few of its riders do, and so he knows what it is worth, and what it is capable of.

title: Foster Grant Head Adds Another Title
description: Arthur T. Castillo, the 52-year-old president of the Foster Grant Corporation, the sunglass producer, has been named to the additional position of chief executive officer. He succeeds Gunther I.O. Ruebcke, 60, who continues as chairman of the Leominster, Mass., company.

title: 1. Sightly Totes
description: The attractive French Provincial prints that are a specialty at the shop called St. Remy are appearing in new guises. The paisley cottons have been laminated to make them waterproof and are being used for travel bags. The shop has a large, barrel-shaped bag that could hold a weekend wardrobe, and it has plastic pockets for wet swimsuits or towels ($75). A smaller tote bag with a pocket for keys or makeup is $45. Both bags come in prints with red, beige, khaki or blue backgrounds. St. Remy is at 156 East 64th Street.

title: Market Place; Printery's Prospects
description: THE possibility of a turnaround at the International Banknote Company has caused a major advance in the price of its stock. And that, in turn, has led to rumors of a takeover. The basic interest is in International's American Banknote arm, the venerable printer of stock and bond certificates, foreign currencies and postage stamps and Federal food stamps.

title: SENATE ALLOWS REMOVAL OF MEMBERS FROM CULTS
description: By a vote of 35 to 23, the Senate today gave final passage to a bill that would allow courts to appoint temporary guardians to remove people from religious cults for 45 to 75 days.

title: Sportspeak And Stuff
description: WILLIAM SAFIRE, the discoverer of the English language, devoted his weekly essay Sunday to the sort of colloquialisms that Bob Lipsyte long ago christened sportspeak. Safire concentrated on the phrase, ''out of left field,'' but he also touched upon such terms as ''ball park figure,'' ''eye on the ball,'' ''to be off base,'' ''something on the ball,'' ''right off the bat,'' ''go to bat for,'' ''to play ball,'' ''be in there pitching'' and ''take a raincheck.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STRUMMERS

title: SYRIA ENDS SIEGE OF LEBANESE TOWN, RAISING HOPE FOR AN EASING OF CRISIS
description: Lebanese Christian militiamen rode out of the battle-weary town of Zahle near here early today as a 91-day Syrian siege ended, bringing a glimmer of hope for the easing of the crisis over the stationing of Syrian missiles nearby.

title: THE COSTS OF DRINKING
description: Weekend and holiday shifts, especially, they keep me awake all night - the ones who don't make it home, and those who aren't safe even there.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: STARS and sidemen are the kings and foot soldiers of jazz. The stars get most of the attention; they have names the jazz public recognizes. But sidemen fight the battles and win the wars. If they are gifted musicians and are committed to the music they are playing, the music and the star will sound good. If they are ordinary musicians or bored musicians, the music will sound tired, no matter how well the star is playing.

title: RCA POTENTIAL AND BRADSHAW
description: Thornton F. Bradshaw, who takes over today as chairman of the RCA Corporation, has already started to tackle the company's biggest problems. One of his first moves was to speed Fred Silverman's departure as president of NBC.

title: Japan Coal Liquefaction
description: The Nippon Oil Company said today that it had reached agreement with the Chevron Research Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California, to introduce the Chevron coal liquefaction process in Japan at an undisclosed cost. Nippon said that it planned to build a pilot plant in Yokohama, southwest of Tokyo, at a cost of about $53 million, based on the Chevron technology, it said, without elaborating. Industry sources said that Nippon Oil would study whether the Chevron-developed bituminous coal liquefaction technology could be applied to low-grade brown coal.

title: NATIONS STUDY NEW COFFEE QUOTA CUT
description: In the face of a growing world surplus that has pushed prices to a five-and-a-half-year low, the 26 consumer nations in the 70-country International Coffee Organization met today and agreed to consider a fresh cut in the annual export quota.

title: Baseball Notebook
description: Schoendienst Finally Sees His Son Play By JANE GROSS

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WITNESS DESCRIBES SECRET TRAVEL FUND
description: The University of New Mexico basketball program maintained a secret account to provide airline trips for basketball players without the knowledge of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the manager of a local travel agency testified today.

title: TINKER TO SUCCEED HIM
description: Fred Silverman announced yesterday that he was resigning as president of NBC today because he had failed to win the expression of support he had publicly sought from Thornton F. Bradshaw, who takes over as chairman of the RCA Corporation today. RCA is the parent corporation of NBC.

title: Edward Hausner Fireworks Go Up in Smoke
description: Jagged tendrils of fire from rockets and Roman candles punctuated a rolling cloud of smoke near the Whitestone Bridge yesterday as police detonated a ton and a half of confiscated fireworks. At the Rodmans Neck range, Lieut. William Sullivan of the bomb squad held a large package of firecrackers that had been intended for illegal use on the Fourth of July.

title: David Weisz, 70, Auctioneer Of Shipyards and Movie Sets
description: David Weisz, an internationally known auctioneer who sold everything from shipyards to movie sets, died today after a long illness.

title: RCA Satellite Bid Rejected
description: A proposal by RCA American Communications Inc., the primary satellite carrier for the cable TV industry, to lease a bonus transmission channel on a new satellite to some of its existing customers was rejected today by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: When Spouses Travel
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In reference to ''Joys of Solitude When Husbands Are Away'' (June 24), I wonder if you realize how much ammunition you have given to those of us who believe in the women's liberation movement? The lives of the successful women you describe are totally circumscribed by their husbands' wishes. How about Mr. Dwyer's reading in the living room while his wife enjoys her favorite television program in bed? What sort of compulsively neat husband can't face a little overnight mess while a drawer clean-out job is in progress?

title: ARTS PROGRAM CUTS REPEAT RECIPIENTS
description: An appropriation for fiscal 1981-82 of $1,120,000 by the New York State Council on the Arts to the Creative Artists Public Service program has aroused concern among the program's officials because they say there is a string attached. In making the appropriation, its largest budget item for fiscal 1982, the council has stipulated that Creative Artists Public Service, whose fellowship program disburses grants to visual artists, film makers, choreographers, composers and writers, must make awards only to first-time recipients.

title: SALVADOR CITY IS SHAKEN BY SURPRISE REBEL RAID
description: Some of the heaviest fighting in a major city since last January's guerrilla offensive has been going on in the streets of this port city for three days.

title: Observer; THE BIG HONCHO RANCHO
description: The center of the fabulous Reagan ranch is the big house where Nancy and the boss live. That's it over there, sort of hunkered down in the shelter of those big gray buildings with the big old trees all around it.

title: Notes On People; THEATER ON THE HUDSON
description: ''The war seemed to be a perfect place for drama,'' Thomas Bird said as the Circle Line boat chugged out into the Hudson River, ''and I didn't want any commercial writers or film makers making false statements for us. They weren't telling our story.''

title: Around the World; Former Iranian Hostage To Get Early Discharge
description: Staff Sgt. Joseph Subic Jr., one of 52 American hostages released last January after being held in Iran for 444 days and the only member of the armed forces who was not given a medal for his performance in Iran, will be discharged from the Army tomorrow, about a year early, Army officials said today.

title: Van Impe Captures 6th Stage in Cycling
description: LARY-SOULAN, France, June 30 (AP) - Lucien van Impe of Belgium won the sixth stage of the Tour de France bicycle race today, covering the 73-mile leg through the Pyrenees from Saint-Gaudens to Saint-Lary-Soulan in 3 hours 32 minutes 32 seconds.

title: The City; Methane Gas Plan Endorsed by Watt
description: After viewing some of New York City's parkland from the air yesterday, James G. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior, yesterday endorsed a proposal that would give the city control of the rights to methane gas emanating from a Brooklyn landfill in the Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: CAMPBELL TAGGART INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
SOLOIST WITH GOLDMA BAND
description: James F. Burke, principal cornet soloist with the Goldman Band for more than 30 years, died last Friday, apparently of a heart attack, while conducting a rehearsal of the Guggenheim Concert Band, successor to the Goldman Band. He was 58 years old and lived in Islip, L.I.

title: Notes On People; Wieghart Named Executive Editor at News
description: The Daily News has appointed James G. Wieghart, the newspaper's former Washington bureau chief and political columnist, to the new post of executive editor.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL HOUSTON (NL) - Signed Henry Jans- sen, catcher from Seton Hall and the club's eighth-round choice in the recent free-agent draft.; BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Signed James Edwards, free agent center formerly with Indiana, to four-year contract worth $700,000 a year plus incentive bonuses.; HOCKEY ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Extended the con- tract of Emile Francis, general manager, by two years through June 1983.; SOCCER BALTIMORE (MISL) - Acquired Joe Fink, forward, from Philadelphia for

title: KEY FIBER EVIDENCE IN ATLANTA CASE COULD BE FOCUS OF LONG LEGAL BATTLE
description: The homicide case in which Wayne B. Williams has been ordered held for possible indictment is likely to produce a protracted and complex legal battle over ''trace evidence,'' a specialty in forensic science that is not so widely discussed as firearm or fingerprint identification but is of increasing importance in criminal trials.

title: Use of State Troopers In Trenton Is Hailed
description: The experimental use of state trooper patrols here was declared a success by Attorney General James R. Zazzali.

title: The City; Bridge Walkway Remaining Closed
description: The pedestrian walk on the Brooklyn Bridge will remain closed until further notice, the city's Department of Transportation said. City engineers are continuing an inspection of the span following Sunday's accident when two cables snapped and a visiting tourist was injured.

title: Lillian Carter Recuperating
description: Lillian Carter, mother of former President Jimmy Carter, was recovering without complications today from a mastectomy to remove a cancerous growth, hospital officials said. Mrs. Carter, 82 years old, was ''in very good spirits'' as she prepared to move from the intensive-care unit at Americus-Sumter County Hospital to a private room,

title: Conoco Votes to Oppose Seagram Takeover Bid
description: Conoco's board of directors voted unanimously Tuesday to oppose an offer by the Seagram Company Ltd. for 35 million shares at $73 a share - a 40.7 percent stake in the oil company.

title: Greek Club Loses 2 Stars
description: The national team of Greece will meet the Cosmos at Giants Stadium tonight without two of its star forwards. The Cosmos, meanwhile, may be without Ivan Buljan, the sweeper who is bothered by a groin injury.

title: Lawrence Peskin Opens New Ad Agency Today
description: Lawrence Peskin, former principal in Harvard, Peskin & Edrick, which became Harvard & Edrick and was acquired last week by Warren, Muller, Dolobosky, is starting a new agency today, Lawrence Peskin Advertising, in the Empire State Building.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Medical International Inc. said it had completed the acquisition of Brookwood Health Services Inc.

title: PEOPLES EXPRESS AIRLINES reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-No yr ago comparable results since the company was only incorporated on Apr 7, 1980; latest results are for the period from Apr 7, 1980 to Mar 31, 1981

title: For Family Continuity
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: When Alma Denny wrote ''Recalling What the Family Never Knew'' (June 24), she hit close to my own life because for the past five years I have been trying to find out things about my own family. A preacher's son, the youngest of six children, I was born when my mother was 43 and knew her but slightly.

title: WOMEN STAGE FIFTH AVE. RALLY FOR RIGHTS AMENDMENT
description: Overhead, purple, gold and white balloons floated in the noonday sky, fragile reminders of the colors of the suffragists; occasionally one would pop with a loud report.

title: Vanity Fair's Return Set
description: For the last 45 years, the only sign of Vanity Fair magazine, the sophisticated darling of the Roaring Twenties, was the monthly notation on the spine of Vogue that said: ''Vogue (Incorporating Vanity Fair).''

title: PRICES FARMERS GET FELL 0.7% FROM MAY
description: Prices that farmers get for their raw products fell seventh-tenths of 1 percent in June from the May level but still averaged 11 percent higher than in June of last year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: LILCO RETAIL UNIT
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said it had formed a separate, wholly owned subsidiary to sell solar water heating systems and high-efficiency gas heat equipment for home use. Lilco's president, Wilfred Uhl, said that the new company, Lilco Energy Systems Inc., had been capitalized at $500,000, with the funds coming solely from the utility's shareholders. Utility customers will pay none of the cost of capitalization or operation of the new company, Mr. Uhl said.

title: Wichita State Asked To Answer Charges
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today asked Wichita State to respond to a list of alleged improprieties in its basketball program going back to 1975 and ranging from improper recruiting to illegal financial assistance.

title: CONTRAST IN STYLES AT GLASS GALLERY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Hollister is a freelance who writes frequently about glass. By PAUL HOLLISTER

title: STUDY SUPPORTS LIMITED SURGERY FOR BREAST CANCER
description: Surgery that spares most of the breast can be as effective as radical mastectomy in treating women with early breast cancer, according to a major study done in Italy and published yesterday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: SOME DEVELOPING LANDS GAIN IN BIRTH CONTROL, REPORT SAYS
description: Contraception in some developing nations is rapidly approaching the levels found in the United States, a publication of Johns Hopkins Hospital reports.

title: Tag Sale Advice
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: J.C. Barden's article on tag sales (''Tag Sales: It's High Season for Aficionados of the Secondhand,'' May 28) reminded me of a sage piece of advice I received from a woman at a roadside auction. She was seated in her well-worn folding beach chair, surrounded by cartons of kitchen gadgets and piles of nested pots, watching me examine a black lacquer box.

title: 12 Cable TV Proposals Filed for New York's 'Outer Boroughs'
description: Stacks of cardboard boxes were needed to file 21 lengthy reports submitted for yesterday's deadline by 14 concerns seeking cable television franchises in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island. The reports, elabo-rating on the original applications, will be examined over the next several months. The Board of Estimate is expected to award contracts by next spring and the four boroughs could have initial cable service in two years.

title: STAGE: 'DAMN YANKEES' (NOT ON STRIKE)
description: ''DAMN YANKEES,'' at Jones Beach, is what it is; so is its star, Joe Namath. A production at Jones Beach is not like productions elsewhere: Zachs Bay laps at the set; fog rolls across the stagelights; for $1 you rent a blanket to keep warm. Mr. Namath is different, too. He is not so much a performer as a personality, and the wonder is not that he can sing or act well, but that he can sing or act at all. Dancing, however, is beyond him, although once or twice he does sway in time to music.

title: WALDHEIM ASSAILS TIGHT-MONEY POLICY
description: Kurt Waldheim, Secretary General of the United Nations, today sharply criticized what he termed ''too exclusive reliance'' on monetary policy in the fight against inflation because of its impact on interest rates.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results reflect an 80 day coal strike

title: A CITY GROTTO RECALLS STORIED PAST OF SHELLS AND CAVERNS
description: GROTTOMANIA, like scurvy, is on the wane. It would be nice to have a grotto, people think, but a pool comes first. Grottoes are from another place and another time, and we do not feel shamed and diminished for the lack of them.

title: Sullivan Testifies Davis Warned Him on Move
description: Charles Sullivan, executive vice president of the New England Patriots, testified today that Al Davis, managing general partner of the Oakland Raiders, warned him against standing in the way of the Raiders' proposed move to Los Angeles.

title: Letters; IF THE TAINO TOWERS HAD NOT BEEN BUILT
description: To the Editor:

title: College Head Calls $75 Per Diem Not Enough
description: The $75 daily expense limit allowed by the University of Arizona is not enough to survive on, the school's president, John Schaefer, said today in his testimony at the trial of the school's former football coach.

title: UNITED CHURCH OF CHRIST REAFFIRMS LIBERALISM
description: Turning aside suggestions that the church moderate its liberal social pronouncements, delegates to the general synod of the 1.7-million-member United Church of Christ reaffirmed the denomination's activist stance and chose peace and family-life issues as priorities for the next two years.

title: Around the Nation; COURT BACKS WOMAN ON SEX BIAS DISMISSAL
description: A woman who was assaulted at work by her lover, a fellow employee, had a valid sex discrimination complaint when she was dismissed but he was not, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: AMEX SEEKS RADIO LINK
description: The American Stock Exchange has asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to build a portable two-way radio system to link floor traders to their clerks. The F.C.C. today set a July 25 deadline for public comment.

title: CONTROL BOARD URGES CITY TO TAKE 'STRINGENT' ACTION FOR '83 BUDGET
description: The staff of the state's Financial Control Board said yesterday that New York City's spending had grown to the point that it might be unable to balance its budget in the next fiscal year without cutting expenses or imposing new taxes.

title: REAGAN AIDES CALL STRAINS WITH HAIG 'FACT OF LIFE'
description: White House officials say they have concluded that difficult, sometimes strained relations with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. are ''a fact of life'' in the Reagan Administration, but they emphasize that Mr. Haig has the President's full confidence.

title: FRENCH ACQUISITION
description: Saint-Gobain-Pont-a-Mousson S.A. said today that it would take control of Logabax S.A., the French office computer company, which is now in the hands of a receiver. Italy's Olivetti S.p.A., in which S.G.P.M. has a 30 percent stake, will hold 65 percent of the capital of a new company, Ste Nouvelle Logabax, and an S.G.P.M. subsidiary, Cie des Machines Bull, will hold the remaining 35 percent, it said. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.

title: COSMOS WIN BY 2-0 FROM GREEK SQUAD
description: Roberto Cabanas scored in the first half and Giorgio Chinaglia in the second as the Cosmos defeated the national team of Greece, 2-0, at Giants Stadium tonight.

title: DIRECTOR HELD LIABLE IN SUIT
description: The State Supreme Court said today that a director of a company forced out of business in what was once alleged to be the state's largest case of fraud is liable for misappropriation of funds by other corporate officers.

title: 2 BOATS SOUGHT IN ATLANTIC
description: Coast Guard cutters and aircraft today searched for two missing pleasur boats blown off course in rough Atlantic waters by the winds of the tropical storm named Bret. The storm hit the Virgina coast shortly after midnight. The Coast Guard said it lost communication with the 43-foot sailingyacht Patriot and the 40-foot-motor-sailer Valiant Lady.

title: Helpful Hardware; ORDERING GARDEN TOOLS; by Barbara L. Isenberg and Mary Smith
description: CATALOGUES are a good source for garden tools. Generally, those from Sears, Brookstone and Lillian Vernon have a small selection of useful implements for the garden. Gardener's Eden has a new 24-page color catalogue that is devoted solely to good-quality gardening equipment for both indoor and outdoor work.

title: By Sports of The Times; Forgotten Tennis Woman
description: SHE has been the forgotten woman at Wimbledon this year

title: Going Out Guide
description: AL FRESCO

title: CHRYSLER OVERTIME
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would have only one of its four operating assembly plants working overtime next week after more than two consecutive months of extensive overtime production. The company said its Belvidere, Ill., plant, which builds the subcompact Omni-Horizon models, will operate two nine-hour daily shifts in its 19th consecutive week of overtime. Chrysler, whose sales for the year are up 23 percent over the disastrous levels of 1980, gave no reason for the cutback in overtime.

title: TWO DIE IN LOS ANGELES BLAST:
description: Firefighters inspect wreckage of hottub rental business destroyed early yesterday by an explosion and fire. Two persons were killed. The police are investigating the cause of the blast.

title: SUIT NAMES LEVITT FOUNDATION HEAD
description: William J. Levitt, the millionaire builder of homes, was accused yesterday of having illegally transferred for his own use at least $8 million from the Levitt Foundation that he created more than 40 years ago as a tax-exempt philanthropy.

title: IN STAVROPOULOS'S CLASSIC MODE
description: ''IWOULD never appear at the Metropolitan Opera in anything that wasn't one of George's floating chiffons,'' Yvetta Graff said at the opening of George Stavropoulos's fall collection this week. ''I've worn his clothes for 21 years - I guess I can say how long, since I've got two grown boys - and they've always been thrilling.''

title: BRZEZINSKI PRAISES WHITE HOUSE, URGES REAGAN-BREZHNEV MEETING
description: The new Administration has shown enough toughness toward the Soviet Union to warrant a meeting between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, according to Zbigniew Brzezinski.

title: WILTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Net income figures include tax credits

title: MICHIGAN PLANE CRASH KILLS 5
description: A twin-engine Cessna 401 developed engine trouble minutes after takeoff from Muskegon Airport last night and crashed in flames, killing the pilot and four passengers. They were identified as Richard Wilson, the pilot, and Dr. David Amos, William White, Charles Schuler Jr. and Dr. Guido Annessa of Muskegon, all board members at Mercy Hospital in Muskegon.

title: GENSTAR OPPOSED ON STOCK OPTION
description: The First City Financial Corporation, which is involved in a takeover bid for the Canada Permanent Mortgage Corporation, asked the Ontario Supreme Court to set aside a one-year option granted the Genstar Corporation of Montreal last week allowing Genstar to buy Treasury shares equal to 10 percent of Canada Permanent outstanding shares at $25 (Canadian) a share.

title: DANISH NEWS TIE-UP SPREADS AS JOURNALISTS QUIT THEIR JOBS
description: Mass resignations by journalists today shut down the Danish national news agency and two of Copenhagen's largest daily newspapers.

title: On Symphony Space
