description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In the article ''Providing Materials for Artistic Groups'' (June 18), Verna Gillis is identified as the director of Symphony Space. The managing director of Symphony Space is Linda P. Rogers. Our theater has received chairs, desks and the like from Materials for the Arts, but we did not receive an air-conditioner. JANE GREEN The Symphony Space Inc. Manhattan

title: GEORGES BANK PERMITS SET
description: The Interior Department said today that it had issued the first permits for exploratory oil and gas drilling in the Georges Bank area in Northeastern coastal waters to the Shell Oil Company and the Exxon Corporation.

title: Advertising; MINOLTA CONTINUES SEARCH FOR NEW AGENCY
description: The Minolta Corporation celebrated its fifth anniversary with Bozell & Jacobs yesterday as it continued the search that may end with a new agency.

title: GARBAGE HAULERS ARE OUT IN JERSEY
description: Garbage collection in northern and Central New Jersey was disrupted today after a teamsters local representing truck drivers struck an association of 35 privately owned refuse haulers.

title: SALVADOR LEADER SAYS BIGGEST THREAT IS FROM RIGHTIST BUSINESSMEN
description: The greatest threat to the Government of El Salvador is from conservative businessmen, not the revolutionary forces on the left, the President of the ruling civilian-military junta said today.

title: XEROX CUTS PRICES
description: The Xerox Corporation said today it had reduced prices on five of its low-volume copiers in the United States, effective immediately. The company said the reductions ranged from $225 to $2,075 and were part of its commitment to be competitive in the low-volume market. Xerox said the copiers involved were the Xerox 3100, 3100 LDC, 3107, 3109 and 660.

title: Bridge: A Marylander at Age of 13 Makes Grade as an Expert
description: Bridge experts seem to get younger all the time. The youngest player ever to become a life master, by three months, is Andrew Kaufman of Bowie, Md., who got his gold card last Saturday at the age of 13 years 4 months.

title: RELIGIOUS PARTIES IN ISRAEL LEANING TO BEGIN COALITION
description: Israel's religious parties, crucial to the formation of the next government, indicated today that they would prefer entering a coalition with Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Likud bloc rather than with the Labor Party of Shimon Peres.

title: POLISH PAPER ACCUSES UNION OF AN ANTI-SOVIET CAMPAIGN
description: Poland's official armed forces newspaper today accused Solidarity, the independent trade union organization, of engaging in an anti-Soviet campaign.

title: PROFILE OF A GUITARIST
description: TAL FARLOW is a tall, raw-boned North Carolinian, a warm, softspoken man with the lines of a frontiersman in his face who is one of the most accomplished jazz guitarists playing today. He is also an expert sign painter who says he gets as much pleasure out of painting signs as he does from playing his guitar.

title: HILLER AVIATION reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-After $7,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: HEAD START IS NOT IN BUDGET BILL BUT SPONSORS VOW TO CONTINUE IT
description: The Head Start program for needy preschool children would be eliminated under the budget package that passed the House last week, but Republican sponsors of the program say they will seek to authorize it under separate legislation.

title: Letters; FOR THE LESSER EMERGENCIES, '111' PERHAPS?
description: To the Editor:

title: EMPLOYEES GET CHRYSLER SHARES
description: The Chrysler Corporation's 94,000 workers in the United States will become stockholders in the No.3 auto maker in an agreement accompanying the Chrysler Loan Guarantee Act, the United Automobile Workers union has announced.

title: The Region; Suit to Exonerate Hauptmann Filed
description: Anna Hauptmann, the widow of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, who was electrocuted in 1936 for the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh's son, attempted to start a court action yesterday to exonerate her husband.

title: CHINA IS PLANNING ORDERLY GROWTH
description: China's new era of orderly development and modernization will stress the role of competent managers and be guided by a team of leaders instead of a single all-powerful ruler like Mao Zedong, the new chairman of the Chinese Communist Party said today.

title: The Region; 2 L.I. Towns Plan SWAT Teams
description: Police officials in Southampton and East Hampton are planning to train SWAT teams. Martin Lang, Town Supervisor of Southampton, said yesterday that because of the number of celebrities and diplomats who make their homes in Southampton during the summer season, the town must be prepared for situations requiring the special weapons and tactics teams.

title: YAMAHA-SPAIN ACCORD
description: The Yamaha Motor Company of Japan said today that it had signed an agreement with Spain's Banesto Group to set up a 50-50 joint venture company in Spain to produce motorcycles for the domestic market.

title: MUDD WAIVED RIGHT TO BE SOLO ANCHOR
description: In order to keep Tom Brokaw at NBC-TV, Roger Mudd waived his right to succeed John Chancellor as sole anchor of ''The NBC Nightly News,'' William J. Small, president of NBC News, said yesterday.

title: House to Hold Hearings On Status of Pro Sports
description: A House Judiciary Subcommittee announced yesterday in Washington that it will hold hearings starting July 14 to look into the effects of antitrust law and policy on professional sports.

title: EVASION OF TAXES BY CUNNINGHAM CHARGING BY U.S.
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, former Democratic chairman of New York State, was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges of conspiracy, tax evasion, perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: Business People; 2 NAMED TO HEAD WHEELABRATOR UNIT
description: Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. has established Kellogg Rust Inc. as a holding company for its two big subsidiaries in the engineering and construction business - the M.W. Kellogg Company and the Rust Engineering Company. At the same time, it named Robert W. Page, 54 years old, president and chief executive officer of the holding company and the subsidiaries and Frank H. Shipman Jr., 59, chairman of all three units.

title: 2 CONSERVATION GROUPS URGE AN IMMEDIATE END TO WHALING
description: Two international conservation groups urged an immediate ban today on commercial whaling to insure the survival of many threatened species.

title: Around the World; BRITISH LABOR PANEL FAVORS A UNIFIED IRELAND
description: In a major shift, the opposition Labor Party's policy group has recommended support for the eventual reunification of Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic, party officials said today.

title: Letters; KICK DOWN THE HURDLES TO CHINA TRADE
description: To the Editor:

title: On Spotless Living
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: After looking at some of the pristine settings shown in the Home Section, I have often had to ask: ''Don't these people have any clutter in their homes? Don't they ever have newspapers lying around? Don't they ever clip recipes that they never quite get around to filing? Don't they ever spill coffee or have a guest who overturns a mixed drink?''

title: SILVERMAN: CAUGHT BETWEEN HIGH AND LOW ROADS
description: FRED SILVERMAN was sitting in his sixth-floor office at 30 Rockefeller Plaza one day not long ago, talking animatedly News Analysis on the phone to a Hollywood producer while two of his executives stood by patiently. Finally, one of the executives turned to the other. ''I don't believe this,'' he said. ''Here is the president of one of the most important companies in the world and he's on the phone arguing about where to schedule a Daffy Duck cartoon.''

title: VACATIONS HANG ON PHONE CALL AS SUMMER SUBLETS GO STALE
description: HUNDREDS of Manhattan apartment dwellers are waiting anxiously by their telephones this summer, some with suitcases already packed, for the call that may never come.

title: FACELIFT IN MEXICO FOR A CLASSIC PULLMAN
description: MEXICO CITY FOR five years now, two young American designers, Susan Wolfe and Laurie Dalton, have been, in Mrs. Wolfe's words, making ''a gringo operation flourish on what's available in Mexico.''

title: ALBANY TALKS SEEK TO AVERT FARE RISE BEYOND 75
description: With the Metropolitan Transportation Authority ready to approve a 75-cent bus and subway fare and a 25 percent increase in commuter rail fares tomorrow, legislative leaders negotiated here into the night with each other and with Governor Carey on a tax plan to keep the fares from rising even higher in two weeks.

title: Letters; WHAT CLASSROOMS NEED: BELL, BOOK AND INSTRUCTIONAL HARDWARE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: TAX LIMIT IN CALIFORNIA THREATENING TO CUT LOS ANGELES COUNTY SERVICES

title: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES RISE BROADLY
description: Prices declined and interest rates rose in all sectors of the credit markets yesterday as dealers tried to reduce their inventories at a time of light investor demand and extremely high financing costs.

title: Executive Changes
description: * American Invsco Corporation, Chicago, has named Irene Gouletas D'Agnese executive vice president for financial management and administration.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
SOVIET ATOM TEST REPORTED
description: The Soviet Union apparently exploded an atomic bomb underground today in the Semipalatinsk region of Central Asia, the Military Observatory at Hagfors reported. Seismic signals measuring 5.4 on the Richter scale indicated a weak atomic explosion in hard rock, the observatory said.

title: Macchiarola Removes Examiners' Chairman
description: Frank J. Macchiarola, the City Schools Chancellor, yesterday suspended without pay the chairman of the Board of Examiners, Ethel Fitzgerald, ''for conduct unbecoming her position and substantial cause that renders her unfit to properly perform her duties.''

title: HOLIDAY CLOSINGS
description: Stock and commodity exchanges, the Federal Reserve Bank and Federal and New York City government offices will close tomorrow, Friday, in observance of Independence Day. Banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will remain open.

title: TOWN DEBATES SIAMESE TWINS' CASE
description: The talk began in this community in the blackearth country of eastern Illinois after the state took custody of the Siamese twins born to a local couple in May.

title: NEW SAUDI OIL OUTLET
description: The first shipment of oil through the 747-mile trans-Arabia pipeline was loaded aboard a tanker today, opening Saudi Arabia's second major oil export outlet and the first on the Red Sea.

title: The U.N. Today; July 2, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Subcommittee on Petitions, Infor- mation and Assistance of the Decoloni- zation Committee - 3 P.M.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Index; International
description: Mitterrand attacks U.S. policies on Central America A2 Reagan aides call strains with Haig ''a fact of life'' A3 Salvadoran leader says biggest threat is from businessmen A8 Government/Politics Agreement reached in Albany on penalties for drunken driving B2 Assembly approves withholding of bail in some cases B2 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Independence Day is Saturday. Most Federal and municipal offices will close tomorrow; New York State offices will be open. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended tomorrow and Saturday; all other rules in effect. Sanitation - Regular collections tomorrow. Collections normally made on Saturdays will be made Sunday. Federal Offices - Closed tomorrow and Saturday. State Offices - Open tomorrow. Courts - State, Federal and local courts closed tomorrow. Municipal Offices - Closed tomorrow. Post Offices - Open tomorrow, closed Saturday; only special delivery and express mail delivered Saturday. Banks - Open tomorrow. Stock and commodity markets -Closed tomorrow. Transportation - Buses and subways on regular schedule tomorrow; on Sunday schedule Saturday. L.I.R.R. and Conrail Harlem, Hudson and New Haven Divisions on regular schedule tomorrow; holiday schedule Saturday. Libraries - Closed tomorrow and Saturday.

title: ARCHITECT AND DESIGNER
description: Marcel Breuer, the Bauhaus architect who played a major role in shaping 20th-century architecture and design, died last night at his home on East 63d Street in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.

title: No Headline
description: IRAN ACCUSES 50 LEFTISTS OF CONSPIRING TO DESTOY THE PARLIAMENT

title: Advertising; EPSTEIN RABOY NAMES PRESIDENT
description: Mitchell J. Epstein and Richard H. Raboy, founders of Epstein Raboy Advertising and both copywriters, have filled their president's office, vacant since Joseph P. Foran left with his 11 kids to run an inn in Maine a year and a half ago.

title: ECOLOGY PROGRAMS SURVIVE CUTBACKS
description: Many environmental programs, particularly those involving energy conservation, were treated with relatively little severity by the House of Representatives in its budget action last week.

title: RIDERS CALL DELAYS WORSE THAN FARE RISE
description: Even on the steaming subterranean platforms of New York City's subway stations, humor dies hard. It may, in fact, be the ultimate test of humor to ask subway riders waiting in grimy stations for trains so crowded that they cannot board them how they feel about an increase in the fare tomorrow with a possible increase to follow two weeks from now. There were some extraordinary answers.

title: Critic's Notebook; CANDY IS DANDY, BUT NOT AT A DOLLAR
description: I SAY we've all got to take turns being reasonable, whether we're going to films or to plays or to pieces. I first came to this philosophical conclusion a month or so ago, while reading a pleasantly intemperate piece in American Film on the general state of movie houses today. The article pointed out, in some detail, the hazards lying in wait for present-day filmgoers, and it wasn't talking about the quality of the films. It was talking about the littered floors, the impertinent ushers, the unshushably noisy audiences, the sloppy projection of already-damaged prints and the price of candy sold in the lobby. To all but one of which items, I must myself say a fervent Amen.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle on the Chinese Communist Party's assessment of Mao Zedong yesterday incorrectly gave the dates of the eco- nomic development campaign known as the Great Leap Forward. It took place in 1958-59.

title: DATING FURNITURE BY OLD CATALOGUES
CONTINENTAL FILES PLAN
description: Continental Air Lines has decided to risk delisting by the New York Stock Exchange in its bid to become the nation's largest worker-owned company.

title: PEKING STRESSES ECONOMIC GAINS AS PARTY PRIORITY
description: The Chinese Communist Party has published a platform of party goals that appeal to almost everyone except people opposed to continued Communist rule of China.

title: Notes on People; It Started With a Fall
description: One of the four musicians honored with special Heritage Awards at the New York Jazz Awards ceremony Tuesday was Vic Dickenson, the trombonist. He has been starring since the 1920's in such big bands as those of Count Basie and Benny Carter.

title: COFFEE QUOTAS ARE CUT AGAIN
description: Falling prices, oversupply and stagnant consumption forced the 70-nation International Coffee Organization today to cut export quotas for the fourth time in the crop year ending Sept. 30.

title: JUDY COOPERSTEIN STILL HAS THE TOUCH
description: The greatest female amateur golfer on Long Island - if not all New York - sits in the coziness of a country club on the North Shore, where, over their tall iced teas, other members peer at the celebrity in their midst.

title: DAN DANIEL, WRITER AND BASEBALL EXPERT 50 YEARS, DIES AT 91
description: Dan Daniel, considered by many the dean of American baseball writers, died early today at Cypress Community Hospital. He was 91 years old.

title: Around the World; 120 DIE AS TROPICAL STORM LASHES THE PHILIPPINES
description: Tropical storm Kelly, the worst in eight months, pounded the central Philippines with heavy rains today.

title: 3 MEXICANS FACE COAST TRIAL ON ALIEN ENSLAVEMENT COUNT
description: A married couple and their son have been ordered to stand trial on charges that they kidnapped, enslaved and imprisoned illegal aliens in a Los Angeles home.

title: Market Place; MONOGRAM'S FEWER SHARES
description: FEW persons have noticed, perhaps, but Monogram Industries has bought back a bigger percentage of its own shares than almost every other New York Stock Exchange company that has not gone private.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JULY 2, 1981; Markets
description: The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 9.22 points, to 967.66, its seventh loss in eight trading sessions, as rising short-term interest rates deflated investor enthusiasm for stocks. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 49.1 million shares from Wednesday's 41.6 million. Conoco, a takeover candidate, rose 3 1/8 points as 1.4 million shares changed hands. (Page D1.) Prices declined and interest rates rose in all credit markets as dealers tried to trim inventory. (D7.)

title: The Editorial Notebook; READING IS ON THE REBOUND
description: What's the meaning of the rise in New York City reading scores, especially at schools in poor neighborhoods? Some say it's a mirage, since test scores are untrustworthy at best, manipulated at worst. But New York's is not the only urban system showing improvement. To get a better sense of what's going on, I dropped in at the end of the term on one of the city's reading-score stars, P.S. 155 in Ocean Hill-Brownsville.

title: HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 5
DANCE: BRYAN HAYES'S 'FIELD'
description: BRYAN HAYES'S new ''Field Dances,'' an hourlong piece that was performed Saturday at Xavier High School, is set to a score by Steve Reich. The dance unfolds in a big gymnasium: a stream of slow circlings, soft-edge lunges and airy, ebbing walks and runs. Sound familiar? But ''Field Dances'' was not at all derivative, despite its resemblances to the sleek calisthenic ''trance'' dances so popular in recent years. Mr. Hayes has a voice of his own, though a quiet one, and an inquiring sense of theater and of shapes and their relationships.

title: FREE BUS TRANSFERS MAY BE VOTED
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, when it meets today to raise the fares on New York City's subways, buses and commuter rail lines, is expected to institute free bus transfers to cushion the blow of a 75-cent fare.

title: News Analysis
description: Today was Canada's 114th birthday, and everyone of singing age was supposed to intone ''O Canada'' exactly at noon. It is doubtful that many did, for Canadians have always been diffident about displaying national fervor. They are even inclined to selfdeprecation and expressions of surprise when other people take notice of them. Lately, Canadians with money or the ability to raise it have been attracting notice to an unusual degree. In a country where much of the economy is dominated by outsiders and where the entrepreneurial class tends to be cautious and conservative (when it is not reduced to outright branch-plant management), individuals and companies of modest size by world standards have been displaying so much aggressiveness that they have sent American businessmen scurrying to Washington for help. Two Investment Trends

title: Gardening; WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH; by Linda Yang; Ailing Street Trees
description: Where the surrounding soil is compacted and water runs off the surface, rain is useless for young or newly planted street trees. Turn and loosen the soil every other week if necessary and water well. If extra water does not help ailing trees, call the Forestry Division of your borough's Parks Department; the number is in the telephone book in the City Government section. A tree planted within the year is still the responsibility of the landscape contractor who planted it; he should also be informed of its poor health. Report a dead street tree to the Forestry Department and request its removal, along with the stump and root system, to facilitate replanting later. Try to determine the cause of death - neglect, vandalism, insects, disease - so that a more appropriate species may replace it. Street tree information is available from the Horticultural Society of New York (757-0915). Tree tips in English or Spanish are also available free from the Street Tree Consortium. Send a self-addressed, stamped envelope to 3 West 29th Street, New York 10001.

title: DEVELOPED NUCLEAR REACTORS
description: William John Ozeroff, a physicist who was a leader in the development of nuclear power reactors, died Monday at the Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation here of lukemia. He was 63 years old.

title: MILE-SQUARE HOBOKEN, STILL A BROWNSTONERS' HAVEN
description: THE funny thing about Hoboken is that it has been discovered - over and over and over again. It's been almost 10 years since New Yorkers began to appreciate the charms of the mile-square city on the other side of the Hudson, but waves of newcomers continue to arrive.

title: HARDY BAND TAKES AN URBAN BUTTERFLY COUNT
description: A little band of nature enthusiasts, rambling everywhere from a cemetery in Van Cortlandt Park to a clump of milkweed behind the Central Park police station house, yesterday completed the first organized butterfly census of Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Letters; REAGAN'S REALISTIC ATTITUDY TOWARD MOSCOW
description: ,2To the Editor:

title: Home Improvement; SOME TIPS FOR THE AMATEUR HOUSE PAINTER
description: ONE of the biggest maintenance jobs faced by the average homeowner every four to six years is repainting the outside of the house. In recent years inflation has tremendously increased the number of homeowners who do the job themselves. Modern exterior paints are easier than ever to apply. And if a good quality paint is carefully applied, results can last longer than ever before. In addition, today's latex paints brush out smoothly and simplify the cleaning of brushes, rollers and other tools. premature cracking or peeling, or they fail to end up with the kind of job that they had hoped for - even when a top-quality paint is purchased. In most such cases, the first impulse is to blame the brand of paint, but more often than not some common-sense rules were not followed in preparing the surfaces or in mixing and applying the paint. To help minimize such disappointments, here are some rules to follow: * Before starting, take time to check all caulking around window and door frames and siding and trim joints. Joints or seams that are open where caulking is missing or cracked will allow water to enter and soak into the wood or masonry, and this is one of the most frequent causes of premature paint failure. * Replace dried out or cracked putty around window panes with fresh glazing compound after first scraping out all of the old material. Also, make all other needed structural repairs to the outside before starting to paint.

title: PARENTS, BOOKS AND OBSCENITIES
description: When ''365 Days'' was published in 1971, one reviewer said, ''The last chapter of this book, published separately as 'The Burn Ward,' is already justly famous. The rest of the book deserves to be.''

title: 9.22 DROP PUTS DOW AT 967.66
description: With short-term interest rates moving higher again, stock prices continued to drop yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, posting its seventh loss in eight trading sessions, retreated 9.22 points, to 967.66.

title: PERU CUTS OIL PRICE
description: Peru has reduced the price of its crude oil by about $4, to $34 a barrel, for exports to Japan in the third quarter, oil industry sources here said today. Petro Peru, the staterun oil company, also agreed to increase shipments slightly to 16,500 barrels a day from 16,100.

title: Advertising; NESTLE, UNIT OF EXXON MAKE SHIFT
description: AN Exxon unit and Nestle made agency changes yesterday. Just a little fireworks before the Fourth. Having seen creative presentations by six ad agencies, the Exxon Office Systems Company is moving its $20 million advertising account to Marsteller from McCaffrey & McCall.

title: RESIDENTS OF CLEVELAND VOTE TO REDUCE CITY COUNCIL'S SIZE
description: Residents of Cleveland, by a margin of 2 to 1, voted yesterday to reduce the size of their City Council, the fourth-largest municipal legislative body in the nation's large cities.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Acapulco y los Arcos Restaurantes plans to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $10 million in convertible subordinated debentures.

title: TIME INC. TO TEST NEW CABLE SERVICE
description: Time Inc. announced plans to use San Diego as a test ground for a new service that will transmit 4,000 to 5,000 pages of news and information to cable subscribers over a number of channels.

title: A 2d Suspect in Cates Slaying Gives Himself Up in Brooklyn
description: A second suspect in the murder of Noel Cates, an Orange County man slain in Queens last month, surrendered to the police last night. The suspect, Mark Braun, 24 years old, of 32 Dorcher Street, Brooklyn, walked into the 75th Precinct station with his mother.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
SEARLE SWEETENER
description: G.D. Searle & Company said that health authorities in Switzerland had approved the marketing of its Aspartame sweetener. Searle said the Swiss approval included use of the product in table-top sweeteners, beverage mixes, breakfast cereals, desserts, topping mixes and chewing gum. The company said it had introduced the sweetener in Europe under the Canderel brand name in France, Belgium and Luxembourg, adding that the product has been approved for marketing in Mexico, Brazil and the Philippines.

title: SINGAPORE OPENS NEW AIRPORT THAT IS CALLED ASIA'S LARGEST
description: Singapore today opened what is believed to the largest airport in Asia.

title: STUDY INDICATES INFANTS RECOGNIZE OWN VOICES
description: Infants will stop crying when they hear recordings of their own wails but will cry harder if they hear another baby crying, according to a study released today at Florida State University.

title: CROAT ACCUSED OF WAR CRIMES IS ORDERED DEPORTED
description: A Department of Justice official said today that the Government would move quickly to deport a person who as Interior Minister of the Nazi German puppet state of Croatia in World War II purportedly ordered the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people.

title: A YOUNG DESIGNER'S RISE
description: What Susan Beebe really wanted was to work for the designer Geoffrey Beene. But three days before her interview last summer, the young graduate of the Parsons School of Design received an order from Bergdorf Goodman for four of the handknit sweaters she had designed. Then Martha's, another elite New York retailer, ordered four more. Mr. Beene was forgotten.

title: CAMP SPECTER: HOMESICKNESS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Victoria Balfour is a freelance researcher and writer. By VICTORIA BALFOUR

title: Disputes End On 2 Salaries
description: Contract disputes were settled yesterday for two of the eight baseball players who filed default notices Tuesday with the Players Association alleging violations during the strike.

title: COURT, 6-3, RULES TV MUST SELL TIME IN FEDERAL RACES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that television stations are required to sell ''reasonable'' amounts of air time in political campaigns to the candidates for Federal office who request it.

title: FORMER HOSTAGE DISCHARGED
description: Staff Sgt. Joseph Subic, the only American serviceman held hostage in Iran who did not receive a commendation medal last month, was honorably discharged from the Army today.

title: NATIONAL GUARD IN ARKANSAS LOSES PLEA ON DISCRIMINATION
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Arkansas National Guard had a ''dismal'' record of racial discrimination and upheld an order requiring the Guard to fill 16 percent of its civilian jobs with blacks.

title: OFFICER TELLS HOW VICTIM OF TAUNTING HAD SOUGHT HELP TO LEAVE CITY
description: The young man who died on a Times Square subway track early Saturday after being taunted by a group of youths had sought help the night before, a Conrail police sergeant said yesterday.

title: 2 U.S. ANGENCIES TAKE ACTION AGAINST RESPIRATORS FOR WORKERS
description: Despite reservations at the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, two other Federal agencies acted today to revoke Government approval of a respirator worn by thousands of workers to protect them from toxic air on the job.

title: NEW STATUS FOR PURCHASING
description: Forklift trucks are ubiquitous at the B.F. Goodrich Company's 60 manufacturing and warehousing sites across the country. They are used to haul aircraft brakes, stack pallets of new tires and load boxes of polyvinyl chloride onto rail cars.

title: The Region; Yonkers Fears Loss of 506 Jobs
description: This city may lose up to 506 city jobs as a result of the state's failure to provide Yonkers with $24 million in aid, City Manager Eugene J. Fox told a meeting of the City Council's Budget Committee.

title: News Analysis
description: The political campaign season got at least a little longer yesterday. The Supreme Court's decision telling the television networks they had to sell commercial time to candidates for Federal office when the Federal Communications Commission said a campaign had begun and not when it suited their convenience may break little constitutional ground. It may leave the networks disappointed that their renewed assertion of a First Amendment status equal to newspapers have again been scorned.

title: FRED MEYER INC.
description: Fred Meyer Inc., a Portland, Ore., shopping center and department store operator, said it had received inquiries about acquiring the company from an unidentified United States company and a foreign company. Meanwhile, it said its board of directors was still considering a $55-a-share leveraged buyout proposal from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company of New York, an investment firm.

title: WARDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-After $269 extraordinary charge from the settlement of a laws

title: Briefs
description: * American Bank and Trust Co. of Reading, Pa., agreed in principle to acquire National Bank and Trust Co. of Kennett Square, Pa., for about $10.7 million in stock.

title: ERNST, E C, INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-Including extraordinary gain of $12,652,000 which includes an $11.8 million gain from the divestment of the I.K. Comstock & Co unit...C-Net loss

title: I. ROY PSATY, 76, THE PRESIDENT OF CONSTRUCTION CORPORATION
description: I. Roy Psaty, president of the Manhattan building concern of Psaty & Fuhrman Inc., died of a heart attack last Friday. Mr. Psaty, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 76 years old.

title: VOTING RIGHTS
description: The 1965 Voting Rights Act is due to expire next year and already loud voices are heard calling for burial of this major civil rights law.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE PLAYBOY INTERVIEW. Edited by G. Barry Golson. 721 pages. Wideview Books. Paper, $9.95.

title: ANXIOUS MOMENTS:
description: Lori Troutner, 14, Steve Starkey, 8, Jenna Starkey, 6, and their mothers waiting as Fort Wayne, Ind., rescuers tried to find a friend, 10-year-old Patrick Taylor, who fell into a storm sewer while playing. The water carried him two blocks underground to a nearby lake; he emerged bruised but alive.

title: Advertising; NEW WEST'S NEW NAME WILL BE CALIFORNIA
description: New West, a Clay Felker creation, once a Rupert Murdoch property, which since September has been a sister publication of Texas Monthly in the Mediatex Corporation of Austin, Tex., will change its name to just plain California with the October issue.

title: GANNETT IN OFFER FOR EL DIARIO
description: The Gannett Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire New York's Spanish language newspaper El Diario-LaPrensa from Diversified Media Inc. for an undisclosed price.

title: At Home Abroad; THE PRICE OF MR. BEGIN
description: The opposition made dramatic gains, the result was just about a dead heat, the next Government will have only a narrow majority. But the world should not be distracted by those details of Israel's election. What matters is that Menachem Begin is almost certain to remain in power. It could matter a very great deal.

title: Advertising; ACCOUNTS
description: * AM Cable TV Industries Inc., Quakertown, Pa., to Spiro & Associates, Philadelphia.

title: 2 FOOD GIANTS SET TO MERGE
description: Shareholders of Standard Brands Inc. and Nabisco Inc. yesterday overwhelmingly approved the merger of the two food industry giants into a new company to be known as Nabisco Brands Inc.

title: TRASHING THE RIGHT TO TRAVEL
description: The Supreme Court's decision in the Philip Agee passport case should confound the President's search for a new Justice who agrees that ''the role of the courts is to interpret the law, not to create new law by judicial fiat.'' The Court, rushing in where Congress has declined to tread, made bad new law. It gave the State Department power to deny passports for reasons never spelled out by Congress. The decision aims at the travels of a man who warrants contempt, but wounds all who believe in a Government of duly enacted laws.

title: A LOSS OF BEARINGS
description: It was a desperate gambit from the start, but how else was a man to keep from feeling old and out of touch on his 34th birthday ? I dug out my childhood roller skates, filed away the rust, and made a beeline for Columbus Avenue. Almost everybody young and trendy in New York seemed to be rollerskating on Columbus Avenue. And if they weren't roller-skating on Columbus, they were shopping at oh-so-cutely monickered boutiques on Columbus, or sitting in sidewalk cafes that showcased the versatility of bacon bits and oozed the esthetic of perpetual Sunday brunch.

title: JAZZ: TORME, MULLIGAN AND SHEARING
description: WHEN a concert is built around such established stellar performers as Mel Torme, Gerry Mulligan and George Shearing, one can usually expect that each will have a segment of the evening to himself and that all three might come together once or twice in the course of the performance.

title: Around the Nation; TENTATIVE PACT REACHED IN CAROLINA RIGHTS SUIT
description: The University of North Carolina has reached agreement with the Federal Government on desegregation guidelines for the state university system.

title: CAR OUTPUT UP IN JUNE
description: The major United States auto makers turned out 708,195 cars in June, a 33 percent increase from the 531,876 built during the comparable month last year, according to company reports released today.

title: U.S. AID FOR THRIFT UNITS POSES QUESTIONS OF NEED
description: Savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks, which have provided most of the money for the $700 billion of home mortgages outstanding in the nation, are reporting record outflows of deposits and mounting losses from operations.

title: Weaver's Manager Is Blamed by Boxer
description: Mike Weaver, the World Boxing Association champion, blamed his manager yesterday for the never-ending legal morass over the tangled heavyweight picture, and he has invited all interested parties to ''meet with me'' in Los Angeles tomorrow.

title: ROME RAISES TRANSIT FARES
description: The City of Rome raised bus and streetcar fares today from 10 cents to 20 cents.

title: Around the World; WHITES BACK SMITH PARTY IN ZIMBABWE BALLOTING
description: The Republican Front, the party of former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia, today won the first of two by-elections reserved for whites and considered important for the future of the minority group in black-ruled Zimbabwe.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-After losses of $81,000 for the qr and $2.3 million for the yr from equity in Muirhead Ltd and $1.6 million gain for the yr on the settlement of litigation...C-Including $1.4 milli gain from the sale of equipment

title: UNCLE SUGAR PAYS OFF
description: Could President Reagan buy his vote in last month's battle over the Federal budget, a colleague asked Representative John Breaux? ''No,'' replied the Louisiana Democrat, ''I was rented.''

title: BLACKS FOR PRETORIA'S PLANES
description: South African Airways plans to recruit black women as flight attendants, the Government has announced. The Government-owned international airline already employs black women as ground attendants at major airports, but until now flight crews have been all-white.

title: SOLIDARISM, AN ANSWER TO REAGAN DARWINISM
description: President Reagan may be a nice guy but he sees the world as a mean, pitiless place. He often reminds us that struggling up the ladder of opportunity, as he did, is an arduous, treacherous, and above all lonely climb.

title: GENERAL PORTLAND REJECTS ACQUISITION
description: Directors of General Portland Inc. today rejected a ''shocking'' unsolicited purchase offer from Canada Cement Lafarge Ltd. and are suing to stop further acquisition efforts, James Lendrum, General Portland chairman, said.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: DILLINGHAM CUTS
description: Shareholders of the Dillingham Corporation of Honolulu overwhelmingly approved a plan to liquidate the company's Hawaiian commercial property and to transfer ownership to a new limited partnership of present stockholders. The company would not estimate the value of the property to be transferred, but market sources estimate it conservatively at about $250 million, equal to about $15 a share on the roughly 16.9 million shares that will be outstanding after conversion of preferred stock and debentures.

title: MITTERRAND CRITICIZES U.S. POLICY
description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that he had ''serious reservations'' about United States policies in Central America. ''The people of the region want to put an end to the oligarchies that, backed by bloody dictatorships, exploit them and crush them under intolerable conditions,'' he said.

title: DUNLAP & ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
AFTER 13 YEARS, AUTO UNION JOINS A.F.L.-C.I.O. AGAIN
description: The United Automobile Workers formally rejoined the A.F.L.-C.I.O. today, 13 years after philosophical and policy differences caused it to bolt the country's main labor organization.

title: THE IMAGE BUILDERS FOR CORPORATIONS
description: John M. Diefenbach, the 42-year-old president of Landor Associates, looked thoughtfully across his office in a huge, creaking, 50-year-old ferryboat. He was discussing the public's perception of American business.

title: Letters; WHAT CLASSROOMS NEED: BELL, BOOK AND INSTRUCTIONAL HARDWARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Business People; FRED THE FURRIER WINS
description: Fred Schwartz, also known as Fred the Furrier at Alexander's, has come out on top in a suit that he and his companies brought against the Great Lakes Mink Association. The suit - a counterclaim that Mr. Schwartz brought after an unsuccessful action by the association against him for alleged misapplication of its Blackgama trademark - was settled with a payment to him of $50,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The worst thing about a fare increase is that you pay more for less.'' - Jeffrey Nichols, a commuter from Port Jefferson, L.I. (B1:3.)

title: Gardening; WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH
description: Flowers

title: Italian Man Is Kidnapped
description: Four men kidnapped a 28-yearold businessman in this southern Italian town today, the police reported. They said Mario Lamedica was overpowered by the men after midnight in the garage of his home.

title: GRAINS SOAR ON RUSSIAN REPORT
description: News that a heat wave was threatening the Soviet Union's wintersown wheat crop and spring grain crops caused huge trade buying of grain and oilseed futures on Middle West exchanges yesterday. As a result, grain and soybean futures prices, which have been under pressure all year long, soared.

title: MAY CONSTRUCTION SPENDING OFF 4.7%
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Spending for new construction in the United States fell 4.7 percent in May to an annual rate of $237.3 billion, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the fourth consecutive monthly decline.

title: TROMPE L'OEIL FROM NATURE
description: He first experimented in his own small apartment. Michael Thornton-Smith, a 29-year-old English artist, decided to make the place look larger by painting a trompe l'oeil scene on one of his closet doors.

title: ALBANY LEADERS FOR STIFFER DRIVING FINES
description: In a frenzied meeting this afternoon legislators from the Senate and the Assembly reached agreement on a series of bills to stiffen penalties for drunken driving and to help educate people about its dangers.

title: Around the Nation; 7 BODIES FOUND ON COAST AT 2 SITES OF SHOOTINGS
description: Seven persons were found dead in two homes in California today, and a fifth person was found critically injured, the authorities said.

title: PANCHO VILLA STATUE UNVEILED IN ARIZONA
description: Amid spirited controversy over Francisco (Pancho) Villa's role in history, a statue of the enigmatic Mexican revolutionary was unveiled yesterday in a downtown park here.

title: Hers; by Patricia O'Toole
description: GRADUATION has come and gone, and not one of the thousands of American schools has asked me to deliver a commencement address. It's just as well. Like other journalists, all I know is what I write in the papers. And if I'd spoken from my instincts instead of my information, anything I might have said would have been out of synch with 1981.

title: Notes on People; Back in the Air
description: New Jersey's Commissioner of Environment, Jerry English, has apparently survived a legislative effort to have her grounded. Acting Gov. Joseph P. Merlino deleted language from a spending plan adopted by the Legislature that would have prevented Mrs. English from traveling by helicopter, as she is wont to do. Mr. Merlino acted under instructions from Governor Byrne, who is in Europe.

title: MAXCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ARIZONA JUDGE, A WOMAN, IS HIGH COURT CONTENDER
description: Sandra D. O'Connor, a 51-year-old judge of the Arizona Court of Appeals, is a top contender to fill the Supreme Court vacancy, Reagan Administration sources said tonight.

title: SENTENCES PASSED IN INVASION PLOT:
description: A Federal marshal, left, escorts four mercenaries to court in New Orleans for sentencing in a plot to overthrow the Government of Dominica, a small Caribbean nation.

title: ASSEMBLY APPROVES ENDING OF BAIL IN SOME CASES
description: The State Assembly gave final approval today to a bill that would allow a judge to hold without bail a person charged with a serious crime while awaiting trial for another offense. The measure now goes to Governor Carey.

title: MOVE TO SHIFT FOSTER CARE TO STATES' CONTROL THWARTED IN HOUSE
description: Two California Congressmen, a liberal Democrat and a conservative Republican, worked quietly and separately last week to remove foster care and selected health programs from the block grants that are the heart of President Reagan's ''new Federalism'' plan to shift power to the states.

title: PORK OUTPUT MAY FALL
description: Pork production during the rest of the year is expected to be 10 percent less than last year and, in response to the production decline, hog prices will be higher, the Agriculture Department said today in a report.

title: City Gets $6.7 Million For a Tract in Nassau
description: Nassau County yesterday paid $6.7 million to New York City for 1,750 acres of city-owned land in Nassau County.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-After $609,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: CAREER DIPLOMATS NOMINATED FOR LIBERIA AND OMAN POSTS
description: President Reagan today nominated William Swing, a Foreign Service officer, as United States Ambassador to Liberia. Mr. Swing is now Ambassador to the Congo.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL HOUSTON (NL) - Signed Balor Moore and Geoffrey Meadows, pitchers. As- signed Moore to Tucson of the Pacific Coast League and Meadows to Sarasota of the Gulf Coast League. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Signed Mark Grant, pitcher, and assigned him to its rookie team in Great Falls, Mont.; BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Released John May, forward, and waived Richard John- son, center. INDIANA (NBA) - Signed Herb Wil- liams, center from Ohio State and the te

title: ROYAL BALLET: 'ISADORA' WITH SANDRA CONLEY
description: WHATEVER one thinks of Kenneth MacMillan's ''Isadora,'' it obviously fulfills its theatrical function as a company display piece for the Royal Ballet. Every member of the cast is totally believable in what is less a conventional ballet than a theater-piece with spoken texts.

title: KUWAIT FOCUS ON REFINING
description: Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifi al-Sabah, told the National Assembly today that the Government would increase the country's oil-refining capacity because selling refined products is so profitable.

title: News of Music; PACKAGED SUMMER FESTIVALS TAKE TO THE ROAD
description: ART may hold up a mirror to nature, but this summer's musicfestival scene is casting a pretty good reflection of the commercial world. The marketing concept that is particularly influencing cities such as New York, Washington, Sante Fe, N.M., and Aspen, Colo., is the package deal - the prefabricated music festival on wheels - or perhaps on wings, by which an entire series of events are booked, manned, rehearsed and performed in one city and then shipped in toto to the next.

title: BRADY MAY GO HOME FOR A WEEKEND SOON
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was shot in the head in the attempt on President Reagan's life, may be able to spend a weekend at home later this month, a hospital spokesmen said today.

title: REAGAN ADVISED TO ADMIT MEXICANS AS GUEST WORKERS
description: The Task Force on Immigration and Refugee Policy today advised President Reagan to let 50,000 Mexican aliens come to the United States each year as temporary workers and to grant permanent resident status to as many as 170,000 Cuban and Haitian refugees already settled in the country, according to Administration officials.

title: BASIC EARTH SCIENCE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
HEARINGS STALLED
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board's hearings into racefixing at New York tracks in the mid-1970's stalled yesterday after Jose Amy, a key figure in the investigations, refused to testify, and no significant new information was revealed by four witnesses. The hearings were recessed until Tuesday, when at least 11 jockeys will be called to testify.

title: DONATIONS ARE SOUGHT FOR YACHT FOR PRESIDENT
description: Conservative businessmen who returned the former Presidential yacht Sequoia to Washington say they will ask executives of major corporations to donate the money to pay for the ship and keep it up for use by President Reagan and his successors.

title: Around the Nation; 2 FORMER BLANTON AIDES SENTENCED TO FIVE YEARS
description: Two men who served as aides to former Gov. Ray Blanton were sentenced to five years in prison today for their part in a clemency-selling scheme.

title: CHICK COREA AND HIS QUARTET
description: THE Kool Jazz Festival's ''Evening With Chick Corea'' at Avery Fisher Hall Tuesday offered both Mr. Corea and his quartet plus, as openers, a pairing of Red Norvo and Tal Farlow, plus a bass player, Steve Novosel. It was a bland concert, comfortably conservative in idiom.

title: WARNER AMEX GETS INVESTMENT
description: Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., the jointly owned communications venture of Warner Communications Inc. and the American Express Company, said that the two parents had each made an equity investment of $100 million in the company to back up its existing $500 million revolving bank credit agreement.

title: Advertising; COUNTRY LIVING SET TO GO MONTHLY
description: Last week, Hearst threw a party to announce that Country Living would be going to a monthly frequency (of the 10-issues-a-year variety) with the February issue.

title: Rowdy Wimbledon Doubles Match Ends Quietly
description: The doubles match during which spectators hurled cushions and programs onto Wimbledon's center court late yesterday was completed today without rowdiness. Sue Barker of Britain and Ann Kiyomura of the United States took just 20 minutes to win their resumed third-round match against JoAnne Russell of the United States and Virginia Ruzici of Rumania, 4-6, 7-6, 9-7.

title: TWO PHILADELPHIA HOSPITALS STRUCK
description: Workers at Hahnemann Hospital pause in their picketing yesterday to let a patient into the emergency room.

title: U.S. RESTS ARGUMENTS IN BELL SUIT
description: The Justice Department rested its case today in the Federal antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and the court called a monthlong recess before Bell begins its defense presentation on Aug. 3.

title: LADY DIANA WON'T VOW TO OBEY CHARLES
description: In a break with royal precedent, Lady Diana Spencer has decided that she will not promise, at her wedding four weeks from today, to obey Prince Charles.

title: CAMPAIGN TO EXTEND VOTING RIGHTS ACT GAINS SUPPORT
description: The campaign to extend the Voting Rights Act of 1965 gained momentum in the last week as two influential Republicans, Senator Barry Goldwater and Representative Henry J. Hyde, endorsed legislative proposals similar to one favored by civil rights organizations.

title: Around the World; DETROIT'S LARGEST UNION AGREES TO A WAGE FREEZE
description: Members of Detroit's largest municipal union agreed to a two-year wage freeze today as Mayor Coleman A. Young moved closer to his goal of financial rejuvenation for the city.

title: FOX'S HIRSCHFIELD EMERGES AS VICTOR IN EXECUTIVE BATTLE
description: Alan J. Hirschfield, vice chairman and chief operating officer of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, emerged today as the victor in a management dispute that ended with the angry resignation of Dennis C. Stanfill as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: U.S. TO SEND 6 JETS TO ISRAEL ON TIME
description: The White House said today that the United States would send six F-16 fighter-bombers to Israel later this month as scheduled. In addition, according to Administration sources, President Reagan will also soon permit the delivery of four other F-16's that were suspended after Israel bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor with American-built planes on June 7.

title: EGYPTIANS SILENT ON OUTCOME OF ELECTIONS IN ISRAEL
description: President Anwar el-Sadat reiterated his call today for an agreement on autonomy for Palestinians in Israeli-occupied lands, but he was silent on the elections yesterday in Israel and on Prime Minister Menachem Begin's evident ability to form a new coalition.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: A CRAFTS FESTIVAL
description: American Crafts Festival, Lincoln Center.

title: GARY WON '75 GONCOURT UNDER PSEUDONYM 'AJAR'
description: In a strange epilogue to the suicide last December of the novelist Romain Gary, a relative of Mr. Gary's, Paul Pavlowitch, says in a new book that Mr. Gary was the author of a 1975 Goncourt Prize-winning novel attributed to a writer named Emile Ajar. Until now it was thought in literary circles that Ajar was the pseudonym for Mr. Pavlowitch, who is Mr. Gary's nephew.

title: MRS. LLOYD GAINS FINAL A 7TH TIME
description: Wimbledon's singles seedings, officially criticized before the tournament by the Women's Tennis Association, were justified today when Chris Evert Lloyd and Hana Mandlikova, seeded first and second, advanced to Friday's championship.

title: ROLLS-ROYCE JET ENGINES
description: Rolls-Royce Ltd. said today that it had received a $60 million order from the Malaysian Airline System for engines to power two Boeing 747 jets.

title: CSX EARNINGS FALL BY 51.3%
description: The CSX Corporation, the nation's largest railroad, said that earnings in the second quarter fell 51.3 percent, to $37 million, or 90 cents a share, from $75.9 million, or $1.94 a share, in the comparable 1980 period.

title: Backing a Style
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Here is one lifelong girl-watcher who wants to applaud the ''Hers'' column of June 27 and express the hope that women's fashions in the next few years will follow the principles you have suggested for the Ergon look.

title: PORTLAND'S TIANT EAGER FOR MAJOR MOVE
description: It's the top of the ninth inning, and there is pandemonium in Portland. In the press box, Dave Hersch, 26-year-old general manager of the AAA Portland Beavers, is banging his notebook against the table and shouting at the top of his lungs, 'You can't make that call! You can't even see back there!''

title: B.P. HALTS OUTPUT OF LIBYAN CRUDE
description: In a continuation of the pressure to bring down crude oil prices, the British Petroleum Company announced yesterday that it was suspending crude oil liftings from Libya because it considered that country's oil overpriced.

title: RAIL COMMUTERS RESIGNED TO POOR CONDITIONS AND HIGHER FARES
description: The 1 P.M. train to White Plains was still on Track 109 at Grand Central Terminal yesterday at 1:12, when a voice came over the louspeaker to announce that the train could not move because of track trouble ahead.

title: LAG IN RIDERSHIP HAMPERS MASS TRANSIT AROUND U.S.
description: New York legislators and Governor Carey sought a plan to prevent a further rise in transit fares. Page B7. By ERNEST HOLSENDOLPH

title: BONN BACKS STEEL PLAN
description: The West German Cabinet today conditionally approved a package worked out by industry ministers in the European Economic Community last week to revitalize the community's steel industry, a Government spokesman said.

title: MOBILE MAYOR SEIZED FOR HOUR
description: A former policeman who was unhappy about his retirement held a gun to the head of Mayor Robert Doyle for nearly an hour yesterday in City Hall here.

title: Notes on People; A New Chapter
description: One would derisively call the other ''Mayor X'' and talk about how a decade ago Mayor X had ''given the city away'' and brought New York to ''the brink of bankruptcy.''

title: Around the World; WALDHEIM PRAISES MOVE FOR CEASE-FIRE IN SAHARA
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations said today that Morocco's proposal for a cease-fire and an internationally controlled referendum on independence in the Western Sahara could open the way to a peaceful solution.

title: Notes on People; Hostage's Story
description: A manuscript for a book described by G. P. Putnam's as the first to be published by an American hostage in Iran has been turned in, and Nov. 4 has been set for publication. The book, called ''Inside and Out: Hostage to Iran, Hostage to Myself,'' is by Richard I. Queen with Patricia Hass.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The bricks and the wooden mantelpiece above our fireplace have become blackened and discolored due to a fire that accidentally got out of control. The mantel is a light-colored wood that was coated with clear varnish. Can you tell us how the bricks and the mantel can be cleaned? - J.H., Middletown, Ohio

title: REAGAN SEES STABLE PRICES
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the economy was showing steady progress toward achieving stable consumer prices, ''and hopefully we've seen the end of double-digit inflation.''

title: Business People; AMERICAN SATELLITE CO. PICKS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Lee M. Paschall, 59, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the American Satellite Company. He succeeds William A. Wheatley, 42, who resigned last month, after 10 months at the corporation, because of ''a difference of opinion.''

title: HIGH COURT UPSETS 2 RULINGS ON POLICE SEARCHES OF AUTOS
description: The Supreme Court today addressed two disputed aspects of the constitutional protection against unreasonable searches, ruling that the police generally need a warrant to open a closed container found in the trunk of an automobile but do not need a warrant to search the passenger area of an automobile after they have arrested the occupants.

title: A MUSICAL PORTRAIT OF ROY ELDRIDGE
description: THE Kool Jazz Festival's Portrait of Roy Eldridge, which took place at Town Hall on Tuesday night, showed careful planning on the part of its producers. Two critics, Gary Giddins and Ira Gitler, helped the jazz festival's George Wein put the program together and served as narrators, and what they came up with was both informative and entertaining.

title: A SEATTLE PAPER IS FOCUS OF FIGHT
description: On their third pass through the Mount St. Helens crater, the pilot of the light plane turned to Eric Nadler, a reporter for The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, and told him:

title: News Analysis
description: With the election of all 1,967 delegates to attend a special Communist Party congress in two weeks, Stanislaw Kania, the party's leader, has strengthened his position, increasing a likelihood that the gathering will reaffirm his policies of moderate change. The election process ended Monday night at a local party conference in Warsaw. Although the majority of the delegates are new and their political leanings are not totally clear, a number of known conservatives and more radical reformers were eliminated.

title: JAMAICA INVESTMENT
description: President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. will have separate meetings tomorrow with a United States business group trying to promote investment in Jamaica.

title: CAREER-ORIENTED COMMUNITY COLLEGES NO LONGER THE STATE U.'S
description: STEPCHILDREN A University In Transition Fourth of five articles. By GENE MAEROFF

title: Technology; PHONES THAT DELIVER MEMOS
description: PICKING up the telephone and hearing a singing telegram is a rare surprise nowadays. But in a few large companies, employees are picking up the phone and hearing talking telegrams sent by their colleagues.

title: OWNERS SHIFT SLIGHTLY IN TALKS
description: Marvin Miller, the players' labor leader, returned to the bargaining table yesterday, the 20th day of the baseball strike. Miller, who had last participated in a negotiating session the night before the strike began, June 12, took note of the modifications the owners' negotiators made in their proposal on professional compensation for premium free agents at yesterday's three-and-a-half-hour meeting and said:

title: BRANIFF AGREES TO DEFER DEBT
description: The Braniff International Corporation, whose principal subsidiary is Braniff Airways, said it had agreed with 37 lender banks to defer principal and interest payments on its privately held debt until next Feb. 1. Earlier, the lenders had agreed to defer about $40 million in debt payments due from last Feb. 1 through yesterday.

title: 28 U.S. Crews Racing in Henley Regatta Today
description: ON-THAMES, England, July 1 - The 142d Henley Royal Regatta gets under way tomorrow in what promises to be another chapter in the growing American participation -some say domination - of this quintessential English event.

title: G.A.O. REPORTS ON EXIMBANK
description: The Export-Import Bank, a United States Government bank that helps finance exports, is running out of money because of its policy of matching other governments' low interest loans to exporters, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: FEDERAL WORKER'S EDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: The City; GRAND JURY CLEARS KILLER OF 'INTRUDER'
description: A grand jury ruled that a 66-year-old Bronx woman was not guilty of any crime in the accidental shooting last Saturday of her husband of 43 years, District Attorney Mario Merola said.

title: Notes on People; PX Privileges Ended for Lady Bird Johnson
description: The Air Force has cut off shopping privileges at its commissary and post exchange at Bergstrom Air Force Base for Lady Bird Johnson, the widow of the former President said yesterday in Austin, Tex.

title: WOMEN DISCUSS POWER AND HOW TO USE IT
description: Women who want power should build coalitions, even if it means being in a room with people they can't stand. They should also try to get on boards, join labor unions and support political candidates who are working for women's issues.

title: THE MORMON NATION
description: While the ubiquitous ''moral activists'' are hard at work selling their vision of tomorrow's America, anyone interested in peeking into the new American Dream need look no further than that part of the United States that Westerners call ''the Mormon Nation.''

title: Details of holiday weekend events may be found on page C1.
description: Six warships of the North Atlantic alliance, their gliding silhouettes cleaving the choppy bay waters and the early morning mists, sailed into New York Harbor yesterday to signal the start of the city's 1981 Harbor Festival over the Fourth of July weekend.

title: APPEALS COURT UPHOLDS CUTS IN A JOBS PROGRAM
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit today upheld the legality of President Reagan's attempt to eliminate more than 300,000 federally subsidized jobs.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Aminoil Seeks Sale Of Refinery Stake
description: Aminoil, a Houston-based subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds Industries, wants to sell its 15 percent stake in Zimbabwe's only oil refinery, according to a spokesman for the operating consortium.

title: BLACK ON DEATH ROW IN ALABAMA GRANTED RETRIAL
description: Johnny Harris, a black on death row whose imprisonment was denounced by the Soviet Union as an example of American injustice, has won a retrial on charges stemming from the stabbing death of a prison guard.

title: 2 INDICTED IN BROOKLYN KILLING OF MAN WHO ASKED DIRECTIONS
description: Two men were indicted for murder by a Brooklyn grand jury yesterday in the June 19 kidnapping and slaying of a 23-year-old Orange County man.

title: ELLA FITZGERALD'S SONGS, PLUS TERRY AND SIMS
description: ELLA FITZGERALD'S musicianship is exceptional, and the joys her singing offers are primarily musical. At this stage in her career she is unwilling to stray far from a repertory of familiar standards, and her versions of these standards seldom plumb any hidden emotional depths.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; SOPHOCLES IN CHELSEA
description: The Greek Theater of New York is inaugurating its new home at 120 West 28th Street with a production of Sophocles' ''Elektra'' in modern Greek. It stars Anna Makrakis, a leading tragedian with the National Theater of Greece, who is also directing the production. The play, described by Miss Makrakis as a ''fierce tragedy where no murder takes place on stage and yet the smell of blood is ever present,'' is the post-Trojan War drama in which Electra prods her brother, Orestes, to avenge the slaying of their father, King Agamemnon, by their mother and her lover. Performances Tuesday through Saturday evenings at 8, matinees Saturday at 2 P.M., Sunday at 3, through July 19. Tickets are $10 ($6 for students and the elderly). Reservations: 869-3530.

title: JUDGE CENSURED FOR PUTTING UP ACCUSED WOMAN
description: A Criminal Court judge who let a woman charged with murder stay at his home for the night has been censured by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct for ''extraordinarily poor judgment and a serious misunderstanding of the role of a judge in our legal system.''

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock, commodity and other financial exchanges, and Federal and New York City government offices are closed today in observance of Independence Day. Banks are open today, along with the New York Federal Reserve, but tomorrow, banks in New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed in observance of the holiday, as will most banks in New York.

title: SELECTIVE SERVICE CHIEF APPOINTED
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Maj. Gen. Thomas K. Turnage to be the Director of Selective Service.

title: Long Island
description: An ''old-fashioned glorious Fourth'' will be celebrated all day tomorrow at the Old Bethpage Restoration, off Round Swamp Round in Old Bethpage, L.I. The day's festivities begin with an 11 A.M. concert by costumed singers in the restored Manetto Hill Church. They will repeat their program of 18th-and 19th-century anthems at 2 P.M. Meanwhile, between 12:30 and 2 P.M., revelers will treat themselves to a picnic modeled after one held in 1843 by the Manhasset Temperance Society. The menu 138 years ago included cold chicken, clams, baked beans, corn and cherry pie; this time it's bring your own. At 1:45 P.M., the old church bell will peal, and marchers will line up for a parade led by a brass band and militia in full regalia. The militiamen will fire a 13-shot salute to the 31-star flag, as their counterparts in 1843 might have done. Admission is $2.75; $1.50 for youngsters. Exit 48 from the Long Island Expressway.

title: POTENTIAL TROUBLE SPOTS FOR SUMMER TRAFFIC
description: A. Palisades Interstate Parkway: From the New Jersey line to the Bear Mountain Bridge, workers are replacing wood railings with steel. Intermittent lane closings B. Route 17: Road work near Interstate 80 will force lane closings in both directions. C. Garden State Parkway: Workk at Interchange 153. One lane closed in each direction. Construction of new median barrier at the Oranges, between Union and Essex. One lane will be closed in each direction.

title: Record Coffee Crop Forecast
description: A record world coffee harvest of 92.4 million bags is expected for the 1981-82 season, the Agriculture Department said today. This would be a 14 percent increase from the department's revised estimate of 82.7 million bags produced in 1980-81.

title: HIGH COURT RULES PACT ON HOSTAGES WITH IRAN IS LEGAL
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Presidents Carter and Reagan had the legal authority to carry out the agreement with Iran that ended the hostage crisis.

title: Westinghouse Set On Siliconix Pact
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it had entered into an agreement to buy an additional 518,698 shares of Siliconix Inc. for $25 a share, or about $13 million.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including $147,479 extraordinary credit from the cumulative effect of an accounting change; shr earnings reflect a 10 per cent stock divd paid Jan 15

title: Cargill Acquisition
description: Cargill Inc., one of the nation's largest commodity trading companies, said it had purchased the cotton, fiber and rubber trading interests of the Bowater Corporation, which is based in London, for a reported $27 million. The acquisitions included the Ralli Group of London and MacLaine Watson & Company of Singapore, the company said.

title: Goodrich Unit Sale
description: As part of its program to redeploy assets, the B.F. Goodrich Company of Akron, Ohio, the big tire and rubber products producer, said it was discussing the sale of its wholly owned Dutch subsidiary, Ciago B.V., to Polysar Ltd. Asking terms were not disclosed. Goodrich, which said the subsidiary had revenues of about $60 million last year, also said it expected to show a gain on the sale.

title: ENERGYWATCH
description: JUNE 26, 1981 Following a surge last week, crude oil stocks fell to 403.4 million barrels.

title: Pop Jazz; IT'S WOMEN'S TURN AT THE JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: THE return of Miles Davis, a showcase of women jazz instrumentalists and four huge jazz smorgasbords highlight the final weekend of the Kool Jazz Festival as it reaches out beyond its Manhattan base to Brooklyn to Purchase in Westchester, to Point Lookout on Long Island and to Saratoga Springs.

title: STATE SENATE APPROVES BONDS FOR MORE PRISONS
description: With the Legislature moving toward its summer recess, the Senate today approved a $500 million bond issue. It would provide $375 million for the construction and rehabilitation of state and local prisons and additional funds for new facilities for juvenile offenders, the state police and psychiatric patients.

title: CONGRESS PUNISHES HOMOSEXUAL CITIZENS
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Films at Modern
description: Four shorts from California's Pyramid Films will be shown this weekend at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: Sports of the Times; A DAY OF TENNIS AT ITS BEST AND WORST
description: WIMBLEDON, England AT the time, John McEnroe had center stage at center court. After having debated the umpire, demanded an audience with the referee and pouted at several calls, he was about to eliminate Rod Frawley, a muscular Australian, in three tedious sets. Perhaps in thankfulness that this semifinal match finally was ending yesterday, the Wimbledon devotees were murmuring. Some were even yelling.

title: PIANISTS REMINISCE ABOUT ART TATUM
description: EIGHT prominent jazz pianists contributed to the ''Portrait of Art Tatum'' at Town Hall on Wednesday evening as part of the Kool Jazz Festival. But the two stars of the evening were talkers.

title: JERSEY'S TRASH PILES UP IN 2D DAY OF HAULERS' STRIKE
description: Garbage began to pile up outside fast-food restaurants and other small stores with limited indoor storage capacity today as a strike by 1,400 truck drivers against private refuse haulers in 108 communities in northern and central New Jersey went into its second day.

title: Topics; GUNS AND BUTTER; AMERICAN SOLACE
description: Those not inclined to look beneath the surface of things might assume that the 8 percent rise in mozzarella cheese production in the U.S. in 1980 has merely to do with pizza consumption. Those willing to dig a bit might care to muse about the American predilection for things Italian and what it says about the Roman Empire.

title: COURT UPHOLDS THE BANNING OF COMMERCIAL BILLBOARDS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that localities may prohibit billboards that carry commercial advertising. However, in five separate opinions, none of which commanded a majority of the Court, the Justices left unclear the extent to which local governments can regulate billboards that carry political or other noncommercial messages.

title: LONG ORDEAL NEARS AN END FOR NEESKENS
description: On the 19th-floor offices of the Cosmos in Rockefeller Center, the elevator doors are covered by huge posters of six past and present team heroes - Pele, Franz Beckenbauer, Giorgio Chinaglia, Vladislav Bogicevic, Carlos Alberto and Julio Cesar Romero.

title: FATHER OF MARIO CUOMO DIES
description: Andrea Cuomo, the father of Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, died Wednesday at Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica following a stroke suffered several weeks ago. Mr. Cuomo, who had owned a grocery store in Jamaica and lived in Holliswood, Queens, was 79 years old. Besides his wife, Immaculata, and his son Mario, he is survived by another son, Frank, of Copiague, L.I.; a daughter, Marie Vecchio of Mineola, L.I., and 11 grandchildren.

title: F.A.A. PUTS OFF ITS PLAN TO CLOSE NEW YORK OFFICE
description: Bowing to political pressure, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it had ''postponed indefinitely'' a cost-cutting plan to close its regional offices in New York and four other major cities.

title: The Region; JUDGE CENSURED IN ESSEX COUNTY
description: ALBANY (AP) - The State Commission on Judicial Conduct, in an 8-to-3 vote, has censured Judge Charles P. Garvey of Essex County Court, saying he solicited loans from lawyers appearing before him and signed his wife's name to a racing-license application.

title: SPACE PANEL OPPOSES SPACE POWER STATIONS
description: Citing excessive cost and technological problems, a committee of the National Academy of Sciences today advised against proposed Federal financing of immense power stations in space that would convert the sun's rays into electricity for Earth.

title: ARGENTINA PUTTING PRESSURE ON PRESS
description: When Manfred Shonfeld, a newspaper columnist, stepped from a taxi last week and was greeted by someone wearing brass knuckles, he learned the limits of press freedom in Argentina.

title: NEW U.S. RULING OFFERS HELP TO SAVINGS UNITS
description: Federal regulators took a major step today to help the nation's financially troubled savings and loan associations by allowing the thrift units to protect themselves from higher costs by investing in an assortment of futures contracts.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 7
FALL SCHEDULE LISTED BY PBS
description: The fall schedule for the Public Broadcasting Service includes only two new prime-time series - ''Enterprise'' and ''John Callaway Interviews.'' The schedule, which no longer includes such staples as ''Bill Moyers' Journal'' and ''Evening at Symphony,'' reflects PBS's leaner financial situation.

title: WHAT A CONSERVATIVE REALLY IS.  AND ISN'T
description: I am a political conservative, of the traditional kind, who enthusiastically voted for and supports President Reagan, in spite of his occasionally distressing pronouncements. But I protest the increasing use of the label ''conservative'' by people who have no idea what it really means. Indeed, it is sometimes associated with sheer narrowness of outlook.

title: Chairman at Pabst Quits 2 Other Posts
description: In another shake-up of its top management, the Pabst Brewing Company announced that Frank C. DeGuire had asked the board of directors to accept his resignation as president and chief executive officer.

title: NEWSWEEK HEAD TAKES CBS PUBLISHING POST
description: Peter A. Derow has resigned as chairman and president of Newsweek Inc. and will replace John S. Suhler as president of the CBS/Publishing group.

title: BLACKOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: NAVY TO TELL OFFICERS TO SHAVE OFF BEARDS
description: The Pentagon is expected to announce next week a rule prohibiting most Navy officers and some enlisted men from wearing beards, The San Diego Union reported today.

title: In The Nation; ABM IS NOT THE ANSWER
description: Secretary of Defense Weinberger's panel of outside defense experts is reported to have advised him to abandon or substantially modify the Carter Administration's plan to hide 200 new MX missiles among 4,600 shelters in the Nevada-Utah desert.

title: BLUES: RUTH BROWN RETURNS
description: THANKS to the writers' strike in Hollywood, Ruth Brown, a rhythmand-blues star of the 50's, is in town, picking up a singing career that she had given up in 1962 to raise her children.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
Real Estate; Tenants Plan Co-op In Bronx
description: A tenant-sponsored cooperative conversion effort is hardly new, but now it has reached out to the Bronx in the largest such effort ever undertaken in the city.

title: IRRESOLUTE ISRAEL
description: Even if Menachem Begin pastes together a new Israeli government, it may not last. In their democratic way, the Israelis have neither repudiated nor vindicated Mr. Begin, neither elected nor rejected the Labor alternative led by Shimon Peres. For a distressed economy, they have refused to choose between conservatism and socialism. To defuse the Palestinian population bomb in the West Bank, they have failed to endorse either absorption and confrontation or partition and accommodation.

title: LANCE FAILS TO HALT AN INQUIRY ON 1974 CAMPAIGN FINANCING
description: Bert Lance, the former budget director, failed today to halt a Federal inquiry into how he financed his unsuccessful campaign for the Georgia governorship in 1974.

title: Foreign Affairs; THE TERRIBLE SILENCE
description: Representative Millicent Fenwick, Republican of New Jersey, turned yet another conference on European-American relations held here this week into an important sounding board.

title: BRITAIN PLANS CATHOLIC-PROTESTANT ADVISORY COUNCIL FOR ULSTER
description: The British Government announced plans today to create an advisory council on Northern Ireland that would be made up of leading Protestants and Roman Catholics from the embattled province. Leaders of both religious groups in the region immediately rejected the idea.

title: VW Deliveries Slip by 4%
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G.'s motor vehicle group deliveries fell a provisional 4 percent, to 1.2 million units, in the first half of 1981 from the first six months of 1980, the auto maker's finance director, Friederich Thomee, told the annual meeting today.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan's New Direction
description: THE Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., having retreated from the battle of the budget in Washington to the golf links of Cape Cod, has been brandishing his five iron and vowing to rally his forces against the Reaganites when Congress reassembles after the holiday weekend.

title: ASBESTOS INJURY SUITS MOUNT, WITH SEVERE BUSINESS IMPACT
description: Damage claims by workers exposed to asbestos and by their families now constitute the largest, and potentially most costly, block of product liability litigation ever to confront American industry.

title: Business People; Schenuit's Nelson Unit Is Sold to Its Officers
description: Last year when Allegheny International Inc. bought Schenuit Industries, a small conglomerate based in Baltimore, A.P. Caltrider, the president of one of Schenuit's subsidiaries knew that his company would not fit into the new family of businesses that Allegheny was building.

title: FRUIT FLY APPEARS TO SURVIVE ERADICATION ATTEMPT
description: The hardy, prolific and devastatingly destructive Mediterranean fruit fly appears to have survived a $22 million eradication program south of the Bay area, which included extensive stripping of fruit trees, ground spraying of insecticide and the release of millions of sterile males to thwart their procreation.

title: TRUMPETERS' NIGHT
description: THE ostensible focus of attention at the Kool Jazz Festival concert Wednesday night in Avery Fisher Hall was Herbie Hancock, and properly so. But in another sense, this was an evening for trumpet playing.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Can Company, Greenwich, Conn., has elected to its board William A. Marquard, chairman, president and chief executive officer of American Standard Inc.

title: GEORGE VOSKOVEC, 76, ACTOR OF CHARACTER ROLES, IS DEAD
description: George Voskovec, the dramatic actor, director and playwright best known for his character roles on the New York stage, died July 1 at his home in Pearblossom, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: M.T.A. PANEL: HOW THEY VOTED, HOW THEY TRAVEL
