description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is made up of a chairman and 13 members. The chairman and five of the members are selected by the Governor. Four members are selected by the Mayor. The county executives of Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester each select one member. A final member is chosen from names submitted by the chief executives of Rockland, Dutchess, Putnam and Orange Counties.

title: SAVING SAVERS FROM 'ALL SAVERS'
description: Saul Klaman, president of a savings bank trade association, calls it a ''truly trail-blazing step.'' Michael Stevenson, speaking for savings and loan associations, calls it ''a stimulator.'' We call it a multi-billion dollar raid on the Treasury.

title: CITY'S FARE RISES TO 75 AND RAILS INCREASE BY 25%
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority raised the fare yesterday for New York City's subways and buses from 60 cents to 75 cents and approved increases averaging 25 percent for Conrail and the Long Island Rail Road.

title: BUSINESS EXPECTED RULING
description: Businesses with claims against frozen Iranian assets said they were not surprised by yesterday's Supreme Court decision upholding the January agreement that freed the American hostages and cleared the way for the transfer of more than $2 billion of assets out of the United States.

title: CHAMBERS OF DOLPHINS IS KILLED IN AUTO CRASH
description: Rusty Chambers, a Miami Dolphins linebacker, and another man were killed when a car spun off a highway and crashed in a culvert, the police said today.

title: New Jersey
description: New Jersey's share of the Harbor Festival will be held at Port Newark, the big container port of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and at Liberty State Park, which looks out at the Statue of Liberty from the Jersey City shoreline.

title: Around the Nation; EDUCATION GROUP OFFERS TEACHERS' GUIDE ON KLAN
description: Teachers should combat active recruiting by the Ku Klux Klan by encouraging class discussions on extremist groups, the National Education Association said today.

title: Credit Markets; PREHOLIDAY SELLING PREVAILS
description: High financing costs over a three-day weekend encouraged speculators and traders to lighten their inventories in the credit markets yesterday. At the same time, dealers said, some bargainhunting investors emerged as buyers at the new, lower prices.

title: CULMINATION OF YEAR'S WORK COMING FOR FIREWORKS MAKER
description: For 11 months out of 12, Patrick Moriarty prepares to watch his work go up in smoke. But Mr. Moriarty could not be happier about it: His Anaheim-based concern, the Pyrotronics Corporation, manufactures fireworks.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio air play.

title: MILK FOR VIETNAM
description: When Vietnam invaded Cambodia and threw out the brutal Pol Pot regime two and one-half years ago, the Carter Administration asked other countries to join in imposing wide-ranging sanctions against Vietnam because it violated international law. Now, rather than reducing sanctions, the Reagan Administration has accelerated that campaign, actively lobbying other countries and organizations to prevent any aid from reaching Hanoi, even milk that the children of Vietnam need desperately.

title: No Headline
description: IRANIANS URGED TO BE ALERT FOR SUSPICIOUS ACTIVITY

title: YALE CREW SPARKLES AT HENLEY
description: ON-THAMES, England, July 2 - Eighty races were contested today in the opening round of the 142d Henley Royal Regatta, and Yale oarsmen made the biggest splash.

title: ITS BOOM YEARS OVER, STATE U. NOW STRIVES FOR EXCELLENCE WITH LESS
description: MONEY A University In Transition Last of five articles. By EDWARD B. FISKE

title: USEFUL ARTS OF AFRICA ON EXHIBIT
description: The attraction that such Western artists as Picasso, Giacometti and Max Ernst have had to African art is both well documented and recognized. But a traveling exhibition called ''African Furniture & Household Objects,'' which has just opened at the Brooklyn Museum (through Sept. 7), focuses on another influential but less noticed aspect of African art.

title: Sohio Participates In Energy Study
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said it was joining the Hampshire Energy Project, a study to determine the commercial and economic viability of converting 15,000 short tons of coal daily to 800,000 gallons of unleaded gasoline and byproducts such as mixed butanes.

title: Auto Output To Rise 42%
description: United States auto makers plan to build 42 percent more cars this week than they did in the comparable week of 1980, but the number of workers on long-term layoff remains virtually unchanged from last week, according to industry reports released today.

title: Westchester
description: What better way to celebrate Independence Day than by combining a picnic in the country with a celebration of the bicentennial of a crucial moment in the American Revolution, the arrival of France's Gen. Jean Baptiste Rochambeau and 5,000 men in Westchester to join George Washington's troops? The linking of the two forces provided the key to victory over Lord Cornwallis, the British general, at Yorktown in Virginia.

title: PUBLISHING: KOSINSKI'S SALES TACTICS
description: JERZY KOSINSKI, one of the few major authors who does not have a literary agent, is several months away from completing his latest novel, a suspense story involving a rock superstar and a once - popular composer of classical music, but he has been discussing it with publishers and inviting them up to his Manhattan apartment to read it.

title: KEN MENDENHALL QUITS
description: Ken Mendenhall, the eight-year center for the Baltimore Colts, said today that he was retiring. Mendenhall, 32 years old, started 118 consecutive games for the Colts, beginning in the fourth game of 1973 and continuing through the last game of 1980.

title: Dividend Rises Climbed in June
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that the number of companies reporting increased dividends during June rose on a yearto-year-comparison basis for the first time since February 1980.

title: PACT ON POLISH DEBT DELAYED
description: Representatives of about 60 American banks failed yesterday to endorse an agreement that had been reached to reschedule $2.7 billion in Polish debts owed this year to foreign commercial banks. Another meeting has been scheduled for next week.

title: The Evening Hours
description: slugging third baseman of the world champion Philadelphia Phillies, hit at least 10 home runs in New York on Wednesday, maybe more. No one could keep track. His opponent was George Brett, the star third baseman of the Kansas City Royals. No, these two superstars weren't scabbing during the major league players' strike. They were in town to plug a video baseball game by Mattel Electronics.

title: MOVING MOUNTAIN GOATS
description: Because their voracious appetites were ruining some of the flora of Olympic National Park in Washington, the National Park Service began a weeklong program Wednesday to move 50 to 60 of the goats to another park. A Park Service official, above, holding down one of the mountain goats to be tagged and prepared for flight by helicopter, left. Goats are flown to a truck for journey to new home in another part of the state.

title: CUT-RATE PARTICIPANTS IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; This Time, It's a Pitcher Who's Seeking Relief
description: ''Would you care for cocktails?'' the new waiter asked a little hesitantly of the couple who had just been seated at a table in the Oren and Aretsky restaurant on Third Avenue.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK ELECTION REFORM
description: In an effort to reform the reforms of Presidential politics, the Democratic National Committee today announced the formation of a party commission whose goals include shortening the Presidential campaign season and giving elected officials a bigger role in picking a nominee.

title: Around the World; FRENCH ASSEMBLY MEETS ON THE SOCIALIST AGENDA
description: With the traditional roll of drums, the French National Assembly today opened the first session of the seventh legislature of the Fifth Republic in the Palais Bourbon on the Left Bank.

title: SUIT ON MUNSON DISMISSED
description: A $4.5 million lawsuit filed by the New York Yankees in a case involving the death of the catcher Thurman Munson was dismissed today by United States District Court Judge Leroy J. Contie Jr. The Yankees had claimed that Cessna, the manufacturer of Munson's plane, and Flightsafety International, the company that taught him to fly, were negligent.

title: BORG AND MCENROE REACH WIMBLEDON FINAL
description: Bjorn Borg and John McEnroe left their trademarks on center court at the Wimbledon tennis tournament today and reached the men's singles final for the second consecutive year.

title: Notes on People; Full Speed Ahead
description: It all began last weekend at the Chautauqua Music Festival in upstate New York when James Galway, the Irish flutist, played ''The Flight of the Bumblebee'' in 52.45 seconds. Mr. Galway challenged the Canadian Brass to play the Rimsky-Korsakov piece faster.

title: RUSSIANS CONSIDERING CANCELING COSMOS DATE
description: A spokesman for the Soviet Embassy in Washington said yesterday that Soviet officials were considering withdrawing from a scheduled match against the Cosmos at Giants Stadium July 12 because of the presence of a South African player, Steve Wegerle, on the Cosmos.

title: SAVIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Net income; revs for the latest yr include $9.4 million royal revs and $5.9 million relating to revisions of certain licensin agreements

title: France Ends Mexico Oil
description: France's state-owned oil company, Total, said yesterday that it had suspended its Mexican crude oil purchases because of Mexico's decision to raise prices by $2 a barrel on July 1. But Mexico said it had not yet increased its prices.

title: HELPED DESIGN U.N. QUARTERS
description: Theodore Hood, an architect and engineer who helped design the United Nations headquarters, died Wednesday of a heart attack at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Hood, who was a resident of New York City, was 62 years old.

title: CIGARETTES' OTHER PERIL
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Weekend; FROM ROSTROPOVICH TO BEACH BOYS
description: THE holiday weekend has its share of appropriate music specials. At 9 P.M. tomorrow on public television, Channel 13 will carry ''Capitol Fourth With the National Symphony,'' scheduled to take place on the Capitol lawn in Washington. With Mstislav Rostropovich conducting the National Symphony Orchestra, the program will include everything from Irving Berlin's ''God Bless America'' to John Philip Sousa's ''Stars and Stripes Forever,'' all leading up to a grand finale of fireworks.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. said it had received approval from the United States Comptroller of the Currency to acquire Westside National Bank of Bradenton, for $11 million.

title: Texasgulf Silent On Elf Bid Talks
description: A legal spokesman for Texasgulf Inc. said the company would have no comment on a six-hour directors' meeting called to weigh a bid by the French oil concern, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, to acquire the Stamford, Conn., chemical, minerals and petroleum concern.

title: A NERVOUSNESS ABOUT FUTURE OF JAZZ RECORDING
description: THE business of making jazz records is precarious indeed. Only a few committed executives in the industry are responsible for making most jazz albums, and unless they are lucky enough to record a jazz hit, the best they can hope for is slow but steady sales. If they work for large record companies, their budgets are usually the first to be slashed when over-all sales begin to slump. And the departure of a single individual from a major company can signal a change in that label's involvement in jazz, at least temporarily.

title: Art Supplier Antitrust Plea
description: Three companies charged with conspiring to fix prices for crayons, fingerpaint, watercolors, chalk and modeling clay have pleaded no contest in Federal District Court here.

title: AT 45, RODRIGUEZ REMAINS THE BLITHE SPIRIT OF GOLF
description: Chi Chi Rodriguez says he was 20 years ahead of his time. Long before the PGA Tour, spurred by falling television ratings, was looking for individuality, long before there was all this chatter about clones and cookie-cutter types, Rodriguez was delighting galleries with his banter and wit and with his gesture of covering the hole with his straw hat after scoring a birdie, the idea being to prevent the bird from getting away.

title: 2 ROCK-AND-ROLLERS AT THALIA
description: THIS weekend's double bill at the Thalia transforms the theater into a wax museum wired for sound. ''The London Rock 'n' Roll Show'' (1974) and ''Blue Suede Shoes'' (1981) are committed to the proposition, as articulated loudly by parties in both films, that ''rock-and-roll will never die.'' But both films look depressingly like evidence to the contrary.

title: LIBYAN IN BRITAIN GETS LIFE
description: Hosni Harhat, a Libyan airlines worker, was sentenced to life imprisonment today for attempting to kill Farag Ghesouda, another Libyan, his wife and two children by leaving a packet of poisoned peanuts in their home. The prosecution said Mr. Farhat had wanted to poison the family because they did not obey Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, when he ordered Libyans living abroad to return home.

title: CONDITION OF VICTIM IN A BRIDGE ACCIDENT IS STILL 'VERY CRITICAL'
description: A Japanese freelance photographer who was struck on the head by a snapped cable on the Brooklyn Bridge last Sunday was reported still in ''very critical condition'' yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, with the outlook for his recovery considered ''very poor.''

title: POLICE RECALL SEEING TAUNTING VICTIM
description: The Connecticut man who died on a Times Square subway track after being taunted and chased by a group of youths and vagrants last Saturday morning was observed at least 15 hours earlier wandering in midtown Manhattan partly disrobed and talking to himself, the police said yesterday.

title: A BEIRUT TRIUMPH: REOPENING OF ROAD
description: A bulldozer came under sniper fire today as it moved up to clear a road between the Moslem and Christian sectors of the capital. The road had been closed for at least three months.

title: CON ED REQUESTS 1.8% RISE, TO COVER COST OF LABOR, TAXES
description: An increase in electric rates to add an annual $62.5 million, or 1.8 percent, has been requested by the Consolidated Edison Company to recover higher labor and property tax costs.

title: Restaurants; A French bistro and a garden spot.
description: REASONABLY priced, decently prepared French food at the bistro level is hard to come by these days, here as well as in France, and for the very same reason: Rising costs dictate higher prices that can be commanded only by food that is fashionably new.

title: OWNERS EXPECTED TO MAKE A MOVE
description: On the surface, there appeared to be no movement in the three-weekold baseball strike yesterday after a relatively brief meeting between the negotiators for the owners and players. But behind-thescenes developments seemed to indicate that the owners could be preparing to make a significant effort to end the player walkout that has forced cancellation of 261 games.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including $390,000 gain on the sale of land a B-Including $390,000 gain on the sale of land and a hotel

title: PRIME UP TO 20 1 2% AT 2 BIG BANKS
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank and the First National Bank of Chicago raised their prime lending rates yesterday to 20 1/2 percent from 20 percent in response to this week's rise in the cost of money.

title: CONOCO SUED BY SEAGRAM
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons filed a countersuit yesterday against Conoco, the oil company in which it is trying to acquire a 40.7 percent interest.

title: Connecticut
description: The Connecticut River is the center of the state's largest celebration of July Fourth, with a festival from 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. in Hartford and East Hartford and on the river that divides them. On the Hartford side, the center of the celebration is, appropriately, the Old State House, where an exhibition of work by Connecticut craftsmen begins at 10 A.M. A ''world championship'' double-Dutch skip-rope contest starts at noon, with a second round at 6 P.M., a farm market runs from 4 P.M. to 6 P.M., and the band of the Governor's Foot Guard, a prerevolutionary militia, gives a concert at 4:30.

title: REAGAN REVERSING MANY U.S. POLICIES
description: At a time when public attention has been riveted on President Reagan's tax and budget plans, his Administration has quietly set about accomplishing a sweeping reversal of policy and practice in the way the Government deals with business and individual citizens.

title: Transactions COLLEGE
description: Named Richard D. Grawer assistant basketball coach. RICHMOND - Named Dick Tarrant b asketball coach. ROANOKE - Named Ed Green athletic director. ST.

title: DANCE: A 'MELODRAMA' IN TAP BY GAIL CONRAD
description: ''WAVE,'' the evening-long tap dance that Gail Conrad offered Wednesday night at La Mama Annex, had its interesting moments. But nothing about it was as interesting as the question it raised: If you are a tap dancer in 1981 and don't want to venture into mere nostalgia, just what are you going to do?

title: THE MORNING OF JUNE 27
description: The dream is the same for everyone. Walking down a crowded street you suddenly discover your nakedness. Somewhere back in consciousness lie your clothes, but here there are no defenses.

title: News Analysis
description: Elections are supposed to answer questions, to resolve a country's vacillations and debates, to clarify the people's mood and will. But the voting in Israel Tuesday has left its citizens with many of their old doubts, and has introduced some new uncertainties.

title: Museum Rates Go Up
description: The American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, is increasing its admission and parking rates, effective immediately. The suggested donation for admission is now $2.50 ($1.50 for children); Hayden Planetarium admission, $3.25 ($1.50 for children and $2.25 for students and the elderly). Parking is $4.25 a car.

title: PRAGUE GETS RIGHTS APPEAL
description: The West German branch of Amnesty International today called on Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak leader, in a telegram to release eight dissidents still detained after a crackdown on the Charter 77 rights group two months ago and to drop charges against 22 others who were released pending trial.

title: Around the Nation; ATLANTA INMATE VANISHES AFTER HELPING IN INQUIRY
description: A 19-year-old prisoner, released from his cell at night to roam the streets of Atlanta in hopes of catching the killers of 28 young blacks, has vanished, the police said today.

title: Gasoline Prices Generally Off
description: Gasoline prices in most parts of the United States are dropping by as much as 3 cents a gallon as drivers take to the highways for the Fourth of July holiday weekend. But prices are edging up on the West Coast.

title: An Appreciation
description: Marcel Breuer designed huge buildings in cities all over the world, but he is most likely to be remembered for things that are very small - things that are not buildings at all. Mr. Breuer's furniture of tubular steel, those chairs he made in the 1920's as a way of exploring the potential of modern technology in furniture design, have become as established a part of the design landscape of the 20th century as the designs of Chippendale were for the 15th.

title: 3 Win Suit Over Device
description: A Federal jury today awarded three Minneapolis men $93 million from the Johnson & Johnson Company in a breach-of-contract suit involving the acquisition of a business.

title: RARE CANCER SEEN IN 41 HOMOSEXUALS
description: Doctors in New York and California have diagnosed among homosexual men 41 cases of a rare and often rapidly fatal form of cancer. Eight of the victims died less than 24 months after the diagnosis was made.

title: Volvo Sets Sales Record
description: Sales of Volvo automobiles in the United States reached a record 37,066 units during the first half of 1981, Volvo officials announced today.

title: CINCINNATI'S MAYOR BIDS REDS PAY CITY
description: With city finances stung by the baseball players' strike over free-agent compensation, the mayor of Cincinnati wants compensation of another sort.

title: The Region; GRAND JURY INDICTS UNION PRESIDENT
description: The president of Local 101 of the International Brotherhood of Craftsmen, Professionals and Allied Trades International was indicted by a grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of racketeering, extortion and embezzlement.

title: SCAPEGOAT FOR MOSCOW'S POLISH TROUBLES
description: To the Editor:

title: Dutch Saudi Project
description: The Dutch construction group Ballast-Nedam Groep said today that it had received a $372.9 million order from the Saudi Arabian Government for the construction of houses and related services. The order is an extension of an earlier contract for the building of towns in Riyadh, Dhahran, Taif and Khamis Mushait, projects that Ballast-Nedam started in 1975.

title: Notes on People; Not a Happy Birthday for Earl Butz
description: It is his 72d birthday today, and Earl L. Butz, the former Secretary of Agriculture, is spending it in prison. Mr. Butz quietly surrendered Monday to Federal authorities at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Chicago to serve 30 days of a five-year sentence for income-tax evasion.

title: Hudson Valley
description: The Hudson Valley was one of the major battlefields of the Revolutionary War, following the adoption of the Declaration of Independence in 1776, and a visit there over the July Fourth weekend can combine a day in the country with an observance of the holiday. This weekend the days of the American Revolution are being remembered in the valley with parades, songs, exhibitions, a mock Revolutionary War battle and other festive activities.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Ackerley Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 500,000 shares of common stock, underwritten by a Drexel Burnham Lambert group.

title: CZECH LETTER SAID TO ADVISE POLAND TO PUT OFF CONGRESS
description: The Czechoslovak Communist Party has told the Polish Central Committee that ''counterrevolutionary'' forces are taking over the Polish party and advised putting off a party congress set to open in 12 days, Polish party sources said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we don't undertake this program, starting from today, from now, nothing can stop us from following the road to catastrophe, to a breakdown of our economy with all the consequences resulting from that. '' - Deputy Prime Minister Zbigniew Madej of Poland. (A4:2.)

title: UNSOLICITED CRITIQUE OF FRANCE'S CABINET
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Superior Oil After the Split
description: THE shares of the Superior Oil Company, once the highest-priced on the Big Board, will be trading near $40 after two 5-for-1 splits in the last year and a half. The latest of these splits goes into effect next Friday. The shares closed yesterday at 186 1/2.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DECLINES IN THE CITY, BUT GOES UP IN STATE
description: The unemployment rate in New York City dropped for the third month in a row in June, but joblessness in New York State increased, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: NEW PRESSURE ON HOUSE TO SPEED TAX PACKAGE
description: The Reagan Administration today increased its pressure on the House Democratic leadership to speed up formulation of its tax package. It was announced that Senate Republican leaders would seek to push the Republican tax package through the Senate by the third week in July.

title: MISSION INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $133,000 for the qr and $288,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $561,000 for the qr and $643,000 for the 6 mos

title: Index; International
description: In Beirut, opening of east-west road is a major achievement A2 Uganda troops said to massacre 60 civilians in Catholic mission A3 Britain plans an advisory council from Ulster A4 Around the World A5 Government/Politics Alabama black wins a retrial A7 Democrats seek election reform A10 F.A.A. postpones a plan to shut its New York office B3 State Senate approves $500 mil- lion bond issue for prisons B5 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Independence Day is tomorrow.- Most Federal and municipal offices are closed today; New York State of- fices are open. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended today and tomorrow; all other rules in effect. Sanitation - Regular collections today; collections normally made tomorrow will be made Sunday. Federal offices - Closed today and tomorrow. State offices - Open today. Courts - Federal, state and local courts are closed today. Municipal offices - Closed today. Post offices - Open today; closed tomorrow; only special delivery and express mail delivered tomorrow. Banks - Open today. Stock and commodity markets -Closed today. Transportation - Buses and subways on regular schedule today; on Sunday schedule tomorrow. L.I.R.R. and Conrail-Harlem, Hudson and New Haven Divisions on regular schedule today; holiday schedule tomorrow. Libraries - Closed today and tomorrow.

title: Around the World; CANADA TELEVISES FUNERAL OF YOUNG CANCER VICTIM
description: The funeral service of Terry Fox, a 22-year-old college student who died Sunday of cancer, was televised nationally today as part of an extraordinary tribute to Canada's greatest national hero in memory. Since Monday, flags on federal and many provincial buildings have flown at half-staff, an honor usually reserved for major public officials.

title: FROM FIREWORKS TO PARADES: A JULY FOURTH GUIDE
description: FOURTH of July celebrations will be staged all over the metropolitan region this weekend. If anything, the festivities seem to have become more widespread and more ingenious every year since the Bicentennial five years ago gave everybody the idea for citywide jubilation on a grand scale. The air over Coney Island will be filled this weekend with acrobatic jets and fireworks. Ships and even a few stagestruck animals will take to the water from the Battery to the Bronx Zoo and out to Queens. The streets of the city will be alive with singers, dancers, musicians and arts and crafts. Spectacular fireworks will illuminate the sky over the Upper Bay between the Statue of Liberty and Governors Island. Most of the events are free. And most are suitable for every member of the family.

title: No Headline
description: ELLENBERGER ADMITS N.C.A.A. VIOLATIONS

title: The City; RENOVATION LOAN GIVEN IN BROOKLYN
description: The development subsidiary of Citicorp and a Brooklyn-based bank announced that they were providing a $22.9 million loan to renovate a large housing development in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: BROOKS FASHION STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
No Headline
description: Around the World; GUNMEN IN GUATEMALA KILL AN ITALIAN PRIEST

title: UNION AIDES FIGHT AIR CONTROL PACT
description: The executive board of the air traffic controllers' union recommended today that the union's 15,000 members ''overwhelmingly'' reject a tentative contract that averted a nationwide walkout on June 22.

title: PLANTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $144,000 for the qr and $199,000 for the yr...C-Including $427,000 or 7 cents a shr income from discontinued operations, $3,988,00 or 62 cents a shr gain on the disposal of discontinued operatio and $816,000 extraordinary loss

title: BAD TIMES FOR A TEXAS BUILDER
description: J.B. Sandlin, who for the last 24 years has put homes on these dusty Texas flatlands, drove his telephone-equipped Cadillac down empty streets that crisscrossed a desolate field of yellow sunflowers.

title: Around the Nation; MINE COMPANY REPORTS POSSIBLE CAUSE OF BLAST
description: An explosion that killed 15 coal miners at a mine near Redstone in April might have been caused by a spark from a faulty light switch, according to a report in a newspaper published by the company that owns the mine.

title: Money Funds Grow in Week
description: The assets of the nation's money market funds grew by $2.29 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: ART: PHILIP GUSTON IN RETROSPECT
description: HERE and there in the late paintings of Philip Guston there is to be found an anthology of the images, ideas and attitudes that have shaped human awareness in the second half of our century. They are not copied, imitated or recycled in any pedestrian way, but they are there for all to see. The remarkable thing is that Guston was able to mate them - however implausibly - with the sense of wonder and the inborn sweetness of character that might have been expected to pull his art in quite another direction.

title: No Headline
description: ANN RENFREW, 20, KILLED IN FALL OFF BRITAIN'S TALLEST MOUNTAIN

title: LOS ANGELES POLICE SEEK A MOTIVE IN 4 SLAYINGS IN HOLLYWOOD HILLS
description: Los Angeles police officers and detectives were trying today to determine the motive for the slaying of two men and two women and the critical injury of a third young woman yesterday in a three-story rented home in the fashionable Hollywood Hills.

title: Auctions; Some snags in London sales.
description: A $3.6-million auction of 66 Impressionist and modern art works at Christie's in London Monday ended with 17 paintings unsold, including such important pieces as Dali's 1934 ''Morning Ossification of a Cypress,'' Picasso's ''Head of a Woman'' from 1900 and ''Landscape Study''from 1907, and a Braque landscape from the Fauve period.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The City; P.B.A. CRITICIZES INDICTMENTS OF 3
description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has denounced the Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, for the recent indictments of three police officers on homicide and assault charges. The president, Philip Caruso, contended that vital information had been withheld from the grand juries.

title: THE STEEP DECLINE IN FOOD FUTURES
description: Food prices on the commodity futures markets - an important signal of what consumers will pay for food in coming months - this year have undergone their longest and one of their steepest declines since World War II. Futures contracts in grain, soybeans, sugar, coffee and cocoa have fallen by 25 to 50 percent.

title: BREZHNEV CALLS TALK 'POSITIVE'
description: Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, left here today after a four-day visit that gave Soviet leaders an opportunity to make known their views on key East-West issues.

title: U.S. SEES TEST OF TIES TO MOSCOW IN AFGHAN AND CAMBODIAN ISSUES
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to tell the Soviet Union that Moscow's response to international proposals on Afghanistan and Cambodia will be used as a test of future East-West relations, Administration officials said today.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $1.1 million for the qr and $1.9 million for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $600,000 for the qr and $1.3 million for the 6 mos

title: Harnishfeger Sells Shares to Kobe
description: The Harnischfeger Corporation, a major maker of cranes and materials-handling equipment, said it had completed the sale of one million shares of its common stock to Kobe Steel Ltd. of Japan for $26 million.

title: Business Digest
description: FRIDAY, JULY 3, 1981 The Economy

title: TRANSIT TAX PLAN DRAWN IN ALBANY
description: Hours after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority increased fares on bus, subway and commuter lines, the legislative leaders tentatively agreed tonight on a program of taxes designed to finance the authority's remaining operating deficits and prevent additional fare increases for the next two years.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DECISIONS STILL PENDING ON BOMBER AND MISSILE
description: The Defense Department confirmed today that deadlines for decisions on the future of the manned bomber and MX missile programs had passed without action but would not say when reports on the projects could be expected.

title: MAKING WHITE HOUSE SOCIAL GUESTS FEEL AT HOME
description: Many a hostess would love to have one or two, and the White House has 36: white-gloved military social aides who help smooth the way at White House social occasions.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD POWER OF STATES TO TAX RESOURCES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the state of Montana's 30 percent tax on the production of coal, most of which is shipped to energy-poor states, does not unconstitutionally interfere with interstate commerce.

title: 55 ARRESTS REPORTED AT CONCERT SUNDAY AT GIANTS STADIUM
description: Incidents during a concert last Sunday at Giants Stadium led to 55 arrests, 60 reported crimes, 417 injuries requiring first aid and 14 that required hospitalization, officials said today.

title: Chrysler-Illinois Loan
description: The Chrysler Corporation said the state of Illinois did not sign an agreement for a $20 million loan before a legislative appropriation for the loan expired on June 30. The company said it continued to count on the Illinois loan as a part of its recovery program.

title: POOLEY LEADS WESTERN OPEN BY A STROKE WITH 68
description: With the Chicago area deprived of baseball, golf was the only wheel in town today, and a record crowd of 26,200 turned out for the first round of the 78th Western Open at the Butler National Golf Club.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 3, 1981
description: International The accord with Iran was upheld by the Supreme Court, which ruled unanimously that Presidents Carter and Reagan had the legal authority to carrry out the agreement that ended the hostage crisis. The Court issued the narrowly worded decision on the final day of its 1980-81 term, only 17 days before more than $2 billion in Iranian assets are due to be transferred out of the United States under the accord. (Page A1, Column 6.) Iranians were exhorted to be alert for any suspicious activities and to report them at once to the authorities. The instructions were issued in an effort to deter further violent attacks on the revolutionary leaders. (A3:1-4.)

title: DECORATIVE ARTS: BALTIMORE ALBUM QUILTS AT THE METS
description: AN important exhibition of quilts, a folk art as American as the Fourth of July, is now on view in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where it will remain through Aug. 30. The show consists of 22 of the finest known examples of Baltimore album quilts, so-called because the 16-to-18-inch squares they are composed of suggest the pages of an autograph album. These color-splashed coverlets are typically patterned with appliques of flower-filled baskets, cornucopias, wreaths, stars, hearts, lyres, eagles, sailing ships, churches, public monuments and locomotives. These were cut and sewn of printed cotton, velvet or silk, both imported and locally produced, predominantly in reds and greens, though occasionally in blues, grays and browns, all against a white field.

title: PIERCE CALLS ON RIGHTS GROUP TO BACK REAGAN FISCAL PLANS
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, the highest-ranking black in the Reagan Administration, presented a case for supporting the President's economic proposals today at the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People here. He called for a ''bridge of understanding'' between blacks and the Administration.

title: Topics; GUNS AND BUTTER; WAR GAMES
description: Army commanders, longing for the days of the draft, say they can no longer attract a cross-section of the population. But the draft is not the only answer.

title: FORMER RIGHTS CHOICE A CONSULTANT TO HAIG
description: Ernest W. Lefever has been hired by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. as a special consultant on terrorism, counterterrorism and nuclear nonproliferation, State Department officials confirmed today.

title: The Region; TURNPIKE WORKERS STAGE A WALKOUT
description: Toll collectors and maintenance workers on the Garden State Parkway walked off the job yesterday on the eve of the holiday weekend to press their demand for wage parity with their counterparts on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: PANEL SAYS NEW PLANES NO NOT REQUIRE 3 PILOTS
description: A Presidential study group, rejecting arguments by the Air Line Pilots Association, recommended today that a third cockpit crew member need not be required to fly new jet airliners.

title: Imperial Delays Alberta Oil Project
description: Imperial Oil Ltd. said that its Esso Resources unit had delayed a decision on the fate of its $12 billion (Canadian) Cold Lake, Alberta, heavy oil project until it received more information on the progress of negotiations on an energy dispute between the federal and Alberta governments.

title: THE RIGHT TRANSIT TAX
description: To the Editor:

title: G.&W. Adds Theater Owner
description: Gulf and Western Industries, a diversified manufacturer and owner of Paramount Pictures, said it would buy the 48.9 percent of Famous Players Ltd. that it does not already own through a share exchange valued at more than $35 million.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE TEMPTATION OF EILEEN HUGHES. By Brian Moore. 211 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95.

title: Around the Nation; 16 FLEE PENNSYLVANIA JAIL; INMATES HELP OFFICERS
description: Sixteen convicts escaped from Northampton County Prison last night, but officials said other inmates prevented a mass escape after the ringleaders of the jailbreak opened 70 to 80 cells. Ten inmates remained at large today.

title: 79TH ST. BOAT BASIN GETS THEATER-IN-THE-ROTUNDA
description: John Sayles - novelist (''Union Dues''), short-story writer (''The Anarchists' Convention'') and film writer-director (''The Return of the Secaucus Seven'') - is putting in an appearance this month as a playwright. The play is ''Turnbuckle,'' a look at life's relationships through the metaphor of the wrestling mat, and the setting is the new Boat Basin Theater, outdoors on the Hudson River at 79th Street. Another Sayles play, ''New Hope for the Dead,'' shares the bill. Mr. Sayles is directing both.

title: Around the World; GUERILLAS IN EL SALVADOR SHELL A TOWN ON BORDER
description: Leftist guerrillas shelled the small northern border town of Arcatao yesterday with mortars and rocket-propelled grenades, but no civilian or military casualties were reported, a military spokesman said today.

title: AMAX ADOBE STAKE SOLD TO FRANCANA
description: Amax Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its 30 percent interest in the Adobe Oil and Gas Corporation to Francana Oil and Gas Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, for $32 a share, or $140.3 million, canceling an earlier deal to sell it for a lower price.

title: JAZZ PIANO: ROSE MURPHY
description: ROSE MURPHY is the sunniest of jazz pianists. Wednesday afternoon she sat at the piano in Carnegie Recital Hall as one of the soloists in the Kool Jazz Festival's series and rolled out lilting, foottapping performances that filled the hall with a gentle glow.

title: Business People; I.T.T. Publishing Group Gets General Manager
description: David S. Davidson has been appointed group general manager of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's publishing group and president of several of its subsidiaries, the company announced yesterday.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE OFF IN JUNE, BUT U.S. CITIES STATISTICAL QUIRKS
description: The national unemployment rate declined in June, but so did the number of Americans with jobs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: INTEREST RATE RISE TRIMS STOCK PRICES
description: Rising interest rates, a recurring nemesis of the stock market, sent prices tumbling on Wall Street yesterday and wiped out the entire advance that the Dow Jones industrial average had made in the first half of 1981.

title: Around the Nation; CALIFORNIA SUES WATT 2D TIME OVER DRILLING
description: The State of California, charging that Federal plans for oil drilling could hurt air quality, has filed its second environmental suit against Interior Secretary James G. Watt.

title: At the Movies; Bill Murray, a black sheep now in 'Stripes.'
description: A week ago, ''Stripes,'' the movie about ''a man who wanted to keep the world safe for democracy ... and meet girls,'' opened in New York. ''Stripes'' stars Bill Murray, who says his achievements make his mother happy ''not because I'm successful, but because I didn't turn out to be a complete wastrel. I was the fifth of nine children, the black sheep of the family. We had no money, and my mother pressured us to pick up occupations. She wanted a plumber, she wanted a dentist, a doctor, a priest, a nun, a carpenter. She wanted one of everything to do all those things we kept getting bills for.''

title: ART: MANHATTAN, THEN AND NOW, IN 2 NEW SHOWS
description: NEW YORK is a city of such rapid changes, vivid contrasts and short memories that one sometimes marvels that its history ever gets recorded in a way that remains intelligible to posterity. Buildings may not come down and go up at quite the ball-wrecking rate of speed achieved in the 1950's and 60's, but the pace of swift alteration in the very look of the cityscape is nonetheless fast and furious. What we see today, whether at street level or in the skyline or, alas, underground, is a city in many respects very different in appearance, not only from the New York of the 1950's, but even from the New York of 10 years ago.

title: Bridge: New Book Offers Insights
description: On the History of the u4Game By ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on strains between White House aides and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. incorrectly attributed a statement that criticism of Jeane J. Kirkpatrick had brought out the tensions. The expression ''he said'' should have read, ''a senior official said''; it did not refer to Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser.

title: FORD LINK TO TOYOTA IS STALLED
description: The yearlong negotiations between the Ford Motor Company and the Toyota Motor Company, aimed at forming a joint venture to build cars in the United States, have come to a standstill, the Japanese concern announced today.

title: REFINEMET INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including unusual income of $1.4 million...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $15,000 for the qr and $186,000 for the yr and extraordinary tax credits of $3,136,000 for the and $3,739,000 for the yr

title: PHILHARMONIC'S EX-CHIEF RETURNS AS PIANIST AT HUDSON FESTIVAL
description: Carlos Moseley has succeeded at so many things over the years that his appearance as piano soloist at the Summer of Music on the Hudson Festival tomorrow night at Lyndhurst shouldn't come as that much of a surprise.

title: NO F-16 RULING YET, U.S. SAYS
description: The White House said today that no decision had been made on lifting the suspension on the delivery of four F-16's to Israel that had been imposed after Israel's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor on June 7.

title: Notes on People; 37, 23, 26, 22, 17, 31 = 2.8 Million (Dollars)
description: The missing winner of $2.8 million in the New York State lottery was found yesterday in upper Manhattan. She is Daisy Fernandez, a 37-year-old native of the Dominican Republic who has three children.

title: Broadway; Warner is planning at least five plays for the new season.
description: THE growing theater department at Warner Communications, which is run by the veteran producer Claire Nichtern, expects to be involved in at least five Broadway productions in the new season. The first will be ''Crimes of the Heart,'' Beth Henley's Pulitzer Prize-winning play, which will open Nov. 4 at the Golden Theater. Mary Beth Hurt, Mia Dillon and Lizbeth Mackay, who starred in a production of ''Crimes of the Heart'' at the Manhattan Theater Club last season, will repeat their roles, and Melvin Bernhardt will again be the director. The co-producers are Martin Richards and Mary Lea Johnson.

title: Nasdaq Trading Up
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that Nasdaq trading volume in the first half totaled 4.07 billion shares, up 59 percent from a year earlier. Over the comparable period, it said, New York Stock Exchange volume rose 16 percent and American Stock Exchange volume declined slightly. The association said Nasdaq volume equaled 67 percent of New York Stock Exchange volume in the first half, up from 60 percent a year earlier.

title: WHERE THE WORLD BANK FAILED
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Slaying Victim Once Charged in Murder
description: One of the four murder victims found at a Laurel Canyon home was once accused of murder in the slaying of a reputed drug informant, officials said today.

title: ROCK: SPRINGSTEEN INAUGURATES NEW JERSEY ARENA
description: Bruce Springsteen's Thursday night show at the Byrne Arena in New Jersey's Meadowlands sports complex marked the new facility's debut as a site for rock performances. It is one of the first large arenas in the nation to have been designed with rock shows as well as sports events in mind, and it seems to work well for music.

title: The Patriotic Press
description: There is more than one way to report the news. Let us illustrate.

title: Fire at Nuclear Plant Shuts Down the Reactor
description: A fire that began in an electrical transformer caused large clouds of black smoke to billow from a nuclear power plant today, frightening nearby residents and automatically causing the reactor to shut down, a spokesman said.

title: CHAMBER: SUMMER AT THE Y
description: Because almost everybody in the music business seems to to have discovered that money, favorable repute or, at the very least, good will can be earned through the presentation of summer concerts - indoors or out - it was probably inevitable that the 92d Street Y music program would push into the hot-weather months sooner or later. It happened Tuesday night.

title: HOLIDAY CLOSINGS
description: Stock, commodity and other financial exchanges were closed yesterday in observance of Independence Day, along with Federal and New York City government offices. Banks in New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed today for the holiday, as will most banks in New York.

title: White Youths Rampage In Asian Area of London
description: About 200 white youths rampaged through a west London district tonight, clashing with residents of Asian origin and throwing gasoline bombs at policemen.

title: MCENROE FINED $750 FOR DOUBLES INCIDENT
description: On the eve of his Wimbledon singles final with Bjorn Borg, John McEnroe was fined $750 today for verbally abusing a linesman during a doubles match earlier in the week.

title: MRS. LLOYD WINS WITH EASE FOR A THIRD WIMBLEDON TITLE
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, saying she thought the omens were with her, won her third Wimbledon singles title today, defeating Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-2.

title: JOHNSON LOSES $93 MILLION SUIT
description: A Federal jury today awarded three Minneapolis men $93 million from the Johnson & Johnson Company in a breach of contract suit involving the acquisition of a business.

title: JOANIE'S CHIEF POSTS UPSET AT BELMONT
description: The July 4 weekend at Belmont Park began with an upset yesterday when Joanie's Chief lighted up the mutuel board by beating the best sprinters in training to win the $58,800 True North Handicap.

title: Patents; A PITCHING TARGET THAT RETURNS THE BALL
description: A wine salesman who has devoted his spare time for a dozen years to training young baseball players was granted a patent this week for a pitching target that returns the ball.

title: News Summary; News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 4, 1981
description: International Poland's Cabinet was reorganized, apparently to help the Government deal more effectively with the country's economic crisis. Eight members were ousted, five new ones appointed, and six reassigned. Except for the replacement of the Minister of Higher Education, all the affected posts were in the economic sector. The shake-up was announced by Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski shortly before the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, arrived in Warsaw for what was officially described in Mokscow as a brief friendly visit. (Page 1, Column 6.) Chris Evert Lloyd won her third Wimbledon singles title, defeating Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-2, in a 60-minute match. She swept all seven of her matches in straight sets, the first such clean slate by a women's singles champion at Wimbledon since Billie Jean King did it in 1967. (1:-5-6.)

title: MOTORMAN KILLED AND 135 INJURED IN AN IRT TRAIN CRASH IN BROOKLYN
description: A subway motorman was killed and more than 135 passengers were injured yesterday afternoon when a Manhattan-bound train plowed into the rear of a second train halted for signal trouble in a darkened tunnel in Brooklyn.

title: PARIS ASKS U.S. AID ON POORER NATIONS
description: The summit meeting in Ottawa this month of the leading industrialized nations will be a failure unless President Reagan shows more sympathy for the problems of the developing world, France's new Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, warned today.

title: JOHN S. BARNETT, 40, AN OFFICER OF CITIBANK MARKETING GROUP
description: John S. Barnett, a vice president in charge of marketing for Citibank's Financial Markets Group, died Wednesday in a scuba-diving accident off Nantucket, Mass. Mr. Barnett, who lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y., was 40 years old.

title: 80 ARRESTED IN PROTEST AT WHITE HOUSE
description: Eighty demonstrators were arrested at the White House today as they staged a sitdown protest against the Reagan Administration's budget cuts and United States involvement in El Salvador.

title: Break the Brand-Name Drug Habit
description: It may take an earthquake to shake doctors and pharmacists out of their habit of prescribing expensive, brand-name drugs. To encourage them to use the lesser-known, equivalent and less expensive generic drugs, the New York Legislature authorized a new prescription form three years ago. It required doctors to sign on the left of the form if they wanted a brand-name product, on the right side if the druggist could substitute a generic drug from a list approved by state and Federal authorities.

title: SUBURBANITES MOVING DOWNTOWN TO LOS ANGELES
description: For 21 years, Arthur Axel has fought rushhour traffic while commuting 22 miles from his home in suburban Torrance to his store in downtown Los Angeles. Starting next month, Mr. Axel will walk to work.

title: Patents; APPARATUS FOR TRACING RADIO INTERFERENCE
description: Radio interference from such ground sources as microwave towers can be traced from a satellite with apparatus invented for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Patent 4,276,553 was obtained this week by Gustave J. Schaefer, an employee of the Hughes Aircraft Company, a NASA contractor.

title: Bridge; OPTIMISM CREDO CAN LEAD TO UNSATISFACTORY RESULTS
description: Optimists far outnumber pessimists at the bridge table, and their credo often leads them into dubious ventures. They will double a small slam because they have two aces or a grand slam because they have two kings, both of which are losing propositions in the long run. Another optimist's rule has much more to recommend it: ''Where there are 12 sure tricks, there should be a 13th.''

title: Son of Phyllis Schlafly Injured in Car Accident
description: John F. Schlafly, son of Phyllis Schlafly, the opponent of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, was critically injured today in a car accident.

title: LAWMAKER'S DRIVING CURBED
description: The Kansas Department of Motor Vehicles yesterday restricted for three months the driving privileges of United States Representative Larry Winn Jr. for refusing to submit to alcohol tests related to a conviction for driving while intoxicated.

title: MONETARY POLICY STIRS CONCERN
description: The managing director of the International Monetary Fund today applauded Washington's ''determination'' to fight inflation, but he cautioned against ''undue reliance'' on monetary policy as an anti-inflation weapon because of the risk of driving up interest rates.

title: PEKING SAYS FORCE MIGHT BE USED TO REUNITE TAIWAN AND MAINLAND
description: China may be forced to resort to ''nonpeaceful methods'' to reunify Taiwan with the mainland if the United States carries out the defense provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act by supplying new weapons, a new Chinese foreign affairs journal has warned.

title: TOWNS TO SPARKLE IN NONTRADITIONAL WAYS
description: They tossed their batons into the air, which fell to earth they knew not where. ''When you throw it up and spin around you never really catch it,'' explained 8-year-old Rebecca Zein of the Red Raiders twirling squad. The Red Raiders of Ridgewood, N.J., were practicing for today's Fourth of July parade. Whether it was putting the final touches on a majestic parade float or poking crepe paper through spokes, readying the yacht for a holiday outing or laying in an extra six-pack, residents of the metropolitan area, like the rest of the nation, prepared to commemorate the signing of the Declaration of Independence in their own ways, many of which would no doubt perplex John Hancock, Thomas Jefferson and the other Founding Fathers. Turtle Race in Jersey

title: BONN FRETS ABOUT SOLVENCY OF ITS SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM
description: Otto von Bismarck, the Iron Chancellor of 19th-century Germany, was hardly a New Dealer. But in 1861, in one of several moves to take the wind out of the sails of the socialists, he gave the Prussians the world's first state-run old-age insurance system.

title: NEW BRANDS OF SUN-CARE PRODUCTS JOIN A BOOMING BUT CROWDED MARKET
description: ''The tan that always gets noticed is the one on your face,'' gushes the advertisement. And so, after years of flaunting the allover tans of bikini-clad, lithe-limbed bathers, Coppertone is showing faces that are ''fabulously tan,'' ''stunningly tan,'' ''gorgeously tan'' and ''adorably tan.''

title: JAZZ: SARAH VAUGHAN'S OLD STANDARDS
description: Sarah Vaughan - along with her piano, bass and drums trio - was the sole performer at the Kool Jazz Festival concert Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall. She was more than enough.

title: Patents; ELECTRONIC TONE FOR TELEPHONE USER
description: An electronic tone ringer was patented this week for the Bell System.

title: PERSONAL VIEWS ON OBSERVATION OF THE 4TH OF JULY
description: This morning is the 205th anniversary of the adoption of the Declaration of Independence. The day is traditionally a time of celebration, of national community, and of some thoughtful discord. To mark the day, The New York Times asked a cross-section of the metropolitan area's more prominent present and former citizens this question: ''How do you relate to the Fourth of July?''

title: STRENGTH SEEN FOR CHRYSLER
description: The Chrysler Corporation's second-quarter results will show that it is ''back on its feet,'' even if hopes of a profit are not fulfilled, a top official of the company said today.

title: FLYERS' MACLEISH TO WHALERS
description: Rick MacLeish, the center who had 38 goals and 36 assists last season for the Philadelphia Flyers, was traded to the Hartford Whalers today in a five-player deal.

title: French Professor Fined For Holocaust Remarks
description: A French court today convicted a university professor, Robert Faurisson, of inciting hatred and racial discrimination by calling the existence of Nazi gas chambers and the massacre of Jews in World War II ''a historic lie.''

title: SHELLFISH FARMING GROWING IN HAWAII
description: After six years of careful nuturing by a benign state government, the growing of shellfish in the controlled environment of aquacultural farms shows signs of maturing into a major industry in Hawaii.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: TEXAS (AL) - Sold contract of Dan G onzales, outfielder with Wichita Aeros, R angers' Class AAA affiliate, to Osaka T igers of Japanese League. BASKETBALL ATLANTA (NBA) - Signed Steve H awes, forward-center, to three-year con- t ract.

title: About New York; ON RIKERS I., FREEDOM'S LIGHT SHINES IN THE DEAD OF NIGHT
description: In the early hours of Thursday morning, long before the sky had turned from black to blue, 111 men were released from the city correctional facilities on the island off Astoria, Queens, called Rikers. Almost to a man, they said what they wanted most from a world suddenly open to them was a cold beer.

title: U.S. RESTS ITS CASE IN BRIBERY TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors finished presenting the Government's case yesterday in the trial of Carlos Marcello, a reputed organized crime leader, and four other defendants who were allegedly involved in an arrangement to pay bribes and kickbacks in exchange for Louisiana state insurance business.

title: IN THE ONCE-MIGHTY ROYAL NAVY, A SENSE OF DESPAIR
description: The Royal Navy, starting next year, will send a squadron built around an aircraft carrier to the Indian and South Atlantic Oceans as a potential reinforcement for American forces in those areas.

title: EX-POSTAL EMPLOYEE LEAVES MILLIONS TO HELP THE SIGHTLESS
description: Clinton Teubert, a retired postal worker who spent a lifetime saving pennies, ended it with an unexplained postscript of kindness: he left most of his $3 million fortune to the blind.

title: The Region; HARTFORD IS ASKED FOR BUS FARE RISE
description: Greyhound Bus Lines Inc. has asked the State Department of Transportation for permission to raise in-state fares nearly 20 percent, Commissioner Arthur B. Powers said.

title: 2 TRAIN CREWMEMBERS KILLED IN COLORADO BRIDGE ACCIDENT
description: A freight train hit a bridge washed out by a flash flood today and two locomotives fell into 25 feet of water, killing two crewmembers.

title: Patents; A METHOD THAT PICTURES A PERSON AT ANY AGE
description: Nancy Burson, a conceptual artist, was granted a patent this week for a method of picturing a person as old or young. She has demonstrated the results on television and plans to arrange for the manufacture of what she calls her age machine.

title: ILLINOIS TOWN FACES LAWSUIT AFTER LIMITING PISTOL USE
description: This quiet village of 23,000 people decided recently to ban the sale and possession of pistols, and with that decision it thrust itself into the center of a long and acrimonious national debate.

title: CONVICT IS STABBED TO DEATH IN A HALLWAY AT RIKERS ISLAND
description: A convicted murderer was stabbed to death last night in a cell block corridor at the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island, according to a spokesman for the New York City Correction Department.

title: GROMYKO IN WARSAW
description: Western diplomats here say they are now less pessimistic about the chances of Soviet military intervention in Poland. The assessment came as Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, flew to Warsaw today for what was described as a ''friendly'' visit.

title: OLD IOWA, OLD FOURTH
description: .6,2IOWA CITY - Soldiers of the American Revolution fought that 18th century war with heavy muskets. In the early 20th century, we kids fought it every Fourth of July not only with exploding powder and shimmering flares, but with all of our senses. Today's Fourth of July, like so many things in our lives, has been homogenized, the tang and the tension cut out. The grime of firecracker powder has been cleaned from our faces. There is no mess of spent skyrockets and pinwheels on the streets delighting the eye with their proof that we had recklessly spent our small sums of money in celebration. There is no smell of scorched red paper (we always believed it came from China) and singed hair, of exploded powder. No sounds of terrified dogs whining as they ran for a hiding place, no whinnying of horses terrified by firecrackers, no voices of men trying to calm them down. Nothing of that wild and dangerous spectacle remains.

title: FARE TALKS SPARK A KOCH-CAREY RIFT
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that Governor Carey had ''lost control'' of the mass-transit negotiations in Albany. Mr. Carey, in turn, accused the Mayor of playing politics with New York City subway and bus fares.

title: OLD DANCE ON TAP
description: The color and light are a little faded and some of the dancing conditions are less than ideal. But by its end, ''Jazz Hoofer: the Legendary Baby Laurence'' has presented both a deft portrait of one of the great old tappers and his telling ''personal history'' of tap dance, stating the case along the way for the neglected art of tapdancing. The new 28-minute film, directed and produced by Bill Hancock, may be seen this afternoon as part of the Carnegie Hall Cinema's 10-day ''Summer Salute to Jazz Greats,'' which will end tomorrow.

title: MELVIN BRISK, FOUNDER OF QUADRANGLE BOOKS
description: Melvin J. Brisk, a literary agent and book-marketing consultant who founded and ran Quadrangle Books Inc. before selling it to The New York Times in 1969, died of a heart attack at his home in Winnetka, Ill., on Thursday. He was 56 years old.

title: The Region; POLICEMAN KILLS MAN ON L.I.R.R.
description: An off-duty New York City police sergeant shot and killed a 19-year-old man who reportedly attacked the officer and a conductor at the Amityville station of the Long Island Rail Road, according to the Suffolk County police.

title: Three London Robbers Take $2 Million in Gems at Cartier
description: Three robbers broke into Cartier today and fled with nearly $2 million in jewels, just missing a $7.52 million shipment in gems that arrived minutes after they escaped, the police said today.

title: Notes on People; DEFIANT AT 92
description: Although he is 92 years old, deaf and partly blind, Robert A. Rabinof is serving 30 days in jail in Clearwater, Fla., because he refuses to pay his former wife $1,200 in alimony.

title: Your Money; LOAN BUSINESS IS CHANGING
description: CONSUMER finance companies, caught between high borrowing costs, relaxed bankruptcy laws and regulated pricing of the loans they make, have been obliged to alter their basic business.

title: ALBANY LEADERS UNABLE TO SHAPE TRANSIT AID BILLS
description: The legislative leaders, fearing an erosion of support for tax measures to aid mass transit, tried unsuccessfully today to draft bills enacting their financing agreement in time for passage tonight. They then announced that the Legislature would return next week to consider the tax plan and a handful of other issues.

title: AS MOROCCO STARTS TO GAIN IN WAR, NATION ERUPTS
description: At a moment when Morocco's six-yearold war in the disputed Western Sahara is finally going well, King Hassan II's country has suddenly exploded.

title: END OF DIP IN GASOLINE PRICES SEEN
description: Crude oil prices are tumbling daily on the world market, but the modest decreases consumers are seeing at gasoline pumps over the Fourth of July weekend might be the last drop in price for a while, oil industry officials said yesterday.

title: A 'BILL OF RIGHTS' FOR UTILITY USERS VOTED IN ALBANY
description: With the bill's sponsors asserting that gas and electric service ''are not a luxury, but a necessity,'' the State Senate and Assembly today approved a measure defining the rights of consumers in their dealings with utility companies.

title: THE DIVERSE CONCERNS OF DENG'S OPPOSITION
description: To the Editor:

title: NOW VS. CABLE TV'S WOULD-BE CENSORS
description: To the Editor:

title: THREE CAPTURED
description: Six inmates wielding knives and gasoline bombs commandeered a milk truck and firebombed a guard tower today during a daylight escape from the maximum-security Trenton State Prison, authorities said.

title: RIDER FATALLY STABBED ABOARD AN IRT TRAIN
description: A Bronx man, fatally stabbed, staggered through eight subway cars late Thursday night and collapsed outside the motorman's cab on the IRT Broadway line shortly before the train pulled into its northern terminal, at West 242d Street and Broadway.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on June 7 misidentified the performers who appeared at a stockholders' meeting of the Sealaska Corporation in Sitka, Alaska. They were Indian dancers.

title: AMANDA MCKERROW: IN THE DANCE LIMELIGHT
description: A month ago, Amanda McKerrow was just one of 26 members of the Washington Ballet, a lively young company based in the capital. True, she had been described by critics as ''splendid'' and ''a dancer to watch.'' But life was the dancer's usual round of ballet classes and rehearsals spiced with intermittent performances.

title: OBSCURE PLAYERS PACING WESTERN
description: The 78th Western Open has its best field of big names in recent years, but for the second straight day the leaders came out of the Who's He? category.

title: ALLIED'S LEAN, HUNGRY LOOK
description: It used to be a sprawling corporate giant with a patchwork of interests and an earnings record that provoked yawns on Wall Street.

title: COAST GUARD THWARTING MARIJUANA TRAFFICKERS
description: A golden marijuana leaf, painted on the mast of the Dauntless, a United States Coast Guard cutter, was unveiled here Wednesday at a ceremony attended by representatives of local lawenforcement agencies.

title: A GUIDE TO FABRIC SHOPS IN MANHATTAN
description: Velveteen, challis, crepe de chine, taffeta, sequined lace, metallic chiffon - all the luxurious fabrics that make the current fashions look and feel so good - also help make them very costly. Lucky the woman with both the talent and the time to make her own clothes. She can get designer patterns and fabrics and produce her own designer wardrobe for a lot less than ready-to-wear at retail.

title: IT'S A DAY FOR PICNICS, AND A DAY FOR PICNIC FOES
description: It is altogether suitable that as the most American of American holidays, the Fourth of July is celebrated with what has become the most American of all feasts - a traditional picnic that generally includes elements of a cookout. It could hardly be said that eating out of doors is an American invention, and the very word picnic is believed to have been derived from the French, piquenique (piquer, to pick, and nique, a trifle).

title: ALBANY'S END OF SESSION BRINGS BILLS IN DISGUISE
description: ''This is the time of year,'' Assemblyman Robert C. Wertz said, ''when the bills start coming up with pictures on them.''

title: Books of The Times Embattled Defender?
description: THE PRESS AS GUARDIAN OF THE FIRST AMENDMENT. By John Lofton. 358 pages. University of South Carolina Press. $14.95.

title: No Headline
description: The war between Iran and Iraq apparently intensified today, with reports from both sides saying the principal action occurred north of the oil-producing province of Khuzistan.

title: Notes on People; DUMPSON TO HEAD COMMUNITY SERVICE SOCIETY
description: New York City's former Administrator of Human Resources, Dr. James R. Dumpson, has been elected president of the Community Service Society, a nonprofit social agency that handles a wide variety of aid programs.

title: The Region; NO TALKS ARE SET IN PARKWAY STRIKE
description: Striking toll collectors and maintenance workers picketed on the Garden State Parkway as their union and the New Jersey Highway Authority each waited for the other to make the first move toward negotiations.

title: 4 Towns Are Evacuated In Wisconsin Derailment
description: Hundreds of people were evacuated in two northwestern Wisconsin counties today after a train derailed, spilling about 17,000 gallons of a corrosive chemical.

title: THREE U.S. CREWS ELIMINATED
description: ON-THAMES, England, July 3 - Three of the four American eights in the Grand Challenge Cup were eliminated today in the opening heats of the event at the 142d Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 36.

title: Pope Cancels French Visit
description: The Vatican has told the French episcopate that Pope John Paul II will not be able to attend the eucharistic congress in Lourdes July 21, a church spokesman said today. The Pope is recovering in a Rome hospital from a virus possibly transmitted through blood he received during surgery for wounds suffered in an assassination attempt May 13.

title: DANBURY PLANS WATER CURBS
description: The city of Danbury, where municipal reservoirs are nearly 40 percent below capacity, is imposing mandatory drinking-water controls on residents beginning Monday. The rules limit watering of lawns and gardens to two hours every other day and prohibit all other outdoor water use.

title: Zoning a Better Midtown
description: After careful study, New York City's Planning Commission has proposed a constructive set of new controls for midtown development. By offering zoning advantages with tax incentives and faster building opportunities, the planners hope to shift growth from the overdeveloped East Side to the neglected West Side, reducing the cost of building in a specified area by 25 percent.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. Jerry Pate won his first victory in almost three years and celebrated his two-stroke victory in the Danny Thomas-Memphis Classic by leaping into the lake in front of the 18th green.

title: Mr. Koch's Memorial Subway
description: In all the primal screaming this week over how to keep the transit fare from rising any higher than 75 cents, everyone seems to have overlooked the real question: Whose bus and subway system is it?

title: QUAKE TOWN'S CHILDREN ARE GUESTS OF WESTPORT
description: On a quiet Sunday last fall, 11-year-old Antonio DiCarlo was spending a peaceful evening at home in Balvano, Italy, with his family when the earth suddenly shuddered and his house began to shake. When the earthquake was over, the little village lay in ruins, with scores of people buried under the debris.

title: Notes on People; SING-ALONG MAN REFLECTS ON 55-YEAR CAREER
description: Since he was born on the Fourth of July in 1910, Mitch Miller today reaches the special age of three score and ten, but Mr. Miller, bestknown perhaps as the man who added the term sing-along to popular music when he was a television star, doesn't plan to blow out 70 skyrockets on a cake.

title: WHEN THE BOAT PEOPLE NEEDED REAL FRIENDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quake Jolts California Area
description: A light earthquake rattled an industrial area near here today, prompting a few telephone calls to the police but causing no damage. Seismologists at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena said that the quake, which occurred at 6:45 A.M., was centered 6 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles and registered 2.4 on the Richter scale.

title: SCHOOLS RIPE FOR AN INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNFLOWER EMERGING AS A COMMODITY
description: Even though it is the state flower of Kansas, the sunflower has had a history of scant regard by most American farmers as nothing more than a pretty weed that grows between their fences and the highway.

title: The Parade
description: There is a small New England town that held its first Fourth of July parade in 1785. Ever since, the town's year has been divided into the period before the Fourth and the period after the Fourth. Autumn is said to begin on July 5.

title: NOT DESIGNER COWBOYS, BUT COWBOYS BY DESIGN
description: Tall, wide-brimmed hats over their eyes and scrambled eggs, sausage and coffee in their stomachs, Frosty and Jeff Crane saddled their horses an hour past sunrise and rode toward Robbers Roost to check stock.

title: SYRIANS STILL IN CONTROL AT APPROACHES TO ZAHLE
description: The Syrian siege of this predominantly Greek Catholic community was declared ended earlier this week, but Syrian Special Forces troops were still controlling checkpoints today right up to the edge of town.

title: Caramore Easy Winner Of Jersey Classic Pace
description: Caramore, a 3-year-old bay colt owned by the Rev. Thomas J. O'Connor, chaplain at Marlboro State Hospital, won the second New Jersey Classic mile pace tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: TOCQUEVILLE'S INSIGHT
description: .6,2NEW HAVEN - One hundred fifty years ago today, a 25-year-old Frenchman, Alexis de Tocqueville, witnessed the exuberant Fourth of July celebration in Albany, N.Y. From May 1831 to February 1832, he was to visit all sections of the United States, most major cities, and a long list of prominent Americans, and out of those travels came perhaps the most significant commentary ever written about our society, ''Democracy in America.''

title: Index; International
description: Bonn worries about solvency of its social security system 2 Syrians still control checkpoints into Lebanese town after siege 3 China hints at use of force over Taiwan 3 Around the World 4 Just as Morocco's war starts going well, riots erupts 4 Government/Politics Illinois town enters national de- bate after banning pistols 6 80 protesters arrested at White House 7 Coast Guard is ''hurting'' mari- juana traffickers 8 New York's Senate passes a util- ity customers' rights bill 23 Some special-interest bills in dis- guise in Albany 35 General Times Sq. renewal plan is ap- praised 1 Around the Nation 5 Californians are moving to down- town Los Angeles 5 Old soldier returns for the Fourth in North Adams, Mass. 5 Handicapped climbers reach top of Mount Rainier 6 Indiana town prepares for week- end at the hydroplane races 7 INDEPENDENCE DAY Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended; all other rules in effect. Sanitation - No collections or street sweeping. Collections normally made today will be made tomorrow. Post Offices - Closed; only special delivery and express mail delivered. Transportation - Buses and subways on Sunday schedule. L.I.R.R. and Conrail Harlem, Hudson and New Haven Divisions on holiday schedule. Libraries - Closed.

title: YACHT OF PRESIDENTS IS REBORN
description: The restored yacht of past Presidents from Herbert Hoover to Jimmy Carter was formally unveiled today, although none of her financial skippers were certain of either future passengers or a future berth.

title: OLD RIVER TOWN IN INDIANA PREPARES FOR ITS DAY AT THE HYDROPLANE RACES
description: Tony Steinhardt retired from the crew of the Miss Madison hydroplane racing team after last season. He wrote a letter making it official.

title: NAVY IS PROPOSING $120 BILLION PLAN TO SURPASS SOVIET
description: The Navy has proposed a vast shipbuilding and aircraft procurement plan that is intended to meet President Reagan's goal of attaining a clear margin of naval superiority over the Soviet Union before the end of this decade. The plan includes two nuclearpowered aircraft carriers, 14 attack submarines and nearly 1,900 airplanes.

title: PAISLEY UNHURT IN CAR ATTACK
description: A single shot fired today at a police car carrying the Rev. Ian Paisley through Belfast missed the Protestant leader, the Royal Ulster Constabulary reported.

title: Notes on People; A PICNIC TO CELEBRATE NANCY REAGAN'S BIRTHDAY
description: Two days ahead of time, Nancy Reagan will celebrate her 58th birthday today with a picnic near George Washington's home in Virginia.

title: Economic Analysis
description: ''Free trade doesn't exist,'' contends Michael Samuels, who watches over international trade matters for the United States Chamber of Commerce. ''It's like infinity - you never reach it.''

title: NEW YORK MUST DIG A LONG, LONG SUMMER
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; NEW WAY OF GETTING HYDROGEN
description: WASHINGTON HYDROGEN is considered a possible replacement for oil and gas as a fuel, and the Energy Department is exploring various methods of generating it. One of them is disclosed in patent 4,276,279, which was obtained this week by researchers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee.

title: Determination Spurs Friede
description: It was the first day of the Giants minicamp five weeks ago. On a grass field adjoining Giants Stadium, the offense was working on passing, and Mike Friede went out for a pass.

title: Notes on People; ROYAL DISAPPOINTMENT
description: After little more than a month, the marriage of Princess Marie Christine Daphne of Belgium and Paul Drake, owner of a Toronto piano bar, is coming to an end.

title: THEATER: CIULEI STAGES 'TEMPEST' AT GUTHERIE
description: For a New York theatergoer who has suffered through this season's lame productions of classics at the Vivian Beaumont Theater and the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it is a bittersweet experience to visit the Tyrone Guthrie Theater. Like its New York counterparts, the Guthrie has only recently fallen into new artistic hands - this is the theater's first season under the directorship of Liviu Ciulei.

title: Garibaldi Anniversary Today in the Village
description: A ceremony marking the 174th anniversary of the birth of Giuseppi Garibaldi, the 19th-century patriot and soldier who fought for a unified Italy, will be held today at 11:30 A.M. at the Garibaldi Monument in Washington Square Park, near the archway at Fifth Avenue.

title: ALBERT DAILEY, SOLO PIANIST
description: Albert Dailey, who replaced the previously announced Duke Jordan as the pianist in the Kool Jazz Festival's solo piano series at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday, is a musician of awesome technique who plays a very full piano. His attack is very positive, his runs come tumbling over one another with great precision and with clear articulation, and he builds crescendos that can be shattering.

title: TEACHERS' LEADER EXPRESSES CONFIDENCE IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: Reports of declining confidence in the public school system have been greatly exaggerated, the president of the National Education Association said today.

title: Currency; DOLLAR HOLDS FIRM OVERSEAS
description: The dollar held firm in European foreign exchanges today with trading subdued by the Independence Day holiday in the United States. Gold bullion eased further in equally quiet trading.

title: Sports of the Times; 'TRUIMPH FOR BRITISH HOUSEWIFE' ON CENTER COURT
description: WIMBLEDON, England OUT on Wimbledon's center court, the grounds crew, in purple and green uniforms, had rolled green mats across the brown grass.
