Suddenly a small table materialized, with a Union Jack for a tablecloth. On it was a huge gold and silver plate that Chris Evert Lloyd was about to receive as the ''ladies singles'' champion. When she won here in 1974 and 1976 she was still Chris Evert, an American who was dating Jimmy Connors, of all people. But yesterday she won Wimbledon for the first time since her 1979 marriage to John Lloyd, her British husband. And as Chris Evert Lloyd glowed, a London critic chuckled.

title: RECORDINGS RAISE QUESTIONS ABOUT TIMERMAN'S ACCOUNT
description: Police tape recordings of interrogation sessions with Jacobo Timerman have raised questions about whether the former newspaper publisher fully explained the authorities' possible motives in arresting and torturing him.

title: Women's Work
description: Despite some fear that the Supreme Court is sanctioning discrimination by sex, one recent decision may help to establish new rights for women in the workplace. More women work than ever before, many at jobs that grandma could not imagine doing; but they are actually losing some ground to men. Now, a five-justice majority has greatly broadened the legal ground on which they may seek redress.

title: Bonn Says a Soviet Spy May Have Tank Plans
description: The West German authorities said today that they were investigating a suspected Soviet espionage operation in which a Soviet diplomat may have obtained top-secret plans to the West German Leopard 2 tank.

title: 3 Oklahomans Sentenced In Bribery Investigation
description: The first two men convicted of charges arising from an investigation of kickbacks to county commissioners in Oklahoma were sentenced to prison terms yesterday by a Federal District judge, and a third was placed on probation.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JULY 4, 1981; The Economy
description: Modest recent gasoline price drops might be the last consumers will see for a while, although crude oil prices are tumbling daily. Analysts predict that, even if crude oil prices continue to slip, as expected, the effect on retail gasoline prices will be marginal. (Page 25.)

title: ARKANSAS SUSPECT JOINS LIST OF 10 MOST WANTED FUGITIVES
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday added Leslie Nichols, sought in connection with the execution-style slayings of four persons in Little Rock, Ark., to its list of 10 most wanted fugitives.

title: SAVINGS IN OWNING A PHONE
description: "NOW 100% LEGAL,'' proclaims the big sign on the window of Phone City, one of several stores in Manhattan that specialize in non-Bell telephone equipment.

title: CALVIN REAGAN
description: .2,2WASHINGTON - It has been a long time since anyone has had anything good to say about Calvin Coolidge, but President Reagan apparently is determined to set history right.

title: PENTAGON BALKING AT JOINING DRUG WAR
description: Proposals to involve the armed forces more actively in stemming the huge flow of illegal drugs and illegal aliens into the United States have won the qualified endorsement of the Justice Department and may result in potentially far-reaching legislation this year.

title: GENSTAR RAISES BID IN CANADA
description: The Genstar Corporation of Vancouver sweetened its proposal to take over the Canada Permanent Mortgage Corporation of Toronto, and Canada Permanent recommended today that its shareholders accept the new cash offer, valued at $260 million (Canadian).

title: WILLIAM KNIGHTON JR.
description: William H.Y. Knighton Jr., a former White House correspondent for The Baltimore Sun, died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 81 years old.

title: TALKS TO RESUME TODAY ON A LESS OPTIMISTIC NOTE
description: Negotiators resume their efforts to end the baseball strike this morning following a series of confusing developments that dimmed earlier hopes that a settlement would come soon.

title: JAZZ: A PAIR OF VIRTUOSO PIANISTS
description: By a coincidence of progamming Thursday, two jazz pianists of exceptional virtuosity and basically similar styles played in Carnegie Hall within a few hours of each other as part of the Kool Jazz Festival. Dorothy Donegan gave a solo concert in Carnegie Recital Hall at 5 P.M., and Oscar Peterson appeared in the main hall at 8 o'clock, playing alone for the first half and with his trio for the second. Their performances offered some interesting contrasts.

title: FORMER AMBASSADOR AND A GLOBE MAKER
description: Luther I. Replogle, a former United States Ambassador to Iceland and the founder and former president of Replogle Globes Inc. of Chicago, died yesterday at Rush Presbyterian-St. Luke's Hospital in Chicago.

title: BAND'S OF 40'S ON FILM
description: From Jimmy Dorsey to Cootie Williams to Ina Ray Hutton's all-female ''Mellow Dears,'' some of the best big bands of the 40's came back for a two-hour film program at Town Hall on Thursday night. But only a small audience of their loyal fans showed up to greet them.

title: An Appraisal
description: The general outlines of the city and state plan for the redevelopment of Times Square and West 42d Street have been known for several months. But they have now moved into a far more definite form -so definite, in fact, that it is possible for the first time to see precisely what the project, should it ever be realized, will look like.

title: DISABLED GROUP CONQUERS MOUNT RAINIER, ICE AND ALL
description: Five blind climbers joined by one man with an artificial leg, an epileptic and two deaf adventurers were part of a group that completed a joyful climb today to the summit of Mount Rainier.

title: Going Out Guide
description: LOOKING BACK

title: SHATTERED STATUTE RESTORED FOR HOLIDAY
description: A little town that refused to let its oldest soldier die threw a party today for the return of a Civil War statue that became a pile of stones one perilous night in the headlights' white glare.

title: Barrios of White Sox In Alcoholism Center
description: Francisco Barrios, the Chicago White Sox pitcher, has entered a Chicago area drug and alcohol treatment center to undergo a rehabilitation program, the team said today.

title: JERSEY TRASH STRIKE AGAINST 35 HAULERS GOES INTO A 3D DAY
description: The big city-owned garbage truck pulled up to two large piles of rubbish in front of 659 and 663 Broad Street in the main shopping area. The driver, Anthony Albanese, told his loaders to put the pile in front of Jordan's Clothing store at 663 into the truck and to leave the other where it was, in front of the Rite Aid Pharmacy.

title: The Region; 400 ATTEND BURIAL OF SUBWAY VICTIM
description: The 26-year-old Torrington man who died on a Times Square subway track after being chased by youths and vagrants last Saturday was buried today.

title: THE BRONX BECKONS APARTMENT HUNTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: SPY CASE AND TOOL INDUSTRY
description: The arrest on espionage charges this week of Marian Zacharski, president of the obscure Polish American Machinery Corporation in suburban Elk Grove Village, Ill., has brought unwanted notoriety to the machine tool company, whose annual revenues are $30 million. But expanding East-West trade relations may be dealt a much harsher blow.

title: HIGH IRANIAN OFFICIALS SAYS PURGE HAS DEFEATED FOES OF GOVERNMENT
description: The Speaker of Iran's Parliament said today that a purge ordered by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini had defeated the opponents of the clergy-dominated Iranian Government.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's hard for me to think of the Fourth in the usual sense anymore.

title: On Language
description: By William Safire Carte Before the Horse Kimble Mead

title: Eric R. Keller Fiance Of Ophelia Laughlin
description: Mr. and Mrs. James B. Laughlin of Blawenburg, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ophelia Gallup Laughlin, to Eric R. Keller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald C. Keller of Wayne, N.J.

title: THEATER: 'DON JUAN' STAGED IN MINNEAPOLIS
description: No one can accuse Liviu Ciulei of playing it safe in his first season as artistic director of the Tyrone Guthrie Theater. In repertory with his own, challenging version of ''The Tempest,'' he is offering a daring, if at times self-immolating production of Moliere's ''Don Juan,'' directed by Richard Foreman. These two shows will be joined by a revival of ''Our Town'' next week, but not just any old ''Our Town'': The Guthrie's will be directed by that Beckett and Albee specialist, Alan Schneider. Need I say that Minneapolis is definitely worth a detour for hungry theatergoers this summer?

title: Columnist in Argentina Facing Action in Court
description: The military Government has asked the federal prosecutor to file charges against a newspaper columnist for publishing information that it said endangered national security.

title: No Headline
description: In a long article, it is not surprising that Peter Stone should have got some things wrong. One of them, alas, concerns my own ideas.

title: New Jersey Guide; CORELLI IN HOLMDEL
description: Franco Corelli, for years a sensational tenor and ''champion belter'' at the Metropolitan Opera and other such houses in the world, has been edging out of his five-year retirement of late. On Thursday night, he will present a concert of opera arias and songs at the Garden State Arts Center.

title: Jane Louisa Knuth Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles J. Knuth of Manhasset, L.I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Louisa Knuth, to David Byron-Brown of London, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Byron-Brown of Brighton, England. The wedding will take place on Aug. 29. Miss Knuth is a freelance translator in London, where her fiance is a programmer with Business Intelligence Services Ltd. Dr. Knuth is director of patents at Pfizer Inc. in New York.

title: Sound; GETTING HIGH-FIDELITY TV FROM CABLE; by Hans Fantel
description: Ripeness is all, said Shakespeare, and television is definitely getting ripe. This observation refers not to the programs but rather to the technical maturity of the medium. For the first time since the inception of broadcast television - exactly 50 years go this month - high-quality signals are now available nearly everywhere in the United States. Cable subscribers no longer depend on the vagaries of off-the-air reception. Instead, they are directly linked to signals optimized in both sight and sound, often far better than conventional TV sets can reproduce. The quality of such signals is wasted unless it is matched by the quality of the receiving set.

title: MALL PLAN STIRS UP A STORM
description: HEMPSTEAD THE proposed construction of a shopping mall in Mitchel Field, with Sears, Roebuck & Company as a prime tenant, is seen by some local merchants and public officials as a threat to the commercial viability of East Meadow and Hempstead.

title: Anne C. de la Selle Wed to Envoy
description: James Gordon Lowenstein, Ambassador to Luxembourg, and Anne Cornely de la Selle were married yesterday. Mayor Camille Polfer performed the ceremony at the Luxembourg Town Hall.

title: COUNTY FAIR RETURNING FRIDAY
description: YONKERS THE Westchester County Fair, dormant since 1949, will be revived at the Yonkers Raceway this Friday, and its nine-day stand may bring back memories for many.

title: FOR A LAOTIAN, FRUSTRATION AND ESCAPE
description: In June 1975, when the Laotian Communists were sweeping aside the coalition Government and taking over the country, a senior, nonpolitical official explained to an American friend why he would not join the mounting tide of people fleeing to Thailand across the Mekong River.

title: PANTS AND FLATS NEW ITALIAN CHIC
description: There are still a few of those male peacocks striding daily through Milan's Galleria in their tight pants, a pack of Marlboros clenched firmly in one hand, the hand of a high-heeled woman clenched just as firmly in the other. This is what the inexperienced tourist, who thinks that the Galleria is the fashion center of Milan, usually sees.

title: ETHICS OF GENE SPLICING TROUBLING THEOLOGIANS
description: The possibility of manufacturing new forms of life or genetically altering human beings, who are described in Christian and Jewish Scriptures as created ''in the image of God,'' is raising new problems for theologians attempting to assess the morality of modern bioethics.

title: Prison Population Grows 5%
description: The nation's prison population grew last year by 5 percent, or 15,000 inmates, the Justice Department said. There were 329,122 men and women in prison in 1980, a record number that marks an increase of 61 percent over the last decade.

title: Dietz Paces Qualifiers For Elite Single Final
description: Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club qualified for the elite single final today at the opening of the two-day Independence Day regatta on the Schuykill.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: NEW JERSEY'S prisons are badly overcrowded, but until now the idea of a new state prison has been about as popular as a pig farm. Everyone agreed it was needed, but no one wanted it in his backyard.

title: THE CABLE-TV REVOLUTION: HOW IT AFFECTS THE ARTS OPPORTUNITIES KNOCK
description: FOR PERFORMERS AND PRODUCERS By TONY SCHWARTZ

title: THE DANCE: MISS RAGIR IN CONCERT
description: Judith Ragir appears to enjoy going berserk on stage. A dancer and choreographer from Chicago, Miss Ragir presented a solo concert Thursday night at the Trisha Brown Studio. In all but one of her dances she portrayed a demented woman. Moreover, she did so with great glee and one even suspected that if she stayed for a time in Manhattan she might eventually take back to Chicago a whole cycle of dances about New York bag ladies.

title: AGENT ORANGE IN STAMFORD
description: STAMFORD PAST the white picket fence and under the American flag that flies from the porch at 955 Cove Road come the sick, the suffering and the questioning. They are veterans of the Vietnam War, but to them the battle is not over. An enemy more deadly, they say, than the one they faced in the jungles of Southeast Asia still stalks them.

title: CUTTING UP THE PIE
description: THE PURSUIT OF INEQUALITY By Philip Green. 320 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $14.95. EQUALITY By William Ryan. 239 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $14.95. By CLIFFORD ORWIN

title: The Region in Summary; NOT TOO HOT FOR GARBAGE STRIKERS
description: As with crooks in casinos, chemical wastes and, last week, ordinary garbage, New Jersey has trouble getting rid of things it does not want.

title: Feminism's Next Step
description: "The women's movement is over,'' said my friend, a usually confident executive, who is also a wife and feminist. ''At least,'' she continued in a grim tone, ''it is in my shop. The men are making jokes about bimbos again, and the other woman in the executive group and I just look at each other. It doesn't matter if we get mad; they act as if we aren't there. When a new job opens up, all they look for now is men. It's as if the word has gone out that we've lost our case; there won't be any equal rights amendment after all, so they don't need to worry anymore about lawsuits over sex discrimination, even though laws against it are still on the books. They figure they can do what they want about women now - or do nothing at all - like the old days.''

title: A CHARLATAN IN PURSUIT OF TRUTH
description: RUMSON THERE'S a trickster here who has duped millions of people, but most of his ''victims'' have loved every minute of it. For 35 years, James Randi has been making a living by sawing women in half, reading minds and commanding objects to float in space.

title: Wine; THE SUBJECT IS ROSE; by Terry Robards "S
description: he restaurant was positioned among the trees on the shore of a cool, green Wisconsin lake, where it could catch the breezes from the water and provide a superb view of the countryside for its customers. It was colonial in style, white clapboard siding with red shutters, and it was the kind of establishment that relied almost exclusively on the magnificent scenery provided by nature to attract its clientele.

title: TODAY'S JAZZ FESTIVAL EVENTS
description: Following is the schedule for today's Kool Jazz Festival events. For information, call 787-2020. Noon. Damrosch Shell, Lincoln Center: Nat Adderly Quartet, Tri-State McDonald's High School Jazz Ensemble, Errol Parker Experience, Howard McGhee Octet, Charles Austin/ Joe Gallivan Trio and others. Free. Noon to midnight. Saratoga Performing Arts Center, Saratoga Springs, N.Y.: Jazz Kaleidoscope Part II, featuring Weather Report with Joe Zawinul, Wayne Shorter, Jaco Pastorius, Peter Erskine and Bobby Thompson Jr., Mel Torme and his Trio, the Dave Brubeck Quartet, Dizzy Gillespie Quartet, Carmen McRae and Her Trio, Illinois Jacquet Quintet, Mel Lewis and the Jazz Orchestra, James Moody All-Stars with Barry Harris and Victor Gaskin, Frank Foster's Loud Minority, Joanne Brackeen Trio, Johnny Griffin Quartet, the Red Norvo-Tal Farlow Trio, Big Sky Mud Flaps and Major Holley's tribute to Louise Jordan, with Doc Cheatham, Eddie Chamblee, Oliver Jackson, Eddie (Cleanhead) Vinson and Billy Butler and others. Admission to grounds, $11, $6 for those younger than 12. Reserved seating in amphitheater, $7 and $8.50. Information: 787-2020 or (518) 587-3330. 2 to 11 P.M. Center for the Arts, State University of New York College at Purchase: Jazzfare II, with Joe Albany, a tribute to Eubie Blake, with Dick Hyman, Kenny Davern, Bobby Rosengarden and Milt Hinton, the Amherst Saxophone Quartet, Ruby Braff Quintet, John Bunch, with Charles Rouse, Tom Harrell, Bill Pemberton and Connie Kay, Candido and His V.I.P.'s, the Valerie Capers Trio, Junior Cook and Bill Hardman with Walter Bishop Jr., Terry Gibbs and Buddy DeFranco with Ross Tompkins and George Mraz, Billy Harper Quartet, Louis Hayes, Julius Hemphill Quartet, Fred Hersch, Robin Kenyatta Quintet, Byard Lancaster and Philly Funk, David Lahm Octet, Warne Marsh Quartet, Marian McPartland with Barbara Carroll and James Williams, Mike Peters's String Fever, Herb Pomeroy Big Band, Gene Taylor, the Michael Urbaniak Group, Mal Waldron, Lynn Weishman and the Tentette Band, Bob Wilber and the Bechet Legacy, Old, New, Borrowed and Bluesy, ''A New Jazz Tap Show'' by Jane Goldberg's Changing Times Top Dance Company, saxophone workshop with Nick Brignola, Sonny Fortune and Charles Rouse and singer's workshop, with Bob Dorough, Stella Marrs, Susannah McCorkle, Marlene VerPlanck and others.

title: ON BUYING AND OWNING A POST OFFICE
description: Despite the ever-present American flags flying above all United States post offices, the United States Postal Service actually owns only 3,691 buildings. The remaining 28,743 post offices in the United States are leased from other owners.

title: GIVING A DEFINITION OF TUITION TAX CREDITS
description: In his recent letter to the editor on tuition tax credits, Saul Schindler asks why ''the general public that does not or cannot afford to send their children to private schools should have to provide scarce tax monies for those who can.''

title: Politics; CANDIDATES IN SIXTH DISTRICT LOOK FOR RUNNING ROOM
description: WHAT a difference a year makes in the search for candidates to run for the United States House of Representatives in Connecticut's Sixth Congressional District.

title: Helicopter Clatter
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKER WITH TIES TO PAST UNCOVERS NEW ONE
description: Henry H. Livingston, a securities analyst, knows more about the history of New York, and the history of his family, than most other New Yorkers. He lives in a 200-year-old house on land in Hudson that has been in his family since it was acquired nearly three centuries ago by his grandfather nine times removed. He knows where that ancestor, Robert Livingston, is buried, and where he lived in Albany.

title: LETHARGY MARKS CLOSING DAYS OF ALBANY LEGISLATIVE SESSION
description: Albany Notes

title: Cosmos' DiBernardo Is Ready to Return
description: Angelo DiBernardo of the Cosmos thinks he should have missed only three or four North American Soccer League games as a result of an injury to his leg earlier this season. Instead, he has missed 10.

title: S.D. Kelley Weds Jeanette Bartlett
description: The marriage of Jeanette Thibaut Bartlett, assistant to the associate director of nursing operations at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, to Sherwood Daniel Kelley, vice president of the Irving Leasing Corporation, an Irving Trust Company subsidiary, took place yesterday in the garden of the Bartow Pell Mansion in the Bronx. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony.

title: ARE LOBSTERING SITES POLLUTED?
description: LONG BRANCH FEDERAL officials and commercial lobstermen are in disagreement over whether some of the lobsters being harvested off the New Jersey coast are being taken from a dump area containing hazardous wastes.

title: Business Conditions; RADIO ADS RIDE A COMEBACK
description: Radio, the advertising medium many gave up for dead in the 1950's and 1960's, when television began to take over, is making a comeback. During the last 10 years, advertising revenues have more than doubled, to an estimated $3.6 billion in 1980.

title: 'NO-GROWTH' THEORY STIRS L.I. DEBATE
description: CENSUS figures indicating that the Island's population has stabilized and the impact of this on companies that previously grew with the population have sparked a debate among Long Island planners over the strength of the Island's economy.

title: Miss Nolin, Airline Aide Plan Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh T. Nolin of Neenah, Wis., formerly of Southport, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Payson Nolin, to Peter Russell Deupree Tagge, son of Mrs. Ann Weller Tagge of Gay Head, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and Lieut. Col. Raymond C. Tagge, U.S.A.F., retired, of Alexandria, Va.

title: headliners; SURPRISE MOVE
description: Boris Gulko knows what it is to be a pawn in someone else's game.

title: Music; 2 FESTIVALS BEGIN
description: EVEN as the Lyndhurst and Caramoor concerts continue to delight Westchester music lovers, two other major county festivals are getting under way. A preview of Summerfare '81 at the State University of New York's Purchase campus at 2 P.M. today will offer nine hours of all-star jazz. And tonight at 8, the Singer's Theater starts its ninth summer of vocal programs in northern Westchester with an operatic doubleheader.

title: Critics' Choices; by Gene Thornton
description: PHOTOGRAPHY Color film is designed to reproduce nature's colors more or less accurately when the subject is illuminated by bright sunlight outdoors or indoors by tungsten light. Under any other lighting conditions, the colors obtained are apt to stray far from nature, as every beginning photographer learns to his dismay.

title: Realty News; MART DIRECTIVE DROPPED
description: The Reagan Administration has terminated , a 1979 White House Community Conservation Guidance Directive that introduced to the Federal level the concept of ''extraterritoriality'' to planning considerations for large new shopping centers .

title: Frederic Sherrill Will Wed Michele Dreyfuss, an Artist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Dreyfuss of New York and Seaview, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michele Dreyfuss, to Frederic Sherrill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias R. Sherrill of New York and Southampton, L.I.

title: Dining Out; AMBIANCE AND RIB-STICKING FARE
description: NOT very much has changed at The Tap in Bronxville since 1934. A light-handed sprucing up by the present owners, Marge Blaner, Peter Behrens and the chef, Dieter Schott, has left the period bar, cut glass, murals of Alpine scenes and comfortable old-world ambiance intact. The menu still lists some dishes that have a decidedly German cast, but they make up a small part of the menu that now favors ribsticking American food and no-nonsense fish selections.

title: ACTRESS WELL-KNOWN FOR HER COMIC ROLES
description: Violet Heming, an English-born actress who made her American debut in 1908 as Wendy in ''Peter Pan'' and grew into a succesful comedy star, died yesterday at her home on the Upper East Side. She was 86 years old.

title: The Region in Summary; ONE SMALL STEP TOWARD LITERACY
description: For years, critics have argued that New York City schools were, in effect, failing many of their foundering pupils by passing them. Not only the children suffered.

title: Europeans' Afghan Plan Is Dismissed by Tass
description: On the eve of a visit here by Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, to discuss a new West European initiative on Afghanistan, the Soviet press agency Tass declared today that it was ''absolutely clear'' that the plan could not serve as a basis for discussions.

title: By Sports of The Times; A Yankee Doodle Celebrates the 4th
description: I N clusters, they were streaming out of the center

title: NEW HANDS ARE CARRYING ON THE DISNEY STUDIO'S TRADITION
description: Walt Disney Studios, the folks who brought us ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,'' ''Fantasia,'' ''Dumbo,'' ''Bambi,'' ''Cinderella,'' ''Peter Pan'' and 13 other animated feature films, has finished number 20, which is due to open in New York this Friday. Entitled ''The Fox and the Hound,'' it is only the fifth animated movie the studio has produced since Walt Disney's death in late 1966. By coincidence, its premiere comes shortly after the Whitney Museum of American Art began a summer-long exhibition of Disney animation that emphasizes the studio's ''Golden Period'' from 1932 to 1942 and includes 150 short cartoons and five full-length films.

title: Headliners; THIRD PLACE IS NO PLACE
description: Fred Silverman heard the footsteps and didn't wait to be pushed. He resigned last week after three disappointing years as president of NBC.

title: THE HOUSE JANE BUILT
description: THE GRAND DOMESTIC REVOLUTION A History of Feminist Designs for American Homes, Neighborhoods and Cities. By Dolores Hayden. Illustrated. 367 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $19.95. By PAUL GOLDBERGER

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A LESS RADICAL TREATMENT FOR BREAST CANCER
description: For almost a century, a diagnosis of breast cancer almost always meant subjecting women to radical mastectomy, a disfiguring operation in which the entire breast, chest wall muscles beneath it and lymph nodes under the arm are removed - with no guarantees of survival. Last week, however, came solid proof that a less drastic procedure can be just as effective, at least with small tumors.

title: Music View;          SINGING IN PRAISE OF SILENCE
description: Old wives to the contrary, silence is not golden. If it were, silence would be heavily traded on international markets, fetching $400 or $500 an antidecibel in London or Zurich. No investment portfolio would be complete without some. Speculators would get rich investing in silence mines. Silence would be hoarded and used as a hedge against inflation. Periodically, the United States Government would drop hints that it was considering going on the silence standard. On crowded Manhattan streets, chains of purest silence would be snatched from the necks of unwary pedestrians. But no. Silence breaks all the market rules. One of the scarcest and most necessary commodities, it is remarkably undervalued. Although there is precious little of it to be found lying about, nobody seems to covet the stuff. For instance, investors apparently did not rush the other day to take up the generous offer of Victor Fuentealba, who proposed to give the American public a sizable block of silence stock, without charge. Mr. Fuentealba, a Baltimore saxophonist and lawyer who is president of the American Federation of Musicians, suggested that all the music in the world be turned off for a day to dramatize the importance of musicians to our daily lives. Live musicians, according to Mr. Fuentealba, are an endangered species that needs protection, perhaps by a tax on blank recording tapes. Anyone who pauses to consider the advance of musical technology in the last 100 years or so will understand Mr. Fuentealba's concern, and his suggestion could indeed have an impact, in a quiet way. He failed to indicate how his plan might be carried out, a minor detail. However, the idea of pulling music off the market for an entire day is the dream of a utopian economist and hardly a practical proposal. I myself know from experience how the real world greets such noble ideas. Some years ago I proposed forming a syndicate to finance the world's first radio station devoted exclusively to broadcasting silence. The station, provisionally known as WPAX, was to be a blow for world peace - a noiseless blow, but a blow. The organization would have been capitalized at several million dollars and I myself was penciled in as board chairman, president and, of course, treasurer. For reasons best known to Wall Street, the project did not get off the ground. The financial community greeted it with silence. Nonetheless, I remain convinced that the world needs WPAX. It was dismissed by shallow minds as an unsound idea, but the financial wise guys probably got a good laugh out of the vacuum tube, too. Consider what WPAX could mean even today to a nation in danger of losing its hearing because of the tyranny of noise and noise's more respectable brother, broadcast music. WPAX proposed to transmit silence for 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year, on a powerful clearchannel beam that would have enabled you to tune in from Hawaii or Alaska or Del Rio, Texas. On this listener-supported station you would hear the purest nothing that modern electronic technology could achieve, no more. With the arrival of Dolby and other noisereduction systems, the silence could now approach an unearthly quality, unpolluted even by stray wisps of static. Nothing but velvety silence, at the twist of a knob, suitable for contemplation or, if you liked, the home production of string quartets or piano music. People could turn on WPAX and sing madrigals, or engage in solo humming. WPAX would be a station in contact with its audience, not merely a corporation pushing a product. A monthly nonprogram guide would describe in detail exactly what music you would not be hearing at any particular moment. A point would be made of not broadcasting, for example, the complete works of Telemann or the ''Ring'' in all available versions. For modest subscription fees, one would receive not only the guide but a copy of John Cage's ''Silence'' and a Tshirt on which nothing was printed. I suppose every sensible person would agree now that our failure to float the WPAX project has been injurious to the nation's musical health, if not to its hearing. Where can the harassed citzen turn for relief, especially in these raucous summer months, from the sound of what the majority of American citizens calls music? The arrival of those holstered little cassette players with their minuscule headphones has been welcome, certainly; let the noise-mesmerized citizenry destroy its musical sensitivity and lose its hearing as unobtrusively as possible. But the peculiar form of intergenerational hostility known as the big-box radio still afflicts us, and the mistuned steel-drum still serenades its metal mate throughout the sleepless city night. Storefront loudspeakers pound out endless rock in hopes of anesthetizing us to the point where we may wander in and buy a heliotrope leisure suit or a pair of cardboard shoes. Souvlaki and pizza parlors, not content with wafting their odors over helpless bypassers, also fling out their aural garbage by means of public-address systems apparently left over from the Munich rallies. Whether you choose to go by foot, by bus, by subway or taxi, you will march to the tune of salsa, reggae, rhythm and blues or the caterwauling of Sinatra. We who have ears and still are powerless not to use them are the daily victims of what the police call victimless crimes. All this sonic cholesterol clogs the ear passages and dulls the soul. The Beethoven Ninth, piped continuously through the brain for years, remains the Beethoven Ninth, granitic and unassailably great. But the brain, weakened by wear like a stone worn away by dripping water, finally refuses to relay the message of Beethoven to the soul. The Beethoven begins to turn to mush and its pounding excitements can no longer be felt in anything like the way Beethoven intended. At last, beaten into submission, the brain and soul are hard put to distinguish between the Beethoven Ninth and Ninth Avenue, between the tingles of Bach and the jingles of Toyota. You know this. We all do. And yet we resist the prophets such as Mr. Fuentealba who would free us from bondage to endless noise in the guise of public music, especially recorded public music. Perhaps we fear the alternatives: if Muzak disappeared from elevators and dentists' waiting rooms, would we have to think of things to say about the weather, as was necessary in primeval times? Do we fear the evangelists of austerity who might want to inaugurate Mozartless Mondays or Wagnerless Wednesdays? Perhaps we hesitate to protest because someone would be sure to charge us with trying to block technological progress: if everyone insisted on hearing music only when he or she chose, would the geniuses of the recording industry have been driven to take us from the 78-rpm record to the LP, and then into the age of stereo? (I stop short of the age of digital, which sounds more like a heart drug than a musical remedy.) I can hear the protests now, however. A world without cassette players? Without Percy Grainger on the strand? Without reggae in the subway? Without the complete Nocturnes, Waltzes, Mazurkas and Scherzos of Chopin on automatically, eternally reversing tape? Without the Beethoven Ninth, the Beethoven Ninth, the Beethoven Ninth, the Beethoven Ninth ...? Yes, it might be worth trying, if only for a day. Mr. Fuentealba's suggestion is a beginning and with the power of 280,000 live musicians to back him up, who knows where it might lead. There might, of course, be better and more practical plans for saving the nation from musical pollution, but that is for impartial investors to decide in their own time. Meanwhile, PAX, brother, PAX.

title: Louis Perkins Fiance Of Drusilla Schmidt
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Cooper of Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Cooper's daughter, Lucy Drusilla Schmidt, to Louis Edward Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mahlon F. Perkins Jr. of Cos Cob, Conn.

title: The World in Summary; CENTRAL AMERICA ISN'T SO SIMPLE
description: The main threat to beleaguered El Salvador, the Reagan Administration contends, is a Cuban-backed Marxist insurgency. Last week, that view was challenged as too simple by some of Washington's friends, including the Salvadoran President.

title: Wendy Cohen Plans Wedding
description: Wendy Cohen and Steven Phillips plan to be married in September in New York. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Annette Cohen of Bellerose, Queens and Martin D. Cohen of Santa Monica, Calif. Mr. Phillips is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Phillips of Fort Lee, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: EVEN THE PENTAGON CAN'T BUY EVERYTHING IN THE CANDY STORE
description: The Reagan Administration is about to learn a lesson that all governments must: In defense planning, as in war, there are no easy options.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: FOR the seventh time in nearly two months, the residents of Cromwell voted last Monday to reject a proposed $4 million school budget and in doing so again foiled the hopes of town officials who need a fully approved budget to begin collecting taxes.

title: Realty News; DESIGNER CONSORTIUM
description: One of the 27 bids submitted for the second phase of housing at Battery Park City calls for the development of the 12 sites by a consortium of prominent architects.

title: SEX EDUCATION: THE BATTLE GOES ON
description: TRENTON ONE of the most far-reaching controversies in New Jersey legislative history - the role of the state in family life - is still being bitterly debated by educators, laymen and legislators.

title: A NEW SPATE OF JANACEK DISKS
description: Leos Janacek's music always seems to hover around the fringes of the repertory, enjoying a surge of interest, disappearing for a while and then resurfacing for another period of re-examination. There has never been a time when the composer had a vogue and then completely vanished, as did Carl Nielsen 20 years ago, nor has he been wholeheartedly embraced and accepted into the pantheon of the greats, as has Mahler. He comes and goes with the same unpredictability that characterizes his music. Now we appear to be in a time when Janacek's stock is high once again, thanks in part to the City Opera's productions of ''The Cunning Little Vixen'' and ''The Makropoulos Affair.''

title: Yarborough Wins 400 Again
description: Cale Yarborough, waiting until he felt the time was right, charged past Harry Gant two turns from the end to win his fourth Firecracker 400 Grand National stock car race today at Daytona International Speedway.

title: Economic Affairs; THE NONDECISION COTTON DUST DECISION
description: O N June 17, the Supreme Court handed down its most important decision in some years on the regulation of health and safety. The central issue was how far the regulatory agencies should go in requiring healthier working conditions in factories.

title: This is the last year annual state event will be held in Trenton suburb
description: TRENTON THE future site of the New Jersey State Fair, held since 1888 at the Trenton Fairgrounds, which was sold last month, depends largely on who is the next Governor.

title: JOHN CARTER'S CASE FOR THE CLARINET
description: The clarinet, Benny Goodman's beloved ''licorice stick,'' practically disappeared from jazz with the advent of Modernism in the 1940's. Its place in the jazz ensemble was usurped by the saxophone, which is also a reed instrument but projects a more powerful sound - at least that's what most jazz histories tell us. But musicians sometimes suggest another reason for the clarinet's sudden demise and the saxophone's ascendency: the saxophone is an easier instrument to master. Modern musicians have stayed away from the clarinet not only because there were few contemporary clarinetists to serve as role models, but because the instrument makes such difficult demands on both the lip and the mind.

title: HE MAKES SURE THE SHOW IS ON
description: ''I 'M the longest act on Broadway,'' Robert A. Boyar said somewhat immodestly the other day, ''in my 33d year as an insurance broker to the bright lights and to the stars.'' Since 1948, in fact, Mr. Boyar, who is 56, has made the slogan ''the show must go on'' a reality - more so than any producer, director, writer or even a star - as he busily arranges insurance (for all risks) for half the shows on Broadway, some productions elsewhere, plus a certain number of actors and actresses as well.

title: HOW TO SUCCEED IN HOLLYWOOD WITHOUT REALLY FILMING
description: Karen Stabiner, author of a 1979 novel about Hollywood, ''Limited Engagements,'' specializes in writing on the film industry. By Karen Stabiner Before the Writers Guild of America began its strike last March against motion-picture and television producers, guild members received a warning about the evils of contributing to script stockpiling. Producers were buying scripts at a furious pace, protecting themselves against a long strike by building up an inventory of producible material. The guild implored its members to avoid temptation: A producer with scripts to produce is less eager to settle.

title: Sniper in Brooklyn
description: A sniper was loose in Brooklyn. For four months, from an apartment building at 2483 West 16th Street in the Bensonhurst section, he fired into the surrounding neighborhood.

title: THE HERO OF INDEPENDENCE
description: THE SAGE OF MONTICELLO Vol. VI, Jefferson and His Time. By Dumas Malone. Illustrated. 551 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $19.95. THE JEFFERSON SCANDALS A Rebuttal. By Virginius Dabney. Illustrated. 155 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $8.95.

title: Photography View; OUTER SPACE 'ART WORKS'; by Gene Thornton
description: Photography's most extraordinary and impressive undertaking of the past 20 years, the close-up exploration of the moon and the other planets, is not ordinarily thought of as an artistic enterprise. It was organized and carried out by scientists and technicians to gather information about places not normally visible to the human eye, and its great and spectacular successes are quite rightly valued today primarily for the new and often surprising information they convey.

title: A 'PIONEER' CONDOMINIUM BUYER IN CITY FIRES PARTING SHOTS
description: It is reminiscence time this summer for Lester D. Kurth. After 15 years as a condominium owner at the St. Tropez, a 300-unit apartment house at 340 East 64th Street, at First Avenue, he is selling his apartment and moving to Sarasota, Fla. He has bought another condominium there.

title: MOUNT WASHINGTON BY COG RAILWAY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- KARL ZIMMERMANN is a writer who lives in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.; his most recent books, ''Amtrak at Milepost 10'' and ''The Western Maryland Railway,'' written with Roger Cook, will be published this summer. By KARL ZIMMERMAN

title: Swede's 5-Year Reign Ends
description: John McEnroe capped a tumultous two weeks at Wimbledon today by ending Bjorn Borg's five-year reign and 41-match winning streak here with a four-set victory in the singles final.

title: ROSS TOMPKINS, PIANIST
description: Ross Tompkins, who was the happily swinging house pianist at the Half Note more than a dozen years ago, when that jazz club was in the West Village and before he went to California with ''The Tonight Show'' band, in which he still plays, gave a somber, somewhat sobersided and only occasionally jazz-oriented solo concert at Carnegie Recital Hall late Friday afternoon as part of the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: NEW LIVES FOR OLD SCHOOLS
description: SCHOOL enrollment in the state continues to decline, more and more school officials find themselves wrestling with the problem of disposing of surplus buildings.

title: The Careful Shopper; A Source of Supplies For Bike Enthusiasts
description: For the serious cyclist, acquiring well-equipped bicycles, accessories, tools, clothing and shoes for touring can pose a problem. Just 10 miles north of White Plains on I-684 (or seven miles up Route 22), the Country Bike Center in Armonk is unusually well supplied.

title: Language and Image
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International

title: Television Week
description: Recognition Factor

title: Art; FABRIC ART AT YALE: A CULTURAL TAPESTRY
description: NEW HAVEN ''TEXTILE'' is a grim, industrial-sounding word that even when combined with ''masterworks'' is unlikely to bring art lovers running. But textile masterworks are, nevertheless, the subject of ''A Sense of Pattern,'' at Yale University Art Gallery, and an extraordinarily beautiful show they make too. (Through Sept. 13.)

title: DELAY IN SUBWAY REPAIRS BLAMED BY TRANSIT CHIEF FOR FATAL CRASH
description: The president of the Transit Authority said yesterday that Friday's fatal subway train crash in Brooklyn had resulted from signal problems caused by long-deferred maintenance of aging and outmoded equipment.

title: NEED SEEN FOR MORE HALFWAY HOMES
description: JOHN, a college junior, is recovering from mental illness after spending six months in a psychiatric hospital. He and eight other young men have been living for the last year at Futura House, a halfway house in White Plains, while completing their education and hunting for jobs.

title: Topics; OUTSPOKEN, UNHEARD; HIDING JUSTICE
description: The highest courts of New York and the United States can say all they want about open trials, but state trial judges know where the power lies - with them. That was recently demonstrated anew when Acting Justice Dennis Edwards Jr. closed his Manhattan courtroom to accept Mark David Chapman's guilty plea to the murder of John Lennon.

title: Other Business; ...AND PERRIER ASIDE, THEY CALL IT SODA
description: That old work horse of the neighborhood barroom, Canada Dry, has declared war on that sprightly thoroughbred of the cafe set, Perrier. In what some are calling the Great Sparkling Water Battle, the competition has become positively effervescent.

title: STATE CALLED LAX ON INSPECTING ROOMING HOMES
description: THE state's Bureau of Rooming and Boarding House Standards, set up by the Legislature last fall to inspect all of New Jersey's 3,500 rooming and boarding houses within a year, has accomplished only a fraction of its task.

title: THE MUDDLE OF MALPRACTICE INSURANCE RATES
description: OVER the next few weeks, thousands of Westchester residents will be receiving ''A Message to Patients About Malpractice Insurance'' from their doctors. The neatly printed, blue-and-green leaflet will be mailed with bills and handed out at office visits. It was prepared by the Westchester County Medical Society to help its 1,800 physician members win public support for a cause they consider a crusade.

title: Averil Payson Meyer Is Wed
description: The marriage of Averil Payson Meyer to Dr. Timothy Gerrish Haydock took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Frank Johnston performed the ceremony.

title: THE GREAT LEAP NOW IS TOWARD PRAGMATISM
description: When Deng Xiaoping is satisfied, he tends in public meetings to stare off into unfocused space, his eyes nearly shut, with inhaled smoke from an ever-present cigarette hissing through his teeth. He did that frequently last week.

title: Stamps; COMMEMORATIVE FOR YEAR OF DISABLED PERSONS; by Samuel A. Tower
description: In a new commemorative the United States has joined the parade of nations from all over the world in observing, through stamps and other means, the International Year of Disabled Persons, as 1981 was proclaimed by the General Assembly of the United Nations.

title: Let Haig Be Haig
description: Reading your superb article ''How Haig Is Recasting His Image'' (by Leslie H. Gelb, May 31), I couldn't help feeling sorry for the stifling of Secretary Haig's talent by Washington insiders.

title: OUT OF THE TREES
description: .6,0,257.6,2,312.8,0City kids don't climb trees. They do almost everything else, but they don't spend any time pulling themselves from branch to branch or clinging to swaying tree trunks perilously high above the ground, trying to survey the distant horizon with the wind in their hair, lofty and free.

title: Lucy Whittemore Betrothed
description: The Rev. James Robinson Whittemore of New York and Suzanne Stoepel Whittemore of Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Bliss Whittemore to State Senator John Philip Burke, son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael H. Burke of Holyoke, Mass.

title: OF FIRECRACKERS AND AMERICAN VALUES
description: With the Fourth of July holiday, I would like to register my shock and outrage at our politicians, police, clergy, mass media and parents who remain silent on the issue of children using firecrackers in the name of celebrating Independence Day.

title: Kathleen Redlich Wed To Jeffrey T. Harkness
description: Kathleen Diane Redlich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin T. Redlich of Huntington, L.I., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Talbot Harkness, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Harkness also of Huntington. The ceremony was performed in St. Peter's Lutheran Church by the Rev. John Jurik and the Rev. Clayton Miller of the Asbury Methodist Church in Yonkers.

title: BILINGUAL PROGRAM SHORT OF TEACHERS
description: TRENTON ASCARCITY of qualified bilingual teachers continues to hamper efforts to educate some 32,000 non-English-speaking students in New Jersey.

title: Presumed Dead
description: When Mount St. Helens erupted last year, it created a special problem for the families of the 27 victims who had been lost forever to the mountain, their bodies buried under tons of mud, rocks and superheated volcanic ash.

title: Reading and Writing; NOT GONE WITH THE WIND
description: Every few years a novel is published that has intimations of immortality for book and author. But no novel has come close to exhibiting the remarkable staying power of ''Gone With the Wind,'' Margaret Mitchell's epic tale of the Civil War, which will be 45 years old on Tuesday.

title: Hotels and Guests
description: To the Editor:

title: A BATTLE FROM THE RIGHT WELCOMED BY MOYNIHAN
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who had expected a re-election challenge from liberal Democrats, has emerged instead as a target of the ultra-right.

title: Critics' Choices; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Of the music festivals in the immediate vicinity of New York City, Caramoor can make a claim to being the most attractive - at least insofar as its setting is concerned. The festival is located on the spacious, 117-acre grounds of an opulent old estate in Katonah, New York, 40 miles north of Manhattan and reachable by car, bus or train.

title: No Headline
description: While Professor Galbraith appears to have a certain fondness for ''double-edged swords,'' there's one that seems reserved for skewering conservatives either way they jump. I refer to the fact that most vocal liberals have in past years spent a great deal of time and effort in their attempts to enlighten us as to just how it is that the rich, thanks to their expensive tax lawyers and accountants, pay very little, if any, taxes.

title: CHALLENGING CANADA'S RUGGED ARCTIC HIGHWAY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ANDREW H. MALCOLM is chief of the Toronto bureau of The Times. By ANDREW H.MALCOLM

title: HALF OF U.S. ATOMIC PLANTS MISS DEADLINE ON ALERTS
description: About half the country's atomic power plants, including all six facilities in New York and New Jersey and one in Connecticut, have missed a July 1 deadline for installation of emergency warning systems to alert the surrounding population in the event of a serious accident, according to Federal officials. Some of the work is reported under way.

title: OPERA: OUTDOOR 'L'ELISIR'
description: Despite frequent interruptions from showers early in the evening, the New York Grand Opera valiantly completed its open-air performance of Donizetti's ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' at the Central Park Mall on Thursday night. After taking cover for the third time midway through Act I, the orchestra and the sound amplification crew finally packed their gear and went home, leaving the cast to forge ahead, accompanied at the piano by Celeste Alexander.

title: Deborah Dwelley Engaged To Wallace J. Gamber Jr.
description: Deborah Hill Dwelley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Allen Dwelley of Salisbury, Conn., will be married on Aug. 8 to Wallace Joseph Gamber Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gamber of Largo, Fla.

title: ROGERS, ON 66, TAKES WESTERN LEAD BY 2
description: ''Did I do that?'' Bill Rogers asked incredulously. He spoke of shooting a six-under-par 66 today and taking the lead by two strokes after the third round of the 78th Western Open.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE GEOPOLITICS OF INFORMATION, by Anthony Smith. (Oxford University Press, $4.95.) The director of the British Film Institute, who regards information as a vast form of wealth, something like mineral resources, argues that through its control of the giant news agencies (The Associated Press, United Press International, Reuters and Agence France Presse) and the burgeoning business of electronic data storage and communication, the West is able to see that its culture dominates the Third World. Our reviewer Robert Manning called this ''a most timely, excellent work of reportage and scholarship.''

title: GULF, SMALLEST OF THE SEVEN OIL SISTERS
description: FEW Companies have a historq as grand and glorious as that of the Gulf Oil Corporation. Born in the Spindletop gusher of 1901 and financed by the Mellon fortune, Gulf went on to successfully challenge the Rockefeller oil empire. In dizzying succession, it opened the world's first gasoline filling station, acquired oceans of oil beneath the deserts of the Middle East and the swamps of Venezuela, and firmly established itself as one of the leading producers, refiners and purveyors of black gold.

title: MCENROE TOPS BORG IN 4-SET WIMBELDON FINAL
description: John McEnroe capped a tumultuous two weeks at Wimbledon today by ending Bjorn Borg's five-year reign and 41-match winning streak here with a four-set victory in the singles final.

title: MOST OF MAOISM'S GONE, BUT MAO'S SHADOW ISN'T
description: 84,2,570.4,0WASHINGTON - When the American journalist Edgar Snow made his way to the remote mountains of northwestern China to interview Mao Zedong in 1936 - at a time when the Communist guerrilla leader was best known for the $250,000 bounty that Chiang Kai-shek had offered for his head - Mr. Snow discovered that the 44-year-old Mao was already venerated by many peasants in the rural hinterlands as a ''savior.''

title: 1-Year Suspension Looms for McEnroe
description: John McEnroe faces as much as a oneyear suspension, and the loss of $14,750, if a recommended $10,000 fine levied against him today by the Wimbledon tournament committee is upheld by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council.

title: A. E. van der Perk Weds Alma Phipps
description: The marriage of Alma Mary Phipps, associate art director of Weight Watchers magazine, to Anton Evert van der Perk, a professor at the Cooper Union College of Art, took place in East Hampton, L.I., yesterday. The Rev. Frederick Schultz, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Anne Gerli, cousin of the bride, and her husband, David Gerli.

title: ECONOMIC PARLEY DELINEATES ISSUES Francis White
description: GROTON ALTHOUGH Governor O'Neill's political relations with Connecticut union leaders reached a new low at last Tuesday's ''business-labor summit meeting'' here, the larger purpose of the conference - to identify important state economic issues - may have been achieved.

title: Business Conditions; INFLATION: 1976 REVISITED?
description: Although the recent deceleration in inflation has been welcome news, in some respects the current drop is remarkably similar to what occurred in the post-recession year of 1976.

title: THE COURAGEOUS DEED OF JACOBO TIMERMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Sailboarding on Today
description: The Enduro sailboarding rally scheduled yesterday at Flushing Meadows Lake in Queens was postponed because of rain. It will be held today from noon to 2 P.M., with races and exhibitions. Admission is free.

title: Mary L. Pope Is Bride Of Kerry Robert Kessel
description: Maria Louise Pope, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Generoso Pope Jr. of Manalapan Fla., was married in Boynton Beach, Fla., yesterday to Kerry Robert Kessel, son of Mrs. James Ruhf of Northport, L.I., and Robert Kessel of Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. A.J. Victor performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church.

title: JUDGE CITES POLITICAL ASPECTS OF SHERIFF CASE
description: DISCIPLINARY hearings against Thomas J. Delaney, Westchester County's ousted Commissioner/Sheriff of Public Safety Services, began fitfully last week with a scattering of accusations, some uncertain answers by an otherwise confident defendant and the promise of a long summer of interrogation.

title: OLDTIME LAWMEN STOP CRIME IN A NEW TEXAS
description: He sits tall in the saddle under the blazing Texas sun, a silver badge on his chest, a pack of Marlboros in his pocket, a holster around his waist and a pair of black Tony Lama boots on his feet.

title: Holly Eisenberger Is the Bride of Carlos V. Freyre
description: Holly Eisenberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Eisenberger of Ocean, N.J., was married in Asbury Park, N.J., yesterday to Carlos V. Freyre, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Freyre of Caracas, Venezuela. The Rev. Joseph K. Mitko performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church.

title: A HOLIDAY FOR BEACHCOMBERS ON EGYPT'S RED SEA COAST
description: The town of Hurghada, on Egypt's Red Sea coast, is one of those increasingly rare backwaters that still promise something akin to a real beachcomber's holiday. There is little but sun, sand and water. The unsullied beach stretches for miles, the sun shines almost every day and the swimming is little short of spectacular. Exquisite coral reefs offer some of the best scuba-diving and snorkeling in the world. Colorful fish abound in the clear salt water and lobsters as heavy as 11 pounds have been taken off the barren offshore islands. The biggest evening entertainment is still the sunset.

title: The Weather and Chemical Weapons
description: Because the Senate has now acted to appropriate production start-up funds for binary chemical weapons, it is logical to look at another side of the question - just how effective do they believe these munitions to be (''Restocking the Chemical Arsenal,'' by Wayne Biddle, May 24)? After World War II, I had the opportunity to ask Dr. Vannevar Bush, one of President Roosevelt's science advisers, why the President had been urged to issue his ''retaliation in kind'' chemical-warfare threat to the enemy. He said that, at the time, it was the worst thing they could think of.

title: Fiddle Dancer Boy Wins Queen's Plate
description: Fiddle Dancer Boy passed Wayover and Frost King in the stretch at Woodbine today to win by a head in the 122d running of the Queen's Plate Stakes, the oldest annual stakes race in North America.

title: BLACKS RETURNING TO SOUTHERN CITIES
description: The Mississippi Legislature now has 17 black members, and all but three are men who left the state in their youth in search of a better life but returned after the civil rights movement and improved economic conditions opened opportunities for them here.

title: 13 Food Outlets Cited By City for Violations
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday cited 13 food establishments for violation of the health code. The department said also that three places had been reopened after correcting earlier violations and that one had been closed after a final inspection.

title: POP: LINDLEY'S MELANGE
description: For years, the lank-haired, multi-instrumental David Lindley has been a fixture in the hipper Los Angeles folk-rock bands, most notably those of Jackson Browne. But now Mr. Lindley has emerged as a bandleader, with a sweet debut album called ''El Rayo-X,'' and Tuesday night he was at the Bottom Line for two sets.

title: Solaita Hits No. 23
description: Tony Solaita hit a two-run homer as his Nippon Ham Fighters and the Lotte Orions played to a 5-5 tie in Japanese baseball today. Solaita, formerly with the Toronto Blue Jays, has 23 homers this season. The Kintetsu Buffaloes pounded out 12 hits, including a bases-empty homer by Vic Harris, formerly with the Milwaukee Brewers, to beat the Seibu Lions, 7-2.

title: NEW AUDI SPORTS A SIMPLE NAME
description: YOU can just see those marketing folk sitting around a polished table in Ingolstadt, West Germany, trying to figure out what to call their new Audi sport coupe.

title: TRAVELING IN PERIL
description: THE COMFORT OF STRANGERS By Ian McEwan. 127 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $9.95. By RICHARD P.BRICKNER

title: Crafts
description: TIERED exhibition celebrating the 30th aniversary of the New Jersey Designer Craftsmen is on view through next weekend at the Bergen Community Museum in Paramus. And at the Long Beach Island Foundation of the Arts in Loveladies, ''Crafts Invitational '81'' features work by 35 N.J.D.C. members. This show will continue through Wednesday.

title: IN THE END, A DEVASTATED ECONOMY IS POLAND'S GREATEST THREAT
description: Last week, the lines of visa applicants in front of Western embassies here were almost as long as the meat lines. In Geneva, a spokesman for an international resettlement group said the number of Poles seeking asylum in Austria had doubled, to about 200 a day. Polish newspapers carried notices on how to apply for CARE packages, those parcels of milk powder, flour, sugar, lard and cooking oil that evoke memories of World War II.

title: TAFT WAS THE POLITEST MAN IN TOWN
description: ''ONE evening Calvin Coolidge took a short walk around the White House with Senator Selden P. Spencer of Missouri. As they were returning, Spencer pointed to the Executive Mansion and said facetiously: 'I wonder who lives there.' 'Nobody,' said 'Silent Cal' glumly. 'They just come and go.' ''

title: FREEZE-DRYING SAVES RECORDS
description: TRENTON AFLEMINGTON dairy, the New Jersey National Guard, the state's Department of Defense and the Army joined forces almost eight months ago to salvage hundreds of irreplaceable New Jersey judicial records that had been damaged by fire and water.

title: No Headline
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JOYS, AND SORROWS, OF LEAVING FOR A FRIENDLY TOWN
description: It started when a young man with a megaphone announced that the buses leaving the Port Authority terminal for the Fresh Air Fund's Friendly Towns were ready for boarding.

title: U.S. MOTTOFICATION
description: To the Editor:

title: A PLANE FOR GARAGE
description: COMMACK LIKE a butterfly in its chrysalis, a sleek airplane has slowly been taking shape here in Jay Hilborn's garage. Mr. Hilborn, a baritone who sings in the chorus of the Metropolitan Opera and elsewhere, is one of an estimated total of 5,000 people around the country - the number grows by about 400 a month, according to organizations affiliated with airplane kits - who are building a new breed of aircraft called ultralights in their basements, garages or even living rooms.

title: Food; SECRETS TRADED: CHEESECAKE FOR CHOWDER
description: CLAM chowder is a dish that incites passions and prejudices. With or without milk or cream? Tomatoes? And when a good recipe turns up, it is jealously guarded and coveted, as was the case with Nora Bennett's chowder.

title: FEMINISM'S NEXT STEP
description: The women's movement is over,'' said my friend, a usually confident executive, who is also a wife and feminist. ''At least,'' she continued in a grim tone, ''it is in my shop. The men are making jokes about bimbos again, and the other woman in the executive group and I just look at each other. It doesn't matter if we get mad; they act as if we aren't there. When a new job opens up, all they look for now is men. It's as if the word has gone out that we've lost our case; there won't be any equal rights amendment after all, so they don't need to worry anymore about lawsuits over sex discrimination, even though laws against it are still on the books. They figure they can do what they want about women now - or do nothing at all - like the old days.''

title: Miss Aubertin Fiancee Of Roswell Curtis 3d
description: Mrs. Gerard Charles Aubertin of Greenwich, Conn., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Chantal Aubertin, to Roswell Mansing Curtis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell M. Curtis Jr., also of Greenwich.

title: IT'S ONLY JULY, BUT-
description: PRISON is about the last place where one would expect to find thoughts of Christmas in July. But Richard Rowe, who is serving the eighth year of a life term at Rahway State Prison in Woodbridge, already has collected more than 10,000 toys in the third annual Ayuda-sponsored drive for inmates' children and other needy youngsters.

title: VONNEGUT'S SPEECH: A DISSENTING VIEW
description: Re: Kurt Vonnegut's speech at Southampton College (''When It's Honorable to Be a Wise Guy,'' Opinion Page): If Kurt Vonnegut spent less time guessing and more time observing, he would wash his mouth with soap, as well as his hands. If he observes carefully, he will see that excessive government is killing the economy as surely as germs killed mothers in Vienna.

title: The Nation in Summary; SQUEAKING WHEELS
description: True to the city's reputation, Chicago's trains and buses are working -but the ride, already the most expensive in the nation, will soon be even more so. Fares on the city transit system will rise tomorrow to 90 cents, and on commuter rail lines by as much as 57 percent, as Mayor Jane M. Byrne and Governor James R. Thompson failed last week to agree on a plan to bail the faltering Regional Transportation Authority out of its debt of as much as $140 million.

title: MORE THAN AGEE'S PASSPORT AT STAKE
description: By a vote of 7 to 2, the Supreme Court last week gave a hard scratch to a persistent Washington itch and at the same time upheld a Government claim of inherent power.

title: Dr.Stark Has Bridal
description: Dr. Barbara Joanne Stark, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Stark of Centre Island, L.I., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to David Bond Baxter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Turner Baxter of Dallas. The Rev. William Smith of the Highland Park Methodist Church in Dallas, performed the ceremony at the Garden City (L.I.) Community Church.

title: 'NEW DEAL' ARTISTS STAR IN A TV DOCUMENTARY
description: ''Ithink one of the horrors of our society - American society - is this break with the past, this lack of continuity. Young people know nothing of the past. For that matter, even people who lived through the past have forgotten. And I think the New Deal and its arts projects are a case in point. It's as though they never existed. Not even in the history books. Not even in the memories of people.''

title: AN ATHLETE TESTS THE SCHOLARSHIP SYSTEM
description: ONE month ago Jon Turner, a 19-year-old college student from Bloomfield, Conn., who was just completing his freshman year, was notified that he had lost his basketball scholarship to George Washington University in Washington, D.C. The notification came in a letter, dated May 29, from Vicki J. Baker, director of student financial aid. It read:

title: by Tony Schwartz
description: Just how cable television works - who owns what, and where it all comes from - is not nearly so mysterious as it often seems. Partly the confusion stems from the fact that most Americans still don't have cable -and out of sight seems to mean out of mind. Worse, the cable industry has created a dizzying video vocabulary all its own: acronyms like MSO and RFP, words like tier and transponder, uplink and downstream, bundling and churn.

title: Art; ART AS ANYTHING BUT ITSELF
description: MORRISTOWN THE grounds of the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences are again the site of an environmental installation, this time the work of Hank de Ricco. The fourth project in a series financed by the National Endowment for the Arts and the Interpace Corporation of Parsippany, it is called ''Rites of Spring'' and will remain on view through July 18.

title: POLISH HARD LINERS DENOUNCE THE PARTY'S LEADERS
description: Ten days before the Polish Communist Party congress, East Germany today published an attack by a hard-line Polish group, the Katowice Forum, against the party leadership and against the manner in which party delegates for the congress were chosen.

title: BLYTHE AND D'RIVERA JAM ON BE-BOP TUNES
description: ''CBS Presents,'' the jazz-festival program of Columbia records, which took place at Town Hall Friday night, was less a corporate advertisement than an informative, wide-ranging survey of contemporary jazz trends. The advertising will come later, when Columbia issues an album recorded at the concert; on Friday the company concentrated on squeezing as much music as possible into the allotted three-hour time slot.

title: THE HEAVY LOSERS ARE BIG WINNERS IN ISRAELI VOTE
description: Israel's many-splintered small parties were heavy losers in last week's elections. But the result - a virtual dead heat between Likud and Labor - paradoxically made some of the little parties more crucial than ever.

title: About Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS THEY acted the way most people do at a reunion, exclaiming over how long it had been since they had last seen each other and reverting to nicknames.

title: Adrienne Thier Fiancee
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ronald S. Thier of Verona, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Adrienne Jan Thier, to Alan Joel Henick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Henick of New Hyde Park, L.I. An Aug. 22 wedding is planned in South Orange.

title: Rain Lashes Dallas Area; River Nears Flood Stage
description: Rain drenched the Dallas-Fort Worth area today, flooding a hospital basement and forcing the police to close highways.

title: Connecticut Guide; RITTER IN 'ANGELS'
description: ''Battle of Angels,'' a 1940 Off Broadway play by Tennessee Williams, is probably more familiar as ''Orpheus Descending,'' the revised Broadway version of 1957 with Cliff Robertson and Maureen Stapleton, or as the Marlon Brando film ''Fugitive Kind.''

title: Belfast Hunger Strikers Urge Compromise Talks
description: Irish guerrillas on a hunger strike in Maze Prison here said today that they were willing to ''hold immediate talks'' on a compromise with the British Government in an effort to avoid further deaths from starvation, their supporters reported.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE BERKSHIRES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- STEPHANIE L. JOHNSON, the author of ''The Best of the Berkshires,'' lives in Williamstown, Mass. By STEPHANIE L.JOHNSON

title: TRIPLE-DECKER FUN AT THE FOUNDATION
description: PEMBERTON IF ANYONE is wondering about the state of the arts south of Fort Dix, a visit to the Foundation Theater on the campus of Burlington County College promises a crackerjack summer evening. Its production of ''The Crucifer of Blood'' is a rich entertainment bursting with the malarkey of a neo-Victorian triple-decker.

title: A JAZZ FESTIVAL IN DAVENPORT
description: Davenport, Iowa, will pay tribute to a local boy who became one of America's greatest jazz musicians at the city's 10th annual Bix Beiderbecke Memorial Jazz Festival, being held this year from July 23 to 26. Eight bands will rotate in performances along the city's riverfront during the festival, a riverboat with live music will take excursionists along the Mississippi and jam sessions will last into the morning hours.

title: WHEN REPUBLICANS ENDORSE DEMOCRATS
description: As a Nassau County Republican Committeeman for many years, I agree that the endorsement of Mayor Koch is intolerable to those who believe in the Republican philosophy.

title: THE E.R.A. COUNTDOWN
description: It was cheering to read of the nationwide demonstrations last week to save the Equal Rights Amendment. Three more states must ratify it before June 30, 1982, or the amendment will die. Nearly a decade's effort now turns on a few dozen legislators in a handful of states - including North Carolina, Illinois, Florida and Missouri.

title: Whirlwinds Add to Peril In California Brush Fire
description: Firefighters battled blazing whirlwinds as they struggled today with a 2,800-acre brush fire that threatened scores of homes 20 miles northeast of San Diego.

title: DEFENSE ATTORNEY FOR SIRHAN
description: Emile Zola Berman, the trial lawyer whose notable cases included the defense of Sirhan Sirhan, the killer of Robert F. Kennedy, died Friday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old.

title: ON THE ROAD FOR THE NEW DEAL
description: ONE THIRD OF A NATION Lorena Hickok Reports on the Great Depression. Edited by Richard Lowitt and Maurine Beasley. Illustrated. 378 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $18.95.

title: GROMYKO CONFERS WITH POLES AGAIN ON PARTY CONGRESS
description: Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, held a second round of talks today with top Polish leaders, amid increasing speculation that his visit will lead to a grudging acceptance by Moscow of a special Polish Communist Party congress 10 days away.

title: SAKE IN A GALLO BOTTLE
description: THE ART OF JAPANESE MANAGEMENT Applications for American Executives. By Richard Tanner Pascale and Anthony G. Athos. 221 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $11.95. THEORY Z How American Business Can Meet the Japanese Challenge. By William G. Ouchi. 283 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Co. $12.95.

title: REPLOTTING THE FAMILIAR TRIANGLE
description: THE cowboys have taken off their black and white hats. The Democrats are talking like Republicans, and the crooks are writing best sellers. How can we tell the good guys from the bad guys anymore?

title: The Nation in Summary; NETWORK'S DON'T DECIDE ACCESS, SAYS HIGH COURT
description: By deciding who's news and who isn't, television networks wield vast power over political candidates. Last week, the Supreme Court gave candidates some power over the networks.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; DRUGS, FRUIT AND TECHNOLOGY ARE CUSTOMS' VARIED QUARRY
description: Bill Archey is only half in jest when he says that the best preparation for his job as Acting Commissioner of Customs would have been to ''enroll in the Fred Astaire school of dance.'' But navigating between the often competing pressures of commerce and law enforcement requires some pretty nimble footwork.

title: 10 PRINCIPALS FINED FOR FAILING TO INSURE PUPIL IMMUNIZATION
description: New York City's Health Department has fined 10 principals of private and public schools for failing to insure that the pupils in their schools were properly immunized. The fines ranged from $35 to $350.

title: Gabrielle R. Crenshaw Betrothed to Andre Dupre
description: Mr. and Mrs. Giver Robert Crenshaw of Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gabrielle Robin Crenshaw, to Andre Rodrigo Dupre, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustavo Dupre of Vina del Mar, Chile.

title: Louganis Heads Squad
description: Greg Louganis, considered the top male diver in the world, headlines the field of 33 divers selected for the United States Olympic Committee's National Sports Festival III. Louganis is the only American diver to win the Olympic Trials in the platform and springboard events, which he did in 1976 and 1980. He went on to win the 1976 Olympic silver medal in he platform event.

title: Miss Groves Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Benjamin A. Groves and Mrs. John D.E. Orr, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter, Amanda Frances Tottenham Groves, to Patrick MacIntyre Outerbridge, son of Ira Stuart Outerbridge Jr. of Pembroke, Bermuda, and the late Patricia Graham Outerbridge.

title: Realty News; 'TOP OF THE FIFTIES' IN RENOVATION
description: When Charles H. Shaw and Frederick DeMatteis bought the Winslow Hotel at 551 Madison Avenue at 55th Street in 1978, they were convinced it was a rare location that could support commercial or residential uses and they did not have precise plans.

title: 4 SEEK TO SALVAGE SILVER IN ARTHUR KILL
description: A court case has focused on an unusual search for tons of silver that sank almost 78 years ago in the Arthur Kill, between Staten Island and the Sewaren section of Woodbridge, N.J.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; PAIR OF PILOTS IS SAFE ENOUGH
description: ''Ladies and gentlemen, as we prepare for takeoff in the new generation of jet airliners, we'd like to inform you that there are only two members of the cockpit crew, rather than three.'' This could be the result of a recommendation last week by a Presidential panel that two-pilot operation of the McDonnell Douglas DC-9 Super 80, already in wide use, is safe, and that the Boeing 767, the Boeing 757 and the European Airbus A-310, all to be certified over the next two years, ''can be operated safely by a crew of two.''

title: BANI-SADR, IN INTERVIEW, ASSERTS KURDS HELP HIM
description: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the deposed and fugitive President of Iran, has been sheltered by rebel Kurdish tribesmen, according to an interview with him published today in Eight Days, a London-based magazine specializing in the Middle East.

title: Prospects
description: Credit Relief is Coming

title: Growth in U.S. Territories
description: Population growth from 1970 to 1980 in three of the United States' island possessions and territories far exceeded growth in the mainland, according to the Census Bureau. Preliminary figures showed the population of the Virgin Islands up 53 percent, to 95,591; that of Guam up 24.5 percent, to 105,821, and American Samoa, 19.3 percent, to 32,395. In the states, population grew by 11.4 percent.

title: THE WEST SEEKS A WAY TO TAME WILD GROWTH
description: Vine Deloria Jr., a member of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe who is now a political science professor at the University of Arizona, was talking about the growing threat of rapid development to the American West.

description: Wariness marks Bonn's reaction to Brandt talks in Moscow 2 Around the World 2 60 policemen are injured in racial rioting in London 3 For a Laotian, disillusionment and escape 3 Bani-Sadr interviewed in Kurdis- tan by magazine 4 Air France agrees to compensate Israelis held at Entebbe 5 Polish hard-liners assail party leaders 6 Timerman says he can't believe doubts on credibility 8 Government/Politics Fake transit tokens in New York City have increased fivefold 13 Order and calm mark final days of Albany legislative session 14 A battle from the right welcomed by Moynihan 21 Most ex-CETA workers placed in new permanent jobs 22 Energy Half of atomic power plants miss warning-system deadline 16 Con Ed fighting plan of landlord's plan to generate own electricity 24 Education/Welfare 10 principals fined for failing to insure pupil immunization 18 Joys and sorrows of leaving for a Fresh Air Fund Friendly Town 20 Students find summer jobs with ingenuity for the unususal 22 General Around the Nation 10 With suspect jailed, Atlanta counts days without new death 10 Rain dampens Washington's cele- bration of Fourth of July 10 New type of Western lawmen pa- trols an apartment complex 10 Westerners debate ways to cope with rapid growth 10 Soaring land values imperil Dal- las arts district plan 11 Rain curtails Fourth of July crowds, but not their spirits 15 4 Jerseyans seek right to salvage silver from Arthur Kill 18 Arts/Entertainment Documentary film about punk rockers is reviewed 24 ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' is performed outdoors 24 3 debuts lift ''Agon'' ballet 24 Laura Dean dance, ''Tympani,'' given East Coast premiere 25 Moliere's ''Don Juan'' is staged in Minneapolis 25 Judith Ragir gives solo dance concert 25 Evans, Blyth and D'Rivera jam at jazz festival 25 Aston Magna Foundation concert of early music 28 Style Pants and flats new Italian chic 26 Obituaries Emile Zola Berman, trial lawyer 14 Violet Heming, comic actress 14

title: The Last Picnic
description: It was to have been the Last Annual Picnic. For eight years, on the Fourth of July, the singer Willie Nelson had staged a cowboy's version of Woodstock - a roundup of countryand-Western performers and their fans.

title: Stage View; THE PLAYWRIGHT SIMPLY HAS TO MAKE A SCENE; by Walter Kerr
description: Now that ''Scenes and Revelations'' has brought the matter up, perhaps we ought to pose a question we often forget to ask. What is a dramatic scene, anyway? Elan Garonzik's new play at Circle in the Square is not precisely overloaded with bona fide dramatic scenes. It contains, by my count, exactly one.
