It is filled with substitutes, though: with flashbacks to Pennsylvania farmland in the early 1890's, with unexpected entrances, with small sad ironies, with letters read aloud in counterpoint, with unbounded though profitless yearning. Helena, the most matronly of four sisters who have had very bad luck in love, longs for a time when the house seemed afloat in lilacs. Rebecca, the youngest, sits on a stoop out in dusty Nebraska - she's the only one who's married and she vigorously hates her husband - dreaming not of a new lover but of the clean sidewalks she's left behind her. And all four, when they are together, look forward wistfully to accepting an uncle's long-standing invitation to visit Manchester, England. I promise not to mention Chekhov at any point in this piece.

title: The World in Summary; FITZGERALD NEEDS PROVERBIAL GOOD LUCK
description: His mother was a Protestant from Belfast and his Roman Catholic father became a Cabinet minister in Dublin. Last week, Garret FitzGerald's minority Fine Gael (Land of Ireland) Party put together a coalition with the small Labor Party and took control of the Irish Government by a three-vote margin, with Mr. FitzGerald as Prime Minister.

title: AIR FRANCE TO COMPENSATE ENTEBBE HOSTAGES
description: Five years after the dramatic rescue of the hostages aboard a hijacked Air France airliner at Entebbe, Uganda, the airline has agreed to compensate the Israelis who were held captive there. It is the first case of its kind in Israel.

title: FOUNDED HANDICRAFTS SCHOOL
description: Lucy Calista Morgan, founder of the Penland School of Handicrafts in Mitchell County, died at her home here yesterday.

title: The Region in Summary; RAVITCH AND FRIENDS BREAK TRANSIT LOGJAM
description: After relying on words for months, Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, acted last week and, in so doing, he couldn't have spoken louder.

title: Bonnie Jan Allsop Wed to Owen Ranft
description: Muriel Jane Allsopp, daughter of Mrs. Peter Bonfield Allsopp of Mill Neck, L.I., and Palo Alto, Calif., and the late Mr. Allsopp, was married yesterday to Owen Henry Ranft, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ranft of White Plains. The Rev. Bruce Rogers performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: FARE TOKENS GET MORE USE AS FARES RISE
description: The number of metal disks, foreign coins and other illicit substitutes for tokens turning up in Metropolitan Transit Authority collection buckets has increased more than fivefold in the last year, from roughly 5,000 to 28,000 a week, according to the authority.

title: CRITICS' ChOICES; JAZZ
description: JAZZ Two unusually versatile pianists, Dick Hyman and Roger Kellaway, will add one more notch to their versatility when they become a piano duo for two weeks at Michael's Pub, starting Tuesday.

title: A POLITICAL LESSON LEARNED
description: NEW JERSEY'S pilot political experiment is now history, and much has been said and written about the ramifications of public financing of primary elections. Indeed, the two victorious gubernatorial candidates already have said that they intend to improve the program.

title: The Nation in Summary; REAGAN PITCHES TO THE N.A.A.C.P.
description: If Ronald Reagan had given a speech to the N.A.A.C.P. national convention last year - he said at the time his campaign aides had lost the invitation - would it have sounded like last week's?

title: Susan Goldstein Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abraham E. Goldstein of Woodmere, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lynn Goldstein, to Jonathan Martin Golden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Golden of Rochester. A Nov. 28 wedding is planned. Miss Goldstein is a senior product marketing specialist with the B.F. Goodrich Company in Akron, Ohio, where her fiance is a marine engineer.

title: Camera; GETTING STARTED IN UNDERWATER PHOTOGRAPHY; by Herb Taylor
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Herb Taylor is a producer of photographic books when he is not taking underwater photos.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; FLOORS, CEILINGS ON COLLEGE LOANS
description: In addition to all their other tests, college students seeking federally guaranteed educational loans apparently will soon have to pass a ''needs test.'' Legislative experts sorting through the budget bills passed last month by the House and Senate said last week that both chambers approved imposing a need requirement, though they differed on its provisions.

title: The World in Summary; HANDS ACROSS THE HIMALAYAS?
description: Jawaharlal Nehru's dream of friendship between the world's two most populous countries has lain in ruins along the 2,500-mile China-India border since 1962, when Mao Zedong's army rolled over India's claims to territories it inherited from Britain. But last week in New Delhi, Mr. Nehru's daughter, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, and Chinese Foreign Minister Huang Hua began the long process of rebuilding Sino-Indian relations.

title: BROKER'S KASH A WINNER IN DIVISION OF SIRE PACE
description: Broker's Kash and Brand New Fella captured the split divisions of the $201,245 New York Sire Stakes Pace for 3-year-old colts and geldings at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: QUINTET PLAYS THE BLUES
description: ''This is my idea,'' said Bill Cosby, the comedian, as he introduced a Kool Jazz Festival program called ''Present Company Included'' at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening.

title: Other Business; MUM'S THE WORD FOR THE NEW GENERICS...
description: Say you're the kind of person who can't afford the great wines of Europe, becomes toungue-tied at the thought of how to pronounce their names and would be hardpressed to detail the differences between a beaujolais and a burgundy. You might be sorely tempted to avoid wine, period.

title: Understanding Galbraith
description: John Kenneth Galbraith makes some telling points in his article, ''The Uses and Excuses of Affluence'' (May 31). However, for several years he has professed to be unable to understand the disincentive effects of high marginal income-tax rates while simultaneously mounting an ironic defense of the hard-working business executive.

title: A CORBUSIER PORTFOLIO
description: A young Swiss architect, Charles Edouard Jeanneret, set out in 1911 on an extended trip through Eastern Europe and the Mediterranean. On this trip, Jeanneret - who adopted an old family name, Le Corbusier, nine years later - carried along a number of pocket-sized sketchbooks, so that he could record buildings and scenes that interested him. Eventually, in 1917, Jeanneret settled permanently in Paris, where he quickly became involved in the avant-garde scene of post-Cubist painting and in the emerging "new" architecture in Paris. But even in those busiest of days, he continued to carry his sketchbooks with him, recording buildings and scenes around him, and jotting down sketches of exploratory architectural ideas.

title: REVOLUTIONARY SUICIDE
description: JOURNEY TO NOWHERE A New World Tragedy. By Shiva Naipaul. 336 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $13.95.

title: FISHING FOR MAKO SHARK IS A CHALLENGE
description: foot Phoenix, the Lady Pat, toward Fire Island Inlet and the Atlantic Ocean, I was reminded that much has changed since I set forth as a boy with my father on such trips.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; ON THE EVIDENCE, AMERICANS WOULD RATHER SUE THAN SETTLE
description: The Supreme Court term that ended last week again demonstrated that Americans in our time are pursing the elusive goal of ''justice for all'' more energetically than any society in history. Whether Americans have thus achieved a more just society is open to dispute, but there appears to be a broad consensus that they have achieved a more litigious one.

title: HE'S CONTENT MAKING 'COMEDIES OF CHARACTER'
description: Annette Insdorf, an associate professor at Yale, is the author of ''Francois Truffaut.'' By ANNETTE INSDORF PARIS When ''Heart to Heart'' opens Wednesday at the Lincoln Plaza, New Yorkers will be able to see a film with no special effects, no heroes, no villains, no chases, no lavish musical numbers and no big stars. This French film by Pascal Thomas has something quite unusual to offer in a summer dominated by sleek superproductions: It is a tender story of love, loss and family ties spanning 15 years.

title: About Long Island
description: THERE are three of us out in the driveway, scowling at the corpse of a lawn mower. All attempts at resuscitation have failed. Vital signs are absent. Nothing remains but post-mortem.

title: Nuptials Planned By Miss Buckley
description: Mr. and Mrs. C.T. Noel Buckley of New York and Williamstown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Mary Buckley, to Long Ellis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis of Pasadena, Calif. and Osterville, Mass.

title: BONN LEADERS REACT WARILY TO BRANDT TALKS IN MOSCOW
description: Statements by Willy Brandt and other Social Democratic Party leaders that the Soviet Union is taking a ''materially different'' position on possible negotiations with the United States on middle-range nuclear missiles are meeting with wary and partially negative reactions from the West German Government.

title: COLLEGE STUDENTS FIND SUMMER JOBS WITH INGENUITY AND ZEST FOR UNUSUAL
description: This summer, Judy Hugo will be seen by thousands of visitors to the Coney Island Aquarium. They will remember her in a distinctive pose -her body leaning far over a pool of green, a silver whistle in her mouth, her blond hair gleaming in the sun.

title: Ideas & Trends; TALKING TELEVISION'S PULSE--A DEBATE OVER PRESSURE POINTS
description: An old American tradition or censorship? The line between democratic self-expression and antidemocratic repression is often finely drawn, as demonstrated recently by the Coalition for Better Broadcasting in its threat to boycott companies sponsoring television programs it considers ''offensive.'' Last week, the boycott was canceled, but the questions it raised remain alive.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 9 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 2 13 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 3 4 4 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 4 5 11 FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon. 5 3 11 GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam's, $12.95.) Leto continues as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet Dune. 6 6 25 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) An illustrated fable about the Sun, the Moon and a hidden treasure. 7 12 37 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history.

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE death of 2,000 fish in Old Town Pond - the second fish kill in Southampton Village in less than a month - is just nature's way of saying enough is enough, according to a Southampton College biologist.

title: A BIT OF OLD ENGLAND BLOOMS ON L.I.
description: Sybil Ittmann is an artist with a passion for plants. She paints them, she grows them, and whenever she changes residences, she packs up her favorites and plants them on the grounds of her new home. A native of England, where gardening, she insists, ''is in the blood,'' Mrs. Ittmann also transplanted her firm notions of what a garden should be when she came to the United States in 1958. ''I love the flowing, informal beds of perennials that are typical of the English garden,'' she says. ''Most Americans shy away from such adventurous flower gardens. They settle for foundation plantings, those brutally pruned shrubs that hug the house.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; COURT CLEARS ITS DOCKET
description: With the Supreme Court's Justices heading to their respective hills, it seemed fitting that the 1980 term closed last week with actions on the environment and natural resources: lead in the workplace, coal in the ground and billboards on top of it.

title: WORLD WAS NOT ENOUGH
description: AN INTRODUCTION TO THE POETRY OF YVOR WINTERS By Elizabeth Isaacs. 216 pp. Chicago: Swallow Press/ Ohio University Press. $15.

title: Dan Daniel Warned 'Em RED SMITHSports of The Times
description: DAN DANIEL, a newspaperman to the end and maybe past it, wrote his own obituary to be used ''in the event of my death, which is scheduled within the next 15 years.'' Dan was 91 when the event came to pass last week, within the time frame he had scheduled. He was always meticulous about those details.

title: YOUNGSTERS LEARN SAILING IN THEIR OWN BOATS
description: GREENWICH YOU have to be an optimist to own an Optimist. That's the opinion of some of the parents whose children are now taking part in the morning junior sailing program at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club here. An Optimist, a stubby, dinghy-sized boat with a square bow, costs $850.

title: BOOM IN DALLAS JEOPARDIZES ARTS DISTRICT PLAN
description: An attempt to mix this city's penchant for thinking big with a new-found commitment to the arts has fallen victim to the city's boom-town prosperity and soaring land values.

title: IT'S TIME TO RECOGNIZE THE ECONOMY'S THIRD SECTOR
description: FOR too long, the American economy and social structure have been viewed as falling into two distinct sectors, public and private. But by any objective measure, the volunteer sector, also known as the third sector, is a strong rival to both government and private industry in terms of dollars spent, people served and services rendered.

title: Miss Early Plans Aug. 22 Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Allen Early of Amarillo, Tex., of the engagement of their daughter, Patricia McIntire Early, to George Howard White 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. White Jr. of Arlington, Va.

title: WHY SOME HOUSES SELL FAST IN A SLOW MARKET
description: Phyllis Braun of Northport, L. I., said she panicked and quickly ran out looking for somewhere else to live. Don and Pat Dight of Ridgefield, Conn., had to change plans. A retired business executive in Briarcliff, N. Y., was reported as having been ''absolutely shocked.''

title: The Lively Arts; SCHISGAL PLAY SCORES IN TRIPLE BILL
description: EAST HAMPTON IN celebration of Guild Hall's 50th anniversary, three celebrated Hamptons residents were commissioned to create one-act plays. James Kirkwood, who wrote ''Surprise,'' is also acting in it; Cliff Robertson, who wrote ''The V.I.P.'s,'' not only is acting in it but also directs it, and Murray Schisgal, who wrote ''A Need for Brussels Sprouts,'' only wrote it.

title: Practical Traveler; HOW TO REAP THE BENEFITS OF A NEWLY STRONG DOLLAR
description: The dollar is going farther in Europe this summer than it has in many years, but just how far it goes depends on how carefully you plan your trip.

title: Dining Out; ITALIAN FARE IN ATTRACTIVE SETTING
description: backed chairs covered in rust-colored plush complete the attractive look.

title: TAKING MIAMI BEACH TO ISRAEL
description: T HE short, quiet chap in the blue blazer is unobtrusively sipping a gin and tonic in one of New York's posher hotels. On the basis of appearances, the 78-year-old man might be a professor emeritus or the retired owner of something sensible, say a haberdashery or an optician's shop.

title: Sagebrush and Fine Wines
description: Is Fort Worth really such a remarkable place for the members of the Confrerie St.-Etienne to meet (''A Toast to Alsatians,'' by Terry Robards, June 7)? Terry Robards must think so, otherwise he would not have felt obligated to remark in his second paragraph that the brotherhood's meeting took place at a ''most unlikely location deep in the heart of Texas.''

title: AT G.M.'S BUICK UNIT, WORKERS AND BOSSES GET AHEAD BY GETTING ALONG
description: FLINT, Mich. A YEAR ago, Eddo Brantley's biggest responsibility was blowing dust off equipment with an air hose. Now, she can shut down one of the principal production lines of an automobile factory whenever she wants.

title: Home Clinic; SOLVING THE NUISANCE OF A DOOR THAT WON'T STAY CLOSED
description: A DOOR that fails to stay closed or latch shut each time you close it is a nuisance. But it can also be a sizable energy-waster either in air-conditioned rooms in the summer or if it leads to an unheated room or area in the winter.

title: Laurie Keeshan And a Lawyer To Wed Oct. 17
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Keeshan of Babylon, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Margaret Keeshan, to John Lawrence Sullivan, son of Dr and Mrs. Robert Burkey Sullivan of Washington, Ill.

title: Personal Finance; YOU MAY BE GETTING RICHER- ON PAPER
description: Y OU may be closer than you think to becoming a millionaire, at least on paper. That's because the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the professional organization of accountants, has just proposed a broad change in the method of determining an individual's net worth.

title: THE PROMISE OF MR. REAGAN'S BUDGET VICTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaking Personally; THE GHOSTS OF WORLD WAR II STILL HAUNT THE LIVING
description: WHEN I went to New Brunswick with my son to attend my alma mater's last Homecoming Day football game, seated between us was Oberleutnant Karl Eric Linsdorfer of the 36th Panzer Grenadiers.

title: TAKING A GAMBLE ON PLAYING CARDS
description: Leonard Schneir has satisfied his fascination with playing cards and gambling accessories by acquiring a most unusual collection of antique cards and gaming phenomena over the last six years. The hundreds of examples of these materials that he has assembled include decks that are witty, boldly graphic, historical, political, patriotic, nostalgic and amusing, and wares that are embellished with an amazing variety of playing cards, dice, poker chips, game boards and roulette wheels.

title: Music; AT MUSIC MOUNTAIN, A BLEND THAT WORKS
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, I wrote about some of the changes planned for this summer at Music Mountain, notably the installation of the Manhattan String Quartet as resident performing ensemble, and a fairly ambitious series of community and educational projects. To find out how they were working out, I spoke to Nicholas Gordon, president of the board of managers and son of the late Jacques Gordon, who founded the festival in the late 1920's.

title: Antiques; ATHENEUM HONORS ITS FOUNDER
description: HARTFORD IN 1841, at the age of 70, Daniel Wadsworth, who had spent much of his life enjoying the study of art and years as a collector of paintings, began to plan a museum for Hartford.

title: Emily J. Bagoly To Wed Aug. 15
description: Mrs. Wallace Chambers of Charlestown, Pa., and Lewis Bagoly of Valley Forge, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Jane Bagoly, to John Pickering 2d, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Timothy Pickering of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Friendship, Me.

title: NEW LAW 'FIRST STEP' IN WASTE FIGHT
description: This article was written by State Senator Eugene A. Skowronski of Derby, Democrat from the 17th District and the chairman of the Environment Committee of the General Assembly, and by Representative Teresalee Bertinuson of Melrose, a Democrat from the 57th District and the House chairman of the Environment Committee.

title: Interest Income
description: To the Business Editor: Rudolph G. Penner's article, ''To Aid Savings, Keep The Tax Law Simple'' (June 21), confirmed my theory that the complexities of our current tax code are resulting in major misconceptions even at the very highest levels of Government. In his article, Mr. Penner, who served in President Ford's Office of Management and Budget, advanced various recommendations based on the assumption that '' ... businesses and individuals who borrow get an advantage because they can deduct their entire interest bill from taxable income.''

title: F.D.R.'S CENTENARY
description: It has been so long since we have taken a President seriously that we may have forgotten how. Indeed, we used to have such veneration for the great Presidents that we held spectacular celebrations for their centennials. Federal and state governments, political parties, newspapers, magazines, and other institutions even used to start their planning far in advance. But Presidents have fallen into such disrepute that, as a consequence, we are on the verge of ignoring the centennial of this century's greatest, Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

title: Rites of Passage
description: To the Editor:$

title: Art; SHOWCASE FOR YOUNG ARTISTS OFFERS AN INTERESTING BEGINNING
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR FOR young artists just beginning their careers, the prospect of finding a gallery to represent them in the marketplace is a daunting one. The world of the commercial dealer seems lofty and inaccesible to the novice. After all, many an artist spends years searching for a gallery where his or her work will be sympathetically received and effectively promoted, and quite a few never find such a place.

title: A LESSON IN DIVERSIFICATION helicopters
description: BLOOMFIELD A VISITOR to Kaman Corporation's headquarters and factories in Bloomfield, just north of Hartford, encounters a bewildering array of activities, ranging from the reconditioning of helicopters for the United States Navy to the manufacturing of guitar strings. Charles H. Kaman, the company's founder and president, has managed to combine these and other diverse businesses into a growing, profitable corporation.

title: Insurance Aide, Noeline Hargrave Planning Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Hargrave have announced the engagement of their daughter, Noeline Hargrave, to Fernand Baruch Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fernand Baruch. Both families are of Princeton, N.J., where the wedding is planned for September.

title: PICKETT, IN CORVETTE, CAPTURES TRANS-AM
description: Greg Pickett, who had the second best qualifying time in yesterday's trials, scored an easy victory today in the Trans-Am 66-lap event that was the feature of Lime Rock's biggest racing program of the season.

title: CUSTODY GOALS PURSUED
description: TWO recently formed Westchester organizations, whose members believe they have the best interests of their children at heart, had diametrically opposed reactions to Governor Carey's veto last week of the joint-custody bill that was passed overwhelmingly by both houses of the Legislature.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: DANCE: 'TYMPANI' GIVEN ITS EAST COAST PREMIERE
description: ''Tympani,'' a new work by the experimental choregrapher Laura Dean, was jointly commissioned by three sponsoring institutions - all in the forefront of support for the dance avant-garde. They are the Walker Arts Center in Minneapolis, the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the American Dance Festival, based here at Duke University.

title: Fashion; SIX BRIGHT BASICS FOR SUMMER
description: Six Easy Pieces for Summertime Cool, comfortable, basic separates add to the versatility of a summer wardrobe. It's all the better if they are sold at a more-than-decent price.

title: Reader Comment; HIGHWAYS: LET THE USER PAY
description: C ALLS are increasingly sounded to ''do something about motor vehicle transportation.'' Proposals range from duplication of the interstate highway network in order to liberate automobile traffic, to highspeed truckways, to revision of speed and weight limits, to the idea proposed by B. Bruce-Briggs in ''Highway, Subway'' (June 28) - increase the Federal fuel tax (fixed in nominal terms since 1958) and redistribute the new revenues to support, inter alia, the New York subway system.

title: Weaver, Tillis Set Fall Bout
description: The clouded World Boxing Association heavyweight situation was apparently resolved Friday at a meeting in Pomona, Calif., with Mike Weaver, the champion, scheduled to meet James (Quick) Tillis in early fall and the winner meeting Gerry Cooney within four months.

title: MOST EX-CETA EMPLOYEES GET JOBS
description: More than 70 percent of the New York State and New Jersey workers who faced unemployment this spring because of proposed Administration cutbacks in the Comprehensive Employment Training Act program have been placed in permanent jobs, the Labor Department has announced.

title: Arab League Group Sees Ex-Lebanese President
description: A special Arab League committee seeking to end the fighting in Lebanon began its second round of meetings here today with an unexpected helicopter trip to the northern mountain stronghold of former President Suleiman Franjieh.

title: QUITE A FIX
description: The great Edmund Burke did not, of course, play bridge, but one of his political dicta has some application to the game. ''Between craft and credulity,'' he declared, ''the voice of reason is stifled.''

title: COUNTRY CLUB HOUSING IN ABSECON
description: INITIALLY, it was the sight of the land that had set Anthony Caldarone's heart aflutter. It was not until a few months later that Kaufman & Broad of New Jersey Inc., a Freehold-based real-estate concern of which Mr. Caldarone is president, understood what it had found at the Seaview Country Club in Absecon.

title: NEIGHBORS ARE STRICTLY LAISSEZ-FAIRE
description: Though officials in New Jersey have vigorously campaigned to open the state's shore to the public, those seeking access to beaches in Connecticut and New York have generally been left to their own devices.

title: BALLET: 3 NOTABLE DEBUTS IN BALANCHINE'S 'AGON'
description: The New York City Ballet came to the close of its spring season last Sunday night at the New York State Theater with a smorgasbord of ballets from its recent Tchaikovsky Festival. But there's more to City Ballet than festivals, and in the afternoon three debuts in a spirited performance of George Balanchine's ''Agon'' brought a new perspective to that classic.

title: Headliners; BEHIND BARS, FINALLY
description: She ran as far as the United States, to a marriage with an American and a home in Maspeth, Queens.

title: THE MAO THAT FAILED
description: Five years after his death and fifteen after he ignited the madcap Cultural Revolution, Mao Zedong has finally been pulled from an already-cracked pedestal. The demigod is decreed mortal after all: a brilliant revolutionary but a bumbling theoretician who couldn't distinguish good Marxists from Capitalist Roaders, mistook right for wrong and the people for the enemy.

title: INSIDE AN OUTSIDER
description: THE STOLEN JEW By Jay Neugeboren. 322 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95.

title: WASHINGTON CELEBRATES ON A RAINY FOURTH OF JULY
description: Hundreds of thousands of people celebrated the nation's 205th birthday here today with music and fireworks, and close friends of President and Mrs. Reagan held a barbecue to honor her 58th birthday.

title: Kathy Freese, a Teacher, Married to Jeffrey Junior
description: Kathy Lee Freese, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Freese Jr. of Dix Hills, L.I., and Jeffrey J. Junior, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Junior of Port Jefferson, L.I., were married yesterday at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church in Dix Hills.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article by Lynn Janson, a club golf pro, on the Views of Sport page in section 5 last Sunday was accompanied by an incorrect photograph. It actually showed the golfer John Schroeder. Matlock Jr., United States charge d'affaires in Moscow.(7:1.)

title: Investing; HERE A YIELD, THERE A YIELD...
description: A currently fashionable timing technique used by investors in choosing between bonds and stocks is to compare bond yields with the dividend yields available on common stocks.

title: A.T. Hyde Fiance Of Marina Brock
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Brock of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marina Matthews Brock, to Albert Todd Hyde, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hyde of Palm Beach, Fla., and Buffalo.

title: FREE BALLET FESTIVAL COMING TO YONKERS
description: WESTCHESTER residents can look forward to four free, outdoor Saturday evening performances by the New Jersey Ballet, the Alvin Ailey Repertoire Ensemble, The New York Street Theater Ensemble and the No Elephant Circus as Theater in the Park '81 opens next weekend.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are seeking an active dialogue on all levels. But a dialogue is useful only if it is candid, and we must learn not to take offense at candor but to use it to help us understand each other.'' -Jack F. Matlock Jr., United States charge d'affaires in Moscow.(7:1.)

title: U.S. AIDE PRAISES AMERICAN VALUES ON MOSCOW'S TV
description: A senior American diplomat used a traditional Fourth of July address over Soviet television today to offer an oblique answer to Soviet propoaganda attacks on the Reagan Administration.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: CAMP DAVID IS NOW BACK ON REAGAN'S FRONT BURNER
description: WASHINGTON AFTER delaying five months while it waited for last week's Israeli elections, the Reagan Administration can no longer put off the search for an Israel-Arab peace formula. The Administration had hoped at first that it could put aside the Middle East to concentrate on the Soviet Union and such trouble spots as El Salvador and Poland. It wanted to limit its Middle Eastern role to forging a somewhat vague, anti-Soviet ''strategic consensus'' among Pakistanis, Saudis, Egyptians, Jordanians and Israelis. But Washington soon found it could not remain aloof and was forced to become enmeshed in the region's ebb and flow, even before addressing the Palestinian question, which it now cannot avoid.

title: Television; MAJOR CABLE-TV SERVICES AVAILABLE IN THE NEW YORK AREA
description: The rapid proliferation of cable television has confused many viewers. To clarify matters, The Times prepared this chart. All of the major cable services now offered in the New York tristate area are listed.

title: ASSESSING SOCIAL AID PRIORITIES
description: Communities in the county need to realize that spending reductions have to be made and that new priorities must be set in order for the Department of Social Services to absorb the impact of severely diminished Federal support, according to the agency's Commissioner, Charles W. Bates.

title: Crafts; QUILTS AND QUILTING PROVIDE COLORFUL LIFE
description: STRAETER of Scarsdale sounds typically American, rather old-fashioned even, as she talks about the quilt she is making, about the Friendship Star Quilters, of which she is a member, and about the annual quilt congress she attended in Arlington, Va., last fall, where she met 400 other quilters from all over the country.

title: The World in Summary; IRAN IS BACK IN THAT OLD FAMILIAR CHAOS
description: In the wake of the massive bomb blast last Sunday that killed Ayatollah Mohammed Beheshti, the gray eminence of the fundamentalist Islamic Republican Party, and 71 other party and Government officials, revolutionary Iran appeared to be headed for another period of chaos and bloody internal purges.

title: Notes; A TOWN IN MAINE CELEBRATES ITS MARITIME ROOTS
description: Though its population is little more than 10,000, Bath, Me., has a lot to shout about this summer. It is the oldest shipbuilding community in the United States, and remains a major builder of ships; its restoration programs have won the praise of community planners, and this year it is celebrating its bicentennial. To mark the occasion, the community is inviting visitors to share in the celebrations during all of August.

title: Gallup Poll Finds 71% Favor National Service
description: More than at any time in the last decade, Americans favor mandatory military or civilian work for young men 18 to 24 years old, according to a recent Gallup Poll.

title: RACING- IN BOATS, NOT CARS--WILL BE HELD AT WATKINS GLEN
description: As president of the Watkins Glen (N.Y.) Chamber of Commerce, John Johnson did his share of wincing this spring when Grand Prix auto racing pulled out of the town because of the severe debt of the local sponsors. But now the Unlimited Racing Commission of the American Power Boat Association has announced that the richest powerboat race in history, the $120,000 Thunder in the Glen world championships, will be held in Watkins Glen Aug. 30, and at least some of Mr. Johnson's distress has been alleviated.

title: SIGNERS OF THE DECLARATION: THE GREAT AND SMALL
description: THE 56 signers of the Declaration of Independence form a fascinating cross section of late 18th-century America. Some were great men; some were not. A few were the best-known leaders in their states; others were in Philadelphia because the really powerful local leaders stayed home to form their state governments.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Sports section last Sunday erroneously identified a Belmont Park horse race that is under investigation. The race being investigated was the second on June 22.

title: Westchester Journal
description: ''I'M just about as unconvertable as you can get,'' Representative Richard L. Ottinger said last week as he discussed his opposition to the budget cuts sought by President Reagan. ''They can promise to move the Capitol to White Plains.''

title: CONCERT: EARLY MUSIC AT ASTON MAGNA
description: The Aston Magna Foundation, which began its ninth summer season of concerts tonight at the St. James Church here, has made itself into perhaps this country's most notable center for the study and performance of early music. And not just music in the abstract. It is one of Aston Magna's brighter ideas to surround such study with a consideration of a given period's general Zeitgeist.

title: DAY CAMPS FILL IN FOR WORKING MOTHERS
description: THE children's annual rite of passage is under way again, but for many Long Island youngsters the trip this summer often involves no more than a five-mile ride. A number of day camp owners say that the 1981 enrollment is up from last year's despite the fact that the region's school-age population is declining, with many parents - reflecting the national trend - both in the work force and having fewer children.

title: Sunday Observer
description: By Russell Baker The Myth of the Hot Dog Patrick McDonnell

title: Business Forum; THE ROAD TO A NEW MONOPOLY?
description: I T has become fashionable, with the arrival of the Reagan Administration, to lament the ''undue burdens'' of regulation in our society.

title: Westchester Guide; ECOLOGY WEEKEND
description: A three-day ecology weekend planned for Aug. 28 through Aug. 30 at the county's 1,000-acre Mountain Lakes Camp in North Salem, is described by Barry Samuels, the county naturalist, as ''a serious undertaking - we feel children under 8 should not be present, since there will be nothing in the way of baby-sitting services and we don't want the workshops interrupted.''

title: Behind the Best Sellers; TONI MORRISON
description: ''I can't think of anybody who doesn't need an editor, even though some people claim they don't,'' said Toni Morrison, author of the best-selling novel, ''Tar Baby,'' published by Knopf and on the hardcover best-seller list for the past 12 weeks. ''I would not like to have written a book that does not receive attentive editing. A writer really needs that third eye, someone who doesn't have the same vested interest in a manuscript.''

title: MISS SPHEERIS'S PUNK VERITE
description: It's breakfast time at the Darby Crash household. Mr. Crash, lead singer of the Los Angeles punk band the Germs, sits playing with his pet tarantula while his companion, Michelle, tells a story: There was a housepainter who had a heart attack and died while working in the Crash backyard. When Michelle found the body, she thought it such a funny sight that she persuaded her friends to pose beside it for pictures. While Michelle is talking, Darby breaks the yolk of an egg he is trying to fry. This seems to make him genuinely upset.

title: A SOCIETY DULLED TO THE CARNAGE OF MALS
description: To the Editor:

title: Film View; IN DEFENSE OF BAD JOKES
description: In his 1978 New Yorker magazine profile of Mel Brooks, later published in his collection ''Show People,'' Kenneth Tynan quoted Mel Brooks as saying, ''I'm a celebrator. That's why I like the Russians. They look at a tree and cry out, 'Look at that tree!' They're full of original astonishments.'' At first this seems to be an off-the-topof-the-head self-appraisal by an artist attempting to characterize himself after everyone else has done it poorly. To call oneself a celebrator, after all, is to admit that one's own worst fault is to love too much the world and everything in it.

title: L.I. Carting Concerns End Protest of 3 Days
description: An agreement has been reached to end the three-day refusal by 14 private concerns to collect trash in the Town of Smithtown, officials said today.

title: Business Conditions; DETROIT'S DIESEL POWER
description: With auto sales back in the doldrums after a rebate-led recovery during the first quarter, it seems that major automobile manufacturers have little to cheer about. There are a few bright spots, however, and the sales performance of diesel-powered cars is one of them.

title: Antiques; OLD SHORE STORE FILLING NEW ROLE
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH THE Johnson family began selling furniture here in the 1890's, first on the second floor of a hardware store and then expanding to a large store at Bay and Trenton Avenues. Hard hit by competition from along the highways, the Johnson Furniture Mart closed its doors last year.

title: WATCH HILL TO POINT JUDITH: 20 MILES OF SUMMER FUN
description: It is 20 miles as the crow flies along the Rhode Island shore from Watch Hill on the west to Point Judith on the east, a great stretch of white sands and grassy dunes facing Block Island Sound. This coastline is a summer playground open to all that offers something for just about everybody. There are five state beaches with parking and bathhouse facilities, several state-owned fishing spots and conservation areas as well as town beaches that also welcome visitors. And along the shore or just inland there is everything from antiques shopping in sedate Watch Hill to disco roller skating in honky-tonk Misquamicut.

title: St. Lawrence
description: To the Editor:

title: LOBSTERING INDUSTRY DECLINING IN STATE
description: THE lobster industry in New Jersey is not what it used to be, and the reasons vary with who is doing the analysis. Some state officials and coastal experts say lobsters have been overexploited. Lobstermen blame state and Federal agencies for allowing pollution of the Atlantic, or foreign fleets far offshore for depleting the species.

title: CRIME UP, ARRESTS OFF IN CITY
description: Although reports of serious crime have risen more than 25 percent in New York City in the last two years, the number of arrests has decreased, an and police officials say they expect this pattern to continue through 1981.

title: July 5, 1981
description: NONFICTION THE ART OF JAPANESE MANAGEMENT: Applications for American Executives. By Richard Tanner Pascale and Anthony G. Athos. 2 EQUALITY. By William Ryan. 8 THE GRAND DOMESTIC REVOLUTION: A History of Feminist Designs for American Homes, Neighborhoods, and Cities.

title: Food; COLD SOUPS FOR SUMMER
description: Although we have had a fair amount of success tracking down the origins of recipes and their names, we have had some difficulty with the curried cream soup dubbed Senegalese. Although the name derives from Senegal, the former French West African territory, we have been unable to find it in any French reference work. We suspect that it may even be an American creation.

title: INVENTOR OF DECODER RENEWS PATENT SUIT
description: A 65-year-old New Haven resident, living in a rooming house with Social Security as his only source of income, is reactivating a lawsuit in which he contends that the Federal Government should pay him $27 million in compensation and damages for appropriating an encoding and decoding device soon after he applied for a patent on it 17 years ago.

title: SHAPING THE BUDGET COULD RESHAPE AMERICA
description: WASHINGTON IT takes a long view of Washington to put the big Reagan victory on budget cuts into perspective. The way the President's men in the last days of June were log-rolling for votes, pushing through hastily prepared legislation and thriving on the confusion reminded the Speaker of the House of a Democratic President he had known. ''It was the old Lyndon Johnson style,'' Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said in a moment of reflection last week.

title: The World in Summary; ITALY'S 41ST GOVERNMENT BREAKS MOLD
description: Italy's patchwork quilt artists have done it again - stitched together a parliamentary majority that excludes the second-ranking Communists. But they had to change the traditional pattern to do it.

title: Dining Out; INN STILL BLOOMS IN 36TH YEAR
description: RIDGEFIELD RESTAURANTS come and go, but Stonehenge, like a hardy perennial, seems to bloom forever. This landmark inn in Ridgefield is in its 36th year.

title: A FESTIVAL GROWS IN SITKA
description: You've heard of the chamber music explosion in the United States. So here we are in Sitka, Alaska, a fishing and logging town originally settled by the Russians in 1741 after they kicked out the Tlingit Indians. Pop. today, 8,000. It is the evening of Friday, June 12, and on the stage of the 500-seat auditorium of the Centennial Building are six musicians engaged in the Brahms Sextet in B flat. The auditorium has a plate glass window behind the players. Occasionally a fishing boat can be seen passing by. Or a bald eagle may make its virtuoso plunge, diving into the waters of Sitka Sound to grab its prey.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: JOSEPH CONRAD By Roger Tennant. Illustrated. 276 pp. New York: Atheneum. $16.95. If every biographer were as scrupulous about the facts, as respectful of the work of his predecessors, as fascinated with his subject, as dutiful toward his readers as Roger Tennant, there would be no bad biographies. While those qualities alone may not ignite into revelation, they stand as safeguards against foolishness and phoniness. ''Joseph Conrad,'' though not the last word on the subject, much less the first, is a clearly written, modestly delivered work that never insults our intelligence or strains our good nature. Here are the formative years in Poland of the ''Pole, Catholic, and Gentleman,'' and the famous years at sea, which at age 30 Conrad would begin to transmute into his marvelous tales. Here are the first glimpses of figures who would grow into such reverberating creations as Almayer, Lingard, Kurtz and Lord Jim. As recognition came to Conrad, so came contacts with such lions of the day as John Galsworthy, Henry James, H.G. Wells, Stephen Crane and Ford Madox Ford. The final years of success were filled with illness, restlessness and brooding, the end of the tether. Given his conviction, expressed in the introduction, that Conrad is ''the greatest writer in the English language,'' Mr. Tennant's lowkey tone is somewhat anticlimactic. His occasional essay at criticism tends toward the conventionally appreciative. On the uses of Marlow as Conrad's narrator in ''Heart of Darkness,'' he writes: ''This method of distanced retrospection allowed Conrad to control his material, to select the significant and the symbolic, and to develop those shifts in time that made the finished story a complex work of art.'' The cool reticence becomes constraining when Mr. Tennant has to deal with Conrad's brushes with women. There are hints of some emotional infirmity or impotence, yet his attachment to his wife and children was powerful. Much remains cloudy, but then Conrad, though a tempting mark for psychology, has never proved an easy one. In a sense, he was a secret agent. Roger Tennant would no doubt concede in his modest way that there are depths of Conrad's personality that he was not able to sound, shadows that he was not able to penetrate, an unassailable darkness at the heart of this chronic alien existing on a cultural shadow line - this unorthodox conservative who shaped a foreign tongue into a prodigious instrument at the service of a prodigious imagination. The facts are here, clearly laid out. If it's revelation you're after, there are always the books. STRUCTURES OF AMERICAN SOCIAL HISTORY By Walter Nugent. 206 pp. Bloomington, Ind.: Indiana University. $12.95. Camouflaged by the graphs, jargon and other apparatus of the professional demographer is information on such interesting items as sex, work, money, chance and dreams. Although Walter Nugent does his best to put off the merely curious with his stonewall title, he cannot altogether prevent human desires and drives from intruding into his pages and making them intermittently readable. Elaborating respectfully on the work of such celebrated analysts as Marx and Engels, Malthus and Frederick Jackson Turner, Mr. Nugent divides America's demographic history into four phases: 1500-1720, which for some reason he likes to call Vorzeit, or prehistory, when the Colonies were developed by immigrants from northern Europe while the native Indians were being decimated by disease; 1720-1870, ''the frontier-rural period,'' when young people settled cheap land, reared large families and built the West (''The average number of children born per average woman in her lifetime, as of 1790, was almost eight''); 1870-1920, which for some reason he likes to call ''The Great Conjecture,'' when the frontier closed and factories opened, drawing millions to new jobs in the cities ( and the ''Nordic alarmists'' of the 1920's ''predicted the exhaustion of oil, minerals, lumber and food supply within a generation or two unless population were controlled, by immigration or other means''); 1920-2020, our own ''Metropolitan Period,'' with its radical changes in family arrangements. Mr. Nugent commiserates with white American men now in their 20's and 30's, the boom babies, who find themselves competing for jobs with women and with minority groups entering the middle class. This is an era when productivity is down and the working young must support increasing numbers of the nonworking elderly, who are the beneficiaries of advances in medical care and social legislation. But demographers think in generations, and for the long term Mr. Nugent is sanguine. As long as population growth is contained - and he draws from history the grounds for his belief that it will be - he foresees a reinvigorated economy, with women, minorities and the elderly developing the skills to realize their inherent productivity and enrich the nation. He leaves us with the hope that if the American people do not again ignore Malthus as they did in the self-confident 1940's and 50's, and if they ''resume their semirational, semiconscious understanding of the relation of population to opportunity in a frontierless age, which put brakes on population growth, their future should be brightly bourgeois again.'' We should live so long. I HEAR THEM CALLING MY NAME A Journey Through the New South. By Chet Fuller. 255 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $12.95. How many generations of reporters will have to go tramping through the ''New South'' before it is worn down into middle age? This account confirms that for the many blacks still working the white man's land for subsistence, or forced to hold two low-paying jobs to meet their bills, or without any job at all, the newness was never all that new. Chet Fuller, a young black reporter for The Atlanta Journal, traveled around four states in three months of 1978, posing as a job hunter. He is fair to the individual whites he encounters, such as the gas-station rednecks who help him out when his car breaks down, and he has a good ear for the street-corner jiving of the aimless young black men he meets wherever he goes. Now and then he hears about progress in race relations. ''You know,'' a hard-working Georgia man tells him, ''if you whup a cracker fair and square now, he just whupped. Used to be - and not long ago - white folks could do anything to you they want, and you couldn't fight 'em back. Now you can whup they head.'' But that is the exception. Mostly, he learns that power still resides with the white landowners, plant bosses and politicians. ''Gadsden is rotten,'' a black woman tells him in a town where white policemen have recently killed a black man. ''They sho' don't b'leeve in helping no black folks here. The way them polices shot Madden, it's a crime. The polices here treat black people like dogs. They can't ask you a simple question, and then when you go to answer it, they tell you to shut up. Just like you ain't grown yourself. That's the way they do.'' Mr. Fuller works hard at padding the book out with his own feelings as an educated comfortably situated black professional confronted by the misery of blacks who have not made it and have no hope of ever making it. But that sort of introspection takes a different talent than most journalists can claim. Still, nobody is likely to quarrel with his observation that ''Your color still matters in the South, in this country.'' He finds no black faces in the front offices where he goes to ask about jobs, and much white manipulation behind the scenes. In the records office of a North Carolina county, he digs into the story of an elderly woman who was induced to put up her interest in 87 acres of land as collateral on a loan of $615 for heating oil - and lost the land.

title: HOSPITAL DENIES HASTENING DEATHS
description: SEVEN babies have died over the last six months in the Newborn Special Care Unit of Yale-New Haven Hospital, most despite the best efforts of doctors and nurses to save them. But a few died without a major effort to keep them alive, because doctors and parents agreed that the struggle was hopeless and that, with no hope of the infants' being weaned from complex life-support equipment, they would eventually die anyway, according to the hospital's chief of staff and the head of the Special Care Unit.

title: CLOCKS TICK IN WARSAW, MOSCOW
description: A Western diplomat in Moscow not known for his sanguine views of Soviet intentions toward Poland was mildly optimistic last week. ''They've got the safety catch on,'' he said.

title: Kim Maltese and Gregory Gross to Marry Sept. 26
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Maltese Jr. of Saddle River, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kim Maltese, to Gregory Andrew Gross, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Gross of Hillsdale, N.J.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; THE DANGERS OF SALT SEEM CLEAR, BUT NOT THE LABELING
description: AFTER sugar, salt is the nation's second leading food additive. Manufacturers must indicate its use on labels, but they don't have to say how much salt a product contains, or how much sodium - sodium being the mineral element and salt (sodium chloride) the dietary form in which sodium is most often found. One teaspoon of salt contains about 2,000 milligrams of sodium.

title: Juilliard Quartet In Museum Series
description: Menahem Pressler, pianist, and the Juilliard String Quartet will open the 28th concert season of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Their performance Oct. 3 in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium will be the first in the chamber-music series, one of 20.

title: Jane C. Ginsburg Engaged to Wed
description: Prof. Martin D. Ginsburg and Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg of Washington have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jane C. Ginsburg, to George T. Spera Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Spera of Mays Landing, N.J.

title: Washington; IN PURSUIT OF HAPPINESS
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., July 4 - The Declaration of Independence has proved to be so popular over the last 205 years that declar-ing independence in pursuit of hap-piness has become a fad and even a danger.

title: Salad Dressing
description: To the Business Editor: I read a follow-up to your story on the Three Mile Island salad dressing mix, ''... And Tasteless Salad Dressing?'' (April 19) in Petr Beckmann's July issue of Access to Energy.

title: New York Times Magazine July 5, 1981
description: William Safire 6 On Language Carte Before the Horse Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer Myth of the Hot Dog Betty Friedan 12 Feminism's Next Step David Gebhard 16 A Corbusier Portfolio Karen Stabiner 22 How to Succeed in Hollywood Without Really Filming Craig Claiborne 24 Food with Pierre Franey Cold Soups for Summer Ken Druse 26 Gardens A Bit of Old England Blooms on L.I. 28 Fashion Six Bright Basics for Summertime Terry Robards 30 Wine The Subject Is Roses 34 Puzzles Answers, Page 33 38 Letters Cover: Photograph by Evelyn Hofer Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: Politics; RACE BY WACHTLER IN DOUBT
description: COURT OF APPEALS Judge Sol M. Wachtler of Manhasset is expected to decide in the next six months whether to leave the state's highest court to run for Governor. As of now, many politicians believe that the arguments against such an effort outweigh the arguments for it.

title: SITTING BACK ON VOTING RIGHTS
description: When it comes to voting rights, President Reagan told the N.A.A.C.P. convention last week, he stands foursquare behind the right of all Americans to cast a secret ballot. That's not much of an explanation for why he hasn't yet taken a stand on extending the 1965 Voting Rights Act.

title: Miss Borden Plans Bridal For Aug. 19
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John C. Borden Jr. of Princeton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Grosvenor Borden, to Douglas Walls Bunnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard W. Bunnell of Madison, Conn.

title: The Careful Shopper; Roses Are a Bargain At Westport Store
description: Because too much of shopping is a ritual search for necessities at affordable prices, it is a pleasure to be guided to a tiny, whimsical flower shop in Westport called Miss Plum's Particulars, the Old-Fashioned Store, that uses a hedgehog wearing an apron as its logo. Here the weekend bargain - and sometimes midweek, too - is four miniature roses for $2, locally grown Greens Farms roses quite capable of filling the car with their scent once well out of range of the cooler. Preservation of that $2 limit despite rising wholesale costs is a matter of principle for the owner, David Quigley, an English teacher for 13 years, who is now enjoying his ''reincarnation'' as a retailer.

title: Suburban to Temperence Hill
description: Temperence Hill, who showed a penchant for running in the mud when he scored an upset in the Belmont Stakes last year, charged through the swampy stretch at Belmont Park yesterday to win the 95th running of the Suburban Handicap.

title: WILL MCEWEN EMULATE ADLER?
description: By common consensus, the San Francisco Opera counts as this country's second most important company, after New York's Metropolitan. It offers an extensive, two-part main season, several venturesome smaller seasons and subsidiary companies, a striking blend of the familiar and the original in casting, bold repertory and a vital, sophisticated opera audience.

title: EXPLORING THE SLIPPERY PATH TO ECONOMIC SUMMIT OF '81
description: ON July 20, President Reagan will do what many other Americans have been doing to take advantage of the dollar's decade-high value against other currencies - he'll go abroad. But instead of resting, he's likely to be listening to complaints from leaders of the six other non-Communist industrial powers about what his Adminstration's tight monetary policy and its consequent high interest rates are doing to their economies. France's new Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, told a European Common Market meeting in Luxembourg last week that their priority should be fighting ''the scourge of unemployment'' rather than inflation.

title: Washington Upset at Henley
description: ON-THAMES, England, July 4 - The last United States entry in the Grand Challenge Cup, the University of Washington's varsity heavyweight eight-oared crew, was beaten today in the biggest upset of the 142d Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Westchester Housing; WHEN HOUSES 'TALK'
description: ''WHAT'S that funny noise?'' a wife asks her husband, a husband asks his wife, or, worse, a visiting friend or relative apprehensively inquires.

title: Paul Samuelson to Wed Martha Scarf
description: Prof. and Mrs. Herbert E. Scarf of Hamden, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Anne Scarf, to Paul R. Samuelson, son of Mr. Paul A. Samuelson of Belmont, Mass., and the late Marion Samuelson.

title: 25 Bodies Exhumed In Coast Hospital Case
description: Twenty-five bodies have been exhumed in Los Angeles and Riverside Counties so far in an investigation into the mysterious deaths of more than 50 patients in five southern California hospitals.

title: A FESTIVAL FOR YOUNG CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: Susan Reiter is a freelance writer with a special interest in dance. By SUSAN REITER

title: THE FANS' 'RIGHTS' ARE OVERSTATED
description: The passionate love affair between America and baseball is marvelous to contemplate. One reads Roger Angell, Roger Kahn and Red Smith, and realizes they are writing not about a mere game but about an ethos or a rite central to the fundamental values, culture and mores of a people. Baseball is much more than a sport; it is a mythology for the American people.

title: RAIN CURTAILS FOURTH OF JULY CROWDS
description: The heaviest Fourth-of-July rainfall on record dampened spirits but not celebrations, as the city engaged in its annual round of parades, volleys of fireworks, fairs and artillery salutes.

title: SUFFOLK FESTIVAL CELEBREATES MARITIME FOLKLORE
description: AMAGANSETT ALTHOUGH still alive and almost healthy after centuries of playing a major role in the area's economic life, the Island's maritime industry has seen better days. And Suffolk County wants to preserve something from its glorious past; at least, the verbal arts and occupational crafts that were handed down from generation to generation of baymen and fishermen who have always harvested the Island's waters for a livelihood.

title: Dining Out; A BIG BONUS IN CLIFFSIDE PARK; For the Espositos, a Hearty Salute!
description: GIVEN the vast number of Italian restaurants in New Jersey, it is surprising how few are truly excellent. We are therefore grateful to John, Nick and Angelo Esposito, three brothers from Amalfi, for opening the Villa Amalfi in Cliffside Park two years ago.

title: The Lively Arts; AN IMBROGLIO THAT LIVES UP TO ITS NAME
description: EAST FARMINGDALE A. FREDERICK HAAS has been an engineer by profession, a historian by avocation and a playwright by preference. Now retired, he writes plays on historical subjects.

title: CHRISTOPHER PLUMMER DUSTS OFF THE CROWN OF 'HENRY V'
description: It is unusual at 51 to be playing the role that made you famous at 26, but on Tuesday Christopher Plummer will appear as the impetuous young king in Shakespeare's ''Henry V'' at the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn. For Mr. Plummer, whose career has spanned film, theater and television, the occasion will mark a return to his first love. ''I've done my share of idiotic parts,'' he says, ''but I've done Shakespeare every few years so that I will remember that this is what acting is all about.''

title: THE CABLE-TV REVOLUTION: HOW IT AFFECTS THE ARTS LEADING CONSULTANT
description: FORESEES THE 'WIRED SOCIETY' regen winfrey trimmed --------------------------------------------------------------------- Carey Winfrey is a freelance writer who frequently reports on television. By CAREY WINFREY

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Summer dance festivals have blossomed, it seems, all over the place. And so has the Joffrey Ballet this week. The first company will perform at the Pepsico Summerfare '81 festival in Purchase, N.Y. on Saturday and next Sunday afternoon and evening in a repertory that includes Agnes de Mille's timeless ''Rodeo'' and works by Gerald Arpino, Jiri Kylian, Marjorie Mussman, August Bournonville, Laura Dean and Robert Joffrey.

title: Youth Is Said to Admit Hoax On Plane Crash in Arkansas
description: A teenager who said that he had found the wreckage of a plane that apparently crashed last month on a flight from Texas to Iowa has admitted that his story was a hoax to collect a $10,000 reward, Sheriff A. L. Hadaway of Polk County said today.

title: Art View; THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE RODIN; by Hilton Kramer
description: WASHINGTON There are reputations in art that soar so high that, if only for a generation or two, they scarcely seem to be reputations in the ordinary sense at all. They acquire instead the status of some eternal verity, and it hardly seems possible that a time might come when the bright light of a renown that is universal in scope will grow dim and even flicker out. The fortunes of art -everything we feel about its permanence and its destiny - seem for the moment so closely bound to the prosperity of these reputations that the very thought of their extinction is unimaginable.

title: Sports; COACH SET FOR ISRAELI GAMES
description: city honors several years agowhen he was playing basketball for Wingate High School in Brooklyn. This week, at a school just outside Tel Aviv, named, coincidentally, Wingate, Mr. Stern will be running a clinic for Israeli basketball coaches. The clinic is part of his duties as head coach for the United States basketball team, which will be participating in the 11th Maccabiah Games beginning tomorrow in Israel.

title: The Nation in Summary; TAX CUTS YIELD PLEASURE, PAIN
description: The revolution of lower expectations shook Massachussets and California last week. As the new fiscal year began, the Bay State and many of its cities were still struggling with budgets - and the hard choices forced on them by Proposition 2 1/2, the tax-cutting initiative passed in November. In Los Angeles, Proposition 13 really began to hurt.

title: GOVERNMENT COMPLEXITY IS FORCING OFFICIALS TO QUIT LOCAL POLITICS
description: AS the municipal election campaigns begin to warm up across Connecticut these days, a surprising number of chief executives of towns and cities are saying they have had enough. The First Selectmen and Mayors who have announced so far that they will not seek reelection this fall offer a variety of reasons for stepping down.

title: IN BRAZILIAN SOCCER, ZICO IS TAKING UP WHERE PELE LEFT OFF
description: RIO DE JANEIRO AFTER a a decade of decline, Brazil has regained the soccer excellence that brought it three World Cups, and it has emerged as the favorite in the next edition of the games a year from now.

title: ANTI-AMERICANISM IN WEST GERMANY APPEARS IN MANY GUISES
description: A recent full-page advertisement in a West German national magazine (cost: $11,898.73 at current rates) said, right in the first paragraph, that ''almost nothing that is sold or used in our restaurants comes from America.'' Their enterprise was German, the advertisers insisted, with German interests, German management, German workers and German suppliers.

title: Dance View; ASHTON'S 'SCENES DE BALLET'
description: For the first time since 1949, Britain's Royal Ballet performed in New York without either Margot Fonteyn or Rudolf Nureyev. The result was not, as some might have feared, the equivalent of the sun setting on you know what. Rather, this season - just concluded at the Metropolitan Opera House - marked a watershed in the company's relation to its New York public. Some of the excitement the old Royal stars could exude, was missing. A younger generation seemed to take its national reputation for reserve too seriously. Nonetheless, the old elegance was always there. The Royal remains a great company, a grand ensemble troupe and one whose novelties are as important as its staples.

title: At Home Abroad; 'AN ABSOLUTE TRUTH'
description: Occupied West Bank - Two years ago a group of Gush Emunim settlers moved into the middle of this intensely nationalistic and religious Arab city. Fifty of them now live in an abandoned Jewish clinic, Hadassah House, guarded by Israeli soldiers. One, who came last summer, is a 20-year-old woman from Brooklyn, Yudit Deutsch.

title: TEEN-AGERS OFFER IDEAS TO YOUTH AGENCY
description: IN the latest step of an effort to coordinate the needs of youth with county services, the county's Youth Bureau has begun a series of regional meetings with young people in Westchester.

title: ATLANTA COUNTING THE DAYS SINCE LAST YOUTH WAS SLAIN
description: The suspect in one of the 28 murders of young blacks here has been sitting alone in an isolated jail cell for almost two weeks while the beleaguered city counts the days that pass without another mysterious disappearance or death.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Censorship. ''So far as writers are concerned, there is no longer a law of obscenity.'' So wrote Charles Rembar in ''The End of Obscenity,'' a book widely reviewed when it was published 13 years ago. As an attorney, Mr. Rembar had played a central role in the legal battles that lifted the bans on ''Lady Chatterley's Lover,'' ''Tropic of Cancer'' and ''Fanny Hill.''

title: ON TO THE HAGUE FOR IRAN ASSETS
description: In upholding last week a key part of the agreement with Iran that brought the 52 hostage Americans home, the Supreme Court time and time again made it plain that it was ruling from its most proper high ground. Repeatedly, the 31-page majority opinion emphasized the narrowness of the argument and its historical foundations.

title: LIBERAL ARTS DEGREES' VERY TANGIBLE VALUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Numismatics; THE DECLINE AND FALL OF THE $2 BILL; by Ed Reiter
description: Five years have passed since the current $2 bill made its debut on the eve of America's Bicentennial. It was intended as a circulating note, rather than merely a memento, but it is clearly not destined to play any role in the commerce of the nation's third century.

title: Longtime Hanoi Leader Heads New Presidency
description: Truong Chinh, a founding member of the Vietnamese Communist Party who was a rival of Ho Chi Minh for its leadership, was elected leader of Vietnam's new collective presidency today.

title: TIMERMAN CHALLENGING REPORTS ON PRISON TAPES
description: Jacobo Timerman, the former Argentine newspaper publisher who was held for two and a half years by Argentina's military rulers, yesterday dismissed reports that tape recordings of a session with his jailers had called into question how complete his account of his arrest and detention had been. Mr. Timerman said that the reports seemed to distort his account and constituted a trial of his case by the press.

title: The Week in Business; THE STOCK MARKET IN A DITHER
description: Grant Tinker, one of the most successful production executives in television, was named last week to take over Fred Silverman's post as head of NBC. Mr. Silverman, who was hired to turn the network around and didn't, was replaced as Thornton F. Bradshaw officially took over as chairman of the parent RCA. Mr. Tinker founded MTM Enterprises with his former wife, Mary Tyler Moore.

title: THE SUN RISES ON NEW SEASON FOR FISHERMEN
description: ''WE'LL stay out here until we run out of bait or beer,'' said Walt Lewandowski, a fisherman trolling the waters of the Cross River Reservoir in a rowboat. ''The sun will go down, and the sun will come up.''

title: Britain, Hungary Surprise
description: Britain and Hungary were surprise leaders, but East Germany, the defending champion, was in a strong position after the first competition in the three men's European Track and Field Cup semifinals today.

title: COMPANY FIGHTING FOR POWER SUPPLY
description: A major company is fighting a landlord's proposal to replace electricity from the Consolidated Edison Company at least in part by the building's own power system. The company has won a temporary restraining order to keep Con Edison service.

title: CHANGE UPSETS PORT JEFFERSON
description: PORT JEFFERSON WHILE the now-customary boatloads of Connecticut tourists disembark this holiday weekend at the ferry dock to join the hordes of visitors streaming into Port Jefferson by land, village residents are continuing the lively debate they have been waging this summer about the pros and cons of the commercial development that has changed their once sleepy waterfront community into a modern tourist attraction.

title: The A.E.I. and Deregulation
description: I find it interesting that Peter Stone should mention the names Eli Lilly and Richardson-Merrell in suggesting a conflict of interest in drug companies' funding American Enterprise Institute research to speed up new drug approvals (''Conservative Brain Trust,'' May 10). Richardson-Merrell's application for F.D.A. approval of thalidomide some 20 years ago is the perfect case in favor of Food and Drug Administration scrutiny of new drugs.

title: Hackbart in Settlement With Bengals on Injury
description: Dale Hackbart, the former Denver Bronco free safety, has reached an out-of-court settlement with the Cincinnati Bengals and Boobie Clark in connection with an injury Hackbart received in 1973.

title: GILBERT MACKAY
description: Gilbert MacKay, chairman of MacKay-Shields Financial Corporation, a pension-trust management concern of Manhattan, died Friday in New York City. A resident of Manhattan, he was 72 years old.

title: Amy Ralston Sets Bridal on Sept. 6
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Ralston of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Amy S. Ralston, to Howard Seife, son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton D. Seife of Yonkers.

title: Chess; WHEN KARPOV LOSES YOU HAVE TO ASK WHY
description: Anatoly Karpov has got it all backwards. When the World Champion fails to take first prize home to the Soviet Union, that's an occasion. But when he achieves another triumph, it's taken for granted.

title: Correction
description: The issue of May 31 carried an essay by Robert Penn Warren that will serve as an introduction to the 35th-anniversay edition of ''All the King's Men,'' to be published by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, not the Book-of-the-Month Club, as stated, although the club will also bring out an edition.

title: Children's Books
description: Teller. Retold by Shirley Climo. Illustrated by Joyce Audy dos Santos. 122 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $8.95. (Ages 9 to 12) By SELMA G.LANES

title: Cole Baker, Engineer, Weds Cathleen Casale
description: Cathleen M. Casale and Cole H. Baker were married yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Kenneth Jones. The bride, office manager with the Market Research Corporation of America in Stamford, Conn., is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Beisler of Union, N.J. Her father is associate staff manager in the business technical department of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company in Newark.

title: Headliners; AUTHOR ANONYMOUS
description: Romain Gary ''is not around to defend himself,'' a critic said last week, as if the late French novelist had been accused of a crime.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; RARE CANCER IN HOMOSEXUALS
description: A series of statistics issued by the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta last week brought fear to homosexual men and a challenge to epidemiologists and cancer researchers. Doctors in New York and California have diagnosed 41 cases, going back 30 months, of a rare and often rapidly fatal cancer, Kaposi's Sarcoma, which can appear as violet-colored spots on the skin, infect the lymph glands and then spread throughout the body.

title: ARNOUX HAS POLE IN FRENCH RACE
description: Rene Arnoux of France, in a turbocharged Renault, set a speed record for the Dijon track today and earned the pole position for the French Grand Prix.

title: Leisure; HOSTAS SHIMMER IN THE SHADE
description: Joanna May Thach is a writer and Long Island gardener. By JOANNA MAY THACH

title: EX-NEW YORK EDUCATOR
description: James Francis Kelly, former executive vice chancellor of the State University of New York and Assistant Secretary, Comptroller, of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, died Friday of cancer in St. Joseph's Hospital in Asheville, N.C. Mr. Kelly, a resident of Hendersonville, N.C., was 65 years old.

title: The Region in Summary; FINDING A HOME FOR TOXIC WASTE
description: Although few New Jerseyans would object to doing something to dispose of the more than 720,000 tons of dangerous chemical wastes produced in the state each year, even fewer would agree to have it done in their communities. Under a bill that got final legislative approval in Trenton last week, they may not have any choice.

title: IS RETIREMENT REALLY FOR EVERYONE?
description: ''THE only object of work is to obtain leisure,'' said W. Somerset Maugham in his short story, ''The Lotus Eater.'' It's not true for everyone, of course. There are people who revel in work, people to whom work is leisure, relaxation, life itself. Then there are those who work all their lives, hoping eventually to obtain that leisure.

title: BUY-DOWNS AND REBATES ON RISE AS SPUR TO SALES
description: The Jay-Schorr Development Corporation, sponsor of Riverview, a new waterfront condominium project in Queens, is offering home buyers mortgage interest rates at 12 1/2 percent for the first three years of a loan.

title: Topics; OUTSPOKEN, UNHEARD; SUBVERSIONS
description: We've always thought that cleanliness is next to Godliness, but some Reagan Cabinet members apparently find it closer to godless Communism. How else is one to interpret the astonishing attack on environmentalists by Energy Secretary James Edwards?

title: DEMOCRATS LIE LOW--FOR GOOD REASON
description: WASHINGTON ''T HE Democrats will be back. You'll live to see it and I'll live to see it.'' That was the insistent prediction of the 68-year-old Speaker of the House, offered as he relaxed after a good back nine on a Cape Cod golf course, one that followed a struggling beginning. But his real difficulty, and his party's, is not slices, shanks or too many putts. Their trouble is that Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. has lately been made to look like a duffer on the floor of the House.

title: ARGENTINE REGIME SEVERELY STRAINED BY ECONOMIC WOES
description: The military Government of President Roberto Eduardo Viola, hammered by a worsening economy and internal division, is being severely strained as the military seems to have lost the majority support it once thought it had from Argentina's 28 million people.

title: ROBBING CITY'S BANKS IS NO LONGER CHILD'S PLAY
description: One of the most publicized bank robberies in New York this year was carried out with apparent ease by a giggling nine-year-old boy who pointed a toy gun at a teller and escaped with about $100. But the spectacular failure of three would-be robbers in midtown last week - two were shot, all were captured - may be more representative of the current trend in bank holdups.

title: Jonina T. Gorenstein Fiancee of a Physicist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gorenstein of Medford, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jonina T. Gorenstein, to Dr. Jonathan Furth Schonfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel B. Schonfeld of White Plains. An Aug. 30 wedding is planned in Lexington, Mass.

title: IN HAMILTON, KUSH IS STILL ON TRIAL
description: Cats, wearing a T-shirt with a cartoon of a wounded player and the words ''I survived Frank Kush's camp.''

title: Yankee Refunding Policy Questioned
description: To the Sports Editor: The New York Yankees recently announced their policy for the handling of ticket refunds for games affected by the players' strike.

title: GRAFFITI CLUTTERING UP THE THE TAX BILL
description: SENATORS and Representatives had already departed last week for their districts and the Fourth of July holiday, leaving the cool long hallways of Congress quiet. But inside the staff offices, without the fanfare of committee hearings, lawyers and economists were down to shirtsleeves, working away on the snowballing proposals to cut taxes.

title: 2 MEN SLAIN IN CHINATOWN
description: Two young men were shot to death in a Chinatown restaurant last evening as other patrons watched, the police said.

title: TOWNS EYE FUTURE OF CABLE TV NET
description: SOMETIME next year, if all goes according to plan, Fairfield County will have its own afternoon and evening television news shows, an early show of the ''Good Morning, America'' type, televised sports and cultural events from near and far, and televised meetings of local school boards and Boards of Selectmen. It may also have the beginnings of a system that will provide burglar, medical, and fire alarms, shop-at-home service, remote control of home thermostats, and instant polling, all over a system that will offer 104 cable television channels to 120,000 homes.

title: PINELANDS PLANS FOR LAND IMPERILED
description: DRASTIC slashing of the Federal budget not only threatens to undercut New Jersey's $81 million pinelands acquisition program, but already has forced Pinelands Commission planners to reshuffle priorities on land that the state intends to buy.

title: On The Isle; 'STRIKER UP'
description: Ironically, it seems the only baseball around these days is a version played to the call of ''Striker Up.'' That's what the umpire will yell today at the Old Bethpage Village Restoration at 2 P.M. to usher in a game between the Mineola Washingtons and the Hempstead Eureka Nine. Of course the game will be played as it was in 1861, with underhanded pitching across a metal home plate, the ''strikers'' swinging 44-inch bats in the hope of scoring an ''ace'' and the umpire elected by the players. But, because it's the only game in town, why not? The 120-year rivalry between the two teams, playing under rules adopted by the 1861 convention of the National Association of Amateur Baseball Players, will be continued July 26 and Aug. 6. The Restoration is on Round Swamp Road and admission is $2.75; for children, $1.50; Nassau residents $2.25 and $1.25, respectively. REAL 'KOOL' JAZZ

title: THANKS TO BASEBALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Deirdre Fricke Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Gilbert Fricke of Wilton, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Deirdre Jo Fricke, to H. Birkett Becker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Becker of Kenilworth, Ill. The wedding is planned for late next month.

title: DAVIS CUP 1959: NEALE FRASER'S YEAR
description: The United States Tennis Association has been advertising next weekend's Davis Cup quarterfinal match at Flushing Meadows, between the United States ans Czechoslovakia, as the first Cup series in New York in 22 years. My initial reaction was disbelief, but a file of yellowing press clippings confirmed that a generation had passed since the last Cup series in New York, a challenge round between the United States and Australia, played on the grass courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. ,

title: OPENING UP NEW JERSEY'S SEA AND SAND
