description: During the last decade, New Jersey's courts and its Legislature have chipped away at coastline restrictions designed to prevent the public from enjoying the state's expansive beaches. Slowly, almost dune by dune, more and more of the 127 miles of Atlantic Ocean shore has been opened for public use.

title: TALKS HALTED AGAIN
description: Whatever slight optimism that might have existed for a quick settlement in the baseball strike came crashing down on the 17th floor of the Doral Inn in Manhattan yesterday. The players rejected the owners' latest modifications of their free agent compensation proposal, and no further talks were scheduled.

title: Pro Wright
description: To the Business Editor: I heartily agree with John Wright's article, ''It Ain't Necessarily So About High Rates'' (June 21). In the pre-Depression days there was a Mormon entrepreneur who devoted a keen mind and restless energy to assembling an empire around himself and his family by expert practice of traditional acts of free enterprise. But soon after the Great Depression struck, Marriner Eccles saw, with dazzling clarity, that somethang was very wrong with Adam Smith's economics as it was operating at the time.

title: Editors' Choice
description: IF ON A WINTER'S NIGHT A TRAVELER, by Italo Calvino. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95.) A novel about reading fiction, by the Italian master.

title: DEAN OF DEALERS REFLECTS ON THE ART WORLD
description: It was 50 years ago this year that a young French dealer named Pierre Matisse first hung up his shingle in the Fuller Building at 41 East 57th Street. This is a volatile city, and nowhere more so than in the world of art, but 1931 has turned into l981 and Pierre Matisse is still there: same man, same address, same telephone number, same profession.

title: The World in Summary; ANOTHER EFFORT ON AFGHANISTAN
description: In 18 months since the Kremlin-sponsored coup and invasion, 85,000 Soviet soldiers in Afghanistan have paid a rising price in casualties. But Moscow last week showed no interest in a West European offer of a forum for negotiating its way out of the Afghan quagmire.

title: TUDOR P. WILLIAMS
description: Tudor P. Williams, who had been a special sales representative for the Statler Hotel and then was head of public relations in New York for Hiram Walker Inc., the liquor company, died Friday of a heart attack at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. Mr. Williams, a resident of Leonia, N.J., was 72 years old.

title: Gardening; WRONG TREES IN THE WRONG PLACES
description: MAN has imported exotic species that have become weeds and crowded out desirable native species. He has imported pests and diseases accidentally and in so doing has tipped the balance of nature away from his most favored species. He has planted the wrong species in the wrong places.

title: THE TRAP OF THINKING WE KNOW IT ALL
description: John H. Marburger 3d made these remarks in a speech at his recent inauguration as third president of the State University at Stony Brook.

title: URBAN TOUR
description: THE PHILOSOPHER IN THE CITY The Moral Dimensions of Urban Politics. By Hadley Arkes. 465 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $27.50. Paper, $6.95.

title: THE WEB OF JOGGERS' MYTHS
description: RECENTLY I entered a five-mile amateur road race sponsored by the Hamden Knights of Columbus. Having never before run five miles in one outing, I announced to my friends that my goal was to finish in under an hour. My unspoken prayer, of course, was to finish, period.

title: Young Athletes And Alcohol
description: To the Sports Editor: This is intended as a response to one aspect of George Vecsey's excellent article on scholastic alcohol use (The New York Times, June 21).

title: INTRUSIVE GEESE ORDERED OUT Club
description: ''EVERYONE complains about the nuisance Canada geese,'' said Steven Sanford, a conservation biologist with the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation in Stony Brook. So to mollify the local complaints, official transfer of the geese began last week under the guidance of the Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: Connecticut Housing; SECURITY SYSTEMS FIND DEMAND
description: ''WE can even detect someone jumping into your swimming pool,'' said the saleswoman earnestly as she leaned forward in the rocking chair.

title: A WINNING MIX OF ELECTRONIC INNOVATION AND LYRICISM
description: ''As Falls Wichita, So Falls Wichita Falls'' (ECM-1-1190), a collaboration between the young jazz guitarist Pat Metheny and the keyboardist and his quartet, Lyle Mays, blends elements of jazz, rock, and turn-of-the-century Impressionism into an evocative quasiclassical music of shimmering translucence. It represents a new direction for two musicians who are best known as jazz-fusion artists. The album takes its name from the 20-minute tone poem that fills up the first side. A sound collage that juxtaposes several layers of keyboard texture and spare guitar against the light, agitated rhythms of the Brazilian percussionist, Nana Vasconcelos, ''Wichita Falls'' is a moodily atmospheric work with the pictorial quality of a sound track. Though no program is given, the score strongly suggests an extraterrestrial visitation with some of the plot elements and mystical overtones of ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind.''

title: NEO-NAZIS ACCUSED IN LONDON RIOTS
description: William Whitelaw, the Home Secretary, called today for a full report on the racial violence in London last night that sent more than 60 policemen to hospitals with serious injuries and caused millions of dollars in property damage.

title: I LOVE L.I., BUT DOES IT LOVE ME?
description: THE beginning of summer brought no joy to this Queens resident. For the citizens of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, it meant having the opportunity once again to swim and fish and picnic at their marvelous parks and beaches. But from where I stand, summer is the time of year when a Maginot Line is drawn around these parks and beaches.

title: BLIND VOTES
description: To the Editor:

title: Haunert's Night
description: Paul Haunert of Westtown, N.Y., rode Night Train to first place in the $1,000 Intermediate jumpoff today at the I Love New York Horse Show.

title: Long Islanders; A PIONEER PILOT CLEARS SOME CLOUDS
description: TO talk to Elinor Smith is to turn back the clock and visit a Long Island in the days of aviation's infancy. It is a Long Island of places like Hazelhurst Field, which became Curtiss Field and Roosevelt Field; of planes like the Farman Pusher, the Jenny and the Waco 9, of pilots in goggles and leather jackets, with names like Bert Acosta, Red Devereaux, Jimmy Doolittle, Louis Gaubert and, of course, Charles Lindbergh.

title: Barbara DeLaney Is Engaged to Herbert C. Smith
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Robinson of Locust, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Robinson's daughter, Barbara Jean DeLaney, to Herbert Cortelyou Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Smith of Rumson, N.J.

title: FOREIGNERS SNAP UP THE HIGH-TECH JOBS
description: W HEN Vir Dhaka was growing up on a farm in Punjab, India, his father, seeing his son was not content to follow in his footsteps, encouraged him to go to college. He did, and later decided to pursue his graduate degree in America. That was 20 years ago. He has since risen through the ranks of the United States electronics industry to become vice president of Xerox's microelectronics research center in El Segundo, Calif.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; CENSORS RIDE INTO MARYLAND SUNSET
description: For 64 years, what Maryland's state board of censors saw was what Maryland got, or didn't get, in movies. But last weekend, having viewed its final film, ''The Great Muppet Caper,'' and given it a ''G'' rating, the nation's last state movie censorship agency faded from the scene.

title: 'TAINTED EVIDENCE' MURDER TRIAL TO OPEN
description: CAPE MAY COURTHOUSE A MURDER trial that will test the state's ability to skirt tainted evidence will begin in Superior Court here tomorrow. On trial is Dr. Harry D. Sugar, formerly of Vineland. He is charged with killing his second wife, Joan, in 1979 and burying her in their backyard.

title: SAN JOSE EMPLOYEES STRIKE OVER EQUAL PAY FOR WOMEN
description: Municipal employees in San Jose walked off their jobs today in a strike aimed at getting women the same pay as men for comparable work.

title: Philadelphia Club Takes Relay Title
description: Six meet records were broken as the Philadelphia Pioneers won the National Athletics Congress relay championships today at Rutgers Stadium.

title: MEXICANS' RIFT GROWS WITH PARIS
description: The French Government expressed concern today over Mexico's decision to ''suspend'' contracts held by French companies in retaliation for France's refusal to pay an extra $2 a barrel for Mexican oil.

title: U.S. BEATS JAPAN
description: Franklin Stubbs of Virgina Tech hit a homer in the sixth inning today, giving the Americans a 3-2 victory over Japan in the final game of the United States - Japan collegiate baseball series. The victory, before the crowd of 6,000, was the third for the American team. The Japanese had clinched the series by 4-1, with the Americans winning the final two games.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have been discussing among ourselves whether it is the function of botanical gardens just to identify, inventory and classify plants, or whether there are social problems of such consequence that we must become involved in the practical application of that knowledge.'' - Dr. James M. Hester, president of the New York Botanical Garden.

title: IS ELECTRONIC-GAMES BOOM HURTING THE MOVIES
description: LOS ANGELES CAPTAIN VIDEO'S ARCADE is nestled between a bank and a movie theater in West Los Angeles. The arcade is a few months old, one of thousands that have mushroomed across the country since the full impact of Space Invaders and Asteroids was felt last summer.

title: 11,000 A.M.C.  Cars Recalled
description: The American Motors Corporation is recalling about 11,000 of its 1981 Concords, Spirits and Eagles to repair a potential problem with the cruise control system.

title: 'Championship Season' To Be Made Into Movie
description: Jason Miller, the playwright and author who won a Pulitzer Prize and Tony in 1973 for ''That Championship Season,'' plans to make the play into a movie next fall. Much of the film will be shot in Scranton, his hometown.

title: Bolshoi Dancer Vanishes On a Trip to Istanbul
description: A Bolshoi ballerina slipped away from her companions in a crowded shopping area in Istanbul yesterday and tonight Turkish police sources said that the United States Consulate here had granted her political asylum.

title: 'The Next President ...'
description: No, says the Supreme Court, it's not up to the television networks to decide when Presidential campaigns begin. When Jimmy Carter wanted to buy a half-hour for a campaign documentary in December 1979, he was reasonably entitled to get it under the law. That decision strikes us as wholly correct. How paradoxical it was for the network news departments to cover the campaign with enthusiasm all through the fall but then, come winter, for their business departments to say, sorry, it's too early for campaign programs.

title: THE ROLE OF THE NUSRE IN MODERN HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: REFUGEES IN SALVADORAN CAMP ARE FORCED TO MOVE BY ARMY
description: A 9-year-old girl in a white dress used one hand to balance a wicker basket stuffed with six clucking chickens on her head. With the other she clutched the hand of her 3-year-old sister. Their dirty faces were freckled with gnats.

title: ARAB GROUP ENDS TALKS ON LEBANON
description: The special Arab League peacemaking committee adjourned its efforts today with a brief statement expressing ''relief'' at what it described as the ''easing of tension in Beirut and Zahle.''

title: Germans Qualify
description: East Germany, defending champion in the men's and women's competitions, easily qualified for next month's finals of the European Cup track and field competition as the semifinals were completed yesterday.

title: WEDDINGS GIVE MANY PREMARITAL JITTERS
description: A H, weddings! The breathless anticipation, the calls of congratulation, the happiness, the joy, the exhaustion, the anxiety, the migraines, the backaches, the seemingly endless series of colds, coughs and convulsive stomachs. It's a wonder engaged couples get to the church at all, let alone on time.

title: Budding Architect to Keep His Fantasy House
description: The house that Robert M. Van Pelt built will probably be allowed to stand, although with alterations to suit county inspectors. Robby Van Pelt is only 13 years old, but he built, by himself, a playhouse on three levels, putting in wall-to-wall carpeting, electricity, beds, tables and other accessories.

title: NEW MARKETER OF PAPAL VISIT SOUVENIRS
description: Mark McCormack, the head of a Cleveland business that promotes celebrities, has an impressive new client. His company, the International Management Group, has been hired by the Roman Catholic Church in Britian as the exclusive marketer of papal souvenirs for Pope John Paul II's schedule visit to Britain in 1982.

title: N.L.R.B. to Hear Players' Case Today
description: The National Labor Relations Board hearing into the players' charges of unfair labor practices by the owners begins today, but it is not expected to produce the controversy that had been anticipated because the owners who might have generated the controversy will not be testifying.

title: An Appraisal
description: For a long time the residents of this city did not know what to make of the Wainwright Building, a 10-story 1891 ''skyscraper'' right in the middle of downtown. The Wainwright is the work of Louis Sullivan, Chicago's great 19th-century architect, and its design played a crucial role in the development of the modern skyscraper. But to the casual eye it was no skyscraper at all; it was little, squat and old. No wonder, then, that plans were made in the early 1970's to replace the Wainwright with a parking lot.

title: WASHINGTON BLOCKING DELIVERY OF CUBAN JOURNALS
description: The Treasury Department, citing a 1917 law that bars trade with certain foreign countries in the event of a national emergency, has ordered Customs officers to block the delivery of about 30,000 copies of Cuban journals addressed to people in the United States.

title: What New Jersey Is Promised
description: What kind of fiscal medicine would be best for New Jersey's ailing economy? That's the key question for voters as they begin to evaluate Democrat James Florio and Republican Thomas Kean, the major candidates for Governor. They disagree in their diagnoses and prescriptions, so there may be a significant choice.

title: China Monetary Data
description: China today disclosed figures for its monetary reserves for the first time since the Communist takeover in 1949, stating that its gold reserves totaled 12.8 million troy ounces and its foreign exchange reserves $2.262 billion at the end of last year. The New China News Agency said that such figures would be issued regularly from now on.

title: Workers Try to Restore Power at Texas Hospital
description: Utility workers today checked flood-damaged generators at John Peter Smith Hospital here to see if full power could be restored to the health facility, which has been without lights and air conditioning for two days.

title: Sassafras Warning
description: The Outdoors column in SportsMonday last week mentioned that the author, Nelson Bryant, had long enjoyed a tea made from the bark of the roots of the sassafras tree. The article failed to mention a finding by the Food and Drug Administration that sassafras contains a carcinogen, a food flavoring called safrole, whose use or sale in interstate commerce has been banned by the F.D.A.

title: LeMond of Reno Wins Bicycle Title
description: Greg LeMond, a 20-year-old from Reno, won the overall title in the Coors International Bicycle Classic today by finishing more than four minutes ahead of his closest competitor. LeMond took the title despite failing to finish in the top 10 in today's final race, the Boulder Park Criterium, after losing a wheel.

title: TANGLEWOOD: A BERNSTEIN FOURTH
description: Tanglewood's 1981 season got under way last weekend. But Tanglewood is the summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, and this was the first weekend with symphony concerts in the Shed; last weekend was devoted to chamber music in the smaller Theater-Concert Hall, across the lawn.

title: China's Army Chief Calls For Loyalty to Party
description: Chief of Staff Yang Dezhi has called on China's armed forces to uphold the leadership of the Communist Party and follow its orders, remarks apparently aimed at diehard Maoists in the ranks.

title: SMUGGLING OF MEXICAN FUEL BRINGS BIG PROFITS
description: Every day the puzzled customs agents watched as the big trucks loaded with cinder blocks, hardly a prime Mexican export, rolled across the border into Texas. The agents assumed the drivers were up to something, but they had no idea what.

title: Commodities; Traders Find Safety In Pooling
description: MOST commodity futures speculators need not be reminded that they lost heavily during the first half of the year, when prices declined sharply in most markets. As usual, the losers were long the market because most small traders do not sell short. They are fearful of selling goods they do not own in the hope that prices will decline before they have to deliver them.

title: 3 U.S. Crews Score in Henley Finale
description: ON-THAMES, England, July 5 (AP) - United States crews won three trophies on the final day of the Henley Royal Regatta today. The University of Washington's junior varsity heavyweight eight won the Ladies' Challenge Plate, the Charles River Rowing Association eight took the Thames Cup and Holy Spirit High School of Absecon, N.J., the Princess Elizabeth Cup for schools.

title: NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN PLANS STUDY OF GLOBAL ECOLOGY PROBLEMS
description: The New York Botanical Garden, known to botanists and horticulturists throughout the world as a leading research center for plant sciences, has decided to establish three new institutes devoted to solving urgent social and ecological problems.

title: ON ELECTED WOMEN
description: The National Directory of Women Elected Officials: 1982, containing the most comprehensive available compilation of information and statistics about elected women throughout the country, will be made public on Friday at the convention of the National Women's Political Caucus in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: Mountains of Records
description: On the highest Blue Ridge mountain in North Carolina, there will be a track and field meet next weekend. But while there will be traditional 100-yard dashes and long jumps on Grandfather Mountain, the 25,000 people expected to attend will really be waiting for the men who toss the bale of hay, or upend the telephone pole, or throw the rock.

title: MARKET PLACE
description: By Robert Metz

title: AMTRAK TRAIN TAKES A BACKWARD ROUTE TO AVOID FLOODING
description: Richard Grant went to sleep after the Amtrak Zephyr pulled out of Chicago and rumbled westward. When he woke up, the scenery outside his car was going backward.

title: FIORI SINKS 100-FOOT PUTT, WINS WESTERN BY 4 SHOTS
description: The first professional golf tournament that Ed Fiori won, in 1979, was a gift when two players faltered. Today Fiori won his second, the Western Open, with a record score and a four-stroke margin.

title: Rodgers Pressed in 10,000-Meter Victory
description: Bill Rodgers, the winner of four New York and four Boston Marathons, won the New York City Pepsi Challenge series 10,000-meter race yesterday in 29 minutes 30 seconds.

title: Fireworks Plea Ends in Stabbing
description: A 29-year-old West Islip man was stabbed in the back when he tried to get a group of youngsters to stop shooting off fireworks near his mother's house, the police said.

title: E.E.C. STEEL PACT RATIFIED
description: An agreement readhed last week on measures to help the European Economic Community's crisis-hit steel industry was ratified Friday following Italian approval of the pact, Etienne Davignon, industry commissioner of the Common Market announced.

title: Radio Pager With Display
description: The Radiofone Corporation said it had started distributing the first radio pager, or ''beeper,'' that will receive and display numbers on a calculator-like display.

title: Russian Advances
description: FERRAND, France, July 5 (UPI) - Viktor Krovopouskov, the Soviet Union's 1976 and 1980 Olympic gold medalist, lost an early duel today but came safely through his first-round pool of the individual saber eliminations in the 39-nation world fencing championships.

title: Arrest at Office of Senator
description: policemen investigating an alarm at the office of Senator Gary Hart arrested a 27-year-old man who allegedly was going through desk drawers. John W. Mack of Florissant, Mo., was held for investigation of second-degree burglary in connection with the incident yesterday.

title: Getting Started
description: Blue sharks are numerous along the Atlantic Seaboard and are logical prey for the beginner. In summer in Northeast waters, blues sharks come in many sizes, from less than 50 pounds to more than 400, although 400-poundes are rare.

title: THE FRINGE, A BOSTON TRIO
description: GEORGE GARZONE, Richard Appelman and Bob Gulotti have been playing jazz together in Boston for more than six years. They call themselves the Fringe, but their chosen idiom is not so far from the contemporary jazz mainstream.

title: DEFINING AN ESTATE TAX LIMIT
description: ''By taxing estates heavily at death, the state marks its condemnation of the selfish millionaire's unworth life.'' - Andrew Carnegie, 1889, industrialist, multimillionaire, philanthropist, advocate of estate taxes.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: For both the American and National Leagues, what are the earliest dates for clinching a pennant? The fewest games for clinching a pennant?

title: U.S.G.A. Eyeing Move From Jersey
description: The United States Golf Association is considering moving its headquarters from New Jersey to Greensboro, a published report said today.

title: Ferragamo Fails in Debut
description: The Montreal Alouettes, despite the National Football League-style offense they acquired with much fanfare and even more money during the offseason, were routed, 48-8, by the British Columbia Lions last night in the Canadian Football League opener for both teams.

title: Eunice Whitney Bride Of D.P. Andrews
description: Eunice Elizabeth Whitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Newcomb Whitney of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Denton Paul Andrews, son of Denver Paul Andrews of Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, and the late Mrs. Andrews. The Rev. Gertrude Brown performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church.

title: KEYS TO MIDEAST PEACE AND STABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Jenkins Rides Idle Dice To Lake Placid Victory
description: Idle Dice and Rodney Jenkins, the most successful team in show-jumping history, raced through a faultless jump-off round in 30.841 seconds to capture first place at the Mercedes I Love New York Grand Prix before 3,500 fans at the Lake Placid Horse Show Grounds today.

title: Dwyer Is Captured By Noble Nashua
description: Noble Nashua, making his third start since finishing ninth in the Kentucky Derby, continued to show improvement by winning the $113,600 Dwyer at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: JERSEY RELAXES GARBAGE-DUMPING RULES AS TALKS BEGIN
description: With piles of trash growing in northern and central New Jersey, state officials will formally relax some garbage-dumping rules for 108 communities today as talks get under way for the first time since the garbage haulers' strike began six days ago.

title: A VERMONT REPUBLICAN GENTLY RESISTS REAGAN
description: The Senate's gentle maverick, Robert T. Stafford, came home from Washington this week, praising President Reagan even as he resisted him.

title: Venezuela Oil Revenue
description: Venezuelan oil revenues next year are expected to drop by 13 percent from this year's projected level of $16.33 billion, according to the preliminary 1982 budget presented to Congress. Next year's oil income is put at $14.2 billion.

title: FREE TO GO TO THE DEVIL
description: .4,0,285.2,2,285.2,0The debate goes on. Are authoritarian regimes as reprehensible as totalitarian regimes, or less reprehensible? Answers that the Government and conservative newspaper columnists give vary from ''less'' to ''hardly reprehensible at all.'' The debate, of course, is of awesome importance to our human rights policy - indeed, to our entire foreign policy.

title: COMING HOME TO JASPER: A TASTE OF THE RURAL LIFE
description: Donna Shook came back from Dallas after spending two days on the highway with her husband, Neil. So did Lee and Connie Welty from Wooster, Ohio, Hugh Potter from Phoenix and many others from towns and cities both near and far.

title: LOWER RATES ARE EXPECTED
description: The credit markets are waiting for the Federal Reserve to encourage lower short-term interest rates, but even those who expect such a move admit that it is far from clear whether a decline would continue through the second half of the year.

title: Cape Cod Resort Seeks To Limit Its Expansion
description: Officials of this Cape Cod resort have voted to stop issuing food and liquor licenses, as well as licenses to expand bars and restaurants.

title: PRO-REAGAN DEMOCRAT REFLECTS HEART OF CONGRESS
description: One treads carefully in this part of the world, if only because the annual rattlesnake roundup in the area last spring produced 45,000 rattlers, which were brought, squirming, in burlap bags and 50-gallon trash cans to a pit in the Nolan County Coliseum, where they were milked of their venom, skinned, fried and eaten.

title: OIL GLUT THREATENS MEXICO'S ECONOMY
description: The sudden drop in world oil prices has highlighted Mexico's dependence on its oil exports and has raised questions in banking and business circles about the wisdom of the Government's current strategy of rapid growth with inflation.

title: ELISABETH BARRETT WED TO A.P. MATSON
description: Elizabeth Esther Barrett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin G. Barrett of New York and Water Mill, L.I., was married in Berkeley, Calif., yesterday to Alexander Paul Matson, son of Prof. and Mrs. Wallace Matson of Berkeley. The Rev. Helon L. Chichester Jr. of St. Cuthbert's Episcopal Church in Oakland, Calif., performed the ceremony at the Berkeley Rose Garden.

title: A New Foreign Minister Is Confirmed in Iran
description: Hussein Musavi Khamenei, 35 years old, was confirmed today as Foreign Minister by Iran's Parliament and afterward outlined a foreign policy based on close cooperation with third world nations and a ''struggle against the U.S.A.''

title: 2 Men Die in Ambushes In the Basque Region
description: Unidentified gunmen killed an army lieutenant and a Civil Guard in Spain's northern Basque region today.

title: STUDY BY RESEARCH GROUP ASSERTS MX MISSILE IS NOT NEEDED
description: The Council on Economic Priorities, an independent research organization in New York, has joined a chorus of objections to the proposed MX mobile missile but has gone beyond most of the opposition to argue that the missile is unnecessary.

title: THE HIGHS AND LOWS OF SHARK FISHING
description: SHARK fishing is often a blend of boredom and intense excitement. The boredom comes during hours spent on the deck of a boat that is wallowing in giant swells far offshore while you wait for something to happen. The excitement when the sharks do appear is born of the average man's instinctive fear of them and the knowledge that his quarry could weigh 200, 500 or 1,000 pounds. Also, many sharks are superlative fighters and none is so spectacular as the powerful, leaping mako.

title: 19 SAVED FROM CANADIAN SHIP
description: A Canadian Coast Guard ship today rescued 19 survivors who had drifted at sea for two days after a research vessel sank with 32 people aboard.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL: WHEN THE WOMEN PLAY THE NOTES
description: FOR the second time in the course of the Kool Jazz Festival, women were featured in a program at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening. The first showcase for women, a week earlier, was called ''Wild Women Don't Have the Blues'' and focused on women as blues singers. The later program, ''Women Blow Their Own Horns,'' presented them as instrumentalists.

title: BROOKLYN BRIDGE SHUT AGAIN AS SAGGING CABLE IS FOUND
description: One of the stay cables that snapped and fell on the Brooklyn Bridge last Sunday was discovered sagging yesterday, and the roadway was closed briefly to traffic for the second weekend in a row.

title: Seeing the Americas, From the Bottom Up
description: On Jan. 26, 1977, George Meegan started walking north from Ushuaia, Tierra del Fuego, a town at the tip of South America that is the southernmost town in the world. His goal was to walk to the northernmost tip of the Americas, in Trudeau Bay, Alaska.

title: TV: WARM LOOK BACK AT W.P.A. AND THE ARTS
description: ''THE NEW DEAL FOR ARTISTS,'' a 90-minute documentary on WNET-TV tonight at 10 o'clock, returns to the 30's and examines a unusual project of Federal financing for the arts in this country. This is not a dispassionate treatise. Introduced by Studs Terkel and narrated by Orson Welles, it is a celebration of an experiment that ended only, as Mr. Terkel sees it, ''when the primitives, the Neanderthals, took over.''

title: BRAKES WERE OFF ON SUBWAY TRAIN INVOLVED IN CRASH
description: The power was on and the brakes were off when a subway train slammed into the rear of a stationary train in Brooklyn on Friday afternoon, investigators reported yesterday. The motorman was killed in the crash and 135 persons were injured.

title: Jazz-Film Month to Open at St. Peter's; St. Peter's Opening Jazz-Film Month
description: ''Stormy Weather,'' the 1943 musical with Lena Horne, Fats Waller, Cab Calloway and the Nicholas Brothers, will open a monthlong festival of jazz films tomorrow at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and East 53d Street. The sponsors of the festival, the first at the church, are the Citicorp Center Market and St. Peter's.

title: NEWSPAPER FORBIDDEN TO USE DATA FROM SUIT
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., July 2A Superior Court judge has barred a weekly newspaper from publishing articles containing information it gained in court proceedings after a man sued the paper for identifying him as the prime suspect in a murder.

title: Sports World Specials Weighty Problem
description: Angelo Fields, pro football's heaviest player, may be the first Houston Oiler to learn that Ed Biles, the new coach, is serious about being tougher than Bum Phillips, his predecessor.

title: MCENROE: SUPERSTAR OF MANY CONTRASTS
description: For two weeks, their names and faces competed for the attention of a country hungry for heroes. At times, their moves were monitored so closely that when she promised not to obey and he said he would try, tradition seemed shattered.

title: Back in Center Ring
description: The last legal act of ''United States of America v. Madison Square Garden Corporation'' ended quietly last week, and it may put the Garden back into the boxing business, from which it has been virtually knocked out of the ring.

title: Tax Collector Gets More Help
description: New York State has opened a Los Angeles field office to collect taxes from West Coast companies doing business in New York, the State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance said.

title: MARTENS WINS EVENT ON TOUR
description: Rene Martens of Belgium won the 10th stage of the Tour de France, covering the 120.6 miles between Nantes and Le Mans in 4 hours 23 minutes 9 seconds, but Bernard Hinault of France retained the overall lead.

title: AN ABUNDANCE OF HAIR ON CITY'S STREETS
description: Hair - the real thing, not the musical - is having a big revival this summer. What seems to be tons of hair can be seen bouncing around the city, more of it than has been fashionable for decades.

title: WEATHER REPORT AT FISHER
description: WEATHER REPORT opened the first of two jazz festival concerts at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday in peak form, and the group's peak form is the best that jazz-rock has to offer. Wayne Shorter, the group's saxophonist, turned in a formidable solo, his tenor seeming to spit notes wildly in all directions, and Joe Zawinul, who was co-founder of the band with Mr. Shorter more than 10 years ago, demonstrated how much color and orchestral richness he is able to get from his keyboard instruments.

title: Meryl Zucker Married To Matthew Neuren
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday, Meryl Robin Zucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Zucker of Great Neck, L.I., was married to Matthew Joel Neuren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Neuren of Baldwin, L.I. Rabbi A. David Arzt officiated.

title: Man of Distinction
description: He was the last man to get a hit off Sandy Koufax, and the man who made the final out for Baltimore in the 1969 World Series to give the Mets their miracle, and the only player to bat behind both Hank Aaron and Sadaharu Oh. He also tied the major league mark for home runs by a second baseman. Now he has added another distinction: He has managed a Met farm club to first place.

title: GEORGE J. SCULLY
description: George J. Scully, a stockbroker for more than 50 years who retired in 1977, died last Friday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Minor Quake Hits 45 Miles of Border
description: A minor earthquake shook a 45-mile area of the border between the United States and Canada for about eight seconds, according to the authorities.

title: SCHOLASTIC STARS: ALREADY HEROS
description: ONE at a time, the teen-agers walked through the fancy darkened dining room as Chris Schenkel, the master of ceremonies, called each name and the pianist played a song from the state each represented. ''A galaxy of high school superstars,'' Schenkel said. They were in the limbo of their last high school summer; no longer children, but not yet considered men and women. They stood in the spotlight as O.J. Simpson presented each one an award, a shiny trophy shaped like the numeral one. For many of them, the direction of their lives had changed forever. Already, they were reaching for No. 1.

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Ralph A. Bohlmann, president of Concordia Seminary here, today was elected president of the Lutheran Church Missouri Synod at the synod's convention.

title: SUNOHIO SOLVES ENVIRONMENTAL SNAG
description: In 1978 Norman E. Jackson faced a serious problem with his company, Sunohio. Operations of the 18-month-old enterprise, in the business of recycling electric transformer oil, were threatened unless the problem could be solved.

title: Changing Fields
description: There was always something special about J.C. Watts, the former Oklahoma quarterback. How many other undergraduates, after all, were gifted enough to make as many as four motivational speeches a week to businessmen or to youth groups? And how many football players can boast of capturing the Orange Bowl's most-valuable-player award for a second straight year? And then get drafted by the Jets? And then sign a Canadian League contract? And then, the next day, quit football?

title: Bridge: Severing Communications Is Difficult for the Defense
description: Some of the most interesting and difficult defensive plays in the game involve severing the declarer's communications. Even the expert finds such plays difficult to judge, and lesser players rarely think of them at all.

title: DESPITE CHILD LABOR LAWS, 8-YEAR OLDS CUT ASPARAGUS
description: In eastern Washington state, the earlymorning sun lights the field as Sergio Fernandez scans for asparagus stalks to harvest. With a rectangular bucket strapped to his waist, holding a long wooden-handled tool with a blade jutting from its end, Sergio moves expertly from one side of a row to another. He chooses a stalk, bends down to hold it, then digs into it beneath the earth, cutting it off with an audible crunch. At the end of a row, he crouches, puts his knife across his knee, and files the blade sharp again.

title: Bolivia Gets Plea on Unionist
description: The Paris branch of Amnesty International, the London-based human rights organization, called on the Bolivian Government today to release a jailed union leader, Genaro Flores, and allow him to be flown here for surgery on a bullet injury to his spine. Mr. Flores sustained the injury on July 19, when he was arrested for union activities.

title: LAWERNCE KRULE MARRIES SUSAN D. FADER IN JERSEY
description: Susan Deborah Fader and Lawrence Jay Krule, both of whom work for General Foods in White Plains, were married yesterday in the sanctuary of Congregation Ahavas Torah in Englewood, N.J. Rabbi Jay Karzan of Des Plaines, Ill. performed the ceremony assisted by Rabbi Avrahom Marmorstein of New York.

title: YEVGENY KHARITONOV DIES AT 40, WAS NONCONFORMIST SOVIET WRITER
description: Yevgeny Kharitonov, one of seven younger Soviet writers whose efforts to form an experimental literary workshop led to a series of clashes with the authorities last year, died of a heart attack here June 29, literary sources reported. He was 40 years old.

title: KEYS TO MIDEAST PEACE AND STABILITY
description: Frol ttf. Edward Said I would expect more objectivity about the reasons for Arab failures and not putting the blame on others (''The Arabs Should Face Their Real Priorities,'' Op-Ed June 21).

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: Everybody remembers his or her first magic show. Mine was in a garage in the dark. I passed out bowls of peeled grapes and described them as the devil's eyeballs. After that, by the light of a lantern on a wall of cinderblocks, there were card tricks and some pigeons we pretended to decapitate. The attraction of magic, to the amateur magician, derived from the fact that it wasn'tmagic at all; it was science in the service of illusion. Having sent in the magazine coupon and received our kit, we knew how everything worked toward achieving the ecstatic grasp.

title: Prost Captures Grand Prix
description: Alain Prost of France drove his Renault Turbo to victory in a two-heat French Grand Prix today, winning on aggregate time after a thunderstorm stopped the race for nearly an hour.

title: McEnroe in Tumultuous Departure
description: John McEnroe, the men's singles champion at Wimbledon, said goodbye to London today amid a shower of glass and broken china left by photographers chasing him.

title: Stancharry Scores; Pincay Suspended
description: Stancharry gained a long early lead and went on to capture the $80,900 Silver Screen Handicap by two lengths today at Hollywood Park.

title: Ann Edith Bookman Wed
description: Ann Edith Bookman, daughter Dr. John J. Bookman of New York, and the late Ruth Lowe Bookman, was married yesterday in Belmont, Mass., to Eric Buehrens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Arthur Buehrens of Kingstown, R.I. The ceremony was performed at Habitat, a former private estate, by the bridegroom's brother, the Rev. John Buehrens, a Unitarian minister of Knoxville, Tenn. He was assisted by the Rev. Alice Hageman, minister of the Congregational Church of the Covenant in Boston. Dr. Bookman is associate professor of clinical medicine at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. The bridegroom's father is marine superintendent at the University of Rhode Island School of Oceanography in Kingstown.

title: San Mateo, Calif., Honors Veterans of Vietnam
description: The only city to offer an official welcome to returning Vietnam veterans staged a spectacular air show today to top off a festive weekend dedicated to the men who fought in the Southeast Asia war.

title: GAIL ALICE EPPS IS BRIDE
description: The marriage of Gail Alice Epps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Wallace Epps of Brooklyn, to Edmund Arthur Gould, son of Douglas Gould of Jamaica, Queens, and the late Mrs. Gloria Gould, took place yesterday at St. Luke's and St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. William Edward Smith performed the ceremony. The bride, a learning disability consultant with the Massapequa (L.I.) school district, was graduated from Elmira College and has a master's degree in special education from Hofstra University. Mr. Gould was graduated from Hofstra's Division of Engineering and is a consultant with the Digital Equipment Corporation in New York.

title: Financial Losses Seen As Music Festival Ends
description: A two-day country music festival, which drew a crowd far smaller than the 50,000 to 100,000 people expected by promoters, ended today and was apparently a financial failure.

title: Sinatra Sues On Cassettes
description: Frank Sinatra and Liza Minnelli have joined in a multimilliondollar suit against a company that they say is selling video cassettes of their performances without authorization.

title: French Sink Drifting Tanker
description: The French Navy sank a Greek tanker today that had been drifting in the Mediterranean for three months with a cargo of highly volatile naphtha on board, a navy spokesman said. The 12,780-ton Kavo Kambanos was abandoned by its crew on April 4 off Tarragona, Spain, after a fire broke out.

title: JAZZ: THE COMEBACK OF MILES DAVIS
description: MILES DAVIS'S Sunday evening concerts at Avery Fisher Hall were the most eagerly awaited events of this year's jazz festival. Mr. Davis, who has periodically forged new directions for jazz since his emergence as a teen-age trumpeter in the l940's, was making a comeback after spending close to five years out of the public eye. Tickets for his two concerts sold quickly despite their price (orchestra seats were $25), and the capacity crowd that awaited the first show seemed quietly expectant.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP NAMES U.S. DIRECTOR
description: The reverse Lend-Lease in the ad game continues this week as the Interpublic Group of Companies announces that Ann Burdus, 47-year-old chairman of McCann & Company, the British arm of Interpublic's a largest component, is coming to town and into the new position of director of strategic planning and development at Interpublic.

title: Washington Watch; Soviet Pipeline And the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Administration is considering revoking a license granted in the final weeks of the Carter Administration to Caterpillar Tractor for pipe-laying equipment for the projected 3,000 mile Yamal pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: U.D. JUDGE, OUSTED IN MICHIGAN, FACES INQUIRY ON ACTIONS
description: Judge Harry G. Hackett's 26 years on the Federal Bankruptcy Court have ended here, but not the investigations into allegations of favoritism and drunkenness that led to his ouster from the bench.

title: WELLS, RICH RESIGNS DINERS CLUB ACCOUNT
description: Wells, Rich, Greene has resigned the Diners Club account, which doesn't matter much, since the client has just been acquired by Citicorp, which plans to merge it into its Carte Blanche card operation.

title: ROSS MARTIN, ACTOR KNOWN FOR TV ROLES
description: Ross Martin, an actor who appeared in more than 200 film, stage and television productions and who was best known for his role in the television series ''The Wild Wild West,'' died Friday. He was 61 years old.

title: Try a Bipartisan Business Tax Cut
description: Republicans and Democrats alike want to reduce business taxes - and for good reason. Inflation has cut deeply into the profitability of American corporations, dampening incentives to invest in productive technology. But consensus over ends has long since been overshadowed by partisan division over means. The public is the loser.

title: W. Side Highway Closed for an Hour
description: The southbound lane of the West Side highway was closed between 57th and 79th Streets for about one hour yesterday while a City Department of Highway crew replaced a steel plate that had shifted in the roadway near 59th Street.

title: Jersey Physician To Go On Trial
description: The trial of a former Vineland, N.J., physician accused of killing his wife was scheduled to begin today in Superior Court here.

title: Melba Moore Still Has Hopes for the Melting Pot
description: Eleven years ago Melba Moore rose quickly to stardom in ''Purlie,'' the exuberant musical about blacks and whites working together to ease oppression on the plantation. Tomorrow she will begin rehearsing her role again for a cable television production of the musical to be shot later this month.

title: ZULU CLANS STEPPING UP BLOOD FEUDS
description: A white lieutenant in a South African Army Reserve paratroop unit is standing trial here on charges of running arms and hiring himself out as a mercenary to a clan of Zulus who are engaged in a blood feud that started in a rural area but is now felt regularly in such urban centers as Johannesburg.

title: ASBESTOS SUBSTITUTE SOUGHT
description: The Interior Department expects domestic use of the sometimes deadly mineral asbestos to remain steady, and it expects use elsewhere to grow at an average rate of 4.5 percent through the year 2000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: *Avis Rent a Car System Inc. has named August Retrone vice president-construction and engineering.

title: NONPROFIT GROUPS CALL ON INDUSTRY TO REPLACE U.S. AID
description: Large companies from coast to coast report a surge in appeals for grants from antipoverty groups, universities, cultural agencies and other nonprofit organizations scrambling to replace money they fear they will lose as a result of Reagan Administration budget cuts.

title: THE REGION
description: A powerful firecracker that exploded in the hand of a 14-year-old boy blew off the end of his middle finger, the police said.

title: 'Morning's at Seven' To Get 5 New Players
description: Nancy Kulp, Carmen Mathews and King Donovan will replace Elizabeth Wilson, Teresa Wright and Richard Hamilton, respectively, tomorrow in Paul Osborne's comedy, ''Morning's at Seven,'' at the Lyceum Theater.

title: SOVIET INTENTIONS IN POLAND UNCLEAR AFTER 3-DAY TALKS
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko returned to the Soviet Union from Poland today after three days of talks with Polish leaders, but a joint communique left unclear what Moscow intends to do about Poland's push for a more flexible form of Communism.

title: PIGGYBACK SAMPLING SYSTEM
description: Just over the horizon, awaiting the completition of a sizable test, is a mass, co-op sampling system that can be targeted as well as magazines, because it will piggyback on magazines.

title: Egyptian to Visit 7 Nations
description: A leading Egyption official, Boutros Boutros Ghali, said today he would visit seven Latin American countries next week to discuss their possible participation in the international force that is to police Sinai after Israel withdraws next year.

title: Petrochemical Plants
description: Shell Canada Ltd. and Imperial Oil Ltd. said today that construction would begin soon on two recently approved styrene petrochemical plants at Bruderheim. The plants are scheduled to go into operation in 1984, the companies said.

title: CUBA'S CLOSE BRUSH WITH A PRE-EMPTIVE STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: AT CUBA CLUB, PARTY'S OVER
description: The Rovers Athletic Club, a luxurious remnant of the British Empire, managed unobtrusively to survive the first 20 years after the Cuban Revolution but now seems about to die, the victim of its own allure.

title: A Plan for Discharged Mental Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: WEAK PRICES DIVIDE THE COCOA ALLIANCE
description: Cocoa beans, the foundation for chocolate and other sweets, are at the center of an increasingly bitter controversy between cocoa producing and consuming countries.

title: THE ROLE OF THE NURSE IN MODERN HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Smith Capitol Hill Rumblings
description: TWO bills bearing directly on professional sports are under consideration by the Congressional Subcommittee on Monopolies and Commercial Law. One would eliminate baseball's treasured exemption from antitrust law; the other would, in effect, prohibit Al Davis from moving the Oakland Raiders to Los Angeles.

title: DR. H.K. KOH WEDS DR. CLAUDIA ARRIGG
description: Dr. Claudia Anne Arrigg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Fred G. Arrigg of Andover, Mass., was married there yesterday to Dr. Howard Kyongju Koh, son of Dr. and Mrs. Kwang Lim Koh of New Haven. The Rev. Joseph Keffer, the Rev. Lucien Malouf, and the Rev. Carleton P. Jones performed the ceremony jointly at the Catholic Church of St. Augustine.

title: ADDENDUM
description: Family Weekly, a Sunday newspaper per supplement, will increase its advertising rates 3 percent, effective Sept. 13.

title: THREE SIGMA RESEARCH GETS MARKETING OFFICER
description: Edgar A. Roll, former president of the Adverrtising Research Foundation, is the new vice president/marketing of the Three Sigma Research Center, suppliers of syndicated audience data for newspapers.

title: NEW FEARS ON 1 2-POINT PRIME RISE
description: The decision by two major banks to raise their prime rates last week by a half point, to 20 1/2 percent, has triggered worries that interest rates might be poised for another upward surge.

title: ROYAL BALLET: SEASON ENDS IN BURST OF NEW CASTING
description: THE Royal Ballet ended its first New York season in five long years with a final burst of new casting Friday and Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House. On Friday, Lesley Collier took on the lead female part in Sir Frederick Ashton's ''Scenes de Ballet,'' in its way a signature role in English ballet. The dance itself is a direct response to the ballet's score by Igor Stravinsky, and even follows his precepts as to the number and gender of dancers to be used. And the music provided the driving impulse for Miss Collier's performance.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The industrial nations seem to be splitting into two rival economic camps: those that favor stimulating their economies to create jobs for the unemployed and those that are eager to persevere with the battle against inflation.

title: LUTZ-SMITH DUO A LONG-RUN HIT
description: WIMBLEDON, England AFTER 17 years, the partnership is still going well, Stan Smith said the other day, even though he and Bob Lutz lost their Wimbledon doubles final to John McEnroe and Peter Fleming.

title: BLIZZARD WINS, 3-0
description: Tore Cervin, Tibor Gemeri and Gordon Sweetzer scored goals today as the Toronto Blizzard defeated the Jacksonville Tea Men, 3-0, to break an eight-game losing streak.

title: CABANAS SPARKS COSMOS VICTORY
description: With the action becoming exciting at the end, the Cosmos defeated the Tulsa Roughnecks, 3-2, in sudden-death overtime tonight at Giants Stadium before a crowd of 33,673.

title: Boeing Jet Sale
description: Indian Airlines said today that it would buy four Boeing 737-200's for delivery in the fall of 1982. It did not disclose the price. The purchases will help the airline, which operates mainly on domestic routes, carry additional traffic for the Asian Games opening here in November 1982, a spokesman said.

title: STAGE: CANTON INCIDENT, CIRCA 1821, AT PERRY ST.
description: IMAGINE ''Pacific Overtures'' without the Stephen Sondheim score and Boris Aronson sets, and you'll have a rough idea of ''Extenuating Circumstances,'' a new historical drama at the Perry Street Theater. This plodding play, an object lesson in the moral ambiguities of 19th-century American imperialism, dramatizes obvious points with a pedantry worthy of ''Sunrise Semester.''

title: Hong Kong Growth Lag
description: Hong Kong's economic growth will slow to from 6.5 to 8 percent this year from 9 percent in 1980, the Bank of America said today.

title: TIME TO CHANGE RULES
description: The indecisive result of Israeli elections probably means another bitter campaign within a year or less. It certainly means that the chance of dealing with the country's formidable economic and social problems is further delayed, and no new hope has appeared for the foundering peace negotiations.

title: 2 MEN ARE KILLED, 4 OTHERS WOUNDED AS SLASHER STRIKES
description: Two men were slain and at least four men were seriously wounded in Manhattan last night and early this morning in a series of apparently unprovoked attacks by a man wielding a knife, the police said.

title: France Views '81 Economy
description: French gross domestic product is expected to rise five-tenths of 1 percent this year after a 1.1 percent increase in 1980, the Economy Ministry said today.

title: BEGIN'S BLOC GETS ONE-SEAT MARGIN IN ISRAELI VOTING
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Likud bloc took a one-seat lead over the Labor Alignment today as the tally of votes in the June 30 parliamentary election neared completion.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in late editions Tuesday on Fred Silverman's resignation as president of NBC incorrectly described the position he held at age 25. At that time, in 1963, he became director of daytime programs for CBS.

title: Police Slay Murder Suspect
description: A 22-year-old man wanted in the slaying of a variety store clerk was fatally shot by the police today, the state Attorney General's office said. Attorney General Gregory Smith said David Dearborn of Kingston was shot after two Kingston policemen stopped him and a companion in a car on Route 111 in Hampstead.

title: 'The Cup Is Different'
description: TENNIS players change confidence almost as often as they change racquets. John McEnroe returned to New York on the Concorde yesterday with his Wimbledon trophy after an incident with some photographers at London's Heathrow Airport. Today he will be playing tennis again, preparing to represent the United States in the Davis Cup quarterfinals against Czechoslovakia, the holder of the trophy, at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows this weekend.

title: DIX HILLS, N.Y. - Among the more demagogic propositions being palmed off on the public is the notion that crime will be substantially reduced if only ''bleeding heart'' judges stop turning defendants loose to sin again. Whenever an accused criminal free on bond while awaiting trial is charged with committing another offense of the newsworthy variety, we hear cries for every remedy from outrageously high bail to the even more repugnant policy of preventive detention.
description: We are being subjected anew to rumbling echoes of Ronald Reagan's campaign oratory, emphasizing a hard line on crime, from doom-sayers of shallow perspective. ''Keep the thugs in jail,'' they demand, ignoring the fact that our jails already are hopelessly overcrowded training schools for the very crimes they purport to deter. Just last week, the New York State Assembly responded to such emotional appeals by passing a bill requiring revocation of bail for any defendant who commits certain violent or otherwise serious crimes while out on bond.

title: JANICE ATTERMAN MARRIED
description: The marriage of Janice Cynthia Atterman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Atterman of Maplewood, N.J., to Ronald Stuart Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kaplan of Cranford, N.J., took place yesterday at the Short Hills in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbis Zev Segal and Oscar Kline performed the ceremony. The bride is a certified public accountant with the Caltex Petroleum Corporation in New York. Her husband. a lawyer, is on the staff of Administrative Law Judge Steven Lefelt in Newark.

title: HELPING PEOPLE SAY WHAT THEY MEAN
description: He: If you hadn't taken so long to put on your makeup, we wouldn't be late again, as usual. She:Half the time we're late it's your fault. You drive like a turtle. The tone of this exchange, if not its precise content, and the damper it puts on an evening and a relationship, are all too familiar to millions of couples. It is symbolic of a widespread problem - communication failure -cited by marriage and family counselors as the single most common cause of marital breakups today.

title: Dynamics Gets NASA Official
description: Alan M. Lovelace, acting administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, announced today that he will leave NASA on July 11 to join the General Dynamics Corporation as vice president for science and engineering.

title: PEOPLE
description: Paul Miller has been named president of Gottlieb-Miller Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., formerly the Gottlieb Group.

title: Index; International
description: Reporter's notebook: At Cuban club, the party's over A2 Zulu blood feuds are on the rise A3 Around the World A5 Government/Politics Study by research group says MX missile is unnecessary A10 Social Security's problems to be tackled anew by Congress A10 Leader of pro-Reagan Democrats knows about cautious steps A11 Vermont Senator praises and re- sists Reagan proposals A11 Inquiry continues on judge ousted from U.S. bankruptcy court A16 Sanitation Department showing concern over worker morale B1 General Around the Nation A8 An appraisal of the Wainwright Complex in St. Louis A8 Coping with brushfires an L.A. summer ritual A8 Amtrak train, on 18-hour detour, backs up to avoid flooding A8 Protecting gains is focus of N.A.A.C.P. convention A9 Newspaper barred from using in- formation from lawsuit A13 On a block of West 42d Street, an afterhours netherworld B1 Folks come from near and far to Old Home Day in Jasper, N.Y. B2 Style Relationships: Weddings give many the jitters A12 Helping people to say what they mean A12 An abundance of hair on city's streets A12 Religion Lutheran Church Missouri Synod elects new president A9 News Analysis Bernard Gwertzman on strain in U.S.-India relations A1 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Prost's Renault wins French Grand Prix C3 Baseball: Steinbrenner says he has baseball peace idea C6

title: Steinbrenner Says He Has Peace Plan
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, intends to request a meeting today with Ray Grebey and Lee MacPhail in order to present some proposals for settling the 24-day-old baseball strike.

title: COST-OF-LIVING RAISES A TARGET AS CONGRESS EXAMINES SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Social Security checks that gave 23 million Americans an 11 percent increase last week to compensate for another year of inflation may be more generous, or at least more prompt, than those produced by the Social Security system in the years to come.

title: Quarterhorse Race To Higheasterjet
description: Higheasterjet, repeating his winning performance in last year's All American Futurity, scored a wire-to-wire victory today in the $508,855 Rainbow Derby for quarterhorses at Ruidoso Downs.

title: JOHN BUNCH IN PIANO BILL
description: JOHN BUNCH organized his jazz festival piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday as a series of medleys, several of which applied extroverted rhythmic treatments to familiar tunes by the likes of George Gershwin and Jerome Kern. A Gershwin medley that concentrated on material from ''Porgy and Bess'' exploded into a stomping shuffle on ''There's a Boat That's Leaving Soon for New York,'' and Mr. Bunch transformed Kern's ''Who Cares'' into an eightto-the-bar boogie-woogie.

title: A NEW BOOK TO HELP PEOPLE COMMUNICATE
description: One of Madison Avenue's favorite ho-to authors - Kenneth Roman, president of Ogilvy & Mather - has struck again.

title: 16-HOUR DEPARTMENT STORE OF STYLES
description: Rain today kept the attendance under 2,000 and delayed some musicians, but it did nothing to dampen the enthusiasm of those who made it to the Center for the Arts at the State University College for a two-day Jazzfair program presented by the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Baby, Ignored by Mothe a Happy Birthday

title: THE ROLE OF THE NURSE IN MODERN HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTECTING PAST GAINS BY BLACKS A KEYNOTE OF N.A.A.C.P. PARLEY
description: DENVER, July 4Protecting gains made by blacks in a conservative atmosphere of Government retrenchment was the major task set before the 72d annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which ended here last night.

title: MONDAY, JULY 6, 1981; The Economy
description: Economists are sharply divided over the near-term course for interest rates following the decision last week by two major banks to raise their prime rates by a half-point, to 20 1/2 percent. Some find the action a sign of unexpectedly strong loan demand. But others see rates falling within weeks. (Page D1.)

title: WAS FOE OF CASTRO
description: Manuel Urrutia Lleo, the first President of revolutionary Cuba, who later became a vocal foe of Fidel Castro, died yesterday at St. John's Hospital in Queens. He was 79 years old.

title: FATHER'S DAY
description: Leo Willette of the National Parks Service was walking around Wolf Trap, the Virginia music center outside of Washington.

title: Education Group Acts On Rights and Elections
description: The National Education Association convention has reaffirmed its support for the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution and approved a resolution urging news organizations to delay projecting election winners until all polls have closed.

title: 225 Haitians Land in Florida
description: As many as 225 Haitian refugees came ashore in south Florida today, the authorities said. A Dade County police spokesman said about 25 refugees arrived at Haulover Beach and about 200 more landed on Key Biscayne. Immigration and Naturalization Service officials arrived with buses to take the Haitians to a processing center.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: KNOWING THE SCORE

title: Belgian Jobless Rate
description: Belgium's unemployment rate, based on the number of jobless drawing unemployment benefits, rose slightly in June, to 9.2 percent, from 9.1 percent in May, according to unadjusted figures released last Friday by the National Employment Office. The number of jobless at the end of June rose to 379,052 from 378,337 in May. In June 1980, the unemployment rate was 7.2 percent.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY'S OURS
description: ,0,193.2,2,193.2,0I have to admit that I never was a Ronald Reagan fan. But after watching Jimmy Carter spend four years seeing if he could violate every campaign promise he made in 1976, I thought that at least President Reagan would set a new example of veracity for an office that had been badly rocked for a decade and a half.

title: ELIZABETH SKLAR, TEACHER, IS BRIDE
description: Elizabeth Cynthia Sklar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Sklar of Morristown, N.J., was married there yesterday to Henry M. Hoyt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt, also of Morristown. Howard Radest, a leader of the American Ethical Union and director of the Ethical Culture School in New York, performed the ceremony at the Sklar home.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's publicized moves to enhance military relations with Pakistan and China have had the predictable consequence of further souring ties with India. American and Indian officials see no early improvement in the situation.

title: MISS STEPHENSON WINNER
description: Jan Stephenson rolled in a 15-foot birdie putt on the 18th green today, averting a possible three-way playoff and winning the $200,000 Peter Jackson Classic at the Summerles Golf Club.

title: MANIC TOPS KICKS
description: Gordon Hill got his team-leading 10th goal of the season, and Alan Willey and Thompson Usiayan also scored as the Montreal Manic broke a two-game losing streak today with a 3-1 victory over the Minnesota Kicks.

title: BANKERS TRUST SHIFT IN PERSONNEL SETUP
description: Just about everyone at the Bankers Trust Company seems to agree that Robert L. Russell is a "nice guy," which often is not considered a positive qualification for the director of personnel.

title: ACCOUNTS
description: General Cigar and Tobacco Company to Warren Pfaff Inc., for its Macanudo and Partagas cigars.

title: SALUTE TO SANITATIONMEN AIMS TO COUNTER MORALE PROBLEM
description: New York City's Department of Sanitation has been thinking about morale. Managers and workers agree that spirits have risen slightly since a few years back, when workers were being laid off and supervisors demoted, equipment was deteriorating and the city was only getting dirtier. Such troubles, say sanitation officials, and the extra scorn they brought on sanitationmen seem to have bottomed out.

title: A NETHER WORLD: A BLOCK OF 42ST
description: It is after midnight on West 42d Street and the last theater patron is gone, along with the tourists, the flower peddlers and the would-be missionaries.

title: LIMITED OFFERING OF BONDS
description: This week's calendar of corporate bond offerings is scanty because underwriters were unable to predict market conditions after the three-day weekend. Like other market participants, they are waiting to see what direction prices will take following money-supply announcements due today and July 10, and in the wake of tomorrow's meeting of monetary policy makers of the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee.

title: Alaska Oil Lease Sale
description: The Federal Bureau of Land Management said it had set Dec. 16 as the date for the first oil and natural gas lease sale in the national petroleum reserve of Alaska. The agency said that 1.5 million acres would be offered at the sale, which will take place in Fairbanks. Lands to be offered will be identified and the final environmental assessment will be released on Oct. 1, it said.

title: PRESIDENT SELECTED FOR DAILEY & ASSOCIATES
description: Philip Joanou, 48, managing director of the Los Angeles office of Dailey & Associates, the largest agency with headquarters on the Coast, has been named president and chief operating officer of the agency, as Peter H. Dailey, 51, the chief executive, moves up to chairman.

title: A SUMMER RITUAL IN LOS ANGELES: COPING WITH BRUSH FIRES
description: It's the time of year in Los Angeles when people start to look out the windows of their homes and wonder whether the brown grass and brush growing outside might soon be lethal.

title: Citizen Watch President
description: Rokuya Yamazaki, 64, last Wednesday became president of the Citizen Watch Company of Tokyo, one of the world's largest sellers of quartz watches. He succeeded Eiichi Yamada, 74, who was named chairman.

title: 700 Gallons of Gas Spill at L.I. Station
description: A night attendant's apparent carelessness and the work of vandals resulted in 700 gallons of gasoline being spilled early yesterday at a service station here, according to the police.

title: Boussac Plants to Stay Open
description: The ailing Boussac-Saint-Freres Textiles Company will remain open and there will be no layoffs, union leaders said Friday after a meeting with France's Labor Minister, Jean Auroux.

title: The U.N. Today; July 6, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the world dis- armament conference - 3 P.M.

title: JUDITH C. SILVERMAN WED TO LAWERNCE SLETZINGER
description: Judith Carol Silverman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Silverman of Cranford, N.J., was married yesterday to Lawrence S. Sletzinger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Meyer Sletzinger of North Plainfield, N.J. The ceremony was performed jointly by Rabbi Moshe Samber of Temple Beth El of Plainfield and Rabbi Norman Pauker, an uncle of the bridegroom, at Temple Beth Sholom in Livingston, N.J.

title: JERSEY'S PORTS THREATENED WITH LOSS OF NEW YORK CITY'S FIREBOAT SERVICE
description: After more than a century of providing fireboat protection to port facilities in New Jersey communities bordering the Hudson River and New York Bay, New York City officials are seeking to end the service, which last year cost city taxpayers an estimated $50,000.

title: Steel Output Off
description: Steel production fell to 2.379 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 1.7 percent from the previous week's 2.419 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Geologist Is Introduced to Life Sciences
description: Until a few months ago George Granata, a 30-year-old geologist, had been looking forward to taking his family to an overseas post in the oil fields of Libya. But that all changed on June 1 when his wife, Janice, 23, gave birth to quintuplets in Toledo, Ohio.

title: Drop in Prime Is Forecast
description: The prime lending rate in the United States could fall to between 10 percent and 13 percent by the end of the year if the United States stays on the right track as far as money supply growth is concerned, Beryl Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, told a Swiss newspaper today.

title: Wayne Simpson: A Price for Persistence
description: From another room in his house, Wayne Simpson hears the tentative plinking of a piano. His 7-year-old son Jason is taking lessons. It is a pleasant sound to Simpson, in some ways a better one than the pop of a baseball into a mitt; Jason is also a good athlete, like his father.

title: Honda May Start Production Early
description: The Honda Motor Company, Japan's third-largest auto exporter, indicated that it may start compact car production at its new plant near Columbus, Ohio, up to six months ahead of schedule.

title: The Talk of Honolulu
description: The tourist at at Waikiki, everyone's natural prey, soon develops the wariness of a rabbit near the fox den because sidewalk hawkers for shared-time condominiums lurk in almost every block.

title: OBSCURED VISION; Retractable Towers
description: The Port Authority's engineers have proved that they can do anything, including building a bus terminal around its buses as gently as a nurse makes up an occupied hospital bed. But they still have a big problem with the World Trade Center.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
United States Deposits
description: The Treasury said today that it had asked the Federal Reserve banks to notify participating tax and loan note depositaries that the United States would directly deposit $1.44 billion in their accounts tomorrow. This represents 20 percent of the total amount that these depositaries can accept under Treasury procedures for one-day notice.
Topics Obscured Vision Intruders in the Dust

title: CHINESE PARTY'S EVALUATION GLOSSES OVER FORMER SOVIET RELATIONSHIP
description: Even though the Russians and the Chinese parted company 21 years ago, the Soviet memory lingers on in China. In train stations, airports, guesthouses, factories and libraries, as well as in the minds of thousands of Soviet-trained Chinese, the Russian language, its designs, its methods and its ideas continue to dot China's landscape.

title: Trial of Ellenberger, Ex-Coach, Goes to Jury
description: Norm Ellenberger, the University of New Mexico's former basketball coach, may have violated National Collegiate Athletic Association regulations, but not state criminal law, his lawyer told a state district court jury today.

title: E.E.C. Backs Free Trade
description: The European Economic Community would like this month's economic meeting of industrialized countries to make a strong statement in favor of free trade, a top Common Market official said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE LAST WORD

title: 8 Tora-san Comedies
description: The Japan Film Center will show eight episodes from Japan's popular Tora-san film series at Japan House, 333 East 47th Street. The first film, Thursday at 7:30 P.M., will be ''Tora-san, Our Lovable Tramp,'' made in 1969. The program will end Aug. 27 with ''Foster Daddy Tora,'' which was made last year and is the latest episode in the comedy series.

title: The Legislature as Motorman
description: Mayor Koch and Governor Carey were arguing about the Governor's tardiness at a Financial Control Board meeting. The board haggled busily over the impact of a $400 million transit deficit on the New York City budget. So who, finally, was left to take charge of the transit problem? Surprise: the New York Legislature, particularlq Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink and Senate Majority Leader Warren Anderson.

title: ANTITRUST LAWYERS BELIEVE U.S. WON'T BAR TAKEOVER
description: Antitrust lawyers in private practice said today that it was unlikely that the Government would attempt to stop outright the acquisition of Conoco by Du Pont, even though it would be largest takeover ever.

title: CHIEF TO LEAVE PRIME COMPUTER
description: Chief executives tend to bow out when their companies are in trouble, but the opposite has occurred at Prime Computer Inc., a fast-growing manufacturer of mini-computers. Kenneth G. Fisher, 50 years old, announced yesterday that he was resigning as Prime Computer's president and chief executive officer ''to pursue other interests, probably of a nonbusiness nature.''

title: CONNECTICUT SETS ZONES TO AID URBAN BUSINESS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today signed legislation making Connecticut the first state, according to Connecticut officials, to authorize urban ''enterprise zones'' designed to stimulate economic development in depressed areas of cities.

title: NORPAC EXPLORATION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CITY TRIES TO REDUCE BIKE ACCIDENTS
description: With the summer cycling season in full swing, New York City officials have begun a ''safety offensive'' that they hope will reduce the number of accidents involving bicycles in traffic.

title: Hunt Oil Unit To Buy Union Life
description: The Union Life Insurance Company of Little Rock will be sold to an Arkansas affiliate of the Hunt Oil Company, the two companies announced.

title: PRODUCER PRICES AS A MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON Although its glamorous sister, the Consumer Price Index, gets more public attention, it is the Producer Price Index that corporate strategists, bond traders, economic forecasters and other professionals regard as the more important measure of inflation.

title: LET THE MILITARY JOIN THE ANTI-DRUG POSSE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK'S ARTISTS NEED LOFTS TO SURVIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: IN TRYING TO CONTROL BLACK FLIES, SCIENTEST LEARNS HOW TO BREED THEM
description: FIRST By JANE E. BRODY ITHACA, N.Y. THOUGH it may seem like a sick joke to those whose vacations are now being ruined by the persistent and painful bites of black flies, Edward Cupp, an entomologist at Cornell University, spent five years and about $150,000 figuring out how to mass-breed the pesky creatures in his laboratory.

title: FRANCE MAY AID AGACHE-WILLOT GROUP
description: The Agache-Willot Group, the big textile and retail organization that employs about 20,000 workers in France and includes both the Christian Dior fashion house and the ailing Korvettes chain in the United States, is in serious financial trouble.

title: Home Loans Up to 16.75%
description: Interest rates on new home loans rose to a record average of 16.75 percent in early June, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The previous record was 16.59 percent in April 1980.

title: NEW CABLE WORK TO GO ON BRIDGE BECAUSE OF A SNAG
description: Because of the sag in one of the two newly secured cables that had snapped late last month on the Brooklyn Bridge, dozens of new cables will be installed to avoid further hazard, the Transportation Department said yesterday.

title: WELFARE DEPENDENCY OF INDOCHINESE REFUGEES WORRYING CALIFORNIA OFFICIALS
description: Each month, California officials estimate, from 5,000 to 6,000 Southeast Asian refugees move to this state, and more than half seek public financial assistance.

title: Reagan Budget Policy Attacked by Kirkland
description: Lane M. Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, sharply attacked President Reagan's economic proposals today and urged working people not to be ''fooled by the fancy mirages projected by right-wing economic fakers.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday gave a wrong first name for the Yale University expert on occupational health who has studied exposure to asbestos. He is Dr. Robert Sawyer.

title: MAN CARRYING RAZOR SEIZED IN SLASHINGS OF 15 VAGRANT MEN
description: A 32-year-old man who was seized while carrying a bloodstained straight razor was charged by the police yesterday with murdering one vagrant and with menacing another.

title: Chess The Way to Beat a Gambit Is Sometimes to Decline It
description: It's unusual, but not impossible, to defeat a gambit by declining it. How this is done can be seen in the game between Grandmasters Lajos Portisch of Hungary and Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union in the second round of the I.B.M. International Tournament in Amsterdam. Twenty-four years have passed since Smyslov was world champion, yet he still has a delicate, accurate touch.

title: Reliance Sells 2 Stocks
description: The Reliance Group told the Securities and Exchange Commission in two unrelated filings made public yesterday that it had sold all of its 300,100 shares of Chris-Craft Industries along with 229,200 of its 821,500 shares of The New York Times Company.

title: Cosmos' Wegerle To Face Russians
description: The Cosmos will use Steve Wegerle, a citizen of South Africa, when they meet a soccer team from the Soviet Union Sunday night.

title: Corporations Alter Names
description: A total of 285 United States corporations changed their names during the first six months of 1981 - a 38 percent increase from the same period in 1980 - a New York-based marketing communications and design consultants firm reported yesterday.

title: Salvadoran Police Report 50 Dead in Political Strife
description: The police said today that at least 50 people were killed over the weekend in El Salvador.

title: Armco in Pact To Buy Ladish
description: Armco Inc., the nation's sixth-largest steel producer in terms of gross tonnage, said that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Ladish Company of Cudahy, Wis., a metal-forging concern, through an exchange of stock valued at about $221 million.

title: ELF'S BID FOR TEXASGULF IS RAISED TO $2.8 BILLION
description: France's state-controlled oil company, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, agreed after negotiations yesterday to sweeten its $2.5 billion bid for Texasgulf Inc., one of the world's largest sulfur producers, to $2.8 billion in cash.

title: 2 TROUBLED CITY HIGH SCHOOLS TO UNDERGO A REORGANIZATION
description: After several years of efforts to improve two of New York City's most troubled high schools, Benjamin Franklin and Charles Evans Hughes, officials have decided to phase out their enrollments and reopen them again as new institutions.

title: Portes, Fibak Advance In Swiss Open Tennis
description: Fourth-seeded Pascal Portes of France had the toughest battle among the top-seeded players on the opening day of the Swiss Open today, needing a tiebreaker in the third set to subdue Tony Giammalva of the United States, 7-5, 4-6, 7-6.

title: MERGER CHRONOLOGY
description: May 6: Dome Petroleum made a bid for 14 million shares of Conoco at $65 a share, reserving the right to purchase as many as 22 million shares. Conoco shares closed up 6 5/8 points on the day, at 56 1/2. Despite an unfavorable recommendation by Conoco's directors, 54.8 million shares were ultimately tendered.
