May 29: Seagram approached Conoco privately and made an offer for 35 percent of Conoco. Conoco shares closed at 51 5/8, down 2. June 1: Conoco announced an agreement to sell Dome Petroleum 52.9 percent of its holding in Hudson Bay Oil and Gas in exchange for 22 million shares of Conoco stock that Dome had acquired through its tender offer plus $245 million in cash. Conoco shares rose to 53. June 17: Conoco turned down two more offers by Seagram, following the exchange with Dome Petroleum: to buy 28.6 million shares directly for $2 billion, or $70 a share; or to purchase 15.9 million shares at $75 apiece and 9.6 million shares on the open market for an estimated $1.7 billion. June 18: Seagram began purchases of Conoco stock on the open market totaling 143,000 shares, for an estimated $7.7 million. Conoco shares closed at 54 1/4, up 1. June 25: The boards of Conoco and Cities Service agreed to a merger. That afternoon, however, negotiations were terminated because Seagram made an unsolicited $2.56 billion tender offer for 35 million shares of Conoco, a 40.7 percent stake, at $73 a share, with the option to acquire further shares.

title: SUING CORPORATIONS
description: .6,2CLAREMONT, Calif. - In sounding a retreat from Federal responsibility for enforcing health, safety, pollution, and environmental requirements in American industry, the Reagan Administration has trumpeted a two-word message to consumers and workers: Caveat emptor.

title: 20 IN U.S. BIBLE GROUP ARE OUSTED BY PANAMA
description: The Government said today that it had expelled 20 American members of the Summer Institute of Linguistics who were working with remote jungle tribes to transcribe their dialects.

title: CHECKS UNBALANCED
description: To the Editor:

title: NL Industries To Review Units
description: NL Industries said that it had begun a ''strategic review'' of its wholly owned metal fabricating units that may lead management to recommend their divestiture.

title: BALLET: NETHERLANDS AND 'SOLDIERS' MASS'
description: EVERY so often, an example of that rare species called a true choreographer does appear on the horizon, and, as obvious this week at the Metropolitan Opera House, that title can be claimed with no trouble by Jiri Kylian, as artistic director of the Netherlands Dance Theater.

title: Las Vegas Gets Bout
description: Eddie Mustafa Muhammad's defense of his World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title against Michael Spinks July 18 has been shifted to Las Vegas, Nev., from Atlantic City, the promoter, Butch Lewis, said tonight.

title: Crew Safe as F-14 Crashes Off L.I.
description: A Grumman F-14 Tomcat fighter jet on a routine test flight crashed and sank in the Atlantic Ocean 12 miles off Shinnecock, L.I., Coast Guard and Grumman officials said.

title: Penn Central Unit Gets Rig Orders
description: The Penn Central Corporation said that its Marathon Manufacturing I nc. unit had been awarded $326 million in contracts to build eight o ffshore oil and gas mobile drilling rigs for the Rowan Companies.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
YOUTH KILLED BY GRAVESTONE
description: A teenager was crushed to death by a huge gravestone that apparently fell on him in a deserted cemetery. The body of Richard A. Vanlaningham, 18 years old, of Salem, was found Saturday by two friends who returned to the old Blue River Christian Church Cemetery to search for him. The youth and about a dozen friends had gone to the cemetery for a party early Saturday, the authorities said.

title: AIDING THE SMALL FARM
description: .8,0,174.8,2,478.4,0WASHINGTON - It is a long way from the House Agriculture Committee's hearing room to the Missouri fields that my brother Clarence is planting. As I watch the agriculture committees of Congress work out a 1981 farm bill, it strikes me that the real distance between here and there is not so much in miles as in understanding.

title: Companies Buy Their Issues
description: High interest rates are a burden for borrowers, but some companies have turned the situation to their advantage, at least temporarily, as they purchase their own bonds or debentures at current low prices. The difference between the low purchase price and the value of the securities on the companies books is recorded as profit.

title: DISPUTE ON RATES STILL LEADS POSTAL SERVICE' LIST OF TROUBLES
description: The United States Postal Service, which last week observed its 10th anniversary as an independent Federal agency, surprised its own managers with its booming growth in the 1970's.

title: Van Gogh's Hallucinations
description: Another hypothesis has been advanced to explain the possible pharmacologic influences on Vincent van Gogh's artistic vision. Last February Dr. Thomas Courtney Lee of the Georgetown University School of Medicine proposed that van Gogh in his later years may have been under the influence of digitalis intoxication, which could account for his propensity for the color yellow and swirling halo effects. He conceded that the evidence, though compelling, was circumstantial.

title: Job Ads Index Steady in May
description: The Help Wanted Advertising Index, an indicator of changes in the demand for labor and changes in general business conditions, was unchanged in May, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: Ruling Bars Suits On Attica Deaths
description: ALBANY (UPI) - Almost a decade after 43 persons died in the Attica prison rebellion, the Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that families of guards slain in the riot could not sue the state if they already had received workers' compensation death benefits.

title: Interpublic-Marplan Agreement Reached
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies and Research International of London have reached an agreement in principle for the British company to acquire the British and West German operations of Marplan.

title: American Jailed in Drug Case
description: A Frankfurt court today sentenced William Backhus, a 45-year-old American private detective, to four years in jail for complicity in procuring a chemical for the manufacture of LSD from a Hamburg company. Mr. Backhus has been in custody here since 1977.

title: HEIZER CORP reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Yr-ago figures reflect a change in valuation and elimination of the deferred income tax reserve implemented on May 7 when the company made its first public offering

title: Michael Kohl Is Dead; East German Official
description: Michael Kohl, an East German Deputy Foreign Minister, died Saturday after a long illness, the East German Government announced. He was 51 years old.

title: SEAGRAM BIDS HINDERED BY CASH-ONLY PROVISION
description: After the Seagram Company completed a deal in August 1980 to sell its United States oil and gas holdings to the Sun Company for $2.3 billion in cash and notes, Charles Bronfman asked his brother Edgar, Seagram's chairman, how he intended to spend the proceeds.

title: Gibb Brothers Can Go Home Again
description: They have been what they called ''tax refugees'' in Miami for several years now, but the Bee Gees music group plans to return to Britain to live.

title: The U.N. Today; July 7, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the world dis- armament conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SHOWING OFF IN AMERICA. From Con- spicuous Consumption to Parody Dis- play. By John Brooks. 296 pages. Atlan- tic-Little, Brown. $12.95.

title: POSI-SEAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CORRECTION
description: In the Dining Out column in The Guide on Sunday, an incorrect price was listed for a typical three-course dinner at the Village Green restaurant. The price is $35 a person without drinks.

title: FARM CHILDREN SHOULD EARN THEIR OWN LAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Hitachi Profit Up 12%
description: Hitachi Ltd., Japan's largest electronics manufacturer, said yesterday that its earnings in the fiscal year ended March 31 rose 12 percent, to a record of $615 million, or $4.64 a share, from $549 million, or $4.18 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $16 billion from $14 billion. The company cited sales growth for semiconductors and computers.

title: ADOLESCENCE APPEARS FAR HAPPIER THAN ADULTS USUALLY IMAGINE
description: IT may sound like psychiatric heresy, but behavioral studies increasingly suggest that most normal teen-agers are actually happy. Constant tumult and pain are not the necessary prerequisites for moving on to a tranquil adulthood, according to this research - although a popular and, to some extent, professional perception holds that they are.

title: U.S. Confirms Defection Of a Bolshoi Ballerina
description: A State Department spokesman confirmed today that Galina Chursina, a 27-year-old ballerina of the Bolshoi Ballet, slipped away from the touring company in Istanbul on Saturday and was seeking to come to the United States as a political refugee.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne proposed an additional one-cent sales tax and a 1 percent city service tax today to provide new revenue for the city, including $115 million for an eventual takeover of the Chicago Transit Authority.

title: 11th Maccabiah Games Begin
description: Sixteen Israeli paratroopers made spectacular jumps into the Ramat Gan national stadium, and 3,500 Jewish athletes paraded in national costumes past Prime Minister Menachem Begin as the 11th Maccabiah Games, the largest ever, began tonight.

title: Talks Under Way In Trash Walkout
description: Negotiations to end the strike by 1,400 private garbage haulers in 108 communities were held today for the first time since the strike began last Tuesday. State and Federal mediators met with negotiators for both sides but there were no direct discussions between the negotiators for Local 945 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the New Jersey State Municipal Contractors Association.

title: ARGENTINE COURT FREES MRS. PERON AFTER FIVE YEARS
description: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron, who has been under house arrest since her overthrow by the military five years ago, was ordered freed on parole today by a federal court.

title: AN ADVISER'S STRICT CRITERIA
description: LATE last week, after President Reagan ordered an end to import quotas for shoes, footwear stocks beat a hasty retreat on Wall Street. One shoe issue that fell was Wolverine World Wide, the world's largest tanner of pigskin leather and the maker of casual shoes sold under the trade name of Hush Puppies.

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS SEE GAIN FOR ISLANDS IN HOUSE BUDGET
description: Environmentalists who for three years have been seeking more Federal protection for the fragile barrier islands along the Atlantic Coast have gained some unexpected support in the latest budget action by the House of Representatives.

title: NEW TACTICS IN PHONE WAR
description: The New York Telephone Company, whose outdoor pay phones have been flayed with sledgehammers, choked with slugs, stuffed with paper and blown up with bombs, escalated its war on thieves and vandals yesterday.

title: The Pinelands, Still Not Rescued
description: Stands of pine and oak ... lush cranberry bogs ... berry bushes that can treat a picker to 200 pounds in a day ... winding, bouncing streams and 17 trillion gallons of pristine water housed under the sand: a precious national treasure, the pinelands of southern New Jersey.

title: Rate Fears Weaken Stocks
description: Fears of higher interest rates generated a broad retreat by stocks yesterday in subdued post-holiday trading and caused the New York Stock Exchange to record its eighth successive decline.

title: ASTRONOMERS 'LISTEN TO THE SUN'S SOUND AND LEARN ITS
description: SECRETS By WALTER SULLIVAN SUNSPOT, N.M. ASTRONOMERS have found that the sun is ringing like a bell, reverberating in a manner that enables scientists at this solarresearch community near Alamogordo to explore for the first time the interior of that enigmatic star.

title: Murder Suspect Saws His Way Out
description: A 25-year-old man being held for trial in the slaying and robbery of a Monsey couple escaped hours before he was to appear in court in a pretrial hearing, Rockland County officials said.

title: Harvester Canada
description: International Harvester Canada Ltd. said today that it was recalling more than 400 workers to its truck assembly plant here. The recall is in anticipation of a stronger Canadian truck market and will raise production to 90 units a day from 49, the company said. It said the recall would allow for the opening of a second shift and increased the work force to 1,600.

title: TUESDAY, JULY 7, 1981; Companies
description: Du Pont agreed to acquire Conoco for $7.3 billion in cash and stock in what would be the largest merger in corporate history. The deal would make Du Pont the nation's seventh-largest industrial company. The offer of $87.50 a share topped Seagram's unfriendly tender bid of $73 a share for 40.7 percent of Conoco. (Page A1.)

title: IRANIAN GOVERNMENT EXECUTES 27 IN CRACKDOWN ON LEFTIST GROUPS
description: Twenty-seven people, described as supporters of left-wing groups, were put to death in Iran overnight, bringing to 130 the number of people executed since revolutionary authorities began a crackdown on their political opponents 16 days ago.

title: CONGRESS MAKING DEEP CUTS IN HOUSE FOR POOR
description: In a substantial overhaul of a key urban aid program, the House and Senate have quietly deepened the housing cuts sought by the Reagan Administration and voted sharply increased rents for low-income tenants living in Government-subsidized buildings.

title: Mental Health of Women TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: Through several decades as residents and students of our city we have been constant readers of The Times and particular admirers of your coverage of science news.

title: 5,000 CITY YOUTHS ARE TOLD CETA JOBS WILL END FRIDAY
description: More than 5,000 New York City youths enrolled in federally financed job-training programs have been told that their jobs will end Friday because of unexpected Congressional budget cuts, city officials said yesterday.

title: Columbia to Buy Outlet Company
description: Columbia Pictures Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Outlet Company, a broadcasting group based in Providence, R.I., that operates five television stations and seven radio stations across the country, in a proposed tax-free exchange of stock valued at more than $100 million.

title: LATE JUNE AUTO SALES DOWN 4.6%
description: Domestic new-car sales fell 4.6 percent from last year in the last 10 days of June to the lowest daily selling rate since 1958, the three largest domestic auto makers reported today. They cited a continuing weak economy, rising prices and a lack of consumer confidence.

title: Bridge: Frenchman's Move Raises Some Etiquette Questions
description: Nearly all the possible problems involving conduct and etiquette at the table are covered in the laws of the game. You may not deliberately look at an opponent's cards, but if he accidentally allows you to see a card, you are entitled to make use of the information. You may not watch another player in the hope of gathering information from the part of his hand from which he selects a card. (Countermeasures against peekers and watchers are generally thought proper, although the laws do not cover the point.)

title: Lever Brothers to Offer Promotion for Charity
description: Is it a trend? Now we have Lever Brothers testing the waters that General Foods has plunged into - a way of capturing consumer interest by linking a product purchase with a cents-off coupon to a corporate donation to a charity.

title: Quality of Teaching TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: Fred Hechinger's article ''The Ways of Modern College Students Vigorously Attacked and Defended'' (June 16th) warned about a decline in the quality of teacher training. Yet, nowhere did he substantiate that the ''quality of teaching'' has deteriorated.

title: Unions Study Pan Am Aid
description: Four labor unions are considering wage concessions to help bail out financially ailing Pan American World Airways, union officials said today.

title: Zaire Debt Meeting Set
description: The major Western nations that make up the ''Paris club'' will meet here Wednesday and Thursday to discuss rescheduling some of Zaire's official debts, French Treasury aides said today. They gave no details of the sums that would be discussed at the meeting, to be held at the Paris offices of the World Bank. Last month, sources at a meeting of the World Bank's consultative group on Zaire said the country had a total external debt of about $5 billion with total repayments of $2.2 billion due in the next three years.

title: AN ART HISTORIAN
description: Karl Kup, an art historian and retired curator of the Spencer Collection of illustrated books, manuscripts and fine bindings at the New York Public Library, died June 25 at a nursing home in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 78 years old and had lived in Manhattan until recently.

title: SNELLING & SNELLING INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-After $148,100 loss from discontinued operations

title: Winner of Inc. Account Is Small-Scale Success
description: It is not a big account. One of the smaller ones to get attention around here, as a matter of fact.

title: Calabria Posts a 67 For State Golf Lead
description: John Calabria, a 33-year-old head club pro from Rochester, scored a 67 today to take the lead in the 54-hole Michelob New York State Open on the 6,795-yard Big G course.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $76,000 for and $95,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including $68,000 income from dis operations...D-Net loss after $1,093,000 loss from discontinued and $724,000 loss on the disposition of some operations

title: Sports of The Times; How the Young Get Their Education
description: THE photograph leaped out of the sports pages of the Toronto Globe and Mail last week: one woman trying to kick another, being separated by a third woman. The scene was not a mud-wrestling pit in some California discotheque, but a soccer tournament for children in the peaceable province of Ontario.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Results for the latest periods reflect the change from FIFO to LIFO accounting which reduced income by 2 cents a shr for the qr and 4 cents a shr for the yr

title: MAN 21, IS HELD IN ARSON-MURDER
description: A fire swept through a home early today, killing seven persons, including two children and a woman nine months pregnant. Authorities said the woman's husband was later arrested and charged with seven counts of murder.

title: JAZZ: NANCY WISLON
description: AT her Kool Jazz Festival appearance Sunday night at Point Lookout, L.I., Nancy Wilson opened with a tribute to the late Julian (Cannonball) Adderley, one of the musicians credited with ''discovering'' her, by performing four tunes she recorded with him more than 20 years ago.

title: STUDY OF ENERGY DEPARTMENT'S 35 REACTORS FINDS SAFETY DEFICIENCIES
description: A Department of Energy study has found that the department has not applied many of the safety lessons learned from the Three Mile Island reactor accident to its own 35 nuclear reactors.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ''WHEN people don't know their history, they make terrible mistakes,'' said A. Bartlett Giamatti, president of Yale University. The history he was talking about was that of the Government's role in supporting higher education. The mistakes he warned against were the threatened cutbacks in Federal aid to students. He called such a policy ''a great danger'' to America's future.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: The Evolution of the Mammals By L.B. Halstead. 116 pages. Illustrations by Giovanni Caselli and Sergio. Hippocrene Books, New York. $12.95.

title: THE LIBRARY WAS A LADDER OUT OF EL BARRIO
description: To the Editor:

title: Uranium Mine Cutback
description: The General Mining Union Corporation said today that it would quit mining uranium at West Rand because it had become unprofitable.

title: Bache to Acquire New York Firm
description: The Bache Group Inc., in the first acquisition of its own since the Prudential Insurance Company of America bought it last month for $385 million, disclosed in response to inquiries that it was buying Bruns, Nordeman, Rea & Company of New York, a 58-year-old brokerage firm.

title: Catholics Continue Talks With Prisoners in Ulster
description: Roman Catholic mediators conducted a fourth round of talks today with eight Irish nationalist hunger strikers, including one who was close to death on his 59th day without food.

title: Canadian Loan
description: The Canada Development Corporation is raising a $1.75 billion (United States) Eurocredit to finance its purchase of a 75 percent interest in the Aquitaine Company of Canada from the Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine of France, the Bank of Montreal, one of the lead managers, said. Interest on the 10-year credit is half a point over the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) for the first five years and five-eighths of a point thereafter, the bank said. The loan has five and a half years of grace and is not officially guaranteed by the Canadian Government, which holds 49 percent of the corporation.

title: PENNSYLVANIA RACE ON FOR LEDERER HOUSE SEAT
description: In normal times, the House seat to be filled in a special Federal election here July 21 would be no great prize, and the race for it would hardly be a contest.

title: WESTINGHOUSE IN JAPAN TALKS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is negotiating with Japan's Mitsubishi Electric Corporation to establish a joint venture in the United States to manufacture integrated circuits, the companies said yesterday.

title: SPLITTING U.S. INDUSTRIES
description: When he visits one of the plants owned by U.S. Industries, said Gordon A. Walker, the 53-year-old chairman and chief executive officer, he always walks through the factory. ''Having come up through the manufacturing route, I think it's important to take its tempo,'' he added.

title: REAGAN AND HABIB CONFER ON MIDEAST MISSION
description: Philip C. Habib, the Administration's special Middle East envoy, conferred today with President Reagan before resuming his behind-the-scenes efforts to help prevent an outbreak of fighting between Israel and Syria over Syrian antiaircraft missiles in Lebanon.

title: WHAT GEN. BRADLEY SAID ABOUT KOREA
description: To the Editor:

title: DEFENDANT, IN UNEXPECTED MOVE, TELLS OF 'HILLSIDE STRANGLER' DEATHS
description: Kenneth Bianchi, on trial in the ''hillside strangler'' case, took the stand today to deny a role in the slayings of 10 young women, then changed his mind and calmly described all the killings in detail.

title: EDUCATION
description: THE 18-year-old talked angrily about his time at South Shore High School where, he admits, he cut a lot of classes, but insists that he spent that time practicing in the school's music room, not in committing the burglaries of which he was accused and for which he was subsequently discharged from the school.

title: Conservative Mastectomy
description: Many women fear the treatment for breast cancer as much as the disease. The once traditional ''radical mastectomy'' involves surgical removal of the entire breast, the muscles beneath it and the lymph nodes under the arm.

title: Arab Banking Reshuffle
description: The central bank of the United Arab Emirates told nine foreign banks today to close a total of 89 branch offices in the country, leaving more business for local banks, the official news agency here said. The foreign banks were not identified.

title: 200 Police Protest Bronx Indictments
description: About 200 off-duty Bronx police officers picketed in front of the Bronx County Courthouse yesterday to protest the recent indictments of three Bronx officers on homicide and assult charges and to criticize the handling of the cases by the Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola. The officers were indicted in the separate shooting deaths of two men.

title: Duran's Next Foe Unranked
description: Pudgy, out-of-shape Roberto Duran learned yesterday that he has little more than a month to get ready for his 75th professional fight. It will be against a 22-year-old who has his picture on the wall, a match that will not erase memories of Duran's 74th fight.

title: Polish Strike Alert Set At the National Airline
description: Members of the independent union declared a strike alert for tomorrow at the national airline LOT and a one-hour warning strike in all ports on Wednesday.

title: Gulf Oil May Sell European Units
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation may sell its European petrochemical operations, which are losing about $10 million a year, following a recent reassessment of its corporate priorities, a Gulf spokesman said.

title: AIR FLORIDA SEEKING WESTERN
description: Air Florida, the Miami-based airline that has expanded at a rapid rate since deregulation, said yesterday that it intended to seek acquire control of Western Airlines and had already bought 9.9 percent of Western's stock

title: INSURANCE BILL CALLED THREAT TO FIRE ISLAND
description: A House proposal designed to protect the fragile barrier islands on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts would stop the construction of houses and commercial buildings on Fire Island and threaten the ability of present owners to sell their property, according to local residents and Long Island officials.

title: FOR DOMINICAN LEADER, A RARE FAREWELL TO POMP
description: Around him were the trappings of great power: the luxurious home, the secretaries and hushed telephone calls, the officers in gold braid, the line of black limousines in the driveway. It was not for acquiring this power that President Antonio Guzman made Dominican history this week, but for saying he would give it up.

title: CABERET: MARIAN MCPARTLAND
description: THE music of Ornette Coleman, which shocked the jazz world 20 years ago and is still too extreme for the main body of jazz followers, has arrived in a most unlikely setting - the Cafe Carlyle, the home base of Bobby Short. However, it is not Mr. Short who has brought Mr. Coleman's music to the Carlyle but Marian McPartland, who has moved into the cafe for the summer, playing there Sundays through Thursdays with Steve Laspina, bass, and Charles Brown, drums.

title: Shultz on G.M. Board
description: Former Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz, now president of Bechtel Group Inc., has been elected to the board of the General Motors Corporation, the No.1 auto maker announced today. Mr. Shultz, 60 years old, also will become a member of the board's finance committee, effective immediately, Roger B. Smith, G.M.'s chairman, said. Mr. Shultz served as Labor Secretary under President Nixon in 1969-70 and was director of the Office of Management and Budget from 1970-72. He was Treasury Secretary and assistant to the President from 1972-74. He joined Bechtel in 1974 and became president the following year.

title: TRANSIT TAX PLAN DRAWS HEAVY FIRE
description: Key members of Governor Carey's transit advisory panel yesterday criticized the mass-transit tax package under consideration in Albany, questioning the legality of some proposals and how much revenue they would actually produce.

title: L.P.G.A. Plans Houston Move
description: The Ladies Professional Golf Association announced yesterday that it was moving its headquarters to Houston and establishing a pension plan for touring players.

title: MISSISSIPPI TO CHOOSE SUCCESSOR TO HINSON TODAY
description: With both sides happy to make President Reagan's budget the issue, tomorrow's special Congressional election in Mississippi's Fourth District approximates a referendum on those policies on territory friendly to the President and his party.

title: Interest Rates Decline Slightly; 6-Month Bills Up to 14.05%
description: Interest rates declined slightly in quiet trading yesterday, with much of the decline occurring after the Federal Reserve announced that the nation's basic money supply was unchanged in the week ended June 24.

title: AAV COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including $277,046 or 22 cents a shr nonoperating gain from the proceeds of a life insurance policy on a former officer who died

title: PANEL AND SCHMIDT DIFFER ON RECESSION
description: The top economic advisers of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany confronted him today with an embarrassing report on the state of the nation's economy that said uncontrolled Government spending, a towering balance-of-payments deficit and immoderate wage agreements - not high interest rates - were the prime causes of Germany's prolonged economic recession.

title: EASTERN CUTS CALIFORNIA FARE TO $134
description: Faced with a summertime travel slump, Eastern Airlines began a new fare war today when it reintroduced discount coupons, reducing the lowest one-way price on the heavily traveled New York-California route to $134.

title: FOR A PEACE ACADEMY
description: .8,0,174.8,2,478.4,0ARLINGTON, Va. - When President Reagan receives the final report of the Commission on Proposals for the National Academy of Peace and Conflict Resolution, he may face a dilemma. His response to that report will reflect in large measure his commitment to peace.

title: College Building Evacuated
description: The science building of C. W. Post College was evacuated today after a laboratory assistant dropped a bottle of liquid bromine in a corridor, loosing an extremely noxious odor, the college said. About 200 people left the building and two lab assistants were taken to Glen Cove Hospital in Glen Cove for treatment of eye irritation, according to a college spokesman.

title: French Workweek
description: The French Employers Association sid today that it had agreed in priciple to reduce the working week to 39 from 40 hours. The agreement, reached after ratified by the unions before being presented in Parliament in Octoberto become law, negotiators said. The employers agreed to reduce the working week after union leaders withdrew a demand that the week be reduced to 35 hours by 1985.

title: BRITISH WOMEN FIGHT INEQUITY
description: Though Queen Elizabeth II and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher may have no cause for complaint, the situation of working women in Britain is grim.

title: MOROCCAN PEACE MOVE REFLECTS GAINS IN SAHARA
description: With his troops buoyed by an apparently successful defensive strategy in the contested Western Sahara, King Hassan II of Morocco has made an attempt to bring the prolonged struggle there to a political conclusion.

title: Munsingwear Inc.
description: Munsingwear Inc., a maker of fabrics and apparel, said that it would proceed with the acquisition of Deep South Industries of Red Springs, N.C., following approval of the combination by Deep South shareholders last week. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. Munsingwear's chairman, Raymond F. Good, said that the acquisition of Deep South, a finishing and fabric manufacturing operation, ''will give us additional flexibility, and it complements our other manufacturing operations.''

title: City Bond Sale Set
description: New York City's will hold a public bond sale next week, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin announced. The sale will be the first long-term financing undertaken by the city in the 1982 fiscal year and the first of three scheduled bond offerings of $75 million each. The sale will be managed by 18 commercial and investment banks headed by Goldman, Sachs & Company and Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income...C-After $100,000 charge for the settlement of litigation

title: FISCAL CRISIS FOR MEDICARE BY 1980 PREDICTED BY 3 OFFICERS OF CABINET
description: The Medicare program, which helps elderly Americans meet their health and hospital expenses, is in even more serious financial condition than Social Security, the trustees of both Government funds reported today.

title: CECIL NORTH, SERVED 3 YEARS AS PRESIDENT OF METROPOLITAN LIFE
description: Cecil J. North, who sold life insurance door-to-door as a student at the Harvard Business School and 39 years later became president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Friday in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: People
description: * F. Stone Roberts has been elected executive vice president of SSC& B Inc.

title: UNITED REALTY INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Bank Deadline On Iran Assets
description: The Treasury Department today set a deadline of Friday for United States banks to turn over to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York all frozen Iranian assets. This is part of the deal worked out by Jimmy Carter, while he was President, that freed the 52 American hostages last January.

title: Charles Dollfus Dead; Balloon Pilot Was 88
description: Charles Adrien Rene Dollfus, a balloon pilot and aeronautical writer who in 1932 became the first Frenchman to cross the Atlantic Ocean in both directions in an airship, died Friday in Paris, a family spokesman said yesterday. He was 88 years old.

title: Brady's Visit to White House Called 'Milestone' by Doctor
description: James S. Brady's visit to the White House Saturday, the first time the press secretary had left the hospital since he was shot in the head March 30 in an assassination attempt against President Reagan, was a milestone in his recovery, his doctors say.

title: Miss de Havilland Rebuts Reports on Her Views of Paris
description: ''It's wrong to say I'm fed up with living in Paris after 27 years, as some have said of me,'' Olivia de Havilland said yesterday, ''but it's true that I'm leaving it. I've put my house up for sale because it's far too big for my daughter and me now, but I won't leave Paris until it's sold.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Most of us did not think these kinds of things could happen in our country.'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. (A1:5.)

title: Article 185421 -- No Title
description: In what would be the largest merger in corporate history, E.I. du Pont de Nemours, the huge chemical concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Conoco, the nation's ninth-largest oil company. The transaction, worth $7.3 billion, would make Du Pont the country's seventh-largest industrial enterprise, just behind the Ford Motor Company.

title: Jockeys Subpoenaed by Board
description: At least seven active and former jockeys have been subpoenaed and are expected to take the stand today when the New York State Racing and Wagering Board hearings resume into alleged race fixing in New York in the mid-1970's.

title: VETO ON FARM BILL THREATENED OVER SUPPORTS ON MILK PRICES
description: The Secretary of Agriculture, John R. Block, said today that President Reagan would veto the 1981 farm bill if Congress insisted on price-support legislation for milk that did not bring the soaring costs of the current dairy program under control.

title: RIOTING IN BRITAIN BRINGS A PROMISE TO PROTECT POLICE
description: The British Government today promised new measures to protect the police after a weekend of rioting in London and Liverpool that was described by a Cabinet minister as ''the most worrying situation of its kind this country has ever seen.''

title: Firefighters Gain Control Of Western Brush Fires
description: By United Press International Firefighters overcame sweltering heat, tinder-dry brush and gusting winds to gain the upper hand yesterday on fires that have blackened more than 13,000 acres in California, Hawaii and Idaho and destroyed a dozen structures.

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
STATE COURT LETS LEGISLATURE TAKE ROLE ON FEDERAL FUNDS
description: In a decision that could mean longer, more intense budget battles, the State Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled today that the Legislature was entitled to some control over the billions of dollars in Federal funds the state receives each year.

title: Britain, Japan In Auto Talks
description: British and Japanese auto makers are scheduled to meet here tomorrow to discuss exports of Japanese vehicles to Britain.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
Alice Baker Married To Hamilton F. Kean
description: Alice Baker, widow of Edgar R. Baker, was married yesterday to Hamilton Fish Kean, a lawyer who is president of the Youth Counseling League. The ceremony was performed in the Nevelson Chapel of St. Peter's Lutheran Church by the Rev. Charles Thorne.

title: PRESERVATIONISTS CAN'T IGNORE THE NEIGHBORS To the Editor:     The implication in the June 22 news story on Albany ''renewal'' that low-income people must be sacrificed to save the buildings which the preservationists covet does a grave disservice to both preservation and neighborhood activism.
description: The article describes a situation in which preservationists are blamed for residential upgrading that has led to massive displacement of low-income residents. This is occurring across the country as the baby boom meets the shortage of quality housing, and has perhaps much less to do with preservation than with demographic and economic factors out of control.

title: TUNICS: INFINITE VARIATIONS
description: Last October, in one of his sensible collections that gave equal importance to trousers and skirts and didn't demand any great imaginative leaps on the part of his viewers, Yves Saint Laurent sent a model down his runway in Paris dressed in a navy blue wool jersey tunic and a gold leather skirt.

title: CART Will Not Appeal Reversal of Suspensions
description: The board of directors of Championship Auto Racing Teams has decided against appealing a Federal judge's decision that lifted 60-day suspensions against seven drivers for racing in non-CART approved events, it was announced today.

title: TOLLEY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $145,763 for the yr and $73,534 for the previous yr

title: WHY IS DU PONT SEEKING CONOCO?
description: Five years ago, two years after it began considering acquisition of an oil and gas company in the wake of the Arab oil embargo, E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company almost bought the Shenandoah Oil Corporation, a small Fort Worth company.

title: Lillian Carter at Home
description: Because she is making ''an unusually quick recovery'' from breast surgery, Lillian Carter was allowed to leave the Americus-Sumter County Hospital in Americus, Ga., yesterday and return to her home in nearby Plains.

title: Wyoming Town Fondly Remembers a Mistake
description: They may not get the real Capt. Lowell Ferguson, but the people of Buffalo, Wyo., are going to celebrate him anyway. Captain Ferguson made his impression on Buffalo when he inadvertently moved it into the jet age by landing his Western Airlines 727 there on July 31, 1979.

title: WALKER COLOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-Including $376,000 income for the qr and $1,192,000 loss for the yr from discontinued operations...C-Net loss...D-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,897,000 for the qr and $1,439,000 for the yr

title: Wells Fargo Bank Fails In Bid for Race Horse
description: The Wells Fargo Bank lost its bid today to get possession of a race horse allegedly bought with funds embezzled from the bank.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Bancshares Inc. and First National Bank of Angleton, Tex., have agreed in principle to a plan for the merger of First National into Allied.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Why is it that pigeons live only in the cities?

title: THE RULES ARE ALL WE'VE GOT
description: New York is becoming a city without rules. We have not reached the anything-goes stage yet, but some days we seem darned close to it. Drivers are running red lights (and killing people) as if traffic signals were an annoyance to be suffered only when a policeman is visible, which means not too often. Litterers are virtually immune from summonses. Shoplifting has become an occupation rather than a serious crime. A 17-year-old in Times Square tells a Times reporter his job profile: ''I rob people. I like to rob people.'' Burglaries are so endemic and the Police Department so depleted from fiscal retrenchment (down from 31,100 officers in 1974 to 22,600 now) that most of the break-ins are not even investigated.

title: No Headline
description: The Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives, initially demoralized by the punishing defeats suffered 10 days ago in the Reagan budget attack, has begun mounting a tactical counterattack for the next confrontation with President Reagan over his tax cut program. With Congress due to resume work Wednesday after the Fourth of July recess, the Democratic leaders have moved their own public relations campaign into the field with more political organization than previously and with the hope that the tax battle offers them a more favorable opportunity than the budget battles they have lost.

title: THE FUTURE OF OPEC
description: When Henry L. Wojtyla and Nicocles L. Michas predicted in April 1980 that there would be a worldwide oil glut, other Wall Street oil analysts described their assessment as bizarre. The two economic strategists for the brokerage firm of Rosenkrantz Ehrenkrantz Lyon & Ross Inc. were written off as knowing as much about oil as Hamlet's friends Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.

title: Index; International
description: Argentine leader is keeping pledge to step down A2 Memories of Soviet influence per- sist in China A3 Military gains in Western Sahara lead to Moroccan peace move A3 Reagan meets with Habib on new Mideast mission A5 Around the World A7 Government/Politics Campaign under way for Leder- er's seat in Congress A11 Mississippi voters to choose suc- cessor to Hinson A12 Reagan veto threatened over milk price supports A14 Conservationists see gain for is- lands in House budget A15 Court gives Legislature some con- trol over U.S. funds B2 General Around the Nation A10 Another town sees the eclipse of Route 66 A10 Hawaii tourists find something for nothing too good to be true A13 Plan protecting barrier islands affects Fire Island A15 5,000 young people may lose jobs in city on Friday B1 City trying to reduce accidents with bicycles in traffic B1 Syracuse fire kills seven; Schanberg: the rules are all we've got A23 Gregory D. Foster: for a peace academy A23 Don Deichman: aiding the small farm A23 William Shernoff: suing corpora- tions A23

title: U.S. SET TO GIVE 85 HAITIANS NEW IMMIGRATION HEARINGS
description: The Justice Department, in a change of policy, said today that it was willing to hold new hearings for 85 Haitians who had been ordered deported in proceedings allegedly flawed by violations of the aliens' rights.

title: MUNICH'S $44 MILLION NEUE PINAKOTHEK DEFIES CLASSIFICATION
description: MUNICH, West Germany ECCENTRICITY has never had much of an audience in West Germany. This society seems to wrap itself in laws and regimentation, and then drapes them in the soft folds of words like gemeinsamkeit, or communality, and konsens, or consensus. It is not so much discomfort with the new or the novel, which often go down well, but more an irritation with the unclassifiable, the things that escape a category or complete explanation.

title: Accounts
description: * Dixie Federal Savings to Ogilvy & Mather, Houston.

title: A NEARLY COMPLETED PLANT FOR DRYING OUT SLUDGE ON L.I. MAY NEVER BE USED
description: Workers are busily painting and plastering a nearly completed $14.5 million public-works plant here that may never be used. It is cheaper, Nassau County officials say, to complete the project than to break construction contracts and incur lawsuits.

title: Braves Are Indian Givers
description: The Atlanta Braves recently reclaimed, until the end of the players' strike, a 1981 Contintental Mark VI furnished to the pitcher Phil Niekro and a 1980 B.M.W. used by the outfielder Ed Miller.

title: MONEY SUPPLY HOLDS FIRM
description: The basic measure of the nation's money supply remained unchanged at $429 billion in the financial week that ended June 24, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: 12 CONCERTS FOR '81-82 SEASON SCHEDULED BY 92D STREET Y
description: Recitals by Bella Davidovich, Garrick Ohlsson, Isaac Stern and Nina Beilina and appearances by Benny Goodman, Jaime Laredo and Sharon Robinson will be featured in the 12-concert series at the 92d Street Y beginning in the fall.

title: Founder Swears Off Crusade to Combat Cursing
description: Five weeks ago, Paul White, who had lost his job as a parking lot attendant after he ''threw something'' at a woman who had cursed him, founded something he called Curseaholics Anonymous.

title: Fugitive Believed Killer Of 5 in Eastern Georgia
description: ''Somebody on the run'' is probably responsible for the shooting deaths of two men, a woman and two children in burglaries at separate east Georgia homes, the authorities said today.

title: Children and Hospitals TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: I was delighted to read your article ''Play Eases the Fears of Hospitalized Children'' (June 9). In addition to providing therapeutic play activities, Yale-New Haven Hospital's Child Life Program is committed to educating and preparing children about the hospital and related medical and surgical events.

title: News Analysis
description: Black African nations have been left uneasy and hostile by what they see as departures in United States policies under President Reagan that promote South

title: MESSAGES WITH A BIT OF HUMOR
description: YOU people who live around here but who don't know D'Agostino Supermarkets at least know D'Agostino Supermarkets advertising. It's got a light touch and a spirit one doesn't generally associate with that genre of advertising, either in newspapers or on radio.

title: Astronomical Research Limited by Man-Made Lights
description: Astronomers say Arizona's observatories are being jeopardized by the state's burgeoning population, as man-made lights glow steadily brighter and make the stars harder to see.

title: CONCERT: 50-STATE YOUTH ENSEMBLES
description: EVERY year at this time, the Universal Academy for Music in Princeton, N.J., organizes a European tour for high-school musicians from all 50 states who travel under the banner of America's Youth in Concert. This year's group, which consists of an orchestra, concert band and choir, stopped off in Carnegie Hall before heading to Europe.

title: MCENROE AFTERGLOW DIMMED
description: The engine was running in John McEnroe's blue Mercedes yesterday afternoon, and the driver was eager to leave a tennis court in peace. Two days before, on Saturday, he had made an inspired exit from the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club. One day before, his exit from Britain became boisterous when photographers broke china and glass as they chased him.

title: TRAINS IN SUBWAY CRASH WERE AHEAD OF SCHEDULE
description: Both subway trains involved in the accident in a Brooklyn tunnel last Friday in which a motorman was killed and 135 people were injured had departed from their terminal about five minutes ahead of schedule, the head of the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks Seen
description: The United States and the Soviet Union may be ready to begin talks on a possible new grain agreement within two or three weeks, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
MOSCOW DISCOUNTS AFGHANISTAN PLAN
description: The Soviet Union today gave a chilly reception to a Western European peace plan for Afghanistan, which was carried here by the British Foreign Secretary.

title: HEAD OF SHISEIDO PLANT
description: Shiseido, the world's third-largest cosmetics company, has opened its first manufacturing and distribution plant in the United States. The facility, in Oakland, N.J., is under the supervision of Mutsuhiro Nakajima, senior vice president of Shiseido (America).

title: APPLIED POWERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Baker and Weber Bowl A Record 300-300 Tie
description: Tom Baker of Buffalo added his name to the Professional Bowlers' Association record books for a third time today by bowling to a 300-300 tie with Pete Weber in the $95,000 Denver open tournament.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrows.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: I T was supposed to be one of those weeks of summer standstill, but nothing was really standing still at all. Perry Ellis had almost completed his resort collection and was in perpetual meeting with Edward M. Jones (formerly of Calvin Klein), the new president of his increasingly successful men's wear division. Buyers were calling from Milan to report that Giorgio Armani's spring men's wear collection was ''the first collection of the next century.'' In three weeks several clubs opened in New York, including one called Youthanasia.

title: No Headline
description: Judge Welles, presiding at the N.L.R.B. hearing, is an avid baseball fan, and during a break in the hearings yesterday he wandered into the spectator gallery to talk to Boone and Mark Belanger, the Baltimore Orioles shortstop.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams Resources and Energy Inc., Houston, has elected to its board L.K. Herzeg, executive vice president of KSA Industries.

title: DESIGNCRAFT JEWEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including $286,000 gain on the early retirement of debt and $351,000 tax credit...C-Including $65,000 tax credit

title: Japan's Conservatives Suffer Setback in Tokyo
description: Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party suffered a setback in Tokyo municipal elections, the first major vote since Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki took office last summer, final results showed today.

title: THE INTERSTATE'S SHADOW IS OVERTAKING ROUTE 66
description: For Middle Western teen-agers contemplating palm trees and movie stars, for college students dreaming of a Christmas vacation in the sun, for parents and grandparents longing for a land of orange blossoms and no snow - for Americans, in short, with California on their minds - Route 66 was the only way to go.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HAIG MAY ABOLISH RIGHTS JOB
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. may decide to eliminate the job of chief of the bureau for human rights, a spokesman said today.

title: MEETING OF ALL OWNERS IS CALLED FOR THURSDAY
description: With telegrams from eight clubs, five in the American League and three in the National, providing the impetus, baseball's 26 major league club owners will gather in New York Thursday for their first meeting since the players' strike began June 12.

title: CRAFTS: ANNUAL FESTIVAL OPENS AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: CRAFTSMEN from around the United States spread their wares throughout Lincoln Center Plaza over the weekend for the fifth annual American Crafts Festival, a fair that reflects the booming crafts market in every way, not all of the ways good. More than 250 artisans have registered for the presentation, which returns this weekend and on July 18, the rain date for last Saturday when a downpour ended the free open-air event at 1 P.M., ab hour after it had begun.

title: LOUIS HAYES AND QUARTET
description: THE Louis Hayes Quartet, which ended the Kool Jazz Festival's series of three concerts at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Sunday afternoon, is built around three virtuosos who offset and support one another.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 7, 1981
description: International Isabel Peron was freed on parole by an Argentine court. The former President and widow of Juan Peron has been under house arrest since she was overthrown by military leaders five years ago. Lawyers for Mrs. Peron said she would likely stay in Argentina for a day or two before leaving for Panama or Spain. (Page A1, Column 4.) New moves to protect Britain's police were pledged by the Government after a weekend of rioting in London and Liverpool that badly injured hundreds of officers and was described by a Cabinet minister as ''the most worrying situation of its kind this country has ever seen.'' (A1:5.)

title: 4 Found Slain in Ohio Inside Burning House
description: A fireworks dealer was found shot to death in his burning home today along with his wife, five-year-old son and brother-in-law in what the authorities called ''an apparent execution-style homicide.''

title: SEIZING THE CRIME ISSUE
description: Will there be life in Washington after the budget and tax debates? Yes, indeed, and when it comes the Democrats had better look sharp or they may find the Republicans have followed their takeover of the national defense issue with a seizure of domestic security, too.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 17.378 percent had been set at its auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper, up from 16.710 percent last week.

title: Man Accused of Rifling Files In Senator Hart's Office Is Ill
description: A man arrested on charges of rifling files and stealing about $10 in change from the office of Senator Gary Hart of Colorado was hospitalized today in fair condition, officials said.

title: VOTERS OF ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pop Life; TODAY'S SONGS, REALLY YESTERDAY'S?
description: SOME people are of the opinion that today's pop songwriters wouldn't know a good tune or a sophisticated lyric if it hit them over the head. Apparently, the publishers of ''Makin' Whoopee,'' the 1928 standard by Gus Kahn and Walter Donaldson, disagree. They have filed a copyright infringement suit against Yoko Ono charging that her song ''I'm Your Angel,'' from the best-selling John Lennon-Yoko Ono ''Double Fantasy'' album, is ''largely copied from and substantially similar to'' ''Makin' Whoopee.'' They are asking $1 million in punitive damages and requesting injunctions that would prohibit the marketing of ''I'm Your Angel'' in any form. They even want all existing copies of the song, on records, tapes, and sheet music, ''impounded and destroyed.''

title: Coke Intends To Buy Bottler
description: The Coca-Cola Company of Atlanta said that it expected to proceed with its previously announced plans to acquire its major bottler, the Coca-Cola Bottling of New York, in a leveraged cash buy-out valued at $10.375 a share, or approximately $218 million.

title: Kitchen Equipment; THE BROILER SPATULA
description: In the kitchen of a French restaurant, if the broiler chef calls out for a spatula, only one tool is meant. It is not wide and paddlelike in shape, nor is it anything made of rubber. Most of those lifters and turners and scrapers that are loosely called spatulas are likely to be called by other, more-specific names, such as the wide turner or the rubber spatula.

title: FOREIGN POLICY
description: .8,2Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger came to town the other day to confide to a New York audience that yes, Virginia, there is a Reagan foreign policy. Its goal, he revealed, is ''peace and freedom.''

title: Economic Scene; The Thatcher Plan's Failure
description: A SPECTER is haunting the Reagan Administration: Thatcherism. The riots in Liverpool this week, stemming partly from the worst unemployment Britain has experienced since the Depression of the 1930's, are grim evidence of the failure of what was once regarded as a brilliant innovation in economic policy.

title: Reservoirs 82.4% Full
description: Rainfall over the weekend brought the levels in New York City's reservoir system to 82.4 percent of capacity, a spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday. Under normal conditions at this time of the year the reservoirs are at 95 percent of their capacity of 550 billion gallons of water. When the rain started last Friday, the reservoirs were 81.9 percent full.

title: Oregon Ratifies Amendment
description: Oregon became the 10th state to ratify a proposed amendment to the United States Constitution that would give the District of Columbia voting representation in Congress. Gov. Victor G. Atiyeh signed the measure yesterday.

title: REPUBLICANS SEEK POWER IN HAWAII
description: Thanks to Ronald Reagan, Republicans came so close to carrying Hawaii last year that their aimless drift may be ending with actual plans to compete with the Democrats, who have dominated politics here for almost three decades.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 8, 1981; The Economy
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods rose six-tenths of 1 percent in June as food prices increased for the first time in seven months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. Although the June rise exceeded May's unusually small gain of four-tenths of 1 percent, it was still small enough to support the Reagan Administration's contention that inflation has fallen below the ''double-digit'' rate of 10 percent a year. (Page Dl.)

title: EAST MIDTOWN'S OFFICE TENANTS LEARN ABOUT INFLATION
description: ''Anyone paying $1,000 a square foot for land must rent for $40 a square foot to break even,'' a Manhattan developer with long experience remarked the other day. ''And I just heard of two sales at $2,000 a square foot! The market is overheated.''

title: FINANCIER INDICTED ON CHARGE OF TRYING TWICE TO KILL WIFE
description: A New York financial consultant has been indicted on charges that he tried twice to murder his wife with insulin injections during Christmas visits to their Newport mansion. She has been in a coma since January.

title: Debra Karen Schiff Married
description: At Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday, Debra Karen Schiff, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin I. Schiff of Oceanside, L.I., and New York, was married to Dr. Michael Block, son of Mr., and Mrs. Jack Block of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Fabian Schonfeld officiated.

title: NATIONAL PARAGON CO reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-Including $387,000 or 15 cents a shr extraordinary credit...C

title: RUPTURING OF RESERVOIR PIPELINES IMPERILS NEWARK'S WATER SUPPLY
description: A valve at an aqueduct was opened here today, apparently by vandals, starting a chain reaction that burst two huge pipelines and cut off Newark from its main water supply.

title: REAGAN NOMINATING WOMAN, AN ARIZONA APPEALS JUDGE, TO SERVE ON
description: SUPREME COURT BY STEVEN R. WEISMAN

title: GRAY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $400,000 for the qr and $1,727,000 for the yr and $2,489,000 gain for the qr and yr on the sale of discontinued operations...C-Net loss after $5 loss from discontinued operatons...D-Including $1,989,000 incom from discontinued operations

title: NIAGARA SHARE CORP reports earnings for As of June 30
TWO BOYS, 10 KILLED AS HIT-RUN MOTORIST DRIVES ON SIDEWALK
description: Two 10-year-old boys were killed last night by a motorist who drove his speeding car up on the sidewalk along two blocks of 10th Avenue in midtown Manhattan and struck them as they played a block apart.

title: 6 Bicyclists Killed In Last Few Weeks
description: Six bicycle riders have been killed in traffic accidents in the city in the last few weeks, Samuel I. Schwartz, assistant commissioner of the city's Transportation Department, reported.

title: Esso Italiana Spending
description: Esso Italiana will invest about $550 million in the next three years, largely in its refining operations, an Esso spokesman said here today. From 1981 to 1984 the company plans to concentrate its spending on projects that include the development of energy-saving and antipollution systems, with about one-quarter of the total investment to be spent on marketing, the spokesman added.

title: IRAN SHOOTS 9 FOES AND OUSTS REUTERS
description: Iran today intensified its drive against what it denounced as ''counterrevolutionary'' elements, as it announced the execution of nine more domestic opponents and ordered the British news agency Reuters to close its Teheran bureau.

title: HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Going Out Guide
description: CLUBBY

title: OPEC Suit Barred
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cannot be sued under United States antitrust laws, under a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The court today upheld a decision that rejected a 1978 lawsuit by the International Association of Machinists accusing OPEC and its 13 member countries of price-fixing in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act. The appellate court declared that, under United States law, a Federal court may not ''adjudicate a politically sensitive dispute which would require the court to judge the legality of the sovereign act of a foreign state.''

title: A.T.& T. Plans High-Speed Cable
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced plans for what it said would be the world's longest high-speed digital coaxial cable system.

title: Dutch Rebuff a Plea by U.N.  For Asylum to 10 Pakistanis
description: The Netherlands has refused a United Nations request to give asylum to 10 Pakistanis, freed from jail in Pakistan last March, in return for the release in Syria of a hijacked Pakistani airliner, the Justice Ministry said today.

title: CITIZENS' 'SAFETY NET'
description: .4,2The general size and shape of the Administration's cuts in social programs can now be discerned. Congress will still make some modifications and adjustments, but in the end, the reductions surely will add significantly to the strains and distress of many groups and regions of the country.

title: EAST SIDE, WEST SIDE, IT'S SHAKESPEARE ALL AROUND THE TOWN
description: UNDER the stars or under glass, the greatest playwright in the English language is flaunting it around New York this summer. Tonight, the 26th season of Free Shakespeare in Central Park opens at the Delacorte Theater with Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival production of ''The Tempest.'' On July 20, the Billy Rose Theater Collection at the New York Public Library's Lincoln Center branch will open an exhibition called ''Edwin Booth's Shakespearean Roles.'' The American Museum of Natural History is presenting the Folger Shakespeare Library's road show, ''Shakespeare: the Globe and the World,'' through Sept. 20.

title: Bridge: Openers of Traditionalists Follow a Distinctive Style
description: In the area of opening leads, traditional players and modernists have quite distinct styles. It used to be normal to lead the top card from three small, and the fourth-best from four-card suits. But nowadays most experts lead third-best from three- or four-card holdings. Each method has advantages and disadvantages.

title: DR. HAROLD J. LEONARD
description: Dr. Harold J. Leonard, former professor of dentistry and head of the periodontology department at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Sunday at the Mary Hart Nursing Home in Succasunna, N.J. He was 93 years old and lived in Mount Arlington, N.J.

title: Around the World; U.S. Accepts 1,100 Poles Who Stayed in Austria
description: The United States has accepted some 1,100 Polish emigres in the last 10 months and may allocate more money to help refugees resettle in the West, an American diplomat said today.

title: Around the Nation; Homosexual Loses Bid To Become Scout Leader
description: A Superior Court judge today turned down a 19-year-old homosexual's request that the Boy Scouts of America be ordered to accept him as an adult troop leader.

title: CONNECTICUT ALLOWS MARIJUANA CIGARETTES AS MEDICINE
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill signed a bill today allowing doctors to prescribe marijuana cigarettes for patients suffering from glaucoma or the side-effects of cancer treatments.

title: Notes on People; The Untiring Lillian Gish, 84
description: She made her stage debut in a melodrama called ''In Convict's Stripes'' in Rising Sun, Ohio. ''I was 5,'' Lillian Gish said, ''and the only acting lesson I ever had was, 'Speak loud and clear or else they'll get another little girl!' ''

title: ROTHSCHILDS AIM TO BUILD U.S. PRESENCE
description: The British and French Rothschilds have joined banking forces in a move intended to build a stronger presence in the United States market, and an important part of their strategy is to attract the business of rich Americans.

title: So the Battle of Words Begins
description: The publicity film ended and, when the lights came back on, the two welterweight champions of the world were standing at the dais, separated by the promoter, Dan Duva, who called them the ''two best fighters in the world.'' Amid a blaze of flashbulbs, the hoopla began.

title: Henry Falk, 91, Gynecologist At Major Hospitals Since '10
description: Dr. Henry C. Falk, director emeritus of gynecology and obstetrics at the Beth Israel Medical Center who had been associated with major hospitals in Manhattan since 1910, died Sunday at Beth Israel. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Coming Up Roses
description: One thing that gets me down is people refusing to look for the silver lining. A woman telephoned the other day, wife of a friend of mine, and said, ''Oh, I wish you'd come and see Pete. He's so down in the mouth.''

title: U.S. FRAMES POLICY ON HALTING SPREAD OF NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The Reagan Administration plans to announce shortly that while it is committed to halting the spread of nuclear weapons abroad the United States will be a ''clearly reliable and credible'' supplier of nuclear technology for peaceful purposes.

title: REAGAN ASSAILS CRITICS OF TAX CUT AND DEFENDS HIS FOREIGN POLICY
description: President Reagan, in the first purely political trip of his term, tonight assailed critics who say he has no foreign policy and called for increased public pressure on Democratic opponents of his economic plan.

title: NEW PACT ENDS 7-DAY STRIKE OF GARBAGE HAULERS IN JERSEY
description: A seven-day strike against private garbage haulers in 108 northern and central New Jersey communities ended today when 1,400 drivers and loaders accepted a three-year contract that gives them a 50 percent pay increase.

title: Around the Nation; Herbicide Data Stolen From Veterans' Activist
description: White House documents on the use of the pesticide Agent Orange were stolen over the weekend from the locked desk of an activist in veterans' affairs, the police said.

title: NABISCO BRANDS' VICE PRESIDNET
description: Martin F.C. Emmett, a veteran Standard Brands executive, and James O. Welch Jr., a longtime Nabisco manager, were named yesterday as executive vice presidents of Nabisco Brands Inc., the food industry's third-largest producer, which was formed by the merger of Nabisco Inc. and Standard Brands Inc.

title: Contract for Mack
description: Mack Trucks said its plant in Hagerstown, Md., would produce power trains for 940 eight-ton Australian Government vehicles under a $97 million contract awarded to its Australian unit, Mack Trucks Australia. A power train consists of the engine, transmission and carrier that transmits power to the wheels of a vehicle. A Mack spokesman said that the five-year agreement would not affect employment in the United States, but that 250 workers would be added at its Brisbane, Australia, plant.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
Summitry And the Bomb (I)
description: The leaders of the seven most powerful industrial nations will meet at the Chateau Montebello outside Ottawa on July 20 and 21. It will be somewhat different from their six previous meetings in two ways.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article Monday on corporate philanthropy incorrectly described the membership of the Conference Board. It includes corporations, government agencies and educational institutions.

title: 'A REPUTATION FOR EXCELLING'
description: Judge Sandra Day O'Connor's place in history is already secure, based on today's announcement that she will be President Reagan's nominee as the first woman on the United States Supreme Court.

title: BRAZIL TO LIFT COFFEE PRICE
description: The Brazilian Government said today that it was raising the minimum price it pays coffee growers, and said that the move could lead to higher coffee prices on the international market.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $236,000 for the qr and $334,000 for 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $23,000 for the qr and $68,000 for the 6 mos

title: Around the World; Mail Bound for Canada Will Go Back to Senders
description: The Postal Service said today that mail bound for Canada and now held in the United States postal system would be returned to senders because of the Canadian postal strike.

title: The Social Security Future Is Now
description: For some years the trustees of Social Security trust funds have been worried by the system's future financial viability. But judging by their most recent report, issued this week, the future is now: ''Without corrective legislation ... the Old Age and Survivors Trust Fund will be unable to make benefit payments on time beginning in the latter half of 1982.''

title: SUN-POWERED AIRPLANE CROSSES CHANNEL
description: After several earlier unsuccessful attempts, the first solar-powered airplane succeeded today in crossing the English Channel.

title: CONGRESS CUTTING FOOD PROGRAMS
description: The budget reductions passed in Congress will affect farmers and the availability of food for school children and millions of low-income families.

title: 40 on Bus Injured In Brooklyn Crash
description: Forty people were injured when a chartered bus from Atlantic City struck a mail truck on the Brooklyn Queens Expressway in Brooklyn last night, the police said.

title: Advertising
description: Philip H. Dougherty Intermarco Looks Back

title: BAKER VOWS SUPPORT FOR NOMINEE
description: Anti-abortion groups today denounced President Reagan's decision to nominate Judge Sandra Day O'Connor to the Supreme Court, but initial reaction in the Senate, which will vote on confirmation, was favorable.

title: An Appraisal
description: The first Kool Jazz Festival in New York - which used to be known as the Newport Jazz Festival - wound up its 10-day run on Sunday to almost everyone's satisfaction.

title: ARIS BOURGEOIS
description: A slice of life from France, or you might call it one man's family, is served up with tolerant charm, kind heart and good humor in ''Heart to Heart,'' an import that opens today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema.

title: ONCE A DRIVER...?
description: To the Editor:

title: HONORED BY POST, NOMINEE DECLARES
description: The first woman to be nominated to the United States Supreme Court declared herself ''extremely honored and happy'' today but told reporters at a hastily called 15-minute news conference, ''I can't address myself to substantive questions pending confirmation.''

title: Alligator Bites Florida Man
description: A 27-year-old man was attacked today by an eight-foot alligator while snorkeling off North Merritt Island. The man was in satisfactory condition, recovering from extensive injuries to his left arm. Alan Clendinen, a boat repairman, was pulled under water by the alligator, which caught him by surprise as he was swimming with a friend. Mr. Clendinen was taken to a hospital, where he underwent surgery on his arm.

title: Discoveries; SEASONINGS, SHOES, LIGHT; 1. Walk the Salt, Please
description: Walk the salt and pepper, please. If conversation lags at meals, you might try winding up a salt and pepper set shaped like a butler and maid and sending them walking across the table. The plastic figures have paddle-like ''feet'' that make them amble slowly when a key winds them up. One fills them by removing their heads and pouring the condiments into them. They are $12.50 the set at Stephen Anson, 1058 First Avenue (58th Street).

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: and-Sullivan-like melody'': SONG OF THE GREAT OUTDOORS

title: American Express Publishing Director
description: Patrick Foglia has become the top ad-selling honcho for both Travel & Leisure and Food & Wine magazines.

title: U.S. Wins 2 Golds In Maccabiah Swim
description: Two United States men swimmers won gold medals on the first day of the Maccabiah Games today.

title: Revolutionary in Santo Domingo
description: Good for President Antonio Guzman, who set a precedent and startled the Dominican Republic with a simple announcement: he will not be a candidate for re-election next year. True, Mr. Guzman promised when he took office in 1978 that he would serve a single term.

title: Scholarships and Steel; AFRICAN INVESTMENT; African Investment
description: It is a familiar white claim in South Africa that nowhere else on the continent are blacks better off, apartheid notwithstanding. But the claim ignores the exclusion of blacks from professional fields.

title: CCI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Market Place
description: Vartanig G. Vartan Strong Dollar Double-Edged THE United States dollar has been a bastion of strength against other world currencies since last autumn. ''Since October, the dollar has advanced roughly 30 percent against the German mark, 7 percent against the Japanese yen and 22 percent against the British pound,'' Standard & Poor's Outlook reported on July 1. ''The dollar's sustained rebound, which has now erased the effects of a decade-long decline, has been due mainly to the wide differential between short-term interest rates in the U.S. and those in Western Europe.''

title: EX-LOUISIANA AIDE ACQUITTED IN BRIBERY TRIAL
description: A former Louisiana state official who was one of five defendants in the racketeering trial of Carlos Marcello, the alleged leader of organized crime in the Southwest, was acquitted today by Federal District Judge Morey L. Sear.

title: PATIENT AWARDED $4.6 MILLION
description: A psychiatrist who admitted having sex with a patient in two years of $110-a-week therapy sessions was ordered today to pay $4.6 million in damages to the woman.

title: Krugerrand Sales
description: World sales for the Krugerrand gold coin rose to 207,011 ounces in June from 112,670 in May, but were still below the 228,354 sold in June of last year, a spokesman for Intergold, the South African marketing agency, said today. Sales for the first six months this year total 1.4 million ounces, up from 1.14 million in the same 1980 period, he said. In view of the recent downward trend in the gold market, the sales figures are considered satisfactory, the spokesman added.

title: EMORY AYERS DIRECTOR
description: George M. Whitmore Jr., former managing director and chief executive officer of Cresap, McCormick & Paget Inc., the management consultant firm, has joined Emory Ayers Associates Inc., a similar but smaller concern, as managing director.

title: THEATER: A PAIR OF ONE-ACTORS BY JOHN SAYLES
description: FANS of John Sayles don't have an easy time guessing what he'll do next. An accomplished novelist (''Union Dues''), Mr. Sayles is game for almost any form of creative endeavor. When he isn't writing fiction, he'll write and direct a personal, independent film about ex-1960's renegades (''The Return of the Secaucus Seven'') or turn out a screenplay for a low-budget horror movie (''Alligator'') or contribute a piece of political reportage to The New Republic. Now he has added theater to his repertory as well by writing and directing a pair of one-act plays that opened at the Boat Basin Theater last night.

title: PRELATE, 52, CHOSEN BY THE POPE TO LEAD THE POLISH CHURCH
description: Bishop Jozef Glemp of Warmia was named today by Pope John Paul II as Archbishop of Gniezno and Warsaw and the Primate of Poland, succeeding Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, who died on May 28.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The net income and shr earnings for the yr ago 9 mos have been restated for an accounting change

title: Books of the Times
description: SHADOW MAN. The Life of Dashiell Hammett. By Richard Laman. Illustrated. 285 pages. Harcourt, Brace, Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: MAY'S RISE SMALLER IN INSTALLMENT DEBT
description: Consumer installment debt increased $1.35 billion in May, the Federal Reserve board reported today. It was the smallest monthly increase since January, indicating that consumers had retrenched along with the rest of the economy.

title: PI-CAS-SO1 1PAINTER
description: .2,2BUFFALO, N.Y. - In the last few years, we have been witnessing a progressive takeover of museum walls by the written word - in the form of the omnipresent, all-explaining, ever-larger wall label.

title: Around the World; 3 Coffins Handed Over To U.S. by Vietnamese
description: Vietnam handed over three wooden coffins today with the remains of three American servicemen missing since the Vietnam War.

title: Canada Firm on Policy
description: A Canadian policy of promoting domestic control of its foreign-dominated oil industry cannot be stopped by threats of a United States ban on Canadian takeovers of American oil companies, Canada's Ambassador, Peter Towe, said today. He told a gas industry luncheon that a suggested Congressional moratorium on Canadian purchases of American companies would be ''highly discriminatory.''

title: JANE DAVISON, 49, HISTORIAN AND WRITER ABOUT OLD HOUSES
description: Jane Davison, a social historian and editor who frequently wrote about houses and architecture, died of cancer in Cambridge, Mass., on Saturday. She was 49 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''She is truly a 'person for all seasons,' possessing those unique qualities of temperament, fairness, intellectual capacity and devotion to the public good which have characterized the 101 'brethren' who have preceded her.'' - President Reagan on Sandra Day O'Connor, his nominee for the Supreme Court. (A1:6.)

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Jim Barr, pitcher, to one-year Class AAA contract and assigned him to Edmonton of Pacific Coast League. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Dismissed H.B. (Spec) Richardson, vice president of baseball operations, and replaced him with Tom Haller, director of player devel- opment. KANSAS UNIVERSITY - Promoted Floyd Temple, baseball coach, to assist- ant athletic director.; BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Signed Richard Washington, f

title: Bibb
description: A small, expensive lettuce with tiny ribbed leaves and a melting flavor. Also known as Kentucky limestone lettuce, it was developed by an amateur horticulturist, John J. Bibb, in Frankfort, Ky. Very subtle, good on its own with an oil and vinegar dressing. Boston

title: 'HOUSTON IS STRONG AND GETTING STRONGER'
description: To the Editor:

title: DUPONT'S CONOCO BID BUOYS STOCKS OF OTHER OIL TARGETS
description: Middle-tier oil stocks advanced sharply yesterday in heavy trading in the wake of the record-breaking $7.3 billion offer by E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company on Monday to buy Conoco, as analysts speculated on which oil company might be the next acquisition target.
