title: AN I.R.A. PRISONER DIES IN BELFAST ON THE 61ST DAY OF HUNGER STRIKE
description: Joseph McDonnell, an Irish Republican Army member, died in Maze Prison early this morning on the 61st day of his hunger strike, Britain's Northern Ireland office said.

title: JAZZ VOCALIST: ANITA O'DAY
description: ANITA O'DAY has been singing for nearly 50 years, and for 40 years she has been one of the major jazz voices. So it may seem a little odd at this late date to find that she has brought her performances into a kind of balance that has previously eluded her.

title: British Car Output Off
description: British car production in June fell to 92,000 units from 96,000 last year, but was above the strikedepressed figure of 52,000 units in May, according to industry department figures released today.

title: News Analysis
description: Sandra Day O'Connor's opinions in her 18 months as an Arizona appeals court judge display careful reasoning and use of precedent. But they shed little light on her attitude toward most of the controversial constitutional issues she will face if she is confirmed as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. Judge O'Connor, a former Republican majority leader of the Arizona State Senate, is widely regarded as conservative in her political outlook. Her legislative record has been attacked by anti-abortion groups that say she cast pro-abortion votes before she became a judge, but those assertions have been disputed by people who sat with her in the Arizona Legislature.

title: KID CREOLE SEARCHES FOR A LOST LOVER
description: AUGUST DARNELL, whose stage name is Kid Creole, calls the show he has fashioned from his recent ''Fresh Fruit in Foreign Places'' album a ''rap musical.'' It is that and more. Kid Creole and the Coconuts have always been a theatrical act, but in the past they performed unrelated songs and depended on energy and momentum to tie their show together.

title: LEBANON CHRISTIANS CLARIFY TIES TO ISRAEL
description: Leaders of the Christian Phalangist Party have given President Elias Sarkis a letter that is said to deal with the issue of their relations with Israel.

title: Geer, DuBois Adds Anso IV Carpet
description: Geer, DuBois Advertising, the same agency that gave us the delightful Peek Freans cookies advertising, have now produced some carpet advertising that doesn't just lie there.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
Transit Report
description: All three of the main commuting lines into Grand Central Terminal experienced delays yesterday morning, with the New Haven line having ''one of its worst rush-hours in weeks,'' said Robert Van Wagoner, a Conrail spokesman.

title: General Mills Net Up by 8.2%
description: General Mills Inc., the diversified food and consumer products company based here, said today that its unaudited net income for the 14-week fourth quarter ended May 31 rose 8.2 percent, to $37 million, or 73 cents a share, from $34.2 million, or 68 cents a share, in the 13-week period one year earlier.

title: Around the Nation; Flight Controllers' Chief Predicts Pact's Rejection
description: The head of the air traffic controllers' union predicted today that the union's members would reject a tentative contract with the Government. He said he would seek to reopen negotiations if that happened.

title: Best Buys; AVERAGE COST OF FEEDING FAMILY OF FOUR REACHES A RECORD HIGH
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City jumped up 52 cents, to a record high of $104.37, during the two-week period June 22 to July 3, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs. Shoppers paid 10 percent more for food than during the same period last year.

title: TAIWAN'S SUSPICION OF 'SMILING DIPLOMACY'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Blow to Sea Tradition
description: It may be a threat to a cherished social tradition, but a beer too many before a boat race can now mean a $100 fine for a yachtsmen under legislation signed today by Governor Carey.

title: URANIUM INDICTMENTS IN CANADA
description: The Canadian Government, which helped organize a worldwide uranium cartel in 1972, filed criminal charges against six Canadian companies today for allegedly restraining competition and trade in uranium within Canada.

title: Around the Nation; Missing Autistic Boy, 12, Is Found in Mountains
description: A 12-year-old autistic boy who had been missing for three days in the White Mountains was found today by a volunteer searcher who was the father of an autistic child.

title: BARBER-GREENE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 6
description: B-Including $2,363,000 or $1.04 a shr, tax credit from a change in Britain's tax laws

title: Around the Nation; Wisconsin High Court Bars Polygraph Tests
description: The Wisconsin Supreme Court, declaring that polygraph tests are unreliable, has ruled that results of such examinations will no longer be admissible as evidence in courts in the state after Sept. 1.

title: U.S. CLERICS FIND RELIGION IS REVIVING IN CHINA
description: The Chinese Communist Party has turned to religious tolerance to help build popularity for its modernization policies, and the result has been ''renewed vitality'' for religious groups, a New York-based delegation of American religious leaders said here today.

title: CLOSE CALL:
description: R.D. Perry is lowered to safety after falling through a window and grabbing a ladder while fighting a blaze in Raleigh, N.C. The fireman aiding him was not named. Eight firefighters were injured, two businesses were destroyed and three vehicles were crushed by collapsing walls when the fire consumed a building near the state Capitol.

title: Lettuce Soup; 4 heads of lettuce (any kind) or equivalent bulk in outer leaves 4 cups chicken stock 2/3 cup milk
description: Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper.

title: Transport Chief In Jersey Quitting
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Louis J. Gambaccini, New Jersey's Transportation Commissioner, is resigning to return to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, where he worked for more than 20 years. his office said the resignation of the 50-year-old Ridgewood resident would take effect Sept. 25. Mr. Gambaccini has been Commissioner since May 1978. His title at the port agency will be assistant executive director and director of administration.

title: SCIENTISTS AT U.S. AGENCY TROUBLED ABOUT FUTURE
description: On the surface, all seems normal on the bucolic ''campus'' of the National Institutes of Health, 306 acres of well-manicured grounds here in suburban Washington.

title: RURAL MICHIGAN BOOMING AS MANY FLEE URBAN ILLS
description: There is not much going on in this little town. What few jobs there are pay the minimum wage. Shopping requires a 40-mile round trip.

title: FRENCH SOCIALISTS ARE SHAKING UP TV NETWORKS
description: Sometimes they were called Giscarpettes. They were the French television journalists who regularly interviewed President Valery Giscard d'Estaing. It was usually agreed, even by the President's supporters, that metaphorically at least, he walked all over them.

title: THE ROYAL NAVY CONCOCTS A ROYAL CAKE
description: Though the armed forces are not known for the finesse of their patisserie, the Royal Navy is building an elaborate 200-pound cake for the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer on July 29. A tight but rather transparent shroud of secrecy hangs over the Royal Naval School of Cookery here, where the construction is taking place and where a visitor could see the still-to-be-completed cake in plain view.

title: The U.N. Today; July 8. 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets to consider the application of Vanuatu for membership at 11 A.M. and 3:30 P.M.

title: PUNK: RE-FORMING ROCK
description: ROCK seems to continually recycle itself, to the extent that most ''new'' movements, no matter how radical they may seem, turn out to be the rediscovery of traditional ideas by a younger generation of performers and listeners. This truism even extends to the abrasive punk rock that is flourishing in Los Angeles and is the subject of ''The Decline of Western Civilization,'' a film that is now showing at the Waverly Cinema in Greenwich Village.

title: BONN REPORTS 10% DROP IN MAY'S EXPORT ORDERS
description: The volume of export orders booked by West German industry dropped sharply in May, on a month-to-month basis, the Government reported today.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'A Reputation for Excelling' - Sandra Day O'Connor
description: WASHINGTON -- Judge Sandra Day O'Connor's place in history is already secure, based on the announcement that she will be President Reagan's nominee as the first woman on the United States Supreme Court.

title: MEXICO CUTS BACK OIL OUTPUT
description: Mexico cut back its oil production by 700,000 barrels a day after its efforts to raise its oil prices prompted cancellation of numerous sales contracts, Petroleos Mexicanos announced yesterday in Mexico City.

title: INDONESIA WEIGHS CUT
description: Indonesia may cut its oil production by 110,000 barrels a day, or 6.7 percent of its current output, to abide by an OPEC decision aimed at reducing the world oil glut, a high-ranking Indonesian official said today.

title: HARRIS BANKCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALL THAT'S LETTUCE IS NOT ICEBERG
description: much of it locally grown - that a shopper in New York might find in his neighborhood market. The greenery doesn't end there, either. If the shopper looks a little further he can find arugula, spinach, beet greens and dandelion leaves, too.

title: CHURCH FIGHTING OVER $138,000 HOARD
description: A tiny fundamentalist church and two of its former members are fighting for control of a hoard of $138,000 in gold and silver. The church says it is meant to tide members over a coming period of ''economic chaos'' in which banks will close and paper currency will become worthless.

title: Notes on People
description: A Tribute to Fiedler Erich Kunzel had a special sentimental reason for asking Ellen Fiedler, Arthur Fiedler's widow, to narrate Aaron Copland's ''Lincoln Portrait'' with the San Francisco Pops Orchestra last night.

title: NEW AIRLINE BATTLE IN TEXAS
description: The battle that is about to begin in the skies of Texas probably will not be as bitter as the tough, mean slugging matches that took place between the state's airlines during the 1970's. But it ought to be a lot more fun, based as it partly is on style and sex appeal.

title: NEW NAME
description: NEW NAME on the one-dollar bill belongs to the new Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan. He and Angela Buchanan, U.S. Treasurer, inspect first issue.

title: Algeria Cuts Gas Price
description: Algeria has notified Japanese importers that prices of its liquid natural gas have been cut by $3.50 a barrel, to $35.50, retroactive to July 1, industry sources said today.

title: Plea by Japan Trade Official
description: Japan's top trade official said today that Japan, as an ''engine of the world economy,'' must do more to insure that its exports do not disrupt the economies of its trading partners.

title: EX-RAND PRESIDENT CHOSEN TO HEAD NEW C.I.A. PANEL
description: The Reagan Administration has selected Henry S. Rowen to head a newly created National Intelligence Council at the Central Intelligence Agency, Administration officials said today.

title: DELANEY RECALLS LIE TO REPORTERS AS 'PLOY' IN A MURDER INQUIRY
description: Westchester County's suspended Police Chief, Thomas J. Delaney, said under oath today that he used a reporter as a ''ploy'' in a stalled murder investigation by lying to him last year.

title: The Washington Star
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt is considering transferring to the State of Texas control over the Matagorda Island wildlife refuge in the Gulf of Mexico, the wintering grounds for the last of the nation's whooping cranes.

title: Careers; Students Get Back To Basics
description: SOME wit once said, ''When in doubt form an association.'' The idea is that when a group can share a problem it appears less formidable, much like the principle behind group therapy. Through an organization quietly formed three years ago, called the Management Communication Association, many leading graduate schools of business administration are sharing their concern about a problem - the inability of many of their students to communicate well. The vague title of the association hardly expresses the extent of worry.

title: People
description: * Thomas Gorman has been named executive vice president-marketing/ advertising for Germaine Monteil Cosmetiques.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL CUTBACKS IN SOCIAL SECURITY AS UNNECESSARY
description: Democratic Senators today accused the Reagan Administration of seeking unnecessary cuts in Social Security benefits in an attempt to move more rapidly toward balancing the Federal budget.

title: Crime Chief Gets 2-Year Sentence
description: Nicodemo Scarfo, identified as the new boss of Philadelphia's organized-crime ''family,'' was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $5,000 on a firearms charge.

title: Food Fair May Sell Stores in Maryland
description: Food Fair Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., the operator of the Pantry Pride supermarket chain, said it was considering selling its 48 Maryland stores.

title: FOR PROSTITUTES, RIGHT TO A TRIAL BY JURY IS HAZY
description: Confusion has arisen in New York City courtrooms over whether a person charged with prostitution is entitled to a jury trial. The law in Courtroom AP1 of Criminal Court in Manhattan is that the defendant in such cases is entitled to a jury trial. What the law is in the other courtrooms, however, is uncertain.

title: PLUNKETT, ON 237-4, SETS DISCUS RECORD
description: Ben Plucknett of the United States shattered his world discus record with a throw of 237 feet 4 inches (72.34 meters) at an invitation track and field meet today.

title: Two Fists and Four Names
description: MUSTAFA HAMSHO is a Syrian middleweight with two arms, two legs and four names. He also has one hard skull and the standard assortment of knees, elbows and thumbs, all tools of his unruly trade. He also has an Irish wife from Bayonne, N.J., and a 4-year-old daughter, Susan.

title: Bottelli Jr., 78, An Architect in Jersey
description: Romolo Bottelli Jr., a New Jersey architect who was among the first to design high-rise apartment buildings for the suburbs, died Monday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 78 years old and had been a resident of Avon-by-the-Sea, N.J., since moving from Maplewood, N.J., eight years ago.

title: Independent Druggests' Aid
description: In order to combat the inroads of the large drugstore chains, which do not use their services, a number of drug wholesalers have come up with another way of helping the independent druggests, who do, by instituting a franchising concept called FamilyCare Drug Centers.

title: Larry C. Morris Passengers Rescued as Helicopter Falls into the East River
description: A employee of Island Helicopter,Inc., removing passengers' luggage from helicopter that lost power on takeoff from the East 34th Street heliport.

title: CRISTOFER'S TV 'SHADOW BOX' WINS TOP HUMANITAS PRIZE
description: The television version of Michael Cristofer's Pulitzer Prize-winning ''The Shadow Box'' won the $25,000 prize in the seventh Humanitas awards announced today.

title: Fuel Grants Await Details
description: The United States Synthetic Fuel Corporation announced today that it would need more information from project sponsors before it decided which synthetic fuel plant proposals would receive Government funds.

title: TV: MOYERS AND A PROVOCATIVE DAME REBECCA WEST
description: TONIGHT'S special edition of ''Bill Moyers' Journal,'' on WNET-TV at 9 o'clock, offers the unusual example of an exceptionally awkward interview being thoroughly absorbing. The guest is Dame Rebecca West, the novelist, critic, journalist and, in the words of Mr. Moyers, literary lioness.

title: Toyota Cuts July Output
description: The Toyota Motor Company, Japan's largest car maker, said today that it is cutting production in July by 9 percent from the year before. Toyota is widely believed by industry analysts here to be considering further cuts in August.

title: 'TRAVIATA' TO OPEN MET'S TV SERIES
description: The 1981-82 ''Live from the Met'' season of nationwide telecasts from the Metropolitan Opera will begin Sept. 30 with a taped version of Verdi's ''La Traviata.'' The performance, recorded last March 28, is conducted by James Levine and includes Ileana Cotrubas, Placido Domingo and Cornell MacNeil.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 8, 1981
description: International New guidelines on nuclear weapons are to be announced soon by the Reagan Administration. The guidelines reaffirm a commitment to halt the spread of nuclear arms abroad but also pledge that the United States will be a ''clearly reliable and credible'' supplier of nuclear technology for peaceful purposes. (Page A1, Col. 3.) A solar-powered plane crossed the English Channel for the first time. The craft, which requires no storage batteries, made the 165-mile flight from a Paris suburb to England in five and a half hours, averaging 30 miles an hour. The 210-pound plane was powered by 16,000 photovoltaic cells that converted solar energy into electricity to drive the motor. (A1:2-4.)

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A FORGOTTEN ANIMAL-PROTECTION LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Rates Still Lofty, Bonds Sag
description: The combination of very high financing costs and a lack of strong investor demand for notes and bonds continued to plague the credit markets yesterday, with some bond prices falling more than a point.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I am asked to name the one main course that can be made in less than an hour, tastes best and makes the greatest impression on guests, there are hundreds of foods that come to mind. But on consideration, it might just as well be a platter of curried chicken.

title: SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for As of June 30
COAST STRANGLER CASE TO BE RE-EVALUATED
description: After the second day of testimony in the ''hillside strangler'' case today, Judge Ronald M. George of Superior Court ordered prosecutors to notify him by next Monday whether they intend to continue with or dismiss 10 counts of murder against Angelo A. Buono Jr.

title: CHALLENGE FOR PUPILS
description: To the Editor:

title: UNSAFE TRAINS OFTEN IN USE, SUBWAY MOTORMEN CHARGE
description: A number of motormen and conductors of the New York City Transit Authority asserted yesterday that subway trains impaired by safetyrelated defects were sent out every day to carry passengers on the subway system.

title: FREE TRADE STRESSED BY U.S.
description: In a policy statement expected to be presented to the Senate tomorrow, the Reagan Administration asserts that it will strongly resist protectionist pressures and mount vigorous challenges to subsidized competition and other trade-distorting measures by foreign governments.

title: British Steel Corporation Lists $1.27 Billion Loss Last Year
description: Britain's state-owned British Steel Corporation lost a record $1.27 billion last year, the company said today.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REMARKS BY REAGAN AND NOMINEE TO HIGH COURT
description: Following are transcripts of President Reagan's remarks and answers to questions yesterday in announcing his selection of Judge Sandra Day O'Connor to serve on the Supreme Court, as recorded by The New York Times, and of a news conference in Phoenix by Judge O'Connor, as recorded by The Associated Press: Reagan Remarks

title: New Yorkers, etc.; CLIPPINGS COLLECT WITH LITTLE PURPOSE
description: RAVELLE BRICKMAN describes herself as an insane clipper. An insane clipper is someone who not only clips, clips, clips, articles, recipes and coupons from magazines and newspapers but one who also proceeds to stash the clips away and never, or almost never, looks at them again.

title: ANALYSTS QUESTION EXECUTIVES OF G.M.
description: The senior management of the General Motors Corporation was questioned by analysts yesterday on how the company was responding to the advanced automation and productivity in Japan that have helped that country gain a major foothold in the American automotive industry. The replies drew a mixed reaction.

title: SEAWELL PLANS TO RETIRE AS CHAIRMAN OF PAN AM
description: William T. Seawell, the Pan American World Airways chairman who has been seeking to halt the airline's economic decline, said yesterday that he would retire by the end of the year.

title: Crocker Bank's Loan Losses
description: The Crocker National Bank, the nation's 12th-largest commercial bank, faces losses of up to $4.3 million from questionable loans and overdrafts made by a Sacramento branch manager who resigned last year after auditors questioned his loan procedures, bank officials said today.

title: SLASHING SUSPECT TO UNDERGO TESTS
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge yesterday ordered that a psychiatric examination be given to a 32-year-old drifter to see if he was competent to stand trial on charges he murdered one vagrant and attempted to assault another last Sunday night and early Monday morning.

title: POWER IN THE AISLES OF A CAPITAL MARKET
description: WASHINGTON AT the Social Safeway you can find a nice leg of lamb, a fresh head of romaine and George Bush. Looking for the Vice President? Try pet supplies. He was spotted there a few weeks ago.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: There may be many reasons why 80 young women, some armed with clutch purses, are able to stop traffic all over the city on these steamy July days.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aeroflex Laboratories Inc., Plainview, L.I., has appointed Arthur J. Hendler executive vice president.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 23
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on Apr 15

title: Kuhn3 Owners Testify
description: As baseball's 26 club owners prepared to meet in New York tomorrow for the first time since the strike began June 12, one of them testified yesterday that owners do not offer their opinions on collective bargaining at meetings called by their player relations committee.

title: RIOTING CONTINUED IN BRITAIN:
description: British policeman with a youngster he had placed under arrest Monday during the third night of violence in Liverpool.

title: Energy Theft Draws Fine
description: A judge has ordered Michael Schwartz to pay $1,860 to the San Diego Gas and Electric Company as restitution for electricity he allegedly got free by turning a meter upside down so it ran backwards. Mr. Schwartz, a 39-year-old public accountant, pleaded no contest yesterday to energy theft and meter-tampering. A grand theft charge was dropped, but Mr. Schwartz was put on two years' probation and fined $200.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP 0.6% IN JUNE
description: The Government's Producer Price Index for finished goods rose by six-tenths of 1 percent in June as food prices increased for the first time in seven months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: GUERNSEY NOVEL, PUBLISHING SUCCESS
description: One of this season's publishing surprises is a novel written by a British civil servant who died in 1976 at the age of 80 after having failed to get the book published in his lifetime.

title: Goodrich Selling 4 More Segments
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company, the big tire and rubber products maker, is in the process of disposing of four more parts of its business in line with a strategic plan to provide more funds for high-growth areas.

title: Sea Museum Bonds Offered
description: The spirit of dauntless fortitude continues to surround the U.S.S. Intrepid, an aircraft carrier whose 31 years of active duty spanned everything from kamikaze attacks to Apollo spacecraft recoveries.

title: FEEBLE HELP FOR THE CARIBBEAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 20.50 20.50 11.50 DISCOUNT RATE** 14.00 14.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 16.70 19.94 8.75 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.72 14.25 8.05 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.32 14.05 7.92 7-YR. TREASURY NOTES 14.24 14.01 9.95 30-YR. TREASURY BONDS 13.37 13.14 10.30 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.22 15.06 22.26 MUNICIPAL BONDS 11.37 11.33 8.25 6-MONTH SAVING 14.300 CERTIFICATES * Split rate, 20.00-20.50 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Notes on People; Unexpected Cost of Moving Furniture
description: Injuries are common among dancers, who usually sprain ankles and strain back muscles and the like performing or rehearsing. But in the case of the President's son, Ron Reagan, a member of the Joffrey II ballet troupe, the back injuries he is suffering now came from moving furniture around the Greenwich Village apartment he shares with his wife, Doria.

title: THRIFTIMART INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 21
Addendum
description: * Tasco Publishing Corporation has changed its name to M. Shanken Communications Inc.

title: RLC Waste Unit To Be Acquired
description: The RLC Corporation and Waste Management Inc. of Oak Brook, Ill., said they had reached an agreement in principle for Waste Management to acquire Rollins Environmental Services, RLC's chemical waste operations, for preferred stock worth $53.2 million.

title: Index; International
description: In Salvadoran turmoil, U.S. presence is potent A2 Phalangists said to write to Beirut leader about ties with Israel A3 Chinese Communists tolerate religious revival A3 Efforts to end the Irish fast encounter a delay A4 Around the World A5 Mitterrand Government shakes up television networks A8 Government/Politics Judge O'Connor ''honored and happy'' to be Court nominee A12 Hawaii Republicans aim to serious compete with Democrats A15 Ex-Louisiana official acquitted in bribery trial A18 Mississippi voters go to polls to fill vacant House seat A18 Ousted Westchester sheriff explains lying to reporter B2 Courts confused over jury trials for prostitution defendants B3 General Around the Nation A10 Judge orders prosecutors to decide on ''strangler'' case A10 Rural Michigan enjoys population boom as many flee cities A10 Financier accused of trying to kill his wife A16 The Region B2 The City B3 Education/Welfare Young math experts ready to represent the United States B1 Health/Science Connecticut law legalizes medical use of marijuana B1 Scientists at U.S. agency are trou- bled about future B6 Religion Tiny church and two ex-members fighting over $138,000 hoard B2 Living Section Food All that's lettuce is not iceberg C1

title: JOCKEYS, AT HEARING, DENY TAKING PART IN FIXING RACES
description: Seven prominent active and former jockeys denied under oath yesterday that they had any role in fixing horse races at New York tracks in the mid-1970's.

title: SCHOLARSHIP AND STEEL; Pink Clink
description: On the West Coast, a former probation officer and prison administrator named Alex Schauss has decided that painting jail cells pink calms inmates and reduces violent behavior. He promotes the ''pink clink'' movement in seminars for jail and prison officials.

title: Annette S. Heyman Wed To Sidney Fine, a Lawyer
description: Annette S. Heyman of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., widow of Lazarus S. Heyman, a real-estate developer of Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Sidney A. Fine, a retired State Supreme Court Justice.

title: CONTINENTAL BANK (NORRISTOWN, PA) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Connors Changes Pace in Bid for No. 1
description: There was a time, not long ago, when it was unnecessary for Jimmy Connors to discuss the fires within him because often enough they raged out of control for everyone to see. But now, as he tries to regain the top ranking less than two months from his 29th birthday, the fires are stoked only when there is a purpose.

title: VIOLINIST' SLAYER FACES DAMAGE SUIT
description: The husbund of the murdered violinist Helen Hagnes plans to sue her killer and the Metropolitan Opera Association for damages, according to papers filed in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan. The slaying occurred last July 23 in the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Judge Says Mrs. Peron May Leave Argentina
description: A federal judge today gave former President Isabel Martinez de Peron permission to travel to Spain for three months.

title: CHEMPLAST INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Herbie Mann to Open Riis Park Series Today
description: Herbie Mann and his Flute and Percussion Theater will perform today at 7:30 P.M. in the first of eight free concerts on the mall at Jacob Riis Park in Queens. The concerts are sponsored by the Gateway National Recreation Area, Queens Council on the Arts, Chase Manhattan Bank and Budweiser.

title: WHEN SAUDI ARABIA BOLSTERS THE I.M.F.
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Health; THOUGH THE HAZARDS ARE CLEAR, 55 MILLION CONTINUE TO SMOKE
description: ''Smoking-related diseases are such important causes of disability and premature death in developed countries that the control of cigarette smoking could do more to improve health and prolong life in these countries than any single action in the whole field of preventive medicine.'' The World Health Organization.

title: AID FOR THOSE WHO WANT TO QUIT
description: The old saw that it is easy to stop smoking - as Mark Twain said, ''I ought to know because I've done it a thousand times'' - is all too familiar to millions of smokers who would like to kick the habit. Many strategies to help enlarge the ranks of former smokers have been devised, ranging from special chewing gums and countdown filters to hypnosis and group therapy.

title: DOW CUTS LOSING STREAK AT 8
description: A last-minute burst of buying catapulted the Dow Jones industrial average into the win column yesterday after eight successive losing sessions.

title: LIKENS HUNGER STRIKE TO ABORTION:
description: Mother Teresa of Calcutta, winner of the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize, visiting Ballycastle, Northern Ireland, where she spoke at the city's Summer Festival. She told her audience that the hunger strike staged by Irish nationalists at the Maze Prison in Belfast was ''like abortion.'' ''Anything that destroys life cannot be right,'' she said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Armco Inc. said it would phase out its large-diameter pipe and tube plant in Houston as part of a consolidation of its stainless steel division in Wildwood, Fla.

title: SCHOLARSHIP AND STEEL; Clark Kent's Quandary
description: In old comic books, it was simple: when Clark Kent needed to turn into Superman, he stepped into a phone booth. But in the 1978 Superman movie he pauses at a pay phone only to find that, alas, it offers no privacy: it's mounted on a stanchion, and below waist level it's completely open to public view.

title: EL SALVADOR'S TURMOIL, U.S. PRESENCE IS POTENT
description: More than 300 Salvadoran business, government and military leaders gathered around the swimming pool of the American Ambassador's residence here to celebrate the Fourth of July.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
YOUNG MATH EXPERTS TO FACE RECKONING
description: They have been doing drills at the United States Military Academy for the last several weeks that have nothing to do with marching. The only kind of formations that mattered were rhombuses and perfect squares.

title: Notes on People; 'Father' Takes on New Meaning for Chicago Priest
description: Last year when the Rev. George Clements, a black Roman Catholic priest in Chicago, said he was going to adopt a child to dramatize the growing problem of homeless black children, the archdiocese said in a statement, ''It may be more appropriate for a priest to leave adoptions to those who are less encumbered by pastoral responsibilities.''

title: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
Lohren's 70-138 Leads State Golf by One
description: Carl Lohren, head pro at the North Shore Country Club in Glen Head, L.I., shot his second straight sub-par round today and took the lead in the 54-hole Michelob New York State Open.

title: ROADWAY EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
Wine Talk; MIKE GRGICH MAY BE THE BEST U.S. WHITE-WINE MAKER
description: RUTHERFORD, Calif. THE man is balding and deeply tanned from the unrelenting sun that bakes the vineyards. He is of medium height and wears sandals, gray slacks and a purple shirt open at the neck. He speaks with an Eastern European accent, sometimes lapsing into his native Croatian when talking to a countryman on the telephone.

title: No Headline
description: New York City will raise to $100 million from $75 million the size of its first long-term bond offering of this fiscal year, to be issued next Monday, the Office of the City Comptroller said yesterday. The city plans to issue $225 million in municipal bonds this year.

title: Alouettes Sign Oklahoma Star
description: Keith Gary, the No.1 draft choice of the Pittsburgh Steelers, has signed a two-year contract with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League.

title: HEAD OF CELEANSE UNIT OUTLINES HIS STRATEGY
description: C. Eugene Anderson, the newly named president of the Celanese International Corporation, the unit of Celanese Corporation that oversees its far-flung international operations, said yesterday, ''Working with our domestic companies, our people here in New York and with the various foreign subsidiaries and affiliates, we plan to develop an overall strategy for these businesses that should carry us well into the future.''

title: BELANGER: A PROUD NEGOTIATOR
description: Mark Belanger's face says it all when he comes from the bargaining table to the press room after each negotiating session fails to produce a settlement in the baseball strike. By the time the session ends, his lean, serious face is dark with stubble and the circles under his eyes are like deep smudges of soot. Before Belanger begins describing his anger and frustration, his face speaks for him and its message is ominous.

title: ENCOURAGING (OR FORCING) A CHILD TO EAT
Around the World; Italy's New Government Presented to Parliament
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini presented Italy's 41st Government since World War II to Parliament today, vowing to fight terrorism, improve the economy and work to strengthen Western Europe's alliance with the United States.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When I visited my local fish market recently, the Seafood Shop in nearby Wainscott, I was queried at some length about clams. ''I have been told,'' a young woman said, ''that quahogs are called chowder clams. Can you make a genuine clam chowder with small clams such as littlenecks and cherrystones?''

title: ELLENBERGER IS FOUND GUILTY
description: Norm Ellenberger, the former University of New Mexico basketball coach, was found guilty today on 21 of 22 counts of fraud and filing false public vouchers.

title: STATE NATIONAL BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Foremost Agrees To Acquire Inland
description: Foremost-McKesson Inc. said it had agreed to buy the Inland Chemical Corporation, which specializes in reclaiming and recycling chemicals.

title: HUNTINGTON HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SHARP RISE IN CAR PARTS FROM ABROAD FORECAST
description: United States automobile makers say they intend to sharply increase in the next few years the percentage of auto parts they purchase or build abroad, according to a recent survey of manufacturers and suppliers conducted by University of Michigan reseachers.

title: MISSISSIPPI DEMOCRAT WINS HOUSE SEAT IN CLOSE CONTEST
description: Wayne Dowdy, a Democrat who received strong backing from organized labor and blacks, apparently won Mississippi's vacant Fourth Congressional District seat tonight in a narrow upset victory over Liles B. Williams, a Republican who is a strong supporter of President Reagan's programs.

title: SALADS, SANDWICHES, SAUCES
description: SINCE I first began to write about food, I have enjoyed indulging, no matter how trivially, in word play. If the subject was chocolate mousse or a charlotte russe, for instance, the temptation was always to write that ''many are cold but few are frozen.''

title: CITY PLANS TO KEEP 5,000 IN CETA JOBS
description: City officials said yesterday that they would come up with $3 million to keep 5,000 youths in job training programs through September.

title: Swiss Shipowner Raises Bank Stake
description: Bruce Rappaport, a Swiss citizen and the chief executive officer of Inter Maritime Management, a corporation based in Geneva, said he had acquired a 5.6 interest in the Bank of New York Company and that he may acquire more shares.

title: PROBLEMS FOR VW AS U.S. IMMIGRANT
description: The rhythm of the assembly line is hypnotic. Young men and women fasten on accessories in measured steps while the freshly painted frames of Rabbits bob down the line to a meeting with their West German-made engines.

title: Giants Oust Richardson And Promote Haller
description: H.B. (Spec) Richardson was dismissed today as vice president of baseball operations for the San Francisco Giants and replaced by Tom Haller, a former Giant catcher and the team's director of player development.

title: Insurer Ordered to Pay Dentist's Defense Costs
description: The New York State Court of Appeals today ordered an insurance company to pay the legal expenses of a dentist being sued by a patient who said he had sexually abused her.

title: E.E.C. Threat On Canada
description: The European Economic Community might take ''countervailing action'' against Canada because it is holding its energy prices far below world levels, community officials said here today.

title: A Person for the Court
description: President Reagan has chosen a woman for the Supreme Court - and more. Other Presidents have had the will, or the opportunity, but never both. Give him credit, as the National Organization for Women does in calling the appointment of Sandra Day O'Connor a victory. The nation's highest court, which remained segregated by race for a century after the Civil War, is a male club no more.

title: Private Links Urged on Mail
description: The Postal Service must form a partnership with private communications companies if it is to make a success of a planned electronic mail service, according to a report submitted today to the mail agency's board of governors.

title: TAXES AND BUDGET AWAIT CONGRESS ON ITS RETURN TODAY
description: At the top of the agenda tomorrow when Congress returns from a 10-day recess will be a confrontation between President Reagan and House Democratic leaders on a tax bill and a House-Senate conference on a $38 billion package of budget cuts.

title: Detroit Edison Issue
description: The Detroit Edison Company won state Public Service Commission approval today for a $1.9 billion debt issue, the utility's largest ever.

title: Around the Nation; WITNESS IN BRIBERY TRIAL TELLS OF OFFER BY F.B.I.
description: A Washington lobbyist testified today that Federal agents investigating insurance racketeering had used threats and offers of immunity in seeking his help in convicting Carlos Marcello, a reputed leader of crime in the Southwest.

title: CITIES SERVICE: TAKEOVER TALK
description: In the fast-paced, big-money world of oil company mergers, one name that has been in the news with increased frequency is the Cities Service Company, the Tulsa, Okla., energy conglomerate that is the nation's 20th-largest oil company.

title: Mead Net Up 10.8%
description: The Mead Corporation, the paper and lumber company, said today that it had a gain in earnings for the second quarter despite soft conditions in the housing industry. The company said that net income for the quarter rose by 10.8 percent, to $39.8 million, or $1.48 a share, on sales of $755.5 million, compared with earnings of $35.9 million, or $1.35 a share, on sales of $679 million in the same period a year ago.

title: Index; International
description: Uganda orders two former Amin aides to stand trial A4 Around the World A5 U.N. panel says Israel could make atomic bombs quickly A6 High U.S. aide sees need to clarify stand on Soviet A7 China keeps up denunciation of United States foreign policy A9 Iran's radio warns that foreign journalists may be spies A10 Greeks fear Albania-Yugoslav rift may imperil Balkan area A12 Government/Politics Reagan decides to transfer Cubans from Fort Chaffee A14 Gov. Brown orders fruit-tree stripping in California A14 Baker moves to end filibuster against anti-busing proposals A18 Lawmakers say constituents op- pose Reagan's programs A20 The man who gives life to Albany Republican views B3 Carey signs bill easing rules on electronic banking B3 Koch plans to shift duties of Ports and Terminals Department B4 Regan audit criticizes racing as- sociation executives B4 General Around the Nation A14 Immigration officials to question Unification Church aide A18 Four are indicted in Manhattan in tax-shelter scheme B3 Funeral for motorman is quiet de- spite calls for protest B3 Health/Science Drug may prevent dangerous herpes infections A14 New opposition arises to rapid- change theory of evolution B11 Obituaries Herman Stark, former owner of Cotton Club B11 Home Section Home Beyond the fringe: A designer's zany world in leather C1

title: Albert Parker, 79, Professor At Dickinson School of Law
description: Albert Parker, professor emeritus of law at the Dickinson School of Law in Carlisle, Pa., who formerly worked for the Justice Department, died Monday at a hospital in Carlisle. He was 79 years old and lived in Carlisle.

title: Hers
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For several weeks it will be written by Laura Cunningham, whose most recent novel is ''Third Parties'' (Coward, McCann).

title: Books of the Times
description: FEROCIOUS ALPHABETS. By Denis Donoghue. 211 pages. Little, Brown. $14.95.

title: OFFICIALS IN NEW YORK AREA DOUBT CUTOFF OF THEIR WATER IS POSSIBLE
description: Municipalities throughout the New York metropolitan area acknowledged yesterday that their water systems were open to vandalism, but expressed doubt that there could be such serious consequences as those that have occurred in Newark.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ARTS-FUNDS RALLIES IN 7 CITIES JULY 18
description: Rallies will be held in New York and a half-dozen other large cities on July 18 not only to oppose the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cuts for the National Endowment for the Arts but to call on the Federal Government to increase funds for performing-and visual-arts organizations. In New York, the rally will be from 3 to 5:30 P.M. in Lincoln Center Plaza, 65th Street and Broadway.

title: A FATHER AND SON GIVE A NEW LOOK TO AN OLD HOTEL
description: The remains of a broken pair of sunglasses lie on the fire escape, one lens spotted with yellow paint. High above, seven stories of yellow clapboard and white-trimmed windows hold almost 5,500 gallons of corn-yellow paint and semigloss white paint. The 440 windows are surrounded by caulking from more than 1,500 empty cylinders. Close to 2,000 panes of glass are held in their sashes with more than 130 pounds of glazing compound.

title: New Ratings On Bonds
description: Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday ''Ba'' ratings on general obligation bonds of Cleveland and Boston, two financially troubled cities.

title: Notes on People; THE FACE IS FAMILIAR, THE NAME IS NOT
description: There were people who looked like George Burns, Goldie Hawn, Woody Allen and Katharine Hepburn. And there were quite a few who looked like Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer.

title: A POLICE AIDE ON L.I. IS AMONG 4 INDICTED IN A TAX-SHELTER CASE
description: A Long Island police official, two lawyers and a business promoter were indicted yesterday on charges of conducting a fraudulent taxshelter scheme involving millions of dollars.

title: GETTY MUSEUM ACQUIRES REMBRANDT 'CLEOPATRA'
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., bought yesterday a Rembrandt drawing for $570,000, nearly $200,000 more than anticipated.

title: COMMERCE SOUTHWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After securities losses of $2,000 for the qr and $1,000 for the 6 mos tax credits of $1,250,000 for the qr and $2,343,0 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $349,000 for the qr and $716,000 for the 6 mos and $1,000 securities gain for the 6

title: China Textile Output
description: The value of China's textile output in the first half of the year exceeded $24 billion, a rise of 14.9 percent from the comparable period last year, the Ministry of Textile Industry said today. In an announcement through the official New China News Agency, it said the total output value of textiles in the first six months of this year was $24.29 billion. It said nine of the 10 major textile industry products ''fulfilled over 50 percent of their annual production quotas.''

title: IN 'WASTED' HOURS, TIMELESS TREASURES
description: K.C. Cole is a science writer and the author of a forthcoming book, ''Between the Lines.'' By K.C. COLE

title: CITIZENS' MOVEMENT BACKING TRUDEAU ON OIL
description: A citizens' movement has sprung up in Canada to support the Government's drive to end foreign domination of the oil and gas industry, and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has hailed it as a movement ''of great importance for our policies.''

title: Ellenberger Avoids A Prison Sentence
description: Judge Phillip Baiamonte of the state district court today deferred sentence for a year for Norm Ellenberger, the former University of New Mexico basketball coach, and said that, at the end of that period, all counts against him would be dropped.

title: Marriott Reports Gain
description: The Marriott Corporation, the hotel and motel chain, said today that it earned $21.8 million, or 81 cents a share, in the second quarter, up from $17.2 million, or 65 cents a share, in the same period a year ago.

title: Notes on People; RUNNING AGAIN
description: It was expected, and yesterday Andrew J. Stein made it official.

title: IN SOME HARLEM NEIGHBORHOODS, STREET LIFE YIELDS TO THE HEAT
description: It felt yesterday as if someone had covered the deteriorating apartment house on West 139th Street in Harlem with a giant electric blanket and locked the regulator on high. Two older women sat in the shadows just inside the building's open doors and waited for an occasional breeze to tickle the sultry stillness.

title: MOZART PREMIERE ON WHITE HOUSE LAWN
description: A recently discovered Mozart symphony received its American premiere today on the White House lawn. With President and Mrs. Reagan in attendance, Leonard Slatkin conducted the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in an 11-minute Symphony in F that Mozart composed in London when he was 9 years old.

title: U.S., IN CHANGE, IS BACKING LOANS TO 4 LATIN LANDS
description: The Reagan Administration has ordered American delegates to international development banks to support loans to Chile, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Chieftain Development Co. completed a $24 million public offering to Canadian investors of 480,000 preferred shares, underwritten by a McLeod Young Weir group.

title: Australian Diamonds
description: The West Australian Government said it would take a 7.5 percent royalty for the first diamonds mined from the Ashton joint venture's Lake Argyle site, the Minister of Mines said today.

title: SCENES FROM CITY'S PAST ON EXHIBIT AT GALLERY
description: A series of black and white photographs depicting the changing exterior of Gracie Mansion from its rather drab wood frame in 1850 to its present grandeur is on view until July 24 at City Gallery, 2 Columbus Circle.

title: Around the Nation; MISSING PERSON REPORTS FALL SHARPLY IN ATLANTA
description: The number of missing black youths reported to the police has fallen in recent weeks, perhaps because parents believe a two-year string of slayings is over, the authorities said today.

title: PAN AMERICAN BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Union Oil of Canada for Sale
description: The Union Oil Company of Canada Ltd. was put on the auction block here today by its parent, the Union Oil Company of California. Local experts estimated the current value of Union Canada at $1.5 billion to $2 billion (Canadian).

title: MIDTOWN HIT-RUN VICTIMS, 10, MOURNED
description: The families and friends of two 10-year-old boys who were killed in related hit-and-run accidents in midtown Manhattan struggled yesterday with the reality of their deaths. The boys were struck down Tuesday night while riding their bicycles on 10th Avenue sidewalks.

title: MARRIOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 19
Around the World; FRENCH COURT APPROVES EXTRADITION OF 3 BASQUES
description: A French appeals court today approved the extradition to Spain of three Basque militants.

title: Malaysia Cuts Oil Price
description: Petronas, Malaysia's state oil company, has lowered its crude oil selling prices by as much as $2 a barrel, bringing the new prices for various crudes to between $36.10 and $37.90 a barrel, industry sources said today.

title: BEYOND THE FRINGE: A DESIGNER'S ZANY WORLD IN LEATHER
description: ''TROPICAL 'Star Wars' '' was the way Issaye Miyake, the Japanese fashion designer, described it. That's more than others have said. Bobby Breslau's East Village apartment tends to leave many visitors speechless.

title: MORGAN, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Design Notebook; GREAT BEACH HOUSES DEFER TO THE OCEAN
description: PAUL GOLDBERGER

title: Q & A
description: Q. We have been treating our oiled walnut furniture (now 26 years old) with an oil that has a linseed oil base. We have had good results in the past. However, recently whenever we use the product a large amount of brown color comes off the furniture, leaving the finish looking dull and streaked. Can you please advise us what we can do to this furniture to restore it? - Mrs. K.G.D., Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: GOLD FALLS BELOW $400 IN EUROPE
description: The price of gold, which only a year and a half ago was at its peak of $850 an ounce, fell below $400 today - to $397.75 in London. It was the lowest level gold had reached since late 1979, when its price began to surge.

title: TESTS SHOW DRUG MAY CONTROL HERPES THREAT
description: An experimental drug shows promise of preventing outbreaks of cold sores and genital herpes, infections that are a nuisance for the healthy but may be fatal to newborn babies or the very ill, a study shows.

title: PACIFIC REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including nonrecurring gains of $53,029 or 6 cents a shr for the qr and $1.1 million or $1.33 a shr for the yr... C-Including nonrecurring gains of $100,976 or 12 cents a shr for the qr and $284,027 or 34 cents a shr for the yr

title: POP: CARMEN MCRAE DOUBLES WITH STANLEY TURRENTINE
description: STANLEY TURRENTINE and Carmen McRae, who appeared at the Savoy in Tuesday, proved a well-matched double bill of pop-jazz middleweights. Mr. Turrentine, the tenor saxophonist who came to prominence in the late 50's as a member of Max Roach's group, has gone on to become the archetypal pop-jazz crossover performer. His albums tend to be glossily orchestrated affairs in which he plays what appear to be jazz-ornamented renditions of contempory pop-soul ballads.

title: HE'S KEEPING GIANTS IN GEAR
description: For two weeks, Eddie Wagner was vacationing at his home in Lakewood, N.J., and putting in an aboveground swimming pool. But his mind was at Giants Stadium, 80 miles to the north.

title: Police Force's Safe Stolen
description: The police said today that they had no idea who had stolen a safe containing as much as $3,000 from the Crystal City Police Department.

title: Briefs
description: * Allied Corp. said it has purchased a one-fifth interest in Calgene Inc. The price was not disclosed.

title: Advertising; Brouillard Account
description: The Bendix Corporation, which in March mutually agreed with D'Arcy-McManus & Masius to end their 37-year relationship, has just picked Brouillard Communications, the corporate advertising specialty division of the J. Walter Thompson Company. It beat out four other agencies for the account. The last campaign from D'Arcy had the theme, ''We speak technology.''

title: ISABEL PERON PREPARING TO GO TO SPAIN TODAY
description: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron, freed by a federal court Monday, has remained secluded inside her country estate near here as she prepares to leave for Spain tomorrow.

title: GETTING NEW WINDOWS ON YOUR WORLD
Notes on People; UP OR DOWN, THE AUDIENCE IS WITH STACY KEACH
description: Although Stacy Keach has done just about everything as an actor, from villains and cowboys to Shakespeare and O'Neill, what he is doing now is @extraordinary. In addition to singing and dancing as the star in the national company of ''Barnum,'' he walks a tightrope.

title: 10 SAVED FROM ATLANTIC
description: A cargo ship rescued the 10 occupants of a yacht that sank in the Atlantic today, officials at the military Search and Rescue Center here said. They said the 10 were in good condition after being picked up from life rafts by the cargo ship Oldendorf.

title: BELGIAN CYCLIST WINS 14TH LEG OF TOUR:
description: Eddy Planckaert, second from left, leading the pack in the Tour de France leg from Brussels to Zolder,

title: IN 1981, AN INQUIRY
description: In June 1945, Eugene V. Rostow, then professor of law at Yale Law School, and now director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, wrote that in the United States during World War II ''100,000 persons were sent to concentration camps on a record which wouldn't support a conviction for stealing a dog.''

title: MEXICANS DENY OIL CUTBACK
description: Mexican oil officials today denied published reports that Mexico was reducing its production of crude oil by 700,000 barrels a day.

title: THEIR VALUE PUT AT $2 MILLION
description: MARSEILLE, France, July 8 (UPI) The police raided a heroin laboratory today and seized morphine base for heroin that they said was worth $2 million.

title: Imperial Shutting Heavy-Oil Plant
description: Imperial Oil Ltd. announced today that it was suspending its $12 billion (Canadian) heavy oil production and upgrading facility at Cold Lake in western Canada because of the continuing governmental dispute over energy issues.

title: Florida Bank Acquisition
description: Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. said yesterday that it would not consider a $210 million acquisition offer from the North Carolina National Bank until several ''complex'' legal questions had first been resolved.

title: Futures in C.D.'s Offered Today
description: The New York Futures Exchange will open the first futures market in bank certificates of deposit today. An offshoot of the New York Stock Exchange, the 11-month-old commodity market also provides markets in Treasury bond and bill futures.

title: MILLER SAYS GREBEY HELD BACK
description: The 30-man executive board of the Players Association, in a fourhour meeting Tuesday night, reiterated its solid support of the players' bargaining team in the 27-day-old baseball strike. The 26 owners, in a meeting today, will announce their backing of their negotiating committee, one of the owners, Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox, predicted yesterday.

title: Satellite Venture
description: Electrohome Ltd. of Ottawa and Microdesign Ltd. of Toronto announced that they wouls form a joint 50-50 venture, the Gensat Communications Corporation, for the production of home satellite receivers.

title: Notes on People; HOWARD HUNT REGAINS RIGHT TO CARRY WEAPONS
description: The Governor of Florida, Bob Graham, and his Cabinet sat as an executive clemency board in Tallahassee yesterday, and restored the right of E. Howard Hunt, the Watergate conspirator, to own and carry firearms.

title: BUCKMINSTER FULLER: CELEBRATING THE 86TH
description: RICHARD BUCKMINSTER FULLER, poet, cartographer, futurist, maverick scientist and, most notably, inventor of the geodesic dome, did not know what to say. ''And that's unusual for me,'' he explained.

title: Market Place; A Conoco Call: Rags to Riches
description: IN the high-risk game of call options, there is nothing like the ''pure play'' to set the mouth of a speculator watering. In simplest terms, this involves the purchase of a call giving its holder the right to buy 100 shares of the underlying stock at a set price until the call expires.

title: 5 BIG CANADIAN BANKS GAIN NEW YORK PERMITS
description: Ending a three-decade-old ''gentlemen's agreement,'' five major Canadian banks received permanent licenses yesterday to engage in full-service banking in New York.

title: DRILLING INDUSTRY SUPPORTING ACCELERATED OFFSHORE LEASING
description: Spokesmen for the offshore oil drilling industry said today that the industry is able and willing to respond to the greatly accelerated offshore leasing program announced by Interior Secretary James G. Watt.

title: Rex M. Whitton Dies; Was U.S. Road Chief
description: Rex M. Whitton, a civil engineer who was head of the Federal Highway Administration from 1961 to 1966, died Tuesday at Lakeside Hospital in Kansas City, Mo., after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Business People; 2Admiral Will Direct Playboy's British Group
description: Adm. Sir John Devereaux Treacher, a Briton who retired in 1977 as Commander in Chief of the Royal Navy's fleet, comes aboard Playboy Enterprises next month as chairman and managing director of Playboy's British Group of Companies, the subsidiary that includes all Playboy operations in Britain, including three London casinos.

title: THE U.S.'S SOUTHERN FLANK
description: Under the Reagan Administration, United States foreign policy toward Central America markedly contrasts with the policies of emerging leaders in the region's neighborhood, Mexico and Venezuela.

title: LEGISLATIVE CHIEFS SEEK VOTES FOR AID TO TRANSIT
description: After a flurry of last-minute compromises by legislative leaders desperate to capture the necessary votes, the Assembly and the Senate hoped to begin debate in the predawn hours today on five new taxes to finance mass transit. The leaders had announced tentative agreement on the taxes last Thursday.

title: CANADA'S CARTEL ROLE OPPOSED
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his Government faced accusations in the House of Commons today that they had broken their own antitrust laws in allowing an international uranium cartel of which Canada was a member to fix domestic and world prices.

title: Advertising; Grey Conahy & Lyon Wins Yarn Account
description: In competition with Ted Chin & Company and Ogilvy & Mather/2, Grey Conahy & Lyon, a subsidiary of Grey Advertising, has won the account of the year-old Craft Yarn Council of America.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption, supplied by Con- tact Press Agency, that appeared June 30 with an article about Soweto, in South Africa, gave the location incor- rectly. The photograph was taken in a squatter's camp outside Cape Town.

title: Dr. Michael Buonocore Dies; Developer of Teeth Sealants
description: Dr. Michael G. Buonocore, chairman of the department of dental materials at the Eastman Dental Center in Rochester, died of Hodgkin's disease Tuesday at his home in Rochester. Dr. Buonocore, who developed plastic sealants on teeth for protection against decay, was 62 years old.

title: A MAN WHOM SOCIETY FORBIDS TO DIE
description: To the Editor:

title: VIOLENCE FOLLOWS 5TH DEATH IN ULSTER FAST
description: Hopes for a quick end to the prison hunger strike here appeared at an end today. Street violence broke out after the death of another hunger striker and a reaffirmation of the British Government stand against the Irish nationalist protesters.

title: ARIZONA BANK (PHOENIX) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MORGAN HAS OPERATING DROP
description: Despite an after-tax rise of almost $14 million from nonrecurring gains, J.P. Morgan & Company reported yesterday that its secondquarter net operating earnings declined 6.8 percent from the level a year earlier.

title: Oil Pipeline Plan Delayed
description: The Trans Mountain Pipe Line Company, citing a drop in worldwide petroleum demand, said today that it had shelved indefinitely its plans for an $800 million pipeline project to move Alaskan crude oil to refineries in the United States Middle West and eastern Canada.

title: British Bond Sale a Setback
description: A major sale of British Government bonds dealt Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party Government a setback in its attempts to meet borrowing needs.

title: CONROY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Ashe, as Mr. Cool, Suited to Cup Captain's Role
description: Stan Smith, who has played 10 years for United States Davis Cup teams and is a member of the team that faces Czechoslovakia on the weekend at the National Tennis Center, listened quietly the other day as Arthur Ashe described his responsibilities as captain.

title: Advertising; New-Product Starts Strong in First Half
description: The first half of 1981 was the most active first half for newproduct introductions in the 17 years that Dancer Fitzgerald Sample has been publishing its New Product News newsletter, and Martin J. Friedman, editor, singles out General Foods, Heinz, Esmark, Borden, Kellogg, Campbell and General Mills for being particularly strong in the new product area.

title: U.S. Is Diplomatic On Leningrad Meet
description: A State Department spokesman said today that the Reagan Administration did not believe that United States athletes should be dissuaded from competing in the Soviet Union because of the continuing presence of Soviet troops in Afghanistan. He also said the Administration had taken no steps to discourage a United States-Soviet track and field meet in Leningrad scheduled this weekend.

title: THE 'MODEL' NUCLEAR DEAL
description: With Israel's raid against Iraq's nuclear reactor fresh in mind, the Reagan Administration is struggling to devise new ways to guard against the spread of nuclear weapons. A new policy is expected soon, but Secretary of State Haig has already announced a ''model'' agreement for selling reactors and nuclear fuel to Egypt. Is this really a well-drawn agreement? Does it establish better controls on Cairo than France and Italy had on Baghdad?

title: 1980 SLUMP TERMED SHORTEST ON RECORD
description: The economic decline that began in January 1980 bottomed out just seven months later, making it the shortest recession on record, according to the National Bureau of Economic Research.

title: STATE TASK FORCE ON CRIME CALLED INEPT BY ABRAMS
description: It was designed to be New York's chief weapon against organized crime. But 11 years after the state's Organized Crime Task Force was established, Attorney General Robert Abrams describes its record as a fraud, and other law enforcement officials portray the unit as inept or ineffectual.

title: U.S. CLARIFICATION ON MOSCOW URGED
description: A senior State Department official said today that he believed the United States ''must be more articulate'' in explaining its policy toward the Soviet Union to offset what he called ''a rise in pacifism, neutralism and antinuclear attitudes'' in West European countries.

title: NEW FIRM TO MANAGE OPTIONS
description: To take advantage of the growing options market, three former officers of J.P. Morgan and five former senior executives of Paine Webber began business yesterday as The Options Group, a partnership that will manage option-related portfolios, analyze options on equities and debt instruments and provide consultative services regarding options.

title: MAJOR FEDERAL POWERS AFFIRMED
description: Facing its first change in membership in nearly six years, the Supreme Court has just ended a term that affirmed the authority of the Federal Government to act in several important areas: to safeguard the health of workers, to regulate foreign travel in the name of national security and to override private legal claims in order to settle a major foreign policy crisis.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including nonrecurring gains of $836,000 or 5 cents a shr for the latest first qr and $1,155,000 or 9 cents a shr for the yr-ago first qr

title: U.S. DROPS TRUST SUITS AGAINST MACK, 2 OTHERS
description: The Reagan Administration today dropped two antitrust suits filed by the Carter Administration after acknowledging that it had created ''a more favorable atmosphere for mergers'' of big business.

title: The U.N. Today; July 9, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the World Dis- armament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: GREBEY'S CREDIBILITY IS QUESTIONED
description: A lawyer for the Major League Baseball Players Association, seeking to link the owners' concern about escalating salaries to their attempt to gain professional compensation for premium free agents, attacked the credibility of Ray Grebey, the owners' labor relations chief, yesterday.

title: MILLER, HERMAN, INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
ISRAEL NEEES NO NEW ENEMY STATE AT ITS BORDER
description: To the Editor:

title: PANEL APPOINTED TO STUDY MILITARY MANPOWER
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan had appointed a commission to study all aspects of military manpower. The study, according to Pentagon officials, will include a review of whether to revive the draft.

title: Advertising; They Seek To Acquire Talent
description: THERE are a number of reasons why one ad agency might want to acquire another. Frequently it is to get accounts. But at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, according to James D. Travis, the president, it is only to bring in talented people.

title: WHITE HOUSE REBUTS CHARGES THAT NOMINEE HAS VOTED FOR ABORTIONS
description: President Reagan was reported today to be urging some of his conservative allies to ''keep an open mind'' on the qualifications of Judge Sandra Day O'Connor, his newly announced choice for the United States Supreme Court, until her confirmation hearings are completed.

title: 2 Boys Killed in 2 Accidents When Hit by Cars in Queens
description: Two boys were killed yesterday when they were struck by cars in separate accidents in Queens. The police said an 18-month-old boy, Aler Garcia, was crushed against the door of a garage next to his home at 90-38 170th Street in Jamaica, Queens, when a car abruptly swerved into the driveway at about 9 P.M. The driver, Isias Molina, 44 years old, of 144-37 72d Avenue, Flushing, Queens, was charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said.

title: MOTORMAN'S RITES DRAW QUIET CROWD
description: Jesse Cole was buried yesterday after a quieter funeral than some of his colleagues in the Transport Workers Union had hoped. Mr. Cole, a subway motorman, died last Friday at the age of 36 when his IRT train slammed into the rear of another train that had halted in front of him between the Utica and Sutter Avenue stations in Brooklyn.

title: UGANDA ORDERS TWO FORMER AMIN AIDES TO STAND TRIAL FOR MURDER
description: After a long, erratic legal process, a magistrate today ordered two former senior aides of Idi Amin to appear before Uganda's High Court to face murder charges.

title: Heimann Joining Warburg, Paribas
description: John G. Heimann, former United States Comptroller of the Currency, has become chairman of the executive committee and a managing director of Warburg, Paribas Becker-A.G. Becker, the New York-based international investment banking firm. His salary has not been disclosed.

title: PENALTY URGED FOR DEMOCRATS WHO OPPOSE PARTY IN HOUSE
description: Charles Manatt, national chairman of the Democratic Party, suggested today that the House party leadership consider disciplining members who consistently worked to defeat party programs.

title: Business People; Lehman Brothers Aide Promoted to President
description: Lewis L. Glucksman was elected president and chief operating officer of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., yesterday, succeeding Peter G. Peterson, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: SLOANE SELLS PORTION OF STORE
description: W.& J. Sloane Inc. has agreed to sell a portion of its flagship Fifth Avenue store in Manhattan for an amount in excess of $10.5 million, the retail furniture chain and its parent company, the City Stores Company, announced yesterday. Neither the square footage being sold nor the purchaser was identified.

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Advertising; Newspaper Ad Revenue Up an Estimated 25%
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau has reported that daily newspaper advertising revenues were up an estimated 25 percent in May, to about $1.62 billion.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CARTER LETTER TO AIDES
description: Following are excerpts from a letter by former President Jimmy Carter on July 3 to his former Cabinet officers and senior staff members:

title: Gardening; MAINTAINING LARGE PLANTS IN CONTAINERS
description: Jack and his beanstalk are unimpressive after you have seen what city gardeners can grow in tubs on doorsteps, porches, paved yards and patios as well as on roofs or balconies. When there is no ground to plant in, containers are the only way to have a garden and big plants sometimes spring from very little pots.

title: U.S. NOTIFIES 44 NUCLEAR PLANTS TO TEST FOR SUSCEPTIBILITY TO CRACKING
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has notified the operators of 44 nuclear plants, including Consolidated Edison's Indian Point No. 2 about 35 miles north of Manhattan, that their reactor vessels should be tested to determine whether they were subject to cracking under certain conditions.

title: Helpful Hardware Streeter; TWO SPECIAL LOCKS
description: An unusual lock or latch can add great style to any door, particularly if it is well made and of high quality material. We have recently come across two very special locks which could inspire a hardware buff to have a door made just to be able to use such a lock.

title: Home Improvement; PLASTIC GUTTER SYSTEMS SNAP TOGETHER WELL
description: Vinyl rain gutters and downspouts have made it easier than ever before for the home handyman to replace his old rotted or rusted gutters with new ones that will never need painting, and that will never rot, rust or deteriorate with age.

title: 90-1 PAYOFF AT MEADOWLANDS
description: While Bruce Springsteen had his fans rocking in the aisles a few furlongs to the east and Grover Kemble and Za Zu Zaz had their fans rolling in Trackside Park, the most beautiful music for long-shot players was taking place on the Meadowlands track tonight.

title: THEORY OF RAPID EVOLUTION ATTACKED
description: A recently developed and increasingly popular theory of evolution, which holds that modern man and other species evolved by rapid, episodic events instead of by the Darwinian model of slow, gradual development through natural selection, has aroused new opposition.

title: British Gas To Sell Stores
description: In another move to return profitable parts of Britain's nationalized industries to private ownership, the Government today ordered the state-owned British Gas Corporation to sell the 900 appliance stores it owns. The shops, which sell stoves and other gas appliances, have annual sales of about $376 million and employ about 33,000.

title: TINKER CONFIRMED AT NBC
description: The election of Grant Tinker as chairman and chief executive officer was confirmed yesterday by the board of NBC. Mr. Tinker was recommended for the post a week ago by Thornton F. Bradshaw, president of NBC's parent company, RCA.

title: SARAH CALWELL IN PEKING
description: The sounds of grand opera in Chinese make a sparkling contrast to the drab auditorium. Sarah Caldwell, director of the Boston Opera, is preparing the China Central Opera Company for a performance of Verdi's ''La Traviata'' on Saturday night.

title: ISRAEL NEEDS NO NEW ENEMY STATE AT ITS BORDER
description: To the Editor:

title: SEPTEMBER VOTE ON NOMINEE FORECAST
description: The Senate's vote on the nomination of Judge Sandra Day O'Connor to the Supreme Court is not likely until September, Senate Republican leaders said today. They also reported no significant opposition developing as yet despite threats from conservative, anti-abortion lobbyists.

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $190,000 for the qr and $324,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $219,000 for the qr $454,000 for the 6 mos

title: LOOKING WARMLY AT A HOT 95o DAY
description: As the temperature rose relentlessly to 95 degrees yesterday and the fumes poured from the cars coming off the nearby West Side Highway, Valentino Paolilla stood shoulder-deep in a hole on 42d Street drilling concrete.

title: MRS. THATCHER PLEADS FOR CALM
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher pleaded with the British people tonight to halt the epidemic of violence in the country's inner cities, which she said threatened to ''destroy everything we value.''

title: MOST MAJOR BANKS LIFT PRIME 1 2 POINT, TO 20 1 2%
description: Most of the nation's major banks raised their prime lending rates yesterday by half a percentage point, to 20 1/2 percent, only a percentage point below the record set last December.

title: The City
description: A Brooklyn man was reported in serious condition after being shot in a Queens cemetery by a police officer who said he thought the crowbar he was carrying was a rifle.

title: DO OIL AND CHEMISTRY MIX?
description: It would be the biggest corporate merger in history. Du Pont, America's largest chemical company, proposes to pay $6.8 billion for Conoco, the ninth largest oil company, to become the seventh largest industrial concern in the country, with $30 billion in sales. Should the Government stop it?

title: Advertising; Timex Advertising
description: Grey Advertising; Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn; Kenyon & Eckhardt, and Warwick, Welsh & Miller were all invited to compete for the gift advertising assignment from Timex, a $5 million piece of business that was being handled by B.B.D.O. The company decided to give it to Grey, which already was the Timex agency for all other timepiece advertising.

title: WALTER SCHLESINGER
description: Walter C. B. Schlesinger, partner of the New York law firm of Schlesinger & Schlesinger, died last Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 87. He lived in Manhattan.

title: WHEN PARENTS LEAVE THE NEST
description: My husband, son, and I stand at the airport gate waiting for my parents. They have been down in Florida, looking for a place to live. I realize that, come September, this is how we'll be meeting from now on. One of us will be standing in a terminal waiting for the other's plane. I will be able to see how they've changed, aged. They won't be a part of my weekly, if not daily, life. They will be saying to my son, ''My, how you've grown.'' They won't be as big a part of his life. My parents and my son won't know each other's day-to-day lives. I'm jealous that my husband's parents, who have no plans to move, will take a larger part in my son's life.

title: Technology; Computers Aid Site Decisions
description: IMAGINE the Smith family driving off for a summer vacation. They pull into a service station, approach a computerized mapping system and ask it to print the following maps: a road map, including indications of where road crews are working, on which other maps can be overlaid; a map of historical sites on their route; a map showing the types of trees, plants and animals that are likely to be found near their rest stops, and a map showing property lines and values in two areas where they might like to buy a vacation home. Moreover, Mr. or Mrs. Smith can then ask for drawings of the countryside as it appears from rest stops the family is considering as picnic sites.

title: PARKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Bridge; 2 SCHOOLS OF THOUGHT SEEN IN THE SHORT-CLUB METHOD
description: For nearly half a century the short club has been a familiar tool for opening bidders with balanced hands. It was the Four Aces in the 30's who introduced the idea of bidding a three-card club suit. This left a problem, however, with a hand containing a doubleton club, three diamonds and four cards in each major, and this became more acute with the growing trend to five-card majors.

title: A JOB IS AS 'DEAD-END' AS YOU MAKE IT
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL JURY INDICTS OFFICIAL OF BOSTON SCHOOLS FOR BRIBERY
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted John J. McDonough, a member of the Boston School Committee, on five counts of bribery and extortion involving a school bus contract.

title: BEGIN SAYS LIKUD FINDS 3 PARTNERS TO FORM COALTION
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he had put together a coalition with three conservative parties that would give him a one-seat majority in Parliament, enough to form a cabinet.

title: WOMAN'S COMA CAUSED CHILDREN TO GET A LAWYER
description: The son and daughter of a socially prominent Newport, R.I., woman who has been in a coma since December as a result of what authorities charge was a murder plot by her husband became suspicious and hired a former Manhattan District Attorney as their lawyer to investigate.

title: IRANIANS ASSERT FOREIGN REPORTERS ARE SPIES
description: The Iranian radio charged foreign powers today with sending spies into Iran in the guise of journalists. Among them, the broadcast said, were three Reuters correspondents who were ordered yesterday to leave Iran within 48 hours. The broadcast called on the authorities to take action against Iranian nationals working illicitly for foreign news organizations. ''The Ministry of National Guidance,'' the broadcast said, ''must take into consideration the destructive action of Iranians who sell their country, identify the spies and hand them over to judicial authorities so that they can be punished.''

title: Around the Nation; SAN JOSE STRIKERS REJECT OFFER IN EQUALITY DISPUTE
description: Striking city workers, demanding equal pay for women doing work comparable to that done by men, have rejected the latest offer to end a three-day walkout.

title: Yacht Hits Bridge Over Maine River; Student Sailors Safe
description: The Vernon Langille, a 36-foot, two-masted schooner, hitting a bridge over the Kennebec River near Bath, Me., and capsizing. Wind and current pushed the vessel into an abutment. The eight persons on board, including seven teen-age students from the Bath Maritime Museum, were rescued from the river by the Coast Guard.

title: Home Beat; CLASSIC FURNITURE IN MINATURE
description: Dale Flick was a carpenter; Martin Stone was a playwright and an advertising copywriter. ''We saw a demand for a new kind of miniature,'' said Mr. Stone.

title: ALPINE GEOPHYSICAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
