description: B-Including $514,000 income from discontinued operations and $46,000 extraordinary credit...C-Including $4,084,000 income from discontinued operations and $3,441,000 extraordinar

title: ABORTION'S EVIL
description: To the Editor:

title: A TAX BILL 'BIDDING WAR' SEEN
description: The much disavowed ''bidding war'' between the White House and the House Democratic leadership for the support of Southern Democrats on a tax bill seems to be developing.

title: Bond Prices Are Up Slightly; Analysts Are Still Cautious
description: Prices of Treasury bonds rose slightly yesterday afternoon after the Federal Reserve arranged purchases for its own account, but many analysts doubted that the central bank's buying signaled any shift to an easier monetary policy that would push interest rates downward.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Business Digest; THURSDAY, JULY 9, 1981; International
description: The Socialist Government in France said it would nationalize some of the nation's banks and major companies in 11 industries. The companies, among France's largest, include Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, Rhone-Poulenc, Saint-Gobain-Pont-a-Mousson and Thomson-Brandt. (Page A1.)

title: DR. WILLY LEIMGRUBER
description: Dr. Willy Leimgruber, a research chemist and director of chemical research at Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., the pharmaceutical, chemical and cosmetics company in Nutley, N.J., died of a heart attack yesterday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 50 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: U.N. PANEL SURVEYS ISRAELI ATOM SKILL
description: An international panel selected by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has concluded that Israel can make nuclear weapons ''within a very short time.'' But it says that a policy of ''deliberate ambiguity'' makes it impossible to determine whether Israel actually possesses bombs.

title: DOCK WORKERS IN POLAND STRIKE BRIEFLY IN A WARNING
description: About 40,000 dock workers engaged in an hour-long job action on the Baltic coast this morning to press demands for better working conditions and higher pay.

title: ITALY SUSPENDS ALL STOCK TRADING
description: Italy's new Government today closed the country's stock markets for the rest of the week in an attempt to halt an accelerating collapse of stock prices that began a month ago. It was the first such Government action since the end of World War I.

title: Kennecott to Sell Carbon Division
description: The Kennecott Corporation, a unit of Standard Oil (Ohio), said it would sell its activated carbon division in Pryor, Okla., which had assets of about $35 million on April 30.

title: U.S. Plan Would Cut National Airport's Use
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis today announced a plan to cut the number of flights at National Airport, ban noisy planes from 10 P.M. to 7 A.M. and bar wide-bodied jets from the congested airport until further study.

title: Sports of The Times; Getting Off on the Wrong Foot
description: REMEMBER the New York Yankees? They were a baseball team that used to play in the Bronx, spending money to bring in the best players available.

title: MOZAMBIQUE PILOT DEFECTS
description: The pilot of a Sovietbuilt MIG-17 jet fighter of the Mozambique Air Force asked for political asylum today after his plane was intercepted over South Africa, Defense Minister Magnus Malan said. General Malan said South African fighters intercepted the plane and the pilot indicated with hand signals that he wanted to land.

title: WARNER ELECTRIC BRAKE & CLUTCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SUIT ON 'ARK' CHARGES STEALING FROM A NOVEL
description: A $210 million lawsuit was filed today in Superior Court against George Lucas, Steven Spielberg, Paramount Pictures and other makers of ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' the blockbuster summer adventure movie that has grossed nearly $50 million.

title: Around the World; 219 DIE IN AN INDIAN CITY IN LIQUOR POISONING CASE
description: The official death toll in a liquor poisoning case in Bangalore rose to 219 today.

title: TREES INFESTED WITH FRUIT FLIES ORDERED STRIPPED
description: Reacting to complaints from a militant group of pregnant women and mothers with babies in their arms, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. today rejected aerial spraying of the pesticide malathion over populous Santa Clara County. Instead he ordered ''massive, all-out ground spraying'' and a mandatory fruit-stripping program to eliminate an infestation of the crop-destroying Mediterranean fruit fly. .

title: Colt Posts Rise
description: Colt Industries Inc. said yesterday that it earned $32.6 million, or $2.40 a share, in the second quarter, up 11.2 percent from $29.3 million, or $2.24 a share, in the same period a year ago. Sales climbed to $624.1 million from $562.7 million.

title: Calendar of Events; A MAILBOX AUCTION
description: Mailbox Auction, Garrison Arts Cen- ter, Garrison-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: CHINA DENOUNCES REAGAN'S POLICY IN THIRD WORLD
description: The Chinese Government's press agency said today that the Reagan Administration's support for Israel, South Africa, South Korea and Taiwan was thwarting third-world efforts to unite against Soviet expansionism and was thus eroding the United States' principal foreign policy aim.

title: 11 U.S. BANKS IN ACCORD ON POLAND DEBT SCHEME
description: A steering committee of 11 United States banks reached agreement yesterday concerning the position American banks should take in negotiating with 400 foreign banks over how to deal with Poland's indebtedness. The stern American position was, in effect, made a preamble to the so-called protocol proposed by the Europeans.

title: THE MAN WHO ENLIVENS G.O.P. VIEWS IN ALBANY
description: If you want to know what the Republican-led Senate thinks about virtually anything, ask Richard J. Roth. On a statewide transit tax to help the Metropolitan Transportation Authority: ''Why should people in Penn Yan be paying for the ZZ train?''

title: The City; Koch Endorses School Official
description: Mayor Koch endorsed Thomas Dunne, a school administrator, for the Democratic nomination for the City Council in the 29th District, which takes in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: DOW RETREATS 0.67, TO 953.48
description: The Dow Jones industrial average resumed its downward trek in mixed and slower trading yesterday. Some observers blamed investor uncertainty over interest rates for the lackluster performance.

title: Going Out Guide
description: FOR THE RECORD

title: News of Music; BOULEZ FINDING A WAY TO ELECTRONIC FUTURE
description: PIERRE BOULEZ'S ''Repons,'' now nearing completion at the Centre Georges Pompidou in Paris, will have its premiere at the Donaueschinger Festival of Contemporary Music in West Germany on Oct. 18.

title: FRENCH SOCIALISTS PRESSING TAKEOVER OF SOME INDUSTRY
description: In an eagerly awaited speech before the French National Assembly, Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy today outlined the new Socialist Government's economic program.It centers on the nationalization of major corporations in the steel and militarysupply industries and some banks, the creation of 210,000 civil service jobs and reduction of the workweek.

title: DIXON, DISSATISFIED, SAID TO SELL 76ERS
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have been sold to the owner of a chain of weight-loss centers, The Associated Press learned today.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 9, 1981
description: International A new economic program for France includes the nationalization of several major corporations, state takeover of some banks, the creation of 210,000 new civil service jobs and reduction of the workweek. The Socialists' broad program, which was outlined in Parliament by Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy, is believed to be assured of early passage. (Page A1, Column 6.) Rioting in three English cities, London, Liverpool and Manchester, together with widespread attacks on the police, continued for a fifth consecutive night. Speaking on television, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher pleaded for a halt in the violence, which she said threatened to ''destroy everything we value,'' but she offered no new programs to help remedy the economic and social problems that most local leaders blame, in part, for the outbreaks. (A1:3-4.)

title: Carpenter Sets Steel Projects
description: The Carpenter Technology Corporation, a medium-sized maker of specialty steels and other metals based in Reading, Pa., said it would spend $165 million on three capital projects as part of a $400 million program to increase its production by 50 percent.

title: Korea to Get Iranian Oil
description: The National Iranian Oil Corporation has renewed its contract to supply the Ssang Yong Refining Company with 50,000 barrels of crude oil daily, the South Korean company said today. The new contract is for one year, starting July 1.

title: BETTER TO BUY OR RENT?  A COMPUTER TELLS YOU
description: ACORNELL professor has designed a computer program that helps consumers weigh the benefits of buying a home against renting one. The program, called the Equivalent Rent Analysis, is designed to help those considering the purchase of their first home.

title: VANUATU, NEW PACIFIC NATION, MOVING TOWARD SEAT AT U.N.
description: Vanuatu, a chain of 70-odd South Pacific islands, 150,000 acres of coconut palms and only 120,000 people, took its first step today toward becoming the 155th member of the United Nations.

title: PANDICK PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
At Home Abroad; 'WE ARE POLES APART'
description: King Hussein has been on the throne of Jordan since 1952. At the start of an interview I asked who were the greatest world figures he had known during that extraordinary period of power. His first choice said a good deal about Arab feelings these days.

title: Texaco Seen Preparing Cities Service Takeover
description: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, is preparing to make a bid for another major oil company, banking industry sources said yesterday.

title: CALABRIA WINS STATE GOLF BY 2
description: John Calabria, the head pro at Brook-Lea in Rochester, fell three strokes off the lead after the first two holes today, but he came back and won the 54-hole Michelob New York State Open. His score was 211, two strokes under par, and two shots ahead of the runner-up, Carl Lohren of North Shore in Glen Cove, L.I. Calabria shot 72 today, Lohren 75.

title: GAIN CITED ON FRENCH TRADE ISSUE
description: Two Cabinet trade officers said today that the United States and France might be about to avert a threatened Atlantic trade war over export credit subsidies.

title: GRANMA IS NOT DANGEROUS
description: The Government is using an inappropriate law for dubious purposes to block delivery of 30,000 Cuban publications to American citizens. No one can sanely argue that national security is jeopardized by the distribution of such Cuban publications as Granma, a clearly labeled and crudely written propaganda weekly.

title: Around the World; THEFT OF VALUABLE BOOKS LEADS TO 2-STATE SEARCH
description: A man already wanted in Ohio on charges of stealing valuable books was sought today by the Philadelphia police for allegedly taking at least $35,000 in volumes, some centuries-old, from libraries in the city.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a book review yesterday, on ''Shadow Man: The Life of Dashiell Hammett,'' the author's name was misspelled. He is Richard Layman.

title: Money Market Notes Put Off
description: Widespread predictions that short-term interest rates are poised for a decline has interrupted the marketing of innovative money market notes that several bank holding companies proposed in late May as an alternative investment to money market mututal funds.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avery Coal Company, Philipsburg, Pa., has elected Edward R. Black chairman and Charles H. Lehmann, vice chairman, to the additional post of chief executive officer. * Chemical Bank has named Vincent F. Pellitteri a vice president.

title: BODIES OF AMERICANS RETURNED BY VIETNAM:
description: Military pallbearers carry the flag-draped coffin of an American serviceman past an honor guard during arrival ceremonies at Hickam Air Force Base in Hawaii. The remains of three U.S. servicemen missing in action since Vietnam War were released recently by Hanoi and arrived yesterday at Hickam. The bodies will be taken to an Army forensics laboratory for positive identification.

title: CAMBEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $68,000 for the qr and $120,000 for C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $733,000 for the qr an for the 9 mos

title: News Analysis
description: With his nomination of Sandra Day O'Connor for the Supreme Court vacancy, President Reagan has won admiring applause from rival politicians for a masterly political stroke as well as a strong judicial choice.

title: DR. RUDOLF MACH
description: Dr. Rudolf Mach, professor of Near Eastern studies at Princeton University and an authority on Arabic manuscripts, died yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 58 years old.

title: WATER IMPORTING BEGINS IN NEWARK
description: As sound trucks cruised city streets broadcasting appeals for conservation, Newark began importing water today to ease the serious shortage caused by the collapse of a vandalized aqueduct yesterday that cut off supplies from five major reservoirs.

title: Islanders Abandon Sale Of 36% of Stock in Club
description: John O. Pickett Jr., the managing general partner of the Islanders, said today that the proposed sale of 36 percent of the team to a partnership that would have included a Long Island cablevision company had been canceled.

title: SOUTHWEST LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DORCHESTER GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Around the World; EX-NAZI, 71, GETS 7 YEARS IN A WAR CRIMINAL CASE
description: Kurt Asche, head of a Nazi German office that transported French and Belgian Jews to death camps in World War II, was sentenced to seven years' imprisonment today.

title: IS HOLLYWOOD REALLY 'S.O.B.' DECADENT?
description: ROBERT PRESTON, a.k.a. Dr. Irving Finegarten (of Blake Edwards's ''S.O.B.''), has been in movies since 1938. But when you ask him whether Hollywood has really become the decadent, venomous world that ''S.O.B.'' portrays, he says he's no authority. ''I moved back East in 1951.''

title: OWNED COTTON CLUB FROM 1929 TO 1940
description: Herman Stark, who owned and operated the Cotton Club at both its Harlem and Broadway sites in the 1930's, died Tuesday at his home in Miami Beach after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL SEATTLE (NBA) - Signed Danny Vranes, forward from Utah and the first- round draft choice, to four-year contract estimated at $1.4 million.; COLLEGE C.W. POST - Named Fred Bruno, coach at Lindenhurst (N.J.) High School, assistant football coach. GEORGIA TECH - Named Michael Spino cross-country coach.

title: U.S. STOPS AIDE TO MOON SECT
description: The immigration authorities stopped Pak Bo Hi, a key official in the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, as he tried to enter the United States today. They said they wanted to question him in detail about the means by which he had become a permanent resident of the United States.

title: ALBANY'S BETTER WAY ON BAIL
description: Considering the national impatience over crime, New York's Legislature has acted with restraint in tightening the state's bail law. Some politicians, notably Edward Kennedy and Edward Koch, have endorsed what amounts to preventive detention -denying bail to suspects not yet convicted, who cannot prove they won't commit a crime while awaiting trial. Albany, responding to a more modest proposal by Manhattan's prosecutors, has approved revocation of bail only after a bailed defendant has gotten in trouble again.

title: LEAVE THE TEETH IN THE BRIBERY ACT
description: To the Editor:

title: DuPont Trust Is Challenged
description: Florida and Delaware asked a Florida judge today to remove three trustees of the Alfred I. duPont Trust and suggested sale of some trust holdings.

title: Arkansas Paper Gets Editor
description: William F. McIlwain, executive managing editor of The Washington Star, was named today as the editor of The Arkansas Gazette. Hugh B. Patterson Jr., The Gazette's publisher, said that Mr. McIlwain, who is 55 years old, would have overall responsibility for the news and editorial functions of the newspaper and would assume the position next month.

title: LAWMAKERS REPORT CONCERNS AT HOME ON REAGAN
description: While Representative James L. Oberstar was riding in a Fourth of July parade through his Minnesota district, the Democratic lawmaker heard an earful from his constituents lining the parade route.

title: GREEKS FEAR ALBANIA-YUGOSLAV RIFT PERILS BALKANS
description: The Greek Government is rebuffing attempts by neighboring Yugoslavia and Albania to embroil it in their dispute over the Albanian minority in Yugoslavia's Autonomous Province of Kosovo.

title: Larry C. Morris Smoldering Pier Fire Blankets West Side of Manhattan in Smoke Firemen in a motor boat entering a cloud of smoke as they searched for the source of a fire in the creosote-treated pilings under Pier 58 at 15th Street and the Hud-
description: son River. Black, eye-stinging smoke billowed over a wide area, prompting scores of complaints from resi-dents. More than 100 firemen battled the stubborn blaze.

title: A MATTER OF PRIORITIES:
description: During a break in a hot practice session for the Davis Cup series against Czechoslovakia, Jimmy Connors sought relief for a parched throat, while John McEnroe poured water over his face.

title: Around the World; ISRAELIS AND LEBANESE CLASH WITH IRISH TROOPS
description: A joint patrol by Israelis and rightist militiamen clashed with an Irish battalion of the United Nations peacekeeping force today just north of the Israeli border, a United Nations spokesman said.

title: Parker Hannifin Plans Tax Benefit
description: The Parker Hannifin Corporation said it will take a one-time, pretax gain of $6.7 million in its 1982 first fiscal quarter on the sale of a one-half interest in an Irvine, Calif., real estate tract.

title: Canada Oil Policy Under Fire
description: A senior official of the Reagan Administration warned Canada today of retaliatory action if the Canadian Government did not modify its ''discrimination'' against American oil and gas producers and suppliers.

title: Critic's Notebook Lamentoso; BALANCHINE'S WOMEN WITH THEIR HAIR DOWN
description: ORDINARILY, one does not expect to find women with loose hair running barefoot in the works of George Balanchine, contemporary ballet's great Neoclassicist, for Mr. Balanchine, with his love of formal design, tends to avoid anything that smacks of Romantic excess.

title: CARTER, FORSAKING A 'MORATORIUM,' DENOUNCES POLICIES OF SUCCESSOR
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, abandoning what aides described as his moratorium on criticism of his successor, has made a wide-ranging attack on President Reagan's economic, environmental and foreign policies.

title: Notes on People; NIXON HOUSE IN MANHATTAN UP FOR SALE
description: If all goes as planned, Richard M. Nixon could make a substantial profit on the Manhattan town house he and his wife, Pat, will be vacating later this month.

title: IMMUNITY FROM TOOL SLUMP
description: Joseph Amaral, a machinist who has spent 40 years at the Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company, painfully remembers past downturns in machine-tool orders when the management cut costs by laying off workers. Other tool makers did the same thing.

title: SECRETARY BELL ATTEMPTS TO EASE TEACHER FEARS
description: T.H. Bell, the Secretary of Education, went before the largely hostile American Federation of Teachers today and sought to persuade an audience of 3,100 people that the Reagan Administration policies many educators deplore would be good for the nation's schools.

title: SHOP TALK:
description: Joji Omura, Japan's Defense Minister, climbs into a Leopard, West Germany's main battle tank, during visit to the 15th Tank Brigade in Coblenz. Escorting him is Gen. Wolfgang Altenburg, commanding officer of the III Army Corps. Mr. Omura is on an official visit to West Germany.

title: REAGAN TO MOVE CUBANS OUT OF FORT CHAFFEE
description: The White House said today that President Reagan had decided to shift the nearly 1,000 Cuban refugees detained at Fort Chaffee, Ark., to another site, possibly the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba.

title: Ovett's 3:31.95 Captures 1,500
description: Steve Ovett of Britain won the 1,500-meter race today in 3 minutes 31.95 seconds, less than a second slower than his world record of 3:31.42.

title: REGAN AUDIT ASSAILS RACING OFFICIALS ON EXPENSES
description: The State Comptroller today questioned the salaries and bonuses paid to executives of the New York Racing Association and called for tighter limits on their expense accounts.

title: STYLES FOR HEROINES OF EXECUTIVE SUITE
description: As it did a few years ago when it focused on ''classics in action,'' Lord & Taylor has gathered together the variegated strands of current fashion, added some notes of its own and dubbed the package ''the new heroines.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe I can say that we have 61 Knesset members who are willing to support a government that I am about, God willing, to form.'' - Prime Minister Menachem Begin. (A1:4.)

title: U.S.-Soviet Arms Talks End
description: The United States-Soviet panel that oversees the 1972 strategic arms agreements today ended its 19th periodic review session, which began May 27. The next session of what is known as the Standing Consultative Commission is to be held later this year.

title: LAW EASES STATE RULES ON ELECTRONIC BANKING
description: Banks will have an easier time setting up branches that use machines and little plastic cards instead of tellers under a bill that Governor Carey said today he had signed into law.

title: MRS. KING LOSES BID TO DISMISS LAWSUIT BROUGHT BY EX-LOVER
description: A judge refused today to throw out a lawsuit against the tennis star Billie Jean King, brought by a woman who was once her lover, but he cleared the way for Mrs. King to seek eviction of the woman from a Malibu beach house.

title: BAKER SEEKS TO END DEBATE ON ANTIBUSING EFFORTS
description: The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., moved today to cut off debate on two antibusing proposals that have tied up the Senate floor since before the Fourth of July recess.

title: Petroleum Data Delay
description: The weekly American Petroleum Institute figures do not appear today because of a delay in statistics gathering as a result of the Fourth of July holiday. The figures will appear tomorrow.

title: COSMOS BEAT BLIZZARD 13TH TIME IN ROW
description: The Cosmos, with the best record in the North American Soccer League, managed an uninspired 2-1 victory over the Toronto Blizzard, the team with the second worst record, before a crowd of 17,642 tonight at National Exhibition Stadium.

title: AIDES TO BROWN BLOCKED INQUIRY, REPORT CHARGES
description: Top campaign aides to Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. were accused by the California Fair Political Practices Commission today of destroying, concealing and altering evidence in an investigation of allegations that the Governor had used public funds for his own political purposes.

title: MOUNTAIN STATES RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
Pakistan-China Oil Deal
description: The state-owned National Tanker Company of Pakistan has signed a contract with the China Ocean Shipping Company to transport crude oil from China to oil refineries in Pakistan, Government sources said today.

title: News Analysis
description: Mississippi voters not only took away a House seat Republicans have held since 1972 but also offered the party of President Reagan two serious warnings yesterday of obstacles to its hopes of winning the

title: CITY WILL REVAMP PORTS DEPARTMENT
description: The New York City Department of Ports and Terminals - the agency that runs wholesale vegetable markets, manages ship cargo facilities and is overseeing the building of a housing and recreation complex on the East River -may soon be confined to more traditional waterfront activities, according to Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner.

title: Pop Jazz; ROCK SINGERS ARE TRYING TO TELL US SOMETHING
description: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN kept stirring up his listeners with full-tilt rock-and-roll and then asking them to quiet down during his shows at New Jersey's Gov. Brendan Byrne Stadium last weekend. And listeners who had been on their feet shouting, their fists punching at the air in time to the beat, did quiet down, again and again, so that Mr. Springsteen could sing his more reflective ballads without distractions. He wanted to make sure his lyrics were heard, and his fans wanted to hear them. Then he would count off another up-tempo rock song, and the audience would be on its feet again.

title: POL POT AIDE SAYS DEATH TOLL WAS THOUSANDS, NOT MILLIONS
description: The former Foreign Minister of Cambodia, dismissing the conventional estimate that three million to four million people died during the three-year rule of Pol Pot, said in an interview that the total was actually 20,000 to 30,000. But the former official, Ieng Sary, acknowledged that these were the result of ''some big mistakes'' by the regime.

title: The City; CUNNINGHAM FILES PLEA OF NOT GUILTY
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the former head of New York State's Democratic organization, pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court in Manhattan to charges that he evaded paying income tax on $35,000 and then lied to cover up the alleged evasion.

title: Around the Nation; Wage Freeze Is Near, Detroit Tells Workers
description: Detroit's budget director says the city will freeze the wages of more than 20,000 city workers this week, though some unions have not yet agreed to that part of a survival plan for the financially ailing city.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A 'LOW-KEY' WATCHDOG
description: The Comptroller General of the United States, as the nonpartisan chief of an investigative agency answerable to Congress, must be able to work well with Republicans and Democrats alike. For that task, Charles A. Bowsher is well prepared.

title: Bill Cunningham In the Lap of Comfort
description: The cool bronze of the Hans Christian Andersen statue in Central Park offered relief to a resourceful passer-by.

title: Economic Scene; The Lessons From Britain
description: BRITAIN'S deep economic slump is a direct result of the monetary and fiscal policies pursued by the Thatcher Government. From an American standpoint, the question is whether the Reagan Administration, set on a similar policy course, can learn some vital lessons from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's failures.

title: The Stall in Italy
description: There is less than meets the eye in the impending confirmation by Parliament of Italy's new Prime Minister, the first non-Christian Democrat in 36 years. Giovanni Spadolini of the tiny Republican Party does not really bring in a new government despite the scandal over a secret Masonic lodge, which toppled the last regime. With minor exceptions, the parties and ministers in his Cabinet served his predecessors; and the Christian Democrats still hold more than half the posts.

title: Topics Lobbies and Leaks
description: Still Offensive

title: energywatch
description: JULY 3, 1981 In what analysts term an ''inventory adjustment,'' crude oil stocks dipped to 401.2 million barrels, down 2.2 million.

title: Bridge; NEW YORKERS CAN PRACTICE ON WEEKEND FOR NATIONALS
description: Many of New York's top-ranked players with hopes of success in the Summer Nationals, scheduled to begin in Boston in two weeks, will seize the opportunity to get in some hard practice in New York City this weekend. The main event in the Big Apple Regional Championship at the New York Hilton Hotel will be the four-session knockout teams beginning at 1 P.M. tomorrow.

title: News Analysis
description: The acceptance near dawn this morning of a plan to bail out the Metropolitan Transportation Authority ended an extraordinary, months-long political nightmare.

title: FILM: SWEETHEART OF THE THIRD REICH
description: NOT surprisingly, Rainer Werner Fassbinder's ''Lili Marleen,'' the new film by West Germany's most talented and prolific director, is made up of contradictions, but what is new for a Fassbinder work is that the film is far more entertaining to watch than it is interesting to speculate about. That means it's a disappointment.

title: Club Excludes McEnroe
description: John McEnroe, winner of the men's singles final at Wimbledon last Saturday, will not be invited to become a member of the All Englanz Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club, the Wimbledon championship committee announced yesterday.

title: POLAND'S AIRLINE STRUCK ON ISSUE OF WORKER RULE
description: In a second sucessive day of token strikes, 6,000 employees of the state-owned airline stopped work for four hours this morning in a dispute over the employees' demand that they be allowed to elect their own general manager.

title: U.S. Steps Up Afghan Aid
description: The United States will donate an extra $21 million to help international relief groups deal with Afghan refugees in Pakistan, a State Department spokesman announced today. The United States will spend $93 million in the current year to help the Afhgan refugees, an increase of $49 million over last year.

title: LITCO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
In the Nation; MR. WATT'S COASTLINE
description: Criticism from right and left may be forcing Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt to retreat - but not far - from his blunderbuss proposal to offer a billion offshore acres, virtually the entire Outer Continental Shelf, for oil exploration in the next five years.

title: THIRD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gain of 56.8% For Dow Jones
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose by 56.8 percent, to $20 million, or 64 cents a share, from $12.7 million, or 41 cents a share, in the same period in 1980, helped by the continued strong performance of The Wall Street Journal, the company's newspaper.

title: More Players Filing Protests for Payments
description: Dave Winfield of the Yankees, Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies and Steve Garvey of the Los Angeles Dodgers are among the latest group of players for whom the Players Association has filed default notices as the result of what the players say are incorrect payments or nonpayments of salaries.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Region; ATLANTIC COUNTY IS STRUCK BY UNION
description: ATLANTIC CITY (UPI) - Members of a teamsters' union local representing almost 750 Atlantic County workers walked off their jobs and forced the closing of all county public health clinics and some other programs.

title: Around the World; Youth Killed in Belfast As British Fire at Sniper
description: A 15-year-old boy was shot to death by British troops tonight as they fired back at a sniper, the authorities said. Irish Republican Army spokesman said the boy had been killed when the soldiers ''fired indiscriminately.''

title: Notes on People; GET $45,000 A YEAR WITHOUT EARNING IT?  NO, SIR!
description: As Lieutenant Governor of Illinois, Dave O'Neal makes $45,500 a year, but just about all he does in the job is collect his pay, he said yesterday.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Restaurants; PIERSIDE ROOST AND WEST SIDE THAI
description: WHAT every good neighborhood deserves is at least one small, moderate-priced and delightful eating place. Such a restaurant is under the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge in Lower Manhattan, the Bridge Cafe. Tucked away on Water and Dover Streets, one of the more obscure corners of the city, this rejuvenated pub-tavern is pleasantly ramshackle, with an old pressed-tin ceiling, wainscotting on the walls, handsome posters and prints, and red-checked tablecloths. The food is a mix-match of Continental and American dishes, with the sort of vegetarian accents that have become the trademark of the young, American chefs.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Topics; LOBBIES AND LEAKS; Newark's Spill
description: As if Newark did not have enough problems, vandals have knocked out 60 percent of the city water supply. Other water systems have come to the rescue, and Newark and other communities supplied by its system will not suffer.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES BAN ON ABORTIONS
description: A Senate subcommittee today approved legislation that could allow the states to prosecute abortion as murder, a first Congressional step toward overturning the 1973 Supreme Court decision that a woman has the right to terminate her pregnancy.

title: GOVERNORS ISLAND TOUR
description: Governors Island, home base for several thousand members of the Coast Guard and their families, will be explored on a walking tour today, sponsored by the South Street Seaport Museum.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; BIG TOP AT FORDHAM
description: A roller-skating elephant will be at Fordham University in the Bronx this morning but not to attend classes. The pachyderm will appear along with jugglers, clowns, acrobats and aerialists in a twohour performance by the Big Apple Circus, the one-ring big top that gives its audience a close look at things. All spectators are seated within 20 feet of the ring in the 1,100-seat tent. Today's 10:30 performance will be the first of 12 given through July 16. There will be three performances tomorrow and two on Sunday. The site is at the corner of Fordham Road and Southern Boulevard, across from the New York Botanical Garden. It can be reached by taking the IND's D train to Bedford Park Boulevard, then the No. 17 bus to Southern Boulevard, or the IRT's No. 4 to Bedford Park Boulevard, then the No. 17 bus. Tickets are $5 for adults, $4 for children. Reservations: 369-5110.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Aristar Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an issue of $50 million in senior notes due 1991 to be offered by a group led by Warburg Paribas Becker Inc.

title: TRUCKER IS FINED $20 FOR ACCIDENT KILLING 3 SISTERS
description: A New Jersey truck driver has been fined $20 for passing a red light in a Somerset County traffic accident in which three sisters died last February. A grand jury found no basis for criminal charges in the case.

title: Quaker Oats Names New Chief Officer
description: William D. Smithburg, the seasoned breakfast-food executive who is president of the Quaker Oats Company, will become its chief executive officer in September, succeeding Robert D. Stuart Jr., 65 years old, who will remain as chairman.

title: TASTY BAKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 13
Winchester Sold
description: The Olin Corporation, maker of Winchester firearms, said a group of executives from its sporting arms plant had signed an agreement to buy the troubled business.

title: STAMFORD TO GET 'SATELLITE' GALLERY OF THE WHITNEY
description: A major New York City museum will have a suburban satellite for the first time when the Whitney Museum of American Art opens a branch in this Fairfield County community on Tuesday.

title: No Justice Dept.  Bar to N.&W. Tie
description: The Justice Department said it was not opposed to the proposed merger of the Norfolk & Western and Southern railways.

title: FRENCH INDUSTRY ATTACKS PLAN
description: Reaction to the new Socialist French Government's nationalization program, outlined yesterday by Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy, was sharply divided today. Predictably, employers condemned the plan, while the major unions applauded it.

title: LITTLE RETAIL EFFECT SEEN
description: Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, cut its quoted prices on wholesale coffee exports by almost 50 percent yesterday, with the top grade dropping to $1.07 a pound from $2, effective Monday.

title: WEGERLE AT ISSUE
description: A soccer tteam from the Soviet Union withdrew yesterday from a tournament because the Cosmos, one of the participants, have a citizen of South Africa on their rooster.

title: HATFIELD AND OTHERS ASSAIL INEFFICIENCIES IN ARMS PURCHASES
description: Mark O. Hatfield, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, led a chorus of his colleagues today in warning that widespread support for increased military spending could quickly wane unless the cost of weapons was brought under control.

title: WATER CONCERNS EASED IN NEWARK AS PIPE ARRIVES
description: Six truckloads of new 48-inch water main arrived here this afternoon, and officials said workmen would begin rebuilding the ruptured aqueduct linking Newark to its five main supply reservoirs tomorrow.

title: JOLSON SINGS AGAIN IN JAMAICA
description: Of all the summertime conclaves that draw vacationers away from home to mix pleasure with some other passion, the Second Annual Al Jolson Film Festival and Convention, which promises to be long on entertainment and short on formal caucus, seems to offer the most tuneful route to the past. It opens and closes tomorrow at the Holiday Inn, 175-15 Rockaway Boulevard, in Jamaica, Queens, near Kennedy Airport, an international entrepot that symbolizes the universal esteem in which the throaty singer was held during his palmy days and is still held among a dedicated segment of those still alive and listening.

title: Broadway; JOANNE WOODWARD RETURNS IN FALL IN SHAW'S 'CANDIDA.'
description: JOANNE WOODWARD recently tested herself in the title role of Shaw's ''Candida'' at Kenyon College in Ohio and pronounced herself ready for a rare Broadway appearance. She wil open in ''Candida'' at Circle in the Square on Oct. 15 for a limited engagement through Nov. 22. The production is coming to Broadway from Kenyon pretty much intact, with Michael Cristofer, the actor and playwright, again staging it. ''Candida'' will mark Mr. Cristofer's Broadway debut as a director. The cast is likely to feature Jane Curtin of television's old ''Saturday Night Live'' show in the role of Proserpine, the secretary in love with Candida's husband. The pivotal role of Marchbanks, the young poet who vies for Candida's affections, will be played by Tait Rupert, a newcomer to Broadway.

title: U.S. IS TOLD TO RELEASE CUBAN
description: The United

title: HIGH-RISE IS PLANNED AT SLOANE'S
description: The Porterfield Corporation, which on Wednesday purchased a portion of the W.&J. Sloane store building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, plans to transform that structure into a high-rise, multipurpose building with offices on top of a scaled-down Sloane store, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I recognize that it takes a lot of courage to enact taxes in the United States in 1981.

title: ACQUISITION WILL FORM CONNECTICUT'S NO.1 BANK
description: In a transaction that would create the largest bank in Connecticut, with assets of more than $3 billion, the Hartford National Corporation is planning to acquire the Connecticut National Bank, it was announced yesterday.

title: PENNZOIL'S $2.5 BILLION CREDIT LINE
description: The Pennzoil Company, moving to provide ''maximum flexibility to act quickly'' during accelerating oil-takeover developments, disclosed yesterday that it had completed arrangements to borrow up to $2.5 billion.

title: CBT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per shr figures have been adjusted for a 20 percent stock divd in Sept 1980 and for a 3-for-2 stock split payable this month

title: EDUCATION OFFICIALS' MISSTEP TOWARD LITERACY
description: To the Editor:

title: VOIDING OF LENNON PLEA ASKED
description: The lawyer for the man who pleaded guilty last month to killing John Lennon asked an acting State Supreme Court justice yesterday to void the plea on the ground that his client was mentally in-competent when he made it.

title: Around the World; Swedish Aide Criticizes Superpowers on Arms
description: Sweden's Under Secretary for Disarmament criticized both the United States and the Soviet Union today for what she called their ''grotesque rivalry for universal military domination.''

title: WROTE BOOKS OF POETRY
description: Isabella Gardner, a poet whose latest work, ''That Was Then,'' was nominated for an American Book Award this year, died Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 66 years old.

title: LABOR IS SCORNFUL OF MRS. THATCHER IN DEBATE ON RIOTS
description: The House of Commons erupted in a storm of bitter recrimination this afternoon after a sixth night of urban violence, with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher forced to shout to make herself heard over the taunts of critics.

title: Devotion Pays Off for Czechs
description: Ivan Lendl and Tomas Smid will be defending Czechoslovakia's Davis Cup championship in the quarterfinal round against the United States beginning this afternoon, but yesterday the Czechoslovak captain preferred to talk about Andrea Holikova.

title: U.S. JEWS WORRY ABOUT BEGIN'S ALLIES
description: Two prominent American Jews warned yesterday that support for Israel among United States Jews would be seriously damaged if Prime Minister Menachem Begin bows to pressures by three Israeli religious parties for stronger Orthodox policies in return for their crucial support in forming a new government.

title: Oil Case Vow by Edwards
description: Energy Secretary James B. Edwards pledged today to aggressively try to recover billions of dollars in alleged overcharges by major oil companies.

title: ORATORY SHIFTS AS DEBATE TURNS TO DEFENSE BUDGET
description: For months the House of Representatives has echoed with pleas for smaller government and less spending, lower taxes and balanced budgets. Bills slicing about $36 billion from domestic programs have whipped through Congress in record time despite the countering cries that social programs were being cut too much.

title: U.S.-CANADA TENSION MOUNTS
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada will meet with President Reagan tomorrow against a backdrop of mounting resentment by American business over discriminatory Canadian investment and energy policies. At the same time, Canada faces a threat by Congress to make things more difficult for Canadian investors here.

title: NAMATH STILL PART OF GAME
description: The helicopter appeared suddenly against the blue sky, and more than 200 children peered through their helmets as it approached the field, hovered, and then landed.

title: CATERPILLAR TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RED BRIGADES THREATEN CAPTIVE'S LIFE
description: Members of the Red Brigades terrorist organization threatened today to kill a prominent Naples politician they have held for two and a half months unless the Naples city government accepts demands it has refused in the past.

title: POP: JOE JACKSON AT THE SAVOY
description: HAVING established himself as one of the brighter lights of newwave rock, the English singer and song writer Joe Jackson has made a detour into pop archivism with his fourth album, ''Jumpin' Jive,'' a salute to black jukebox music from the 1940's.

title: TOWN HALL SHUT DOWN AFTER PATCHOGUE FIRE
description: Brookhaven Town Hall here was closed this morning after a fire caused extensive damage to the basement and knocked out the electricity.

title: Credit Markets; RATES UP DESPITE FED MOVE
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday, despite moves by the Federal Reserve to supply more credit to the banking system temporarily.

title: OLD PHOTOS AND AFRICANA IN NEWARK
description: Photographs of Europe from the mid-1800's and 20th century art work from the Cameroon grasslands of Africa are on display through Sept. 8 at the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street.

title: CENTRAL PENN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST NATIONAL STATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1980 results do not reflect operatons of the former First N Bank of South Jersey, purchased as of Dec 31, 1980; and is now as the First National State Bank of South Jersey, an affiliate parent holding company

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock spli in the form of a divd effective Feb 27, 1981

title: MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STOCKS RISE AS VOLUME SLIPS
description: The stock market moved decisively higher late yesterday as volume edged lower. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 5.52 points ahead, at 959, in what was considered by many analysts as a technical rally.

title: LEAVES FOR SPAIN:
description: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron greeting supporters at airport in Buenos Aires. Mrs. Peron, released from five years' house arrest, yesterday boarded a flight to Madrid.

title: PRYOR SCREEN MARATHON
description: A midnight screening tonight of ''Which Way Is Up,'' with the comedian Richard Pryor, begins a continuous two-day showing of four films starring Mr. Pryor at the Embassy 5 Theater, Broadway and 46th Street.

title: The City; YOUTH SUES TO GET HALF OF LOTTO PRIZE
description: A 17-year-old Manhattan youth sued a neighbor for $1.4 million yesterday, contending that he was entitled to half her recordbreaking state Lotto prize because he had selected the winning number and had prayed for her to win.

title: The Evening Hours
description: ''E VERYBODY seems to be enjoying himself,'' said a pleased Marco Ricotta the other night, ''and herself.'' And indeed they were, all except the moose head. It was the first evening party of the Starbucks ''after work club,'' held from 6 to 9, and the disco-cum-Western environment was bouncing. Mr. Ricotta, who owns the club, decided, he said, to open his late-night establishment early ''for the tired executive who can't wait till 1 o'clock in the morning to party.'' So he laid on a barbecue, spotlighted his bleached steer skulls, backlighted his imitation cactus plants, turned on the shooting red neon arrows and turned up the sound system.

title: SURVIVAL, INC.
description: .8,2In the event of a nuclear attack upon the United States, the board of directors of the Exxon Corporation will operate with a reduced quorum. It is already authorized to do so by Section 4 of Article II of the corporate bylaws, which shall be effective ''during an emergency...resulting from an attack on the United States or any nuclear or atomic disaster or from the imminent threat of such an attack or disaster.''

title: Publishing; A CRITIQUE FINDS A UNIVERSITY PRESS
description: ARTICLES in The New Yorker often reappear as books, so it is no surprise that Thomas Whiteside's three-part series about the bookpublishing industry, which appeared in that magazine last year, has been issued in book form. But unlike most of Mr. Whiteside's halfdozen other books, ''The Blockbuster Complex: Conglomerates, Show Business and Book Publishing'' was published by a university press.

title: THE COMMON DENOMINATOR OF REPRESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: KHOMEINI ORDERS MILITARY PURGE AND INCREASED PRESSURE ON LEFT
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered a purge of the Iranian armed forces today and an intensified campaign against his political opponents, denouncing them as the ''last remnants of the United States.''

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Imperial Group, a British tobacco, food and brewing conglomerate, named Geoffrey C. Kent as chairman of the board yesterday following the abrupt resignation of M.A. Anson, who had held the post for a year.

title: Official Israeli Election Tally Gives Victory to Likud Bloc
description: The official results of the Israeli elections of June 30 were announced today, and they showed that Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Likud bloc had edged out the Labor alignment by 10,405 votes. Likud received 718,941 votes and Labor 708,536.

title: Business People; MORGAN STANLEY'S MAN IN CONOCO-DU PONT LINK
description: At Morgan Stanley's Midtown headquarters, they call Bruce D. Fiedorek, an athletic 30-year old vice president, ''the quarterback'' on the record, $7.3 billion Conoco-Du Pont merger agreement.

title: Burns Backs Tight Money
description: Arthur F. Burns, United States Ambassador to West Germany and former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he would be ''astounded'' if the United States changed its tight monetary policy as a result of the world economic summit meeting scheduled in Ottawa later this month.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OLD NEW YORK FLORA AND FAUNA ON SHOW
description: A petrified cross-section of a pear tree from the 17th-century farm of Peter Stuyvesant is one of the 250 exhibits in a show called ''Of the Land's Bounty: The Gardens, Meadows and Forests of New York Province and State'' at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, between 76th and 77th Streets. The exhibition, on view through Oct. 1, affords a look at the flora and fauna of our area from the mid-17th to the 19th century.

title: Royce Captures Final In Driscoll Pacing Series
description: Royce won the $193,000 final of the Governor Alfred E. Driscoll Pacing Series tonight at the Meadowlands. John Campbell drove Royce to a three-quarters-of-a-length victory over Honorable Winner, a 29-to-1 shot.

title: MUSIC FOR A SUMMER'S NIGHT FROM VERDI TO SOUSA
description: NATURE created the out of doors. Man created music. Summer music puts the two together. From the cool hills of Tanglewoood in the Berkshires to the secluded elegance of Westchester's Caramoor to the urban dockside setting of Manhattan and Brooklyn - man-made music - secluded for most of the year behind the soundproof walls of the concert hall - now takes its chances with the random, capricious and often wonderfully surprising sounds of nature. It is a phenomenon that only the summer concert experience can provide.

title: JIRI KYLIAN, THE SPIRIT OF NETHERLANDS BALLET
description: It was the morning after the Netherlands Dance Theater opened at the Metropolitan Opera House this week. Jiri Kylian, the company's 34-year old director and choreographer, was being greeted with excited squeezes, waves and words of praise everywhere he went backstage. His dancers laughingly quoted for him exuberant phrases from the newspaper reviews. The Netherlands Dance Theater, which will perform at the Met tonight and tomorrow afternoon and evening, had astonished and delighted New Yorkers once again.

title: News Summary; News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JULY 10, 1981 International Britain's House of Commons seethed with bitter recriminations after a sixth successive night of urban violence, and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was taunted and denounced by left-wing critics. Members of her own Conservative Party demanded stringent measures to combat the wave of rioting, looting and assaults on the police in the inner cities. In Manchester alone, more than 1,000 white and black youths stormed a police station and shattered and looted more than 150 shops. (Page A1, Column 1.) Poland's airline, LOT, was struck for four hours by about 6,000 employees over a demand that they be allowed to elect the line's general manager. The protest was believed to be the first walkout affecting civil aviation in the Soviet bloc. (A1:2.)

title: Foreign Affairs; A VOICE AT THE TOP
description: .4,2,156.4,0,496.8,2BONN, July 9 - Chancellor Helmut Schmidt finds it astonishing to ponder that he will be the senior participant at the Ottawa summit conference of industrial nations this month.

title: Japan, Britain In Truck Pact
description: Japan's auto industry bowed to British pressure today and agreed to exercise ''voluntary restraint'' in the export of commercial vehicles to Britain.

title: CHESAPEAKE CORP OF VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
Around the Nation; Nonunionists on the Job In Georgia Power Strike
description: Nonunion employees of Georgia's largest electric utility were on the job today as electrical workers struck the Georgia Power Company for the first time in 50 years.

title: Failures in England
description: A record number of business failures, 2,296, was recorded in England and Wales in the second quarter, Dun and Bradstreet Ltd., a business information service, said today.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $298,000 for qr and $610,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including $55,929,000 income discontinued operations

title: FOR WAR'S CASTAWAYS, PRISON IN SALVADOR IS HOME
description: A pregnant woman with a brown plastic bowl of tortillas balanced on her black hair approached the iron gate, followed by a small girl.

title: TAX BILL DEADLINE MINIMIZED
description: House Democrats said today that tax relief could go into effect on Oct. 1, even if Congress missed President Reagan's Aug. 1 deadline for passage of a tax bill.

title: Bauxite Mining Suit Dismissed
description: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit seeking to halt bauxite mining in Western Australia by subsidiaries of the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metals Company.

title: At the Movies; KURT RUSSELL, FROM BASEBALL TO THE SCREEN
description: ''ESCAPE From New York,'' directed by John Carpenter, opens in several New York theaters today. The star is Kurt Russell as a fellow called Snake Plissken. Old Snake wears an eyepatch and a scruffy beard, he talks low and raspy, kind of like George C. Scott, and he's hard, man, with great big muscles.

title: Zimbabwe Gold Mine
description: The Rio Tinto-Zinc Corporation said today that its subsidiary, Rio Tinto Mining (Zimbabwe), expects its Renco gold mine, south of Fort Victoria, to yield more than 52,500 ounces of gold annually.

title: Monsanto Faces 2d Suit
description: A $1.35 billion suit has been filed against the Monsanto Company on behalf of 43 former employees and survivors of former employees, contending that workers at a chemical plant were knowingly exposed to toxic substances that cause long-term health problems.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After securities losses of $684,000 for the qr and $705,000 for the 6 mos and $1,050,000 special gain for the 6 mos from interest collected on nonperforming loans...C-Including securit gains of $270,000 for the qr and $223,000 for the 6 mos

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock spli effective June 24, 1981

title: 7 OFFICERS INDICTED IN NEW ORLEANS
description: Seven New Orleans police officers were indicted by a Federal grand jury today after an investigation of numerous charges of police brutality and other harassment.

title: 21 FACE CHARGES IN JERSEY IN THEFT OF RAIL PROPERTY
description: TRENTON July 9 - A statewide grand jury indicted 21 individuals today on charges of stealing $1.3 million in railroad equipment from the Amtrak system and its predecessor over a six-year period.

title: Abbott Laboratories
description: Abbott Laboratories said second-quarter earnings rose 15.5 percent to a record $60.7 million, or 49 cents a share, from $52.5 million, or 42 cents, in the similar 1980 period. The health products maker had record sales of $579 million, up 16.2 percent.

title: Around the Nation; Electric Shocks Used To Spur Bible Pupils
description: The Rev. Dwight Wymer, pastor of Immanuel Baptist Church here, acknowledged today that he had used an electrical device to give children in his summer Bible class slight shocks to force them to ''listen'' to God.

title: PENNSYLVANIA GOVERNOR ASKS PLAN TO SHARE COST OF REACTOR CLEANUP
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh of Pennsylvania said today that the crippled nuclear power plant at Three Mile Island continued to represent a threat to health and safety, and he asked government and industry for $760 million to decontaminate the plant. His plan calls for the Federal Government to provide almost $200 million in aid.

title: PIER FIRE'S SMOKE MAKES A HOT DAY EVEN WORSE
description: A five-alarm fire on an abandoned Hudson River pier at 16th Street continued to burn and smolder for a third day this morning, sending smoke and irritating fumes from the West Side to the East Side.

title: Chemical Bank's Operating Net Increases 15.3%
description: The Chemical Bank announced yesterday that its net operating earnings increased by 15.3 percent in the second quarter, to $53.5 million, from $46.4 million in the comparable period of 1980.

title: VOTES ON TRANSIT TAX PACKAGE
description: Following are the votes by which the Legislature approved taxes to subsidize mass transit (Y - ''yea''; N - ''nay''; A -absent):

title: VALUABLE LETTERS STOLEN FROM GLASSBORO COLLEGE
description: Ten valuable letters, including some written by George Washington, Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin, are missing from the Glassboro State College Library.

title: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POTENTIAL TROUBLE SPOTS FOR SUMMER TRAFFIC
description: A. Palisades Interstate Parkway: Intermittent lane closing in a one-mile section south of the New Jersey line. B. Route 17: Road work near Interstate 80 will force lane closing in both directions. C. Garden State Parkway: Work at Interchange 153. One lane closed in each direction. Construction of new median barrier at the Oranges, between Union and Essex, will close one lane each way.

title: WROTE SECRET STUDY OF HITLER
description: Dr. Walter C. Langer, an American psychoanalyst who producd a secret and prophetic psychological study of Hitler for the Office of Strategic Services in 1943, died July 4 in Sarasota, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: The U.N. Today; July 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Exercise of the In- alienable Rights of the Palestinian People - 3 P.M.

title: NEW YORK REFRAINS
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; 2 at Bozell & Jacobs Set Out on Their Own
description: Kathleen Kavanagh and Joseph Genova, the co-creative directors of the New York office of Bozell & Jacobs, have quit after a year and a half, according to Miss Kavanagh, the writing half, ''to try our own wings.''

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, JULY 10, 1981; The Economy
description: Democrats in Congress said tax reductions could go into effect on Oct.1, even if Congress missed President Reagan's Aug.1 deadline for passing a tax bill. However, both the White House and Democratic leaders rejected an initiative by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas toward a compromise on the tax bill. (Page D1.)

title: TV Weekend; MARX BROTHERS, PARENTS, 2D 'ROOTS' AND BALZAC
description: WITH new programming at a premium in the summer months, the viewing game becomes a matter of choosing wisely among the reruns. Tomorrow at 8, for instance, WNEW, Channel 5, is offering the Marx Brothers in the 1935 romp ''A Night at the Opera.'' Groucho, as Otis B. Driftwood, schemes mightily to get $200,000 out of Margaret Dumont, who plays the opera patron. Before it's over, the script by George S. Kaufman and Morrie Ryskind leaves grand opera gasping for breath through the laughter.

title: TO PUT A SWIFT END TO THE END BASEBALL STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Analysis
description: The cost of modernizing China's armed forces with American weapons and equipment would be ''enormous,'' according to many analysts in this country and abroad. They question whether either the United States or China has the resources to make China a major military threat against the Soviet Union. A report by the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London estimated that the cost of modernizing one of China's 11 armored divisions would be $664 million, if the present divisional structure was followed.

title: Anaconda Project In Newfoundland
description: ST JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 9 (AP) - The Anaconda Company and the Newfoundland government said they had agreed to share the cost of a $500,000 study to determine the feasibility of a $1 billion aluminum smelter in the Canadian province.

title: The Region; BYRNE FIGHTS CURB ON PINELANDS UNIT
description: Governor Byrne notified Senator Steven P. Perskie, an Atlantic City Democrat, that he could not support the Senator's bill to dilute the power of the 15-member Pinelands Commission to control development in the ecologically important southern New Jersey region.

title: INAPPROPRIATE TRIBUTE TO PRESIDENT MARCOS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region; COMMUTERS GET A SURPRISE RIDE
description: A commuter train - the 6:07 P.M. -unexpectedly passed six stations on Conrail's New Haven line last evening, carrying hundreds of surprised passengers to Bridgeport.

title: SAL COMMUNICATIONS CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Notes on People; A VACATION RESORT DISALLOWED AS A DEDUCTION
description: In a case involving Jack R. Howard, former president and general editorial manager of the E. W. Scripps Company, the United States Tax Court has ruled that the exclusive Bohemian Club Grove of California is a ''vacation resort'' and that, as a result, membership expenses are not deductible.

title: Advertising; A Rooster Will Crow For the Putnam Trust
description: The Frank Vos Company, specialists in direct-marketing advertising, has landed the Putnam Daily Dividend Trust, a Boston-based moneymanagement company that is part of Marsh & McLennan. And as part of the job, the agency has created a new logo for the company, a rising sun with a rooster in the foreground.

title: GEORGE E. RICHARDSON
description: George E. Richardson, president of Humbert & Jones Inc., a Manhattan advertising agency, died Sunday while visiting friends in Saddle River, N.J. Mr. Richardson, a resident of Jamesburg, N.J., was 62 years old.

title: ART: MET PUTS DRAWINGS IN A SPECIAL PLACE
description: OVER the last few months the Metropolitan Museum has got itself a whole new throughway on the second floor. It leads from the European old-masters rooms to the Andre Meyer Galleries. In this way a systematic visitor can stay within the context of great painting all the way from what were once called ''the Italian primitives'' to the Impressionists and Post-Impressionists. (A sharp turn to the right toward the end of the tour will get the visitor into the 20th-century rooms as well.)

title: OWNERS SUPPORT GREBEY
description: No surprises emerged from the meeting of the 26 major league club owners last night as they expressed strong support for their bargaining team in the four-week-old baseball strike. But earlier in the day Kenneth E. Moffett, the Federal mediator, made a surprise visit to New York, left a compensation proposal with the chief negotiators for the owners and the players, and scheduled a bargaining session for 2 P.M. today, the first meeting since last Saturday.

title: TESTIMONY BEFORE N.L.R.B. IS COMPLETED
description: The final witnesses testified yesterday in the National Labor Relations Board hearing on the baseball strike, with Ray Grebey ending seven hours on the stand by persistently denying that he or Commissioner Bowie Kuhn had ever pleaded poverty for the owners of the 26 teams in the major leagues.

title: About Real Estate; REBIRTH OF BAYSIDE PROJECT AS A LUXURY CONDOMINIUM
description: THE ill-fated Village Mall apartment development was no blessing to the Bayside area of Queens. Construction began in 1974 and stopped the following year. Two ugly unfinished steel superstructures stood for six years as testimony to the housing tribulations of the middle 1970's. Soaring interest rates sank the overextended builders.

title: LIFEGUARDS MIX SUMMER FUN WITH VIGILANCE
description: Amid the squeals of splashing children and the swoosh of small waves curling across the Rockaway Beach sand, Ed Zap contemplated the satisfaction of being a lifeguard.

title: ISRAEL BANS TOURS FROM JORDAN SIDE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin issued an order today closing Israel's border with Jordan to two-way tourist traffic. The rules, in retaliation for similar Jordanian procedures that have been in force for some time, will mean curtailment of the relatively free movement permitted across the Jordan River since Israel captured the West Bank in the 1967 war. The rules apparently do not apply to West Bank residents.

title: SLIGHT INCOME GAIN REPORTED FOR MAINLAND PUERTO RICANS
description: The gap between the incomes of Puerto Rican families and all others in the United States has slightly narrowed in the last year, after widening for two decades, but an official of a national Puerto Rican service organization said yesterday that proposed Federal budget cuts threatened the new gains.

title: RAY AT NEW YORKER, TOO
description: Interest in the films of Satyajit Ray has been so great this summer that some fans are being turned away from the showings of them at the monthlong retrospective in the Museum of Modern Art. Today the New Yorker Theater, Broadway and 88th Street, will open its own six-day Ray festival with two of the Bengali director's best known works, ''Pather Panchali'' and ''Aparajito.''

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cards' Arneson Retires
description: Mark Arneson, who says he no longer can take the frustration of playing for a losing team, has retired after nine seasons as a linebacker with the St. Louis Cardinals. They have a 16-32 record for the last three seasons.

title: Triton to Acquire Parts of Pneumo
description: The Pneumo Corporation and the Triton Group said they had agreed in principle for the purchase by Triton of Pneumo's food-drug operations for $65 million in cash. For the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, 1980, those operations earned $14.3 million on sales of $683.6 million, Pneumo said.

title: VELASQUEZ RIDES 6 WINNERS AT BELMONT
description: Jorge Velsquez yesterday became the first jockey ot win six races in one day at Belmont Park and the first to ride six winners in six mounts at any New York track in one day.

title: A CZECH PLAYWRIGHT WHO SHOULD BE FREED
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER'S OUTDOOR EVENTS
description: The out-of-doors choices are diverse in Westchester County this weekend -an old-fashioned county fair starting today in Yonkers, wind surfing off the Playland beach in Rye tomorrow and the Yiddish Music and Theater Festival, an increasingly popular annual event, at the Kensico Dam Plaza near Valhalla on Sunday.

title: Market Place; The Changes In Discounting
description: THE big mergers involving brokerage firms this year have seen Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc. walk down the aisle with the American Express Company, and Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. breathe ''yes'' to the Prudential Insurance Company.

title: OLD STYLE DISNEY
description: IN any list of palships that cannot be, that of a fox and a hound would seem to be among the most unlikely. They live in worlds of differing obligations, interests and diets. It is the sweetly realized point of ''The Fox and the Hound,'' Walt Disney Productions's new animated feature, that Tod, a fun-loving, orphaned fox, and Copper, a hound dog that grows up to take his job seriously, somehow manage to preserve a friendship that began when each was a pup, innocent of the roles society would impose on them.

title: Postal Unions Seeking Raises of Almost 50%
description: Two major postal unions today demanded wage increases of nearly 50 percent over the next three years as the Postal Service said cost-of-living adjustments and benefits alone would push the cost of a mailing a letter up to 40 cents by 1983.

title: The City; SEX CLUB OWNERS GET 8-YEAR TERMS
description: Contending that white-collar criminals should be treated the same as violent ones, a Federal judge gave eight-year prison terms to three operators of Plato's Retreat for evading taxes on $2.3 million ''skimmed'' from receipts.

title: BOB GRAY, MAN ABOUT CAPITAL, HAS A PARTY
description: He wears out a tuxedo each year, and at the rate he is partying, Robert Keith Gray may just have to begin to replace that black-tie uniform every six months.

title: TARGET OF 1965 VOTE PROTESTS
description: Joseph R. Bibb, a voter registrar here who was a target of protest marches in 1965, died Tuesday. He was 86 years old.

title: Transactions; FOOTBALL BALTIMORE (AFC) - Reached agree- ment on terms of four-year contract with Randy McMillan, fullback from Pitt and No. 1 draft choice.  CINCINNATI (AFC) - Signed Rex Robinson, place-kicker.  CHICAGO (NFC) - Signed Gerald Diggs, defensive back; John Majarian, linebacker, and J.J. Stewart and Alfred Wring, tackles.  HOUSTON (AFC) - Signed Nick Eyre, offensive tackle.  LOS ANGELES (NFC) - Signed George Lilja and Bil
description: NEW YORK ARROWS (MISL) - Ex- t ended contract of Don Popovic, head c oach, through 1983. NEW YORK UNITED (ASL) - Waived K yle Hutchins, defender.

title: U.S. SEEKS FLEXIBILITY IN ARMS SALES
description: The White House today made public a new Presidential policy directive on sales of conventional arms that was said to be aimed at giving the Reagan Administration greater flexibility in using the transfer of weapons as a tool of foreign policy.

title: Israeli Swimmers Win 3 Gold Medals
description: Israeli swimmers won three gold medals today as Israel maintained its lead over the United States in the swimming finals at the 11th Maccabiah Games.

title: News Analysis
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. was scrambling today to withstand the damage inflicted by strong attacks on two fronts yesterday, undoubtedly one of the most uncomfortable days of his political career.

title: Index; International
description: Around the World A2 Uganda guerrillas in need of outside backing A2 Salvadoran prison now houses refugees A2 Khomeini orders a purge of Iran's armed forces A2 Red Brigades threaten to kill Naples politician A3 Rowny says an arms treaty should limit Soviet build-up A3 U.S. Jews worry about religious parties in a Begin coalition A4 Ex-foreign minister says Cambo- dian death figures unrealistic A6 Government/Politics Goldwater says Judge O'Connor's foes should ''back off'' A11 Rhetoric changes as defense budget debate begins A12 Mayor writes to Washington about a trade-in on Westway B16 Hatfield assails inefficiency in arms purchases D15 General Around the Nation A10 Study shows Puerto Rican income half of national median A10 The Talk of Santa Fe: Mecca for the Glitterati A10 Appellate court orders release of imprisoned Cuban refugee A13 Voiding of guilty plea in Lennon murder case is sought D15 The City B3 The Region B6 Health/Science Dengue fever outbreaks spurs precautions in Florida D14 Navy toughens enforcement ef- forts against drug abuse D14 Energy Pennsylvania Governor seeks funds for nuclear plant cleanup A10 Weekend Events: Weekender Guide C1 Summer festival of arts opens tonight in Purchase C1 County fair in Yonkers and Yiddish festival near Valhalla C11 Al Jolson festival in Queens C24 Theater: Broadway C2

title: NO NEW CHARGES AS BUS-STOP SHELTER INQUIRY ENDS
description: A long Federal investigation of the New York City franchise for shelters at bus stops, which caused a political furor, has ended without the filing of criminal charges beyond one indictment issued last year.

title: For Children; Sailing, Sailing
description: hour cruise around Manhattan, includes historic sights, landmarks and passage under 20 bridges, aboard yachts that leave from Pier 83, at the foot of West 43d Street. For a brochure of prices, and schedule, call 563-3200. THE PIONEER, an 1885 gaff-rigged schooner, takes city sailors on a 3-hour tour of New York Harbor. Sailings: Monday through Friday at 1:30 and 6 P.M., and on Saturday and Sunday at 10 A.M., and 2 and 6 P.M. Evening sails on Friday, Saturday and Sunday at 9:30 P.M.; South Street Seaport Museum, 203 Front Street. Tickets, $15 (those under 13, and the elderly, half-price on 10 A.M., 1:30 and 2 P.M. sailings). Reservations required: 766-9076.

title: ART: SHOWCASE OF CULTURE
description: The department stores did it. The banks did it. The supermarkets and franchise-food chains and specialty shops did it. They all followed their public to the suburbs long ago, and profited hugely from the move. But cultural institutions, for the most part, showed no similar alacrity in bestirring themselves. They, too, have expanded their operations during this time, but they have remained steadfastly loyal to the city, beckoning the suburban public to come to them, showing little inclination to make any moves of their own.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Current figures give effect to a capital gain distribution of $15,928,944 or 98 cents a shr paid in Feb; asset figures repres net assets

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Article 188807 -- No Title
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday authorized $1 million for a study on the environmental and engineering aspects of building a coal shipment terminal in New York Harbor.

title: G.T.E. Unit Seeks Satellite Channel
description: The G.T.E. Satellite Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to lease space on Canada's Anik B satellite to serve customers in the United States, until its own satellites are launched in 1984.

title: FIAT SIGNS ACCORD WITH ALFA AND STATE-RUN STEEL CONCERN
description: Fiat and Alfa Romeo, the two Italian automobile makers that have been at odds in the past, have reached an agreement to explore cooperation in planning and production to reduce costs.

title: Auto Layoffs Up in Week
description: The number of temporary layoffs in the United States auto industry more than doubled to reach 34,430 this week as the annual model change-over period got into full swing, according to industry reports today. At the same time, the auto makers reported that car production fell 20 percent from last week.

title: General Dynamics Says No to Airbus
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said it had decided against joining a consortium of companies setting up the European Airbus Industrie A-320 commercial airlines program.

title: THEATER: RAUL JULIA IN PARK 'TEMPEST'
description: EVEN taking inflation into account, you're likely to find that the free tickets for the New York Shakespeare Festival's production of ''The Tempest'' are overpriced. This is a laughably mindless and threadbare show that's been scattered willy-nilly across the expansive stage of Central Park's Delacorte Theater. Seen in broad daylight, rather than under the stars, it could pass for a drunken picnic.

title: Auctions; ANOTHER BIG SALES SEASON
description: THIS season's sales at three of New York's art-auction houses have surpassed last season's totals by 15 to 25 percent, increases that New York may once again eclipse London's position as the capital of the art-auction world. Traditionally, the figures for New York are reported in early July after most of the major sales have ended, even though some galleries - Sotheby Parke Bernet and William Doyle - continue to hold auctions through August.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of June 30
description: B-After $2.48 capital gain distribution paid in Feb 1981; asset figures represent net assets

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings figures have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in Apr 1981

title: DICKY WELLS AT THE WEST END
description: DICKY WELLS, the trombonist whose unusual assortment of moans, wheezes, mutters and exclamations were a prominent feature of Count Basie's orchestra from 1938 to 1950, is leading his own group this weekend at the West End, Broadway at 114th Street.

title: PAGEAMERICA COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
Disney Name Rights Sold
description: Walt Disney Productions, which has been paying a royalty to a Disney family corporation, Retlaw Enterprises Inc., for use of the Disney name, said it had acquired full rights to the name for $46.2 million.

title: BUTTERY TOAST IN MANILA
description: 84,2,496.8,0McLEAN, Va. - Before Vice President Bush's celebrated Presidential-inauguration toast to Ferdinand E. Marcos - ''We love your adherence to democratic principle and to the democratic processes'' - passes forever into the satirists' domain, let us not forget that this startling obeisance is a natural expression of President Reagan's foreign policy.

title: KOCH WRITES U.S. ABOUT A TRADE-IN ON WESTWAY AID
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had sent a letter to Washington asking if the Reagan Administration would approve a trade-in of Federal dollars intended for the Westway to subsidize the city's ailing transit system.

title: U.S. PANEL PROPOSES UNIFORM LAW SAYING LIFE ENDS AT BRAIN'S DEATH
description: A Presidential commission today recommended that the states endorse the concept that human life ends when the brain stops functioning. It urged all 50 states to adopt a simple uniform law defining death as the ''irreversible cessation of all functions of the entire brain, including the brain stem.''

title: Money Funds Add $2.7 Billion
description: The assets of the nation's money market funds grew by $2.7 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: DANCE: RIKA BURNHAM
description: MOST of the ingredients were there. The Burnham Company is an agreeable one. Howard Levy's poetry was engaging, and the musical accompaniment by Shulce, Bach and Glass was pleasant. Phil Sandstrom's fluorescent sculptures were attractive, and gave off a flattering glow. And the Tribeca studio was a pristine dance space. But Rika Burnham's three-part ''Untitled,'' performed at the White Dog Studio on Wednesday, never quite came to more than its parts.

title: The Talk of Santa Fe
description: Northern New Mexico has been an oasis for writers, artists and photographers since D.H. Lawrence and Georgia O'Keeffe settled here in the 20's. The literati have been well established for decades, but now the glitterati are moving in and, much to Santa Fe's dismay, the town is fast becoming an open secret.

title: Sunshine Bid Is Set Back
description: The Sunshine Mining Company's attempt to take over the Silver Dollar, Sunshine Consolidated and Silver Syndicate mining companies took another turn today when the directors of two of the smaller concerns making alternative offers to exchange each other's stock.

title: Katz Says He Paid $12 Million for 76ers
description: Harold Katz, a native of south Philadelphia and the founder of Nutri-Systems Inc., a chain of weight-loss clinics, announced today that he had bought the Philadelphia 76ers for ''a shade over $12 million.''

title: FIVE TAXES VOTED IN ALBANY TO GIVE MASS-TRANSIT AID
description: A package of five taxes to subsidize mass transit and in particular the operating deficit of the troubled Metropolitan Transportation Authority was narrowly approved today by the New York State Legislature.

title: Deaths From Illegal Liquor Rise to 308 in Southern India
