description: The death toll in India's worst illicit liquor tragedy rose to 308 today as victims were still being taken to hospitals in the southern Indian city of Bangalore, the police said.

title: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DENGUE FEVER OUTBREAK WATCHED BY FLORIDIANS
description: Outbreaks of two strains of the tropical disease dengue fever in Cuba and in the Eastern Caribbean have led local and Federal health officials to recommend cautionary steps. They suggested that Americans traveling to the affected areas take along mosquito repellent and that Haitian refugees, now landing in Florida by the hundreds, be detained at least 10 days to guard against introducing the disease into the United States.

title: SCREEN: ANTIRAPE TRACT
description: ''Primal Fear'' (''Mourir a Tue-Tete'') was shown at the 1979 New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times of Oct. 8, 1979. The film opens today at the Thalia, Broadway and 95th Street.

title: ARTS FESTIVAL OPENS TONIGHT IN PURCHASE
description: TAKE five long summer weekends, several hundred performers from all over the world, four theaters and 500 acres of lawns and gardens - and that is Summerfare '81, the major arts festival staged at the State University of New York's College at Purchase in Westchester. The festival opens in a college theater tonight with a production of Sean O'Casey's ''Shadow of a Gunman'' by the Abbey Theater of Dublin, then spreads all over the neighboring Pepsico Sculpture Garden and the college grounds tomorrow in an extravagant parade of artists, gargantuan puppets, bands and an army of local residents who will lead visitors to an enormous outdoor production of Benjamin Britten's medieval-style mystery play-opera, ''Noah's Flood.''

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $99,235,000 for qr and $108,891,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net income including $3,0 gain from discontinued operations...D-Including $7,807,000 gain discontinued operations

title: Making a Pilgrimage to Mecca, Me.
description: OLD TOWN, Me. THERE were these two kids in Green Bay, Wis., faithful readers of Boys' Life and The American Boy. Both magazines carried seductive advertisements for the Old Town canoe, and the kids had a dream. If they had an Old Town canoe they would ship it by rail to the Chain of Lakes country in the northern Wisconsin woods, paddle through the lakes to the source of the Wisconsin River, ride the Wisconsin southwest to the town of Portage, where a mile overland would take them to the headwaters of the Fox, which flows northeast through Lake Winnebago to Green Bay.

title: Books of the Times
description: THE REAL CAMELOT. Paganism and the Arthurian Romances. By John Darrah. 160 Pages. Thames & Hudson. $13.95.

title: CONTEST OVER TAX STRADDLES
description: In the midst of the crusade to cut taxes, there is one part of the tax package now working its way through Congress that stands out because it is a clear-cut effort to close a loophole and raise tax revenue.

title: TUITION-AID RISE GAINS IN ALBANY
description: The Republican-dominated State Senate unanimously approved late tonight a bill that would increase grants under the state's Tuition Assistance Program. The bill would also have the state take over the costs now borne by colleges for the work-study program and create a new tuition assistance plan for college students in remedial programs.

title: GOLDWATER TELLS OPPONENTS OF O'CONNOR NOMINATION TO 'BACK OFF'
description: Conservative groups today intensified their attack on Judge Sandra Day O'Connor, President Reagan's nominee for the Supreme Court, but Senate Republicans predicted victory and Senator Barry Goldwater warned that her critics should ''back off.''

title: U.S. VOWS TO FIGHT PRESS CURB
description: Several members of Congress called on the Reagan Administration today to oppose all attempts within a United Nations agency to impose restrictions on press freedoms around the world.

title: TANZANIAN WITHDRAWAL LEAVES KAMPALA JUMPY
description: Tanzania's partial withdrawal of troops from Uganda has created nervousness and uncertainty here over what diplomats and Government officials say is an expected guerrilla attack on Kampala.

title: Trial of Seagram Suit to Proceed
description: Federal District Judge James Latchum has refused to delay the trial of a lawsuit by the Seagram Company to overturn a Conoco bylaw that limits stock sales to foreign investors to 20 percent of outstanding shares. The trial is scheduled to begin on Monday.

title: FUTURES IN C.D.'S STARTED
description: At precisely 9 A.M. yesterday, Abbe Schwartz sold a $1 million contract in domestic bank certificates of deposit to James McManus on the floor of the New York Futures Exchange and, amid a chorus of competing shouts and a sea of waving arms, created the first trade in certificate of deposit futures on any commodity market. The seller was a floor trader for Shearson Loeb Rhoades, and her opposite represented M.K.I. Securities, bond brokers.

title: Around the World; U.S. Says Soviet Marines Conduct Syria Landings
description: The Defense Department said today that Soviet marines landed in Syria on Tuesday as part of joint maneuvers, and a spokesman added that the Pentagon attached ''great significance'' to the apparent Soviet ability to project its military power with amphibious operations.

title: STAGE: 'FIDDLER ON THE ROOF'
description: IF you were a rich man, you could n't buy a better show than the joyous re-creation of ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' a musical that seems destined to be a theatrical Phoenix, that opened last night at the New York State Theater. You can't dismiss it as a rerun of the Broadway hit that ran for 3,242 performances from 1964 to 1972. It's more than that. Tradition. That's what it is.

title: Krishnas, Moonies and the State
description: By their nature, cults have always challenged established governments and faiths. That's especially so in the United States. Our collective conscience, and ultimately our mutual safety, demand tolerance for zealous believers even when they claim a monopoly on truth. A pluralistic society must keep government off their backs. But it's harder for some than others.

title: MASSACHUSETTS ALERTS GUARD FOR STRIKE BY STATE WORKERS
description: Gov. Edward J. King put National Guard units on alert last night for possible duty at the maximum security prison in Walpole and at state mental and public health institutions in anticipation of a walkout by 28,000 Massachusetts employees who have not been paid for more than a week because of the lack of a state budget.

title: WHERE IS THE ELECTRIC CAR?
description: The president of the Ford Motor Company thought he had a development important enough to call a news conference. The company's researchers, he announced, had achieved a breakthrough in advanced battery technology that would make mass production of electric cars feasible within five to 10 years.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Copper Mines Close in Chile
description: About 5,000 small copper mining companies have ceased operations in this country as a result of the lowest world copper prices in Chilean mining history, the National Mining Society said today.

title: SCRIPTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICA'S BREEDING GROUND FOR CRIMINALS
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTING IN ALBANY: A TEST OF LOYALTY AND ENDURANCE
description: Dazed and exhausted, the members of the State Legislature were held through the night until enough of them put aside qualms or political fears and embraced the tax plan designed to rescue the metropolitan transit system.

title: Boycott Aura Persists In U.S.-Soviet Track
description: American athletes are back in the Soviet Union this week to resume a series of track and field meets that began in 1958.

title: Around the Nation; 2 Indicted for Conspiring To Sell Secrets to Poland
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a former Hughes Aircraft Company engineer and the president of the Polish American Machinery Corporation for espionage in a conspiracy to sell military secrets to Poland.

title: Caterpillar Off 5.8% In Quarter
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said today that its second-quarter earnings dipped 5.8 percent compared with the same three-month period last year. The company cited high interest rates that reduced demand for its products.

title: CITY SHIFTS SOME DATA SERVICE
description: In an economy move, New York City officials announced yesterday that they would shift some data transmission services from New York Telephone Company lines to coaxial cables of Manhattan Cable Television.

title: PANEL FORGOES TAX BREAK AND COST-OF-LIVING RISE FOR CONGRESS
description: The House Appropriations Committee today reluctantly abandoned a proposal that would have given members of Congress a big tax break.

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SCHICK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Maa 31
description: B-Including $46,000 extraordinary income from the settlement of debt...C-Net income including $480,000 tax credit

title: ARMS NOMINEE SAYS A PACT SHOULD END SOVIET BUILDUP
description: Edward L. Rowny, President Reagan's nominee for the post of chief arms control negotiator, said today that the United States would seek an arms agreement with the Soviet Union that would not merely limit the number of weapons systems, but effectively restrain a ''Soviet build-up in strategic capabilities.''

title: BOOKS: KEYS TO HEALTH
description: JANE BRODY'S NUTRITION BOOK: A Lifetime Guide to Good Eating for Better Health and Weight Control. 552 pages. Norton. $17.95.

title: The City; POOLS AND BEACHES TO EXTEND HOURS
description: The New York City Parks Commissioner, Gordon J. Davis, announced that city pools and beaches would remain open two hours longer every day, at his discretion, for the ''duration of the heat wave.''

title: Advertising; Accounts on the Move Here and There
description: Out of town, we see new business coming in for Mullen Advertising in Beverly Farms, Mass.; Eisaman, Johns & Laws in Los Angeles, and Tyson Ketchum in Philadelphia.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Guardian Industries Corporation, Northville, Mich., has named Jeffrey A. Knight controller.

title: ALBERTA IS BLAMED FOR OIL RIFT
description: The Canadian Energy Minister, Marc Lalonde, blamed the province of Alberta today for a decision by Imperial Oil Ltd. to suspend a $10 billion (United States) oil sands project at Cold Lake.

title: Tale of Revenge
description: ILLUSTRIOUS CORPSES (Cadaveri Eccellenti), directed by Francesco Rosi; screenplay (Italian with English subtitles) by Mr. Rosi, Tonino Guerra and Lino Januzzi, based on the novel, ''The Context,'' by Leonardo Sciascia; executive producer, Alberto Grimaldi; director of photography, Pasquale De Santis; editor, Ruggero Mastroianni; music, Piero Piccioni and Astor Piazzolla; a co-production of Produzioni Europea Associate (Rome) and Les Artistes Associes (Paris). Running time: 121 minutes. At the Thalia, Broadway at 95th Street.

title: Ruling Called Too Lenient
description: The New Mexico Attorney General and the foreman of the jury that convicted Norm Ellenberger, the former University of New Mexico basketball coach, on 21 counts of fraud and of filing false public vouchers said yesterday that Ellenberger should not have received the light sentence he did.

title: Briefs
description: * Advent Corp. said its creditors committee had approved and agreed to recommend to creditors adoption of terms of a revised plan of reorganization. Required funding is to be provided by Peter J. Sprague, former chairman and chief executive; Nolan K. Bushnell, a former director, and Alan R. Trustman, the recently named chairman and chief executive.

title: SUN BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PITTSBURGH NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST UNITED BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1981

title: Press Group Elects Leader
description: Sir Denis Hamilton, chairman of the Reuters news agency, was elected president of the Commonwealth Press Union today. The union groups 800 newspapers, agencies and periodicals throughout the Commonwealth.

title: Notes on People; NEW YORK URGED NOT TO DEMOLISH 3 THEATERS
description: Tony Randall, Jose Ferrer and Madeleine Sherwood, representing the Actors Equity Association, showed up at New York's City Hall yesterday to urge that the city halt the proposed demolition of three legitimate theaters in midtown to make way for a new hotel.

title: Advertising; Tracking Cash Flow At Ogilvy
description: FOR Graham Phillips, who has just been named managing director of Ogilvy & Mather in New York, managing the cash position of the agency is one of his most important functions.

title: BEING COOL IS A MATTER OF STYLE
description: There are hot fashions and there are fashions for hot weather and the two aren't necessarily synonymous. But when the mercury rises well into the 90's, as it has this week, New York women also rise to the sweltering occasion and, in varying degrees, manage to keep their cool.

title: 'ESCAPE FROM NEW YORK'
description: MANHATTAN is a giant island-prison inhabited by humanity's dregs - murderers, terrorists, thieves, swindlers, perverts of all persuasions, petty criminals and people who are permanently disoriented. The place is a zoo without bars, but there's no way out. The bridges have been mined and walled off. The tunnels are sealed. The once great buildings are mostly shells, but because these Manhattanites don't read much, and don't care about books one way or the other, the Public Library on 42d Street doesn't look to be in quite the state of disrepair of the other landmarks.

title: TRUST CO OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago per shr figures reflect a 100 percent stock divd in Dec 1980

title: SOUTHERN AFRICA POLICY
description: Those who expected the recent testimony before the House Subcommittee on African Affairs by Assistant Secretary of State Chester A. Crocker to spell out the Reagan Administration's policy toward South Africa and South Africa's continued domination of Namibia were sorely disappointed. The testimony was long on procedure but short on substance. As with most foreign policy issues facing President Reagan, a clear-cut public policy and rationale was postponed pending further review.

title: NAVY IS TOUGHENING ENFORCEMENT EFFORTS AGAINST DRUG ABUSE
description: The Chief of Naval Operations today announced a plan for stricter enforcement of the Navy's ban on drug use by sailors. It will include expanded testing of suspected users and education.

title: BALLET: TWO NETHERLANDS PREMIERES
description: FOR its second program, the very popular Netherlands Dance Theater presented two local premieres by Jiri Kylian, its artistic director: ''Dream Dances'' and ''Overgrown Path.'' The same bill at the Metropolitan Opera House Wednesday night was completed by ''Sinfonietta,'' the exultant rhapsodic paean to nature that so typified the Kylian style here two years ago.

title: Habib in Beirut Again To Renew Peace Talks
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, arrived here tonight for a third round of diplomatic efforts aimed at easing the crisis between Israel and Syria over the Syrian missiles in Lebanon.

title: Separate, and Unequal, in Britain
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher did not alter her chilly style in her initial plea for an end to Britain's urban riots. Nor did she reveal any new insight as a result of the disorders, which have spread from Liverpool to London and Manchester. But she and all Britain will likely draw some powerful lessons from this first experience with such disturbances, as Americans did in the 60's. They are important lessons, for Britain and for America still.

title: COURT GRANTS TIMES $229.718 FOR '80 WALKOUT BY DELIVERERS
description: The New York Times won a $229,718 judgment yesterday in a civil case against the newspaper deliverers' union. The judge in the case, Thomas Griesa of United States District Court, found the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York and the union's vice president, Lawrence May, guilty of contempt for a Sept. 17, 1980, work stoppage by the deliverers. The paper and the union have a no-strike contract, which calls for the handling of grievances through an arbitration panel.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FERTILE FLIES RELEASED IN ERROR IMPERIL CALIFORNIA FRUIT CROP
description: Hundreds of thousands of Mediterranean fruit flies erroneously thought to be sterile were released in California last month and now pose a new threat to the state's $14 billion produce crop.

title: Business People
description: Dr. Charles A. Sanders, who has headed Massachusetts General Hospital since 1972, becomes executive vice president of E.R. Squibb & Sons , the health-care products company, in September.

title: GEORGE V. ROBBINS
description: George V. Robbins, director of green coffee operations for the General Foods Corporation and a past president of the National Coffee Association, died June 30 at his home in San Diego, where he had moved from Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: G.E. POSTS RISE OF 8.2% FOR PERIOD
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that its secondquarter earnings rose 8.2 percent from the similar period a year ago on a 12.1 percent gain in revenue.

title: Notes on People; EDNA ST. VINCENT MILLAY'S HOMETOWN CELEBRATING
description: There has been a flurry of activity this week in the small upstate New York town of Austerlitz, in Columbia County near the Massachusetts border.

title: Around the Nation; Chemical Plant Is Sued Over Toxic Substances
description: A $1.35 billion lawsuit has been filed against the Monsanto Company on behalf of former employees who say they were exposed to toxic chemicals that caused health problems ranging from cancer to heart disease.

title: VIRGINIA NATIONAL BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHIEF JUSTICE R.J. MAUGHAN OF THE SUPREME COURT OF UTAH
description: Chief Justice Richard J. Maughan of the Utah Supreme Court died at his home Tuesday after a long illness, a spokesman for the court said. He was 63 years old.

title: About New York officer; ON BEACH PATROL, HEAT'S THE LEAST OF THE PROBLEMS
description: The mass baptisms are no problem; neither is nudism, which has been abandoned in favor of the impossibly tiny swimsuits of the day. There are occasional drunken brawls, a spate or two of what is classified as ''public lewdness'' and some hubcap thefts. People park willy-nilly, and lost children, their hair wet with salt water and tears, wander in off the boardwalk. A dismembered body was found in a trash bag last month, but it was not considered a major problem.

title: ROUGH RIDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN MOTORS IN SALE TO RENAULT
description: The American Motors Corporation said that it exercised part of its option to sell preferred stock and warrants to Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, the French state-owned automaker, for an aggregate price of $45 million.

title: MAN, 23, SLAIN IN MACHETE ATTACK IN VIEW OF DINERS ON 43D ST. PATIO
description: Two men armed with machetes pursued a third man on Ninth Avenue last night and slashed him to death on 43d Street outside the Manhattan Plaza apartment complex, the authorities reported.

title: MASSACHUSETTS WORKERS BALKING
description: Thousands of state employees walked off the job today to protest payless paydays as Gov. Edward J. King assailed the State Senate for its part in a deadlock over a new state budget.

title: BUYING COOLING DEVICES
description: T HIS is the time of year when sales of room air-conditioners zoom, especially if the weather is as hot as it has been the last week in New York. But overheated shoppers are wondering why they didn't acquire their air-conditioners before the mercury started its predictable summer climb. And, of course, they should have. Right now, prices are generally high and selection low.

title: Transit Battle, Transit War
description: The transit tax package will win by a nose: that was the prediction of Stanley Fink and Warren Anderson, the New York legislative leaders. The margin was even narrower; the package won by a hair. But the five taxes, coupled with a $100 million operating grant, should cover the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's foreseeable deficit until 1983. Equally important was the Legislature's authorization to seek $5 billion in capital in the next five years. But even with these signal victories, the longer struggle to save public transportation in the metropolitan region is only beginning.

title: Spanish Minister Says U.S. Must Alter Attitude
description: Foreign Minister Jose Pedro Perez Llorca said today on his return from talks in Washington that he had told United States leaders that they could no longer regard Spain as a mere tool to be used for American strategic needs. ''Spain must be seen as an active partner of interest in Europe,'' he said.

title: CORDERO HAS 4 WINNERS
description: Angel Cordero won four races with six mounts yesterday at Belmount. Park.

title: Indian Mill Collapse Kills 22
description: At least 22 people were killed and 200 others were believed trapped when a four-story silk mill collapsed near the west Indian town of Surat, the Press Trust of India said today. It said the mill collapsed last night after a boiler exploded.

title: WHAN SUMMER CUM, TO SING CUCCU IS HUMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Three Leftists Are Executed by Iran
description: Iranian firing squads executed three more leftist opponents of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's fundamentalist regime today, the Teheran radio announced.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply fell $1.3 billion in the week ended July 1, and has now declined for two consecutive months.

title: TEXASGULF INQUIRY ASKED
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation has asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate for antitrust violations the proposed $2.8 billion aquisition of Texasgulf Inc. by Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the French state-controlled oil concern, because the proposed merger could seriously restrict domestic supplies of phosphate fertilizers.

title: BOOKS INCLUDED 'COMPULSION'
description: Meyer Levin, the author of ''Compulsion,'' a highly successful novel about the 1920's Leopold-Loeb murder case that was made into a play and film, as well as a score of books of fiction and Judaica, died of a stroke Thursday night in Jerusalem. Mr. Levin, who lived in New York and spent his summers in Israel, was 75 years old.

title: AKZONA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOALBY'S 71-142 LEADS SENIOR OPEN BY 1 STROKE
description: Bob Goalby, who says he's driving better than at any time in his long career, matched his opening round with a one-over-par 71 today to take a one-stroke lead in the United States Senior Open at Oakland Hills.

title: Books of The Times
description: Women Are People, Too By LE ANNE SCHREIBER THE CINDERELLA COMPLEX: Women's Hidden Fear of Independence. By Co- lette Dowling. 266 pages. Summit. $12.95.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1981; International
description: Prime Minister Trudeau of Canada assured President Reagan that participants in the upcoming Ottawa summit meeting would avoid ''unacceptable'' criticism of each other's economic policies. Recently, the Reagan Administration has been criticized by foreign officials for its policy of high interest rates. (Page 1.) Canada's environment minister charged that the U.S. had not lived up to an agreement to reduce air pollution that causes acid rain in Canada. (30.)

title: 'TERRORNIKS' REDISCOVER A STANDBY CULPRIT
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH CYCLIST RETAINS LEAD IN RACE:
description: Bernard Hinault in action during the 16th stage of the Tour de France. He won the 24-mile leg in 50 minutes 30 seconds. Gerrie Knetemann of the Netherlands finished second.

title: NCNB DROPS BID FOR FLORIDA BANKS
description: The NCNB Corporation, a North Carolina-based bank holding company, announced yesterday that it was withdrawing its $210 million proposal for a merger with Florida National Banks of Florida.

title: VIOLENCE STILL MARKS LIFE IN KAMPALA
description: There is a place in Kampala's Akii-Bua Road where, shaded by leafy trees, the bullets of past battles have become embedded in the paving, so deep it seems that they could never be removed. If critics of President Milton Obote are to be believed, the violence that begat the bullets, and other woes, are just as deep.

title: No Headline
description: Basque separatists shot and killed a retired civil guard in the northern Spanish town of Basauri. The separatist guerrillas of E.T.A. were blamed for his death.

title: STERILIZATION EFFECTIVE AGAINST FRUIT FLIES
description: The American battle against the Mediterranean fruit fly began in 1928, when the insect was found to have infested citrus fruit in Florida. It has been an up-and-down struggle ever since, with the use of sterile males by the millions emerging as the most environmentally acceptable strategy.

title: OIL AND GAS FEVER COME TO MICHIGAN FARM AREA
description: This little town with the luxury name could soon be the Houston of Michigan, the Tulsa of the northern woods, if the oil-@ and gas-drilling boom in progress here pays off.

title: N.L.R.B. Decision Put Off Till August
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association's charge of unfair labor practices against the club owners will not be resolved until at least the first week in August.

title: Patents; NEW CHIEF SWORN IN AT BUREAU
description: GERALD J. MOSSINGHOFF took over as head of the patent office this week and expressed optimism that the bureau would be one of the most efficient agencies in Government and would be adequately staffed.

title: WHAN SUMMER CUM, TO SING CUCCU IS HUMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Fish-Rubbings Display
description: A popular method of recording the size of fish caught in 19thcentury Japan was to obtain an impression by painting or inking the exterior and rubbing it on paper.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain was denounced in the House of Commons for not taking stringent measures to combat the wave of rioting in inner cities.

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: NBD Bancorp is the parent company of National Bank of Detroit

title: OWNERS WANT CHANGES
description: Marvin Miller, the players' union chief, announced early today that the Major League Baseball Players Association had agreed, despite reservations, to accept the proposal submitted by Kenneth E. Moffett, the Federal mediator, to end the strike by the players. But the owners' negotiators, who offered a counterproposal, said they could not accept Mr. Moffett's plan ''line by line, word by word, with no changes.''

title: HOUSE GROUP SOFTENS TAX-STRADDLE PROPOSAL
description: The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to narrow a tax loophole in commodity straddles, but declined to close it all the way.

title: ARMY CHAPLAIN IN TWO WARS
description: Lieut. Col. Charles S.H. Hunter Jr., a retired Army chaplain who served in World War II and the Korean War and was an aide to Gen. George S. Patton, died July 2 at his home in Tampa, Fla. He was 77 years old.

title: Summer's Magic Sway
description: Officially the temperature is 98 degrees. That's because they measure it on top of an ice house in Central Park. Actually the temperature is 173 degrees, trucks are sinking into melting asphalt like mastodons in quicksand, and steam is pouring out of the ears of a fallen jogger down on the sidewalk who is being worked over by an ambulance crew.

title: REFORMING VOIR DIRE
description: The need for extra State Supreme Court judges to hear criminal cases in New York City is obvious. In 1980, the criminal parts were able to try to completion only 2,100 of the 20,000 felony indictments handed down. The great majority of untried indictments were pleabargained, sometimes to unacceptably low charges carrying minimal punishments. If more judges were available, fewer cases would be plea-bargained.

title: No Headline
description: As Lebanese soldiers patrol the roads leading to Zahle, residents of that predominantly Christian town return to their homes, riddled with shells during the three-month siege by Syrian gunners.

title: AN OCCUPATION OF CIVIL LIFE
description: There was great change in the nation in 1873, when the men of the Supreme Court sat together and ruled on Bradwell v. Illinois. It was an era when the slaves had been freed, the frontier was retreating and women were fighting for the constitutional right to practice law, finally reaching the highest court with their case.

title: 3 GUILTY OF $11 MILLION IN THEFTS
description: The personal manservant of the 82-year-old reclusive owner of the Lundy Brothers seafood restaurant in Sheepshead Bay and two other men were convicted yesterday of having stolen $11 million from the restaurateur in the last eight months of his life in 1977.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONTHLY U.S. GOLD IMPORTS LISTED
description: United States gold imports rose to 321,947 ounces in April from 184,949 in March but were down from 483,506 ounces in April last year, the Bureau of Mines said today.

title: ACROSS THE RHINE FROM BONN, A LEGENDARY WORLD
description: Across the river, glowering, is the city, the capital of West Germany and a capital of nebulousness, a place so politicized that even cabdrivers ask if they can go off the record to answer a question.

title: U.S. Envoy Will Support More Arms to Salvador
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador said today that he will recommend, at the request of the Salvadorans, that the United States provide more arms aid after the first group of American military advisers goes home in August.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $975,000 tax credit from sale of the company's German operations

title: MITEL CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in Oct 1980; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchang

title: EVERYDAY SOUNDS AMPLIFIED
description: David Van Tieghem's ''Proceed Accordingly'' on Thursday evening at the Performing Garage was a mostly interesting, sometimes provocative mixture of percussion, whimsy and athletic pantomime.

title: FAR EAST TINDERBOX
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Give Soviet an Edge
description: A strong showing by the American men and two stirring sprints by a 17-year-old New Jersey girl, Michele Glover, were not enough to counter Soviet dominance of the women's events today as the national teams met for the first time since 1978.

title: CANADIAN CHARGES U.S. FAILS TO ACT ON ACID RAIN
description: Canada's environment minister, John Roberts, charged last night that the United States Government had failed to live up to an agreement to reduce air pollution emissions that cause acid rain to fall on his country.

title: WOMEN'S CLOTHES SIZES: IS AN 8 ALWAYS AN 8?
description: ''There isn't a woman alive who knows what her real size is,'' said Gillis MacGil. Miss MacGil, one of the legendary models of fashion and currently the owner of Mannequin, a company that employs runway models, was talking about a situation that often bewilders many female consumers when it is time to buy clothes.

title: Index; International
description: Across the Rhine from Bonn, a legendary world 2 Mrs. Peron leaves Argentina, but Peronism is gaining strength 2 Violence still afflicts the streets of Kampala 3 Liberal Afrikaner students take a defiant step by holding meeting 3 Mrs. Gandhi says India must match Pakistan's F-16's 3 Around the World 4 U.S. critic of raid on Iraqi reactor plans talks in Israel 4 Aides urge London to be flexible on Belfast hunger strike 5 Government/Politics Housing Department held lax on lead-paint peril 8 Air Force loses suit on officer's wearing of skullcap 8 Senate refuses to bar filibuster by liberals on busing 24 New York's Legislature hurries to finish business and adjourn 25 Bill to increase state's Tuition Assistance Program passes 26 State Senate declines to confirm Carey's commerce chief 27 General Jet returns to U.S. after hijacking to Cuba 6 Around the Nation 6 3 Coast veterans end hunger strike on promise of inquiry 17 A youth's frustrating job search 25 Hearing on Portman hotel project becomes emotional debate 26 Westchester Jail inmates take over a cellblock 26 Man charged in Manhattan slash- ing is charged in more attacks 27 Haitian children at upstate center awaiting adoption 27 Arts/Entertainment Philharmonic will start concerts in the parks July 29 10 Rock musical opens in Moscow 10 ''Case of Legless Veteran,'' docu- mentary on persecution 11 CBS Inc. to help finance next sea- son of plays at Kennedy Center 13 Synagogue's annex design aban- dons modernism 13 ''The Cinderella Complex,'' by Colette Dowling, reviewed 15 David Van Tieghem amplifies everyday sounds 15 Robert Altman sells his film studio for $2.3 million 15 Style Consumer Saturday 9 Women's clothes sizes: Is an 8 al- ways an 8? 9 De Gustibus 9 Health/Science Sterilization has been effective in fighting fruit flies 7 Obituaries Meyer Levin, author of ''Compul- sion'' and many other books 16 Sports Two agencies study possible drug use by New York jockeys 18 McEnroe swept by Lendl; Con- nors wins to even Davis Cup 19 Proposal in baseball negotiations stirs some optimism 19 Women put Soviet Union in lead over U.S. in track meet 19 Saga of John Henry: from oats to riches 19 George Vecsey on the strange sound of applause for McEnroe 20 Judge puts off until August reso- lution of baseball labor hearing 21 Features/Notes Going Out Guide 11 Saturday News Quiz 12 Notes on People 15 About New York 27 News Analysis Leslie H. Gelb on the lack of a Reagan foreign policy speech 4 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Announced that Wally Backman, infielder on option to Tidewa- ter, has been placed on disabled list with torn rotator cuff.; BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Obtained Bobby Wilkerson, free-agent forward, after his former club, Chicago, failed to match Cavaliers' offer.

title: REAGAN WORLD VIEW: IS A SPEECH NEEDED?
description: For a month, President Reagan's critics have been calling on him to make a speech on foreign policy. Some of these critics say that either he does not have a foreign policy or it is in disarray.

title: SCHEIB, EARL, INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,032,000 for the latest yr and $433,000 for the previous yr

title: SENATE BARS CURB ON BUSING FILIBUSTER BY LIBERALS
description: The Senate today rejected a move to invoke cloture to stop a filibuster by liberal Senators. The liberals are opposed to a proposal that would severely limit the power of Federal courts to issue school busing orders in desegregation cases.

title: Justice White Refuses to Bar Shutting Seamen's Hospitals
description: Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court refused without comment yesterday to grant an emergency stay of the the closing of United States Public Health Services hospitals and facilities that provide free medical care to an estimated 55,000 merchant seamen.

title: CITY BONDS AGAIN RATE BBB GRADE
description: Standard & Poor's, the investment rating firm, yesterday reaffirmed its low investment-grade rating on New York City's general obligation bonds. The BBB rating, first issued this spring, applies as well to the proposed $100 million public offering of city bonds to be sold next week.

title: CONTROL DATA SETS 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
description: The Control Data Corporation announced a 2-for-1 split of its common stock, subject to stockholder approval.

title: Briefs
description: * A.Z.L. Resources Inc. said its subsidiary, Solar Petroleum, had completed the acquisition of a 25 percent interest in 1.4 acres of oil and gas leases in the Williston Basin area of eastern Montana and western North Dakota.

title: SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A U.S. 'HARD-LINER' WILL GO TO ISRAEL
description: The State Department confirmed today that a high-ranking official would be traveling to Israel soon for talks with the Begin Government, and there were indications that the talks would center on the question of future use of American weapons in Israeli military operations. The department said that its counselor, Robert C. McFarlane, would be ''visiting Israel for the next several days'' in what a statement called ''the context of ongoing exchanges with the Government of Israel.''

title: Housing Decline Link To Rent Curbs Denied
description: Rent control is not the chief cause of the abandonment of buildings and the decline of a city's housing stock, according to a study made public today.

title: No Headline
description: Jay Haas said it wasn't easy to explain his five birdies in a six-hole stretch today that helped him post a 6-under-par 66 and take the lead after two rounds of the Greater Milwaukee Open.

title: SAN FRANCISCO FIRE, CALLED WORST SINCE '06, RAZES 25 BUILDINGS
description: A blaze described by this city's Fire Chief as the worst in several years, perhaps the biggest since much of the city burned after the 1906 earthquake, roared through 25 old wooden buildings in an area three blocks south of Market Street early today.

title: POLISH COMMUNIST CHIEF MAY ASK RE-ELECTION VOTE BY WHOLE PARTY
description: As the Central Committee met today to plan the agenda for an emergency congress of the Polish Communist Party, opening Tuesday, reports circulated in Warsaw that Stanislaw Kania, the party's first secretary, might place his re-election before the entire congress.

title: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSING AGENCY IS SAID TO LAG ON LEAD-PAINT PERIL TO CHILDREN
description: More than six months after a bluntly worded Government report accused the Department of Housing and Urban Development of ''confusion and noncompliance'' in programs aimed at eliminating lead poisoning in children, the housing agency has been attacked as sluggish in its response to the problem.

title: CBS TO HELP FINANCE SEASON OF KENNEDY CENTER'S PLAYS
description: CBS Inc. and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts are expected to sign contracts soon that will provide for joint financial backing of the center's next 36-week season of six plays, the forerunner of a national theater company.

title: WINTER, JACK, INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: B-After $1,196,000 loss from discontinued operations... C-Net loss after $1,315,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Ageless Actress
description: For the nonagenarian actress Cathleen Nesbitt, everything is comparative, she said yesterday in a telephone call from Boston, where she is playing Rex Harrison's mother in ''My Fair Lady.''

title: Miss Michelson Bride of Lawyer
description: Barbara Jane Michelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Michelson of New York, was married yesterday to Peter James Heffron of Bethesda, Md. Civil court Judge Burton Sherman performed the ceremony at the Michelson home.

title: SENATE DECLINES TO BACK CAREY'S NOMINEE FOR COMMERCE POST
description: The State Senate declined this morning to confirm the nomination of George G. Dempster, Governor Carey's choice as Commerce Commissioner.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. COURT, FINDING NO PERIL IN A YARMULKE, BARS AN AIR FORCE BAN
description: A Federal district judge today turned aside an Air Force order barring a Jewish officer from wearing his yarmulke in uniform.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $28,000 for the qr and $62,000 for the 6 mos

title: STRONG CROPS FORECAST FOR CORN AND WHEAT
description: A robust United States corn crop of more than 7.12 billion bushels and another record-breaking wheat crop were forecast today by the Agriculture Department's Crop Reporting Board.

title: MRS. GANDHI ASSERTS INDIANS WILL MATCH PAKISTAN'S F-16'S
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India would have to acquire sophisticated aircraft to match the F-16 fighter bombers being provided by the United States to Pakistan.

title: Minister Agrees to Halt Teaching With Shocks
description: A minister here, responding to warnings from the county prosecutor, agreed today to stop using electric shocks to teach his Bible students.

title: JURY BLAMES CON EDISON IN '80 EXPLOSION IN BRONX
description: A special grand jury declared yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company was ''primarily responsible'' for a natural-gas explosion at a street-repair site in the Bronx last summer in which a baby girl was killed and 13 other persons were injured.

title: Gershwins Featured In Film-Concert Series
description: The music of George and Ira Gershwin will be featured in a series of films and concerts every Monday next month at the Goodspeed Opera House on Route 82 in East Haddam, Conn. Beginning the series Aug. 3 will be ''An American in Paris'' with Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron.

title: An Old Way to Help Addicts
description: The idea that Government should maintain addicts on heroin to keep them from having to steal for the habit seems radical nowadays. Yet 60 years ago, drug clinics freelq dispensed morphine to addicts from Atlanta to Los Angeles.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
STANLEY N. GREENE, 70, AN ACTOR AND PRODUCER
description: Stanley N. Greene, an actor, producer, film maker and director, died of cancer on July 4 at his home in New Rochelle. He was 70 years old.

title: Children Grow in Brooklyn
description: ''Yesterday me and all my friends went to the park with my father One the way he brought us a piesar and a sola when we was about to go across the street a car came speeding by and one of my friend almost got hit but luckly for me I save her Then my father told me that was the braves thing you could have done and we went on to the park At the park we played lost of games and then we had a little picknick were everybody had fun then it was time to go On the way home we had a big race all the way home it was three blocks away but I could not make it so I lost and they were teasing me and I got made and said so At the end I felt sad.''

title: CITIES FIGURE LOSS IN MILLIONS AS BASEBALL STRIKE DRAGS ON
description: Baseball's All-Star Game was supposed to break records in Cleveland next Tuesday. Ticketholders had booked more than $500,000 worth of hotel rooms, and 75,000 fans were expected to spend more than $2.6 million in the city.

title: Roy A. Hunt Jr. Dead at 56; Retired Mellon Bank Official
description: Roy A. Hunt Jr., retired vice president of the Mellon Bank, died Wednesday in Presbyterian-University Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 56 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: Miami Crowd Protests Police Slaying of Black
description: The fatal shooting by the police of a 26-year-old black man ignited a disturbance last night in a predominantly black section of Miami, the police said.

title: 2 HELD, 6 STAY AND IT RETURNS
description: Two men today hijacked a jet airliner carrying 180 passengers and 12 crew members from Chicago to Miami and forced the pilot to fly them to Cuba, officials said. When the plane landed in Havana, the two men were arrested and six other passengers got off voluntarily.

title: Goodbye, Holden Caulfield
description: An average American adolescent is walking down a street, licking a cone of Rocky Road, carrying a Frisbee. A full set of teeth, a full head of hair, the right number of pounds, heading for ''Super-man II.''

title: SOKYS ATOM WINS HAUGHTON
description: Sokys Atom swept to the outside at the top of the stretch tonight and won the richest race in the 41-yearold history of Roosevelt Raceway.

title: WHIRLPOOL NET CLIMBS SHARPLY
description: The Whirlpool Corporation, a leading manufacturer of home appliances, said today that its secondquarter profits nearly tripled from the same period last year, mainly because of improved sales overseas and increased interest income.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Debby Austin Retains Lead
description: Cathy Reynolds shot a career-best sixunder-par 66 today and was one stroke back of the leader, Debbie Austin, after two rounds of the $150,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association Mayflower Classic.

title: A New York Lawyer Is Picked to Be Envoy
description: President Reagan announced his nominees for Ambassadorial posts in Denmark, Finland and Guatemala today. John L. Loeb Jr., 51 years old, a New York lawyer and one-time environmental adviser to Nelson A. Rockefeller when he was Governor of New York, was selected to be Ambassador to Denmark.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GREAT SCOTT

title: BROWN, FACING A QUARANTINE, YIELDS ON FRUIT-FLY SPRAYING
description: San Francisco, July 10 - Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. today ordered aerial spraying with the pesticide malathion in an attempt to avoid an economically devastating Federal quarantine of California produce because of an infestation of the Mediterranean fruit fly.

title: 2 Nicaraguan Officials Join Rebels Abroad
description: Deputy Defense Minister Eden Pastora and Deputy Interior Minister Jose Valdivia have resigned and left the country to fight alongside leftist guerrillas elsewhere in Central America.

title: FIRST SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PARKS CONCERTS OPEN JULY 29
description: The New York Philharmonic will begin its 17th season of free concerts in New York parks on July 29 at 8 P.M. The first concert, on the Great Lawn of Central Park, will be conducted by Edo de Waart, music director of the San Francisco Symphony, and will end with the traditional opening-night fireworks - this time accompanying Tchaikovsky's ''1812'' Overture.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 1 percent stock divd paid in Dec 1980 and a 60 percent stock distribution paid Nov 1980

title: LANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
DROP IN AVERAGE FOR GIRLS' MATURING IS FOUND TO BE SLIGHT
description: The generally held belief that American girls are maturing some five years earlier than they did in the last century was disputed in a report made public today.

title: 'ANARCHY' FEARED
description: Spreading urban violence erupted in more than a dozen cities and towns across England yesterday and early today as policemen and firemen fought to control thousands of black, white and Asian youths on a spree of rioting, burning and looting.

title: Sports of The Times; No Flags, No Victory, but Applause
description: MOST New Yorkers are too ''sophisticated'' to wave the flag, Harry A. Marmion said yesterday when he tried to sell 4,000 American flags at the Davis Cup match between Czechoslovakia and the United States.

title: HEARING ON PORTMAN HOTEL PROJECT TURNS INTO EMOTIONAL DEBATE
description: A hearing yesterday on the environmental impact of the proposed Portman Hotel project turned into a sometimes emotional debate on the $292.5 million complex that is slated to rise in the Times Square area.

title: UNION COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $292,000 for the qr and $752,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including $559,000 extraordinary tax credit for the qr and 6 mos, $471,000 net gain for the qr and 6 mos on the repurchase of debentures, $28,000 loss from discontinued operations for the qr and $146,000 gain from discontinued operations for the 6 mos

title: COMMERCE SOUTHWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIREMAN COMES TO HIS FAMILY'S RESCUE:
description: Anthony Itri helping his wife, Donna, down a ladder early yesterday as fire destroyed their home in South Boston. Mr. Itri was responding to a fire alarm with his ladder company when he discovered that it was his house on fire and that his wife and four children were trapped on a third-story porch. He scaled up a ladder and led them to safety. No injuries were reported in the blaze.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $535,000 or 12 cents a shr gain from sale of the company's Sunburst Yarns Inc subsidiary

title: John Henry: Oats to Riches
description: It hasn't been a very successful year for Vic Nickerson and the 30 horses he trains. When a friend came by his stable at Aqueduct recently and asked if there was anything he could do to help, Nickerson, a slim man of 52 years whom everyone calls Lefty, replied,''Yeah, make about 10 of these horses disappear.''

title: Marcia Dolan Triumphs
description: Marcia Dolan of the Ridgewood Country Club, Danbury, the medalist, won the women's Tri-County Golf Association championship today, defeating Reggie Hawes of the Westchester Country Club, 4 and 3, at the Country Club of New Canaan.

title: The City; AMBULANCE RUNS RISE WITH HEAT
description: The Emergency Medical Service reported a sudden jump in calls within the city, which it attributed to the stifling heat.

title: Patents; DEVICE TO HELP SAILORS TO DOCK, AND STAY DRY
description: Small-boat owners often find docking and mooring difficult, and sometimes fall overboard. C. Estaban Valencia, a world traveler who is now 75 years old, received patent 4,276,850 this week for a helpful apparatus: A funnel-shaped shield is installed on the pier, and a sailor can insert into the shield a rod that can be latched temporarily while a rope is placed for proper mooring.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Melvin J. Brisk last Saturday incorrectly described his role with Quadrangle Books Inc. He was a former president. The company was founded by Michael Braude in 1959.

title: Bridge: 'This Is Your Life' Feature Will Honor B. Jay Becker
description: An unusual event at 11 P.M. will conclude today's play at the Big Apple Regional Championships at the New York Hilton Hotel. Edgar Kaplan will moderate ''A Salute to B. Jay Becker,'' in which the veteran player, winner of the 1981 Vanderbilt at the age of 76, will hear anecdotes about himself recounted by a panel of experts.

title: PUERTO RICO'S FUTURE
description: .2,2SAN JUAN - President Reagan's economic-recovery program and its potential impact on Puerto Rico is of great concern to the island's 3 million United States citizens.

title: UNITED'S PLAN UPSETS J.A.L.
description: The Japanese Government is under no obligation to permit United Airlines to serve Japan, Japan Air Lines said today in a statement to the Civil Aeronautics Board of the United States.

title: Patents; PREFABRICATED ROADWAY FOR USE ON SOFT GROUND
description: A roadway that can be carried on a truck and spread in a marshy area was patented this week for the Army.

title: ROBLIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to June 20
description: B-Including tax credits of $103,000 for the latest qr and $346,000 for the previous qr

title: ISRAELI PALNES STRIKE PALESTINIAN TARGETS IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israeli jets bombed Palestinian targets in southern Lebanon today in a 40-minute raid, the first such attack in five weeks.

title: FIRST KENTUCKY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSING FUNDS FOR VENEZUELA
description: The Venezuelan state housing agency, Inavi, is negotiating an eight-year external financing of about a billion dollars for low-cost housing projects, Dieter Sydow, president of the agency, said today.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STATE LEGISLATURE RECESSES IN RUSH OF COMPROMISES
description: The 204th session of the Legislature recessed tonight after enacting into law a flurry of last-minute compromises, including a plan to handle nuclear emergencies in the state and a program to help the state's thoroughbred and harness race tracks.

title: MASSEY TO END ITS REFINANCING
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Canadian farmequipment manufacturer, said that it would begin Monday to close its $715 million refinancing program, which is designed to pull it from the edge of bankruptcy.

title: FOR JOYFUL EATING: THE ELEGANT OYSTER, LUSTY CLAM
description: Clams and oysters, both at their best when eaten fresh, icy cold, raw and on the half shell, might seem to be interchangeable, inspiring much the same style and tone of connoisseurship. In fact, these bivalves are almost polar opposites in the type of appreciation they inspire, for reasons that are difficult to fathom.

title: 4 HELD IN CUTOFF OF NEWARK WATER
description: Four local youths were arrested today and accused of turning on a pipeline valve that led to the collapse of a section of an aqueduct supplying 60 percent of Newark's water.

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $5.8 million for the qr and $13.4 million for the 6 mos...B-There ae no yr-ago com- parable figures available because the company changed from a fiscal yr ended Aug 31 to a calendar yr

title: AFRIKANER STUDENTS TAKE A DEFIANT STEP
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 9 At the risk of being branded as renegades by relatives and friends, Afrikaner students who have rejected the racial policies and values of the tightly structured community in which they were raised gathered here this week for the first national congress of a dissident student organization they have formed.

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The City; JUDGE DISMISSES SUIT AGAINST KOCH
description: A judge threw out a lawsuit by Theodore W. Kheel, the labor lawyer, charging that Mayor Koch had violated state election laws to gain an edge in this year's mayoral election.

title: Patents; DRUG MADE FROM DNA TESTED ON MICE CANCERS
description: A drug derived from DNA, patented this week by a Belgian scientist, is described as useful in treating cancerous tumors. Dr. Andre Trouet, professor of medicine at the University of Louvain, assigned patent 4,277,466 to the International Institute of Cellular and Molecular Pathology in Brussels.

title: WOUNDED IN MANEUVERS
description: A Thai soldier being removed from battlefield in Wattana Nakhon, Thailand, after he was shot in the leg during military exercises. He was reported to have lost the leg. About 3,000 Thai troops staged the maneuvers near the border with Cambodia, in what may have been a show of strength to deter frontier violations by the Cambodians.

title: CONTINENTAL EMPLOYEES WIN SUIT
description: Continental Air Lines, struggling to fend off a takeover by Texas International Airlines, obtained a double advantage yesterday when it won a favorable California court ruling and recruited George A. Warde, a leading figure in the aerospace industry, to serve as its president.

title: 'Minimasterpiece' Salute Mostly Hyperbole
description: ''When you're performing at the White House, you're catering to a certain crowd, and you may find yourself exaggerating a bit to fit the occasion,'' Leonard Slatkin, the 36-year-old music director of the St. Louis Symphony, said yesterday.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOCIAL SECURITY SLICERS FIND AN EASY TARGET
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLD ROCK MUSICAL OPENS IN MOSCOW
description: A musical combining Western rock, torrid dance, Russian Orthodox chants and Russian-American romance may sound custom-made for a resounding ''nyet'' from the guardians of Soviet culture. ''Perchance'' (''Avos'' in Russian), with lyrics by Andrei Voznesensky and music by the 36-year-old composer Aleksei Rybnikov, is just that, but it still premiered last week at the Lenin Komsomol theater.

title: COUNCIL MORE OPTIMISTIC ON GROWTH
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted today that economic activity would be flat and might even decline over the balance of 1981, but that growth would pick up again and inflation would diminish next year.

title: Your Money; FLUX IN SECOND MORTGAGES
description: ''BORROW today and pay it back with cheaper dollars'' was one of the main slogans used by banks and other financial institutions to encourage consumers to take out loans by taking second mortgages on their houses.

title: THE KILLER UNDERDOGS
description: To the Editor:

title: PENSION PLAN CUTS OPPOSED BY UNIONS
description: Three major labor organizations today attacked President Reagan's recommendations for cutting Social Security benefits, contending that the Administration had substantially exaggerated a financial problem that could be solved with far less drastic remedies.

title: ARCHITECTURE: ABANDONING ORTHODOX MODERNISM
description: It is no news that architects have been edging, slowly and fearfully, away from the glass boxes of modernism. They have not always had a sense of where they were going, but they have been absolutely certain of what they were leaving behind. Buildings like the new Asia Society on Park Avenue at 70th Street, the American Telephone and Telegraph building on Madison Avenue at 55th Street or the addition to the Frick Collection on East 70th Street do little to suggest to us a clear new direction - but they do a great deal to show us how widespread the rejection of orthodox modernism has become.

title: FLEXI-VAN NAMES HEAD
description: The Flexi-Van Corporation, a diversified financial services concern, yesterday named Lewis Rubin, a 43-year-old financial expert, to the post of president, replacing Philip Orzeck, who will remain on the company's board. The company, which specializes in long-term leasing and short-term rentals of marine cargo containers and chassis, as well as highway trailers, called the move a switch of emphasis from sales and marketing, which is Mr. Orzeck's field, to finance, Mr. Rubin's area of expertise.

title: ROBERT ALTMAN SELLS STUDIO FOR $2.3 MILLION
description: Robert Altman's Lion's Gate Films has been sold for $2.3 million to a group headed by Jonathan Taplin, producer of ''Mean Streets'' and ''The Last Waltz.''

title: Chemical Blast Kills Worker
description: A chemical tank exploded at a plastics plant today, killing one worker and critically injuring one. The death of Delbert Boers, 58 years old, of Gobles, came in the second serious explosion in less than a year at the American Cyanamid and Chemical Corporation plant.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MCENROE IS STRAIGHT-SET LOSER TO LENDL IN DAVIS CUP
description: Despite impeccable behavior and the support of the National Tennis Center crowd, John McEnroe lost to Ivan Lendl in straight sets yesterday in the first match of the quarterfinal Davis Cup round between the United States and Czechoslovakia.

title: Recall of 10-Speed Bicycles Announced by Safety Agency
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today the recall of 30,000 Yamaha 10-speed bicycles that it said might have a structural defect that could cause them to collapse.

title: PITCHED FOR THE CARDINALS
description: William A. (Wild Bill) Hallahan, once a member of the St. Louis Cardinals Gashouse Gang, died Wednesday night.

title: MOBILE HOME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DUBLIN EXHORTING LONDON ON ULSTER funeral
description: Senior officials from Ireland urged the British Government today to adopt quickly what they described as a flexible approach to the continuing hunger strikes by republican prisoners in Northern Ireland. Otherwise, the Dublin officials warned, relations between Ireland and Britain may suffer.

title: FREDERICK C. KEMPNER
description: Fredrick C. Kempner, a lawyer and retired partner of the Manhattan law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15.

title: Pennsylvania Allows Bingo
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh, saying his action would end law enforcement hypocrisy, today signed a bill making small-stakes bingo games legal for the first time in Pennsylvania.

title: A Legacy of the 'First Philadelphia Lawyer'
description: Since he popularized the phrase ''Philadelphia lawyer'' in his defense of the journalist John Peter Zenger 246 years ago, Andrew Hamilton is especially important to attorneys in Philadelphia.

title: TEXACO MAY SEEK $5.5 BILLION
description: Texaco Inc., which is expected to make a takeover bid for another oil company soon, is negotiating an option to borrow $5.5 billion from a group of American and foreign banks, banking sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Patents; CHEMICAL IN CANDY TO INHIBIT SMOKING
description: A Californian offers a method of inhibiting tobacco smoking without causing physiological symptoms of nicotine withdrawal.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: A pipeline break spewed toxic chlorine gas over a municipal water treatment plant for half an hour today, injuring at least 24 persons.

title: MODEL FLORIDA INFANT UNITS OVERFLOW
description: Stephanie Marie McElrath, a 1-pound 11-ounce premature baby flown by the Air Force from Florida to a hospital in Georgia when her doctors were unable to find an intensive-care bed for her, was holding her own today after surgery.

title: SUSPECT IN SLASHINGS OF VAGRANTS NAMED IN TWO MORE ATTACKS
description: The 32-year-old drifter who was arrested Monday and charged with the murder of a vagrant was charged yesterday with two additional slashing attacks.

title: SPERRY EXPECTS 75% EARNINGS UP
description: The Sperry Corporation said that it expects to report a 75 percent decline in earnings for the first quarter and possibly a decline in the second quarter as well.

title: Rangers' Jennings Cited
description: The United States Hockey Hall of Fame in Eveleth, Minn. has elected three new members, including William M. Jennings, president of the New York Rangers.

title: Medics Say Somalia Aid May Cause Malnutrition
description: Doctors, appealing on behalf of hundreds of thousands of refugees in Somalia, said today that protein-poor food supplied by international donors may be causing severe malnutrition.

title: Czechs Are Said to Sentence A Rights Activist to 4 Years
description: A Czechoslovak human rights activist has been sentenced to four years in prison and there are indications that at least 10 other dissidents arrested in May will soon stand trial in Prague, emigre sources said here today.

title: NUCLEAR CUTBACK
description: To the Editor:

title: A YOUTH'S FRUSTRATING JOB SEARCH
description: ''Hey, check this out,'' said Dezie Collins. It was his all-purpose introduction to almost any topic, whether he was poised to talk about his search for a job, his attempts to get the high school diploma that has eluded him since he dropped out of school more than a year ago, or his music.

title: NO GUARDS HELD
description: Nearly 300 of the 400 male inmates at the overcrowded Westchester County Jail here took over six of the nine main cellblocks and a nearby dormitory yesterday afternoon in what officials called a ''spontaneous'' uprising.

title: WILLIAM R. BUTLER
description: William R. Butler, a former advertising manager of The New York Herald Tribune, died Monday at the Colburn Memorial Home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 83 years old and lived in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: BILL COULD CURB A.T.&T.'S PLAN TO DISTRIBUTE NEWS AND DATA
description: The Senate Commerce Committee made public today a draft amendment that would bar the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from originating information services of the kind that newspapers and broadcasters might offer.

title: A PLAN TO AID THRIFT UNITS
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today proposed to allow its 12 regional banks to pay interest on the demand deposits of member savings and loan associations.

title: TOPAZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FLORIDA POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Star Game Put Off
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday that baseball's All-Star Game, scheduled for Tuesday night in Cleveland, would be postponed.

title: 'LEGLESS VETERAN'
description: Howard Petrick's ''The Case of the Legless Veteran'' is yet another horror story about the post-World War II political persecutions in this country prompted by the so-called ''red scare.'' The victim this time is James Kutcher, an Army veteran who had lost both his legs at the Battle of San Pietro. In 1948 Mr. Kutcher was discharged from his $36-a-week job as a Veterans Administration file clerk because of his membership in the Socialist Workers Party, to which he had belonged since 1938 and which had recently been put on the United States Attorney General's list of subversive organizations.

title: WHAN SUMMER CUM, TO SING CUCCU IS HUMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've lost the subways and most of the parks, and we just can't afford to lose our libraries.'' - Thomas E. Slade, New York City's Assistant Police Commissioner. (1:6.)

title: News Summary; News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1981 International Rioting erupted in a dozen English cities, including London. Policemen and firemen attempted to control thousands of frenzied black and white youths on a rampage of rioting, burning and looting. A Government spokesman described the violence as by far worst since the scattered riots started a week ago, and said that in some cities ''we are facing anarchy.'' In London, more than 250 arrests were made and more than 40 people were injured. Blazes broke out in at least six sections of the city. William Whitelaw, the Home Secretary, said he could not rule out the use of troops in situations of ''extreme ferocity.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) Canada's Prime Minister took steps to set a mood of harmony and cooperation at this year's annual conference of the leaders of the seven major industrial democracies, which will held at Ottawa on July 20 and 21. Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau assured President Reagan in a meeting at the White House that the conference would avoid ''unacceptable'' criticism of each other's economic policies. The White House meeting followed a series of preliminary meetings Mr. Trudeau has had with other participants. (1:1.)

title: WALLACE WOLCOTT
description: Wallace Wolcott, a retired architect and former member of the firm of McKim, Mead & White of New York City, died June 30 in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, where he had lived since his retirement 20 years ago.

title: North Carolina's College Deal
description: It is hard to know whether the United States and North Carolina have finally found a satisfactory path to desegregation of the state university system. Even with the best will, the once all-black and all-white public colleges of the South are difficult to merge and mix. In most places, only Federal pressure and court action guaranteed progress.

title: FREIHOFER'S EXPANDS TO KEEP PACE WITH BIG BAKERS
description: The stage was set for the introduction of the Charles Freihofer Baking Company into the greater Albany area shortly after the turn of the century, when Charles, Frank and Edwin Freihofer stopped in Troy during a train ride from Philadelphia to Montreal.

title: FREEDOM FOR MRS. PERON REFLECTS PERONIST POWER Madrid
description: The Plaza de Mayo was filled with marching soldiers on parade as the military Government celebrated Argentina's independence day yesterday with the trappings it knows best.

title: FLORIDA TO SUE U.S. IN REFUGEE DISPUTE
description: Florida is preparing a lawsuit against the Federal Government over its handling of Haitian and Cuban refugees in the Miami area, Gov. Bob Graham announced here today.

title: Doctors Separate Twins Joined at the Livers
description: Twin girls, joined from the breast bone to the navel and at the livers, were successfully separated today and doctors said they expected the infants to make a ''normal recovery.''

title: G.M. DELAYS VACATION PAY
description: Officials of the United Automobile Workers said today that there was little they could do to prevent the General Motors Corporation from issuing vacation paychecks later than usual to its 376,000 hourly workers.

title: OFFERING BY G.T.E.
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation has started a public offering of five million shares at a price of $28.875 each, underwriting group managers said yesterday. Proceeds from the sale will be used to reduce short-term debt and for further investment in, or advances to, subsidiaries to finance their operations.

title: BRIDGEPORT MELEE AT A CITY PROJECT LEAVES 9 INJURED
description: Eight policemen were hurt in a rock-and bottle-throwing incident at a housing project here last night and a passer-by was shot in the arm.

title: STAR SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to June 20
No Headline
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo said in an interview today that he did not fear another coup attempt despite what he acknowledged was right wing ''restlessness'' within the armed forces. ''I don't live with the fear of another coup, but with the problems posed by unemployment, the surging dollar and terrorism,'' he said.

title: 3 VETERANS END HUNGER STRIKE
description: Three veterans of the Vietnam War ended a 45-day hunger strike today after they were promised that Congress would conduct hearings on their grievances, according to a spokesman for the men.

title: ADDICTS AND VANDALS TROUBLING CITY LIBRARIES
description: New York City's libraries are struggling to preserve not only their traditional peace and quiet, but also their very safety as they fend off drug addicts, vandals, thieves, derelicts and teenagers who curse and even threaten the staff.

title: CAREY AIDES HINT AT VETO
description: The State Assembly gave final passage today to a bill to increase the amount of money available under the state's Tuition Assistance Program. But top aides to the Governor said he might veto the measure.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday incorrectly identified some areas that would be denied Federal flood insurance under a bill passed by the House of Representatives. The bill would deny the insurance for new or substantially rebuilt housing and commercial structures on undeveloped sections of barrier islands. It would not affect insurance for structures in developed areas, such as Fire Island, Atlantic City or Miami Beach.

title: DETROIT- A TALE OF TWO CITIES
description: When the United States emerged from the turbulent 60's, Detroit had become just about everybody's best example of the worst aspects of our nation's deteriorating northern metropolitan centers.

title: AN INSTANT MOB ON FIFTH AVENUNE
description: To the Editor:

title: KATHERINE W. STRAUSS
description: Katherine Wolff Strauss, president of the Women's City Club of New York from 1957 to 1961, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan.

title: The City; CAUSE STILL UNCLEAR IN SUBWAY DEATH
description: The Medical Examiner's office said it had not yet determined what caused the death of Gerard Coury, the 26-year-old visitor from Connecticut who died on the tracks of a Times Square subway station on the morning of June 27, reportedly after he was stripped, taunted and chased by bottle-throwing youths and vagrants.

title: SAMUELS CHALLENGED AS HEAD OF CITY CENTER
description: A fierce battle is being waged for control of the board of the City Center of Music and Drama. The battle pits the center's controversial chairman, John S. Samuels 3d, who has relinquished the chairmanships of the New York City Ballet and Opera in the last two years, against some of New York's most powerful arts administrators and cultural leaders, who wish to unseat him at City Center as well.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STOCKS WEAKEN WITH DOW OFF 3.33
description: The stock market failed to maintain Thursday's technical rally yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average moved lower shortly after trading began. It closed off 3.33 points, at 955.67, as uncertainty over the course of interest rates again slowed buying.

title: ERNEST A. SCHELLING
description: Ernest A. Schelling, who operated a general store in Pound Ridge, N.Y., for more than a half century, died June 24 at the Veterans Hospital in Gainesville, Fla.

title: TRUDEAU ASSURES U.S. OF HARMONY FOR WORLD TALKS
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada assured President Reagan today that participants in the forthcoming summit meeting at Ottawa would avoid ''unacceptable'' criticism of each other's economic policies.

title: John Lampe Marries Nancy Jane Wilson
description: At St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Philadelphia Nancy Jane Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Wilson of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to John Scarborough Lampe, son of Mrs. Robert Van Gelder of Sun City, Ariz., and the late Dr. Herman Ferdinand Lampe of New York. The Rev. F. Lee Richards performed the ceremony.

title: A WISTFUL LETTER FROM THE 'BOY NEXT DOOR'
description: As time goes by, one thing seems absolutely certain about President Reagan: He used to write a lot of letters.

title: TRAVEL OFFICES COLOR DRAB MOSCOW SCENE
description: Window shopping is not a widespread practice in Moscow, where shops, for the most part, are bleak and utilitarian outlets for scarce goods. Window displays are usually unimaginative pyramids of faded goods, working hours are roughly stenciled onto ill-fitted doors and store names are usually confined to stark descriptions of offered wares: ''meat,'' ''shoes,'' ''produce,'' ''books.''

title: Responsibility for Fund Is Disavowed by Strack
description: David Strack, the athletic director at the University of Arizona, testified today that Tony Mason, a former football coach at the school, told him four years ago about a special cash fund operating outside university channels.

title: Bennington's 'Quiet' President Stepping Down
description: In 1976, when Dr. Joseph S. Murphy, then president of Queens College in New York, accepted the presidency of Bennington College, a liberal arts school in Vermont with a reputation for anarchic tendencies, he was asked why.

title: HAITIAN CHILDREN WHO ESCAPED BY BOAT AWAIT ADOPTION UPSTATE
description: About 1,500 miles from their homes in Haiti, 58 children who escaped to this country by boat without their parents are being cared for here in Dutchess County while they await adoption.

title: Possible Drug Use by Jockeys Studied
description: The possible use of cocaine and other drugs by several New York jockeys in the mid-1970's is under investigation by the New York Racing Association and the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: SEANTORS ACCEPT TALKS WITH HOUSE ON CUTS IN BUDGET
description: Senate Republican leaders overrode the objections of President Reagan today and agreed to go to a conference with the House to resolve differences between the two chambers' versions of more than $38 billion in budget cuts.

title: ASSETS SENT TO FED BANK ELECTRONICALLY Iranian account
description: There were no bags of dollar bills, nor cases filled with checks. It all happened electronically. One hundred banks around the country yesterday transferred almost $2 billion of Iranian assets to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, practically without a hitch.

title: A.&S. CHIEF GOING
description: Lasker M. Meyer, who was named chairman and chief executive officer of Abraham & Straus in February 1980, will leave those posts to return to the Foley Department Stores in Houston this fall, according to trade sources. The 55-year old Mr. Meyer, who had been president of Foley's before joining A.& S., is expected to succeed Stewart Orton, Foley's chairman, early next year, the sources said. Both Abraham & Straus and Foley's are divisions of Federated Department Stores Inc. A spokesman at Federated, asked yesterday about reports of Mr. Meyer's shift, said that the company would not comment. Mr. Meyer, reached at his office in Brooklyn, also declined comment.

title: HOUSE SETS ASIDE PROCUREMENT BAN
description: A House committee narrowly lost the first round today in its fight to restrict what it considers wasteful military spending practices.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
description: The shr earnings reflect two stock splits

title: Speaking Personally; AMUSEMENT PARKS: IT'S NOT ALL FUN AND GAMES
description: LAST summer, I worked at one of the shore's amusement parks. As a teacher interested in the Roman games, I found the job historically and psychologically fascinating.

title: DANCER IS FOLLOWING FAMILY'S FOOTSTEPS
description: THE setting was a storefront studio in Greenwich Village, and Gail Conrad, a New Jersey-raised dancer and choreographer, was rehearsing her company of dancers and musicians for her production of ''Wave.''

title: RIOTS STRIP AWAY BRITISH ILLUSIONS
description: Nothing in their national experience - not soccer hooliganism or the ''mods'' versus ''rockers'' rumbles of the 1960's - prepared Britons for the fury and scope of youth violence that erupted in urban neighborhoods throughout the country last week.

title: STATE ECONOMY DEVELOPING INTERNATIONAL ORIENTATION
description: NAUGATUCK TWO technicians are now at work in Peking, installing a $350,000 precision-measuring machine manufactured in Bridgeport by Moore Special Tool Company Inc. In West Germany, professional photographers are using presses made by Seal Inc. of Naugatuck to mount and laminate portraits.

title: REV. JOHN J. MCMAHON FORMER JESUIT PROVINCIAL, DIES AT 76
description: The Rev. John J. McMahon, former head of the New York Province of the Society of Jesus, died yesterday at his home in the Bronx. He was 76 years old.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Homeless School
description: For 40 years, the Wiltwyck School for Boys - an agency for neglected or disturbed youngsters, mostly from New York City - has been a place where, when you had to go there, they were eager to take you in.

title: The Region; BACK TO SEA FOR MOUND OF MUCK
description: The same environmental fears that prompted a ban on the dumping of sludge in the ocean may last week have doomed a plan to spread it on the land as fertilizer. As a result, officials said an innovative waste treatment plant in Wantagh, L.I., though nearly complete, may never be used.

title: No Headline
description: Gypsy moths en masse succumb to only one effective kill - chemical spraying - and it is high time to be realistic about it.
