As ardent an environmentalist as anyone, I believe that a stand of dead trees is an ecological blight, devoid of birds (except, perhaps, woodpeckers) or animal life, a community fire hazard, a source of soil erosion and an esthetic rebuke to our delinquent stewardship of natural resources.

title: CON EDISON STARTS SOLAR HEAT PROJECT
description: CONTINUING its expansion into practical applications of solar energy in its service area, Con Edison has announced the beginning of a two-year demonstration project to provide solar-assisted water heating systems to 700 houses in New York City and Westchester County.

title: Realty News; MADISON AVENUE
description: Rose Associates/Dwelling Managers Inc., a leading real-estate organization active in New York, Boston, the Meadowlands in New Jersey and the Washington area, is relocating from 522 Fifth Avenue to 380 Madison Avenue.

title: 12,000 CITY PUPILS TRYING TO RAISE READING SCORES
description: A ''last chance'' summer reading program has begun for 12,000 New York City public-school pupils who are trying to avoid having to repeat their grades in the fall.

title: Seitz's Points
description: To the Sports Editor: In my opinion, the points made by Peter Seitz (The New York Times, July 5) are utterly absurd. For example, Seitz states, ''Clearly it is not the club owners or the players who are betraying the national pastime but the fans and the misguided sports gurus of whom I write.''

title: Jacqueline Long Married to Denis Maksymowicz
description: Jacqueline Flint Long, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Arnold Long of Weston, Conn., and East Chop, Mass., was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Denis William Maksymowicz, son of Mrs. William Maksymowicz of Elizabeth, N.J., and Pompano, Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Maksymowicz. The Rev. Charles Weiser performed the Roman Catholic cermony in the Princeton University Chapel.

title: CRITICS CHOICES
description: ART A pessimist, in my book, is a man who thinks that after the Fourth of July it just isn't worth anyone's while to go to the dealers' galleries. It is perfectly true that an important opening in July is as rare as a bluefish without teeth.

title: Stamps; SHE WAS THE MOST POPULAR POET OF HER TIME
description: The poetry of Edna St. Vincent Millay, palpitating with the ecstasies and despairs of a youth that would never grow old, made her the idol of the generation of ''FLaming Youth'' of the Twenties. The young anti-Victorians took as their ''Psalm of Life'' her verse about the candle burning at both ends.

title: No Headline
description: Where is it written that all Americans are entitled to a singlefamily home and a backyard for their children? My parents raised three children in an apartment and rather than teaching us resentment because we shared a hall, they taught us to be considerate of other people's possessions. What's the big deal about playing alone in a backyard? When I was growing up in Queens, if I didn't like the crowd down on the corner, there was always a game of handball going on down the block. SHARON POIDOMANI, Elmhurst, N.Y.

title: REAGAN WILL URGE PATIENCE BY ALLIES ON INTEREST RATE
description: President Reagan, who is to meet in a week with the leaders of the major industrial democracies in Ottawa, will urge them to give him time to bring down the high American interest rates that are choking the economies of Europe, Administration officials say.

title: POWERBOATS SET FOR GRAND PRIX
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH THE 1981 Benihana Grand Prix, described as ''the world's biggest offshore powerboat race,'' will be held next Wednesday, and the guiding light for the event is Rocky Aoki, a 13-year resident of Englewood.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD REACHED IN STRIKE OF SCREEN WRITERS
description: A tentative settlement was reached at 2 A.M. today in the 13-week Hollywood writers' strike against movie and television producers. Gary Ellingsworth, chief negotiator for the 8,500-member Writers Guild of America, termed the settlement ''truly historic.''

title: STARLINGS: BIRDS OF A FEATHER
description: WHOM should we thank, Shakespeare or Eugene Scheifflin? Perhaps we should credit both for the enormous starling populations in the United States, including New Jersey.

title: Holding The Forte
description: William Safire is always enlightening and amusing, as witness his clear explanation of the pronunciation of forte (On Language, June 14).

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SALT LAKE CITY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- GEORGE RAINE reports for The New York Times from Salt Lake City. By GEORGE RAINE

title: FERRAGAMO MAKES RECOVERY
description: The beginning was awful, the middle dark but the end wonderful. Vince Ferragamo, the quarterback imported from California in the offseason as the most expensive player ever in the Canadian Football League, played in the Montreal Alouettes' home opener last night, after a miserable performance in a 48-8 trouncing at Vancouver last Saturday. By the end of the game, the fans who had begun to wonder whether he was worth the price had found that he might be.

title: Editors' Choice
description: IF ON A WINTER'S NIGHT A TRAVELER, by Italo Calvino. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95.) A novel about reading fiction, by the Italian master.

title: Antiques; SHORELINE BREEZES AT OUTDOOR SHOW
description: WESTBROOK COLLECTORS who enjoy their antiques shows al fresco will be within wafting range of cool Long Island Sound breezes next Saturday when they attend the annual outdoor festival in this small town nestled on the shoreline between Clinton and Old Saybrook.

title: FRED CREIGHTON IS BACK--BUT HOW FAR?
description: FRED CREIGHTON recalls those ''mental games I used to play with myself.'' ''I used to imagine what I'd be doing,'' he says, ''if I wasn't in hockey.''

title: Politics; ABORTION DIVIDING 2 PARTIES
description: WHILE the Conservative and Right to Life Parties maintain a tenuous relationship throughout most of the state, the two parties have broken in Nassau County, with the Conservative Party in effect trying to put the Right to Life Party out of business in the county where the Right to Life Party is strongest and where much of its leadership lives.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: THE AGGLOMERATION OF AMERICA
description: W HEN French social philosopher Alexis de Tocqueville arrived in the United States 150 years ago he marvelled at this country's knack for business. ''The greatest industrial undertakings are executed without difficulty,'' he wrote.

title: SAVING WATER IN THE WATER CLOSET
description: HOBOKEN HENRY MORTON, the first president of Stevens Institute of Technology, might have looked askance at the display that dominates a campus showroom here. Mr. Morton founded Stevens in 1870, hoping to raise engineering to new heights.

title: Article 191022 -- No Title
description: The State of California has $200 million in tax refunds that it is unable to give away. The money is what remains of about $600 million that was to be returned to taxpayers from the state-operated Disability Insurance Fund under a 1979 law.

title: LITERATURE AS A RESPITE
description: INTO each life a little break, or pause, should come. Mine arrived on a murky, heat-blurred afternoon in July. A local college, one that specializes in the performing arts, needed a teacher for a course called Masterpieces of European Literature. I once taught literature, and an old resume had somehow levitated to the top of the pile. Could I, asked a cool, air-conditioned voice, ''do'' the likes of Aeschylus, Sophocles, Chekhov, Shakespeare and T. S. Eliot?

title: Haas, on 67-201, Forges 5-Shot Milwaukee Lead
description: Jay Haas shot a five-under-par 67 today to open a five-shot lead in the $250,000 Greater Milwaukee Open, but he wasn't ready to claim victory yet.

title: Westchester Guide; ROADSIDE TACKY TIME
description: John Margolies spent five years driving more than 100,000 miles in a quest for the essence of what might be called American Junk architecture. Like junk food, it bespeaks a culture once viewed as tacky, but is acquiring the mellow patina of age.

title: A Road to Status
description: IT is Wednesday, matinee day on Broadway, and they are waving cars away from the chock-full parking garage around the corner on 43d Street. In front of me is a Dodge, in back a Chevy. Both are sent packing. But there is room for the Ferrari. There is always room for a bright red Ferrari.

title: WORKING WITHOUT LEAVING HOME
description: THEY don't stand around the water cooler any more or daydream in company meetings. They have given up work in high-rise office buildings and plugged their computers into suburban homes.

title: The World in Summary; BEGIN COUNTS ON HARD-CORE CADRE
description: Governing Israel with only a one-seat majority in Parliament will be ''easier'' than if he had won big, Prime Minister Menachem Begin contended last week, making the best of his situation, which just happened to be that of a man with a one-seat majority. Official returns from the June 30 election gave Likud 48 votes in the 120-seat Knesset and he said three small religious parties would add 13 to his coalition.

title: NOMINEE FOR HIGH COURT: A RECORD DEFYING LABELS
description: Like supporters and detractors of her Supreme Court nomination, Sandra Day O'Connor devoted the better part of this week to a review of the state legislation and judicial decisions that constitute the record of much of her public life.

title: Recordings; KEEPING UP WITH ALICIA DE LARROCHA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about classical records. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: No Headline
description: Roger Swain neglected to say anything about the smell - the combination of desiccated bodies and dead leaves is not pleasant.

title: DOWNING COUNTRY: A LANDSCAPING LEGACY
description: WHEN the steamboat Henry Clay, racing with a rival vessel, the Armenia, caught fire off Yonkers and exploded near Riverdale in 1852, more than 90 passengers were burned to death or drowned. Among them was Andrew Jackson Downing. Not quite 37 years old, he was at that time the leading landscaper, the most respected horticulturist and the most powerful arbiter of taste in the United States.

title: FAMILY HISTORY
description: EMMA By Charlotte Bronte and ''Another Lady.'' 202 pp. New York: Everest House. $11.95. THE ROAD TO HAWORTH By John Cannon. Illustrated. 138 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $11.95.

title: The Nation in Summary; MR. CARTER'S VIEWS ABOUT THAT OTHER FELLOW'S POLICIES
description: Jimmy Carter has been largely out of sight for five and a half months, apparently nurturing his grudge and saving ammunition. Now he has surveyed the changes wrought by the Reagan Administration in Washington and - of all things - found fault almost everywhere. Mr. Carter's review, made earlier this month in a three-page letter ostensibly to his former Cabinet members and White House aides, was made public last week. Among his findings:

title: TOP MYSTERY PRIZE
description: WHODUNIT? The question had mystery and crime writers from five continents guessing at the recent Crime Writers Third International Congress held in Stockholm. Who had written the world's best mystery story?

title: THE PEACE CORPS: BRINGING THE WORLD BACK HOME
description: MORE than 80,000 Peace Corps volunteers, including the 6,000 serving today, have made a difference in the lives of people in isolated villages and city slums in more than 90 countries since the birth of the Peace Corps in 1961. But the success of the Peace Corps lies, just as importantly, in what America has received in return. The friendships and experience, personal maturity and technical skills, proficiency in languages and a unique knowledge of other people and cultures form the rewards - and the resources - from which Americans can and should draw.

title: Suspect Held in Killings Of 5 in Rural Georgia
description: A 47-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the shooting deaths of five persons, including an 8-year-old girl, in two counties of rural eastern Georgia.

title: Art; INDONESIAN TEXTILE DESIGN
description: KATONAH THE redness suffusing the Katonah Gallery makes it seem, momentarily, as if sacrifices have been offered there. The hue emanates from a group of Indonesian textiles lent, for the first time, by a Swiss collector, Samuel Josefowitz. On view through July 26, these 30 extraordinary cotton weavings - ceremonial cloths, mantles, skirts and hangings - were assembled under the aegis of the gallery's exhibitions chairman, Gretchen Adkins. Completing the production is an illustrated catalogue written by the show's curator, Monni Adams, professor of art and anthropology at Harvard University.

title: WHAT HUMANISTIC EDUCATION IS--AND ISN'T
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess; THIS IS THE STUFF THAT CHAMPIONS ARE MADE OF
description: Many a player will mope through a tournament after an early-round loss, throwing away one point after another, as if resigned to total disaster.

title: STRAIGHT AND NARROW WAYS TO JAM TRAFFIC
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Isle; INSIDE BROOKHAVEN
description: To help Long Islanders get through the long, hot summer, the Brookhaven National Laboratory opens its doors to the public each year at this season. The free guided tours, from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. Sundays, start today, and highlights of the visit include Isabelle, the high-energy proton accelerator that is under construction; an aquarium full of genetically identical fish used for cancer research; a phosphorescent wall on which shadow images are captured by strobe light, and Brookhaven House, the solar residence developed by lab engineers and architects. The laboratory is on William Floyd Parkway in Upton. For information: 282-2345.

title: CONNECTICUT TRIBES SEEK LAND AND IDENTITY
description: THE state's 5,200 Indians, sometimes called the ''the invisible minority,'' have come into view in recent weeks, the result of a legal victory that guarantees the establishment of a new reservation and opens the way for the expansion of several others, but also of a legislative defeat that leaves the Indians for the first time in 300 years without an official liaison at the State Capitol.

title: Gardening; AVOIDING A HODGEPODGE OF FLOWERS
description: ALL too often our flowered gardens are planted with a minimum of effort toward planning. We see a photograph of an attractive plant in a magazine or catalogue, or perhaps we admire a plant in a garden center and decide that we must have it. After lugging it home, we search out the first vacant spot in the garden, dig a hole and plop it into the ground.

title: WEEDS
description: With the peak of ragweed season almost upon us, it may seem odd, if not in outright poor taste, to sing the praises of common garden-variety weeds. One could argue that weeds provide a substantial stimulus to the economy: Sales of herbicide and allergy ''remedies'' alone probably equal the gross national products of some small countries. And would anyone making a list of the cleverest inventions of the century dare leave out the Weed-Eater? It is not, however, for their dollar-generating value that my admiration of the vermin of the plant world is based. I like weeds for the very reason that most people abhor them. Weeds are very tough. Biologically speaking, weeds unhesitatingly root where the angels in the plant world fear to tread.

title: No Headline
description: While the tax advantages and inflation-hedging aspects of home buying may have ''drained a disproportionate share of total credit into home financing,'' only one in five home buyers today is a first-home buyer; the other 80 percent are getting rich on the sale of their overpriced homes and purchasing even more expensive real estate. KAREN A. GROSSMAN, Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; FRUIT FLIES DO MULTIPLE DAMAGE
description: Concern for the health and profitability of California's $14 billion fruit and vegetable industry last week pitted man against the Mediterranean fruit fly, growers against environmentalists and the Federal Government against Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. So far, only the fruit fly seemed to be winning.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 12, 1981
description: International Rioting continued in London and two other cities after the worst night of violence since the rioting began in England eight days ago. A memorial service in the east London district of Walthamstow for an Asian family whose members died in an arson attack became a brawl involving 500 youths. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher held urgent meetings with Home Secretary William Whitelaw. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: STATE UNIT TO EXPAND CONSUMER 'HOT LINE'
description: NEWARK WANT to know how to complain to department stores, contractors or government agencies? Want to know what to do about errors on purchases made with a credit card?

title: WHAT TO ASK JUDGE O'CONNOR
description: Some of the objections to Sandra O'Connor are about as relevant to her fitness for the Supreme Court as abortions are relevant to stadiums.

title: The High Cost Of Starting Out
description: I know times change, and comparing today's standards and prices with yesterday's is probably unfair, but I can't help thinking back upon our early married years (''The High Cost of Starting Out,'' by Howard Husock, June 7). We felt fortunate to find a third-floor apartment in a commuting suburb.

title: JOHN HENRY WINS TURF STAKES
description: John Henry waited calmly behind a slow early pace, moved between two rivals on the stretch turn and drew off in the final quarter-mile to win the $162,300 Sword Dancer Stakes by 3 1/2 lengths at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Miami District Is Quiet In Aftermath of Killing
description: Little trouble was reported today in a black section of Miami where stones were thrown last night and two whites were beaten in sporadic violence after police officers shot and killed a black gunman.

title: PLAN TO RETURN THE BLACK BEAR TO JERSEY PROVOKES A DISPUTE
description: With a million acres of pineland in southern New Jersey newly protected by state and Federal legislation from undue encroachment by civilization, the state's Bureau of Wildlife Management decided the time had come to restore the black bear, which had been abundant until the last century, to its native pineland habitat.

title: At Home Abroad; FULFILLING A PROPHECY
description: When President Sadat signed the Camp David agreements, his Arab critics predicted that peace with Egypt would simply free Israel's hand on other fronts. They say now that events on the ground have proved them right: The Begin Government has accelerated the building of settlements in the occupied West Bank, become more deeply engaged in Lebanon, sent its war planes as far as Baghdad. And it has been able to press this more forward policy without fear of a military response because there is no threat from Egypt.

title: Roman Catholics End Mediation Effort in Ulster
description: Rebuffed by both sides, a team of Roman Catholics concluded a weeklong mediation effort today and issued an appeal to Britain to negotiate directly with the eight Irish Republican Army hunger strikers in Belfast's Maze Prison.

title: A HALFHEARTED TWO-PARTY SYSTEM
description: LIKE the last of the dinosaurs before the Ice Age, I am the sole Republican representative on New Haven's 27-member Board of Aldermen. From nine Republican aldermen when I began serving in 1977, there is today only one.

title: DIFFORD AND TILBROOK- TOP SONGWRITERS
description: There have been several ''golden ages'' of popular songwriting. For many listeners, especially listeners whose tastes were shaped in the years before rock and roll, the golden age of the pop song was the 30's and 40's, when writers like Jerome Kern and Cole Porter were at their zenith. Fans who are somewhat younger might point to the 50's, when Chuck Berry, Otis Blackwell and the team of Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller wrote enduring anthems to youth, the open road and the automobile. Then there are the mid-60's, when Lennon and McCartney of the Beatles, Ray Davies of the Kinks, and Jagger and Richards of the Rolling Stones stretched the limits of pop song forms while creating some unforgettable melodies and literate, allusive lyrics.

title: BASEBALL NEGOTIATIONS BREAK OFF
description: Ray Grebey, top right, owners' representative, criticizing proposal to end the baseball strike.

title: Martha Buttenheim Wed
description: At the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday, Martha Bradford Buttenheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar M. Buttenheim of Princeton, was married to Vytas A. Kisielius, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfonsas Kisielius of Sidney, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Wallace Alston performed the ceremony. The bride is a June graduate of Princeton University. Mr. Kisielius, an alumnus of Princeton, class of '78, attends the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

title: Photography View; A NEW VIGOR IN THE FIELD OF PORTRAITURE
description: Portraiture, one of the most venerable of photographic genres, has become a vital arena in contemporary photography. Partly this is a reaction against what is loosely termed formalist photography; partly it seems an investment in the recondite. Some of the medium's most powerful images are portraits - think of Julia Margaret Cameron's Tennyson, Edward Steichen's Garbo, Richard Avedon's June Leaf - yet our ability to explicate how we distinguish them from the accumulated masses of everyday portraiture remains rather primitive.

title: Follow-Up on the News; The Pope's Ring
description: Visiting Rio de Janeiro last July, Pope John Paul II went to a favela - a community of the desperately poor -known as Vidigal. He climbed a steep dirt road to the slum and received a tumultuous welcome.

title: DIVERGING ON THE SUMMIT
description: WHEN the leaders of the industrialized world gather in Ottawa just a week from now - four for their first economic summit - they will be confronting an unusual divergence of economic conditions, of beliefs on what policy should be, and of opinion on what, if anything, can or should be endorsed at this annual gathering.

title: Art; BLACK ART IN JERSEY CITY
description: JERSEY CITY THOSE viewers who missed ''emerging and Established,'' the show recently held at the Newark Museum, have a chance to see it, or something like it, at the Jersey City Museum through July 31.

title: SOUR CHERRY CROP WORST SINCE 1945
description: New York State's crop of sour cherries, normally the second largest in the nation, has plummeted to the smallest level since record-keeping began in 1938.

title: Childen's Books
description: THE MARZIPAN MOON By Nancy Willard. Illustrated by Marcia Sewall. Unpaged. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Cloth, $9.95. Paper, $4.95. (Ages 7 to 10) By SELMA G.LANES

title: Mailbox; The Manhattan Student Athlete
description: To the Sports Editor: Frank Litsky's article ''Manhattan College: Grades Over Games'' (The New York Times, June 24) was one of the most refreshing pieces I have read regarding my alma mater's athletic program in quite some time.

title: U.S. Judge Bids Indiana Pay for City's Busing
description: Federal District Judge S. Hugh Dillin has ordered Indiana to pay for busing of 5,583 black pupils from the city school system to six school systems in the suburbs.

title: THE BUTCHER WON A WIFE
description: HOUSEHOLD SAINTS By Francine Prose. 227 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $10.95.

title: Children's Books
description: THE LEGEND OF TARIK By Walter Dean Myers. 185 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $9.95. (Ages 12 to 16) By MALCOLM BOSSE

title: Return of the Salmon in Maine
description: BANGOR, Me. FOR the 10th year in a row, the Atlantic salmon is back in the Penobscot River in growing numbers. Ted Williams, who has fished the Miramichi in New Brunswick most summers since he left off massaging curve balls in the American League, is disturbed about the future of that famous stream, but to conservationists and admirers of the greatest fish that swims, the Penobscot is a wonderfully exciting story.

title: EXCHANGE OF CLERGY
description: FAIRFIELD IT raised a few eyebrows here when the Rev. T. Roy Everall made his parish rounds in shorts, though to the clergyman it was the most natural thing in the world. In Auckland, New Zealand, where he lives, it is a perfectly acceptable practice, he said, for professional men to combat the summer heat by going about their business clad in shorts, knee socks and cool open-neck shirts.

title: ROCKY ROADBED FOR SUBWAYS
description: It was a tragic irony that subway motorman Jesse Cole was killed just hours after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority raised the city's transit fare to 75 cents. The M.T.A. had said the increase would help meet the rising costs of parts and labor needed to maintain its rattletrap equipment; Mr. Cole's fellow transit workers said the subway collision in which he died July 3 resulted at least in part from inadequate equipment maintenance - specifically, the failure of some 60-year-old signals.

title: Title to Miss Pepper, 15
description: Dottie Pepper, a 15-year-old high school student from Gansevoort, won the New York State women's amateur golf championship today. She beat Joan Placek of Northport, L.I., 4 and 3, in the final at the 5,900-yard Rome Country Club, becoming the youngest ever to win the championship.

title: U.S. RECOVERY AND SOCIAL CONCERN ARE NOT MUTUALLY EXCLUSIVE
description: To the Editor Deirdre Henderson's rejoinder (letter July 5) to your June 28 editorial ''Crude Triumph'' prompts a rejoinder in turn from one who was deeply involved in the first years of the ''social programs'' era, which started almost 20 years ago. Her letter reflects the unfortunate shrillness that has entered the necessary debate on how best to define the Federal role in social policy.

title: The Week in Business; ELF RAISES ITS BID FOR TEXASGULF
description: It was merger week all over for top oil companies. Aside from the Du Pont-Conoco deal, there was France's Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, raising a $2.5 billion bid for Texasgulf to $2.8 billion in cash, an offer that Texasgulf's directors said they would accept.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A NUCLEAR MOTE IN THE FEDERAL EYE
description: While the attention of most nuclear safety watchdogs has been focused on commercial facilities, the Government has been operating 13 large-scale nuclear reactors of its own, many of them, according to a study by an Energy Department panel, in less than optimal fashion.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: DELANEY AND THE PUBLIC'S RIGHT TO KNOW
description: since 1974 as elected Sheriff, since 1979 as Commissioner/Sheriff of the merged Department of Public Safety Services and even since February, when he was suspended by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello for misconduct and mismanagement.

title: GLASGOW CELTIC TEAM LOOMS AS A FORMIDABLE FOE
description: Glasgow Celtic, the class of Scottish soccer for a century, will meet the Cosmos at Giants Stadium tonight in the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup tournament, which has attracted much attention as a result of the withdrawal of a Soviet team.

title: Bass Fishing on Connecticut
description: three or four large dace - I began to wonder if we had made a poor decision.

title: U.N. PARLEY ON CAMBODIA WILL OPEN TOMORROW
description: Led by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., the United States meets here tomorrow with China and 73 other nations in an effort to force the removal of the Vietnameseinstalled regime in Cambodia.

title: Music View; HOW MOZART MIRRORS OUR TIME
description: What? Mostly Mozart? Can it be that time again? Haven't we had enough of Mozart and his poisonous friends for a while? To which there might be several answers, but this one will do for now: if one composer must monopolize our summers, let it be W.A. Mozart. No composer wears so well, which is clear but still a mystery. How could any composer survive as much institutionalized adoration and commercialization as we have heaped on poor Amadeus?

title: HOW TO ALLEVIATE A HEAP OF (GARBAGE) TROUBLES
description: WHILE on Prince Edward Island several years ago, I asked Jim, a back-to-the-land log cabin dweller, ''What do you do with your garbage?''

title: CRITICS CHOICES
description: DANCE Summer is the time to catch up on what the rest of the dance world is doing outside New York City, or at least that segment of it that didn't come east for the various regional festivals this past year. The Bella Lewitzky Dance Company, which will appear at the Pepsico Summerfare '81 festival on Friday, Saturday and next Sunday, is a West Coast-based modern dance troupe that grew out of the style of Lester Horton, so seldom seen in these parts today.

title: PICKINGS NOT SLIM ON JERSEY FARMS
description: IN VANS and chartered buses, in compacts and Cadillacs - even on bicycles and afoot - city residents and suburbanites are flocking to the state's pick-it-yourself farms. If business is as good as anticipated, they will keep on flocking until the last pumpkin beckons in October and the late broccoli is ready in November.

title: Food; STATE SHINES LIGHT ON L.I. BOUNTY
description: ''CATCH AMERICA'' is the name of a campaign designed to promote consumption of fish and seafood, and the Island is the focus of an attractive and useful booklet called ''The Gill-lectable Gourmet's Guide to Long Island Fish.''

title: Computer Draws Rail for $1 Million Pace
description: Computer, who probably would have been favored from any post position, drew the rail today and enhanced his chances of winning the $1 million Meadowlands Pace Friday night.

title: New York Times Magazine July 12, 1981
description: Jim Quinn 7 On Language Watchdogs of the Word Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer Mail-Order Tanks Steve Cady 12 The High-Stakes World of Horse Breeding Richard Eder 24 France Bets on the Left French voters have long been convinced that the only real alternative on the left is the Communist Party. But when Francois Mitterrand and his rejuvenated Socialist Party gave them another option, they elected to take the plunge. John Culhane 26 Jack Lemmon: Behind the Smile Willa Petschek 44 Fashion Rented Clothes Fit for a Royal Event Craig Claiborne 48 Food with Pierre Franey Shrimp, Plain and Fancy 55 Puzzles Answers, Page 40 62 Letters Cover: Photograph by Susan Copen Oken Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: CHARLOTTE WINOKUR TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Sylvia Winokur of New Haven of the engagement of her daughter, Charlotte S. Winokur, to Peter W. Silver, son of Betty S. Silver of North Tarrytown, N.Y., and the late Henry Fluegel Silver. An October wedding is planned. Miss Winokur, a daughter of the late Morris Winokur, is a physical therapist with the Easter Seals Rehabilitation Center of Eastern Fairfield Country in Connecticut and also a supervisor of acute care at Bridgeport Hospital. Mr. siver heads Pete Silver & Associates, an advertising and marketing communications company in Southport, Conn.

title: Miss Van Sickle, Teacher, Is Bride
description: At the Upper Ridgewood Community Church in Ridgewood, N.J., yesterday, Susan Jean Van Sickle, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. David Charles Van Sickle of Ridgewood and Mantoloking, N.J., was married to Thomas Harmon Castle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Castle of Darien, Conn. The bride's father, a minister of the Reformed Church of America, performed the ceremony.

title: Ilie Nastase; TANTRUM THROWERS THROUGH THE YEARS
description: IT has taken far more than one act of gross misbehavior to persuade this writer, as a member of what can be described as the international tennis fraternity, to publicly berate certain of his offending fellow members, and one in particular. The time has come.

title: WESTCHESTER JAIL INMATES RETURN TO CELLS
description: A violent protest at the Westchester County Jail was brought under control this morning after about 300 inmates, demanding what they called ''reforms,'' seized all nine of the main cell blocks and a floor of a nearby women's unit, knocking down walls and destroying interior fixtures.

title: The Week in Business; DUPONT AND CONOCO
description: In what would be the largest merger in corporate history, E.I. du Pont de Nemours offered $7.3 billion for Conoco, the nation's ninthlargest oil company.

title: Camera; WILL VIDEOTAP SYSTEMS REPLACE HOME MOVIES?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Janet Kealy is active in film and video production and teaches filmmaking at the School of Visual Arts.

title: Ault Gets Winning Hit
description: Doug Ault, formerly with the Toronto Blue Jays, doubled home the tiebreaking run in the eighth inning, giving the Hanshin Tigers a 5-3 victory over the Yomiuri Giants in the Japanese League today.

title: The Region in Summary; MAN-MADE FLOOD DRIES OUT NEWARK
description: It took months of conservation and some fortuitous rainfall to end the drought emergency in New Jersey in May, but it took only a few minutes for vandals to create a new water-supply crisis in Newark last week.

title: SIGNS ON THE WAY TO THE CROSSROAD
description: The perils of Poland produced another cliff-hanger last week as the Communist leadership prepared for the opening on Tuesday of a special party congress after 12 months of revolutionary reforms. First Secretary Stanislaw Kania had scarcely finished saying goodbye in Warsaw to the departing Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, when the Polish party came under heavy new pressure from militant trade unions.

title: Art; 2 SHOWS: SCULPTURES, LANDSCAPE PHOTOGRAPHS
description: TWO shows, located at opposite ends of the state, are under review. The first, at the Washington Art Association, in Washington Depot, consists of recent portrait sculptures and drawings by Philip Grausman. The second is a selection of landscape photographs by Paul Caponigro at Photo Graphics Workshop in New Canaan (212 Elm Street).

title: Pocket Zipper, $27.60, Wins American Derby
description: Pocket Zipper, a 12-1 shot, won the $140,000 American Derby at Arlington Park today in a three-horse photo-finish.

title: Janet Geerlings, Violinist, to Wed
description: Mrs. Clarence Johnson of Springfield, Ohio, and Henry J. Geerlings of Newport Beach, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Lynn Geerlings, to Alexander Macdonald Doman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nichols R. Doman of New York and Shelter Island, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Aug. 29 in Cincinnati.

title: CONRAIL ADDS LOGIC TO FARE INCREASE
description: WHEN the fares on the New Haven line of Conrail go up 25 percent early next month, commuters will have the small joy of knowing that, while the extra money will provide no immediate improvement in service, the new fares at least appear to have a certain logic.

title: Index; International
description: Two ancient Greek statues glory in the affection of Italy 3 Radical reformers fear views will not prevail at Polish congress 3 New Italian Government wins final approval 3 South Africans
