title: Miss Aleu Wed To Craig Morton
description: Rebecca Jean Aleu and Craig Scott Morton were married yesterday in the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: Caroline Boyce Bride of Charles Uhl Jr.
description: Caroline Elizabeth Boyce and Charles Harrison Uhl Jr., candiates for master's degrees in historic-preservation planning at the Cornell University School of Architecture, Art and Planning, were married yesterday in the Weekapaug (R.I.) Chapel. Bishop Robert B. Appleyard of the Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh performed the ceremony.

title: FACING A 40TH BIRTHDAY...
description: I'VE begun a chronological countdown that will end on July 21, my 40th birthday. It all seems to have passed so quickly, as if time played its sleight of hand on me by causing the years to disappear under a web of memories. In a life that is full of options, this passage of time has not been one.

title: Washington; SUMMITRY AND THE BOMB (2)
description: When the leaders of the major industrial nations meet in Ottawa on July 20-21, President Reagan will be asked some hard questions about United States policy on the export of nuclear knowledge and materials to other countries.

title: No Headline
description: We baby boomers had the toughest time getting into college. When we got in, many were denied financial aid because the available funding could not keep pace with the influx.

title: About Westchester
description: FROM the standpoint of visual appeal, the best time to visit Playland just might be early evening. Although the cream-colored Art Deco buildings are freshly painted now and look fine in the brightest glare, the park's old-fashioned mood is best accentuated when the afternoon sun starts heading toward the horizon and dusk puts a pinkish glow in the sky. Then, the lighted Dragon Coaster looks like a half-finished wooden skyscraper strung with jewels, and the handcarved carousel appears to have been snatched from the 19th century.

title: The Nation in Summary; STRIKING FOR A PRINCIPLE
description: Though San Jose, Calif., has a self-proclaimed feminist as mayor and a city council on which women are a majority, 2,000 city employees struck last week in a dispute over obtaining for women the same pay as men for comparable work.

title: PANEL MULLS PLAN TO CURB RACKETS
description: HARTFORD CONCERN that organized crime is making inroads in the state is leading officials here to consider a two-pronged counterattack involving revisions of the state laws and expansion of lawenforcement units.

title: Food; SHRIMP, PLAIN AND FANCY
description: If we were to be asked to single out one shellfish as our favorite, it would certainly be shrimp. Apparently, we are not alone in this preference, for we have been told by many fish experts that it is also the favorite of the nation.

title: 'I WRITE PLAYS TO CLAIM A PLACE FOR ASIAN-AMERICANS'
description: One warm May evening in 1979, a skinny Stanford University senior with a boyish grin sprinted across the campus and burst into the Stanford Computer Center in joyous search of his girlfriend, who was working there.

title: Kelly of Ireland Takes 17th Cycling Stage
description: LES-BAINS, France, July 11 (AP) - Sean Kelly of Ireland led a pack of 14 riders to a sprint finish today and won the 17th stage of the Tour de France cycling race.

title: A COMMUNITY EFFORT PAYS OFF
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS ''I JUST wanted a place to take ballet classes,'' said Judy Ellison, explaining why two-and-a-half years ago she joined a grassroots committee of concerned citizens to save an aging elementary school from demolition and developers.

title: Other Business; A NEW LIGHT FROM I.B.M. AT THE CHECKOUT
description: When International Business Machines late last year unveiled one of the first commercial products to use holography - a supermarket checkout scanner that reads those mysterious computerized bars on merchandise -its competitors gathered 'round.

title: Art; BUILDINGS, TOO, HAVE A FACE
description: JERSEY CITY MICHAEL FAUERBACH, whose paintings are on view at the Five Corners Library, has done for the faces of New York City buildings what Chuck Close has done for the faces of New York men.

title: PALMER IN 3-WAY SENIOR TIE
description: Arnold Palmer made one of the charges that was his trademark earlier in his career, shooting a two-under-par 68 today and sharing the third-round lead in the United States Senior Open at Oakland Hills.

title: PLAN TO MERGE F.B.I. AND DRUG AGENCY PRESSED
description: Justice Department officials have decided that the Federal Bureau of Investigation should join the battle against narcotics. Further, they are proposing to merge the Drug Enforcement Administration with the F.B.I., or at least to make the drug agency a ''semiautonomous subsidiary'' of the bureau.

title: Haig, in the Bahamas, Discusses Caribbean Aid
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and the Foreign Ministers of Mexico, Canada and Venezuela met today and agreed to act together in assisting the nations of the Caribbean and Central America.

title: TRASH PACT IS EXPECTED TO RESULT IN RATE RISE
description: NEWARK THE thousands of tons of garbage that accumulated in streets, basements and alleys during the recent seven-day strike by trash collectors were slowly but surely being whittled away this weekend. The 1,400 drivers and loaders who began a walkout against private garbage haulers in 108 northern and central New Jersey communities on July 1 were working overtime to clean up the mess.

title: Meeting Is Rescheduled For Rail Commuters
description: The public meeting of the Yonkers Rail Commuters Council, which was mentioned in the article ''For Rail Commuters, Time to Speak'' (June 28), has had to be rescheduled to accommodate the speakers.

title: Petra Kummer, Model, Wed to Kim Townsend
description: Petra Regine Charlotte Kummer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Kummer of Ludwigshafen, West Germany, was married yesterday in Old Brookville, L.I., to Kim Townsend, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Townsend of Floral Park, L.I. . The Rev. Malcolm Moore, a Congregational minister of Huntington, L.I., performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. Frank A. Calderone, a family friend.

title: INDICTMENT OF FINANCIER CHARGING A PLOT TO MURDER HIS WIFE HAS NEWPORT
description: AGOG By ENID NEMY

title: WOMAN'S WANTS
description: THE CINDERELLA COMPLEX Women's Hidden Fear of Independence. By Colette Dowling. 266 pp. New York: Summit Books. $12.95.

title: September Bridal For Sarah Bryan
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Robert A. Bryan of Ipswich, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Landfield Bryan, to Malcolm Bruce Severance, son of Malcolm Douglas Severance of Rumson, N.J., and the late Marie Appleby Severance.

title: Art; 'CARDS' CAPTURE LIFE'S COMPLEXITY
description: SOCIAL criticism and satire, once important partners in the graphic arts, are not exactly in the mainstream these days. Until recently, however, generations of artists, nurtured on Hogarth, Goya and Daumier, dipped their pens in acid to produce the biting commentaries that reached a high point in the years between the two world wars.

title: HECKSCHER MUSEUM GROWS IN CONCEPT
description: ORIGINALLY built in 1920 to house the private collection of August Heckscher, the Heckscher Museum in Huntington never was the exclusive province of the cultured elite. As part of a construction project that included the creation of Heckscher Park out of existing marshes and swamps, the museum and its activities have always been influenced by community concerns and, to some degree, municipal support.

title: CLOSING THE BOOKS ON GENTLER TIMES
description: year-old proprietor of a large bookstore here, is going out of business with considerable panache, but Mr. Keene would be the last to say he is going out gracefully.

title: Arraignment of Soldier Is Delayed by Airlines
description: Army Pvt. Joseph G. Christopher will not be arraigned in New York City as planned tomorrow on murder and assault charges because commercial airlines have refused to transport him from Buffalo for fear of bombs or other attacks on their aircraft, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Miss Smith, Mark Ponski To Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, and Mrs. Smith of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., of the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Anne Smith, to Mark B. Ponski of Troy, Mich. He is the son of Marian Ponski of Detroit and Mrs. Stanley Jakubowski of Niles, Ill.

title: Robin Ellsworth Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Sabin Ellsworth of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Robin Ann Ellsworth, to Stephen H. Merry, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harold Merry of Dumont, N.J. An Oct. 31 wedding is planned. The future bride is a bond supervisor for Aetna Casualty & Surety Company in Trumbull, Conn. Her fiance is an advertising manager for the Nestle Company in White Plains.

title: MIDWIFERY IS DISPUTED
description: Carol Warnock, a midwife, smoothes her daughter's hair and gazes out at the mountains beyond her remote farmhouse. Three weeks after her acquittal on a charge of practicing medicine without a license, she is pensive.

title: SPEAKER O'NEILL 'OBSTRUCTIONIST,' REPRESENTATIVE FROM L.I. ASSERTS
description: Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill of the House of Representatives borders on socialism and ''personifies everything about politics that the public hates today,'' Representative John LeBoutillier of Long Island told a convention of young Republicans here today.

title: Business Conditions; WORLD RICE SHORTFALL
description: Major crop losses in key countries like Japan and South Korea caused world production of rice - the grain that feeds half the world - to drop slightly last year. According to the Department of Agriculture, 377 million tons of rough rice were harvested, a drop of 2 percent from 1979.

title: Dance View; 'SOLD OUT' PERFORMANCES THAT NEVER ACTUALLY TOOK PLACE
description: Probably the oddest dance event in many months was one that never happened. Nor was it supposed to have happened. Indeed, not happening was the point of it. But let's begin at the beginning.

title: GUESS WHO'LL SUBSIDIZE THE PRESIDENTIAL YACHT
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET UNION TOPS U.S. TRACK TEAM
description: Bolstered by a strong showing in the women's events, the Soviet Union rolled to victory over the United States today in their dual track and field meet. Theoverall total score for men's and women's events was 204 points to 178.

title: DON'T THROW OUT THE BABY WITH MEDICAID-MEDICARE BATHWATER
description: In 1964, two years before Federal Medicare and Medicaid programs began to pay health care bills of the poor and the aged, Americans visited physicians 3.8 times a year on the average, but the figure for the poor was 4.7. By 1978, visits to doctors among the poor had climbed to an average 6.2 times a year, compared to five times annually for other Americans.

title: The Meaning Of Malpractice Verdicts
description: In a letter to the editor (Opinion Page, June 21), Dr. Mark I. Pittman misinformed the public regarding the meaning of 75 percent of the verdicts favoring doctors in malpractice cases in this area. He inferred that this meant that the lawsuits never had any basis.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 10 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 2 14 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 3 3 5 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 4 5 12 GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam's, $12.95.) Leto continues as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet Dune. 5 4 12 FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon. 6 10 3 THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.) Two veteran homicide detectives trapped by the seductive vices of Hollywood. 7 11 9 XPD, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $12.95.) The British and the Russians race to get proof that Churchill once did business with Hitler.

title: BLUEGRASS: RICKY SKAGGS
description: Anyone familiar with Emmylou Harris's recordings has felt the influence of Ricky Skaggs, a Kentucky-born bluegrass specialist who helped Miss Harris in her explorations of that genre. Now Mr. Skaggs, who was also a member of the Country Gentlemen, a leading progressive bluegrass ensemble, is out on his own.

title: SERIALISM SINCE SCHOENBERG'S DEATH
description: Thirty years ago tomorrow, Arnold Schoenberg died in Los Angeles. Thirty is not so epochal a number as 50 or 100, and that may be reason enough to explain why the anniversary is not being widely observed.

title: Miss Corning Has Nuptials In Greenwich
description: Valerie Alden Corning, daughter of Mrs. Victor A. Colage of Palm Beach, Fla., and Nathan E. Corning of Manchester, Mass., was married in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday to Edson W. Spencer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer of Long Lake, Minn. The Rev. James L. Kellaway performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Reading and Writing; AGING AGITATOR
description: Garry Trudeau, the creator of the ''Doonesbury'' comic strip that exposes some of the social foibles and political follies of our time, was encountered the other afternoon breaking open a fortune cookie. It arrived with a pot of tea; never mind where. Mr. Trudeau, who treasures his privacy, found a touch of wisdom in the serendipitous message: ''Keep your plans secret for now.''

title: HARMON COVE PROGRESS SLOWED BY THE ECONOMY
description: A decade ago, the dominant view in the Meadowlands was of unbroken fields of marsh reeds and open land tattered with trash. That vista was changed in the mid-1970's by construction of Giants Stadium and the Meadowlands Racetrack. The July 2 opening of the $85 million Byrne Arena, all white and angular and $35 million above cost projections, completed the sports complex and added a new dimension to the Meadowlands skyline. But the most dominant element, visible from miles around, is Harmon Cove Towers.

title: Realty News; CHURCH STREET
description: Mitchell, Schreiber, Watts & Company, a stock brokerage organization, has leased the second through the fourth floors at 110 Church street with a total of 36,000 square feet of office space for 5 years.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL OFFICIAL FEAR FOR RARE MICHIGAN SONGBIRD
description: The population of the nearly extinct Kirtland's warbler has slipped a little since last year, but Federal and state officials are more concerned about the next few years, when the bird's habitat will be temporarily reduced.

title: Antiques; JAPANESE TEXTILES- TWO EXHIBITIONS OF A PROVOCATIVE CRAFT
description: For centuries Japanese weavers have been responsible for some of the most sophisticated, graphically arresting and exquisite textiles ever produced. The costumes, gowns, obis, coats, jackets, vests, pantaloons, kimonos and bedcoverings they have crafted are memorable for their provocative textures, glowing colors and arresting surface embellishments, unmatched in most other cultures.

title: Battling Gypsy Moths
description: Roger Swain's article on the gypsy moth was as witty as it was informative - especially his ''good news'' that my flowering dogwood and 150-year-old black walnuts are safe (''Learning to Live With Gypsy Moths,'' June 14). Unfortunately, the ignorant creatures infesting Suffolk County did not seem impressed as I read the article to them under my barren trees; they simply continued to munch the leaves of my equally ''safe'' locust trees. CHARLES GUZZETTA, Mount Sinai, N.Y.

title: Cubs, White Sox to Play For Charity After Strike
description: Mayor Jane Byrne's proposed exhibition game for charity between the Cubs and the White Sox has received approval from baseball's leaue presidents, but only after resolution of the current strike.

title: LAWRENCE: A WALL STREET BOUTIQUE THAT LIVED Salvigsen
description: J IM MOLTZ'S office is sparse, making an almost humble statement for the chairman of a Wall Street brokerage firm. No gilt-framed portaits of the founder, no Orientals on the floor and no white-gloved waiters on call. He does have an impressive view through his windows - the towering black monolith of One Liberty Plaza, home of the giant Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: Bills to Assist Transit Are Signed by Carey
description: Governor Carey yesterday signed into law the package of bills intended to produce $793 million in new revenues for public transit, particularly the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Business Forum; WHEN SHAREHOLDERS BECOME THE VICTIMS
description: S EVERAL times a month business publications report a familiar ritual. Bidder announces a tender offer for the shares of Target, offering 150 percent or more than the current market price. The management of Target promptly announces that the price is inadequate, that Bidder does not appreciate the time-honored ways in which Target does business, that the market does not appreciate how soon Target's profits will skyrocket if management is just left to do its job. Bidder, the management says, would spoil all this, and shareholders who take the offer are foolish.

title: New Jersey Guide; IT'S ELMER FOR PETER
description: Peter Yarrow, the tenor of Peter, Paul and Mary, the celebrated 1960's folk-pop group, and later a record producer and solo performer, is giving a concert next Sunday in the Salem County community of Elmer.

title: THE HIGH-STAKES WORLD OF HORSE BREEDING
description: MAGAZINE Steve Cady covered horse racing as a sports writer for The New York Times for 15 years. By Steve Cady is value as a syndicated sire could be $20 million or more. She could be worth $3 million on the brood-mare market. And the fruit of their brief liaison, arranged by a computer in an office building in Lexington, Ky., might bring close to $2 million as an untried yearling at a blue-chip auction like those taking place July 20 and 21 at nearby Keeneland and at Saratoga in upstate New York two weeks later.

title: COMPUTER GRID WEIGHED FOR HARBOR
description: HUNTINGTON IN an effort to ease a boating-traffic problem in Huntington Harbor, the Town of Huntington is considering implementing a computer grid to allow it to exercise greater control.

title: Adrienne J. Reilly Is Wed to Lawyer
description: The marriage of Adrienne Jean Reilly, who is with the personal trust department at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, to Robert Andrew Nelson, an associate with the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel, took place at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony.

title: On Language; WATCHDOGS OF THE WORD
description: Samuel Johnson, the first great dictionary maker of our language, opposed the establishment of an English version of the French Academy, enpowered to accept or reject new words. ''The edicts of an academy,'' he wrote, ''would probably be read by many, only that they might be sure to disobey them.'' But an English Academy would have one value not foreseen by Johnson - it would at least be able to suppress false edicts masque@r-ading as rules. And we would be spared some of these recent examples of pop grammar.

title: ARGENTINA AND SOVIET ARE NO LONGER JUST BUSINESS PARTNERS
description: The Soviet Union is competing hard with the Reagan Administration to improve relations with Argentina, and it may be having better luck.

title: ONLY ULTRAS FIGHT MRS. O'CONNOR FOR THE HIGH COURT
description: ''Honored and happy,'' Sandra Day O'Connor was also silent and circumspect on questions of her judicial philosophy last week after President Reagan nominated her as an associate justice of the United States Supreme Court. The 51-year-old Arizona state judge would be the first woman on the Court.

title: COMPLIANCE VARIES ON 'SUNSHINE' LAW
description: NORTH HEMPSTEAD THE business of making public policy should be carried out in public, according to the State Open Meetings Law, more commonly known as the Sunshine Law. In several towns, however, minority-party board members say they are consistently kept in the dark on important issues.

title: POLAND'S COMMUNISTS PREPARE TO MEET, SOBERED BY 'REALISM'
description: For months, the extraordinary congress of the Polish United Workers' (Communist) Party that opens Tuesday had been billed as the pivotal event in Poland's struggle for a more open, democratic, perhaps even popular, system of rule. The propulsion for change, unleashed by workers' strikes a year ago, had affected the party, it was said, so that a grass-roots movement for reform would sweep away the old leadership and perhaps even install a new form of Polish Communism. At the least, the congress would somehow resolve the play of forces and personalities contending for power, overcoming paralyzing divisions and reinvigorating the party for its proper leadership role - a protective umbrella to allow society to evolve in a more liberal direction, without overt interference from Soviet bloc neighbors.

title: Architecture View; PEI'S ELEGANT ADDITION TO BOSTON'S ARTS MUSEUM
description: BOSTON What do you do after you've designed the East Wing of the National Gallery in Washington? If you are the architect I.M. Pei, you design the West Wing of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, adding one more museum to the distinguished list completed by the firm in recent years. Boston's West Wing will open to the public on July 22, after a week of ceremonies, festivities and previews that start next Thursday. The $22-million, three-story wing provides 80,000 square feet of dramatic new space and is the product of a crash, three-year construction program. It is part of a five-year master plan being carried out under the guidance of the museum's director, Jan Fontein, and associate director, Ross W. Farrar, that is rearranging collections, renovating facilities and providing new galleries and public spaces for the 111-year-old arts institution.

title: NEW VIOLENCE HITS 10 ENGLISH CITIES BUT IS LESS SERIOUS
description: Scattered violence erupted again yesterday in London and nine other cities after the worst night of riots and looting since the turmoil in England began nine days ago.

title: VOTES BY WOMEN IN G.O.P. ATTACKED
description: Leading officials of the Democratic Party today challenged the National Women's Political Caucus, one of the country's two largest feminist political groups, to stop supporting Republican women in Congress who vote for the Reagan Administration's budget cuts.

title: WHO KNOWS WHY LAKE IS DRYING UP?
description: or what can be done about it.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: RUTGERS OFFERING A PIRANDELLO 'FIRST'
description: waving Beatrice knows that her husband is cavorting with the wife of his bank clerk, Ciampa. The lovers are caught in their lair and are punished, right?

title: The World in Summary; MITTERRAND MEANS WHAT HE SAID
description: Those French who voted for Francois Mitterrand mainly to defeat Valery Giscard d'Estaing found out last week that they had elected not just the man, but his platform.

title: Karen M. Jones, an Editor, Bride of Jeffrey Weinsten
description: Karen Midkiff Jones and Jeffrey Joseph Weinsten were married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Robert A. Nunn performed the ceremony.

title: Connecticut Housing; MOVES TO AID MOBILE HOME PARKS
description: WHEN Richard and Pat Loso decided to ''trade up'' two years ago, they took along a cherished blue spruce tree from the front yard of their old house to plant in the front of the new one. They also put in azaleas and rhododendrons and set aside a small area near their 200-square-foot patio for a vegetable garden.

title: DENVER POST BASES ITS HOPES ON 2 EXECUTIVES FROM DALLAS
description: Denver has borrowed extensively from Dallas, from energy resource development to coaching skills for the Broncos football team. In June, a publisher and an editor were imported from Texas to guide The Denver Post in the next phase of its losing arm-wrestle with The Rocky Mountain News.

title: POWER IS CUT OFF TO PORTION OF S.I.
description: A blackout, caused by an explosion in a power substation of Consolidated Edison, darkened the eastern half of Staten Island for more than five hours last night, knocking out power to 40,000 customers, the police and Con Edison said.

title: DRUG-INJECTION PUMP USED FOR LIVER CANCER
description: Medical researchers have announced the development of an innovative drug-injection system that employs a surgically implanted pump to keep victims of liver cancer alive longer and to ease the often agonizing side effects of chemotherapy.

title: Dining Out; A NORTH-SOUTH ITALIAN BALANCE
description: PERHAPS because its kitchen uses garlic with a restrained hand, La Riserva in Larchmont bills itself as a restaurant offering northern Italian cuisine. Somehow the cooking of Italy's northern regions has become fashionable and that of the south looked upon with relative contempt - refined, light prepartions associated with the north and heavy, oily, spicy dishes with the south, assumptions that have some basis but many exceptions. Despite La Riserva's claim to allegiance to the north, however, it offers a healthy representation of many of Italy's regions, and diners can enjoy a smooth, subtle tortellini with cream as well as bold peppery tomato sauce ''pizzaiola.''

title: OLD LYME HOT-DOG VENDOR TAKES A STAND
description: OLD LYME WHEN Howard E. McKee of Old Lyme began his summer job, he figured he could count as customers all the people he had met in his 15 years as a physical education teacher and coach.

title: Politics; GOVERNOR'S USE OF THE VETO HAS POLITICAL CONSEQUENCES
description: HARTFORD IN the early months of his administration, Governor O'Neill was cautious in his dealings with the General Assembly, expressing few preferences on legislation and avoiding, wherever possible, taking controversial stands.

title: CABARET: DUO PIANISTS
description: A summerlong program of piano duets at Michael's Pub began last week with Dick Hyman and Roger Kellaway playing on the Pub's resident Steinway and an August Fortner piano brought across town from Downey's, the Eighth Avenue restaurant owned by Gil Wiest, who also owns Michael's Pub.

title: A GULAG STORY
description: WITHIN THE WHIRLWIND By Eugenia Ginzburg. Translated by Ian Boland. Introduction by Heinrich Boll. 423 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.50.

title: The World in Summary; WHO'S IN CHARGE OF FOREIGN POLICY?  WELL...
description: On economic policy, the Reagan Administration has developed a reputation as a smooth-functioning team with a clear strategy, well-established priorities and steady direction from the White House. But that same crisp, purposeful teamwork has been lacking on foreign policy. The top players have occasionally seemed at odds, bickering over turf or credit, their timing off or their public comments out of step.

title: Emily M. Snoddy Wed To Mark Allan Baker
description: Emily Marguerite Snoddy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Martin Snoddy Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to Mark Allan Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Fulton Baker of Chicago. The Rev. William Strain performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's decision last month to help finance the modernization of Pakistan's armed forces has raised troubling questions among military leaders and civilian analysts in Washington and other NATO capitals. There are two basic issues: One is whether arms aid on the scale projected by the agreement can enable Pakistan to build a defense against the ''serious threat'' that the Administration sees as a result of the Soviet military intervention in neighboring Afghanistan.

title: Business Conditions; GASOLINE TAXES RISING
description: Although recent declines in retail gasoline prices have been welcomed by consumers, a spate of tax increases in states across the country may have erased the benefits. And the trend could spread.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; PUTTING BOTANY AT THE SERVICE OF HUMAN PROBLEMS
description: The New York Botanical Garden has long been known as a research center for plant sciences as well as 258 public acres of nature made more perfect and less raw. Last week, the institution approved a plan to bring its expertise to bear in the world at large, establishing three new institutes to cope with social and ecological problems.

title: A NEW MOOD EXPECTED AT PARIS-BONN TALKS
description: For the moment at least, the old magic is gone. President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany are meeting in Bonn tomorrow and Monday, but the close relationship that existed between Mr. Schmidt and Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the former French President, is a thing of the past.

title: THE POLLING OF AMERICA
description: NEW RULES Searching for Self-Fulfillment in a World Turned Upside Down. By Daniel Yankelovich. 278 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: R.E. Carter Weds Mary McL. Mead
description: Mary McLain Mead was married in Newport, R.I., yesterday to Rudulph Ellis Carter, a former Foreign Service officer. The Rev. Frederick Baldwin performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of Mr. Carter's aunt, Elizabeth Brooke Blake.

title: Officer Cleared by Grand Jury In L.I. Youth's Fatal Shooting
description: A Suffolk County grand jury has cleared a New York City police officer of any wrongdoing in the fatal shooting of a Ronkonkoma teen-ager on June 22.

title: CITY'S ZONING: A TOUGH GAME THAT FEW CAN PLAY
description: It was positively ingenious. The developers would avoid certain zoning stringencies by presenting their roject not as one mixed-use high-rise, but as two separate buildings - a residential cooperative and a hotel - one on top of the other. To a pedestrian it would appear to be one building. But for the purposes of the city's zoning laws it would be two buildings. It sounded fine to the Buildings Department, which issued the necessary construction permit.

title: Elizabeth Wilson Wed To Ens. Barry Sullivan
description: Elizabeth Julia Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Barry Wilson of Baldwin, L.I., was married there yesterday to Ens. Barry Joseph Sullivan, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Sullivan of Glenview, Ill.

title: LOU JACOBS JR.
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lou Jacobs Jr. is a frequent contributor to this column. An autowinder is a small version of a motor-drive, a rather heavy apparatus which can wind the film and cock the shutter at four or more frames per second. However, a full-fledged camera motor is expensive ($350 and up) and really only necessary for professionals who must shoot fast action and have complete sequences.

title: Music; A NEW SUMMER FESTIVAL PLANS CONCERTS AT TWILIGHT
description: NEW YORK CITY may be the Big Apple, but Scarsdale has the Apple Tree Barn Gardens, site of Westchester's newest summer series. Officially dubbed the Twilight Music Festival, because the concerts will start at 5 P.M., the performances begin a week from today and continue on three more Sundays through Aug. 23.

title: CITY LOSING MILLIONS IN TAXES
description: New York City is losing at least $200 million a year in uncollected taxes owed by businesses big and small, according to city officials. Some of the tax money, they say, will never be collected because it is hidden in unreported cash transactions that are difficult, if not impossible, to monitor. But other revenues, the officials acknowledge, have been lost because of bad management, inefficiency and the lack of auditors.

title: Sunday Observer; Mail-Order Tanks; Patrick McDonnell
description: I knew, of course, that the Reagan Administration had gone into the business of merchandising weapons in a big way. Still it was surprising to be awakened to a tank outside my apartment.

title: Waltrip Triumphs In Nashville Race
description: Darrell Waltrip held off Bobby Allison's late charge to win a nearly race-long duel between them tonight in the Nashville Busch 420 Grand National stock car race.

title: ANDERSON DEFENDERS GAIN FINAL
description: John Birmingham and Frank Fuhrer, the defending champions from Pittsburgh's Oakmont Club, survived a late challenge by George Marucci and Henri deLozier today and reached the final of the 45th Anderson Memorial golf championship.

title: CHINA SAYS THE VIETAMESE MUST BE DRIVEN OUT OF CAMBODIA
description: China said today that Vietnam's refusal to attend next week's United Nations conference on Cambodia supported Peking's view that Hanoi's 200,000 troops in Cambodia must be driven out by force.

title: Business Conditions; EUROPE'S JOBLESS WOES
description: Recession and continued high rates of interest in major industrialized countries are putting larger numbers of people out of work worldwide.

title: PETE ROSE'S RACE AGAINST TIME
description: IN the 41st year of his life and the 19th year of his career in baseball, Pete Rose paused the other day to consider the box score on the baseball strike.

title: MOVIES ON CABLE
description: There is an ever-growing number of subscription cable services offering uncut, uninterrupted feature films for at-home viewing. And their programming overlaps considerably, at least when it comes to big-hit films. Nevertheless, here is a guide to some of the ways in which these services vary:

title: The Region in Summary; CONNECTIUT TRIES ENTERPRISE ZONES
description: Like many states, Connecticut has concluded that urban renewal is, as one state official put it, a ''monumental flop.'' Last week, though, Connecticut became the first state to embrace President Reagan's alternative, the ''urban enterprise'' zone.

title: ONE CALL COULD STOP THE NUCLEAR ARMS RACE
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALY'S NEW CABINET APPROVED
description: Italy's latest Government crisis formally ended today when Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini won a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies.

title: Connecticut Guide; YACHT CLUB OPEN HOUSE
description: Reportedly the second oldest yacht club in America (New York Yacht lub is the oldest), the New Haven Yacht Club was chartered in 1882 and enjoyed an elegant reputation as host to such notables as the Shah of Iran, Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford before World War II brought about its demise. In 1967, the charter was reactivated and the club reorganized in a house at 144 Cove Street.

title: JACK LEMMON: BEHIND THE SMILE
description: John Culhane, a writer and film historian, is the author of a book on movie special effects to be published by Ballantine this fall. By John Culhane ack Lemmon, in his temporary dressing room in a gas station in Agoura, Calif., demonstrated how he would deliver his first speech to Walter Matthau in the film ''Buddy Buddy'' - if he could get away with it.

title: A Reader Writes; ON BOYS AND BASEBALL CARDS, AND BUSINESS
description: M Y eight-year-old son began collecting baseball cards this season, and it is none too soon. The activity not only provides him with a link to the sport during the players' strike, but is an initiation into the world of American business. For the lessons a boy learns from managing a shoebox full of baseball cards are as hard and sobering as any gotten over the bargaining table in a complex labor dispute.

title: SAILORS READY BOATS FOR RACE WEEK
description: LARCHMONT THIS is the time of year when skippers, ranging from juniors of grammar school age to seniors, who in some instances are grandparents, prepare for the competition-packed Larchmont Race Week.

title: Cheryl Corso, Bank Aide, Bride of W. Michael Bliss
description: Cheryl Ann Corso, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Corso of Hamden, Conn., and W. Michael Bliss, son of Dr. and Mrs. William R. Bliss of Ames, Iowa, were married yesterday in Purchase N.Y. The Rev. John Muscat, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Manhattanville College Chapel.

title: REVIEWS OF MAJOR CABLE SERVICES AVAILABLE IN THE TRISTATE AREA
description: The cable TV web covers many dozens of companies competing for local franchises across the country. The proffered services vary widely. The metropolitan New York area alone is encompassed by about a dozen different cable operators. Manhattan, the only New York City borough to be wired so far, is divided between Teleprompter and Manhattan Cable (I happen to be in the Manhattan Cable zone both at work and at home). And their current schedules reflect, give or take a couple of specialized categories, the types of programs that are likely to be offered to the average cable subscriber at this point in the highly competitive game. Pay Television

title: Topics; PROMISES; Promises
description: New York City officials say they will find $3 million to keep 5,000 young people in job training programs through September. About half would have been cut because the city had overspent its training funds, the other half because Washington does not know how to keep a promise.

title: HOLBERT TRIUMPHS IN CAN-AM AT GLEN
description: The veteran driver Al Holbert sped to victory in a Can-Am race at the Watkins Glen racing course today after two front-runners retired with engine problems and another leader fell back because of a broken wheel.

title: KLANS' RALLY ROUTED BY BARRAGE OF ROCKS ON STREET IN MERIDAN
description: A Ku Klux Klan rally was broken up shortly after it began today when a screaming crowd of counterdemonstrators pelted the white-robed Klansmen with rocks and bottles. Two persons received minor injuries and four others were arrested.

title: Topics; POET'S CORNER
description: We may not have a Westminster Abbey in this country, but thanks to the Postal Service, we have a Poet's Corner.

title: Pier Fire Still Smoldering
description: A fire that began Wednesday still smoldered on an abandoned Hudson River pier yesterday.

title: COLONEL MCCORMICK TO THE RESCUE
description: MINNESOTA RAG The Dramatic Story of the Landmark Supreme Court Case That Gave New Meaning to Freedom of the Press. By Fred W. Friendly. Illustrated. 243 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95. By NEAL JOHNSTON

title: The Careful Shopper; Greater Than Usual Markdowns on Tano
description: The 30,000 mailing-list customers of Tano Inc. have been informed of its semiannual sale, with increases in the usual markdowns of 20 to 40 percent on its own shoes, handbags, attache cases and luggage, and drastic markdowns on seasonal wares from other major manufacturers. Larchmont's outlet, opened early last month, is the newest in Westchester, with others in Hartsdale, Mount Kisco, Yonkers, The Galleria in White Plains and Peekskill. A Tano shop at Mohegan Lake is planned for late summer, the 14th shop.

title: WHERE THE BUFFALO ROAM AND THE ANTELOPE PLAY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JEFFREY MARSHALL is the editor of a weekly newspaper in New Jersey. By JEFFREY MARSHALL

title: Prospects
description: The Economy Becalmed

title: McEnroe's Demeanor
description: To the Sports Editor: Little respect is due John McEnroe Sr., an attorney, for his failure to instill in his tennis-playing son the demeanor that most great athletes, however competitive they may be, usually demonstrate even under the most trying of conditions.

title: San Francisco Arrests Suspect in Major Fire
description: A suspect in one of the city's largest fires since the great fire of 1906 was in custody today as investigators searched for bodies in the ruins of 27 buildings.

title: Mary K. Dabney Will Be Married
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Taylor Dabney 3d of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Kinsman Dabney, to James Clinton Wright, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Harvey Wright of LaSalle, Ill. An Aug. 29 wedding is planned at the Forest Hill Presbyterian Church in Richmond.

title: Mary Griggs Is Bride Of Harold LaBonte 3d
description: Mary Louise Johnson Griggs was married yesterday to Harold Roland LaBonte 3d. The Rev. Robert M. Wainwright, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in St. Andrews by the Sea, a summer chapel in Hyannis Port, Mass.

title: A PILGRIMAGE TO A MYSTIC'S HERMITAGE IN ALGERIA
description: If you have trouble pronouncing Tamanrasset, the most southerly Saharan oasis in Algeria, do not worry. It is easier than you think. When I asked for a flight to Tamanrasset at the Algerian Airlines office in Algiers, the clerk hesitated a moment and then replied with a forgiving smile, ''Ah, vous voulez descendre sur Tam, M'sieur ...?'' In Algeria everyone settles for Tam.

title: GREEN HERON; Butorides striatus
description: Size: 18 to 22 inches. Color: Blackish green crown; purplish neck and breast.

title: Miss Herrick Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Foster Herrick of Southampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Grant Herrick, to Eric R.A. Woodward, son of Eudoxia Muller Woodward of Belmont, Mass., and the late Robert Burns Woodward.

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE process of hiring two additional inspectors for Indian Point is under way, but not even the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which has posted the openings, can say for sure when they will be filled.

title: The World in Summary; ULSTER MEDIATION ALMOST SUCCEEDS
description: For a time last week, it appeared that outside mediation efforts might end the four-month hunger strike at Maze prison near Belfast. But despite reported signs of give by Irish Republican Army prisoners, Margaret Thatcher's ministers hung tough.

title: CIVIC GROUP TO PURSUE MAILBOX ISSUE
description: WHEN, one warm summer day in 1976, Fridtjof Schroder of Greenburgh read a letter sent to him by the White Plains postmaster, little did he realize that the reply would be provided five years later by the United States Supreme Court.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THE Economic Data Corporation of New Brunswick had a terrificsounding investment scheme that promised the sky in a nationwide direct-mail marketing campaign. The idea gained considerable attention; however, for the corporation itself, such attention was not always flattering.

title: WITH LTV A MEMORY, HE'S TAKING HIS ACT TO THE OIL PATCH
description: DALLAS J AMES J. LING, corporate gunslinger, sits high in his leather boardroom chair, decked out like an urban cowboy in jeans, a denim shirt, cowboy boots, a tooled leather belt inscribed ''J.J. Ling'' and a huge silver belt buckle emblazoned ''The State of Texas.''

title: Practical Traveler; BUYING AND USING A CAR N EUROPE
description: If you buy a Peugeot 505 diesel sedan with minimal options from Peugeot Wolf, the French manufacturer's authorized dealer in Manhattan, the price, including New York City sales tax, will be about $13,150 - subject, perhaps, to a little downward negotiation with the salesman. If you buy that same car in Paris, however, use it for a month of sightseeing, drop it off at the port of Antwerp, Belgium, and have it shipped home, the total cost of the car, including taxes, insurance, shipping and customs duty (about 3 percent of the purchase price), will be about $11,250.

title: Long Islanders; DRAWING A LINE ON A LIFE'S WORK
description: FROM the time he was 3 years old, growing up in the Corn Belt in northwest Missouri, George Booth knew he wanted to be a cartoonist. By a relatively early age, he had achieved that ambition. His cartoons appeared in Leatherneck, the Marine Corps magazine, during his two hitches in the service, from 1944 to 1948 and 1950 to 1952, and he later sold cartoons to The Saturday Evening Post, Collier's, Playboy, Look, Saga, Park East - ''almost every magazine in town.''

title: Film View; WHY 'S.O.B.' DESERVES TO BE S.R.O.
description: Because of the high cost of filmmaking in this country and because of the need to reach the largest possible audience, worldwide, Hollywood has never been particularly receptive to personal cinema. It cannot afford filmmakers who pursue the same obsessions from film to film and who sometimes indulge in the kind of autobiographical explorations we expect in European filmmakers on the order of Ingmar Bergman, Francois Truffaut and Federico Fellini. Though no artist of any merit can function very long without maintaining connections to his own experiences, real or imaginary, the best of the successful Hollywood filmmakers -people like Chaplin, Lubitsch, Ford and Hitchcock - have usually managed to disguise these connections to fit the tastes of the mass market.

title: U.S. Takes Doubles, Leads by 2-1 in Cup
description: In a match crucial to United States chances of advancing in the Davis Cup, Stan Smith and Bob Lutz scored a 9-7, 6-3, 6-2 doubles victory over Ivan Lendl and Tomas Smid of Czechoslavakia yesterday.

title: Kush's Team Wins
description: Tom Clements threw three touchdown passes, including tosses of 44 and 15 yards to Keith Baker, to lead the Hamilton Tiger-Cats to a 47-10 victory over the Ottawa Rough Riders tonight in their Canadian Football League home opener. The victory gave the Tiger-Cats a 2-0 record under their new head coach, Frank Kush.

title: Leisure; ON WATERING: HOW MUCH DOES THE LAWN NEED?
description: When water use is restricted, lawns cannot be watered. Fortunately, grass species usually planted for lawns in the Northeast - Kentucky bluegrass and fine fescues - are drought tolerant. They can survive even prolonged periods without rainfall by becoming dormant. Crowns at bases of grass stems remain alive and when rains return, they produce new top growth.

title: Numismatics; U.S. TREASURY RESUMES SALE OF GOLD MEDALLIONS
description: Two new gold medals will go on sale Wednesday in the United States Treasury's American Arts Gold Medallion program - in spite of the fact that nearly a million examples of last year's two medals still haven't been sold by the government.

title: Topics; Coming Home
description: There is a phenomenon familiar to everyone who has ever participated in a high school election: a candidate who has been in some way deprived is a shoo-in. The winning votes are cast both out of sympathy for that unlucky person and guilt over the relief that the misfortune is someone else's.

title: Antiques Flagg, 1909, J.C. Leyendecker; CEREAL MAKER HAD A TASTE FOR ART, TOO
description: EAST HANOVER WHEN the National Biscuit Company bought the concern that made Cream of Wheat, a popular hot cereal since the turn of the century, it probably did not realize all that it was getting.

title: Cuba Says It Foiled Plot To Assassinate Castro
description: Cuba said today that it had thwarted a plot to assassinate President Fidel Castro and seized five Cuban exiles who it said had been trained for the mission in Florida.

title: Sound; CBS IMPROVES THE STANDARD LP DISK
description: The dust hasn't yet begun to settle from the impact of digital recording on the phonographic world, but a fallout of new ideas and developments is already raining down on us. As reported in this column on June 28, Philips and Sony promise all-digital playback by 1983, proposing to replace the conventional LP record with a tiny, laser-scanned disk. And now comes news from CBS of a scheme to bolster the performance of the conventional LP so that it may hold its own - at least for a decade or so -against the laserized challenger. The coexistence - peaceful or otherwise -between the projected Philips/Sony all-digital format and the conventional LP disk thus seems a likely prospect for years ahead.

title: HEARINGS TO BEGIN ON HUGHES ESTATE
description: Judge Pat Gregory, whose Probate Court declared Howard Hughes a Texan for estate purposes two years ago, will hear proceedings beginning Monday to determine who should inherit the Hughes estate, estimated at $163 million to $1.2 billion.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; MISS PIGGY
description: Ionesco wrote a play about rhinoceroses, Orwell used barnyard animals to illustrate a political fable, and the best seller lists often include books about cats. So it is perhaps not surprising to find the nonfiction best seller list currently graced with the presence of none other than Miss Piggy.

title: Investing; TUMBLING PRICES HEIGHTEN GOLD'S ALLURE
description: I NVESTORS in gold had their faith in the metal tested again last week as its price twice dipped briefly below $400 a troy ounce, the level that investors currently consider a significant psychological barrier.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: ON THE BORDER Portraits of America's Southwestern Frontier. By Tom Miller. 226 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: Westchester Housing; NEW MORTGAGE LOAN ON THE SCENE
description: THE fixed-rate mortgage, by which a homeowner knew how much the monthly payments would be for 25 or 30 years, is ''an old friend riding off into the sunset,'' according to Robert Hooley, vice president of the People's Westchester Savings Bank - and among bankers the old friend can't ride fast enough.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Does a summit solve a problem? The answer is no. But we do intend to make clear our belief that we are part of an interdependant system, and that we're sensitive to the impact of our policies on our partners.'' - Myer Rashish, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, discussing next week's summit conference in Ottawa. (1:4.)

title: Quaker Group Sending China Heart Aids Worth $7.6 Million
description: The American Friends Service Committee said today that it had received $7.6 million worth of pacemakers meant for use in China, the largest gift in its history.

title: Other Business; FORMULA: CASSOULET, CABERNET AND QUICK TURNOVER
description: PARIS Joel Fleury calls it ''the formula.'' Purchase a picturesque but financially ailing brasserie in a not-so-central neighborhood. Retain the stained-glass skylights, the mahogany bar, the Art Nouveau tiles and the noisy brasserie charm. Then, offer a decent $20 meal, keep the restaurant open 365 days a year, and, most important, keep the place packed.

title: The Nation in Summary; LEGISLATING ON LIFE AND DEATH
description: The hearings leading to last week's vote were among the most emotional in Senate history and the outcome is not likely to cool the controversy. By a 3-to-2 vote, a Senate subcommittee approved a measure that states ''the life of each human being starts at conception'' and that could, if it becomes law, allow states to prosecute abortion as murder.

title: PLANS FOR LAND AT FT. TOTTEN CAUSE BATTLE IN QUEENS
description: Although Fort Totten in Bayside, Queens, was never engaged in battle during the Civil War, for which it was built, hostilities over the use of some of its land have begun in its neighboring communities.

title: A. Valerie Eichen Is Bride
description: The marriage of A. Valerie Eichen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Eichen of Highland Park, N.J., to Dr. Bruce E. Belsky, son of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice W. Belsky of New Brunswick, N.J., took place yesterday at the Regency in Verona, N.J. Rabbi Steven Kushner performed the ceremony. The bridegroom and his father are dentists.

title: THERE'S A CONFERENCE ON CAMBODIA BUT VIETNAM ISN'T COMING
description: Last week, a United States Air Force C-130 transport and a 10-member military honor guard flew to Hanoi to retrieve the remains of three Americans killed during the Vietnam war. The ceremony was more than usually noteworthy because such transfers are about the only official contacts that take place nowadays between Vietnam and the United States.

title: POLISH LIBERALS SEE CONSERVATIVE THREAT
description: In a report disseminated today, a group of liberals charges that there is a danger that Poland's Communist Party will be taken over by conservatives who will frustrate the general desire for change.

title: JERSEY SHORE DIVERSIONS BEYOND THE BEACH
description: PAULA SPANN is a writer based in Baltimore. By PAULA SPANN

title: Linda Carlson Bride of L. A. Himelfarb
description: Linda Gertrude Carlson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Joseph Carlson of Plainfield, N.J., was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Laurence Alec Himelfarb, son of Mrs. Irving Rappaport of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Water Mill, L.I., and the late Samuel Himelfarb. The Rev. Lori Roberts, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: The World in Summary; A PRISONER WITH A NAME IS FREED IN BUENOS AIRES
description: Unlike her predecessor, Evita, Isabel Martinez de Peron never had star quality. But the more than 1,000 people who massed before a Buenos Aires courtroom last week to celebrate ''Isabelita's'' freedom after five years of house arrest obviously believed that the military men who overturned her regime have turned out rather lackluster, too.

title: JAMES R. CONNELL
description: James R. Connell, a former vice president and director of the Flintkote Company, a producer of building materials, died Friday at his summer home in Madison, Conn. Mr. Connell, who was also a resident of Manhattan, was 81 years old.

title: Theme Parks
description: To the Editor: The article on theme parks in the Notes Column (Travel Section, May 31) failed to mention a new facility called Waterfun Village in the Thousand Islands-St. Lawrence Seaway region, near Alexandria Bay, N.Y., which opened this month.

title: Audrey von Lepel Is Wed to Dr. Bruce J. Siedlecki
description: Audrey Elizabeth von Lepel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Juergen-Heinz von Lepel of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Bruce Joseph Siedlecki, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus J. Siedlecki of Beechhurst, Queens. The Rev. Stephen Morris performed the ceremony, assisted by Deacon Charles Roger in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L.I.

title: CROMWELL BUDGET PASSES
description: WHEN budget time comes around again next year, Cromwell residents are likely to have vivid memories of the struggle that forced its school budget to a record eight votes before final approval last Monday. The controversy that had continued since early May finally ended when the residents voted 359 to 219 to approve the $4.07 million budget, a $5,584 increase over the one defeated a week previously. The Cromwell Middle School resounded with cheers and applause when the final tally was announced.

title: Bridge; WHAT HAPPENS WHEN A WIRE GETS CROSSED
description: Disputes in Poland are not limited to those in politics and labor unions. A recent issue of ''Brydz'', a monthly magazine, lashed out at the Rules and Ethics Committee of the Polish Bridge Association.

title: A JUDGEMENT ON COLLEGE SPORTS
description: Last Tuesday, Norm Ellenberger, former basketball coach at the University of New Mexico, was found guilty on 21 of 22 counts of fraud and the filing of false public vouchers. Most of the counts stemmed from Ellenberger's receiving reimbursement from the state-run university for trips he did not make or for which he had been reimbursed by a travel agency or by a corporation that sponsored clinics he conducted in various cities. Testimony at the trial indicated that money reimbursed by the university, which dismissed the coach in 1979 in the midst of a recruiting scandal, had found its way into a secret fund maintained by the basketball program to provide airline trips for players, a violation of rules created by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Headliners; CHRISTMAS MURDER CASE
description: If Claus von Bulow tried to kill his wife, he was very patient about it. Mr. von Bulow, a New York City financial consultant, was indicted last week in Newport, R.I., for trying twice to do away with his socialite wife, Martha Auersperg von Bulow. During Christmas holiday visits to their seaside Newport mansion in 1979 and 1980, the grand jury charged, Mr. von Bulow injected his wife with insulin, knowing she had hypoglycemia and that insulin could kill her. The second injection was said to have caused her to go into a coma, from which she has not emerged since January. Mr. von Bulow made no public comment on the indictment.

title: Gigi Grace Pugh Plans Marriage
description: The engagement of Gigi Grace Huntley Pugh to Jimmie Lennart Sundstrom has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Cresson Pugh of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Rockport, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Margaret Masi of New York and the late Lennart A. Sundstrom of Stockholm.

title: Long Island Journal
description: SOMETIME around 10 o'clock on Thursday night, the glow of the moon will grow dimmer and the sky over the South Shore will grow darker. It will not be a signal of the end of the world, as frightened observers once thought, but simply one of the unusual movements of the heavens: a lunar eclipse.

title: Susan Strong, a Teacher, Married to Jeffrey Hugel
description: Susan Elaine Strong and Jeffrey Charles Hugel were married yesterday in Christ United Methodist Church in Marietta, Ohio. The Rev. Karl A. Kling, a Presbyterian minister and a former classmate of the bridegroom at the Peddie School, performed the ceremony.

title: Dining Out; LIFE BEGINS ANEW FOR OLD INN
description: THREE months ago, the defunct Marlboro Inn in Montclair was reopened by a mixed bag of nine friends. The new owners include an attorney, an airline palot, their wives and so on, none of whom had hotel or restaurant experience but who shared a common interest in re-creating the charming inns they had visited in their travels.

title: CARLA FRACCI, 'PRIM BALLERINA ASSOLUTA'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Ludina Barzini is an Italian writer who lives in Milan. By LUDINA BARZINI

title: Art View; EXPRESSIONISM RETURNS TO PAINTING
description: In art, every authentic style comprehends a distinctive point of view. It exalts certain emotions, and upholds certain attitudes. It makes a judgment about the medium, and a judgment about life. Upon its emergence it proffers a revision of existing ideas about art, and thus - either by implication or by direct assault - represents a challenge to the prevailing orthodoxies. Every genuine change of style may therefore be seen as a barometer of changes greater than itself. It signals a shift in the life of the culture - in the whole complex of ideas, emotions and dispositions that at any given moment governs our outlook on art and experience.

title: REAGAN'S SHIFT TO THE CENTER RAISES CLAMOR ON THE RIGHT
description: WASHINGTON FOR seasoned watchers of President Reagan, his mid-week speech in Chicago was a familiar scene gone slightly, and tellingly, awry. His trusty index cards had given way to a teleprompter. The crisp cadences of his off-the-cuff orations were replaced by long and harshly partisan sentences that visibly wearied both Mr. Reagan and his audience. Despite the last-minute effort by aides to correct a ''mistake'' in the speech text, Mr. Reagan admitted that his appointment of Judge Sandra Day O'Connor to the United States Supreme Court culminated a ''search for a highly qualified woman.''

title: Virginia Antoinette Ferris Bride of Michael N. Cerre
description: Virginia Antoinette Ferris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dakin Bennett Ferris of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael Nolan Cerre, a writer for television shows. Canon Wendell L. Phillips, rector emeritus of Christ Episcopal Church in Rye, performed the ceremony aboard the sailing vessel Lene Marie moored at the American Yacht Club.

title: THE LEGAL DRINKING AGE: SHOULD IT BE 21 AGAIN?
description: AFEW years ago, at the height of the movement to establish 18 as the legal voting age in New Jersey, supporters of the proposal were fond of quoting: ''Old enough to die for my country, old enough to vote.''

title: L.I.R.R. FARE RISE SEEN AS SUBWAY SUBSIDY
description: LAWMAKERS and commuters are complaining that the new Long Island Rail Road fare increases, averaging 22.2 percent, are tailored to fit the financial problems of New York City's subways - not those of the less severely straitened railroad.

title: NATURE'S REVENGE
description: PORNOGRAPHY AND SILENCE Culture's Revenge Against Nature. By Susan Griffin. 277 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: Children's Books
description: THE HORSEMAN'S WORD By Georgess McHargue. 259 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $9.95. (Ages 12 to 16) By ANNIE GOTTLIEB

title: YOUTH WORK PROGRAMS FACE FIGHT FOR SURVIVAL
description: Wearing a hard hat and heavy work boots, 16-year-old Jim Watts, his face streaked with sweat and his pants caked with dirt, stood on a forest trail near this Hudson River village and said that coming to this rural area, 50 miles from his New York home, had changed his life.

title: MASSACHUSETTS GUARD ON STRIKE DUTY
description: Members of the National Guard washed clothes and cooked meals at state hospitals today as legislators tried to end a state employees' strike by resolving a budget stalemate that has delayed paychecks since July 1.

title: Personal Finance; ESTATE PLANNING FOR TWO-INCOME HOMES
description: T HE conventional marriage, in which the husband works and the wife stays home, is a continuing challenge for estate planners, who worry how to provide for the wife yet minimize estate taxes if the husband dies. But with more and more women pursuing careers, estate planners have turned their sights on two-income couples. While such couples are in many ways better off from an estate-planning standpoint, they, too, have tax problems.

title: MOVING: FRIENDS LEARN THE HIDDEN COST
description: SHE was my friend until recently. She still is, but now the business of friendship must be conducted cross-country, and although we pretend that the miles create no change in our relationship, they do. We phone, we write, we send presents at appropriate times of year. Yet, the information we exchange is more factual, more narrative than before. Somehow, where we've been and what we've done and whom we've met replace how we feel. It seems trivial, selfish now to report, ''I feel sad today'' long-distance, with the clock beside the phone ticking away costly minutes.

title: Lynn Tappan Is Engaged To Christopher A. Taylor
description: Mrs. Robert Dodge Merrill of Kennebunkport, Me., has announced the engagement of her granddaughter, Lynn Merrill Tappan, to Christopher Alan Taylor, son of Mrs. Madelyn Taylor of Washington and the late William E. Taylor.

description: M04,45,11,11,11 THE ECONOMY Gross National ProductI Q'81V Q'80Year Ago In billions, annual rate2,853.8$2,730.6$2,571.7 Real G.N.P. Growth Annual rate, 1972 dollars, in percent8.44.03.1 Corporate After-Tax ProfitsI Q'81IV Q'80Year Ago In billions, annual rate$168.3$164.3$184.9 Industrial Production IndexMay.Apr.Year Ago Percent change, monthly and year to year0.30.12.9 Housing Starts Thousands of units, annual rate1,1521,340938 New Orders for Durable Goods By manufacturers, in billions$83.9$82.9$67.3 Plant and Equipment SpendingI Q'81IV Q'80Year Ago In billions, annual rate$312.2$299.6$291.9 Inventory-Sales RatioApr.Mar.Year Ago Current dollars1.681.651.78 Sales at Retail OutletsMay.Apr.Year Ago In billions$85.9$85.7$76.0 Index of Leading IndicatorsMayApr.Year Ago Percent change, monthly and year to year1.80.42.5 EmploymentJuneMayYear Ago In thousands98,39299,23596,780 UnemploymentIn thousands7,7848,1717,811 Unemployment Rate In percent7.37.67.5 Merchandise ExportsMay.Apr.Year Ago In billions$18.9$19.8$17.6 Merchandise Imports In billions$22.3$23.3$21.7 Current Account Surplus/DeficitI Q'81IV Q'80Year Ago Goods and services, in billions$3.1$1.4$3.0

title: Margaret Sutton Bride Of George John Khouri
description: Margaret Mary Sutton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Joseph Sutton Jr. of Westlake, Ohio, was married yesterday to George John Khouri, son of Mrs. John Khouri of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Khouri. The ceremony was performed in St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Joseph Scannell.

title: Dining Out; PROVINCIAL FARE A LA FRANCAISE
description: TO a great extent, Le Soir, in Bayport, is similar to some small, informal restaurants in the French provinces. The attractive building is white stucco, punctuated by dark beams inside and out. In Normandy, the half-timbering would probably be structural, but here the function is decorative, yet the effect is pleasing.

title: HOW PLANNERS RE-TUNED MIDTOWN ZONING KEYS
description: The city's recently released final draft of the new midtown zoning contains substantial changes in how developers and architects must calculate the size and shape of new buildings.

title: Miss Bartlett Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis T. Preston of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Preston's daughter, Victoria M. Bartlett, to Barry G. Donaldson, son of Col. William R. Donaldson, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Donaldson of Hanover, N.H.

title: Politics; VOTERS FACING AN UNREAL ISSUE
description: JUST as a play needs a plot, political campaigns need issues. And when none are forthcoming from the electorate, candidates must forgo their own and hope to catch the fancy of the voters.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; MORE ON WATT AND THE ENVIRONMENT
description: For environmentalists, several events last week may have blurred some, though not all, of the battle lines that seemed to have been forming since the ascendancy of the Reagan Administration.

title: Ann C. Bailey Is Bride Of Walter Watson 3d
description: Ann Crowninshield Bailey, daughter of Mrs. Irving H. Chase of Lincoln, Mass., and Richard B. Bailey of Boston, was married yesterday to Walter Watson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Watson 2d of Boston. The Rev. Carl Scovel performed the ceremony at Kings Chapel House (Unitarian) in Boston.

title: Topics; THE LION'S MEOW
description: Periodically, angry tribute is paid to the capability and credibility of the British Broadcasting Corporation's overseas service. For instance, Iran's outraged mullahs have denounced the B.B.C. for carrying a bulletin on the bombing of their party headquarters only five minutes after the blast occurred.

title: GARDENS STRIPPED IN FRUIT FLY FIGHT
description: As tens of thousands of people in the area infested with Mediterranean fruit flies strove to strip their gardens of produce, attorneys for several cities went to court to stop aerial spraying of a pesticide used to kill the insects.

title: ROBBINS WEIGHS THE FUTURE- BALLET OR BROADWAY?
description: It is improper to say an artist is at the height of his career; it suggests he has nowhere to go but down. Still, think of Jerome Robbins. If he is not at the height of his career, then certainly he is in something approaching an apogee, and at a youthful 62 (choreographers, along with orchestra conductors, are ageless; it comes with the territory) Mr. Robbins is considered to be the greatest American-born ballet choreographer of all. This is a distinction he has earned not only in ballet, but on Broadway as well, although, characteristically, it is a distinction he will deny. Actually, he will not deny it flat out; it is more that he will ignore it, skittering away from outright assertions about himself as if they were immodest, unfair, an invasion of privacy, or perhaps all three. Mr. Robbins, awesomely wary, absolutely precise, is elusive.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: A NEW $500 MILLION PRISON BOND ISSUE, BUT WHY AND FOR WHAT?
description: EVEN before they had restored order, officials knew what had triggered last week's uprising at the Westchester County Jail: overcrowding. And with 23,595 prisoners in custody last week and a capacity for only 22,749, New York State authorities were worried, too. But the problem isn't new; during the last decade, the inmate population has doubled, more than matching the growth in state facilities. The Legislature responded this month by passing a $500 million bond issue to build new cells and renovate old ones. But it still needs the voters' approval and several groups, arguing that more prisons will only breed more prisoners, are campaigning against it.

title: RENTED CLOTHES FIT FOR A ROYAL EVENT MAGAZINE
description: When Prince Charles announced his engagement to Lady Diana Spencer last February, the price of Moss Bros. shares shot up on the London Stock Exchange. No wonder. So esteemed is this clothing rental establishment that most of the male guests attending the Royal Wedding in St. Paul's Cathedral on July 29 - and the other formal events generated by the wedding this summer -will be wearing morning suits and top hats hired from the venerable Victorian firm for the day.

title: Headliners; DOWN ON HIS LUCK
description: Robert Astles - ''Major Bob'' to his friends - didn't much care who buttered his bread, but he always knew which side it was buttered on. A working-class Briton who emigrated to Uganda in the mid-1950s, he curried favor successively with the king of the country's dominant tribe, with the once and once-again President Milton Obote and, finally, with the deposed President-for-Life Idi Amin.

title: 2 PAPERS IN DALLAS IN A 'FREE-FOR-ALL'
description: Early last month, The Dallas Morning News was preparing to assign a reporter to cover Toronto full time. Executives of The Dallas Times Herald learned of the plan and acted first.

title: New York Political Notes
description: In its waning hours, the Legislature has again quietly passed a bill that would divide the Bronx and Manhattan into two judicial districts. But unlike the past, Manhattan and Bronx Democrats were split on the measure.

title: Melinda Susan Marshlow Is Engaged To David W. Mooney, Aide of Bank
description: Mrs. Ackerman Marshlow of Pelham, N.Y., and Robert Welch Marshlow of New York, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Melinda Susan Marshlow, to David Walton Mooney, son of Mrs. Gerard Cornelius Mooney and the late Mr. Mooney of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

title: A CHILDHOOD OF SERMONS AND SONNETS
description: MY father was an itinerant writer. In the 20's, when I was born, he was trying to earn a living as a play fixer, which meant that he was hired to rewrite ailing plays so that they could open in New York City. In one tryout in Boston, he told me years later, a play he had ''fixed'' opened and closed the first night. The cast, which included Louis Calhern, realized in the middle of the first act that there were only three people in the audience. Calhern advanced to the proscenium and suggested they join the cast so they wouldn't feel lonely.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; THE SUN GREETS A SOLAR CHALLENGE
description: Lifted by hope and a break in the weather, Solar Challenger, an aircraft powered completely by the sun, flew 165 miles across the English Channel last week. Piloted by 28-year-old Stephen R. Ptacek, the 210-pound plane rose from Cormeilles-en-Vexin near Paris and, under sunny skies, set down at the Royal Manston Air Force Base on England's southeastern coast five and a half hours later.

title: Homosexuals And the Nazis
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR WOMEN, A LANDMARK REDISCOVERED
description: At the time, it was the greatest achievement of American women ever seen - but who has heard of it today? Seven years ago, Jeanne Madeline Weimann, with equal surprise, stumbled across it in old Chicago books and became ''fascinated and then obsessed by this undiscovered landmark in women's history.'' It was the huge, Renaissance-style Woman's Building of the Columbian Exposition of 1893, a great world's fair that rose for six months by Chicago's lakefront.

title: HOT TIMES IN HYDROPOWER, WITH A LITTLE HELP FROM CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON P ROSPECTORS once sought their fortunes by panning for the bits of gold that tumbled down the nation's waterways. Now, say a number of modern-day forty-niners, forget the gold: The waterways themselves offer prospects of a fortune.

title: 'Household Saints'
description: From the very first sentence of Francine Prose's fifth novel, you know you're under the spell of a first-rate storyteller: ''It happened by the grace of God that Joseph Santangelo won his wife in a card game.''

title: Debbie Austin's 68-205 Leads by Nine Strokes
description: Debbie Austin shot a three-under-par 33 on the front nine today and had an eagle on the 426-yard, par-5 16th hole to open a nine-stroke lead today over Myra Van Hoose and Louise Parks after three rounds of the $150,000 Mayflower Classic.

title: Margo Shearman Becomes a Bride
description: Margo Dodge Shearman, daughter of Dorothy Shearman of Needham, Mass., was married there yesterday to Don Armin Howard, son of Mrs. George Sheard of Hamilton, Ohio, and the late Robert D. Howard. The Rev. Richard L. Dodds performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of Needham.

title: FRESH AIR CHILDREN ENCOUNTER NATURE, EYE TO EYE
description: Sheba Clarke's eyes sparkled when she heard that farmers often mixed molasses with hay to get their cows to eat. ''I love that,'' she said with envy. ''I wish my mommy did that too.'' Sheba joined about 20 other children and their host parents this morning at Muscoot Park in upper Westchester County for a picnic and a tour arranged by the Fresh Air Fund.

title: MALLS PUSH MARKETING PROGRAMS
description: NEW JERSEY has been called the Mall State at times, and in areas such as Paramus, where shopping centers rub elbows, the description fits. Even New York residents come to New Jersey to shop, lured not only by the presence of major department stores but also by the absence of a sales tax on many items.

title: Keystone Beatrix, $34, Winner in Sire Stakes
description: Keystone Beatrix and Quick Mouse won the split divisions of the $196,060 New York Sire Stakes for 3-year-old pacing fillies at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: Winds of Winter Wins
description: Winds of Winter, part of the Phil Johnson-trained entry with Match the Hatch, won the $39,725 Oceanport Handicap on the grass at Monmouth Park by a neck today.

title: WHITNEY HAILED AS CULTURAL RESOURCE
description: STAMFORD THE opening of a branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art here this Tuesday is being accepted as a welcome addition by Connecticut art lovers. Artists, critics and patrons of the arts also agree that the Whitney branch could serve as a major boost to such underserviced areas as Stamford.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC Wilson Pickett, Solomon Burke, Ben E. King and Don Covay were four of the most popular 1960's soul singers. They were secular preachers who celebrated the flesh in the intensely gritty style of gospel music, and since they all recorded for the Atlantic label, they sometimes recorded together as a super-charged vocal group, the Soul Clan.

title: WHERE POTATO IS KING, NEW CROPS TAKE HOLD
description: THE potatoes are growing again this summer on eastern Long Island - and so are the cauliflower, grapes, spinach, lettuce and other vegetables that are being cultivated by an increasing number of local farmers who are trying to diversify the region's agricultural base and stay in the business of farming, a proposition that becomes more difficult each year.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE STRANGER BESIDE ME, by Ann Rule. (NAL/Signet, $3.50.) The story of Theodore Robert Bundy, the prototypical ''boy next door'' who is suspected of having killed 36 young women in five states and was convicted of three murders in 1979. The account is all the more remarkable because it is told by a crime writer who knew him for 10 years but hadn't the slightest inkling that he was the guilty man when she set out to report on the case. Our reviewer Thomas Thompson called this ''as dramatic and chilling as a bedroom window shattering at midnight.''

title: DESPITE BUDGET SLASHING, CROP SUPPORTS GET FATTER
description: For the past few weeks, President Reagan has been learning that when farm legislation is the agenda, the Administration's wishes are treated like so much chaff. Republican or Democrat, the priority of farm state Congressmen is taking care of their constituents and the lobbyists who represent them.

title: The Nation in Summary; HIGH ANXIETY ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: When Social Security is discussed these days, the question isn't whether the system will fail, but when. In their annual report last week, the fund's trustees supplied the most pessimistic answer yet: next year.

title: Crime
description: Behold a classic British mystery novel written by C.P. Snow - Charles Percy Snow; Lord Snow; ''The Two Cultures'' Snow; the author of the 11 volumes of the ''Strangers and Brothers'' saga; the scientist-administrator-novelist-philosopher who died last year.

title: Wendy B. Fass, Duke '80, to Be Bride Of Bruce E. Mosler in Virginia Aug. 15
description: Wendy Beth Fass and Bruce Elliot Mosler plan to be married in Williamsburg, Va., on Aug. 15. The future bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Fass of Newport, News, Va., who have announced her engagement to the son of John Mosler and Sheila Sanders Mosler, both of New York.

title: PARAGUAY ACCUSED OF IMPERILING INDIANS' SURVIVAL
description: A formal complaint filed recently with the United Nations accuses Paraguay of actions calculated to destroy an indigenous tribe of 700 Indians known as the Toba-Maskoy.

title: Deborah Horan, Editor, Bride of Craig M. Ferrer
description: Deborah Lynne Horan and Craig Michael Ferrer, 1978 graduates of Ohio Wesleyan University, were married at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday. The Rev. William Donovan of St. Thomas More and the Rev. Zdenak Bednar of the Wilton (Conn.)

title: BRINGING 'THE GREEKS' TO WILLIAMSTOWN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert L. King is a freelance writer with a special interest in theater. By ROBERT L. KING

title: MAKING A BEGINNING OF AN ENDING
description: THE fact that no life was lost makes me feel a bit guilty to complain about our apartment building burning down, to dwell on it, or to continue to feel that my life has been irretrievably altered. ''Count your blessing - you have your life, and that's what matters.''

title: R.G. Orf to Wed Lisa T. Heffernan, Banking Officer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Phillip T. Heffernan of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa T. Heffernan, to Roger Gerard Orf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Orf of St. Charles, Mo.

title: Grand Jury Checking Case Against Atlantan
description: A Fulton County grand jury here has begun deliberations on the merits of charges by the police against Wayne B. Williams, the 23-year-old Atlantan arrested last month and charged with the murder of one of the victims of a series of murders of young blacks in the Atlanta area.

title: CONSUMER RATES
PURSUIT OF JUSTICE IS LONG AND DANGEROUS
description: MOSCOW THEY dribble into Moscow with their shabby briefcases and their worn-out expressions, arriving from the provinces to appeal against the wrongs they feel they have suffered at the hands of local authorities.

title: Americans in Spain
