description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Talk
description: Ron's story. During the past fortnight, more than five months after Ronald Reagan's inauguration, Dell Books has been slipping into the mass-market racks 100,000 copies of the only book ever written by the 40th President. ''Where's the Rest of Me?'' ($2.95), written in collaboration with Richard G. Hubler, is considered by many political writers to be the best source of information about the first 54 years of Mr. Reagan's life. How it came to be written and what's happened to it since make a curious footnote to the ways of book publishing and its relations with politics.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Dining Out column in The Guide last Sunday, an incorrect price was listed for a typical three-course dinner at the Village Green restau- rant. The price is $35 a person without drinks.

title: JAZZ PIANIST: PATTI BROWN AT HANRATTI'S
description: Patti Bown is known primarily as a pianist, a jazz pianist with a strong, adventurous approach, a melodic instinct, an unusual harmonic imagination and an intense sense of rhythm. At Hanratty's, Second Avenue at 91st Street, where she is appearing through tonight, Miss Bown is also singing songs that she has written, and she says that one of them, ''There's Something About Rhythm,'' sums up her philosophy of life.

title: Lahore
description: To the Editor: Barbara Crossette's article, ''Lahore, a Survivor With a Bittersweet History'' (Travel Section, June 14) filled me with nostalgia. Lahore was once considered ''the Paris of the East,'' and for me it will always remain so.

title: Business Forum; ECONOMIC AFFAIRS: IN THE C.P.I. WE CANNOT TRUST
description: T HE United States has received very good, and quite surprising, news on the inflation front in the last three months. After rising at rates of around 13 percent annually since 1978, consumer price inflation has slowed to an annual rate of 7 percent over the last three months.

title: DAVE ANDERSONSports of The Times; 'The Kid' at Newmarket
description: that boyish smile, those long fingers when he shook hands, the straight, dark hair. In his silks, he could have been at Belmont or Santa Anita, but no, everything else was different. He was here at Newmarket, leaning on a wooden railing near the huge scale of the jockey's waiting room in this small stucco building with a thatched roof. Next to it was a brick building the size of a small farm house where they take the bets at this race track out here in the English horse country northeast of London.

title: SPINNEY HILL CLAIMS VICTORIES
description: GREAT NECK THE community of Spinney Hill won its second apparent victory in recent weeks when Cox Cable Communications abandoned plans to locate technical and administrative facilities for its Great Neck cable television operation in an office building that is part of the neighborhood's urban renewal project.

title: Paul Reiss Weds Joanne Melloni
description: Joanne Tracy Melloni, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent R. Melloni of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Julian Reiss, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Jacob Reiss of Bronxville, N.Y. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed at the Fordham University Church in the Bronx by the Rev. Eugene O'Brien, former president of the Fordham Preparatory School.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Social Insecurity Is the Social Security system really on the brink of bankruptcy, as we've been hearing? That is what some people in the news department at CBS were wondering recently; so, they set out to get some answers from Administration officials, members of Congress, economists and families across the country. They will air their findings Thursday night at 10 in the special report ''Social Insecurity.'' Dan Rather will be the anchorman for the program, and there are reports from correspondents Charles Collingwood, George Herman, Bruce Morton, Bob Schieffer, Susan Spencer and Richard Wagner.

title: 2 Long Island Fishing Spots Closed After DDT Discovery
description: Southampton Village, on eastern Long Island, has closed Agawam Lake and Old Town Pond to fishing after high concentrations of DDT-derived compounds were found in a dead goldfish.

title: BRANCH OF WHITNEY SEEN AS AID TO ARTS
description: STAMFORD THE opening of a branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art here on Tuesday was greeted by artists, critics and patrons as a ''welcome addition'' to the growing arts community in the suburbs. The new Whitney branch is expected to draw many Westchester residents as part of its audience.

title: JACOBY: FINISHING IS GOAL
description: The crowds begin trickling into the resort town of Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., the day before the race. Some of the regulars, with campers and vans full of kids, grab the front-row seats in a parking lot along the Manasquan Inlet. Others arrive at dawn on race day. Carrying coolers, beach chairs and binoculars, they stake their claim along the inlet jetty or on the beach.

title: Health Code Violations Cited at 18 Food Places
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 18 food establishments for violations of the Health Code. In addition, one establishment was reopened after a new inspection and one was closed for failing to comply with regulations.

title: Headliners; INNOCENT ENOUGH
description: His role in American history may be a dubious one, but E. Howard Hunt would appreciate having it properly understood.

title: Yvonne Balboni Wed To Mark F. Bregman
description: Yvonne Marie Balboni and Mark Fielding Bregman were married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Paul Dinter performed the ceremony.

title: BUDGET TAKES TOLL ON ECOLOGY
description: TRENTON AS A result of reductions in the Federal budget by the Reagan Administration, New Jersey will lose at least $86 million for major environmental-protection programs within the next year or so.

title: DONALD SUTHERLAND FIGHTS HIS 'ODDBALL' IMAGE
description: He is a Nazi spy: he will slip a knife between his landlady's ribs, stab a clumsy comrade, throw a paraplegic off a cliff and stroll calmly to tea as if from an uneventful afternoon. He is ''Nick the Noz,'' a helicopter news reporter whose half-crazed chatter fractures the airwaves.

title: N.A. Stephens to Wed Lisa Kunstadter
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John W. Kunstadter of New York and London of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Jan Kunstadter, to Nicholas Andrew Stephens, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Stephens of New York and Andover, N.J.

title: Follow-Up on the News; A $500,000 Token?
description: Two years ago, the Transit Authority introduced a new subway token, with two purposes in mind: to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the opening of the system, and to give the authority $500,000 or more in profit.

title: Stage View; WHERE ARE THE NEW MUSICALS?
description: Last month the members of the New York Drama Critics Circle committed what could be taken for an act of theatrical heresy; they elected not to give an award to a ''best new musical'' of the 1980-81 season. To an outsider, it might seem that the critics were being perverse. No fewer than five musical hits arrived on Broadway this season: ''42nd Street,'' ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' ''Woman of the Year'' and ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music.'' By and large, these shows got favorable reviews from members of the Critics Circle, as did a sixth musical, ''Tintypes,'' which failed to find a large Broadway public. So why didn't the Critics Circle get together behind one of the six and christen it the best? You'd think we'd all come down with amnesia.

title: Preston Pearson Says He Is Quitting Football
description: The veteran running back Preston Pearson, a Dallas Cowboy for six years and a National Football League player for 14, says he is through with professional football.

title: STAR AND VICTIM
description: PLAYED OUT The Jean Seberg Story. By David Richards. Illustrated. 386 pp. New York: Random House. $13.95.

title: Alida Jay Will Be Married on Sept. 19 To Thorvald Boye, a Lawyer in Oslo
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dean Jay of Lloyd Neck, Huntington, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Alida Jay, to Thorvald Boye, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thore Boye of Oslo. The wedding is planned for Sept. 19 in Lloyd Neck.

title: New Jersey Housing; MAKING IT LOOK EASY IN PRINCETON
description: ONE is reminded of Candide's resolve to cultivate his own garden. The Princeton-based Hillier Group, architects, planners and interior designers, is ranked among the largest concerns of its type in the United States. Its most ambitious current undertaking is the planning and design of a $700 million city on Seddon Island in the heart of Tampa, Fla., a city that will include housing for 14,000 and a mile and a half of waterfront facilities.

title: No Headline
description: Pam Garfield must be one of my neighbors, and I have some words of reassurance for her concerning the alleged ''mediocrity'' of Queens.

title: ITALY ENTHRALLED BY 2 GREEK WARRIORS
description: Two classical Greek statues that have been on display here for two weeks have caused an outpouring of curiosity and adulation of a kind that is usually attracted in this country by soccer players.

title: R. C. Wein Weds Katherine A. Sur
description: Katherine Anne Sur, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Sur of Westfield, N.J., was married there yesterday to Lieut. (j.g.) Robert Charles Wein, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Wein Jr. of Perryville, Md. The Rev. Robert T. Lennon performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Trinity.

title: JUSTICE REHNQUIST: FIRM WAYS, WITTY MEANS
description: Throughout the speculation that preceded President Reagan's selection of Sandra Day O'Connor for the Supreme Court last week, the prediction most often heard was that, regardless of gender, Mr. Reagan was looking for ''another Rehnquist.'' Despite similarities in origins and education - both Judge O'Connor and Justice Rehnquist practiced law in Arizona and were classmates at Stanford law school - it is too early to tell if that is what the President has found. But there is little doubt as to what ''another Rehnquist'' means.

title: Theater in Review; 'ANGEL STREET' CHILLS AUDIENCES ANEW
description: ''ANGEL STREET'' opened on Broadway in December 1941, an unexpected hit if ever there was one. Its stars, Vincent Price and Judith Evelyn, were not well known at the time, and the show had so little advance sale that no tickets were printed beyond the first Saturday night. Yet this Victorian thriller stayed around for 1,295 performances and went on to movie fame under the title ''Gaslight,'' starring Ingrid Bergman and Charles Boyer.

title: On Partridge
description: To the Editor:

title: DRIVING TO WORK WITH THE SUN IN YOUR EYES
description: ABOUT three years ago, my husband, who had been commuting to ''the city'' on the Long Island Rail Road for more than 30 years, found himself, for business reasons, having to move to Manhattan. It would be easy to blame the L.I.R.R. for our move - as everyone knows it is almost never blameless - but in our case it would not be true.

title: Henry Feuerstein And Elise Meyer To Marry Oct. 11
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Cohen of New York and Greensboro, N.C., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Cohen's daughter, Elise Ann Meyer, to Henry I. Feuerstein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Feuerstein of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. The prospective bride is the daughter also of the late John H. Meyer.

title: Patricia Rainford Wed To Michael H. Irving
description: Patricia Luces Rainford of Bronxville, N.Y., and Michael Henry Irving of Rowayton, Conn., were married yesterday in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas F. Pike of New York performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the rector, the Rev. Daniel Miner.

title: DOCTORS TREAT ROCK FANS' ILLS, FROM ALCOHOL TO STUBBED TOES
description: The boy, shirtless, blue-jeaned and barefoot, had that tanned, muscular, blond look that is quintessentially Californian.

title: Frances Leavitt Fiancee of D. J. Meick
description: Mr. and Mrs. Brooks Russell Leavitt of Spencer, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Shackelford Leavitt, to Douglas Joseph Meick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Meick of Alexandria, Va.

title: U.S. Conducts Nuclear Test
description: The United States conducted an underground nuclear test in the yield range of less than 20 kilotons yesterday at its test site in Nevada, the Energy Department announced. It was the seventh American underground nuclear test this year.

title: LUCK OF THE ECONOMY SO FAR SMILES ON REAGAN
description: From President Reagan's viewpoint, the economic news could hardly be better these days. Inflation has been slowing for several months. The economy's overall performance has tapered off after a surprisingly strong first quarter that threatened to do in the President's proposed tax-relief package. The dollar has been climbing to ever-higher levels against other currencies, chiefly because interest rates in the United States have been bumping along at or near record highs. The interest rates have earned the Administration a heaping measure of criticism in Europe, criticism that will be expressed to the President personally at the Ottawa summit later this month. That, however, is the least of Mr. Reagan's problems, officials indicate.

title: MEN'S DESIRES
description: THE HITE REPORT ON MALE SEXUALITY By Shere Hite. 1129 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: OVETT'S 3:49.25 WINS OSLO MILE AS SEVEN RUNNERS BETTER 3:51
description: The mile moved to a new frontier tonight when seven runners shattered 3 minutes 51 seconds, led by Steve Ovett's winning 3:49.25 and an American record 3:49.68 by Steve Scott, who was third.

title: MILLER CITES IMPORTANCE OF PLAYER SERVICE CREDIT
description: Even before talks broke down, Marvin Miller, the players' labor leader, emphasized yesterday how difficult it would be for baseball's club owners and players to reach a settlement and end the strike that has canceled 377 games. ''There will be no settlement,'' Miller said, ''without full service credit.''

title: BRITTEN'S POPULARITY IS UNDIMINISHED
description: According to the unwritten laws of historical inevitability, a composer who achieves a certain amount of reclame when alive will almost surely fall into disfavor immediately upon his decease. In this century, Sibelius is the classic example of a composer revered in his lifetime, scorned after his death and rehabilitated by the next generation. Some, like Verdi or Wagner, were never actually banished from the repertory but they did suffer a severe drop in prestige, while other giants of their ages, like Meyerbeer and Telemann, never regained their former standing.

title: Iran Seizes Bani-Sadr Brother And Executes 5 More Foes
description: Iran's Islamic revolutionary regime announced today that it had arrested the brother of Iran's former President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr. and that it had executed five more opponents.

title: THE 'BINDER' SOMETIMES BOOMERANGS
description: Lawyers routinely advise their clients not to sign anything when buying or selling property without consulting them first, but they say such advice is frequently and foolishly ignored.

title: Art; DIVERSITY AND CONTRAST STRENGTHEN ARTIST'S PATH
description: GARDEN CITY THE exhibition at Adelphi University's Ruth S. Harley University Center Gallery would seem, at first glance, to be a group sculpture show. There are nearly 50 works on display revealing a wide diversity of styles, artistic attitudes and materials.

title: MOBILE TO VOTE ON METHOD OF ELECTING OFFICIALS
description: Voters will decide Tuesday whether to continue electing their City Commissioners at large, and their decision could render moot a Federal suit challenging the present system on the ground that it discriminates against blacks.

title: SOUTH AFRICA AWAITING CHANGE OF U.S. ENVOY
description: The Afrikaans-language press of South Africa's governing National Party is portraying the imminent replacement of the present United States Ambassador as a step by the Reagan Administration to promote closer ties with Pretoria.

title: July 12, 1981
description: NONFICTION THE CINDERELLA COMPLEX: Women's Hidden Fear of Independence. By Colette Dowling.

title: No Headline
description: Roger Swain's article suggests to me that he hasn't been on the front lines with the gypsy moths.

title: SALVADOR RACKED BY MASS SLAYINGS
description: Thirty feet below the silver-painted cables of a one-lane suspension bridge on the banks of the rushing Metayate River, 36 miles north of San Salvador, there is a mound of dirt that slopes to the base of three shade trees. Beneath the freshly turned earth, witnesses say, lie the bodies of 28 murdered peasants.

title: Prince Edward Island
description: To the Editor: Ralph Blumenthal's article on Prince Edward Island, ''A Province of Wholesome Pleasures'' (Travel Section, June 7) rekindled fond memories of our own trip there in 1977. Alas, we arrived in mid-September and the lobster dinners of which he writes were nowhere to be seen.

title: FRANCE BETS ON THE LEFT
description: Richard Eder is The Times's Paris bureau chief. By Richard Eder aris favors a persistent drizzle, but it managed to achieve a thunderstorm on May 10, the night that Francois Mitterrand won the presidency and swept away Valery Giscard d'Estaing and the dwindling, 23-year heritage of Charles de Gaulle.

title: SPORTS ON CABLE
description: For the voracious sports fan, cable television is a worthwhile investment because it offers round-the-clock athletic events ranging from major-league baseball games and thoroughbred horse racing not available on local commercial channels to such esoterica as polo and high-school wrestling.

title: Senegal
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to read Joan Chatfield-Taylor's article, ''For Visitors to Senegal, an Intimate Glimpse of Village Life'' (Travel Section, May 31) and to learn that the Senegalese, at least on a small scale, are taking the tourist trade into their own hands.

title: TALKS BREAK OFF
description: Just when it seemed as if the negotiators might be generating some bargaining momentum for the first time in the 30-day-old baseball strike, the talks collapsed again yesterday and a controversy erupted over the authorship of the Federal mediator's proposal that had triggered the new talks.

title: THEIR MEN IN BRAZIL
description: HITLER'S SECRET WAR IN SOUTH AMERICA 1939-1945 German Military Espionage and Allied Counterespionage in Brazil. By Stanley E. Hilton. Illustrated. 353 pp. Baton Rouge, La.: Louisiana State University Press. $20.

title: WHICH WAY TO MOSCOW?
description: Now the despairing cry for a Soviet policy can be heard inside the Reagan Administration. The President's own officials complain that they cannot drive the anti-Communist bus if friendly passengers aren't told its destination.

title: CRITICS CHOICES
description: THEATER At this late date, it might seem impossible for a writer to say anything fresh about the affluent singles of Manhattan's ''Annie Hall'' era. Nonetheless, a first-time playwright named Kevin Wade has gracefully bucked the odds in a sweet new comedy called ''Key Exchange.'' Mr. Wade actually has wise, truthful observations to make about his bright, upwardly mobile characters - and he makes his points with charity, feeling and the breeziest of wit.

title: POP: JERRY JEFF WALKER
description: Jerry Jeff Walker, who appeared at the Savoy on Thursday, is the quintessential ''outlaw'' among contemporary singer-songwriters. More urbane than Willie Nelson but still strongly tied to the Texan honkytonk tradition, Mr. Walker fits squarely into the ''progressive country'' category, which was invented in the early 1970's for artists like Mickey Newbury, Kris Kristofferson and Lee Clayton, who also brought a literary flair to their country laments.

title: Notes; FROM UNCLE SAM: LANGUAGE LESSONS, PARK GUIDES AND DIPLOMATIC BRIEFINGS
description: The United States Government Printing Office in Washington has just brought out a new edition of its ''Subject Bibliography on Travel and Tourism,'' and once again it is full of useful titles. Among the listings are guides to back-country trails in 40 national parks, booklets on basic conversation in a dozen languages, travel tips for older vacationers and, for the first time, a series of ''Post Reports'' issued by the State Department to introduce American diplomats to their host countries and now made available to the general public.

title: IN THE 50TH STATE, A TASTE OF JAPAN
description: ROBERT TRUMBULL, formerly a Times correspondent, lives in Honolulu. By ROBERT TRUMBULL

title: The Region in Summary; INQUIRY GIVES GOLDIN SHELTER
description: In his primary bid for City Comptroller, Assemblyman John P. Dearie has referred to his opponent, incumbent Harrison J. Goldin, as ''the most investigated elected municipal official in the recent history of New York City.'' After last week, though, Mr. Dearie may need a new campaign theme.

title: In Favor of Takeover Of Electric Utility
description: The article concerning the issue of a public takeover of Con Edison's electricity-distribution system in Westchester (''Board to Assess Utility Takeover in Upstate Town,'' June 14) suggests what the citizens of Westchester are up against in their struggle for lower electric rates.

title: NUDISM: IS IT FADING IN POPULARITY?
description: HACKETTSTOWN IT IS 3 o'clock on a Sunday afternoon, and the regulars at the Goodlands Country Club are packed around the Olympic-size pool. Couples lie motionless in the hot sun, covered only by a film of tanning lotion. At the same time, a few paunchy businessmen, attired only in espadrilles and Timex watches, rest in the shade of a cabana.

title: AH, THE SOUNDS OF SUMMER
description: time to throw open the windows, move outdoors and enjoy the peace and tranquillity of summer in the suburbs.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL CHICAGO (NFC) - Signed Todd Bell, defensive back of Ohio State, fourth-round draft choice, and Scott Zettek, defensive end of Notre Dame, eight-round draft choice.

title: NATO IS FACING PARALYSIS OF WILL, EXPERTS CONTEND
description: A wide range of European and American political leaders, diplomats and foreign-policy experts believe that the NATO alliance faces growing erosion of common outlook and paralysis of will in its ability to deal with the Soviet Union.

title: 'Glitching': The Wave of the Future
description: Marilyn Levine's recent trenchant article (Opinion Page) on chronic channel changing or ''glitching,'' as the syndrome will probably come to be known, will undoubtedly persuade a large number of ''glitchers'' to come out of the closet into the open where they can be heard. I must confess that I myself am an inveterate and obsessive channel changer, much to my wife's sorrow, and I feel that Marilyn's frank and revealing piece will create more understanding of and tolerance for this apparently prevalent, but furtive practice.

title: TRIAL BEGINS UPSTATE IN A 1952 DOUBLE MURDER
description: A man whose sister reportedly broke a 28-year vow of silence to turn him in went on trial this week on charges of murdering two hunters in the wooded hills of Orange County in 1952.

title: Nicaragua Paper Suspended
description: La Prensa, Nicaragua's leading opposition newspaper, has been suspended for 48 hours by the Government for publishing what the Interior Ministry charged were false reports. La Prensa has often been critical of the Sandinist Government since it came to power two years ago.

title: Outline of Settlement Proposed by Moffett
description: Terms of the settlement proposal suggested by Kenneth E. Moffett, the Federal mediator in the major league baseball strike:

title: No Headline
description: [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] husband and infant son and I moved into an older (1920's) house on a small lot.

title: Home Clinic; ELIMINATING THE SOURCE OF MOISTURE ON BASEMENT WALLS
description: AT this time of year, many homeowners are plagued with dampness and ''sweating'' basement walls, a condition that causes objects in the basement to develop musty odors or become scarred by mildew. Although this can be attributed to moisture seeping through the walls,more often than not the problem is condensation - warm, moist air inside on the cool masonry.

title: The Nation in Summary; DU PONT IS BIG, NIMBLE, HUNGRY
description: Last week's merger agreement between E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the largest chemical producer in the land, and Conoco, the ninth-biggest oil company, seems likely to get Washington's blessing.

title: The Region; ALBANY MARATHON FINALLY DELIVERS ON TRANSIT TAXES
description: The art of political compromise, to the untrained eye, sometimes looks like the craft of coercion. So it appeared last week as, after 20 hours of wrangling on the Assembly and Senate floors, a $793 million package of taxes for transit aid emerged from Albany amid a litter of twisted arms and bent wills.

title: MARINES' VIETNAM ART LEFT UNSEEN
description: In a basement storeroom of the Washington Navy Yard, an odd collection of artworks is largely unseen and until recently unwanted by the public.

title: Follow-Up on the News; A Better Bench
description: After a three-year test, the Parks Department said it had found a better bench. Constructed of galvanized steel and heavy planks, the bench was said to be vandal-resistant.

title: Stretching a Point
description: To the Editor: The cartoon caption (Travel Section, June 14) was fine as far as it went, but it might have been extended by the words I have added in italics:

title: Allison Smith Wed in South
description: Jean Allison Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Smith of Atlanta, was married at the Peachtree Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Timothy Aldis Straus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Straus of New York. The Rev. Charles I. Mann Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Saving Airline Tickets
description: To the Editor: Paul Grimes states in his article, ''Useful Reading for Travelers: The Fine Print On Tickets'' (Travel Section, June 21), that it would be a ''major'' mistake to discard an air ticket after it has been used because a photocopy of it might be needed in post-flight action to get compensation for a grievance.

title: ...TURNING 10 YEARS OLD
description: WHEN my son, McDavid, turned 10 years old, we planned a large party to celebrate. I asked him whether he was pleased with the arrangements and he said yes. The thought of being 10 was exciting, he told me, but it was also scary.

title: No Headline
description: Ironically, some of the best advice for promoting natural control of the gypsy moth was put forward in 1917, but was never implemented. In their classic study, ''Control of the Gypsy Moth by Forest Management,'' G.E. Clement and W. Munro urged that gypsy moth populations could be reduced in the long run by growing resistant forests.

title: North Carolina's Senate Bars Paramilitary Training Camps
description: The State Senate has banned paramilitary training activities in North Carolina.

title: AMERICA NEEDS FEWER IMMIGRANTS
description: One of the major problems in making public policy is that politicians, like von Clausewitz's generals, always tend to fight the last war. It is deceptively simple to define the future in terms of our past. Abraham Lincoln said it so well: ''As our case is new, so we must think and act anew. We must disenthrall ourselves.''

title: The Lively Arts; ADELPHI ENLISTS STARS FOR 'VANYA'
description: TONIGHT'S opening of ''Uncle Vanya,'' starring Jean Marsh and Wayne Rogers, signals a breakthrough in the Adelphi University Olmsted Theater's search for a summer identity.

title: SUMMER FESTIVAL IN THE ETERNAL CITY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PAUL HOFMANN, a retired Times correspondent, lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: Business Forum; READER COMMENT: H.M.O. TREATMENT; JOAN Z. BERNSTEIN
description: D EBORAH RANKIN'S column, ''When Your Health Plan Gets Sick'' (June 7), raised some interesting questions about what an employer can do if the Health Maintenance Organization it offered its employees is ''sick.''

title: BYRNE UPSTAGES PERSKIE
description: TRENTON ENVIRONMENTALISTS and pinelands supporters breathed an uneasy sigh of relief last week after Governor Byrne announced that he would not support a bill to alter the area's Comprehensive Management Plan and revise the powers of the Pinelands Commission.

title: HABIB REPORTEDLY HAS BROADER ROLE
description: President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, Philip C. Habib, continued his efforts to resolve the Syrian-Israeli missile crisis today as reports circulated here that his mission had been expanded to try to help resolve Lebanon's internal strife.

title: Dining Out; SKILLFULLY SPICES HUNAN FARE
description: WESTPORT AS recently as three years ago, there were few, if any, Hunanstyle Chinese restaurants in Connecticut. Since then, at least three or four have sprung up in Fairfield County alone. This peppery and oily style of Chinese cooking has caught on, as has its near neighbor Sichuan.

title: A SON REMEMBERS
description: JOSEPH CONRAD Times Remembered. By John Conrad. Illustrated. 218 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $19.95.

title: About Long Island
description: ROSLYN LOADED with 22 Reggie bars and a six-pack of Coke, our son went off to camp the other day. Apparently, you can't buy these essentials in New Hampshire.

title: Soviet Pipe Loans
description: Representatives of four major Japanese steel makers have failed to reach agreement with the Soviet Union over terms of a loan to buy 750,000 tons of large-diameter steel pipes, steel industry sources said. The Soviet side rejected a Japanese proposal to provide a five-year supplier credit with interest at 7.75 percent, demanding eight-year terms. The order would be worth about $400 million.

title: SAFETY AGENCY TO FORGO 'COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS'
description: Barred by a recent Supreme Court decision from weighing benefits against costs when protecting workers from health hazards, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration will instead use the most ''cost-effective'' regulations, according to the agency's director, Thorne G. Auchter.

title: THE HURT OF CUTBACKS IN FEDERAL SCHOOL AID
description: To the Editor:

title: SHORTER PULLS AWAY TO DEFEAT RODGERS IN 10,000-METER DUEL
description: Frank Shorter and Bill Rodgers, two of the best long-distance runners of the 1970's, battled head to head today for the first time in the 1980's, and Shorter came up the winner. He placed first in a 10,000-meter race that commemorated the 25th anniversary of The Times Herald-Record newspaper, finishing in 29 minutes 32.9 seconds and nearly 100 yards ahead of Rodgers.

title: Charles G. Meyer, 71; A Developer in Queens
description: Charles G. Meyer, former president of the Cord Meyer Company of New York and secretary of the Cord Meyer Development Company, which began developing Forest Hills, Queens, at the turn of the century, died Saturday after a long illness at the Hilaire Nursing Home in Huntington, L.I. Mr. Meyer, a resident of Locust Valley, L.I., was 71 years old.

title: MURRAY GROSS, VICE PRESIDENT OF GARMENT UNION, DIES AT 74
description: Murray Gross, a retired vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and a member of New York City's Human Rights Commission from 1962 through 1978, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74 years old.

title: May Revenues Up 10%
description: The May report from the Publishers Information Bureau, released by the Magazine Publishers Association, says that while ad pages were level, with May 1980 at 11,405, revenues rose 10 percent, to $297.8 million.

title: Donna Grey Is Married to Peter Gelb
description: The marriage of Donna Grey and Peter Gelb, assistant manager of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, took place at the home of Seiji Ozawa in West Stockbridge, Mass., yesterday. Rabbi Howard Kaplansky performed the ceremony.

title: C.I.A. VIEWS ON SOVIET OIL: RISKY
description: The Central Intelligence Agency apparently wants to believe - perhaps it needs to believe - that the Soviet Union will face a major oil crisis in the next 10 years.

title: OWNERS SEEM CLOSE TO THEIR FINAL POSITION
description: The owners' bargaining team, reacting to instructions to move faster in an attempt to settle the baseball strike, may be approaching its bargaining limit. If so, the end of the strike, which became 31 days old yesterday, could be far in the future.

title: Notes On People; Skipper Bids Farewell but Hopes to Return to Sea
description: She came ashore in Honolulu for a spell of shore duty yesterday but Lieut. Beverly Kelley said she was looking forward to a return to the sea soon.

title: Fifth Avenue Mile Is Proposed
description: The mile-run mania that is sweeping European track and field may spread to the United States later this year. Discussions about staging a major mile race along Fifth Avenue in New York City in late September were held here with top runners who competed in last night's Dulux Games at Bislett Stadium.

title: No Headline
description: For Nu-West Homes Ltd. and Ralph Scurfield, a schoolteacher turned carpenter, the days of building small houses in the Canadian prairie city of Calgary are long gone.

title: THE COST OF LOST HISTORY
description: Among all the arguments and negotiations keeping Poland in ferment, the issue of history is sometimes overlooked. But it is of central importance.

title: DANCE FESTIVAL: 5 DISPLAY EXPERIMENTAL WORKS
description: Anyone interested in knowing what some of our younger choreographers are up to would have found a visit yesterday to the American Dance Festival instructive.

title: F.D. Kittredge Jr. Weds Cynthia Briggs
description: Cynthia Jane Briggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor R. Briggs of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Frank Dutton Kittredge Jr., son of Mr. Kittredge of Darien, Conn., and Barbara Bradshaw Kittredge of Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. B. Whitman Dennison and the Rev. Edwin Cromey performed the ceremony at St Mary's Episcopal Church.

title: PRIME COMPUTER SANS FISHER
description: The jarring effect on the market after the resignation of a Prime Computer Inc. top executive was powerful, even for the surprise departure of someone widely regarded as an executive thoroughbred.

title: SOME USING FLOOD INSURANCE TO PAY SHARPLY HIGHER RATES
description: Property owners who build below high-water levels on barrier islands or in coastal zones likely to be affected by flooding will soon have to pay painfully higher rates for federally subsidized flood insurance.

title: POLAND'S PLIGHT ENGULFS AUSTRIAN REFUGEE CAMP
description: Jerzy Gruszecki, 28 years old, is an auto mechanic by trade, but the only work he does these days consists of sweeping the floor for an hour each afternoon in the cramped dormitory where he lives with his wife.

title: Virgin Islands Gets Charter
description: President Reagan has signed into law a resolution approving a constitution for the Virgin Islands, the White House has announced. Up until now, Mr. Reagan noted in a statement Friday, accomplishment of self government for Virgin Islanders was achieved by acts of the United States Congress.

title: Fibak Takes Final
description: Wotjek Fibak of Poland won nine of the first 10 games today and scored a 6-1, 7-6 victory over topseeded Yannick Noah of France in the final of the $174,500 Swiss Open tennis championship.

title: Red Smith Gentlemen, Shake Hands
description: BY some curious accident, Bowie Kuhn, the supreme being of baseball, and Ray Grebey, the one and only spokesman for the Player Relations Committee Inc., have never met. You would think it inevitable that they were acquainted, for Ray Grebey knows everything there is to know about the finances and labor relations of major league baseball and Bowie Kuhn knows everything Grebey knows, plus the approximate location of second base.

title: JOBLESS PAY ISSUE CAUSES HAWAII RIFT
description: A controversy involving whether unemployment benefits should be paid to about 5,000 state employees in Hawaii who went on strike two years ago has led to a Federal contempt citation for a state official.

title: RETAI SALES IN CITY RISE 11.7% IN JUNE
description: Sales by big retailers rose an average 11.7 percent in New York City last month from the comparable period a year earlier, the fourth consecutive month of double-digit increases, a spot-check found.

title: Palmer To the Pope
description: WHEN the British Open begins here Thursday at the Royal St. George's Golf Club, the BBC will televise it live throughout the United Kingdom from mid-morning to dusk each day, not merely on the weekend, when ABC will show it to American viewers. Several nations, including Australia, pick up the BBC feed by satellite each day. But when the BBC returns to its London studios for half an hour of noontime news, the video beam to Australia will be silent.

title: Erdos & Morgan Survey On Magazine Influence
description: For its client, the Standard Rate and Data Service, the research company, Erdos & Morgan, surveyed 2,000 advertisers and agency people to discover what influences their buying decisions in the magazine space area. Here is some of what it discovered:

title: The Region; Klansmen Make Quiet Appearance
description: About 15 hooded Ku Klux Klan members made a brief and peaceful recruitment appearance a day after Klansmen were pelted with rocks and bottles by protesters in neighboring Meriden.

title: MEETING TOMORROW ON TEXTILE PACT
description: Officials from textile importing and exporting countries will gather here Tuesday to discuss the future of an agreement that regulates most of the world's trade in textiles and apparel.

title: LIZ & CHUCK & DI & MEG & ANNIE & SYLVIA
description: My Aunt Sylvia was invited to the Royal wedding. Don't ask how or why - it's a long story involving her hairdresser. He knows someone... That someone made a couple of phone calls... And a week later, there's a fat invitation wadded into her mailbox. ''They don't need postage, Royalty. Just drop it in the box. Me, a half-hour last week at the post office.''

title: Wendy Nelson Bride Of Dr. Harley Rotbart
description: Wendy Lynn Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin J. Nelson of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Harley Aaron Rotbart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rotbart of Denver. Rabbi Lawrence Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center in White Plains.

title: SEAGRAM COUNTERS OFFER BY DU PONT TO ACQUIRE CONOCO
description: A multibillion-dollar takeover battle intensified yesterday as Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, the liquor company, moved to break up an agreement for the purchase of Conoco Inc., the nation's ninth-largest oil company, by E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.

title: SUMMARY OF MAJOR ACTIONS TAKEN BY NEW YORK LEGISLATURE IN 1981 SESSION
description: Following are some of the major actions of the New York State Legislature in its 1981 session, which recessed Friday night. Finance

title: The Region; Westchester Ends Jail Takeovers
description: Westchester County officials and inmates of the County Jail in Valhalla, N.Y., said yesterday that they had reached an agreement to end a series of takeovers and to handle prisoners' grievances.

title: HAAS POSTS 73-274 FOR 3-SHOT MILWAUKEE VICTORY
description: Jay Haas survived a double-bogey 6 on the last hole today and posted a one-over-par 73 to win the $250,000 Greater Milwaukee Open by three shots from Chi Chi Rodriguez.

title: Anthony Rosenzweig Weds Debra Weinstein
description: Debra F. Weinstein and Anthony Rosenzweig, who are medical students, were married yesterday in Great Barrington, Mass., at the home of the bride's father, Lloyd B. Weinstein. Rabbi Abraham Soltes performed the ceremony.

title: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: With the bases loaded and one out, a hard grounder is hit to the third baseman. He steps on the bag, forcing the man from second, and then throws home. The catcher misses the tag as the runner from third crosses the plate, but he quickly throws to first to nip the batter for the third out. Does the run count or is it an inning-ending double play?

title: HOUSEHOLD TO ACQUIRE COAST BANK
description: The Household Finance Corporation announced on Friday that it intended to acquire a bank in California by taking advantage of a loophole in Federal law. Through the bank, Valley National of Salinas, the finance company could establish a deposit-taking banking operation throughout the state.

title: NEW YORK PHONE, CITY ISSUES DUE
description: New-issue activity in the corporate bond market is expected to pick up this week, with some investment bankers estimating that more than $1 billion could be marketed.

title: Still No Mother Bomb
description: American society has been sitting on a potential time bomb for 15 or 20 years; now there is new reason to think that it will not explode.

title: The City; Price of Gas Falls 3d Straight Month
description: The average New York City retail price of gasoline fell for the third month in a row, going to $1.472 a gallon during the last week in June, a 1-cent drop from May.

title: STAGE: PLUMMER PLAYS HENRY VAT STRATFORD
description: setting prologue. When this actor strides out to the stage's apron to bid us ''gently to hear, kindly to judge'' the play, his rich baritone caresses the farthest reaches of the theater. Mr. Plummer doesn't so much project the verse as let it fly out - on wings of kindness and nobility that are at one with Shakespeare.

title: The City; A Welfare Inquiry On Lotto Winner
description: The New York City Department of Social Services says it will try to recover welfare benefits paid to a woman who won a $2.8 million Lotto jackpot. A spokesman for the city agency said the law allows the department to recover welfare payments when a recipient comes into money.

title: 500 Million TV Viewers To See Royal Nuptials
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation said today it expected at least 500 million viewers around the world to watch its television coverage of the wedding of Prince Charles, the Prince of Wales, and Lady Diana Spencer.

title: Banner Gala Wins
description: Banner Gala overcame a stumble at the start yesterday and scored a six-length victory in the $54,800 Garden City Stakes on the inner grass course at Belmont Park.

title: TV REPORT SUGGESTS SOVIET WILL AWAIT POLISH OUTCOME
description: The Soviet Union, in a television report from Warsaw broadcast here last night, has offered the clearest indication yet that it has decided to await the outcome of this week's emergency congress of the Polish Communist Party before deciding whether to make a new effort to halt the movement toward political liberalization in Poland.

title: The City; Goldin Suggests Transit Reports
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin announced plans to ask the Board of Estimate ''to take a major and active role in monitoring mass transit.''

title: Newfoundland Plant Studied
description: Petro-Canada, Canada's state-owned energy company, and Gulf Canada are considering using oil and natural gas from East Coast offshore areas and the Arctic for a petrochemical plant in eastern Canada, Petro-Canada said.

title: Marilyn Lasser Married
description: Marilyn L. Lasser, daughter of Mrs. Arnold A. Lasser of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Lasser, was married yesterday to James D. Nuber, son of Mrs. Donald Nuber of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late Mr. Nuber. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Suzanne Volkman, Editor, Is Wed to Edward Skloot
description: Suzanne Volkman, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Samuel Volkman of Washington, was married yesterday to Edward Skloot, son of Martha Skloot of New York and the late George J. Skloot. The ceremony was performed at the Central Synagogue by the bride's father, who was assisted by Rabbi Deborah Prinz.

title: MICHAEL SPINKS IS UNDER PRESSURE
description: In the mornings, there was this hill by the Concord Hotel golf course he called Death. In the steamy afternoons, there were the brutal sparring sessions. But for Michael Spinks, the nights were worst of all.

title: Sports World Specials; Business Decision
description: After 20 years of hockey in peewee leagues, at the University of Notre Dame, in the minor leagues and with the Montreal Canadiens, it is time for Bill Nyrop to make a decision. He will become 29 years old a week from Thursday, an age when most professional hockey players must start to think about leaving the game and dealing with the real world. Nyrop must make that decision in reverse. He has already left. Now he is thinking about coming back.

title: Follower of Charles Manson Is Denied Parole for Murders
description: A parole board has refused to release Patricia Krenwinkel, a follower of Charles M. Manson, from prison, saying she was still a danger to society and had never shown remorse for the murders in which she took part.

title: Liebler Wins
description: Steve Liebler of Portsmouth shot a two-under-par 70 today over his home course, the Elizabeth Manor Golf and Country Club, and won the Eastern Amateur golf tournament by three strokes.

title: PALMER IN PLAYOFF WITH CASPER, STONE
description: Billy Casper sank an eight-foot putt for a par on the 18th hole today and created a three-way tie with Arnold Palmer and Bob Stone and an 18-hole playoff tomorrow for the United States Senior Open golf title.

title: OIL BUYERS TAKE A NEW TACK
description: The talks went on for weeks, over the phone, on the telex and across bargaining tables in New York, Lagos, London and Tripoli. There was fist-thumping and threat-making, and bluffing that would have put a poker champion to shame. At least one man lost his job. More than a few established business partnerships broke up in frustration.

title: 2 Die in Genoa Tanker Blast
description: A lightning bolt touched off an explosion today aboard an empty Japanese oil tanker docked in this northern Italian port. The police said that two people were killed and that four were missing.

title: POWER RESTORED TO 39,000
description: Power was restored before dawn yesterday to 39,000 customers on eastern Staten Island who were without electricity following an explosion and fire in a Consolidated Edison power substation late Saturday.

title: Companies
description: Seagram raised its bid for Conoco to $3.8 billion in cash for 51 percent of the oil company's stock. The bid is designed to top Du Pont's offer of $7.3 billion for all of Conoco, with only $3.1 billion in cash and the rest in Du Pont shares. (Page A1.)

title: Michael James Is Dead; Foreign Correspondent
description: Michael James, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times who covered the Korean War and other major events in Asia in the 1950's, died yesterday at a Veterans Administration hospital in San Diego where he had been treated for cancer. He was 59 years old.

title: MCENROE WINS, CLINCHING SERIES
description: John McEnroe, who opened the Davis Cup round against Czechoslovakia with a loss to Ivan Lendl, moved the United States into the semifinals yesterday with a convincing victory over Tomas Smid.

title: WHEN THE CHILDREN ARE IN SUMMER CAMP
description: They eat dinner at unconventional hours or they don't eat dinner at all. They go to movies on a whim with no concern for hiring a babysitter; they leisurely tour museums, lingering before one painting if they wish; they listen to chamber music instead of rock, and they regain possession of the telephone. They even talk to one another in a different way.

title: What Next to Relieve 911?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kriek Beats Pfister In Newport Final
description: Second-seeded Johan Kriek defeated Hank Pfister, 3-6, 6-3, 7-5, today to win the $100,000 Miller Hall of Fame Tennis Championships.

title: Around the Nation; 8 Are Exposed to PCB Spilled in Alaska Village
description: About 200 to 300 gallons of PCB, a toxic chemical believed to be a cause of cancer, has been spilled in the isolated village of Kake in southeastern Alaska. The authorities said that eight men and possibly some children had been exposed.

title: Down the Buttery Slope
description: Available now: 426 million pounds of butter, at 50 cents a pound below cost.

title: TEACHERS TRY TO LEARN HOW TO COPE WITH JOB'S STRESS
description: The lights had been dimmed and several dozen men and women sat in silence, their eyes closed as they concentrated on their breathing and tried to feel tension draining from parts of their bodies.

title: ALAN PATON, AT 78, STILL GOADS HIS BELOVED COUNTRY
description: Suddenly Alan Paton is 78 years old. The fact occasions surprise, since his voice has not been trailing off in South Africa. A well-turned Paton polemic, mixing moral reflection and salty advice to white politicians and others who seem ill disposed to heed it, is still apt to show up in the local press, injecting a little incandescence into gray columns of ritualistic debate.

title: MCCLOSKEY DEFENDS REMARKS ON SUCCESS OF JEWISH LOBBYING
description: Despite criticism from Jewish leaders, Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, says he will stand by his remark that American Jews had a ''tendency'' to ''control the actions of Congress.''

title: Around the World; To Resist 'Despotism'
description: Iran's deposed President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, has urged his countrymen to resist ''despotism'' and pledged to make a comeback, a Turkish newspaper reported today.

title: Commodities; Trading Of Futures In C.D.'s
description: FEW futures markets have been born amid so loud a chorus of maledictions as the new domestic bank certificates of deposit that went into operation on the New York Futures Exchange last Thursday. But in the case of the N.Y.F.E., the detractors were potential competitors -namely, the huge Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange - which plan to start C.D. futures markets of their own, and not the voices of hedgers and speculators.

title: FIRST OIL RIG OFF CAPE COD IN POSITION:
description: The Zapata Saratoga, a Shell Oil Company exploratory oil rig, in position on Georges Bank, about 150 miles southeast of Nantucket, Mass. A month ago, the state approved oil and natural gas exploration in that area and said drilling could begin in August. Exxon, Getty, Mobil and Shell have already applied for drilling permits.

title: MISS AUSTIN WINS BY 4
description: Debbie Austin made three bogeys on the front side of her final round and another on the 11th hole, but managed a four-stroke victory today over Hollis Stacy and Myra Van Hoose in the $150,000 Mayflower Classic.

title: Renee Brandner Bride Of Steven M. Davidson
description: The marriage of Renee Adrienne Brandner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Brandner of Stamford, Conn., to Steven Mark Davidson took place yesterday at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Davidson of Old Bethpage, L.I. Rabbi Alex Goldman performed the ceremony.

title: SALVADRAN BISHOP ACCUSES ARMY OF SLAYING AT LEAST 27 CIVILIANS
description: Msgr. Arturo Rivera Damas, the senior church official in El Salvador, charged the Salavdoran Army today with having murdered at least 27 civilians during the last week.

title: CITY ENDURES HEAT FOR 16TH DAY
description: New York City was enveloped in 90-degree heat for its sixth consecutive day yesterday, with no relief expected for today. From the northern Bronx to the southern rim of Staten Island, backyard hoses, cooling showers, pitchers of lemonade and hundreds of illicitly opened fire hydrants helped consume 1.58 billion gallons of water over the 24 hours that ended yesterday morning.

title: COSMOS TURN BACK GLASGOW CELTIC, 2-0
description: Julio Cesar Romero and Jeff Durgan scored the goals as the Cosmos defeated Glasgow Celtic, 2-0, before a crowd of 29,215 at Giants Stadium tonight in the first round of the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup tournament.

title: Hamlet, With Suds
description: The Public Broadcasting System takes great pride in the fact that it is noncommercial, a demilitarized zone on a strident marketing battlefield. But as public subsidies decline, even purists are wavering on the question of whether it should seek advertising. An experiment with commercial messages has now been proposed to ease the fiscal pressure. It is a sensible suggestion.

title: SEATTLE CLERGY SUPPORT TAX PROTEST AGAINST NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: A group of religious leaders in Washington, inspired by a Roman Catholic archbishop, is supporting the refusal to pay Federal income tax to protest Government spending on nuclear arms.

title: ADOLPH KATZ
description: Adolph Katz, a real-estate owner and manager who bought and sold dozens of apartments and hotels on the West Side, died Friday on a visit to Tel Aviv. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Safety Council Says Men Run Higher Risk of Car Accidents
description: Men are twice as likely as women to be involved in fatal car accidents because they drive in riskier situations, according to the National Safety Council.

title: EXONERATION OF CALVIN COOLIDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Started
description: For a $5 membership in the United States Board Sailing Association, one receives a newsletter and a schedule of regattas across the country. The association, which is sanctioned by the International Board Sailing Association, also provides information on the different types of sailboards available, sailboard dealers and sailing schools.

title: Notes On People; Captain Kangaroo Suffers a Heart Attack
description: Robert Keeshan, who has been television's ''Captain Kangaroo'' to millions of children, was described as ''stable'' in the coronarycare unit of Etobicone Hospital in Rexdale, a suburb of Toronto.

title: BUT CAN HOLLYWOOD LIVE WITHOUT GEORGE LUCAS
description: LOS ANGELES DAY by day, month by month, George Lucas has been cutting the ropes that bind him to Hollywood. Ironically, the creator of such quintessentially Hollywood entertainments as ''Star Wars'' and ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' has always been painfully ill at ease among the deal-makers in three-piece suits and sharks in designer blue jeans who muscle their way to success in the movie industry. ''A foreign country,'' he has called Hollywood. And now he has gone home for good.

title: U.S. ACTS IN PHILADELPHIA SQUATTERS CASE
description: Squatters illegally occupying 67 federally owned houses here won a promise this week from Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Samuel R. Pierce that the Government would help them find somewhere else to live if they leave the houses by Sept. 18. If they do not leave, Mr. Pierce said, they will be evicted.

title: BEGIN EQUATES RAIDS ON IRAQ AND ENTEBBE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin today compared the June 7 attack on Iraq's Osirak nuclear reactor to the Isreali mission that recued more than 100 hostages in Entebbe, Uganda, on July 4, 1976. Mr. Begin, who said that both were "rescue operations," drew the parallel at a ceremony commemorating the fifth anniversary of the death of Lieut. Col. Yehonatan Netanyah,the commander of the Entebbe raid.

title: WOMEN ASSAIL WHITE HOUSE'S HIRING
description: President Reagan's announcement that he intends to nominate Judge Sandra Day O'Connor as the first woman to serve on the Supreme Court has focused renewed attention on the Administration's record in appointing women to high Government positions.

title: DRUNK DRIVERS BEWARE!
description: To the Editor:

title: CAIRO IS SWELTERING THROUGH THE MONTH OF THE FAST
description: Late on the first night of the month, a group of sheiks in Saudi Arabia spotted the faint crescent sliver of the new moon and declared that the holy month of Ramadan had begun.

title: Around the World; 5 Pakistanis Said to Die In Clash With Indians
description: Five Pakistani soldiers were reported killed today in the third border clash in a week with Indian troops in the disputed northern state of Kashmir.

title: CABARET: TEMPTATIONS
description: EVEN though they haven't had a major hit in years, the Temptations, who played two shows at the Savoy on Friday, remain one of America's premier black vocal groups. With four lead singers of differing timbre anchored by the rich bass-baritone of Melvin Franklin, this Motown quintet is as adept at the harder pop-funk modes that dominate today's black music as it is at the precise doo-wop harmonies that gave it its first hits.

title: Flooded Ship Docks Safely
description: A 550-foot Peruvian cargo ship that was flooded with 12 feet of water docked safely in San Francisco Bay today.

title: WORRISOME SLUMP IN OPTIONS TRADING
description: The big trading floor of the Chicago Board Options Exchange has become legendary for a hectic pace that has grown more raucous each year. But something unusual is happening this summer. Congestion has eased considerably and the runners are noticebly less frantic.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chemical Bank has named Raymond T. Downey a vice president.

title: Self Control
description: There is never a shortage of volunteers, Hidy Ochiai said, when he wants to perform his demonstration of concentration technique. When Ochiai lectured at the Washin-ryu Karate Club on Worth Street in lower Manhattan on Saturday, he included ''one of my favorite techniques to do.''

title: CENSUS BUREAU, LACKING A DIRECTOR, SEEKS A DIRECTION
description: Six months ago the Census Bureau, having weathered a controversy over its competence to count people, was riding a wave of self-assurance in the belief that it had conducted the most thorough dicennial enumeration in the nation's history.

title: FOUR AGREE TO REPAY PYRAMID LOSERS
description: An investigation into pyramid games by the New York State Attorney General's office has ended with the conviction of three persons and an agreement by them and one other to reimburse losers.

title: The City; Cooke Criticizes TV Programming
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke exhorted New York's Roman Catholics yesterday to pressure television stations and networks to discontinue ''destructive television programming.'' In a letter read in the archdiocese's more than 400 parishes, the Cardinal denounced the ''distorted sexuality'' and violence on TV.

title: PARIS-BONN TALKS FOCUS ON SECURITY Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany began a two-day conference here today by agreeing that Western Europe should negotiate with the Soviet Union from a position of military strength, spokesmen said.

title: MUSIC: WATERLOO GROUP GIVES STRAUSS-HOFMANNSTHAL CURIO
description: ASIDE from their highly successful operas, Strauss and Hofmannsthal collaborated on several projects that look quite bizarre on paper and most of them understandably never got past the talking stage. One that did was an arrangement of Beethoven's ''Ruins of Athens,'' a curio that was quickly shelved and forgotten after its 1924 premiere in Vienna failed to impress. Apparently something about this oddity appeals to Gerard Schwarz, for the conductor has unearthed the work and Saturday night he conducted a concert version at the Waterloo Festival in Stanhope N.J.

title: PRESIDENT IS NAMED BY PITTSON
description: Hendrik J. Hartong Jr., executive vice president of the Pittston Company, last week was named president, chief operating officer and a director of the diversified corporation, which has more than $1.3 billion in assets. As president he succeeds Nicholas T. Camicia, 65, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: JAN STEPHENSON TESTS NEW IMAGE ON WOMEN'S GOLF
description: INDIANAPOLIS STANDING behind the thin yellow rope on the ninth green at the Country Club of Indianapolis last Wednesday, the gallery in the brilliant sunshine shaded their eyes and followed Jan Stephenson as she approached in a pro-am group. This was the day before the Mayflower Classic, and the curious wanted to see her as much as watch her play golf.

title: Index; International
description: Alan Paton, at 78, still goads his beloved country A2 Sixth hunger striker dies in Bel- fast prison A2 South Africans raid black guer- rilla bases inside Angola A2 Salvadoran church official ac- cuses army of 27 murders A3 Cairo is sweltering in the month of the fast A4 Around the World A5 Brandt visit to Moscow troubles Schmidt and NATO A6 Moscow it awaits outcome of Pol- ish congress A7 Four names are on list of candi- ates for Polish congress A7 Growing number of Poles seeking asylum in West A7 Possible delay in approval of for- eign aid bill causes concern A7 Government/Politics U.S. attempts to deal with urban home squatters in Philadelphia A9 Census Bureau in disarray, no di- rector A10 Reagan Administration's record in hiring women criticized A11 Congress gearing up to restrain regulators A11 Women's Political Caucus meet- ing ends A16 Comment by Rep. Pete McClos- key irks Jews A16 City renegotiating with Brooklyn Army Terminal developer B3 General Around the Nation A8 Disappearance of couple leads to a murder charge A9 First of 2 new water pipelines in Newark's aqueduct finished B1 The Region B2 Four agree to repay New York pyramid game losers B3 The City B3 SportsMonday Baseball: Parties in strike may find further concessions hard C1 Basketball: 76ers' new owner ar- rested in 1973 fraud, paper says C5 Boxing: Michael Spinks looks up, not back C6 Columns: Dave Anderson on Mark McCormack C4

title: Washington Watch; A Squeeze on Arms Makers
description: WASHINGTON DEFENSE procurement officers and now members of Congress are becoming increasingly worried about the financial pincers tightening around small business and the impact of this squeeze on the mammoth arms buildup being planned by the Reagan Administration.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JULY 13, 1981
description: International Moves to punish rioters in Britain have been tentatively agreed upon by the Government, which, however, will investigate the underlying causes of the riots that in the last 10 days have scarred more than 30 English cities and towns. Political sources said the Cabinet would meet today. Among the measures already given provisional approval are the establishment of special courts with increased powers, legislation to make parents financially liable for their childrens' acts, and a youth employment program costing millions of pounds. (Page A1, Col. 1.) Need for a stronger Western Europe was agreed upon at the opening of a two-day meeting in Bonn between West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and President Francois Mitterrand of France. Spokesmen for both sides said it was agreed that Western Europe should deal with the Soviet Union from a position of military strength. (A1:2.)

title: REAGAN'S MILITARY STRATEGISTS PLAN EXPANDED CRUISE MISSILE PROGRAM
description: Military strategists in the Reagan Administration foresee a greatly expanded mission for cruise missiles, especially those launched at sea, and are working on a plan for a sevenfold increase in the deployment of such seaborne missiles by 1987.

title: The U.N. Today; July 13, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: International Conference on Cambo- dia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NIGERIAN OIL COULD FILL A U.S. NEED
description: To the Editor:

title: Ronnie Zeitlin, a Lawyer, Is the Bride of Lloyd Siegel
description: Ronnie Zeitlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zeitlin of North Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday at the Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Center in East Rockaway, L.I. to Lloyd Siegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Siegel of South Euclid, Ohio.

title: Notes On People; Margaret Going Home
description: Princess Margaret of Britain, and her daughter, Lady Sarah Armstrong-Jones, return to London today after winding up a weeklong visit to Canada with a quiet weekend at the cottage of Ontario's Lieutenant Governor, John Aird, in the resort village of Port Carling, Ontario.

title: CITY IS RENEGOTIATING LEASE ON ARMY TERMINAL'S LAND
description: The Koch administration is negotiating new financial terms with the developer it selected to renovate the Brooklyn Army Terminal - 100 acres of federally owned land that is to be become city property at a long-anticipated ceremony on the waterfront today.

title: REV. FRANCIS T. M'GOUGH
description: The Rev. Francis Timothy McGough, assistant pastor of the Good Shepherd Church in the Inwood section of Manhattan, died last Tuesday at the parish house after an extended illness.

title: AMAX OF CANADA HEAD
description: James H. Foreman, former senior vice president in Amax Inc.'s molybdenum division, has been named president of Amax of Canada Ltd., a mining subsidiary of Amax Inc., the diversified natural resource company that had a net income of $470 million on sales of almost $2.95 billion last year.

title: China Beer Drinkers Face a Long Summer; CHINA BEER DRINKERS FACE A LONG SUMMER
description: The annual summer beer shortage has struck China. The Friendship Store, which supplies foreigners with their daily needs, has run out of the Tsingtao and Peking brands of beer, the two that it normally carries.

title: CAUCUS QUESTIONS BUDGET PRIORITIES
description: The National Women's Political Caucus today attacked President Reagan's budget, cheered a critic who said the proposed tax reduction was unfair to women, and elected as its chairman a Republican who said Mr. Reagan was ''full of jelly beans'' for saying he favored equal rights but not the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: Around the World; Cuban Exile Leader Hopes to Topple Castro
description: The leader of an organization of Cuban exiles says he is undeterred by the capture of a group that intended to assassinate President Fidel Castro.

title: AS THE WHALE SLAUGHTER GOES ON AND ON
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Bethe and Pollack Survive To Finals of the Big Apple
description: Teams led by Henry Bethe and Bill Pollack met last night in the finals of the Big Apple Regional Knockout team championship in the New York Hilton Hotel, after defeating their fellow New Yorkers in the semifinals yesterday afternoon.

title: Bloodhound Best At Vermont Show
description: A bloodhound, Ch. Serendipity's Nick Chopper, owned by 17-year-old Kenneth Sexton of Springfield, Pa., was gaited by Vic Capone today to the best-in-show award in a field of 1,392 dogs at the Green Mountain Dog Club's 30th annual show.

title: FOR CHILDREN OF MIGRANTS, A HARVEST OF LANGUAGE
description: Each morning of midsummer, as Antonio Aguilar kneels in trays of manure to pick mushrooms, his 8-year-old daughter, Mayre, boards the bus for Pioneer School here.

title: News Analysis
description: When the 204th session of the New York State Legislature was not delaying something, it accomplished quite a bit. But it spent most of its six months putting off issues it had intended to face, or extending laws that many lawmakers believed were in need of reform.

title: Bellino and Son
description: Joe Bellino enjoys managing a wallpaper business in Verona, N.J. But still, how many times do you get a chance to buy a professional baseball team, with a dugout you can sit in alongside your son?

title: AN OFFERING OF PRAYERS BY THE BAY Hummel
description: At 8:30 this morning, the Rev. Frederick W. Hummel of the Mattituck Presbyterian Church called the worship service to order. Twenty participants sat in a circle on the front porch of the Marratooka Club, a private beach club that overlooks Great Peconic Bay. A feathery breeze caused barely a ripple in the water and, except for a distant powerboat and a lone, crying gull, there was an expectant hush as Mr. Hummel began with a prayer.

title: Around the World; Police Disperse Squatters In West Berlin Protest
description: The police used tear gas and night sticks today to disperse about 5,000 squatters and their sympathizers who rampaged through a fashionable suburb.

title: REPORTS ON HOSTAGE DEAL FINDS NO BANK DECEIT
description: Carter Administration officials appeared more concerned with protecting American banks than American contractors in their handling of the hostage negotiations with Iran, Fernand J. St Germain, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said today in releasing a 61-page staff report.

title: Sanchez Is Sharp In Tuneup Bout
description: Salvador Sanchez of Mexico City, the World Boxing Council featherweight champion, tuned up for his showdown with Wilfredo Gomez, the World Boxing Association champion, with a 10-round unanimous decision over Nicki Perez last night.

title: SUPPORTERS OF REGULATORY REFORM MOVING TO TRIM AGENCIES' POWERS
description: President Reagan's proposal to restrict the power of Federal regulatory agencies and ease the impact of regulations on many aspects of the nation's life has gained momentum in Congress.

title: IN SALVADOR, A U.S.-TRAINED UNIT AT WAR
description: An elite Salvadoran Army unit trained by United States military advisers is engaged in a major operation in the mountains surrounding this isolated village about 42 miles northeast of the capital.

title: Pelham Bissell 3d Dies; City Judge for 30 Years
description: Pelham St. George Bissell 3d, a New York City judge for 30 years who had long been active in the Society of Mayflower Descendants and other American heritage societies, died Saturday of leukemia at the Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 68 years old and lived on the East Side.

title: Marathon to Jones
description: Hugh Jones, a 25-year-old graduate in city planning from Liverpool University, overcame heat, humidity and a thunderstorm today and won the first Oslo Marathon in 2 hours 13 minutes 6 seconds.

title: Kentucky Post for Allen?
description: Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. has conceded he would like to see George Allen, the former coach in the National Football League, replace Fran Curci as coach at the University of Kentucky.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Various Views Of Coca-Cola
description: AVE a Coke and a smile.'' So runs a current advertising theme for the Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft drink company and a recurring investment favorite on Wall Street. But some brokerage houses are restraining their enthusiasm this hot summer as far as Coke's stock is concerned.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE GREAT ALL-TIME BASEBALL RECORD BOOK. By Joseph L. Rei- chler. 544 pages. Illustrated. Macmil- lan. $19.95.

title: Sweet Thoughts
description: Rick Sweet is not a millionaire. He is a catcher, and a first baseman, and a third baseman, and anything else that will help interest a major league team in his services. He is not worried about the compensation that would be required from the team he joins, because he knows he will not reach that economic stratosphere. Sweet is being paid during the strike because he is playing for Tidewater, the Mets' top farm team. For a former National League catcher, there are better places to be than the International League.

title: Senator Assails Army For Manual on Sauce
description: Senator William Proxmire ridiculed the Army yesterday for spending $6,@000 on 17 pages of instructions on buying Worcestershire sauce.

title: MORE UNPAID MASSACHUSETTS WORKERS MAY STRIKE
description: By 6 A.M. tomorrow, one-fifth of the Massachusetts National Guard, men and women who would normally spend the day in civilian jobs, will be in uniform, replacing the state employees who have been off their jobs at 25 mental health institutions since Friday.

title: SANITATION CHIEF DEMOTES OFFICERS
description: Charging corruption and inefficiency in the enforcement of New York City's sanitation laws, the Sanitation Commissioner has demoted all 17 Lieutenants and sergeants in his department's armed 124-man police force.

title: GERMANS ASK TO BYPASS BRECHT HEIRS
description: Twenty-five years after the death of Bertolt Brecht, a group of West German theatrical directors and performers has called on the East Berlin Academy of Arts to place the playwright's works in a national trust and strip the legal heirs of some of their rights.

title: Elaine Friedman and Alvin Fried, Dentists, Wed
description: The marriage of Dr. Elaine Carol Friedman and Dr. Alvin Donald Fried, who are dentists, took place yesterday at the Temple Gates of Prayer in Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Albert Thaler performed the ceremony.

title: N.Y.R.A. Tracks Bar Saumell, a Jockey
description: Larry Saumell, a 34-year-old jockey, was denied access to Belmont Park, Aqueduct and Saratoga, effective yesterday, for possessing a battery device before the start of the second race at Belmont Park June 22.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MOZART ON THE HOUSE Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival returns for its 15th season today, and the first order of business will be the New York premiere of a piece written by Mozart when he was 9 years old. The work, Symphony in F, will be performed by the 40-piece Mostly Mozart Orchestra under the direction of Leonard Slatkin, direct from its out-of-town tryout at the White House and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington last week.

title: U.S. Swimmers Take 4 Golds
description: American swimmers swept four gold medals with record times today at the 11th Maccabiah Games. Mike Saphir of Los Angeles broke the Maccabiah record of 4 minutes 39.31 seconds in winning the 400-meter individual medley in 4:38.36.

title: MYSTERY ON PACIFIC ATOLL LEADS TO MURDER CHARGE
description: A murder trial scheduled to begin in Federal Court here this fall will center on the disappearance of a San Diego couple who were swept up in the romance of cruising under sail in the South Pacific.

title: A.T.&T. Asks Suit Dismissal
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has asked a Federal judge to dismiss the Government's antitrust suit that seeks to break up the world's largest company. A.T.& T. contends that the Government has not proved any unlawful conduct.

title: THATCHER CABINET WORKING ON PLANS TO CURB DISORDERS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government has tentatively decided upon a package of measures designed to punish rioters and to deal with the underlying causes of 10 consecutive days of urban violence, political sources reported tonight.

title: ISRAEL AGAIN BOMBS PALESTINIAN TARGETS IN SOUTH OF LEBANON
description: In the second air strike on Lebanon in three days, Israeli planes bombed Palestinian targets today along the southern Lebanese coast for more than an hour and a half. At least 25 people were believed killed or wounded.

title: BOARDSAILING IS IN THE RACE FOR ATTENTION
description: DURING some heavy weather at the recent Block Island Race Week, Ray Yturraspe was struggling to winch in the jib sheet on the 40-foot sloop. Grind, grind, grind. Then he looked up and saw a sailboard whiz by. Ken Winner, a world champion board sailor, was just getting in from heavy air practice.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Magazine Age, a trade publication that covers the advertising side of the magazine business, is out with its first special issue. The First Annual Buyer's Guide to Consumer Magazines, which comes out with the July issue, will supply decision-makers with information on magazines' gross ad revenues and circulations 1978 through 1980, the top ad categories of each and how many pages of each were carried.

title: SIXTH I.R.A. HUNGER STRIKER DIES
description: Martin Hurson, a member of the Irish Republican Army, died early today in Maze Prison on the 45th day of his fast, Britain's Northern Ireland office said. He was the sixth Irish nationalist prisoner to die in a bid for political prisoner status.

title: Toback/LGFE
description: Just because there are only eight people in the Toback/LGFE unit at Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, there's no reason for it not to have both a chairman and president. So Harvard Toback, former president, takes the chair and Hobert Henklein moves in as president. And for good measure Robert Higbee becomes creative director.

title: Alban Wins Stage Of Tour de France
description: Robert Alban of France won the 18th stage of the Tour de France cycling race today by finishing a 123-mile course through the Alps in 6 hours 14 minutes 29 seconds.

title: THERAPY THAT AIDS PARENTS
description: ''I T is profoundly and sadly true that children tend to become just what their parents consciously or unconsciously wanted them to become,'' said Howard Kogan, a Manhattan therapist.''For this reason,'' he added, ''knowing oneself well is surely one of the better defenses against - as the slang goes - laying your trip on your kid.''

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Announced that Bobby Butler, defensive back from Flor- ida State and the team's No. 1 selection in the collegiate draft, has agreed to contract terms.

title: SOME ON COAST LEAVE HOME TO ESCAPE FRUIT-FLY SPRAY vegetables
description: Some Santa Clara valley residents were preparing today to leave their homes and the Red Cross was setting up shelters for people who want to avoid the pesticide malathion. It is to be sprayed from helicopters early Tuesday in the state's battle against a destructive fruit fly.

title: Weeklong Music Series At Downtown Plaza
description: A week of free outdoor music featuring jazz, Dixieland, salsa and big-band pieces will begin July 27 at noon with Tone Kwas and His Orchestra at 1 New York Plaza, at Water and Broad Streets.

title: Robin Kase Wed To Dr. S.H. Weiss
description: Robin Joanna Kase, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Neil Kase of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday in the North Country Reform Temple in Glen Cove, L.I., to Dr. Stanley Herbert Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Weiss of Brooklyn. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz of the Hillcrest Jewish Center, who officiated at the wedding of the bride's parents 30 years ago, performed the ceremony.

title: A HOT STAFF COOLS CARS OF L. I.R.R.
description: Inside the Long Island Rail Road's Dunton repair shop in Jamaica, Queens, it was much hotter than 90 degrees yesterday. When Donald McMillin went down into a crawl space underneath the cars to pump out refrigerant, he was greeted, over and over again, with blasts of 135-degree air.

title: Around the Nation; Hollywood Gang Unit Reports Limited Success
description: Members of an anti-gang police unit expressed frustration after their second night of patrolling Hollywood streets.

title: MOBIL INCREASING NEW YORK PRICES BECAUSE OF TAXES
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it had increased its prices for gasoline, diesel fuel and jet fuel in New York State by 3 cents a gallon because of new state taxes levied on oil companies in legislation signed on Saturday.

title: CANDIDATES LISTED FOR POLISH CONGRESS
description: A list of four candidates for party leader, each representing a different faction in Poland's Communist Party, has been drawn up for delegates to vote upon on the first day of the special emergency congress Tuesday, reliable party sources said today.

title: Idaho Range Fire Controlled
