description: A 14,000-acre range fire started by lightning near this southeastern Idaho community has been brought under control by firefighters, officials said today.

title: Teresa M. Hennelly Is Married to Stephen Baldwin
description: Teresa Marya Hennelly and Stephen Carl Baldwin were married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. John B. MacNab, the minister, performed the ceremony.

title: POTENTIAL GRAVEDIGGERS FOR THE BIG APPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: WRITERS TO VOTE TOMORROW ON PACT
description: Motion-picture and television writers will vote Tuesday on a tentative contract to end their 13-week-old strike.

title: NEW 76ER OWNER WAS TIED TO FRAUD
description: The new owner of the Philadelphia 76ers was involved in a Florida fraud case that resulted in his arrest in 1973, a published report said today.

title: Kathy L. Howard Married On L.I. to Mitchell Jacobson
description: At Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday, Kathy Lynn Howard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Howard, was married to Mitchell Lawrence Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Jacobson.

title: SIMMS AND TODD: A YEAR OF DECESION
description: IF a movie producer needed a quarterback, Central Casting would have invented Phil Simms. Start with a handsome, blue-eyed young man - 24 years old, 6 feet 3 inches tall and 216 pounds. Family? How about a wife named Diana who reassures everyone in the neighborhood Grand Union after her husband's team loses? How about a 10-month-old son named Christopher David as blond as his parents?

title: Lancias Finish 1, 2 And Retain Title
description: Italian-made Lancias finished first and second today in a six-hour endurance race for sports cars at the Watkins Glen road course, giving Lancia the world endurance championship for the second year in a row.

title: Prefontaine Run Won by Mascali
description: Paul Mascali, a former St. John's University distance runner now representing the Athletic Attic of Brooklyn, won the fifth annual Steve Prefontaine Memorial 5-kilometer run in 15 minutes 36.9 seconds yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: EPHRAIM BODINE
description: Ephraim Bodine, head of the Bodine Automobile Supply Company on Staten Island and long active in the borough's social and philanthropic organizations, died Saturday at his home in West Brighton, S.I. He was 70 years old.

title: BONDS MAY BECOME MORE ATTRACTIVE
description: Since mid-June, when yields for long-term Treasury bonds began climbing from 12.55 percent to almost 13.5 percent last week, many market analysts have been saying that a decline in short-term interest rates was the key ingredient needed to revive investor demand for bonds.

title: Texaco Unit Sets Gas Sales
description: Texaco Canada announced that its wholly owned subsidiary, Texaco Canada Resources, planned new natural gas sales of up to 30 million cubic feet a day by 1983 to Progas, a Calgary, Alberta, distributor of natural gas to United States customers.

title: SON IS HELD
description: William A. Keeler, president of the Arco Oil and Gas Company, and his wife were shot to death today at the family's home in North Dallas.

title: The City; G.E. to Clean Up Waste at Dumps
description: ALBANY (AP) - The State Department of Environmental Conservation has condemned 91 acres of land at four hazardous-waste dumps in the Upper Hudson Valley, to help the General Electric Company clean up industrial wastes accumulated over decades.

title: BRANDT'S SOVIET VISIT TROUBLES SCHMIDT AND NATO
description: Willy Brandt's recent visit with Leonid I. Brezhnev in Moscow has created, as expected, certain problems for the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and, a bit surprisingly, some new difficulties for NATO that the Atlantic alliance might have done without.

title: Notes On People; Birthday Is Fun for 105-Year-Old Artist
description: They threw a birthday party yesterday at the Salmagundi Club on lower Fifth Avenue and out came a cake with five candles. ''This is your fifth birthday - of your second century,'' said Carl Thomson, the president of the nation's oldest professional art club, as he moved the cake closer to the frail little man with a great shock of white hair and a bushy white goatee.

title: Film Makers' Magazine, Moving Image, Planned
description: There has been an explosion of magazines about videoland, but none, really, specifically for the video maker. Enter Moving Image, a magazine for video and film makers, that will be published by Sheptow Publishing, San Francisco.

title: NATION'S GROWTH IN 1981 FORECAST AT 2.6%
description: The Council of Economic Advisers, in a report to be issued this week, has expressed considerably more optimism about the course of the nation's economy over the next 18 months than it had in its previous forecast, published in February.

title: DELAY IN ENACTING FOREIGN AID BILL CAUSES CONCERN
description: The Reagan Administration's emphasis on its economic legislation is threatening to force a delay of Congressional action on the foreign aid budget that could seriously complicate its prospects for passage, Congressional and Administration officials say.

title: Steinbrenner Prods Owners
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, said yesterday that the owners' rejection of the Federal mediator's proposal had ''cost us time, not ground'' in reaching a settlement of the baseball strike.

title: Harry Kafka, Film Aide, Marries Harriet Taub
description: At the Town and Village Synagogue in New York yesterday, Harriet Taub, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Taub of Cliffside Park, N.J., was married to Harry Kafka, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Kafka of North Bergen, N.J. Rabbi Henry Glazer performed the ceremony.

title: SENATE TAX BILL QUESTIONED
description: While the Ways and Means Committee tries this week to finish drafting a tax-relief bill for House floor action, the Senate is likely to pass and send to the House a bill of its own drafted in the Finance Committee.

title: The Region; Bathhouse Burns At Jones Beach
description: A fire in a Jones Beach bathhouse injured at least 15 people, caused more than 3,000 people to flee the complex and nearly destroyed the wooden building yesterday afternoon, authorities said. No one was seriously hurt.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES FILLS TWO TOP POSTS
description: Robert A. Schoellhorn, president of Abbott Laboratories, became its chairman last Friday, succeeding Edward J. Ledder, 63 years old, who remains a director.

title: 20 ON 'TAXI' SAFE
description: One woman was fatally injured when a clam boat and a water taxi collided just north of Fire Island yesterday morning. Twenty persons who were aboard the water taxi reached shore safely, mostly by wading in water four feet deep.

title: 3 to Be Charged In Game Fixing
description: Rick Kuhn, a reserve forward for Boston College from 1976 to 1979, is one of three persons who are expected to be indicted on charges of conspiring to fix the results of basketball games during the 1978-79 season, according to a report yesterday on the ''CBS Sports Sunday'' television program.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK BENEFITING CITY
description: The Department of Environmental Protection was looking for ways to deal with droughts. The City Planning Department wanted a company able to manufacture smoke alarms that could be heard outdoors as well as indoors. The Office of Labor Relations sought to increase employee productivity and wound up with 30 pages of information.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The balance of power is a condition for peace.I really think that the latest initiatives taken by the Soviet Union -the deployment of SS-20 missiles and Backfire bombers - have resulted in a new superiority of the Soviets.

title: A VERY DIFFERENT KIND OF 'ACTION' FOR YOUTHS
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Tentative Pact Rejected In San Jose Strike
description: The City Council today rejected a tentative agreement reached this morning in the walkout by San Jose municipal workers over the issue of equity in pay for men and women.

title: EQUALITY--NOT YET
description: For black Americans, racial equality is a tradition without a past. Perhaps, one day America will be color-blind. It takes an extraordinary ignorance of actual life in America today to believe that day has come.

title: Doctor Charged With Hiring Hoodlums to Menace Partner
description: Dr. Howard B. Turnoff, a cardiologist, is free on $7,500 bond after being arrested on charges that he hired hoodlums to threaten his former partner's life, burn his boat and fire bullets into his car.

title: GIFTED TEACHERS WITHOUT ROOM TO BREATHE
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes On People; CBS Gives $500,000 for Chair at Kennedy School
description: Ten years ago today the United States House of Representatives killed a proposed contempt citation against CBS and Frank Stanton, then its president, for the network's refusal to divulge sources of information used to produce the CBS documentary, ''The Selling of the Pentagon.'' At the time Mr. Stanton said he was ''very pleased'' by the action.

title: Helen S. Sackler Married To Tony Miles Ettinger
description: Helen Sue Sackler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin M. Sackler of Bergenfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Tony Miles Ettinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel H. Ettinger of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Samuel Mendelowitz performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: FIRST OF 2 NEWARK PIPELINES FINISHED
description: The first of two new 900-foot pipelines in Newark's ruptured aqueduct was finished here this morning, and officials said that, if tests went well, drinking water would be flowing through it tomorrow at 6 A.M.

title: Advertising
description: Philip H. Dougherty Filling A Niche With Beer

title: Pressure Cited In Drug Case
description: A state attorney general showed unusual deference to the Philadelphia Phillies players and bended to perceived pressure from the press in prosecuting a doctor for improperly prescribing amphetamines in the names of the players, a published report said today.

title: EDWARD LITTLE, 100, WHO ONCE DIRECTED COLGATE PALMOLIVE
description: Edward H. Little, former chief executive officer and chairman of the Colgate-Palmolive Company, died Sunday at the Trezevant Manor Retirement Home in Memphis at the age of 100. He was for many years a resident of Manhattan, where Colgate-Palmolive has its headquarters.

title: Transactions
description: SOCCER JACKSONVILLE (NASL) - Bob New- ton, forward, was fined $250 and sus- pended for two games by Commissioner Phil Woosnam for hitting Elias Figueroa of Fort Lauderdale in the mouth with an elbow during a game June 27.

title: Around the World; State Dept. Bids Taipei Explain Death of Teacher
description: The State Department called on Taiwan today for a ''full investigation'' of the death of Dr. Chen Wen-cheng, a professor who taught at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh and who died under unexplained circumstances after being interrogated by Taiwan security forces 10 days ago.

title: JUDAIC CONVERSINS AND LAW OF RETURN
description: To the Editor:

title: HALT IN ATLANTA INQUIRY ASKED
description: A Fulton County Superior Court judge today refused to halt temporarily the deliberations of a grand jury looking into the latest in a string of murders of young black people, but he set a hearing for 2 P.M. tomorrow to hear arguments on the request.

title: TWO TEHERAN BAZAAR MERCHANTS ARE AMONG 22 EXECUTED IN IRAN
description: Iran's campaign against ''counterrevolutionaries'' reached into Teheran's business community today as two members of the capital's bazaar were among 22 people put to death on charges of anti-state activities. Six others were executed as drug or sex offenders.

title: Uranium Halt By Phillips
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said its Phillips Uranium Corporation subsidiary was suspending operations at its Nose Rock Uranium Mine in New Mexico.

title: Around the World; Tokyo Court Awards Damages Over U.S. Base
description: The Tokyo District Court today ordered the Japanese Government to pay $100,000 in damages to 114 of 148 residents living near a United States air base who had filed a noise pollution suit.

title: The City; Fire Damages Martinique Hotel
description: A three-alarm fire damaged six rooms on the 16th floor of the Martinique Hotel, but all guests were safely removed from that floor and the floors above and below it. A Fire Department spokesman, John Mulligan, said the only injury was suffered by an insurance company fire patrolman who sustained a broken wrist, apparently while trying to force a door.

title: FOREIGN SOCCER TEAMS LACK PRACTICE
description: Glasgow Celtic and Southampton of England, the foreign participants in the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup, entered the soccer tournament without their head coaches and with little practice, and neither had played a match since their season ended the last week in April.

title: WHEN WALDHEIM RUNS, ALL THE WORLD'S HIS STUMP
description: He cannot hire a hall, television time or a brass band, but Kurt Waldheim has been running a strong if discreet campaign to succeed himself as Secretary General.

title: The Region; Connecticut Utility Plans Canal Plant
description: The Connecticut Municipal Electric Energy Coooperative will build a 3,000-kilowatt hydroelectric station on the Windsor Locks Canal, Gov. William A. O'Neill announced.

title: KAISER OFF
description: The Westinghouse Corporation, the country's second-largest electronics equipment concern after the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that earnings in the second quarter increased 7.5 percent, as revenues increased 11.7 perecent.

title: PLUNKETT, HOLDER OF DISCUS RECORDS, BARRED ON DRUG USE
description: Ben Plucknett, who broke the world record for the discus throw twice in the last two months, became yesterday the first American to be banned indefinitely from competition because of positive drug tests. Both world records were annulled.

title: ALL-WHITE JURY SELECTD IN TRIAL OF 6 NAZIS IN CAROLINA BOMB PLOT
description: An all-white jury was selected today to hear the trial of six Nazis charged with conspiring to set off a series of explosions in Greensboro last year.

title: Foreign Air Fares Up
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today approved increases in foreign air fares, effective Aug. 1, on the basis of projected rises in costs. The C.A.B. said fares for Atlantic flights could go up 5.3 percent, fares to and from Latin America 3 percent and fares in the Pacific area 2.7 percent.

title: JESUITS ASSAIL U.S. BROADCAST
description: The Jesuit order is planning to lodge an official protest with the United States Government because of a report by the Voice of America that four seminary students detained in Honduras were transporting arms.

title: Rohm & Haas
description: The Rohm & Haas Company said that it would build an $18 million plant in England for the manufacture of its Kathon biocide, a chemical used to control the growth of microorganisms in paints, metalworking fluids and cooling tower water. Construction is to begin early next year, with completion expected in 1983, the company said.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 14, 1981
description: International An economic and monetary policy rift was underscored in a joint announcement by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and President Francois Mitterrand that they would oppose the policies of Washington at the Western economic conference in Ottawa next week. West Germany and France fear that the continued high interest rates in the United States will increase Europe's troubling inflation and unemployment. (Page A1, Column 5.) An Israeli-American accord on arms appeared likely. In a possible effort to clear the way for a resumption of F-16 deliveries to Israel, Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Robert C. McFarlane, a State Department counselor, issued a declaration in Jerusalem. It said that ''misunderstandings'' arising from Israel's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor on June 7 had been ''clarified to the satisfaction of both sides.'' (A1:4.)

title: IS BOG TURTLE ENDANGERED? WELL, YES AND NO
description: New York State has spent $519,000 to purchase a 132-acre preserve in Putnam County for the bog turtle, one of seven creatures on the state's endangered species list. Despite the state's concern, the Federal Government does not believe the turtle is in peril.

title: Asmuth Swim Winner
description: Paul Asmuth, fighting choppy seas and unusually warm water, defeated 19 other marathon swimmers today to capture the 23 1/2-mile Around-the-Island Swim for the second straight year. Asmuth, 23, of Mission Viejo, Calif., a former champion swimmer at Arizona State University, easily outdistanced his professional competitors for a time of 8 minutes 49:30 seconds and the $6,000 first prize.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: HOSPITALS may seem to be nations unto themselves, more or less alike - in the mind's eye - everywhere in the world. But that is not at all true. All are products of the culture that surrounds them, presenting differences in environment, if not in care, that can be startling to anyone accustomed to United States hospitals.

title: OIL STOCKS STAR IN DULL MARKET
description: Feverish trading in oil shares, particularly those involved in takeovers or those rumored to be targets, dominated an otherwise lackluster and trendless market yesterday. Conoco again led in volume as Seagram moved to outbid Du Pont's offer for the oil company and rose a further 7 points, to 84 3/8, on 1.7 million shares.

title: Index; International
description: Waldheim quietly campaigns for new term at U.N. title: Ford Brazil Strike Over
description: The 9,000 workers who had shut down one of the three Sao Paulo factories of the Brazilian unit of the Ford Motor Company since July 6 returned to work without an agreement today rather than allow a court to declare the walkout illegal.

title: The City; Transit Report
description: Thirty trains on the Babylon and main lines experienced delays of up to 45 miniutes in yesterday morning's rush hour because of signal problems in Brentwood.

title: CHASE AND CITIBANK HELP RAISE BILLIONS IN TAKEOVER STAKES
description: When it comes to raising really big money, the nation's largest corporations have been coming home to their traditional bankers, Chase Manhattan and Citibank.

title: New Oil Group Member
description: Tunisia will apply to join the nine-nation Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries when the group holds its next ministerial meeting on Dec. 9, Secretary General Ali Ahmed Atiga said today. The group's members are Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iraq, Algeria, Libya, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Syria.

title: Bridge: Bethe Team Rallies to Win Knockout in the Big Apple
description: The premier event of the Big Apple Regionals - the Knockout Team Championship - ended Sunday night at the New York Hilton Hotel in a victory for Henry Bethe, Mark and Stasha Cohen, all of New York, and Chuck Lamprey of White Plains.

title: DEE HARRIMAN
description: Dee Harriman, who was active for many years in the Westport (Conn.)

title: STRANGLING CASE MAY BE DROPPED
description: Prosecutors today recommended dismissal of murder charges against Angelo Buono, accused in the so-called hillside strangler slayings, because the credibility of the state's star witness had been destroyed.

title: MAN DISCHARGED BY CON ED WINS BACKING OF JUDGE
description: A Consolidated Edison employee who contended that he was dismissed last January because he had complained about safety hazards has been upheld by a Labor Department judge in his bid to be reinstated.

title: MAN WHO SENT NOTE THREATENING REAGAN ENTERS A GUITLY PLEA
description: A 22-year-old man from Drexel Hill, Pa., pleaded guilty today to threatening the life of President Reagan and was sentenced to a year in prison and five years' probation.

title: I.B.M. NET UP 5.2% IN QUARTER; NCR'S PROFIT DECLINES 7.8%
description: Three large computer companies reported second-quarter results that reflected the deleterious effects of the strong dollar on the earnings of multinational companies.

title: FOR ALBANY'S FRESHMEN, BAPTISM BY LEGISLATION
description: They are paid a bit more than average but come under a great deal of pressure, experience much boredom and have little real power. People they have never met call them by their first names and ask them for things. And their hours are ghastly.

title: Japan-Soviet Steel Loan
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation said today that the Soviet Union had accepted terms for a Japanese-supplied credit needed to buy 750,000 metric tons of large-diameter steel pipes from Japan. Moscow will pay 7 3/4 percent annual interest on the $400 million loan over five years, the company added.

title: Why Pension Liability Grew
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Lists Trade Surplus
description: Japan posted a $1.47 billion trade surplus on a customs-clearance basis in June, the Finance Ministry reported today.

title: MOURNING IN ULSTER AND PARADING TOO
description: Thousands of Protestants today celebrated a 1690 victory over Roman Catholic forces a few hours after a sixth hunger striker died this morning at Maze Prison here.

title: THE VIETNAM MEMORIAL
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA COURTS WON'T BAR SPRAYING TO KILL FRUIT FLIES
description: The California Supreme Court refused tonight to grant a restraining order that would have prevented the state from spraying the pesticide malathion over a densely populated area of Santa Clara County that is infested with the Mediterranean fruit fly.

title: THE U.S. SHOULD PRESS ISRAEL TO PURSUE PEACE
description: .4,0,165.6,2,726.8,0PRINCETON, N.J. - Menachem Begin's continuation as Prime Minister of Israel means that after 18 months of idling in neutral, neither the Israeli nor United States Governments can any longer plead forthcoming elections, in either country, to justify postponing hard decisions. Yet there is no indication that the heads of either Government are willing to view their interests, and to act on them, in ways that make that peace remotely likely.

title: CONGRESS STARTING IN WARSAW TODAY
description: The Soviet Union and its allies today sent middle-ranking delegations to attend a special congress of the Polish Communist Party that opens tomorrow.

title: YONKERS, LACKING BUDGET, SEEKS AID
description: Nearly two weeks into its fiscal year, Yonkers is still without a municipal budget. A deficit remains from last year, and the State Legislature has adjourned temporarily without voting the aid that Yonkers deems crucial to defray an even larger budget gap this year.

title: 'The Greatest Match' in Boxing
description: FOR boxing buffs, there are something like 50 shopping days before Christmas. The key date is Sept. 16, when Sugar Ray Leonard engages Thomas Hearns in a rumble at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas. The proprietors of the world's two welterweight championships are expected to settle their conflicting claims in the parking lot where the sorriest match of recent years - Larry Holmes versus the husk of Muhammad Ali -set a record of $6 million for gate receipts last fall.

title: Toyota Maps Canada Plant
description: Shoichiro Toyoda, the president of the Toyota Motor Sales Company, said today that Toyota had completed a feasibility study on a plan to build a plant to make aluminum car parts in British Columbia.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Computer Investor's Group Inc. announced an offer to exchange $57.50 in cash and 40 shares of a new series of its cumulative preferred stock for each $1,000 of its outstanding 5 3/4 percent convertible debentures due 1988.

title: FOR BROKAW, ANCHOR SPOT OFFERS AN IDEAL FORUM
description: TOM BROKAW has been up, as usual, since the inhospitable hour of 4:30 A.M. He has put in his two hours as anchor on ''Today,'' sat through several meetings and answered a slew of telephone messages and correspondence that piled up over the long weekend he spent in England watching the Wimbledon tennis matches.

title: U-BOAT SUNK OFF BLOCK ISLAND IN '45 CASTS SPELL OVER DIVERS
description: It might seem like an adventure reserved only for the proteges of Jacques Cousteau - a 110-foot descent through dark and frigid water to the wreck of a Nazi submarine, which became a tomb for more than 40 German sailors in the final hours of World War II in the Atlantic.

title: Cronkite's Appeal Still Strong
description: He has been off the the ''CBS Evening News'' since last March, but Walter Cronkite has not lost his appeal to the American people, according to a survey conducted by the International Platform Association, the professional organization of the lecture.

title: New York; MASTERPIECE PRICE HIKE
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation gave us fair warning. Last week, as the Legislature was preparing to enact a package of taxes to prop up the sagging New York City transit system for another year or so, the giant company advised us that we would suffer if those taxes - two of which directly affect oil companies - became law. On Sunday, Mobil dropped the other shoe. It increased by 3 cents a gallon its prices for gasoline, diesel and jet fuel to its dealers and distributors in New York State. All or most of that increase will likely be showing up at retailers' pumps very soon, if it has not already.

title: Sales Increase For Sandoz
description: The Sandoz Group's sales rose 16 percent, to 3 billion francs, in the first half of 1981, compared with 2.52 billion in the same period a year ago, Sandoz A.G. said today.

title: TV: MILTON FRIEDMAN ECONOMICS SERIES IN RERUN
description: "FREE TO CHOOSE," a 10-part series first shown on public television last year, is back for a rerun on WNET-TV on Tuesdays at 10 P.M., and is even more intriguing and provocative than the first time around. The star is Milton Friedman, the Nobel Prize-winning economist whose theories have greatly influenced the policies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and President Reagan. The current rioting in the streets of Britain gives the series an unfortunate but pronounced urgency.

title: SENATE AGAIN REJECTS CLOTURE IN DEBATE ON BUSING
description: The Senate today again rejected an attempt to limit debate by a group of liberal and moderate lawmakers fighting to prevent enactment of anti-busing legislation.

title: OWNERS EXPLORING NEW IDEAS IN TALKS
description: Negotiations in the baseball strike appeared yesterday to be moving swiftly on the upgrade as indications surfaced that the negotiators for the owners and the players could have something well worth talking about tomorrow.

title: STAGE: ABBEY THEATER PRESENTS 'THE SHADOW OF A GUNMAN'
description: ''THE Shadow of a Gunman'' may be one of Sean O'Casey's best plays, but it follows as a clear third to his ''The Plough and the Stars'' and ''Juno and the Paycock.'' The play may have pulled Dublin's venerable Abbey Theater out of artistic and financial bankruptcy when it was produced in 1923, the first play the 19-year-old National Theater had accepted from the rough-hewn, fledgling playwright. But viewed dispassionately ''The Shadow of a Gunman'' is, indeed, fledgling playwriting: a string of near-vaudeville turns and melodramatic, act-ending deaths perpetrated by the boarders in a dismal Dublin tenement on two seedy boyos as they try to live unscathed through a day in 1920 shaped by the random violence of the Irish War of Independence.

title: The U.N. Today; July 14, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: International Conference on Cambo- dia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. -

title: THE COOL COIFFURES
description: Summertime in New York is the worst time to have long hair.

title: Ex-Im and Mint Chiefs
description: The Senate today approved the nominations of William Draper 3d as president of the Export-Import Bank and Donna Pope as director of the Mint. They were confirmed by voice vote.

title: Steel Output Falls
description: Steel production fell to 2.276 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 4.3 percent from the previous week's 2.379 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Sayers, After 5 Years, Leaves Southern Illinois
description: Gale Sayers, a member of the Professional Football Hall of Fame, announced his resignation today as athletic director at Southern Illinois University-Carbondale effective Sept. 1.

title: In The Nation; A CONCERN FOR REAGAN
description: Drawing parallels between the urban riots in Britain and those that gave the United States its ''long hot summers'' in the 1960's can be tricky. The British disorders, unlike the American, do not seem to be fundamentally racial; and in any case, the two societies are quite different.

title: House Adopts Bill for Funds For Intelligence Work in 1982
description: The House today approved a mostly secret bill authorizing funds in the fiscal year 1982 for operation of the nation's intelligence services, including the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: WATT ASKS CHANGE ON TRAIL VEHICLES
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, in another move to relax Government regulation, has proposed canceling a Presidential order that restricts the use of motorcycles, snowmobiles and other so-called off-road vehicles on Federal property.

title: D'AMATO REGRETS THE HINT OF CAMPAIGN LOAN CONFLICT
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato says he should have been more sensitive to the appearance of a conflict of interest when he borrowed $130,000 for his campaign last year from a bank with which he had a close relationship when he was an official of the Town of Hempstead, L.I.

title: Around the Nation; Alaska Considers Limit On Spending Oil Riches
description: The Legislature convened in special session today to consider Gov. Jay Hammond's demand that they rewrite the state constitution to limit annual increases in state spending.

title: A REPUBLICAN FEMINIST OUT TO CHANGE THE PARTY
description: Kathy Wilson, the new chairman of the National Women's Political Caucus, became a Republican at the dinner table, naturally and gradually. She became a feminist on the job, suddenly and furiously.

title: Habib Arrives in Saudi Arabia For Talks on Mideast Mission
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special enovy, arrived in Saudi Arabia today to continue his efforts to ease tensions between Israel and Syria over Syrian missiles in Lebanon.

title: A NEW LEAK RUPTURES NEWARK WATER PIPELINE
description: A major new break occurred today on Newark's main water-supply aqueduct, about a mile over the hillside where construction crews have worked around-the-clock since Wednesday morning to rebuild a ruptured 825-foot section of the conduit.

title: DETAILS ON SOVIET SATELLITE DISCLOSED
description: The Soviet Union may launch a new manned mission to link up with a space station-satellite complex created in orbit last month, a veteran Russian astronaut hinted today.

title: Market Place; Baby Boomlet: How to Benefit
description: IN their constant search for investment guidelines, Wall Street people often turn to demographics. The study of income, age and other characteristics of particular population groups can provide insight into the potential market for many corporate products and services.

title: Talking Business with Robert Rodale; Improving Agriculture
description: The concept of organic farming is almost synonymous with the name of Robert Rodale. Mr. Rodale, a spare, soft-spoken 52-year-old, looks like the avid experimental farmer that he is. But behind the white goatee is, as well, a successful entrepreneur who has parlayed his privately held Rodale Press into an $80 million business. The Rodale publications have informed readers for years about the latest in organic farming and a wide range of how-to techniques for selfreliance in food, farming, health and shelter.

title: China's Grain Import Needs
description: China will be a steady importer of foreign grain, including United States wheat and corn, for the foreseeable future but will be extremely slow in expanding those orders from current levels, a senior Agriculture Department official said today.

title: DEMOCRATS ADOPT TAX OFFENSIVE
description: House Democrats, shifting from the defensive to the offensive, today outlined a strategy for winning support for a Democratic tax bill from Republicans who represent middle-income districts, especially in the Northeast.

title: REAGAN CRITICIZES EFFORT TO UPDATE POWER IN SUBWAY
description: The State Comptroller charged yesterday that the New York City Transit Authority was ''about 10 years behind'' schedule in modernizing power substations in the subway system.

title: MANHATTAN COMPANY ACCUSED OF FRAUD IN METAL INVESTING offices
description: The deal for the purchase of $69,690 worth of tantalum - a rare metal -began yesterday with a handshake and ended with handcuffs and criminal accusations of a possible $2 million fraud.

title: FEAR OF INVASION DOMINATES RUSSIA
description: 913To the Editor:

title: KENTUCKY GOVERNOR BROWN SEEKS TO OUST CURCI
description: Gov. John Y. Brown Jr., saying ''I'm tired of losing,'' indicated today that he was determined to have Coach Fran Curci of the University of Kentucky football team dismissed.

title: Cooper Agrees To Sell Airmotive
description: Cooper Industries Inc. said it had signed an agreement in principle to sell its Cooper Airmotive division to an investor group for $150 million cash plus a 9 percent equity interest in a new company to be formed from the division. Cooper added that completion of the transaction would result in a pretax gain of about $50 million.

title: URBAN ENTERPRISE BILL DEBATED
description: A Senate panel heard sharply conflicting testimony today on the impact of bapartisan legislation designed to lure businesses into impoverished urban areas, such as the South Bronx.

title: Rollei Output Continues
description: The Singapore unit of Rollei, the West German camera company, will lay off 1,000 workers but will continue production unabated with the 3,000 who are left, the factory's receivers announced today. The parent company has declared bankruptcy, and the Singapore operation has been placed under the control of receivers - the accounting firm of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co.

title: Ford German Unit
description: Ford-Werke A.G., the West German unit of the Ford Motor Company, said that it planned to add 900 workers at its Cologne/Niehl plant to increase production of the Fiesta model.

title: POST-STRIKE PROBLEMS LOOMING
description: As the players' strike passed its 32d day, baseball officials said yesterday that no policy had been drawn yet on how to resume or resolve the season when the strike ended.

title: PREVENTIVE PENALTY FOR DRUGGED DRIVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Shell Plans to Sell Its Canadian Unit
description: The Shell Oil Company said today it planned to sell its Canadian unit to Husky Oil of Calgary, Alberta, for $360 million, in American funds.

title: Palmer Takes Senior Playoff
description: Arnold Palmer, at 51 years of age, showed today that he can still produce one of the late charges that helped make him famous. He made up six shots in nine holes and won a three-way playoff from Billy Casper and Bob Stone to take the second United States Senior Open golf championship.

title: Symbolic Sludge
description: A brand-new $15 million plant in Wantagh was designed to dry sewage sludge for land disposal on Long Island. Now, though, the plant and several others under construction in the area may turn out to be unnecessary - unfortunate symbols of environmental laws and regulations that focused too narrowly on cleaning up the oceans.

title: MOSCOW JEWS BURY MATRIARCH
description: Judith Lerner was buried today in a pleasantly shaded glade at a suburban cemetery, her funeral attended by dozens of men and women to whom she had become a symbol of hope and courage in the difficult world of the Soviet Jew.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Inaugural Addresses ''Everybody collects something,'' Sidney Romero said yesterday from Hammond, La. ''My son collects baseball cards, my wife collects strawberry crate labels and I collect inaugural addresses.''

title: 2 Plead Not Guilty to Charges Of Delivering Data to Poland
description: An American radar engineer and a Polish businessman accused of giving sensitive United States military documents to Poland pleaded not guilty today to espionage charges.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on June 29 on ''Leading Underwriters of Initial Public Offerings in 1981'' listed the wrong headquarters city for D.H. Blair. Its head office is at 44 Wall Street in Manhattan.

title: Official Approves Continental Plan
description: Continental Air Lines will be permitted to sell 15.4 million shares of common stock to an Employee Stock Ownership Plan, but the airline must first get shareholder and employee approval, a state official ruled today.

title: BIG HOPES FOR PUDDING POPS
description: First, there was Jell-O, a gelatin dessert, and its sales were good. Then General Foods created Jell-O pudding. Now, if the giant food company has its way, there will be Jell-O Pudding Pops, frozen pudding on a stick.

title: Advertising; Callaway And the Cobra
description: IN the cramped and busy offices of Holland & Callaway the reproduction of the hooded cobra on the desk of Jim Callaway, president and chief executive, seems very much at home. Just another agency executive's desk ornament, one muses. Another creative excess.

title: Texasgulf Tender Wait Expires
description: Societe Nationale Elf Acquitaine, the French Government-controlled oil company, said that the waiting period under United States antitrust laws had expired, clearing the way for it to proceed with its acquisition of Texasgulf Inc.

title: The Riot Experts
description: What a lot of experts in riot control have suddenly flowered on both sides of the Atlantic. The newest is New York's Governor Carey, who predicts social upheaval in this country by October because of the Reagan Administration's budget cuts. ''Telescoped Thatcherism,'' he calls it, referring to the two years of austerity practiced by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain. The Governor's words are not merely provocative; they are arrogant. How does he know what causes riots?

title: Woman Shot in Attack on Pope Leaves Hospital
description: Ann Odre, who was shot in the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II two months ago while on a group pilgrimage to European religious sites, was discharged from the Buffalo General Hospital yesterday. The 59-year-old widow from Buffalo had undergone two operations in a Rome hospital and then was flown home for further surgery.

title: Addendum
description: * Leo Burnett opening an office in Athens called Leo Burnett Advertising S.A., the result of a joint venture with Interad, also in Athens.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If anybody should think that one sovereign country should consult another sovereign country about a specific military operation, in order to defend its citizens, that would be absurd.'' - Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel. (A7:3.)

title: Genuine Trouble In a Mock Flight
description: Preparation for the next flight of the space shuttle Columbia are moving ahead smoothly, more or less. In a mock flight last week at the Johnson Space Center here, Joe H. Engle and Richard H. Truly, the astronauts assigned to the Sept. 30 launching, dodged solar flares, tested the shuttle's radiator system and operated the remote-controlled manipulator arm that will unload the craft's cargo bay.

title: PABST POST SOUGHT BY ENTREPRENEUR
description: Irwin L. Jacobs began his career as a turnaround artist with $330 million in bad debts and the motto: ''big risks, big rewards.'' It's been uphill ever since.

title: DISMISSAL OF ACTION ON READER'S DIGEST IS URGED BY COUNSEL
description: The Federal Election Commission's attorney has recommended dismissal of a complaint accusing the Reader's Digest of violating an election law by distributing videotapes about an article critical of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.

title: ELSIE C. WOODWARD, PHILANTHROPIST, DIES AT 98
description: Elsie Cryder Woodward, widow of William Woodward and one of the last grandes dames of New York society, died yesterday in her sleep in her apartment at the Waldorf Towers. She was 98 years old.

title: EDUCATION
description: LONGVIEW, Tex. MEL and Norma Gabler seem simple folk at first. She dwells on the grandchildren. He mows the lawn. They have lived for years in the same modest ranch house here in this dusty East Texas industrial town.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE presidents of some of the country's leading research universities are alarmed by a threat to clamp security restrictions on their classrooms and laboratories. They have urged the Secretaries of Defense, State and Commerce to lift those restrictions and have warned that the impact of such regulations would seriously interfere with research and teaching.

title: Shanghai Peking Opera Opens Aug. 12 at Tully
description: The Shanghai Peking Opera Troupe, with a score of performers from Shanghai, will give 15 performances at Alice Tully Hall from Aug. 12 to 23.

title: People
description: * Stephen William Norcia has rejoined SSC&B Inc. as an executive vice president.

title: PAN AM EXPECTED TO MAKE CUTBACKS
description: Pan American World Airways, hit by disastrous losses that threaten the survival of its airline operations, is expected to announce today a reshuffling of routes, including a shutdown of its stations at La Guardia and Newark International airports. New York operations will be concentrated at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Floods Strike South China
description: Flooding caused by torrential rains destroyed about 1,700 homes in Guangxi in southern China, Radio Peking said today. It said there were deaths and injuries, but did not give specific figures.

title: Air Fares Cut By American
description: American Airlines will introduce an advance-purchase discount July 29 that will cut Toronto-Los Angeles and Montreal-Los Angeles fares by 45 percent for adults and 55 percent for children. The airline said the discount will apply to flights on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays between July 29 and Dec. 11, 1981.

title: JUDGE CHANGES MIND ON POLLUTION RULING
description: A Federal judge reversed today his previous decision, ruling today that the Justice Department cannot seek $1 million in damages for toxic water pollutants leaching from the Kin-Buc landfill.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard LITERARY DEMOCRACY. The Declara- tion of Cultural Independence in Amer- ica. By Larzer Ziff. 333 pages. Viking. $20.

title: Lanier Switches Unit To Greenville Agency
description: Lanier Business Products in Atlanta, which has had all of its advertising done in Chicago agencies, has moved closer to home for the promotion of its new Telephone Answering System.

title: LUMBER STRIKE IN CANADA
description: British Columbia's huge forest products industry was crippled today by a strike of more than 50,000 workers. It threatens to increase the prices Americans pay for newsprint, pulp and lumber in coming weeks.

title: Home News Cable Service
description: Dow Jones & Company and Tocom Inc. today announced plans for the first widespread use of cable television for delivering home information retrieval services.

title: JERSEY REFUNDS ORDERED ON ALLSTATE AUTO POLICIES
description: An appeals court today ordered the Allstate Insurance Company, the largest insurer of automobiles in New Jersey, to return an estimated $22.3 million to 502,000 auto-insurance policyholders in the state on the ground that the company had improperly raised its rates last year.

title: ITS DUTCH OWNERS SELL E.P. DUTTON TO VOLT
description: Four months after its Dutch owners hung out the ''for sale'' sign on E.P. Dutton, the 129-year-old American publisher is being sold for an undisclosed sum to Volt Information Sciences of New York. Volt is the leading producer of Yellow Page directories and a leading provider of technical services to the telecommunications industry.

title: Johnson, Ex-Dodger, Tells of Cocaine Habit
description: Lou Johnson says he sold his World Series ring to a drug dealer for $500 to help support his cocaine habit, and recalls a time when he held a gun to his wife's head. That was after he became known as Sweet Lou during the two years he helped the Los Angeles Dodgers win National League pennants in the mid-1960's.

title: News Analysis
description: The Israeli attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor last month has revived debate in Washington over a critical question: Has the 35-year international effort to curb the spread of nuclear weapons failed?

title: 2 FILLIES RACE AS 2 SCRATCH
description: In what was believed to be the first unscheduled two-horse race in New York racing history, heavily favored Chilling Thought outran Polite Rebuff by 11 lengths yesterday at Belmont Park in the 75th Astoria Stakes.

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL GETS UNDER WAY
description: MOSTLY MOZART'S 15th anniversary season opened last night at Avery Fisher Hall with a recently discovered Mozart symphony that proved to be something considerably more than a curiosity piece, though decidedly less than a candidate for inclusion in the standard orchestral repertory. It could fairly be called, however, a prodigious creation.

title: Warner Amex Sued on Lease
description: The competition for leasing rights to scarce satellite microwave transmission channels in the pay television industry has led to a $28 million suit for breach of contract against the Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment Corporation.

title: PANEL TO URGE CONTINUING ARTS AGENCIES
description: Charlton Heston, co-chairman of President Reagan's Task Force on the Arts and Humanities, said today that his group would recommend continuation of the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities.

title: KIRKLAND ASKS CURBS ON IMPORTS
description: The chief spokesman for organized labor said today that the Reagan Administration had ''abdicated responsibility'' by avoiding actions to protect American workers against unfair foreign competition in a world where ''free trade no longer has meaning.''

title: No Headline
description: A nine-member committee, representing top handicappers from throughout the world, will select the 14 horses for the Aug. 30 Arlington Million, Joseph Joyce, the Arlington Park track president, said today.

title: CAREY WEIGHS SETBACKS OF '81 IN PLANNING CAMPAIGN FOR '82
description: Governor Carey, laying the groundwork for a possible re-election drive next year, is seeking a strategy to overcome what he and his aides perceive as a politically disastrous legislative session.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: The spire of Trinity Church, on Lower Broadway, at one time dominated the Manhattan scene; now it is a handsomely quaint landmark at the west end of Wall Street. Seen from down The Street, it has the appearance of a building buried deep in an archeological dig, a trench of office skyscrapers.

title: Strike Banned At Railroad
description: A judge today blocked any further strike action by employees of Burlington Northern Inc. Federal District Judge Bernard M. Decker issued an injunction against the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen.

title: WORRY OVER ILLEGAL ARMS EXPORTS GROWING AMONG U.S. PROSECUTORS
description: Federal investigators and prosecutors say they are increasingly concerned about the extensive illegal exporting of arms and sophisticated technology from the United States to countries such as Libya and the Soviet Union.

title: The City; Battered Baby Girl Is Being Sought
description: City authorities continued their search this morning for a badly battered baby girl who was taken from her crib in New York Hospital Sunday morning by her parents in violation of a Family Court order, the police said. The parents are also being sought for violating that court order.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Dismisses Claims Of 4 to Hughes Estate
description: Judge Pat Gregory of Probate Court today rejected four claims to share in the Howard Hughes estate after a two-and-a-half-hour hearing opening the latest phase of the five-year-old case.

title: BROWN ADMITS MISTAKES BY HIS AIDES
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. admitted today that his office had made many mistakes in its dealings with the California Fair Political Practices Commission during an investigation of charges that his staff used state tax money for his personal political campaign purposes.

title: SCHOLAR REKINDLING DEBATE ON 'EARLIEST MAN'
description: SINCE their identification from part of a jawbone found in India in 1934, some enigmatic apelike creatures known as ramapithecines, which appeared about 14 million years ago, have been a source of spirited debate among anthropologists. The major question: Were they remote ancestors of man or an evolutionary dead end?

title: Irving's Argentine Deal
description: The Irving Trust Company's purchase of 49.99 percent of Banco Austral for $9 million will become final this week, the Argentine bank said today.

title: C.I.A. CHIEF ORDERS INQUIRY INTO FRAUD CHARGES AGAINST AN AIDE
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, has begun an internal investigation into the past business practices of Max C. Hugel, the agency's deputy director for operations, after receiving charges that Mr. Hugel was guilty of securities fraud when he managed an electronics company.

title: INGERSOLL NEWCOMER
description: As Clyde H. Folley sees his new job it will add about a mile to his drive to work and at least five years to his career. Mr. Folley was appointed yesterday as senior vice president and chief financial officer of the Ingersoll-Rand Company, the $3-billion-a-year manufacturer of compressed air systems and other industrial equipment, based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: The Region; 2 Men Held in L.I.  On Sex Charges
description: A rented house in Baldwin Harbor was used as a haven where young boys were taken and sexually abused, officials said. Two men were arrested there Saturday night and detectives seized a large number of videotapes made there that showed men engaged in sexual acts with boys 8 to 15 years old.

title: Around the Nation; Attorney General Urged To Support Rights Act
description: Civil rights leaders today urged Attorney General William French Smith to support extending the Voting Rights Act for 10 years without major alteration.

title: Please Use Strike Again Disrupts Deliveries of 3 Papers
description: Deliveries of The New York Times, The New York Post and The Wall Street Journal in Suffolk County and parts of Nassau County, Brooklyn and Queens were disrupted again yesterday by a strike of newspaper deliverers against Crescent News Distributors Inc., the wholesale distributor in the area. The strike began last Thursday.

title: 1,000 ATTEND PLAZA REHEARSAL
description: At 12:15 P.M. yesterday, just as sunlight moved off the temporary platform set up on the north plaza of Lincoln Center, Leonard Slatkin brought his baton down. A startled pigeon flew off the bronze head of Henry Moore's divided reclining figure in the reflecting pool opposite the opera house, and 36 members of the orchestra began their annual free outdoor rehearsal before last night's opening of the Mostly Mozart Festival's 15th anniversary season.

title: BRIEFS
description: A.A.R. Corp. said that it and Brooks & Perkins Inc. have changed to Aug. 31 the date for special shareholders meetings to vote on the previously announced acquisition of Brooks & Perkins by A.A.R.

title: Irwin, Weiskopf Withdraw
description: The withdrawal of seven players, including Hale Irwin and Tom Weiskopf, cut further today into an already small field of Americans set to compete in the 110th British Open golf championship.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CFS Continental Inc., a food services company, has named Donald W. Hansen executive vice president.

title: RCA Shifts Executives
description: The RCA Corporation announced some executive changes yesterday, the first since Thornton Bradshaw took over as chairman on July 1. The company announced that William C. Hittinger, who has been executive vice president of research and engineering, will assume additional responsibility for RCA Communications and the company's international operations.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. gave the political affiliation incorrectly for Senator S.I. Hayakawa of California. He is a Republican.

title: College Researcher Turns to Garden
description: These summer days, Prof. A. David Baker is likely to be found pursuing his research in the garden instead of the laboratory. Professor Baker, who teaches at Queens College, is an originator of an analytic technique in organic chemistry called photoelectron spectroscopy and from there, the way he tells it, the garden's just a short hop.

title: The City;
description: A Manhattan judge said he would decide later this week whether Daysi Fernandez will get any of her lottery prize of $2.8 million prior to a legal battle over the money. The New York State Lottery Division has held up her first payment - $200,000 - pending the court ruling.

title: BONN AND PARIS AGREE TO OPPOSE U.S. RATE POLICY
description: West Germany and France agreed today to join in opposing United States economic and monetary policies at the sevennation economic summit meeting that begins in Ottawa next week.

title: FANCY FULL
description: The new fashion message from Perry Ellis is big and full.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY HAIG
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today to the opening session of the General Assembly Conference on Cambodia:

title: Stocks Slide In Italy
description: Italian stock prices resumed their sharp decline today as markets reopened after a three-day closure ordered by the Government. The index for the Milan exchange, the nation's largest, fell 9.6 percent.

title: Hess Expects 2d-Quarter Loss
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation said it expects a second-quarter loss as a result of poor results in refining and marketing operations. The company said it expects writedowns in the value of crude oil and refined product inventories and will make provisions for losses under certain crude oil supply contracts for the rest of the year.

title: BEGIN AND U.S AIDE 'CLARIFY' POSITIONS ON REACTOR RAID
description: The United States and Israel announced tonight that ''misunderstandings'' arising from the bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor June 7 had been ''clarified to the satisfaction of both sides.''

title: Notes On Fashion
description: I T was a good week to do a little digging. The place to start was Bloomingdale's, which is going to introduce the first jewelry of Basile, Armani and Missoni in September. At the same time, the store will throw a party to introduce Bill Blass's line of designer chocolates for Godiva and, at the party, Godiva and Bloomingdale's will donate a check to Diana Vreeland for the Costume Institute. This led, naturally, to a little more digging to verify the scattered talk that Merle Norman, the West Coast cosmetics company, was helping to finance Mrs. Vreeland's next show at the institute, dedicated to the 18th-century woman. Gary Hollister, president of Merle Norman, confirmed it, saying, ''We are going to be the sole sponsor of the show, which means that we're putting up all of the money it will take to help Mrs. Vreeland with the show, and the amount is substantial.''

title: PILOTS PENETRATE THUNDERHEADS FOR DATA ON BIRTH OF A STORM
description: IT had been a frustrating season for the radar operators, aircraft and sailplane pilots, weathermen and other researchers, mobilized for the most ambitious effort ever undertaken to learn what nourishes, starves and otherwise controls summer storms. Last Saturday seemed more of the same - until a dramatic change occurred.

title: WHY DO SOME PEOPLE TURN AWAY FROM OTHERS IN TR
description: OUBLE BY JOEL GREENBERG

title: PART OF CONSTRUCTION ON CANAL TO THE GULF STAYED BY U.S. COURT
description: A Federal appeals court has halted construction on parts of the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway until the Army Corps of Engineers can file a new assessment of the impact of the $1.8 billion barge canal on the environment.

title: The City; Driver Indicted In Hit-Run Deaths
description: A 40-year-old Brooklyn man was indicted for murder in the hit-andrun deaths of two children last week. The suspect, Alfredo Gomez of 359 12th Street, was charged with two counts of second-degree murder, reckless endangerment and leaving the scene of an accident.

title: MRS. THATCHER, IN LIVERPOOL, URGES UNITY
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher visited Liverpool today to appeal to the people of the riot-bruised city to unite with the police to end urban violence.

title: No Commissaries for Carter
description: Jimmy Carter is not eligible for Defense Department commissary privileges, a White House aide said today. Edward V. Hickey, who heads the White House military office, said the former President, who was once an officer in the Navy, did not qualify for the right to shop at the commissaries. Mr. Hickey said the three service secretaries would determine whether Mr. Carter was allowed to shop at the post exchanges.

title: South African Rugby Club Is Granted Visas by U.S.; South African Rugby Club Is Granted Visas by U.S.
description: The State Department said today that members of a South African rugby team, the Springboks, have been granted visas to come to the United States in September for rugby matches in Chicago, Albany and New York City.

title: MOBIL IS REORTED TO SEEK $5 BILLION TO BID FOR CONOCO
description: The multibillion-dollar takeover battle for Conoco Inc. spread yesterday to the Mobil Corporation, as banking sources disclosed that Mobil was negotiating to borrow some $5 billion to bid for Conoco.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD IS REACHED IN SAN JOSE WALKOUT
description: Mayor Janet Gray Hayes announced late this evening that a tentative agreement had been reached in the municipal workers' strike in which ''equal pay for comparable work'' was a central issue.

title: Light and Spider Webs
description: Ever since it was observed a century ago that spiders attack a tuning fork touching their web, it has been known that they learn when a prey is on their web from the web's vibrations. Vibrational signals are also used by male spiders to notify the female of their approach and to avoid being eaten, at least until after mating.

title: TV: MILTON FREIDMAN ECONOMICS SERIES IN RERUN
description: ''FREEDOM TO CHOOSE,'' a 10-part series first shown on public television last year, is back for a rerun on WNET-TV on Tuesdays at 10 P.M., and is even more intriguing and provocative than the first time around. The star is Milton Friedman, the Nobel Prize-winning economist whose theories have greatly influenced the policies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and President Reagan. The current rioting in the streets of Britain gives the series an unfortunate but pronounced urgency.

title: House Approves $2.2 Million For Marine Life Sanctuaries
description: The House passed a bill today authorizing $2.2 million in the fiscal year 1982 to operate six sanctuaries for marine life on the East and West Coasts.

title: Car Inventories At July 1 High
description: Fairly strong production and lagging sales in June resulted in record-high inventories of new domestically built cars on July 1, the trade publication Automotive News said today.

title: i; Ian Peter Cargill, 65; Ex-Aide of World Bank
description: Ian Peter M. Cargill, a former senior vice president of the World Bank, died on Friday in London shortly before he was to be invested as a knight of the United Kingdom. He was 65 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: Abu Dhabi Oil Output
description: Oil production in Abu Dhabi totaled 109.3 million barrels in the first quarter of this year, down 12.3 percent from the same 1980 period, the official Emirates News Agency said today. The report gave no reason for the lower production.

title: CHIEF OF CENSUS BUREAU
description: When Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's political operative, was asked to pass on the nomination of Bruce K. Chapman as director of the Bureau of the Census, he observed that he had never recommended a member of the Ripon Society for anything, but there had to be a first time for everything.

title: MISHAPS MAR U.N.'S CAMBODIA MEETING
description: A series of diplomatic mishaps marred the opening today of a conference aimed at negotiating the removal of Vietnam's troops from Cambodia.

title: MADISON AVE. BUS LANES PASS A TEST
description: The two-month-old bus lane experiment on Madison Avenue is working well but is not meeting expectations because of a continuing shortage of Transit Authority buses, city officials said yesterday.

title: THE LA SCALA BALLET: NUREYEV'S 'ROMEO AND JULIET'
description: MILAN'S La Scala Opera House is best known for its opera company, but there was a time in the 19th-century when its ballet company produced the best dancers in Europe.

title: Acid Spill in Middletown, Pa., Forces Evacuation of 1,000
description: About 1,000 residents of this south-central Pennsylvania town were evacuated yesterday and the rest of the borough's citizens were ordered to stay indoors because of an acid spill, officials said.

title: 6-Month Bills Rise to 14.23%; Bell Bonds Set at 15.725%
description: Weak investor demand for long-term bonds was amply demonstrated yesterday when underwriters announced that the New York Telephone Company's new 40-year debentures will be sold today at a yield of 15.725 percent - a record for new triple A-rated Bell System debt.

title: Around the world; Pakistan Asks India To Clarify Press Reports
description: The Foreign Office summoned the Indian Ambassador here today and demanded an explanation of ''tendentious'' Indian press reports of military activities along the border between the two countries.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Acquire Translator
description: Ogilvy & Mather International announced an interesting and unusual acquisition yesterday. In keeping with the ''International'' in its title it has bought Euramerica Translations, a six-year-old New York company that does what its name suggests - in 38 languages.

title: MOBIL PRICE INCREASE IS CALLED RETALIATION FOR NEW YORK TAXES
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink charged today that the Mobil Oil Corporation's decision to increase its prices by 3 cents in response to new state taxes on oil companies was an act of ''vengeful retaliation.'' He said it was ''a political response, not an economic response'' to the new levies.

title: Jets' Chief Testifies
description: Jim Kensil, the president of the New York Jets, testified today that the Raiders should not be allowed to move out of Oakland even though the Los Angeles area can support two National Football League teams. As the 10th week of the trial of the Raiders' antitrust suit against the N.F.L., opened today, Kensil, a former executive director of the N.F.L., told the United States District Court jury that ''the fans of Oakland should in no way be left in the lurch.''

title: U.S. SEEKS TO RAISE EAST EUROPEAN REFUGEE QUOTA
description: Attorney General William French Smith has asked Congress to authorize the admission of 2,400 additional refugees from Eastern Europe, mainly to help accommodate the flow of people leaving Poland.

title: LOCALITIES STRUGGLING TO PREPARE FOR FUTURE WITH REDUCED U.S. AID
description: Virginia's Fairfax County expects to increase the cost of school lunches by 15 cents, to 75 cents per pupil.

title: The Region; Vergari Will Meet With Jail Inmates
description: Westchester County's District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, after first hedging on meeting with inmates at the county jail here, reversed himself last night and agreed to the session if it appeared that it would be ''helpful in cooling things down there.''

title: MASSACHUSETTS GOVRNOR SIGNS AN INTERIM BUDGET
description: This was a long day of tension and political maneuvering in Massachusetts, with the outcome still clouded by nightfall: No state budget had been adopted; state workers had no paychecks; their protest strike broadened again into new areas of state function.

title: AMING FOR A BIGGER PIE, NOT A LARGER SLICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Poland's Half a Loaf
description: Neither the fiery slogans of Gdansk nor the ugly threats of the Kremlin will prevail at Poland's Communist Party Congress this week. The remarkable rebellion that began in Polish factories a year ago has produced a more representative convention than any seen in a Communist country for a very long time. But its delegates are no freer than Poland itself.

title: Chess: Ivanov, Victor in Canada, Earns International Rank
description: Igor Ivanov, who defected from the Soviet Union when his plane made a stop in Labrador on his return from a tournament in Cuba, won the Canadian Zonal Tournament in Montreal. In the Canadian tournament, the first stage of qualifications for the 1984 world championship, Ivanov posted a 12 1/2-2 1/2 score in capturing Canada's single qualifying place. He will now be awarded international master rank, according to the rules of the International Chess Federation.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Do American Indians grow beards?

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Companies
description: Mobil indicated it would join the multibillion-dollar takeover battle for Conoco. Banking sources said that Mobil was negotiating to borrow some $5 billion to make a bid for Conoco. Meanwhile, speculation continued that Texaco and Standard Oil Company of California may enter the contest shortly. (Page A1.) The nation's largest companies have been calling on Chase Manhattan and Citibank to raise really big sums of money. (D6.) John S.R. Shad, the Securities and Exchange Commission's chairman, gave his blessing to the recent wave of corporate mergers and takeovers. (D6.)

title: TUNING INTO SATELLITE TV
description: In 1979, the Neiman-Marcus Christmas catalogue offered a backyard satellite earth station for $36,500. Like his-and-her dirigibles, windmills and other products occasionally featured in the catalogue of the Dallas-based retailer, the dish-shaped antenna was an exotic plaything for the rich.

title: DEMAND FOR CORN MAY RISE PRICE
description: World and domestic demand for American corn and other feed grains will be strong in the coming marketing year, and reserves on hand by Oct.1, 1982, will drop to one of the lowest levels since 1974, the Agriculture Department predicted today.

title: TO MAKE THE THRIFTS MORE APPEALING TO SAVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C.'s Chief Gives Blessing to Mergers
description: John S.R. Shad, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today gave his blessing to the recent wave of corporate mergers and takeovers, echoing the general theme of the Reagan Administration that ''bigness in business does not necessarily mean badness.''

title: RECORDS ALLURING TO COE
description: The pressure is off, but the hunger and motivation remain with Sebastian Coe. ''You give so much in an Olympic year,'' said the 1980 gold-medal winner at 1,500 meters. ''Mentally, you get the end of it and you're a bit dry. The problem at the end of 1980 was how could I possibly key up again so soon? When you're training and touring, you say, 'why, really?' then you run 1:41.7 for 800 meters and you realize why.'' Coe lowered his world record for the 800 from 1:42.33 to 1:41.72 last month in Florence, Italy.

title: POSTAL ESTHETICS AND ECONOMICS FORCE CLOSING OF BRANCH USED IN CAPOTE FILM
description: This community's tiny post office, tucked in a corner of John Hall's store where it has stood unchanged for three generations and where portions of Truman Capote's ''A Christmas Memory'' were filmed, closed Friday partly because officials believed it tarnished the Postal Service image.

title: Chief Resigns
description: David C. Struckhoff has resigned as president and chief executive officer of the Council on Foundations, and the organization, whose members give more than 40 percent of the grants made by private groups, is searching for a successor.

title: Around the World; Malaysia Arrests an Aide Of Next Premier as Spy
description: The Malaysian Government detained a close aide of the country's next Prime Minister today and ordered the expulsion of three Soviet Embassy officials, accusing them of spying.

title: WEINBERGER IS PRESSED TO DECIDE ON NEW BOMBER AND MX BASING
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has come under increasing pressure to make two tough decisions - one on selecting a new long-range bomber, the other on basing the MX nuclear missile - that will go far toward setting the policy on the military posture of the United States and on spending for the rest of this decade.

title: Time's Profit Grows 20.9%
description: Time Inc., the nation's largest magazine publisher, yesterday reported second-quarter earnings of $49.2 million, or $1.60 a share, up from $41.6 million, or $1.49 a share, a year before.

title: ITALY WON'T TALK WITH TERRORISTS
description: ROME (AP) - Italy will not barter with the Red Brigades for the lives of three kidnapping victims held by the Marxist terrorists, Interior Minister Virginio Rognoni told the Parliament today.

title: CHALLENGE IN ACCOUNTING
description: The job doesn't pay anything, said Richard S. Hickok, new president of the international accounting firm Klynveld Main Goerdeler, but you can't beat the challenges.

title: Linda Grey Going to Bantam
description: Linda Grey, editor in chief of Dell Books, will move to Bantam Books next month as editorial director of adult fiction and nonfiction. At the same time, Alan Rinzler, executive editor of trade books, which is primarily Bantam's hard-cover and trade paperback line, has been named editorial director of trade books.

title: JUNE RETAIL SALES UP STRONG 1.2%
description: Retail sales rose 1.2 percent, seasonally adjusted, in June after falling for two consecutive months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: DALLAS STUNNED BY SLAYING OF COUPLE
description: They huddled in small groups today in the almost deserted halls of the Schreiber Memorial United Methodist Church, trying to make sense of what seemed utterly senseless.

title: MAYOR KOCH AND THE POLITICS OF MASS TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: CAR'S AIR-CONDITIONING HAS
description: RAIL COMMUTERS STEAMING By ARI L. GOLDMAN

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $6.8 million extraordinary gain

title: Canso Credit Line
description: The United Canso Oil and Gas Company, a Calgary, Alberta, oil and energy exploration concern, said it had established a $175 million (Canadian) line of credit to help finance its previously announced acquisition of Great Basins Petroleum Ltd., the Canadian unit of the Great Basins Petroleum Company of Los Angeles, and two subsidiaries. The Canadian dollar is worth approximately 83 United States cents.

title: INTERMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONOCO BID IS EASED BY DUPONT
description: With the bidding war for Conoco Inc. leading to by far the biggest takeover ever transacted, E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the huge chemical complex, yesterday increased its offering price for the ninth-largest oil company to $7.6 billion.

title: CENTURY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
City's Bonds Draw Investors
description: Investor demand for New York City's newest bond issue was ''exceptionally good in the midst of a very bad market over all,'' an official at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment banking firm that is orchestrating the $100 million sale, said yesterday.

title: INDIA, AND REAGAN'S TILT TOWARD PAKISTAN
description: 04.8,0,340.4,2,1288,0The Administration has embarked on far-reaching programs of military aid to Pakistan and China, highlighted by a controversial plan to provide NATO-model F-16 fighter-bombers to Islamabad. Both deliberately orchestrated initiatives were intended to send warning signals to Moscow, but their resonance has proved equally powerful in the world's most populous non-Communist country, India, which has fought traumatic wars with Pakistan and China and still considers them potential military adversaries.

title: ISAELIS DOWN MIG IN A LEBANON RAID
description: Israeli jets shot down a Syrian MIG fighter over southern Lebanon today as Syrian aircraft tried to disrupt an Israeli air strike against Palestinian targets, the military command announced.

title: Todd Cruz on Probation For Theft in Edmonton
description: Todd Cruz, a shortstop in the Chicago White Sox system, was placed on a nine-month ''conditional discharge'' today by a judge in Edmonton, Alberta, for breaking into a department store, a team spokesman said.

title: HUTTON, E F, GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid June 30

title: MERRILL LYNCH TOPS $1 BILLION IN EQUITY
description: Merrill Lynch & Company reported yesterday that during the second quarter its equity, the funds invested by its shareholders, passed the $1 billion mark, reinforcing its position as the nation's largest securities firm.

title: JOHNNYCAKE IS TRADITIONAL, AND CONTROVERSAL, IN RHODE ISLAND
description: USQUEPAUGH, R.I. Benjamin Franklin extolled their flavor, calling them ''better than a Yorkshire muffin.'' The Marquis de Lafayette consumed them in great quantities whenever he was in Rhode Island. An American diplomat abroad always has ingredients sent overseas so he can make them. To the residents of the nation's smallest state, they have been a staple for centuries, eaten at breakfast, lunch, dinner and in between.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 26
French Skipper Claims Record for Atlantic Trip
description: Marc Pajot, a French yachtsman, arrived today at this southernmost tip of England from New York and claimed a world record for the fastest west-to-east crossing of the Atlantic Ocean under sail.

title: Around the World; Iran Opens Its Campaign To Elect New President
description: Iran opened a 10-day presidential election campaign today, with Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai saying he thought he could win.

title: FORD DISPALYS ITS CARS OF THE FUTURE
description: The car of the future will look a lot different from the one now in your driveway, but the engine is not likely to be radically changed.

title: Brazil Ford Struck Again
description: One day after going back to work in what appeared to be the end of the weeklong walkout, some 9,000 workers today again struck one of the three factories belonging to the Ford Motor Company's Brazilian unit.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Suit Seeks Seizure Of Diluted Orange Juice
description: The Food and Drug Administration filed suit today to seize 800 55-gallon drums of what the agency says is adulterated orange juice concentrate from Citrex Inc., a juice processor in San Antonio.

title: STEELMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Japan to Push E.E.C. Goods
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan directed Government offices today to promote imports from the 10-nation European Economic Community to shrink Japan's lopsided trade surplus with the Common Market, a spokesman at the Prime Minister's office said.

title: INSILCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COLLEGE VACATION FOR THE OVER-60'S
description: up-and-go. According to him, it's because he didn't waste any energy growing when he was young.

title: LAWYER WAS COUNSEL FOR CITY
description: William Chamberlain Chanler, a trial lawyer who served as Corporation Counsel of New York City under Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia from 1938 to 1942, died Monday at his home in Goldens Bridge, N.Y. He was 85 years old.

title: SLAYING SUSPECT IN ATLANTA ASKS RELEASE ON BAIL
description: Wayne B. Williams, who is charged with murdering one of Atlanta's 28 slain young blacks, promised a Fulton County Superior Court judge today that he would stay out of trouble if the court granted his request for bail.

title: PAN AM PLANS 10% CUTBACK
description: Pan American World Airways announced plans yesterday for a 10 percent cutback in flight operations and comparable labor reductions to stem record financial losses that threaten its survival as an airline.

title: EX-MEMBER OF JUNTA IS ARRESTED IN ARGENTINA
description: A former member of the ruling military junta here was placed under 10-day house arrest today for his increasingly critical remarks about the Government.

title: HEARINGS START ON INTERNMENT OF JAPANESE-AMERICANS IN '42
description: Nearly 40 years after the internment of 110,000 Japanese-Americans in wartime camps, a Federal commission began hearings here today to decide what compensation, if any, was due to those who were held in the camps and their families.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary income of $700,000 for the qr and $2.1 million for the 6 mos...C-Including extraordinary income of $500,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect accounting for compensated absences

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
HONEYWELL EARNINGS UP 27.5%
description: Honeywell Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose 27.5 percent, to $71.4 million, or $3.15 ar share, from $56 million, or $2.51 a share, in the second quarter of 1980.

title: Notes On People; Irate Reader Makes Views Known
description: Newspaper editors often get angry reactions to editorials, and in his 25 years as a newsman, John Bowman, the editor of The Streator (Ill.) Times Press, says he has had his share, though nothing like he had last Friday.

title: Stocks Slip With Dow Off 6.09
description: The stock market drifted lower yesterday amid moderate volume. The decline and slower activity, analysts said, were partly attributable the wait-and-see stance of institutional investors in the face of uncertainty about the outlook for interest rates and the shape of the tax bill being debated in Congress. Also, a trading halt in two key takeover-related shares dampened activity somewhat.

title: BASTILLE DAY: NEW FACES IN THE CROWD
description: In 1936, when an earlier Socialist Government, Leon Blum's Popular Front, achieved the unheard of and gave every man and woman in France a month's vacation, a conservative Paris paper ran a cartoon showing an elegant old gaffer looking with scorn at the ocean. ''I shall never bathe in it with Communists,'' he said.

title: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In response to ''New Yorkers, etc.'' (July 8)
description: A GUARANTEE

title: Around the Nation; Consultant Found Guilty In Theft of Trade Secrets
