description: A guilty verdict has been returned against the president of a consulting firm on charges that he stole trade secrets from three semiconductor companies.

title: JUDEGE ASSERTS CASEY, C.I.A. CHIEF, MISLED STOCK BUYERS IN '68
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, knowingly participated with several others in an investment offering for a farming company in 1968 that ''omitted and misrepresented facts'' to investors, according to a Federal District Court decision handed down in May.

title: Soccer Player Is Suspended
description: The North American Soccer League has fined Bob Newton of the Jacksonville Tea Men $250 and suspended him without pay for two games for having caused what Keith Walker, director of officials, called the worst injury of its kind ever in the league.

title: Around the Nation; Financier Denies Efforts To Kill Wife by Injection
description: Claus von Bulow pleaded not guilty today to charges that he twice tried to murder his wife with insulin injections during visits to their Newport mansion.

title: SANTA CLARA UNRUFFLED AFTER SPRAYING
description: Twenty-one-year-old Rick Rollans peered closely at the leaves of the lush green olive tree he was methodically stripping early today in the wake of the first spraying of the pesticide malathion over the green lawns and fashionable homes of the Santa Clara Valley this morning. He failed to find a hint of the pesticide.

title: NEW DEPUTY FOR C. I. A.
description: John H. Stein, true to his profession, is not a household name. With 20 years of service in the Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine operations, Mr. Stein, the newly appointed Deputy Director for Operations, has made a point of staying out of the news.

title: Seagram's Deal Maker And the Bid for Conoco
description: After 40 years in investment banking and countless mergers fostered, financed and blocked, Mark Millard thought he had seen it all. And then came Conoco.

title: DISNEY, WALT, PRODUCTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Companies
description: Du Pont sweetened its offering price for Conoco to $7.6 billion, as the bidding contest for the ninth-largest oil company intensified. The chemical company's offer works out to $95 a share for 40 percent of Conoco, and an exchange of 1.7 shares of Du Pont for each of the remaining Conoco shares. (Page D1.)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle in Science Times yesterday incor- rectly identified Federal laws that are said to authorize regulations on the transmission of scientific and techni- cal information to foreign nationals. They are the Arms Export Control Act of 1976 and the Export Administration Act of 1979.

title: APECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including foreign currency translation gains of $363,000 for the qr and $632,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including foreign currency translation gains of $74,000 for the qr and $54,000 for the 6 mos

title: Floods Hit China Area
description: Floods have hit Sichuan Province, threatening the homes of two million people, the Chinese radio said tonight. Two towns, Jintang and Ziyang, have been flooded and about a million acres of farmland inundated. The radio said 8 to 16 inches of rain fell in the provincial capital of Chengdu and 20 counties in a 20-hour period ending yesterday afternoon.

title: REMARKS BY SOVIET DELEGATE ARE RECEIVED WITH RELIEVED APPLAUSE
description: The head of the Soviet delegation to the Polish party congress said today that Moscow was confident that the Polish Communists would overcome their economic and political crisis through their own efforts. But he maintained that the Soviet Union could not be indifferent to the plight of its ''friends and allies.''

title: CHASE'S OPERATING NET OFF
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation reported yesterday that its net operating earnings declined 2.3 percent, to $100.6 million, in the second quarter of 1981 from $103 million in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: Lost Refuge
description: A friend who likes to read called in agitation. ''The story in The Times about unruliness, even violence, by library patrons threw me into a panic,'' he said.

title: LANECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 6
Keaton Retrospective At Lincoln Plaza Cinema
description: A Buster Keaton film festival will run from Aug. 12 to Sept. 19 at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema, Broadway at West 62d Street. Presented by New Yorker Films and Raymond Rohauer, the festival will consistof 11 features and 23 shorts.

title: Weinberger Sees Peril Of Conventional War
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said tonight that there was no guarantee that nuclear balance between the United States and the Soviet Union would deter a major conventional war.

title: Q & A
description: Q. As people frequently ask, is there a genuine difference between prawns and shrimp or are the two names interchangeable?

title: PROFITING BY OTTAWA
description: .8,0,174.8,2,478.4,0WASHINGTON - It is curious that Reagan Administration officials have been working diligently to deflate expectations that any concrete achievements will result from the conference in Ottawa of the leaders of the world's seven leading industrial countries.

title: Alan Ball Still Has A Kick
description: Alan Ball is 37 years old and the only member of England's 1966 World Cup champions still active as a soccer player. He said today that he didn't believe he could be another Stanley Matthews, who played until he was 50 and then was knighted for his contribution to English football.

title: Vauxhall Plans 2,000 Layoffs
description: Vauxhall Motors, a British unit of the General Motors Corporation, said it planned to dismiss another 2,000 workers amid a continuing decline in demand for its vehicles in domestic and export markets. The cuts, which are in addition to a layoff earlier this year of 6,000 workers, would reduce the company's work force to about 21,000.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said that an average rate of 17.185 percent was set at the weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper, compared with a 17.378 percent rate last week.

title: Hunt Pleased With Ruling
description: W. Herbert Hunt, flush with a Federal court victory over the Securities and Exchange Commission, today predicted further disclosure of illegal activity by the regulatory agency in its investigation of silver dealings by Mr. Hunt and his brother Nelson B. Hunt.

title: AIC PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S SPEECH ON ADMINISTRATION'S POLICY ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the Foreign Policy Association at the New York Hilton Hotel:

title: No Headline
description: Associated Press LEADERS IN TOUR DE FRANCE: Pedaling through Alpe d'Huez are, from left, Bernard Hinault of France, Lucien van Impe of Belgium and Robert Alban of France. Hinault leads in the overall standing with a total time of 77 hours 32 minutes 27 seconds; van Impe is 9 minutes 39 seconds behind and Alban 1 minute 10 seconds back. Yesterday's stage, the 19th, was won by Peter Winnen of the Netherlands. Tour ends Sunday.

title: INVENTORIES UP 0.7% IN MAY
description: Inventories held by United States businesses rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, the fifth consecutive monthly increase, as sales fell and the national economy sagged, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Index; International
description: As the royal wedding draws near, the British are agog A2 Vietnam urged to withdraw from Cambodia A3 Leftist chic are out in force at Bastille Day fete in France A3 Argentina places ex-member of junta under house arrest A3 Around the World A5 Menachem Begin receives a formal bid to form a government A8 Haig aide insists rights policy is evenhanded A10 Government/Politics Mobile, Ala., voters reject change in form of government A12 Largest conference ever begins work on budget A14 About Washington: Camera corps takes over on Capitol Hill A14 Ex-Deputy Director of C.I.A. viewed as a nonprofessional A18 Securities lawyers say inquiry on Hugle case is unlikely A18 Nassau reaches settlement to ease crowding at county jail B2 General Around the Nation A12 Youths flee Atlanta fear at Minnesota camp A12 Suspect's sister testifies against him in 1952 slayings B2 Jersey high court sets rules on hypnotized witnesses B3 Sewage from plant in Sheepshead Bay imperils beaches B3 Warrant issued for removing baby from hospital B4 Indutry/Labor Federal mediator joins talks between postal service and unions A16 Obituaries Rene A. Wormser, lawyer who specialized in estate planning A16 William Chanler, former New York City Corporation Counsel A16 Living Section Food Outdoor cooking with Latin flavor C1

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Company of America said it had shut down 39,000 tons of annual aluminum production at two plants because of continuing weak demand.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gains on the sale of discontinued operations of $15 for the qr and $15,855,000 for the 6 mos...C-After losses from operations of $54,000 for the qr and $44,000 for the 6 mos

title: HERCULES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
obsever; NO, NO, DON'T DO IT
description: President Reagan has been taking a lot of abuse from people who say he has no foreign policy. It's time the President got himself a foreign policy, they say. It's time he made a speech to tell everybody what it is. What rot.

title: POLISH PARTY SPLIT OVER VOTING RULES
description: An extraordinary congress of the Polish Communist Party began today with a procedural dispute behind closed doors that delayed the election of a new party leader.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: The horseshoe crab Cannot grab you, Cannot stab you. He cannot pinch you, He cannot sting you, There is no trouble He can bring you. So when you meet him, Kindly treat him. (Since you cannot eat him.)

title: 2 BRAVES PITCHERS STILL DRAW PAYCHECKS
description: The paychecks are still coming in for John Montefusco and Gene Garber, pitchers for the Atlanta Braves, even though no baseball has been played since June 11.

title: Around the Nation; Razing of Detroit Church For Auto Plant Begins
description: The police ripped a door off a Roman Catholic church today and evicted a dozen squatters who had tried for a month to stop a General Motors construction project from leveling Poletown, a old neighborhood largely inhabited by Polish immigrants and their descendants.

title: MOBIL SAYS IT WANTED TO PUT FUEL PRICE RISE AS HIGH AS 6
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected a possible fuel price increase of 5 or 6 cents a gallon it contended was necessary to offset new state taxes on oil companies because ''we didn't think the marketplace could handle that.'' Instead, it said, it selected a 3-cent increase for gasoline, diesel fuel and jet fuel.

title: Chevron Gas Well
description: Chevron U.S.A. said it had drilled the deepest producing well yet in the Overthrust Belt in southwestern Wyoming - a natural gas well 16,780 feet deep. The company said that the well flowed natural gas at a stabilized rate of 2.8 million cubic feet a day.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Economic Scene; Summit Test For Reagan
description: PRIME MINISTER MARGARET THATCHER initially was determined to reject the contention of her critics that high unemployment had something to do with the rioting that has swept working-class areas of British cities.

title: NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MELLON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DIPLOMAT QUESTIONS 'INTREPID'S' STORY
description: William Stephenson was knighted after running Britain's wartime secret service in the United States, his story became the subject of the 1976 book ''A Man Called Intrepid,'' and two years ago, NBC-TV ran a three-part, six-hour series based on the book. But a new book by Winston Churchill's private secretary has stirred a controversy by attempting to debunk the reputation of Sir William, the Canadian-born millionaire industrialist whose exploits have become a legend of World War II.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Including $576,000 or 6 cents a shr net nonrecurring gain on the sale of a mobile home park; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: Steinbergs Offer to Buy Reliance, Leasco Stock
description: Saul P. Steinberg, chairman and president of the Reliance Group and of the Leasco Corporation, moved yesterday to make those companies private by offering, with members of his family, to buy all of the common shares outstanding for about $500 million in cash, stock and debentures.

title: FIRST AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Moses Lifts Streak In 400 Hurdles to 67
description: Edwin Moses of the United States and Steve Ovett of Britain came close today to breaking their world records in their track specialties.

title: BEST BUYS
description: LOCAL produce is starting to come into the New York market and is bringing lower prices for many summer vegetables. String beans are an excellent buy at 38 cents a pound. These can be steamed or tossed while hot in a lemon and olive oil dressing and served as a salad.

title: On the Outside Looking In
description: THE baseball strike entertains nobody, but it must bring a flicker of wry amusement to Charlie Finley, the demon insurance peddler, and Marshall Field, the publisher. Finley was trying to persuade Field to throw in with him as purchasers of the Chicago Cubs when The Chicago Tribune bought the team out from under them.

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FORT HOWARD PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dr. Harry McCord Scrivener, Headed Drug-Counseling Unit
description: Dr. Harry McCord Scrivener, director of the drug rehabilitation and family counseling unit of the Southeast Nassau Guidance Center in Wantagh, L.I., died of a heart attack June 30 while jogging in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens. He was 43 years old and was a resident of Forest Hills and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The U.S. has a broad agenda of specific arms control efforts and negotiations already under way or about to be launched. The charge that we are not interested in arms control or that we have cut off communications with the Soviets on these issues is simply not true." Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: The City; Fines Are Upheld For Transit Strike
description: Contempt convictions and $720,000 in fines against transit workers' unions during the New York City bus and subway strike in April 1980 were upheld by a state appeals court in Brooklyn.

title: OUTDOR COOKING WITH LATIN FLAVOR
description: RECENTLY a group of Latin Americans scaled a rocky hill in upstate New York, forded a stream in the pouring rain and set down in a dripping wood for a cookout. Undaunted by the weather - and the gypsy moths - they hauled up heavy bags of meat and fish, bread, empanadas (meat pastry turnovers), tortillas, salads, a bowl of black beans and two cases of wine. They even brought tapes of Latin music - a serious South American barbecue must include dancing. The white wine was put to cool in the running stream, the red wine uncorked and passed around. Then they set to work to make a fire.

title: NOUVELLE CUISINE'S LUKEWARM DISHES CATCHING ON
description: The word ''tiede'' has joined ''au poivre vert'' and ''caramelise'' in the vocabularies of those who would understand a contemporary French menu. ''Tiede'' means lukewarm, and more and more dishes are being served that way. And although most of these dishes, such as poached salmon, were designed for the formal table rather than the picnic bench, many of them make ideal summer fare.

title: LOWER OIL STORES STIR CONCERN
description: High interest rates are causing an erosion of oil inventories that some Reagan Administration energy experts fear could leave the United States vulnerable to a sudden interruption of foreign oil supplies.

title: NEW BATTLES ERUPT IN ULSTER AS I.R.A. MILITANT IS MOURNED
description: Street battles flared in Northern Ireland today as Roman Catholic mourners filed past the coffin of Martin Hurson, the sixth Irish nationalist hunger striker to die since early May.

title: Bridge: Experts Sometimes Make Bids That Seem Eccentric
description: Problems arise in standard bidding methods when holding the strength for a two no-trump opening but with a slightly unsuitable distribution. The hand is usually too strong for a one-bid but not quite strong enough for a game-forcing opening.

title: REUTERS WEIGHS PURCHASING OF UNITED PRESS INTERNATIONAL
description: Reuters, the London-based news agency, said yesterday that it was ''actively considering'' buying United Press International from its American owners, the E.W. Scripps Company. The combination, if carried out, would make Reuters the world's largest news agency.

title: Umpires Are Out A Refund
description: The major league baseball umpires, who received a month's paycheck July 1, will be required to refund part of the money because they are entitled to only 30 days' salary in the event of a strike.

title: THE MASS PRODUCTION OF 'GOURMET' FOOD
description: THE aroma beckons, promising freshness and awakening memories of grandma in the kitchen. In storefronts that turn out warm cookies and croissants there is no grandma, however, and probably not even a kitchen. Just an oven, a sales clerk and a busy cash register.

title: CANRAD-HANOVIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $183,800 for the qr and $294,500 for the 6 mos

title: MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Baseball Antitrust Status Challenged
description: The Justice Department told Congress today that it supported legislation that would subject baseball to the same antitrust laws adhered to by other sports.

title: THE STAGE: MALCOLM X AND ELIJAH MUHAMMAD
description: THE writing of historical drama is a risky business, especially when the history is as fresh as yesterday's headlines. The specter of famous real-life characters can frighten well-meaning playwrights into contriving preachy message plays or sanctimonious pageants or bland docu-dramas about stick figures. But Laurence Holder, the author of two one-act plays at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, doesn't frighten easily. In the second of his works, ''When the Chickens Came Home to Roost,'' he has taken a pair of intimidating, legendary men - Elijah Muhammad and Malcolm X - and brought them to utterly convincing life.

title: AT CONOCO, A WARY WATCH
description: When climbing into his car in the morning, the Conoco manager no longer receives the polite how-do-youdo from his suburban New York neighbors. Instead they shout across the lawn: ''Who owns you today?''

title: REAGAN ASSAILS LACK OF A 3D YEAR
description: The House Ways and Means Committee approved a two-year cut in individual income tax rates today. President Reagan promptly denounced the Democratic bill because it does not include the third year of rate cuts that he has urged.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: JOANN, a 35-year-old mother of two, was scheduled to undergo a sterilization operation. She arrived at the hospital at 8 A.M., was through with surgery by 10, was discharged shortly after 1 P.M. and was home in time to lunch with her sons. She recalls: ''It made all the difference not having to spend the night in the hospital. I wasn't sick and I'm sure I recovered a lot faster at home than I would have in a sterile hospital room.''

title: U.S. Takes 3 Golds; Soccer Team in Final
description: On a day when United States athletes earned three gold medals, the United States soccer team upset Britain, 3-1, today and advanced to the final against South Africa at the Maccabiah Games.

title: PARIS
description: IT is an optometrist's shop now, at 28 rue Boissy d'Anglas. The window displays expensive binoculars and modish sunglasses. Most of the busy people striding past do not even glance at them. How could they know that, 60 years ago, this was Le Boeuf sur le Toit, the boite that was the cradle of modernism in French painting, film and literature?

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 29
FIRST CITY BANCORPORATION OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising by Philip Dougherty; The Coast Is Getting New Taste
description: THE consumers of Los Angeles and San Francisco will soon be getting what the consumers of Boston have already experienced. A taste of Nadler & Larimer advertising for Cheshire English Pub Beer. And if they are swayed by ''One taste will tell you why the English spend so much time in their pubs,'' they might have a taste of the beer as well.

title: HAIG SAY U.S. HOPES TO BEGIN ARMS TALK SOON
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said yesterday that the Reagan Administration hoped to begin ''formal talks'' with the Soviet Union between mid-November and mid-December on limiting medium-range nuclear weapons in the European area.

title: Keefe Brasselle, Acted Lead in 'Cantor Story'
description: Keefe Brasselle, a film actor known for his leading role in ''The Eddie Cantor Story,'' died last Tuesday in Rancho Los Amigos Hospital in Downey, near Los Angeles. He was 58 years old and had been hospitalized several times during the last few years for a liver ailment.

title: The Region
description: Two new 350-foot sections of pipe will be laid through the woods here to bypass the major break that occurred Monday in Newark's main water-supply aqueduct.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Harry Saferight, catcher, and assigned him to Rochester of the International League.; COLLEGES

title: About New York
description: New York often seems a city in perpetual flux, with change the only constant. One morning, with a small belch of explosives and a puff of plaster dust, the building around the corner is reduced from a sum to its parts. The next day, the grocery down the street becomes a gourmet shop. Once thriving businesses are abandoned. Abandoned buildings are transformed into cooperative lofts.

title: FIRST ATLANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STATE STRIKE ENDS IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Since Paul Revere and Sons finished coppering its dome in 1802, the Massachusetts State House on Beacon Hill has served as both a shrine to the values of American democracy and a workhouse of contemporary state politics - two functions that have sometimes seemed at odds.

title: ART'S WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including gains of $418,000 for the qr and $1,982,000 for the yr from separated operations...C-Including $137,000 gain from separated operations

title: CREST-FOAM reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: 1980 results have been restated to include the operations of General Semiconductor Industries on a pooling of interests basis

title: Jr. JUDGE O'CONNOR MAKES COURTESY CALL AT CAPITOL; Attorney General William French Smith
description: Sandra Day O'Connor sat down between Senators Howard H. Baker Jr. and Robert C. Byrd this afternoon and immediately scored a political point.

title: Careers; Ph.D.'s Get Business Skills
description: ABOUT three years ago the New York State Office of Education, with the help of the National Endowment for the Humanities, worked out a program with New York University to provide a short, intensive program of business courses called Careers in Business - Campus to Corporation to ''retread'' holders of doctoral degrees in liberal arts subjects so that they could find jobs in business.

title: Escapee Yields Hostages
description: A 23-year-old prison escapee yesterday abducted a broadcast station sales executive and then held two other station employees hostage for several hours before surrendering, the police said.

title: Israeli Officer Killed By Concealed Bomb
description: The Israeli military commander of the Rafah region of occupied Sinai was killed today by a bomb at the southern end of the Gaza Strip. Five other Israelis - two soliders and three policemen - were wounded.

title: CHIEF U.S. MEDIATOR ENTERS NEGOTIATINS ON POSTAL CONTRACT
description: The chief Federal labor mediator, Kenneth E. Moffett, today entered lagging negotiations between the United States Postal Service and major postal unions as the contract deadline approached.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a review in Weekend on Friday of a dance concert by Rika Burnham, the credit for the fluorescent light structures was incorrect. They were created by Randy Williams.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FACE TO FACE Marlene VerPlanck has almost certainly visited you, if anonymously, in your home at some time in the last number of years. She is a singer and her voice on television commercials has warbled the goodness of a cigarette, the yumminess of a soup, the joys of Amtrak, the coolness of a cola, the lovability of New York (she did the ''I Love New York'' jingle). More recently, she has been showing up in person at clubs, and tonight she starts at Marty's, in the garden room of the East Side restaurant at 1265 Third Avenue, near 72d Street (249-4100).

title: VASQUEZ PROPOSED MONEY, MAPLE SAYS
description: Eddie Maple testified yesterday that Jacinto Vasquez, a fellow jockey, asked him if he ''wanted to make some money'' in connection with a fixed race at Saratoga in 1974 but that he did not report it to the stewards because ''I just made light of it.''

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $1,622,000 for the 6 mos.. C-Net loss

title: MOBILE VOTES TO RETAIN AT-LARGE ELECTORAL SYSTEM
description: Voters decided overwhelmingly here today to retain the city's present form of government, which is being challenged in court by blacks who contend that it weakens their voting power.

title: Washington; REAGAN AT THE SUMMIT
description: President Reagan's first major test in the field of foreign policy will come next week when he meets with the other leaders of the industrial nations in Canada.

title: Gulf Oil's President Elected Chairman
description: James E. Lee, the president of the Gulf Oil Corporation, was elected chairman and chief executive officer of the world's seventhlargest oil company by the board of directors yesterday, effective Dec. 1.

title: Aqua-Chem Buyer
description: The Coca-Cola Company said it had agreed to sell its Aqua-Chem Inc. subsidiary to Societe Lyonnaise des Eaux et de l'Eclairage, a Paris-based company, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Completion of the sale is expected in the third quarter of 1981, the Atlanta-based company said. Aqua-Chem, with headquarters in Milwaukee, had sales of $130 million in 1980.

title: UNION IN SAN JOSE ACCEPTS PAY PACT ,N15
description: A union that struck so that women would get pay equal to men's pay for comparable jobs approved an agreement today that both sides called a major step toward wage parity.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including net gains from major land sales of $65 million or $1.32 a shr for the latest 6 mos and $10.4 million or 22 cents a shr for the previous 6 mos and $8 million net charge associat with the phasing out of unprofitable product lines

title: Russians Buy Canada Grain
description: The Canadian Wheat Board today announced the sale of just over 2.3 million metric tons of wheat and barley for shipment to the Soviet Union.

title: The City; Dormitory Notes To Aid Columbia
description: The New York State Dormitory Authority has issued $36 million in three-year notes for Columbia University, according to William Sharkey, executive director of the Dormitory Authority. The notes carry an interest rate of 8 1/8 percent.

title: FIRST UNION BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Texas Oil's Profit Up
description: The Texas Oil and Gas Corporation, citing increased levels of production and higher prices for its natural gas, said today that its profit for its fiscal third quarter rose 35.7 percent from the same quarter a year ago. The oil and gas exploration and production concern said it earned $50.6 million, or 53 cents a share, in the quarter ended May 31 compared with $37.3 million, or 39 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1980. Revenues rose 37 percent, to $415.6 million from $303.9 million.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: FROM time to time I sit quietly in my kitchen, looking over my equipment, trying to decide what to write about next in this column. Doing just that the other day I was startled - almost embarrassed, actually - when my eye fell on an old black steel frying pan. In all these months, how could I have neglected it?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The U.S. has a broad agenda of specific arms control efforts and negotiations already under way or about to be launched.

title: No Headline
description: Following are the texts of letters exchanged today by Max Hugel in resigning as deputy director of operations for the Central Intelligence Agency and William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, in accepting the resignation. Hugel's Letter

title: Giants Opening Camp on a Positive Note
description: Instead of wearing the traditional white coach's shirt, Ray Perkins of the Giants wore a brown polo shirt with flowered short sleeves. Assistant coaches played tennis. Harry Carson, the linebacker, visited from his home in nearby Ossining.

title: JOHN SAMUELS RESIGNS AS HEAD OF CITY CENTER
description: John S. Samuels 3d, under pressure from a group of dissident board members, announced his resignation yesterday as chairman of the City Center for Music and Drama.

title: WORLD OF MEN'S CLUBS: A GUIDED TOUR
description: MEN'S clubs appear to be increasingly in the center of controversy these days -the question of female membership in particular has raised some hackles. But I still regard them fondly. As a member at various times of six clubs in Paris, London and New York and as a visitor to others in Singapore, Dublin, Milwaukee, Cairo, San Francisco, Boston and Kuala Lumpur, I have always found them to be places of comfort, where for a few hours one can escape the abrasions of business and the demands of family.

title: Tests Asked in Slayings
description: Psychological tests have been requested for 14-year-old David Keeler, held on two counts of delinquent conduct in the shooting deaths Sunday of his parents, William A. and Anita Keeler. Doug Mulder, a lawyer hired to defend the youth, asked in a hearing yesterday that psychiatric and psychological tests be conducted.

title: About Washington
description: Self-government seemed in danger of degenerating into one vast photo opportunity on Capitol Hill today as some of the longest-smiling politicians in the land crossed paths and camera lenses in a daylong scramble for attention.

title: 'SEIZE BEAT' FROM FUSION CHAMPION
description: BLONDIE'S disco hit ''Heart of Glass'' sparked the still-developing alliance between white new-wave rock and black disco and funk in 1978-79, but the most consistent champion of punk-funk fusion has been New York's Ze records. At one time or another, Ze's roster has included the punk-funk pioneer James Chance and various refugees from Dr. Buzzard's Original Savannah Band, all of whom have been dedicated to making original, offbeat dance music.

title: Gulf to Buy Back 10 Million Shares
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it will buy up to 10 million of its own shares from time to time, beginning later this month.

title: DICOMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $21,000 for the qr and $70,000 for the 6 mos

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''BLONDIE is a group,'' the promotional buttons used to read, but many listeners insisted on thinking of Deborah Harry, the group's blond lead singer, as Blondie. These days, Blondie is not a group. Several members of Blondie have been producing records for or playing with other groups, and Miss Harry recently completed ''Koo Koo,'' her first solo album, with the help of her boyfriend and songwriting partner, Chris Stein, and the production team of Bernard Edwards and Nile Rodgers.

title: WINE TALK
description: powered generators at the Chalone winery, and there is no telephone, for the distance from Soledad, the nearest town, is too great.

title: 10 Disputed Claims Resolved Favorably
description: During June, 10 of the 13 national advertising claims investigations conducted by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus were resolved when the advertisers were able to support the disputed claims. An unusually high percentage.

title: PRUDENTIAL TOPS BID FOR CONGEN
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said last night that it had agreed to acquire the Connecticut General Mortgage and Realty Investment Trust for $340 million in cash. The offer tops a $267 million offer initiated on June 16 by the pension fund of the British coal miners' union.

title: Chicago Beaches Reopened
description: Park District officials reopened all but one city beach today after closing them for a day after the discovery of high counts of human waste bacteria. Marshall Weil, a park district spokesman, said the latest tests for contamination indicated levels safe for swimming, except for the Ardmore Avenue beach on the North Side.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP (CINCINNATI, OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHASE MANHATTAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
International Paper Gains 9.1% In Quarter; Boise Net Slips 17%
description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest paper producer, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter increased 9.1 percent as sales rose 9.4 percent.

title: The Region; Station Repairs Set For Raritan Line
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The directors of N.J. Transit, the state's masstransit agency, authorized $1.2 million for the improvement of 13 stations on the Raritan Valley Line.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After securities losses of $2.3 million and $4.4 million in latest qr and 6 mos, respectively...C-After securities losses of $2.6 million and $5 million in the qr and 6 mos respectively

title: TV: CECIL RHODES SITS FOR AN IRONIC PORTRAIT
description: TNIGHT at 8 on WNET-TV, Channel 13, ''A Touch of Churchill, A Touch of Hitler: The Life of Cecil Rhodes'' is the kind of biography of an Englishman that only the British would dare attempt. The attitude is sneering. The tone is withering. In terms of journalistic balance or objectivity, the entire piece is terribly unfair, but, it would seem, scathingly on target. It is the kind of eccentric portrait that Cecil Rhodes undoubtedly deserves.

title: INQUIRY ON HUGEL SAID TO BE UNLIKELY
description: The disclosure today of assertions that Max C. Hugel and others violated Federal securities laws, which led to Mr. Hugel's resignation as deputy director of operations for the Central Intelligence Agency, is not likely to lead to any enforcement action by the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to securities lawyers.

title: DOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POLICE SEEK HER PARENTS
description: A warrant was issued yesterday for the arrest of John and Pat Powers for removing their 15-month-old daughter from New York Hospital in violation of a Family Court order.

title: FISHER SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SRI's Washington Chief
description: William B. Bader still has not quite figured out how to negotiate the last two miles to his new job - but he is working on it. The 49-year-old Mr. Bader was appointed this week as vice president in charge of the Washington, D.C., office of SRI International, a nonprofit consulting company based in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Lord Avie Wins Easily In Return to Monmouth
description: Lord Avie, last year's 2-year-old champion, made a triumphant return today to Monmouth Park after an absence of almost five months due to a strained ligament.

title: On Leftover Leftovers
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I identified with ''A Leftover Primer: Meals That Come in From the Cold'' by Robert Farrar Capon (June 24). Just last week my daughter went home after a visit with the folks and left us with a pot of cooked bulgur.

title: The City;
description: Secret Service agents seized $1 million in counterfeit $5, $10 and $20 bills and arrested four men in a raid at 653 West 161st Street, in Washington Heights. A printing press, plates and $50,000 worth of fake food stamps were also seized.

title: JERSEY COURT SETS HYPNOSIS RULES
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that testimony gathered from a witness with the aid of hypnosis could be used in a criminal case, and for the first time laid out rules that must be followed for hypnotically induced evidence to be admissible.

title: FLOYD PRIMED TO TACKLE BRITISH OPEN
description: When he played the British Open golf tournament for the first time 12 years ago, Ray Floyd was neither awed nor impressed. His score, 16 shots behind the winner, Tony Jacklin, reflected inexperience.

title: AS THE WEDDING DRAWS NEARER, BRITISH ARE AGOG
description: Barbara Cartland, the romantic novelist, isn't coming, even though she is the bride's stepgrandmother. She says she doesn't want to distract public attention. The Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Protestant clergyman and politician, isn't coming because Basil Cardinal Hume is to deliver a prayer. President Reagan isn't coming, partly because of security problems, but his wife is.

title: GREATER JERSEY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary gains of $90,009 for the qr and $120,138 for the 6 mos

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Broker Loan Rate Cuts
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Marine Midland Bank said separately yesterday that they were cutting their broker loan rates to 19 1/2 percent, effective immediately. Manufacturers Hanover was previously posting 20 1/2 percent; Chase, 20 percent, and Marine Midland, 20 3/4 percent.

title: Market Place; Technology Sector Tested
description: technology stocks appear vulnerable, following their spectacular performance of the last two years. In a similar vein, he advised clients this week: ''The key to success in 1981 will be avoiding the big losers.''

title: Government Corn Sales Criticized
description: President Reagan's budget officials are putting pressure on the Agriculture Department to immediately sell millions of bushels of Government-owned corn, raising fears that farm prices will drop, a Congressman from the Middle West said today.

title: RENE A WORMSER, 85, LAWYER
description: Rene A. Wormser, a lawyer who specialized in estate planning and wrote six books on the subject, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 85 years old.

title: MILES DAVIS'S 'HORN'
description: MILES DAVIS'S recent performances at the Kool Jazz Festival, his first New York appearances in five years, have generated considerable controversy. Those who liked what they heard pointed out that Mr. Davis was playing the trumpet superbly, and that his solos were models of dramatic construction and moody intensity.

title: SEWAGE FLOWING AFTER EXPLOSION PERILING BEACHES
description: Three big diesel engines that generate the power for pumping and treating 85 million gallons of sewage a day have failed at a plant in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn and sewage has poured into Jamaica Bay, threatening to pollute beaches in the area.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
News Analysis
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today delivered a good part of the foreign policy speech that Mr. President Reagan said last week did not need to be given, and he gave it on a matter that the Administration has up to now not cared to spotlight.

title: TIMES FIBER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ETHICS HEARING OPENED ON WILLIAMS BY SENATE A. William and Lawyer, Kenneth Feinberg
description: The Senate Select Committee on Ethics began hearing evidence today to determine whether Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. violated the rules of the Senate through his activities depicted in the Abscam investigation. If he is found culpable, he could be censured or expelled from office.

title: Times Announces Executive Changes
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, announced several executive changes yesterday in the newspaper's business management.

title: 4 photos of novelties; DISCOVERIES; 1. It's Real Soap
description: Real soap, the kind we used before soaps got embellished with deodorants or strong perfume, is still to be had. A company called Kiss My Face has imported a big square cake from Greece, where the soap is made from olive oil and mineral alkali so that it produces abundant lather and is not drying. The soap weighs 250 grams (over 1/2 pound) and is $2 the cake from Whole Foods, 117 Prince Street in SoHo, and other health food stores.

title: Notes On People
description: At dedication ceremonies yesterday for New Jersey's $85 million arena in East Rutherford, Governor Byrne commented publicly for the first time on the dispute over the fact that the arena is named for him.

title: SOLOMON IS UPSET
description: John Alexander, who has been out of action almost a year with an ailing back, upset second-seeded Harold Solomon, 6-2, 6-7, 6-1, in the first round of the $175,000 United States Pro tennis championships tonight.

title: Enough of Straddles
description: In recent years, well-heeled investors have latched onto a dandy gimmick for reducing taxes and even deferring them indefinitely. It's called the ''commodity tax straddle,'' and is almost as hard to explain as it was to discover. But luckily for most ordinary taxpayers, Congress has finally caught up with this $1.3 billion loophole. Committees of both the House and Senate have recommended changes in the law that would at least close it somewhat.

title: Reagan Gives Allen a Post
description: President Reagan announced today the appointment of George Allen as chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. Allen, former coach of the Los Angeles Rams and Washington Redskins, replaced Al McGuire in the four-year, nonsalaried position.

title: UNITES STATES HOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONFEREES START WORK ON BUDGET CUTS Latta and Senator Ernest F. Hollings
description: A mammoth House-Senate conference, said to have more participants and issues than any other in the 192-year history of Congress, began today to try to resolve differences in two packages of budget cuts approved by the two chambers.

title: TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Foxboro, in Reversal, Will Allow 9 P.M. Start
description: Town selectmen reversed an earlier vote in a board meeting tonight, clearing the way for the New England Patriots to play the Dallas Cowboys in a Monday night football game.

title: Cigarette Ad Accord Set
description: Three cigarette companies have agreed to pay $100,000 each in civil penalties to settle charges that they did not ''clearly and conspiciously'' display the Surgeon General's health warning in all cigarette advertising.

title: WILDLIFE UNIT ASKS WATT'S OUSTER
description: The National Wildlife Federation, the biggest and probably most conservative of the major environmental groups, asked President Reagan today to dismiss James G. Watt as Secretary of the Interior.

title: Brave Jerry Brown
description: In one sense, you've got to admire the courage of California's Governor, Jerry Brown. Not his political courage: when he was advised that only helicopter spraying would protect the state's crops against an invasion of Mediterranean fruit flies, what leadership did he offer? He led the flight into hyperbole by warning that the ''aerial attack'' posed ''unacceptable'' health hazards for half a million people.

title: CONTROVERSIAL FATHER GIGANTE WINS APPLAUSE
description: His life sounds like grist for the Hollywood mill: Born the youngest of five sons of Italian immigrants living in lower Manhattan, he pushes himself as an athlete, receives a basketball scholarship to Georgetown University, as captain leads the team to national prominence, enters a seminary after graduation, becomes a ''street priest'' in the Bronx slums, enters politics, wins an election and becomes a power broker.

title: SAN FRANCISCO
description: SCHOOL begins promptly at 7 A.M. as dozens of budding Escoffiers don their tall white hats and spotless aprons, ready to peel, wash, chop and simmer under the tutelage of master chefs.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest Rates Up Modestly By MICHAEL QUINT

title: HAIG AIDE INSISTS U.S. RIGHTS POLICY IS EVENHANDED
description: The third-ranking official of the State Department told Congress today that the department was not planning to abolish the office of Assistant Secretary for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, a step that some officials had discussed after the rejection of President Reagan's first nominee for the post.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt NEW RULES. Searching for Self-Fulfill- ment in a World Turned Upside Down. By Daniel Yankelovich. 278 pages. Illus- trated with charts. Random House. $15.95.

title: DETROITBANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ASBESTOS IS MORE THAN A LITIGATION PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Tries Rights Activist
description: A Soviet activist on human rights, Irina Grivnina, went on trial today on charges of slandering the Soviet state, the press agency Tass reported. Dissident sources said she was arrested in September in a crackdown on an unofficial group looking into alleged abuses of psychiatry.

title: KV PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
SISTER TESTIFIERS ON TWO 1952 SLAYINGS
description: A sobbing, repentant sister testified today against her brother at his trial for the 1952 murders of two hunters, breaking a vow of silence she had made then to their mother, who is now dead.

title: Envoy to The Hague Named
description: President Reagan today nominated William J. Dyess, a Foreign Service officer and a former spokesman for the State Department, as ambassador to the Netherlands. If confirmed by the Senate, he will succeed Geri M. Joseph, who has resigned.

title: WAS AND ITS MADNESS
description: DAVID WAS and Don Was were in New York last week to try to explain to a breathless world the meaning behind the madness that is ''Was (Not Was).'' The duo with this catchy name surfaced this year on a 12-inch single called ''Wheel Me Out,'' which grafted an odd recitation - ''I am a former scientist, now on wheels,'' it began - on to a rich, bubbling disco-rhythm track, with punctuations from a formidable trumpeter and guitarist.

title: The City; Garage Liability Upheld on Appeal
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Operators of ''park and lock'' garages are liable for damage to vehicles parked there and the theft of items from those cars, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: AND NOW, A LIENSE TO READ MAGAZINES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CABLE TV EMPIRE BUILT BY ROGERS
description: Few people here are old enough to remember that the call signal of Toronto's most popular radio station, CFRB, stands for Canada's First Rogers Batteryless.

title: THRIFT INDUSTRY REGULATORS CITE PERIL
description: Richard T. Pratt, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today that 80 percent of the country's 4,700 savings and loan associations are experiencing operating losses and that one-third, with assets of $200 billion, are ''not viable'' under present economic conditions and may not survive.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Oct

title: The U.N. Today; July 15, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: International conference on Cambo- dia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BRITISH RIOTS STEM FROM DEEP RESENTMENTS
description: At the outset, 12 nights ago, the rioters in London were principally young blacks and Asians who have felt both economic troubles and the added pain of racism.

title: .  Around the World; 2 Guatemala Policemen Killed in Attack on Bus
description: Unidentified people firing machine guns riddled a bus with gunfire, killing two policemen and wounding four young men studying to be policemen, the Government said today.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ALTHOUGH I do not inevitably serve desserts at the end of every meal in my home, many readers feel that a meal is horribly neglected if it isn't topped off by a sweet of one sort or another. That is why I have often been asked to offer recipes for desserts that can be prepared and served after a main course and salad, all within an hour.

title: White Plains, N.Y. THE LIVING SECTION:
description: I found Enid Nemy's article on compulsive clipping worthy of saving for possible future reference. My only question is: What should I file it under? ANN McKEON Manhattan

title: China Cuts Oil Price
description: China has agreed to cut the price of its exports of crude oil to Japan to $34.90 from $36.50 a barrel, officials of the Japanese Trade and Industry Ministry said today.

title: ARIZONA BANK (PHOENIX) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
31% Rise In Mergers
description: The corporate merger pace, which rose by 46 percent in the first quarter, continued its resurgence with a 31 percent rise in the second quarter, a company that tabulates nationwide merger activity reported today.

title: ALLIS-CHALMERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After $2.2 million charge from the closing of a French subsid

title: Allis Chalmers Net Off 69.4%
description: The Allis Chalmers Corporation, a diversified manufacturer of mining and industrial machinery, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter plunged 69.4 percent, to $4.1 million, or 20 cents a share, from $13.4 million, or $1.01 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: FREELANCE JOURNALIST FOR ABC RADIO SLAIN ON A STREET IN BEIRUT
description: A freelance journalist who worked for ABC Radio was killed early today on a Beirut sidestreet as he was walking to his apartment.

title: EX-C.I.A. DEPUTY IS VIEWED COLBY AS LACKING PROFESSIONALISM
description: Before his resignation today, Max C. Hugel was in charge of the largest directorate in the Central Intelligence Agency, the branch responsible for covert action and clandestine counterintelligence overseas.

title: THE DIMINISHED MAO IS STILL A GIANT
description: To the Editor:

title: About Real Estate; OFFICE BUILDING, 1981 STYLE, IS COMING TO WHITE PLAINS
description: Names have a history. The name Centroplex has come to downtown White Plains as the designation of a new office building, but it turns out that the building was the second choice for the honor.

title: Owens Has Buyer For Parts of Lily
description: Owens-Illinois Inc., the nation's 95th-largest industrial company, said today that it had reached an agreement in principle with an unidentified purchaser to sell substantial segments of its Lily paper-products division.

title: CHRYSLER UP
description: Sales of new cars by the nation's Big Three auto makers continued to slide in the first 10 days of July, down 17.4 percent from the same period last year, to the worst sales levels since 1961.

title: Warner, Bicking Ends Ilford/Ciba Relationship
description: Warner, Bicking & Felwick has terminated its relationship with the Ilford/Ciba-Geigy Corporation, a photo products company that it had worked for for 11 years.

title: BRITAIN ANNOUNCES TOUGHER MEASURES TO COMBAT RIOTING
description: In a toughening counteroffensive against rioters, the British Government has decided to permit the country's traditionally unarmed police to use plastic bullets, armored vehicles and water cannon to quell disorders.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per shr amounts restated for a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 1

title: CHANGES SOUGHT IN CITY TAX
description: PLAN TO AID BUSINESS By EDWARD A. GARGAN

title: Count de Ganay Weds Frances Akin Spence
description: Frances Akin Spence of New York and Paris, daughter of Frances Amberg Spence of Chicago and Dr. William Thornton Spence of Washington and Annapolis, Md., was married in New York yesterday to Count Thierry de Ganay of Paris. He is the son of Mrs. Claude Bouchinet-Serreulles of Paris and the late Count Philippe de Ganay.

Newspaper deliverers returned to work last night after the settlement of a six-day strike against a wholesale distributor that disrupted deliveries of The New York Times, the New York Post and the Wall Street Journal in Suffolk County and parts of Nassau County, Brooklyn and Queens.

title: NASSAU AFFIRMS ACCORD TO CASE JAIL'S CROWDING
description: Nassau County signed an out-of-court settlement today with the Legal Aid Society, ending a two-year Federal court battle to halt overcrowding at the county jail.

title: Around the world; At Least 10 Indians Die In Hindu-Moslem Melees
description: At least 10 people have been killed in Hindu-Moslem clashes this week in Hyderabad, local officials say.

title: Notes On People; Reggie Jackson's Stolen Car Recovered, Sort of
description: Reggie Jackson got back his stolen Mercedes Benz yesterday. Or, to be more precise, parts of it. ''The doors and the trunk were gone, the wheels were gone, but the engine, the transmission and the basic frame, those we found,'' said Sgt. Jeffrey Kracht.

title: AT U.N. HANOI IS URGED TO PULL OUT OF CAMBODIA
description: Two Southeast Asian nations said today that a Vietnamese troop withdrawal from Cambodia was in Vietnam's own interest.

title: The B-Plus Legislature
description: What kind of grades did the New York Legislature earn in 1981? For neatness and scholarly deportment, somewhere between a C and a D. For solid accomplishment - despite the absence of the Governor at some crucial moments - a solid B+. If it comes back into special session in October and passes reasonable versions of three ''must'' bills, even the B+ might become an A-. And if, at the regular session beginning in January, it does something constructive about Medicaid, the Legislature will have earned a flat A.

title: YOUTHS FLEE FEARS OF ATLANTA AT A MINNESOTA CAMP
description: Except for thickets of pine trees and a hot summer sun, this sparsely populated area in remote northern Minnesota had little in common with Atlanta, a busy metropolis of close to a million people as far away as Mars to the thinking of some here.

title: STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
TEXASGULF INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $18,599,000 gain from the sale of iron ore properties in Australia and a lignite property in Texas;shr ear reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May; yr-ago results include pr ulative effect of change in accounting for investment tax credi $39,050,000 or 61 cents a shr

title: ROWAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: 1980 revs have been restated

title: JOHN J. McCORMICK
description: John J. McCormick, a real-estate appraiser and vice president of John J. Reynolds Inc. since 1950, died Sunday at a hospital in Spring Lake, N.J., where he had a summer home.

title: COLLEGES ADVANCE TUITION PAYMENT DUE DATES
description: There was a time when college and private school tuition did not have to be paid until the school year had begun. No more. In an effort to resolve cash-flow problems and augment their investments, many college and preparatory schools, hard-pressed by inflation, are asking parents to submit tuition payments earlier than ever.

title: C.A.B. Approves Western Purchase
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board approved a request by Air Florida to purchase a half interest in Western Airlines, the country's ninth-largest commercial carrier, by establishing a voting trust of up to a 50 percent interest in Western.

title: LYDALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WALLACE J. PANGBORN
description: The Rev. Wallace J. Pangborn, professor emeritus of theology at St. Peter's College in Jersey City, died Monterday in Jersey City at St. Joseph's Home for the Aged.

title: VULCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-After $134,000 foreign currency translation loss...C-Includin $130,000 foreign currency translation gain; shr earnings reflec a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Mar

title: Around the Nation; Former Officers in Miami Indicted in Drug Inquiry
description: Nine former Dade County detectives were indicted today on charges of narcotics racketeering after a two-year investigation of drug corruption involving a reputed major cocaine dealer, Mario Escandar.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 15, 1981
description: International Britain set tougher antirioting policy, permitting the traditionally unarmed police to use plastic bullets, water cannon and armored vehicles to quell disorders. The Government was considering the use of army camps as detention centers for people convicted of violent acts during the 12 days of urban riots. (Page A1, Column 1.) The seeds of Britain's urban violence were sown in part by widespread unemployment and a deep sense of frustration, oppression and lack of opportunity pervading working-class young people. At the outset, the rioters were mainly blacks and Asians, but angry white youths, in growing numbers, have joined them. (A1:1-3.)

title: WELCOME WORDS ON MUSEUM WALLS
description: To the Editor:

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $2,101,000 extraordinary gain on the repurchase of mortgage backed bonds

title: A HIGH C.I.A. AIDE RESIGNS AND DENIES FRAUD ALLEGATIONS
description: Max C. Hugel, chief of clandestine operations at the Central Intelligence Agency, resigned today in the wake of allegations that he participated in fraudulent securities transactions when he managed an electronics business in the 1970's.

title: HERITAGE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago figures restated to reflect a pooling of interest due to the acquisition of the City National Bank and Trust Co of Salem, NJ in Nov 1980

title: POP: A BUYONT EMMYLOU HARRIS
description: THE omens seemed right for Emmylou Harris's concert Monday night at the Dr Pepper Festival. Although the weather looked increasingly muggy and ominous as the afternoon advanced, by 7:15, when Miss Harris appeared, it had cleared gloriously and a fresh breeze was blowing off the Hudson - making the festival's new pier site all the more appealing.

title: BEGIN GETS FORMAL REQUEST TO FORM NEW CABINET
description: President Yitzhak Navon announced today that he had decided to call upon Prime Minister Menachem Begin to form the next government of Israel.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago appointed Karl F. Hoenecke a member of the board.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SECRETARY OF LABOR JOINS TALKS IN BASEBALL TODAY
description: Negotiations in the baseball strike resume today, and this time Secretary of Labor Raymond Donovan will participate. Kenneth E. Moffett, the Federal mediator, said yesterday in Washington that Mr. Donovan would accompany him to New York for the resumption of talks between representatives of the players and the club owners beginning at 2 P.M. at the Doral Inn.

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SECRETARY OF TRANSPORTATION WOULD BACK WESTWAY TRADE
description: Secretary of Transportation Drew Lewis said yesterday that if Mayor Koch and Governor Carey submitted a joint request, he would approve a plan to trade in Federal funds earmarked for the Westway for use on mass transit.

title: The Region; New Site Sought For Toxic Dump
description: HARTFORD (AP) - A Texas-based company dropped plans to open Connecticut's first authorized hazardous-waste dump on 200 acres in Enfield as it began searching for a site elsewhere in the state.

title: ATHLETICS CAN COMBAT TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: To the Editor:

title: O'NEILL URGES BUDGET AND TAX ACTION THIS MONTH
description: President Reagan today prevailed upon Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. to seek to have the House complete action on budget cuts and tax cuts before the August recess, delaying the recess for a week if necessary.

title: PRINCETON'S BLACKS FIGHTING TO KEEP THEIR AREA INTACT
description: Clyde Woody, who has lived in the historic black neighborhood here for 36 years, was chatting recently about the latest offer for his two-and-a-half-story house.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $368,000 for the quarter and $737,000 for the 6 months...C-Including $2,950,000 gain from the sale of assets...Year-ago results have been restated to comply with accounting rules on accrual of salaried employe vacations

title: CONTINENTAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MASON CASE GOES TO JURY
description: Tony Mason, the former University of Arizona football coach, obtained university money through lies and used it to pay star players, the prosecution told the jury that began deliberations today.

title: 2D NETWORK AT CBS RADIO
description: CBS Radio has announced a young-adult network to begin next spring. The second service, as yet unnamed, will offer two minutes of news with a one-minute commercial every hour and four 90-second features, each with a 30-second commercial, daily.

title: ADMINISTRATION PLEDGES AID ON NEW GRANT SYSTEM
description: The Reagan Administration pledged today to help states and localities make an ''orderly transition'' to a new system of distributing grant money but warned that it would intervene should any community attempt to distribute the funds inequitably.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: TO simplify the installation of ceiling tiles on almost any existing ceiling or over exposed joists when finishing a basement or addition, Armstrong World Industries has introduced a system that uses four-foot lengths of a lightweight metal ceiling track instead of conventional wood furring strips.

title: SCHOOL OFICIALS INDICTED IN STUDENT VISA CASE
description: Five school officials and a college recruiter were indicted yesterday, charged with using fraudulent visas to bring Iranian students into the United States. The Justice Department says the inquiry is continuing.

title: SAMUEL LEMBERG DIES AT 84 INVESTOR AND A PHILANTHROPIST
description: Samuel Lemberg, a real estate executive and philanthropist, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84 years old. The owner of the Midwood Trading Company, a real estate investment and management concern at 400 Madison Avenue, Mr. Lemberg came to New York City at the age of 9 from Russia and went to work when he was 12.

title: ARREST AT DISPUTED CHURCH
description: The police arrested a man today for sitting on a bulldozer and refusing to leave a partly demolished church in the Poletown neighborhood, where an automobile plant is to be built. Jerry Dajnowicz, 39 years old, was charged with entering a vacant dwelling without permission, a misdemeanor. Mr. Dajnowicz was one of several persons protesting demolition of the Immaculate Conception Church who camped out across from the building last night.

title: EMPLOYEE BID STALLS AT CONTINENTAL AIR
description: If things had gone as planned, Continental Air Lines would now be the nation's largest employee-controlled company.

title: SANITATION AUDIT SAYS MILLIONS WERE WASTED
description: New York City's Department of Sanitation wasted millions of dollars in overtime pay during the 1980 fiscal year, according to a 28-page audit released yesterday by the state's Comptroller, Edward V. Regan.

title: Pressure Tactic Denied By Kentucky Governor
description: Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. said today that he was not trying to force out a football coach at the University of Kentucky and had not intended his negotiations with George Allen to become public before he discussed the matter with the university's president, Otis Singletary.

title: SOVIET DISMISSES TALK BY HAIG ON ARMS CURB
description: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass today dismissed Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s pledge to begin arms limitations talks and said the United States was trying to hide the ''aggressive'' nature of its foreign policy.
To the Editor:

title: NEWARK CUTS RED TAPE TO RUSH WATER REPAIRS
description: Until a new hole burst Monday afternoon in Newark's aging and vandalized aqueduct in the woods here, a handful of men controlling the fate of water supplies for about 600,000 people were in a jubilant and self-congratulatory mood.

title: WHY DETROIT'S SLUMP PERSISTS
description: The American auto industry had only modest hopes for 1981, after a disastrous year in which the domestic producers lost more than $4 billion. Sales, they said, would increase to 10 million cars from 8.9 million in 1980.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 5
description: Shr earns reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed June 15

title: SAFEWAY EARNINGS OFF
description: Safeway Stores Inc., North America's largest food retailer, today reported second-quarter net earnings of $25.5 million, or 98 cents a share, a 32.3 percent drop from $37.7 million, or $1.44 a share, a year ago. Sales in the quarter were $3.78 billion, up 11.3 percent from $3.35 billion. Safeway operates more than 2,000 supermarkets in the United States and Canada.

title: Topics; UNDER THE RAINBOW; ROOFSCAPES
description: This is a time for rooftops. They are the traditional summer landscape of the city. Or they were before air conditioning, when roofs and stoops were the only places where the breezes stirred.

title: AMERICAN HOSPITAL SUPPLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of LIFO accounting

title: Around the World; TERRORISTS THREATEN TO KILL HOSTAGE IN ITALY
description: Red Brigades terrorists said today that they would kill Ciro Cirillo, one of three hostages in their hands, if their demands were not met within 48 hours, the police reported.

title: PALMER REGAINS HIS OLD TOUCH
description: After the sixth hole, trailing by six strokes, Arnold Palmer was puzzled. He knew he was hitting the ball well, but bogeys were burying his confidence.

title: Around the World; AFGHANISTAN IS TRYING TO CURB TERRORISM
description: The authorities in Afghanistan are trying to curb rebel terrorism in the capital that has killed three backers of the Government, diplomats said today.

title: POST HOME FOR SALE FOR $20
description: MILLION By KERRY GRUSON PALM BEACH, Fla. SHE was the undisputed queen of Palm Beach society, and today, seven and a half years after the death of Marjorie Merriweather Post, the 115-room mansion from which she reigned is on the market for a regal sum.

title: SOCIALIST HEADS MEET IN BONN WITH FOCUS ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Socialist party leaders from 18 countries began two days of talks here today expected to focus on East-West arms control.

title: TPC COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gardenning; MOST FERN PROSPER IN THE COLL GLENS
description: THINK cool. Think ferns - or even better, grow them. Ferns' natural habitats are the places where most gardeners would prefer to be when it's hot and muggy: Cool glens with just the suggestion of a breeze, where the soil is deep, rich with humus but not soggy or dank. And if the morning or evening sunlight touches there for an hour or so, that is just about perfect - for ferns.

title: DUES PLAN DIVIDES WOMEN'S CAUCU
description: A division has developed within the fouryear-old Congresswomen's Caucus over a proposal to require members to pay $2,500 in annual dues.

title: Topics; UNDER THE RAINBOW; VOYAGE TO NOWHERE
description: ''Step right up for the Nothing Tour,'' says the man in the white cap. He waves you onto the bus, one of those new Grummans that has been out of service since spring.

title: Company Earnings; PHILIP MORRIS POSTS 22% GAIN; TELEDYNE AND TRW IMPROVE
description: Philip Morris Inc. reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter climbed 22 percent and revenues increased 16.5 percent. Philip Morris, the nation's second-largest producer of cigarettes after R.J. Reynolds Industries, said net income in the three months rose to $184.5 million, or $1.48 a share, from $151.2 million, or $1.21 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago. Operating revenues increased to $2.89 billion from $2.48 billion.

title: PACT RATIFIED, WRITERS RETURN
description: HOLLYWOOD July 15 (AP) -Writers overwhelming ratified a new contract with major film and television producers last night to end a 13-week strike and a year of labor turmoil in the entertainment industry.

title: FICTION: OFTEN MORE REAL THAN FACT
description: WHILE editors, publishers and reviewers continue to debate the merits and demerits of ''faction'' -the literary device that blends history and fiction - Larzer Ziff thinks that the Norman Mailers, Gore Vidals and other practitioners of the genre are trying to tell us something important.

title: 3 MAJOR U.S. NETWORKS GIVEN PERMISSION FOR CHINA BUREAUS
description: The three major American broadcast networks have been given permission to station correspondents in Peking, China announced today.

title: Mrs. Katz Sues to Halt 76er Sale
description: The wife of Harold Katz, the diet entrepreneur who is paying $12 million for the Philadelphia 76ers, sued today to block the sale because she said it could hurt her divorce settlement.

title: MUSIC: HARDLY ANY MOZART
description: IF anything ever kills the Mostly Mozart Festival in its present incarnation, it could be predicability. The programming of greater or lesser quantities of music by Mozart is not likely to do it; he was a genius and composed works of sufficient variety and number to keep all sorts of listeners interested almost indefinitely. What could wear out the public, however, is the engagement year after year of thrice-familiar performers who specialize neither in Mozart nor anything else unless it be a generally tasteful Romantic performance style that is applied more or less evenly to Baroque, Classical and Romantic works.

title: FOR THE CARIBBEAN, A NEW APPROACH TO ASSISTANCE
description: The islands and countries of the Caribbean Sea, from the Bahamas 1,500 miles south to Venezuela and from Belize 2,000 miles east to Barbados, share the memories of empire but now speak only the common language of poverty and desperate, largely unfulfilled longings.

title: Weaver-Tillis Bout Set For Chicago Area Oct. 3
description: Mike Weaver, the World Boxing Association champion, will meet undefeated James (Quick) Tillis Oct. 3 at the suburban Rosemont Horizon arena, officials announced today.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Technology; SHARPER IMAGE FOR TELEVISION
description: THE emergence of new sources of television programming, such as the video cassette, videodisk and cable networks, has stimulated a demand for larger, sharper and more life-like television pictures. Projection television sets are just starting to catch on. Yet projection sets, despite numerous improvements, still provide a somewhat dim and fuzzy picture.

title: RATING CONCERN PROFIT UP 17.5%
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter ended June 30, aided by gains in all its major divisions, rose 17.5 percent from the second quarter of 1980 to $32.9 million, or $1.17 a share, from $28.0 million, or $1 a share.

title: ALASKA LEGISLATURE VOTES TO LIMIT RISE IN STATE'S SPENDING
description: The Alaska Legislature, called into special session at the insistence of Gov. Jay Hammond, voted today to rewrite the constitution to limit spending of the state's oil revenues.

title: Market Place; THE CONOCO EXTRAVAGANZA
description: THE opening salvo in the bidding war for Conoco Inc. was fired on Thursday, June 25, when Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, the American subsidiary of the huge Canadian liquor company, offered $73 a share in cash for 35 million shares, or 40.7 percent, of Conoco's 86.8 million shares. That was described as a $2.5 billion offer.

title: SOCIAL INSECURITY
description: To many people, the Social Security crisis is a matter of poor financial management, of Government insensitivity to the financial problems of the aged, or of callous political decisions that curry favor with taxpayers by holding down on taxes at the expense of retired persons. There is indeed a very real problem, but, at root, it is not any of these.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
