title: COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
4 KILLED AND 100 INJURED IN CENTRAL AFRICAN BLAST
description: Four people, including a French citizen, were killed and about 100 others were injured last night when a bomb exploded at a crowded movie theater in the Central African Republic capital of Bangui, reports reaching Paris said today.

title: THE HAITIANS AND WALRUS COURTS
description: How can America continue to be a haven for refugees fleeing genuine persecution without also inviting a flood of illegal aliens looking for better jobs?

title: CORRECTION
description: A map of Minnesota yesterday incorrectly labeled the river that forms Minnesota's border with Wisconsin in the southern sector of both states. It is the Mississippi.

title: At Home Abroad; ESCAPE FROM EXTREMES?
description: Roy Jenkins stood in the back of an open Land-Rover, and the Social Democratic campaign caravan set off. To get the voters' attention a loudspeaker played brassy music: Aaron Copland's ''Fanfare for the Common Man.''

title: REAGAN SENDS MIXED SIGNALS ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: President Reagan has privately assured black leaders that he will not cripple the Voting Rights Act of 1965, but at the same time Administration officials are cutting back civil rights enforcement by the Justice Department and weakening the regulations against racial discrimination in employment.

title: MUSEUM, CHILDREN AND ARCHITECTURE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Rhoda M. Gilinsky is a freelance writer. By RHODA M. GILINSKY

title: THE GLOSS OF PATINA OF FINE FURNITURE
description: Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After $3 million net loss in connection with the settlement o litigation and claims against the company related to Valley For Corp

title: CONTINENTAL TELEPHONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Critic's Notebook; HOW MUSEUM CATALOGUES TALK
description: HOW solid they look, our great museums, and how discreet! When night falls, and the doors close, we might think that the main purpose in life of our great museums was to sit tight, keep a straight face and give nothing away.

title: WEST CHEMICAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $85,000 for the quarter and $247,000 for the 6 months...C-Includes tax credits of $167,000 for the q and $305,000 for the 6 months

title: STOCKS REBOUND, PUSHING DOW UP 5.90
description: The stock market rallied yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at 954.15, up 5.90, regaining almost as many points as it had lost the previous day. However, much of the increase in the average was attributable to a 4 3/8-point rise in International Paper, to 48, following news about plans to sell some units.

title: PIERCE, QUIET NO MORE, SAYS 'BALONEY' TO HIS CRITICS
description: For the last six months, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. has remained one of the most reticent members of the Reagan Cabinet, earning the name ''Silent Sam'' among his own staff. Today, Mr. Pierce broke his silence.

title: GUERRILLAS FIRE DOZENS OF ROCKETS AT ISRAEL AFTER AIR RAID, KILLING 3
description: In apparent retaliation for Israeli air raids into southern Lebanon yesterday, Palestinian guerrillas fired dozens of rockets at northern Israeli towns today, killing three persons and wounding 25.

title: SOO LINE RR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $1.1 million gain from the settlement of property tax litigation...C-Includes $900,000 gain from tax refunds and affilliate dividends

title: ALL PRECINCTS IN THE CITY TO GET NEW BURGLARY UNITS
description: The New York City Police Department, which had eliminated almost all investigations of residential burglaries, will set up special burglary units in every precinct within the next five months.

title: POLISH COMMUNISTS TO SELECT LEADERS BY SECRET BALLOT
description: For the first time in the Soviet bloc, a Communist party has decided to elect its entire leadership by secret ballot with a choice of contenders.

title: CITY IS PUSHING SHIFT IN PACKAGE FOR TRANSIT AID
description: New York City officials, fearing that some of the taxes enacted to aid mass transit might be difficult to collect and harmful to the city's economy, have drafted a proposal to have one of them repealed and replaced. They also plan to suggest changes in another.

title: ARMSTRONG, A J, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
The City; Miami Man Killed Near Queens Diner
description: A Miami restaurant manager visiting New York City for a reunion with an old friend was shot to death outside a diner in Queens in a robbery attempt, the police said.

title: PREMATURE OPTIMISM ABOUT LIMITED BREAST CANCER TREATMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefs
description: * Airborne Freight Corp. bought two DC-9-32 cargo planes from Evergreen International for $10.6 million.

title: MANY BOKS ON GARAGE SALES
description: WANT to make some fast bucks? A few hundred or so? Maybe even a grand? Hold a garage sale. Maybe in your neighborhood they call it a yard sale, a porch sale, a tag sale or a rummage sale.

title: SMITHKLINE PACT
description: Japan's Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Company Ltd. and the Smithkline Corporation of Philadelphia have agreed to form a joint venture company in Philadelphia to develop and market pharmaceuticals in the United States, Fujisawa said.

title: Bridge; U.S. HAS NUMERICAL EDGE IN PLAYERS OF WORLD CALIBER
description: When the United States plays in a world championship match, the Americans are usually favored, but their edge in ability and experience may be quite slight. But this is with four active players. If the size of the team is increased to 40, or 400, or 4,000, the odds on an American victory take quantum jumps and approach certainty.

title: DANT & RUSSELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: REAGAN MEETS COURT NOMINEE
description: As President Reagan predicted her confirmation by the Senate, Judge Sandra Day O'Connor of Arizona met key senators today in a continuation of her effort to be approved as the first woman on the Supreme Court.

title: Turner Antitrust Exemption Unjust
description: Ted Turner, owner of the Atlanta Braves, said today that baseball's exemption from antitrust laws was unjustifiable and that he supported legislation to subject it to the same laws regarding competition as other sports.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Credit Markets; FUNDS RATE RISE STIFLES RALLY
description: Despite three infusions of funds by the Federal Reserve yesterday, two temporary and one permanent, the Federal funds rate went from 16 1/2 percent at the opening to 20 percent at the close. While too much can be read into the movement of overnight interbank lending rates on a Wednesday, the end of the bank statement week, they have been exerting a strong influence on all short-term rates.

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ECONOMIC TROUBLES BESETTING NICARAGUA
description: The revolution in Nicaragua is in deep economic trouble. If the crisis provokes a political upheaval, one of the most constructive attempts at social change in the third world today could be destroyed.

title: DAN RIVER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
TIN SURPLUS NARROWING
description: World tin production and demand have moved more closely into balance than was indicated three months ago, the International Tin Council said here today.

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
I.B.M. INTRODUCES 3 NEW PROCESSORS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced three new processor models that it said would significantly increase the performance and storage capacity of its IBM 8100 information system.

title: CHESEBROUGH-POND'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FREE LAND KEEPS A SCHOOL OPEN
description: Harley Kissner believes that tiny towns like Antler ''wither and die'' without schools, and since there can be no schools without an adequate number of children, the 72-yearold bachelor is offering free land to modern-day homesteaders willing to settle here.

title: COSMOS TRIUMPH OVER SOUTHAMPTON, 2-1
description: The Cosmos played a lethargic first half but redeemed themselves in the second and defeated Southampton of England, 2-1, in the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup at Giants Stadium tonight.

title: The U.N. Today; July 16, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: International Conference on Cambo- dia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRITON TO PURCHASE PNEUMO DIVISIONS
description: The Pneumo Corporation of Boston and Triton Group Ltd. have reached agreement in principle for Triton's purchase of the Pneumo food and drug division for $65 million cash, the companies said today.

title: Nicklaus's Son Charged With Drunken Driving
description: The son of Jack Nicklaus was charged with driving while intoxicated today on the highway named for his father.

title: News Analysis
description: Shaken in spirit, riot-weary Britons have begun the tortuous process of debating what has gone wrong in a society from whose special qualities of civility the troubled nation drew a measure of pride through the worst of its economic battering.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPROMISE BUDGET FOR MASSACHUSETTS GETS FINAL APPROVAL
description: The Massachusetts House and the Senate approved a compromise $6.35 billion state budget tonight, ending a legislative dispute that disrupted state government for 15 days.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Flexi-Van Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 1.2 million cumulative convertible preferred shares, to be sold through a Dean Witter Reynolds group.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS
description: Texas Instruments Japan Ltd. said it had started commercial production in Japan of 65-k RAM (random access memory) chips. The company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Texas Instruments Inc., reportedly plans an initial monthly production of 500,000 very-large-scale circuits and aims to increase monthly production to 1 million units by the end of 1981.

title: THRIFT INDUSTRY CREDIT SOUGHT
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has asked the Federal Reserve Board to revise conditions for access to its discount, or lending, window to provide ailing thrift institutions with what could be an important source of back-up credit.

title: NEW BRITISH PARTY IN ELECTION DEBUT
description: ''We were not willing to go on being the fig leaves for policies we believed to be detrimental,'' said Roy Jenkins, his voice rising with unaccustomed passion. ''So we have set out to create a great shift - a geological flux - in British politics. With your help we can imprint the name of Warrington on the history of our country.''

title: ISRAELI ARABS HOPE TO FLEX THEIR POLITICAL MUSCLE
description: One lesson learned from Israel's general election has been the potential power of the Arab vote. It now represents nearly 10 percent of the country's electoral strength, enough to swing the ability to form a government into the hands of one major political party or another.

title: Blocker, No. 1 Choice In Draft, Signs Met Pact
description: Terry Blocker, a 21-year-old center fielder who was the No. 1 selection of the Mets in the free agent draft last month, signed yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: U.S. Five Captures Maccabiah Crown
description: The United States basketball team, led by Dan Schayes, the first-round draft choice of the Utah Jazz, defeated Israel, 91-71, today and retained the title on the final day of competition at the 11th Maccabiah Games.

title: EVANS & SUTHERLAND COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in April 1980 and a 200 percent stock dividend paid in June 1981

title: The Region; Rate Rises Urged For Jersey Utilities
description: NEWARK (UPI) - In separate actions, administrative law judges recommended increases in energy adjustment charges of $74.9 million for Public Service Electric and Gas Company and $18.5 million for Atlantic Electric Company.

title: 6-HOUR NIGHTLY SHUTDOWN OF SUBWAYS IS PROPOSED
description: A report prepared for the Citizens Union recommends shutting down New York City's subway system between midnight and 6 A.M. to hold down the Transit Authority's deficits and future fare increases.

title: CESSNA AIRCRAFT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TO BE ON MARKET NEXT YEAR
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a new artificial sugar substitute for use in dry food products such as drink mixes, instant coffee and tea, puddings, fillings and cold cereals.

title: DEATHS OF 3 MENTAL PATIENTS LINKED TO HEAT WAVE
description: New York City's Chief Medical Examiner said yesterday that the deaths of two mental patients at state hospitals and that of another at a city hospital during last week's spell of 90-degree weather were heat-related.

title: COAHES SPLIT OVER ELLENBERGER CASE
description: The coaches were thinking of Norm Ellenberger this week. He was no longer one of their peers and had not been since 1979. But the coaches thought of him because they had once matched their basketball teams against his at the University of New Mexico, or they had become acquaintances on the recruiting circuit, or they considered themselves friends.

title: VITRAMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TOMLINSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
84 Giants Show Up At Camp
description: With the temperature in the 80's and the humidity in the 50's on a glorious summer day, the Giants began the 1981 season today.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOSPITAL TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TYLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE PANEL VOTES CUTS IN ESTATE TAX AND LEVY ON GIFTS
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, in its continuing effort to put together its own tax package, today approved changes in estate and gift taxes that would be more generous than those already voted by the Senate Finance Committee.

title: DRECO ENERGY SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-There are no year-ago comparable figures because the company only went public in December 1980

title: DUN & BRADSTREET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CABLE TV PROVISIONS ACCEPTED
description: The cable television industry, using a telephone deregulation bill as its vehicle, succeeded today in convincing a Senate committee to accept proposals restricting the authority of local governments to regulate cable companies.

title: MCGRAW-HILL NET RISES 13.4%
description: McGraw-Hill Inc., the New York-based publishing, broadcasting and information services concern, reported yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 13.4 percent, to $20.2 million, or 81 cents a share, from $17.8 million, or 72 cents a share, in the same period in 1980.

title: VAIL ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Yr to April 30
DANKER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BUMPER CROP OF GRAIN BELT RAIL CARS
description: Just two summers ago, when the big white elevators alongside the Santa Fe main line here were groaning with the weight of a fat harvest, Sherm Baird could not beg or borrow a railroad hopper car to move the grain to market.

title: The City; Beaches Approved After Plant Repair
description: A warning against swimming at Coney Island and two other public beaches was lifted after temporary repairs were completed at a disabled sewage-treatment plant in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.

title: LA SCALA BALLET: MISS RAZZI AS JULIET
description: IF the overall level of La Scala Ballet's top dancers has not yet manifested itself at the Metropolitan Opera House, Anna Maria Razzi's debut here as Juliet in Rudolf Nureyev's ''Romeo and Juliet'' Tuesday night was a bright omen.

title: PANEL ON ETHICS REVIEWS WILLIAMS ABSCAM TAPES A. Williams Jr.
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said today that ''all acts will be played out'' when he appears again before the Senate ethics committee on July 28 to explain his activities during the F.B.I.'s Abscam investigation in an effort to avoid censure or expulsion from Congress.

title: News of Music; ENTRIES FOR GRAZ DUE
description: The League of Composers-International Society for Contemporary Music is again in the midst of its National Composers Competition. Entries, which are due by Aug. 7 and are to be judged by a jury convening in New York on Aug. 22, will be narrowed finally to six.

title: Isaac Soyer, a Painter Of the American Scene
description: Isaac Soyer, Realist painter of the American scene and people, died of a heart attack at Lenox Hill Hospital on July 8. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS HOPES FOUND HIGH
description: Optimism among businessmen about third-quarter sales and profits is at its highest point since the second quarter of 1980, according to a Dun & Bradstreet survey of about 1,400 executives that was released yesterday.

title: HOW TO GROW PLANTS USING STRAWBERRY JARS
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Even when poor, England felt a sense of self-respect. That's not here anymore.''

title: 'BOAT PEOPLE' COOL TO JAPANESE OFFER OF FULL ASYLUM
description: Until two years ago, freighters that picked up Vietnamese ''boat people'' at sea had to provide a formal guarantee of resettlement in another country before Japan would give their passengers temporary shelter here, and no Indochinese refugee was admitted for permanent resettlement.

title: AFTER 28 DAYS, ZOO TEAM RECAPTURES ELUSIVE GATOR
description: DENVER July 15 - For 28 days and nights they stalked the beast, using nets and drag lines and long poles with nooses. But it was not until early this morning that a group of weary Denver zookeepers at last recaptured the alligator Albert, and returned it to captivity.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The asphalt tiles in my den need waxing. I have tried many waxes, but as soon as alcohol is spilled on the floor, it develops white spots that I am unable to remove - yet they seem to disappear in time. Is there a wax I can use that is alcohol-resistant? - Mrs. G.B., Westbury, L.I.

title: BOOTHE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Notes On People; Sarah Caldwell Finds Smooth Going in China
description: Sarah Caldwell, the American conductor and director, has found directing the China's Central Opera Company in Peking in her version of Verdi's ''La Traviata'' to be an experience devoid of some of the problems she usually encounters.

title: NO MOVEMENT SEEN
description: After Secretary of Labor Raymond Donovan spoke of the ''nice spirit'' in the baseball strike talks, negotiators for the players and the owners recessed yesterday. But the players were angered because the owners had failed to produce the new proposal the players were expecting.

title: REPUBLIC STEEL, GULF IN VENTURE
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation completed their previously announced formation of a partnership to own, operate and develop Republic's coal properties on the North River tract in Fayette county, Ala., the companies said.

title: ATLANTA SUSPECT IS DENIED RELEASE
description: A Fulton County Superior Court judge refused today to set bail for Wayne B. Williams, who is charged with murdering one of 28 young blacks slain here. The judge said there was a substantial likelihood that Mr. Williams would flee if released.

title: Around the World; IRAN WIDENS ITS PRESSURE ON BANI-SADR SUPPORTERS
description: Iran's campaign against opposition groups supporting the fugitive former President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, was widened today to include his disbanded guard corps.

title: The Region Grant; Bank Robber Slain In Connecticut
description: One of two holdup men was killed, the second was captured and a woman hostage was wounded during a robbery this morning at a branch of the Farmington Savings Bank, the police said.

title: DEKALB AGRESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
VIETNAM VETERANS IN AN IOWA TOWN BEGIN ORGANIZING TO REACH THEIR GOALS
description: Vietnam is a fading memory for most of this town's 8,000 citizens. At the corner drugstore and the pool hall, talk runs to whether the bullheads in the lake are biting, or the damage the hailstorm did.

title: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS A NEW INFORMATION ACT
description: The Reagan Administration called today for changes in the Freedom of Information Act, saying the law interferes with efficient government, is being abused by business interests and costs too much.

title: CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN METALS SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Notes On People
description: Gerald R. Ford Library Open Last April former President Gerald R. Ford dedicated his Presidential library, a $4.3 million, low brick building set among the manicured hills of the University of Michigan campus at Ann Arbor. Staff members under William Stewart, the library's acting director, have been getting the papers in order and this week the doors were opened to researchers.

title: WESTERN CO OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: 1980 share earnings adjusted for 2-for-1 stock splits in the se quarter of 1981 and the third quarter of 1980

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: B-Including $8.1 million nonrecurring pretax gain from the sale of aircraft and related equipment

title: VYQUEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WEST GERMAN JAILED AS SPY
description: A West German was sentenced to 10 years in jail today by an East Berlin military court on charges of spying on East Germany and Poland. An official news report said that the defendant, Alfred Bechthold, had posed as a builder to question East Germans about border security. In the last two years, 23 reputed Western agents have been arrested in East Germany.

title: STATOIL GAS FIND
description: The Norwegian state oil company, Statoil, said today that it had found unexpected reserves of natural gas in the Sleipner area of the continental shelf, southwest of Stavanger. A Statoil spokesman said it was too early to know the extent of the reserves, but that the gas was of similar quality to that in the Heimdal area north of Stavanger, where production is due to start in 1986.

title: VATICAN DISCLOSES $26 MILLION DEFICIT
description: The Vatican, in a rare public disclosure of the state of its finances, announced today that the Curia, the government of the Roman Catholic Church, would have a deficit of about $26 million this year.

title: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods include $8,464,000 pretax income from the sale of Texas land

title: NEW TWIST IN BIDDING FOR CONOCO
description: The Seagram Company may take on a partner in its multibilliondollar bidding battle for Conoco Inc., Wall Street sources said yesterday. The Du Pont Company, meanwhile, began mailing out a 180-page prospectus detailing its offer, made only 24 hours before, to pay $7.6 billion for Conoco, the nation's ninth-largest oil company.

title: WEINBERGER HOPES TO PUBLICIZE SOVIET MISSILE DATA
description: With the Soviet Union apparently deploying its new medium-range SS-20 nuclear missiles at a rapid pace, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has become involved in a dispute with intelligence agencies over publicizing evidence of the deployment, according to Administration officials.

title: 3 SEIZED AFTER CAR CHASE IN KIDNAPPING OF COUPLE
description: Two men and a woman accused of kidnapping a couple leaving a restaurant in Manhattan's theater district early yesterday were arrested after an automobile chase through streets on the West Side.

title: Hoboken Housing
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: As Anna Quindlen pointed out in her July 2 lead article (''Mile-Square Hoboken, Still a Brownstoners' Haven''), waves of affluent New Yorkers continue to settle in Hoboken. Each succeeding wave thrusts the city deeper into a housing crisis.

title: BRITAIN ACCEPTS OFFER BY RED CROSS FOR FACT-FINDING MISSION ON ULSTER
description: Britain, under international pressure to find a way to end the Irish Republican Army's prison hunger strikes, tonight accepted a fact-finding mission by the Red Cross.

title: WARNER PROFITS JUMP 66.4%
description: Warner Communications Inc. reported yesterday that profits in the second quarter soared to a record $42.6 million, or 66 cents a share, up 66.4 percent from $25.6 million, or 45 cents a share, in the April-June quarter a year ago.

title: Business People; NEW CHIEF EXPECTED AT ABRAHAM & STRAUS
description: John Burden 3d, president of Burdine's, a Miami department store group, is expected to be named today as chairman and chief executive officer of Abraham & Straus. Howard Sokol, Burdine's executive vice president, is expected to succeed Mr. Burden there.

title: GANNETT'S NET UP IN QUARTER
description: The Gannett Company, a communications group that owns more than 100 newspapers across the nation, today reported record second-quarter earnings of $46.6 million, or 86 cents a share, compared with $40.5 million, or 75 cents a share, in the 1980 quarter, after an adjustment for a 3-for-2 stock split in January.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE E
description: AVERY high-quality window-washing and utility kit is available from an interesting new hardware and housewares store in SoHo. The store, Turpan Sanders Inc., at 385 West Broadway, carries a wide range of industrial-quality products, such as the Unger window-washing kit.

title: Around the Nation; OFFICERS WALK OFF JOBS IN CALIFORNIA AND INDIANA
description: By The Associated Press Law-enforcement officers walked off their jobs yesterday in Riverside, Calif., and Terre Haute, Ind., in disputes about fringe benefits and wages.

title: Going Out Guide
description: STANDING UP

title: Hers
description: WHAT'S really hurting us? Inflation. Like radiation, inflation charges the air around us with invisible menace. Soon, there may be an official statistic: inflation deaths. People will simply keel over at the counter, felled by the high cost of living. Even those who can afford to pay may not be able to withstand the stress of rapidly rising prices. Watching the economic indicators can endanger our health. Blood pressure can link up to the prime, and hypertensive types may just slump over and die, their deaths attributed to ''the silent killer.''

title: Dr. Ethel Weiss-Shed Is Dead; Psychologist at City College
description: Dr. Ethel Weiss-Shed, chairman of the department of psychology at City College, died of cancer Tuesday at her summer home in Goldens Bridge, N. Y. She was 47 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: BRITISH PANEL SEES A RISE IN RACIAL DISCRIMINATION
description: A Government commission said in a report issued yesterday that there had been a rising trend in racial harassment and violence in the last year.

title: The City; Marshal Accused Of Fund Misuse
description: A city marshal was accused of misappropriating more than $30,000 in money owed the Parking Violations Bureau, and the case has been referred to the Bronx District Attorney, Stanley N. Lupkin, the Commissioner of the Department of Investigation, said yesterday.

title: ALTON MARSHALL, UNOPPOSED, ELECTED HEAD OF CITY CENTER BOARD
description: The board of governors of the City Center of Music and Drama formally accepted the resignation of John S. Samuels 3d as chairman yesterday. Alton G. Marshall, former president of Rockefeller Center Inc., was unamimously elected chairman. He immediately announced his intention to return the City Center to its original mandate of fostering the performing arts at popular prices.

title: Around the Nation; FIRE NARROWLY MISSES KENNEDY SPACE CENTER
description: A fire came within two miles of facilities at the Kennedy Space Center today before firefighters began to bring it under control, a spokesman for the Division of Forestry said.

title: COCA-COLA TO SELL 3 WINE CONCERNS
description: The Coca-Cola Company announced it had agreed in principle to sell the wine business of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York to a group including the First Boston Corporation and top-level managers of the New York bottler's wine business.

title: ATHEY PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange

title: Company Earnings; ALLIED AND PPG UP; CPC, BAXTER GAIN
description: The Allied Corporation announced yesterday that improved oil and gas earnings helped lift net income in the second quarter of 1981 by 19.2 percent as sales increased 16.9 percent.

title: Tex Schramm Testifies In Raider-N.F.L. Case
description: Tex Schramm, president of the Dallas Cowboys, testified today he was surprised to learn in March, 1980, that Al Davis was planning to move his Oakland Raiders to Los Angeles because Davis had told him about a month earlier he would probably keep the team in Oakland.

title: Around the Nation; POSTMASTER GENERAL ASSAILED BY UNIONS
description: Leaders of postal workers' unions accused Postmaster General William F. Bolger today of following a plan that could provoke a nationwide mail strike.

title: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOUTHEASTERN PUBLIC SERVICING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $5.4 million after tax gain from the sale of marketable securities...C-Includes $1.3 million after tax in recognized unrealized losses on securities 1980 results restated to account for the cost of certain employee compensated absences Share earnings adjusted to reflect aggregate stock distribution paid through July 1, 1981

title: Notes On People; Reagan's Father-in-Law Honored by Ireland
description: In ceremonies at the Irish Embassy in Washington, it was not President Reagan who was the center of attraction, but his father-inlaw, Dr. Royal Davis.

title: Advertising; ZIFF-DAVIS PUBLISHING GETS SUBSCRIPTION LIST
description: Ziff-Davis Publishing has acquired the subscription list of Next magazine from the International Thomson Business Press, which terminated the publication Friday, and will apply it to its Psychology Today magazine.

title: RESTORING A VICTORIAN WHIMSY House
description: IT was built in 1860 to represent a human brain. Remodeled in 1872 to make people laugh. And now, Joseph Pell Lombardi, a Manhattan architect, is restoring every whimsical detail and carnival color of the house in Irvington on the Hudson known locally as the Domed Octagon House. The architect, whose restoration work includes the lobby of the Chrysler Building and the Liberty Tower, bought the house in February 1979 for $75,000 from the National Trust for Historic Preservation. The trust had earlier bought the house for $115,000 to keep it from being razed by tract home developers.

title: BROWN CALLS FOR DISASTER STATUS IN FRUIT FLY SPREAD
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. today asked President Reagan to declare three California counties a major disaster area. He called for Federal aid to battle a spreading infestation of the Mediterranean fruit fly.

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Jan 5

title: MISSING INFANT IS FOUND WITH MOTHER IN STAMFORD , Deputy police Chief, and Capt. Joseph Ligi
description: A woman accused of taking her 15-month-old daughter out of New York Hospital five days ago in violation of a Family Court order was picked up with the child by the police yesterday at the railroad station in Stamford, Conn.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VOTE PERMITS MILITARY TO AID IN DRUG ARRESTS
description: Despite Pentagon opposition, the House voted overwhelmingly today to authorize military personnel to help civilian authorities seize narcotics shipments and arrest drug smugglers at sea.

title: The City; Suspect Describes 'Village' Shootings
description: A man charged with killing two men and wounding six others in a shooting spree in Greenwich Village last November testified in his own defense in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: William Lanning, 69, Counsel For New Jersey's Legislature
description: William M. Lanning, who retired in December as chief counsel to the New Jersey Legislature after 41 years of state service, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Mercer Hospital in Trenton. Mr. Lanning, who was a resident of Trenton, was 69 years old.

title: WATT ORDERS INQUIRY ON OIL ROYALTIES
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt appointed a commission today to investigate what he said was the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars annually because of the underpayment of royalties for oil and gas leases on Federal and Indian tribe lands and the outright theft of these resources.

title: Notes On People; Carter Looks Back at the Press in Pique
description: Unlike Richard M. Nixon and some other predecessors, Jimmy Carter rarely attacked the press while he was in the White House, but in a new interview, he has some bitter things to say.

title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect an accoun change

title: POLLS BY G.O.P., GALLUP DIFFER ON '82 OUTCOME
description: A new poll commissioned by the National Republican Congressional Committee concluded today that Republicans would win 51 percent of the vote if the 1982 House and Senate elections were held now. However, a Gallup Poll also released today showed that Democrats would still top Republicans in a similar election, 49 percent to 45 percent.

title: Notes on People; Keeshan Improving
description: The word from Toronto yesterday was that Robert Keeshan, television's Captain Kangaroo, was ''in stable condition and improving slightly.'' On Saturday he collapsed at Toronto International Aiport with a heart attack.

title: NEW V.A. CHIEF SAYS VETERANS OF VIETNAM AREN'T NEGLECTED
description: Robert Nimmo, the new Veterans Administration chief, said today that some Vietnam-era veterans had ''particular problems,'' but 95 percent were doing well and that they had not been shortchanged by the Government.

title: TODD SHIPYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: B-Includes $2,525,000 tax credit

title: ADMINISTRATION NOW PREDICTING SLOWER INFLATION
description: The Reagan Administration, asserting that its drive for a balanced budget in 1984 is on schedule, lowered its official inflation forecast today and predicted that interest rates would decline significantly in the next few months.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Company News item in Business Day on Tuesday gave an incorrect date for shareholders' meetings to consider the acquisition of Brooks & Perkins Inc. by the AAR Corporation. The date is Aug. 11.

title: HOME-MAILING ADS AROUSING INQUIRIES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Deborah Blumenthal is a freelance writer. By DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL

title: AMERICAN AIR POSTS PROFITS
description: Despite a threatened strike by air traffic controllers, American Airlines ended the second quarter this year with net earnings of $27.8 million, or 82 cents a share, a ''dramatic'' improvement over the similar period last year when the company lost more than $30 million, the airline's chairman, Albert Casey, announced today.

title: 12 ARE SLAIN IN EL SALVADOR
description: At least 12 people were killed in political violence in various parts of El Salvador in the 24 hours ending this morning, the authorities said.

title: News of Music; 2 FORGOTTON OPERAS
description: For better or worse, opera companies continue to delve ever deeper into forgotten repertory. Next season, the Long Island Opera Society plans a concert performance of Verdi's ''Il Corsaro'' at the State University College at Stony Brook, L.I. This is purported to be ''Il Corsaro's'' first performance in America.

title: News of Music; ARPEGGIOS
description: For its Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall next Thursday, the Cleveland Quartet will use a matched set of Stradivarius instruments once owned by Paganini and now on loan from the Corcoran Gallery. ... Leon Bates, the pianist, will play Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky with the National Symphony of Zimbabwe next month. Mr. Bates will also give lectures and master classes under the auspices of the State Department. ... The Guggenheim Concert Band will hold a weeklong festival of music and lectures devoted to John Philip Sousa and Victor Herbert beginning Tuesday.

title: No Headline
description: Dave Hill, among pro golf's millionaires, says he has given up playing on the PGA Tour on a regular basis and may pursue business interests in Oklahoma

title: Clerc Gains, Dibbs Out In Brookline Pro Tennis
description: Jose Luis-Clerc, the top-seeded player, struggled to victory today to join John Alexander, thirdseeded Eliot Teltscher and Andres Gomez in the third round of the $175,000 United States Pro Tennis Championships.

title: Executive Changes
description: * Airco Inc. named Richard H. Leazer president of Airco's Ohio Medical Anesthetics, a producer of anesthetic agents.

title: WILLIAMSTOWN THEATER: IT'S PARADISE FOR ACTORS
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. AS the tall, dark and handsome Achilles in the Williamstown Theater Festival's production of ''The Greeks,'' Christopher Reeve had just donned his armor and helmet and gamely marched off stage with spear in hand to die in battle. The first act was nearly over and now, lounging in jeans near a willow tree on the lawn behind the theater, Mr. Reeve had nothing to do for the rest of the play but enjoy the fresh air and beauty of the Berkshire mountains while waiting to take his bow at the final curtain.

title: FAKE STONE FINISHES ON A REALISTIC BUDGET
description: INTERIOR designers and architects have been faking it for quite a while - faking materials like marble, granite and onyx. But now, instead of being associated only with traditional, grand interiors, illusionistic surfaces are being taken up by more avant-garde designers.

title: G.E.-JAPAN DEAL ON NUCLEAR UNIT
description: The General Electric Company and eight Japanese companies have agreed to jointly test and develop an advanced boiling water nuclear reactor, G.E. annnounced in Tokyo. Financial terms of the development effort were not disclosed.

title: GERMANS HAVE REASON TO OPPOSE U.S. MISSILES
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; SOVIET DISSIDENT IS GIVEN 5 YEARS' INTERNAL EXILE
description: A dissident was sentenced today to five years of internal exile for publicizing accounts of Soviet abuse of psychiatry for political ends.

title: PAT BRADLEY SEEKS TOP BILLING
description: When Pat Bradley started on the women's pro golf tour in 1974, she was considered one of the longest hitters on the tour with the potential for many victories. But she has won only eight tournaments in eight years while becoming one of the richest women in golf and possibly the most frustrated with her performance.

title: AID TO POOR LANDS KEY SUMMIT ISSUE
description: The issue of how best to channel billions of dollars in aid from the industrial democracies to the poor nations has emerged as a likely point of contention at the Ottawa economic summit conference next week, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Design Notesbook style paneled in pine; A REMARKABLE MAISONETTE ON PARK AVE
description: SURELY the greatest maisonette ever constructed in New York is the 21-room triplex at 666 Park Avenue, at the northwest corner of 67th Street. To call it a maisonette at all is rather like calling a Bugatti a runabout - this is not the small insertion on the ground floor of an apartment building that most maisonettes are, those little and charming places that coyly pretend to be both apartments and townhouses. No mistakes can be made about this place. It is not little, it is not coy, and it is not, in the conventional sense, charming.

title: NEW-WAVE ROCK SEEKS 'CHART PENETRATION'
description: Industry conventions are endemic to the pop-music business; some might say they're epidemic. But the New Music Seminar on Monday and Tuesday at Privates, an East Side rock disco that closed recently as a result of neighborhood pressure, was different. So different that it can serve as a neat symbol of the state of the rock-music business today.

title: THE ARGENTINE GULAG
description: The Argentine Foreign Minister, Oscar Camilion, on June 26 complained to the United States charge d'affairs in Buenos Aires about allegations made on television that there are concentration camps in Argentina. Mr. Camilion later told reporters that the allegations, made by Hector Timerman, the son of Jacobo Timerman, were ''intolerable.'' In addition, Mr. Camilion compared the Timermans to Joseph Goebbels, Hitler's Minister of Propaganda, accusing them of spreading the ''big lie.'' The record must be set straight.

title: ECHLIN MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
News of Music; BUFFET, FRENCH CLARINET MAKER, SOLD
description: A BUSINESS deal involving musical instruments has just been completed that will affect musicians all over the United States. The names are not as famous as Steinway, Baldwin, Stradivarius or Guarneri; but for thousands of orchestra and band musicians they have equal importance. Central to this transaction is the Buffet clarinet, an instrument manufactured in France and overwhelmingly favored by America's symphonic, jazz and pop clarinetists.

title: FILMWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,408,000, or 24 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $524,000, or 9 cents a share, for the previous quarter and $4.3 million char for the latest quarter for the interest on debt that was repaid in June 1981

Ladd, vice president of the General Electric Credit Corporation, who was well prepared yesterday to talk about the new $2 million ad campaign prepared by Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn. You might already have seen it, since the ads began running this month in business publications.

description: Share earnings reflect losses from foreign currency translation of 9 cents and 15 cents for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, and gains of 1 cent and 5 cents for the previous quarter and 6 months respectively

title: 400 IN JAIL CHOSEN FOR RELEASE BY FEDERAL JUDGE IN ALABAMA
description: A Federal judge today ordered 400 state inmates freed July 24 to relieve overcrowding of what he termed ''grossly inadequate facilities.''

title: HOME LOAN PLAN BACKED
description: Federal regulators today approved a new type of home loan, combining features of existing plans, in an attempt to protect lenders while helping home buyers qualify for loans they might otherwise be unable to afford.

title: PRESIDENT VOICES 'CONFIDENCE' IN CASEY DESPITE ACCUSATIONS
description: President Reagan today expressed ''continuing confidence'' in William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, despite two separate accusations of stock fraud that resulted in a court ruling against Mr. Casey and the resignation of his top deputy.

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BERLE IS 73:
description: Milton Berle, the television comedian, preparing to cut a cake - in the shape of a television screen - at party in Dallas. He celebrated late; his 73d birthday was Sunday.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOME SELLERS FIND BUYERS SCARCE AS 8% MORTGAGES
description: Since January, when Emil Griglak put his sevenroom house in the southwest suburbs on the market for $69,900, only a handful of people have looked at it. With two children now grown and married, Mr. Griglak and his wife are eager to retire to Florida and are now offering to finance a buyer at an interest cost lower than prevailing rates.

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DAMAGED ASSETS AT THE 'COMPANY'
description: The Central Intelligence Agency belied its name in the peculiar matter of Max Hugel. Director William Casey was unwise to appoint his ill-prepared political chum as chief of clandestine operations. But it is scarcely intelligible that the clearance procedure failed to discover a blackmail threat from Mr. Hugel's former business associates. That requires some explaining. And Mr. Casey, it now appears, has some further explaining to do about his own role in a bitter shareholders' dispute.

title: IRON ORE DATA LISTED
description: Iron ore and iron ore agglomerate shipments and consumption through May are up slightly from figures for the first five months of 1980, the American Iron Ore Association said today.

title: Home Beat
description: IT'S been quite a month for Paul Haigh, an English architectural designer. No sooner was his showroom for John Kaldor Fabricmaker finished than Knoll International introduced the tables he had worked on for years.

title: Dixon Joins Syndicate Seeking to Buy Phils
description: F. Eugene Dixon, who is about to divest himself of the Philadelphia 76ers, said today that he had joined a syndicate seeking to buy the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: VICTORIAN DOORS ARE ENJOYING A REVIVAL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- George Raine contributes frequently to The Times from Salt Lake City. By GEORGE RAINE SALT LAKE CITY EIGHTY years ago, when each arriving train brought new immigrants and as the grandchildren of Mormon pioneers built their homes throughout the quickly growing state of Utah, pattern-book houses were the rule. These neat, Victorian structures lined the streets, outlined in a grid system, like neutral-tone checkers. Yet, there was a unique and sometimes glaring individuality about most of them: the gingerbread wood screen door, usually vividly painted in two or three colors.

title: EX-ARMY WARRANT OFFICER ACCUSED OF BEING SOVIET SPY
description: A former Army warrant officer who had access to top secret coding devices was arrested today on charges of supplying the Soviet Union with such vital secrets that he was awarded the rank of colonel in the Soviet Army.

title: TO MAKE THE SUBWAY FIT THE CHANGED CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: REIN URGED ON MERGER CREDIT
description: The multibillion-dollar bidding war for Conoco and the flood of recent merger activity could make it tougher for small business to obtain credit and could keep interest rates at their near-record levels, economists and bankers said yesterday.

title: Index; International
description: Israel's divided Arabs seek to flex political muscle A2 Weinberger striving to publish se- cret data on Soviet missile A3 Vietnam hints it might talk with international panel A3 ''Boat people'' are cool to Japa- nese offer of asylum A4 Around the World A5 For the Caribbean, a new ap- proach to problems A6 Vatican reports increased deficit for the Curia A7 Britain accepts Red Cross offer of Ulster fact-finding mission A10 Government/Politics Governor asks disaster status in fruit-fly crisis A12 President says Mrs. O'Connor will be confirmed A14 Mobile rejects move to alter com- mission form of government 4 A16 Speaker O'Neill promises aid on budget, tax bill A17 20 cities appeal to Congress for transit assistance A19 Pierce, quiet no more, says ''balo- ney'' to his critics A20 Administration says new grant system will be fair A21 Senate ethics panel reviews tapes from Williams trial B2 General Around the Nation A12 Federal judge orders 400 inmates released in Alabama A12 Judge denies bail for suspect in slaying in Atlanta A14 Newark shelves the red tape to re- pair its water pipeline fast B3 The London Underground runs a smooth system B3 Three seized after car chase in kidnapping in Manhattan B5 Home sellers scramble for inno- vative ways to attract buyers B8 Six in education indicted in visa fraud case B8 Home Section Home Fake stone finishes on a realis- tic budget C1

title: CAMBODIA: STILL A SIDESHOW
description: Cambodia remains a victim state. To Americans during the Vietnam War, it was an inconvenient sanctuary for the Vietcong, a target to be bombed and invaded. Thus weakened, it then became a laboratary for the crackpot experiments of a Chinese-backed zealot, Pol Pot. He in turn was overthrown in 1979 by the Soviet-backed Vietnamese, moving imperially to visit fresh sorrows on that trampled land.

title: RCA VIDEODISK COSTS A FACTOR IN 24.3% LOSS
description: The RCA Corporation, citing high costs for the introduction of its videodisk system and other factors, reported a 24.3 percent decline in second-quarter earnings.

title: PEMEX SEES MORE EXPORTS
description: The director of the state oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, said yesterday that Mexico had confirmed standing orders and obtained new ones that will enable it to reestablish by August its oil export level of one million barrels a day reached during the first six months of 1981.

title: WURLITZER CO reports earnings for Yr to March 31
Business People; ABC'S TOP TEAM OF 3 ALL SIGNING ON AGAIN
description: The American Broadcasting Companies announced yesterday that its top three executives - Leonard H. Goldenson, chairman and chief executive officer; Elton H. Rule, president, and Frederick S. Pierce, executive vice president - had signed new four-year contracts.

title: WEINBERGER SAID TO FAVOR AIRBORNE MX SYSTEM
description: The Air Force has told Administration and Congressional officials that Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has decided to recommend basing the MX nuclear missile aboard a fleet of aircraft, but a Defense Department spokesman said today that ''no decision has been made.''

title: SMITH, A O, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HANOI HINTS IT MIGHT TALK WITH A U.N. PANEL
description: Vietnam, which has boycotted the conference on Cambodia here, left the door ajar today for talks with the committee of nations that the conference plans to establish.

title: MOBIL ROLLS BACK GAS PRICE INCREASE
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation, which raised its gasoline price 3 cents a gallon Sunday in response to new state taxes, reduced the increase to 1.3 cents today.

title: CAIRO ASKS DEATH FOR LIBYANS
description: The prosecution in the trial of Libyan agents charged with infiltrating Egypt to sabotage installations asked today that the defendants be sentenced to death, the official Middle East News Agency reported. The agency said the court would issue its ruling in the case of one defendant Sunday. It said that the trial of three others was continuing, and that five more were awaiting trial.

title: CHINA UPHOLDS MAO'S PHILOSOPHY
description: A Chinese magazine disclosed today that the writers of the Communist Party's assessment of its 32 years of ruling China had been ordered to uphold Mao Zedong thought regardless of any criticism of Mao.

title: Clauser's Catamaran Wins Power Race
description: Satisfaction, a new catamaran driven by Paul Clauser of North Miami Beach, won the $35,000 Benihana Grand Prix offshore powerboat race today.

title: 20 CITIES APPEAL TO CONGRESS FOR TRANSIT HELP
description: Public transit officials from more than 20 cities around the nation appeared before a House transportation subcommittee today to criticize proposed reductions in Federal help. They said a $50 billion package of capital assistance would be needed in the next 10 years.

title: Business People; PAINE WEBBER FIRM GETS NEW PRESIDENT
description: Even after being named president of one of the country's oldest and largest brokerage houses, Donald E. Nickelson could not forget about the one that got away.

title: TRANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-after losses from discontinued operations of $182,000 for the quarter and $384,000 for the 6 months

title: LONDON SUBWAY: DIFFERENT PHILOSOPHY
description: While New York subway riders clatter along on grimy trains that run with uncertain frequency, patrons of the London Underground enjoy clean trains and short waits, all of which London Transport accomplishes with an insignificant operating subsidy.

title: Sports of The Time; SANDWICH, SPAGHETTI, BEER
description: like furnaces and a slim smokestack at a local power station that creates a science-fiction backdrop. Out on the course, skeletons of bleachers for 19,000 spectators rise above the high grass swaying in the gentle breeze. In what are normally cow pastures, dozens of hospitality and shop tents, big and small, have turned the British Open into Ringling Brothers, Nicklaus and Watson, the greatest circus in golf. This is Royal St. George's with its gingerbread clubhouse where the 110th British Open begins today.

description: B-Includes $15.3 million gain from discontinued operations

Secretary of Labor Makes Hectic Exit
description: On the 34th day of the baseball strike, Raymond J. Donovan, the Secretary of Labor, was nearly trampled on a Manhattan street corner by dozens of cameramen, photographers and reporters yesterday while clusters of lunchtime strollers gaped at the scene.

THRIFT-INDUCING BUSES
description: To the Editor:

Advertising; AMAX CORPORATE ADS BEING HANDLED BY GREY
description: Now that its work is already appearing, it can be disclosed that Grey Advertising has become the corporate agency for Amax Inc., the diversified minerals and energy company.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 16, 1981
description: International A milestone in the Soviet bloc was set by the Polish Communist Party as it agreed to elect its entire leadership by secret ballot with a choice of contenders. The delegates at the emergency party congress in Warsaw also voted to expel seven former high officials from the party. (Page A1, Column 6.) Upholding of Mao Zedong thought regardless of any criticism of the late leader was the directive given to writers of the recent assessment of Communist Party rule in China, according to a Peking magazine. It marked the first time that China's controlled press has reported any behind-the-scenes activity leading to a party decision. (A4:1-2.)

title: GAS INJECTION SET IN ANGOLA
description: A gas-reinjection facility costing $160 million is to be installed in an oilfield in Cabinda, Angola, to double the field's current output of 100,000 barrels of oil a day, the official Angolan news agency reported today.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JULY 16, 1981; The Economy
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, working on its own tax package, approved changes in estate and gift taxes that would be more generous than those already voted by the Senate Finance Committee. The Senate began debate on the tax bill drafted by the Finance Committee along the lines proposed by the Administration to include tax cuts for business and individuals. (Page A1.)

title: TRANSCON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BANKERS TRUST NY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The City; Landmark Status Gains for East Side
description: The New York City Planning Commission has recommended that landmark status be granted to a large part of the East Side of Manhattan and to the Empire State Building.

description: B-Includes $29,400 gain from discontinued operations and $1,404,731 tax credit...C-Includes $3,314,405 gain from discontinued operations and $2,051,000 tax credit

title: The City; Quotations Law To Be Rescinded
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs said it planned to rescind a law that prohibits the use of out-of-context quotations from reviews in promoting a play, movie or other performance or artwork.

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
Nuclear Bonds In Northwest
description: The Washington State Public Power Supply System, the nation's largest issuer of tax-exempt bonds, plans to sell from $250 million to $350 million of new revenue bonds late this month or in August to continue financing its nuclear generating plants 4 and 5, officials of the agency said yesterday.

title: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES FOREIGN TAKEOVER CURB
description: A House subcommittee voted unanimously today to discourage foreign acquisitions of American companies. It would do so by restricting foreign companies' flexibility to borrow funds to finance the takeovers.

title: AFTER POLAND'S SURGE OF HOPE, PARTY TALKS SEEM A LETDOWN
description: As delegates gathered for the opening of the special congress of the Polish Communist Party, a violent thunderstorm swept over Warsaw, spewing hailstones and lightning over the meticulously restored medieval Old Town. One bolt struck a church and, to general merriment, a Pole yelled at the heavens: ''You've got the wrong address! It's over there!''

title: NICKLAUS SHOOTS 83, 13 STROKES OFF PACE
description: Jack Nicklaus shot an 83, the worst round of his professional career, and a pair of little-known players on the international golf circuit, Nick Job of England and Vicente Fernandez of Argentina, emerged as first-round leaders at the British Open Championship today. Job and Fernandez shot par 70.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We must rid ourselves of what remains of Napoleon's ancien regime.

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $1,694,000 tax credit for the qr and $54,527,000 gain for the 6 mos on the sale of proprietary medicine business C-Including $1,344,000 income from discontinued operations for the qr and $3,808,000 income for the 6 mos from the proprietary medicine business

title: Sports News Briefs; MARYLAND STARTS INQUIRY ON CREDIT CARD MISUSE
description: The University of Maryland athletic department was ordered today to submit a full report about the misuse of a telephone credit card by members of the football team.

title: No Headline
Seoul Textile Exports
description: South Korea exported $2.97 billion worth of textile products in the first half of this year, up 30.8 percent from a year ago, the Commerce and Industry Ministry reported today. Officials said the six-month tally accounted for 51.6 percent of this year's export target of $5.75 billion. Arrivals of letters of credit for textile exports in the January-June period amounted to $3.17 billion, up 42.5 percent from the same period of last year, the ministry said.

title: QUAINT COUNSEL FOR TEEN-AGERS
description: The Adolescent Family Life, or ''chastity,'' bill is moving through Congress with dismaying ease. The measure has cleared the Senate Labor and Resources Committee unanimously, winning the vote even of Edward Kennedy. It is a sad and puzzling spectacle, given the Administration's railing against welfare dependency. The two issues are clearly connected.

title: SOVIET DEFENSE AIDE REVEALS BUILDUP IN RESPONSE TO U.S.
description: Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, Chief of Staff of the Soviet armed forces, said today in the party journal Kommunist that the Soviet Union had begun to strengthen its strategic nuclear arsenal to counter United States military spending.

title: ALAGASCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 23
MIRRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quebec Party Worries Bank
description: Several major Canadian banks, including the Bank of Montreal, may move their head offices from Montreal to Calgary or Toronto, partly as a result of the Parti Quebecois language policy, the chairman of the Bank of Montreal said in an interview published today.

FIRST TENNESSEE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Automobile production fell 9 percent this week from last, and temporary layoffs rose slightly as the summer model change-over continued, according to industry reports released today.

title: RAPIDATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rates Stable in Quiet Trading; Money Data Are Awaited
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday, as many investors continue to avoid the long-term bond market in favor of the higher yields and greater principal protection available in money market instruments due in three months or less.

title: US INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ATLANTA SUSPECT LOSES COURT BIDS
description: Wayne B. Williams, facing a possible indictment on charges of murder in the case of the most recent victim in a series of killings of young blacks, today lost two efforts to win judicial relief.

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
ISRAEL'S 199 MEDALS LEAD
description: The 11thMaccabiah Games came to a festive close tonight as 3,600 athletes paraded through the streets of downtown Jerusalem, and 10,000 fans, sitting in an outdoor amphitheater, viewed a sound and light show projected on the old city walls.

title: BIG FLOOD RAVAGING THE YANGTZE RIVER VALLEY
description: A major flood was reported in the Yangtze River valley today after six days of heavy rain. The river level was reported to be higher than any recorded in this century as the water surged from Sichuan Province through heavily populated regions toward the East China Sea at Shanghai.

title: Pressure Seen On Yamani
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister, has come under heavy pressure from other Arab oil ministers to reduce his country's oil production, now believed to be about 10 million barrels a day, industry sources reported today.

title: Sports News Briefs; DRUCKER RESIGNS POST
description: Norm Drucker, the supervisor of officials for the National Basketball Association for the last four years, has resigned effective Sept. 30. A professional basketball referee for 24 years before becoming supervisor of officials, Drucker was also supervisor of officials for four years with the old American Basketball Association.

title: LINDBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest period includes sales and earnings of Harris Metals Inc on a purchase accounting basis

title: EMPIRE OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SOME ON MX PANEL FAVOR AIR SYSTEM
description: Several members of a panel studying alternative plans for deploying the MX nuclear missile have suggested to Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger that carrying it aboard specially developed aircraft might be the best solution to the issue of how to base the weapons, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chairman Chosen, By Del E. Webb
description: To hear Robert K. Swanson tell it, the odds are still in favor of the house. The newly appointed chairman and chief executive officer of the Del E. Webb Corporation, the land developer and owner of Nevada casinos and hotels, said that with enough time and luck, fortune will again smile on his gaming empire.

title: SPECTRADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THEATER: SHAW'S 'MISALLIANCE' IN CHELSEA
description: IF we're going to see lots of Shaw revivals in New York - and we can dream, can't we? - let's hope that every one of them comes equipped with Stephen Porter and Philip Bosco. Two seasons ago, you may recall, Mr. Porter directed Mr. Bosco in a ''Major Barbara'' at Circle in the Square that was a few inches away from sublime. Now this duo has applied its skills to ''Misalliance'' at the Roundabout, and the streak, knock wood, continues. Maybe this ''Misalliance'' isn't quite as good as the ''Major Barbara'' - you'll notice scattered dips in Act I - but it's three-quarters of the way to perfection. As Mr. Bosco is better than ever, I wouldn't lose much sleep over that delinquent 25 percent.

title: The U.N. Today; July 17, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: International Conference on Cambodia - 3 P.M. Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations - 10:30 P.M.

title: Dow Up a Slim 1.33 In Lackluster Day
description: Some last-minute buying left the stock market with a slight gain yesterday. But, this aside, the market moved in the narrowest range in weeks as volume shrank to 39 million shares from 49 million the day before. Many investors were reportedly discouraged when Wednesday's rally fizzled shortly after the opening.

title: Broadway; PETER STRAUSS SET FOR 'EINSTEIN AND POLAR BEAR' IN FALL
description: ''EINSTEIN AND THE POLAR BEAR,'' starring Peter Strauss, will go into previews on Broadway on Oct. 10 and open a week or so later. Most recently, Mr. Strauss co-starred with Peter O'Toole in the television spectacular ''Masada,'' playing the leader of the 960 Zealots who fought the Roman legions in 73 A.D. In Tom Griffin's ''Einstein and the Polar Bear,'' he will play a celebrated writer, living in self-imposed isolation in New England, who meets a young woman on a cold day in February. The play, first done as a staged reading at the O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., and then as a full production at the Hartford Stage Company, will be directed by J Ranelli. Mr. Ranelli directed ''Herzl'' on Broadway, although mostly he works in regional theater. The producers of ''Einstein and the Polar Bear'' are Emanuel Azenberg, Max A. Allentuck and Wayne Rogers, and no, the play is not about J. D. Salinger, at least not palpably so.

title: TV Weekend; THE AGED, THE COURTS AND 'OMNIBUS'
description: PUBLIC TELEVISION'S retrospective of five CBS News documentaries continues, tonight at 9 on Channel 13, with ''Don't Count the Candles,'' a 1968 ''essay'' by Lord Snowdon, on the subject of aging. CBS was impressed with a series of photographs he published on the subject and asked him to do something similar with a television camera. The result is less investigative than esthetic, but it is also moving, poignant and sometimes surprisingly funny.

title: FACTORY USE DECLINED TO 79.6% DURING JUNE
description: Manufacturers operated at 79.6 percent of capacity in June, a half-point decline from May and the biggest onemonth drop since last July, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

ESQUIRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

SOCIALISTS DEBATE MERITS OF ATOM-FREE NORDIC ZONE
description: The leaders of the Socialist International, including four Western European heads of government, ended two days of talks here today by calling for further discussion of the possible creation of a nuclear weapon-free zone in northern Europe, and by reiterating previous appeals for an early start to disarmament talks.

title: MOBIL'S MISTAKEN PRICE RISE
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation has made its mark in the advertising world as a tough media street fighter that has pioneered an aggressive style of advertising in explaining oil industry profits, pricing and policy decisions.

description: B-Net income including $887,000 or 21 cents a shr income from sale of real estate

description: Kenneth Rex McElroy was the bully of Nodaway County until an angry crowd confronted him last week and someone put a bullet in his brain.

title: Market Place; Hospital Issues Still Rate High
description: HOSPITAL management issues, like most other groups in the stock market, have encountered some selling pressure lately. But many followers of this industry - which was in its infancy a decade ago - still give it high marks for potential performance in the long run.

title: 7-Eleven Food Stores Pares Agency Search
description: The report from informed sources is that 7-Eleven Food Stores, part of the Southland Corporation, has narrowed the field in its agency search from five to three.

title: OWNERS REJECT PLAYERS' REQUEST FOR ARBITRATION
description: In an effort to end the five-week-old baseball strike, the players proposed last night that the dispute be submitted to binding arbitration, but the owners promptly rejected the idea.

title: The Region; Parkway Workers Reach Settlement
description: After bargaining for more than 20 straight hours, union representatives and administrators of the Garden State Parkway reached a tentative agreement yesterday to end the two-weekold toll collectors' strike.

title: Sports News Briefs; HOLMES-COONEY FIGHT IS CALLED A PROBABILITY
description: A Larry Holmes-Gerry Cooney fight early next year was a ''70-30 probability, pretty good odds,'' Mike Jones, one of Cooney's comanagers, said yesterday. Jones said ''an agreement in principle'' had been worked out in which Don King and Sam Glass would promote the fight between the two undefeated heavyweights for Holmes's World Boxing Council championship.

title: Advertising; Crazy Horse's Campaign
description: A four-legged cop, a four-legged clown and a four-legged jogger are one thing, but a four-legged taxi? Well, that's carrying horse costuming a bit far.

title: Penn Central Net Soars 69%
description: The Penn Central Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings surged 69 percent in the second quarter ended June 30 to a record $48 million, or $1.84 a share, from $28.4 million, or 91 cents a share, a year earlier, reflecting the impact of its acquisition of GK Technologies Inc. on March 31.

title: CBS Profit Off 22.8% in Period
description: CBS Inc., the diversified communications concern, said yesterday that earnings in the second quarter fell 22.8 percent, to $41.9 million, or $1.50 a share, from $54.3 million, or $1.94 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to a record $998.2 million from $971.8 million.

title: JEAN MARSH IN 'VANYA'
description: Jean Marsh, who appeared in the Public Broadcasting Service production of ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' and Wayne Rogers of the television series ''House Calls,'' are featured in a production of Chekhov's ''Uncle Vanya'' at the Actor's Conservatory Theater at Adelphi University on South Avenue in Garden City, L.I. The play, directed by Philip Minor, runs through July 26, with performances this weekend at 8:30 tonight, 5:30 and 9:30 P.M. tomorrow and 7 P.M. on Sunday. Reserved seats, at $13.50, are available only for tomorrow afternoon; all other seats, $6 and $8, are in a carpeted bleacher area. Information: (516) 741-2313.

title: Lois Stair, Presbyterian Aide; Led Church Unity Delegation
description: Lois H. Stair, the first woman to be elected moderator of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., died Monday night at her home in Deerfield Beach, Fla. She was 58 years old.

title: REAGAN ANNOUNCES A POLICY TO CURB THE SPREAD OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: President Reagan formally announced a nuclear policy today that affirmed his Administration's commitment to preventing the spread of nuclear weapons as a ''fundamental national security and foreign policy objective.''

title: HOUSE APPROVES $26 BILLION RISE IN ARMS BUDGET
description: The House endorsed the Reagan Administration's military buildup program today by approving a $136 billion military authorization bill for the fiscal year 1982, making it the costliest military measure in the nation's history.

title: SAMUELL, BARRED JOCKEY, WINS RESTRAINING ORDER
description: Larry Saumell, the jockey who was denied access to Belmont Park, Aqueduct and Saratoga by the New York Racing Association after he was accused of possessing an illegal battery device before a race last month, won a temporary restraining order in State Supreme Court yesterday and will be allowed to ride pending a Monday hearing.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Company News item in Business Day on Friday incorrectly described a real estate transaction by the Radice Corporation. The company will acquire 266 acres in Clearwater, Fla.

title: DOLLAR SURFEIT SEIZES CHICAGO TRANSIT Authority
description: It seemed incongruous for a transit system skidding toward bankruptcy, but there they were: dollar bills, hundreds of thousands of them, like ants at a picnic, covering the tables and floors in a Chicago Transit Authority counting room and piling up at a rate that threatened to bury the employees counting them.

title: CITY IS MOVING TO DISCOURAGE COOKING BY SIDEWALK VENDORS
description: New York City is making a new effort at strict enforcement of all existing regulations on food vendors, especially those who cook in the streets.

title: PACCAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MARY KAY COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FLORIDA COMMERCIAL BANKS INC (MIAMI) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Metropolitan Baedeker; HISTORIC PATERSON RENEWING ITS PAST
description: a place that people think less of going to than of leaving. It is a city with houses of aluminum siding and asbestos shingles, where the streets have diners and corner taverns with neon signs and where the major presences on the skyline are the Beaux-Arts domes and towers of the county courthouse and the city hall because this city was never prosperous enough to clutter itself up with glass skyscrapers. Paterson has not changed much since the early 1950's, except for the ripping down of a few downtown buildings in the expectation of an urban renewal that never came; if the city looks in any way different from 30 years ago, it is that its center seems just a little bit older and a little bit more tired.

title: EX-OFFICER DENIES SPYING FOR SOVIET
description: A former Army warrant officer pleaded not guilty today to selling military coding secrets to the Soviet Union, and a magistrate ordered him held in lieu of $500,000 bond.

title: FIRST & MERCHANTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Notes On People; The 'No Name' File
description: When her son adopted ''No Name'' as his Citizens Band radio call identification, Selma Ghelberg decided she liked it so much she would apply for ''NO NAME'' license plates for her car.

title: AUTONUMERICS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
ART: DAN FLAVIN LIGHTS SOHO WITH NEON
description: WHEN brightly colored and bent into signs, neon confers magic on the urban scene, but as a unit of white light it does little for human well-being. Fluorescent's glare does not enhance intimate dinners, nor is it imaginable as the cozy light emanating from the woodcutter's cottage of fairy tales. Basically, the tube is the light of offices and subway arcades, and when Dan Flavin first brought it into art galleries during the 1960's, he was, in effect, doing what Marcel Duchamp had done with his ready-mades nearly 50 years earlier. Mr. Flavin has continued to work with neon in its pure form, placing the bars sometimes in their ''natural'' context, as at the railroad tracks at Grand Central Terminal and in the entrance to the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. But he has also explored, through color, the medium's expressive possibilities, besides revealing himself as a romantic through his rapid expressionistic drawings of landscapes.

description: B-Share earnings are not available because the company became public in November of 1980

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 17, 1981
description: International A POLITICAL SOLUTION IN EI Salvador was reflected in a policy statement issued by the Reagan Administration. It committed itself to a political rather than a military resolution of the Salvadoran conflict and pledged support for free elections. The statement omitted previous references to the war as an arena of Soviet-American conflict. (Page A1, Column 6.) A new American nuclear policy was formally announced by President Reagan. It affirmed a commitment to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, efforts to ''improve regional and global stability'' to help deter countries from developing nuclear arms and to make the United States a more ''predictable and reliable'' supplier of nuclear technology for peaceful uses. (A4:1-4.)

title: UNDOING THE HIGH COURT
description: Columbus, Ohio - The exceedingly dangerous character of attempts led by right-wing zealots to eliminate United States Supreme Court jurisdiction in cases dealing with abortion, legislative reapportionment, school busing, and school prayers is not fully perceived.

title: LA SCALA'S LUCIANA SAVIGNANO IN TONIGHT'S DANCE SPOTLIGHT
description: When a foreign dance company makes its New York debut with such superstars as Rudolf Nureyev, Carla Fracci and Dame Margot Fonteyn, it can be tough for the permanent principals. The public often gets little more than a glimpse of them.

CAREY SIGNS A BILL RAISING PUBLIC EMPLOYEES' PENSIONS
description: Governor Carey today signed a bill that will provide pension increases for nearly 277,000 retired public employees around the state. About two-thirds of the retirees have never before received a pension supplement.

title: CIVIC UNIT DISAVOWS A SURVEY PROPOSING SUBWAY SHUTDOWNS
description: The New York City Citizens Union disavowed yesterday any connection with a study released by William Woodward, a candidate for the City Council, that recommended shutting down the subway system between midnight and 6 A.M.

title: The Editorial Notebook; THE BALD POLITICIAN PUZZLE
description: It's time for voters to bridle at male politicians who use too much hair spray, writes Mark Shields in The Washington Post. He fears some freshman members of Congress apply so much that ''if they tripped, they might very well break their hair.''

description: * Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., named Lewis A. Jacobson vice president and national sales manager.

title: FOUR INDICTED IN '80 MURDER OF IRANIAN PRESS AIDE
description: A grand jury has indicted four men on charges of conspiring to murder Ali Akbar Tabatabai, a former press attache at the Iranian Embassy who was an outspoken critic of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Around the Nation; PROSECUTOR INVESTIGATING BROWN CAMPAIGN AIDES
description: The District Attorney's office began an official inquiry today into allegations that workers at Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s campaign office destroyed documents in an effort to thwart an investigation.

title: NEW BRITISH PARTY SHOWS STRENGTH IN FIRST ELECTION
description: The new Social Democratic Party, in the first electoral test of its campaign to break the power monopoly of the two major parties, scored a symbolic victory last night by coming within a hair's breadth of capturing the Warrington constituency, which had been a Labor stronghold for more than half a century.

title: PRIVATE OTTAWA TALKS AS ISSUE
description: The seven heads of government who are to meet at the Ottawa economic summit conference next week have been asked by President Reagan to limit private meetings among themselves and to devote more time to meetings in which they are joined by their aides, Administration officials said today.

title: Restaurants; A COOL SHUSHI HOUSE ON A SUMMER'S DAY
description: REFERRING to the tropical look of the traditional Japanese bamboo and paper house, Fosco Maraini in his book ''Meeting With Japan'' observed: ''The Japanese often live in northern snows with the provisional attitude of southerners forced northward by events.'' Bernard Rudofsky, in his book ''The Kimono Mind,'' quotes the 14th-century philosopher Yoshida Kenko: ''A house should be built with the summer in view. In the winter, one can live anywhere.''

title: ALUMINUM CO OF AMERICA (ALCOA) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
