R.J. REYNOLDS AND F.T.E. GAIN
description: R.J. Reynolds Inc., the nation's leading producer of cigarettes, announced yesterday that earnings in the second quarter increased 21.1 percent, while revenues climbed 16.9 percent.

title: MISSES BROWNLEE AND LITTLE TIED FOR LEAD
description: Vivian Brownlee, who has not finished higher than 24th in her last 18 tournaments, lost a ball in the woods and three-putted two greens today. But she shot a 4-under-par 68 at the Meadow Brook Club and tied Sally Little for the lead in the first round of the Ladies' Professional Golf Association WUI Classic.

title: STATE LEGISLATORS EXPRESS CONCERN OVER TAX ON OIL
description: Many New York State legislators were unaware that the gross-receipts tax they passed last week was largely a levy on service stations and not on oil companies. Many still do not believe that is what they enacted, and there is already some sentiment building to revise the tax.

title: Thomas Jones, 65, M.I.T. Aide Who Was Head of Research
description: Dr. Thomas F. Jones Jr., vice president for research at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for the last six years and a former president of the University of South Carolina, has died in Boston. He was 65 years old.

title: SEARLE'S ENRICHING SWEETENER
description: The lemonade was free. The strawberries and the chewing gum were, too. These confections, offered at a press conference by G.D. Searle & Company yesterday, are just a few of the food items that will contain the company's new low-calorie sweetener.

title: 300 IN JAPAN PROTEST CARRIER
description: About 300 demonstrators marched peacefully today to protest the return of the aircraft carrier Midway to Yokosuka after a three-week cruise, the police reported. Some 3,000 demonstrators, charging that the Midway was armed with nuclear weapons, demonstrated at the ship's arrival June 5. The Japanese Government has denied that United States ships are carrying nuclear arms into the country; United States officials have refused to comment.

The movie version will be directed by Milos Forman in Prague, Vienna and Salzburg, Austria, next year. Mr. Shaffer will write the screenplay for his tale of the relationship between Mozart and Salieri.

description: A representative of the 120,000 Japanese-Americans interned in World War II urged today that the Federal Government pay each survivor of the camps at least $25,000 to compensate for property losses and ''false imprisonment.''

The President says the lawsuit is ''old news.'' Mr. Casey says any infraction was the fault of brokers and accountants he relied upon.

description: B-After $397,000 loss from disocontinued operations 1980 results are restated for both periods

title: MILLS BROTHERS, 56 YEARS AND 2,246 RECORDS LATER
description: With a performing career that has spanned 56 years, the Mills Brothers, who are appearing with Helen O'Connell and Harry James at the Westbury Music Fair this weekend, are not only one of the longest running show business acts, but they also have probably made more records than anyone else - 2,246. Originally a quartet, the group now consists of Herbert Mills, 68 years old, Harry Mills, 67, and Donald Mills, 65.

title: PUBLISHING: THE PRESIDENT'S RESEARCHER
description: THIRTEEN years ago, after he had finished the fourth part of his six-volume biography of Thomas Jefferson, Dumas Malone hired a graduate student from the University of Virginia as a part-time researcher. The last volume was published on July Fourth, the 155th anniversary of Jefferson's death, and now Steven H. Hochman, whose research job expanded to full time in 1973, is getting ready to leave Charlottesville for Plains, Ga., to take up his new duties as research assistant for former President Jimmy Carter.

title: FESTA ON CARMINE ST.
description: The sights, sounds and aromas of the eighth Festa Italiana of Our Lady of Pompei Roman Catholic Church will fill Carmine Street from the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue through July 26.

Auctions
description: HAS the auction boom in Art Deco and Art Nouveau wares leveled off? Was it buyer resistance or the owners' reserves - the prices below which they will not sell - that caused problems this season? Or has too much material become available too quickly for collectors and dealers to absorb?

title: Notes On People; Double Duty
description: For two weeks of every summer in the last 14 years, John F. Lehman Jr. has reported for flight officer duty with the Naval Reserve, and on Monday, the 38-year-old lieutenant commander again reports for reserve training, at Oceana Naval Air Station in Virginia.

title: GIANTS' KELLEY FACING 2 TESTS
description: For weeks, Brian Kelley had been working and waiting. He ran two or three miles a day. He sprinted. He ran up and down the stairs at Giants Stadium. He lifted weights. He played racquetball.

description: Interest on loans to help United States businesses export their products will be raised to 10 3/4 percent for everything except aircraft, the Export-Import Bank announced today.

A POLICE VOICE FROM AN UNLIKELY SOURCE
description: It's a problem and not a problem. Betsy Gotbaum is a 42-year-old woman who looks like a fresh-faced college senior. It's a problem when adults who look like adults momentarily forget that she is one of them. It's not a problem when she wants to wangle something for her favorite organization in the city, the state and maybe the world -the New York City Police Foundation. Mrs. Gotbaum is the foundation's executive director, and the very idea is apt to knock strangers off their pins long enough to write a check.

title: SAUDIS WILL PAY FOR REPAIRS ON IRAQ'S REACTOR
description: Saudi Arabia said today that it would pay the entire cost of rebuilding the Iraqi nuclear reactor that Israeli planes wrecked on June 7.

description: According to the American Stock Exchange Inc., Kenneth R. Leibler is the youngest man to attain the post of executive vice president since the exchange stopped trading stocks on the curb at Broad Street and moved indoors, 60 years ago.

title: IRAN ARRESTS 200 LEFTISTS AS VIOLENCE INCREASES
description: Iran today announced the arrest of 200 leftists in raids on hideouts in various parts of the country as violent antistate incidents increased.

title: MSGR. JOHN A. PINARD
description: Msgr. John A. Pinard, who had been a pastor at several Roman Catholic churches in New York City, died Tuesday at the Putnam Hospital Center in Carmel, N.Y., after a long illness.

title: ART: NEW GALLERY OFFERS SURPRISING AMERICANA
description: HIGH summer may not be the most auspicious time to get a new gallery going in uptown Manhattan, but at least two of them seem to this observer to have made a very good start.

PAULEY PETEROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
energywatch
description: JULY 10, 1981 Crude oil stocks increased to 402.0 million barrels, while refining output dipped and crude imports climbed to 4.1 million barrels a day.

title: AMUSEMENT PARKS PROVIDE NEW RIDES AND NEW TWISTS
description: THE old roller coasters are still there, and you can hear the shrieks of the passengers as they rumble by. But today's thrill seekers also put on bathing suits to plunge down a seven-story water slide into a swimming pool. A fellow and a girl may still snuggle closer when their gondola sways at the top of the Ferris wheel, but later on they do their own swaying to the sound of a band. And though young men still try to impress their dates by ringing the bell with a sledgehammer, they are just as likely to show off by zipping around a twisting track in a formula race car.

title: VOPLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Foreign Affairs; POLAND LURCHES ONWARD
description: For a nerve-racking year, the convening of a special congress to reform the Polish Communist Party was awaited as a watershed. If only the Poles could keep their movement going that long without forceful Soviet intervention, it was felt, the future would look different.

title: Alcoa and Reynolds Off
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, reported income for the second quarter fell 45.2 percent, to $81.5 million, or $1.09 a share, from $148.8 million, or $2.08 a share, in the second quarter last year.

title: JUDGE TIMBERS LEAVING U.S. APPEALS COURT POST
description: Judge William H. Timbers announced yesterday that, at the age of 65, he was stepping down as an active judge on the Federal appeals court in Manhattan. The action creates a fourth opening on the important 11-member court.

title: MENTAL TEST ORDERED FOR MOTHER ACCUSED OF NEGLECTING INFANT
description: A Family Court judge ordered psychiatric tests yesterday for a mother accused of removing her 15-month-old daughter from New York Hospital where the baby was being treated for an eye injury and body bruises.

title: Sports News Briefs; ATHLETES SEEN SEEKING SHARE OF TV REVENUES
description: Larry Fleisher, general counsel for the National Basketball Players' Association, said today that athletes would be demanding a share of the wealth to be gained by professional leagues through the future sale of broadcasting rights to pay and cable television concerns.

title: FRANCE TO LOOSEN CENTRALIZED RULE
description: France's new Socialist Government has approved what may be the most far-reaching of all its proposals, the decentralization of government.

description: T HE tea sandwiches were fresh, but the tea was lukewarm. The Scotch was smooth, but the cake was a bit dry. And as for the icing, well, when their forks failed to penetrate it, most of the guests decided not to try it.

title: DECONTROL OF A.T. & T. IS VOTED
description: The Senate Commerce Committee today passed, by a 16-to-1 vote, a landmark bill to lift regulations from much of the telephone industry and allow the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to enter new and growing fields of information processing and distribution, although it restricts Bell from beaming classified advertising to homes or establishing its own electronic newspapers.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Notes On People; New Heights
description: Once tall mountains posed the challenge to be scaled, but more and more it seems to be man-made structures, like the World Trade Center and the world's tallest building, the Sears Tower in Chicago.

title: DUDLEY MOORE STARS AS A SCREWBALL IN 'ARTHUR'
description: WHEN we first meet Arthur (Dudley Moore), we don't actually see him - we hear him. He's a manic, disembodied laugh that comes from the back seat of an elegant gray Rolls-Royce as it cruises in stately fashion around nighttime Manhattan. The driver of this extraordinary status symbol is Bitterman (Ted Ross), Arthur's loyal, longtime, ever-patient chauffeur. Arthur, who is very, very rich, is also lonely and extremely drunk.

title: BURROUGHS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE LEADERSHIP MAY LET TAX CUTS INCLUDE 3D YEAR
description: Two Southern Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee indicated today that the leadership was ready to let the House add a third year of cuts in individual income tax rates to the two-year bill being drafted by the committee.

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Region; Aqueduct Checked From the Inside
description: Equipped with portable oxygen packs and searchlights, workers crawled through the empty, parallel pipes in Newark's aqueduct yesterday searching for worn or corroded spots before water from five reservoirs was returned to them today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article about Tom Brokaw Tuesday, a comment on his straightforward and aggressive qualities was incorrectly attributed. It was made by Robert Pierpoint of CBS.

ISRAELI JETS DESTROY 5 BRIDGES IN LEBANON
description: Israel intensified its air attacks against Palestinian strongholds in southern Lebanon today and destroyed five bridges on guerrilla supply routes.

title: Around the World; ADAMSON DEFENDANT CALLS CONFESSION FORCED
description: An 18-year-old herdsman charged with the murder of Joy Adamson, the naturalist and author, said today that he was whipped, burned, kicked and starved by the police before signing a confession he could not read.

title: CENTRAL FIDELITY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
John Franklin Bardin, Novelist and Editor, 64
description: John Franklin Bardin, a novelist, editor and publicity man, died at Beth Israel Hospital on July 9. He was 64 years old and a resident of the East Village.

title: MATCHMAKER FOR SCHOLARS
description: Daniel Cassidy's computer is a matchmaker of sorts. If you've roped cattle in Arizona or are left-handed, his computer has a scholarship for you.

title: SOVIET ACCOUNTS OF POLISH CONGRESS OMIT KEY FACTS, UNDERLINE OTHERS
description: The Soviet press today printed its first substantial report on Poland's Communist Party congress, offering a version of the Warsaw events that would make the congress scarcely re-cognizable to anybody reading about it in the Western press.

title: M.T.A. DRAFTS $6.7 BILLION PLAN
description: Hundreds of new subway and commuter rail cars, major rehabilitation of stations and dozens of less visible maintenance improvements await commuters in the New York metropolitan area, according to a five-year $6.7 billion plan announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: PLUCKNETT MAY RETAIN DOMESTIC ELIGIBILITY
description: The Athletics Congress said today that Ben Plucknett of San Jose, Calif., the discus thrower who was banned indefinitely by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, may be allowed to compete in domestic events, pending a hearing.

description: ''ARTHUR,'' starring Liza Minnelli and Dudley Moore, opens today (and is reviewed on page C10). ''Arthur'' has the feeling of an old Depression-era movie, the kind people went to so they could lose themselves in fantasy and sit in the dark dreaming of Roll-Royces and mansions and silk sheets and champagne.

RETIREMENT AT 68 IS GAINING FAVOR AS AN ANSWER FOR SOCIAL SECURITY

title: MISS AIMEE IN SKI POST
description: Inez Aimee was named executive director of the United States ski team and the United States Ski Educational Foundation yesterday. She replaces Bill Traeger. Miss Aimee said the organization's fundraising goal for this year would be $5 million.

title: Arthur M. Bartley Dies at 89; A Game-Bird Conservationist
description: Arthur M. Bartley, co-founder and former executive director of Ducks Unlimited, the nonprofit conservation organization, died Tuesday at his home in Blue Point, L.I. He was 89 years old.

title: Campbell Conversion
description: The Hospitality division of the Campbell Soup Company has retained Reichenstein Advertising in Mountainside, N.J., to be ad agency for the Eastern region of a chain of restaurants it plans to start. In the East the restaurants will be known as H.T. McDoogal's. According to the agency, Campbell plans to convert its Hanover Trail steakhouses to McDoogal's.

description: Residents of the Port Richmond section of Staten Island and police officers from the 120th Precinct there were searching for a 7-yearold girl who has been missing since Wednesday night.

title: A CAMP WHERE THE PROGRAM IS PROGRAMMING swim , withDavid Evans, and Jonathan Bing
description: Children in T-shirts and shorts sit at picnic tables in the wilderness, talking, laughing and complaining about camp food - a familiar scene at summer camps since the first one opened a few miles from here a century ago.

title: SUBWAY FAN LETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: STATEMENT ON NUCLEAR SPREAD
description: Following is a statement by President Reagan, made public by the White House today, outlining his policy on limiting the spread of nuclear weapons:

title: BANK AMERICA, 2 OTHERS POST EARNINGS DECLINES
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and the Continental Illinois Corporation yesterday reported sharply lower net operating earnings for the second quarter of 1981, compared with the second quarter in 1980.

title: UNITED PARK CITY MINES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes pre-tax gain on the disposal of assets of $560,000 for the quarter and $757,000 for the 6 months C-Includes $31,000 gain on the disposal of assets

title: Dutch Shell Opposes Rule
description: The Royal/Dutch Shell Group, the world's second largest oil company, warned shareholders that it would likely report a loss on currency transactions of up to $850 million for the second quarter because of a controversial United States accounting standard to which it must conform.

title: Economic Scene; Why Don't Rates Drop?
description: THE chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Murray L. Weidenbaum, has changed his description of the American economy from ''soggy'' to ''spongy.'' Half a year ago, Mr. Weidenbaum was presumably calling the economy ''soggy'' in the sense defined by The American Dollar Dictionary, published in 1949, as ''damp and heavy'' or as ''thoroughly wet'' (the Federal Reserve having excessively liquified the system).

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; GUGGENHEIM TRAVELS
description: The free Guggenheim Band concerts are a small-town tradition in the big city. Tonight at 8, the 54-piece ensemble will strike up a program of ''Rhapsodies of the British Isles'' in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center. The program includes Noel Coward songs and music from ''The Pirates of Penzance.'' Tomorrow at 8 P.M. the band will be at Seaside Park in Brooklyn to play ''The Spirit of Vienna,'' with music by Schubert, Haydn and Strauss. And Sunday at 8 P.M. the band will be back at Damrosch Park with ''The Spirit of Vienna.'' Ainslee Cox is the conductor, and the trumpet players Douglas Hedwig and Bruce Engle are featured this weekend. Information: 867-8290. SCARSDALE CRAFTS SHOW

title: JUDGE QUESTIONS DEBBELLO CHARGE AGAINST SHERIFF
description: A retired judge who is presiding at hearings on misconduct charges brought by Westchester County Executive Alfred B. DelBello against his political rival, Thomas J. Delaney, the suspended Commissioner/Sheriff, began today to question the substance of some of the 42 accusations.

title: HOUSE PANEL NARROWS SCOPE OF BILL TO BAN NAMING AGENTS
description: A House subcommittee approved a proposal today to narrow the circumstances when a private citizen would be breaking the law in disclosing the names of Central Intelligence Agency agents.

title: POSTAL WORKERS GOING ON STRIKE COULD BE JAILED
description: The Justice Department has advised Postmaster General William F. Bolger that any postal worker who goes out on strike could be immediately arrested on felony charges.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A RARE CLUB DATE FOR MARY OSBORNE
description: MARY OSBORNE, who is not only the best woman jazz guitarist performing today but is, aside from the young newcomer Emily Remler, virtually the only one, is playing in a New York club for the first time in 31 years tonight and tomorrow evening and next Tuesday through Saturday. She will be leading a trio at Bechet's, Third Avenue near 75th Street.

title: A WEST SIDE WALK THROUGH ARCHITECTURAL HISTORY
description: Joe Zito conducts walking tours that are not easy to forget. ''Look at this!'' he says, fairly lunging toward a stoop on West 81st Street.''That railing is the Kilroy Was Here of Queen Anne.''

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Toyota-Ford Talks
description: Two Toyota Motor Company executives, Tatsuo Hasegawa and Hideo Tamura, have left for the United States to resume talks with the Ford Motor Company about the possibility of jointly producing small cars in America, a company spokesman confirmed today.

title: MICHAELS WEIGHS TRIP TO TRADE MARKET
description: Although denying that he is under pressure to produce a winning season, Coach Walt Michaels of the Jets said today that ''if the situation presented itself,'' he would change his policy and consider making a trade for veteran players who could provide immediate help.

title: B.P. Stock Issue Termed Success
description: The British Petroleum Company, the world's fifth-largest oil company, said it completed a record $1.18 billion new share issue that earlier seemed set for disaster.

title: COMMERCIAL TRUST CO OF NJ reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Books of the Times
description: COMMON GROUND. A Naturalist's Cape Cod. By Robert Finch. 142 pages. With Drawings by Amanda Cannell. David R. Godine. $12.95.

title: GRAINGER, W W, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EMANUEL AX, EPITOME OF A NEW BREED OF PIANIST
description: A generation ago, celebrated concert pianists tended to be lofty individualists who rarely performed with other musicians, preferring to give solo recitals in isolated grandeur. All that has changed today, and Emanuel Ax certainly ranks prominently among the new breed. While the 32-year-old pianist scarcely disdains the role of soloist, he is just as likely to be heard playing happily with his peers in a variety of harmonious chamber combinations.

title: Pop Jazz; BLACK UHURU, REGGAE AMBASSADORS TO THE WORLD
description: ''REGGAE is not a thing you can just keep in a music category,'' maintains Puma Jones, who is one of three singers in the leading Jamaican reggae group Black Uhuru.

title: Potential Trouble Spots for Summer Traffic
description: A. Palizades Interstate Parkway: Intermittent lane closings in a one-mile section south of New Jersey line.

title: MCGRAW-HILL OUSTS 2 EDITORS AFTER TRADE BOOK CHIEF QUITS
description: Jon Gillett, general manager of Graw-Hill Book Company's trade division, resigned yesterday. Minutes afterward, the company dismissed two of its three top editors and announced that it was combining its hardcover and paperback general book operations.

title: Around the World; AFGHAN REBELS REPORTED TO KILL 27 KARMAL AIDES
description: Afghan rebels have killed 27 senior members of President Babrak Karmal's National Fatherland Front since it was founded last month, a source from Kabul said today.

title: PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After $59,000 loss from discontinued operations for the quart and $867,000 gain from discontinued operations for the 6 months C-After $5,071,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: THRIFT UNIT TROUBLES INCREASE
description: At least 100 more savings and loan institutions have been added to the list of most troubled thrift institutions, which had totaled 263 at the end of May, the head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: JUDGE O'CONNOR MEETS LEADERS ON CAPITOL HILL
description: Judge Sandra Day O'Connor, nominated to the Supreme Court, kept up her busy pace today on Capitol Hill, including a meeting with the Senate's chief opponent of abortion.

title: GENERAL TELEPHONE & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results reflect Canadian foreign currency translations

title: SEALED POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DOROTHY DALTON
description: Dorothy Upjohn DeLano Dalton, daughter of the founder of the Upjohn Company and a former board member, died yesterday at the Borgess Medical Center in Kalamazoo, Mich.

title: Notes on People; Pulitzer Secretary
description: Columbia University said yesterday that the new secretary of the Pulitzer Prize Board would be Robert C. Christopher, a former editor at Time and Newsweek who most recently was a member of the editorial board of The Daily News.

title: In The Nation; GRUDGING ARMS CONTOL
description: Two days after Secretary of State Haig said that the Reagan Administration was ''developing more vigorous policies for inhibiting nuclear proliferation,'' those policies turned out to include acquiescence in the development of breeder reactors, with which weapons-grade nuclear materials can be produced.

title: FEATHERS: A FLUFFY BIT IS THRIVING
description: A year ago, the most visible hot weather fashion trend on the streets was the cutout T-shirt, razored into a hundred different patterns, then beaded and occasional feathered. Now, of course, that T-shirt is as tired as last summer's bathing suit, but what has survived is the little feather, which has been borne along with the seasonal fashion currents to become, this summer, a full-blown trend of its own.

title: U.S. 'CLARIFICATION' OF SALVADOR STAND STRESSES ELECTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration, in a policy statement that it hopes will stem public criticism, committed itself today to a political rather than a military solution to the conflict in El Salvador.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Borman's Inc. agreed to sell 10 of its Arnold's Drugstores to Revco Discount Drug Centers Inc., for an undisclosed price.

title: VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Around the Nation; ALABAMA TO APPEAL ORDER FREEING INMATES
description: Alabama's Attorney General angrily announced today that the state would appeal a Federal court order freeing 400 inmates and granting early parole review to 50 others.

title: Around the World; 14 ARRESTED IN PAKISTAN IN ROUNDUP OF DISSIDENTS
description: Pakistan's military authorities have arrested 14 political leaders in the first major roundup of dissidents in about five months, authoritative sources said today.

title: AREA TO BE SPRAYED WITH PESTICIDE IN CALIFORNIA IS INCREASED 25 MILES
description: Officials battling a Mediterranean fruit fly infestation added 25 square miles today to the area that will be sprayed with a pesticide after the aerial missions bogged down for the third night in a row.

title: HYDRO OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $8,000 for the latest period and $30,000 for the previous period; shr earnings are on a fully diluted basis; yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted from amounts previously reported to give effect to common equivalent shrs

title: Belgian Steel Merger
description: The European Economic Community Commission, the executive arm of the Common Market, said today that it favored the merger of the Belgian steel companies Cockerill S.A. and Hainaut-Sambre S.A., but stressed that its formal approval was conditional on an improvement in the merged company's financial structure. The companies agreed to merge last month, but have not worked out details of the new company's financial structure.

title: PATRIOTIC SMUGGLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPITOL FOOD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
STATE IS ORDERED TO TAKE 250 PRISONERS FROM CITY
description: A Federal judge ordered New York State yesterday to accept 100 prisoners from overcrowded New York City jails today, 50 more on Monday and 100 next Friday.

title: PATIENTS' DEATHS TIED TO THE HEAT ARE INVESTIGATED
description: A New York State commission began an investigation yesterday into the deaths of three psychiatric patients during last week's hot weather.

title: THE BROOKLYN BRIDGE
description: .8,2WEST TISBURY, Mass. - Tragedy and the Brooklyn Bridge are old companions. For all the magnificent service and lift to the soul that the majestic structure has been providing for nearly a century, its toll in human life has been high.

title: About Real Estate; UNITY SOUGHT BY TENANTS SIGNING A 'NO BUY' PLEDGE
description: ''Whereas,'' the document often begins, ''the tenants of such-andsuch have been presented with a preliminary proposal to convert the premises to cooperative ownership. ...''

title: EXCERPTS FROM EL SALVADOR SPEECH
description: Following are excerpts from a speech on El Salvador today by Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, to the World Affairs Council here:

title: STANDARD REGISTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REYNOLDS, R J, INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Business people; Japan's Big Board Debut
description: It isn't every day that a Japanese businessman makes history buying stock in an American car company. But at 10 A.M. today Yoshio Terasawa, president of Nomura Securities International Inc., will step down on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange to join the bidding as its first Japanese member. To commemorate the occasion he will buy 30,000 shares of the General Motors Corporation common stock on behalf of the Nomura Investment Trust Management Company, the world's biggest mutual fund.

title: UNION OF PILOTS WILL ACCEPT 2-MEMBER CREWS IN COCKPITS
description: The nation's largest pilots union has agreed to abide by the report of a White House task force that concluded that only two pilots were needed in the cockpit for safe operation of the new commercial jetliners.

title: MOBIL JOINS CONOCO QUEST WITH $3.92 BILLION BID
description: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company, yesterday joined the bidding war for Conoco Inc., the ninth-largest, with a bid of $90 a share in cash for 43.5 million shares, for a total of $3.92 billion.

title: GRACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
COMPUTER IS PRIMED FOR SWEET TRIUMPH
description: When young Jerry Silverman wasn't hustling chocolate egg creams at Larry's Luncheonette on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, he was prowling the perimeter of Yonkers Raceway, a few miles to the north, looking for a soft spot to sneak through the fence.

title: JERSEY PANEL RESCINDS KEY RULE ON BLACKJACK
description: The State Casino Control Commission, declaring a financial emergency in Atlantic City's casino industry, moved today to rescind a rule allowing blackjack players to back out of bets early if a hand looks bad.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
JOCKEY DIES OF INJURIES
description: The jockey Joe Blanks died in the Royal Sussex Hospital this morning from injuries he suffered in a fall last week. Blanks, 24 years old, had been in critical condition since falling from his mount during the last race July 8 at Brighton. He was trampled by a number of following horses and never regained consciousness.

title: VIACOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: POLISH CONGRESS VOTES FOR NEW CENTRAL COMMITTEE
description: The emergency congress of the Polish Communist Party was voting tonight on a list of 275 candidates for 200 seats on the Central Committee, but the main question of who will be party leader remained unsettled.

title: SOVIET ASKS ATOM-TEST TALKS
description: The Soviet Union called on the United States and Britain today to resume talks on extending the 18-year-old nuclear test-ban treaty to make it cover underground explosions. The Soviet Union and other Communist nations at the 40-nation Disarmament Conference said in a joint declaration that the talks should resume immediately.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $1.4 million special gain from the sale of shrs in a Japanese affiliate

title: CBS AND RCA SEEK NEW BROADCASTING: SATELLITE TO HOME
description: CBS Inc. and the RCA Corporation filed separate requests yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission to start services that would beam television programs from satellites directly to homes and apartments with small receiving antennas.

description: Quebec signed a contract here today to sell a 12-year, 8.6 percent bond issue of 20 billion yen, or about $100 million (United States), according to the Nomura Securities Company, lead manager for the public offering.

description: Helen Klintrup, a former vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency and retired executive director of the Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration Inc., died of cancer yesterday at the New York Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: The assets of the nation's money market funds grew by $3.5 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

description: The White House today sent Republican Congressional leaders the compromises it is recommending to a House-Senate conference that is considering more than $37 billion in budget cuts.

description: Raskin ,2WASHINGTON - Contrary to what President Reagan might think, he is hardly following the defense and foreign policies of virtually any conservative Republican leader of the 20th century.

description: Marvin Miller, the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players' Association, yesterday characterized credited service as ''the only issue I can think of that affects every single major league player.''

ARMS EXPORTER IS BELIEVED LINKED WITH ATTEMPT TO MURDER LIBYAN
description: Investigators looking into the attempted assassination of a Libyan student in Colorado last year say they have found evidence that links the man accused of the attack to a former agent for the Central Intelligence Agency. The former agent, Edwin P. Wilson, is a fugitive from charges that he illegally exported arms to Libya and trained terrorists there.

title: BRITAIN PLANS TO STUDY BASIC ROOTS OF UNREST
description: The British Government announced today that it would make an official study of ways to solve the problems of the inner cities that have led to almost two weeks of rioting.

title: For Children
description: ANIMALS, ART AND FUN, a program of art workshops with Stan Stein, Sundays at 11 A.M. Youngsters should bring sketch pad, pencils and crayons. The Long Island Game Farm and Zoo, Chapman Boulevvard, Manorville, L.I., exit 70 on the Long Island Expressway. Art program free; admission to the farm: 2 to 11 years old and the elderly, $2.90; others, $4.75. Workshop reservations: (516) xxx-7443.

HEARINGS ON BAIL BEGUN AT THE SITE OF JAIL DISORDER
description: Three State Supreme Court judges set up court today under the basketball hoops of the Westchester County Jail's gymnasium and heard dozens of inmates plead for reduced bail.

title: FULFILLMENT ELUDES SAUER, A FORMER JET
description: George Sauer Jr. had just lost his job as an assistant coach with the Carolina Chargers, a minor league football team that collapsed in a swirl of accusations, bad debts and player demands. ''I guess,'' Sauer said, laughing, ''this is just part of my personal unsuccess story at finding part-time jobs.''

title: BROOKE SHIELDS IN ZEFFIRELLI'S 'ENDLESS LOVE'
description: THERE are two sorts of people who'll be going to see ''Endless Love'' - those who have read the richly imaginative novel on which the movie is based and those who have not. There will be dismay in the first camp, but it may be nothing beside the bewilderment in the second.

title: BANCOKLAHOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HARRY CHAPIN, SINGER, KILLED IN CRASH
description: Harry Chapin, a folk-rock composer and performer active in many charitable causes, was killed yesterday when the car he was driving was hit from behind by a tractor-trailer on the Long Island Expressway in Jericho, L.I., the police said. He was 38 years old.

title: POLL SHOWS AMERICANS LOSING FAITH IN FUTURE OF SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM
description: A majority of the American people, 54 percent, no longer believe that the Social Security system will have the money available to pay them the full benefits they would be entitled to at retirement, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

description: chord songs have an immediate singalong appeal loaded with a broad ironic humor: they laugh at the rock-and-roll adventurism that they also celebrate. And on stage, Mr. Johansen delivers them with an exuberantly big-voiced sassiness.

FRIDAY, JULY 17, 1981; The Economy
description: Two Southern Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee indicated that the leadership was prepared to allow the House to add a third year of cuts in individual income tax rates to the two-year bill being drafted by the committee. But they set a condition: realization in 1982 of President Reagan's forecast of lower inflation and a smaller budget deficit. (Page A1.)

title: ZAMBIA DEFERS COURT ACTION ON AIDE LINKED TO THE C.I.A.
description: A Zambian Foreign Ministry official accused of spying for the United States was ordered today to remain in jail while prosecutors completed paper work for court proceedings, the official Zambia News Agency reported.

title: Around the World; I.R.A. MILITANTS DISCOUNT RED CROSS VISIT TO PRISON
description: Irish nationalist hunger strikers at Maze Prison near Belfast charged today that a Red Cross mission to the prison was a British ''pawn.'' They reiterated their call for direct negotiations with the British Government as the ''best way'' to find a solution.

description: The Ludlow Corporation, of Needham Heights, Mass., said it had received a merger proposal from Tyco Laboratories Inc. valued at about $75 million.

title: Notes On People; A Ford Son Joins Protest Against Nuclear Power
description: Steven Ford, a son of former President Gerald R. Ford, said yesterday that he was on the same side of the ''generation gap'' that separates President Reagan's daughter Patti Davis from her father on the issue of nuclear power reactors.

description: Secretary of State Haig's effort to put a more positive gloss on the Administration's views about strategic arms control is commendable and shows grace under pressure. But it is transparently flawed.

description: Civil rights activists are worried that progress in school desegregation will be slowed if President Reagan and Congress are successful in their current efforts against busing.

Brezhnev Talks With Karmal
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, held talks in the Crimea today with Babrak Karmal, head of the Sovietbacked regime in Afghanistan. The Tass press agency said Mr. Brezhnev had told Mr. Karmal that international tensions had ''considerably worsened recently'' because of actions by ''imperialistic circles, above all the U.S.A.''

title: Miss Caponi Shares L.P.G.A. Lead at 140

description: The proposed Tudor City land exchange between New York City and Harry B. Helmsley, the real-estate developer, could be in jeopardy because of new opposition within the Koch administration.

title: FLOOD WATERS RISE IN SOUTHEAST CHINA
description: Residents of a city in Sichuan Province need boats to cross a street after six days of rain. A major flood was reported in the Yangtze River valley, with the river at its highest level this century; four tributaries in Sichuan overflowed their banks. Casualties are unknown.

description: This was John Woodring's first day as a pro football player - or at least as a potential one. In company with 52 other rookies at the Jets' training camp, Woodring wandered around the team's sports complex in quiet fashion, feeling his way.

title: 3,500 Acres Burned in Idaho
description: A lightning-caused range fire blackened 3,500 acres of sagebrush in southern Idaho today as crews from the Bureau of Land Management fought to contain it. A bureau official said that the fire caused little property damage.

title: MUSTAFA MUHAMMAD IS READY
description: The last workout had ended, and Eddie Mustafa Muhammad had just wiped the perspiration from his forehead. He was back in the light-heavyweight division to defend his World Boxing Association championship tomorrow in a 15-round fight against undefeated Michael Spinks.

title: U.S. Raises Quota for Poles
description: The United States has increased its admission quota for Polish refugees crowding Austrian camps, Interior Minister Erwin Lanc said today. Mr. Lanc said the United States, reacting to an Austrian request, would admit 2,400 additional refugees from Eastern Europe. The usual American quota has been 4,500 a year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OFFBEAT

title: MEDFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENATE PANEL TO REVIEW CHARGES ON CHIEF OF C.I.A.
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee today ordered its staff to review charges of financial impropriety against William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Korvettes Wins Court Protection
description: Federal Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland approved a petition by Korvettes Inc. for court protection under Chapter 11 provisions of the bankruptcy laws.

title: AMERICAN MICROSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for 12wk to June 13
description: B-Net income including net income from discontinued operations $810,000 for the 12 weeks and $1,542,000 for the 24 weeks and $4,476,000 extraordinary gain for the 12 and 24 weeks on the extinguishment of debt

title: LABOR SECRETARY URGES TALKS IN CAPITAL MONDAY
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan met today with the chief negotiators for the baseball players and owners in a continuing effort to persuade them to reach a negotiated settlement of the 36-day-old strike.

title: 2 Aides Quit Over 'Style'
description: Two top officers at the National Semiconductor Corporation have resigned in a rift over management styles. The company is one of the world's largest manufacturers of computer components and systems.

title: BABY'S PRESENCE WAS KEPT SECRET BY HER MOTHER
description: The young woman who took her 15-month-old baby girl from New York Hospital last Sunday in violation of a Queens Family Court order kept the secret of that baby so well that neither her family nor her co-workers knew that she had been pregnant or had given birth.

title: 5 STATES TO REJECT CALIFORNIA PRODUCE
description: Beginning Monday, five Southern states will reject a broad range of California fruit and vegetables that have not been fumigated with a potent poison to kill the Mediterranean fruit fly, they said today. California agricultural officials, vowing that they would go to court to fight the action, said that the quarantine amounted to a ban on shipments to those states,

title: U.S. Leads Wightman By 2-0 Over Britain
description: In one of the more one-sided matches in Wightman Cup history, Andrea Jaeger defeated Anne Hobbs of Britain, 6-0, 6-0, in 42 minutes tonight and gave the United States a 2-0 lead in the four-of-seven-match competition.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Anadite Inc. said its board had authorized the purchase from time to time of up to $500,000 worth of the company's common shares.

title: Brother Albert Paul Gladhill, Taught at Manhattan College
description: Brother Albert Paul Gladhill, former executive vice president of Manhattan College, died Wednesday at his home in the Christian Brothers residence in the Bronx.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mason Aides Face Trial
description: Six assistant coaches to the former University of Arizona football coach Tony Mason will be prosecuted despite Mason's acquittal, Bob Corgin, the Attorney General, said today. Mason was found innocent yesterday by a Pima County Superior Court of 15 counts of theft, fraud and conspiracy.

title: Business-Debt Payments Slow
description: The promptness with which American business paid its bills slipped to an all-time low in the first quarter of this year as a result of high interest rates, according to a report issued yesterday by TRW Information Services, a division of TRW Inc.

title: FIRST OF MICHIGAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 10 per stock dividend declared Sept 25, 1980 The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange

title: AMERICAN MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SAYING IT WITH A LITTLE MORE THAN FLOWERS
description: In the past, things were relatively clear-cut. To buy flowers - a bunch of daisies, a dozen roses or or a clay container full of daffodils, for example -one went to the corner flower shop.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: I was there. In the afternoon of June 30, walking on Fifth Avenue across 51st Street, I heard shouts of ''Stop thief! Stop thief!'' A man in sneakers was darting between cars from the north side of the street to the south side.

title: IN SISTER CITIES OF EL PASO AND JUAREZ, 400 YEARS OF HISTORY ERASE A
description: BORDER By JOHN M. CREWDSON

ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Reflects $10.6 million reduction resulting from a change to LIFO accounting Year-ago results have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in November 1980 and a 50 percent stock dividend paid in March 1981

title: GANG FIGHTS TRANSFORM HOLLYWOOD BOULEVARD INTO A WAR ZONE
description: For the last two weekends, a special task force of more than 50 law officers has been trying to keep order on Hollywood Boulevard, the historic strip in the onetime capital of the movie industry. In the last six months, the boulevard has become a war zone. Mann's Chinese Theater, where stars like Marilyn Monroe and R2-D2 made imprints in wet cement, is now a territorial marker for gangs that have been warring among themselves.

title: Chemical Spill Pollutes Cuyahoga in Akron
description: Almost a billion gallons of pungent, bacteria-laced chemicals tinted 20 miles of the Cuyahoga River red today, impairing the operation of a waste treatment plant, officials said.

title: JUDGE O'CONNOR TALKS WITH POTENTIAL CRITICS
description: Senator John P. East, Republican of North Carolina, said today that he would wait and ''hear the evidence'' before making up his mind on Judge Sandra Day O'Connor's nomination as a Supreme Court Justice.

title: Pakistani Delegation Ends Talks at Pentagon
description: A military delegation from Pakistan ended five days of talks at the Pentagon today on weapons Pakistan plans to buy with $1.5 billion in aid being offered by the Reagan Administration.

title: FASCINATING CONOCO DRAMA
description: The multibillion-dollar poker game for the alluring oil and coal jewels at Conoco Inc. is drawing bigger and more attentive crowds in executive suites as the heady dealing enters its fourth week.

title: WESTERN MARINE ELECTRONICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rally at the Ranch
description: Loretta Lynn's 100-acre Tennessee Dude Ranch at Hurricane Mills was alive with the sound of motorcyles being revved up yesterday as 5,000 motorcyclists from several countries held their annual BMW rally.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We will not intentionally direct our fire against the civilian population.

title: AMALGAMATED SUGAR REFINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S., REACTING TO RAIDS, PUTS OFF ANNOUNCEMENT ON ISRAELI F-16'S
description: The Reagan Administration today postponed a planned announcement that the United States was resuming delivery of F-16 fighter-bombers to Israel.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
WELL TESTS GO ON, ESSO UNIT SAYS
description: Esso Resources Canada Ltd., a unit of Imperial Oil Ltd., denied published reports that its test well in the Beaufort Sea was flowing at a rate of 8,000 barrels a day.

title: Congen Bid Ended
description: Britain's National Coal Board pension fund, having been outbid for control of Connecticut General Mortgage and Realty Investments, said it had dropped its offer.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tuition Going Up In Jersey Colleges
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The New Jersey Board of Higher Education voted unanimously to increase tuition at state and county colleges in September.

title: HUNT, PHILIP A, CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $66,000 for the quarter and $123,000 for the 6 months...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $43,000 for the quarter and $108,000 for the 6 months Year-ago results have been restated t reflect the adoption of LIFO accounting

title: PIZZA TIME THEATRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Charge Called in Error Against Nicklaus's Son
description: An Ohio Highway Patrol lieutenant admitted in court yesterday that a trooper erred in charging Steven Nicklaus, a son of Jack Nicklaus, with drunken driving.

title: Fred R. Conrad Central Park Dairy Restored
description: Carpenters at work yesterday at the dairy, first built in 1869 as a place for children to come and play and buy ''perfectly fresh milk.'' The new dairy, off East 65th Street near the Zoo, will be used as a visitor information center, and for free concerts and lectures during the winter.

title: HOW 'PRINCE OF THE CITY' IS BEING 'PLATFORMED'
description: ''Prince of the City,'' a $10 million movie about corruption in the New York Police Department, will open Aug. 19 in New York in a highly unusual - if not unprecedented - way.

title: TO CATCH A MUGGER - AND ROUGH HIM UP
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Jacob Wolfowitz, Expert In Probability and Statistics
description: Dr. Jacob Wolfowitz, a teacher of and researcher in mathematical statistics and probability theory, died yesterday at University Community Hospital here.

title: A.M.C. Loss Narrows
description: The American Motors Corporation, the smallest of the major United States-based automobile manufacturers, today reported a loss of $19.9 million in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $88.1 million in the second quarter of 1980.

title: MANY IN SALVADOR DUBIOUS OF U.S. VOTE POLICY
description: Despite the Reagan Administration statement yesterday stressing the importance of free elections in El Salvador, there is skepticism in many quarters here that such elections are possible. And church leaders and some foreign diplomats here still feel that any solution to the conflict must include negotiations with the leftist guerrillas, a course that Washington continues to rule out.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Net
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation reported yesterday that its second-quarter net operating earnings, before securities transactions, declined 2 percent, to $55 million, or $1.63 a share, from $56.1 million, or $1.69 a share, in the comparable period of 1980.

title: 2 Long Shots Battle For Giants Spots
description: Teams in the National Football League do not usually seek recruits from such Division III colleges as Fordham and St. Peter's. But there are two such players in the Giants' camp at Pace University.

title: Datsun Name To Disappear
description: Nissan, the Japanese auto maker, confirmed that Datsun, a name it has patiently cultivated in the United States for the past 23 years at a cost estimated in the tens of millions of dollars, will be phased out in favor of the name Nissan.

title: STALEY, A E, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LEBANON ASSAILS ISRAEL AT U.N.
description: The Security Council met tonight in urgent session and heard Lebanon's deputy delegate charge that Israel's bombing of Beirut was a deliberate effort to torpedo ''serious peace moves'' in the stricken country.

title: Juan Carlos Peralejo Weds Assumpta Ahern, Student
description: Assumpta Maria Ahern, daughter of Richard I. Ahern of New York and the late Mrs. Ahern, was married yesterday to Juan Carlos Peralejo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Justo Peralejo of Madrid. The Rev. Kenneth Jadoff performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK (PALM BEACH COUNTY, FL reports earnings for Qtr to Jun
Judge Harold P. Burke Of U .S. District Court
description: Judge Harold P. Burke of United States District Court in Rochester, who served on the Federal bench for 44 years before his retirement a month ago, died yesterday at Rochester General Hospital. Judge Burke, who had been hospitalized a number of times since February when he suffered complications from the flu, was 86 years old.

title: 45 KILLED AT HOTEL IN KANSAS CITY, MO., AS WALKWAYS FALL
description: Two crowded ''sky bridges'' inside the lobby of the Hyatt Regency Hotel here collapsed tonight, killing at least 45 people and injuring about 145, according to the police and rescue workers.

title: TIBOR UDVARDY
description: Tibor Udvardy, a Hungarian tenor whose opera appearances ranged from New York to Moscow, died of a heart attack today.

title: Inflation Dips In Britain
description: Britain's annual inflation rate fell to 11.3 percent in June, the lowest level since May 1979, according to Government figures published today.

title: E.E.C. Seeks Cuts in Steel
description: The Commission of the European Economic Community asked the European steel industry today to voluntarily limit output of three products that are not subject to mandatory production quotas.

title: Gradual Sales Of Corn Set
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block assured corn producers today that sales of Government-owned corn would be done gradually so as not to disturb the regular markets.

title: DEBATES ON TAX CUTS DISPLAY CONABLE BEFORE A NATIONAL AUDIENCE
description: In the 35th Congressional District in upstate New York, Representative Barber B. Conable Jr. has earned a reputation as the author of newsletters on official Washington.

title: The Talk of Meriden
description: Twice in the last few months, Ku Klux Klansmen have marched on the streets of Meriden. And twice they have been set upon by demonstrators armed with golf clubs, baseball bats and rocks.

title: WIENERWALD'S U.S. CHALLENGE
description: Friedrich Jahn, an Austrian-born restaurateur, likes his eating places to have that Alpine flavor. Since getting into the business 25 years ago, he has built a chain of nearly 500 Wienerwald restaurants, marketing split roast chicken, french fries and salads served by dirndl-clad waitresses in rooms that feature rustic Alpine murals, hefty crocks of beer and artificial edelweiss on bare wooden tables.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL DIAMOND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $54,000 for the quarte and $62,740 for the 6 months

title: UNION METAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes gain from discontinued operations of $99,000 for the qr and $150,000 for the 6 mos

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Iran's Politics of Death
description: Iran's clerical rulers recently expelled Western reporters, charging that the press sought to discredit their regime. But what could be more defamatory than the official news reports that Iran disseminates every day?

title: LATE RALLY LIFTS PRICES ON STOCKS
description: A late rally lifted both stock market prices and volume yesterday after what had earlier promised to be a typically listless preweekend summer session. Instead, the buying spread beyond shares involved in the Conoco takeover drama, although Mobil Oil's formal entry into the bidding yesterday continued to focus attention on that battle.

title: HADRON INC reports earnings for Yr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to include three companies acquired and pooled during 1981

title: ATLANTAN IS INDICTED IN 2 SLAYINGS
description: Wayne B. Williams, a 23-year-old music promoter and talent scout, was indicted today on charges of murdering two of the 28 young black people slain here in the last two years.

title: FLAGSHIP TO WEIGH ROYAL TRUSTCO BID
description: Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami announced today that it had resumed negotiations with Royal Trustco Ltd. of Toronto, parent of Canada's largest trust company group, on its possible takeover by the Canadian company.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 18, 1981
description: International Beirut was bombed by Israeli jets, which also crippled three more bridges in southern Lebanon. The planes attacked a densely populated area of Beirut containing Palestinian guerrilla headquarters. Palestinian reports said 123 people had been killed and more than 550 wounded, mostly in Beirut. The United Nations Security Council met at Lebanon's request to deal with the increasing Israeli attacks. (Page 1, Column 6.) Lebanese civilians will not be spared in Israeli's widening attacks on Palestinian installations in Lebanon, Prime Minister Menachem Begin announced as Israeli planes bombed Beirut. His warning was intended to press Lebanese authorities to curb Palestinian military operations against Israeli from Lebanon. (1:3.)

title: NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALBANY'S DELAY ON NEW BUDGET IS CALLED COSTLY
description: The 42-day delay in enacting a New York State budget earlier this year cost the state and its local governments $36.2 million, the state's Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said today.

title: U.S. Ships Save Greek Crew
description: Two American warships rescued 39 people from a Greek tanker that caught fire in the Arabian Sea, a United States Embassy spokesman said today. There were no reported casualties among the crew of the tanker, the Irene Sincerity.

description: B-Including income from discontinued operations $3,000 for the quarter and $71,000 for the 6 months Year-ago results have been restated

description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect 50 percen stock distributions paid in 1980 and 1981

title: POLISH CONGRESS, IN SECRET BALLOT, BACKS CENTRISTS
description: Voting for the first time by secret ballot, delegates to the emergency congress of the Polish Communist Party elected a new Central Committee today, sending some of the most prominent figures in the leadership down to defeat.

title: WARNING BY BEGIN BEIRUT AND SOUTH LEBANON
description: As Israeli planes struck at Beirut today, further widening the war against Palestinian guerrillas, Prime Minister Menachem Begin announced that the guerrillas could no longer expect to hide amid civilian populations in Lebanon.

title: FIRST LINCOLN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MOUNTAIN BANKS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After $18.8 million loss from Transamerica's United Artists Corp unit which is considered a discontinued operation

title: MERCURY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SERVICEMEN HONORED
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger attends Pentagon ceremony honoring former prisoners of war and those missing in action. With him are Vice Adm. William P. Lawrence, left, Naval Academy's head, and Col. Don Phillips, commander of the 3d U.S. Infantry.

title: TRYING GOOD SIMPLE DISHES, NOT PRETENTIOUS ONES
description: When meals are being prepared on a limited budget, it would seem that the most obvious common sense solution would be to concentrate on excellent preparations of good, honest foods that are relatively inexpensive. Instead, too many home cooks and restaurant chefs apparently feel compelled to offer second- and third-rate examples of foods that are expensive to buy or costly to prepare, with results that inevitably are depressing, if not downright disastrous.

title: PRESERVING MANHATTAN'S ARCHITECTURAL HERITAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: 'TRACK,' VEHICLE FOR MIDDLE-AGED CHILD STAR
description: Gary Coleman, of television's ''Diff'rent Strokes,'' could be described as a child star if he were even the least bit like a child. But he isn't. Mr. Coleman is a pint-sized fellow who has somehow managed to reach middle age before puberty, and who couldn't possibly get away with his intense mugging if he weren't so tiny. ''On the Right Track'' is a vehicle for Mr. Coleman that depends entirely on the premise that he is lovable. Only his most ardent television fans are likely to accept this.

title: ALCATEL PLANS IN U.S.
description: Alcatel Electronique S.A., a unit of the French computer maker Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, is negotiating to buy an American computer company for about $100 million, company sources said today. They declined to identify the concern.

title: Lasers From Satellites A Link to Submarines
description: A Boston patent attorney was granted a patent on an invention of his own this week. Charles E. Pfund received patent 4,279,036 for a method of satellite communication with submarines by laser beams. He applied for it in 1962, but issuance was delayed by the National Security Agency.

title: NORTHWEST NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TAX ABATEMENTS HERE
description: .8,0,174.8,2,478.4,0The partial-tax-abatement program of the New York Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board has helped generate more than $1.8 billion in construction activity in the city's five boroughs. The 336 approved projects, when completed, will retain or create more than 86,000 jobs.

title: HLH PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Yr to March 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $7,200 for the latest year and $40,000 for the previous year

title: U.S. Warned on Tour by Rugby Team
description: Admitting the South African national rugby team to the United States for a series of matches later this year could lead to serious political problems for American officials planning the 1984 Los Angeles Summer Olympics, the president of the International Olympic Committee said yesterday.

title: COUNTRY-ROCK: JIMMY BUFFETT
description: A large auditorium is not the ideal setting for a singersongwriter, especially one like Jimmy Buffett, whose talent for anecdotal lyrics outweighs a singing voice that is offhanded and guitar-playing that is merely functional. But at Radio City Music Hall, where he performed Thursday with his country-rock sextet, the Choral Reefer Band, Mr. Buffett did a creditable job of projecting an intimate club atmosphere in a large space.

title: Litco Stockholders Approve Its Sale
description: Stockholders of Litco Bancorporation, holding company of the Long Island Trust Company, have overwhelmingly approved a previously announced proposal by Banca Commerciale Italiana to acquire all Litco's outstanding shares for at least $35 a share. The transaction is worth more than $93 million to Litco stockholders.

title: Oak Ridge, Tenn., Sued Over Housing Project
description: The local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, supported by other citizens' groups, filed suit today accusing the city of Oak Ridge of racism for rejecting a $3.9 million Federal grant designated for a low-income housing project.

title: Man Charged With 2 Murders May Be Suspect in 12 Others
description: A Brooklyn man charged here with two murders may have committed as many as 12 others in at least five states since 1979, the police said today.

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Curl Posts 2d 65 in Row To Retain Lead in Golf
description: Rod Curl matched the lowest 36-hole total on the PGA Tour this season, shooting a second straight five-under-par 65 today for the second-round lead in the $200,000 Quad Cities Open.

title: Water Is Flowing To Newark Again
description: With a major pipeline installation completed here, water flowed without incident yesterday through Newark's Pequannock aqueduct for the first time since vandals destroyed an 825-foot section of it on July 7.

title: ART AND MUSIC NOTATION COMBINE AT JAPAN HOUSE
description: Musical notation is first of all a functional system - a way of telling musicians what and how to play. But from the first, as with the writing and printing of words, there has been a graphic, visually artistic side to notation. Anyone who follows or reads a score knows that notation mirrors the curves and lines of sound, and that the synchronism can itself be esthetically pleasing.

title: MASSMUTUAL CORPORATE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Benjamin Spiegel, 65; Administrative Judge
description: Benjamin Spiegel, a senior administrative law judge with New York City's Department of Environmental Protection, died last Sunday at the Flushing Hospital and Medical Center in Queens. He was 65 years old and lived in Flushing.

title: No Headline
description: The third-place consolation game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament was ordered discontinued today but the tournament field, at least for the present, will remain at 48 teams.

title: TV Issue Dividing N.C.A.A.
description: The possibility of a split within the National Collegiate Athletic Association grew stronger yesterday when the College Football Association's board of directors presented two of the three major networks with its proposal for a major college football television contract.

title: 76-Pound Bass Caught
description: A 76-pound striped bass, the largest known to have been caught on rod and reel, was taken off Montauk a few hours before dawn today by Robert Rocchetta of Setauket, L.I. Rocchetta, fishing from his 24-foot Rainbow II about a mile and a half east of Montauk Point, was using 40-pound test line and a live eel as bait.

title: A TALK WITH MR. JAVITS
description: The light is fading into hazy yellow on this summer evening. Inside the grand East 57th Street duplex, ''The Senator'' sits in quiet, his cane on the arm of his chair, as his wife shows a visitor in. He is bent and withered from the nerve and muscle disease that has afflicted him. One is tempted to think that like the day, Jacob K. Javits is fading too.

title: NEW YORK CENTERS TO HOUSE HAITIANS
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that 86 Haitians would be transferred tomorrow from Florida to a detention camp in Brooklyn and that 50 would be sent on Sunday to a Federal correctional facility in Lake Placid.

title: U.S. STATEMENT ON AIR STRIKES
description: Following is the text of a statement released today by the State Department regarding Israeli air strikes in Lebanon:

title: DR. LEE MORRISON
description: Dr. Lee Morrison, professor of communications at the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, L.I., died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 64 years old and lived in Patchogue, L.I.

title: ABC'S OF SAFE DRIVING
description: D RIVING defensively may simply mean leaving home early so you don't have to speed to work. But there are also on-the-road strategies - eight hours of them if you take the $25 National Safety Council course.

Carey Signs Boxing Bill
description: Governor Carey signed a bill today to strengthen state regulation of boxing safety.

title: Inland Reports Gain in Quarter
description: The Inland Steel Company said today that it earned $29.5 million, or $1.40 common share, in the second quarter of 1981, after a loss of $22.4 million in the second quarter last year.

title: THE SON OF A BAVARIAN BRICKLAYER
description: IN golf, a new name emerges almost every week. At the British Open, a new name to remember is Bernhard Langer of West Germany, who at 140 is only two strokes behind the leader, Bob Rogers, halfway through the tournament. After he shot three-under-par 67 yesterday, the interrogation was also an introduction to Bernhard Langer, a 23-year-old Bavarian bricklayer's son with curly blond hair and a mustache so blond it's almost invisible.

title: Cattleman and Reporters End Their Four-Year Libel Dispute
description: A lawsuit filed by a millionaire Arizona cattleman against Investigative Reporters and Editors, Inc., was dismissed today when the two parties agreed to drop the litigation.

title: DEMOCRATS MOVING TO RESTORE SOCIAL SECURITY CUT
description: House Democratic leaders today moved to continue the Social Security minimum benefit of $122 a month, which was eliminated in both the House and Senate versions of a $37 billion package of budget cuts for the fiscal year 1982.

title: SIAMESE TWIN CASE DISMISSED
description: A judge today dismissed charges that a family doctor and parents of severely deformed twin boys born joined at the waist tried to starve the infants to death, the prosecutor said.

title: TRANSOHIO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SNAG DEVELOPS IN SHIFT OF IRAN FUNDS
description: Disagreements between Iranian and American negotiators meeting secretly in the Netherlands are likely to stall transfer by the United States of more than $2 billion in once-frozen Iranian bank deposits and have aroused concern among American companies with claims against Iran.

title: SOUTHERN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.N. COUNCIL MEETS BEIRUT AND SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israeli jets today bombed a densely populated area of Beirut containing Palestinian guerrilla headquarters and, in wide raids in southern Lebanon, knocked out three more bridges. Palestinian reports said the raids had left at least 123 dead and more than 550 wounded, most of them in the Lebanese capital.

title: Dance Star Afflicted by Broadway Malady
description: Switching from the world of what she calls ''serious dance'' to being a star of the Broadway musical ''Sophisticated Ladies'' has been an experience filled with trauma, according to Judith Jamison.

Jersey Parkway Workers Vote To Reject Accord on Contract
description: A two-week strike by toll takers and maintenance workers on the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey continued as union members overwhelmingly turned down a tentative agreement yesterday.

title: THE AGES OF PERSON
description: Difficult questions about age fill the mail this week. Mr. C.S. of Chester, Pa., for example, writes that since the 1930's the Supreme Court has often been re-ferred to as ''nine old men'' and asks:

title: MEXICO NOW A FAVOR GOVERNMENT OIL BUYERS
description: Faced with reluctance by oil companies in the United States and elsewhere to purchase higher-priced Mexican crude, President Jose Lopez Portillo said today that the Mexican Government would now prefer dealing with other governments instead of with private companies.

WHAT READING IS FOR

title: THE M.T.A. RESTORES MOST OF CUTS ORDERED IN RUNNING SUBWAYS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority relented yesterday on most of $7.5 million in spending cuts it had demanded in subway operations.
