Panel Cites Progress At Three Mile Island
description: A Federal advisory committee has reported that the undamaged reactor at Three Mile Island, next to the one that was crippled in the 1979 accident, can be restarted ''without undue risk to the health and safety of the public.''

title: EVANS PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rogers Leads Open by a Shot
description: One day after he shot an 83, his worst round as a pro golfer, Jack Nicklaus shot a four-under-par 66 at Royal St. George's today. But so did Bill Rogers, and because Rogers had a 72 yesterday, he held a one-stroke lead with 138 after 36 holes of the British Open championship.

title: Y to Screen 25 Films on Jewish Life
description: The Jewish Film Festival, with more than 25 recent films on Jewish life, will take place at the 92d Street Y Sept. 9 to 15, except for Sept. 14, when the festival will move for the day to the Jewish Museum.

title: Canada Prices Up by 12.8 %
description: Canadian consumer prices in June rose 12.8 percent above prices in June 1980, surpassing the previous record increase of 12.6 percent in April, Statistics Canada reported today.

title: PERKIN-ELMER'S BIG GROWTH STARTED WITH A SMALL RESEARCH CONTRACT
description: In the late 1960's, the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, then a manufacturer of analytical instruments and optical components for the Government, began work on a small research contract for the Air Force.

title: HOUSING STARTS OFF 11% IN JUNE
description: Housing starts declined 11 percent in June from the May level to the lowest annual rate since the bottom of last year's recession, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: NEW ENGLAND MERCHANTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said first-half results were aided by an after-tax gain of $5.3 million, or $1.68 from the sale of two DC-9 aircra in the first quarter

title: Judge Bars Move To Block Westway
description: Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan denied a request for an injunction to stop the acquisition of land for the Westway project.

title: Japan May Aid Refiners
description: Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry is studying aid for domestic oil refiners facing difficulties because of slow demand and exchange losses arising from the yen's depreciation against the dollar, ministry officials said today. The moves are expected to include raising the ceiling prices of oil products, continuing a 15 percent curtailment in refining, and purchases of crude oil and products by the Japan National Oil Corporation for a national stockpile, they said.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The men who build New York by hand sat in the sun on the 27th floor and ate clams and drank beer. The big steel beams on which they sat grew warm, and so did they. They took off their shirts, opened the clams with pocketknives and talked.

title: ARREST IN SPY CASE IS LINKED TO TRAILING OF SOVIET BY F.B.I.
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation stumbled on Joseph George Helmich last August when a Soviet K.G.B. agent whom they were trailing met the former Army warrant officer to discuss a final payment for military coding secrets supplied in 1963 and 1964, according to American intelligence sources.

title: SOUTHERN PACIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Auto Pollution Curbs Survive a House Vote
description: The House narrowly rejected a move today to suspend a requirement that certain states adopt annual auto pollution inspection programs.

title: TWO COURTS IN NEED OF ADDED SESSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Kite String Kills Boy in Brazil
description: A 4-year-old boy died here when his throat was cut by a kite string that was covered with broken glass, a local hospital said today.

title: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Man Fleeing Mob Was Electrocuted
description: The Medical Examiner's office said yesterdat that Gerard Coury, the Connecticut man who was stripped by a mob and chased into the subway at Times Square on June 27, apparently died of electrocution when he touched the third rail.

title: REAGAN RELUCTANTLY ACCEPTS TYING TAX RATES TO INFLATION
description: The Reagan Administration would reluctantly accept as part of the 1981 tax-relief bill an initiative to create automatic adjustments of the income tax to offset inflation, starting in 1985, a spokesman for Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today.

title: INDUSTRIAL VALLEY BANK & TRUST CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30
description: B-After securities gains of $4,000 loss from disocntinued operations of $456,000 and tax credit of $424,000 C-Net loss after securities losses of $10.3 million and loss fr discontinued operations of $50,000 n year-ago quarter The 1980 six months loss after securities losses of $10.3 million and loss from discontinued operations of $13,000 D-After securities losses of $201,000 loss from discontinued operations of $481,000 and a tax credit of $721,000

title: LITTLE PROGRESS IN POSTAL TALKS
description: The United States Postal Service and two major postal unions bargained all day today in the presence of three Federal mediators, but little progress was reported in the negotiators' efforts to reach agreement on a new contract before Monday night.

title: ESSEX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KINDER-CARE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: Share earings have been restated for a 5-for-4 stock split paid December 1980

title: HALF OF MINORITIES DROP FROM CLASS FOR STATE POLICE
description: One hundred forty-three men and women graduated today from the New York State Police Academy, but missing from their ranks were half of the black and Hispanic recruits who entered the 22-week training course in February.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Preparing Organisms To Make Amino Acids
description: A team of 14 Soviet inventors received a patent this week for a method of preparing microorganisms that produce amino acids, which are used in the agricultural, food, chemical and pharmaceutical industries.

title: PEERLESS TUBE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Patents; New Radio Pinpoints Crash Sites
description: WASHINGTON A NEW survival radio for pilots whose planes have been forced down in inhospitable terrain will guide a rescue craft to within 14 feet of a crash victim. The ranging system has been invented by Edward J. Nossen, an engineer in the RCA Government Systems division at Camden, N.J.

title: ABC Seeks to Bar New Satellite TV
description: The American Broadcasting Companies asked the Federal Communications Commission to block the introduction of direct broadcast satellite systems, which would transmit programming from satellites directly to consumers' homes.

title: PRESIDENT AND TOP AIDE RESIGN A.& P. POSITIONS
description: David W. Morrow, the president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, and Allan A. Feder, its senior executive vice president, resigned yesterday from the loss-ridden supermarket chain.

title: Pardee Leaving New York Fed
description: Scott E. Pardee, a senior vice president at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York who was in charge of foreign exchange operations, has resigned effective Aug. 31, a bank spokesman said yesterday.

title: RULES TO AID HANDICAPPED OFF
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis today rescinded rules requiring recipients of Federal mass transit funds to build wheelchair lifts into all new buses and to install elevators in existing rapid rail systems.

title: IN LIVERPOOL, MANY BLAME THE POLICE, NOT POVERTY CONDITIONS, FOR UNREST
description: Eleven days after the burning and rioting began, acrid puffs still drift over the racially mixed Toxteth district. Bulldozers are leveling the rubble of about three dozen shops.

title: Kid Creole in the Park
description: A free performance of music and theater will be given Monday at 8:30 P.M. by Kid Creole and the Coconuts at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Delacorte Theater in Central Park, near Central Park West and 81st Street. Led by August Darnell, the group is an outgrowth of Dr. Buzzard's Original Savannah Band, a Latin disco band also headed by Mr. Darnell. Seats will be available at 6:15 P.M. Call 535-5630.

title: INLAND STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Your Money; A Small-Scale Oil Investment
description: FOR the small investor, it has been difficult to get a slice of the activity in oil and gas deals. Big investors, those with large tax shelter needs and at least $5,000 to spare, could participate in limited oil drilling partnerships. At best, these partnerships promised big returns. At worst, they created tax, or even actual dollar, losses. But traditionally, oil action for small investors has been limited to buying shares in publicly held companies.

title: CON EDISON ASKS FOR $81 MILLION GAS RATE RISE
description: The Consolidated Edison Company applied to the New York State Public Service Commission yesterday for an $81.4 million increase next year in its rates for the use of natural gas.

title: Roof of Arena in Kansas City Collapsed About 2 Years Ago
description: The collapse of the walkways today at the Hyatt Regency Hotel was the second such incident involving a major structure here in just over two years.

title: IN PARTS OF AFRICA, ANCESTRAL SPIRITS GUIDE THE LIVING
description: In the language of the people who live there, the village's name is said to mean ''a place of death.'' Recently it lived up to its reputation.

title: No Headline
description: House-Senate conferees assigned to Postal Service issues in the budget for the fiscal year 1982 have agreed to delay the nine-digit ZIP code until at least Oct. 1, 1983, Senator David Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, said today.

title: OLD STONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DeLaurentiis's Son Killed
description: The only son of Dino DeLaurentiis, the movie producer, was killed Wednesday in a collision between a small plane and another aircraft about 300 miles southwest of here, officials said. Federico DeLaurentiis, 25, was the only passenger in a Cessna 185 flown by Sumner Putman, 36, of Anchorage, who was also killed. The pilot of the other plane was also killed. Mr. DeLaurentiis was in Alaska to make a film about salmon, according to an executive of the Dino DeLaurentiis Corporation.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: 1980 shr earnings reflect 10 percent stock divd paid Feb 1981

title: NEESKENS PUT BACK ON COSMOS' ROSTER
description: In a sudden reversal in policy, Coach Hennes Weisweiler of the Cosmos reinstated Johan Neeskens as an active player yesterday. The action was taken after a meeting in the Cosmos' headquarters in midtown Manhattan that included the coach; Neeskens, the 29-yearold midfielder from the Netherlands; Krikor Yepremian, general manager of the Cosmos, and Mike Diamond, Neeskens' attorney and agent.

title: A Race for Presidency Is Ruled Out by Carey
description: Governor Carey today ruled out a race for the Presidency, telling a news conference that his statement applied ''forever and thereafter.''

title: UNIMAX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Includes $900 gain from discontinued operations and $238,000 extraordinary gain for the qr and $17,300 gain from discontinued operations and $575,000 extraordinary gain for the 6 mos...C-Includes $200,000 extraordinary gain for the qr and $619,000 loss from discontinued operations and $1,124,100 extraordinary gain for the 6 mos

title: ACME-CLEVELAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pavarotti Gets the Chance to Return a Favor
description: When he was in Italy to hire artists for the 1965 season of the Greater Miami Opera Association, of which he has been artistic director for 30 years, Emerson Buckley heard a relatively unknown tenor from Modena who impressed him greatly.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
A SCHOLARLY DETECTIVE SOLVES A LITERARY PUZZLE
description: One of the mysteries of 19th-century literature has been solved - specifically, the identification of the ''Marguerite'' in Matthew Arnold's early poems and love life and similar momentous attitudes of Victoriana that have long tantalized scholars. The answer came after an international search through unpublished journals, diaries and letters tracked down in archives from Birmingham to Newcastle, from New Haven to Wellington, New Zealand.

title: RULES PANEL PASSES RESOLUTION TO ALLOW SENATE TV COVERAGE
description: The Senate Rules Committee tiptoed a step closer to the electronic age today by approving a resolution that would permit televising of Senate floor proceedings.

title: Pilots Seek New Airline
description: A group of Scandinavian Airlines System pilots has proposed an employee-owned airline to fly not-so-lucrative secondary routes in Scandinavia, an S.A.S. spokesman said today. The proposal to form Airdanmark, which would charter its planes to S.A.S., was also seen as a possible solution to the airline's estimated surplus of about 100 pilots. Airdanmark would be a combined Danish corporation and limited partnership with starting capital of $10 million, the proposal said.

title: Motorola Planning Buildup in Japan
description: Motorola Inc. said it would increase its operations in Japan and named Stephen L. Levy to the new post of senior vice president, Japanese operations. William J. Weisz, vice chairman and chief operating officer, said the appointment of a senior executive who would have line management responsibility for all of Motorola's activities in Japan was part of the corporation's plan for further serving the Japanese market, the world's secondlargest electronics market. The plan also includes a proposed consolidated company, Nippon Motorola Ltd., that will result from the merging of Motorola's existing companies in Japan.

title: The Public Housing Wrecking Crew
description: When it comes to housing, Congress is way ahead of the White House with the budget ax. So far, the Senate and House have passed housing bills that would reduce total assistance by about a third, or $10 billion, from President Carter's last budget. The cuts betray a profound lack of attention to reality.

title: ISRAEL'S CULTURAL MIX
description: To the Editor:

title: EDWARD R. DELEHANTY
description: Edward R. Delehanty, New York State commander of the American Legion in 1967, died Thursday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Albany. Mr. Delehanty, who was a resident of Albany, was 74 years old.

title: FIRST BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Police in Terre Haute Reject Amnesty Offer
description: More than 100 police officers rejected an offer of partial amnesty in exchange for going back to work and remained off the job for the third straight day today.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 32.

title: THE ARTS ARE IN ECONOMIC TROUBLE. SO, WHO NEEDS THEM? THE NATION.
description: During most of the 20th century, the state of literature and the fine arts in America has not caused undue worry. Artistic endeavor flowed exuberantly along on the tide of economic expansion.

title: AFTER MONTHS MARKED BY DISCORD, MADRID PARLEY SOUNDS OPTIMISTIC
description: After nine months of public wrangling and painstaking private negotiations, the 35-nation Madrid conference on security and cooperation in Europe has reached a decisive crossroads.

title: Knight-Ridder Aide
description: W.H. Harwell Jr., president and publisher of The Tallahassee (Fla.) Democrat, has been named vice president for operations of the city group of Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc., which is based here. He will be responsible for the operation of company's 17-city group of small- and medium-sized newspapers. Mr. Harwell, 51 years old, will also join Knight-Ridder's operating committee and will move to the company's Miami headquarters.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS FORMS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Net loss...C-Includes $549,000 gain from the sale of Dataroyal Inc stock

title: JAPAN'S BUSINESS SECRET
description: THEORY Z. How American Business Can Meet the Japanese Challenge. By William G. Ouchi. 283 pages. Addison-Wesley. $12.95. THE ART OF JAPANESE MANAGEMENT. By Richard Tanner Pascale and Anthony G. Athos. 221 pages. Simon & Schuster. $11.95.

title: STA-RITE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONSANTO NET SURGES IN QUARTER
description: The Monsanto Company, a diversified chemical producer, reported yesterday that it had sharply higher earnings and sales for the second quarter compared with the same period a year ago. Net income quadrupled, to $93.8 million, or $2.32 a share on a diluted basis, compared with $23.2 million, or 64 cents a share, also on a diluted basis.

title: MONEY SUPPLY RISES BY A SHARP $6.9 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a $6.9 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply, startling the credit markets, where a rise of $2 billion to $3 billion had been widely expected.

title: BRITONS SAY NEW PARTY'S SUCCESS MAY SIGNAL BIG SHIFT
description: The Social Democratic Party, barely four months old, came within an ace last night of winning a by-election in a constituency where the Labor Party has reigned supreme since World War II.

title: Bank Robber, 10, Gets Probation
description: A 10-year-old boy who surrendered last February in the robbery of a mid-Manhattan bank was placed on a modified probationary period by Judge Peggy C. Davis in Family Court.

title: A SETBACK FOR U.S.
description: The Israeli air strikes in Beirut today disrupted the Reagan Administration's plans for what it hoped would be the most intensive and productive several weeks of Middle

title: QUALITY CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After $2,775,174 loss from cumulative effect of change on method of accounting

title: U.S. ADVISES TOTAL ABSTINENCE FROM DRINKING FOR PREGNANT WOMEN
description: Pregnant women should drink absolutely no alcohol because they may be endangering the health of their unborn children, the Surgeon General's office has officially advised doctors in the United States.

title: BANK SOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXPERTS FIND THEMSELVES VICTIMS OF LESSER PLAYERS
description: The gods of bridge like to remind their subjects now and then of their own existence. Experts riding high find themselves losing to teams that on paper are vastly inferior, and know that the gods are laughing.

title: GOLDEN WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONQUERED WINS MILLION-DOLLAR PACE
description: From 10th place midway through the stretch, Conquered staged a stirring rally on the outside and scored a half-length victory tonight in the Meadowlands Pace.

title: BURROUGHS PLANS A PALNT IN JAPAN
description: The Burroughs Corporation, a Detroit-based computer concern, plans to build a computer assembly plant in Japan in 1982, the Japanese news agency Kyodo reported.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Until cyclists are given due space in the traffic system, accidents and traffic violations will continue to plague cyclists and pedestrians.

title: Soviet Again Sells Gold
description: The Soviet Union has resumed small sales of gold after withholding the metal from the market for several weeks, two senior dealers said here today. They emphasized, however, that an exact assessment of Soviet activity was impossible.

title: C.A.B. JUDGE TO ALLOW BID BY TEXAS AIRLINES
description: Texas International Airlines won a round today in its battle to take over Continental Air Lines when a Civil Aeronautics Board law judge gave preliminary approval to Texas International's offer.

title: Soviet Lifts Citizenship Of a Satirical Writer
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it had lifted the citizenship of Vladimir Voinovich, a 49-year-old satirical writer who emigrated to West Germany in December after years of conflict with Soviet authorities.

title: MOBIL SAYS ITS BID MEETS U.S. CRITERIA
description: The Mobil Corporation, anticipating a major antitrust investigation of its $7.7 billion offer to buy Conoco Inc., yesterday vigorously defended its bold takeover move for the nation's ninth-largest oil company as one that ''meets existing merger guidelines of the Department of Justice.''

title: Chapin Lacked Valid Auto License
description: Harry Chapin, the folk-rock composer and performer, was driving without a valid license when he was killed Thursday on the Long Island Expressway, officials said. The police said Mr. Chapin's car was hit from behind by a tractor-trailer when the singer's car shifted lanes.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: PROVIDENT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NORANDA MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds; the company is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: Search Intensifies For S.I. Girl, 7
description: A 7-year-old girl missing from her home in Port Richmond, S.I., since Wednesday evening was the subject of a wide search by the police and neighborhood residents.

title: F.B.I. ENTERS MISSOURI SHOOTING CASE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it would enter the investigation into the death of Kenneth Rex McElroy, who was shot July 10 as a crowd gathered around his pickup truck in the town of Skidmore.

title: LANGUAGE OF FRIENDSHIP
description: An American woman who was born in Dusseldorf, West Germany, stood on the sidelines of a soccer match today, waving a Taiwanese flag.

title: KENNEDY RESIDENTIAL AREAS TROUBLED BY ENCROACHING AIR CARGO CONCERNS
description: Seventeen years ago James Lewis bought a house in Springfield Gardens, Queens, well aware of the consequences of living within earshot of Kennedy International Airport.

title: Chief of Yugoslav Region Is Out in Apparent Purge
description: The President of Yugoslavia's Autonomous Province of Kosovo stepped down today in an apparent purge linked to riots by ethnic Albanians in the region in March and April.

title: 46% Don't Miss Baseball, Poll Says
description: Asked how much they have missed baseball during the five-week-old strike, almost half the Americans sampled said not at all, according to the latest Associated Press-NBC News poll. The sampling also revealed that support for the owenrs and players is divided, and that the strike has tarnished the game's image for nearly half the respondents.

title: The Economy
description: The Reagan Administration would reluctantly accept in the tax bill an initiative by Congressional Republicans to create automatic adjustments of income tax to offset inflation, starting in 1985, according to a spokesman for Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. It is doubtful, however, if the House would adopt such a plan. (Page 1.) In a House-Senate conference on budget cuts, Democrats moved to restore the Social Security minimum benefit of $122 a month. (8.)

title: Mayor Koch Adopts the Foster Kids
description: Mayor Koch ought to be taken at his word on foster care. He says he, too, is unhappy about New York City's sprawling, inadequate and costly system. But he says he needs more time to fix it up. When, then, will he say enough is enough?

title: China Moves to Curb Widespread Bribery
description: The Chinese Government acknowledged today that a widespread ''de facto bribery system'' exists here and said that the State Council, or Cabinet, issued orders on Wednesday to curb it.

title: MONSANTO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DISASTER BEGAN WITH A 'BIG SNAP, LIKE LIGHTNING IN YOUR BACKYARD'
description: It began suddenly, with a terrible, sharp sound that cut through the pleasant tunes being played at a regular Friday night dance.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Asarco Inc. completed the previously announced sale of 2.5 million shares of its common stock to M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an Australian corporation, at $56.50 a share, for a total price of $141,250,000.

title: U.S. MOVES TO INCREASE COAL SALES
description: The Reagan Administration will relax stripmining rules, accelerate the deasing of Federal lands and promote dredging of harbors and rivers as part of a program to stimulate exports of United States coal, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige announced today.

title: Member of the Wedding
description: ''The proudest and most excited man on the entire island of Eleuthra'' in the Bahamas is Henry Sands, caretaker of a villa owned by Lady Patricia Braebourne, daughter of the late Earl Mountbatten of Burma.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Shr earnings adjusted for a 4 percent stock divd paid in May 1981

title: TO CATCH A MUGGER - AND ROUGH HIM UP
description: To the Editor:

title: NANCIE E. CARAWAY MARRIED TO NEIL ABERCROMBIE
description: Nancie Ellen Caraway of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Caraway of Houston, was married in Palm Springs, Calif., yesterday to Neil Abercrombie of Honolulu, a Democratic State Senator in Hawaii. The Rev. Clifford Campbell of the Palm Springs Community Church performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Don Abercrombie, mother of the bridegroom.

title: Music View; WILL TECHNOLOGY BE THE DEATH OF 'GOLDEN-AGE' LEGENDS?
description: Music critics in the year 2981, should the breed survive that long, will have no dearth of material on hand should they wish to make an intensive study of late 20th-century performance practice. In fact, the recorded evidence of how we make music in concert halls and opera houses today is already so vast, that we are dangerously on the verge of drowning in an excess of information. Not only that, the obsessively thorough phonographic documentation of all musicians, major and minor figures alike, may well eventually undermine the very stuff from which musical legends are made.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY--'I AM 58--AND FURIOUS'
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Business Editor:

title: THE EXPLOITS OF EL SID
description: THE LAST LAUGH By S.J. Perelman. Introduction by Paul Theroux. 192 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $12.95.

title: THE BIGGEST OMNIBUS ISSUE OF THE YEAR
description: A royal romance has set the world agog and the result is an outpouring of commemoratives celebrating next week's wedding of Prince Charles, heir to the throne of Britain, to Lady Diana Spencer. To be held in St Paul's Cathedral, and dubbed "the wedding of the century," the event has produced one of the biggest omnibus issues of the year.

title: Westchester Guide; 'ALL'S WELL' AT CROTON
description: Over the last two decades, the Croton Shakespeare Festival has presented two dozen of the bard's plays and several non-Shakespearean dramas, comedies and musicals during its two-week summer season. This year's festival opens at 8 P.M. Thursday with a production of ''All's Well That Ends Well.''

title: Carol Martin Byler Married
description: Carol Martin Byler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Harpel Byler of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Stephen Russell Martyn, son of Mrs. Louis Martyn of London and the late Mr. Martyn. The Rev. Lawrence M. Horton, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Samuel Silver of Clearwater, Fla., performed the ceremony. The bride is president of the exporting concern of S.R.M. International Ltd. in Rowayton, Conn. Mr. Martyn is managing director of Bloomcastle Ltd., a dress manufacturing company in London.

title: ABOUT THOSE OCT. 1 RENT GUIDELINES
description: The Rent Guidelines Board this month approved a new set of rent guidelines for leases taking effect during the year that starts Oct. 1. It is called Rent Guidelines Order 13.

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART STICKS TO THE BASICS
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival stuck to basics for its Friday evening program at Avery Fisher Hall, which was repeated last night. No Salieri, no galant exotica, no childhood precociousness. Just mostly mature Mozart, with a late Haydn symphony as a chaser.

title: NEW SHOPS THAT DO THE COOKING
description: DINING out in the Hamptons at the height of the season invariably means fighting crowds, making reservations at least a week in advance, or both. Many summer residents find it easier to dine in. And there are more shops than ever this season offering prepared food for excellent meals at home.

title: Miss Schmidt To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Schmidt Jr. of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Whitefield, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Erica Etheridge Schmidt, to William Singer Moorhead 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moorhead Jr. of Washington and The Plains, Va.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: ALTHOUGH its predecessor, the autogiro, did not fare well, the helicopter has become very popular in New Jersey. Executives and state officials use various models to reduce their traveling time, hospitals handle emergency cases that copters bring to their lawns or to nearby parks and radio stations are able to describe highway traffic conditions by assigning reporters to helicopters.

title: A DEPARTURE LEAVES FEW REGRETS AT THE C.I.A.
description: At the end of June, expressing confidence that his stewardship of the Central Intelligence Agency was progressing smoothly, Director William J. Casey sent a memorandum to all employees, notifying them that the agency was lowering its public profile. ''The difficulties of the past decade are behind us,'' Mr. Casey said.

title: 'FAIRCHESTER,' A HAVEN FOR EXECUTIVE TALENT
description: GREENWICH CONFIRMING Fairfield County's status as a major center of corporate headquarters, most of the world's largest executive-search concerns have established offices in Greenwich or Stamford, and more are on the way. Compared with major cities such as New York, Chicago, Los Angeles or Houston, where most of the search companies maintain large staffs, lower Fairfield County would seem to be a minor outpost.

title: POLICE SAY PLASTIC SHIELDS FOR TELLERS CUT BANK HOLDUPS
description: After having installed bullet-resistant plastic or glass barriers atop tellers' counters, more than 350 bank branches in the city are being robbed far less often.

title: KENT SCHOOL SELECTS A NEW HEADMASTER
description: An Episcopal priest has been appointed headmaster of the Kent School in Kent, Conn. He succeeds Sidney N. Towle, who died in 1980.

title: NO LACK OF CANDIDATES IF SENATE OUSTS WILLIAMS
description: WASHINGTON FOR two days last week, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. sat in a Senate hearing room and witnessed a rerun of the taped evidence that led to his conviction on May 1 of Federal bribery and conspiracy charges. At stake is his 23-year career as a member of the Senate.

title: A DIFFERENT ATTITUDE TOWARD THE MOTH
description: IT is as close as I care to be to a candidate for the title of Public Enemy No. 10. I am not exactly shunned, but I am often given a wide berth or a jaundiced eye. There is doubt among my friends of my sanity and a lot of confusion over my intentions.

title: The Region in Summary; THIS IS KEEPING NEW YORK CLEAN?
description: Perhaps only slightly more surprising than the fact the New York City Sanitation Department has its own police force was the decision last week by Commissioner Norman Steisel to demote all 17 of its lieutenants and sergeants.

title: LESSON 1 AT FRESH AIR CAMP: A SKUNK IS NOT A PET
description: Walking down one of the narrow, meandering roads on the Sharpe Reservation here, John McShane, a naturalist for the Fresh Air Fund camp, paused and pointed to a tree.

title: HORSE DIES IN SPILL
description: Kading scored a half-length victory over Motor Mouth in the $100,000 American Trotting Championship at Roosevelt Raceway tonight in a race marked by the accidental death of one of the other horses. The top two finishers qualified as the country's representatives in the $250,000 Roosevelt International Trot next Saturday night.

title: The Nation in Summary; VERY TALL ORDER FOR VERY LARGE CONFERENCE
description: The largest Congressional conference committee ever - 72 senators and 183 representatives divided into 58 subconferences for the reconciliation of 250 to 300 differences - picked its wary way last week through the political minefield presented by President Reagan's cuts in social spending. But as many flares went up over his tax cut proposals. And even though the pressure was on to act by Aug. 1, lest the Congressional summer recess be delayed, neither Administration, Senate or House seemed able to resist new maneuvers.

title: Topics; STAND FIRM SIT UP; GODLY VOLTS
description: There is a peculiarly American institution known as the ''hot seat.'' At least that is what it used to be called in tabloids, gangster movies and the conversation of those who could not bear to call the electric chair by its rightful name.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HOBY & STUB By Mary Collins Dunne. 156 pp. New York: Atheneum. $9.95. (Ages 10 to 14) By CYNTHIA KING

title: Mudd Keeps His Title In Public Links Golf
description: Jodie Mudd of Louisville, Ky., won his second straight United States Public Links golf championship at Bear Creek Golf Course today, defeating Billy Tuten of Palatka, Fla., 3 and 2 in the 36-hole final.

title: Dorinda Campbell Is Wed
description: Dorinda Whitmarsh Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Page Campbell of Aurora, N.Y., was married yesterday to Randall Gardner Hicks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan C. Hicks of Downers Grove, Ill. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church in Ithaca, N.Y., by the Rev. David M. Talbot and the Rev. A. Richard Strauss. The bride is a pre-kindergarten teacher at the Belle Sherman School in Ithaca. Mr. Hicks, a research associate with Vanderbilt University, is working on a research project at Cornell University.

title: PRESIDENTIAL PROSE
description: My old paper - which once claimed to be The Guardian of Manchester, but is now The Guardian of the whole of Britain - has just printed a mock tribute to ''the consistent awfulness, not to say awe-fulness'' of Presidential prose. The mocker, one Richard Boston, began, none too convincingly, with a sentence of his own worthy of Dwight D. Eisenhower: ''One of the good things about having a Republican as President of the United States is their (sic) prose style.''

title: THOSE INSATIABLE CORPORATE GIANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: HARTFORD ALREADY SHOWS THE STRAIN
description: HARTFORD CONNECTICUT'S chief executives have often exercised powers given them by the Legislature to fine-tune budgets that ran into trouble. Such adjustments, however, usually aren't made until the middle of the fiscal year.

title: TEACHER LAYOFFS: ARE RULES FAIR?
description: LAST month's graduation days marked the last day of school for many teachers. The continuing decline of student enrollments in elementary and secondary schools in suburban New Jersey means that fewer teachers are needed. As a result, local districts have implemented ''Reductions in Force,'' known simply as RIF.

title: Major News in Summary; BEIRUT BOMBING ECHOES SHARPLY FAR AND WIDE
description: Israel last week carried its policy of pre-emptive/retaliatory strikes against Palestinians into the heart of Beirut, demolishing buildings that housed guerrilla headquarters as well as hundreds of civilians. The Lebanese Government said 300 people were killed and 800 wounded in the raids on the Lebanese capital and in the south of the country, where Israel bombed launching ports for guerrilla strikes and also destroyed bridges that served as supply links for civilians and guerrillas alike.

title: TOTALITARIANISM HAS THE EDGE IN REPREHENSIBILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME FOR RETARDED STIRS CEDARHURST
description: CEDARHURST TWICE rebuffed in its recent efforts to house the mentally retarded in the Five Towns area, the New York State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities is once again attempting to purchase a house here. The question is whether Cedarhurst residents will permit a group home in this upper-middle-class community.

title: A LIBRARY INVITES LISTENERS
description: IN the library of the Cooperative Extension office in Riverhead there are no books, only three carrousels that hold 650 two-track tape cartridges. Along with a five-channel tape player, a telephone receiver and an operator, the tapes comprise Tele-C.U.E., Suffolk County's new public service telephone information system.

title: Margaret Carbonell Married
description: Margaret Rose Carbonell and Philip Gregory Smith, who are with KNXT-TV in Los Angeles, were married yesterday in Palos Verdes, Calif. The Rev. Harvey A. Tafel of the Swedenborgian Church performed the ceremony at the Wayfarer's Chapel. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Carbonell of Stamford, Conn., is an associate producer, and her husband, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip W. Smith of Denver, is an associate director.

title: Carol Judith DeBakker Wed to Gregory J. Rice
description: Carol Judith DeBakker, daughter of Mrs. Robert H. Brown of Altoona, Pa., and the late Dr. Andre DeBakker, was married yesterday to Gregory J. Rice, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gregory Rice of River Edge, N.J. The bridegroom's father, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Altoona. The Rev. John J. Lafferty celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: State Patronage Jobs
description: On the Island I want to thank Frank Lynn for his diligence in reporting information that is unknown to the average taxpayer about political appointments. His article ''Albany Ex-Aides and L.I.'' on state patronage jobs dispensed by Governor Carey in Nassau and Suffolk Counties was illuminating and informative even to me, a member of the state Democratic Committee.

title: TO DELIMIT THE LIFE OF A HUMAN BEING
description: To the Editor:

title: Patricia S. Nebenzahl Engaged to William J. Frish
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Nebenzahl of Chicago and Glencoe, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Suzanne Nebenzahl, to William J. Frish, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Frish of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Raymond T. Bond, 88, Dead; Retired Head of Dodd, Mead
description: Raymond T. Bond, former president of Dodd, Mead & Company, book publishers, died Thursday at his home in Jamaica, Queens. He was 88 years old.

title: Mary Kredatus Fiancee Of Daniel Cronheim
description: Mr. and Mrs., Edward Kredatus of Clifton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Anne Kredatus, to Daniel Cronheim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cronheim of Watchung and Deal, N.J. A fall wedding is planned.

title: High-Tech Jobs
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Margaret Woodward Is Wed
description: Margaret Beale Woodward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Cabell Woodward Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married in Christ's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Victor Kiarsis Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Kiarsis of South Dartmouth, Mass. The Rev. Daniel R. Heischman performed the ceremony.

title: The Region in Summary; MOBIL DISCOVERS A TIGER IN THE TANK
description: Having considered a 5- or 6-cent-a-gallon increase in gasoline prices justifiable but unfeasible, the Mobil Oil Corporation announced last week that it would raise gasoline prices by 3 cents a gallon in order to pay new New York State taxes, but subsequently settled for an increase of 1.3 cents gallon.

title: At Home
description: ''Too broke to travel this summer? Let Jo-Jo help. Customized stayat-home vacations my specialty. Better than the real thing at half the price.'' - FLYER RECEIVED BY RESIDENT

title: Regal Report
description: To the Business Editor: Being the printer of E.F. Hutton's 1980 annual report, there is one correction I would like to make in your ''E.F. Hutton's Regal Report'' (June 28). The West German paper that was used was not silver, but white, on which we printed a specially formulated silver ink.

title: Major News in Summary; RIOTS END BUT SHOCK LINGERS
description: The astonishing wave of what some Britons called ''copycat'' violence spread to 30 cities before subsiding last week. And then police officers searching for a gasoline bomb factory busted their way with sledgehammers into 11 houses in Brixton, a racially mixed London neighborhood in which riots had erupted in April and again two weeks ago.

title: Kathy Martin Sets Course Mark on 66
description: If the tournaments were only two rounds instead of four each week, Kathy Martin would probably have at least one or two victories in her 10 years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour. Instead, she has no victories, but a string of outstanding performances in consecutive rounds.

title: The Cuisinart Complaint
description: I've a simple question to pose: What is a poor (i.e., low on funds), aspiring cook and faithful reader of the food column to do without a food processor (''Mastering the Mini Dumpling,'' by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, June 21)? Naturally, I would love to have one but such gadgetry is beyond my simple means. This Sunday, I threw down The New York Times Magazine and threw up my hands.

title: MUSIC: GLENN BRANCA, AVANT-GARDIST
description: During the last three years, Glenn Branca has emerged as the most prominent composer working in the increasingly active field of rock avant-garde experimentation. His largest work to date, ambitiously entitled Symphony No. 1, which opened Thursday at the Performing Garage and will be played there nightly through today, is the acme of what recent New York art-rockers have yet accomplished.

title: Letitia Victoria Coburn Married to Hal Leyshon
description: Letitia Victoria Coburn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest E. Coburn of Buckingham, Pa., was married yesterday to Hal Richards Leyshon, son of Mrs. Hal Leyshon of New York and the late Mr. Leyshon.

title: Dance View; KYLIAN PUTS HUMANIST THEMES INTO MOTION
description: Jiri Kylian finds it curious, if flattering, that his ballets recall those of Antony Tudor. By his own account, Mr. Kylian, the 34-year-old Czechoslovak-born artistic director of the Netherlands Dance Theater, has never seen the great English-born choreographer's major works. Yet, as the Dutch company's season in New York has just indicated, Mr. Kylian remains in the same line of descent as Mr. Tudor.

title: The World in Summary Francois Mitterrand; WASHINGTON TRIES STROKING EUROPE ON ARMS CONTROL
description: The Reagan Administration filled in some of the blanks in its foreign policy last week by outlining principles to govern arms talks with the Russians and to control the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: TENNIS TANTRUM
description: To the Sports Editor: I wish to congratulate Sidney B. Wood Jr. for a long-overdue indictment of tennis players' offenses toward the public and officials ("Tantrum Throwers Through the Years," The New York Times, July 12). I am glad he did not spare anyone, pre-and-post-Gonzales era.

title: WHAT IT TAKES, THESE DAYS, TO MAKE THE BAND PLAY ON
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Carol MacGuineas is a freelance writer with a special interest in music. By CAROL MacGUINEAS

title: CONCERT SERIES STARTS IN HAMPTONS
description: SOUTHAMPTON BACK in May, several local residents, some with a deep interest in the arts and some with professional backgrounds, drafted a program to bring outstanding artists to Southampton residents and to those who work in New York City and spend weekends or vacations on the East End. As a result, the Southampton Performing Arts Festival '81 will make its debut next Sunday with the first of five concerts billed by the sponsors as the International Prize-Winning Young Artists Series.

title: Day Captures 3 Events In All-Comers Track
description: Gene Day of the Tip Astor Track Club of the Bronx, won three events in the Metropolitan Athletics Congress All-Comers meet held yesterday at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: RESEVOIRS BOLSTER THEIR SECURITY
description: SIX months before vandals disrupted Newark's water supply, the New York City Department of Environmental Protection increased security on the Croton Reservoir system in Westchester and Putnam Counties, a gravity-fed group of 12 reservoirs and four lakes that one water engineer calls ''the pressure pot.''

title: HEARTBEAT MONITERED
description: Bruce Harper of the Jets, who suffered heart-and-lung inflammation after pneumonia during the offseason, put on pads today for the first time. He also had a remote-control device that monitored his heartbeat.

title: BLACK UTOPIAS
description: THE PURSUIT OF A DREAM By Janet Sharp Hermann. Illustrated. 290 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.50.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: '' I think everyone did an incredible job - the police, the firemen and the people at the hospital.

title: THE IDYLLIC ISLANDS OF LAKE MAGGIORE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- SARAH FERRELL is an editor on the staff of the Travel Section. By SARAH FERRELL

title: CITIES OFFERED HELP TO TRACE SCOFFLAWS
description: IN an effort to deal with the problem of scofflaws and also to generate more revenue for cities and towns, a state municipal organization is contracting the services of a private data-processing concern to collect and process parking violations.

title: GRAND CANYON
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME BUYERS BEWARE!
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE'S WATERFALLS OFFER COOL RETREAT
description: THE rolling hills of Connecticut are drained by numerous small streams and rivers, many of which are generously endowed with beautiful waterfalls along the run to the sea. The falls lie hidden in the woods, undiscovered even by nearby residents. Many of these natural jewels have cool, secluded swimming holes carved out beneath them.

title: CLERC, UNSEEDED FRENCHMAN IN SEMIFINAL
description: Top-seeded Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina, getting better as the tournament progresses, registered a 7-5, 6-2 victory over Manuel Orantes of Spain in the quarterfinals of the $175,000 United States Pro tennis championships today.

title: ZOO TO THE WORLD
description: Michael Wright is an editor of The New York Times Week in Review. By Michael Wright he afternoon breeze isn't quite strong enough to cut the baking heat or break up the swarms of gnats on Saint Catherines Island off the Georgia coast, the subtropical home for 215 mammals, birds and reptiles. Herds of Dama gazelles and Addax antelopes gallop about a pasture thick with delicate, blue toadflax flowers, shaded here and there by massive oaks. In the southern Sahara, the Addax - which resemble small reindeer with long, twisted horns - have been decimated by oil-rig crews and nomads; on the island, their numbers have increased from six to 35 since 1975. The population of Dama gazelles in their northern African habitats have been destroyed by hunters and the competition from domestic animals that have intruded on their grazing lands. The Aldabra tortoises, natives of islands in the Indian Ocean, graze quietly in their enclosure. Five species of cranes settle into nests they've built in their own swampy enclave. Saint Catherines, a Bronx Zoo outpost, is a refuge for many endangered species of northern and central Africa. It can be reached only by a 30-minute boat ride.

title: THE SYMPHONY: ALL THOSE NOTES NEEDN'T BE SOUR
description: IT WOULD be impossible in this space to reply to every issue raised by Marcia Gwynne Sloat in her greatly misinformed article, ''New Jersey Is an Artistic Gusher'' (Opinion Page, June 14).

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: GREENPORT Village officials got some good news from the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development when the Federal agency announced its approval of an $885,750 grant for local renovation projects. The H.U.D. decision effectively ended a threeyear losing streak for the village, which has had its applications to the agency turned down since 1978.

title: Diana S. Walker To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Ridley of Naples, Fla., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Ridley's daughter, Diana Sloan Walker, to William Macy Steers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R.C. Steers Jr. of Rye, N.Y., and Onteora Park, Tannersville, N.Y.

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE occasion was a meeting of the Westchester Legislature's newly formed Committee on Corrections, and Diane Keane, the chairman, was welcoming State Supreme Court Justice Isaac Rubin by explaining why the Legislators wanted to question him: ''There's serious overcrowding at the County Jail; we're looking for a solution,'' she said.

title: New Jersey Guide; START YOUR MOTORS
description: Many of the country's top drag racers - in fact, some 600 of them -are at Madison Township Raceway Park in Englishtown for the 12th annual Summer Nationals, the seventh of 11 events in the National Hot Rod Association's national racing series. Purses total $510,000.

title: The Nation in Summary; MRS. O'CONNOR MAKES THE SCENE
description: The grumbles largely turned to pledges of support last week as Sandra Day O'Connor made her way, judiciously, around Capitol Hill. She apparently assuaged supporters of restrictions on abortions by declaring that she personally opposed the medical procedure.

title: REAGAN, MRS. THATCHER, AND ULSTER
description: The time has come for President Reagan to use the ''special relationship'' between the United States and Britain to advise Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to disengage from Northern Ireland.

title: INQUIRY CONTINUES IN SUBWAY DEATH
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday that his office would continue to investigate the death of Gerard Coury now that it had received an autopsy report from the Chief Medical Examiner.

title: Follow-Up on the News; TERRORIST DEMAND
description: For nearly three months, while the M-19 terrorist group in Colombia held Chester A. Bitterman 3d captive early this year, the kidnappers' demand was unvarying: either the Summer Institute of Linguistics, an American missionary group to which Mr. Bitterman belonged, got out of Colombia or Mr. Bitterman would die. The institute resisted, and Mr. Bitterman, who was from Lancaster, Pa., and was preparing to translate and disseminate the Bible among Indian tribes, was found shot dead in Bogota last March 7.

title: REAGAN AND THATCHER DIFFER OVER ECONOMICS
description: LAST week, as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher rebuffed calls for a costly youth employment program to remove a presumed cause of rioting in British cities, and as President Reagan pushed for tax and spending cuts that will reduce many social programs, the two leaders' economic policies seemed so similar that one could have been tempted to see in Britain a precursor of things to come in the United States.

title: NEW BUDGET IS UGANDA'S LAST CHANCE
description: A train hit a truck at a railroad crossing near Kampala the other day and people were hurt. To some careful observers of Uganda's affairs, it was cause for a small celebration - not the accident, but the fact that a train had been operating. ''Two years ago, there were no trains at all,'' one analyst said. ''It's not much, but it's something.'' Only in Uganda, perhaps, could optimism be woven from such frail thread.

title: PLANS FOR SITE NEAR MACY'S
description: A corner property with a frame house on Queens Boulevard at 55th Avenue in Elmhurst is about to be redeveloped--but not by Macy's. Seventeen years ago Macy's had to redesign the plans for its huge circular store next door because it could not come to terms with the owner.

title: N.F.L. FACES LABOR PROBLEMS, TOO, BUT NOT ON FREE AGENCY
description: Twenty-two of the National Football League's 28 training camps opened last week, and for the first time in history major league baseball games were not being played concurrently in the city stadiums.

title: New Jerseyans
description: as the first stop for medical care - the doctor population is shrinking.

title: Other World Events; Indian Satellite Slips Into Its Slot
description: Indian scientists proved their sophistication last week by maneuvering an Indian-designed and developed communications satellite into geostationary orbit over the equator above the Indonesian island of Sumatra. The spacecraft, called Apple, was launched June 19 from French Guiana aboard a European Space Agency Ariane rocket. It is expected to function for a year.

title: Jane Olberg Married to William Prowell, Lawyer
description: Jane Glynn Olberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Forbes Olberg of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, was married there yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church to William Parsons Prowell. He is the son of Mrs. Richard P. Prowell of New York and Hadlyme, Conn., and the late Mr. Prowell.

title: INCREDIBLE EDIBLES
description: Waste not, want not - especially in these inflationary days. So why not develop some expertise on the use of common plants for food? Today at noon, the Museum of Long Island Natural Sciences at the State University at Stony Brook is sponsoring a lecture-walk on ''Edible Wild Plants.'' It will cost $3 to learn what's safe to eat and how, and what to keep away from. For information, call 246-8373. Then, on Saturday, at 10 A.M., the Muttontown Park and Preserve Nature Center will examine ''Edible and Useful Plants'' in another nature walk. The preserve is on Muttontown Lane in East Norwich and, although the program is free, advance registration at 922-3123 is a must.

title: Antiques; A SUCCESS STORY IN POTTERY
description: Imitation may be the sincerest of flattery, but it can pose problems. And it did for the Grueby Faience Company of Boston, one of the most accomplished - and imitated -producers of ceramics at the turn of the century.

title: GRAFFITI ART DISPLAY
description: Six pieces of subway-train graffiti represented on a poster for The Village Voice were captioned ''The graffiti shown above is no longer visible, having been defaced by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.''

title: REPORT FROM SPLITSVILLE
description: SINGLED OUT A Civilized Guide to Sex and Sensibility for the Suddenly Single Man - or Woman. By Richard Schickel. 115 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $8.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an error in computer-card punching, an incorrect entry appears today in the No. 8 position of the hardcover nonfiction bestseller list in The Times Book Review. The books listed as No. 9 to No. 15 should each be ranked one position higher. The 15th book should be ''Nice Girls Do,'' by Irene Kassorla (Stratford Press, $9.95).

title: GROWTH OF FLEA MARKETS CHALLENGES MERCHANTS
description: WESTBURY FLEA markets offering discount merchandise are continuing to proliferate throughout the Island, vying with established retailers for billions of consumer dollars. Thousands of shoppers are thronging the markets at Roosevelt Field, Commack, Smithtown, Huntington Station, Valley Stream, Republic Airport in Farmingdale and Belmont and Aqueduct Race Tracks, among other places, to browse, buy and seek out bargains in an often carnival-like atmosphere.

title: Surendra Shah Weds Alice DeNormandie
description: Alice Woodward DeNormandie and Surendra Vaghji Shah, both of New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James De Normandie in Lincoln, Mass. The bridegroom is a son of Maniben V. Shah of Nairobi, Kenya, and the late Vaghji Pethraj Shah.

title: RACE-FIXING HEARINGS SHOW MORE INVETSIGATING IS NEEDED
description: There is no question that thoroughbred horse races were fixed in New York in the mid-1970's. There is no question that jockeys were paid to hold back their horses so that gamblers financed by organized crime could execute betting coups. Con Errico, a former jockey, has been convicted of passing along bribes to riders. The jockey Jose Amy, who has admitted taking bribes from Errico, and the jockey agent Eddie Belmonte, who has been accused of offering bribes to other riders, have been barred from racing. At present, no related charges against anyone else are pending before either administrative or judicial bodies, but it is clear that numerous jockeys, gamblers and criminal organizers must have participated.

title: AMID SMOKE AND SHAME, BRITAIN THINKS IT ALL OVER
description: LONDON THIRTEEN years ago, the Kerner Commission issued its report on the riots that had scarred America's cities and conscience. ''Without responsive and representative local government, without effective processes of interracial communication within the city, and without alert, well-trained and adequately supported local police,'' the commission said, ''national action, no matter how great its scale, cannot be expected to provide a solution.''

title: AN HERB WITH ELEGANCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Ruth Tirrell grows most of her own vegetables and herbs in a Massachusetts garden. BY RUTH TIRRELL

title: Miss Martin, James Evarts Are Married
description: Rebecca Stanard Martin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold C. Martin of Hartford and Rensselaerville, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Maxwell Evarts. The Rev. Darwin Kirby performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Rensselaerville Presbyterian Church.

title: Hitler's War
description: To the Editor:

title: Isabel J. Kaplan Officer's Fiancee
description: The engagement of Isabel Jane Kaplan to 2d Lieut. Gregory Cady Davis, U.S.A., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Allan S. Kaplan of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., parents of the future bride.

title: CHATTANOOGA
description: To the Editor:

title: The World in Summary; WARRINGTON LOOMS LARGE
description: With British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher ruling from the Conservative right and the opposition Labor Party sliding precipitously leftward, the center ground seemed inviting but risky. The new Social Democratic Party, founded less than four months ago, last week gambled and won big, surprising even its supporters by its showing in a parliamentary by-election in the Labor stronghold of Warrington.

title: LISTENING TO THE VOICE OF THE BARD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Arthur Holmberg teaches theater at Harvard and writes frequently on the arts. By ARTHUR HOLMBERG

title: JOSTLING TO POWER UP THE NEXT JETS
description: W ILL the sleek A320, the blunt-nosed MDF-100, the porpoise-snouted 7-7 all use the new PW2025? Will they also employ the revved-up CFM56-2000? And the redirected RJ500? Or will any of them come to market at all?

title: Krystyna Biernacki-Poray Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wladyslaw O. Biernacki-Poray of Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Krystyna Biernacki-Poray, to Joseph George Goddu, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Goddu, also of Montclair.

title: N.J. OFFICIALS PLAY A WAITING GAME
description: TRENTON THOUGH they don't deny they have been following the progress of the Reagan Administration's proposals to reduce Federal spending, legislators in New Jersey have generally been circumspect in their reactions to the cuts. With all 120 seats up for election in November, no one is particularly eager to discuss the politically sensitive choices the reductions will pose, much less any tax increases that may be needed to ease their impact. In fact, the Legislature, which is in recess, is expected to avoid the subject entirely when it returns in September and disband as quickly as it can until after the elections.

title: ROUSING U.S. SCIENCE TO MEET HALLEY'S RED DAWN
description: ''To the man in the street, the solar system consists of Mars, the rings of Saturn and Halley's comet,'' Brian Marsden, an astronomer at the Harvard-Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, once remarked.

title: TV View; A VINTAGE SOAP-OPERA CONTINUES TO CHARM
description: The cupboard for television classics is understocked but not exactly bare. The memory of anybody who grew up after 1950 is likely to retain splendid bits of everything from Milton Berle, Lucille Ball and Sid Caesar to Olympics sports events and space walks. In the bread-and-butter area of weekly series, American television has had ''All in the Family,'' ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and other quality situation comedies, but, in terms of sustained drama and classy production, none can claim to be more accomplished than the British series ''Upstairs, Downstairs.'' Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, a summer package of ''Festival of Favorites,'' celebrating the 10thanniversary season of public television's ''Masterpiece Theater,'' will begin presenting five episodes of the 55 ''Upstairs, Downstairs'' shows that were broadcast over four seasons.

title: DON'T LET THIS SUMMER BE THE LAST
description: T HE Ottawa economic summit meeting could be the most important summit yet. The heads of government of the seven main industrial countries will meet to address not only the usual specific issues - macro-economic policy, energy, trade, etc. -but also the future of economic summitry itself, and, thus, of the cooperation among the heads of government that has enabled them to confront serious and unsolved domestic economic problems in the later 1970's without relapsing into the beggar-thy-neighbor economic policies with which their predecessors reacted to such problems in the 1930's.

title: LEGISLATORS SET TO MEET ON O'NEILL VETOES
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly passed 547 bills in its last session, of which Governor O'Neill approved all but 15. When the legislators return to the Capitol tomorrow, they will have a three-day limit for debating and acting on the 15 vetoes, but they are planning a session of only one day.

title: CARS, CARS, EVERYWHERE
description: Consumers looking to buy a new car this summer have an unusually wide range of models to choose from. Automotive News, an industry publication, reports strong production and lagging sales in June pushed inventories of 1981 model cars to record levels as the third quarter began.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE STRIKES DOWN LAW BANNING HEAD SHOPS IN NEW YORK
description: New York State's year-old law against ''head shops'' has been struck down by a Federal judge in Manhattan. The judge, John M. Cannella of United States District Court, said the statute was ''impermissibly vague.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: JAZZ The Savoy Sultans were one of the legendary Harlem jazz bands of the 1930's and '40's. For nine years, they were the house band at the Savoy Ballroom, a jumping band that was so popular with the Lindy Hoppers who packed The Track, as the Savoy's dance floor was known, that some well-known bands refused to play opposite them.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: THEATER The late British playwright Joe Orton, who flared briefly but brightly in the 1960s, has rarely received his due in New York productions of his work. That injustice is now being rectified by the letter-perfect revival of his first full-length play, ''Entertaining Mr. Sloane,'' at the Cherry Lane.

title: A Mother's Opinion Of Father's Day Pieces
description: Leon Gersten's recent article, ''Home Is Where the Memories Linger'' (Opinion Page), has given me the inspiration I'll need to get through a steamy summer with my teething twins.

title: The Region in Summary; IN N.J., ALLSTATE IS IN TOUGH HANDS
description: It's not likely to change the notorious reputation of New Jersey drivers, but a state appeals court ruled last week that the Allstate Insurance Company had nevertheless overcharged 502,000 New Jersey policyholders and ordered about $22 million refunded to them.

title: World's Athletes Set For University Games
description: The World University Games, the biggest international sports meet since last year's Olympics in Moscow, open tomorrow with nearly 5,000 athletes from colleges and universities in 80 countries taking part.

title: No Headline
description: The article on the role of Governor Carey's aides on Long Island neglected an important point. Betty Schlein, the Governor's representative in Nassau County, has greatly aided communication between the Island and Albany for private citizens and business people who don't have the same access that Francis Purcell has to the Governor's ear.

title: THE NEW BOOT THAT BALANCES
description: Boots, boots, boots. In nearly every major fall fashion collection shown in Europe and the United States, svelte, flat-heeled boots were part of almost every silhouette. In Milan, Gianni Versace tucked pants into midcalf-high boots. The Missonis, known for their knit creations, teamed ankle-high versions with leggings and sweater minidresses. In Paris, Claude Montana showed knee-high styles trimmed in fur over jodhpur-cut pants. And in New York, Calvin Klein, Anne Klein, Oscar de la Renta, and a host of others combined boots with day clothes, play clothes and even evening wear.

title: PREDICTING PROFITS
description: I N his column, ''The Diverse Art of Forecasting'' (June 16), Robert Metz presented some interesting statistics on the accuracy of earnings forecasts. However, there are broader issues to be addressed that should influence a company's decision to adopt such a program.

title: The Polish Awakening
description: John Darnton's article, ''The Polish Awakening'' (June 14), should be obligatory reading in our schools.

title: MEADOWLANDS ROLE DISPUTED
description: LYNDHURST OFFICIALS of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission felt there was ''nothing new'' when an organization consisting of the mayors of the 14 municipalities in the area started a public drive for a greater voice in commission affairs.

title: THE MILE HAS NO PROBLEM SURVIVING IN A METRIC AGE
description: STEVE OVETT stood with hands on hips in silent contemplation of the men's 200 meters. As Dwayne Evans of the United States swept around the turn on his way to victory, Ovett smiled, perhaps feeling that he would finish his mile race later in the evening in a similar fashion.

title: ALL GLUTS ARE NOT CREATED EQUAL
description: I N his recent article, ''Lulled to Sleep by the Oil Glut Mirage'' (June 28), Daniel Yergin argues that there is no glut on world oil markets because ''a glut implies some major collapse in world oil prices.'' Unfortunately, this view neglects some major features of the world oil market.

title: PHONING FROM ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: UNCLUTTERED IMAGE OF THE BARD AT DREW
description: MADISON BY JUPITER, the best news in recent years from the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival at Drew University is that Paul Barry is directing a fresh, high-spirited and well-spoken ''Cymbeline.''

title: Staten I. Search Grows For Missing 7-Year-Old
description: The police and scores of neighborhood volunteers yesterday expanded the search for a 7-year-old Staten Island girl missing since Wednesday evening.

title: JAVA'S BUSY TOWNS AND SERENE SHRINES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- DAVID TABACOFF, a news producer for ABC television, lives in New York. By DAVID TABACOFF

title: ADOPTION: NEW VIEWS ON BLACKS
description: INTERRACIAL adoptions, which reached their peak in the late 1960's, are waning, particularly in nonintegrated areas of the Island. Adoption agencies are attempting to find black homes for black children, who far outnumber the white children available.

title: DRAWING BACK THE VEIL ON THE VERY RICH
description: T is fun to snoop on the rich. But there are few opportunities to do so. Some hints regarding their behavior, however, can be obtained from the Statistics of Income which provided detailed data on income tax returns. The last, detailed, published version released by the Internal Revenue Service describes tax returns filed for 1978, and it contains some interesting points.

title: Bridge; EAST MEETS EAST
description: The recent emergence of the People's Republic of China on the bridge scene inevitably raised the delicate question: Would the players of Taiwan meet their mainland cousins over the table?

title: FOR A PRICE, EVERYONE CAN BE CREDITWORTHY
description: What a deal. You deposit anywhere from $300 to $2,000 in the bank, and in return get the opportunity to earn 5 1/4 percent annual interest. Then you can borrow as much as you have in the bank, as long as you don't withdraw the deposit money. For this you pay only 18 percent interest.

title: The Nation in Summary; MASS. FEELS MORE PAIN ON PROP 2 1 2
description: Nobody thought Proposition 2 1/2 would be easy for Massachusetts politicians to deal with, but few expected so quickly to see that much fumbling.

title: Recordings; RICKIE LEE JONES--A FINE ENCORE
description: Rickie Lee Jones's self-titled first album was one of the most auspicious and intriguing pop debuts of recent years. She was only 24 when Warner Bros. released ''Rickie Lee Jones'' in April 1979, but in the album's cover portrait her flowing blond hair was topped by a jaunty beret and a cigarette was clamped between her teeth. She looked like a 50's hipster who had somehow materialized 20 years later with her beat sensibility miraculously intact, and that was what she sounded like. Her music, and especially ''Chuck E.'s in Love,'' the album's hit single, was rooted in the world of jazz and poetry and espresso joints and the open road that Jack Kerouac and his contemporaries had celebrated. It was a world her friend Tom Waits, a distinctive singer-songwriter with several albums under his belt, seemed intent on reviving and revisiting.

title: WORKING TO PREVENT A RECURRENCE AT JAIL
description: VALHALLA AN inch of water stood on the flagstone floor of the entrance to the County Jail here during the recent riots as a Corrections Department van pulled up. More than 500 county and state officers in riot helmets, flak jackets and armed with shot guns stood guard in the hot night.

title: DANCE: FESTIVAL LOOKS AT VAUDEVILLE
description: Ordinarily, the American Dance Festival takes dance very seriously. But Thursday night it turned frivolous with a program at Duke University's Page Auditorium called ''Vaudeville Alive and Dancing'' that consisted of numbers in the spirit of old vaudeville routines. Although some of the performers were obviously too young to have appeared in real vaudeville shows, the kinds of dances they did would have surely been familiar to vaudeville audiences.

title: Martha Doyle Fiancee Of George G. Schwartz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Layton Doyle of Hingham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Sutcliffe Doyle, to George Gampfer Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Jay Schwartz of Belle Island, Rowayton, Conn.

title: Recordings; RUSSIA'S BARBAROUSLY COLORFUL SHOWPIECES GAIN FRESH FLAVOR
description: The showiest pieces for the gargantuan, fully developed symphony orchestra come from the late 19th century and the early years of our own century. Before that, the orchestra was still evolving, with composers still exploring the medium. After that, music went into a reaction from which it is still emerging.

title: Terry Antrim Is Bride of John Leness
description: At Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Greenwood, Va., yesterday, Terry Carter Antrim, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry T. Antrim of Coconut Grove, Fla., was married to John Southworth Leness, son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Leness of New York. The Rev. Howard La Rue performed the ceremony.

title: The Region in Summary; WILLIAMS CASE TO SENATE PANEL
description: In May a Federal jury found the evidence against Harrison A. Williams Jr. strong enough to convict him of bribery and conspiracy in the Abscam scandal. Last week a Senate committee began reviewing the same evidence to determine whether the New Jersey Democrat was also guilty of conduct unbecoming a Senator.

title: HEAD OF GUILD FOR BLIND SEEKS TO 'REINTEGRATE' THE DISABLED
description: Since its founding in 1914, the Jewish Guild for the Blind has been taking in blind people, teaching them skills and generally caring for them. It also serves a variety of multihandicapped people in its handsome, spacious quarters at 15 West 65th Street and at its Home for Aged Blind in Yonkers.

title: MOJACAR
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWSPAPER'S SLOGAN INSPIRES COMPOSER'S WORK
description: MORRISTOWN LAST FALL, when David Sampson was looking for a subject for a new musical composition, he bought The New York Times and The Daily News every day for a week, selected five articles of contrasting significance and mood and then used each as the basis of a movement for narrator and orchestra.

title: Other World Events; Bani-Sadr Speaks to Iranians
description: Iran's ruling clerics forced the ouster of Abolhassan Bani-Sadr as President, but he won't go away.

title: MORTIMER HEINEMAN, ADVERTISING EXECUTIVE, DIES
description: Mortimer Heineman, an advertising executive who helped create the slogan ''Promise her anything, but give her Arpege,'' died Friday of a heart attack. He was 74 years old and a resident of Purchase, N.Y.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: A WOMAN'S AGE, by Rachel Billington. (Bantam, $3.50.) England's changing times from 1905 to 1975, and how four generations of upperclass women responded to them - eccentric Eleanor, who spent most of her time on a deserted island with lovers and husbands; her daughter Vi, who became a member of Parliament; her granddaughter Violet, who wrote children's books, and her great-granddaughter Ethne, who returned to the island's ''simple life.'' An absorbing old-fashioned novel by a woman who knows at firsthand whereof she writes.

title: 'FANTASTICKS' BACK IN TRIUMPH
description: ''THE FANTASTICKS,'' the American theater's longevity record setter, originated Off Broadway, but it is, by rights, East Hampton's born-again musical.

title: ROGERS EXTENDS LEAD IN BRITAIN TO 5 SHOTS ON 67
description: Bill Rogers shot a three-under-par 67, his second consecutive sub-par round, and extended his lead in the British Open golf championship to five strokes today.

title: Architecture View; A 'GARDEN OF DELIGHTS' AT COOPER-HEWITT
description: The Cooper-Hewitt has had the happy idea of taking on the art of landscape for its summer show this year. Almost the entire museum - located at 2 East 91st Street in the old Carnegie Mansion - including the museum garden and conservatory, has been given over to the seasonally appropriate theme of gardens and flowers, or, more formally and correctly, to ''horticulture and the decorative arts.''

title: 'FOREIGN LEGION' TALK OF TROUR DE FRANCE
description: There are plenty of Frenchmen, Belgians, Dutchmen, Spaniards, Germans, and even Luxembourgeois, Swede, Swiss and Portuguese in the Tour de France bicycle endurance race. But the main national attraction is the Anglo-Saxon group, five riders who are putting some English on an otherwise unexciting competition.

title: No Headline
description: Isaac Asimov's dismissal of the creationist argument from analogy or argument from design misses the point that it is not an obscurant, but an enlightened argument. Deists of the 18th century developed this line of thought in order to infer the presence of God through the use of reason and experience, rather than by revelation.

title: Follow-Up on the News; FEMALE TROOPERS
description: After futile efforts to hire women and train them routinely with men as troopers, the New Jersey state police signed up 30 women and trained them as the first all-fe@male class of trooper candidates in the nation. After they graduated in June 1980, the state police said their work would be monitored for five years with the help of Seton Hall University.

title: Dining Out; SEAFOOD AND SEASCAPES
description: NORWALK GOOD seaside views in a restaurant are no guarantee of equally gratifying food. Such is the case at Skipper's, a large restaurant facing Long Island Sound. The tranquil view cannot be faulted. The two dining levels with wraparound windows take full advantage of the shoreline and the comings and goings of the boats that shuttle back and forth to Long Island.

title: HISTORIC HOTELS RIDE REVIVAL WAVE
description: Visitors to San Antonio's 122-year-old Menger Hotel are once again able to have a drink at the bar where Teddy Roosevelt organized his Rough Riders. They can also spend the night in one of the antiquefilled rooms where O. Henry or Oscar Wilde slept.

title: Tom Mahoney, Author And Former Journalist
description: Tom Mahoney, an author, newspaperman and public relations executive, died Friday at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., following a brief illness. Mr. Mahoney, who lived in Manhattan and Poughkeepsie, was 75 years old.

title: RIVERHEAD
description: A PROPOSAL by town officials here to use a canine squad to assist patrolling police officers has left many residents feeling that the town is going to the dogs in more ways than one.

title: TAKING A TAXI FROM JERUSALEM TO CAIRO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JOHN GODDARD is a reporter for the Canadian Press wire service. By JOHN GODDARD

title: VIEWS OF OLD NEW YORK
description: Well-known buildings and gardens of New York City in the 18th and 19th centuries are the subjects of an exhibition of paintings, engravings, photographs, prints and artifacts on view through Friday at City Gallery, on the second floor at 2 Columbus Circle.

title: A FABLE OF RECLAMATION
description: THE HERITAGE The History of a Detestable Word. By Siegfried Lenz. Translated from the German by Krishna Winston. 458 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $16.95. By SALMAN RUSHDIE

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Shoe Styles and Sizes In Wide Range for Men
description: Traditional men's styles from 30 nationally advertised manufacturers (white bucks, tassel slip-ons, wing-tip brogues and penny loafers) are available at Shoe Mart Factory Outlet, a familyowned discount shop established in Bridgeport in 1956. There is one other Shoe Mart, specializing in casual shoes and work shoes, including steeltoes, in Monroe. A mailing list notifies customers of sales beyond the monthlong July and January promotions on 900 styles. Most sizes are available, from 5 to 16 and in widths from AAAA to EEEE.

title: IN DEFENSE OF DIFFICULTY
description: For a critic to be remembered for his style, rather than for the substance of his discourse, is always an ambiguous fate, especially when the style in question is regarded as problematical. We turn to criticism for clarification, after all. Yet in criticism, as in other branches of literature, there are times when clarity and economy of statement may not in themselves be sufficient. Something subtler and more complicated, even at the risk of confusion and obscurity, may be required.

title: At Home
description: ''Too broke to travel this summer? Let Jo-Jo help! Customized stay-at-home vacations my specialty. Better than the real thing at half the price.'' - Flier addressed to Occupant.

title: SCHEDULED AUCTIONS WILL HEAT UP COIN MARKET
description: Unlike the weather, the coin market has been tepid rather than torrid in recent weeks - but things could heat up considerably between now and Aug. 1, thanks to a series of three important public auction sales. All will take place in New Orleans, which not just coincidentallyis also the scene of the upcomng convention of the American Numismatic Association.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW
description: NONFICTION

title: Jets Hope Rudolph Helps Rush
