description: When it comes to rushing the opponent's passer, the Jets have been delinquent in recent seasons, ranking close to last in the National Football League a year ago with only 28 quarterback sacks in 16 games.

title: Gardening; HOSTAS WELL SUITED FOR SHADED AREAS
description: SHADE gardening has grown in popularity in recent years. The list of plants suitable for planting in the shade is quite long, although it certainly can't compare with that for a sunny location. The annuals include the familiar impatiens, coleus, begonia, torenia and lobelia. Among the perennials are astilbe, party ferns, pachysandra, vinca, epimedium and many others. None of these are more attractive or versatile, however, than the hostas, or plantain lilies.

title: STILL A SURE-SHOT 'ANNIE'
description: IT is hard to believe that ''Annie Get Your Gun'' is a 35-year-old musical. It seems like only yesterday that it began its Broadway run of 1,147 performances. The original production boasted Ethel Merman and songwriter-lyricist Irving Berlin, both in top form. Together they flooded the theater with hit songs. And then in 1966, when Miss Merman did a revival of the musical, Irving Berlin provided her with one more excellent number, ''Old Fashioned Wedding,'' just to show he hadn't lost his touch.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: TAKING STOCK IN THE STREET
description: W ALL STREET's latest outburst of merger fever is, of course, focused on energy, as the bidding for Conoco gets ever wilder, and speculative headlines look ahead to other potential targets. But energy is not alone by a long shot. Take a look at what's been happening in the brokerage business.

title: The World in Summary; OLD FRIENDS FALL OUT IN ARGENTINA
description: Interservice rivalry can get rough in junta-land, Argentina's former Navy commander in chief, Adm. Emilio Massera, found out last week. His old buddies, the army generals he helped to seize power in 1976, placed him under house arrest for 10 days for criticizing them.

title: Speaking Personally; THE DAY WHEN JOHNNY FIRST GOES OFF TO COLLEGE
description: THIS is my big year for endings. For one thing, I am coming up fast on 40, which I see as the end of the ''when I grow up'' phase. As I get used to the idea of being an ''older woman,'' I have another, much more visible adjustment to make. Our oldest child, a son, has graduated from high school will be off to college. His room will still be his; however, for all practical purposes, he will not be living live here anymore.

title: DELANEY'S CAUTIOUS REPLIES
description: SHERIFF THOMAS DELANEY conceded last week, as he neared the end of his stint as the first witness in his own disciplinary hearings, that last year he had assigned to himself the use of a 1976 red and white Cadillac seized in an undercover police operation.

title: McAdoo Wonders As He Waits
description: GREENSBORO, N.C. THE hot sunny afternoon had suddenly turned dark. There was a gentle, almost apologetic rumble of thunder, and then the rain came, lightly but steadily, hitting the large living room window in the house on Ross Avenue.

title: No Headline
description: Isaac Asimov's analogy questioning why some people will accept the technologically mysterious automobile but not evolutionary theory contains a flaw. The analogy is imperfect because the causal role of an engine in making an auto run can be directly demonstrated, by removing the engine from the car.

title: Margaret O'Neil Betrothed
description: The engagement of Margaret Morris O'Neil to Richmond Young Holden Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Holden of Weston, Mass., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Francis C. O'Neil of Hyannis Port, Mass., parents of the future bride. A September wedding is planned.

title: At Home Abroad; A DESOLATE PROSPECT
description: Grime, damp, rubble. Mean streets, boarded-up houses, squalid shops. This is Toxteth, in the center of Liverpool: A scene of unrelieved desolation.

title: No Headline
description: The ''scientific'' creationists have put science on a pedestal in thinking that they have enhanced the Creation by calling it ''scientific.'' Actually, their action lowers creationism from its exalted spiritual sense, as properly taught in churches, and places it in the chemistry, biology and physics classroom, along with mice, monkeys and mathematic calculations. HENRY J. HEIMLICH, M.D., Cincinnati

title: VERDY TACKLES THE BOSTON BALLET
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Sharon Basco is dance critic of The Boston Herald American. By SHARON BASCO

title: Camera; FLOWER PHOTOGRAPHY--A LABOR OF LOVE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Pamela J. Harper is a writer, lecturer and photographer who also owns a commercial slide library.

title: Theater; THE RISE AND RISE OF SWOOSIE KURTZ
description: Her dressing table is awash in all the tools and talismans of the theatrical trade, from cold cream to congratulatory telegrams, from artful wig to throat-soothing yogurt and herb tea. There are, however, some mementos that instantly mark this island of clutter as belonging to one, and only one, New York actress. Three inscribed certificates - from the Outer Critics' Circle, the Drama Desk and the Tony Awards - attest to the very special gifts of the inimitably named Swoosie Kurtz.

title: AH, MY SLIPPERS FIT
description: ARE you overweight? Ready to give your waistline another chance? To help you choose a favorite from the latest crop of diet books, I will divulge, for the first time ever, the essential secrets of an authentic diet book.

title: CHILDREN IN MOURNING
description: HOW IT FEELS WHEN A PARENT DIES By Jill Krementz. Illustrated. 110 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $9.95.

title: GOING AFTER HIGH TECH
description: RALEIGH, N.C. S IX decades ago, the textile industry swept southward from New England in search of cheap labor and a ready supply of cotton. In North Carolina it found a home.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Summit Season

title: CRIME
description: Jonathan Gash is the pseudonym of a London physician who specializes in tropical medicine. But his books have nothing to do with his profession: Their anti-hero is Lovejoy, a seedy but relatively honest antiques dealer. The first Lovejoy book, ''The Judas Pair,'' came out in 1977 and attracted a good deal of positive attention. Nor did the subsequent books, ''Gold by Gemini'' (1978) and ''The Grail Tree'' (1979), let anybody down.

title: WRITER'S PLIGHT: A LIBEL SUIT
description: SOMETIME during the summer of 1978, Philip Cioffari, a writer and Professor of English at William Paterson College in Wayne, started dreaming about his next short story.

title: Connecticut Housing; FOREING BUYERS EXERTING INFLUENCE
description: WHEN he went into the residential construction business 18 years ago, Felix Danziger of Stamford was not thinking about foreign buyers. There weren't any.

title: CROATIAN MOVEMENT LEADS TO CONVICTION OF 5 OVER BOMBINGS
description: Five men have been convicted and 10 others are awaiting trial as investigations of possible planned violence in the United States by demonstrators for Croatian independence from Yugoslavia continue in New York and other major cities in the United States.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: BRINGING A BIT OF VEGAS TO SOUTH AFRICA'S 'HOMELANDS'
description: who started from scratch and built a major hotel and tourism empire in 15 years - the Kubla Khan of southern Africa.

title: LONG ISLANDERS
description: ''THE days of 'happy talk' news are, I think, gone forever. The audience has become more sophisticated and demanding.'' The speaker is Don Dunphy Jr. of Westbury. That's right, the son of Don Dunphy, the announcer whose voice was once synonymous with boxing broadcasts. Since the apple doesn't fall far from the tree, it's not surprising that Don Jr., who grew up in Manhasset, should have fashioned a career in television.

title: Follow-Up on the News; REPLACING BOOKS
description: When Clarkson College in Potsdam, N.Y., dedicated its new Educational Resources Center as a ''library of the future'' in October 1980, bibliophiles were aghast. The $4 million center, which featured computers, videotape decks, slide projectors and a television studio, replaced a library building that housed only books.

title: FIVE STAR FLIGHT WINNER IN JERSEY
description: McKEE CITY, N.J., July 18 - Five Star Flight, known for his early speed, captured the $179,625 Jersey Derby at the Atlantic City Race Course tonight despite a slow start.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A NEW CHIEF AT CENSUS BUREAU
description: Last week's announcement of a new director for the Census Bureau may have come late, but to employees of the troubled agency it seemed much better than never.

title: Constance Bryden Married
description: The marriage of Constance Bryden, an executive secretary with Reader's Digest in New York, to James Rutherford White, an account executive with Grey Advertising, took place yesterday in Bloomsburg, Pa. The Rev. Jean Pinto performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Bryden 3d, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is a son of Frances B. White of Merrick, L.I., and John D. White.

title: Washington; WHAT TO DO ABOUT BEGIN?
description: On the eve of President Reagan's first meeting with the other leaders of the industrial world in Ottawa, and at the start of his first attempt to renew peace negotiations in the Middle East, Israel has bombed Palestinian guerrilla headquarters in a densely populated civilian area of Beirut in Lebanon.

title: No Headline
description: WHEN a raw wind sweeps across the sand dunes of Royal St. George's, the members like to say, ''One more sweater.'' But yesterday the golfers and the galleries were taking off their sweaters. They strolled around in their shirtsleeves almost as if they were at the Bob Hope Desert Classic or the Heritage Classic instead of at the British Open, where the rain is supposed to be horizontal, where the chill is supposed to require cashmeres and turtlenecks, where only the beer is supposed to be warm.

title: LITCHFIELD WORRIES ABOUT ITS VILLAGE 'HEART'
description: LITCHFIELD CLUSTERS of backpack-laden youths parked their bicycles on the Village Green near the spot where colonists melted a statue of King George III into ammunition to battle the British two centuries ago.

title: BYRNE HEARS 2 SIDES ON CASINOS RULE CHANGE
description: Governor Byrne, protesting recent legislative action calling on him to make decisions for state agencies in ''emergencies,'' spent this afternoon in the Assembly chamber of the State House hearing spokesmen for Atlantic City casinos testify that they were in imminent peril of closing if they were not allowed to make more money.

title: MICHAELLE MELTON ENGAGED TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Melton Jr. of Dorset, Vt., and Tequesta, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Michaelle Elizabeth Melton, to Thomas David Stott, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Tarsney Stott of North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Gabriella Plimpton Will Be Married Sept. 12 to a Foreign Service Officer S18.1
description: Announcement has been made by Jane Plimpton of Rockport, Me., and Herbert W. Plimpton of Boston of the engagement of their daughter, Gabriella Plimpton, to H. Kirkby Ressler, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Blair Ressler of Englewood, N.J., and Quogue, L.I.

title: SCHOOL PROGRAM TO COUNTER THE KLAN
description: ''WE feel that Connecticut is ready for recruitment,'' Bill Wilkinson, the national leader of the Ku Klux Klan, said last week. And in the last week, the efforts of the Klan to gain adherents to its philosophy of white supremacy and anti-Semitism were seen in several parts of the state.

title: Watts Decides To Join Ottawa
description: J.C. Watts, former University of Oklahoma quarterback, has reversed his field for the second time in six weeks and has decided to play for the Ottawa Rough Riders of the Canadian Football League.

title: Dominique Geer Wed To Robert J. Bordash
description: Dominique Amy Geer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Geer of New York and Brewster, N.Y., was married in Brewster yesterday to Robert J. Bordash, son of Mrs. Edward F. Clark of Rye, N.Y., and the late Michael A. Bordash. The Rev. Maurice Hammel of Pignans, France, uncle of the bride and a Reformed Church of France minister, performed the ceremony at the Geer home.

title: BALLET: LA SCALA TROUPE PRESENTS 4 PREMIERES
description: Friday night's performance of Milan's La Scala Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House gave members of the home team more of a chance to shine than earlier in the week.

title: The Region in Summary; CROWDED COUNTY JAILS FINALLY GET SOME ATTENTION
description: With room for 517 inmates and a population sometimes exceeding 900, overcrowding at the Nassau County jail has prompted protests by prisoners, lawsuits from their attorneys and orders from state and Federal officials to reduce the number of inmates at the facility in East Meadow. Last week, the lid on the sardine can was lifted a little.

title: THE NEW OLD TESTAMENT
description: THE ART OF BIBLICAL NARRATIVE By Robert Alter. 195 pp. New York: Basic Books. $13.95.

title: Ireland, '40: The I.R.A. And A Hunger Strike
description: On April 19, 1940, David Gray, the United States Minister to Ireland, wrote the following letter to President Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

title: No Headline
description: John Darnton was admirably incisive in explaining the Polish psyche. Yet, in explaining how the spirit of rebellion sprang up overnight, he lists only three contributing events.

title: GRAND CANYON
description: To the Editor:

title: A FRENCH F^ETE IN MISSOURI
description: On Aug. 8 and 9, Ste. Genevieve, Mo., will celebrate its French heritage with its 16th annual Jour de Fete. The weekend will be marked by flea markets, window displays, a quilt raffle, band concerts and traditional French food and song. In addition, there will be an Esplanade des Arts in which more than 200 craftsmen will participate in exhibitions and demonstrations of skills as diverse as carving wood and painting portraits, cutting silhouettes and making apple butter.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: IF ON A WINTER'S NIGHT A TRAVELER, by Italo Calvino. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95.) A novel about reading fiction, by the Italian master.

title: Eliza Halliday Frazer Bride of John Tomlin
description: Eliza Halliday Frazer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gilfillan Frazer Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., was married yesterday to John Frederick Tomlin, son of Henry B. Tomlin Jr. of Greenville, S.C., and the late Mrs. Tomlin. The Rev. James H. Blackwood performed the ceremony at St. Michael's of the Valley Episcopal Church in Rector, Pa.

title: UNHAPPILY FOR SOVIET, POLAND IS SOMETHING VERY SPECIAL
description: If there is one certainty in the Soviet position on Poland, it is that the Poles continue to present a series of agonizing dilemmas for the men in the Kremlin.

title: STILL A PROBLEM: CONDOMINIUMS VS. RENTAL UNITS
description: PROSPECTIVE renters may find renting an apartment in Connecticut increasingly difficult as existing rental units continue to be converted to condominiums. Federal studies indicate 366,000 rental units across the country were converted to condominiums between 1970 and 1979; approximately 1,100,000 rental units were expected to be converted nationwide during 1980-1985. In Connecticut, thousands of rental units have been converted in the last few years in urban, suburban and rural areas. Conversion is not a problem unto itself, however, but is only symptomatic of a problem affecting the entire housing market: a serious shortage of affordable housing.

title: FROM 300 B.C., A STARTLING CONCEPT IN CAMERAS
description: In 300 B.C., Euclid blinked one eye and noticed the obvious: An image seen by one eye is slightly different from the image seen by the other. Since then, people have been interested in, even obsessed with, reproducing the three-dimensional impression obtained when the brain combines two views of an object.

title: DAMAGE BY GYPSY MOTHS DIPS
description: AS the temperature soared into the 90's and the hottest topic of conversation became the debilitating heat, rarely a mention of an even more disagreeable summer phenomenon, Porthetria dispar - the gypsy moth - was heard on the Island.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE FINGER LAKES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JANE DIECKMANN is a writer and editor who lives in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: CAREY SIGNS 3 BILLS DESIGNED TO HELP HORSE RACING
description: Governor Carey today signed three bills designed to assist New York's ailing racing industry. The bills would reduce the state's ''takeout'' - the percentage it receives from the betting - at the New York Racing Association Tracks. They would also offer incentives for horse breeding in the state and cut state taxes on racing.

title: SCARSDALE'S EFFORTS TO ATTRACT BLACKS
description: "SCARSDALE had an aura about it that made me afraid to drive into the place," a black woman confided recently at a party. Since then she has moved to Scarsdale at the invitation of a group of white residents, who not only wanted more minorities, mainly blacks, to share the good life of Scarsdale, but also were willing to pay money to have them come.

title: THEATER, UNIVERSITY TO JOIN FORCES
description: AN unusual arrangement between a professional theater and a university will go into operation this fall, when Stamford's Hartman Theater begins building its scenery at Boston University, becomes involved in the academic programs of the theater arts school and presents two-week runs of all its productions at the university theater prior to regular four-week engagements in Stamford.

title: About Westchester
description: NEW ROCHELLE BEFORE there were color televisions in every other home, before the unusual and the strange were trumpeted on the pages of a dozen tabloids, there was the circus.

title: BO DEREK TAKES TO THE JUNGLE TO BRING 'TARZAN' BACK ALIVE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- David Lewin is a London based writer who frequently reports on cultural events. By DAVID LEWIN

title: Offshore Title Format Revised
description: The Offshore Commission of the American Power Boat Association has accepted a new format for the 1981 Imperial Industries world championship.

title: EFFECTS OF 204TH LEGISLATURE ON THE COUNTY
description: ALTHOUGH the New York State Legislature recessed a week ago Friday, it is expected to return to Albany in two weeks to complete some unfinished business, specifically a bill to give $79 million in aid to small cities, including $10 million for Yonkers to help the city balance its budget and prevent layoffs.

title: JOHN MULDOWNEY IS AIMING TO FOLLOW HIS MOTHER'S LEAD
description: More than anything else, John Muldowney wants to follow in his mother's footsteps - or tire tracks, really. He is the son of Shirley Muldowney, who, in the seven-year history of the National Hot Rod Association championship circuit, is the only driver who has twice won the Winston world title of drag racing. He wants a chance to drive 2,500-horsepower, 250-mile-an-hour cars, the kind in which she competes.

title: Injured Greg Polis Sues Capitals for $5 Million
description: Greg Polis, a former forward for the Washington Capitals, has filed a $5 million breach-of-contract lawsuit charging that Abe Pollin, the team owner, failed to provide competent medical treatment of Polis's injured knee.

title: ON PGA TOUR, BREAKING EVEN IS AS CRUCIAL AS BREAKING PAR
description: THAT golf professionals are entirely on their own, even to the purchase of a soft drink from the concession stand, explains why their community has no sympathy for striking baseball players. A golfer is an independent entrepreneur who makes and pays for his own travel arrangements. There is no salary, no guaranteed purse. If he fails to qualify on Monday, he has spent money and lost a week without earning a dime. If he makes the field but misses Friday's 36-hole cut, he has spent more money and time, and still not earned a dime. And even if he makes it through to the final round Sunday, he could come out with less than $1,000 in earnings.

title: ...NOR OIL STUDIES
description: even telling - that he chose to castigate the Ford Foundation and the Harvard energy reports and not the more traditional forecasters, who missed the future by an even wider margin.

title: A BEAUTY WINNER WITH 'POSITIVITY'
description: Pamela Jenks has had quite a year. First she became Miss Black Personality of 1980 and then Miss Black America of Boston and now she is Miss Black America of 1981, pledged to carry the Oath of Positivity across the length and breadth of this land.

title: MEETING THE PRESIDENT ON URBAN RENEWAL
description: THERE have been many events in my years as a public official that have brought excitement and feelings of pride, but nothing that will top the pleasure of meeting with President Reagan and Vice President Bush at the White House last month.

title: Art; WAITING FOR THE SUN TO WORK ON 'LEO'
description: PURCHASE THE environmental sculptor Roger Hendricks reports that his piece ''Leo'' lighted up on schedule a week ago last Saturday in its meadow at the State University College here. The parade it was meant to coincide with, however, was late. This turned out to be a bonus, for the delay enabled visitors to observe the installation undistracted by the paraders, who were inaugurating Pepsico's ''Summerfare '81.'' As it was, the artist had cause to hold his breath when the elephants and heavily costumed dancers came close to his work - one wayward pachyderm (or performer) could have easily spoiled it.

title: The Nation in Summary; STATUS QUO IN MOBILE
description: For the third time since 1965, Mobile, Ala. has decided that a form of government that was good enough for 1911 is good enough for now. Last week's vote, however, is far from the last airing of the issue.

title: 18 FOOD PLACES CALLES HEALTH CODE VIOLATORS
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 18 food establishments that it said had violated the health code. The department also named one restaurant that had been closed for failing to correct earlier violatio VIOLATIONS La Caridad, 2199 Broadway.

title: Patricia Hamilton to Be Wed Sept 27 To Steven E. Tisch, Movie Producer
description: Mr. and Mrs. William B. Keast of New York and Bel Air, Calif., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Keast Hamilton, to Steven Elliot Tisch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Preston Robert Tisch of New York and Rye, N.Y.

title: Michael G. Maher And Reid Peters To Wed Sept. 19
description: The engagement of Jean Reid Peters to Michael G. Maher has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Peters of Manhasset, L.I., father and stepmother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Maher, also of Manhasset.

title: Film View; UNREAL HEROES FOR THE 80'S
description: The superheroes of this summer's movies have accomplished some remarkable feats, not the least of which is temporarily banishing the memory of what movie heroism used to be. Only a few years ago, we watched loner after loner battle the system, proving that one man could make a difference and fight injustice. Now we're watching comic book characters single-handedly save the world from utter destruction. Why have we passed so emphatically from ''Serpico'' to ''Superman''? The answer isn't particularly encouraging.

title: A TOAST
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TREASURES OF XIAN
description: To the Editor:

title: BIDDING UP
description: Rapid-fire bidding for Conoco Inc., the nation's ninth largest oil company, intensified with a cash-and-stock bid valued at more than $7.7 billion from Mobil, the second-largest in oil.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: New styles in romance. ''There's no place closer to the American heartland than Kansas City - which is why market researchers so often use it to gauge changing fashions in popular taste.'' Vivien Lee Jennings, who told us this, has reason to feel that way -she is president of Rainy Day Books, a five-store chain based in Fairway, Kan., a suburb of Kansas City. Partly for business, partly for pleasure, Mrs. Jennings reads 50 books a week, most of them ''romance novels,'' stories centering on the relationship of a man and a woman told from the woman's point of view, and discusses them with customers in her stores. She reports her findings in a nationally circulated weekly newsletter called Boy Meets Girl.

title: CINDY GRAHAM, STEVEN L. LANDIS TO MARRY SEPT. 12
description: The engagement of Cynthia Lynn Graham, daughter of Mrs. Robert L. Graham of St. Louis and the late Dr. Graham, to Steven Alan Landis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark L. Landis of Great Barrington, Mass., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother.

title: MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: For years, I had avoided going to China. It is possible, even likely, that the Chinese Government and masses were not aware of this deprivation.

title: Colts Trade Fred Cook to Redskins
description: Fred Cook, defensive end and a free agent, has been traded to the Washington Redskins for draft choices, the Baltimore Colts said today.

title: Notes
description: AT 40,253 MILES, THE INTERSTATE HIGHWAY SYSTEM IS 95 PERCENT COMPLETE By John Brannon Albright

title: GARDEN WALKS IN NEWPORT
description: From now to mid-September six of the seven historic houses owned and operated by the Preservation Society of Newport County in Rhode Island are remaining open until 8 o'clock on different nights of the week, affording visitors an opportunity to walk through the landscaped grounds at a time of the year, when, according to a society spokesman, they are ''at their best.''

title: Fans Have Right To Be Heard
description: To the Sports Editor: The article by Peter Seitz (''The Fans' 'Rights' Are Overstated,'' The New York Times, July 5) entirely misses the point. It is precisely because of the fact that baseball is not an essential service that the fans' rights and wishes should be the foremost consideration.

title: Shooting A Wedding
description: Any amateur photographer who is asked to take pictures at a wedding of a friend or relative should consider the ramifications of such a decision before agreeing to take on the task. Weddings are unique events that cannot be redone if something goes wrong, and the photographer has the responsibility of getting everything properly exposed and appealingly posed.

title: Miss McVey Bride Of J.R. Thomas Jr.
description: Cecilia Maria McVey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Don Carr McVey of Warren, N.J., was married there yesterday to Joseph R. Thomas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas of Union, N.J. Msgr. Richard Behl performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at Our Lady of the Mount Roman Catholic Church.

title: IN N.Y., CUTS AND COMPLICATIONS
description: ALBANY WHAT will happen to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the bulk of President Reagan's budget cuts take effect in October? ''Chaos is a good term,'' said Brad Johnson, the director of Governor Carey's Washington office. His boss expressed similar feelings last week. ''We'll have problems,'' the Governor told reporters, predicting that ''classes of people like the elderly'' will ''feel the crunch'' and so will local governments across the state.

title: Cosmos Must Win In Final Cup Game
description: The mission of the Cosmos and the Seattle Sounders in tonight's deciding game of the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup at Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands is clear and simple. The Cosmos must win and all the Sounders need is a tie.

title: ANDREW M. GREELEY
description: ''The Cardinal Sins,'' the current fiction best seller by the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley, is the author's first novel but just one of some 80 books he has written on theology, sociology and popular history during the past two decades. ''I suppose I have the Irish weakness for words gone wild,'' Father Greeley confessed in a recent telephone conversation. ''Besides, if you're celibate you have to do something.''

title: Barbara A. Bordeman Wed to C. J. Kearney
description: Barbara Anne Bordeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Bordeman of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to Christopher Joseph Kearney, son of Mrs. Edward F. Kearney also of Manhasset, and the late Mr. Kearney. The Rev. John Denniston performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: TRADING WITH THE KREMLIN: WHAT RULES SHOULD APPLY?
description: AMONG the questions on the United States' agenda for this week's Ottawa summit is European and Japanese sentiment about East-West trade - a matter on which President Reagan is said to have decided only last week not to push too hard. The National Security Council has been bitterly divided on the subject, and on whether to revoke the licence the Carter Administration issued Caterpillar Tractor to sell to the Soviet Union pipelaying equipment for a natural gas pipeline to Western Europe. Clyde H. Farnsworth, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, talked recently with Lawrence J. Brady, Assistant Secretary of

title: ART
description: This year and for exactly 23 past, the A.A.A. Galleries at 663 Fifth Avenue (at 52nd Street) has mounted a summer exhibition of Old Master prints. As the A.A.A. Galleries are invisible from the street and have no shingle to hang out, not every summer visitor to New York may know that they have one of the largest stocks of prints, old and new, in the country.

title: Chess; WHEN A REFUGE DOESN'T PAN OUT
description: The legendary drawing bishops-of-opposite-color is showing itself more and more to be based on the wishful thinking of a player losing the game rather than on fact. It is true that in various simple endgames where the defender is a pawn down but there are no other pieces on the board, bishops that can never confront each other often guarantee a draw, yet in a myriad divergent situations, look out for trouble.

title: TOTALITARIANISM HAS THE EDGE IN REPREHENSIBILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Careful Shopper; Bally Discounting Discontinued Styles
description: All Bally of Switzerland discontinued styles, overruns, closeouts and samples are discounted at the manufacturer's first United States outlet, opened last month at the $5 million world corporate headquarters and computerized distribution center in New Rochelle.

title: POLISH PARTY CONGRESS IS BOTH ASTONISHING AND DISAPPOINTING
description: Midway through last week's session of the extraordinary congress of the Polish Communist Party, Mieczyslaw Rakowski, the party's most prominent liberal, delivered an impassioned plea for liberalization and reform. There was no other way except ''renewal,'' he told the 1,955 delegates, or the country would become steeped in a bloodbath. As the Deputy Prime Minister stepped down from the podium to a thunderous ovation, a visiting American journalist watching it all on closed-circuit television was moved by the sight of a man trying to sway a vast congregation to a position of conscience. ''Incredible!,'' he exclaimed. ''Absolutely incredible! That was Teddy Kennedy speaking to the Democratic convention.''

title: Miss Dodge, Wheaton '81, Has Nuptials
description: Alexandra Talbot Dodge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Longstreth Dodge of Newtown Square, Pa., was married yesterday to Mark Joseph Panarese, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Gerard Panarese of Milton, Mass. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: A TOWN GOING TO THE DOGS
description: IF you drive casually through our neighborhood, you will be struck by its attractive tree-studded lawns, neat houses and infinite variety of birdcalls. One can glimpse the scarlet of the cardinals, flitting here and there, and on a small pond there are ducks and geese. A beautiful, old weathered barn stands on the edge of the pond, motif No. 1 of Ridgefield, Conn., and probably the most photographed and painted building in this town.

title: IT'S JUST AS HE LEFT IT
description: ''Do you give students equal time?'' asked David H. Eisenberg of Westbury, Adelphi '81, after reading ''Little Touches That Say She's Back'' (Opinion Page), a father's views on his daughter's life style at home during summer vacation from college. By DAVID H. EISENBERG

title: CLARIFYING SOME MIXED SIGNALS ON ANTITRUST LAW
description: When officials from the antitrust division of the Justice Department met with staff attorneys last week, they had to correct some misunderstandings about the Reagan Administration's antitrust policy.

title: BONN HONORS HELEN WOLFF FOR ISSUING TRANSLATIONS
description: The 1981 Inter Nationes Award for Literature and the Arts has been given by West Germany to Helen Wolff in recognition of her contribution in bringing translations of German works to readers in the United States.

title: NO TRUCE IN WAR ON GYPSY MOTHS
description: THIS year's gypsy moth devastation is coming to an end or is over, depending upon when the young caterpillars that have been attacking the leaves mature, form pupae and emerge as moths. But next year's attack is in the early stages - and now is the time that homeowners can take steps to at least alleviate its impact.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: ALBERT EINSTEIN'S SPECIAL THEORY OF RELATIVITY Emergence (1905) and Early Interpretation (1905-1911). By Arthur I. Miller. Illustrated. 466 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley. Cloth, $39.50. Paper, $27.50. REALITY AND SCIENTIFIC TRUTH Discussions with Einstein, von Laue and Planck. By Ilse Rosenthal-Schneider. Illustrated. 148 pp. Detroit: Wayne State University Press. $13.95.

title: THE SHERRIES OF SPAIN
description: he setting was an elegant bar in a popular restaurant, with lots of young adults milling around, obviously people on the way up, the kind always depicted as well dressed and smiling in television commercials, the ones who intuitively seem to know precisely what to drink.

title: A CANOE ADVENTURE IN WISCONSIN'S WILDS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JERRY L. KLEIN is a graduate student at Washington University in St. Louis. By JERRY L.KLEIN

title: Unfair Ball
description: To the Sports Editor: I yield to none in my regard for Pete Rose, even as he threatens the records of some of my earlier heroes. But Joseph Durso's report (''Pete Rose's Race Against Time,'' The New York Times, July 12), suggesting that a long strike threatens his attempt to overtake Ty Cobb's hit record (561 away), doesn't play fair.

title: New Jersey Housing; STRONG HOUSING POLICY IS URGED
description: ''AS POLITICIANS, we generally have a very short attention span,'' Assemblywoman Leanna Brown of Chatham said recently. ''But we were awake every blessed minute of those hearings.''

title: PEE WEE REESE NIGHT AT EBBETS FIELD
description: A RECENT= item in the news told of a baseball fan who came to admire Pee Wee Reese when the guy's daughter read ''The Boys of Summer,'' in which Roger Kahn revisits the Dodgers of the early 1950's whom he knew when they played in Brooklyn.

title: Other World Events; Sichuan Floods Sweep Yangtze
description: Flooding in the Yangtze River valley in China's Sichuan Province last week reached the highest levels since 1905 and preliminary reports indicated several thousand people had been killed.

title: HAROLD URIS RECOLLECTS WITH PRIDE
description: Between World War II and 1971 the Uris Buildings Corporation put up over 13 million square feet of office space in Manhattan - more than all the office space built in Boston or Philadelphia during that time. The Uris brothers, Harold and Percy, built one of the largest private office buildings in the world, at 55 Water Street, and they exercised a lasting effect on the development of midtown as well.

title: PANEL VOTES TO ADMONISH A NEW YORK JUSTICE
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct said yesterday that a State Supreme Court justice ''created an appearance of impropriety'' by accepting $879.60 in reductions on rooms and meals at Caribbean hotels that were arranged by a longtime friend who had frequent business dealings with the court.

title: VOLUNTEERISM SEEKS TO BROADEN EFFORTS
description: VOLUNTEER and paid staff leaders of the American Volunteer Community met at Yale University recently to examine in depth the theme ''Citizen Action for a Changing World.'' The annual conference, held for the first time in the Northeast, was sponsored by Volunteer, the National Center for Citizen Involvement, based in Washington and Boulder, Colo.

title: HOUSE RENTAL MARKET THRIVES
description: room Southampton mansion with an indoor swimming pool and surrounded by six acres of land for rent during the summer for $100,000.

title: ROAD SHOW
description: New York's Mayor Koch seems to be giving up talk for letter writing. He has been mailing old questions about the Westway project to Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis. And predictably, he is receiving back familiar answers.

title: Kathryne Ford Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Lee Ford Jr. of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Kathryne Elizabeth Ford, to David Wilkinson Carr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carr of Charlottesville, Va. An Aug. 29 wedding is planned.

title: NO TRUCE IN WAR ON MOTHS
description: THIS year's gypsy moth devastation is coming to an end or is over, depending upon when the young caterpillars that have been attacking the leaves mature, form pupae and emerge as moths.

title: Ana Hernandez Becomes a Bride
description: Ana Margarita Hernandez and Modesto Alex Maidique were married yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Octavio Cisneros, director of the Spanish Apostolate, Diocese of Brooklyn, performed the ceremony.

title: Stage View; BROADWAY CAN LIVE WITHOUT TV
description: The Greek theater had its gods and the Elizabethans had their kings, but who, pray tell, does our theater celebrate? If the past season is any indication, our cosmic icons include the following, all of whom were at least mentioned, sometimes personified and occasionally worshiped in new plays and musicals: Miss America, Marie Osmond, June Lockhart, Bob Newhart, Barbara Walters and Merv Griffin. Perhaps that's how it should be. If culture inevitably reflects the society that spawns it, surely it must, these days, reflect the primacy of television in American life. If we don't have a Zeus or a Henry V to look up to, did the Greeks and Elizabethans have a Johnny Carson?

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; RESIST THE POWER OF SUGGESTION
description: While police departments nationwide seem entranced by hypnosis as a memory aid for witnesses, New Jersey's Supreme Court last week broke the spell. The court ruled that while testimony from a hypnotized witness could be used in a criminal case, specific guidelines must be followed.

title: The Nation in Summary; QUESTIONS FOLLOW HOTEL DISASTER
description: The scene - two of three concrete ''skybridges'' arching a hotel atrium, crashing down onto a jammed dance floor - is the stuff of summertime disaster movies. Friday evening, in the new Hyatt Regency Hotel in Kansas City, Mo., it was not film but fact.

title: CLOTHES STORE FOR SHORT MEN
description: In the beginning, Joe De Filippis considered calling his clothing shop for men 5 feet 8 inches and under the Short Stop, the Small Shop or the Little Store. One tall wiseacre even suggested the Masculine Munchkin. But the moment Mr. De Filippis, who is 5 feet 5 inches tall, came up with the Cadet General Store Inc., he knew he had hit upon the ideal name for the establishment, which recently opened in Greenwich Village at 523 Hudson Street.

title: TYING PENSIONS TO PRICES
description: It is an oft-heard complaint - inflation eating away at the standard of living of retirees who are dependent on pensions. Some companies have tried to solve the problem with ad hoc increases in pension benefits, but the costs of such improvements can quickly become prohibitive.

title: RIOT PREVENTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Follow-Up on the News; BAA, BAA MOWER
description: ''There are a lot of people out there who are like me, who hate cutting the grass,'' Louis R. Valente said. Mr. Valente, a former New York transit policeman turned sheep raiser in Cornwallville, N.Y., offered last April to rent a sheep for the summer to anyone who wanted an automatic lawnmower. The news account gave the rental fee as $35.

title: AN ART OF THE MOMENT
description: THE PASSION FOR JAZZ By Leonard Feather. Illustrated. 208 pp. New York: Horizon Press. $9.95. NIGHT CREATURE A Journal of Jazz, 1975-1980. By Whitney Balliett. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $15.95. RIDING ON A BLUE NOTE Jazz and American Pop. By Gary Giddins. 313 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $16.95.

title: COUNTDOWN IS ON FOR THE GYPSY MOTH
description: THIS year's gypsy moth devastation is coming to an end or is over, depending upon when the young caterpillars that have been attacking the leaves mature, form pupae and emerge as moths. But next year's attack is in the early stages - and now is the time that homeowners can take steps to at least alleviate its impact.

title: MORE THAN FRUIT FLIES ARE CLOUDING BROWN'S FUTURE
description: Jerry Brown, who wants to win a seat in the United States Senate next year, didn't need an infestation of Mediterranean fruit flies, which last week showed signs of spreading. And he could have done without the charges from the California Fair Political Practices Commission that members of his staff concealed, altered and destroyed evidence in an investigation of charges that Governor Brown had used state funds for his personal political purposes.

title: Major News in Summary; TROUBLE AT THE TOP FOR C.I.A.
description: To his friends, Max C. Hugel was shrewd and brash enough to be a Central Intelligence Agency spymaster, but to his critics he was meant to self-destruct. Last week he did.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; F.D.A. APPROVES A COMPETITOR FOR SACCHARIN
description: Life was distinctly sweet and potentially fattening for the purse of G.D. Searle & Company of Skokie, Ill., last week. The Food and Drug Administration approved the company's new sugar substitute for use in dry food products, including cereals and instant tea.

title: Art; ARRESTING SCULPTURE DOTS THE CORPORATE LANDSCAPE
description: PARSIPPANY SUMMER is the season for outdoor sculpture exhibitions, and residents of this area who like contemporary art have a collection of distinguished and arresting works waiting for them through Aug. 18.

title: No Headline
description: To the Sports Editor: Peter Seitz claims that baseball fans have no ''rights'' to an end of the strike of major league baseball players. The American Baseball Fans Association, speaking for all baseball fans, disagrees. Mr. Seitz recognizes that ''baseball is much more than a sport'' and that ''it is a mythology for the American people.''

title: Major News in Summary; COMPASS NEEDLES FLICKER IN OTTAWA
description: President Reagan is taking a breather, of sorts, from his preoccupation with domestic economic policy to hear first hand about its impact on other major non-Communist nations.

title: AN ALLIANCE OF SKEPTICS
description: Having won over most of the domestic opposition, Ronald Reagan now takes his economic magic show before the allies, at his first industrial summit in Ottawa.

title: Sound; NEW PROCESS SPEEDS SIGHT AND SOUND
description: Time has been hailed by both poets and economists as our ultimate possession - the only thing that truly belongs to us. Given the intensely personal aspect of time, individuality is often expressed in the private tempo of our lives. Some hanker for a bucolic pace set by the seasons rather than the clock; for others, things just can't move fast enough. They seem driven by the need to concentrate experience, as if by cramming more into each minute they could augment the content of their days.

title: Topics; STAND FIRM SIT UP; PINELANDS POLITICS; Pinelands Politics
description: After wavering on his commitment to the preservation of 1.1 million acres of pine barrens in southern New Jersey, Governor Byrne now says he is ''totally opposed'' to a bill aimed at allowing increased development.

title: Susan Hardwick Is Wed in Capital
description: Susan Bohannon Hardwicke and Leonard Lee Wouters were married yesterday in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Robert F. Waggener performed the ceremony.

title: KYLE NELSON IS BETHROTHED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth W. Nelson of Emerson Hill, S.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kyle Carolyn Nelson, to Anthony Lawrence Galante, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Galante of Todt Hill, S.I. A September wedding is planned excitingly danced.

title: Mailbox; Now Let's Hear From Educators
description: To the Sports Editor: Hurrah for Judge Phillip Baiamonte, who has expressed in the clearest of manners the case of the professional ''amateur'' athlete (''A Judgment on College Sports,'' The New York Times, July 12, a transcript of the judge's remarks at the sentencing of Norm Ellenberger).

title: Mary S. Metz Is Betrothed
description: The Rev. Ronald Irwin Metz and Mrs. Metz of Washington and Seal Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Selden Metz, to James Frederick Evans 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans Jr. of Cazenovia, N.Y.

title: Antiques; 2 WEEKEND SHOWS: A COLLECTOR'S TREAT
description: THE inveterate antique collector can enjoy the best of two summer show worlds this weekend - shopping both indoors and out of doors - by visiting the Essex Antiques Show in that riverport village and the Nathan Hale Antiques Festival at the patriot's 18th-century homestead in Coventry. Both shows are for the benefit of historical society house-museums.

title: DROPPING OF GRAND PRIX PERPLEXES WATKINS GLEN
description: Once a year for more than a generation, the world's most famous drivers gathered at this sleepy Finger Lakes hamlet to put their million-dollar Grand Prix racing cars through the twists and turns of a 3.4-mile-long race course. They were cheered on by hundreds of thousands of fans, and the race put Watkins Glen on the map.

title: A CHILD OF THE STATE
description: IN THE BELLY OF THE BEAST Letters from Prison. By Jack Henry Abbott. Introduction by Norman Mailer. 166 pp. New York: Random House. $11.95.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: AT the end of a poem about great battles, Carl Sandburg wrote, ''I am the grass. I cover all.'' As I write this, the clatter and clank of Island-wide battles are sounding to the left, the right, the front and the rear of me. Summer is here, and the voice of the power mower is heard in the land.

title: Hechizado Takes Brooklyn by 4 Lengths
description: Hechizado, an Argentine-bred distance specialist who raced in Panama until this spring, led from the start yesterday and scored an upset in the $230,500 Brooklyn Handicap before a crowd of 36,872 at Belmont Park.

title: IMAGININGS OF A NEW LIFE
description: MEMOIRS OF AN ANTI-SEMITE By Gregor von Rezzori. 287 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: HYDRAULIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Marianne Bergan Wed To Steven O. Cordier
description: Marianne Bergan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis T. Bergan of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven O. Cordier, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Cordier of Racine, Wis. The Rev. John J. Denniston performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: 201-Yacht Fleet Opens Larchmont Race Week
description: One of the largest one-design fleets in recent years, with 201 sailboats competing in 10 classes, opened the 83d annual Larchmont Race Week today on Long Island Sound.

title: STATE OPPOSING PLAN TO AMEND AIR ACT
description: ABOUT a dozen environmental and civic organizations in New Jersey, as well as the state's Department of Environmental Protection, have joined a nationwide campaign to oppose proposed Congressional amendments to the Federal Clean Air Act.

title: UNCERTAINTY OVER JOBS
description: Lags in reporting changes in how small businesses are coping with high interest rates have some analysts worried that official Government employment statistics may be overstated.

title: No Headline
description: Readers may be interested in a more elaborate version of the elephant story recounted in the article on Poland. As a very young refugee from Vienna, I grew up with this story, which was attributed by my family to Paderewski.

title: CREATIVE FOOD SERVED ELEGANTLY
description: LAST year, Carol's, in Southampton, changed chefs early in the season and then, with Richard Hegge in the kitchen, went on to startle diners with some of the most creative, beautifully presented and delectable food in the Hamptons. This season, Mr. Hegge is attempting to scale even more ambitious gastronomical heights.

title: No Headline
description: It is true that inverse Polish snobbishness frequently points out shortcomings in Polish material accomplishments.

title: REAGAN'S FRIENDS
description: Having whipped the Democrats without breaking a sweat, President Reagan must now look forward to coping with his hottest friends. This could be a heavy struggle. Coping with friends often is.

title: Salmon Traveling In Political Circles
description: AFISH prized by Indians who live along its natal streams, by poor and wealthy anglers, by heads of state, by all, indeed, who appreciate superb table fare and splendid fighting qualities, the Atlantic salmon remains sorely in need of help.

title: No Headline
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Schratwieser of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Louise Schratwieser, to Joseph Michael Roberts 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts Jr. of Mountain Lakes, N.J. An October wedding is planned. Miss Schratwieser is a systems analyst with Decision Data Inc. in Washington. Her fiance is an associate with the Washington law firm of Grove, Jackiewicz, Gilliam & Cobert.

title: Practical Traveler; AIRLINE PACTS EASING TRAVEL FACE CHALLENGE
description: The day may be approaching when many amenities that air travelers have taken for granted decrease sharply and in some cases disappear. For example, on some trips it may no longer be possible:

title: The Nation in Summary; SETTLEMENT IN SAN JOSE
description: An extraordinary strike of city workers, believed to be the first in the nation over comparable pay for women, ended last week in San Jose, Calif. City Hall and municipal employees approved a $5 million agreement that includes $1.5 million to help close a salary gap between men and women, plus funds for 15.5 percent general raises over two years. The strike began after a study underwritten by City Hall found that jobs dominated by men pay more than comparable work done by women and after union and city negotiators couldn't agree on a remedy.

title: FLAUNTING FLAMBOYANCE
description: The average, well-appointed, modern apartment is a triumph of optimism over odds. Working within a stultifying shell, the intrepid designer must infuse drama, all the while taking care not to overwhelm.

title: Molly Reading Is Married To Thomas Louis Saeli
description: Molly Ann Reading, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Persell Reading of Jamestown, N.Y., was married in the First United Methodist Church there yesterday to Thomas Louis Saeli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Frank Saeli of Williamsville, N.Y. The Rev. Roland L. Archer and the Rev. John Heffernan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Dining Out; INVENTION IS THE PHILOSOPHY
description: INSTALLED in a remodeled brown clapboard house next to the railroad tracks in Chappaqua, The Ordinary has a bright, simple charm with its wide pine floorboards, hanging greenery, starched white-onburgundy linen and remarkable though nonfunctioning espresso machine.

title: LEAD POISONING CONTROL DRIVE BEGINS IN BROOKLYN
description: The day began slowly for Lenny Vaughn, director of community relations for the City Health Department's lead poison control program. For 20 minutes, he paced up and down Lexington Avenue between Throop and Tompkins Avenues in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, with a bull horn, imploring parents in deteriorating housing to bring their children out to be tested.

title: THE MONEY SUPPLY TAKES A SURPRISE JUMP
description: The nation's money supply shot up by $6.9 billion in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve reported Friday. The report of the unexpectedly large rise prompted a sharp jump in both short- and long-term interest rates. Three-month Treasury bill rates increased more than 0.25 percent to 14.82 percent, and yields on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 13.58 percent from 13.4 percent.

title: Last Week's Tally of the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: TEAMSTER HOUSING PLAN FACING REJECTION
description: thick plan being proposed here depicts Hampton Hills, a development of 900 town houses, 500 garden apartments, 400 apartments for the elderly and 200 single-family homes, all clustered near a new hotel and convention center and a shopping plaza. The entire development, with a 150-acre golf course, would stand atop what planning studies have identified as the largest reservoir of pure underground water left on the Island.

title: HOUSES GET TWO MASTERS, TWO MASTER BEDROOMS
description: Two years ago David Walton and Robert Young, both single and in the market for homes, decided to pool their resources and share the cost of buying a house. They settled on a model in the new Westbury, L.I., development, The Hamlet.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; WHO PAYS WHEN DEMOCRACY FAILS?
description: Details of World War II lose clarity as history fades and revisionist interpretations abound. But victims have a habit of remembering and last week, nearly 40 years after the internment of 110,000 Japanese-Americans in Government relocation centers, a Federal commission began hearings in Washington to establish why internment was ordered and to decide whether compensation was due its survivors and their descendants.

title: Index; International
description: British riots prophesied by rock bands for years 3 In Britain, the police begin seri- ous soul-searching 3 15,000 attack police at British Em- bassy in Dublin 4 Nomination for Irish ambassador in trouble 5 Around the World 6 Leader says Marshall Islands may seek full independence 7 C.I.A. chief's woes stir old concerns 9 Few committments expected at Ottawa summit meeting 11 Government/Politics Democrat, despite party's disfa- vor, plays key budget role 14 Abuses of Freedom of Informa- tion Act charged 16 Senate expected to defeat plan to cut windfall oil profits tax 17 Panel admonishes justice for ac- cepting reduced hotel rates 20 Former Interior Secretary An- drus assails policies of Watt 23 Carey signs three bills to assist the horse racing industry 27 Votes in Congress 37 General Around the Nation 22 Michigan family adjusting to life in Dallas 22 Specific hotel, not atrium design, scrutinized in disaster 24 Guild for blind seeks to ''reinte- grate'' the handicapped 30 5 in Croatian movement con- victed of bombing 32 Jersey expects bumper crops of wheat and feed-corn 32 Police say plastic shields for tell- ers help cut bank holdups 32 Dropping of Grand Prix per- plexes Watkins Glen 34 Staff of Oregon weekly hampered by libel suits 35 City opens intensive lead-poison control drive in Brooklyn 39 Arts/Entertainment Marlene Verplanck, pop singer, at Marty's 39 The Moody Blues rock at Madison Square Garden 39 La Scala Opera Ballet presents 4 premieres 40 Mostly Mozart concert sticks to the basics 40 Glenn Branca offers his rock Symphony No. 1 40 American Dance Festival looks back on vaudeville 40 Style A beauty winner with ''positivi- ty'' 41 A clothes store for short men 41 Obituaries Mortimer Heineman, advertising executive 26

title: JERSEY ANTICIPATING ITS BIGGEST HARVESTS OF WHEAT AND CORN
description: New Jersey is expecting bumper crops of wheat and feed corn this year, largely as a result of farmers' switching from soybeans for fear of drought and low soybean prices.

title: Philip Lotz, Bank Officer, Marries Wendy Darling
description: Wendy Darling and Philip Lotz were married yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church in Huntington, L.I. The bride's uncle, the Rev. Arthur R. Boone, assisted by the Rev. P.M. Renzulli, performed the ceremony.

title: ECUMENICAL BANK GIVES NEEDY LOANS
description: While it is customary for churches to give to the needy, an ecumenical version of the World Bank is now encouraging denominations and religious groups to invest in the poor.

title: DEPALMA: 'I'M MUCH MORE OF A ROMANTIC THAN HITCHCOCK'
description: The opening sequence of the new film ''Blow Out'' is immediately recognizable as the work of Brian De Palma: a couple, entwined in each other's arms on the floor, are watched through a window by a man, who, in turn, is watched by another figure, a figure wielding a knife. The knife comes down, and the killer moves on to his next victim, a girl who is taking a shower. The sequence is intended as something of a self-parody - most pointedly, of the director's previous movie, ''Dressed to Kill'' - but it is also an ironic distillation of motifs dominant in Mr. De Palma's recent work, namely illicit sex, voyeurism and violent murder, all served up with expressionistic horror.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 19, 1981
description: International A Palestinian quarter was in ruins in Beirut after the Israeli bombing that killed at least 300 people and injured about 800 others. The target of the Israeli planes was two headquarters of guerrilla organizations. Rescue crews continued to search for bodies in the rubble of destroyed apartment houses. Militiamen occasionally fired rifles into the air to break up the congestion caused by curious passers-by. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: WOMEN'S SHELTER GETS AID
description: DESPITE the State Legislature's failure to enact the aid package that the city of Yonkers says it desperately needs, good news arrived from the Federal Government last week.

title: AN EXPERIMENT OF WOMEN, 1893
description: THE FAIR WOMEN The Story of the Woman's Building, World's Columbian Exposition, Chicago 1893. By Jeanne Madeline Weimann. Illustrated. 611 pp. Chicago: Academy Chicago. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: F.C. Maynard 3d Will Wed Miss Stone
description: The engagement of Sarah Gunnison Stone to Frederick Charles Maynard 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Stone Jr. of Middletown and Madison, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maynard Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., and Weekapaug, R.I.

title: No Headline
description: Until the philosophers and mathematicians whose works (Aristotle's ''Physics'' and ''Metaphysics;'' Euclid's ''Elements'') have virtually molded the course of modern scientific thought are brought into the fray, the creationists will continue to further their cause. They may well be able to clothe their theory in the terms of modern science, but they will find it more difficult to justify themselves using the language of Aristotle. MELINDA ROONEY, New Castle, Del.

title: BRITISH GRAND RPIX TO WATSON
description: John Watson of Britain, driving a McLaren, took the lead seven laps from the finish and won the British Grand Prix today.

title: HOW ENGLISH ARTISTS HAVE COME TO VIEW NEW YORK
description: No one can live in New York as a practicing critic of art and not know that ours is the city where a great many English painters and sculptors most want to be. Letters, telephone calls and visits from intermediaries - all tell the same tale.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: DANCE Dance events turn up in many places and in many forms in the summer. Certainly, the novelty of the week is the Aboriginal Dance Festival company from Australia, performing Thursday at 6:30 P.M. in the ''Creative Time'' series at the Battery Park City Landfill (Gate 19 at Chambers and West streets).

title: The World in Summary; NEW TRY TO END HUNGER STRIKES
description: With six hunger-strikers dead in Northern Ireland and two others weakening precariously, Britain moved to deflect international criticism last week by permitting International Red Cross representatives to interview Irish Republican Army prisoners. British officials told the visitors they could make ''recommendations to improve the conditions of imprisonment.''

title: MICHAEL SPINKS CAPTURES TITLE
description: The plan to go from light-heavyweight champion to heavyweight champion, which had been carefully arranged and publicized by Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, was delayed, perhaps permanently, this afternoon.

title: Stock Options
description: To the Business Editor:

title: SEX BIAS FOUND IN TEACHERS RETIREMENT PLAN
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the New York State Teachers Retirement System violated civil-rights laws by giving lower payments to women than to men.

title: The Darwin Controversy
description: The amount of evidence supporting evolution is staggering (''The 'Threat' of Creationism,'' June 14).

title: RAPE IN MARRIAGE: NO REFORM IN SIGHT
description: THIS month the New York State Legislature tabled for another year a law that would make it a crime for a man to commit society's most violent, cruel and debasing act - rape - upon the woman he has promised to love, honor and cherish. By its failure to repeal a husband's immunity from prosecution for raping his wife, our legislators have decided for all of us that a man may force sexual relations on his wife at any time and with any amount of force, with the full sanction of society.

title: POP: MARLENE VERPLANCK
description: Marlene Verplanck is a singer whose basic musical home is the recording studio, where she is in great demand for television and radio commercials. This is a field that requires precision, range, patience and an ability to be a quick study.

title: Katherine Netzer Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dick Netzer of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Martha Netzer, to Gregory Bunger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hilary Bunger of Weston, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: AT HOME
description: ''Too broke to travel this summer? Let Jo-Jo help! Customized stay-at-home vacations my specialty. Better than the real thing at half the price.'' - Flier addressed to Occupant.

title: BRITAIN'S ROYAL FAMILY--SEASONED TV PERFORMERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Martin A. Jackson is a freelance writer. By MARTIN A. JACKSON

title: Elin Peterson Is Bride of Mark Sullivan
description: The marriage of Elin Peterson and Mark Stephen Sullivan, graduates of Dartmouth College, took place at the Old Swedes Episcopal Church in Wilmington, Del., yesterday. The Rev. Charles Mayer performed the ceremony.

title: M.D. Baker Weds Ellen M. Dignan
description: Ellen Marie Dignan, daughter of Mrs. Patrick Gregory Dignan of Bedford, N.Y., and the late Mr. Dignan, was married yesterday afternoon to Marcus Daly Baker of Pittsburgh, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Allen Baker Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Charles M. Kavanagh of the Cathederal Preparatory Seminary in New York performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford.

title: TEEN-AGERS CALL ILLICIT DRUGS ONE OF LIFE'S COMMONPLACES
description: Through their friends and their families, in the magazines they read and the movies they watch, at parties, at home and in school, nearly every teen-ager in the New York metropolitan region has come to regard illicit drugs as commonplace.

title: SHIFTING TRADE WINDS IN THE BOOK BIZ
description: Random House, E.P. Dutton and Bantam Books still close up shop around noon each Friday during the summer, but many other book industry traditions are rapidly going by the boards. Among them is the summer lull, that three-month hiatus before the onset of the big fall publishing season.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in last Sunday's Arts & Leisure section incorrectly identified two of the performers in ''Sophisticated Ladies.'' Hinton Battle was at the left in the picture and Greg Burge at the right.

title: ON THE FARM, A HARVEST OF RED INK
description: FARMERS, it is generally conceded, are notorious gripers. But this year it appears they have a good number of very legitimate complaints to air: Bumper grain crops seem likely to depress prices, higher interest rates are hammering margins and lower profits seem inevitable. With the nation's corn now high as a cow's eye and a record wheat crop headed for the bin, a sense of malaise is apparent in the agricultural heartland.

title: ROCK: THE MOODY BLUES
description: The Moody Blues, the English rock quintet that appeared Tuesday at Madison Square Garden, made its reputation by joining the synthesized sound of a classical orchestra to a rock rhythm foundation. Its 1967 album, ''Days of Future Past,'' is a landmark of rock ''psychedelia'' for two reasons. It was one of the earliest programmatic ''trip'' records, and the first such record to present the cosmic truisms of ''head music'' in a symphonic setting. ''Days of Future Past'' helped usher in the ornate English art rock movement that flourished in the 70's with groups like Yes, Genesis and Supertramp.

title: MUST RENT LAW'S JUSTICE BE 'ROUGH'?
description: Louella Hatch, who rents an apartment in the Bronx, and Louise Henry, who owns apartments in Brooklyn, have diametrically opposite views on most aspects of rent stabilization. But in one thing they agree: Each feels it has been administered unfairly.

title: OWNER UNIT SEEN AS KEY IN BASEBALL STRIKE TALK
description: The presence of the elusive board of directors of the player relations committee, which establishes the bargaining position for the owners' negotiating team, could determine the success or failure of the Washington phase of the talks in the baseball strike that hit the 37-day mark yesterday.

title: 3 Ex-Major Leaguers Are All-Stars in Japan
description: Tony Solaita, Jim Lyttle and Leron Lee of the United States will play in the Japanese professional all-star baseball games, starting Saturday in Osaka.

title: Home Clinic; AN INEXPENSIVE CANOPY LOWERS COST OF AIR CONDITIONING
description: ONE simple way to lower the cost of running a room air-conditioner, whether installed in a window or in an opening cut through a wall, is to make certain the unit is shaded from the sun.

title: CRISIS OF CONSCIENCE MOVES SALVADOR CHURCH
description: ''The church is the only institution with the moral authority to speak about the violence,'' a Cabinet minister acknowledged last week. ''But we are going to ask it to be more constructive.''

title: Dining Out; NO JAPANESE STEAK HOUSE, THIS
description: SINCE its opening last January, Sukeroku, a Japanese restaurant in Little Falls, has earned a word-of-mouth reputation that keeps it filled to capacity most evenings. This proves that many diners in New Jersey are interested in this particular cuisine. However, it is unfortunate that a serious restaurant such as this, which is operated primarily by Japanese, fails to take the opportunity to teach occidentals the intricacies and order of Japanese meals.

title: BLIND VIOLENCE IN A BLIND ALLEY
description: When the cycle of death subsides again in the Middle East, there will still be an Israel and there will still be a Palestinian problem. The P.L.O. will still get blood money from Arab states and arms from the Soviet bloc. Israel will still get F-16's from the United States.

title: 'STEVIE'--SECOND LIFE FOR A MOVIE
description: Robert Enders, the filmmaker, is the exception that proves his own rule: If you want to sell a story idea to a movie studio, don't make an ''art film.''

title: CABARET: JAYE P. MORGAN IS SINGING AT LES MOUCHE
description: Until recently, anyone trying to get to the cabaret and restaurant of Les Mouche, 11th Avenue at 26th Street, first had to run a gauntlet of garrish lights, musical tumult and mirrors in the disco room. The two aspects of Les Mouche now have separate entrances from the street and the rooms can maintain their individual and distinctive identities.

title: 'The Last Laugh': The Exploits of El Sid
description: S. J. Perelman, it turns out, left behind four chapters of an autobiography when he died in 1979. He planned to call it ''The Hindsight Saga,'' a perelmaniacal spin off ''The Forsythe Saga.'' These bits of memoir, published for the first time in ''The Last Laugh,'' are the tailpiece to a collection of 17 of Perelman's comic sketches for The New Yorker. Even in its fragmentary state, ''The Hindsight Saga'' strikes me as the best thing Perelman ever wrote. So much so, in fact, I can't help but wonder why some editor, somewhere along the way, didn't take El Sid, as admirers sometimes called Sidney Joseph Perelman, by the back of his custom-collared neck and push his nose and the round-rimmed spectacles on the bridge above and the Cold Stream Guards thatch on the lip below into this sort of material long ago.

title: Other World Events; U.N. Addresses Absent Vietnamese
description: Vietnam hinted last week that it might be willing to talk to other countries about Cambodia, provided they leave their United Nations credentials at home. A conference on Cambodia at the world organization named seven countries - Thailand, Malaysia, Japan, Sri Lanka, Nigeria, Senegal and the Sudan - to urge Hanoi to pull its 200,000 troops out of Cambodia. Vietnam and the Soviet Union boycotted the conference, making it possible for China to insist on a declaration that would permit its favorite Cambodians, the Pol Pot regime, and other insurgents to keep their weapons.

title: Miss Cummings Will Wed Oct. 3
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cummings of Providence, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Ellis Cummings, to John Hincks Duke, son of Betsy Trippe Wainwright of New York and Old Black Point, Conn., and William Hincks Duke of New York. An Oct. 3 wedding is planned.

title: DESIGNER SHEETS: CLASS FOR THE MASSES
description: ''D ESERT tones are important -the entire color palate is very grayed pastels.'' The speaker is Robin Roberts, who is not discussing a collection of Georgia O'Keefe art. He is talking about his new ''Japan Style'' sheets. To the British-born designer, sheets are works of art. More to the point, they are highly remunerative.

title: FARMERS MARKETS THRIVING IN DOWNTOWNS
description: OSSINING ''ARE you sure it's four for $1?'' asked Ivy Dachman, a local resident. Turning to a nearby shopper, she whispered, ''Last week at the supermarket, I paid 79 cents for just one head of iceberg lettuce.''

title: Siran Hovnanian Fiancee Of Robert D. Mardigian
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hirair S. Hovnanian of Deal, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Siran H. Hovnanian, to Robert Douglas Mardigian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mardigian of Birmingham, Mich.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: 'Silent Spring' Update The timing was accidental but turned out to be perfect for Channel 13's rebroadcast Friday night at 9 of ''The Silent Spring of Rachel Carson.'' This 1963 CBS documentary, based on Rachel Carson's book ''Silent Spring,'' has been on Channel 13's schedule for some time. But it's being shown by chance at the very time that its subject matter, the danger of pesticides to man and the environment, is making front-page headlines. The current controversy in California - the much-criticized aerial spraying of the pesticide melathion to wipe out the Mediterranean fruit fly - is likely to be part of the update at the end of the program, when Bill Moyers interviews Dr. Barry Cgmmoner, a leading spokesman for environmentalists.

title: The Nation in Summary; NO GO, AGAIN, FOR VA. REDISTRICTING
description: The Reagan Justice Department last week turned thumbs down on a legislative reapportionment plan for Norfolk, Va. because it violated a landmark civil rights law that some Reagan supporters want eliminated.

title: A CITY THAT'S LONG ON CHARM, SHORT ON AID
description: PLAINFIELD NOT too many years ago, this city was a haven for millionaires and a paradise for Republicans. Well-heeled Plainfield residents commuted by train to Newark or New York five days a week, returning in the late afternoon to their sprawling houses and leafy streets. It was a city that would have supported President Reagan's call for cuts in government spending and for increased self-reliance by communities.

title: CHOOSING A PATH ON A SUMMER AFTERNOON
description: IT'S late in the afternoon, and the slant shafts of the sunlight fill the lawn with shadow. From my vantage point on the patio, I inspect the grass. It's very shaggy, like the boy who's trudging down the street right now, his hair matted around his head and dipping down to cover his eyes. I watch him as he passes by and then turn back to the grass. It needs cutting, definitely.

title: U.S. CLINCHES WIGHTMAN WITH 4-0 LEAD
description: The United States doubles team of Andrea Jaeger and Pam Shriver defeated Britain's Anne Hobbs and Jo Durie, 6-1, 6-3, tonight as the Americans won their fourth straight match and clinched the Wightman Cup.

title: Peggy Benziger Engaged to Wed R.B.Williams
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Joseph Benziger of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marguerite Marie Benziger, to Richard Bruce Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Williams of Bay Head, N.J. An Oct. 17 wedding is planned.

title: THE TREASURES OF XIAN
description: To the Editor:

title: FERMENTING BEER SALES
description: The nation's brewers entered the busy summer season under a full head of steam. Patrick A. King, a research analyst at the United States Brewers Association, says withdrawals from brewers to wholesalers through May reached an estimated 71.3 million barrels, up 2.1 percent from a year ago.

title: On the Renovations For St. Agnes Cathedral
description: In response to the article ''Renovation Opposed for Cathedral'' and as a member of the opposition, may I say that we are indeed reacting against all the unnecessary work planned as well as the liturgical changes, which will draw no one closer to God but will deny the poor. Despite Msgr.

title: Music; LEVITT CONCERTS OFFER VARIETY OF PROGRAMS; BY ROBERT SHERMAN
description: ''IT all started as a landfill project,'' said Joyce Mueller, managing director of the Levitt Pavilion programs, talking about the site of what is undoubtedly the most ambitious free summer festival in Connecticut. ''There was actually a garbage dump here at one point, but then they turned it around and built our band shell on a triangular piece of land raised about 12 feet above the Saugatuck River in Westport.''

title: COUNTING THE JOYS OF A GRANDSON'S VISIT
description: IT'S always gratifying when the children want to come home for a weekend to see Old Dad and Old Mum. Well, they're not exactly children. Our son is a junior executive in his early 30's and his wife is a busy wife/ mother/artist/cook and is pregnant as well.

title: No Headline
description: Victor Regalado shot a 66 today to take a two-stroke lead in the third round of the $200,000 Quad Cities Open, getting the lead from Rod Curl.

title: S. J. Perelman's 'The Last Laugh'
description: S. J. Perelman, it turns out, left behind four chapters of an autobiography when he died in 1979. He planned to call it ''The Hindsight Saga,'' a perelmaniacal spin off ''The Forsythe Saga.'' These bits of memoir, published for the first time in ''The Last Laugh,'' are the tailpiece to a collection of 17 of Perelman's comic sketches for The New Yorker. Even in its fragmentary state, ''The Hindsight Saga'' strikes me as the best thing Perelman ever wrote. So much so, in fact, I can't help but wonder why some editor, somewhere along the way, didn't take El Sid, as admirers sometimes called Sidney Joseph Perelman, by the back of his custom-collared neck and push his nose and the round-rimmed spectacles on the bridge above and the Cold Stream Guards thatch on the lip below into this sort of material long ago.

title: L.I. BLOC SPLIT ON TRANSIT PACKAGE
description: LONG ISLAND legislators split widely on the five taxes enacted to subsidize mass transit, including the Long Island Rail Road, but there was a significant pattern in the voting. It was not the frequent straight party-line voting, but a vote demonstrating the responsibilities that go with a majority party in the Legislature and the freedom that goes with being part of a downtrodden minority.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: PARLIAMENT passed a new tax on tea in 1767, and by 1773 the colonists in Boston, dressed as Indians, were dumping tea overboard to protest. Things are working a little faster in Connecticut this summer. Last Tuesday, the day before the first payment was due on the new unincorporated business tax, a protest group arrived at the Capitol wearing tea bags.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 11 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 2 15 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 3 3 6 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 4 6 4 THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.) Two veteran homicide detectives trapped by the seductive vices of Hollywood. 5 4 13 GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam's, $12.95.) Leto continues as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet Dune. 6 5 13 FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon. 7 8 39 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history.

title: MAKE ROOM FOR THE VIOLENT CRIMINALS
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. DIVIDED ON IMPACT OF U.S. CUTS
description: NASSAU and Suffolk officials appear to be divided over the potential impact of Federal budget cuts on the Island. Nassau officials maintain that their losses would be manageable, while Suffolk officials see the budget-cutting as more of a threat to programs the county administers for citizens.

title: GREENWICH TAKES NO BACK SEAT FOR CHAIRS
description: JOHN FENWICK, a Quaker, came to South Jersey in 1675. His land holdings eventually encompassed Salem and Cumberland Counties of today, or roughly one-tenth of New Jersey.

title: AN ABSTRACT EXPRESSIONIST STILL MAKES 'DISCOVERIES'
