description: STONY BROOK ALTHOUGH Abstract Expressionism was neither a coherent style nor a clearly defined school, it nevertheless had legions of apologists and theoreticians who promoted the new philosophy of picture making with missionary zeal. Often the artists themselves were the most vocal and articulate spokesmen.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; VATICAN TRIES TO MAKE ENDS MEET
description: No mystery, secular or sacred, has been guarded more closely by the Catholic Church than its finances. But an announcement made by the Vatican last week should dispel the notion that the secrecy shrouds hidden treasures.

title: THE MANY MOODS OF ZUCCHINI
description: f all the vegetables that have come into our kitchen over the last few decades, zucchini has been the most fascinating, for we have watched it evolve from an obscure squash to an American favorite. When we published our first zucchini recipe in the early 1960's, it was a considerable oddity. There were very few people who were conversant with its uses in casseroles, creamed dishes, salads or the many other dishes it can enhance. It was still so unfamiliar to most in the 1960's, in fact, that it was necessary to define it among the ingredients as ''green Italian squash'' when we wrote about it. Today, the number of zucchini admirers and the recipes they develop increase every day. No matter how often we use zucchini throughout the summer, we are never bored with it. Our favorite recipes include zucchini in casserole and stuffed zucchini. The list of things that may go into a stuffed zucchini is a long one. Both the stuffings outlined here have a ground-pork base plus a variety of herbs and grated Parmesan cheese.

title: EYEGLASS DISPUTE IS PUT TO COURT TEST
description: BUTLER IN NOVEMBER 1978, Heinrich Scholler, a West German law professor, came to the National Institute for Rehabilitative Engineering here to be fitted for eyeglasses that he hoped would correct tunnel vision in his right eye.

title: Kenty Undergoes Surgery on Eye
description: Hilmer Kenty, the former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, remained hospitalized today after undergoing surgery to repair a detached retina in his right eye, a hospital spokesman said.

title: 2 BIG STUDIOS GO AFTER HISPANIC FILM AUDIENCE
description: Simultaneously with its release of ''Superman II'' a month ago, Warner Bros. broke sharply with Hollywood tradition and distributed a Spanish-language version of the movie in Los Angeles, Miami and New York.

title: CUTTING MEDICAL-STUDENT LOANS MAY DRIVE DOCTORS' FEES UP
description: The high cost of medical care has made the public angry at doctors, but Reagan Administration cost-cutting measures as represented by a Senate bill could drive physicians' fees even higher.

title: Jo Ann Schwartz, Designer, Is Wed to Robert J. Schoen
description: Jo Ann Schwartz, daughter of Arthur Schwartz of Swampscott, Mass., and the late Mrs. Schwartz, was married yesterday to Robert J. Schoen of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Schoen of New York.

title: THE 17 YEARS OF 'FIDDLER' TRADITION
description: IN the beginning, or about the time it was trying out in Detroit, ''Fiddler on the Roof'' was supposed to be only a moderate hit, or, depending on how you looked at it, a semiflop. That was the summer of '64, and now, many performances later (no one knows how many; ''Fiddler'' is always playing somewhere) the musical is back, this time at the New York State Theater, where it looks very much as it did when it opened on Broadway at the Imperial Theater. ''It's a masterpiece,'' Maria Karnilova said firmly the other day. ''Why fool around with a masterpiece?''

title: FEUD CONSUMES A RURAL BRAZIL TOWN
description: Had it not been for the sudden turns of political life peculiar to this remote town in Brazil's vast back country, Jose Peixoto Alencar would probably have finished out his days holding the same city council post he has held for the last quarter of a century. Instead he is the Mayor.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DAMP SIDE

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL Israel could not join a cease-fire in Lebanon as long as Palestinian groups continue their attacks on Israel. Prime Minister Menachem Begin reportedly told Philip C. Habib, the American special envoy in the Middle East. Israeli officials said Mr. Begin told Mr. Habib during the course of two meetings that a halt in the fighting was not a solution to the more basic problem of a Palestinian Liberation Organization arms buildup within striking distance of Israel's northern settlements. He reportedly stressed that Israel could agree to a cease-fire only the context of a border peace arrangement. (Page A1, Column 6) Shipment of more U.S. jets to Israel would be affected by Israel's cooperation in reducing the level of violence in Lebanon, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig said in a television interview. (A3:3-6.)

title: LAZY SUMMER DAYS FOR THE JUNIOR CARRIAGE TRADE
description: For some young New Yorkers, summer rides about the city have none of the problems adults face on public transportation in 90-degree heat. Tots in strollers are traveling in the lap of luxury, protected by parasols, fringed awnings, mosquito netting and with sling-back seating conducive to summer afternoon napping. Most eye-catching are the strollers built for two, by design or with the addition of a pair of plastic clamps that join two strollers to make a double.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: The Reagan Administration's new policy on nuclear proliferation (news article July 8) clearly signals to both friend and foe a ''business as usual'' approach to this vital question.

title: Con Ed Rate Rise Of 1.7% in Effect
description: A 1.7 percent increase in bills for 2.8 million electric customers of the Consolidated Edison Company in New York City and Westchester County took effect yesterday. The increase, to cover $62.5 million additional wage and tax costs, was authorized by the Public Service Commission last March.

title: Article 200619 -- No Title
description: FINANCES By MICHAEL GOODWIN

title: Marital Proceedings in a Midsummer Season
description: June is supposed to be the month for weddings, but July seems to be holding its own, at least among some well-known Americans. On Wednesday, Buddy Rogers, the man who was married to America's Sweetheart, Mary Pickford, for 44 years until her death two years ago, plans to take a new wife.

title: WILIAM PRESSER, UNION LEADER ,DIES
description: William Presser, a former national official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in the Cleveland suburb of Lyndhurst. He was 74 years old.

title: All Smiles
description: Preston Pearson, a 36-year-old running back and pass receiver who has played for three teams in five Super Bowl games, twice has been told he was ''too old'' for the National Football League.

title: RISE JIM BEATS PROUD APPEAL
description: Rise Jim, probably the fastest horse to come out of New England in a decade, passed the odds-on favorite, Proud Appeal, at the top of the stretch and drew off to a 1 3/4-length victory yesterday in the $54,700 Tom Fool Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: CORPORATE RACES GET COMPETITIVE
description: FINALLY, it happened. Corporations had come together to reveal that they indeed ruled the world. Or so it seemed. Here, in Stanford Stadium yesterday afternoon, in an atmosphere mildly redolent of the Olympics, the opening ceremonies consisted of teams parading behind standard bearers whose upraised flags read not France or England or United States or Somalia, but General Electric and Texas Instruments and Ford, and - sort of representing the Third World economies -the Food Fair Markets of Sunnyvale, Calif.

title: Wightman Sweep for U.S.
description: Chris Evert Lloyd and Rosie Casals defeated Virginia Wade and Glynnis Coles, 6-3, 6-3, in doubles today to complete a 7-0 sweep by the United States over Britain in the 53d Wightman Cup tennis series.

title: New Orleans Seeking Cause of Power Failure
description: Utility engineers searched today for the cause of a power failure yesterday that left a quarter of a million homes and businesses without electricity in steamy July heat.

title: Yangtze Waters Pass China's Largest Dam
description: Torrents of water from the Yangtze River swept past China's largest dam today without damaging it and surged toward an area that suffered disastrous floods last year.

title: POLISH CHIEF: A PRAGMATIST
description: When Stanislaw Kania was first named as Poland's Communist Party leader in the wake of last summer's labor unrest, his first speech was read on Polish television by a dapper young announcer. A ripple of excitement passed through Warsaw: the new party secretary was attractive and young. Then the error was discovered, and people crowded the news kiosks to see what the new chief really looked like.

title: A Queen of Hearts
description: Richard Burton cited her beauty, Robert Wagner noted her ''terrific sense of humor,'' and Omar Sharif found her ''wonderfully vibrant'' and ''very down to earth.'' But it was Gregory Peck who may have found the key to Sophia Loren.

title: U.S. ADDING 42 CENTERS FOR VETERANS OF VIETNAM
description: The storefront counseling program for Vietnam-era veterans, a target of President Reagan's initial budget-cutting plans, is now to be expanded under pressure from veterans' organizations and their supporters in Congress.

title: 6 Plus 200 Plus 8 Add Up to a Toughie
description: There were only six problems and the 200 young contestants had eight hours over two days to solve them, but it took even longer than that to grade their answers. That's because the problems, some of which required several pages of complicated proofs to solve, were just a bit tougher than the normal high school fare.

title: LIST OF VICTIMS IN KANSAS CITY
description: This is a revised list, released by the police, of some of those killed in the Hyatt Regency Hotel disaster on Friday. ADLER, John J., 74 years old, Fairway, Kan. ALCALA, Connie, 50, Topeka, Kan. ALLEN, Velma, 49, Kansas City, Mo. ANDREW, Carol. 33. BARTELS, Bonnie, 36, Lenexa, Kan. BARTELS, William 3d, 38, Lenexa, Kan. BARTON, Robert, 56, Kansas City, Mo. BENTEAU, Robert C., 49, Parkville, Mo. BERGES, Calvin W., 57, Kansas City, Mo. BERGES, Florence, 62, Kansas City, Mo. BERGMAN, John W., 30, Shawnee, Kan. BERGMAN, Pearl, 58, Shawnee, Kan. BOLTON, James, 63, Chesterfield, Mo.BOLTON, Julia, 50, Chesterfield, Mo. BOTNEN, Henry, 51, Overland Park, Kan. BOTTENBERG, Louis, 67, BROOKS, Jaqueline, 24, Kansas City, Mo. BURGESS, Florence, 62, Kansas City, Mo. CARMONA, Delores, 35, Topeka, Kan. CAST, Theodore, 72, Holden, Mo. COFFEY, Gerland, 42, Leavenworth, Kan.

title: THOUSANDS OF STATE WORKERS STRIKE IN MINNESOTA
description: A strike by Minnesota state workers that could involve up to 18,000 employees began at 12:01 A.M. today after state and union negotiators broke off talks late yesterday afternoon.

title: COUNSELING FOR PEOPLE WHO PLAN TO ADOPT
description: The prospect that Reagan budget cuts will reduce funds for agencies providing foster care for the nation's 400,000 homeless children is increasing the need for adoptions, social service workers report.

title: IMMIGRATION POLICY MAY OMIT A WORKER-IDENTIFICATION CARD
description: The announcement of a comprehensive immigration policy, delayed by disagreements among President Reagan's advisers, is expected this week. But the plan may not include a suggested national identity card.

title: FINK RULES OUT STATE GUARNTEES OF WESTWAY FEE
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink ruled out yesterday any state commitment to pick up all extra costs for the proposed Westway highway project that might be left by shortfalls in Federal aid.

title: HATRED OF 1940'S STILL VIVID TO JAPANESE
description: Four decades after the fact, the Japanese of the Hood River Valley still have trouble understanding why their neighbors turned against them and why the Government of the land where they were born locked them behind barbed wire fences beneath machine guns on guard towers.

title: 2 UNIONS REPORT NO PROGRESS IN POSTAL TALKS
description: With only one day left before their contract expires, the United States Postal Service and unionized workers continued to bargain toward a new work agreement today, but leaders of the two major unions said that no real progress had been made.

title: Belgian Market Aide Is Killed by His Wife
description: Fernand Spaak, chief aide to the president of the Common Market and a member of one of Belgium's most influential political families, was shot to death by his wife, who then electrocuted herself in the bathtub of their apartment here, the police said today.

title: Mancini Winner, Stays Unbeaten
description: Ray (Boom-Boom) Mancini, the unbeaten 20-year-old lightweight, went the distance for the first time in 20 professional fights and won a unanimous 12-round decision today over Jose Luis Ramirez of Mexico.

title: Hinault Captures Cycling
description: Bernard Hinault, a 26-year-old Frenchman, won the Tour de France bicycle endurance race today for the third time in four years. ''I will get my revenge,'' he promised last year when an injury forced him to withdraw from the race, and today he got just that.

title: BRITISH STRIFE MEANS HEAVY WEDDING SECURITY
description: Next week, when Prince Charles sets out in the royal wedding procession in a gold-and-black carriage drawn by four gray horses, his two-mile route to St. Paul's Cathedral will be lined not only with many, many thousands of delighted subjects, but also with row after row of grim-faced policemen, many of them carrying guns.

title: ADDICT BEARS WITNESS TO LOST YEARS
description: Michael Tappan was a 12-year-old growing up amid affluence in Locust Valley, L.I., when he began using illicit drugs. First he tried marijuana, and later more potent drugs. Before his 16th birthday, he recalled recently, he had experimented with cocaine and numerous kinds of tranquilizers, nearly everything short of morphine and heroin.

title: Javelin Hits Maree
description: Sidney Maree of South Africa, the United States 1,500-meter champion, was hit by a javelin today before a race against Sebastian Coe of Britain.

title: SEARCHERS QUIT TITANIC'S AREA
description: The crew of the R.V. Gyre, off Newfoundland, was packing up its complex search equipment today and heading for Boston, hoping that some of the undeveloped film aboard would determine whether they had found the Titanic.

title: Remains Brought From Laos Turned Over to U.S. in Hawaii
description: Skeletal remains believed to be those of four United States servicemen who died in Laos arrived today from Thailand.

title: Goldin and Dearie To Meet in Debate
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin and State Assemblyman John C. Dearie, the two Democratic candidates for City Comptroller, will debate each other for the first time on Aug. 2.

title: Getting Started
description: For the technical information on crab courtship in this column, this writer relied on William W. Warner's ''Beautiful Swimmers'' (Penguin Books), which won a Pulitzer Prize in 1977.

title: HEMPSTEAD BAY COLONY FACES END OF AN ERA
description: It is Long Island's most exclusive and perhaps least-known summer colony. It has no name and if you don't already belong, you can't join: The membership books were closed in 1964.

title: SOUNDERS WIN TRANS-ATLANTIC CUP
description: The Seattle Sounders rallied from a two-goal deficit and captured the second annual Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup by playing the Cosmos to a 3-3 tie at Giants Stadium tonight.

title: IF THERE WERE NO K.G.B., WOULD THE SCALE AND INTENSITY OF TERRORISM BE DIMINISHED?
description: In addition to reviving the standard image of the Soviet Union as a military juggernaut, Washington has also resurrected the old idea that the Soviet Union is managing a worldwide conspiracy. ''International terrorism'' apparently has replaced human rights as a major concern of United States foreign policy. A Senate subcommittee is investigating ''Soviet and surrogate support for international terrorism.'' The Central Intelligence Agency's 1981 report on terrorism has added a new category of terrorist acts: ''conspiracy.''

title: COLUMBIA RADIO LOSES SIGNAL
description: The radio station of Columbia University, which broadcasts throughout the New York metropolitan area, lost its signal over the weekend after its aging transmitter in midtown Manhattan failed.

title: EVEN TOP ROOKIES LEAD UNEASY LIVES AT JET TRAINING
description: SITEF813HEMPSTEAD, L.I. THE Jets put their unheralded rookie free agents on the top floors of the dormitories at Hofstra University here. That is not a confidence builder: those are the floors that will be emptied out first for the incoming college students.

title: Boat Explosions Injure 5 in Islip
description: Five persons, including two firemen, were injured when the engine on a cabin cruiser exploded in Islip, the police said. The accident occurred late Saturday morning when passengers on the 27-foot boat, which was docked in a canal, started the engine.

title: Nicaraguans Celebrate Revolution Anniversary
description: The Nicaraguan Government marked the second anniversary of the Sandinist revolution today by promising tighter controls over private capital while turning over some stateconfiscated farms to peasants.

title: BRITISH-IRISH TIES SEEN AT LOW POINT
description: A dispute over how to end the hunger strike by Irish Republican Army inmates here has abruptly plunged relations between the British and Irish Governments to their lowest point in nearly a decade, Irish Government officials said today.

title: BOBBY CARPENTER FACES THE DECISION OF HIS LIFE
description: DANVERS, Mass. THE most acclaimed hockey player the United States has produced wears a Gregory's Deli jersey as he skates against Moynihan Lumber. Outside the Town Line Twin Rinks on Route 114, it is a steamy July evening. But inside it is cold, and the men from the town wear the warmup jackets of their youth as they join Sgt. Bob Carpenter of the Peabody police force watching his son, Bob Jr.

title: Talking To the Russians
description: The United States has taken a bit of the steam out of mounting allied pressures for a statement of its intentions in dealing with the Soviet Union. That was obviously the purpose of Secretary of State Alexander Haig's New York speech shortly before today's opening of the Western industrial summit here.

title: CONVICT-AUTHOR KNOWEN BY MAILER IS BEING SOUGHT IN FATAL STABBING
description: A convicted bank robber whose letters to Norman Mailer from prison were recently published with an introduction by Mr. Mailer is being sought by the police in the fatal stabbing of a waiter outside a Lower East Side restaurant early Saturday morning.

title: NOTES OF PEOPLE
description: Mailer House in Dispute A judge on Cape Cod has ordered Beverly Mailer to move out of the Provincetown waterfront home she once shared with her former husband, the writer Norman Mailer, and ordered her to pay the present owners of the house $13,650 in back rent.

title: HAIG TIES TENSIONS TO F-16 DELIVERIES
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that a decision on resuming the delivery of F-16 fighterbombers to Israel would be affected by Israel's cooperation in reducing the level of violence in Lebanon.

title: TOKEN NONSUPPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: Conferences Of 7 Nations Began in '75
description: The economic summit conference has been an annual event since 1975. Following are summaries of the six previous meetings. Rambouillet, France, 1975 - The conferees rejected a return to fixed exchange rates while agreeing on the need for monetary stability and for international economic cooperation.

title: Oil Cleaned Up
description: A 400-gallon oil spill in the Delaware Bay that created a 12-mile-long slick about 2,000 feet wide had been cleaned up and posed no danger to the environment, the Coast Guard said.

title: Cosell Fans
description: Howard Cosell, a name that raises the pitch of voices in sports circles when mentioned, may have surprised a few of his critics last month. ABC's top sports broadcaster was in Kansas City on Sunday night, June 7, preparing to broadcast a baseball game the following night between the Royals and the Yankees.

title: Banks Need a Hand, Not a Handout
description: Are savings banks and savings and loan associations near collapse? Richard Pratt, the Chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, came close to saying they were, in talking to the House Banking Committee a few weeks ago. Others, notably leaders of the commercial banking industry, are skeptical.

title: THAT FRESH DIVORCE DECREE: IT SHOULD BE FINAL--BUT IS IT?
description: Those who think that a judge's signature on their divorce papers is a green light to remarry should be forewarned. A divorce is not official until a county clerk places a seal upon the documents.

title: THEFTS, TOO, WARRANT POLICE ATTENTION
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN JOINS SIX WORLD LEADERS FOR ECONOMIC AND POLITICAL TALKS
description: President Reagan arrived here this afternoon to work out economic and political differences with the leaders of six other industrial democracies and almost immediately had to fend off attacks on high American interest rates from two of his strongest European critics.

title: FOES OF CUTS IN ARTS PLAN NEXT STEP
description: The American Coalition to Support the Arts will hold a strategy meeting in New York this week to follow up Saturday's moraleboosting rallies by artists and performers across the country to head off a proposed halving of the Federal arts budget, a spokesman for the group announced yesterday.

title: S.I. PARENTS WORRY ABOUT CHILDREN AS HUNT FOR GIRL GOES ON
description: ''Now I worry if my Anthony goes around the corner,'' Karen Lewis said as she sat on the steps of an apartment building on Staten Island where Holly Ann Hughes, a missing 7-year-old child, lived with her mother and brother. ''You can't keep the kids inside, especially when it is this hot. But we are worried about that little girl and our own kids.''

title: SOCIETY'S STAKE IN COMMUNICATIONS ADVANCES
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Analysis
description: The recent Israeli bombing attacks on Beirut and southern Lebanon and the continued Palestinian rocket bombardment of northern Israel have again heightened fears that a major military conflict could erupt between Israel and

title: HARD ROCK: VAN HALEN AT THE GARDEN
description: DESPITE all the talk about a commercial resurgence of prerock styles of pop, the music that is keeping the record business afloat is the heavy-metal brand of hard rock established by Led Zeppelin in the late 1960's. And the triumphant appearance of Van Halen, one of the heaviest of heavy-metal rock groups, at Madison Square Garden on Friday was impressive evidence of the style's commercial strength.

title: Beck, Prudhomme Win
description: Gary Beck and Don Prudhomme won the two top titles at the 12th annual National Hot Rod Association Summernationals drag racing championship today. Beck of El Toro, Calif., took the unlimited top fuel title and Prudhomme, the defending champion of Granada Hills, Calif., won the funny car title.

title: Pennsylvania Teeming With Jim Smiths
description: It was a big weekend for Jim Smith and his friends, Jim Smith and Jim Smith, not to mention a few dozen other Jim Smiths.

title: New World Opens For Michael Spinks
description: The music at the victory party was still playing, the pieces of congratulatory cake were still on the table, and as Michael Spinks rested on the floor and leaned back on his elbows, his stomach still hurt. When he said, ''I'm starting to feel this,'' he was not talking about the excitement of being the World Boxing Association's light-heavyweight champion. He was talking about his bruised body.

title: Oh Happy Day
description: A woman of our acquaintance has always wanted to be Queen of England and thus, she claims, free of any domestic decision weightier than whether to wash her neck or her feet first. She likes the hours, she likes the pay, and whenever she reads that ribbon-cutting is boring, she reminds herself that she once met a group of women who made their living seeding pimentos. It was not much of a living, and the pimentos all looked alike.

title: Bonnie Spar Married To Glenn Ira Goldberg
description: Bonnie Spar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Spar of Lake Success, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Glenn Ira Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Goldberg of New York. Rabbi David Jay Gelfand of Great Neck, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: BEGGIN TELLS HABIB HE CANNOT ACCEPT A CEASE-FIRE NOW
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin met yesterday with President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, Philip C. Habib, and reportedly told him that Israel could not agree to a cease-fire in Lebanon as long as Palestinian groups continued to launch attacks across the border into Israel.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We must decisively state, if the situation will require it, authorities will execute their constitutional obligation to save the state from disintegration and the nation from catastrophe.'' - Wojciech Jaruzelski, Prime Minister of Poland. (A4:4.)

title: LUXURIOUS LOG CABIN OFFERS SECLUDED SUMMIT SETTING
description: The leaders of seven industrial nations said that they wanted an informal setting for their seventh conference, so the Canadian Government is providing what is described as ''the world's biggest log cabin.''

title: RELATIVES AND NEIGHBORS HIT HARD BY DISASTER
description: The people who work in the Wang Laboratories sales office here used to joke about not wanting to work next to Bonnie Bartels because it would mean coming to work at 7 in the morning and not leaving until 9 at night. But they staged an office party Friday in honor of the admired saleswoman's birthday. They did not know it would be their last time together.

title: KOTAR WANTS GIANT JOB BACK
description: Including the quarterbacks Phil Simms and Scott Brunner, the Giants used 11 players to carry the ball for a total of 1,730 yards last season. Doug Kotar, the running back, was not among them.

title: LA SCALA BALLET: MAURIZIO BELLEZZA AS ROMEO
description: A new Romeo courted Juliet on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. In Rudolf Nureyev's ''Romeo and Juliet'' for Milan's La Scala Opera Ballet, Maurizio Bellezza took over the leading male role, which had previously been danced here by the choreographer himself.

title: Index; International
description: Around the World A2 Blood feud flourishes in Brazil's back country A2 Soviet Union reacts warily to Kania's re-election in Poland A4 British authorities concerned about security for wedding A5 Irish officials said relations with Britain are severely strained A5 History of the site of the summit meeting A8 Government/Politics Assembly Speaker rules out state guarantees on Westway project B1 Study suggests return to trolleys on 42d St. in Manhattan B3 Budgets will be pinched again when sales tax rises Sept. 1 B3 Urban League's head sees danger to blacks in Reagan's policies B7 General Around the Nation A6 Japanese-Americans of Hood River Valley recall prejudice A6 Pleasure boat owners venture out seldom A6 Searchers for Titanic leave site and head for port A10 Relatives and neighbors among most affected by hotel disaster A10 Haitian refugees are moved from Miami to Brooklyn A18 A mock military battle is fought in Fort Drum, N.Y. B1 An era is ending for Hempstead Bay Colony on Long Island B1 Surveys find increasing awareness of drug-abuse hazards B2 A 19-year-old recalls his experience with drugs B2 The Region B2 Convicted bank robber sought in stabbing B3 Columbia's radio station lost its signal B3 S.I. parents voice concern as hunt goes on for girl, 7 B3 The City B5 SportsMonday Baseball: Year's extension of basic agreement urged C10 Boxing: Michael Spinks finds a new world opening for him C3 Columns: Dave Anderson on Bill Rogers, a clone no longer C1

title: Bernstein 'Mass' in Capital
description: The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts will mark its 10th anniversary in September with a production of Leonard Bernstein's ''Mass,'' which had its premiere at the inauguration of the center. Tom O'Horgan will be the director and John Mauceri the musical director. There will be 14 performances from Sept. 10 to 20.

title: A Forward Retreat on El Salvador
description: The Reagan Administration has wisely chastened the tone and modified the substance of its approach to El Salvador. It has always been true that ''only a genuinely pluralistic approach'' can end the terrible violence, but it was not always clear that American policy would support that approach.

title: ARTHUR C. SCHIER
description: Arthur C. Schier, retired vice president of the General Foods Corporation, died Friday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Mr. Schier, a resident of Manhasset, was 81 years old.

title: Donna Caponi's 73-282 Wins by 2
description: Donna Caponi scored her fourth victory of the year and her ninth in the last 16 months when she held on to win the $125,000 W.U.I. Classic today by two strokes from Julie Stanger.

title: 2 Peregrine Falcons Sighted Nesting in White Mountains
description: Scientists have reported that two peregrine falcons were spotted nesting in the White Mountains in the first sighting in 28 years of nesting peregrines occupying a natural cliff in the East.

title: LOVELY DAY AT THE COTTAGE IN THE LAKE
description: Noon on a weekend, sunshine blazing down on the water, the kind of day Michigan boat owners dream about in darkest February. And here at the Emerald City Harbor, are all the big cabin cruisers out cruising on Lake St. Clair?

title: POLAND'S PREMEIR SAYS SOME PRICES WILL RISE BY 110%
description: Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski told Poland's emergency Communist Party congress today that the price of food, coal, natural gas and housing would have to be increased 110 percent and that wage increases would have to end.

title: Iran Says It Bombed Iraqi Hydroelectric Plant
description: Iran said today that its jets had knocked out power in large areas of Iraq by bombing a hydroelectric plant in Iraq's Kurdistan region.

title: SALVADORAN RIGHT SEEKS MORE POWER
description: A group of conservative Salvadoran business leaders, encouraged by what they say are clear signs of support from the Reagan Administration, have intensified a long-running campaign to change the makeup of the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte.

title: Carrie Beth Kavetsky Is Wed to Timothy Barnard
description: Carrie Beth Kavetsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Kavetsky of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Timothy Martin John Barnard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Barnard of Radlett, England. Rabbi Michael Rosen performed the ceremony at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens.

title: BEFORE HOTEL DISASTER, WALKWAY SWAYED TO THE RHYTHM OF DANCERS
description: The Steve Miller Orchestra was playing Duke Ellington's ''Satin Doll,'' a cool jazz tune that for all its smoothness will support a moderate jitterbug or Lindy at the medium swing tempo being laid down by Mr. Miller as bandleader. In the lobby and on the aerial walkways of the flashy, year-old Hyatt Regency Hotel two nights ago, men in tuxedos and women in elegant gowns were dancing or just keeping time to the resurrected big-band sound.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CITY'S STATEMENT IN BOND OFFERING
description: Following are excerpts from New York City's ''Official Statement,'' describing ''certain of the major economic and social factors affecting the city'' in connection with the offering of $100 million in bonds.

title: The High Cost of Sentiment
description: WHEN Frank Schimpf died on Jan. 31, 1976, he was 84 years old and had worked for the New York Yankees for 70 years. In 1905 when the team was called the Highlanders, Frank's mother laundered their uniforms for 50 cents each and Frank delivered them to the players' lodgings. There was no clubhouse in the hilltop park at 168th Street and Broadway; the players dressed for work at home and walked to the grounds in uniform.

title: Basic-Pact Extension Urged
description: The possibility of a year's extension of the collective bargaining agreement between the players and owners arose yesterday as negotiators in baseball's 38-day-old strike prepared to move their bargaining table to Washington under the scrutiny of Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan.

title: JOB LOSS: ORDEAL AT HOME
description: B EING dismissed from a job, it has often been said, is one of the most painful experiences a person can endure. Only death of a loved one or divorce are believed to induce more stress.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Herbert Mitgang SWEETSIR. By Helen Yglesias. 332 pages. Simon & Schuster. $13.95. THE MISSING PERSON. By Doris Grum- bach. 252 pages. Putnam. $11.95.

title: CRABBERS: NEED PERSISTENCE, AGILITY
description: PURSUING the blue crab is a marvelously democratic endeavor. If you can get to sound, bay, estuary, salt pond or a tidal river along the East Coast in summer or fall, you'll need little more than a longhandled net and a fair amount of persistence and agility.

title: Police Follow Trail Of Torn Envelopes
description: A Freeport man was arrested yesterday and accused of robbing a woman of $25 in church collection-plate money.

title: TO 'THE MAN WHOM SOCIETY FORBIDS TO DIE'
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOK PACKAGERS COME OF AGE
description: WHILE book sales have generally been sluggish for months, with the notable exception of self-help guides and blockbuster novels, a number of other books are also doing well.

title: He's No Longer a Clone
description: UNTIL now Bill Rogers was always one of those clones out there on the golf tour - blond, slim-hipped and all but invisible. When people talked about how dull the golf tour was, they were talking about all those clones. Nice guys, but dull. Worse, none of those clones ever seemed to win a major tournament. They won a bankful of money but never a major.

title: Man Shot to Death In Chinatown
description: A man was shot to death in a Chinatown restaurant and the teen-ager who shot him then accidentally shot himself as he tried to put the weapon away, the police said.

title: ISRAEL, IRELAND AND THE WORKINGS OF PROPORTIONAL REPRESENTATION
description: To the Editor:

title: WALTON CAPTURES 50-MILE BIKE RACE
description: Hugh Walton, 10-time national champion of Canada who is now a professional, rallied on the last lap to overtake Dave Kellogg and win the Greenwich Criterium 50-mile bicycle race today.

title: Soviet Wrestlers Win 7 Divisions
description: Wrestlers from the Soviet Union dominated the final bouts of the world junior wrestling championships yesterday, winning four divisions for a total of seven gold medals of a possible 10.

title: U.S. PROLIFERATION OF NUCLEAR PERILS
description: To the Editor:

title: TO 'THE MAN WHOM SOCIETY FORBIDS TO DIE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington to Pay Half of Spraying Cost
description: Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block said in a television interview today that the Federal Government would split with California the costs of aerial spraying against the Mediterranean fruit fly, but he declined to pay a share of the state's much larger eradication expense.

title: Noble Nashua Wins the Swaps
description: Noble Nashua rallied from nextto-last place in the field of seven to win the $217,000 Swaps Stakes for 3-year-olds at Hollywood Park today.

title: A COOL CITY BUS OR SUBWAY? NO RELIEF IN SIGHT
description: A New Yorker in search of a cool ride has a 1-in-3 chance of finding air-conditioning that is working on a subway car and a 1-in-7 chance on a bus, a Transit Authority survey has found.

title: BORG RECOVERS TO BEAT LENDL IN FOUR SETS ON STUTTGART CLAY
description: Bjorn Borg won a $75,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today, fighting back to defeat Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, 1-6, 7-6, 6-2, 6-4.

title: Back to the Minors
description: Much of the ritual will be the same as it has been for 41 years when Bob Gibson, Johnny Mize and the late Andrew (Rube) Foster of the Negro Leagues are inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y., on Aug. 2. Their playing achievements will be detailed, Gibson and Mize will be presented with plaques and there will be speeches of thanks.

title: Amy Waldhorn Is Bride of Walton W. Waterbury
description: Amy Waldhorn, daughter of Mrs. Herbert F. Waldhorn of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Dr. Waldhorn, was married yesterday to Walton Whitwell Waterbury, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester E. Waterbury of Hancock, N.H. Justice of the Peace Lawrence J. Goldstein performed the ceremony at the Waldhorn home.

title: TO 'THE MAN WHOM SOCIETY FORBIDS TO DIE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: United States Team Gains A Strong Victory in Israel
description: Of the 80 gold medals won by American representatives in the Maccabiah Games last week in Israel, one went to the United States bridge team.

title: Idol Moments
description: Like millions of young soccer players around the world, Allan Abuto Nyanjong of Kenya always wanted to meet Pele and get a chance to show his skills to the Brazilian, who retired as a player in October 1977.

title: First Michigan 500 Postponed by Rain
description: The first Norton Michigan 500 Indy-style race was canceled because of heavy rains today and rescheduled for Saturday.

title: Great Britain
description: Margaret Thatcher ... 55 ... Prime Minister of Britain ... elected with absolute Parliamentary majority in 1979 ... Conservative ... wants to dismantle much of the welfare state established by previous governments, and return Britain to prominent world role ... is fighting inflation with tight money but has reaped criticism for high unemployment and deep recession ... violence in Northern Ireland and recently in English cities her main concerns ... popularity low because of wilting economy ... will look for support for monetarist policy ... called ''Iron Lady,'' tough-minded, not given to compromise. Japan

title: Sports World Specials; A Lion in Business
description: Until last season, when the Detroit Lions won nine of 16 games, their National Football League competition had been a long series of bleak experiences for their fans. The Lions' last winning season had been 1972. Now, once more on the winning side of the ledger, the team is expecting another big lift this season.

title: News Analysis
description: In the final days approaching tonight's secluded start-up of the seven-nation economic summit meeting, the Reagan Administration has sought to cushion the impact of mutual disagreements, but preliminary discussions began with leaders of the industrial nations visibly more divided than at any of the six previous meetings.

title: TANGLEWOOD: 'GODUNOV'
description: APPARENTLY pleased with the results of last summer's semistaged ''Tosca'' in the Music Shed at Tanglewood, Seiji Ozawa conducted an even more ambitious operatic undertaking with the Boston Symphony Orchestra on Saturday night, an abridged version of Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov.'' While ''Tosca'' had been acted out by singers in concert dress against a set of sorts, this ''Boris'' was fully staged with costumes and props.

title: Barr Wins Playoff On 8th Extra Hole
description: Dave Barr parred the eighth extra hole today to beat Woody Blackburn in a playoff that had started with five contenders for the Quad Cities Open golf title.

title: ROGERS WINS BRITISH OPEN BY 4 SHOTS ON 71-276
description: It could have come apart completely. The five-stroke lead had dwindled to one, tee shots were sailing, and the hand nervously fumbled a routine attempt at pulling the ball out of the seventh hole after a double bogey.

title: MERCHANTS IN NEW YORK CITY AREA BRACING FOR RISE IN STATE SALES TAX
description: Residents of New York City and seven surrounding counties will begin to feel another pinch in their budgets on Sept. 1, when the state imposes an additional one-quarter of 1 percent sales tax to be used to subsidize operating costs for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: 90,000 See World Games Open
description: The World University Games officially opened today, bringing together athletes from more than 80 countries to compete over the next 10 days in the world's largest sports event outside the summer Olympic Games.

title: Legislators Agree To Deadline on Aid
description: Legislative leaders have set a deadline of tomorrow night for agreement on how to distribute state revenue-sharing funds to localities.

title: No Headline
description: Rugby Protesters Arrested

title: 5,000 Protest in Ottawa
description: An estimated 5,000 protesters, some shouting ''Yankee, go home!,'' marched past the United States Embassy in the Canadian capital today as President Reagan and other Western leaders gathered for their economic summit meeting. It was part of what the organizers called a ''Popular Summit'' sponsored by 60 left-wing, disarmament, environmental and other organizations, most of them Canadian, in opposition to United States support for the Government of El Salvador. There was no violence.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: No Headline
description: The Soviet Union reacted warily today to the reelection of Stanislaw Kania as leader of Poland's Communist Party, suggesting that Moscow was far from satisfied that Mr. Kania could fulfill past pledges to keep Poland a reliable member of the Soviet bloc.

title: Books of Atlanta Fund Challenged by State
description: A state consumer official said today he would subpoena the fund-raising records of a group representing mothers of Atlanta's slain black children. Dr. Tim Ryles of the Office of Consumer Affairs wants them to comply with Georgia's charitable solicitation law.

title: WAR EXERCISE TURNS FORT DRUM INTO A DUTCH PLAIN
description: Beneath the pine forests and through the dewy brush of this North Country Army base, the combined air, naval and land forces of New York State held off an ''enemy'' advance for two days and nights of arduous battle, dust and sore feet.

title: WILL TROLLEYS CLANG AGAIN ON 42D STREET?
description: Bring back a touch of the past with a trip across Manhattan's 42d Street by trolley? It makes good sense, says John S. Dyson, chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York. Citing a new study, he said yesterday that such a trip river to river could take only 18 minutes, instead of 45 minutes chuffing and wheezing by bus.

title: Troy Holbrook Bride of Jonathan Kaye
description: Troy Lisa Holbrook and Jonathan George Kaye, graduate students at Yale University, were married yesterday in Hamden, Conn. Walter Lawton, a leader of the New York Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the Laurel View Country Club.

title: HAITIANS ARRIVE IN BROOKLYN AND LAKE PLACID
description: Federal officials over the weekend began moving several hundred Haitians to detention centers around the country, including an immigration center in Brooklyn and a Federal prison near Lake Placid, N.Y., in an effort to ease serious overcrowding at a Miami camp.

title: DAVID A. LEHERR
description: David A. Leherr, the city editor of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, who underwent surgery for cancer of the pancreas last Monday, died yesterday in West Penn Hospital. He was 43 years old.

title: SURVEYS FIND YOUTHS REGARD ILLICT DRUGS AS HARMFUL
description: Two surveys of high school students, one by The New York Times and the other by the National Institute of Drug Abuse, disclose a growing belief by young persons that smoking marijuana and using other kinds of illicit drugs can be harmful to their health. The institute, an agency of the United States Department of Health and Human Services, regards marijuana as a ''dangerous drug'' that adolescents should not smoke, but it says that evidence linking the drug to disease in humans tends to be ''uncertain'' and ''unconfirmed.''

title: A DREAM DIES AT 92 RIDGE STREET
description: Not long ago, on a list of properties that New York City proposed to take over for nonpayment of taxes, I found a familiar address: 92 Ridge Street, a six-story tenement in Lower Manhattan. Once, this news would have brought forth a tear. Today, only a shrug.

title: DANCE: BELLA LEWITSKY PLAYS SUMMERFARE '81
description: PEPSICO SUMMERFARE '81 offers a number of unusual amenities, among them the pastoral setting of the State University of New York at Purchase, where the festival is held, and the campus's wellappointed, if slightly too colorful theater facilities. And this year - the lively festival's second - a number of dance attractions are being offered that otherwise would go unseen by New Yorkers.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Astrex Inc. said it would purchase a maximum of 100,000 shares of its own stock in the open market from time to time.

title: FOOD STAMPS' FATE AT STAKE IN BUDGET CONFERENCE PANEL
description: All over Capitol Hill this week, 45 groups of lawmakers will be meeting to reconcile differences in the budget cuts adopted by the House and Senate. One group will be deciding the fate of the food stamp program, a sweeping welfare effort that will feed 22 million Americans this year.

title: POLISH PARTY PUTS LIMITS ON TENURE OF ITS LEADERS
description: The Polish Communist Party ended its emergency congress today with the adoption of rules placing limits on the terms of party leaders and in principle rendering them more accountable to the rank and file.

title: Steel Output Up
description: Steel production rose to 2.32 million tons last week, up 1.9 percent from the previous week's 2.28 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: POLANSKI ON POLISH STAGE AMID POLITICAL UPHEAVAL
description: Roman Polanski returned to Poland recently to direct and co-star in a production of Peter Shaffer's ''Amadeus.'' It seemed like a straightforward artistic proposition, but he found himself in the center of a controversy that shows that the political convulsions in Poland are affecting its cultural life.

title: Chess: U.S. Title Tourney Offers 3 Places in Interzonal Test
description: Grandmasters Lubomir Kavalek of Reston, Va., and Samuel Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., shared the lead after six rounds of the United States Championship with 4 1/2-1 1/2 scores here in the Americana Hotel.

title: MURDER CONSPIRACY TRIAL TO BEGIN FOR A MEMBER OF PEOPLE'S TEMPLE
description: The People's Temple horror story will be told again, beginning tomorrow, at the trial of Larry Layton, who is accused of plotting a murderous attack as his last job for Jim Jones, the religious leader who later led most of his flock into suicide.

title: CLOSE RACE FORECAST IN PHILADELPHIA CONGRESSIONAL ELECTION TODAY
description: On this humid day, under threatening skies, David B. Glancey was out at 7 A.M. shaking hands at transit stops. At 4:30 P.M. he had a union rally to attend, at 7:30 P.M. another, and for 9 P.M. there was a radio program waiting.

title: DIRECTORY ASSISTANCE BEYOND THE CALL
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Police Brutality Suit On Philadelphia Dropped
description: The Justice Department has dropped its 1979 police brutality suit against Philadelphia city officials.

title: IN A HOT SPELL, MUSCOVITES JUST MOVE TO THE RIVER
description: Muscovites accustomed to complaining about bitter winters have had something less commonplace to talk about in recent weeks - a heat wave that has exhausted supplies of cool drinks, packed local beaches and camping spots and raised anxieties that there could again be fires such as the ones that raged in surrounding woods and marshlands the last time the Soviet capital had an extended hot spell, in 1972.

title: East and West Reject Compromises in Madrid
description: The 35-nation conference on East-West cooperation in Europe entered what diplomats described as a critical phase today after Eastern and Western representatives both turned down compromise proposals suggested by the other side to break the deadlock.

title: DYSON PROPOSES AGENCY FOR CHEAP POWER
description: John S. Dyson, chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York, proposed yesterday that a new agency distribute inexpensive hydroelectric power equally throughout the state, in part to forestall a scramble by municipalities setting up public-power districts to obtain such electricity.

title: Jenkins Expected to Get Villanova Track Post
description: Charlie Jenkins, a former Villanova runner and a gold-medal Olympian, is expected to be named as Villanova's new track coach tomorrow, The Associated Press has learned.

title: Koch to Permit Rugby Match
description: Over the opposition of the Organization of African Unity, Mayor Koch said yesterday that a rugby match between a South African rugby team and a United States all-star team would be permitted to be held at a city athletic facility.

title: Mothers' Manual
description: John H. Boyd has become the new publisher of Mothers' Manual, replacing Henry B. Kratz, who died last month. The six-times-a-year publication is now at a 900,000 circulation, distributed through obstetricians and sent directly to new mothers at home.

title: ROGER DOUCET
description: Roger Doucet, a former opera singer and nightclub entertainer best known for his rendition of "O Canada" at Montreal Canadiens' hockey games, died yesterday from a brain tumor at the age of 62.

title: 2 Private Investigators To Aid Atlanta Suspect
description: Attorneys for Wayne B. Williams, charged with killing two of Atlanta's 28 young black murder victims, have hired two private investigators in their attempt to discredit the police case.

title: Giants Install Shotgun Offense
description: Two decades ago, the San Francisco 49ers devised the shotgun offense to make the most of the running and passing talents of a rookie named Billy Kilmer. Because the shotgun required a mobile quarterback or tailback, the 49ers traded their immobile quarterback, Y.A. Tittle, to the Giants, and Tittle became a legend of sorts.

title: SLIDE TO 940.54 IS SHARPEST SINCE JAN. 20
description: Stock market prices broke on a wide front yesterday amid mounting fears that interest rates would remain high and eventually damage the economy without achieving further success in reducing inflation.

title: Air Florida to Buy 3 New Boeing Jets
description: Air Florida said that it had signed contracts for three newgeneration Boeing 757-200 twinjets for delivery in 1983 and would use them on an expanded route schedule between the Northeast and Florida.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: There were all manner of transcultural visitation and departure last week - involving Britons, Italians, one Brazilian and the biggest, most orange, weekend moon.

title: A PAINLESS ROAD TO PHILANTHROPY
description: To the Editor:

title: DISPLAY ON LABOR IN CAPITAL
description: The Smithsonian Institution has opened an art, music and film exhibition called ''Images of Labor.'' It features 32 commissioned art works based on famous quotations from the labor movement.

title: A CUBE POPULAR IN ALL CIRCLES
description: The summer's most popular cubes are not the colorless frozen water kind that do nothing but melt lazily in chilled glasses filled with tea, Perrier or Kir. No: This summer's big cube is a maddening Mondrian-colored plastic puzzle, composed of 27 subcubes that rotate on horizontal and vertical axes. It's called Rubik's Cube, after Erno Rubik, a teacher of architecture and design at the School for Commercial Artists in Budapest.

title: REAGAN AND ALLIED LEADERS AGREE TO DISCUSS CURBS ON SOVIET TRADE
description: Leaders of seven major industrial democracies today endorsed an American proposal to discuss the possibility of further restrictions on trade with the Soviet Union, but they came to no agreement on whether to proceed with this course of action.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 21, 1981
description: International Plane deliveries to Israel were halted indefinitely by President Reagan in an effort to promote a cease-fire in Lebanon. Meanwhile, leaders of six other major industrial nations joined Mr. Reagan in issuing a statement deploring the escalation of fighting in the Middle East and calling for restraint by Israeli and Palestinian forces. (Page A1, Column 6.) Yasir Arafat vowed to fight back against the ''barbarian war'' that he said had been started by Israel. As Israeli artillery and jets pounded Palestinian positions in southern Lebanon for the 11th consecutive day, Mr. Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said in Beirut: ''We have nothing to lose.'' (A1:5.)

title: Notes On People; The New Mrs. Autry
description: Gene Autry, the onetime singing cowboy star who owns the California Angels baseball team and several television and radio stations, married a bank executive over the weekend.

title: Bad Advice on Immigration
description: The Cabinet has muffed President Reagan's assignment to help him shape a comprehensive immigration policy. No system for deciding which aliens enter and stay in the United States can be cohesive, or even coherent, that fails to address the question of worker identification.

title: Dancemobile Groups To Play Grant's Tomb
description: The Harlem Cultural Council's Dancemobile, the free, traveling outdoor dance festival that starts its 15th summer season this week, has begun a new program.

title: E.E.C. Sets Dumping Fee
description: The European Community Commission today announced a provisional anti-dumping duty of up to 19.9 percent on imports of the chemical phenol from the United States.

title: WAS THE DINASAUR ACTUALLY SPRIGHTLY?
description: THE popular notion of the dinosaur pictures a ponderous, lumbering behemoth whose great hulk and weight and deliberate movements kept it from roaming far from its birthplace.

title: BUSH TELLS BLACKS OLD AGENDA IS OUT
description: Vice President Bush told participants at the National Urban League conference here today that the door to the White House was open to them but warned that they should not ''bring us an old agenda that has led to the status quo.''

title: A NEW YORK LAW TO KEEP ART DEALERS HONEST
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXT OF CONFERENCE COMMUNIQUE
description: Following is the text of a communique issued today by Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau representing the views of the participants in the economic summit meeting:

title: GENERAL ASSEMBLY ADOPTED DECLARATION ON CHILDREN'S RIGHTS
description: In November 1959 the United Nations General Assembly adopted the Declaration of Rights of the Child, which incorporates 10 principles, including the rights of name, nationality, nutrition, shelter, medical care, love, family and legal protections.

title: REDISTRICTING PROVING AS TROUBLESOME TO GROWING STATES AS TO THE SHRINKING
description: As Congressional redistricting slides the foundations of national political power south and west, the states that gain new members of Congress are having at least as much trouble adjusting to their new status as Northeast and Middle Western states are having in coping with delegations that will shrink.

title: Bosch Plans Layoffs
description: Robert Bosch G.m.b.H., a maker of automotive equipment, will reduce the work force at its Brazilian subsidiary, Robert Bosch do Brasil S.A., by about 1,800 employees, to 6,500, following a sharp fall in orders from the Brazilian car industry, a company spokesman said today.

title: Store Owner Slays Suspect, Seizes 2d in Holdup Attempt
description: The owner of a Brooklyn jewelry store shot and killed one person who attempted to rob him in his store last night and captured a second suspect in the attempted holdup, the police said.

title: BROADCASTING DEREGULATION PROTESTED
description: More than 30 public-interest, labor and religious groups today urged Congress to reject as unfair and dangerous deregulution-of-broadcasting provisions written into Senate budget legislation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on July 11 incorrectly described the origin of malathion, the insecticide used to combat the Mediterranean fruit fly in California. It was developed as an insecticide by the American Cyanamid Company in the late 1940's and was patented in 1951.

title: The Region; Ex-Kearny Mayor And Two Indicted
description: NEWARK (UPI) - A former Mayor of Kearny, the Hudson County purchasing agent and an associate, were indicted in a scheme to extort $12,000 from a furniture dealer who wanted to expand his business.

title: NOTEBOOK: CANADA USING CONFERENCE TO BUOY ITS IMAGE
description: Aware of the rigid demands of Asian courtesy, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, as host for the seven-nation economic summit meeting here, paid a special visit last night to the suite of Japan's Prime Minister, Zenko Suzuki.

title: Gardner M. Day, 81; An Episcopal Rector
description: The Rev. Gardiner M. Day, former rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass., died Sunday at his home in Amherst, N.H. He was 81 years old.

title: Roxane Kamenstein, 72, Won Awards for Fashion Designs
description: Roxane Kamenstein, an award-winning fashion designer, died Saturday at University Hospital in New York. Mrs. Kamenstein, who lived in Miami Beach and had homes in New York City and Westport, Conn., was 72 years old.

title: SOMBER MOOD AT HYATT HEADQUATERS
description: Until tragedy struck in Kansas City last Friday night, the Hyatt Hotels Corporation had enjoyed a 24-year string of good fortune that carried its name and a reputation for fastidious service and plush accommodations to practically every major city in the country.

title: NEW DEFINITION OF DEATH ASSAILED
description: A Roman Catholic bishop today challenged a Presidential commission's call for a new definition of death, saying the recommendation could be a ''stepping stone'' toward euthanasia.

title: Bausch Gets Lens License
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc., the nation's largest contact-lens maker, announced yesterday that it had obtained a nonexclusive license to make and market an extended-wear contact lens developed by the American Hospital Supply Corporation. Extended-wear lenses may be worn for weeks at a time.

title: BEIRUT THREATENS TO ASK FOR SANCTIONS ON ISRAEL
description: Lebanon said today that it would seek sanctions against Israel unless the Israelis agree to halt their attacks.

title: Gunmen in Iran Wound A Presidential Candidate
description: Assassins today shot and wounded a candidate in Iran's coming presidential election, but the Teheran radio indicated that the voting would go ahead on schedule this Friday.

title: Scott Paper Credit
description: The Scott Paper Company announced that it had arranged a sevenyear, $300 million revolving credit agreement with a group of 16 United States banks led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. Scott said that the agreement was part of the financing for a previously announced plan for more than $2 billion in capital investment over the next five years.

title: Mayer, Gottfried Eliminated
description: Second-seeded Gene Mayer was upset by unseeded Stanislav Birner of Czechoslovakia and the defending champion, Brian Gottfried, was eliminated by Angel Giminez of Spain today in the opening round of the $200,000 Washington Star International tennis championships.

title: Lisbon Regime Is Split Over Premier's Policies
description: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao's policies were disavowed publicly today by the Christian Democratic members of the coalition Government, widening the gulf between the Prime Minister and his conservative allies.

title: REAGAN'S CHOICE FOR SCIENCE ADVISER TAKES CAUTIOUS STANCE
description: President Reagan's newly appointed science adviser cautioned today against expecting any quick practical applications from two widely discussed new technologies: high-energy laser beams as defense weapons and nuclear fusion for electric power.

title: Texaco Oil Flow
description: Texaco Inc. said that an oil discovery in the Gulf of Mexico some 90 miles southeast of New Orleans tested 1,009 barrels of oil and 545,000 cubic feet of natural gas daily from depths between 11,746 feet and 11,806 feet. Texaco said that it is the operator of the well and has a 70 percent interest in the block. The remaining 30 percent is held by Tenneco Inc. Texaco said that production would begin as soon as producing equipment and pipelines were installed.

title: The City; Search for Girl, 7, Is Widened on S.I.
description: The search for a 7-year-old Staten Island girl who disappeared last week -reportedly after buying a bar of soap at a delicatessen - was widened to include the waters of the Kill Van Kull.

title: Warranty Set By Cadillac
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that its Cadillac division would give free limited warranty coverage to all of the controversial V8-6-4 engines it used in 1981 models.

title: Advertising; Secondary Selling To Callers
description: WHEN Mary Howitt wrote '' 'Will you walk into my parlor?' said the spider to the fly,'' more than a century ago, she didn't have Infophone in mind. But if it had been around then, she could have.

title: Ohio Edison Write-Off
description: The Ohio Edison Company said it might be forced to write off $80.1 million of costs associated with canceling construction of four nuclear plants because of a recent ruling of the Ohio Supreme Court, the utility said over the weekend. It said the write-off would cut its net income by about $53 million.

title: ARAFAT SAYS P.L.O. WILL FIGHT BACK
description: Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, pledged today to fight back against the ''barbarian, inhu@manitarian war'' that he said had been started by Israel. As he spoke, Israeli artillery and planes pounded Palestinian positions in southern Lebanon for the 11th consecutive day.

title: The City; Court Clears Way For Lottery Payoff
description: Justice Francis N. Pecora of State Supreme Court cleared the way yesterday for a Manhattan woman to receive the first part of her $2.8 million lottery prize, even though a neighbor contends he should get half of it. The judge refused to tie up the money in an escrow account until a claim against Daysi Fernandez, 37 years old, by Christopher Pando, 17, is settled.

title: POSTAL LEADERS CONTINUE TALKS AS PACT EXPIRES
description: Negotiators for the United States Postal Service and two major unions continued bargaining early today past a 12:01 A.M. deadline in an effort to reach agreement on a new three-year contract.

title: Magazine Says Garvey Lost Money on Libel Suit
description: By United Press International Although Steve Garvey, the Los Angeles Dodgers first baseman, has accepted a cash settlement to drop his $11.2 million libel suit against Inside Sports magazine, a magazine spokesman said yesterday that the agreement left Mr. Garvey and his wife with at least $50,000 in unreimbursed expenses.

title: COAST GUARD SAVES A HONDURAN VESSEL CARRYING MARIJUANA
description: The United States Coast Guard over the weekend rescued the 12-man crew of a fishing vessel of Honduran registry after they tried to burn seven tons of marijuana they were carrying and scuttle the ship, authorities said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellweather issues.

title: PACT ON IRAN ASSETS
description: American and Iranian negotiators meeting near Amsterdam have at last reached tentative agreement on conditions for the transfer by the United States of more than $2 billion in oncefrozen Iranian bank deposits, an Administration official said today.

title: SOVIET INVITED TO SISCUSS NEW GRAIN PACT
description: A running dispute between the Agriculture Secretary and the Secretary of State over who would negotiate with the Soviet Union on a new grain trading pact has been settled, and an invitation for new talks has been sent to Moscow, an Agriculture Department official said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LIGHT STUFF

title: KOCH ASKS NEW AGENCY ON FUNDS FOR WESTWAY
description: Mayor Koch proposed yesterday the creation of a state authority to raise money to pay for costs of the Westway highway project that will not be covered by the state or the Federal Government. The Mayor said he did not trust Governor Carey's ability to commit future state funds for this purpose.

title: No Headline
description: People

title: 65% OF CUSTOMERS WITHOUT LOW-COST POWER
description: The chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York said yesterday that 65 percent of the state's utility customers now got ''virtually none'' of the inexpensive hydroelectric power he wants to distribute equally.

title: Talking Business with Kanaga of Arthur Young Accountants And Ethics
description: The accounting profession has been one of the principal beneficiaries of the wave of government regulation that mounted steadily during the 1960's and 1970's. Such regulatory legislation as the 1974 Employee Retirement Income Security Act and the 1977 Foreign Corrupt Practices Act were sometimes referred to within the profession as ''acountants' full-employment acts.'' These laws and others increased the need of corporations for financial reporting, auditing and other accounting services.

title: Saddler, Ex-Champion, Finds a Fighter
description: Through his dark glasses, Sandy Saddler does not like what he sees, except when he watches Tony Santana, the lone professional fighter he trains.

title: DEBATE OVER RIGHTS OF CHILDREN IS INTENSIFYING
description: The children's rights movement, a stepchild of the liberation struggles of the 1960's, has grown into a force affecting the battle over billions of Federal dollars, a host of Government services, and an ever-increasing number of issues involving parents and the courts. The movement, which has been defined as everything from a worthy effort to insure children's maximum potential to an errant attempt to accelerate the breakup of the American family, is currently facing what its leaders call its greatest trial: the policies of the Reagan Administration. This circumstance follows an unparalleled decade of judicial and legislative efforts to define children's rights in relation to the state, the family and the juvenile-justice system. The Rights of Children: A Decade of Change First of five articles.

title: A PARKS INTERN PROGRAM BLOSSOMING FOR SUMMER
description: For the first time since before New York City's fiscal crisis began, the Parks Department has been able to hire trained horticulturists and landscape gardeners to help in the restoration of Central Park, Prospect Park and the city parks in Queens.

title: Ray-Ban Account To Jordan Case
description: Jordan, Case & McGrath can look on the bright side of the business all of time now that Bausch & Lomb, the country's leading maker of visual care products, has assigned the Ray-Ban Sunglasses account to Jordan, Case.

title: Fell Wins 4 at Belmont, Including Daily Double
description: Jeff Fell scored four victories in five mounts and heavily favored Fio Rito won the $54,300 Evan Shipman Stakes in the rain at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: MINNESOTA STATE WORKERS STRIKE FOR CONTRACT
description: Thousands of Minnesota workers put up picket lines around state office buildings, hospitals and parks today in their first statewide strike.

title: TURK SAYS HE TRIED TO KILL THE POPE
description: Mehmet Ali Agca admitted on the first day of his trial here today that he tried to kill Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square on May 13, but said that Italy had no right to try him.

title: Technologies' Net Up 21.6%
description: The United Technologies Corporation today reported earnings for the second quarter ended June 30 of $122.6 million, a 21.6 percent increase over the $100.8 million reported in the previous year's second quarter. Sales rose 19 percent, to $3.56 billion.

title: Japan-Brazil Pact
description: Japan is expected soon to pledge cooperation in a project to develop the Amazon River Basin, which Brazil estimates will cost more than $30 billion, Foreign Ministry officials said today. The International Trade and Industry Minister, Rokusuke Tanaka, and the Foreign Minister, Sunao Sonoda, will visit Brazil soon and convey Japan's readiness to cooperate in the project to develop iron ore, copper, manganese and nickel resources as well as to develop agriculture and forestry, and to build railways and ports, the officials said.

title: Military Analysis
description: The conviction is growing among senior officers of the military services that the most urgent problem facing the military establishment is not choosing among the variety of new weapons promised by the Reagan Administration but the availability of the oldest weapon of all, manpower.

title: YEAR'S EXTENSION FOR 3 CITY TAXES IS VOTED BY COUNCIL PANEL
description: The Finance Committee of the City Council voted yesterday to continue three taxes for another year. They are the personal income tax on city residents, a city earnings tax on nonresidents and a 4 percent tax on the sale of credit rating and reporting services.

title: News Analysis
description: The emergency party congress ended today and when the votes and the tumult died down, one thing was clear - the Polish Communist Party is vastly different from what it was six days ago.

title: INQUIRY IN SMUGGLING FINDS NEW YORK ROLE IN ARMS TRAFFICKING
description: A five-month Customs Service investigation into illegal conspiracies to smuggle helicopter gunships to South Africa has brought growing law-enforcement attention to weapons trafficking in New York.

title: Credit Markets; DOW PLUNGES 18.36; INTEREST RATES CITED
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday in trading that was hectic at times, and dominated by the fear that the large $6.9 billion increase in the basic money supply will spur Federal Reserve efforts to prevent a decline in short-term rates, action that may even result in higher rates.

title: Secrecy Is Not the Only Security
description: The House Intelligence Committee is trying gamely to write a law that protects the identities of American secret agents without threatening the freedom to discuss and criticize their labor. Technically, that's a tricky assignment even for skilled legal draftsmen; politically, it's a thankless task at a time of anxiety over national security. But the sanctity of free speech no less than the safety of spies demands that the lawmakers keep trying.

title: FRANCE ASKED TO DEFER MERGER
description: The United States has asked France to delay acquisition by a French Government-controlled oil company of Texasgulf Inc., the world's largest producer of sulfur and a leading producer of other minerals and petroleum.

title: Social Democrats Oust West German Legislator
description: West Germany's governing Social Democratic Party today expelled a leftist member of Parliament who had accused Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of practicing ''secret diplomacy'' against the German people in connection with the NATO decision to deploy United States nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: Gypsum Stake May Be Lifted
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, a leading producer of lumber, plywood and other forest products, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it plans to increase its stake in the National Gypsum Company of Dallas, a major producer of building materials, to more than 15 percent.

title: ADDING POWER AT A. &P.
description: James W. Wood, the veteran supermarket executive who was named chairman and chief executive officer of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company last year, has added the office of president to his string of titles and consolidated his power at the loss-ridden chain.

title: NOT GUILTY PLEA FILED BY PRIVATE HELD IN KNIFINGS
description: An Army private from Buffalo was arraigned in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday on charges of murdering one man and seriously wounding another in separate mid-Manhattan knifing attacks last Dec. 22.

title: Louis Cheslock, a Composer; Member of Mencken's Circle
description: Louis Cheslock, the last surviving member of H.L. Mencken's Saturday Night Club, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 82 years old.

title: Bill Allows Civil Suit On Wrong Conviction
description: Isidore Zimmerman, who spent 24 years in prison - including time on death row - before the murder conviction against him was dismissed by the State Court of Appeals, will be able to sue the state under a bill approved by Governor Carey.

title: C.D. Trading Set for Chicago
description: The Chicago Board of Trade will open a futures market in domestic certificates of deposit tomorrow morning if, as expected, the Federal Commodity Futures Trading commission approves its proposal at a hearing in Washington at noon today.

title: Pacific Power Unit To Buy Coal Mine
description: The Pacific Power and Light Company said that Nerco, its coal-mining subsidiary, had signed a letter of intent to purchase a metallurgical coal mine 20 miles west of Chattanooga, Tenn., from Barnwell Industries of Fairlawn, N.J.

title: WHAT A DOLLAR CAN BUY
description: To the Editor:

title: Light on Life and Love
description: We are not as far from caves and forests as we thought. The sun our ancestors worshipped does indeed control us; scientists report that humans, even after adapting for centuries to dim city life, secrete a hormone called melatonin in response to levels of natural light. According to the seasons, our bodies signal solar deprivation through changes in mood, bodily functions and fertility.

title: THEIR WRAP AND WOOF IS BUSINESS SAVY
description: They are not the solitary crafts people meditatively weaving mantras into double rugs while brown rice bubbles nearby. Though they have learned their craft with great care, filling their hearts with ''harness and treadle, warp and weft, reed and heddle,'' Jeffrey Aronson, Penny Samelson, Michael Abrams and Susan Horton represent a new breed of weaver who is not so short-sighted as to let reverence obscure the bottom line.

title: NO AMBIGUITY JUSTIFIED
description: If anyone - say President Reagan - has harbored honest doubt about the need for renewal of the historic Voting Rights Act of 1965, that doubt should have been dispelled by the Reagan Justice Department's rejection last week of a Virginia reapportionment plan.

title: A CHURCH WINS BATTLE ON TAXES
description: The New York City Tax Commission has ruled that a church on the Lower East Side does not have to pay the taxes levied on its property after the small congregation demolished its church building and planted a garden on the site seven years ago.

title: Jet Defense to Bump and Run
description: Their names were Hudson, Sample, Beverly and Baird, and they had something in common besides forming the Jets' defensive backfield in their 1968 Super Bowl season.

title: REAGAN ATTACKS EFFORT TO KEEP MINIMUM PENSION
description: President Reagan today accused House Democrats who are trying to preserve the minimum benefit guaranteed by the Social Security system of ''opportunistic political maneuvering, cynically designed to play on the fears of many Americans.''

title: ENGINEERS TURN EXTREME COLD INTO ALLY TO PODUCE MORE POWER
description: FOR most of the 70 years since its discovery, superconductivity - the ability of certain ultracold substances to conduct electricity without resistance - has been a scientific curiosity beyond the reach of industrial exploitation. But engineers now seem close to taming it as the basis of a new generation of energy-saving power systems.

title: Soccer Player Plans Suit Over Elbowing Incident
description: Elias Figueroa, a defender with the Fort Lauderdale Strikers, said today that he has instructed his lawyer to file a damage suit against the Jacksonville Tea Men and Bob Newton, a forward with the team.

title: Mayor's Daughter Attacked
description: The teen-age daughter of the Mayor of Trenton was punched in the face today when she surprised a would-be thief in the family's kitchen, authorities said. Mayor Arthur Holland said his daughter, 17-year-old Elise, received two stitches in her upper lip after the assault. The intruder escaped but a woman who apparently had been acting as a lookout was arrested, according to the Trenton police.

title: Bridge: Social Aspects Important For Event in Westchester
description: In the hurly-burly of competitive play, the social aspects are sometimes neglected. A good example in this area is demonstrated annually by the Westchester Contract Bridge Association, which concludes its double knockout team championship with a buffet supper. The 1981 event, organized by Bill Hoffman of Irvington, N.Y., and Jack Bonney of Peekskill, N.Y., ended under the stars at the Purchase Country Club.

title: Ladish Accepts Armco Offer
description: The Ladish Company, a privately held metals concern based in Cudahy, Wis., said yesterday that its board had voted to reject a $270 million takeover offer by ACF Industries in favor of a revised $286 million stock acquisition offer from Armco Inc. Armco, the nation's fifth-largest steel producer, had earlier bid $221 million for Ladish.

title: YOUTHS HELP SPRUCE UP IN SUBWAYS
description: Anna Sumpter, a 14-year-old from the West Bronx, was looking forward to working as a counselor under New York City's Summer Youth Employment Program. Starmane Green of Brownsville had ''put in for school -to teach the kids'' when she signed up with Summer Youth and was eager to start. But when the girls showed up for their first day on the job, they were handed brooms and directed to the Times Square IRT subway station.

title: Article 201221 -- No Title
description: Citing Martha Graham as a ''supreme innovator'' without whose independent spirit ''the arts in the 20th century would not be the same,'' Betty Ford presented the first $25,000 Samuel H. Scripps Award to the 86-year-old modern-dance choreographer last night at the American Dance Festival here.

title: WILL BASEBALL FANS RTURN?
description: Will baseball fans forgive and forget when the strike ends? Or will they turn away from baseball and spend their time and money on other pastimes cultivated during the lost summer?

title: Hair-Care Conflict At Ogilvy & Mather
description: The conflict that caused the rift between Bristol-Myers's Clairol Products division and Ogilvy & Mather, which has been handling three Condition brands, resulted from the Rave Hair Products, the account that the agency has from Chesebrough-Ponds.

title: Notes On People
description: McG. Thomas Jr. Baby-Sitting Position Leads to a Royal Wedding

title: The Region; Jersey to Control Camden Finances
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Governor Byrne has signed a measure that will allow the state to control the municipal operations of Camden until the city becomes financially stable.

title: JUDGE BACKS REFUSAL BY C.I.A. TO PROVIDE DATA ON EX-AGENT
description: The Central Intelligence Agency acted properly in refusing to release copies of more than 8,000 documents to Philip Agee, a former C.I.A. agent who has vowed to obstruct the agency's work, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Abbatiello Sidelined
