description: Carmine Abbatiello, the leading driver at Roosevelt Raceway, will be out of action because of a broken hand he suffered in the American Trotting Championship last Saturday night. Abbatiello's left hand was placed in a cast yesterday and he will be unable to drive for at least a week. Keystone Hallmark, the horse Abbatiello drove in the championship, suffered a broken neck and died instantly after a spill.

title: CITIZENS UNION SAYS COUNCIL VIOLATED VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: The Citizens Union of New York City has charged the City Council with redrawing Council district boundaries for the purpose of ''protecting white incumbents.'' And it asserts that the changes violate the Voting Rights Act of 1965 by diluting minority voting strength.

title: Budget Legislation And Food Stamps
description: This is one of a series of occasional articles following one program, food stamps, through the legislative process.

title: CHARITIES FAVORED IN TAX VOTE
description: By a vote of 97 to 1, the Senate today approved legislation that would let taxpayers who take the standard deduction on their tax returns also claim a separate deduction for charitable contributions.

title: U.S. JOINS SEARCH FOR CONVICT-WRITER
description: Federal law enforcement authorities have joined the search for Jack Henry Abbott, the convict-author who is suspected of having stabbed a waiter to death outside a Lower East Side restaurant last Saturday morning.

title: MOBIL SUIT BY CONOCO IS PLANNED
description: Directors of Conoco Inc., after a three-hour special board meeting, voted unanimously yesterday to oppose a $7.7 billion takeover bid from the Mobil Corporation and authorized the company to sue Mobil on antitrust grounds.

title: The City; JURY VOTES NO BILL IN BRONX SHOOTING
description: A Bronx County grand jury has ruled that a police officer acted properly in the line of duty on July 1 when he shot and killed a man who was brandishing a machete.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Do conifers and deciduous trees have differences besides the shape of their leaves?

title: Vengeance on Flies
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES:

title: Canada Mail Strike Goes On
description: Government representatives and leaders of the Canadian Union of Postal Workers met for four and a half hours today with a mediator but declined to say if any progress was made toward ending the 22-day-old strike by postal employees.

title: AILING HARVESTER'S GRUELING BATTLE
description: International Harvester's grueling five-month, $4.9 billion financial restructuring was supposed to be completed last week. But the company's self-imposed deadline passed quietly, as a handful of dissident bankers have yet to approve a new credit arrangement.

title: ARTHUR K. TRAIN
description: Arthur K. Train, author of ''Spoken Like a Frenchman,'' a guide to French argot, died of heart failure Saturday at the Emerson (N.J.) Convalescence Center.

title: f4; EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aluminum Company of America named Marvin E. Gantz Jr. a director and vice chairman of the board. * Colgate-Palmolive Company appointed Thomas M. Casey a director.

title: 200,000 REINFORCE DIKES ALONG YANGTZE RIVER
description: An army of 200,000 workers shored up dikes along the Yangtze River today and tamed flood waters that swept through central China, killing more than 3,000 people and ravaging vital crop land.

title: N.F. L. NET IN 1970 PUT AT
description: $22.5 MILLION

title: The City; Columbia's Station Off the Air Again
description: An attempt by Columbia University's radio station to transmit from the World Trade Center ended after 45 minutes with station managers awaiting a permit from the Federal Communications Commission to broadcast from that site.

title: Sports of The Times; Even Soccer Stars Miss Baseball
description: EVEN soccer players miss baseball. While negotiations continue in Washington, some of the best foreign-born players in the North American Soccer League feel a gap in their lives because baseball is shut down.

title: THE RISKS OF WESTWAY
description: It is beginning to appear that most species can learn how to stand upright in less time than it takes our city and state governments to reach a decision on building a road.

title: Flagship Accepts Royal Trustco Bid
description: The executive committee of Flagship Banks Inc., Florida's fifth-largest bank holding company, has approved in principle a $290 million (United States) acquisition offer by Royal Trustco Ltd., Canada's largest trust company group, officials of the two concerns said today.

title: Lakers Bid for Kupchak
description: Mitch Kupchak, a free-agent forward, has received an offer sheet from the Los Angeles Lakers and is expected to sign it early this week, his agent, Larry Fleisher, said yesterday.

title: Article 201340 -- No Title
description: Two yearling colts sired by Northern Dancer, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes in 1964, were sold for $6,800,000 at tonight's session of the Keeneland Selected Yearling Sale. The $3,500,000 paid for one of them, out of the mare South Ocean, was a world record for a yearling colt.

title: Hewlett-Packard Plans British Plant
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, a major supplier of precision electronic equipment, announced plans for a new manufacturing facility in Britain that would make advanced disk memory devices used with Hewlett computer systems and engage also in research and development.

title: CALVIN COOLIDGE, THE SUPPLY-SIDER
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSEUMS' OPTIONS
description: In 1897, Mark Twain wrote: ''A round man cannot be expected to fit in a square hole right away. He must have time to modify his shape.'' With the impending deep cuts in the Government's support of cultural programs, time to adapt to starkly altered conditions is a necessity that may not be accorded American museums this year. The Government would do well to avoid precipitous action if it values the preservation of our cultural heritage.

title: PUBLISHERS TURNING COOL TO THE TIE-IN NOVELIZATION OF MOVIES
description: LOS ANGELES TURNING movies into successful books is a tricky business. A few years ago, Bantam, Dell, Ballantine, Warner Books and half a dozen other paperback houses were offering hundreds of thousands of dollars for screenplays they could transmute into novels. Today, the average price paid for a movie is $25,000. Such recent box-office successes as ''Bustin' Loose'' and ''The Four Seasons'' never even got a nibble from publishers.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has certified for commercial service two models of a Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group jet engine, the company announced.

title: Du Pont Up 50.6%; Carbide Rises 29%
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical producer, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter of 1981 increased 50.6 percent as sales rose 14.2 percent.

title: No Headline
description: The New York Times/Chester Higgins Jr. Yet Another Challenge for Subway Riders Getting into the IRT Times Square station yesterday required some fast lane-changing to stay on the right track.

title: K.G.B. DISINFORMATION
description: The current concern in some Congressional and journalistic circles about Soviet ''disinformation'' activities in the United States news media rests upon a fundamental misunderstanding of the K.G.B. program.

title: TO TIDE OVER THE THRIFTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We call on all states and parties to exercise restraint and, in particular, to avoid retaliation which only results in escalation, and to forgo acts which could lead in the current tense situation in the area to further bloodshed and war.'' - Statement on the Middle East by the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan, West Germany and the United States. (A8:3.)

title: Notes On People; A Red, White and Blue Isolde for Bayreuth
description: The first American-born performer to sing the role of Isolde in ''Tristan and Isolde'' at the Bayreuth Wagner Festival in West Germany will be Johanna Meier.

title: Market Place; High-Yielding Turnpike Bond
description: THE crush of traffic at important New Jersey Turnpike exits this summer is no fun for motorists. But it is good news for holders of the turnpike bonds.

title: Imported Car Stocks Up
description: Inventories of new imported cars in the hands of American dealers, importers and distributors stood at 441,000 on July 1, compared with 432,500 a month earlier, the trade paper Automotve News reported today. This level is 51 days' supply at current sales rates, compared with 48 days' supply a month earlier, it said.

title: Sheriff and Judge Agree On Chaining of Prisoners
description: A judge declined today to issue a formal order that would keep Sheriff Tommy Robinson from chaining any more jail inmates outside prison facilities, but he told Sheriff Robinson not to do it again.

title: PENN CENTRAL IN TALKS ON MERGER WITH COLT
description: The Penn Central Corporation said yesterday that it was holding merger discussions with Colt Industries regarding the merger of Colt with one of Penn Central's subsidiaries.

title: U.S. AND 6 ALLIES URGE ALL SIDE IN MIDDLEAST TO CEASE REPRISALS
description: President Reagan today put off indefinitely the delivery of two shipments of American jet fighter-bombers to Israel because of the ''escalating level of violence'' in the Middle East.

title: Briefs; BRIEFS
description: * Dibrell Brothers Inc., a supplier and exporter of tobacco, said that it would acquire the principal assets of B.V. Tabak Export and Import Compagnie of Amsterdam for about $25 million. Tabak is an international tobacco merchant with processing and exporting operations in Brazil and Zimbabwe.

title: EDUCATION
description: THE hopes that were aroused in the early 1970's for a greater black presence on college and university faculties by the end of the century now seem to be fading.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Interest rates, once considered a topic that appealed mostly to financiers, have moved to the top of the agenda of this summit conference of the leaders of the industrial world.

title: KANSAS CITY SUBDUED AS FUNERALS BEGIN FOR VICTIMS OF DISASTER
description: When the 40-story Hyatt Regency Hotel opened here a year ago, the event was another milestone in a master plan by the city's prestigious Hall family to bolster Kansas City's newly fostered pride as a progressive Middle Western city.

title: Canada Policies Are Criticized
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige today criticized Canada's foreign investment policies as discriminatory and harmful to the United States.

title: CALIFORNIA ENDS FIRST PHASE OF FLY SPRAYING AS QUARANTINE WIDENS
description: California completed the first phase of its aerial pesticide war against the Mediterranean fruit fly early today and went to court to stop several state quarantines from impeding shipments of Californian fruits and vegetables.

title: 23 Die in Guatemala Unrest
description: At least 23 people died during a weekend of violence in Guatemala as guerrillas marked the anniversary of the leftist triumph in nearby Nicaragua, the police reported today. About 10 members of the security forces were said to have been among the casualties when leftists attacked rural towns, blew up Government buildings and blocked roads.

title: INDEXING TAXES TO INFLATION
description: While debate continues on the third year of an income-tax cut, the Senate, with hardly any fuss at all, voted last week for a proposal that would hold down tax increases indefinitely. It was approved as an amendment to the Senate's tax package.

title: IN ULSTER, PROTESTANT MILITIA GRIMLY STANDS BY
description: In a grimy red brick building on East Belfast's Newtonards Road, the militant Protestants of the Ulster Defense Association await the death of each Roman Catholic hunger striker in a sullen and fearful mood.

title: ALTERNATIVE PLANS MADE FOR MAIL DELIVERY
description: New York City's Postmaster, George F. Schuman, said yesterday that ''regardless of any eventuality, the mail will be processed and moved to the best of our ability.''

title: WOMAN IN KIBBUTZ KILLED BY ROCKET
description: An Israeli woman was killed this morning during a rocket attack on a kibbutz near the Lebanese border. She was the fourth Israeli civilian to be killed in the recent upsurge of fighting.

title: Rutherford Will Bypass Pocono for Norton 500
description: Johnny Rutherford will not drive in Sunday's scheduled Pocono 500 Grand National stock car race because of complications following the postponement of yesterday's Norton Michigan 500.

title: Heritage First Finisher In Mackinac Yacht Race
description: Heritage, a 63-foot yacht, became the first boat to finish the 74th annual Chicago-to-Mackinac Island yacht race, race officials said tonight.

title: CAREY KILLS BILL ALLOWING REMOVAL OF 'COERCED' MEMBERS FROM CULTS
description: Governor Carey announced today that he had vetoed a bill that would have allowed courts to appoint temporary guardians to remove people forcibly from cults.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Strike Explained
description: When Ronald Reagan was the host of G.E. Theater and bicycles had a single gear, baseball cards came in opaque paper wrappers, five to the nickel pack with a generous portion of bubble gum. The gum, sickly pink in large thin sheets, was always stale; when dropped on a hard surface it shattered like Turkish taffy. And it made no better bubbles than a stick of Dentyne. But the gum was part of the experience, the price for the sinful pleasure of gambling on finding a rare Richie Ashburn or Elroy Face.

title: PSYCOTHERAPISITS FOCUS ON FINAL SESSIONS AS CRUCIAL TO
description: SUCCESS By DAVA SOBEL

title: James L. Buffington, French-Horn Player
description: James L. Buffington, a French-horn player who performed with many of New York's chamber orchestras and also had a career in jazz and popular accompaniment, died yesterday of a stroke in Englewood, N.J. He was 59 years old.

title: LETTERS
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES: It was a pleasure to read of Edward Cupp's success in rearing black flies in his laboratory as described in Jane Brody's article ''In Trying to Control Black Flies, Scientist Learns to Breed Them First'' (July 7th). However, one particular statement of Miss Brody's is in error.

title: Forest Strike Widens
description: The last of British Columbia's three major forest unions, 7,000 members of the Canadian Paperworkers Union, walked out today, bringing to 60,000 the number of forest workers on strike. Members of the International Woodworkers of America went out July 12 and were joined by the Pulp, Paper and Woodworkers of Canada the next day.

title: Brooklyn Synagogue Robbed Of Scrolls Valued at $50,000
description: A Brooklyn synagogue was robbed between Sunday night and yesterday morning of seven religious scrolls worth $50,000 to $70,000, the police reported.

title: POST OFFICE BUSINESS AS USUAL
description: As the midnight deadline for a postal strike approached last night, there was the usual collection of lastminute patrons in the main post office here.

title: CONCERN REPORTS DISAPPEARANCE OF EX-C.I.A. AIDE'S ACCUSER
description: The Triad Energy Corporation yesterday announced the disappearance of its president, Samuel F. McNell, whose allegations of fraud prompted the resignation last week of Max C. Hugel as chief of clandestine operations for the Central Intelligence Agency. At the same time, the company had trading in its stock halted.

title: FORD UNABLE TO ACHIEVE TOYOTA PRODUCTION TIE
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had been unable to reach agreement with the Toyota Motor Company for joint production of a Toyota-designed small car or van in the United States.

title: Notes On People; REALTY AGENT BLOWS THE WHISTLE ON A FORD MOVE
description: When he went to Pittsburgh four years ago, the young minister made it clear that he wanted to live quietly, and for the most part he suceeded. So much so, in fact, that when he moved from the city last month, almost no one knew he was gone.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: city school systems in the near future.

title: Selection of Jury Begins In Miami Riot Trial
description: Jury selection began today for the retrial of the last defendant charged with murder in the city's 1980 racial riots.

title: THE DOORS OF ISRAEL MUST REMAIN OPEN FOR ALL JEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: Vitamin Deficiency
description: Some of the psychoactive drugs widely used to treat mental patients can create a riboflavin deficiency in laboratory animals, according to a study by researchers at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: THE DOORS OF ISRAEL MUST REMAIN OPEN FOR ALL JEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region; Jersey Lag Cited On New Fire Law
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Most of New Jersey's 100,000 hotels and apartment buildings do not have the fire alarms and smoke detectors required by a law enacted last January, the state's Division of Housing said yesterday.

title: HOW POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 28-July 1 with 1,467 adults around the United States.

title: Economic Summit Meeting
description: Leaders of the seven major industrial democracies meeting in Ottawa agreed to delay consideration of tightened trade restrictions with the Soviet Union. The group, however, approved an American proposal to hold a conference on limitations of high-technology and miltary exports to Eastern bloc countries. (Page A1.)

title: Moratorium on Whaling Is Proposed by Reagan
description: President Reagan made a personal plea to the International Whaling Commission today for an indefinite moratorium on commercial whaling.

title: Saumell's Stay Draws Appeal
description: Lawyers for the New York Racing Association and the New York State Racing and Waging Board said yesterday that they planned to appeal a temporary restraining order that allowed the jockey Larry Saumell to accept mounts at Belmont Park.

title: U.S. TO PROSECUTE YOUTHS TO COMPEL SIGN-UP FOR DRAFT
description: The Selective Service System, with the approval of the Reagan Administration, asked the Justice Department today to begin prosecuting young men for failing to register for military conscription.

title: MINORITY JOB SEEKERS PROTEST AT TWO BUILDING SITES
description: About 500 black and Hispanic protesters scuffled with the police yesterday during demonstrations at two major midtown building sites on 56th Street, where the protesters said they were seeking jobs for minority workers.

title: Business people; LAWYER HEADS SCOA
description: ''You can't be a lawyer without getting interested sometimes in what your client is doing,'' said George R. Friese, a 45-year-old lawyer, explaining his new appointment as president and chief operating officer of SCOA Industries, a $1-billion-a-year retail company based in Columbus, Ohio.

title: TALKS RESUME IN WASHINGTON
description: On the 39th day of the baseball strike, negotiators for the players and owners moved their dispute to Washington today to give Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan a chance to help them settle their differences. If there was any immediate benefit, it appeared to be in the improved atmosphere that prevailed in the talks.

title: MUSIC: SUN RA AND ARKESTRA
description: LISTENERS at the Battery Park City Landfill on Sunday evening could wiggle their toes in the sand and enjoy Sun Ra's incantations to the universe. This Art on the Beach concert presented ''Omniverse II'' with Mr. Ra and the Omniverse Arkestra.

title: RKO OFFERS TO TRANSFER CHANNEL 9 TO JERSEY TO INSURE A NEW LICENSE
description: RKO General, which operates WOR-TV on Channel 9 in New York City, has offered to move its main studio to New Jersey and concentrate on New Jersey news as a condition for renewal of its broadcasting license.

title: Editor of The Oakland Tribune Gets Added Role of Publisher
description: Robert C. Maynard, editor of The Oakland Tribune-Eastbay Today, today was given the additional role of publisher of the two newspapers.

title: SIKORSKY NAMES A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Robert F. Daniell has not yet qualified for a pilot's license. Nonetheless, he was named president yesterday of the Sikorsky Aircraft division of the United Technologies Corporation.

title: I. Arnold Ross, Served In Assembly in 1930's
description: I. Arnold Ross, a lawyer and former New York State Assemblyman, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a stroke. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DEATH OF TAIWAN PROFESSOR CAUSES UPROAR ON A PITTSBURGH CAMPUS
description: The death of a professor from Carnegie-Mellon University hours after he was interrogated by security police in Taiwan who accused him of anti-Government activities has stirred questions from his colleagues and disclosed a deep rift among Taiwan citizens living in this area.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Bill Babcock, left-handed pitcher who was second choice in free-agent draft, and assigned him to Sarasota in Florida rookie league.; BASKETBALL LOS ANGELES - Presented offer sheet to Mitch Kupchak, free-agent forward for- merly with Washington Bullets, who must match offer or lose Kupchak if he signs sheet.; COLLEGE MANHATTAN - Appointed Tony Branch, former assistant at Louisville, top assistant to Gordon Chiesa, head basket- ball coach, and Joe Napolitano, former assistant a
description: ATLANTA (NFC) - Released three p layers: Michael Wright, running back f rom Texas Christian, Terry White, defen- s ive back from Pittsburgh, and Darrell C handler, running back from Virginia S tate. Cliff Toney, eighth-round draft c hoice from Auburn, left training camp. BUFFALO (AFC) - Signed Justin C ross, tackle-center from Western State; M ike Mosley, wide receiver from Texas A & M, Ben Garry, running back formerly w ith Baltimore Colts, John Macon, run- n ing back from Purdue, and Kent Davis, c ornerback from Canadian Football L eague. CHICAGO (NFC) - Signed Wentford G aines, cornerback. DALLAS (NFC) - Released 19 free a gents: Scott Carter, linebacker, San D iego State; Mark Cruise, defensive back, R hode Island; Greg Grim, defensive back, M ississippi State; Marlon Heggs, wide re- c eiver, Georgia Tech; Mike Linker, tack- l e, Puget Sound; Tom McLaughlin, punt- e r, Iowa; Jeff Morrow, punter, Kent S tate; Kelvin Newton, linebacker, Texas C hristian; Rich Pennella, punter, Louis- v ille; Rick Ruzika, tackle, Columbia; R obert Salter, defensive back, Gram- b ling; Mike Simpson, defensive back, Cen- t ral Michigan; Greg Sims, defensive back, G uilford; Jeff Thomas, linebacker, Con- n ecticut; Jeff Townsend, defensive back,. W ichita State; Willie Underwood, defen- s ive back, Clemson; Brett Ure, lineback- e r, Utah State; Gary Walker, defensive b ack, San Jose State. George Stephenson, t ackle from Auburn, left camp voluntarily a nd was placed on reserve list. DENVER (AFC) - Jon Keyworth, run- n ing back from 1974-1980, announced re- t irement.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Michiko Kakutani THE FLOWERING OF IRELAND. By Katharine Scherman. 368 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: The Region; Caesars' Founders Lose Court Appeal
description: The Appelate Division of Superior Court yesterday upheld a ruling by the Casino Control Commission that Caesars World must cease casino operations in New Jersey unless the company's founders, Clifford S. and Stuart Z. Perlman, sever all ties with Caesars' casinos in Atlantic City and Nevada.

title: DOMINIQUE SANDRA SEEKS MORE THAN HER 'INHERITANCE'
description: AT the start of ''The Inheritance,'' it appears as if Dominique Sanda has been cast as a bashful bride in turn-of-the-century Italy. This would seem to be a terrible mistake, because Miss Sanda hasn't the least bit of bashfulness to her makeup. But it soon becomes apparent that we're in Sidney Sheldon country, because the bride turns into a scheming witch who's after her father-in-law's money. Because he has a couple of sons, it takes Irene (Miss Sanda) the whole length of the movie to work - if one can call it work - her way to the top.

title: Carey Vetoes Criteria On Plant Air Quality
description: Governor Carey today vetoed a bill that would have subjected the State Power Authority's proposed 700-megawatt coal-and garbage-fired power plant to the city's air-quality standards.

title: East Europe Hit by Floods
description: Flood waters continued to rise in Austria, Czechoslovakia and Hungary today as torrential rain flowed into swollen rivers for a third consecutive day. Czechoslovakia halted all shipping on the Elbe River, which has risen six feet in the last 24 hours, the official Czechoslovak press agency said. The Danube River has overflowed its banks in several places in Austria, and it has risen by six feet in two days in western Hungary.

title: RESOLUTION ON LEBANON
description: Following is the draft of a proposed Security Council resolution on the current fighting between Israeli and Palestinian forces:

title: HOUSE UNIT SUGGESTS RENEWAL TILL 1992 OF VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: After a 10-minute session with no debate, a House subcommittee voted unanimously today to recommend passage of a bill extending all the temporary provisions of the Voting Rights Act until 1992.

title: Success Story
description: It's a long way from a sharecropper's shack in Pike County, Ala., to a mansion in Beverly Hills, but Eula McClaney made the trip. For a woman who began her working life walking behind a mule-drawn plow and now rides around in a Rolls-Royce, it was an inspirational journey to success, and the New York Public Library is now going to make sure that her milestones are preserved for posterity.

title: Lebanon's Tapline Debt
description: Saudi Arabia has given $120 million to Lebanon to pay off that country's debts to the Trans-Arabian Pipeline Company, or Tapline, the official Saudi press agency said today. Caltex, Mobil, Texaco, Standard Oil of California and Exxon own Tapline, which pumps oil from Saudi Arabia's Ras Tanura terminal on the Persian Gulf to a refinery at Zahrani, Lebanon.

title: NEW MUSICAL DELAYED
description: Allan Carr, the producer, announced yesterday that Mike Nichols and Tommy Tune would not direct the new Broadway musical ''The Queen of Basin Street,'' as previously announced. Mr. Carr said that there were ''creative, artistic and financial differences'' between himself and Mr. Nichols and Mr. Tune. No new director has been named yet. Mr. Carr said that ''The Queen of Basin Street,'' based on the film hit ''La Cage aux Folles,'' had been postponed until next spring.

title: INDUSTRY AND THE K.G.B.
description: Although the K.G.B. is best known for its espionage operations in the West, some of them quite spectacular, its greatest long-term contribution to Soviet Union's interests has been, in my judgment, the undramatic year-in, year-out collecting of restricted or classified information on American technology. This bread-and-butter work probably consumes at least 80 percent of its operational manpower in the United States today.

title: INA Net Edges Up
description: The INA Corporation, the diversified Philadelphia-based insurer, reported yesterday that operating net in the second quarter increased 2.4 percent, to $75.9 million, or $1.89 a share, from $74.1 million, or $1.91 a share, on a smaller number of shares, in the similar period a year earlier. In the latest quarter INA had capital losses of $888,000, while in the 1980 period, capital losses were $1.2 million. Net income in the second quarter rose 2.7 percent, to $75 million, or $1.86 a share, from $73 million, or $1.88 a share, a year earlier.

title: Chase Offers Equimark $125 Million Investment
description: In a move intended ultimately to position itself in the Pittsburgh consumer-banking market, the Chase Manhattan Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to invest $125 million in the troubled Equimark Corporation, that city's third-largest bank holding company.

title: Short-Term Rates Move Up; Bond Buyers Still Scarce
description: The credit markets stabilized yesterday but remained extremely nervous as long-term interest rates fell slightly, while short-term rates moved higher.

title: LYUDMILA ZHIVKOVA, BULGARIA CULTURE AIDE
description: Lyudmila Zhivkova, one of Bulgaria's most powerful political figures, has died, the Government press agency B.T.A. reported today. She would have been 39 years old next Sunday.

title: Judge Orders List of Cubans In Prison for Lack of Papers
description: A Federal district judge today ordered Attorney General William French Smith to provide him with a list of all Cubans being detained solely because they lacked proper papers when they entered this country.

title: Sports of The Times; ABOUT THE MAN IN UPPER SEVEN
description: I N 1929 Red Badgro was a rookie right fielder with the St. Douis Browns in spring training at West Palm Beach, Fla. In those days of innocence and nationad prohibition, the players seldom went adventuring far from the club's hotel, a pasteboard palace near the railroad station. There was gambling at Bradley's in Palm Beach, and George Lamaze had a club there that offered fine victuals and booze, but not many of the Browns could afford those pleasures.

title: Delaying Planes Isn't Saying Much
description: By delaying the delivery of a few more F-16's, President Reagan is either telling Prime Minister Begin that he does not want American planes raining death on downtown Beirut or he is telling him nothing. Yet the President does not say what he means, because he is reluctant to make American military aid contingent on Israeli conduct and because he recognizes that in a 33-year cycle of violence between Israelis and Palestinians there have been outrages enough on both sides.

title: Hunts Paying Civil Penalties On Soybeans
description: The Government accepted a settlement today with Nelson Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt that requires the brothers and members of their family to pay $500,000 in civil penalties and prohibits them from trading in soybean futures for two years.

title: News Analysis
description: Summarizing the proceedings at this seventh annual economic summit conference of the major industrial democracies, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada maintained last night that each participant ''went some distance'' in accommodating the views of the others.

title: CONCERT: ASPEN CHAMBER SYMPHONY
description: A GOOD musical performance should arouse in the listener a sense that the universe is firmly under control. An ineffable feeling of well-being must set in fairly quickly, and it is perhaps only the hardened observer who can feel it necessary to distance himself from the general warm glow in order to note how this good performance differs from the last one. Still, even the flintiest soul would have found it difficult to hold itself apart from the community last night at the Mostly Mozart Festival Hall while Shlomo Mintz was playing Mozart's Violin Concerto No. 4 in D (K. 218). Mr. Mintz, a young Israeli violinist whose stature has been increasing fast of late, gave one of those totally assured, pitch-perfect, rhythmically right performances that make listeners turn to their neighbors and smile.

title: Rose Kennedy Is 91
description: She has 29 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, and many of them are expected to be on hand today when Rose Kennedy celebrates her 91st birthday at the family compound on Cape Cod.

title: Motion Bars Saumell Again
description: The jockey Larry Saumell, barred from New York Racing Association tracks July 12 after being charged with possession of a battery before a race at Belmont Park June 22, was barred again yesterday under a legal maneuver by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: KOCH PLAN WOULD PUT WORKS OF ART IN ALL NEW PUBLIC BUILDNGS
description: The Koch administration proposed legislation yesterday that would require that works of art be included in every newly constructed or substantially reconstructed municipal building open to the public.

title: MANY QUESTIONS RAISED BY NEW PROPERTY-GAINS TAX
description: Whatever else may be said about it, the 10 percent gains tax on large transfers of real estate enacted by the New York State Legislature three weeks ago as part of the financial package to aid the city's transit system came suddenly and unexpectedly. When an assistant to Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink was asked where the idea originated, he said it came from the Municipal Research Institute.

title: MOYNIHAN ASSAILS WHITE HOUSE ON CASEY FILES
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan charged today that the White House and the Justice Department had ignored the Senate Intelligence Committee's repeated requests for confidential files relating to the business dealings of the Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey.

title: Books of the Times
description: DUCHESS. THe Story of Wallis Warfield Simpson. By Stephen Birmingham. 335 pages. Little, Brown. $15.95. ------

title: IN TOKYO, A RAUCOUS HONKY-TONK AREA THAT HAS NO CRIME
description: Ikebukuro, in western Tokyo, is a teeming district with bars, cheap eating places, porno shops, Turkish baths that serve as cover for prostitution and two dozen ''love hotels,'' where rooms can be rented by the hour. At night, its narrow alleys are awash with garish lights, and hawkers urge strollers into sleazy places.

title: U.S. ASSAILS CHICAGO INTEGRATION PLAN
description: The Department of Justice today criticized as ''incomplete'' the Chicago school board's plan for voluntary school desegregation and asked the Federal judge overseeing the case to require the board to submit a revised plan ''that desegregates schools as much as is practical in September 1982.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Computer Store Inc. said it had bought four computer outlets from Carrols Development Corp. on undisclosed terms.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm as much an Englishman as Prince Charles is. India's not my home.

title: New Lehman Corporation Chairman
description: Edmund A. Hajim, 44, a managing director of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, the international investment banking and brokerage firm, has been elected chairman of the Lehman Corporation, the firm's $600 million, closed-end fund. He has also been named to the newly created office of the chairman of The One William Street Fund, a $300 million, no-load equity mutual fund managed by the Lehman Management Company, the investment advisory arm of the firm.

title: Bomb in Switzerland Injures 15 People
description: Fifteen people were hurt today when a bomb apparently planted by Armenian nationalists exploded in a department store in Lausanne. It was the third bombing incident linked to Armenian nationalists in Switzerland in three days.

title: KOKO TAYLOR RECORDS 'FROM HEART OF WOMAN'
description: WHEN KoKo Taylor closed the ''Blues Is a Woman'' concert at last summer's Newport-New York Jazz Festival, her ferocious intensity took a number of listeners, and most of the concert's reviewers, by surprise. One would have thought from reading the critics's reactions that her performance was utterly lacking in restraint and subtlety. Miss Taylor is a powerful performer, but she can also be a sensitive one, and she has finally made an album that proves it. ''From the Heart of a Woman,'' which has just been released by Alligator records, is her finest recording.

title: Bonn Plans to Cut Borrowing
description: West Germany has decided to reduce public borrowing in the present climate of high United States interest rates, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt told reporters here today at the end of the economic conference.

title: SALVADOR TROOPS FLY TO HONDURAS
description: An American-trained battalion of the Salvadoran Army landed in Honduras last week and then crossed the border back into El Salvador to attack this village.

title: THE TEXT OF COMMUNIQUE ISSUED AFTER THE OTTAWA CONFERENCE
description: The following is the official Englishlanguage version of a communique issued by the heads of state at the close of their two-day economic summit conference today: Declaration of the Ottawa Summit

title: 'Overcomer' Award
description: He had trouble with school work, so he turned to sports, and by the time his academic trouble was traced to a common learning disability, Bruce Jenner was already on his way to becoming an Olympic decathalon champion.

title: Wine Talk
description: STUBBORN SOIL ON A STEEP SLOPE YIELDS WINES OF GREAT INTENSITY AND F LAVOR By Terry Robards CALISTOGA, Calif.

title: Polish Plane Is Hijacked To West Berlin
description: A twin-engine turboprop Polish airliner was hijacked to West Berlin today while en route from Katowice to Gdansk with 50 passengers and a crew of 5 aboard.

title: HOTEL CHANGE INCREASED STRESSES
description: A change in the design of the Hyatt Regency Hotel's suspended walkways doubled the stress on sections that were to pull apart in the collapse that killed 111 persons last week, The Kansas City Star said today.

title: Reports of Police Abuse Studied in Manchester
description: The chief of police here started an investigation today into charges of police brutality during riots in a predominantly black district of Manchester two weeks ago.

title: NEXT DEATH BY FASTING MAY FORCE AN IRISH VOTE
description: The imminent death here of a republican hunger striker who was recently elected to the Dublin Parliament will jeopardize the three-week-old Government of the Irish Republic and may result in new elections, officials from the republic said today.

title: Purolator Moves
description: Purolator Products, makers of automotive filters and other items, has decided to take its advertising account to Helfgott, Towne & Silverstein. The agency said that its 1981 billings might be just under $1 million, but that next year's will be about $2 million. The agency up to now has been Bozell & Jacobs.

title: Nadia Comaneci Takes Gold
description: Nadia Comaneci of Rumania produced two scores of 10 in her four exercises today and won the women's overall gold medal in gymnastics at the World University Games.

title: Bronx Girl, 3, Falls to Death
description: A 3-year-old girl fell to her death from a fifth-floor window in a Bronx tenement while her mother slept in another room yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: CENSUS DEEMS COLLEGE TOWN A METROPOLITAN AREA
description: Generations of students who attended Pennsylvania State University would never have imagined that this town could become the center of a metropolitan area.

title: Polish Primate to Visit Rome
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Primate of Poland, will arrive in Rome Thursday for a visit, the rector of Rome's Polish Pontifical Institute said today. Pope John Paul II appointed Monsignor Glemp to succeed Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski as Archbishop of Warsaw and Primate of Poland on July 7.

title: DOW UP BY 5.7% IN 2D QUARTER; SCHERING-PLOUGH DOWN 20.9%
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the country's second-largest chemical concern after E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, announced yesterday that gains by the bulk of its foreign operations caused net income in the second quarter to increase by 5.7 percent while sales climbed 21.8 percent.

title: JUAN CARLOS SNUBS ROYAL WEDDING OVER GIBRALTAR HONEYMOON PLAN
description: The stately, orderly preparations for the royal wedding a week from tomorrow were disrupted tonight when the Spanish Government announced that King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia had declined their invitation to the ceremony as an act of protest.

title: DR. ABRA KARDINER, 89, A STUDENT OF FREUD'S DIES
description: Dr. Abram Kardiner, a leading American psychoanalyst who was one of the last living persons to have been analyzed by Sigmund Freud, died Monday at his summer home in Easton, Conn. He was 89 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: LETTUCE HEAD FOOTNOTE
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: As a footnote to ''All That's Lettuce Is Not Iceberg'' (The Living Section, July 8), I wonder if your readers have discovered what good food lettuce hearts are? Any lettuce will do, but romaine's large heart makes it ideal.

title: Mobil Reports Hebron Results
description: Mobil Oil of Canada said its Hebron well off the coast of Newfoundland flowed at a rate of 2,322 barrels of oil and 3.2 million cubic feet of natural gas a day from more than two miles below the sea floor.

title: California Files Lawsuit On Produce Quarantines
description: California asked the Supreme Court today to lift a quarantine five states imposed on its fruits and vegetables because of the infestation by the Mediterranean fruit fly.

title: U.S. TAX INCENTIVES FOR REHABILITATION
description: The Chrysler Building. The Texas School Book Depository in Dallas. The old Boston Naval Shipyard. Philadelphia's Bellevue Stratford Hotel. All have been rehabilitated with the help of Federal tax incentives that would be greatly expanded under tax bills now moving through Congress.

title: Correction
description: A table yesterday showing gains and losses in Congressional districts resulting from the 1980 census contained one error and one omission. Florida gains four House seats, for a total of 19; Indiana loses one seat, dropping from 11 to 10.

title: F.B.I. INVESTIGATING SLAYING OF LIBYAN STUDENT IN UTAH
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting a ''preliminary inquiry'' into the killing of a Libyan student here on the theory that the slaying may have been politically motivated, a spokesman for the bureau said in Washington today.

title: EATING RAW FISH CAN POSE DANGERS
description: A warning from the national Centers for Disease Control says that the growing popularity of raw fish dishes has increased the risk of fish tapeworm disease for Americans.

title: Index; International
description: Border conflict with Cameroon produces conflict in Nigeria A2 Moscow court sentences dissident to 4 years A2 Honky-tonk area of Tokyo has raucous tone but no crime A3 Britain's nonwhites resent being treated like outsiders A3 Imminent death of I.R.A. man may bring new Irish elections A3 Italian prosecutor demands life sentence for Mehmet Ali Agca A6 Salvadoran troops, in assault on rebels, first land in Honduras A8 Government/Politics Administration rejects Chicago integration plan A12 Dissident beats Mayor's choice in Philadelphia House race A12 House panel recommends exten- sion of Voting Rights Act A19 3 Mayors assail Albany for delay on revenue-sharing accord B2 Parking revenue rises with fewer meters B3 John A. Esposito is optimistic about his uphill mayoral race B3 Brooklyn's president says a cen- sus recount is ''bizarre'' B3 Lawmakers and courts redefine child rights and foster care B4 General Around the Nation A12 Judge refuses to drop charges in Hillside Strangler case A12 Obituaries Dr. Abram Kardiner, a student- patient of Freud's A19 News Analysis Steven R. Weisman discusses out- come of summit meeting D1 Drew Middleton on expansion of the American fleet A7 Steven V. Roberts discusses So- cial Security battle A15 Living Section Food A choice selection of takeout food C1

title: Tank Cost Up Fivefold, With Inflation Blamed
description: The cost of the Army's new M-1 tank has jumped fivefold in the last nine years, to some $2.5 million per vehicle, with inflation the chief reason, Congressional investigators reported today.

title: Hudson Bay Seeks Francana Shares
description: The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company said it had begun discussions aimed at acquiring the 42 percent interest in Francana Oil and Gas Ltd. which it does not already own.

title: Filly Is Sold for $1 Million
description: A record price for a yearling filly was set by a member of the first crop of Alleged at tonight's final session of the Keeneland Selected Yearling Sale.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP 0.6% IN JUNE
description: Americans' personal income grew only sixtenths of 1 percent in June for the third straight month, the Commerce Department reported today. It was viewed as a continuing sign of a sagging economy,

title: FUTILE TO PRESS FOR A ONE-STROKE MIDEAST PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: And A Time For Riot
description: For the big picture on the recent rioting in England, the man to see is Prof. Harold Liverworth, the world's foremost rioting expert. The professor has rioted on six continents; been tear-gassed, clubbed and cut by broken glass more times than he can remember, and been arrested for looting in 13 countries, all in the cause of academic research.

title: SENATE OPPOSES IT
description: The House rejected the counsel of President Reagan today and voted overwhelmingly to preserve the minimum Social Security benefit for people now receiving it.

title: Aulby Defeats Sliker In Canadian Bowling
description: Mike Aulby of Indianapolis converted a 5-10 split in the ninth frame tonight and it helped him score a 205-202 decision over Gil Sliker and win the $100,000 Canadian Open on the Professional Bowlers Association tour.

title: Blackwood Fears Footsteps of Time
description: There may be nothing to match the heady feeling of an athlete in his prime. There may also be nothing to match the frustrated feeling of the athlete when he becomes older and finds he is not longer wanted.

title: IN CRISIS WITH CAMEROON, NIGERIA TURNS SELF-CRITICAL
description: Nigeria has ordered ''stepped-up vigilance'' along its borders in the latest unfolding of a frontier dispute with neighboring Cameroon that has divided opinion here, wounded the nation's self-esteem and rekindled controversy over offshore oil rights in areas contested by the two countries.

title: OFFICIAL SAYS FLIES WON'T LIFT PRICES
description: An Agriculture Department official said today that consumers ''should not see any increase in supermarket prices'' or any decline in the supply and quality of fruit and vegetables because of the Mediterranean fruit fly outbreak in California.

title: SPARSE CELEBRATIONS FOR MENOTTI AT 70
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes From The Cellar
description: There were actually two conferences in Ottawa: the summit conference of the Big Seven, which was held down on the Ottawa River flat at the Chateau Montebello; and the Cellar Conference of the 1,500 media types, which was held in a basement on the summit of Parliament Hill. Following are notes from the cellar on the summit:

title: Kupchak, Lakers Agree; Next Move Is Bullets'
description: Mitch Kupchak signed an offer sheet with the Los Angeles Lakers today, a club spokesman said, leaving the next move up to the Washington Bullets.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ''Let us hope,'' says Edward Stevenson, ''when Phil Rizzuto rejoins colleagues Messer and White in broadcasting the Yankee games, he will confide to his listeners where, during the baseball strike, he pastured his holy cows.'' OLD MIKADO HAD A FARM

title: AQUITAINE PROCEEDING ON TENDER
description: Despite a request from the United States asking that France delay the acquisition of Texasgulf by its Government-controlled oil company, the French concern started to make payments yesterday for Texasgulf's tendered shares.

title: BROOKLYN PRECINCT STRUGGLES TO TURN CRIME RATE AROUND
description: A clergyman in Brooklyn's 77th Precinct says he is going to buy a gun for protection, even though another minister in the neighborhood was arrested several years ago for keeping a sawed-off shotgun under his pulpit.

title: VOLCKER SEES MORE TIGHTENING
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today outlined plans for further cutbacks in the growth of the money supply, warning that efforts to escape from high interest rates by abandoning policies of restraint would merely stir greater inflation and be self-defeating.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I bought something called laos in an Oriental grocery. I was told by the shop owner that this was a form of mushroom. When I got home I discovered that the dried pieces were somewhat woody and cut wafer-thin about an inch in diameter. They don't seem to be edible like mushrooms, and I wonder how they are used.

title: Koch Ends Insistence On a Westway Accord
description: Mayor Koch has decided that a commitment by Governor Carey to the ''fair fare'' plan for mass-transit riders is no longer necessary for Mr. Koch to agree to the Westway's construction, Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. said yesterday.

title: MANUFACTURER SEES BIG PROFITS IN SMALL ROBOTS
description: After working on robot technology for 22 years at the General Electric Company, Ralph Mosher left in 1971 to form Robotics Inc. and began producing heavy industrial robots. He sold about a dozen before running into financing problems and the 1974-75 recession.

title: The Pop Life; HALL AND OATES FIND THE SOUND
description: HALL AND OATES enjoyed a string of hit singles in the mid-70's - ''Rich Girl,'' ''She's Gone,'' ''Sara Smile.'' Their sound was literally blue-eyed soul, with blond-haired, blue-eyed Daryl Hall taking the emotive lead vocals against John Oates's harmony vocals and guitar, and arrangements that recalled the duo's apprenticeship as recording artists and backup musicians at Philadelphia's Sigma Sound Studio, home of the crack soul producers Gamble and Huff. But during the last year, Hall and Oates decisively eclipsed their earlier successes. ''Voices'' (RCA), their first self-produced album, yielded no fewer than four top-10 singles, beginning with a winning remake of the definitive blue-eyed soul recording, the Righteous Brothers's ''You've Lost That Loving Feeling,'' and continuing with ''Kiss on My List'' and other Hall and Oates originals.

title: News Analysis
description: As the House was voting today to condemn President Reagan's proposed cuts in minimum Social Security benefits, one Democratic strategist said, ''The press releases are already written that will be sent into the district of every Republican who votes against this bill.''

title: Metropolitan Venture
description: Bernard Weissbourd, a 58-year-old Chicago developer, has been named to head a major new commercial real estate development organization that is a joint venture between his company, Metropolitan Structures, and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The venture, which has a net worth of more than $500 million, plans development projects totaling $2 billion to $3 billion over the next decade, Mr. Weissbourd said.

title: Best Buys; MARKET BASKET PRICES HIT RECORD HIGH
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose $1.77, to an all-time high of $106.14 for the period of July 6 to 17, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs. Shoppers paid $9.61 more for food than during the same period last year, making this the largest increase this year in the average weekly cost of food.

title: American Express Gains
description: The American Express Company, aided by a strong performance from its newly acquired investment unit, said yesterday that its secondquarter profit rose 15.8 percent from a year earlier.

title: DATA ON ORDERS REVISED
description: United States manufacturers' new orders and shipments have been a bit stronger this spring than earlier reported, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet; BARBEQUED CHICKEN MISSOURI-SYLE
description: IFIND it a source of some irritation that chickens that have been simply roasted on a spit are often sold as ''barbecued'' chickens. Such chickens are called in French ''a la broche.'' To my mind the term ''barbecued'' should be applied to foods that have been cooked before or over a fire while being basted with a sauce of one sort of another. And, ideally, the foods should be cooked over charcoal.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 22, 1981
description: International Israel linked a cease-fire in Lebanon to a broad withdrawal by forces of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The Israelis rejected a United States appeal for an immediate truce and reiterated their longstanding refusal to deal with the P.L.O., but they authorized Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, to act as an intermediary in negotiations with Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 6.) U.S. diplomatic efforts were pressed to promote a truce in southern Lebanon. A senior Reagan Administration official said that preliminary reports from a meeting between Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Mr. Habib offered ''some basis for forward movement'' toward a cease-fire. (A1:5.)

title: SWIMMING IN THE FLOOD OF U.S. BRIEFINGS
description: While the senior United States official began his detailed briefing on happenings at the summit meeting 40 miles away, his aides quietly scurried among the hundreds of attentive, news-hungry journalists in the auditorium. With whispers, nods and little torn pieces of paper as their tools, the aides were inviting selected journalists to ''private'' meetings in rooms upstairs.

title: COURTS, THE CONGRESS AND CITIZENS ARE REDEFINING THE CONCEPT OF FOSTER CARE
description: The futures of 600,000 children across the nation who are in the care of the state - more than the total number of adults in state and Federal prisons -depend on the outcome of struggles being waged nationally in Congress, locally in cities like New York and in state courts and citizen-review panels. It is in the area of foster care that an abstract concept - the rights of children in relation to the state - takes on stark human meaning. Currently there is a movement to define not only children's rights to child-welfare services, but also to re-examine the basic premises of out-of-home care.

title: Waltrip Rides Pressure-Packed Road
description: It's all very well to say you win some, you lose some, but that complacent phrase does not take into account the psychological strain of winning and losing. The competitor's spirit is just so elastic, and, beyond that, stress enters.

title: PANEL ADDS A TAX-CUT 'TRIGGER'
description: The Democratic majority on the House Ways and Means Committee, moving toward a test of strength with President Reagan, voted today for a third year of tax-rate cuts but only if the President's economic forecast for 1983 is realized.

title: H.J. Barnum's Note On Advertising Awards
description: Monday's column about Michael Ulick's anti-awards ad and the comments from creative directors on the subject caused some soul searching by Dr. H.J. Barnum, chairman of Barnum Communications, an agency in the health care field, who writes:

title: PROMOTION PLAN FOR POLICE TO USE MINORITY QUOTAS
description: Sixteen percent of the police officers who are promoted to sergeant in New York City will be black, Hispanic or female candidates under an agreement reached yesterday to settle a series of civil-rights suits.

title: CITICORP EARNINGS FALL
description: Citicorp's net operating earnings in the second quarter ended June 30 plunged by 40 percent from the comparable period of 1980, the nation's largest bank holding company reported yesterday.

title: Paine Webber Unit Names a President
description: Michael Johnston, 43 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of Blyth Eastman Paine Webber, the investment banking unit of Paine Webber Inc. He was also named chairman of Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, a research firm that conducts the firm's institutional equity and investment management business, of which he had been president and chief executive officer. He will remain chairman of the firm's international operation.

title: GERMAN URGES U.S. TO BATTLE INFLATION WITH FISCAL POLICY
description: Otto von Lambsdorff, the West German Minister of Economics, expressed sharp disagreement today with the contention of top United States officials that the West European governments had offered no alternatives to the monetary, fiscal and foreign exchange rate policies pursued by the Reagan Administration.

title: EX-SERGEANT DRILLS FOR JETS JOB
description: John Misko, a former Army sergeant who was cut by the Buffalo Bills last year, would like to do the punting for the Jets. Tomorrow he will meet Chuck Ramsey, the man the Jets entrust with the job.

title: TIMES BOOKS APPOINTS JONATHAN SEGAL AS EDITOR
description: Jonathan B. Segal has been named vice president and executive editor of Times Books, the trade-book affiliate of The New York Times. He has been senior editor at Summit Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster.

title: Discoveries; BACK RUBS, OTHER EXERCISES AND TIMELY STUFF; Massage T-Shirt
description: shirts say all sorts of things these days - polite or otherwise - but the ones designed by Sue Price have a practical message. Miss Price is a professional masseuse in California and rubs down celebrities like Barbra Streisand and her husband, Jon Peters. Aware that people enjoy having their backs rubbed but that the amateur masseur rarely does the job properly, she has designed a shirt that says ''Rub My Back'' on the front. The back of the shirt is instructive: it diagrams where the fingers should be placed for a proper massage at the neck, the vertebrae and the shoulder blades. The shirt is made of white cotton and polyester, printed in red or navy and comes in women's sizes small, medium and large and men's small, medium, large and extra large. The price is $12.95, plus $1.50 postage from Magic Fingers, 2210 Wilshire Boulevard, Suite 426, Santa Monica, Calif. 90403.

title: NEW CENSUS IN BROOKLYN ASSAILED
description: A Census Bureau recount showing that the population of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section and two neighboring areas in Brooklyn has declined by 34 percent from the 1970 census was termed ''bizarre beyond belief'' yesterday by Howard Golden, the Borough President.

title: Strike by City Workers Cuts Providence Services
description: City lawyers went to court today seeking a restraining order to halt a walkout by some of the hundreds of workers who are taking part in a protest strike that has brought city services to a standstill.

title: MCA Theme Park Doubles in Cost
description: MCA Recreation Services, a division of MCA Inc., a major film maker and distribution company, said that a $100 million movie theme park it has planned for the Orlando area has grown into a $200 million concept.

title: Minnesota's Bonds Lowered
description: Minnesota, where state workers have gone out on strike for higher pay, had its bond ratings lowered yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: 4 Seized Trying to Halt South Africans' Match
description: Four anti-apartheid demonstrators crashed a small truck through the gates of the Gisborne rugby field today and sprinkled the ground with shards of broken glass in an attempt to stop the first match of a touring South African rugby team.

title: A CHOICE SELECTION OF TAKEOUT FOOD
description: HOT weather is still the best excuse for not cooking, and now, thanks to the many takeout shops selling cool food, a vacation from the stove can be arranged on a moment's notice. Virtually every Manhattan neighborhood now has a takeout shop to call its own.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Commission Rejects Ban On Commercial Whaling
description: The International Whaling Commission rejected a ban on commercial whaling today despite conservationist arguments and a last-minute plea from President Reagan yesterday.

title: TOWN SPLIT ON HOW TO USE OLD GARDEN STATE TRACK
description: This South Jersey community is divided over how to use its prime piece of real estate -the abandoned 286-acre Garden State Race Track in the heart of its commercial area.

title: TWO ISRAELI FORCES ATTACK IN LEBANON
description: Israeli forces attacked Palestinian guerrilla strongholds in southern Lebanon early today with the apparent objective of overrunning the guerrilla fortification of Beaufort Castle.

title: Going Out Guide
description: AD HOC

title: U.N. COUNCIL URGES TRUCE IN LEBANON
description: The Security Council tonight approved a resolution calling for an immediate cease-fire in Lebanon but carefully avoiding any rebuke of Israel or threat of sanctions.

title: RULING SUPPORTS TAX ABATEMENT ASKED BY TRUMP
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the Koch administration had exceeded its authority by denying a $20 million tax abatement to Donald Trump, the developer, for the apartment and office tower he is building on the site of the old Bonwit Teller store in midtown Manhattan.

title: MISS STREEP AND KLINE CAST IN MOVIE 'SOPHIE'
description: After a two-year search, Meryl Streep and Kevin Kline have been chosen to play the doomed lovers in the film version of William Styron's novel about a survivor of Auschwitz, ''Sophie's Choice.'' How and why they got the roles casts a certain amount of light on the way things are done in Hollywood.

title: Toa Airbus Order
description: Airbus Industrie of Europe has agreed to allow Japan's Toa Domestic Airlines to postpone without penalty the purchase of two Airbuses and to open negotiations on the possible cancellation of orders for three other planes, the airline said.

title: Personal Health
description: IN mid-life, Paul Gaugin left his wife, family and a staid bank job to live in the South Seas and paint. In his mid-40's, Charles Dickens moved out of the bedroom he shared with his wife and took a 19-yearold mistress. William Shakespeare, who wrote two plays - ''King Lear'' and ''Timon of Athens'' - in which abrupt character transformations of middle-aged men led to their ruin, is said to have retired from marital sex before age 45 and retired from work at 46.

title: British Jobless at 2.85 Million
description: Britain's unemployment, considered a factor in the country's recent rioting, rose in July for the 14th consecutive month, to 2.85 million persons, or 11.8 percent of the work force, the Government reported today.

title: SOMALIA'S SUSPECT CALL FOR TALKS WITH ETHIOPIA
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: MARKET-TESTING OF SOAP OPERA ABOUT YOUTH
description: ANEW syndicated soap opera may have found the ultimate approach to ''give 'em what they want'' programming. ''Young Lives'' is having a ''special preview'' this week at 5:30 P.M. on WPIX-TV, Channel 11. Viewers who watch all five episodes are being asked to answer several questions being published in the current issue of TV Guide.

title: Eastern Air Narrows Loss
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that its loss in the second quarter ended June 30 narrowed to $4.6 million, from $15.9 million in the same 1980 period. The Miami-based carrier attributed the loss in the 1981 second quarter in part to high interest expenses.

title: POLICE SAY COUPLE BEAT BOY TO DEATH FOR LYING
description: A 25-year-old waitress and the former drug addict she lived with in the Bronx were charged yesterday with beating and kicking the woman's 8-year-old son to death because, the couple told the police, he had repeatedly lied and cheated.

title: Maytag Earnings Rise
description: The Maytag Company, the nation's third-largest producer of home laundry equipment, today announced second-quarter earnings of $8.2 million, or 58 cents a share, up from $7.5 million, or 56 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $99.1 million from $79.1 million. The 1981 results included the operations of the Hardwick Stove Company, which Maytag acquired Jan.1.

title: Polish Airline Union Cancels Strike Threat
description: Employees of the Polish state airline LOT agreed today to suspend indefinitely a strike threatened for Friday, a union spokesman said.

title: EGGPLANTS AND ME: A STORY OF ABUNDANCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert Farrar Capon, an Episcopal priest and food writer, is the author of ''Supper of the Lamb'' (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich). By ROBERT FARRAR CAPON

title: Careers; Relocating Corporate Employees
description: ''W E'RE not putting anyone on the couch, but we're helping them to manage stresses that come up,'' Ned M. Sohn observed. Mr. Sohn, a relocation expert for the Chemical Bank, exemplifies an interesting combination of backgrounds -a master's degree in psychology and a real estate broker's license. ''I'm the home search manager,'' he said.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES BLOCK GRANTS
description: Block grants, a centerpiece of President Reagan's proposal to restructure Federal domestic programs, have failed to effectively reach the poor, according to a study by the National Urban League.

title: Raiders' Profits Called Higher Than Average
description: An auditor testifying for the National Football League said today that the Oakland Raiders make ''substantially more'' money than most of the league's other teams.

title: Military Analysis
description: The Navy intends to expand the offensive capacity of the fleet with phased introduction of 150 surface ships armed with Harpoon and Tomahawk missiles that supplement the power of carrier battle groups, according to Adm.

title: AT A DALLAS CAFETERIA, IT'S MILLIONAIRE PIE
description: DALLAS THERE is genuine Meissen and Royal Doulton china in the oak cupboards, Oriental rugs on the walls, a buffet upstairs decorated with drawings and prints from Shakespeare's plays and sonnets and an air of hushed propriety at the elegantly appointed restaurant on Knox Street just north of downtown Dallas.

title: BRITISH WEIGH RACIAL FACTOR IN DISORDERS
description: Jimmy Patel, a 26-year-old shop assistant here, has never been to India, the land his parents came from in the 1950's, and he gets very tired of having people assume that he is an immigrant.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A City Brief item in Metropolitan Report on Monday gave the incorrect name of the group sponsoring the debate between Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin and Assemblyman John C. Dearie at the Pelham Parkway Jewish Center on Aug. 2. The sponsor is the Bronx Citizens Club.

title: Criton Unit Starts Lightolier Tender
description: The Criton Corporation, a Seattle-based investment group, said that a subsidiary was beginning its cash tender offer of $22 each for shares of Lightolier Inc., a maker of lamps and lighting fixtures based in Jersey City. When the proposal was first made a week ago, directors of Lightolier rejected it.

title: WE'RE NO HOLIER FOR OUR 'HOLY WAR'
description: .2,2CHICAGO - One year into its holy war, the United States, is not, and stands small chance of becoming, a holier, happier, more civil, or more moral nation.

title: EXPERIMENT IN RANDOM TEXTS
description: ''THE difference between the English and American pop charts,'' a British visitor to the United States remarked recently, ''is that in America most of your top 40 artists are in their 30's or older. In Britain, the top artists are all in their 20's, or younger.'' In general the distinction is a valid one, but lately there has been a startling exception on the British independent-label best-seller charts. One of the top albums has been ''Nothing Here Now but the Recordings,'' a collection of tape experiments by the 67-year-old American author William Burroughs on the Industrial Records label.

title: New Yorkers, etc.; A DINNER PARTY FOR THE FIRST LADY
description: It was a dinner for a few ''chums,'' said Pat Buckley, but to the social world that follows such things with a microscopic and sometimes jaundiced eye, it was a coup. For the guest of honor was the First Lady, and the party Monday night at the Buckley maisonette just off Park Avenue was the first such event that Nancy Reagan had attended in New York since the Inauguration. The President was in Canada for the economic summit conference.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan's Steamroller
description: OTTAWA PRESIDENT REAGAN achieved a new international stature, starring here at this most political of economic summit conferences. With the help of what seemed like a huge American delegation, which communicated at something over the million-word level, Mr. Reagan succeeded in simultaneously upstaging and downgrading the other national leaders.

title: Egypt Cuts Oil Price
description: Egypt has lowered its crude oil prices for the third time this year, cutting its prices by $3 a barrel, effective July 1, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today. The newsletter, which is based in Nicosia, Cyprus, said that Egypt's Suez blend was being sold at $33 a barrel, compared with $40.50 at the beginning of the year.

title: ISRAEL LINKS TRUCE TO DEEP PULLBACK BY FORCES OF P.L.O.
description: Israel yesterday rejected a United States appeal for an immediate cease-fire and reiterated its longstanding refusal to deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization. But it authorized Philip C. Habib, the American special envoy, to act as an intermediary in talks with Lebanon.

title: SOME RAMIFICATIONS OF A HUMAN LIFE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The bitter takeover battle between the Nu-West Group of Calgary, Alberta, and the Cities Service Company heated up as Nu-West, the target of a Cities Services suit last year, filed a $1 billion (Canadian) counterclaim against the company and its president, Charles J. Waidelich.

title: T.W.A. Flights
description: Trans World Airlines said it will begin new service between Newark and both Miami and West Palm Beach in September for $99 one way.

title: VIETNAM CASUALTIES IDENTIFIED
description: The Defense Department today identified three Navy and Air Force airmen whose remains were turned over by Vietnam two weeks ago.

title: Japan Wins Ship Order
description: The Sanoyasu Dockyard Company said today that it had won two orders from United States and Norwegian owners to build a total of five bulk carriers worth 28 billion yen, or about $120 million. Mowinckels Rederi of Norway ordered two 60,000-deadweight-ton carriers worth about $55.7 million for delivery in July and September 1983, the company said. Sanoyasu also said it would build three 40,000-deadweight-ton carriers worth about $64.7 million for Lygnos of New York for delivery by August 1983.

title: JUDGE REFUSES TO DROP CASE AGAINST SUSPECT IN STRANGLINGS ON COAST
description: A Superior Court judge today ordered Angelo A. Buono, a 46-year-old automobile upholsterer, to be tried for the 10 Hillside Strangler murders, ignoring a request from county prosecutors to dismiss the case because they had lost confidence in the credibility of their star witness.

title: REPUBLIC STEEL UP
description: American steel companies recorded sharply higher profits during the second quarter of 1981, but analysts cautioned that lower auto, building and machine tool sales presaged a downturn for the remainder of the year.

title: Toll in China Floods Put at 700 to 800
description: A flood control official in Sichuan Province said today that last week's floods in the upper reaches of China's Yangtze River, the worst in decades, had left between 700 and 800 people dead, far fewer than the earlier estimate of 4,000 dead.

title: Clerc Winner In Final
description: Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina overcame a poor start and showed that he was one of the world's best on clay as he beat Hans Gildemeister of Chile today, 0-6, 6-2, 6-2, in the final of the United States Pro tennis championship.

title: Advertising; Programs In Hispanic Markets
description: ENTER cable TV, and communications satellites, and all of a sudden there is a great need for specialized programming. Enter independent networks to supply it - USA Network, ESPN, HTN, MSN, et al.

title: KOCH FOE STUGGLING TO STAY ON BALLOT
description: The first step in defeating Mayor Koch is to get on the ballot against him, and John A. Esposito says he is ''guardedly optimistic'' that he can make it.

title: THEATER STUDY RATES CALIBER OF AUDIENCES
description: The Off Broadway audience is better educated and more affluent than the Broadway audience, a survey conducted by the Off Off Broadway Alliance has found. The survey was made among 4,747 theatergoers at 28 Off and Off Off Broadway theaters.

title: INDUSTRY'S ROLE IN ACADEMIA
description: The announcements are coming out almost weekly now: Du Pont gives $6 million to the Harvard Medical School for genetic research; Hoechst, the West German chemical giant, gives $50 million to the Massachusetts General Hospital for medical research; 10 companies contribute $7.5 million for a new computer center at Stanford; Control Data, Burroughs and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing pledge up to $5 million for computer research at the University of Minnesota; Exxon finances an $8 million project on combustion research at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Market Place; Colonial Penn: What Next?
description: A WHILE back, Colonial Penn Group looked like a hot takeover candidate. The company wrote much of the personal insurance purchased by older Americans, and its largest market, a lucrative one, was the accident and health business of individuals over age 55.

title: Dispensable Pork
description: After cutting funds for food stamps, youth employment, Medicaid and a host of other social programs, the Reagan Administration endorsed two highly questionable multibillion-dollar construction projects of particular interest to powerful legislators - the Clinch River breeder reactor and the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway.

title: Bridge; REVISION OF LAWS CORRECTS INJUSTICE FROM A PENALTY
description: ''The Laws of Contract Bridge,'' which relate to rubber bridge and not duplicate, has recently been issued in a new edition. This ends six years of work, primarily by the national laws commission of the American Contract Bridge League but with some input from England. Copies may be obtained for $3.95 from The Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y., 10025.

title: Kitchen Equipment; STEEL FISH PANS
description: Any good cook can improvise, of course, and do well enough under the worst of circumstances. A story I've told often has to do with the time I steamed a striped bass without the aid of a fish steamer. The steamer has a tray that allows you to lift the fish out whole. In lieu of the tray I used cheesecloth, swathed the beast in it and got the fish out of the pot in reasonably good condition.

title: Argentine Trotter Bucks the Odds
description: Nineteen years ago, Constancio Formia arrived in this country with his trotter Thomas Atkyns too late to compete in the Roosevelt International. Political turmoil in Argentina had prevented the horse from getting out of the country in time for the 6,004-mile trip.

title: SNUB MOSLEY, 71, JAZZ TROMBONIST WITH FATS WALLER
description: Snub Mosley, a jazz trombonist who played with Louis Armstrong and Fats Waller and was featured on an instrument he invented - the slide saxophone - died Tuesday morning in his home at 555 Edgecombe Avenue. Mr. Mosley, who was 71 years old, suffered a stroke in January that was complicated by pneumonia.

title: Blaupunkt Products Assigned to Stanton
description: J.B. Stanton Inc., an advertising and public relations agency that has made a bit of a specialty out of promoting electonic entertainment equipment, is going to be introducing Blaupunkt Home Entertainment Products in the United States for the West German manufacturer, the Robert Bosch Corporation.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: He is a venerable composer of contemporary music, and when he turns 85 in November, Virgil Thomson, a musican of his time, will get a venerable birthday present from the Orchestra of Our Time - a production of Mr. Thomson's 1934 opera, ''Four Saints in Three Acts.''

title: THE NAME GAME
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: William Cole (''Uninspired First Name Is Just Too Much,'' July 1) obviously belongs to the ''If Only I'd Had the Latin'' school of self-apologists.

title: DEFROSTING?  DON'T USE ICE PICK
description: When the coating of ice around the freezer in a refrigerator grows so thick that the door no longer closes tightly, the only thing worse than defrosting at 1 A.M. is plunging in with an ice pick.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM International, a manufacturer and seller of communication and graphics systems, appointed, as corporate vice presidents, Errol W. Bartine, president of AM International Services; C. Victor Meyer, president of AM Varityper, and Dieter E.A. Tannenberg, president of AM Bruing.

title: IN RURAL AMERICA, THE SUMMER COUNTY FAIR IS A FAMILY RITE
description: year-old Billy Rygh complained as photographers at the Winnebago County Fair here urged him to pose just one more time with his grand champion steer, Ichabod.

title: Union Pacific Raises Net 8%
description: The Union Pacific Corporation, a diversified transportation, natural resources and land development concern, said yesterday that its railroad and some of its energy interests helped increase secondquarter earnings 8 percent from the similar period in 1980.

title: LOUISIANA TO TEACH 'CREATION'
description: Gov. David C. Treen signed into law today a bill that requires students in Louisiana public schools to be taught both the theory that the creation of mankind and the universe came about through divine intervention and the scientific explanation based on the theory of evolution.

title: MARKET'S SLIDE DECELERATES
description: With the chronic fear of near-record interest rates continuing to hang over the stock market, the Dow Jones industrial average barely avoided a new 1981 closing low yesterday. The Dow finished at 934.46, down 6.08 points, after recovering part of its day's loss.

title: CONFEREES RAISE ARTS BUDGET
description: At a reconciliation conference yesterday in Washington between House and Senate budget committees, a spending level of $119.3 million was recommended for the National Endowment for the Arts for fiscal 1982 and 1983, and $113.7 million for the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: CONFEREES RAISE LIMIT TO $30,000 FOR NEEDS TEST ON STUDENT LOANS
description: Senate and House negotiators agreed tonight to a compromise under which students from families earning up to $30,000 a year would automatically qualify for federally guaranteed loans.

title: 3 MAYORS ASSAIL LEGISLATURE FOR REVENUE SHARING DELAY
description: Mayors of New York State's three largest upstate cities yesterday criticized the Legislature's delay in reaching an agreement on revenue-sharing for New York municipalities.

title: Floods Ravage North India
description: Two-thirds of the Sibsagar district in the northeastern state of Assam and 500 villages in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh have been affected by floods, the Press Trust of India news agency reported today. It said that more than 200 people had died in flooding and that 100,000 had been left homeless in Jaipur, capital of Rajasthan in northwest India.

title: ANTHEM IS COMPOSED FOR ROYAL BRIDAL
description: The first music that Prince Charles and Lady Diana will hear after they are married next Wednesday in St. Paul's Cathedral will not be a work that has long been part of the liturgy but a new anthem by William Mathias, commissioned by the Prince for the occasion. The invitation was conveyed to Mr. Mathias, a professor of music at University College of North Wales, by Sir David Willcocks, who is directing the music for the wedding.

title: Jordan Engine Loan
