description: Alia, the Jordanian airline, has obtained a $70.41 million loan from Lazard Freres and Company to buy Rolls-Royce engines for the five Lockheed Corporation Tristar 1011 planes it plans to purchase, airline sources said today.

title: AGREE ON GOAL BUT NOT THE MEANS
description: The United States and six other industrial democracies concluded their seventh annual economic conference today with a pledge to revitalize their economies, but with no precise agreement on how to accomplish this in the immediate future.

title: Pepsico Profit Up in Quarter
description: Pepsico Inc., the nation's second-largest soft drink producer, said yesterday that earnings in the second quarter rose to $88.6 million, or 96 cents a share, on revenue of $1.65 billion, compared with $77.5 million, or 85 cents a share, on revenue of $1.38 billion a year earlier.

title: BARGAINERS SETTLE POSTAL CONTRACT, AVERTING A STRIKE
description: The United States Postal Service and two unions representing 500,000 of the nation's 667,000 postal employees reached agreement this afternoon on a new $4.8 billion contract, ending threats of disruption in mail deliveries.

title: Chicago Tax Rise Voted To Aid Transit System
description: The City Council approved several measures yesterday to assist the financially troubled Chicago Transit Authority, including a $213 million tax package proposed by Mayor Jane M. Byrne.

title: CONFEREES DROPPING PENALTY FOR RENT CONTROL
description: House and Senate conferees today killed a Senate-approved proposal that would have prohibited housing subsidies to localities, such as New York City, that have rent controls on new and vacant housing.

title: Savin Improves Its Toner Copiers
description: The Savin Corporation said it had developed a new process that will improve the performance and speed of its liquid toner copiers and permit its copiers to make copies on papers with high rag content, such as a company letterhead.

title: Winston in Mexico
description: SALEM, N.C. July 21 (UPI) - R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International Inc. said it had signed an agreement with Mexico's secondlargest cigarette company that will help Reynolds promote its Winston brand in Mexico. The agreement involving Reynolds and Cigarros La Tabacalera Mexicana is a supplement to a licensing arrangement in effect for six years and calls for an undisclosed increase in advertising and promotional spending.

title: FOR ARMS TALKS SOON
description: When Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. presented the Reagan Administration's strategic arms limitation policy last week, he made no promises that negotiations would resume any time soon. The Administration, he said, is committed to arms-limitation talks -but not on any specific timetable and not until some conditions, including modifications in Soviet foreign policy, are met. On this most crucial question, a wide gulf separates theory and practice, intention and rhetoric, in this Administration.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 18.14 percent was set at the weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper, compared with 17.185 percent last week.

title: BASEBALL MEETINGS PRODUCE NO GAIN
description: Despite the day-long presence of Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan in the bargaining sessions, negotiators in baseball's 40-day-old strike emerged from the second day of the Washington talks today with no progress and apparently no reason to feel that a quick settlement is possible.

title: WRONG QUEEN
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 22, 1981; Economic Summit Meeting
description: The seven major industrial democracies concluded their economic summit meeting with a pledge to revitalize their economies, but no agreement on how to accomplish this. World leaders attending the Ottawa conference vowed to defeat inflation and unemployment, avoid protectionist policies and help poor nations. Grievances, however, remained against President Reagan's economic policies, and the resultant high interest rates. (Page A1.)

title: Yet Another Magazine For the Wealthy
description: There is no longer such a group as the idle rich.

title: Exxon Leads Offshore Bids
description: The Exxon Corporation today raised eyebrows at a near-record Federal auction of offshore oil and gas leases at the Superdome by offering bids ranging up to $110 million over those of the closest competitors.

title: COMPOSERS' SHOWCASE TO CELEBRATE 25 YEARS
description: The Composers' Showcase will celebrate its 25th anniversary with three programs at the Whitney Museum of American Art this fall, each performed twice during the same evening.

title: Westway Bugaboos
description: The Westway maze seems even more confusing with the approach of Aug. 1, the deadline for the release of Federal highway trust funds for 1981. New York State has asked for $80 million to buy the 12th Avenue roadbed from the city. The Federal Government says it needs Mayor Koch's consent. The Mayor says many things, but ''yes'' is not among them. And while he and Governor Carey argue, the ordinary New Yorker has been denied his right to the facts and is unable to decide whether Westway will save his city or doom civilized society.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Eric Por- ter, right-handed catcher who just com- pleted is junior year at Iowa State.; COLLEGES VILLANOVA - Named Charley Jen- kins, former Olympian, head track coach, replacing Jim (Jumbo) Elliott.; FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Released Vlade Janakievski, free agent kicker from Ohio State.  CHICAGO (NFC) - Signed Wentford Gaines, cornerback, to new contract.  CLEVELAND (AFC) - Brought in Bob Lisowski, fullback, for tryout.
description: SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Obtained A rtie Owens, running back, from New Or- l eans for a 1982 draft choice; signed Gary A nderson, free agent tackle. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Signed Dave L ogan, defensive lineman, to series of one- y ear contracts; announced that Steve Get- t el, free agent offensive lineman, had left c amp after informing club officials that he w anted to end his tryout.

title: Kool Ultra Arrives
description: Using the same patented cigarette filter that it slipped into the Barclay cigarette, and which was so heavily promoted, Brown & Williamson Tobacco is now entering another low-tar number in the marketplace called Kool Ultra.

title: ITALIAN PROSECUTOR RRQUESTS A LIFE SENTENCE FOR THE POPE'S ASSAILANT
description: The prosecutor today demanded the mandatory life sentence for Mehmet Ali Agca for attempting to kill Pope John Paul II and for wounding two Americans.

title: The Region; College Executive Indicted on L.I.
description: Lawrence Dell Aquila, an associate vice president of Nassau Community College, was indicted on charges of receiving ''unlawful gratuities'' from the New York Arrows soccer team while performing his job as supervisor of the college's physical education complex.

title: Italians Find 3 Dead in Alps
description: An Italian rescue team today recovered the bodies of three French mountain climbers who were caught in an electrical storm while climbing in the Alps last weekend, rescue officials reported. The officials said Bernardo Gonnetand, the guide for the five-man climbing team, had been struck by lightning and killed instantly, and the two other climbers had died of exposure later.

title: U.S. WIDENS EFFORT FOR MIDEAST TRUCE
description: The Reagan Administration moved today to broaden diplomatic efforts to achieve a cease-fire in southern Lebanon after drawing encouragement from the initial subdued Israeli reaction to the latest American postponement of shipment of warplanes to Israel.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Anytown, U.S.A. The mailman has a delivery for the building on the corner. ''Morning, Mr. Stanley,'' he says evenly. ''Morning,'' says Mr. Stanley. Farther up the block a dog growls at the mailman, who laughs and says it's all in a day's work. A man standing in a doorway grins at the mailman. ''How are you, Mattie,'' he says. ''He's a good boy if we could just keep the hair out of his eyes.'' The mailman, who is as bald as a man has ever been, just grins back. He's heard this all before. ''Morning, John,'' he says at the next building. ''Hi, Mattie,'' says John. Any minute, it seems, Thornton Wilder will appear from behind a tree. ''Morning, Mattie,'' he will say.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT GETS 4 YEARS
description: A Moscow court today sentenced Feliks Serebrov, 50 years old, to four years at hard labor followed by five years of banishment to a remote area for his participation in a group seeking to expose Soviet use of psychiatry to punish dissidents.

title: Russ Francis Quits
description: Russ Francis of the New England Patriots, considered by many the best tight end in pro football, announced his retirement for personal reasons today.

title: LUKEWARM ISN'T NEW
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: There's nothing particularly new about serving food warm or at room temperature, or combining hot and cold foods in the same dish (''Nouvelle Cuisine's Lukewarm Dishes Catching On,'' July 15).

title: Spain-Portugal A-Plant Seen
description: Spain and Portugal have agreed in principle to build a joint nuclear power station on Spanish territory, according to Portuguese officials.

title: PHILADELPHIA RACE GOES TO DISSIDENT
description: State Senator Joseph Smith, a dissident Democrat running as an independent with the backing of the Republican Party, overcame his own party's concerted, well-financed opposition to win a seat in the House of Representatives in a special election here today.

title: A ZIP CODE FOR ALL THE PEOPLE SHOULD USE LETTERS, NOT NUMBERS
description: To the Editor:

title: FEWER ON STREET PARKING METERS REALIZING MORE
description: The Traffic Department has succeeded in doing something that city leaders hope they will see more of in New York - getting more for less.

title: Hospital Report
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy was admitted yesterday to the Beth Israel Medical Center for surgery today for removal of what her surgeon said was at least one, and possibly more, enlarged parathyroid glands.

title: The Region; Crash Kills 2 Nuns At L.I. Convent
description: Two nuns who were on their way to a funeral were killed when the car in which they were riding went out of control and hit a building on the grounds of their convent-school complex in Brentwood, the police said.

title: ASSETS MISSING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday ordered a 10-day suspension in the trading of shares in the Triad Energy Corporation, after a committee of Triad directors announced that the bulk of the company's assets had been mysteriously withdrawn from its bank account.

title: Ban to End, DeCinces Says
description: As the baseball strike reached the 490-game mark today, it appeared the ban on public statements about the negotiations imposed three days ago by Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan would end tomorrow.

title: JOB FULFILLS EXPECTATIONS OF NEW REPRESENTATIVE
description: Learning to live as a commuting Representative has not been easy for Marge Roukema, with a lonely Capitol Hill apartment and a host of new legislative responsibilities at this end and new constituents at the other who want reassurances about the Federal Government's changed direction.

title: The City; Trump Suing City And Housing Chief
description: Donald J. Trump, the real-estate developer, filed suit yesterday against New York City and a city housing official for $138 million, charging that they discriminated against him by denying a tax abatement for a major building he is constructing.

title: SCALA BALLET: TETLEY'S 'SACRE DU PRINTEMPS'
description: MILAN'S La Scala Ballet made barbaric rituals look tame on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The rituals were those of Glen Tetley's version of ''Le Sacre du Printemps.'' But whereas Stravinsky's music sounded awesome, even as conducted by Michel Sasson in an arrangement for small orchestra, a cast featuring a new set of dancers in the leading roles emphasized the faults of both the choreography and the company.

title: Q & A
description: Q. We have a finished family room in our basement that is about 12 feet by 20 feet. It has a concrete floor covered with a single piece of rubber-backed nylon carpet that was cemented down around the edges for about six inches around the border. In cold weather when the room is heated the carpet lies flat, but in warm weather when the humidity climbs above about 60 percent the carpet ''bubbles'' up in several places. The room is air-conditioned, but this does not seem to help. Do you have any suggestions as to how I can eliminate the ''bubbling'' problem? - J.P.L., Annapolis, Md.

title: JAZZ: STRING FEVER, FROM JAZZ AH CORDES
description: THE appearance three and a half years ago of Jazz Ah Cordes, a group that emulated the style and repertory of the Quintet of the Hot Club of France, which featured the guitarist Django Reinhardt and the violinist Stephane Grappelli, developed an enthusiastic following of older listeners who remembered the quintet's recordings of 40 years ago and younger listeners who were fascinated by its swinging chamber jazz style.

title: DANCE: PILOBOLUS PREMIERE OF 'BONSAI'
description: The Pilobolus Dance Theater has not performed in New York City since its sole 1977 Broadway season, but it does wend its always merry way through the rest of the country.

title: Wilson Schmidt Dies; World Bank Nominee
description: Wilson Schmidt, President Reagan's nominee to represent the United States at the World Bank, died at a hospital here yesterday after being injured Sunday night in a fire at the prestigious Cosmos Club.

title: Key Rates
A Lawyers' Group Wins Case On Maps Citing City Potholes
description: A judge in Manhattan has ordered New York City to accept thousands of maps detailing potholes and other street defects from a lawyers' group that has been recording street hazards in response to the yearold city pothole law.

title: REAGAN DENIES RUMORS THAT CASEY MAY QUIT
description: President Reagan and William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, denied today that Mr. Casey planned to resign in the light of criticism of his past business dealings.

title: U.S. STUDIES LATIN BANK ROLE
description: The Reagan Administration has asked for the resignation of the senior American official at the Inter-American Development Bank, in a move that bank officials suggest may be part of an effort to make the international bank more politically responsive to the Administration's views.

title: 3 AUXILIARY OFFICERS IN BROOKLYN ACCUSED OF FAKING SHOOTING
description: Three auxiliary police officers were suspended early this morning after one officer wearing a bulletproof vest was shot in the chest on a Brooklyn street as part of a publicity stunt, the police said. Though the vest stopped the bullet, the officer was hospitalized with chest bruises.

title: ST. JOE MINERALS NET DROPS 5.7%
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation, the nation's largest producer of lead and zinc, said yesterday that earnings fell 5.7 percent, to $23.3 million, in the second quarter ended June 30.

title: U.S. Captures 3 Golds In Track-Field Events
description: Mel Lattany, David Lee and Leo Williams won track and field gold medals at the World University Games today, but a hamstring injury forced the United States team captain, Willie Banks, to abandon the defense of his triple-jump title.

title: AT URBAN LEAGUE, MONDALE DERIDES REAGAN VALUES
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, describing the Reagan Administration's policies as a radical assault on the American ideal of fairness, called on the National Urban League today to fight ''icy indifference to human need and justice.''

title: Advertising; NEW HUMOR MAGAZINE SCHEDULED FOR THE FALL
description: Having written a history of the supermarket industry, Randy McAusland is taking the natural next step -he is founding a humor magazine.

title: COSMOS PREVAIL IN SHOOTOUT
description: The Cosmos twice made up deficits in regulation time tonight, then won their first shootout of the season for a 5-4 victory over the Montreal Manic at Giants Stadium.

title: Advertising; HOWARD JOHNSON GETS NEW AGENCY FOR CHAINS
description: Colarossi/Griswold-Eshleman is becoming the new agency for two of the Howard Johnson Company's restaurant chains.

title: OWNERS' BOARD TALKS TO PLAYERS
description: For the first time during the 41-day-old baseball strike, the two key committees for the players and owners met today in secret session. There was no immediate indication of productivity after the 90-minute meeting between the players' negotiating committee and the board of directors of the owners' player relations committee. But the meeting might have served to keep the talks going rather than having them break off again.

title: Crunch Felt in Ball Park Areas
description: A Dun & Bradstreet study released yesterday shows that 58 percent of the businesses located near major league baseball parks have been adversely affected by the strike and that 7 percent would be forced to shut down if the strike lasted the rest of the season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was born free and I want to die free as a citizen of this great country.'' - Gabriel Isahar Isaharov, 99 years old, on being granted citizenship by a Federal judge. (B6:1.)

title: U.S. AND BRITISH RIOTS: EXPERTS SEE FEW PARALLELS
description: Despite some similarities between the urban riots that erupted this summer in Britain and those of the 1960's in the United States, a number of Americans familiar with both countries say there are such great differences that close parallels cannot be drawn.

title: PEOPLE WHO HELP WITH THE CHORES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Marcelle Sussman is a freelance writer. By MARCELLE SUSSMAN

title: AS CHILDREN CONTINUE TO LABOR IN THE FIELDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Cusick, 68, a Lawyer And Ex-Member of Assembly
description: Charles A. Cusick, a lawyer and former member of the New York State Assembly, died Tuesday at his home in Weedsport, N.Y., after an illness of several months.

title: TV: A BLITZ ON THE ROYAL WEDDING
description: LET all those who insist that television news is overly preoccupied with troubles and disasters hold their peace - if not forever, at least for the next week or so. Britain's royal wedding of Prince Charles to Lady Diana Spencer takes place on Wednesday, and the scheduled clutter of fluff is reaching unprecedented proportions. Many will doubtlessly find the bridal blitz diverting. Others, perhaps longing for another Mark Twain who might remind us of our anti-monarchist roots, may find the electronic frenzy disgraceful. In any case, coping with the usual summer-programming doldrums, television is diligently beating the drums for what NBC might call another Big Event.

title: A Brand-New 99-Year-Old Nephew for Uncle Sam
description: He knows only four English phrases and can name only three American Presidents, and that, said the Immigration and Naturalization Service, meant that Gabriel Isahar Isaharov could not become an American citizen.

title: Judge Is Asked to Reject F.B.I. Bugging Records
description: The lawyer William M. Kunstler asked a Federal District judge today to strip the Federal Bureau of Investigation of any evidence obtained by electronic surveillance of a law office frequented by reputed organized crime members.

title: Bhutto's Widow Freed After Five Months
description: Nusrat Bhutto, the widow of Pakistan's executed former Prime Minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was released from jail today after nearly five months in detention, The Associated Press of Pakistan reported.

title: 'PERSON UNKNOWN' KILLED BULLY, INQUIRY FINDS
description: A six-member coroner's jury in rural Nodaway County ruled yesterday that the killing of an unpopular Skidmore resident outside a bar July 10, apparently by a vigilante mob, was the work of ''person or persons unknown.''

title: Mistrial Is Declared in Case Of Boxing Promoter's Lawyer
description: A Federal District judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the case of Jennifer King, an attorney for Ross Fields, the boxing promoter being investigated in the embezzlement of $21 million from the Wells Fargo Bank. Miss King was being tried on three counts of obstruction of justice and one of perjury.

title: Bridge: 3 Important Days Starting For Grand National Team
description: For a small contingent of players arriving here today, the next three days will be more important than the subsequent week of play in the Summer Nationals. Eight teams, including one from New York City, have survived local, unit, district and zonal play to reach the quarter-final of the Grand National Teams.

title: Market Place; MANEUVERING IN CONOCO BIDS
description: WALL STREET professionals call it ''a free look,'' not committing investors to anything, simply ''a chance to get in line.'' As a consequence, many investors in Conoco, faced so far with multibillion-dollar takeover bids from Seagram, Du Pont and Mobil, sent some or all of their shares yesterday to Joseph E. Seagram & Sons.

title: HARVESTER OFFER
description: The International Harvester Company said it had received offers by two Canadian concerns for the purchase of its Pacific truck and trailer subsidiary in North Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Three Ethnic Albanians Are Jailed in Yugoslavia
description: Three ethnic Albanians were sentenced to jail terms ranging from six to eight years today for antis@tate activities in the first of a series of trials stemming from violent Albanian nationalist riots in Yugoslavia's province of Kosovo last spring.

title: WESTERN BANKS CLAIM UNITY ON POLISH ISSUE
description: A task force of Western banks said today that it had reached ''unanimous'' agreement on a joint position to be taken on Poland's debt.

title: FOX CHIEF'S SELECTION DUE TODAY
description: Alan J. Hirschfield, the winner in a nearly two-year power struggle at the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, is expected to be named chairman and chief executive of the company tomorrow by Marvin Davis, the oil billionaire who purchased Fox last spring for $800 million and turned it into a private company.

title: ISRAELI JETS LEAVE 50 DEAD ON THE ROADS OF LEBANON
description: Israeli fighter-bombers made four raids today on two temporary bridges that had been built to replace spans destroyed in raids on the coastal road between Beirut and Tyre last week.

title: KENNEL PAMPERS DOGS WITH FANCIEST CARE
description: The Canine Country Club pampers its tenants, making them feel at home with fresh vegetables right out of the garden, poached eggs or an early morning recitation of the 23d Psalm.

title: OPERA HOUSE IS OPENING IN CATSKILLS
description: The chapel of a former summer camp here in the northern Catskill Mountains has been transformed into an opera house that will open Saturday evening with a performance of Gian Carlo Menotti's ''The Consul.'' On Sunday afternoon Mozart's ''Cosi fan tutte'' will be sung in a new English translation.

title: William F. J. Ryan, Designed Coats of Arms for Catholics
description: William F. J. Ryan, a designer of coats of arms for leaders of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, died Sunday in Hyannis, Mass.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: ARECENT tour through a cutlery store provided a surprising education in the variety of types and purposes of scissors. We all know about scissors for fabric, paper, hair and fingernails.

title: The City; Company Fined In Copter Scheme
description: A Federal judge imposed a $5,000 fine on a California aviation company for its part in a conspiracy to violate the law by shipping helicopters with a military capability to South Africa.

title: Executives
description: * Anderson, Greenwood & Company, a valve manufacturer, named Roman F. Arnoldy and Douglas J. Bourne to the board of directors.

title: Administration Urges Delay In New G.I. Benefits Program
description: The Reagan Administration urged Congress today to delay action on a new G.I. bill providing a permanent education assistance program, but sponsors said they would push ahead with it anyway.

title: CITY AND STATE PUSH FOR PACT ON WESTWAY BY TOMORROW
description: Representatives of Mayor Koch and Governor Carey struggled last night to work out a final agreement that would clear the way for construction of the long-delayed and much-debated Westway highway project.

title: CONTINENTAL AIR FIGHTS RULING
description: Continental Air Lines said it had filed suit in United States District Court in Los Angeles seeking to overturn a ruling by the California Corporations Commissioner that has effectively blocked it from carrying out a controversial employee stock ownership plan.

title: CHINESE AIDE SAYS WORST OF FLOODING IS OVER
description: A senior Chinese Government official said today that the worst of the Yangtze River flooding was over as flood crests dissipated upon reaching the industrial city of Wuhan.

title: VINES IN CITY GROW RAPIDLY, GIVING SHADE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Linda Yang is a regular contributor of gardening articles to The Home Section. By LINDA YANG

title: MISS HOLTZMAN IN RACE FOR BROOKLYN PROSECUTOR
description: Vowing to ''curb the influence of political clubhouses'' in the District Attorney's office, Elizabeth Holtzman declared her candidacy yesterday for the Democratic nomination for Brooklyn District Attorney.

title: Jacob Wolfowitz, 71, Taught Math at Cornell and Columbia
description: Dr. Jacob Wolfowitz, a professor of mathematics at Cornell and Columbia Universities, died July 16 following a heart attack in Tampa, Fla., where he was teaching at the University of South Florida. He was 71 years old.

title: JAPANESE CAR MAKERS STUDY EXPORT PLANS
description: After more than a decade of spearheading Japan's export drive, car manufacturers here are being forced to reassess their basic strategies because of recent agreements to curb shipments to the United States and several West European countries.

title: SWISS RATES CUT
description: The four biggest Swiss banks today lowered their interest rates on time deposits with maturities between three months and 11 months to 8 1/2 percent from 9 percent.

title: PACE AND SCOPE OF INQUIRIES RISE IN HOTEL DISASTER
description: Lawyers and investigators for virtually all of the companies involved in the design, construction and operation of the Hyatt Regency hotel here are conducting nearly a dozen separate investigations into the circumstances that led to the deaths of 111 persons last Friday after two aerial walkways collapsed onto the hotel's crowded lobby floor.

title: DOW OFF 9.80, TO 924.66, ITS LOW FOR THIS YEAR
description: The stock market failed yesterday to sustain a rally attempt and prices then plunged abruptly, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest closing this year. The indicator tumbled 9.80 points, to 924.66, bringing its combined loss this week to 34 points.

title: METROMEDIA SEEKS TV STATION
description: Metromedia Inc. announced yesterday that it had reached agreement to purchase what is widely regarded as one of the best television stations in the country - WCVB-TV, Channel 5, the independently owned ABC affiliate in Boston - for a record $220 million.

title: MOBIL MAY RAISE CONOCO CASH OFFER
description: In an apparent step to outmaneuver E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company in its multibillion-dollar bid for Conoco Inc., the Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it might increase the cash portion of its own offer for Conoco to ''at least as high'' as the $95 a share being offered by Du Pont. It gave no details on when - or if - it would increase its bid although Wall Street analysts said they expected a move very soon.

title: RASMUSSEN DEFIES THE YEARS
description: Randy Rasmussen's freckled face was twisted into a grimace; 260-pound offensive linemen do not enjoy running the 40-yard dash.

title: Saumell Wins Appeal to Ride
description: Larry Saumell, the jockey who was barred from riding in New York after he was accused of dropping an illegal electrical device just before a race at Belmont on June 22, will be able to ride again beginning today.

title: BEGIN TOURS NORTHERN ISRAEL TO BOLSTER MORALE IN SHELTERS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin, accompanied by senior military officers, made a visit to northern Israel today to buttress morale as Palestinian guerrillas across the border in Lebanon continued their rocket fire for the eighth day.

title: Index; International
description: Experts see few parallels be- tween U.S. and British riots A2 In Belfast, rain heightens feeling of being ''trapped'' A3 Chinese official says worst of Yangtze flooding is over A5 Polish tension eases as negotia- tors avert strikes A7 Salvadorans held on Coast as aliens ask Reagan for asylum A8 Five nations press for Namibia action A8 Around the World A9 Reagan says Mitterrand broke the ice at Ottawa A10 Many U.S. Jews distressed over Israeli and P.L.O. raids A13 Government/Politics Republicans dividing and con- quering in Texas redistricting A16 Walter Mondale challenges Rea- gan ''indifference.'' A17 New Representative finds her work satisfying and rewarding B2 Carey signs measure to promote nuclear safety B2 Koch and Carey aides press for pact on Westway B3 Several court and legislative challenges await Westway B3 General Around the Nation A16 Pace and number of investiga- tions increase in hotel accident A16 Reagan denies rumors that Casey will quit as head of the C.I.A.A18 Croatian-Americans uneasy after arrest of 9 terror suspects A20 Notes from around the sanitation circuit B1 Port Chester pinning its hopes on redevelopment projects B1 5 lawyers accused of soliciting medical malpractice clients B4 Religion Jesuit Center on Broad Street hopes for brighter future B4 Home Section Home The furniture of Marcel Breuer: classics and surprises C1

title: RESEARCHERS FIND STIFFNESS A CLUE TO TREATMENT OF JUVENILE DIABETES
description: By studying the hands of victims of childhood diabetes, doctors can predict which sufferers are most likely to develop eye and kidney disease, the most dangerous complications of their condition, a study shows.

title: KOCH FINDS MOBIL GAS 'CHEAPEST'
description: When the Mobil Oil Corporation raised its prices last week in response to new state taxes, Mayor Koch strongly suggested that unhappy consumers could buy their gasoline at another company's pumps.

title: CITIBANK TO PAY $350,000 FINE
description: Citibank, the nation's second-largest commercial bank, said it had consented to pay a civil fine of $350,000 levied against it by the Federal Reserve Board for violating a Fed rule on the amount of premiums that can be paid to obtain bank deposits.

title: No Headline
description: The House passed an $11.2 billion appropriation bill for the Interior Department and related agencies today. The measure includes provisions quarreling with policies of Interior Secretary Watt.

title: ARREST OF 9 IN TERRORIST GROUP BRINGS UNEASY CALM TO CROATIAN-AMERICANS
description: The arrest of nine Croatian nationalists last month, which Federal agents say halted ''the most violent terrorist group in the United States,'' has brought an uneasy calm to the nation's two million Croatian-Americans.

title: SOLOMON AND PECCI UPSET IN 2D ROUND
description: Pascal Portes, a 22-year-old Frenchman, upset Harold Solomon, 1-6, 6-3, 6-2, and reached the third round of the $200,000 Washington Star tennis tournament today.

title: HERSHEY NET UP 23.1%
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation, a major producer of chocolate and confectionary products, including chocolate bars, breakfast cocoa and chocolate syrup, said today that strong candy sales helped it post a 23.1 percent gain in second-quarter profit on a 4.4 percent rise in sales. In the quarter ended July 5, Hershey said it earned $14.4 million, or $1.02 a share, on sales of $296.4 million. During the same period a year ago, Hershey had net income of $11.7 million, or 83 cents a share, on sales of $284 million.

title: SOWING CROPS NOW TO ENJOY IN THE FALL
description: It's time to plant the vegetable garden - again. Peas, lettuce, beets and beans are finished or finishing. But their rows will be not be empty long; weeds are quick to take over unless a new crop is started. Besides, it is a waste of good growing space not to keep all vegetable garden rows productive from the start to the end of the growing season.

title: Woman Dies of Burns in Fire At Boarding Home in Jersey
description: An 81-year-old woman who survived a fire in a boarding home that killed six residents last February died today of burns suffered in the fire.

title: CALENDAR: FROM SEASIDE TO MUSEUM GALLERIES
description: Seashore Botany, Horticultural Soci- ety of New York, 128 West 58th Street.

title: SUSPECT DENIES KILLING 2 HUNTERS 29 YEARS AGO
description: A 53-year-old handyman accused of the murders of two hunters in Orange County 29 years ago took the stand today in his own defense and denied the charges against him.

title: No Headline
description: The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee City's Solar Energy Sites Visited More than 50 solar energy designers, planners and architects toured several solar projects sponsored by the State Energy Research and Development Authority. At the Fireboat House, above, a solar energy center at 89th Street and East End Avenue, residential and small commercial applications were demonstrated. Large solar collectors atop the Southbridge Towers complex on Beekman Street, left, provide more than 30 percent of the hot-water requirements for 692 apartments.

title: Argentine Cargo Plane Said to Crash in Soviet
description: A plane entered Soviet airspace from Iran on Saturday, collided with a Soviet plane near Yerevan in Armenia and crashed, the Tass press agency said today.

title: JERSEY'S CASINOS BLAMED FOR A HOUSING SHORTAGE
description: Under pressure from New Jersey's Public Advocate, the Casino Control Commission agreed at a meeting here today to study what the advocate's office says is a housing shortage caused by the growth of the casino industry in Atlantic City.

title: A COUNTRY HOME THAT'S FIT FOR A PRINCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Susan Goodman is a freelance writer living in London. By SUSAN GOODMAN LONDON PRINCE Charles's new home, Highgrove, to which he will soon bring his bride of next week, Lady Diana Spencer, is well suited to his sporting tastes and his need for privacy. A substantial Georgian house of gray Cotswold stone standing in 347 acres of park and farmland, Highgrove is close to the village of Tetbury in Gloucestershire. The Prince will continue to farm the land, which also provides excellent stabling and paddocks for his horses.

title: The Region; Suffolk Rights Unit Asks U.S. Inquiry
description: The Suffolk County Human Rights Commission has asked the United States Attorney to look into the increasing racial incidents in the county. The commission charges that Suffolk law enforcement authorities have been lax in investigating the incidents, which have included cross burnings on the lawns of two black families in Copiague.

title: Better Deaf Than Dumb Allies
description: The best thing about the allied economic summit conference is that it still exists. Only a few months ago the French suggested that the seventh annual meeting in Ottawa be the last. But that meeting's only real decision was to start a new round of summit sessions in France next summer and to improve the year-round, lower-level consultations. They have never been more needed.

title: The Region; War Crimes Laid To Ex-Lithuanian
description: NEWARK (AP) - The Federal Government sought to revoke the citizenship of a Clifton man who is accused of participating in the murders of 2,100 unarmed civilians in his native Lithuania during World War II.

title: The Talk of Port Chester
description: For several years, the officials who run this small Westchester County village on Long Island Sound at the portals to Connecticut have insisted that the economy of its rundown central business district is about to turn the corner.

title: WITH THE LETTUCE, A NEW LOVE GROWS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Fred Halliday is a novelist and screenwriter who lives in New York. By FRED HALLIDAY

title: SALVADORANS HELD ON COAST AS ALIENS ASK REAGAN FOR ASYLUM
description: A group of 150 Salvadoran refugees, some of whom had been held as illegal aliens for as long as nine months, petitioned President Reagan today for political asylum.

title: Rogers of Saints Ailing
description: George Rogers, the New Orleans Saints' No. 1 draft pick, will not travel to Miami tomorrow for a scrimmage with the Dolphins. Rogers, a running back from South Carolina, has been sidelined all week with a pulled hamstring. Coach Bum Phillips said that, although the injury is not serious, he wanted to give it time to heal.

title: DEMOCRAT'S LOSS LAID TO TIES WITH PHILADELPHIA'S MAYOR
description: Mayor William J. Green, at an unusually candid news conference, today assumed part of the blame for the defeat yesterday of his party's candidate for Congress, a Democrat running in a district where Democrats outnumber Republicans by 4 to 1.

title: IN BELFAST, RAIN AND A 'TRAPPED' MOOD
description: It rained again today in Belfast, a cold, steady drizzle whipped by a sharp wind off the Cavehill Mountains.

title: A CITY TOWN HOUSE, RISEN FROM ASHES
description: THE brick town house on West 11th Street in Greenwich Village is a close match for its 140-year-old neighbors, but there are differences: On the middle floors, its front wall angles in and out, and in the windowed prow of the second-floor library, overlooking the sidewalk, there stands a toy bear from London named Paddington.

title: OUR MULTIPURPOSE LADY IN THE HARBOR
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRYSLER MAKES 3-MONTH PROFIT, FIRST SINCE 1978
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which was on the edge of bankruptcy a little more than a year ago, reported today that it earned $12 million in the second quarter of 1981. This was its first profit in more than two years.

title: HERS
description: SEX hasn't been the same since it became sexuality. The instant it became sexuality, sex lost pizazz. Everyone became responsible for ''mutual fulfillment.'' Once responsible for ''mutual fulfillment,'' many people found they were less interested in attaining it. What was so appealing about ''fulfillment'' was the way it sneaked up on you. Who wants information at the expense of delirium and zip? Too many couples ended up eyeing each other grimly in the dark, monitoring one another's progress. No wonder so many people simply threw up their hands and signed up for Home Box Office.

title: Business People; PUROLATOR CHOOSES CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER
description: Frederick H. Cook, 65, has been named president and chief executive officer of Purolator Inc., the filter manufacturer that is also the world's largest courier company and one of the three biggest armored car companies in the United States. He succeeds Paul A. Cameron, 59, who has been named vice chairman.

title: 'Not in My Neighborhood'
description: Clean Coal Deserves a Place

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 23, 1981
description: International The United States criticized Israel because of the Israeli air strikes in Lebanon. Two top Reagan Administration officials suggested that the policies of Prime Minister Menachem Begin had set back American efforts to obtain a cease-fire and had made it more difficult to resume deliveries of F-16 jets to Israel. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israeli jets made four raids on two makeshift bridges on the coastal road between Beirut and Tyre. At least 50 people were reported killed. Farther north, at least 18 people were reported killed and an oil pipeline was set afire in two Israeli strikes. (A12:1-3.)

title: Advertising; D'ARCY KEEPS THE AIR FORCE
description: In competition with four other ad agencies, D'Arcy-McManus & Masius managed to hold onto the Air Force Recruiting Service account, which could be spending as much as $7.3 million during the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL UNIT PLANS TO SUE WATT TO SPEED SPECIES PROTECTION
description: An environmental group served notice today that it plans to sue Interior Secretary James G. Watt to force him to resume listing animal and plant species threatened with extinction, a process that has virtually halted since the Reagan Administration took office.

title: A HIRSUTE HEMINGWAY ESCHEWS RESPECTABILITY
description: WE discover in ''Ernest Hemingway: Selected Letters, 1917-1961'' that on Jan. 23, 1923, Hemingway wrote Ezra Pound a somewhat curious piece of intelligence.

title: Brig. Gen. F.H. Wirsig, An Early Marine Pilot
description: Brig. Gen. Frank H. Wirsig, an early Marine Corps aviator, died Sunday as a result of Alzheimer's disease, a disorder of the central nervous system, at a nursing home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 77 years old.

title: Business People; MOVE AT PAINE WEBBER
description: ''Thank you, Paine Webber,'' is heard a lot on Wall Street these days, especially in the company's own offices. In the third promotion to be announced in the last two weeks, Jack L. Rivkin, 40, has been named president and chief executive officer of Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, the research arm that conducts the firm's institutional equity and investment business.

title: CAREY SIGNS NUCLEAR-SAFETY MEASURE
description: Governor Carey announced his approval today of bills to promote nuclear safety and to establish fines and prison terms for those who illegally dump toxic chemicals in the state among a host of others that he signed.

title: CUSTODY AND THE LEGAL CLASHES
description: When the Rev. Francis Pizzarelli opened the rectory door at Infant Jesus Catholic Church in Port Jefferson, L.I., in March 1980, he found a wiry 15-year-old seeking sanctuary. His name was Jamie Schaeffer and he had bolted from a custody hearing after a Family Court judge ruled that he must leave his father's home in Long Island and return to his mother's home in Florida. ''The police are looking for me,'' he told the priest.

title: TALKS IN POLAND AVERT TWO STRIKES
description: The political mood in Poland improved today after late-night negotiations between the Government and the independent trade union Solidarity averted strikes against the stateowned airline and by dock workers at Baltic ports.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THE use of large attic fans that exhaust hot air from the top of the house while drawing in cool air through open windows downstairs was once the most popular means of cooling a house in the evening. These fans became less popular as air-conditioners became more popular. Climbing energy costs, however, have revived interest in these fans and have resulted in the introduction of models specifically designed to make installation quick and easy.

title: CONFEREES QUARREL OVER AID FOR FARM OR FOOD STAMP PROGRAMS
description: Congressional negotiators argued angrily and fruitlessly today over whether farmers or food stamp recipients should get more money in the 1982 budget.

title: JESUITS FIND NEW CENTER NEEDS MORE THAN FAITH
description: On the third floor at 50 Broad Street, down the block from the New York Stock Exchange, brass letters spell out ''Jesuit Center'' on the doors of one of the offices.

title: 5 NATIONS PRESS NAMIBIA ACTION
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and the foreign ministers of four other Western nations have agreed on the urgent need for action to make South-West Africa independent. But Mark MacGuigan, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, said today that he was not optimistic about an early solution.

title: Coping With Crime
description: If crime is a major public issue, you'd never know it from the response in Washington.

title: 3M, SPERRY DECLINE
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the largest maker of photographic products, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter advanced 18.7 percent, while sales increased 13.6 percent.

title: Puerto Rico to Accept 800 Haitian Refugees
description: Puerto Rico agreed today to accept up to 800 Haitian refugees now housed in Florida refugee centers.

title: Clifton A. Hipkins, 84, Dealer In Bonds and Yachting Leader
description: Clifton A. Hipkins, a retired municipal bond dealer and a prominent yachtsman, died Saturday at a nursing home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 84 years old and lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: EXXON NET UP BY 77% IN QUARTER
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest industrial company, yesterday reported that it earned $1.83 billion, or $2.11 a share, over all in the second quarter, up 77 percent from the $1.03 billion, or $1.18 a share, it had reported for the comparable period a year earlier.

title: OIL: NIGERIA'S MIXED BLESSING
description: The business of oil is all-pervasive in Nigeria, from the foreign executives eager to carve out a share of the riches to the hundreds of thousands of Nigerians who have set up beach shanties near the big cities to cash in on the oil boom.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Flora Lewis THE INTELLECTUAL RESISTANCE IN EUROPE. By James D. Wilkinson. 358 pages. Harvard University Press. $20.

title: SOVIET COMMANDANT OF EAST BERLIN IN '48
description: Maj. Gen. Aleksandr G. Kotikov, the Soviet commandant in Berlin during the 1948 blockade, had died at the age of 79 after a long illness, the Soviet Defense Ministry newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda reported today.

title: 2 MENACHEM BEGINS
description: .8,2On July 22, 1946, the Irgun Tzvai Leumi, under the leadership of Menachem Begin, bombed the King David Hotel in Jerusalem, killing 91 people. Mr. Begin argued at the time - and the evidence seems to support him -that his underground group gave ample warning to the British Mandatory authorities, who used the hotel as their headquarters, to evacuate the building. Whether or not one agrees with its tactics, the Irgun's target was not innocent civilians but a military and political installation.

title: Ballplayers Still in There Swinging
description: The baseball strike may be bad for the baseball business, but it has produced one commercial bonanza -a boom in lucrative personal appearances by out-of-work ballplayers. That, at least, is the word from Martin Blackman, a 43-year-old sports sales consultant, who said yesterday that his corporate clients had been clamoring for striking stars to lend a touch of celebrity to sales meetings and product promotions.

title: Boy, 4, Hit at Gimbels As Truck Jumps Curb
description: A 4-year-old boy was critically injured last night when he was run over by a delivery van that jumped a curb in front of Gimbels department store at 33d Street and hurtled down a crowded sidewalk, forcing pedestrians to jump for cover, the police reported.

title: PERILOUS REAGANOMICS
description: To the Editor:

title: TO MANAGE STATE PENSION FUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Business People; HIGH-LEVEL POSTS FILLED AT WARNER
description: There does not seem to be much more room at the top of Warner Communications Inc., the movie, music and electronic games company. Bert W. Wasserman, 48 years old, the company's chief financial officer, has been elected to the office of the president.

title: Technology; SOLAR COLLECTOR DEVELOPMENT
description: A SHAKEOUT is under way in an important segment of the solar energy business and, for once, the big names are among those throwing in the towel.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Ilene Goldsmith Rapkin has been named publisher of the Ziff-Davis Inflight Group, Pan Am, Clipper, USAir magazine and Piedmont Pace.

title: Military Analysis
description: Israel's air, sea and ground drive against the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon is not a reaction to increased guerrilla activity but a carefully orchestrated campaign that has as its objective the freeing of northern Israel from pressure by the guerrillas.

title: Sports of The Times; Home, Home on la Rue
description: The French border guards are always amazed at the arrival of the Mercedes with the Wyoming license plates that bear the silhouette of a bucking bronco. The guards speak to the wiry driver in English, only to have him answer in flawless Parisian French.

title: Athens Protests Charge By Hungary's Embassy
description: The Greek Government protested to the Hungarian Embassy today over a charge by the embassy that Athens tried to put pressure on a Budapest professor who had sought asylum in Greece but then changed his mind and was flown home.

title: BELGIAN-THAI ZINC VENTURE
description: Belgium and Thailand have agreed to establish a joint venture to produce zinc, Thai officials said today.

title: THEATER: 'ARMS AND THE MAN'
description: If you're going to stage a play that contains a two-man, one-woman love triangle, there's one ingredient that's nearly essential these days: Blythe Danner. Put this actress at the apex of such a triangle, and the audience will immediately understand why the men must fight to the finish for her affections. Among her many gifts, Miss Danner has a remarkable ability to create ravishing women without presenting herself as flawless. While she conveys intelligence, sensitivity and glamour, she also insists on injecting notes of silliness, insecurity and even pig-headedness. The resulting characterizations are all the more irresistible for being fully rounded. And all the more vulnerable, too. No wonder we quickly find ourselves rooting for the better of the rival suitors to win her heart.

title: 'RACE UPON RACE'
description: We come back to Dickens. In the end no other writer of fiction in English approaches him in vividness, in exotic invention of character, in social vision, in the size of his canvas. No one else so grips us, on the printed page, in the teeming drama of his imagination.

title: U.S. DOCTORS TENTATIVELY CONCLUDE THAT HINCKLEY WAS PROBABLY SANE
description: Several Government psychiatrists have tentatively concluded that John W. Hinckley Jr. not only is competent to stand trial for the shooting of President Reagan, but also was probably sane at the time of the assassination attempt last March, according to doctors and lawyers familiar with the case.

title: COCA-COLA FALLS 2%
description: The General Foods Corporation, the country's biggest coffee producer and a leading factor in the packaged food industry said that earnings in the first quarter of the fiscal year 1982 dropped 30.5 percent, to $50.3 million, or $1.02 a share, from $72.4 million, or $1.45 a share, in the corresponding fiscal quarter a year earlier. Sales increased 16.4 percent, to $2.06 billion, from $1.77 billion.

title: Jury Acquits 2 Members Of Philadelphia Cult
description: Two members of the radical cult Move were acquitted by a Federal jury today on weapons and conspiracy charges.

title: ON THE SANITATION CIRCUIT, A DEPARTMENTAL COOK OFF AND SOME GARBATE WIT
description: Lesson No. 1 for New York City garbage-watchers: The ''they'' in ''Why don't they clean that up?'' is a fugitive. If bags of garbage pile up outside your apartment house, maybe the super couldn't find the room to store them. Do sanitation men drop garbage as they hurl it into their trucks? ''Look at the work speedup,'' one said.

title: POPE'S ASSAILANT SENTENCED TO LIFE
description: Mehmet Ali Agca was found guilty today of attempting to kill Pope John Paul II and two American women in St. Peter's Square on May 13. He was sentenced to life in prison.

title: ALSANDS APPROVES FURTHER SPENDING
description: The Alsands consortium said today it would invest a further $20 million in its billion-dollar oil sands project in northeastern Alberta.

title: Issue and Debate; CURBING BRIBERY ABROAD
description: Four years ago, Congress spoke out in a seemingly clear voice against bribery of foreign officials by American companies when it passed the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The legislation, which came after yearlong hearings, also called for public companies to keep accurate records, a requirement that at the time also seemed simple and reasonable.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Appointed Bob Fontaine, former San Diego Padres general manager, as player development coordinator.; COLLEGES EASTERN ILLINOIS - Named Tom Westhoff assistant football coach.  NORTHWESTERN - Named Ron Wellman baseball coach.; FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Extended the con- tract of William Andrews, running back, through the 1982 season for a package re- portedly worth $400,000 over 1981 and 1982.  BALTIMORE (AFC) - Picked up the following players
description: ST. LOUIS (NFC) - Signed Gary Wool- f ord and Willie Underwood, free agent de- f ensive backs.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES RELIEF ON OIL TAX
description: The heavily Democratic Ways and Means Committee completed its draft of a tax bill early today with a decision to give the oil industry billions of dollars of relief from the ''windfall profits'' tax.

title: 3 Diamonds Captures Pace
description: Three Diamonds broke the track record for a 2-year-old filly tonight in winning the $284,200 John Chapman Memorial Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: DURABLES ORDERS OFF 0.8% IN JUNE
description: Orders for manufacturers' durable goods fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the first decline since January and was viewed by many analysts as another indication that the national economy remained weak.

title: Currency Markets; DOLLAR OFF AMID SIGNS OF SAGGING ECONOMY; The Associated Press
description: The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday following new reports of a weakening United States economy that bolstered hopes that interest rates may retreat from current near-record-high levels.

title: Five Lawyers Indicted On a Charge of Bribery
description: Five lawyers were indicted yesterday on commercial bribery charges stemming from a reported scheme to solicit clients for medical malpractice suits.

title: AVON GAINS 6%
description: Avon Products Inc., the largest seller of door-to-door cosmetics and owner of Tiffany & Company, reported second-quarter net earnings of $52.7 million, or 87 cents a share, up 6 percent from $49.6 million, or 82 cents a share in the second quarter of 1980.

title: Effect of National Strike In Argentina Is Limited
description: A national strike called by hard-line Peronist labor leaders met with only limited success today. The police here estimated that about 10 to 15 percent of the workers did not show up for work this morning, and news reports from around the country indicated that the number could not have been much higher elsewhere.

title: UNSOLD $113,000 HOME WILL BE RAFFLED FOR $100
description: When John and Carilyn Redman had trouble finding a buyer for their $113,000 home in northern Virginia earlier this year, they hit on a novel solution to beat the high mortgage interest rates: They decided to raffle it off.

title: MET MUSEUM GETS A $10 MILLION GIFT
description: A gift of $10 million, one of the largest single monetary donations in its history, has been received by the Metropolitan Museum of Art from Harold D. Uris, the builder and real-estate developer. The money will be used for the creation and endowment of the Ruth and Harold D. Uris Center for Education at the museum, which will entail reconstruction of the Junior Museum area in the building's south end.

title: STAFF TAKES LEADING ROLE AT CONFERENCES ON BUDGET
description: ''Let's get our staffs together and narrow these issues,'' Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee, said at the outset of one of 58 subconferences seeking to resolve differences in the budget packages adopted by the House and Senate.

title: Holdup Suspect Is Shot Dead
description: In Struggle With a Detective

title: COX NET RISES 22%
description: Citing advertising gains, the Cox Broadcasting Corporation reported today that its second-quarter net income rose 22 percent, to $16.4 million, or $1.22 a share, from $13.5 million, or $1 a share, in the similar period a year ago. The company also reported second-quarter operating revenues of $101.7 million, a 28 percent increase from $79.2 million in the 1980 period. The company's president, William A. Schwartz, said broadcasting revenues for the second quarter increased 18 percent.

title: JOSEPH N. KATZ
description: Joseph N. Katz, the founder and board chairman of Empire Kosher Poultry Inc., died Monday.

title: A COSTLY AND FUTILE STAB AT
description: CRIMETo the Editor:

title: Informer in Case of Bonanno Dies of Cancer in California
description: Louis E. Peters, the Cadillac dealer whose work as an informer helped the Federal Bureau of Investigation convict Joseph Bonanno Sr., the reputed Mafia leader, has died of cancer at a hospital here.

title: BRITISH WON'T ALTER HONEYMOON PLAN
description: The British Government today rejected suggestions that Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer begin their Mediterranean honeymoon cruise in some port other than Gibraltar.

title: CRASHING RED LIGHTS
description: W e used to play it as kids on the city sidewalks. When the leader turned around and proclaimed ''Red light!'' we stopped in our tracks, notwithstanding our rush to reach the goal. At ''green light,'' we moved.

title: Advertising; WOMEN'S MAGAZINE IS PLANNED
description: YES, there is another women's magazine on the drawing boards. This one, however, will not dwell on food, fashion, cosmetics or beauty, because, as the subtitle of Woman's Life notes, it is ''for the woman who reaches beyond herself.''

title: THREE-DAY BATTLE IN KABUL SUBURB CALLED ONE OF BIGGEST FOR AFGHANS
description: Three days of fighting around a Kabul suburb last week were described here today in Western diplomatic reports as some of the fiercest and costliest fighting near the capital since the onset of Afghanistan's guerrilla war and the arrival of Soviet troops.

title: The Region; Water Restrictions Remain in Newark
description: Restrictions on water use for this city's 355,000 residents, which were imposed on July 7 following the rupture of two pipelines supplying 60 percent of the city's water, will continue until Monday, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said.

title: U.S. ECONOMY DOWN AT A RATE OF 1.9% IN SECOND QUARTER
description: The nation's economy weakened quickly in the second quarter, receding from a strong first period, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: The City; Acting Director Of Budget Named
description: Louis A. Friedrich, a deputy director of the city's Office of Management and Budget, was named Acting Director to replace James R. Brigham Jr., who will leave municipal government on July 31.

title: BAYREUTH, West Germany
description: WHEN Johanna Meier, a young soprano fresh from the Manhattan School of Music, traveled to West Germany in the 1960's to audition for opera work, her auditioners listened, applauded and told her to sing Wagner.

title: AIR FORCE CHIEF CALLS THE STEALTH A 'PAPER PLANE' FAR FROM REALITY
description: The Secretary of the Air Force, Verne Orr, has asserted that the Stealth plane, which Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger is seriously considering as the nation's next long-range bomber, is ''a paper airplane'' that is far from development.

title: THE FURNITURE OF MARCEL BREUER: CLASSICS, AND SOME SURPRISES
description: MARCEL BREUER'S chairs are not only modern classics, they have become a symbol of 20th-century design. They also have held their own for more than 50 years - a rare if not unique achievement in the history of furniture design. ''Breuer simply changed the course of 20th-century furniture,'' said J. Stewart Johnson, curator of design of the department of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art. ''He is seminal. He started it all and made everything happen.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WHAT'S COOKING

title: LTV TO INSTALL 2-STRAND CASTER
description: The LTV Corporation said that it would install a $165 million continuous caster at its Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation Indiana Harbor Works in East Chicago, Ind. The company said the two-strand caster would be the first of its type in the Western Hemisphere.

title: ST. REGIS PAPER
description: The St. Regis Paper Company announced plans to invest about $116 million in two projects. They include a $98 million conversion of its Bucksport, Me., paper mill to utilize coal and wood waste instead of fuel oil and expenditure of $18 million to rebuild a kraft paper machine as part of major expansion at the company's Pensacola, Fla., plant. The Bucksport project is expected to be completed in mid-1984 and the Pensacola project in 1983.

title: JANE BLALOCK RELISHES THE TOUR
description: Jane Blalock says she wants to play about five more years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour and then might go to law school.

title: A DISTORTED VIEW OF MORMONISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Markets; TREASURY NOTES SET A RECORD
description: Confusion remained the dominant theme in the credit markets yesterday, with investors once again ignoring bullish news and selling on whatever negative developments cropped up. As a result, movements in the markets were narrow, with prices showing a slightly downward bias at the close.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Kevlon Oil Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 600,000 common shares, to be sold through a Boettcher & Company group.

title: CHINA IN WATCH ACCORD
description: The Daini Seikosha Company, which makes Seiko watches, has signed an agreement with China's Hangzhou Municipal Wristwatch Manufacturing Factory to assemble parts for automatic wristwatches, the Japanese company said today. Under the agreement, Daini Seikosha will supply the Chinese factory with automatic winding parts for 180,000 watch bodies during the first six months of production, scheduled to begin about mid-August. Value of the accord was not disclosed.

title: Two Guards Flee Hungary
description: Two Hungarian border guards, in uniform but without weapons, fled to Austria today and asked for political asylum, the police reported. The men, both 23 years old, were taken to a refugee camp. Their identities were not disclosed.

title: UNIONS SEE BENEFITS IN STRIKE
description: The conversation between the lawyer and the general manager turned to the expiration of the National Football League collective bargaining agreement in 1982. ''Keep your powder dry,'' Prentiss Yancey told Eddie LeBaron of the Atlanta Falcons.

title: A Funeral-Home Rule Is Approved by Agency
description: The Federal Trade Commission today ended almost a decade of studies by approving a regulation designed to put persons making funeral arrangements on more nearly even terms with undertakers.

title: Doctor Reports Brady Is Doing 'Very Well'
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, attended a dinner at a downtown restaurant last night to celebrate his wedding anniversary and was ''in a super mood this morning,'' a hospital spokesman said.

title: CHICAGO OPENS C.D. TRADING
description: Trading opened today in domestic certificates of deposit on the Chicago Board of Trade, marking the start of an intense battle for dominance of the market.

title: REAGAN, REFLECTING ON OTTAWA PARLEY, PRAISES MITTERRAND
description: President Reagan, reflecting over his threeday economic summit meeting in Canada, acknowledged that in advance he had been a bit apprehensive about how it would work out but said that the smooth reception by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and a surprisingly vigorous anti-Soviet statement by President Francois Mitterrand of France had quickly broken the ice at the first session.

title: GIANT ROOKIE FACES AN UPHILL STRUGGLE
description: Mark Reed faces many obstacles. The Giants selected him on the eighth round of last April's National Football League draft, and most eighth-round choices do not make the team. He played at Moorhead (Minn.) State and his best game came against Bemidji State, and they are not exactly football powers.

title: THYSSEN, IRAQ IN DEAL
description: Thyssen Henschel, a subsidiary of Thyssen A.G., said today that it had received a 250 million mark contract, equal to about $102.5 million, from Iraq to build 82 locomotives. Delivery of the locomotives, which will be financed with Iraqi funds, will begin toward the end of 1982 and will continue in 1983, it said.

title: RODINO VOICES MERGER WORRY
description: The Reagan Administration should give specific guidelines on how it will enforce antitrust laws pertaining to mergers, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey and chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today.

title: Western Fires Burn Thousands of Acres
description: The largest range fire in Oregon this year burned at least 10,000 acres today near the Idaho border.

title: CAROL FOX, HEAD OF CHICAGO LYRIC OPERA, DIES
description: Carol Fox, a co-founder and former general manager of the Lyric Opera of Chicago, who helped build it into one of the country's major opera companies, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. She was 55 years old.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JULY 23,1981; The Economy
description: The gross national product declined at an annual rate of 1.9 percent in the second quarter, weakening quickly after showing strength in the first quarter. Inventory accumulations and weaknesses in every major economic sector were reported by the Commerce Department. (Page A1.)

title: 4 Hurt by a Bomb in Geneva; Link to Armenians Suspected
description: A bomb left in a coin-operated locker at the main railway station here exploded late this afternoon and injured four persons, one critically, the police announced. A second bomb exploded later in another locker.

title: Time and the Timeless
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: As a working mother who becomes frantic at the prospect of unscheduled time, I was delighted to read K.C. Cole's article (''In 'Wasted' Hours, Timeless Treasures,'' July 9) and discover that I'm not unique in my discomfort. She, in turn, may derive solace from an observation of Wolfgang Kohler, one of the founders of gestalt psychology. He wrote: ''I entirely agree with the observation of the great chemist and great physiologist (Prof. Otto Loewi, the Nobel Prize winner) that the solution of problems is often suddenly presented to us when we are not actively concerned with them.

title: KUWAIT OIL SALE DIP CITED
description: Kuwait's crude oil exports have dropped to their lowest level in a decade, the daily Al Watan reported today. Quoting ''reliable'' sources, the newspaper said the country's oil exports fell over the past three months to an average of 900,000 barrels daily.

title: PENN CENTRAL SET TO ACQUIRE COLT
description: The Penn Central Corporation, a conglomerate with interests in real estate, oil and amusement parks, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Colt Industries Inc. for $100 a share, or a total of $1.4 billion in cash and stock.

title: HOME BEAT
description: THE goal was ''to broaden the approach of the ways women use the built environment,'' according to the group of feminists who put together the recently published ''Making Room: Women and Architecture.'' The thick, magazine-like publication is the 11th in a series of monographs on feminist subjects.

title: ISRAELI AND P.L.O. RAIDS DISTRESS MANY U.S. JEWS
description: Widespread distress among American Jews over the increased fighting in the Middle East, including the Israeli bombing of Beirut, was indicated by an informal survey yesterday, with a number of spokesmen urging a cease-fire and negotiations.

title: G.E. PLANS TO SHUT FLAT IRON PLANT
description: The General Electric Company said it plans to close its 77-year-old flat iron plant here, putting about 1,000 employees out of work, because it is phasing out its metal irons in favor of plastic bodied irons.

title: 2 TOP U.S. OFFICIALS CRITICAL OF BEGIN FOR MILITARY ACTS
description: Two high Reagan Administration officials today criticized Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, suggesting that Israel's recent military actions had set back American diplomatic initiatives in the Middle East and had made it difficult for Washington to resume deliveries of F-16 fighter-bombers to the Israelis.

title: China Bids Japan Halt Surveys Near Islands
description: China demanded today that Japan stop conducting maritime surveys around a disputed group of islands northeast of Taiwan and said it deeply regretted recent Japanese activities in the area.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Associated Press article in some editions yesterday incorrectly reported the 1979 revenue for the Oakland Raiders football team. The Raiders had a gross revenue of $12 million.

title: AUSTRALIA OIL OUTPUT
description: Australian oil exploration should continue to find new reserves at an average of 200 million barrels a year until the year 2000, Kenneth Richards, managing director of Esso Australia Ltd., predicted today. New finds could balance reservoir depletion at current output rates, provided they are in timely sequence and producers have incentives to make the necessary huge investments, Mr. Richards told a mining conference. Australian reserves are currently around 1.87 billion barrels, with 92 percent in the Bass Strait.

title: RECORDINGS TO MARK STRAVINSKY'S 100TH
description: MURMURS of the coming Stravinsky centenary are already audible, even though the full roar of the 1981-82 season is still several months away. In late fall, CBS Masterworks will issue a 31-record extravaganza documenting its long relationship with the composer. This release might be subtitled ''Stravinsky on Stravinsky,'' since the composer either directly participated in or supervised all of these performances.

title: The Region; New York City Yields on Water
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - The City of New York, at a meeting here yesterday of the Delaware River Basin Commission, bowed to pressure from New York State and agreed to resume releasing water from two reservoirs into the Delaware and Neversink Rivers.

title: Advertising; AD BUREAU ANNOUNCES A NEWSPAPER CO-OP
description: At the meeting of the International Advertising and Marketing Executives in Toronto yesterday, the Newspaper Advertising Bureau announced the formation of the Newspaper Co-op Network, an innovation that will allow manufacturers to fulfill the ultimate desire of the national newspaper advertiser - one order, one bill.

title: Paul Smith, Energy Counsel
description: For Mobil Oil, Is Dead at 58

title: PROTESTERS BATTLE POLICE
description: The New Zealand police said they would call in reinforcements for future rugby matches involving a South African team after a violent demonstration today and nationwide protests that resulted in the arrests of more than 70 persons.

title: ABC Newscast Tops Rivals for First Time
description: TV's ''World News Tonight'' led the evening-news audience-popularity ratings last week for the first time in its history, excluding the atypical week of the Republican National Convention last summer. The newscast edged out ''The CBS Evening News,'' which has long dominated the ratings.

title: Advertising; REPUBLICANS TO START STRONG RADIO CAMPAIGN
description: The National Republican Congressional Committee, which has discovered how well it can get its point across, and help candidates for elective office with good old advertising, is now prepared to use it to push the President's economic package.

title: Blue Skies Expected For Day of Wedding
description: The London meteorological office, offering some news that everyone here badly wants to hear, said today that it expected warm, dry weather for next Wednesday, the day of the royal wedding.

title: Music and Words and Talk About the Weather
description: When a noted conductor gets together with a legendary lyricist, what do they talk about? The weather, of course. That, at least, is the report from Michael Tilson Thomas on a chat he had in Los Angeles the other day with Ira Gershwin.

title: WESTWAY FACES HURDLES BEYOND CAREY AND KOCH
description: Should Governor Carey and Mayor Koch formally come to terms on the future of the Westway project, several legislative and court challenges could still block its construction. To date, however, such actions have not succeeded in delaying the project.

title: REPUBLICANS DIVIDING AND CONQUERING IN REDISTRICTING OF TEXAS
description: Conservative Texas Democrats in the Legislature here, like conservative Texas Democrats in Congress, are getting into the habit of voting with Republicans. Consequently, Congressional redistricting seems likely to retire one moderate Democratic member of Congress, give another a tougher district and preserve conservatives of both parties.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paula Deitz, co-editor of The Hudson Review, is a guest columnist.

title: Briefs
description: * Anixter Brothers Inc. agreed to buy Automatic Equipment Development Corp. of West Haven, Conn., for about $10 million in common stock.

title: CONCERT: TILSON THOMAS CONDUCTS SALIERI SYMPHONY
description: AT its best moments, the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall can remind us of an aspect of classical style stressed by Charles Rosen in his critical writings. Musical details and dramatic structures can be intimately related. The shape of a two-note phrase or the relationship between a rest and an accent can reveal largescale gestures of an entire work.

title: Advertising; E.T. HOWARD LANDS UNITED MUTUAL SAVINGS
description: The E.T. Howard Company has landed the 133-year-old United Mutual Savings Bank, which has 13 offices in this market. It was previously a client of Muir & Company.

title: PROFITS FALL AT LUMBER CONCERN
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company and the St. Regis Paper Company, two leaders in the forest products field, reported diverse earnings results for the second quarter yesterday.

title: JOHN C. HADGES
description: John C. Hadges, president of Winco Tankers, which operates American and foreign-flag tankers and dry-cargo vessels, died Monday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: LOCKHEED HAS GAIN IN QUARTER
description: The Lockheed Corporation today reported second-quarter earnings of $14.8 million, or 83 cents a share, a sharp reversal from a year ago when the aerospace company took a $70 million write-off on its Tristar program and reported a loss of $26.6 million.

title: U.S. Denies Disaster Aid On Mediterranean Fly
description: The Reagan Administration today rejected Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s request to declare three California counties a Federal disaster area because of infestation by the Mediterranean fruit fly.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times July 15 on preparations for the wedding of Prince Charles incorrectly identified the English queen in whose memory Charing Cross was erected. The queen was Eleanor of Castile, the wife of Edward I.

title: SPENDING LIMITS
description: President Reagan understands that economic recovery requires the Government to provide an anchor of certainty in a world buffeted by surprise. Thus, he has proposed a multi-year tax cut. But multi-year certainty about the level of Federal expenditures is also essential.

title: Rita Jenrette Granted Divorce
description: Rita Jenrette, whose marriage broke up after her husband, John W. Jenrette Jr., was convicted as a result of the Abscam bribery investigation, has been granted a divorce in Washington.

title: BORG-WARNER PROFIT UP 33%
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation, a diversified transportation and industrial concern, said today that its secondquarter profit rose 33 percent from the similar period last year.

title: POLISH DEBT EXTENSION
description: Western banks and Poland reached initial agreement today on extending the deadline on more than $5 billion in Polish debts due for repayment by the end of this year.

title: A RISKY INDEX OF CRIME
description: ON-HUDSON, N.Y. - The Attorney General's Task Force on Violent Crime recently approved the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10-year-old proposal to create a national computerized criminalhistory system - a system that President Reagan should reject.

title: Broadway; FEIFFER CHOOSES PRODUCERS TO DO IS PLAY IN NEW YORK
description: JULES FEIFFER, who has had his pick of Broadway producers after his play ''Grownups'' opened recently to mostly glowing reviews at Harvard, has decided to go with Emanuel Azenberg and Mike Nichols. ''Grownups'' will open Dec. 7 at the Lyceum Theater. The Lyceum's current attraction, Paul Osborne's ''Morning's at Seven,'' will close by Labor Day and go on tour.

title: WOMEN, WAR AND EQUAL RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: MICHELE BOGART MARRIED TO PHILIP PAULY
description: Michele Helene Bogart and Philip Joseph Pauly, teachers at the University of Georgia in Athens, were married yesterday in New York. Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz performed the ceremony in her chambers.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO MUTE CRITICISM OF BEGIN OVER AIR ATTACKS
description: The White House sought today to dampen public statements about Israel, backing away from personal criticism of Prime Minister Menachem Begin and focusing attention on the diplomatic drive for a cease-fire in southern Lebanon.

title: BASEBALL TALKS BREAK OFF, WILL RESUME NEXT WEEK
description: After four days covering 24 hours of talks with Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan in attendance, negotiators for baseball's club owners and players broke off their efforts tonight to end the strike that has lasted for six weeks and canceled 500 games. The talks will not resume until at least the middle of next week.

title: At the Movies; A BLOWING OF HORNS FOR 'BLOW OUT'
description: A WEEK or so ago, Filmways Pictures threw a blowout for ''Blow Out,'' which opens in four New York theaters today (for a review, see page C5). Reporters from exotic places like Paris and Hamburg and Philadelphia and Boston were welcomed to the Hotel Plaza, where they were plied with strong drink and beef and asparagus and big strawberries smothered in whipped cream. Then they were introduced to five big shots.

title: CHRYSLER, UNION SET PROFIT SHARING
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers have agreed on an innovative profit-sharing plan that includes cash payments, shares of stock, discounts on cars and a lottery that will give some lucky employees company products free.

title: AUTO OUTPUT AHEAD OF 1980
description: United States auto production was expected to exceed 4 million vehicles this week, achieving that mark a month earlier than in 1980, an industry publication reported today.

title: Foreign Affairs; 2-HANDED DIPLOMACY
description: The prime value of a meeting like the seven-nation Ottawa summit conference comes from the need all participants feel to make it look successful, both to their very different home audiences and to the world at large.

title: Around the Nation; CALIFORNIA WINS ROUNDS AGAINST QUARANTINES
