description: California won major battles today in its fight to halt quarantines against its crops, as a Federal judge ordered Florida to lift its quarantine and four other Southern states said they would not enforce theirs.

title: JUVENILE OFFENDERS IN COURT: THE DEBATE OVER TREATMENT
description: In recent years, the manner in which American society deals with its youngest criminals has changed in dramatic ways. After eight decades of attempting to put the interests of juvenile offenders first, a number of legislatures and courts have begun to place greater emphasis on protecting the public from violent young offenders and on imposing ''adult'' punishment on those guilty of serious crimes. In the process, children's rights to special treatment in the courts are being severely restricted. In most states and in the Federal courts the judicial system treats as juveniles children under age 18, but in New York, Connecticut, North Carolina and Vermont only those under 16 are so treated. How the New York City courts handled two recent cases, involving somewhat similar homicides by juvenile assailants, illustrates some of the recent changes and the attendant problems.

title: MOSCOW BARS KEY AREA FROM ATOM-FREE ZONE
description: The Soviet Union is not prepared to remove nuclear weapons to have the Kola Peninsula included in a proposed nuclear-free zone for Northern Europe, Novosti, the Soviet press service, said here today.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Long Island Lighting to Greenstone & Rabasca, Melville, L.I.

title: NEON, HOTELS AND DINERS
description: MARCEL BREUER'S death three weeks ago at the age of 79 was not merely the end of the career of a true master of 20th-century design - it was, in a sense, also the severing of a crucial link between our time and the golden years of modern design's infancy. Mr. Breuer was the last of the great masters of the Bauhaus, that extraordinary German school of design. His work at the Bauhaus, and during the post-Bauhaus decades of the 1930's and 40's, had a freshness and excitement to it that seemed, in and of itself, to encapsulate all the promise of the modern movement.

title: FROM BIRDS TO CREEPY CRAWLERS AT SHARON'S NATURE FESTIVAL
description: A two-day nature festival starts tomorrow in Sharon, Conn., at which answers will be given to almost everything you ever wanted to know about birds, bees, snakes, ferns, mushrooms, wildflowers, wild edibles, creepy crawlers, wolves, turtles and even whales and dolphins.

title: COONEY-HOLMES LACKS A DATE
description: Time was the essence as both sides met last night to reach the final agreement that would enable Gerry Cooney, the undefeated No.1 contender, to meet Larry Holmes, the undefeated champion, for the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship.

title: Pop Jazz; A REUNION OF SOUL CLAN AT THE SAVOY TONIGHT
description: THE SOUL CLAN made only one record, and that was in the mid-1960's, but the group has not been forgotten. Like the Million Dollar Quartet, a one-time-only 1950's collaboration of Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis, Johnny Cash and Carl Perkins, the Soul Clan was a gathering of a musical aristocracy.

title: HIT BIT OF SHAVIAN WIT
description: FROM the moment a wild-eyed Anthony Heald springs onto the stage, jut-jawed and swinging a very large gun at stiff arm's length - a clerk bent on swift murder and suicide on his afternoon off - he has the audience bursting into loud and prolonged laughter. In George Bernard Shaw's ''Misalliance,'' directed by Stephen Porter and presented by the Roundabout Theater Company, the young actor has succeeded in turning the relatively small part of Gunner into a comic tour de force.

title: Notes on People; MEMENTO FOR SCHMIDT
description: West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, failed to win President Reagan's support for his drive against high interest rates at the economic summit conference in Ottawa this week. But it seems Mr. Schmidt did get a little something from the American President - a saccharin dispenser shaped like a fountain pen.

title: THE CENTER STIRS IN BRITAIN
description: Roy Jenkins, running under the new colors of Britain's Social Democratic Party, won a stunning 42 percent of the vote in a threeway by-election last week. Mr. Jenkins is a special person and industrial Warrington, the scene of his triumph, is a special place. And he did not win the seat he sought. But after all the necessary discounting is done, the new party's achievement remains momentous.

title: 'ROCK CITY,' A SCRAPBOOK OF LONDON POP
description: ''ROCK CITY'' is a wild and woolly scrapbook of London's pop scene in its heyday, which the movie defines as the era between 1964 and 1973. It's a collection of clips, randomly assembled, featuring just about everybody who was anybody in those days. Bopping down memory lane, the viewer encounters Rod Stewart, Pete Townshend, Cream, the Rolling Stones in loud outfits and war paint, and Otis Redding, who offers a version of ''Satisfaction'' that puts even the Stones to shame.

title: MITSUI TO END IRAN FUNDS
description: Japanese investors in a $3.2 billion petrochemical complex in Iran will send a delegation to Teheran next week to inform oil officials there that Japan will put no more money into the nearly completed project, a Japanese official said today.

title: HELMUT DE TERRA, 81, SPECIALIST IN GEOLOGY OF PLEISTOCENE EPOCH
description: Helmut de Terra, a specialist in Pleistocene and Cenozoic geology who taught at at Yale, Ohio State, Columbia and the New School, died Wednesday in Bern. He was 81 years old.

title: GOLDWATER HINTS CASEY SHOULD QUIT
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, chairman of the Intelligence Committee, said tonight that he believed that William J. Casey should consider resigning as Director of Central Intelligence - or the President should consider asking him to -because he appointed an unqualified person as a top deputy.

title: PROPOSAL FOR A PRELUDE TO 'NO TRAINS AT ALL'
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTORATION SCANDAL: ANNE HYDE AND JAMES
description: Not for 321 years has an heir to the British throne married an Englishwoman. The last time it happened, there was little talk about the bride's youthful innocence.

title: FOR AN ENGLISH TOWN, WEDDING MADNESS AND HISTORY
description: B.J. Broad, watch and clockmaker, has added commemorative teaspoons to his shop window. Across from it, on Hyde Lane, P.& J. Berry, clothiers, displays only red, white and blue garments, interspersed with wedding items. But neither can match B.V. & R.C. Hicks, who have turned their general store into an orgy of celebratory trinkets - mugs, plates, candies, booklets, pens, posters, cookie tins and even balloons.

title: KATHY WHITWORTH SHARES GOLF LEAD AT 69
description: Kathy Whitworth is 42 years old, has 81 victories on the professional tour and needs only $1,031 to become the first woman golfer to earn $1 million. Yet she has never won a United States Women's Open championship. She had not even started well in an Open during her 23-year career - until today.

title: CONFEREES SET TO END SOCIAL SECURITY FLOOR OF $122 IN FEBRUARY
description: House and Senate conferees agreed today to retain the Social Security minimum benefit until February. The decision provides six months for Democrats to find a way to stave off the elimination of the provision.

title: Business People; HIRSCHFILED NAMED CHAIRMAN OF FOX
description: Following a nearly two-year power struggle at the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, Alan J. Hirschfield, 45 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer by Marvin Davis, the Denver oil man who purchased the company last spring and took it private.

title: CARTER PICKS LIBRARY SITE
description: Former President Jimmy Carter wants his Presidential library to be built on land near downtown Atlanta that he saved from highway development while he was Georgia's Governor. Gov. George Busbee said today that he had been advised of Mr. Carter's wishes by Charles H. Kirbo.

title: ELIZABETH LOWENSTEIN
description: Elizabeth Corn Lowenstein, former executive secretary of the New York section of the American Camping Association, died Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JULY 24, 1981 International A muting of U.S.-Israeli discord and a halt in public criticism of the policies of Prime Minister Menachem Begin was sought by the White House. Publicly, officials stressed an even-handed appeal for military restraint by both Israeli and Palestinian forces, but privately they acknowledged they had been dismayed by the heavy Israeli air attack in Beirut last Friday and upset at the setback they felt it dealt to peace efforts. (Page A1, Column 1.) New shipments of F-16 jets to Israel were urged by the leaders of 34 American Jewish organizations. They said that President Reagan's suspenion of the deliveries would appear to be ''one-sided punishment of Israel'' that encouraged ''those committed to Israel's destruction.'' (A3:1-2.)

title: BONN IS REASSURED ON U.S. ARMS VIEW
description: President Reagan sent Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany a letter on the eve of the Ottawa meeting, forcefully confirming the United States commitment to begin arms control talks this autumn, a Government spokesman said today.

title: The Region; JURY VOTES NO BILL IN FATAL SHOOTING
description: A Suffolk County grand jury has returned no bill against a New York City police sergeant in the fatal shooting of a 21-year-old Amityville man who attacked a conductor on a Long Island Rail Road platform.

title: TV Weekend; 'AUSCHWITZ,' TV NEWS, 'SUPER RICH' AND ROCK
description: TV's ''News Closeup'' goes outside its own precincts tonight at 9 o'clock to present ''Return to Auschwitz,'' a documentary about Kitty Hart, who returns to the World War II death camp with her son David. The program, originally 90 minutes long, was produced by Peter Morley and Kevin Sim for Britain's Yorkshire Television. It has already been shown on PBS.

title: ENDING DASHES A VISION FOR TIME INC.
description: Henry R. Luce, when he was running his Time Inc. magazine empire, was interested in eventually expanding it to include a newspaper, a longtime Time Inc. editor recalled yesterday, and he used to ponder a minor but perplexing problem.

title: BOSTON BANK MIX: RISK, CONTROVERSY
description: Over the last few decades, the First National Bank of Boston, a proper and prosperous institution, has developed an unorthodox style of specialized commercial lending centered in a ''special industries'' division and catering to more risky or troubled borrowers.

title: Sports of the Times; TO THOSE IN THE LIVERY SET, IT'S ONLY MONEY
description: DURING the 1980 summer yearling auction at Keeneland, Mrs. C.V. Whitney telephoned the sales company to ask how much had been bid for a pair of horses consigned by the Whitney Farm.

title: HOUSE REBUFFS REAGAN ON CUTS IN ARTS FUNDS
description: The House has rebuffed President Reagan's bid to halve Federal support for the arts, approving a $157.5 million budget next year for the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: CITY AND ALBANY RENEWING TALKS ABOUT WESTWAY
description: City and state officials scheduled new discussions in City Hall today in an effort to reach an agreement that both sides say will clear the way for work to begin on the Westway highway project.

title: E.E.C. PRICE INDEX UP
description: The consumer price index in the 10-member European Economic Community rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in June for the second consecutive month, representing an annual inflation rate of 12.5 percent, according to figures released today. At 12.5 percent, inflation in the E.E.C. has varied less than two-tenths of 1 percent since the beginning of the year. The rate for the year ending June 30 was highest in Greece at 25.2 percent, followed by Italy at 20.9 percent, France 13.2 percent, Denmark 12.9 percent, Britain 11.3 percent, Luxembourg 8.4 percent, Belgium 7.4 percent, the Netherlands 6.7 percent and West Germany 5.6 percent.

title: Advertising; 3 NEW PUBLICATIONS ON MAGAZINE FRONT
description: In other areas of magazine land, the Goldhirsh Group, Boston publishers of the highly successful Inc. magazine, reports that its new entry, High Technology, due out in September, 300,000 copies strong, will carry 53.5 pages of advertising. Not bad for a beginner.

title: YONKERS SETTLES FIRE DEPT. BIAS SUITS
description: A settlement was reached yesterday in two civil-rights suits that accused Yonkers of discriminating against black, Hispanic and female applicants for the Fire Department.

title: Notes on People; PRECIOUS EYESIGHT
description: A 100-year-old man, believed to the oldest person ever to have undergone cataract operations and plastic lens implants in both eyes, left Deepdale General Hospital in Queens yesterday and returned to his home in South Ozone Park.

title: Business Digest
description: Friday, July 24, 1981 Companies

title: 2 IN AUXILIARY TO POLICE CITED IN GUNFIRE HOAX
description: Two New York City auxiliary police officers were arrested yesterday after one was accused of shooting the other in a hoax intended to dramatize the need for equipping the unarmed volunteer force with bulletproof vests.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; EGLEVSKY IN WESTBURY
description: Romantic Old Westbury Gardens on Long Island will be the setting tonight for the Eglevsky Ballet. The company will perform two works choreographed by George Balanchine, two by Edward Villella and a pas de deux by Michael Vernon. Gates open at 6 P.M., so there will be time to stroll through the gardens and enjoy a picnic supper from home before the ballet starts at 7 o'clock. Admission is $3 for nonmembers, $2 for the elderly and $1 for members and those 6 to 12 years old. From New York City take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 39 south. Old Westbury Gardens is on Old Westbury Road between Jericho Turnpike and the expressway. Information: (516) 333-0048.

title: Advertising; BUNCHING CONCEPT AIMS ADS AT ONE GROUP
description: John W. Hawks, when he was a manager of WAYE Radio, Baltimore, was musing about reaching rich consumers via his medium and was troubled because there is always waste circulation since the democratic nature of airwaves make them available not only to the rich and poor, but also to the middle class.

title: JERSEY APPROVES UTILITY INCREASE OF $50 MILLION
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company was granted a $50.7 million rate increase today by the State Board of Public Utilities.

title: G-MEN DON'T MIX WITH NARCS
description: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, with 2,000 agents spread thinly along international drug pipelines, has not been much of a match for shrewd, well-heeled dealers. Its prey commands fleets of ships and planes, records deals by computer and hides its bounty in foreign banks. And the agency's low morale and weak management don't help.

title: Topics; WITHDRAWAL SYMPTOMS; MINOR MEDICAL; Minor Medical
description: An acquaintance of ours, a man of moderate means, sought medical security through individual membership in Blue Cross/Blue Shield. During 1980 his premiums amounted to $596, and 1981 increases raised the quarterly payments $34, a 23 percent jump.

title: READING REACHES RAIL LAND ACCORD
description: The Reading Company, which once operated the Reading Railway but now is a real estate holding company with anthracite coal interests, said that it had reached an agreement in principle with the Federal Government for payment for its rail properties that were assimilated into the Consolidated Rail Corporation in 1976.

title: Business People; NEW HEAD APPOINTED AT ARCO OIL AND GAS
description: O. Glenn Simpson, 58, senior vice president for Arco Oil and Gas Company, a division of the Atlantic Richfield Company, has been named president. He replaces William A. Keeler, who, with his wife, died from gunshot wounds on July 12.

title: L.I. RECITAL SERIES
description: A performing-arts festival at Southampton College of Long Island University will open Sunday at 5:30 P.M. with a free recital by Walid Howrani, a pianist.

title: Corrections
description: In an article in Business Day about the shoe industry (June 27, 1981), the trademark ''Candie's'' was used incorrectly to refer to a type of shoe. The mark ''Candie's'' is the registered trademark for shoes, clothing and accessories of El Greco Leather Products, Inc. The company said sales of shoes bearing the ''Candie's'' trademark had doubled in the last year.

title: 5 OIL COMPANIES SLIDE, BUT TEXACO GAINS
description: Five of the nation's largest oil companies yesterday reported significant declines in second-quarter earnings and said that their operating results had been impaired by reduced demand for petroleum products and continuing pressure on profit margins in their refining operations.

title: JETS' BLINKA SEEKING A REVISED CONTRACT
description: Two years ago, when he was - in his words - ''a dumb ole country boy,'' Stan Blinka signed a four-year contract to play for the Jets.

title: UP 0.7% IN JUNE
description: Despite sharply higher housing costs, consumer prices rose only seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Government reported today.

title: Business People; PROMOTION AT AMERICAN PHILIPS
description: Cees Bruynes, 48, president and chief operating officer of the North American Philips Corporation, a leading manufacturer of consumer electronics, has been named to the additional position of chief executive officer of the company, effective Jan. 1.

title: Article 206303 -- No Title
description: The Canada Development Corporation said yesterday that it had arranged $2.1 billion in loans with a consortium of 28 banks to pay for its recent acquisition of the Aquitaine Company and the future purchase of Texasgulf's Canadian holdings.

title: Topics; WITHDRAWAL SYMPTOMS; GUN CONTROL
description: Ever since John Lennon died nearby from a gunshot wound, the New York Road Runners Club has used the blast of an air horn instead of a blank pistol to start its races in Central Park. But the horn is not a wholly satisfactory solution.

title: BRITISH SHIP CONTRACT
description: Austin & Pickersgill, a shipbuilder based in northern England, said today that it had received an order worth about $85 million to build four 30,000-deadweight-ton bulk carriers for companies owned by Thomas Demseris, a Greek shipowner.The new vessels can carry 636 containers as an alternative to bulk cargoes. The vessels are to be completed by the end of 1983.

title: The Evening Hours
description: T HEORETICALLY, none of the people who make parties buzz and glow are in New York in the summer. Theoretically, anyone who plans a glamorous event in July or August should be demoted to the ranks in Kalamazoo. Theoretically, it's all true, but it doesn't mean a thing. Everyone is around if there is something to be around for.

title: TIMES CO. NET UP 28.2%
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its profits in the second quarter were 28.2 percent higher than in the same period a year ago, while revenues rose 12 percent.

title: G.O.P.'S TAX STRATEGY IN HOUSE: ALL OR NOTHING
description: President Reagan and Republican leaders in the House of Representatives decided today on a one-vote, all-ornothing strategy in which the House will choose between the Democratic tax bill drafted in the Ways and Means Committee and an Administration bill being sweetened to appeal to as many members as possible.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART IS IMPLANTED IN MAN AT HOUSTON HOSPITAL
description: A team of surgeons implanted an artificial heart in a 36-year-old man today, the second such operation performed in the United States, officials at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital said.

title: Market Place; THE OUTLOOK IN TECHNOLOGY
description: THERE are two ways of looking at the recent slide in shares of technology companies. One is to cry about the losses. The other is to be of good cheer and buy the shares at depressed prices.

title: Topics; WITHDRAWAL SYMPTOMS; SURRENDER LOGIC
description: The surrender rule allows blackjack players to drop out for half their bet if the first two cards betoken defeat. It's part of the game around the world and it takes a little of the advantage away from the house.

title: ARMY SAYS JUST ONE OF ITS U.S. DIVISIONS ISN'T COMBAT-READY
description: Less than a year after conceding that six of its 10 divisions based in this country were unfit for combat, the Army said today that all but one had shaped up.

title: LUNCH IN WASHINGTON: A TIME FOR POWER
description: It is 1:15 P.M. at the Maison Blanche restaurant, one block from the White House. The cold watercress soup is tangy, the fillet of striped bass sublime and the pastry cart a colorful array of tastes and textures.

title: Around the Nation; PUERTO RICO THANKED BY REAGAN ON HAITIANS
description: President Reagan telephoned Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo today to thank him ''for making the politically difficult decision'' of accepting 800 Haitian refugees at Fort Allen, the Governor's press office said.

title: CITY TO SELL HARLEM BROWNSTONES BY LOTTERY
description: The sale of 13 abandoned city-owned brownstones in Harlem through a lottery that would favor Harlem residents was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: DENNIS BLAIR GETTING RESPECT AT DANGERFIELD'S
description: A rising young comic, Dennis Blair is the headliner at Dangerfield's, the club at First Avenue and 61st Street where Rodney Dangerfield gets no respect. If Mr. Blair's name is not yet a household word, the odds are that it will be; he's a very funny man.

title: ART: MAURICE GOLUBOV
description: THE art world, like most organisms, has a biological clock, and it tends to run down as the temperature rises. Summer, therefore, is not the best time for a blockbuster show or even an artist's maiden voyage. But that alone may make the season ideal for a major performance by Maurice Golubov, a Russian-born painter who appears to have spent his life evading or flouting rules. Also, it seems very much in character that Mr. Golubov should have his first retrospective at the age of 76 - a traveling show that is making its last stop at the Jewish Museum (1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street).

title: U.S., CHINA, TAIWAN
description: The Administration will soon be making decisions on the sale of arms to China and an advanced jet fighter known as the FX to Taiwan. Both decisions will have profound consequences for our long-term interests in Asia and the world.

title: ARKANSAS SEEKS TO EASE CROWDING IN ITS PRISONS
description: When Sheriff Tom Robinson rid his overcrowded jail of 19 state prisoners by chaining them to state prison fences and posts last week, it was widely viewed here as a bizarre and minor unpleasantness in a prison system that was the first in the nation to be forced to operate under Federal court guidelines.

title: G.O.P. RADIO TAX-CUT ADS SET
description: After intraparty disputes over how hard to hit the Democrats, Republicans today announced a nationwide radio advertising campaign intended to win votes for President Reagan's tax-reduction bill next week.

title: ZENITH NET PLUNGES
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation said today that earnings plunged 48.8 percent, to $2.1 million, or 11 cents a share, in the second quarter ended July 4, from $4.1 million, or 22 cents a share, in the 1980 period because of price cutting.

title: CONOCO BID RAISED BY SEAGRAM
description: In a dramatic move that could bring the multibillion-dollar bidding contest for Conoco to a close before long, Joseph E. Seagram & Sons yesterday increased its bid for the nation's ninth-largest oil company by $7 a share, to $92, or a total of $4.1 billion for a 51 percent interest.

title: DON'T DISCOUNT A RETURN TO THE GOLD STANDARD
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Few countries at war debate their own righteousness. And so Israel, which is in a quasi war with the Palestine Liberation Organization along the border with Lebanon, is engaged only in a quasi debate, wondering quietly whether it has done right. Since the air raid last Friday against a heavily populated neighborhood in Beirut, and Prime Minister Menachem Begin's announcement that the proximity of civilians would no longer deter Israeli strikes at Palestinian guerrilla sites, Israelis have conducted nothing more than a genteel discussion.

title: ARREST RELAXES PEOPLE IN ATLANTA, BUT THEIR VIGILANCE PERSISTS
description: At City Hall, Mayor Maynard Jackson's weekly new conferences, once dominated by questions about the ''missing and murdered children'' investigation, now turn as much attention to the need for more policemen to fight crime in general, to finding new sources of tax revenue and to rumors of possible irregularities in the water department.

title: Credit Markets; PRICES RISE FOR 2-YEAR ISSUES
description: Prices rose slightly yesterday for corporate and Treasury issues due in two years and more. Dealers said a significant number of investors were attracted by prices that were almost at record lows.

title: WILLIAM K. CLARKE
description: William Kendall Clarke, novelist and playwright, died June 26 in Marlborough, Conn.

title: TRADING CONOCO AT POST 14
description: Brokers huddled six-deep around post No.14 on the floor of The New York Stock Exchange yesterday as the multibillion-dollar takeover battle for Conoco Inc. intensified with Joseph E. Seagram & Son's sweetened offer for the nation's ninth-largest oil company.

title: MAX LIEBMAN, TV PRODUCER, IS DEAD
description: Max Liebman, who transferred the show-business savvy of the Broadway musical theater to the television screen with the popular ''Your Show of Shows,'' the most famous of the variety programs in the 50's, died Tuesday in New York. He was 78 years old.

title: Around the World; RED CROSS DROPS EFFORT TO END IRISH FASTING
description: Three Red Cross officials admitted failure today in their weeklong attempt to mediate an end to the hunger strikes by Irish nationalist prisoners in the Maze Prison and flew back to Switzerland.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Joan O. Rothberg elected executive vice president of Ted Bates Advertising/New York.

title: The City; 4 KHOMEINI FOES HELD ON LIBERTY I.
description: Four Iranian students protesting the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and today's ''illegal'' Presidential election in Iran were arrested yesterday after chaining themselves to a balcony railing on the pedestal of the Statue of Liberty.

title: OWNER OF WILLIWAW BANNED FOR 2 YEARS
description: Harvey Ward, the professional captain of Williwaw, one of the country's foremost ocean-racing yachts, has admitted cheating, and the 48-foot sloop's owner, Seymore Sinett of Plainfield, N.J., has been suspended for two years, the sport's governing body disclosed yesterday.

title: Around the World; ITALIAN TERRORISTS FREE KIDNAPPED EXECUTIVE
description: The Red Brigades today freed a kidnapped auto company executive whom they had held for 50 days.

title: Economic Scene; HOLDING CARTER RESPONSIBLE
description: THE national economy stumbled during the second quarter into what may be the start of another recession, and the Reagan Administration promptly blamed the Carter Administration for the decline.

title: POTENTIAL TROUBLE SPOTS FOR SUMMER TRAFFIC
description: A. Palisades Interstate Parkway: Intermittent lane closings in a onemile section south of the New Jersey line. B.

title: YONKERS UPSET BY ALLOTMENT
description: Governor Carey and the legislative leaders reached agreement today on a $79.9 million aid package for the state's localities outside New York City. The program includes $6.4 million for the financially pressed city of Yonkers, substantially less than that city's officials had hoped to get.

title: AETNA VENTURE WITH FOX-FILM
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, a major insurance concern, said it had reached preliminary agreement with the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation to jointly develop some of the film company's properties.

title: U.S. TRACK GROUP BANS FOUR FOREIGN RUNNERS
description: Four foreign track and field athletes, including Allison Roe. the first female finisher in this year's Boston Marathon, have been banned from competing in the United States, The Associated Press reported today.

title: OFFER ANTICIPATED FOR WESTERN GEAR
description: The Western Gear Corporation of Lynwood, Calif., a machinery maker, said that a large industrial company was negotiating to acquire it, but did not identify the prospective buyer. Although an offer has not yet been made, Western Gear said that the expected price would be $178 million, or $28 a share.

title: CABINET IN ISRAEL HOLDS A MEETING TO DEAL WITH CRITICISM FROM U.S.
description: The Israeli Cabinet met yesterday to discuss relations with the United States in the light of criticism from Washington.

title: GENETIC DISEASE THAT ATTACKS JEWS CALLED POTENTIALLY CURABLE
description: Gaucher's disease, one of the most common genetic disorders among Ashkenazi Jews, is potentially curable in adults, according to leading researchers who attended a workshop on the disease at Mount Sinai School of Medicine yesterday.

title: IN LONDON, STAG PARTY FOR PRINCE
description: As London began dressing itself up in acres of red, white and blue bunting for the royal wedding next Wednesday, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and other political leaders paid a formal call on Buckingham Palace today to congratulate the bride and bridegroom.

title: THE BRAWL IN THE TAX TROUGH
description: Out of concern for the American economy, we did not applaud President Reagan's original plan for cutting back income taxes. An across-the-board reduction is more likely to stimulate consumption than investment and promises no relief from the greatest danger, inflation. But now that we see the irresponsible tax cuts that Congress intends to produce, we would happily settle for the President's first instinct.

title: HOSTAGES ASKING U.S. TO PAY $1000 FOR EVERY DAY IN CAPTIVITY
description: The Federal Government should pay the families of the Americans held hostage in Iran $1,000 for each day of their captivity, a lawyer told a Presidential compensation commission today.

title: No Headline
description: TITANIC ELUDES SEARCHERS: Jack Grimm, a Texas oil man who financed a nine-day search for the wreck of the Titanic, displaying at a news session yesterday in Boston a photo of the ocean floor taken during the North Atlantic expedition. The mission failed to find the vessel, which sank in 1912 on her maiden voyage, killing more than 1,500. ''I'll never rest till we've solved the secrets'' of the location, Mr. Grimm said.

title: U.S. JEWISH SPOKESMAN URGE DELIVERY OF F-16'S
description: Leaders of 34 American Jewish organizations urged President Reagan yesterday to resume delivery of F-16 fighter planes to Israel. They said suspension of shipments would appear to be ''one-sided punishment of Israel'' and ''encourage those committed to Israel's destruction to escalate their attacks against the Jewish state.''

title: No Headline
description: ANNOUNCES PLANS FOR HUNGER STRIKE: Lech Walesa, head of Poland's Solidarity union, addressing workers at locomotive plant yesterday in Poznan. Union leaders announced plans to stage hunger demon-strations in three cities to protest food shortages in the country, ending Saturday with a rally in Lodz, the country's second largest city. According to the union, people in some areas live on bread and seasonal vegetables.

title: ROSELAND AT 62 KEEPS IN STEP WITH THE 80'S
description: HABITUES of Studio 54 have moved on to other discotheques. Punk rockers rarely scuttle north of Houston Street. But just about everyone else nowadays seems to go to Roseland, the dance palace on West 52d Street that has been attracting New Yorkers of all ages for 62 years.

title: Briefs
description: * Agency Rent-A-Car Inc. said it had increased its stake in Spencer Companies Inc. to 436,755 shares, or 25.5 percent, through purchases in July of 85,755 shares at prices ranging from $10.75 to $11.25 a share.

title: Energy Watch
description: Supplies of crude oil declined sharply to 393.5 million barrels from 402.3 million in what experts termed an inventory adjustment.

title: THE CHIEF INFLATOR OF MEDICAL-CARE BILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMY PLANS TO MOVE NERVE GAS WEAPONS
description: The Army said today that it would move 888 Weteye nerve gas bombs and two tons of nerve gas from the Rocky Mountain Arsenal in Denver to a storage site in Utah before Oct. 10.

title: FLORIDA AWAITS RAIN AS LAKE SHRINKS
description: The level of Lake Okeechobee, the principal source of fresh water for 3.5 million residents of south Florida, dropped this morning to 9.77 feet, the lowest ever recorded. Gov. Bob Graham has already declared a drought emergency area in 16 counties served by the lake. Now the state is planning to start seeding clouds for rain.

title: A KING'S NEW FRIENDS
description: To the Editor:

title: PERFORMING TIBETANS
description: Sixteen Tibetan monks, members of the Tantric College of the Dalai Lama, will perform their ritual music and dance for the first time for a Western audience at 7:30 tonight in Altschul Auditorium at Columbia University's School of International Affairs, Amsterdam Avenue and 118th Street.

title: WESTERN BOOM TOWNS OBTAIN AID FROM MINING COMPANIES
description: The sign on Highway 93 reads, ''Entering Challis, Pop. 793,'' but it is clear for all to see that the figure is badly out of date. A subdivision of 109 houses has just gone up on the bluff south of town; they are adding 12 classrooms to the local elementary school, and even the Village Inn Motel has built a new two-story wing.

title: ART: POST-MINIMALISTS SHOW RECENT SCULPTURE
description: AFTER Minimalist sculpture, what? Well, why not Post-Minimalist sculpture? And what, pray, is Post-Minimalist sculpture? Well, it's Minimalist sculpture with certain differences. Minimalist sculpture, it will be recalled, was abstract. Post-Minimalist sculpture isn't. That's what they say about it, anyway. Post-Minimalist sculpture boasts of something called ''content'' and ''allusion.'' Which is to say, it often looks like something you've seen before - a chair, say, or a building or a parcel of birthday-party decorations. What it doesn't look like is an unadorned cube or a bald sphere or a naked tetrahedron. On the other hand, it might - just a little. But whereas Minimalist sculpture was neat, smooth and slick, with clean surfaces and well-made edges, Post-Minimalist sculpture is sometimes - well, a little tacky. Closer to life, you might say.

title: ILLNESSES AT PARK SPUR INQUIRY
description: The City Health Department began an inquiry yesterday into the circumstances that caused 10 people to become suddenly ill on Wednesday in a park in Queens.

title: GEORGE HAMILTON, COMIC ZORRO
description: GEORGE HAMILTON has always been too much, which may be why he never did make it as a film personality of the first rank earlier in his career. His very full head of hair is beyond blackness - it absorbs light in the manner of a collapsed star (no pun intended) - and it's so slick that grease would slide off it. When in delight or surprise he widens his eyes, they seem about to pop from their sockets. The smile is too broad, too ready, and the the teeth of a whiteness that suggests they were manufactured in Dresden.

title: GOODYEAR AND UNIROYAL GAIN
description: Two of the nation's major rubber companies yesterday reported substantial second-quarter profit gains, which they attributed in part to an improved tire market compared with last year.

title: 4 INDICTED ON CHARGES CONCERNING $850,000 HOSPITAL AGENCY THEFT
description: The president of a microfilm corporation and three employees of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation were indicted by a grand jury in Manhattan yesterday on charges involving the theft of $850,000 from the municipal hospital system.

title: THEATER: 'STEAL AWAY,' MOTHERLY BANK ROBBERS
description: ''STEAL AWAY,'' the new play by Ramona King at the New Federal Theater, is as warm and friendly as a church supper. In fact, it is about the kind of women who frequently run church suppers: respectable, cheerful and sturdy, and, when they have to be, tough as nails. In ''Steal Away,'' they are black women in Chicago in the 1930's, and what they do, all in a good cause, is to turn to crime. Needless to say, they do not lose a trace of their respectability or cheerfulness when they do.

title: TREMOR AT MOUNT ST. HELENS
description: A tremor rippled through Mount St. Helens today as the volcano unleashed a steam plume that rose almost half a mile above its shattered crater.

title: IRAQ EXPECTED TO ACCELERATE DRIVE TO MAKE NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Lewis A. Dunn of the Hudson Institute, a specialist on the spread of nuclear weapons, told Congress today that Iraq was likely to accelerate its drive to gain atomic weapons in the wake of last month's Israeli bombing raid against an Iraqi reactor.

title: In the Nation; THROWING MONEY AT PRISONS
description: Supreme Court Justice Powell yesterday temporarily stayed the early release of about 270 inmates from Alabama's prisons. They had been ordered freed to relieve overcrowding in what District Judge R.E. Varner called ''grossly inadequate facilities.'' Most of the inmates complete their terms within 90 days anyway, and the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals had refused an appeal from Judge Varner's order.

title: REAGAN'S PANEL TO URGE REVISIONS IN JUSTICE SYSTEM
description: An advisory panel appointed by the Reagan Administration has decided to recommend sweeping changes in the criminal justice system to increase the likelihood that violent offenders will be captured, convicted and imprisoned.

title: T-SHIRTS ON THE SIDEWALK
description: He wants to be everything in the world. That's what Nino Porco in the T-shirt said: ''I want to be a renaissance man of the 80's.'' In a way, he is. He's selling T-shirts on the streets. He can be found at the General Motors Plaza or on any shady sidewalk selling T-shirts. ''I started by making one for myself and my girlfriend said I should make more and sell them. So, I just find a spot on the sidewalk and do it. One of a kind, right there. It takes an hour.''

title: LATIN SALUTE AT BEACON
description: Ntozake Shange, author of ''For Colored Girls,'' will recite poetry and introduce Sara Gonzalez, Cuban vocalist, and other Latin American artists in a cultural salute to Cuba, the people of Central America and the Caribbean tomorrow, 8 P.M., at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street. Tickets are $5, $7 and $10. Information: 477-5891.

title: AT BROOKHAVEN LAB, A FREE TOUR INTO THE FUTURE
description: It is a place where people talk offhandedly about the big BLIP, quarks, an all-female species of fish and machines that pack the wallop of 33 billion electron volts. And they don't forget Isabelle. Isabelle is so strong that when someone zaps her with 400 billion electron volts, she doesn't even flinch.

title: GULF AND WESTERN CHARGES REJECTED
description: Two attacks by Gulf and Western Industries Inc. on a 1979 suit by the Securities and Exchange Commission accusing the conglomerate of a wide variety of securities law violations were dismissed by Judge Barrington Parker in Federal District Court in Washington, D.C.

title: AIDING ART VIA 1040
description: To the Editor:

title: The City; UNION COMMENTS ON SUBWAY CRASH
description: Union officials representing subway workers angrily disputed a report by the Transit Authority that laid blame for a subway accident July 3 on Jesse Cole, the motorman killed in the Brooklyn crash.

title: WALDHEIM SEES 'DE-ESCALATION'
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim told the Security Council today that hostilities in Lebanon had ''deescalated'' and he expressed hope ''that this trend'' would lead to a full cease-fire.

title: Around the World; UTAH SEEKS TO EXTRADITE LIBYAN IN MURDER
description: Gov. Scott M. Matheson of Utah today signed papers requesting extradition of Mohamad A. Shabata, a Libyan, from the Cook County Jail in Chicago, where he is being held in connection with the slaying of a countryman whose body was found in Ogden, 35 miles north of here.

title: DRAWINGS FROM KOREA
description: More than 90 abstract drawings from 20th-century Korea will be on exhibit for the first time in the United States at the Brooklyn Museum, 188 Eastern Parkway, at the corner of Washington Avenue.

title: Around the World; IRAN LEFTISTS ASSASSINATE CANDIDATE FOR PARLIAMENT
description: Leftist terrorists assassinated a candidate for Iran's Parliament today, the official Teheran Radio reported. It said that ''American bullets'' had been used.

title: MCDONNELL'S NET GAINS
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that operating earnings rose to $48.3 million in the second quarter from $43.7 million a year earlier. But the company expressed concern about a slowdown in new orders, and said that if it persisted, ''substantial reductions in production rates will be required, with a consequent negative effect on future earnings.''

title: THIRD HYATT WALK REMOVED DESPITE PROTEST FROM MAYOR
description: The remaining aerial walkway was removed from the lobby of the vacant Hyatt Regency hotel here overnight, despite protests from Mayor Richard L. Berkley that the removal might make it more difficult to determine why two other walkways collapsed last Friday afternoon, killing 111 persons and injuring 188 others.

title: STABLER IS RETIRING AFTER 11 PRO YEARS
description: Ken Stabler, the quarterback whose passing led the Oakland Raiders to victory in the 1977 Super Bowl, sent word through his agent that he would retire rather than start a 12th season, General Manager Ladd Herzeg of the Houston Oilers said today.

title: SCOTTO BEGINS SENTENCE FOR LABOR RACKETEERING
description: Anthony M. Scotto, who rose from the turbulent waterfront of Brooklyn to become one of New York's most influential and politically active union leaders, began serving a five-year term yesterday for labor racketeering.

title: CITY APPROVES NEW PURCHASE OF TWO-MAN GARBAGE TRUCKS
description: The purchase of 247 new two-man, side-loading garbage trucks at a cost of $22 million was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: The Region; JERSEY OPENS DRIVE ON SWEATSHOPS
description: Citing a proliferation of apparel industry sweatshops in the northeastern part of the state, New Jersey's Attorney General and Labor and Industry Commissioner announced the creation of a task force to prosecute violators of state labor laws.

title: AUTO SALES 7.7% HIGHER IN MID-JULY
description: Sales of new cars by the nation's three largest auto makers rose by 7.7 percent in the July 11-20 period, from the same period last year, ending three consecutive selling periods of declining sales.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Arkansas Power and Light Co., a unit of Middle South Utilities Co., registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $90 million in first-mortgage bonds through public bidding.

title: CABARET: PANAMA FRANCIS
description: IN the year and a half since Panama Francis and his Savoy Sultans first appeared at the Rainbow Room, the band has expanded on its basic repertory of material associated with bands that played at the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem and it has acquired an ease and confidence that adds sparkle and luster to everything it plays.

title: WILLIAM F. KENNEDY
description: William F. Kennedy, a lawyer and executive of the International Nickel Company of Canada until his retirement in June 1971, died Monday at the Cabrini Medical Center. Mr. Kennedy, a resident of Manhattan, was 75 years old.

title: The Region; TOLL TAKERS END STRIKE ON PARKWAY
description: A 22-day strike by toll collectors and maintenance workers on the Garden State Parkway ended when both sides accepted a Federal mediator's contract recommendation, an official said.

title: Notes on People; DAUGHTER YASMIN TO CARE FOR RITA HAYWORTH
description: A judge in Los Angeles Superior Court ruled yesterday that because she is suffering from senile dementia and is no longer able to care for herself, Rita Hayworth should be placed under the care of her daughter, Princess Yasmin Khan of New York City.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Executives
description: * Angeles Corporation, investment consultants, named Jerry E. Goldress a director.

title: PUBLISHING: A NOVEL'S LONG TREK INTO ENGLISH
description: WHEN David R. Godine issues ''On Heroes and Tombs'' next Thursday, it will mark the end of an unusual effort to publish that highly acclaimed novel in English, 20 years after its publication in Spanish and long after its translation into French, German, Italian and other languages.

title: Transactions; FOOTBALL JETS (AFC) - Released Dan Cernansky and Frank Lewandoski, linebackers.  Signed Richard Ruzika, tight end.  CHICAGO (NFC) - Signed Lenny Wal- terscheid, safety.  DALLAS (NFC) - Waived Greg Alex- ander, Doug Alston, Vendel Freeney Don Jones and Dan Neubauer, defensive backs; Jeff Roberry, defensive tackle; Wayne Whittman, defensive lineman.  Released Randy Geister, offensive line- man; Jeff Kestner, offensive tackle; Rick Kirk, Pat McShea and Gary Winemaster, linebackers; Lyle Pe
description: DETROIT (NHL) - Traded Al Jensen, g oalie, to the Washington Capitals for M ark Lofthouse, right winger.

title: PRICES UP BY 0.5% IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The seasonally adjusted cost of consumer goods in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey region showed a modest rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in June despite higher costs for electricity, food, transportation, housing and medical care.

title: U.S. ACHIEVES 4 GOLD MEDALS
description: American hurdlers and swimmers won four gold medals, and Rumanians dominated the gymnastics competition at the World University Games today.

title: FUNDS' ASSETS RISE $2.4 BILLION
description: The assets of the nation's money funds rose $2.4 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday, continuing the steady rise this year as investors seek the higher yields offered by the funds compared with other investments.

title: POSNER INTERESTS INCREASE HOLDINGS
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation, which is controlled by Victor Posner, the Miami Beach financier, said it had increased its stake in Johnson Controls Inc. to 1,310,838 shares, or 10 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Sharon Steel said the amount included 281,000 shares purchased between June 26 and July 17 at prices ranging from $30.50 a share to $31.50 a share.

title: REVLON ALSO GAINS
description: Schlumberger Ltd., the world's leading supplier of well logging services to the petroleum industry, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter increased 27 percent, while sales climbed 17.7 percent.

title: Corrections
description: In an article yesterday about a new opera company in the Catskills, the name of one of the singers was incorrect. The leading role in ''The Consul'' tomorrow night will be sung by Alexandra Hunt.

title: Index; International
description: Off the beaten path, an English town delights in The Wedding A2 Queen Elizabeth is 'greatly touched' by wedding good will A2 An heir to British crown last mar- ried an Englishwoman in 1660 A2 Israeli Cabinet meets to discuss U.S. relations A3 Soviet bars Kola Peninsula from a Nordic nuclear free zone A3 Bonn reassured in letter from Reagan on U.S. arms view A3 Around the World A5 Government/Politics House approves funds for Tennes- see-Tombigbee waterway A8 Army says only one U.S. division is not combat-ready A9 Two auxiliary police officers ar- rested in vest incident B2 Yonkers settles suits charging hiring bias by Fire Dept. B2 Barbaro qualifies for primary in race against Koch B3 Four indicted on charges involv- ing theft of $850,000 B3 General Around the Nation A6 Arrest easing Atlantans, but they keep their guard up A6 Arkansas still struggles with overcrowding in prisons A11 Jersey Power and Light gets a $50.7 million rate increase B2 New fire truck causes stir B2 Health/Science A genetic disorder affecting some Jews called potentially curable B3 Style The Evening Hours A16 Lunch in Washington: A time for power A16 T-shirts on the sidewalk A16 Features/Notes Notes on People A17 About New York B1 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Roseland, at 62, keeps in step with the 80's C1 Dennis Blair, young comic, gets respect at Dangerfield's C3 Free tour into the future at Brook- haven Laboratory C12 Nature festival runs gamut from birds to crawlers C28 Art: A guide to discreet changes at the Frick C1

title: FOR SLEEPLESS CYCLISTS
description: Anyone with the urge to take a 20-mile bicycle tour around the city in the wee hours of the morning may want to join like-minded persons at Columbus Circle tomorrow at midnight.

title: THE ONCE UNASSAILABLE STAR
description: For decades The Washington Star was so powerful and secure that A.J. Liebling, the late press critic of The New Yorker, could describe it as a ''disgustingly rich newspaper with an unassailable position.''

title: JAPAN-MEXICO OIL ACCORD
description: Japanese oil companies have agreed to continue buying 100,000 barrels of oil daily from Mexico and may eventually take up to 200,000 barrels more, the companies announced today.

title: DAVIS BELITTLES ROZELLE CHARGE
description: Al Davis, owner of the Oakland Raiders, testifying in the final stages of his team's antitrust suit against the National Football League, said today that he loved professional football as much as Commissioner Pete Rozelle did.

title: About Real Estate; A BROOKLYN HEIGHTS SITE, A DEVELOPER FROM PARIS
description: Jacques de Roquancourt arrived in New York from Paris two years ago determined to make his way as a developer. Almost the first thing he did was to start walking.

title: A GUIDE TO THE DISCREET CHANGES AT THE FRICK
description: THERE are two favorite fallacies about the Frick Collection that need to be discredited. One is that nothing ever changes there, that when the curators are through dusting the pictures for the day they can go upstairs and put their feet up. The truth is that in the discreetest possible way the Frick is changing all the time.

title: Bridge; NEW YORKERS FACE BATTLE IN GRAND NATIONAL TEAMS
description: A powerful team from New York overwhelmed its opponents in the first 16 deals of the Grand National team championship quarterfinal stage here this afternoon.

title: News Analysis
description: The closing of The Washington Star would leave the nation's capital the largest American city served by only one newspaper. Yesterday newspaper executives and students of the industry said they were alarmed and appalled by that prospect and they described the planned shutdown as a ''tragedy'' that would diminish an exchange of ideas and opinions considered vital to the development of national policy.

title: PAN AM POSTS ANOTHER LOSS
description: Pan American World Airways yesterday announced a net loss of $103.1 million for the second quarter of 1981. This continues a trend that threatens the airline's survival and led to a decision last week to reduce operations by 10 percent and make comparable cuts in the labor force.

title: LORD GORONWY-ROBERTS, LABORITE
description: Lord Goronwy-Roberts, a former Labor Government minister and deputy Labor leader in the House of Lords from 1975 until his retirement in 1979, has died at age 67.

title: WASHINGTON STAR IS TO SHUT DOWN AFTER 128 YEARS
description: The Washington Star, a 128-year-old daily long regarded as one of the best afternoon newspapers in the country, will cease publication on Aug. 7 because of continuing circulation and economic losses.

title: Auctions; BIG YEAR FOR AMERICANA
description: AMERICANA commanded some stunning prices this season at both Sotheby Parke Bernet and Christie's. Sales of American paintings, prints, decorative arts, American Indian art, and arts and crafts wares from the turn of the century totaled $38.5 million at Sotheby's and $10.5 million at Christie's. Adding sales of American books, autographs, coins and stamps at Christie's, its total came to $43.9 million.

title: A FIRE ENGINE OF A DIFFERENT COLOR
description: Why did the fireman wear a green T-shirt? Because that was the color of his new truck, a $96,000 American LaFrance fire engine called the Century New Yorker that made its first run with Engine Company 65 at 5:30 P.M. on Tuesday.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE BEAST. By Jonathan Fast. 290 pages. Random House. $12.95. THE MONTAUK FAULT. By Herbert Mit- gang. 285 pages. Arbor House. $12.95.

title: A BITTER AND ANGRY NEWS STAFF MOURNS ITS FALLEN STAR
description: Murray Gart, editor of The Washington Star, poked his head into a political columnist's office this morning. ''Sorry,'' said Mr. Gart quietly. ''We're not very happy, Murray,'' replied the columnist, Jack Germond. ''That's what I hear,'' said Mr. Gart, who suggested that the two men have a chat ''when you're ready.'' Mr. Gart disappeared and Mr. Germond, turning back to his desk, observed cheerlessly, ''I don't think I'm ever going to be ready.'' And so it went at The Star today, as staff members reacted sadly, bitterly, angrily to the news that Time Inc. will close the 128-yearold newspaper.

title: FOOD STAMP COMPROMISE TO CUT NUMBER ELIGIBLE
description: Months of disagreement over the food stamp program ended today as Congressional conferees worked out a compromise that will cut $6 billion in benefits in the next three years.

title: COSTLY LAISSEZ-FAIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: FORD EARNS $60 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: The Ford Motor Company reported today that it had earned a profit of $60 million, or 50 cents a share, in the second quarter, in contrast to a loss of $467.9 million in the second quarter of 1980.

title: METCALF OUT TO PROVE A POINT
description: Joe Theismann, the Redskin quarterback, took the snap, dropped back and tossed a short pass to No. 21, the halfback, who bounced off one linebacker, cut away from another and ran free into the secondary before a coach's whistle stopped the play.

title: J. CLAYTON STRAWBRIDGE, PHILADELPHIA EXECUTIVE
description: J. Clayton Strawbridge, a member of the board of directors of Strawbridge & Clothier, the Philadelphia department store, died Wednesday at his estate, The Waves, in Newport, R.I. He was 86 years old.

title: 'WOLFEN' WITH FINNEY
description: THE problem with most supernatural thrillers is that sooner or later they have to explain their supernaturalism, and then they fall apart. Michael Wadleigh's ''Wolfen'' comes very close to avoiding this problem by sliding discreetly into its supernatural world.

title: DOW GAINS SLIGHTLY, TO 928.56
description: Takeover stocks thundered back into popularity yesterday as Colt Industries, the session's biggest winner on Wall Street, soared more than 20 points. The Dow Jones industrial average, after plunging 34 points over the three previous trading days, rose 3.90 points, to 928.56.

title: Restaurants; TEX-MEX STAGE SET AND NORTH ITALIAN
description: SINCE it opened four years ago, El Coyote, on Broadway near Ninth Street, has become one of the livelier and more popular settings for Tex-Mex dining, especially late in the evening. Think more Tex than Mex and you will not be disappointed by this rustic, adobe and knotty-pine eatery with its comfortable booths and its young and obliging staff. A folkloric mural and accessories that suggest a border-town souvenir shop create a cheerful backdrop against which the hefty platters of satisfying, typical specialties can be enjoyed at relatively modest prices.

title: ROCKWELL NET UP BY 14.4%
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, citing increases in its aerospace business earnings and interest income, said today that its profit for the quarter ending June 30 rose 14.4 percent from the same period in 1980 on virtually unchanged sales.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the nation's capital, one newspaper just isn't good enough, no matter how good it is.'' - Eugene C. Patterson, executive editor of the St. Petersburg Times. (A12:5.)

title: FIRE-ENGINE RALLY IN ROCKEFELLER PLAZA
description: Fire engines, from the first 1898 horse-drawn ''waterous pump'' to the 1930 Ahrens Fox pumper, will hit the city streets again tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., when about 15 antique engines will be on display in Rockefeller Plaza between 48th and 51st Streets. Also shown will be modern equipment, the superpumpers and supertenders used to fight fires today.

title: FESTIVAL IS OFF TO EARLY START
description: The National Sports Festival opened today, somewhat abruptly. Officials, the 2,500 athletes and a capacity crowd at the Carrier Dome witnessed the opening ceremonies. The actor Cliff Robertson, Mayor Lee Alexander and John F.X. Mannion, chairman of the Syracuse Organizing Committee, were among those delivering speeches. But the opening was upstaged by the unexpected, early start of competition.

title: A FOE OF KOCH TAKES HEART FROM OPPOSITION IN CONEY I.
description: Meetings like the one in Coney Island this week give Frank J. Barbaro hope that somehow the polls and politicians are wrong - that perhaps he can defeat Mayor Koch in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary.

title: AFTER 20 YEARS, JAYE P. MORGAN IS BACK IN TOWN
description: JAYE P. MORGAN is back in New York for the first time in 20 years, but Wall Street has scarcely flickered an eyelid in interest. That is because this Jaye P. Morgan is no relation to the J.P. Morgan (she became Jaye P. instead of Mary Morgan when she was class treasurer in her junior year in high school), and the notes she deals with are musical, not financial. She is singing at Les Mouches, 559 West 26th Street, at 11th Avenue (695-5190), tonight and tomorrow at 9 o'clock and midnight. There are a $10 music charge and $15 minimum at tables.

title: BRASCAN'S NEW BID FOR NORANDA
description: Brascan Ltd., thwarted two years ago in an attempt to take over Noranda Mines Ltd., today announced a renewed assault on Noranda, this time in association with a powerful arm of the Quebec government.

title: Notes on People; TRYING TO TELL THE HEROES FROM THE VILLAINS
description: Having directed many of his movies, such as ''Serpico'' and ''Dog Day Afternoon'' in New York, Sidney Lumet has learned the value of casting nonprofessionals rather than professional actors in some roles.

title: About New York; THE POWER AND THE GLORY FADE TO PRISON GRAY
description: The friends of Anthony M. Scotto -and there are still a great many of them, although nowadays they are not eager to be quoted by name - agree that the best way to describe his life in recent weeks would be schizophrenic.

title: The City; PRIVATE BUS LINES WIN FARE INCREASE
description: The Board of Estimate approved fare increases for six private bus lines serving Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Advertising; ELAN: FOR THE BLACK WOMAN
description: educated black women that will enter the marketplace this winter, is a result of the desire of an unpublicized black entrepreneur to better the lot of some of his own employees.

title: The Region; DEFENDANT DENIES OWNING SHOTGUN
description: John Youmans continued to deny yesterday that he even owned a shotgun in 1952, when two hunters he is charged with killing were shot to death in the hills of Orange County.

title: Around the World; POPE STAYING IN HOSPITAL UNTIL SECOND OPERATION
description: Pope John Paul II will stay in the hospital until after his recovery from a second operation on his intestines that will probably take place next month, the Pope's doctors said today, dispelling rumors that he may be about to return to the Vatican.

title: The City; JODY POWERS TO GO TO A FOSTER HOME
description: The 15-month-old girl who was believed to have been a victim of child abuse and was taken from a city hospital by her mother in violation of a Family Court order, will be placed temporarily in a foster home, officials of the City Human Resources Administration said.

title: WATERWAY BARELY SURVIVES IN HOUSE
description: The Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway, one of the most sacred of Congressional cows, barely survived today when the House of Representatives, by 10 votes, agreed to provide an additional $189 million for the project.

title: TRAVOLTA STARS IN DEPALMA'S 'BLOW OUT'
description: ''BLOW OUT,'' Brian De Palma's flashy, eclectic new suspense thriller, is all about a young man's successful search for the perfect scream, not just any old scream, but the full-bodied, allout, deep-from-the-diaphram scream of ultimate terror by a nubile young woman at the exact moment she understands her murder is at hand.

title: BAND: SOUSA-HERBERT FESTIVAL OPENS
description: NOW that the former Goldman Band has been transformed into the Guggenheim Concert Band, with Ainslee Cox as music director, some changes are being made in the programs that have been delighting outdoor audiences in New York for more than six decades. But band concert enthusiasts need not be concerned; the changes are so subtle, in a way, that they might pass unnoticed if Mr. Cox and his organization did not wish to draw attention to them.

title: AFTER SHIFT TO RIGHT, SWEDES LOOK AGAIN TO SOCIALISM
description: After lurching away from Socialism in 1976, Sweden now seems to be lurching back after five years of government by non-Socialist parties whose divisiveness has brought little movement away from welfare state concepts.

title: Notes on People; A BOOK THAT HAS READERS COMING AND GOING
description: For Joaquin and Maura Kuhn, there's no pal like a palindrome - a word, phrase or sentence that reads the same backward or forward. POOR DAN IS IN A DROOP, for example, or that very well-worn palindrome, ABLE WAS I ERE I SAW ELBA.

title: 'EYE OF NEEDLE,' ESPIONAGE AND PASSION
description: ''EYE OF THE NEEDLE'' is an ambitious, energetic thriller that stops short of real excitement for reasons that are hard to pinpoint. It's an entertaining movie, and an extremely well-acted one. Ken Follett's novel, on which the film is based, affords both a catchy spy gimmick and an interplay of strongly conflicting emotions. Alfred Hitchcock could have worked miracles with this story's mixture of love, suspicion and intrigue; as it is, the director is Richard Marquand, and he does much more than a creditable job. His film is suspenseful all the way. But it never truly manages to catch fire.

title: THE CHIEF INFLATOR OF MEDICAL-CARE BILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: BUDGET CONFERENCES NEARING AN ALIGNMENT OF FINAL TRIMS
description: Congressional leaders today praised the progress made by a House-Senate conference to align $37 billion in budget cuts, and said that they expected the final legislation to be approved by Congress next week.

title: Ellis Island Is Crumbling
description: Mention Ellis Island and what do most people conjure up: nostalgic images of a gateway of hope, seas of straining immigrant faces, beards, boots, long overcoats, a Babel of languages and dialects, heavily clad women in babushkas clutching in one hand a saucer-eyed child and in the other a knotted bedsheet bulging with the possessions of the first half of a life. Throat-choking scenes of Americans-to-be. Romantic. Sepia-colored.

title: Portugal's Premier Faces Increasing Criticism
description: Portugal's political crisis deepened today as Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao came under open attack from his Christian Democratic coalition partners.

title: 2D RAILWAY, C.&N.W., WINS COAL FIELD ACCESS
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a plan that gives the Chicago & North Western Transportation Company rail access to the coal-rich Powder River Basin in Wyoming.

title: TWO SHARE LEAD OF 4 SHOTS IN OPEN
description: Kathy Whitworth, the sentimental favorite in the 36th annual United States Women's Open championship, shot birdies on the last two holes at the La Grange Country Club today and finished at 5-under-par 139. That kept her in a tie for the lead midway through the open but with a different player.

title: LA SCALA BALLET: NUREYEV
description: Rudolf Nureyev and Carla Fracci made their first joint New York appearance in ''Giselle'' Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: No Headline
description: Wayne Levi overcame putting problems with a four-under-par 67 for 137 and a one-stroke lead in the second round of the $300,000 Anheuser-Busch golf tournament today.

title: Providence Removes Police From Its Cleanup
description: Police officers with shotguns were ordered off garbage trucks in Providence, R.I., yesterday in a move to get talks moving in a public workers' strike. Other municipal labor disputes went on in California, Minnesota and Ohio.

title: VAN PELT STILL NEGOTIATING
description: Brad Van Pelt, the Pro Bowl linebacker, said he had still not reached agreement with the Giants on an extension of his contract, which has one year plus an option year remaining. The proposed five-year extension is believed to be worth $1 million.

title: HOUSE APPROVES REACTOR FUNDS
description: The Clinch River breeder reactor project was kept alive today when the House, by 20 votes, provided another $228 million to begin construction on the $3.2 billion project.

title: HARVEY FLETCHER, PIONEER IN STEREO
description: Harvey Fletcher, who headed a team of scientists that developed stereophonic sound and demononstrated it to a startled audience in New York in 1934, died Thursday at a convalescent home in Provo, Utah. He was 96 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It may be true, as has been suggested to the court, that 'every man has his price;' but when that price is money only, the public official should be required to pay the penalty when he gets caught.'' - Judge George C. Pratt, upholding seven Abscam convictions. (1:2.)

title: BRIEFINGS COULD DELAY NEW TALKS
description: The remainder of the major league baseball season teetered on the brink of eradication yesterday as union officials prepared for a series of player meetings that could delay resumption of negotiations for nearly two weeks. But, the officials said, no matter how soon talks resume, nothing will happen unless there is a ''drastic change'' in the owners' bargaining position.

title: Art Vandal Fined in Chicago
description: A part-time art student who admitted throwing red paint on a Joan Miro sculpture must pay to clean the artwork, at a cost of $17,000. Crister Nyholm, 24, pleaded guilty Wednesday to a charge of criminal damage to property in the incident May 1 in downtown Chicago. A Cook County circuit Judge, Fred Suria, ordered the defendant to pay for cleanup and court costs, and sentenced him to 30 months' felony probation.

title: NOMINEE CITES PLANS FOR F.T.C.
description: President Reagan's choice to head the Federal Trade Commission left little doubt at his confirmation hearing today that there would be a major change in the course of the F.T.C. Many businessmen say it has imposed too many regulations on industry.

title: POOR READERS BEING HELPED TO GO AHEAD
description: If reading were merely a matter of sounding out letters and pronouncing words, most of the seventh-graders repeating their work in the city's public schools this summer would probably have had high enough reading scores to have avoided being held back.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Beause of editing errors in the Auctions column of Weekend yesterday, the total of $43.9 million in American specialty sales was attributed to the wrong auction house, and the place where the Jean and Howard Lipman collection of American folk art will be sold Nov. 14 was omitted. Sotheby Parke Bernet held the specialty sales and will auction the Lipman collection.

title: DOW COAL PROJECT
description: The Dow Chemical Company said that it had successfully started a computer-controlled coal liquefaction mini-plant that is now converting 200 pounds of coal a day. Other concerns have expressed interest in the technology, which Dow is interested in licensing and expanding for further development, the company said.

title: ARAB FUND TO EXPAND
description: The Arab Monetary Fund expects to almost double its capital in the next six months, to about $900 million, officials of the fund reported today. The fund, the Arab world's equivalent of the Washington-based International Monetary Fund, mainly helps Arab countries with balance-of-payments problems.

title: Bowdoin Professor Becomes The College's 12th President
description: Dr. A. LeRoy Greason, a professor of English at Bowdoin College and a former dean of the college, was elected the 12th president of Bowdoin today.

title: Bridge; NEW YORKERS GO INTO LEAD IN GRAND NATIONAL CONTEST
description: Teams from New York and Pennsylvania clashed here this afternoon in one semifinal of the Grand National Team Championship while Chicago and Texas battled in the other.

title: WATER SECURITY CHIEF IN NEWARK ABSENT FROM JOBS FOR MONTHS
description: The chief of security for the city's Pequannock Watershed is an 80-year-old former City Councilman who is paid $24,255 a year, even though he lives in Florida and has not visited the aqueduct system in months.

title: COOLING FOODS FOR SUMMER
description: Summer, more than any other season, provokes controversy over the kind of food best suited to the weather. Few will argue that winter's cold is best warded off by hot and lusty soups and stews, steaming porridge, cocoa and toddies, or that the mild days of spring suggest foods equally mild in temperature and flavor such as fresh greens, steamed new potatoes and young salmon, grilled lamb and tiny chickens, and much anticipated firsts such as asparagus, strawberries and pungent rhubarb. Even autumn with its harvests of vegetables and game has its own menu, and the first crackling cold days of fall inspire bracing dishes not quite as complex and heavy as those of deepest winter.

title: KENNEDY AIRPORT SEEKS TO CUT INSPECTION LINES
description: Federal officials at Kennedy International Airport are trying to cut the long waits in inspection lines this summer with the addition of more temporary inspectors, but their hopes for a more permanent solution to the seasonal logjams rest on an abbreviated inspection system to be tested at two other major airports.

title: PRESIDENT ADDS TO CONCESSIONS IN TAX-CUT BILL
description: The Reagan Administration, openly offering tax concessions to win votes in the House of Representatives, today introduced still another version of its three-year tax-relief bill that included future automatic ''indexing'' of tax brackets to offset inflation.

title: Dexter Cup Won By Defiant Yankee
description: Defiant Yankee won the $233,955 Dexter Cup at Roosevelt Raceway tonight in a preview of the Hambletonian Trot that will be held for the first time at the Meadowlands Aug. 8.

title: Patents; ULTRASONIC BEAM AIDS BLIND
description: WASHINGTON A WARNING cane for the blind that sends ultrasonic signals to detect obstacles was patented this week for the Polaroid Corporation of Cambridge, Mass. Gilbert M. Elchinger, an employee, obtained patent 4,280,204.

title: FORMERLY AT LENOX HILL
description: Dr. Harry F. Wechsler, a former director of medicine at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan and a member of its staff for more than 40 years, died Wednesday at the hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: K MART TO GET 44% OF MEXICAN CHAIN
description: The K mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest retailer, said it would acquire 44 percent of the Astra Company, one of Mexico's largest retail chains, for an undisclosed price.

title: MODERATE ADVANCE PUTS DOW AT 936.74
description: The stock market posted a moderate advance yesterday as takeover and earnings developments produced some of the largest price changes. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 8.18 points, to 936.74.

title: SHEARSON FINISHES BOSTON PURCHASE
description: Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., a major brokerage house, and the Boston Company, a money management firm, said that they had entered into a definitive agreement whereby Boston would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Shearson.

title: Don Hogan Charles
description: SEGMENTED BUS TESTED: Passengers boarding a 60-foot bus for a demonstration yesterday near City Hall. The 63-seat Hungarian vehicle, hinged to facili-tate turning, is 20 feet longer and has 50 percent greater capacity than a standard bus. It is in use in Louisville, Ky.; San Mateo, Calif., and many cities in Europe.

title: 3 REVOLUTIONARY GUARDS SLAIN AS IRAN GOES TO POLLS fired
description: Three revolutionary guards were reported slain in Teheran today as Iranian voters went to the polls to decide which of four candidates will succeed the ousted President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr.

title: GLUT IN AIR DISCOUNT COUPONS
description: ''This could be bad,'' said the coupon scalper named Billy earlier this week, as he waited at La Guardia's Eastern Airlines terminal with a few hundred $1 bills and a fat wad of Eastern coupons. ''You feel like buying a thousand?''

title: DANCE: WAYS OF THE ABORIGINES ON A CITY LANDFILL
description: When dancers entered by marching down the side of a hill late Thursday afternoon, one could truly believe that they were stepping from one world into another. The dancers were members of a company called Aboriginal Artists of Australia, which is making its first American tour. And the hill they marched down was on the landfill at Battery Park City. An ancient form of dance thereby found its way to modern America.

title: BRYANT POND ENTERS AGE OF PUSH BUTTONS
description: Mrs. Sterling Mills, wife of a local lumberman, has been using hand-crank telephones for the past 20 years but will soon be compelled to change to something entirely new - Touch-Tone phones.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AT THE MUSEUM

title: PUERTO RICANS SEE AN EXODUS TO THE MAINLAND AS AID IS CUT
description: Puerto Rico, which will bear the full brunt of Federal budget cuts but get none of the benefits of proposed tax reductions, is already feeling the effects of the loss of Federal programs, and officials here say a huge new wave of migration to the mainland will ensue if help is not provided.

title: MAYOR'S COMMERCIAL IMAGE CALLED LEGITIMATE PUBLICITY FOR CITY
description: Mayor Koch, it seems, likes the New York Mets, Brooke Shields, nearly every newspaper and television station in the city and an occasional Chipwich ice cream sandwich.

title: EXPOS WOULD HEAD SOUTH
description: In the most radical plan devised by a team for getting back into shape, the Montreal Expos confirmed yesterday that they would hold workouts at their spring-training base in West Palm Beach, Fla., when the baseball strike ended.

title: Emily Chambers, 78, Is Dead; Leader in Social Service Work
description: Emily Zimmerer Chambers, who was active in educational and social service programs, died Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a brief illness. She was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Briefs
description: * American Gasohol Refiners Inc. said it had secured $35 million in financing for construction of an ethanol distilling plant in Colwell, Kan.

title: VENEZUELA OIL FLOW CUT
description: Venezuela's daily oil production fell to 1.69 million barrels in the week ended Tuesday, 97,000 barrels below the previous week, the energy ministry said today. This put average daily production this year at 2.12 million barrels, down from 2.16 million in 1980.

title: 25 GO FREE AFTER WESTCHESTER JAIL BAIL REVIEW
description: A series of unusual bail hearings for inmates at the Westchester County Jail has ended, with 24 men and one woman walking free to await court action.

title: FINANCIAL FILINGS AT ISSUE
description: In Senate confirmation proceedings this year, William J. Casey, now the Director of Central Intelligence, failed to disclose stock holdings in one corporation and the receipt as a gift of a $10,000 interest in another business venture, according to a review of public records and information provided by a close business associate.

title: Mitchell Is Not Liable On Charges of Malice
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that former Attorney General John Mitchell has absolute immunity from charges of malicious prosecution in the arrest of antiwar demonstrators 10 years ago.

title: CATSKILLS REAWAKENING AFTER A LONG SLEEP
description: In the glittering resort hotels there is talk of casino gambling, while in the decaying towns the topic is unemployment and crime. But the center of discussion throughout the hills is the new face of the Catskills - people from New York City seeking second homes, a melange of off-brand religious groups who want isolation and artists needing cheap studios.

title: Park Food Sellers Cleared in Illness
description: The Health Department said food vendors were not responsible for the illness that overcame nine children from a day-care center and one of their counselors Wednesday in Astoria Park, Queens.

title: Architect Faces Charge In Collapse in Florida
description: An architect today became the fourth person to face professional disciplinary charges in connection with the collapse in March of a nearly completed condominium.

title: Earnings; AMERICAN BRANDS UP BY 2.4%
description: American Brands Inc., a leading domestic and international producer of cigarettes, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1981 edged up 2.4 percent. Sales, however, dropped 6.3 percent.

title: 450,000 TONS OF CORN BOUGHT BY SOVIET UNION
description: The Soviet Union has bought 450,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery after Sept. 30, the date a current five-year grain agreement between the two countries expires, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Daring the Offshore Depths
description: Interior Secretary Watt's five-year plan for offshore oil and gas development points in the right direction - toward more exploration and new energy discoveries. But development on such a breathtaking scale requires the kind of judicious management that Mr. Watt has yet to demonstrate. A vociferous champion of development who sneers disparagingly at most environmental groups can hardly be relied upon to insure that precious coastlines and fish are not recklessly harmed.

title: SOLUTION EMERGING ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The broad outlines of a Congressional solution to the financial problems of Social Security, both in this decade and in the next century, are emerging from bipartisan conversations of Senate and House leaders.

title: DOCUTEL COMPLETES U.S. OLIVETTI SWAP
description: The Docutel Corporation said it had completed its previously announced purchase of the American assets of the Olivetti Corporation's financial systems for an exchange of stock.

title: BRIBERY BAN IS BACKED
description: A former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman charged today that proposals endorsed by the Reagan Administration to amend a 1977 law banning overseas bribes would implicitly sanction payoffs.

title: WARSAW CUTS THE MONTHLY MEAT RATION BY 20 PERCENT
description: The 7.7-pound monthly meat ration for Poles was cut by 20 percent today.

title: SEAGRAM OBJECTS TO CONOCO TACTICS
