description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons yesterday accused Conoco officials of ''desperate, last-ditch tactics'' to block a takeover by soliciting negative comments about the giant liquor company from Norway and Dubai, where Conoco has significant oil operations.

title: FOR KATHY RINALDI, TURNING PRO IS FUN
description: On the day when 14-year-old Kathy Rinaldi announced that she would play tennis as a professional, her father nagged her to eat lunch.

title: Smoldering Mine Fire Breaks to the Surface
description: Volunteer firefighters kept watch today on a mountainside where Centralia's 19-year-old underground mine fire has broken to the surface for the first time.

title: F-16'S MAY BE SENT IF ACCORD HOLDS Israel (p.4)
description: United States officials said today that the suspension of fighting across the Israeli-Lebanese border should be followed by vigorous efforts to end the civil war in Lebanon. They said the cease-fire should also be used to restore ''movement and momentum'' to the broad Middle East peace negotiations growing out of the 1978 Camp David agreements.

title: Patents; CRYSTAL IN LENS REACTS MORE PROMPTLY TO LIGHT
description: A New York eye specialist has invented a spectacle lens made of a layer of liquid crystal between a pair of identically curved sheets of glass or plastic. Visibility through the lens is electrically controlled according to the intensity of ambient light.

title: LOOKING AT MAO AS PRACTICING EGALITARIAN
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN'S CAR SALES UP
description: Japan's share of the West German car market rose to 10.2 percent in the first half of 1981 from 9 percent in the first six months of 1980, the federal motor office said today.

title: Patents; ELECTROLYSIS DEPOSITS METALS ON INERT SURFACES
description: A process for the electrolytic deposition of metals, conceived after research at Columbia University, was patented this week. Patent 4,279,711 was granted to Paul F. Duby, professor of chemical metallurgy at the university; Jack A. Scott, a graduate student, and Paul H. Vining, a former student and now a process engineer for Mansfield Carbon Products Inc. of Nashville.

title: MECHANICAL HEART GIVEN MAN IN TEXAS
description: A 36-year-old man was in stable but critical condition yesterday after surgeons in Houston, fighting to save his life, removed his heart and replaced it with a mechanical substitute, the fourth artificial heart known to have been implanted in a human being.

title: HENRY J. HASKELL
description: Henry C. Haskell, an editor and columnist for The Kansas City Star and The Kansas City Times, died Tuesday at the age of 79.

title: SALVADOR TRIES TO RALLY SUPPORT FOR 1982 ELECTIONS
description: A grieving woman, lighting candles at the four corners of a body covered by a sheet, appeared on the television screen. It might have been her husband, daughter, son, or a friend killed by the political violence. A narrator asked viewers if they wanted the violence to continue. The bereaved woman said, ''El Salvador deserves your vote.''

title: Currency Markets; DOLLAR MIXED ABROAD; GOLD PRICES OFF SLIGHTLY
description: The dollar was mixed on European currency exchanges yesterday, and a London dealer described trading as nervous. Gold was little changed.

title: JUNE GAIN HELPED CUT U.S. DEBT
description: The Government's finances showed a $15.1 billion surplus in June, trimming the Federal deficit to $49.4 billion for the first three quarters of the fiscal year 1981, the Treasury Department said today.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 25, 1981
description: International Israel agreed to a cease-fire in Lebanon, reportedly on the condition that Palestinian guerrillas halt any further military buildup in southern Lebanon. The agreement was announced in Jerusalem by Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, and a separate announcement was later made in Beirut by the Palestine Liberation Organization. An Israeli official said that the Lebanese Government had indicated its willingness to try to curb the Palestinian guerrillas. (Page 1, Column 6.) The P.L.O. accepted the cease-fire. Kurt Waldheim, Secretary General of the United Nations, which participated in the negotiations, said that Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, had sent him a message saying that his guerrillas would honor a cease-fire ''if the other side did.'' Both sides handled the ceasefire acceptance in a gingerly way. There appeared to be face-saving on both sides that enabled them to say that they had not made a deal with each other. The Israelis avoided the term ''cease-fire'' and said it was not an agreement but an arrangement with the United States and the Lebanese Government. (1:5-6.)

title: Your Money; New Yields For Savings
description: THE beleaguered thrift industry has been battling for the small investor's dollar as people desert savings institutions for alternate investment vehicles. The institutions are beginning to offer new plans. Among these was one recently offered by a New York savings bank. As with most savings plans, there are some provisions that can surprise the unwary investor.

title: IDAHO SILVER MINES' FIERCE MERGER WAR
description: Jameson's, a Gay Nineties-style dining hall and saloon in this tiny northern Idaho mining community, has been filled for years with the chatter of friendly businessmen. These days, however, the mining executives seem almost hostile, and their talk is in hushed tones.

title: VISITING ARTISTS FACE CULTURE SHOCK
description: For 23 men and five women from the Stone Age cultural tradition of Australia's aboriginal tribes, what might prove even more terrifying than the flight across the Pacific to the United States?

title: U.N. CONTACT WITH ARAFAT CREDITED IN BREAKTHROUGH
description: The United Nations played a role in the cease-fire announced today that neither Israel nor the United States could undertake, dealing directly with the Palestine Liberation Organization to win its assent.

title: GERMANS PLAN PIPELINE LOAN
description: West German commercial banks said today that they had reached a broad agreement with the Soviet Union to help finance construction of the controversial 3,000-mile pipeline to bring gas from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: BARBER IN HOSPITAL
description: Marion Barber, the Jets' second-round draft choice, suffered a slight concussion in practice Thursday and was hospitalized for observation. The 6-foot-3-inch, 230-pound running back from Minnesota will miss the weekend workouts. Richard Ruzika, a tight end from Columbia, decided Friday that he did not want to play pro football and left camp.

title: 3 GOLD MEDALS TO MARY WAYTE
description: Mary Wayte, a high school sophomore from Mercer Island, Wash., won three gold medals in swimming today at the National Sports Festival.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY DIP CUTS RATES
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday after the Federal Reserve announced a $5.9 billion drop in the nation's basic money supply that almost completely offset the previous week's abnormally large, $6.9 billion increase.

title: Mormons Expand Top-Level Leadership
description: For the first time in more than a decade, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has expanded its top-level leadership, with the appointment of Gordon B. Hinckley as a counselor.

title: Judge's Ruling a Setback to N.F.L.
description: United States District Court Judge Harry Pregerson ruled today that the National Football League is not a single entity, handing the league a major setback in its court battle with the Oakland Raiders and Los Angeles Coliseum Commission.

title: AILING KNEES CITED
description: For 10 years - seven with the Pittsburgh Steelers and the last three with the Giants - Jim Clack has been an offensive lineman in the National Football League. Today, the day he was scheduled to begin workouts at training camp here, the Giants' starting center retired - or was retired.

title: Ill Winds for Social Security Reform
description: Everyone who has paid Social Security taxes for 10 years, no matter how little, is currently entitled to a minimum retirement benefit of $122 a month. Eliminating this benefit, says Jim Wright, the House Democratic leader, strikes at ''the poorest and oldest and the most politically defenseless.'' No way, responds the Reagan Budget Office: only one recipient in ten will be seriously hurt - and they are eligible for increased welfare benefits.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 20. 1. Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, is announcing the company's first profit in more than two years. 2.

title: SON OF REAGAN TERMED THE TARGET OF TERRORIST PLOT
description: A terrorist organization planned to seek the release of 11 of its members, sentenced to prison here recently, by kidnapping a high-ranking Government official or President Reagan's son Ron, according to testimony from one admitted member of the group.

title: AUSTRALIA COAL VENTURE
description: The four partners in the the Oaky Creek coking coal joint venture in Queensland have decided to proceed with the project, M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., the senior partner, said today. Coal should be ready for export from the 2.3-million-ton-a-year plant by 1983, the company said. M.I.M. has a 78 percent stake in the project with the rest held by Estel Delstoffen, with 9.5 percent; Italsider S.p.A., 7.5 percent, and Nacional Siderurguca S.A., with 5 percent. Financing of the project is being arranged with a group of banks led by the Bank of New South Wales, Citibank and Toronto Dominion Bank, with the First Boston Corporation as financial adviser.

title: Madrid Parley Adjourns With No Accord in Sight
description: The participants in the deadlocked European Security Conference agreed today, after eight months of debate, to adjourn until Oct. 27.

title: HERBERT J. FRENSLEY
description: Herbert J. Frensley, former president and chief executive officer of the contracting company Brown & Root, died Monday at Methodist Hospital.

title: 173-Year Sentence In Jersey Murder
description: A computer operator was sentenced yesterday to 173 to 179 years in prison in the mutilation-murder of a prostitute and the beatings of four other women. He was also fined $2,350.

title: KEY TO CONTENT TRIUMPHS
description: Rokeby Stables' Key to Content took the $150,000 United Nations Handicap on the grass at Atlantic City race course tonight, winning by a neck from Ben Fab.

title: 2 More Challenge Koch in Primary
description: The field for the Democratic nomination for Mayor grew more crowded yesterday as two political unknowns filed petitions to qualify for the Sept. 10 primary.

title: Braniff Loss Is Narrowed
description: The Braniff International Corporation today said its net loss in the second quarter shrank to $40 million from $48.5 million a year before.

title: Patents; ART WORKS IN WAX
description: A Maryland artist has patented a process for preparing works of art with wax.

title: Patents; DEVICE OVERRIDES ERRORS IN HELICOPTER CONTROL
description: A helicopter control system designed to eliminate abrupt, unintentional maladjustment of the control stick has been invented for the United Technologies Corporation of Hartford. It is already used on the company's S-76 commercial helicopters.

title: Anderson Favors More Yonkers Aid
description: The State Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, said he would favor giving the City of Yonkers an additional $4 million in state assistance, if Governor Carey would agree to it.

title: Suit on Rents Cites Delays for Elderly
description: The Legal Aid Society filed suit charging New York City officials with ''inordinate delays'' in processing applications by the elderly for rent-increase exemptions.

title: LONDON GALLERY GIVEN OLD MASTERS
description: ''I just feel lost now,'' a bewildered Thomas Wealthy said as he sat at his stool in the small Courtauld Institute of Art Gallery, dwarfed by somber paintings by such masters as Michelangelo, Rubens and Rembrandt. ''I have worked with the same paintings for 16 years and I know them like the back of my hand. I haven't gotten used to these new ones yet.''

title: HONEYWELL TO INVEST $9 MILLION IN FRANCE
description: Despite the threat of a French Government takeover of one of its major investments, Honeywell Inc., the computer concern, said today that its board of directors had approved a $9 million capital investment in its wholly owned French subsidiary, Honeywell S.A.

title: NUCOR STEEL MILL BEGINS SHIPMENTS
description: The Nucor Corporation said that its small steel mill here began shipping steel to market this week. The $90 million plant, which uses scrap as its basic raw material, will produce about 400,000 tons of recycled steel annually when it reaches full capacity in about a year, a company spokesman said.

title: Guy Owen, 56, Wrote 'Flim-Flam Man' Book
description: Guy Owen, a North Carolina writer whose ''The Ballad of the Flim-Flam Man'' was made into a movie, died Wednesday in Rex Hospital. He was hospitalized in January with liver cancer and had recently been readmitted.

title: LET'S CALL THE WHOLE THING OFF
description: IT'S time to call off the baseball season. Abandon the charade, cut off the water treatment, put everybody out of misery. Since negotiations broke off Thursday night, no talks are possible until early next week. Even with a quick settlement - which is hardly likely - the players could not be in shape for another two weeks. That would leave a six-week season with a mockery of a playoff and a sham of a World Series.

title: ISUZU WILL SEND PARTS TO G.M. UNIT
description: Isuzu Motor Ltd. of Japan said that it had accepted a request by the General Motors Corporation to supply Isuzumade parts for the ''J'' car to G.M.'s Australian unit, General Motors Holden Ltd., possibly beginning next spring.

title: YEA FOR THE M.T.A.
description: .8,2I for one cannot protest the recent M.T.A. fare hike and the accompanying promises that this would in no way improve service. For the transit system, as it now operates, has hidden advantages that can't be measured in monetary terms.

title: Stabler's Exit Still Mystifying
description: Ken Stabler, the quarterback who often left opposing defenses guessing during his 11-year professional career, still had everyone wondering today why he had suddenly announced his retirement.

title: PRINCE'S GUEST LIST EMBRACES KINGS AND CHARWOMEN
description: Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer have invited a potpourri of personal friends and people whom they have never met to their wedding Wednesday - kings and gamekeepers, presidents and comedians, generals and charwomen.

title: The Economy
description: The Administration introduced still another version of its threeyear tax-relief bill that includes automatic ''indexing'' of tax brackets to offset inflation. This and other concessions were aimed at winning support in Wednesday's House vote. President Reagan plans a Monday television address. (Page 1.)

title: THE VIETNAM WAR'S SILENT MAJORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Notebook; ABC 'VIEWPOINT' LOOKS AT TV NEWS
description: Television - or more specifically, television news - has begun making tenative efforts to investigate itself. This summer, WBBM-TV, the CBS-owned station in Chicago, presented a one-hour documentary, ''Watching the Watchdog,'' that promised to examine controversial techniques of reporting on television, including its own. Instead, the program became largely an indictment of ABC News and Geraldo Rivera, its controversial correspondent.

title: WALKER SET FOR BANNER YEAR
description: Wesley Walker and Lam Jones are the two wide receivers whose 40-yard dash times of 4.38 seconds gave the Jets an extra dimension on offense at this time last year, an advantage that was supposed to make the team a contender. It never happened.

title: FEDERAL GOVERNMENT ROLE IN EDUCATION IS AT ISSUE
description: THE RIGHTS OF CHILDREN: A DECADE OF CHANGE Last of five articles

title: SOME CALL FOR RESIGNATION
description: Several Republicans and Democrats on the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence today urged William J. Casey to resign as Director of Central Intelligence, going beyond the suggestion made last night by their chairman, Senator Barry Goldwater, that he consider stepping down.

title: FOREMOST NET AT RECORD
description: Foremost-McKesson Inc. said today that earnings for the first quarter, ended June 30, increased 11 percent, to a record $16 million, or $1 a share, from $14.4 million, or 91 cents, in the 1980 quarter. Per-share earnings on a fully diluted basis rose to 92 cents from 81 cents. Revenues rose 13 percent, to a record $1 billion from $960.7 million.

title: TIME GETS NIBBLES ON PURCHASE OF WASHINGTON STAR
description: Time Inc. said today that it had received a handful of inquiries but no substantive purchase offers for The Washington Star, which is to cease publication in two weeks.

title: Index; International
description: Salvadoran junta tries to gather support for 1982 elections 2 Argentina says its nuclear plants won't comply with safeguards 3 Around the World 3 United Nations played key role in cease-fire 4 European royalty becomes less expensive, more circumspect 5 Royal guests include high and mighty, the low and humble 5 Government/Politics House approves funds for Clinch River reactor 8 Leaders praise House-Senate con- ferees' on resolving budget 9 California asks Supreme Court to halt produce quarantines 20 Mayor Koch likes a lot of people and products, but it's all ethical 25 Carey signs bill to increase Tui- tion Assistance Program funds 25 Two more file to run for New York mayoral nomination 27 General Around the Nation 6 A few families of missing Ameri- cans get an answer 6 Terrorist testifies group planned kidnappings to free members 15 Time Inc. gets nibbles on Wash- ington Star sale 24 Revitalization in Catskills brings problems 25 Artists from a Stone Age culture perform and visit in Manhattan 27 Judge dismissed suits on the rights of the handicapped 27 Health/Science Researchers investigate effects of marijuana on sexual activity 15 News Analysis John F. Burns on Soviet's attitude toward Polish party talks 3 Sheila Rule on problems of civil rights groups 15 Education/Welfare Many 7th-graders attend reading classes, to get promoted 27 Arts/Entertainment Atlantic to run Caro's biography of Lyndon B. Johnson in 5 parts 10 Nureyev with Milan's La Scala Ballet at the Met 10 Aboriginal Artists dance at Bat- tery City landfill 11 London's Courtauld Gallery in- herits collection of Old Masters 11 Historic American Theaters suc- cessful with restorations 13 ''Destination Peace,'' book on Is- rael's foreign policy, reviewed 14 ABC News's ''Viewpoint,'' series looks at news coverage on TV 48 Style Consumer Saturday 21 To the airport: Getting there the fastest 21 The glitter jacket 21 De Gustibus: Cooling foods for summer 21 Obituaries Harvey Fletcher, pioneer in stereophonic sound 20 Sports Cruises pin hopes on Motor Mouth in International Trot 16 Site and date still unresolved for Holmes-Cooney title bout 16 Player briefings could delay re- sumption of baseball talks 17 George Vecsey suggests baseball call off the season 17 Miss Lauer's 67, Miss Whit- worth's 70 create Open tie at 139 17 Kathy Rinaldi becomes tennis professional at age 14 17 Clack, Giants' center, retires be- cause of knee problems 17 Wesley Walker in form, expects good year with Jets 18 Canadian five upsets U.S., 78-76, in World University Games 19 Features/Notes Notes on People 10 Going Out Guide 12 Saturday News Quiz 20 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: TO THE AIRPORT: GETTING THERE THE FASTEST
description: Summertime is travel time. Every day thousands of people head for the roads, the rails or the skies. People in a hurry to reach their destinations take a plane, naturally. But the trip to the airport is sometimes as long as the flight itself.

title: REMAINING VETERANS REPORT
description: The last eight veterans - Billy Taylor, Bo Matthews, Earnest Gray, Gary Shirk, Tom Mullady, Gordon King, Dave Jennings and Joe Danelo - reported to camp.

title: CLEMENCY GIVEN MAN CONVICTED ON DRUGS IN '72
description: A 36-year-old New York man who has been imprisoned since 1972, when he was convicted of possessing illegal drugs, was granted clemency yesterday by Governor Carey after a judge suggested that the prisoner might not have been guilty.

title: ARGENTINA SAYS ITS NUCLEAR PLANTS WILL NOT COMPLY WITH SAFEGUARDS
description: Argentina, disappointed by the policy announced last week by the Reagan Administration to limit the spread of nuclear arms, will not put its nuclear installations under international safeguards, the head of Argentina's nuclear programs said.

title: Two Questions in Title Bout
description: Some hard bargaining remains as to the time and place, but shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday morning, the essential agreement was reached for a Larry Holmes-Gerry Cooney match, perhaps the most anticipated heavyweight title bout since Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier met for the first time 10 years ago.

title: Kathryn Casey, 73, a Lawyer At Federal Trade Commission
description: Kathryn Casey, retired trial attorney for the Federal Trade Commission, died Tuesday at the New Rochelle Medical Center.

title: PALESTINIANS SAY A U.N. INITIATIVE BROUGHT ABOUT THE HALT IN CLASHES
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization announced today that it would abide by what it termed a cease-fire arranged by the United Nations.

title: What Ails the Adirondacks
description: New York's six-million-acre Adirondack Park is the largest in America, a wilderness with high mountains and sparkling rivers and lakes. The area is unusual also because it is dotted by a few towns and villages, mostly along its eastern edge, and because almost 60 percent of the land is privately owned. Unusual as well as essential is the fact that a state agency controls local zoning and private land use. The park is threatened at the moment from three directions.

title: 7 DEFENDANTS LOSE BID FOR NEW TRIAL ON ABSCAM COUNTS
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday rejected claims by seven Abscam defendants, including four former Congressmen, that they had been unfairly induced by overzealous Government agents to engage in criminal acts.

title: TALE OF AMERADA HESS: OIL CONCERN POSTS LOSS
description: Contrary to the views of many Americans, an oil company can lose money. Yesterday the Amerada Hess Corporation, ranked 19th among United States oil companies, reported that it had lost $53.7 million in the second quarter.

title: TRUCK DUTIES ARE DISPUTED
description: The United States told Japan, in talks ending here today, that it would not permit Japanese light trucks sold in the United States to again be classified as components, as they were until last August.

title: 'INCONTROVERTIBLE' K.G.B. LINKS TO TERROR
description: To the Editor:

title: CIVIL RIGHTS CHALLENGE
description: The National Urban League billed its 71st annual conference, which ended Wednesday in Washington, as one of the most important it ever held. Thousands of participants gathered around the theme of ''New Strategies for the

title: Honor for Wilder
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center has chosen the honoree for its next Spring Gala, to be held May 3, 1982. He is Billy Wilder, the director, screenwriter, and producer whose movies are known for their wit and sophistication.

title: CARO'S JOHNSON BIOGRAPHY TO RUN IN 5 PARTS IN ATLANTIC
description: In what its editor calls ''a commitment without precedent in our 124-year history,'' The Atlantic Monthly will run five installments - including two cover stories - of a biography of Lyndon B. Johnson. The book is ''The Years of Lyndon Johnson,'' the first of a projected three volumes by Robert A. Caro, who won the 1975 Pulitzer Prize for his biography of Robert Moses.

title: KATHY ARENDSEN SHOWS OFF SUPERIOR FASTBALL AT FESTIVAL
description: From his vantage point behind the wooden leftfield fence at Meachem Park, LeRoy Wegmann watched Kathy Arendsen overpower another batter with a rising fastball.

title: HOMESTAKE'S NET OFF 65.3%
description: The Homestake Mining Company, the nation's leading gold producer, said today that higher exploration costs and lower precious metals prices resulted in a 65.3 percent drop in its second-quarter earnings compared with a year ago.

title: FROM LONDON, ENVY OF OUR STRAPHANGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Payton Reports
description: The running back Walter Payton reported to the Chicago Bears' training camp today without a contract. He said he would not practice until he signed a new agreement.

title: Purged of Contempt
description: A follow-up: Robert A. Rabinof has given in and, having paid his former wife the back alimony he owed her, the 92-year-old Mr. Rabinof has been released from a Florida jail.

title: STUDY LINKS USE OF MARIJUANA TO A FLUCTUATION IN SEX DRIVE
description: Pharmacological researchers may have resolved the contradiction between scientific findings that marijuana decreases sexual drive and reports from users who maintain the drug works as an aphrodisiac.

title: Liebman Service Monday
description: A service for Max Liebman, the producer of NBC-TV's ''Your Show of Shows'' in the 1950's, who died Tuesday at the age of 78, will be held Monday at 1 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell's, 1076 Madison Avenue.

title: VOTING RIGHTS RULING UPSETS VIRGINIA'S POLITICIANS
description: To be black in Virginia's largest city is to feel, periodically, the thrust of Federal force. In the late 1940's, Norfolk was the first city to begin using the Federal bulldozer, knocking down block after block of decrepit housing in an enthusiasm for urban renewal that drove thousands of poor blacks out of the downtown area. Three decades later, a cluster of high-rise office buildings rises from the sea of vacant lots left by urban renewal.

title: SUBWAYS MUST KEEP RUNNING ROUND THE CLOCK
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICERS MAY BUY BRENTANO'S
description: Macmillan Inc., the diversified publishing company, has been negotiating the sale of the nationwide Brentano's Inc. bookstore chain, a subsidiary, to three executives of the chain, well-placed retailing industry sources reported yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An incorrect photograph was published with an article in Business Day yesterday about the promotion of Cees Bruynes, president of the North American Philips Corporation, to chief executive officer as well.

title: OPEC PLANS SEMINAR
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, will be the chairman of a seminar on energy and third world development here Nov.24-26, the OPEC News Agency said today. The seminar will be attended by ministers from member nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and participants from other governments, international organizations and major companies. The agenda will include OPEC's pricing policy options, energy issues in the developing world and the potential for energy self-reliance for oil-importing third world states, the agency said.

title: PROTEST CANCELS RUGBY MATCH
description: Demonstrators swarmed onto a rugby field today and forced the cancellation of the second match of South Africa's controversial tour of New Zealand.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The Red Brigades, who last night freed Renzo Sandrucci, an auto company executive held captive for 50 days, today released a second hostage.

title: No Headline
description: Associated Press Boy Beaten to Death Is Buried by Foster Parents Foster parents of Michael Walden attend graveside services in Danbury, Conn., for the 8-year-old boy, who was reportedly beaten to death July 19 in the Bronx by his natural mother, Jolie Ness, and Metin Arifoglu, man she lived with.

title: POLISH GAINS, SOVIET FEARS
description: In the aftermath of the Polish Communist Party's congress, the Soviet Union continues to confront a problem of historic proportions: what to do about cracks in the structure of Communist power in Poland that the

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: No Disciplinary Action In Bronco Drug Inquiry
description: Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, said today that a league inquiry on charges of drug use by three Denver Bronco players had been completed, and that no disciplinary action would be taken.

title: G. HEILEMAN OFFERS TO BUY SCHLITZ
description: Schlitz - the beer that made Milwaukee famous and then fell into disfavor with beer drinkers because someone changed its formula - may be swallowed by an upstart brewer that has become one of the fastest growing in the industry by selling little-known regional beers.

title: HISTORIC THEATERS' RESTORATION BECOMING COMMON
description: Members of the League of Historic American Theaters, meeting here this week to bring themselves up to date on the continuing fight to rescue old theaters, generally agreed that in their field, at least, there was no need for panic about the threat of Federal cutbacks in funds for restoring and maintaining abandoned theaters and opera houses.

title: U.S. SEES HOPE FOR WIDER PEACE
description: Israeli and Palestinian forces agreed separately today to a cease-fire across the Israeli-Lebanese frontier.

title: A Picnic for a Rockefeller, but Not for Vendors
description: When Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia threw a Fourth of July picnic at which 12,000 frankfurters were served, little did he know that by not letting the job out for public bid, he was letting the hot dogs get him into hot water with vendors.

title: Defense Rests in Trial Of Labor Bribery Case
description: Attorneys for Carlos Marcello rested their case today shortly after an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged that Mr. Marcello, said to be an underworld leader, was a specific target of a covert operation investigating labor bribery.

title: WAS AN ADVISER TO PRESIDENTS
description: Gabriel Hauge, retired chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and an adviser to President Dwight D. Eisenhower, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: Reagan and Muldoon Confer
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Robert D. Muldoon of New Zealand conferred today on security in the Pacific and on relations between their countries. Both leaders said that their meeting, the first between the two men, was fruitful. Mr. Muldoon said he had given ''no indication'' to Mr. Reagan that New Zealand could take part in a multinational peacekeeping force in Sinai after Israel withdraws next April under its peace treaty with Egypt.

title: A Doleful Note
description: It's beginning to appear that the pianist Abbey Simon may be making a minor career out of playing in churches, and he likes it, on the whole, although an occasional problem crops up.

title: 7 IN CONGRESS CONVICTED
description: Of the 16 persons convicted on corruption charges so far as a result of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam operation of 1978 and 1979, one was a United States Senator and six were members of the House of Representatives.

title: ISRAEL'S FOREIGN POLICY
description: DESTINATION PEACE. Three Decades of Israeli Foreign Policy. By Gideon Ra- fael. 394 pages. Stein & Day. $16.95.

title: LET'S BUILD WESTWAY
description: .8,2The debate on Westway is in the 11th hour. The approval of New York City for the purchase of the underwater land on which the Westway landfill would rest is required by Aug. 3 in order to fall within the Federal fiscal year. If Westway dies, it will be an enormous tragedy for this city and for New York State.

title: Death in the Afternoon
description: The Washington Star, so went the conventional praise, was the best afternoon daily in the United States. The praise was deserved, but also helps to account for its impending death. Nearly all afternoon papers have bucked an ill wind that has blown journalism little good. Last year 17 afternoon papers ceased publication, victims of the TV evening news, changed reader habits and declining advertising. But knowing why doesn't diminish the loss.

title: Second Prosecutor Planning Inquiry on Gov. Brown Aides
description: District Attorney Herb Jackson said today that he would investigate possible criminal conduct in the alleged cover-up of political use of a state computer by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s office.

title: EUROPE'S ROYALTY: BIT THREADBARE BUT STILL STRONG
description: The yearly maintenance charges on Queen Elizabeth's royal yacht cost the British people more than the entire 1981 budget for the Casa Real, the royal household of Spain. The operating expenses of the King of Sweden are even less. And a few years ago, Crown Prince Harald of Norway had to ask for an advance on his state allotment to repair the roof on his house.

title: A SKIRMISH IN ONGOING SUGAR WAR
description: The latest chapter in the continuing argument over the place of sugar in the American diet seems to offer no more reliable guidelines to consumers now than it did about 10 years ago,when the controversy began to gain momentum.

title: GEORGES BANK START BY EXXON
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. drove a steel shaft into the ocean floor off the coast of New England and became the first company to start exploratory drilling for oil and gas in the Georges Bank fishing grounds.

title: WHAT BUSINESSMEN WANT FOR SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: The owners of an Argentine cargo plane that disappeared six days ago on a flight from Iran said today that the aircraft was forced to fly into Soviet airspace. But Jose Patetta, general manager of Transportes Aereos Rioplatenses, could offer no clues as to what happened to the plane after it entered Soviet airspace.

title: AT A CAMP WITH NUNS
description: In my entire childhood, I spent only one summer at camp. Eighteen years ago, I went to Mattituck, a small town of potato fields on Long Island's North Fork, to Camp Immaculata, run by nuns of some order whose name I have forgotten. It was not an exceedingly wealthy camp, although it was not poor either. The layout was simple: 10 cabins, painted an identical white with green shutters. Each cabin was given the name of a bird. I was in the Wrens; my sister Lisa, four years older, was in the Blue Jays. The trees surrounding our cabins blocked out the sun, which was fine with me.

title: CAREY SIGNS BILL THAT INCREASES AID FOR TUITION
description: Governor Carey has signed a bill to increase the amount of money available under the state's Tuition Assistance Program. The new law provides for increases in both the maximim award, available to the poorest students, and the minimum award, which goes to students from middle-income households.

title: 3 East African Heads of State Call for Regional Cooperation
description: The Presidents of Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania, whose relations soured after the collapse of the East African Community, met in Nairobi today and agreed to work for cooperation in the region.

title: DENNISON OFFERS OFREX $48 MILLION
description: The Dennison Manufacturing Company of Waltham, Mass., said that it had agreed to acquire the Ofrex Group, a British maker and distributor of stationery and industrial products, for $48 million, paying 130 pence, or about $2.40, a share.

title: THE GLITTER JACKET
description: Evening clothes are among the sure successes of the coming fall fashion season, spurred by Nancy Reagan's penchant for parties and her obvious pleasure in dressing up, many designers believe.

title: CAREY AIDES NOW BACK WESTWAY BONDING PLAN
description: Aides to Governor Carey said for the first time yesterday that they were prepared to go along with Mayor Koch's proposal for a new state authority to raise money to cover unanticipated costs of the $1.7 billion Westway highway project.

title: Butz Released 5 Days Early
description: Earl Butz, former Secretary of Agriculture, was released from a Federal prison today after serving 25 days of a 30-day sentence for tax evasion. Officials at the Metropolitan Correctional Center said Mr. Butz was released released five days early because of good behavior. Mr. Butz, 72 years old, pleaded guilty May 22 to a charge of fraudulently understating his 1978 income by $148,114.

title: CALIFORNIA ASKING HIGH COURT TO BAN STATES' CURBS ON FRUIT
description: As five Southern states dropped their blockades of California fruits and vegetables in the face of orders from lower courts, California continued efforts today to get the United States Supreme Court to forestall new quarantines.

title: Menace Of the Random
description: Two men wielding machetes chased a third down a Manhattan street one evening recently and hacked him to death at a sidewalk cafe in front of a large audience of diners.

title: LAWSUITS ON TRANSIT FOR CITY'S DISABLED DISMISSED BY JUDGE
description: A Federal judge dismissed a group of lawsuits yesterday that sought to compel New York City to carry out an extensive program to make mass-transit facilities fully available to handicapped persons.

title: Argentines Press Soviet On Collision of Planes
description: Argentine diplomats in Moscow said today that they were still pressing Soviet officials for a full explanation of the weekend collision of an Argentine and a Soviet plane in the Soviet Republic of Armenia.

title: MURDER SUSPECT IN VILLAGE FOUND NOT RESPONSIBLE
description: A jury last night found Ronald K. Crumpley ''not responsible by reason of mental disease or defect'' in the murders of two men and the attempted murders of seven others on Nov. 19, 1980, at two Greenwich Village sites frequented by homosexuals.

title: Dior Owner Is Arrested
description: Jean-Pierre Willot, one of four French brothers who own the Christian Dior group, was arrested today and charged with misuse of the assets of Dior and of the brothers' Paris department store, La Belle Jardiniere.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RULING BY FEDERAL JUDGE UPHOLDING THE ABSCAM CONVICTIONS
description: Following are excerpts from the ruling by District Judge George C. Pratt in which he upheld the convictions of seven Abscam defendants: Entrapment as a Matter of Law

title: 4 Convicted of Contempt For Trying to Stop Grain
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today found four Missouri farmers guilty of civil contempt of court for trying to block removal of grain last week from a bankrupt elevator at New Madrid, Mo.

title: Canada Upsets U.S. Five
description: Jay Triano and Stu Granger combined for 40 points tonight as Canada posted its first international basketball victory over the United States, 78-76, at the World University Games.

title: Emily Tucker Is Wed To Harry W. Fowler
description: The marriage of Emily O'Connor Tucker of Katonah, N.Y., widow of Carll Tucker Jr., to Harry Winthrop Fowler, chairman of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York, took place at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday.

title: A.T.& T. TUG OF WAR
description: Even though the Senate Commerce Committee has cleared for floor action a bill to deregulate much of the telephone industry and give new operating room to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Judiciary Committee is considering possible amendments to keep some restraints on Bell.

title: ONE ORDEAL AMONG HUNDREDS ENDS AT ARLINGTON
description: Today, more than 14 years after he was listed as missing in action over North Vietnam, Comdr. Ronald W. Dodge of the Navy was buried in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 20.50 20.50 11.25 DISCOUNT RATES* 14.00 14.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 18.75 20.05 8.76 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.75 15.40 8.05 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.60 15.20 8.10 7-YR. TREASURY NOTES 14.23 14.73 10.19 30-YR. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Contents
description: July 26, 1981 NONFICTION COVERING ISLAM: How the Media and the Experts Determine How We See the Rest of tha World. By Edward W. Said. 7 THE DAY THEY STOLE THE MONA LISA.

title: PARENTS' GUIDE TO VISITING DAY AT CAMP
description: THERE is a short but special season of the year that fits neatly between the beginning of July and the end of August. It is the time when parents of children away at summer camp have finally adjusted to tiny loads of laundry, sinfully small grocery bills and plenty of peace and quiet, and it precedes the period when they start dashing off to concert halls, R-rated movies, getaway weekends for two and other ''adult'' activities - before the kids come home.

title: Business Conditions; OPEC'S NO.1 TRADER
description: Aggressive marketing by America's trading rivals as well as OPEC's efforts to diversify its sources of supply have pushed the United States out of first place as the world's leading exporter to member nations of the oil cartel, according to statistics compiled by the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development. And developments on foreign exchange markets cast doubt on when, if ever, America will regain the lead.

title: NEW JERSEY MAN OVERPOWERS WOULD-BE THIEF IN APARTMENT
description: After Timothy Blake returned from an hourlong jog, he found his possessions stacked by the door of his apartment and a would-be thief munching on a chicken leg, authorities said today.

title: HITLER'S RUSSIAN BLUNDER
description: The confusion of ''Soviet Union'' with ''Russia'' contributes to obscuring a key point in the German-Soviet war: namely, why so many Balts, Ukrainians, Caucasians and others refused to fight for Mother Russia. This was because, for most of these peoples, Russia was not their ''mother'' but rather their scourge. BOHDAN WYTWYCKY

title: Flawed System Is No Defense
description: To the Sports Editor: The tongue-lashing that Judge Phillip Baiamonte administered to big-time college sport before sentencing Norm Ellenberger was long overdue. But, as welcome as Judge Baiamonte's remarks may be, one should realize that they don't do much to bring justice to bear on the situation the judge deplores.

title: 52 FOOD OUTLETS CITED FOR HEALTH VIOLATIONS
description: Fifty-two food establishments have been found to be in violation of New York City's health code, the Health Department reported. It also named two establishments that were reopened after a final reinspection, and one that was closed. VIOLATIONS Bloomsday Cafe, 2259 Broadway. Vasilos Salouros, 40 Peck Slip. Aldo's Ristorante, 332 E. 86th St. Cibao Restaurant, 22 W. 24th St. Molfetas Restaurant, 307 W. 47th St. Yum-Yum Hot Dog Inc., 436 W. 52d St. Delancey St. Deli Restaurant, 1162 1st Ave. Rosinbar Rivera & Rudolfo Hernandez, 975 10th Ave. Munchie's Shoppe, 620 Castle Hill Ave., Bronx. B & W Tavern, 401 E. Tremont Ave., Bronx. Old Time Bar, 1151 E. Tremont Ave., Bronx. La Cabana Fried Chicken, 1566 Watson Ave., Bronx. Mon Wah Restaurant, 4126 White Plains Rd., Bronx. Mario's Pizzeria, 692 E. 187th St. Bronx. Slimen Luncheonette, 105 Brighton Beach Ave., Brooklyn. Happy Health Food, 702 Brighton Beach Ave., Brooklyn. Hustle Inn, 2836 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. Lantern Lounge, 1150 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Hank's Place, 2574 Fulton St., Brooklyn. Flambo Bar, 140 Neptune Ave., Brooklyn. Pak Lee Chinese Kitchen, 2309 Stillwell Ave., Brooklyn. Cuckoo Mike's Restaurant, 888 5th Ave., Brooklyn. ABC Deli & Grocery, 58-04 8th Ave., Brooklyn.

title: 4 NEARBY FESTIVALS WORTH VISITING
description: THE summer scene in Westchester is brimming with cultural happenings. For those who would like to venture a little beyond the county borders, though, at least four nearby festivals offer special delights of their own.

title: MISS WHITWORTH SHOOTS A 71-210, TAKES SOLE LEAD
description: Kathy Whitworth, the 41-year-old Texan who has 81 professional golf victories but not a single United States Open championship, took sole possession of first place in the third round of the 36th annual Women's Open championship today at six-under-par 210.

title: Barbara Benner, David G. Kaytes Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur James Sullivan Jr. of Clifton, N.J., have announced the enagagement of Mrs. Sullivan's daughter, Barbara Anne Benner, to David George Kaytes, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Elias Kaytes of Franklin Lakes, N.J. A Sept. 26 wedding is planned at St. James Episcopal Church in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Dining Out; PASSABLE FARE AT DINNER THEATERS
description: WHEN it comes to dinner theaters, the play, not the food, is in the spotlight and is what attracts patrons in the first place. At least that is our conclusion after evenings spent at two Fairfield County dinner theaters.

title: Footnotes; FOOTNOTES
description: The one new hardcover fiction best seller, ''Trade Wind,'' has been blowing off-stage for a few weeks. Two new nonfiction titles, ''The Hite Report on Male Sexuality'' and ''The Cinderella Complex,'' present, respectively, data on the true nature of men (somewhat polymorphous) and a theory of the true nature of women (somewhat oldfashioned).

title: Headliners; OPEN SEASON, OPEN MARKET
description: It's enough to set any card-carrying realtor's teeth gnashing. Earlier this year, when Carilyn and John Redman put their home in the Virginia suburbs of Washington, D.C., on the market, high interest rates kept prospective buyers at bay.

title: THE MAKING OF THEODORE ROOSEVELT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Geoffrey C. Ward is the editor of American Heritage magazine. MORNINGS ON HORSEBACK By David McCullough. Illustrated. 445 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $17.95. By GEOFFREY C. WARD

title: NORTH CASTLE'S ALARM LAW IN DISPUTE
description: ARMONK ANEW local law regulating burglar and fire alarms in the town of North Castle - a northern Westchester municipality with many reasonably affluent communities - is causing some alarms of its own among residents.

title: POWELL LIFTS ALABAMA STAY AND 222 PRISONERS GO FREE
description: Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell of the United States Supreme Court today lifted a temporary stay blocking release of prisoners in the Alabama state system to end overcrowding, and 222 inmates stepped to freedom.

title: IONA
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Business; ANOTHER ONSLAUGHT IN BEER
description: Here comes Miller again. In the hotly competitive world of beer, Anheuser-Busch, the brewing industry's leader, has managed to hold its lead against Miller's remarkable surge. One Bud advantage has been its broader product line, most notably, Michelob, its entry at the upper or ''superpremium'' end, which accounts for about 7 percent of all beer sold.

title: Speaking Personally; AN ENORMOUS MAZE WITH NO READY EXIT
description: THE first Wednesday of the month comes too soon, I thought as I climbed the stairs of the Municipal Building. I always felt sick when it was my day to report to the local Welfare Office.

title: WILFRED BURCHETT
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S A SPECIAL WORLD AT THE BEACH
description: 13HUNTINGTON ITS incredible sunsets, isolation and raw beauty make Hobart Beach, commonly called ''Sand City,'' the most magnificent town beach in Huntington, and possibly the Island, according to people who frequent it.

title: CABLEVISION GAINS ON ISLAND AND OFF
description: WOODBURY FLUSHED with success after having obtained one of the most soughtafter cable television franchises in the nation, covering 10 towns in Fairfield County in Connecticut, Cablevision is planning to nearly triple operations on the Island in the next few years.

title: LONG ISLAND'S NORTH FORK FRETS OVER NEW POPULARITY
description: In the last few months, demand for land has been rising rapidly along with prices here on the North Fork, one of the twin prongs splitting off from Long Island's wide midsection.

title: UNDERWATER CAMERA
description: Scuba divers and snorkeling enthusiasts who have wished for a selfcontained underwater camera that did not cost as much as the widely accepted Nikonos have until now been limited to two choices: buying or improvising a special housing for their existing camera, or buying an ''all-weather'' amphibious camera such as Minolta's Weathermatic 110. Unfortunately, this camera is really not a diver's camera since underwater depths are limited to about 15 feet at most.

title: RESTRICTIONS URGED NEAR GREAT SWAMP
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP IN WHAT may be one of the most sweeping moves to curtail the development of ecologically sensitive land in New Jersey, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has recommended constraining the development of several thousand acres surrounding the Great Swamp Natural Wildlife Refuge.

title: MALKIEL MATH
description: To the Business Editor:

title: A PROPER U.S. DECISION TO BOLSTER PAKISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Die of Food Poisoning
description: Five elderly residents of a nursing home died within six days ending Wednesday and 48 suffered food poisoning in the first incident of fatal salmonella illness reported in Minnesota in five years. The five who died were women from 79 to 103 yeaars old. They were residents of the Greeley Health Care Center.

title: UNION TESTING CASINO AGENCY'S REGULATORY POWERS
description: Atlantic City's largest and fastestgrowing union challenged today the constitutionality of legislation that requires the Casino Control Commission to regulate unions representing casino employees.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; MYSTERY OF LIFE IN LOUISIANA
description: It's all a matter of interpretation. Last week, Gov. David C. Treen of Louisiana signed into law a measure that means state public schools either must or may teach that mankind's creation could have come about through divine intervention.

title: T. J. Dembinski Weds Anne Corley Whitmire
description: Anne Corley Whitmire and Thomas John Dembinski, 1979 graduates of the College of William and Mary, were married in the Bethlehem Chapel of the National Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul) in Washington yesterday.

title: Pacific Nine Triumphs
description: The Pacific League beat the Central League, 5-3, today in the first game of the Japan All-Star baseball series. Jim Lyttle, a former major leaguer, homered for the losers. A crowd of 40,049 saw the game in Osaka Koshien Stadium.

title: LAVISH MANSION, SPLENDID ENTREES
description: HIDDEN among the trees of a large estate surrounded by the reservoirs of Carmel is Dreamwold, a remarkable restaurant owned and meticulously operated by Jeanne and Peter Mazuryk. Only for the last 18 years a restaurant, the house reminds one of San Simeon, in miniature and in a lower key. A Hollywood entrepreneur, whose name is less memorable than his house, conceived and produced the lavish mansion in the 1920's. Since then, the Mazuryks have added their own international collections and warm welcome as one enters and threads the small corridors and precious anterooms to the terrace, the Bombay Lounge or the Mediterranean Room, depending upon weather and season.

title: LIVING WITH ENEMIES
HOW TO GROW EDELWEISS WITHOUT GOING TO SWITZERLAND
description: The days of plant hunting expeditions are not over, but different. The time when men like Frank Kingdon-Ward, E.H. ''Chinese'' Wilson and Reginald Farrer traveled to the ends of the earth, undergoing many hardships to bring back exotic plants, have changed.

title: LOOTING THE MEANS OF PRODUCTION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Seymour Melman, professor of industrial engineering at Columbia University and national co-chairman of the peace organization SANE, is author of "The Permanent War Economy" and is writing a book, "Profits Without Production." ---------

title: Clare Kuser Wed To A.Marc Fox, a Student
description: Clare McHugh Kuser, daughter of Mrs. Ellen McHugh Kuser of Princeton, N.J., and R. George Kuser Jr. of New York and Troy, Ohio, was married yesterday to A. Marc Fox, son of Mrs. Percival M. Fox of Paget$ Bermuda, formerly of Montreal, afd the late Mr. Fox. Superior Court Judge Richard J.S. Barlow Jr. of Trenton, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: COMMEMORATIVE PAIR MARKD ROYAL WEDDING
description: When Charles Philip Arthur George, the Prince of Wales, takes Lady Diana Spencer as his wife this Wednesday, it will be the first time in more than 300 years an Englishwoman is marrying an heir to the British throne.

title: Moscow Renews Offer On Nuclear Missiles
description: Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister, renewed an offer today to reduce the number of nuclear missiles targeted on Western Europe if the West dropped plans to deploy missiles there aimed at the Soviet Union.

title: RULES ON RADIOACTIVE SHIPMENTS SCORED
description: WASHINGTON FOUR years ago, the New Jersey Legislature enacted measures designed to reduce the risks associated with the truck transportation of radioactive material.

title: BY ONE MEASURE, MADRID COOLS DOWN
description: In a nation that was scared stiff in the winter, the institutionalized rites of the Western European summer are a soothing balm. As the mercury climbs into the high 90's, frazzled politicians, disgruntled generals and even, it seems, Basque terrorists turn from their schemes and dark plots to the logistics of getting to the beach.

title: On Language; VOICE IMPRINTS
description: A student asks her teacher, ''Why should I read? I can get all I need to know by listening.'' Over a period of slightly more than 100 years, we have gone from voice to print and back again. We were gossipers, we became readers, and now we are back, if not all the way to gossiping, at least to watching and listening as much as we read.

title: Investing; WHY MUNIS ARE HITTING STUNNING HIGHS
description: TAX-EXEMPT bonds - those issued by thousands of local governments and their authorities - are being widely touted as the most attractive investment for individuals in today's bond market. While yields on Treasury and corporate bonds remain slightly below their historic highs, new tax-exempt yields are breaking records.

title: LIKE IT OR NOT, DUBLIN IS CAUGHT BY CROSSFIRE
description: Even television viewers accustomed to nightly horror reports from Northern Ireland were shaken last week by film showing 13-year-old Denis Thompson weeping beside his mother's grave. She was killed five years ago by an Irish Republican Army bomb in a boutique in Ballymena. ''Yvonne would have been 31 years old today,'' said the boy's anguished grandfather, Nathaniel. ''It is ridiculous that so much has been said about the hunger strike when the people who are the innocent victims are forgotten.''

title: The Region in Summary; THE NEW JERSEY TV CONCESSION
description: Moving Channel 9 across the Hudson may not be much of a loss for New York, but it will amount to a long-cherished goal for New Jersey - a VHF television station to call its own.

title: Israel Is Said to Supply U.S. Arms to Iranians
description: The Argentine cargo plane that crashed last week over the Soviet Union was returning from the third of a dozen scheduled trips in which Israel was supplying American-made tank parts and ammunition to Iran, it was reported today.

title: Bridge
description: One of the world's most famous clubs - the Mayfair - reopens today in new quarters. The club, which has long been on or near 57th Street, has moved south to the Gramercy Park Hotel, 2 Lexington Avenue, near 21st Street.

title: FATHERS AND DAUGHTERS
description: LOST AND FOUND By Julian Gloag. 206 pp. New York: The Linden Press. $10.95. THE FATE OF MARY ROSE By Caroline Blackwood. 208 pp. New York: Summit Books. $11.95. By EDITH MILTON

title: A U.S. JUDGE DISMISSES ONEIDAS' LAND CLAIM
description: A suit brought by Oneida Indians claiming 5 million acres of land in upstate New York has been dismissed by a Federal judge as lacking ''sufficient legal basis.''

title: RACING NEAR END AT BRIDGEHAMPTON
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON THE spectacular view from the bleachers at the Bridgehampton Raceway explains why this race track's days are numbered. The 2.85-mile racing circuit, which in its heyday attracted some of road racing's greatest drivers, is situated on 520 acres of prime Hamptons real estate that has just been sold for $3 million.

title: COOPER-HEWITT BECOMES A BOWER OF GREENERY
description: Of all life's gentle pleasures few are so universally understood and shared as the joy of a summer garden, whether its centerpiece is a Persian watercourse, a tangle of Elizabethan flowers and herbs, a stately avenue of formal French trees or the patterns of smooth white Japanese stones. So for the summer season, the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, on Fifth Avenue and 91st Street, has, in a sense, brought the outdoors inside with an exhibition called ''Gardens of Delight.''

title: N.J. SQUARES OFF WITH INSURERS
description: Although sessions of the New Jersey Republican Platform Committee are usually parochial affairs, David R. Leonard, associate counsel for the Allstate Insurance Company, traveled all the way from Northbrook, Ill. to Liberty State Park in Jersey City last week just to attend one.

title: FINNEY COMES BACK TO FILM
description: English critics regularly cite Albert Finney as one of the great actors of his generation, but American audiences have not had many opportunities to judge for themselves. We may have read about his stage triumphs in London, but only a couple of them have ever made it across the Atlantic. And his movie roles have been few and far between. In the 20 years since his electrifying debut in ''Saturday Night and Sunday Morning,'' he has made only a handful of films, including ''Tom Jones,'' ''Two for the Road,'' ''Scrooge'' and ''Gumshoe.'' His last screen appearance was in ''Murder on the Orient Express,'' almost seven years ago.

title: PENTAGON PAPERS, A DECADE LATER
description: Floyd Abrams is to be complimented for his fine piece,''The Pentagon Papers a Decade Later'' (June 7).

title: Convict Benefits
description: After newspaper articles had disclosed that many imprisoned criminals were receiving monthly Social Security benefits - including David Berkowitz, the so-called Son of Sam killer in New York - President Jimmy Carter last October signed into law legislation restricting the benefits.

title: IS THE CITY BUILDING ITS TAX BASE OR ERODING IT?
description: Five years ago, as Fortune 500 companies began complaining that it was too expensive to build new, larger corporate headquarters in New York City and big construction projects began to taper off, visions of a ghost town Manhattan began to flicker in the eyes of city officials.

title: Hughes Under the Gun, Inheriting Center Position
description: Whether Jim Clack was pushed into retirement or went there voluntarally yesterday, one thing remains certain for the Giants: The man who stepped in at center is Ernie Hughes, who has never played that position in a game.

title: EFFORTS TO INTENSIFY TO CUT AUTO DEATHS
description: WORRIED about the possiblity that Suffolk County this year will again lead New York State in the number of auto-accident fatalities, police and safety officials in the county are stepping up their efforts to make local roads safe for drivers, passengers and pedestrians. Nassau officials, concerned with their county's rate, are doing the same thing.

title: MARY LAMB AND MR. WRONG
description: OTHER PEOPLE A Mystery Story. By Martin Amis. 224 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95. By EVAN HUNTER

title: Outlawing Pistols
description: When the Board of Village Trustees in Morton Grove, Ill., voted last June 8 to ban both the sale and individual possession of handguns, officials of the Chicago suburb said they expected a constitutional battle with the National Rifle Association.

title: Politics; THE DEBATE ISSUES ALSO ARE DEBATABLE
description: BEFORE there can be debates during a campaign for governor, there must be a protracted debate about where, when and how to conduct them. The posturing of the candidates, like boxers at a weigh-in, allows the contenders to strike belligerent poses without wasting any campaign money or energy while the voters are vacationing.

title: Train Derails, Families Flee
description: A Missouri Pacific freight train ran off the tracks today and carbolic acid leaking from a derailed car forced several familes to flee their homes. Eight more cars containing liquid propane were derailed, but the police said there appeared to be no danger of the vapor escaping.

title: PHEROMONES
description: To the Business Editor: ''A Moth-Eaten Tale of Money, Sex and Nature's Way'' (June 21) implied that the pheromone used in the Bag-A-Bug Japanese beetle trap was supplied by the Health-Chem Corporation.

title: Woman Racer Qualifies
description: Brenda Jones drove Miss KYYX three laps on the Columbia River today to qualify for tomorrow's Columbia Cup regatta, becoming the first woman to race on the unlimited hydroplane circuit. Fifteen boats qualified for the cup's $32,500 top prize. Miss Jones, 23 years old, qualified for the race by safely completing three consecutive laps.

title: NANCY STANLEY TO WED
description: Mr. Robert C. Stanley Jr. of Red Bank, N.J., and Mrs. Nancy Knothe Stanley of Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Kathryn Stanley, to Brehon Somervell Griswold, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Griswold of Yeamans Hall, S.C., formerly of New York. A September wedding is planned at St. George's by the River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J. Miss Stanley is with the marketing department of Computervisions Corporation in Bedford, Mass. Her fiance is with the sales department of Georgia Pacific Corporation in Wilmington, Mass.

title: Washington; HOW OLD RED ENDED THE STRIKE
description: A baseball fable: The baseball strike had gone on for 43 days but was finally settled by a bleacher bum, who had a simple idea. Maybe two ideas. First, he thought the strike was taking the fun out of the summer for too many people and that nobody had the right to do that. And second, that baseball was too important to be left to the owners and the players.

title: New Jersey Housing; NEW SCHOOL IS 'HOME' TO DISABLED YOUNG
description: PARAMUS WHEN Lauren Valenta was 2 years old, doctors advised her parents that she had cerebral palsy and should be institutionalized because, as her mother recalled, there was ''nothing for her.'' Undaunted, the family moved from Sussex County to Bergen County largely because the latter had a program for such handicapped youngsters.

title: A SOVIET FILMMAKER'S PLIGHT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Grenier is the film critic for Commentary. By RICHARD GRENIER

title: Chandler Retains His Title
description: Jeff Chandler, finally escaping the clutching grasp of Julian Solis, successfully defended his World Boxing Association bantamweight title for the third time by scoring a knockout in the seventh round today.

title: In Flooding in Sichuan
description: In the first Government confirmation of casualty figures, the New China News Agency said today that this month's floods in Sichuan Province left 753 dead, 558 missing, 28,140 injured and 1.5 million homeless. It was the worst flooding since 1949, the agency said.

title: INDEX
description: International Soviet silences domestic critics of psychiatric abuses 3 Around the World 4 Church of England to let some divorced people remarry 6 British press chides Nancy Reagan on protocol 7 Soviet plan to convert utilities to use more oil faces problems 8 U.N. plans conference in Nairobi on new energy sources 9 Rajai appears headed for huge victory in Iranian election 10 U.S. promoter arranging a rodeo exchange with China 11 Indians fight Quebec on fishing rights 13 United Nations reports a Palestinian violation of cease-fire 15 Government/Politics Senator's objections to Casey called "personal" 16 Marines preparing five-year expansion plan 17 Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley may run for Governor 20 Federal court bars an inquiry on conservative newsletter 22 State Comptroller has $120,000 in surplus campaign funds 28 Casino employees challenge Jersey's right to regulate 32 Governor Carey distributes largesse while campaigning 39 General Around the Nation 18 Trolley line to Tijuana opens in San Diego 18 Washington, D.C., fighting chronic fiscal crisis 18 Milwaukee Police Chief under fire from black community 21 Ex-Jersey Abscam prosecutor replies to judge's criticism 24 An ex-transit officer faces mental tests in the slayings of two men 25 Fire-fighters demonstrate rescue techniques 29 Number of violent crimes reported in the city down in May 30 $25 penalty helps meter readers gain entry to homes 35 Fresh Air Fund hosts broaden family ties 38 Health/Science E.P.A. study tells of indoor air pollution woes 19 Religion Homosexuals' church asks to join National Council of Churches 34 Arts/Entertainment The SRO Trio, pop singers 42 Janis Ian is joined by a rock trio 42 Summer gardens at the Cooper-Hewitt 42 Tantric ritual music and dance presented 42 Jessye Norman, the soprano, at the Mostly Mozart Festival 42 Style Conference studies violence in the family 43 Helping the young learn law 43

title: MOSCOW SILENCING PSYCHIATRY CRITICS
description: With the conviction this week of Feliks Serebrov, a key figure in efforts to document Soviet use of psychiatric hospitals to punish political offenders, the authorities here have completed a series of prosecutions aimed at silencing domestic criticism of a practice that Moscow seems particularly keen to conceal.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF NATURE ON CAPE COD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ELLSWORTH E. ROSEN is a public relations executive in Boston with a summer cottage in South Wellfleet. -------

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; TIME AND MONEY ARE NOT ENOUGH TO SAVE THE STAR
description: It faced problems common to many afternoon newspapers - declining circulation, weak advertising, evening television, rush-hour traffic and a morning paper nearly twice its size. It faced some less common ones as well - mice in the newsroom, muggers in the parking lot and a computer system with the unfortunate habit of breaking down during national emergencies. When it came to news, though, The Washington Star usually managed to hold its own with The Washington Post and sometimes even beat its prosperous rival to a big story. Such was the case last week when the 128-year-old daily, in perhaps its final front-page exclusive, bannered the news of its own demise. Time - and Time Inc.'s money - had simply run out.

title: 'HARRY CHAPIN WAS A CITIZEN-ARTIST'
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR THE U.S. EMBASSY IN MOSCOW: GEORGIA BRICKS
description: A brick is not just a brick, especially when 1.4 million of them are needed for the new United States Embassy in Moscow. American experts carefully searched many countries for just the right brick to serve as a symbol of this nation in a foreign land, and in January they finally made their decision.

title: FRENCH HORSES 1,2 IN INTERNATIONAL TROT
description: The French scored a 1, 2 sweep tonight of the 23d Roosevelt International Trot. Ideal du Gazeau, freshened by a vacation on the Normandy seacoast, won by a neck from Jorky in the prestigious $250,000 race.

title: Art; ART OF 45 'CLASSIC AMERICANS' AT STAMFORD
description: THE Stamford Museum and Nature Center has on view through Sept. 7 an exhibition titled ''Classic Americans.'' The show consists of the paintings, drawings and sculptures of 45 artists, most represented by a single work, that Robert Metzger, its curator, has selected as representing the best of the generation of artists who became known in the first half of the century.

title: Basenji Is Selected Best of 1,025 Dogs
description: Robert House's and Robert Harris's Basenji, Ch. Kstar's Adonis of Anubis, was named best of 1,025 dogs at the 81st show of the Providence County Kennel Club today.

title: DATSUN'S 280ZX, A TURBO TO LOVE
description: THE number of cars, trucks and other conveyances on my wish list has gone up again. In fact, the list seems to be getting out of hand, and I still haven't even acquired the '56 Ford pickup that started it all. There's never been any real reason to buy that ancient truck, affordable though it might be, but the latest item is a steed of different stripe. It is a 1981 1/2 Datsun 280ZX Turbo, and it is one of the sweetest bits of horsepower to gallop down the road in a long, long time.

title: MISS ASHFORD, SANFORD TAKE 100-METER SPRINTS AT FESTIVAL
description: In 1979 she took the track world and herself by surprise. Now Evelyn Ashford knows she can run fast. Earlier in the week, Miss Ashford set an American record in the 100-meter dash with the time of 10.90 seconds at a meet in Colorado Springs. Today during the National Sports Festival, the country's No. 1 women's sprinter ran a wind-aided 11.01 in winning on a newlysurfaced synthetic track that felt more like a soft cushion than a running surface.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are the most important number in the Middle East equation.'' - Yasir Arafat (14:3)

title: Connecticut Housing; UNLOCKING THE KEY TO POPULARITY
description: ANYONE who has ever owned a home relatively close to the water knows that this time of year brings forth house guests as predictably as in the old days the warm weather heralded the arrival of the neighborhood ice cream truck.

title: ALL-AMERICAN HOT DOGS
description: Russell Baker insists that ''the great American hot dog'' has gone the way of the two-pants suit, Mom's apple pie and the Brooklyn Dodgers (''Myth of the Hot Dog,'' July 5).

title: APPEALING FARE SERVED BY THE SEA
description: DESPITE a rather unlikely location in the Sun Haven Motel in Napeague, halfway between Amagansett and Montauk, Le Cocobeach Cafe is one of the better restaurants to make its debut in the Hamptons this season. Come to think of it, the name is also unlikely. Cocoa Beach is more than a thousand of miles away in Florida. But in its informality, the place is definitely beachfront.

title: APPRECIATING 'SCHEMES' INSIDE
description: HEMPSTEAD ONE of the particular characteristics of artists' installations - so called because they are conceived for and constructed in specific interior spaces - is their transitory nature. An installation exists, by definition, in relation to a site that is usually only temporarily available, and although it may be made of durable materials, the assumption is that it will soon be removed from the studio, gallery or other location that houses it.

title: WHERE ILLEGALITY LIES
description: To the Editor:

title: HOBOKEN: WRINKLES IN THE FACELIFT
description: HOBOKEN THE Hoboken renaissance is nowhere more apparent than on that section of Washington Street between Fifth and Sixth Streets. On one side of Washington Street, Hoboken's main thoroughfare, Lesley's Delicacies, a new cafe, features quiches, espresso and chocolate mousse. A few doors down, on the other side of Washington Street, a combination book store, art gallery and cafe is expected to open shortly.

title: An Ageless Art
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE TAKING STOCK IN AMERICA
description: O NCE again, the Japanese are coming, and on Wall Street, it is already being called ''the friendly invasion.'' This time, instead of invading American consumer markets with their Toyotas, Sonys and Panasonics, the Japanese are bringing their money. In increasing numbers, they are coming to buy stocks on Wall Street and to wheel and deal in America's commodities pits.

title: 3-1 Love Sign First In Sheepshead Bay
description: Last year Love Sign won five stakes in New York, including the Test, Alabama and Beldame, and was rated only a step or two behind Genuine Risk and Bold 'n Determined in the 3-year-old filly division. This year she had been without a victory in six starts.

title: The World in Summary; COUNT OUT KOLA, SAYS THE SOVIET
description: In the thermo-cold nuclear exchange, image and mirror image sometimes revolve so fast that it is difficult to tell which face is forward, or why. So it was last week in the matter of the proposed nuclear-free zone for Northern Europe, an idea talked about in Scandinavia for years and promoted by the Kremlin again recently.

title: 2 FUNDS EYE PARKS RENEWAL
description: HARTFORD WITH $325 million in commercial office construction under way and more in prospect, business and civic leaders here are beginning to think about giving two of the city's most important public spaces a much-needed facelift.

title: Suzuki Returns to Japan
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan returned here today after attending the summit meeting of seven leaders from industrialized nations in Ottawa this week.

title: JODY BLATT PLANS BRIDAL ON SEPT. 13
description: Priscilla Blatt of White Plains has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jody Blatt, to Dr. Robert Charles Shepard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Shepard of West Hempstead, L.I. Miss Blatt is a daughter also of the late Dr. Lester J. Blatt, who was a surgeon.

title: ANGLICANS TO RELAX CURBS AGAINST REMARRIAGE AFTER DIVORCE
description: The Church of England Synod has agreed to modify its rules on marriage so that some divorced persons can be remarried by the church.

title: 3 REPORTED PICKED FOR APPEALS COURT
description: A law professor and two judges have reportedly been selected by the Reagan Administration to fill three of the four vacancies on the Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

title: PARENT OPPOSES FUNDS FOR SCHOOL TEAMS
description: Robert E. Tomasson, in his article ''Public Education and Private Fees'' (June 28), makes two common errors. He suggests that those without children in the schools have led the fight against paying for ''the public education of other people's children ... as with the sports programs.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; EARLY WARNING FOR DIABETICS
description: A simple test that involves pressing one hand against the other may be a diagnostic key for doctors treating juvenile diabetics. Diabetes that strikes children is usually more severe than the adult variety, frequently resulting in small blood vessel damage that can lead to blindness and kidney failure.

title: Nina Davis, H.W. Pollock Are Married
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Plymouth, Mass., yesterday Nina Riker Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Shippen Davis Jr. of Shrewsbury, N.J., was married to Harry Winslow Pollock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E.D. Pollock of Hancock, N.H. The Rev. Peter C. Moore performed the ceremony.

title: Lauren Piper Married To Christopher Franco
description: Lauren Scott Piper, daughter of Edwin E. Piper Jr. of Albuquerque, N.M., and Julie Denison of Albany and Lake George, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Patrick Franco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Franco of Greenwich, Conn.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: FRANKLIN, Hancock and Jefferson have been hanging around the Morgan Press in Dobbs Ferry, acting historic but unstatesmanlike. Othello and Chaucer are there, too, but they won't be for long. They're all just typefaces in the crowd, which is moving to Maryland.

title: RAIL BUFFS PUSH EFFORT TO SAVE OLD LINES
description: LIKE wildlife preservationists, railroad enthusiasts have their own endangered species to protect. They consider railroad lines, abandoned or operating, rare animals that are becoming extinct.

title: HAIG APPLAUDS BEGIN AND ARABS FOR CEASE-FIRE Rashidiyeh, Lebanon (p.14)
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. sent messages of ''appreciation and thanks'' today to three of the leaders involved in achieving the cease-fire that ended 16 days of intense shelling along the @Lebanese-Israeli border, State Department officials said.

title: KIM CARNES LIFTS 'BETTE DAVIS' TO THE TOP
description: There is much talk these days about how the popular-record business is changing. But then something comes along to reaffirm the old ways of doing things. Take Kim Carnes, whose single, ''Bette Davis Eyes,'' has ridden serenely on the top of the charts for weeks and has propelled the album that contains it, ''Mistaken Identity,'' to the top of the album charts, as well.

title: The Nation in Summary; PRESIDENT GIVES AGAIN TO GET TAX BILL PASSED
description: Ever since the White House first modified its tax cut proposal last month, adding sweetners to preserve the principle of a three-year cut, it has piously insisted the bidding war was over. Last week, with House Democrats putting forward a bill for this week's vote that makes a third year dependent on whether the economy in 1983 lives up to President Reagan's expectations, the Administration came right back into the game.

title: The Careful Shopper; Envelope Handbags At Bridgeport Outlet
description: Custom orders for industry, awnings, tarps, canopies, boat covers and ready-made soft carryalls - from bitty bags ($10), to coalbags ($7.50, $10, $12 and $15), to still larger, two-handled zippered cases more like soft footlockers in dimension ($45) - all these and more are the fiefdom of Elizabeth Josephson, president of the Josephson Bag & Canvas Company, founded in 1922 in Bridgeport. This year the Acricite Division of the company added an assortment of Lucite merchandise and some items combine a fabric carrier with a Lucite handle, for instance.

title: BEGIN WONDERS, HOW RELIABLE IS REAGAN ANYWAY?
description: JERUSALEM ISRAEL and the United States are locked in an uncomfortable embrace. Bound by intricate personal and cultural ties, emotional and moral commitments, military and political interests, the powerful benefactor and the vulnerable dependent have again stirred up old doubts about each other's reliability and common sense.

title: Realty News; BROADWAY TOWER SOLD FOR $38 MILLION; Broadway
description: The 38-story office tower at 1250 Broadway is being sold for approximately $38 million.

title: Some Union Leaders Vote Against Postal Pact
description: Officers of American Postal Workers locals in nine Northeastern states voted today to urge their members to reject a tentative contract agreement, an official said.

title: Jacqueline Heyman Is Wed
description: Jacqueline Kerry Heyman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kerry Heyman of Water Mill, L.I., and Miami, was married yesterday to Stephen Clark Snowden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Snowden of Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Randall Saxson performed the ceremony in the First Presbytertian Church in Southampton, L.I. Mr. Snowden is an assistant manager of the Stallion Station Farm, a thoroughbred horse farm in Lexington, where his father is owner of the Fairfield Farm, another thoroughbred farm.

title: A POTPOURRI OF MEDIEVAL TREASURES AT THE METROPOLITAN
description: One of the best bits of news that has lately come out of the Metropolitan Museum is the fact that some time this fall there will be an exhibition of curatorial acquisitions, not one of which will have cost more than $5,000. After a long period in which people have talked of nothing but biggest-ever new galleries and biggest-ever new acquisitions, there is a blessed modesty and sanity about this project.

title: Connecticut Guide; BONANZA FOR READERS
