description: Southport's Pequot Library will have more than 25,000 books and magazines for sale in its auditorium Friday through Monday. Among them are Life and Sports Illustrated magazines from the 1930's to the 60's, priced from 50 cents to $1.

title: Diana Mrvos Fiancee of Frank Rath Jr.
description: Dr. and Mrs. Miles D. Mrvos of Fox Chapel, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diana Lois Mrvos, to Frank Eugene Rath Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rath of Butler, Pa., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: IN DEFENSE OF MARRIGE
description: MANY marriages fail, not because the institution of marriage has failed in these times, but because one or the other or both partners enter matrimony with unrealistic expectations, with too many individual problems or with the inability to withstand the pressures of daily living. None of these problems, of course, can be solved simply by finding a new mate.

title: Business Forum; WHERE'S AMERICA'S OLD TEAM SPIRIT?
description: W HEN Americans think about the reasons for their economic success, the Lone Ranger rides high in the saddle. The wilderness was conquered by individual settlers who pushed West. Our pantheon of economic gods - Henry Ford, Thomas Edison, Edwin Land - has room only for individual entrepreneurs. Supply-side economics preaches that the country will return to economic greatness if America unchains its individual entrepreneurs.

title: Lendl Is Stunned By Gomez in 3 Sets
description: Andres Gomez of Ecuador stunned topseeded Ivan Lendl, 2-6, 7-6, 6-4, and advanced to the semifinals of the $200,000 Washington Star clay-court tennis tournament today.

title: A TAX INDEX BETS ON DEMOCRACY
description: If you are truly weary of politicians ''cutting'' taxes every other year but nonetheless collecting ever larger sums for Federal spending, take heart from a live proposal to end the shell game. It is called ''indexing'' the income tax, and the Senate has voted to try it starting in 1985.

title: Sponsor Clarifies Origin of Bill
description: To the Sports Editor: Red Smith takes two intentionally wild strikes and then hits a home run in his July 6 column, ''Capitol Hill Rumblings.'' He suggests that the current baseball strike is responsible for my bill to end pro baseball's antitrust exemption.

title: Baby Condor Dies on Coast
description: A baby California condor, one of the world's rarest birds, has died after hatching in a rocky, isolated nest in Santa Barbara County, a National Audubon Society naturalist reported. John Borneman of the Condor Research Center in Ventura said Thursday that the chick, one of two condors known to be hatched this year, may have died without emerging from its egg.

title: TRIUMPH OF AN ALSO-RAN
description: Grandmaster Jesus Nogueiras and international master Jose Vilela, both of Cuba, shared first place in the Che Guevara Memorial Tournament in Havana. Each scored 12 1/2-4 1/2 in the event sponsored by Radio Rebelde. Final Standings PlayerPoints Nogueiras12 1/2 Vilela12 1/2 Timoshenko11 1/2 Schussler10 1/2 Palermo10 G. Garcia 9 1/2 Zapata 9 1/2 Sisniega 9 Garcia 8 1/2 PlayerPoints Ochoa 8 1/2 Hernandez 7 1/2 Vera 7 Diaz 7 Pinal 6 1/2 Fernandez 6 1/2 Andres 5 1/2 Barreras 5 1/2 Velez 4

title: Egypt Gives Political Asylum To an Iranian Air Force Pilot
description: An Iranian Air Force pilot fled to Egypt yesterday in a military Boeing 707, and today Egypt announced that he had been granted political asylum.

title: Brazilian State Loses Much of Coffee Crop
description: The State of Sao Paulo has lost almost two-thirds of its 1981-82 coffee crop because of recent frosts, the state's agriculture secretary, Afif Domingos, said.

title: ADVOCATES TAKING BIGGER ROLE IN HELPING AGED GAIN BENEFITS
description: AN elderly woman could not afford to eat much more than tea and crackers because she was not aware that she was eligible for supplementary security income through the Social Security Administration. A recent widower in his early 70's was so depressed that he could not cope with daily household chores. A widow in her 60's could no longer keep up with rental increases on a fixed income; she needed a housemate with whom expenses could be shared.

title: FIREFIGHTERS DISPLAY RESCUE TECHNIQUES Jr.
description: Ten fire trucks crowded the street in front of the RCA Building yesterday in midtown Manhattan as dozens of firefighters and spectators watched a demonstration of a rescue technique designed to save the lives of people beyond the reach of Fire Department ladders.

title: THE QUIET COWBOY IN MR. REAGAN'S POSSE
description: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Cabinet's steer-roping ace doesn't much like to toot his own horn: Cowboys regard a man for what he is and what he can do, not for what he says. Their world is far from Washington, where Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige says wryly everyone would be a billionaire if people were paid by the word.

title: 3 Guards Held Hostage For 5 Hours in Missouri
description: Two inmates armed with pistols held three guards hostage for five hours today at the Missouri State Penitentiary before surrendering after prison officials agreed to send them to another prison, officials said.

title: Prospects
description: Recession Ahead?

title: The World in Summary; AFTER CONGRESS, POLAND COMES TO THE HARD PART
description: Unless the nation can forestall economic chaos and get down to work, Stanislaw Kania warned last week, ''history will brand us as the people who talked Poland to death.''

title: A PIANIST WHO ALWAYS WANTED TO BE A CONDUCTOR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Harlow Robinson writes frequently about the performing arts. By HARLOW ROBINSON

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 26, 1981
description: International The cease-fire in southern Lebanon appeared to be holding, despite a Palestinian rocket attack on two towns in southern Lebanon held by Maj. Saad Haddad's Israeli-backed militia. A small but well organized guerrilla faction, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, said it was responsible for the shelling, and said it would not take part in suspect cease-fire.'' The group's defiance raised the question whether Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, would be able to keep other guerrilla factions from violating the cease-fire. (Page 1, Col. 6.) The United States thanked three of the leaders involved in bringing about the cease-fire that ended 16 days of intense shelling on the Lebanese-Israeli border. State Department officials said that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had sent messages of ''appreciation and thanks'' to President Elias Sarkis of Lebanon, Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia. Yasir Arafat of the P.L.O. was omitted, because of a 1975 understanding with Israel that Washington would not deal directly with the P.L.O. (1:5.)

title: The Region in Summary; CULT BILL BAILS TO CONVERT CAREY
description: If getting out of cults were as easy as getting into them seems to be, the New York State Legislature would not have approved a bill empowering courts to forcibly remove members, as it has for the past two years, and Governor Carey would not have vetoed it, as he did for the second time last week.

title: RELATIVE RISKS IN WAR ON PESTS
description: The special benefits of detente with the People's Republic of China were quietly heralded last week at the United States Department of Agriculture, whose representatives had just returned from that country bearing a variety of insect predators. The specimens they brought back, such as green lacewings, predatory mites and parasitic wasps, could help defend American produce from a variety of destructive pests, ranging from the gypsy moth - that scourge of Northeastern trees and shrubs - to the aphids and mites that attack cotton, tobacco, fruits and vegetables. For their part, the Americans left behind presents of native American wasps, which are foes of aphids and caterpillars.

title: The Nation in Summary; SEARCHING FOR THE FATAL WEAKNESS
description: After the horror, the questions. Nearly a dozen inquiries were under way last week into the circumstances that led to the collapse, the previous Friday night, of two aerial walkways onto the crowded lobby dance floor of the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Kansas City.

title: RIPPLES IN OTTOWA BUT NO WAVES
description: Those who had hoped for more from Ottawa than communiques on unity of intention and serious of discussion were disappointed. But it could have been worse. The fears, new this year, that disagreements over economic policy between the leaders of the major leading industrial democracies would become open ruptures were not fulfilled. The process survived; the eighth annual such meeting is now set for Paris, next year, and, not insignificantly, the prime ministers and President Reagan preserved face.

title: TWO MORE CLASSICAL LABELS VIE FOR ATTENTION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about classical records. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: Red Smith; The Long, Hot, Empty Summer of No Baseball
description: JACQUES BARZUN wrote - and if he isn't sick of re-reading it, he has a strong stomach - that ''whoever wants to know the heart and mind of America had better learn baseball.''

title: COURT BARS ELECTION PANEL INQUIRY ON CONSERVATIVE NEWSLETTER
description: A Federal District Court has refused to allow the Federal Election Commission to investigate a conservative newsletter that circulated promotional material opposing the Presidential candidacy of Senator Edward M. Kennedy in 1980.

title: No Headline
description: President Reagan, leaving the White House yesterday for Camp David, Md. In a statement Friday, he supported William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence. ''I have not changed my mind about Bill Casey,'' he said.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE TRANSIT OF VENUS, by Shirley Hazzard. (Playboy Paperbacks, $3.50.) In charting the passage, over three decades, of two sisters from Australia among the professional and civil servant set in Britain and America, Shirley Hazzard focuses on Caro, whose emotional life turns full circle about a faithful astronomer. Our reviewer Gail Godwin said that ''this engrossing, masterly novel combines the satisfaction of a family saga with a highly structured plot reminiscent of Greek tragedy.'' Winner of the 1981 National Critics Circle Award.

title: ISRAEL FRONT QUIET
description: The cease-fire along the Israeli border with southern Lebanon appeared to be generally holding tonight, despite a Palestinian guerrilla rocket attack this morning on Lebanese towns in the enclave of Maj. Saad Haddad's Israeli-backed militia.

title: Salt Lake Fire Contained
description: A fire that blackened more than 9,000 acres on Antelope Island in the Great Salt Lake was brought under control this morning, but a new blaze ignited by lightning threatened the nearby Lakeside Mountain, fire officials said.

title: ROYAL WEDDING HERALDS A NEW DAY FOR ANGLICANS
description: Though the exchange of vows between Prince Charles and Lady Diana in the presence of the Archbishop of Canterbury this week fulfills rich English religious and cultural traditions, British church weddings in general are a relatively uncommon event. In England and Wales, only one marriage in three is now performed in the church. In the London area, the figure drops to one in five. It is another sign, some observers say, that the Anglican church does not touch the everyday life of the people as it once did and that its power, real and ceremonial, has waned.

title: THE STRIKE, AND THE THINGS WE'VE LOST
description: So that we may play the game in our heads. A.Bartlett Giamatti, the president of Yale, who writes about baseball now and again, addressed the conflictive figures of the game in this newspaper a month ago and implored them to ''go back to work. You will lose a country if you impose autumn on a people who need and deserve a summer without yet another denial;

title: Other World Events; FOR TERRORISTS, BUSINESS AS USUAL
description: Reports by Italian police that the Red Brigades had been virtually put out of business were evidently premature. The left-wing terrorists can still pick and choose their kidnapping victims and, as they proved last week, set them free (or not) pretty much on their own terms.

title: CEASE-FIRE LEADS TO HOPES FOR A WIDER SETTLEMENT
description: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, talking to each other through third parties, last week ended two weeks of costly conflict that had shocked and angered world capitals. Separately, they proclaimed a cease-fire that promised a respite from bombing, artillery barrages, commando raids and civilian deaths in Lebanon and northern Israel.

title: Other World Events; NIGERIA PUTS ITS FOOT DOWN
description: ''Any threat to this republic will be resolutely met and repulsed with force,'' Nigeria's President, Shehu Shagari said last week, as he ordered ''stepped-up vigilance'' along the Nigeria-Cameroon border. Mr. Shagari's firm language was needed to appease his nationalistic critics, who have advocated military action against Cameroon in the long-standing dispute over offshore oil rights. ''The battle tom-tom must start drumming,'' one commentator wrote, reflecting sentiments rekindled last May, when five Nigerian soldiers were killed in a fight with Cameroon troops. The announcement of added security measures suggested that army reinforcements had been deployed along parts of the largely contested frontier.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Transit Mystery
description: It could have been the climax to a taut crime movie: a $600,000 theft pulled off under the very noses of police guards. The money was in a safe, which was in a locked revenue room, which was watched at all times by police officers at New York City Transit Authority headquarters in Brooklyn.

title: HECKSCHER SHOWS L.I. COLLECTORS' BEST
description: HUNTINGTON THE Heckscher Museum is celebrating its 60th birthday, and during the course of those 60 years, it has become one of the primary small museums in the country, a kind of cosmopolitan cultural doyenne of the Island, with an international reputation for its collections and exhibitions.

title: COUNSELING LIFTS HOPES OF DEAF
description: CAMDEN A DEAF person who needs a lawyer, doctor, insurance agent or realestate broker faces a dilemma that his hearing friends do not: How to convey his needs to someone with whom he cannot communicate.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THEATER David Henry Hwang is a young Chinese-American playwright from Los Angeles who, so far, has made a specialty of dramatizing the immigrant experience. If there's nothing new about Mr. Hwang's subject, there is much that is novel about his approach to it.

title: HELPING THE YOUNG LEARN LAW
description: Was Thomas Hughes guilty as charged of hurling rocks and smashing seven stained glass windows in the Teachers College library at 10:20 P.M. on July 2?

title: CASE OF THE PURLOINED PASSWORD
description: BOSTON S INCE last fall, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been conducting a criminal investigation into a curious computer-age crime - the theft of an information file called a password directory from the electronic memory of National CSS Inc., one of the nation's largest timesharing companies.

title: THE PUBLIC VIEW OF THE LEGISLATURE
description: THE recently completed state-funded study of the Connecticut General Assembly was just another incident in a seemingly neverending debate over how to improve the state legislative process.

title: The Region in Summary; ACCORD REACHED ON WESTWAY--SOUND FAMILIAR?
description: Even if last week's ever-so-tentative Westway agreement between Mayor Koch and Governor Carey stands up, babies conceived when the highway was, in 1974, may be able to cast ballots before there is a Westway to drive on.

title: GARBAGE INQUIRY IS IMPERILED
description: WHEN a special Assembly subcommittee convenes next month to investigate the relationship between organized crime and the garbage industry, it could find itself being denied information by key state law-enforcement authorities, those who apparently know the most.

title: TEACHING THE OVER-60'S PROVIDES SURPRISES
description: HARTFORD ''I DON'T believe in God,'' the student told her teacher after a class on religion and society. ''I just want you to know.'' The remark took the professor, an Episcopal priest, by surprise. ''I don't know a single undergraduate who would say that to me,'' he later said.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: SOPRANO AT FULL POWER
description: Jessye Norman is not exactly an unknown vocal presence in New York, but her appearance Friday night at the Mostly Mozart Festival in Avery Fisher Hall revealed that an exceptionally talented singer has developed into an artist of extraordinary technical confidence and interpretive magnetism. Miss Norman's natural gifts have always been impressive, but on this occasion she demonstrated in no uncertain terms that her voice has matured into a magnificently expressive and pliant instrument that responds to her every wish.

title: Susan Mayer Has Nuptials
description: Susan Winthrop Mayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Huntington Mayer of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Gifford Breck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gifford Breck Jr. of Weston and Harwichport, Mass. The Rev. Rebecca Spencer performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church.

title: YET TO BE SUED
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: The Wedding There will be more than Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer on hand this week when television covers the royal wedding in London. British journalists, cricketeers, economists, pubgoers, historians, Cockney street-corner sociologists, American expatriates and just about anyone else who could conceivably have anything to say about things British will be spotlighted. Even the Muppets will get into the act.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH IN DUBLIN TO BACK FAST
description: Thousands of demonstrators shouting ''Brits out!'' and ''Unlock H-Block!'' marched through downtown Dublin today in support of the hunger strikers in Northern Ireland and against the policies of the British and Irish Governments.

title: ''The Lifeblood''
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexandra Grace Klima Married to David Dalury
description: Alexandra Grace Klima, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ivo M. Klima of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Francis Dalury, son of Mrs. Jean Dalury of Grantham, N.H., and Robert Dalury of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Henry A. Albrecht performed the ceremony in St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: Citizen Panel Says Cost Of Road Is Exaggerated
description: The chairman of New York Citizens for Balanced Transportation yesterday charged Stanley Fink, the Speaker of the Assembly, with exaggerating the cost to the state of building the Westway.

title: STATE GIVES ROAD PROJECTS A GREEN LIGHT
description: STATE transportation officials are ready to begin what they expect to be the last major spurt of highway construction in New Jersey. The remaining roadblocks to completing what the state's Department of Transportation considers priority links in the Interstate System are being removed, and officials expect to be in the final design or early construction stage on all five projects by early next year.

title: POP: JANIS IAN AND ROCK TRIO
description: Janis Ian, who appeared Tuesday and Wednesday at the Bottom Line for four shows, is an enormous pop talent who has produced one of the most substantial (and underrecorded) songwriting catalogues of the last decade.

title: Diane Schaeffer Bride Of Peter G. Bergner
description: The marriage of Diane Amy Schaeffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Schaeffer of Brooklyn, to Peter Gregg Bergner, son of Robert Bergner of New Rochelle, N.Y. and Lois Grinker of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., took place yesterday. Rabbi Theodore Steinberg performed the ceremony at the Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Center.

title: AN UNSUNG HARRY CHAPIN
description: THE American dream implies that all of us must be actively ''involved.'' Harry Chapin lived his words with a vibrant spirit and love that few of us will ever match.

title: FRESH AIR HOSTS BROADEN FAMILY TIES
description: Most of the thousands of New York City children who have enjoyed summer vacations sponsored by the Fresh Air Fund have been welcomed in homes where children their own age have become temporary brothers and sisters.

title: CAMPERS TO TEST THE TIMELESSNESS OF AREA ECOLOGY
description: NORTH SALEM IT was just 250 years ago that this onetime agricultural community was founded by the Rev. Thomas Hale and 23 other settlers. But Westchester County's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation is planning to demonstrate that in many ways the passing of time has done little to change the ecology here.

title: THE LIMIT OF FAIRNESS IN CRITICIZING ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Carla Lynn Clay Is Affianced
description: Gen. Lucius D. Clay Jr., U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Clay of Colorado Springs have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carla Lynn Clay, to Richard Kingsley Berry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Berry of Darien, Conn., and West Tisbury, Mass.

title: Practical Traveler; HOW TO MAKE LIFE EASIER WHEN TRAVELING WITH PETS
description: It is constantly growing easier to have a pet dog or cat accompany you on a vacation, or to make arrangements to leave it comfortably and safely near home. Reliable information on such things as whether hotels have special arrangements for pets may, however, be hard to find, although this situation is improving; the listings in many guidebooks include information on accommodations for pets, and booklets devoted principally to listing hotels that welcome pets are also available.

title: Topics; CULTURE SHOCKS; CLAP TRAPS
description: Early applauders are too much with us at New York concerts. It's worse in winter, when so many concertgoers dressed to impress are just as eager to demonstrate their knowledge that the music is about to end.

title: 5 Held in Slaying of Officer
description: Five men were jailed today in connection with the fatal shooting of an undercover police officer last night when gunfire broke out as the police were making arrests in a drug case. Four of the men were Cuban refugees, the authorities said. Four of the five were charged with first-degree murder in the slaying of Gerald A. Rauft, 38 years old.

title: Abroad at Home; FOR THE SAKE OF ISRAEL
description: Over the two weeks of intense Israeli bombing in Lebanon, American officials expressed increasing concern about the effects on the U. S. position in the Middle East. But the American diplomatic move, when it came, was really more in Israel's interest than in ours. It was an intervention to save Israel from the consequences of its own policy.

title: 'STRATEGIC STABILITY'--PATHS AND PROSPECTS
description: WITH the decision on what, if anything, to do about developing the B-1 bomber still hanging fire, the Reagan Administration has been worrying about the other half of the $100 billion question as well - the MX missile. Its deployment is considered by some specialists a critical brace for an increasingly weak leg of the strategic triad, the intercontinental ballistic missile. Other analysts contend the MX system either should be canceled outright or modified, and more attention given to strengthening the triad's other limbs: bombers and submarines.

title: INTERPRETING THE LANDSCAPE
description: Nature is mute; our portrayal of it, which constitutes the domain of the landscape in art, is what speaks to us. What landscapes tell us is not necessarily what we might expect: as much as they seem to limn the world as it is, they are best at describing our attitude toward the world. Every landscape portrays the culture in which it was made. As Gene Thornton suggested recently on this page, in the course of discussing photographs of space exploration, 21st-century man may have difficulty distinguishing those 20th-century photographs made in the interests of science from others made in the interests of art. But what he will be able to distinguish is how his lessevolved ancestor saw himself in relation to his native planet.

title: The Nation in Summary; THE HARD LINE AGAINST CRIME
description: If the goal of criminal justice is the capture, conviction and imprisonment of criminals, then the recommendations from the Attorney General's Task Force on Violent Crime qualify as a back-tobasics approach.

title: New Director of Admissions
description: Named by Columbia College

title: PHONING FROM ABROAD
description: To the Editor:$

title: New Jersey Journal
description: EVERYBODY knows that crime is a big problem these days, especially the mayors of big cities, and Mayor Arthur Holland of Trenton is no exception. Mr. Holland's three-story, 150-year-old row house in the city's Mill Hill area, a renewal district, was robbed last week by a burglar who may have broken local records for both audacity and stupidity.

title: Business Conditions; WINE TROOPS ALONG
description: With one notable exception, conditions did not change much in the wine business last year. Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, an investment banking house, reports that sales of domestic and imported wines were up 6 percent from 1979 levels, to 512 million gallons, consistent with growth trends established during the past decade.

title: CAINE STRETCHES HIS RANGE
description: In Britain Michael Caine is still seen as the archetypal example of the working-class lad made good: a male Cinderella, so to speak, or a frog who hauled himself out of the mire and was magically revealed as a dapper young prince. Certainly, he seems supremely qualified to play the lead in ''Victory,'' a professional soccer player unexpectedly promoted to officer rank in the field and then captured by the Nazis.

title: HALCYON DAYS
description: The unspoiled natural beauty of the Island from the Civil War through World War I is the subject of a new exhibition, ''The Long Island Landscape 1865-1914: The Halcyon Years,'' which opens today at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton. With some 100 works by artists such as William Sidney Mount, Childe Hassam, Thomas and Mary Nimmo Moran, William Merritt Chase and Winslow Homer, the exhibition will focus on the significant role played by those artists, who worked on the Island during this period. The museum is on Job's Lane, and the show can be seen through Sept. 20 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays and from 1 to 5 P.M. on Sundays. ANTIQUE CAR MEET

title: IS COGENERATION NEXT HOUSEHOLD WORD?
description: JERSEY CITY IT IS 1984. A Jersey City householder is paying a monthly bill for heat piped into her home from the electricity plant down the street, while in Trenton an official looks over the charges for steam used to run state office air-conditioners.

title: PLAYHOUSE HIT: ECONOMY
description: SHARON ''IT'S curtain! It's curtain!'' a woman in a green sleeveless cotton dress calls into the parking lot as the lights in front of the red barnlike Sharon Playhouse begin to flicker. A graying man, lean and tall, clambers up the slight incline to the theater's entrance. Intermission is over. The second and last act of the ''King and I'' is about to begin.

title: Scholarship Babies
description: To help mark its 150th anniversary, the Rochester Institute of Technology in upstate New York offered two years ago to give $1,500 scholarships to 150 babies born on the school's anniversary day, June 12, 1979.

title: ANOTHER BREAKTHROUGH FOR WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: Advocates of equal rights for women scored major a breakthrough this month not only at the United States Supreme Court, but also at the U.S. Mint. On July 13, just six days after naming Sandra Day O'Connor to serve on the nation's highest court, President Ronald Reagan chose sculptress Elizabeth Jones to fill the prestigious post of chief sculptor-engraver at the Mint.

title: Realty News; Stamford, Conn.
description: The Olin Corporation has leased 40,000 square feet of office space at 1290 Summer St. in Stamford for 10 years at an aggregate rent of more than $11 million.

title: Dr. Linda E. Stanley Wed
description: Dr. Linda E. Stanley, daughter of Effie R. Stanley of Philadelphia and the late Municipal Court Judge Frank L. Stanley, was married yesterday to John David Sorrell, son of Mrs. Ethel Boss, also of Philadelphia, and the late Norman Sorrell. The Rev. Graham Patterson performed the ceremony at the Summit Presbyterian Church in Philadelphia. The bride is a teaching fellow in the department of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Sorrell, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is an associate vice president for development with the Insurance Company of North America.

title: IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF HARDY IN DORSET
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- DAVID YEADON is the author and illustrator of "Hidden Corners of Britain" and "Backroad Journeys of Southern Europe," both published this year. ------------

title: SMALL RECORDERS CAPTURE VACATIONS
description: Among the paraphernalia carried by vacationers as they indulge their seasonal orgies of wanderlust, the tape recorder has become almost as common as the camera. In fact, parallels can be drawn between them. Half a century ago, when the first compact cameras and fast films ushered in the era of push-button photogaphy, countless people realized that fleeting images from their journeys could be held fast for lasting enjoyment. Today, the miniaturization of recording equipment leads to a similar discovery: sounds encountered on one's peregrinations can also be kept for the pleasures of reminiscence.

title: POP MUSIC
description: More and more Jamaican reggae artists have been establishing footholds with North American audiences. The recent Black Uhuru concert at the Palladium may be difficult to top, but two of the finest vocalists reggae has produced will be doing their best this week. Sunday evening, Dennis Brown, a powerful, honey-voiced singer who has tried his hand at both fire-and-brimstone religious parables and the mellow pop reggae Jamaicans call ''lovers rock,'' will be at the Ritz on East 11th Street.

title: MARINE LIFE TO BE INVENTORIED
description: FOR the next two years, a group of biologists will be counting the clams, oysters, scallops, mussels and other shellfish and finfish on the Connecticut side of Long Island Sound.

title: Antiques; COLONIAL CHAIRS: INDICATORS OF STATUE
description: HARTFORD WHAT is perhaps the largest exhibit ever of merican seating furniture made before 1740 is now at the Wadsworth Atheneum, 600 Main Street. Using 30 examples of Pilgrim century stools, chairs and other forms of furniture designed for the ease and comfort of colonists, the exhibit illustrates not only the styles then in favor, but also illuminates the differences in the work of the various chairmakers - joiners, turners, caners and upholsterers.

title: DEFENDANT FACING PSYCHIATRIC TESTS
description: A former New York City transit police officer faces 30 days of mental tests to determine his future after his involvement in the fatal shootings of two men and the wounding of six others in November at two Greenwich Village sites frequented by homosexuals.

title: Editors' Choice
description: IF ON A WINTER'S NIGHT A TRAVELER, by Italo Calvino. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95.) A novel about reading fiction, by the Italian master.

title: ON 'CHATS' AND CHATTY SPORTS ANNOUNCERS John O'Connor
description: With cable threatening some of the traditional structures of broadcast television, an element of uncertainty in the ''communications'' business is unavoidable these days. This might account for the curious phenomenon of the press conference, bursting with optimistic bravado, being replaced more and more with the low-keyed ''chat.'' One Friday recently, for instance, a CBS Cable lunch for a few journalists was followed later in the afternoon by a gathering during which the press was invited to meet, informally, Grant A. Tinker, the new chairman and chief executive officer of the National Broadcasting Company. The refreshingly blunt but sensible Mr. Tinker had to remind his persistent questioners, eager for a headline, that he was only there for a chat. ''If I were here to make news,'' he explained, ''we would have done it earlier in the day.''

title: Miss Ziegler Wed To Paul Daimler
description: Daryl Ann Ziegler and Paul Harper Daimler were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Alexander Ziegler, in Darien, Conn. The Rev. William Gray Tolley of the Union Presbyterian Church of Bay Ridge in Brooklyn performed the ceremony.

title: DRIVING BY TV
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUIS C. MIANO
description: Louis C. Miano, an industrial and commercial real estate developer in the New York metropolitan area, died Friday at his summer home in Amagansett, L.I. Mr. Miano, who also was a resident of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was 71 years old.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: BANKRUPTCY IS DENIED
description: To the Editor:

title: OEDIPUS IN ARGENTINA
description: ON HEROES AND TOMBS By Ernesto Sabato. Translated by Helen R. Lane. 479 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $17.95.

title: JULIE VITTORIA IS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Vittoria of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Julie Marie Vittoria, to Jeffrey John Atkinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Atkinson of Norwalk, Conn.

title: SPRINGBROOK TOUR MAY BE ENDED
description: A rugby match between the South African Springboks and a local team was canceled today after an estimated 3,000 anti-apartheid demonstrators had stormed the field and a report had been received that a stolen light plane might be crashed into the stands.

title: A DRUNK-DRIVING LESSON LOST IN THE ROUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: IS IT RIGHT TO TURN ON RED?
description: WHEN New Jersey instituted its ''Right Turn on Red'' program, it expected to save energy and expedite traffic. An unforeseen result has been to encourage a behavior that threatens the life and limb of that nearly extinct class called pedestrians.

title: F.A.A. to Allow Blind to Keep Their Canes at Airliner Seats
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it was changing its rules to permit blind passengers to keep flexible travel canes at their seats on airliners.

title: Hotel in Fatal Las Vegas Fire Gets Approval for Reopening
description: The MGM Grand Hotel, where 84 persons died in a fire last November, has been approved for reopening. The hotel installed a new $5 million fire safety system after the Nov. 21 fire.

title: MOYNIHAN REPORT DEPLORES BUDGET
description: For the fifth time in as many years, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has issued a report saying that New York State is being shortchanged in the Federal budget. This time, however, he includes new calculations indicating that the state may not fare as badly as he has suggested in the past.

title: NEW BEAUJOLAIS, OLD RULES
description: Terry Robards's experience negates the old rule that Beaujolais Nouveau be consumed quickly after bottling in the fall (''The Beaujolais Season,'' June 21). And with an insider's wink, he suspects commercial interests behind the myth, as wine consumed early turns both inventory and money.

title: PHONING FROM ABROAD
description: To the Editor:$

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: PRIME TIME PREACHERS The Rising Power of Televangelism. By Jeffrey K. Hadden and Charles E. Swann. Illustrated. 217 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley. $11.95.

title: SELLING PHOTOGRAPHS ON A FREELANCE BASIS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- George Duryea is director of the School of Modern Photography in Little Falls, N.J.

title: IN PRAISE OF MODERN DANCE
description: The first Samuel H. Scripps Award was presented at a dance festival in Durham, N.C., last week and the recipient was Martha Graham, the 86-year-old modern dance choreographer.

title: INDOOR AIR CALLED THREAT TO HEALTH
description: Indoor air pollution is a serious and growing problem that can cause discomfort, illness and even death, according to a report prepared for the Environmental Protection Agency by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: DEMONSTRATORS IN POLISH CITY DEMAND MORE FOOD
description: Several thousand people turned out today in the rain to take part in a ''march against hunger'' organized by the Solidarity union to demand more food and a different distribution system.

title: THE MAN WHO BROUGHT 'PIRATES' TO LIFE IN A NEW WAY
description: Gilbert and Sullivan traditionalists may argue over its respective merits, but no one can say that the New York Shakespeare Festival production of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' lacks energy. When William Elliott bounds into the pit and sets his 15-piece orchestra into motion -which he does by leaping about three feet into the air - the musicians are off and running with the conductor's ingenious arrangement of the score, obviously relishing every minute of it. In fact, the players invariably emerge at the end of the performance dripping wet, partly after two hours of strenuous physical exertion and partly from a water-gun fight that bursts out in their ranks during the frantic finale.

title: HITLER'S RUSSIAN BLUNDER
description: In the final analysis, Hitler lost his war because of his lack of originality. He was merely an amplifier (a genius at that) of all the pan-Germanic, racist and nonracist nationalistic ideas that had been permeating Germany since 1817.

title: CAPITAL FIGHTING CHRONIC FISCAL CRISIS
description: When large numbers of whites fled this city from the 1950's to the 1970's, thousands of stately homes were sold at bargain prices. Now it costs an average of $167,118 to buy a twobedroom house in the capital, and housing costs rank with those in the most inflated real estate markets in America, which are largely on the West Coast.

title: GIVING HELP TO A HOMLESS YOUTH
description: BOBBY is a handsome young man with an engaging smile he finds hard to suppress, even as he tells of a life that is like something from an updated Charles Dickens novel.

title: GABRIEL GARCIA MARQUEZ MEETS ERNEST HEMINGWAY
description: Irecognized him immediately, passing with his wife Mary Welsh on the Boulevard St. Michel in Paris one rainy spring day in 1957. He walked on the other side of the street, in the direction of the Luxembourg Gardens, wearing a very worn pair of cowboy pants, a plaid shirt and a ballplayer's cap. The only thing that didn't look as if it belonged to him was a pair of metal-rimmed glasses, tiny and round, which gave him a premature grandfatherly air. He had turned 59, and he was large and almost too visible,but he didn't give the impression of brutal strength that he undoubtedly wished to, because his hips were narrow and his legs looked a little emaciated above his coarse lumberjack shoes. He looked so alive amid the secondhand bookstalls and the youthful torrent from the Sorbonne that it was impossible to imagine he had but four years left to live.

title: Brooklyn Man, 55, Shot Dead While Taking Out the Garbage
description: A 55-year-old Brooklyn man working the night shift at a Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet in the Crown Heights section was shot to death early yesterday in an encounter with two men just outside the restaurant, the police reported. The company later posted a $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of his assailants.

title: COG RAILWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR THE U.S. AND ISRAEL, RUDE AWAKENINGS
description: WASHINGTON LOOKING back on it a year or two from now, the Israeli air strike into the heart of Beirut may well be seen as a turning point in the Reagan Administration's appreciation of the complexities of the Middle East and the difficulties of dealing with an independent and headstrong ally such as Menachem Begin.

title: Nancy Lee Luick Wed To James H. Bryan Jr.
description: Nancy Lee Luick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Burns Luick of Belmont, Mass., was married there yesterday to James Hanan Bryan Jr., son of Mr. Bryan of Wilton, Conn., and Mrs. Robert A. Sander of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Joseph A. Pelletier, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: IONA
description: To the Editor:

title: MARY TURTON ENGAGED TO CHARLES M. AMS 3D
description: The engagement of Mary Quarrier Turton to Charles M. Ams 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ams of Pawlet, Vt., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Turton of Southport, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be.

title: THE SECOND HALF OF SUMMER BRINGS MUSIC TO THE EAR
description: THE tempo is picking up as the second half of summer approaches. What with concerts under the stars almost every night of the week, ambitious art exhibitions opening and a full schedule of colorful fairs, August promises to be a hectic period for Long Islanders who like to take advantage of what the Island has to offer.

title: CAREY USES BILL-SIGNING TIME TO GARNER POSITIVE PUBLICITY
description: Governor Carey is on the stump around the state, attacking Republicans and dispersing state largesse as he goes. In Utica, it was Mr. Carey, the educator, signing a bill Thursday to provide money for a long-delayed campus of the State University of New York.

title: PRESSURES TO REPEAL TAX GROW
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly, which was back at the State Capitol for a one-day stand last Monday and is due back again for a special session next Friday, is under mounting pressure to convene yet again to repeal the new state tax on unincorporated businesses.

title: U.N. REPORTS TRUCE VIOLATIONS BY PALESTINIANS
description: A United Nations spokesman said today that Palestinian guerrillas had fired 130 rockets and artillery shells into an area controlled by Lebanese Christians along the Israeli frontier in violation of the cease-fire. There were no reported attacks on Israeli territory.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: TEHERAN REPORTS AN ELECTION VICTORY FOR RAJAI
description: Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai, the candidate of Iran's ruling Moslem fundamentalists, has been elected to succeed the deposed President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the Teheran radio said today.

title: BRADLEY TESTS PROSPECTS FOR GUBERNATORIAL RUN
description: As he toured Northern California this week, Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, the state's most successful black politician, said: ''I have gone out to test the waters to see what the prospects are if I should run for governor. Things look good.''

title: Krohn Edges Sanders, Wins Seven-Mile Race
description: Bill Krohn, a former Manhattan College runner, beat Odis Sanders, the defending champion, by two seconds today and won the Dannon seven-mile race around Titicus Reservoir. Krohn's winning time of 33 minutes, 47 seconds was a course record.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 12 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 2 16 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 3 4 5 THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.) Two veteran homicide detectives trapped by the seductive vices of Hollywood. 4 3 7 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 5 5 14 GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam's, $12.95.) Leto continues as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet Dune. 6 14 28 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) An illustrated fable about the Sun, the Moon and a hidden treasure. 7 15 2 THE CLOWNS OF GOD, by Morris West. (Morrow, $14.95.) What happens when the Pope has a revelation that the end of the world is near and the Cardinals force him to abdicate.

title: IONA
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; CULTURE SHOCKS; LEAN MAGIC
description: On the theory that a library reflects its owner, what can you say about someone whose current book-buying is divided between cat cartoons and diet strategies? Simple. You can say that person is the average adult American.

title: FOR MONGOLS AND HORSES, A U.S. TOUR
description: So far in their quest to get better acquainted, Americans and Chinese have endured each other's odd foods, awkward eating utensils, complicated languages, silly questions, endless delegations of politicians and quizzical customs.

title: Dining Out; A SURPRISE OR TWO IN SECAUCUS
description: ONE of the paradoxes of New Jersey dining is that, although patrons lament the lack of New York City-quality restaurants in the state, when a high-caliber restaurant does open, these very same people bemoan the nearly Manhattan-level prices.

title: Safety in Boxing A Contradiction
description: To the Sports Editor: The regular occurrence of serious injury and death from head injury in boxing has prompted the New York Legislature to pass safety measures, including having an ambulance at boxing matches.

title: A VISITOR'S IMPRESSION OF THIRD WORLD CENTER
description: Elizabeth Hagen's letter of June 21 comparing Princeton University's Third World Center with South Africa's apartheid system is clearly an overstatement.

title: Emily Chambers, 78, Is Dead; Leader in Social Service Work
description: Emily Zimmerer Chambers, who was active in educational and social service programs, died Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a brief illness. She was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Honoring Le Gallienne
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DAY-CARE SCHOOL
description: Barbara Hanna Gill's suggestion that school districts experiencing declining enrollment allocate space for day care also occurred to us in the North Bellmore school district in Nassau County on Long Island (Letters, June 21, in response to ''Divorce Suburban Style: Single at Midlife,'' by Andree Brooks, May 24). Recognizing the growing need for child care and the existence of unused space in school buildings after 3 P.M., a group of parents, teachers and other concerned individuals in our community worked to develop a nonprofit corporation to provide after-school child care for elementary school-age children in our district.

title: FIBAK IN SEMIFINALS
description: Top-seeded Wojtek Fibak of Poland scored a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Erik Iskersky of the United States, a qualifier, and gained the semifinals of the $75,000 Dutch Open tennis tournament.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; WILLIAM G. OUCHI
description: It was his love life that first introduced William G. Ouchi to the recently much vaunted Japanese style of corporate management. Mr. Ouchi, author of ''Theory Z: How American Business Can Meet the Japanese Challenge,'' was born and reared in Hawaii. His father-inlaw-to-be was trying to run a Hawaiian life insurance company in the Japanese manner, which stresses a more democratic environment in the workplace and worker participation in decision making. So when Mr. Ouchi went to pick up his future wife on dates, he recalls, ''I heard about Japanese management from her father, whether I wanted to or not.''

title: SWEDISH OPEN RAINED OUT
description: All matches in the $75,000 Swedish Open tennis championships were rained out today. Weather permitting, the men's and women's singles semifinals will be played tomorrow and the finals Monday.

title: Sunday Observer; INSTINCT FOR SURVIVAL
description: Up the street a few blocks from here there is a fellow who ever so often tosses a cinder block off a roof, three or four stories up. Now and then he hits somebody down below, which is no great feat of marksmanship, since it is Times Square and often packed wall-to-wall with people.

title: PENTAGON PAPERS, A DECADE LATER
description: That the papers held no danger to the country because of military secrets is, I believe, true.

title: 22 Accused of Violations Of Laws on Bald Eagles
description: An 18-month undercover investigation into trafficking in protected birds, most of them bald eagles, has resulted in an indictment against 22 persons, 16 of whom were arrested by Federal and state wildlife agents in a raid early yesterday.

title: CREATING A THEATER JUST FOR DANCE
description: One of the most extraordinary exercises in tenacity and in will to survival within the dance world has been played out in recent months under the leadership of Eliot Feld and Cora Cahan. Mr. Feld ranks as one of the country's few major ballet choreographers and is artistic director of the Feld Ballet. Miss Cahan is the company's executive director. Both have earned reputations for being aggressive about their goals. Without that so called aggressive quality, the following story would not be possible.

title: Food; SOUPS FROM THE SEA
description: We have always believed that the seasons are as much a state of mind as they are a state of weather. We can see a robin in the snow, and suddenly it feels a bit like spring. And that means asparagus and shad are on the way.

title: New Jersey Guide; A FIRST FOR A MAJOR WORK
description: Benjamin Britten's monumental ''War Requiem'' is not performed often because it requires two orchestras (a main orchestra and a chamber orchestra), a large choir and soloists. But in Princeton on Friday, the work will be given what is believed to be its first performance in New Jersey.

title: SMOKED FISH FIRES THE TASTE BUD
description: OCEANSIDE AT the end of Mott Street, where custom-built houses and pleasure boats surround Bedell Creek, sits a small, seemingly out-of-place green cedar-shingled shack. Only a wooden sign with faded letters spelling ''Fresh Fish Daily'' announces one's arrival at Wykert's Dock.

title: BOOM TIMES FOR THE BUILDERS OF NEW YORK
description: THEIR names decorate the varicolored signs that are tacked to the pedestrian ''bridges'' that detour passers-by around rambunctious construction sites. Turner Construction. Tishman Realty and Construction. George A. Fuller. HRH Construction. Morse Diesel.

title: Court Stops Libel Suit Against Solzhenitsyn
description: A libel suit against Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has been dismissed by Federal District Judge William W. Schwarzer.

title: EAT THOSE WORDS, PHILIP ROTH
description: AMAJOR cultural event in 1980 was the Picasso retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. There, in its infinite exuberance for all the world to ogle, was Picasso's repeated affirmation of the machismo of the Catalan male.

title: U.N. PLANS PARLEY ON ENERGY SOURCES
description: As the Reagan Administration moves to cut back on Federal efforts to develop renewable energy sources and other alternatives to oil, the rest of the world is starting to move in the opposite direction.

title: INDIANS BATTLING QUEBEC OVER FISHING RIGHTS
description: Just before the salmon began to leap the boiling rapids of the Little Mingan River, a band of Montagnais Indians set nets here in a gesture of defiance of white society. Three hours later, game wardens who had been watching the operation from a helicopter transferred to speed boats and rushed up to seize the nets.

title: TV AT TRIALS STIRS A DISPUTE
description: WITH some trial lawyers opposed and the television industry in favor, the Connecticut judiciary is scheduled to decide over the next several weeks whether the state's courtrooms should be opened to television coverage.

title: Serena W. Sarnoff Betrothed
description: The engagement of Serena Warburg Sarnoff to Thomas Hartley Benenson has been announced by Robert W. Sarnoff of New York and Mrs. John B. Rogan of Charlottesville, Va., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Edward H. Benenson and Mrs. Richard Lewisohn, both of New York.

title: No Headline
description: Pat Cody of Paramount, Calif., beat Nancy Reed of Winter Park, Fla., 6-3, 6-4, for the 40's title and Betty Pratt of Winter Park defeated downed Elizabeth Harper of Altadena, Calif., 6-0, 6-4, for the 50's crown in the national senior women's grass-court championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

title: WILDLIFE HAVENS IN THE YARD
description: ''IT'S not like I have wolf packs running around my backyard,'' said Tim Anderson, describing his family's 2 1/2-acre property on Mead Pond in Rye, which was certified recently as a back-yard wildlife habitat by the National Wildlife Federation. ''We're right in the middle of suburbia, not far from the New England Thruway and the Playland Parkway, but it's a slice of something that was once woodlands.''

title: 141ST ORANGE COUNTY FAIR
description: According to officials of the Great Orange County Fair, running through next Sunday in Middletown, 1981 marks the 141st consecutive year for the fair, one of the largest of its kind in the Northeast.

title: NEW YORKERS GAIN TITLE BRIDGE FINAL
description: Contract bridge teams from New York and Texas, survivors of an original entry of more than 6,000, battled here today in the final of the Grand National Team Championship. After 32 of the scheduled 64 deals, New York led Texas by 7 international match points, 75 to 68.

title: The Betrayers Of Betrayers
description: To the Sports Editor: The article by Peter Seitz (''The Fans' 'Rights' Are Overstated,'' The New York Times, July 5) had me in complete agreement until he stated that it is not the club owners or players who are betraying baseball but the fans and writers. What nonsense!

title: Beauty EXERCISING SLOUCH AWAY Most people who work in offices are unaware of the insidious consequences of sitting hunched over paperwork, typewriter and telephone hour after hour, week after week. At the end of a rough day, they may experience muscular aches across the upper back. While that is certainly a painful inconvenience, eventually office workers can become so worn into their individual variations on the slumped position that they assume them unconsciously. And the long-term effects of poor posture are even more serious -if simple steps to correct it are not taken.
description: The office-slump problem can often be traced to a sheer lack of energy, according to Dr. Howard F. Hunt, chairman of the physicaleducation department at the University of California, San Diego. ''Because of this lack, people begin to sag noticeably,'' he says. ''They just don't seem to have the energy to sit tall and walk tall - and to remind themselves to sit taller and walk taller. So the upper-body muscles in front, the pectorals in particular, become shorter and tighter, and this makes the slouch that much more difficult to correct. At the same time, the supporting muscles in the upper back - especially the trapezius and deltoid muscles - become longer and weaker and so fail to keep the shoulders from slumping forward. All this makes for the rounded back and rounded shoulders.''

title: Topics; CULTURE SHOCKS; SIGN ON, MR. CHIPS
description: What college professor nowadays would dare to return a student's paper unread because of lapses in spelling or grammar? Surely the students would rebel, branding the don old-fashioned and eccentric, and desert his classes.

title: KILLING CLOUDS EX-CONVICT WRITER'S NEW LIFE
description: Richard Adan was a 22-year-old, Cuban-born actor and dancer. He had recently toured Spain, performed in a dramatic series for public television and finished writing a play about the Lower East Side for production next season by the La Mama experimental theater.

title: Fee on Dumping Sludge Cut From U. S. Budget
description: House and Senate conferees agreed last week to cut a provision from the Federal budget that would have cost New York City an estimated $95 million every year.

title: New, Lighter Penny Seen Saving Millions
description: The United States Mint will soon replace the ''copper penny,'' which is actually a mixture of copper and zinc with a new, lighter-weight coin containing more zinc. Frank Deleo, a spokesman for the Mint, said the change would save about $25 million a year.

title: Banker to Marry Susan McDaniel
description: Susan Page McDaniel, an assistant buyer in the modern-furniture department at Bloomingdale's in New York, plans to be married Sept. 12 to Robert Quentin Wyckoff Jr., an assistant vice president of the Bessemer Trust Company in New York.

title: DONNA REICH IS FIANCEE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Reich of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Donna Susan Reich, to Howard Alan Bachman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Bachman of Fair Lawn, N.J. Miss Reich and her fiance are seniors at Harpur College. The future bride's father is a principal in the Loweth-National Buying Corporation. The senior Mr. Bachman is executive director of the American Guild of Authors and Composers.

title: BUSINESSES OWNED BY BLACKS STILL FIGHTING AN UPHILL BATTLE
description: Twenty years ago, before racial segregation laws were wiped off the books and black people became welcome as shoppers in the downtown stores, the black business district anchored by Fourth Avenue and 18th Street was flourishing, with small service shops by the dozens, four movie theaters and several restaurants and small hotels.

title: OF LAND AND LORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Willard Dickerson Jr. to Wed Amanda Kirkpatrick
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Sharp Kirkpatrick of Wyomissing, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amanda Swinnerton Kirkpatrick, to Willard Dwight Dickerson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dickerson of Williamstown, Mass.

title: AN INFORMAL LOOK AT THE ROYAL FAMILY
description: R.W. Apple Jr. is chief of the Times's London bureau. By R.W. Apple Jr. hen Lady Diana Spencer marries the Prince of Wales on Wednesday, she will become a member of a most extraordinary family - a family that can trace its descent from Charlemagne, Egbert of Wessex and George Washington; a family in which no one has a job, in the usually accepted sense of that word; a family whose members can almost never decide on the spur of the moment to go to a movie or eat in a restaurant or spend a weekend out of town; a family whose influence resides in not being seen to exercise it; a family that symbolizes the British nation yet is mostly of foreign blood.

title: HITLER'S RUSSIAN BLUNDER
description: While Drew Middleton's article covers most of the events at that time, it overlooks the interesting role of the flight of Rudolf Hess, Hitler's deputy, to Scotland on May 10, 1941, in which he brought detailed plans on Operation Barbarossa and, in vain, tried to enlist British support for this venture. WALTER T. SCHONFELD (Former Research Analyst Nuremberg War Crimes Trials)

title: Turner, Indiana U. Star, Seriously Hurt in Crash
description: Landon Turner, the Indiana University basketball star, suffered some paralysis in both legs and hands in a car crash today about 50 miles southeast of Indianapolis.

title: ALLEN IS LONGING FOR PHONE CALL THAT HAS NOT COME
description: LOS ANGELES THE phone rings often for George Allen, former head coach of the Los Angeles Rams and the Washington Redskins. The White House tells him it's sending out two men to discuss how to reduce American flab. CBS, for which he does pro football color commentary, lets him know he will be teamed this season with Lindsey Nelson rather than Vin Scully. An editor at Simon & Schuster wants to discuss his book in progress.

title: PUBLIC POWER
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Realty News; Times Square
description: The New York State Urban Develop-ment Corporation has extended by one month the deadline for submissions from developers for the 42d Street redevelopment project. The new deadline is Sept. 4.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; TRADE
description: Trade paperbacks are softcover books usually sold in bookstores and at an average price higher than mass-market paperbacks. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: 'THE NOBLE TRADE'
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I.R.R. KEEPS ADDING COMMUTERS
description: DESPITE complaints about higher fares, ineffective or erratic airconditioning and overcrowded cars, more and more commuters are riding the Long Island Rail Road. While United States Census figures indicate that the Island's population has stabilized, ridership on the L.I.R.R., in the wake of high gasoline prices and continued traffic jams, continues to grow.

title: Strike Cancels Summer Feeling
description: To the Sports Editor: Last summer I read with great interest ''Spartan Seasons,'' by Richard Goldstein.

title: MALKIEL MATH
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Shepherd a Rookie With Experience
description: During the ceremonies preceding a stock car race on the afternoon of Oct. 26, 1980, at Martinsville, Va., Morgan Shepherd, a race driver, married Debbie Bienge in the presence of 20,000 race fans. A part-time preacher and a justice of the peace officiated.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IT'S not the Caribbean, but for a number of Westchester scuba divers, Long Island Sound must suffice. At a depth of 20 feet, even in midsummer, the temperature is only 60 degrees; underwater visibility can be less than three feet; there are no brilliantly colored fish or startling coral reefs. The Sound, however, is accessible, and challenging, and as one diver put it, ''not pretty but full of character.''

title: Children's Books
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Annie Gottlieb is a freelance writer and critic. DOES THIS SCHOOL HAVE CAPITAL PUNISHMENT? By Nat Hentoff. 170 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $8.95. (Ages 12 to 16) By ANNIE GOTTLIEB

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE GREEN MOUNTAINS
description: Sculptured from some of the oldest rock formations in North America, the Green Mountains roll gently in low, rounded peaks through the 250-mile length of Vermont. Named for their lush vegetation, the Green Mountains lack the stark splendor of New York's Adirondacks or the Presidential Range of the White Mountains in New Hampshire. The 4,393-foot peak of Mount Mansfield, Vermont's highest, is easily overshadowed by 6,288-foot Mount Washingotn in New Hampshire. What the Green Mountains lack in height, however, they make up for in beauty. The 9,609-square-mile region is home to fertile valleys, virgin forests, mountain streams and lakes.

title: DANCE: TIBETAN RITUALS
description: One of the most unusual and affecting concerts of the season took place Friday at the Altschul Auditorium of the Columbia University School of International Affairs, if indeed the ceremonial dances and music performed by 16 monks from the Tibetan Namgyal Monastery could be described as a concert.

title: The Nation in Summary; SNAPPING UP THE RIGHT TO STRIKE
description: In passing one of the nation's most liberal laws of its kind last year, the Minnesota legislature gave many of the state's employees the right to strike. Last week, they used it.

title: REVITALIZATION PLAN SET FOR INWOOD
description: INWOOD LOCAL residents have long regarded this unincorporated community next to affluent Lawrence in the Five Towns as the stepchild of the Town of Hempstead and the Nassau County government. But now town officials have advised them that a long-range revitalization plan is in the works that will improve both the community's status and its economy.

title: Experimental Heart Sustains Houston Patient for 2d Day
description: A 36-year-old Dutch tour bus driver, waiting for a heart transplant, spent his second full day with a manmade heart today amid controversy about Dr. Denton Cooley's use of the experimental device.

title: MANY CARDINALS MISSING
description: The St. Louis Cardinals opened their full training camp today without Jim Hart, their longtime quarterback, and E.J. Junior, their No. 1 draft pick linebacker.

title: A TRIBUTE TO A SUPERSTAR OF BASEBALL'S PEON YEARS
description: The strike of baseball's multimillionaires recalls a conversation I had with the great Ed Walsh about 25 years ago, a few years before he died, broke, at the age of 78.

title: DROP INDICATED IN CRIB-DEATH RATE
description: BRIDGEPORT ON the sixth floor of Bridgeport Hospital, 17 infants are being monitored around the clock to forestall sudden-infant-death syndrome, a condition that last year claimed 46 lives in Connecticut.

title: TAXING PROBLEMS
description: REAGANOMICS Supply-Side Economics in Action. By Bruce R. Bartlett. Foreword by United States Representative Jack Kemp. 229 pp. Westport, Conn.: Arlington House. $14.95.

title: The World in Summary; RISKY CHOICE: TO VOTE OR NOT
description: Voting in Iran's presidential and parliamentary elections last week proved almost as dangerous as running for office. While Iran's state radio announced that citizens were voting ''enthusiastically'' and in great numbers, widespread violence was reported and Teheran residents reached by telephone from London said turnout was noticeably down from the republic's first presidential election last year, when 14 million of Iran's 22 million eligible voters went to the polls.

title: Sports of The Times; Mike Glenn's Commitment
description: MIKE GLENN of the Knicks lived in two worlds when he was growing up. During the day he went to school where people communicated with their voices and their ears, and after school he played with his friends who communicated with their hands and their eyes.

title: AROUND THE MADELEINE: HORS D'OEUVRES TO BONBONS
description: The Madeleine a Corinthian-style Paris landmark intended by Napoleon to be a temple to the glory of his army, was consecrated as a church to Mary Magdelen in 1814 under Louis XVIII. It has had its ups and downs - at one time it was a candidate to be Paris's first railway stationbut today it remains what it was in 1814, a fashionable church at the center of a fashionable district.

title: COG RAILWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation in Summary; GETTING SERIOUS ABOUT THE DRAFT
description: Ronald Reagan opposed draft registration during the campaign. Since then, he has often given the impression he could take it or leave it.

title: Richer Pacts for Payton
description: Walter Payton, the Chicago Bears' leading rusher, signed a series of three one-year contracts today that his agent said are worth close to $700,000 a year.

title: UN-CONVENTINAL PLAY
description: Since contract bridge began to supplant auction in the 20's, the laws governing play have been issued quite frequently: in 1927, 1935, 1943, 1948, 1963 and now 1981. The gaps between revisions have grown longer, not so much because the lawmakers have become slower but because the foundation is sound and needs little amendment.

title: SOVIET'S PLAN TO USE MORE COAL RUNS INTO PROBLEMS
description: The Soviet Union, which may face a tight oil supply in the 1980's, has disclosed that a planned conversion of electric utilities to more use of coal has run into difficulties, with little improvement likely before the middle of the decade.

title: EX-JERSEY PROSECUTOR TERMS CRITICISM UNFAIR
description: A former United States Attorney for New Jersey said today that a Federal judge who criticized him and his staff for moving too slowly on the Abscam investigation into political corruption had a ''warped'' view of the role of prosecutors.

title: LIBRARIES SEEKING FINANCIAL HELP
description: TRENTON THREATENED with cuts in Federal and state financing, New Jersey's public libraries are seeking a cure for their monetary ills. Major changes seem likely in the statewide library system.

title: FOR THE MOBILE, RENTED FURNITURE
description: ''IT'S like a Chinese restaurant -you can pick one from Column A and two from Column B,'' said Ernest J. Rosenfeld, waving toward a sea of sofas, dining and bedroom sets, lamps and pictures.

title: DID TCHAIKOVSKY REALLY COMMIT SUICIDE?
description: Not everyone dotes on mystery stories. Edmund Wilson spoke for a sizable part of the reading world when he said he did not care who killed Roger Ackroyd. But the historical, nonfictional whodunit exercises a powerful fascination for most of us, even those who realize how little artistic significance may be detected in some of the solutions arrived at by the Sam Spades and Arsene Lupins of scholarship. At the moment, for instance, the mystery being followed most closely by the musical world concerns the shadowy last days and death of Piotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky. And not only the musical world: the New York City Ballet's George Balanchine, in his new ballet set to parts of the ''Pathetique'' Symphony, exploits the enigma of Tchaikovsky's death in a bizarre and doom-haunted production.

title: Tony Mason Is Hired
description: A Tucson television station has hired Tony Mason, the former University of Arizona football coach, to do sports commentaries. Jay Watson, general manager of KOLD-TV, said he expected Mason to begin his weekly commentaries ''in a couple of weeks.'' The terms of the hiring were not disclosed.

title: Music; IVES CENTER DRAWS YOUNG COMPOSERS
description: IT may be that Charles Ives became such an original composer because hardly anybody played his music during his lifetime, leaving him free to write without interference from academic, critical or even audience circles. Still, not many composers would choose to emulate that particular route to immortality, and one - Richard Moryl, who teaches at Western Connecticut State College, in Ives's hometown of Danbury - has designed a program to help insure performances of new works by his colleagues.

title: G.O.P. 'GYPSY MOTHS' TEST THEIR WINGS
description: As the details of the Reagan budget were being worked out last month, 15 moderate Republicans from Northeastern and Middle Western states threatened to desert their party unless more money was devoted to health, energy and transportation. The final G.O.P. plan contained an extra $2 billion for those areas, and though only two Republicans eventually voted no on the budget, the point had been made.

title: Practical Traveler; A CORRECTION
description: The discussion of the costs of purchasing and taking delivery of a new car overseas that appeared in this column on July 12 did not take into account the local sales taxes that would be imposed when the vehicle was brought to this country. All such cars are subject to any sales taxes in the states in which they are ultimately registered.

title: WILL CABLE TV BE INVADED BY COMMERCIALS?
description: Although cable television was never conceived of as television without commercial interruption, there has been a widespread impression - among the public, at least -that cable would be supported largely by viewers' monthly subscription fees. These days, however, as cables are laid across the country and new programs constantly pop up to fill the gaping maw, cable experts are talking as glibly about the potential advertising revenues as they are about opportunities for programming.

title: Donna M. Esperian Bride Of Scott Wallace Russell
description: At St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church in Framingham, Mass., yesterday, Donna Marie Esperian, a May graduate of New Hampshire College, was married to Scott Wallace Russell, a former student at the college and front-office manager at the Sheraton World Hotel in Orlando, Fla.

title: Miss Meier To Be Bride
description: The engagement of Sharon Eleanor Meier to Warren Francis Clark has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Meier of Washington and Portsmouth, R.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Raymond C. Ploetz of Washington Township, N.J., and Minneapolis and the late Warren F. Clark.

title: Fashion; DRESSING FOR THE TOP
description: Recently, high-ranking women have been inching away from wearing just somber suits. But most women still find that a business 'uniform' is required attire if they want to make it at the top of the corporate ladder.

title: The Region in Summary; LOSING AGAIN IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: Many low-income Atlantic City residents supported the legalization of casino gambling because they hoped to share in the promised economic resurgence. Now that prosperity is arriving, it seems, it is the poor who must move out to make room for it.

title: SUSAN SAPERSTEIN TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Saperstein of Millerton, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Barbara Saperstein, to Dr. Barry Rabin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Rabin of Brooklyn. A Nov. 1 wedding is planned. Miss Saperstein is an editor in the public-relations department of the Boston University Medical Center. Dr. Rabin is in a residency program in ophthalmology at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston.

title: Patients Need to Be Alert and Informed
description: ''The Muddle of Malpractice Insurance Rates'' by Joseph L. Stile (July 5) presents only the medical profession's simplistic side of a problem that is costly to the physician and patient alike.

title: Czechoslovaks Cleared To Play for Canucks
description: Two Czechoslovaks have been cleared by the National Hockey League to play for the Vancouver Canucks next season.

title: The World in Summary; KING AND QUEEN OF SPAIN REGRET
description: Politics was thicker than blue blood when Spain's King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia declined their invitation to the wedding this week of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer.

title: Susan Georgen Married to Walter Saad
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., yesterday, Susan Myra Georgen and Walter Keith Saad, 1979 graduates of the University of Notre Dame, were married by the Rev. John Corr.

title: HITLER'S RUSSIAN BLUNDER
description: Drew Middleton reminded us of Stalin's puzzling naivete in his dealings with Hitler.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Special states. Although Alaska and Hawaii are celebrating their 22nd birthdays as full-fledged members of the United States this year, both remain lands apart. This is partly because they are far from any of their sisters - Alaska's principal city is some 1,250 miles from the nearest point in the ''lower 48 states''; Hawaii's capital is 2,000 miles from the California coast. Each state is unique in its compound of diverse cultural and ethnic heritages and its geographical and economic conditions.

title: YOUTH NETWORK AIDS BURGEONING NUMBER OF RUNAWAYS
description: FOR a young person having trouble at home, running away often seems to be the only solution. About 3,500 did it last year in Westchester, and the number has been growing every year. Almost always, they find running away is not the answer, but it is very hard for them to return and try to find a solution.

title: Carter Wins 500; Foyt Injured
description: Pancho Carter survived an early spin, a 97-minute delay caused by a serious fuel fire and a late charge by Tony Bettenhausen to win the Norton Michigan 500 race for Indianapolis-type cars today at Michigan International Speedway.

title: A LORD, A KING, AND A COMMONER Mountbattan
description: MOUNTBATTEN A Biography. By Richard Hough. Illustrated. 302 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company will replace on an attrition basis its 16,900 capacitors containing polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB's), a suspected carcinogen, a company spokesman said.

title: Changes Asked in Yachting
description: The United States Yacht Racing Union plans to ask the Offshore Racing Council, the international governing body of grand prix yacht racing, to make changes that would broaden the responsibility for the handicapping of yachts.

title: Other World Events; STUDENT CASUALTIES IN AFGHANISTAN
description: By televising the funeral of 30 military high school cadets in Kabul last weekend and lauding them as ''martyrs,'' Afghan authorities indirectly admitted that fighting had taken place near the capital during the previous week.

title: Sperm Whale Hunting Limited to West Pacific
description: The International Whaling Commission, holding its annual meeting here, voted today to ban the hunting of sperm whales in all oceans other than the western Pacific. The species is considered endangered.

title: POLAND UNDER REPAIR
description: For almost a year now, Poland has had a functioning labor movement. But for most of that year it has lacked a functioning government. Now, after its extraordinary congress, a profoundly changed Communist Party is attempting to reconstruct a governmental authority. Its success will determine the fate of Poland's national experiment.

title: 'Mourners Below'
description: OURNERS BELOW,'' James Purdy's 11th novel, takes place in a timeless drift that vaguely resembles World War II. Two brothers, Justin and Douglas Bledsoe, have been blown to bits. They died ''in the same division, on the same day,'' and their ''grim unmended bathrobes'' are sent home in a crate to the small Midwestern town where they were born. ''There was nothing to bury but maybe a dog tag and some scraps of clothes.''

title: SUPPORT FOR VICTIMS OF DISABLING ILLNESS
description: WHEN Molly Cohen telephoned a neighborhood center for the elderly when she was seeking an activity for her husband, Sid, a recent stroke victim, she was told, ''Don't bring him here. He'll depress the others.''

title: Business Conditions; HOW HIGH THE RATE?
description: West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's comment in Ottawa last week that real interest rates - calculated by deducting the rate of inflation from the nominal interest rate - are at their highest levels in Germany ''since the birth of Jesus Christ'' may be accurate. As far as the United States is concerned, however, Schmidt's estimate was off by roughly 1,940 years.

title: NEW ALLIANCE FOR EDUCATION, INDUSTRY ASKED
description: CONNECTICUT'S system of public elementary and secondary education is among the best in the nation. This contention is supported by interstate comparisons of test results, postgraduation follow-up studies, literacy rates and other data. Despite the records of the 165 local and regional districts making up the system, public education has recently come under a barrage of criticism from some of the more vociferous representatives of Connecticut's businesses and industries - ironically, the very institutions that stand to lose the most from a system of education weakened by declining confidence.

title: NEW PARTNER FOR METROPOLITAN STRUCTURES
description: One of the nation's largest development organizations, Metropolitan Structures, which is based in Chicago, has decided to pursue all its future projects as the 50-50 partner of the nation's second largest insurance company, Metropolitan Life.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said today that negotiations for the withdrawal of Soviet SS-20 missiles targeted on Western Europe could begin only after a firm decision to install comparable American missiles.

title: UNLOVED AND ANGRY
description: MOURNERS BELOW By James Purdy. 295 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95. By JEROME CHARYN

title: STUTTERERS FIND A WAY TO OVERCOME
