description: OLD BRIDGE THREE times a month, members of a group called the First Amendment meet at Old Bridge Regional Hospital here to practice speaking. They do vocal exercises, ask questions, give short talks and enact roles. When the meeting is over at 10 P.M., they adjourn to a diner, where conversation can last until the early hours of the morning.

title: SOLAR ENERGY ADDS TO RENEWAL PLANS IN BRONX
description: Amid the forsaken buildings and rubble-strewn lots of the South Bronx, three rehabilitated buildings have been moved into the age of solar energy conservation.

title: OYSTERING: A FAMILY TRADITION THRIVES
description: EVERY fisherman says his catch is the biggest and best. And according to an oysterman, Hillard Bloom, Connecticut produces the tastiest, plumpest oysters.

title: BEHIND THE RISING DIVORCE RATE
description: LOOK around at five couples you know who have been married, ostensibly happily, for 15 years or more. One of them will untimately wind up in the divorce courts. The national epidemic of mid-life divorces has not spared Westchester; marriages of 15, 20, and 25 years can no longer be regarded as secure or stable.

title: U.S. FIVE DEFEATS SOVIET
description: Howard Carter of Louisiana State scored 28 points and John Pinone of Villanova 27 as the United States beat the Soviet Union, 113-107, in double overtime at the World University Games basketball tournament today.

title: C.J.'S NICHE
description: To the Business Editor:

title: MARINES PLANNING 5-YEAR EXPANSION
description: The Marine Corps has drawn up an ambitious five-year plan to reorganize its manpower, obtain a vast increase in firepower, acquire more tactical mobility and expand its combat support elements.

title: Bait Techniques for Luring Big Bass
description: ROBERT ROCCHETTA'S 76-pound striped bass caught off Montauk, L.I., earlier this month reinforces the notion held by many anglers that live bait, particularly the live eel, is the most effective way of going after very large stripers.

title: A LORD, A KING AND A COMMONER
description: DUCHESS The Story of Wallis Warfield Windsor. By Stephen Birmingham. Illustrated. 344 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $15.95. THE KING OVER THE WATER By Michael Pye. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $12.95.

title: GIBSON, THE HUNGRY LION, APPROACHES THE HALL
description: THE voice on the telephone was a clear, forceful tenor. ''This is Bob Gibson,'' the man said. ''Bob Gibson, the pitcher?'' I said. ''Who the hell do you think?'' ''Well,'' I said. ''I'm an admirer of your work.''

title: ITALIAN CATACOMB REVEALS ANCIENT JEWISH SITE
description: A team of American and Italian archeologists excavating near the southern Italian hill town of Venosa this summer has discovered a vast catacomb that was apparently used as a burial ground by the town's Jews in the last centuries of the Roman Empire.

title: MARTHA COBURN BETROTHED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Coburn of Weston, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Anne Coburn, to Geoffrey Graham Blum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Blum of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: a street library; MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: or years, I had avoided going to China. The East has been my particular interest and fascination for decades, but when China did open, I avoided even a visit. I had become desperately bored by MarxistLeninistliberationist jargon. So, it must be said at the outset that, when curiosity finally triumphed over slogan sickness, I traveled to China with one suitcase and a duffel bag - as well as a lot of other baggage in my mind.

title: Swiss Rock Slide Kills 6
description: EMS, Switzerland, July 25 (AP) - Earth and rock apparently loosened by several days of heavy rains crashed down on a tent at a campsite, killing five girls and their 18-year-old leader, the police said. All the victims of last night's rock slide at the campsite about two miles outside Domat-Ems in eastern Switzerland were Swiss.

title: LOMBARDI WAS A COACH IN BERGEN, NOT HUDSON
description: The New Jersey Weekly of July 5 reported a suggestion to rename the new sports arena in the Meadowlands in honor of Vince Lombardi, instead of our Governor.

title: CROTON RIVER DRIES IN ONGOING DROUGHT
description: WITH the level of New York City's reservoir system continuing to rise since drought-emergency measures were put into effect last winter, at least one area of Westchester County seems to be suffering the effects of the continuation of the drought emergency.

title: A TIMELY HARVESTING OF SUMMER'S JOYS
description: CONVENIENCE and frugality are not the only reasons for growing one's own fruits, vegetables and flowers. Certainly it is handy to be able to go to the backyard for lettuce for a salad, strawberries for dessert and a bunch of zinnias for the table, but convenience alone is not all that important. And it may be more costly to grow one's own than purchase them, especially when the cost of time, equipment and supplies is considered.

title: New Jerseyans
description: PUT away the lesson plans and pull out the Legislative Manual. For the next two years, it's away from the school system in Lakehurst and over to the State House in Trenton for Edithe Fulton of Toms River.

title: Cheryl Renee Pone Bride Of Vernon Lequith Outlaw
description: Cheryl Renee Pone, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jesse J. Pone Jr. of Old Westbury, L.I., was married yesterday to Vernon Lequith Outlaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Outlaw Jr. of the Bronx.

title: African News Agency Plans To Start Operating Next Year
description: The Pan-African News Agency will start operating next year, its controlling intergovernmental council decided yesterday.

title: Art; TRENTON OFFERING ART DOUBLEHEADER; TRENTON
description: NEW JERSEY artists, known and unknown, are getting attention in both of Trenton's museums right now. At the State Museum through Aug. 30 is a major retrospective by Jacob Landau, the printmaker, while at the City Museum in Cadwalader Park is the third in a series of shows by local protagonists. This exhibition, which will continue through Thursday, is co-sponsored by the museum and the Trenton Artists Workshop Association.

title: OH, IT'S A ROYAL TIME
description: THE dispatch from London said: ''As the London social season races toward the crescendo of The Wedding, it has acquired in this special year a glamour not seen in decades.''

title: Crafts; ENVIRONMENTAL ART IS ENLIVENING WORKPLACE
description: MAYBE you can't fight City Hall, but in the Secaucus Municipal Building you're welcome to grapple with the art. Specifically, that means a monumental fiber work that is suspended in the two-year-old structure.

title: Antiques; SALEM OFFERS TASTE OF COLONIAL AMERICA
description: SALEM JUST before the hour, the tall-case clock in the front parlor of the Salem County Historical Society Museum plays six tunes in a tinkling music-box style. This is the time to arrive, for the music sets the scene for a visit to Colonial America.

title: 'ANNIE' IS STILL A SURE SHOT
description: IT is hard to believe that ''Annie Get Your Gun'' is a 35-year-old musical. It seems like only yesterday that it began its Broadway run of 1,147 performances. The original production included Ethel Merman and the songwriter-lyricist Irving Berlin, both in top form. Together they flooded the theater with hit songs. And then in 1966, when Miss Merman did a revival of the musical, Irving Berlin provided her with one more excellent number, ''Old Fashioned Wedding,'' just to show that he hadn't lost his touch.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE conquest of space means one thing to the world, quite another to Long Islanders. The booming of the suburbs, you graybeards will remember, began more than 30 years ago because the city had no place to put all its people and its people had no place to put anything in their apartments.

title: Pamela C. Noble Wed to Professor
description: The marriage of Pamela Cusick Noble, a candidate for a master's degree in biostatistics at the University of Vermont, to Dr. Takamaru Ashikaga, an associate professor of mathematics at Vermont and director of the biometry facility at Vermont's College of Medicine, were married in Scarborough, N.Y., yesterday.

title: The Week in Business; LITTLE ACCORD AT THE SUMMIT
description: The heads of state of seven major industrial nations closed their seventh summit meeting with pledges to revitalize their economies, but no precise agreements. President Francois Mitterrand of France, right, and other European leaders charged that high American interest rates were crippling investment in their nations. President Reagan made no economic concessions, but the United States did warm up to global negotiations on north-south economic disparities.

title: Reader Comment; A JOB FOR CONGRESS
description: I AM disappointed that Paul MacAvoy, who has had the opportunity to observe government first-hand, did not give closer attention to the institutional roles and responsibilities involved than he reflects in his article on the Supreme Court decision in the cotton dust case, ''The Indecisive Cotton Dust Decision'' (July 5).

title: BY DIANE HENRY
description: Curtis Katz readily acknowledges that he has become known as one of the ''bad guys'' in New York City's booming business of cooperative conversions. But, Mr. Katz, who is converting several Manhattan buildings, says the label is unjust. His public relations agent agrees with him. So does his attorney, city Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky. And some tenants who want to buy their apartments from Mr. Katz support him.

title: Diane Ross Bride of Willis R. Buck Jr.
description: Diane Marie Ross and Willis Roome Buck Jr., candidates for doctoral degrees in English at Yale University, were married in the Dwight Memorial Chapel on the Yale campus in New Haven yesterday. The Rev. Alfred H. Whisler, rector of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: MODERN COMFORT ON THE WATER
description: For about 20 years, Valentino, the Italian designer of fashion and furnishings, favored speedboats. Then he decided to slow down, and last year he commissioned Cantieri San Lorenzo, the Italian boat builder, to make him a yacht that would be fast -reaching speeds of up to 23 knots - but that would satisfy his yearning for the kind of comfort that no speedboat affords.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A PRACTICAL USE FOR $10 MILLION
description: Museums have always been magnets for philanthropists wanting to endow their gifts with a touch of class, but rarely has so generous a donation been made for such necessary but unglamorous uses as that announced last week by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Met is getting $10 million from Harold D. Uris, a builder and real estate developer, to create and endow the Ruth and Harold D. Uris Center for Education.

title: Leila Farrah, Tore Farnes, Physicians, Have Nuptials
description: Dr. Leila Farrah, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abdulrahim A. Farrah of Bronxville, N.Y., and Hargeisa, Somalia, was married in Bronxville yesterday to Dr. Tore Farnes, son of Dr. and Mrs. Oluv Farnes of Oslo.

title: Other Business; THE CROISSANT TAKES ON A FAST FOOD LOOK
description: When Edgar Bronfman, chairman of Seagram, and Richard Beeson, former chief executive officer at Canada Dry who also was an executive at Kentucky Fried Chicken, get involved in croissants, one can assume that the business is more than continental chic.

title: REGAN CAMPAIGN FUND HAS $120,000 SURPLUS
description: A number of investment-oriented companies -some of which do business with the state - have supplied State Comptroller Edward V. Regan with much of the almost $120,000 he has in surplus political campaign funds.

title: HANDICAPPED GAIN NORMAL CLASS SPOTS
description: THIS fall, Paul Stangel will be back in the Glen Cove school system for the first time in five years. The 13-year-old has been attending classes at different centers run by the Board of Cooperative Educational Services since the second grade. His parents had requested during his second year in the Glen Cove Elementary School that he be sent to the specialized centers when they realized that he was hyperkinetic and was not learning to read along with his classmates.

title: VENEZUELAN CABLE CAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Wedding Is Held For Beth McLane
description: Judith Elizabeth McLane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. McLane of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Rene Stocker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodor Stocker of Zug, Switzerland.

title: No Headline
description: Muckler Stable's Apalachee Honey closed with a rush at Monmouth Park today to capture the $160,120-added Sorority Stakes for 2-year-old fillies.

title: Notes; A SAMPLER OF LATIN AMERICAN CRUISES AND EXCURSIONS
description: For those who dread the return of winter, these hot days might be a good time to plan a trip to South America - where, six months from now, it will be the height of summer. Seasons in the Southern Hemisphere are, of course, the reverse of those in the Northern, and the extremes of temperature can be just as wide. For those who prefer milder weather, Central America offers agreeable year-round temperatures, in addition to food, architecture and geography of continuing interest.

title: GAMES THAT SUPERPOWERS CAN PLAY
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ
description: During the first two nights of the recent Kool Jazz Festival, Joe Williams was a ubiquitous presence. On the opening night, he served as host for the first half of a program called ''the art of jazz singing'' and gave his own demonstration of how it is done.

title: THE EARTH'S SECRETS ARE HIS DELIGHT
description: IN the office of Donald J. Weidner on the third floor of the Earth and Space Sciences Building of the State University at Stony Brook, there is a rectangular wood-and-metal plaque.

title: B.J. Klimley, Miss Eimicke Are Married
description: Laura Suzanne Eimicke, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Victor W. Eimicke of Bronxville, N.Y., was married in the Reformed Church there yesterday to Brooks James Klimley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Klimley of Chicago. The Rev. Dr. Charles L. Copenhaver performed the ceremony.

title: Theater in Review; 'TALLEY'S FOLLY' AT SUMMERSTAGE
description: FOR the final offering of its three-play season, Roger Shoemaker, artistic director of Summerstage at Trinity College, has come up with a lovely production of Lanford Wilson's ''Talley's Folly.''

title: BLACKS SEEK DISMISSAL OF MILWAUKEE POLICE CHIEF
description: A black man's death in police custody has brought calls from Milwaukee blacks for the discipline of the three officers involved and for the dismissal of Police Chief Harold A. Breier.

title: SPRAY LUBRICANTS AN ANSWER TO MANY A HOUSEHOLD PROBLEM
description: displacing lubricants of the penetrating type that come in easy-to-use spray cans are part of almost every professional mechanic's tool kit. Many homeowners, however, still do not realize how useful and versatile these spray lubricants can be around the house and how many maintenance problems they can help to solve.

title: Personal Finance; 'LOOPHOLE CERTIFICATES' AND OTHER QUERIES
description: T HE following are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q. I recently bought a large ''loophole certificate'' and had to borrow part of the principal from the same bank to meet the required minimum. How much interest must I report on my tax return - the total amount of interest earned on the C.D. or only my net interest earnings after subtracting the interest on my loan from the bank?

title: Politics; A POLITICAL DILEMMA FOR THE G.O.P.
description: A FEW hours after the attempted assassination of President Reagan on March 30, two detectives from the Greenwich Police Department arrived at the home of Prescott Bush Jr. to offer to guard the New York insurance executive pending the possible assignment of Secret Service agents. If the President were to die, Mr. Bush's younger brother, George, the Vice President, would become the 41st President, with his immediate family subject to Federal protection.

title: POLITICAL POLLS: HOW EAGLETON TAKES A PULSE
description: CHARLES JACOBS'S article, ''A Political Lesson Learned'' (Opinion Page, July 5), rings with the first law of politics: If you don't like the message, blame the messenger.

title: BRITISH PRESS CHIDES MRS. REAGAN ON PROTOCOL
description: Nancy Reagan is finding it difficult to charm the British press. This morning, only 24 hours after she arrived in London to attend Wednesday's royal wedding, both popular and quality newspapers mocked her in prominently displayed stories. Much was made of the fact that the First Lady has decided neither to curtsy nor to bow to Queen Elizabeth II when she goes to Buckingham Palace but to shake hands.

title: New Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK AREA'S RELIANCE ON IMPORTED FOOD GROWS
description: New York State and its neighbors, once major agricultural producers, have grown dangerously dependent on imports of most of their food from other parts of the nation and abroad, food experts and public officials say.

title: SENATORS' CRITICISM OF C.I.A. CHIEF CALLED 'PERSONAL' BY WHITE HOUSE
description: White House officials said today that Republicans on the Senate Intelligence Committee seemed to have such strong ''personal'' objections to the fitness and judgment of William J. Casey that the Director of Central Intelligence might have to resign.

title: DEBATING THE CRITICAL POWER SHORTAGE
description: The man with the tape recorder could not be bothered with the usual preliminaries. He got right to the point in a way that can be disconcerting when one has been fretting about the raids on Beirut, the hotel cave-in in Kansas City, the indictment of a man for the Atlanta murders and three new recipes for zucchini, to say nothing of the futures of Conoco, Brooke Shields, the universe and the French franc.

title: POWER AGENCY PLAN: WHAT IT MEANS
description: WESTCHESTER County's search for cheaper electric rates brightened considerably last week, with bipartisan political support and even a nod of approval from the Consolidated Edison Company, for the creation of a county municipal power agency that would be authorized to purchase lower-cost power from any source.

title: Crime
description: Roy Lewis is a British author who writes traditional mysteries. Some of them are expert; most are bland, since Mr. Lewis is not one to rock the boat. Though he always has worked within the conventions, he has one edge over most writers of his kind. He was trained as a lawyer and called to the bar, and in those of his books that deal with legal matters, a calm authenticity prevails.

title: Reading and Writing; AN AMERICAN PLEIADE
description: Almost every literate visitor to the United States agrees that in the first 200 years of its existence this country got itself a great literature.

title: The Week in Business; VOLCKER VOWS MORE MONEY SUPPLY CUTS
description: The Federal Reserve Board plans more cutbacks in the money supply, chairman Paul A. Volcker said. The announcement came as European Summit leaders urged the United States to ease monetary restraints. On Friday, the Fed reported that the broad money supply, M1-B, fell $5.9 billion in the latest reporting week to a seasonally adjusted average of $428.9 billion. That followed a startling $6.9 billion jump the week before.

title: HITLER'S RUSSIAN BLUNDER
description: The article implies that if the Germans had captured Moscow - instead of concentrating on the Ukraine and the Caucasus - the Germans could have won the war with Russia.

title: CURIA WITHOUT AMICA
description: To the Editor:

title: VIOLENCE IN THE FAMILY ASSESSED AT CONFERENCE
description: Researchers from several professions dealing with family violence met here this week for four days of self-assessment that gave them cause for quiet satisfaction but also concern about the future of their work.

title: BARTER BECOMES BIG BUSINESS IN WORLD TRADE
description: When Levi Strauss, the world's largest maker of blue jeans, decided to expand its European operations in 1978, it began talks with the Government of Hungary. Hungary wanted to build a blue jeans plant, but did not have enough hard currency to pay for it. The solution: Hungary bought equipment and expertise from Levi Strauss, and Levi Strauss agreed to buy back a share of the production. The company now takes 60 percent of the plant's annual output, about one million pairs a year, which it sells in Europe and Africa.

title: Graydon C. Smith Will Be Married
description: The engagement of Graydon Calvert Smith to Kevin Gerard O'Connor has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Pike Smith of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Edmund O'Connor of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: CRIME RATE FOR MAY SHOWS FIRST DECLINE IN CITY IN 14 MONTHS
description: The number of violent crimes reported in New York City decreased slightly in May, marking the first time since March 1980 that the monthly rate had shown a decline, according to the Police Department.

title: Wedding on L. I.  For Miss Keegan
description: Margaret M. Keegan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Keegan of Patchogue, L.I., was married there yesterday in St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church to Samuel Morgante, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Morgante of Jamestown, N.Y. The Rev. Edward J. Boyle performed the ceremony.

title: Helen Joline, a Nurse, Wed to Michael Sirois
description: Helen Pendleton Joline and Michael Raymond Sirois were married yesterday in Hanover, N.H. The Rev. Parkman D. Howe Jr. performed the ceremony in St. Thomas' Episcopal Church.

title: Karen J. Balinski Wed To Thomas John Shea
description: Karen Joan Balinski, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thaddeus A. Balinski of Perth Amboy, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas John Shea, son of Joan Ann Shea of Port Washington, L.I., and Joseph Charles Shea of New York. The Rev. Robert Zamorski performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Court Rules Pardoned Agents Can Appeal Their Convictions; The Washington Star
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that two former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation convicted of approving illegal break-ins could appeal their convictions even though they had been pardoned by President Reagan.

title: REPORTERS AND A CRITIC
description: COVERING ISLAM How the Media and the Experts Determine How We See the Rest of the World. By Edward W. Said. 186 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $10.95. Paper, $3.95.

title: OREGON SMOKING LAW SIGNED
description: Smoking in retail stores and many other Oregon commercial establishments will be restricted by the middle of 1983 under a bill signed into law last week by Gov. Victor G. Atiyeh. The measure, which takes affect July 1, 1983, requires that smoking areas be set aside in banks, many restaurants, retail stores, schools, auditoriums and arenas and other public places.

title: The Region in Summary; MISS HOLTZMAN RUNNING FOR D.A.
description: There might be more criminals in the hands of the law if politicians had less of a hand in law enforcement, Elizabeth Holtzman implied last week in announcing her candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Brooklyn District Attorney.

title: Nancy Doyle Affianced to John Palmer
description: Nancy Carr Doyle and John Spencer Palmer, who are with NBC-TV in Washington, will be married on Jan. 2. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Doyle's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Carr Doyle of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: DANCE
description: Molissa Fenley is the first entry among the avant-garde dancers and choreographers who are performing this month on a landfill in lower Manhattan. The ''Art on the Beach'' series, as it is called, encompasses musical events and emphasizes art exhibits on the site.

title: Judith Mary Anderson Married to Bruce R. Fulco
description: Judith Mary Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Anderson of Nanuet, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Bruce Richard Fulco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Fulco of Southbury, Conn. The ceremony was performed in St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Otto Hentz of Georgetown University and the Rev. William E. Warren.

title: CHURCH FOR HOMOSEXUALS ASKS TO JOIN COUNCIL
description: A church organized 13 years ago to accept practicing homosexuals has grown to more than 170 congregations in the United States and overseas, and is now applying for membership in the National Council of Churches.

title: Elaine T. Kanelos Married
description: Elaine Terese Kanelos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Kanelos of Lake Geneva, Wis., was married there yesterday to Thomas M. Whalen, son of Mrs. John L. Whalen of Spring Valley, Ill., and the late Mr. Whalen. The Rev. Allan Mattingly performed the ceremony at St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church. The bride is in charge of advertising and sales promotion support in the cash management account department of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York, where her husband is a vice president of marketing service management.

title: Realty News; Broadway
description: Smith Barney Harris Upham Company, a securities and brokerage concern, has leased the entire 23d floor at 100 Broadway with more than 9,000 square feet of office space for 10 years at an aggregate of more than $2.5 million.

title: HITLER'S RUSSIAN BLUNDER
description: Drew Middleton's fine retrospective of the Wehrmacht's assault on Russia prompts this observation (''Hitler's Russian Blunder,'' June 21).

title: BLACKS SHIFT TO SHARPER CRITICISM ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: President Reagan's relations with blacks have frequently been awkward. His campaign was marked by a shouting match with Bronx ghetto residents and by his pilgrimage to Mississippi's Neshoba County Fair, an old-time segregationist stronghold. Only 19 of 400 top appointments in the Administration have gone to blacks. When the most senior of the 19, Housing and Urban Development Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr., visited the White House recently, Mr. Reagan had trouble picking him out among a group of big city mayors.

title: POP: THE SRO TRIO SINGS
description: In the last two years, the singing trio SRO has made two noticeable changes: it has dropped the stars that once glittered between the capital letters of its name, and Nancy Hillner, the original woman in the group, has been replaced by Denise Nolin.

title: TECHNICALITY COULD VOID PLAYER PACT
description: If the baseball strike drags on much longer, the 26 major league club owners may face the loss of all their players through a legal technicality.

title: Strange Shoots 64, Shares Lead With 2
description: Curtis Strange shot a courserecord seven-under-par 64 today to pull into a three-way tie with John Mahaffey and Howard Twitty at 209 after three rounds of the $300,000 Anheuser-Busch tournament at Kingsmill Golf Club.

title: Shelton, in a Porsche, Is Trans-Am Winner
description: Monte Shelton of Portland, Ore., led from the start today and won the 100-mile Trans-American auto race by 18.34 seconds at Road America.

title: AFTER OTTAWA, ALLIES STILL FAR APART ON THIRD WORLD
description: WASHINGTON THE most serious difficulties for leaders of the Atlantic Alliance have usually been not in Europe, but in the gray areas of the third world - Korea in 1950, Dienbienphu in 1954, Suez in 1956, the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, the Vietnam war and, more recently, Iran and Afghanistan. This is where the fighting has been and where the danger of conflict with the Soviet Union has been greatest. So it was not surprising that when Western and Japanese leaders met in Ottawa last week, the main items on their agenda were pushed aside by the flareup in the Middle East.

title: SOME PATENTLY INGENIOUS DEVICES
description: Some of the most gimmicky of 19th-century gadgets are among the thousands of United States patent models that Cliff Petersen, an aeronautics engineer, has had catalogued and is offering by mail. The collection is the remains of what American inventors devised between 1790 and 1898, the bulk of which was first sold by the United States Government in 1926 to Sir Henry Wellcome, who planned to install the 150,000 models in a patent model museum.

title: THE BALLET STAR AS GUEST ARTIST
description: Barry Laine writes frequently about dance. By BARRY LAINE

title: Connecticut Journal
description: POLITICS has been making strange bedfellows of late in New Haven, where Mayor Biagio DiLieto, who is skirmishing with some of his fellow Democrats this summer, is enjoying a full-blown honeymoon with the area's first-term Republican Representative, Lawrence J. DeNardis, of Hamden.

title: After Upset, Barrett Wins 2 Swim Golds
description: Bill Barrett of U.C.L.A., upset early in the day by a California prep school star, recovered and won two more gold medals today and shared top honors in swimming at the National Sports Festival.

title: David Heidecorn to Wed Deborah Joan Stern in Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney L. Stern of Perth Amboy, N.J., and West Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Joan Stern, to David Heidecorn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Heidecorn of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: MANNERS, ENGLISH-STYLE
Miss Funkhouser Becomes a Bride
description: Eleanor Kent Funkhouser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Paul Funkhouser of Jacksonville, Fla., was married yesterday in Bryn Mawr, Pa., to Michael Doar, son of John Doar and Anne Leffingwell Doar of New York. The Rev. Thomas Halcott performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: A $25 PENALTY OPENS HOMES TO METER READERS
description: One of the banes of urban life, increasing with husbands and wives both away from home as wage-earners, is the problem of getting actual instead of estimated readings for electric and gas use. This is aside from paying the regular bills.

title: A 'TOM JONES' AT BEST VULGAR
description: ''TOM JONES'' is based on the great British film of 1963, which was adapted from the Fielding novel that detailed the adventures of a young man in 18th-century England. The book for the musical version was created by the husband-and-wife team of Don and Pat MacPherson in 1967 for summer-stock production in Jackson Hole, Wyo. It went from there to the lounge at the Desert Inn in Las Vegas, where it played seven nights a week, two shows a night for more than two years. It has been back to Las Vegas twice since then. At An Evening Dinner Theater, this is the second production of the musical.

title: BALTIMORE, Md.
description: The exhibition of Mondrian's drawings and watercolors that has now come to the Baltimore Museum of Art (through Sept. 20) is an event of very great interest. Mondrian's place as a pioneer figure in the creation of abstract art is well known, of course, and his historical position among the masters of the modern movement looks even more secure today than it did at the time of his death in 1944. What could still be construed as a sectarian view of art in that distant period is now firmly established as a vital tradition that commands the loyalty of many living artists. Geometrical abstraction of the sort that Mondrian introduced into modern painting may still have its portion of highly vocal enemies - there is almost no artistic position on the current scene, after all, that doesn't - but that in itself is a proof of its continuing existence.

title: THE SPY WHO RAN INTO THE HEAT
description: William J. Casey was trying to ride out a political storm last week but the barometer was dropping fast. ''This will either die out or Casey will go,'' said a White House aide, ''and I imagine that we will wait through the weekend before something happens.''

title: No Headline
description: Ana Maria Carrasco of Venezuela bettered the world record with 6,970 points today as she qualified easily for the tricks water skiing final at World Games I.

title: No Headline
description: Ten thousand CARE packages destined for elderly and ailing people in the southwest region of Silesia were unloaded here today in the first part of a planned $14 million in food aid from the organization.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE STEPS UP INQUIRY ON CASEY FINANCES
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York and vice chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said today that the panel would broaden its inquiry into the business dealings of William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence.

title: SAN DIEGO GETS AN OLD-STYLE TROLLEY
description: They opened the ''Tijuana Trolley'' this week, a streetcar line that runs 27 blocks through downtown San Diego and links the city with the Mexican border, 14 miles to the south.

title: 21 Die in Pakistani Flooding
description: Monsoon rains inundated the Punjabi capital of Lahore, and five people were crushed under collapsing buildings there, officials said. They said 16 other people were killed in flash floods.

title: Shergar Sweeps Triple
description: Shergar, a 3-year-old owned by the Aga Khan, won the $286,000 King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Diamond Stakes today and completed a rare triple in British horse racing.

title: FRUIT FLY PESTICIDE LONG IN USE HERE
description: THE pesticide malathion, which is being used to combat the spread of the Mediterranean fruit fly in California, has been widely applied without incident in New Jersey and across the country, according to state and Federal officials.

title: The World in Summary; LIFE WITHOUT EXPLANATIONS
description: It has been easier to render justice than discover truth in the case of Mehmet Ali Agca, who boycotted most of his trial in Rome last week and was sentenced to life in prison. He refused to answer questions, precluding any chance to tell the court why he shot Pope John Paul II.

title: LONDON TO BROADWAY--FROM 'NICKELBY' TO 'CATS'
description: LONDON The brightest and most felicitous lyrics of the current London theatrical season were written as nursery rhymes in 1939 by that august poet, T.S. Eliot, and one of the few new shows of merit was written in 1871 by the Russian playwright, Alexander Ostrovsky. Eliot's posthumous contribution is to Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical, ''Cats,'' the most popular English musical since the composer's pre-Eliot collaborations with Tim Rice (''Jesus Christ, Superstar,'' ''Evita''). London has quickly become ''Cats'' conscious and a Broadway production is inevitable. At the same time, theatergoers are joining the queue at the Royal Shakespeare Company's small, experimental Warehouse Theater to see ''The Forest,'' which comes to London from the R.S.C.'s home at Stratford-Upon-Avon. Ostrovsky follows Maxim Gorky and Nikolai Erdman as R.S.C. Russian rediscoveries.

title: GOAL BY BULJAN GIVES COSMOS OVERTIME VICTORY OVER MANIC
description: For the second time in 72 hours and for the third time this season, the Montreal Manic and the Cosmos played into overtime today. The outcome did not change; the Cosmos won.

title: STABLE SAUDI ARABIA
description: To the Editor:

title: CHANNING ENCHANTS IN 'DOLLY'
description: WESTBURY ''HELLO, DOLLY!'' has a lot going for it besides Carol Channing - that's been proved - and everything else Carol Channing has going for her was the stuff of show-business legend way before the star took charge of the musical matchmaker 17 years ago.

title: Business Forum; THE BURDEN OF FRIEDMAN'S MONETARISM
description: M ILTON FRIEDMAN is not a big man, but he is very heavy. His monetarist economic ideas are a deadweight burden on the shoulders of Menachem Begin and the Israeli economy. They crush down on Margaret Thatcher as England riots. They are crippling the Nobel Laureate's old friend, Ronald Reagan, the United States economy and indirectly, all of our trading partners. Professor Friedman is barely five feet tall, but his shadow falls across the last decade of global inflation.

title: FOR FULTON FERRY AREA A NEW SENSE OF PURPOSE
description: On Brooklyn's western waterfront, a river's width away from the crush of lower Manhattan, a cluster of shabby brick buildings offer magnificent vistas of the city's skyline.

title: Realty News; PARK PLACE
description: The 14-story office building at 53 Park Place has been sold by the Park Place-Dodge Corporation to 53 Park Place Realty Company, of which Marvin S. Winter is a principal, for $2.75 million.

title: QUAKE SURVIVORS HEAD HOME
description: WESTPORT NINETEEN Italian children, survivors of the earthquake that struck southern Italy last November, returned to their hometown of Balvano last week. They had been brought here for a vacation and to help raise money for the reconstruction of their town.

title: Reagan Plans to Limit TV Speech to Tax Cuts
description: After pleas from Republican leaders, President Reagan has dropped plans to talk about the financially troubled Social Security program in a televised speech Monday and will focus his remarks on his tax-cutting program, the White House said today.

title: Sara Moore Wed To Keith Lashley
description: Sara Moore and Keith Livingstone Lashley were married yesterday in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Craig Moore, parents of the bride, in Danielsville, Pa., by the Rev. George Williams of the Unitarian Church of the Lehigh Valley. The bridegroom is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edgar Lashley of Milford, Conn.

title: JET'S DEFENSE UNDERGOES RIGORS OF 'GARDI METHOD'
description: As usual, the voice is booming. Joe Gardi is not shy, and, despite his constant battles with overweight, he strides with aplomb before 100 extraordinary physical specimens - mostly young men, who would be Jets - and shouts them through the day's calisthenics at the team's training camp here. ''Yoga!'' he screams, and they dutifully assume the lotus position.

title: ADULATION GROWS AFTER DEATH OF SOVIET FOLK HERO Vysotsky
description: The event was announced nowhere in the newspapers or posters of the Soviet capital, but the authorities knew as well as the rest of Moscow that yesterday was the first anniversary of the death of Vladimir Vysotsky.

title: 156 Haitians in Sailboat Are Rescued Off Florida
description: More than 150 Haitians, some of them emaciated, have been rescued from a wooden sailboat off the coast of southern Florida, the Coast Guard said today.

title: Foot Patrols Cut Fear, Not Crime, Study Says
description: Police officers walking a beat on foot reduce citizens' fear of crime, but do not reduce crime, according to a major study released today.

title: ANALYZING THE PANGS OF JEALOUSY
description: Jealousy has been described by Freud and by Margaret Mead as the consequence of threats to self-esteem; by Darwin as the operation of the monogamy instinct; and by various others as a reflection of guilt, the fear of loss, the replaying of the Oedipal situation and the reaction to the violation of sexual property rules.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: He's scheduled to be the Secretary General at a model United Nations session at Deerfield Academy this fall, and the 17-year-old senior thought it would be a good idea to learn something about the real thing this summer. That might have meant reading up on the organization at the library and perhaps taking a public tour but, as the young man acknowledged the other day, ''I'm lucky.''

title: Ghosts at the Wedding
description: British police are understandably anxious that Wednesday's royal wedding may provide a tempting target for the Irish Republican Army. But a terrorist outrage in the streets of London seems unlikely. The I.R.A. has found a more devastating way to spoil the party - through fasting. While fairyland reigns in England, a destructive emotional revulsion rules in Ireland.

title: FERN S. COHEN IS MARRIED TO ROBERT DOUGLAS BILLET
description: At Temple Emeth in Teaneck, N.J., yesterday Fern Suzan Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Allen Cohen of Teaneck, was married to Robert Douglas Billet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Billet of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Louis Sigel officiated.

title: Inmate in a Fight With Jean Harris
description: Jean S. Harris, serving a term for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, was involved in a fight with another inmate at the Bedford Hills Correctional Center, according to a spokesman for the New York State Department of Correctional Services.

title: Iran Says Reports 'Lie' About Argentine Plane
description: Iran tonight dismissed as a ''lie'' and ''fairy tale'' reports that an Argentine plane that crashed in the Soviet Union last weekend had carried military equipment from Israel to Iran.

title: Henning Winner
description: Harold Henning of South Africa shot a 1-under-par 71 in the final round today and won the $80,000 Dutch Open golf championship. Henning, 47 years old, finished with a total score of 280 and won the $13,000 first prize. He was one shot ahead of Ray Floyd of the United States, who shot a final-round 70.

title: CONFEREES NARROW KEY ISSUES
description: House and Senate conferees today narrowed the biggest areas of disagreement delaying completion of a $37 billion package of budget cuts, and they were optimistic about reaching agreement tomorrow.

title: Strike Back, Fans
description: The baseball strike has led to the creation of at least half a dozen organizations aimed at stirring fan revolt against baseball. Though there is no big-name advocate heading any of the groups, if warfare can be waged with petitions, press releases, letters to the editor, news conferences and advertisements, the battle has been joined.

title: Utility Workers End Strike
description: About 5,400 members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, on strike against the Georgia Power Company since July 9, ratified a new contract yesterday and will return to work tomorrow, officials said.

title: Izzy Zimmerman's New Day in Court
description: Any efficient system of retribution for crime would have killed Izzy Zimmerman long ago. He was in fact condemned to death in 1937 for supplying the gun that killed a policeman during a restaurant holdup on Manhattan's East Side.

title: U.S. Powerlifters Excel
description: Jim Cash of Manhattan, Kan., set two world records in powerlifting today and three other Americans won gold medals in the event in a sweep that gave the United States 10 gold medals after three days of competition in World Games I.

title: Payton Said to Get $700,000 a Year
description: Walter Payton, star running back of the Chicago Bears, has signed three one-year contracts worth close to $700,000 a year, his agent said last night.

title: 70TH WAGNER FESTIVAL OPENS
description: The 70th Richard Wagner Festival began yesterday in Bayreuth with a new production of ''Tristan und Isolde,'' with the Chicago-born soprano Johanna Meier singing Isolde.

title: Rugby Tour in New Zealand
description: The New Zealand Government, postponed until Tuesday a decision on whether to call off the South African rugby tour that has led to violent demonstrations.

title: STATE SEEKS SPOT FOR FARMERS' MARKET
description: Hoping to lower food prices for consumers and to encourage the region's small farms, New York State is trying to set up a wholesale ''farmers' market'' where local growers may sell directly to retailers, restaurants and food cooperatives. But the state's first effort, at the city-owned Hunts Point Market in the Bronx, has been rebuffed by produce merchants.

title: MAN KEPT ALIVE BY ARTIFICAL HEART GETS REAL ONE
description: A 36-year-old man kept alive for three days by a plastic heart received the heart of a 29-year-old donor today. Doctors said they were optimistic about the patient's chances of survival.

title: RIGHTEOUS OUTRAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. to Begin Inquiry In Rural Georgia Threats
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation says it will conduct a ''preliminary inquiry'' this week into a series of shootings, cross-burnings and threats aimed at racially mixed families in this rural southern Georgia county.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MOVIES

title: ICE SHOW GETS TOUCH OF DISNEY
description: DURING the 50's and 60's, it seemed every town and suburb was building arenas, called cultural centers, sports centers or entertainment centers. It is probably more than coincidence that this phenomenon has paralleled the durable and increasing attraction of ice shows as one of the few live staples to survive attractions that are electronic and visible in the parlor.

title: Return of Riggins
description: After a season away from football, John Riggins is back, and General Manager Bobby Beathard of the Washington Redskins couldn't be happier.

title: Kendrick F. Bellows, 74, Dies; Former Official of Con Edison
description: Kendrick F. Bellows, a retired vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died at his home in Plainfield, N.J., yesterday after a short illness. He was 74 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: Israel is now engaged in some sober arithmetic, adding up the pluses and minuses of its intensive bombing of Lebanon, including Beirut, and of the cease-fire that halted the fighting on Friday. The ledger shows significant gains for Israeli interests, militarily and politically. But the losses, from the Israeli perspective, are equally dramatic, including the diplomatic damage to Israel's reputation and the enhanced status of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: MAKING THE SALT COUNT EASY
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR PLUNKETT '81 POSES A BIG TEST
description: that is, vitamins - even the washroom graffiti reads, ''Take your salt and sportsmins.''

title: VARIABLE VERDICTS ON HUMAN UPHEAVALS
description: To the Editor:

title: CARL VAN BRUNT MARRIES BONNIE AUGUST IN JERSEY
description: Bonnie August, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph August of River Edge, N.J., was married yesterday to Carl Van Brunt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Van Brunt of Mount Kisco, N.Y. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the Van Brunt home.

title: Con Ed Reports $40 Million Saving
description: A $40 million saving to electric customers in New York City and Westchester has resulted from the use of 1.5 percent sulfur-content oil at three generators since last August, the Consolidated Edison Company announced.

title: Rajai's Vote Put Higher Than Bani-Sadr's in Iran
description: The Iranian state radio said tonight that Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai received 1.5 million more votes in Iran's second presidential election than his ousted predecessor, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, received in the first, which was held in January 1980.

title: WOMAN, 87, WHO LIVED IN TERROR IS FOUND DEAD
description: The police did not always believe a woman here when she told them of invaders in her home and nighttime terror. But after her locks were changed, the officers paid special attention to the house.

title: LOIS J. NAFTULIN MARRIED TO JUDGE EDWARD LEHNER
description: Lois J. Naftulin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Naftulin of Philadelphia, was married in Melrose Park, Pa., yesterday to Judge Edward H. Lehner of the Civil Court of the City of New York. Rabbi Edward Maline performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Naftulin.

title: HIKERS FINDING A 'WHOLE DIFFERENT WORLD' ON THE APPALACHIAN TRAIL
description: They started, most of them, in Georgia in the spring and they have moved north with the warm weather. Once they were a rarity, sometimes only one a year, but their numbers have increased sharply. They are the hikers who are out to go the entire distance of the Appalachian Trail and many of them are now passing through the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut sections of the trail on the way to its end at Mount Katahdin in Maine.

title: WESTWAY NON-HURDLE
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY THE U.S. KEEPS TRACK OF CUBAN JOURNALS
description: To the Editor:

title: TWINS BORN AFTER ONE UNDERGOES SURGERY IN WOMB
description: A University of California medical team has performed the world's first known successful surgical treatment of an unborn child, a male twin now 11 weeks old, doctors reported today.

title: CORPORATE AID HELPING TWIN CITIES TO THRIVE
description: From the architecturally innovative pedestrian mall that has revitalized the downtown business area to the newly restored residential neighborhoods bordering the commercial district, Minneapolis is a company town, a thriving urban center where virtually every civic improvement has been planned and paid for by the prosperous corporations that have their headquarters here.

title: BANKS CAUGHT IN RATE SQUEEZE
description: Caught in a profit squeeze as the result of high interest rates, the nation's 15 largest banking concerns experienced a difficult second quarter.

title: by Brendan Murphy
description: You'd have to look far and wide to find a piece of federally owned land on which conflict between users and managers has risen to as high a pitch as it has at the Cape Cod National Seashore.

title: DIRECTOR OF MET OPERA STUDIO
description: William H. Nix, who was stage manager and director of the Metropolitan Opera Studio, died of cancer Saturday afternoon at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: LA SCALA BALLET: A DIFFERENT 'GISELLE'
description: LA Scala Ballet's ''Giselle'' had a new leading couple Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. And it is no exaggeration to say that with Anna Maria Razzi's Giselle and Marco Pierin's Albrecht, the production as a whole had a dramatic coherence that was missing earlier with its guest stars.

title: REFORMS IN WATER PLANS HOLDING UP U.S. FUNDS
description: The future of the multi-billion-dollar Federal sewage treatment construction program, a major element of the nation's effort to clean up streams, lakes and coastal waters, is hanging in the balance.

title: LEADERS OF P.L.O. DENOUNCE FACTION THAT BROKE TRUCE
description: The Palestinian guerrilla leadership today sharply criticized a radical faction that has refused to honor the shaky cease-fire along the Israeli border in southern Lebanon.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS GAIN A VICTORY IN HUNTING BAN ON SPERM WHALES
description: The decision by the International Whaling Commission for a virtual ban on the hunting of sperm wales as its annual meeting in Brighton yesterday represented a victory for conservationists.

title: Maruzen Oil Planning Cuts
description: The Maruzen Oil Company announced a plan that calls for a cut in its work force, separation of two small oil refineries and the sale of assets.

title: Nehemiah Holds Off Foster
description: Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah's immediate goals are faster times in the 110-meter high hurdles. But looking toward the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, Nehemiah and his new coach, Wilbur Ross, have set their sights on a more ambitious gold-medal plan - the hurdles and the decathlon.

title: ALICE RICHMOND WED TO HEALTH OFFICIAL
description: Alice Elenor Richmond, a lawyer in Boston, was married there yesterday to David Lee Rosenbloom, commissioner of Health and Hospitals for the City of Boston. The ceremony was performed at the Castle, the former president's house on the campus of Boston University, by Rabbi Sanford Seltzer, regional director of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

title: OIL DRILLING IN GEORGES BANK
description: At 4:57 P.M., Wes Campbell, a driller working for the Shell Oil Company, lowered a column of steel pipe deep into the Atlantic, 200 miles off the coast of Massachusetts. The drilling column stiffened slightly as it hit bottom and then punched a 17 1/2-inch hole in the sandy face of Georges Bank.

title: GOLDIN'S OFFICE FINDS LAPSES IN CITY CONTROL OF LONG GUNS
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, has urged New York City to tighten its controls on rifles and shotguns sold to residents. A study by the Comptroller's office of the Firearms Control Board found ''poor communication'' between the board and the Police Department, Mr. Goldin said. The study found that licenses had been issued to ineligible applicants and that there were violations by gun dealers.

title: ROYAL WEDDING GIFTS: EXTRAORDINARY AND ORDINARY Diana
description: Expressing the good wishes of the American people, President and Mrs. Reagan are giving Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer a wedding present befitting a future King and Queen. It is a magnificently engraved Steuben glass bowl. In addition, the Reagans are giving a handmade porcelain centerpiece by Boehm.

title: VISITORS AND WORSHIPERS FIND SOLACE AMID NATURE AT CATHEDRAL IN A VALLEY
description: From the plain wooden pews beneath a canopy of evergreens, visitors can absorb the soothing scenery beyond the sturdy Altar of the Nation, which forms the centerpiece of the Cathedral of the Pines, one of the nation's most active ecumenical centers of worship.

title: Brubeck and Mann To Share Bill Aug. 12
description: Dave Brubeck and Herbie Mann will share the bill in a performance Aug. 12 at 7:30 P.M. on Pier 16 at the East River and Fulton Street, at the South Street Seaport Museum.

title: THE TWO KINDS OF 'FOREIGNERS' AMONG
description: USTo the Editor:

title: HAYNES FORSEES IMPROVED SEASON
description: If there were any unfavorable reviews of the Giants' No. 1 draft choice last year, Mark Haynes did not read about them.

title: CONFREES STRUGGLE WITH BROADCAST DEREGULATION
description: Legislation that would substantially diminish the Government's role in regulating radio and television is spurring a fierce debate in Washington that includes members of the House and Senate, the new head of the Federal Communications Commission and consumer and public-interest groups.

title: HUDSON MARSH GAINS STATE PROTECTION
description: Once a battleground between rival Indian tribes, a now-peaceful tract here bordering on tidal wetlands in the Hudson River will be preserved as a prime breeding ground for fish, a wildlife refuge for birds and an undeveloped recreational area for people.

title: Precipitous Descent
description: He's not considered a member of Britain's Royal Family, but like the Queen, Walter Lee Sheppard Jr. claims direct descent from Edward III and other royal progenitors.

title: I DON'T NEED A PASSPORT
description: On one thing, the United States Supreme Court was right.

title: WESTWAY TALKS BRING ON ACCORD ON KEY DETAILS
description: City and state officials said yesterday they had tentatively agreed to a plan that, if remaining details were worked out, could clear the way for construction of the Westway highway project.

title: Commodities; C.D. Trades Will Need Liquidity
description: THE new futures markets in domestic bank certificates of deposit that started on the Chicago Board of Trade last Wednesday and the New York Futures Exchange on July 9 could not have come at a more opportune time.

title: NIGERIAN OFFICIAL, WARNING U.S., TALKS OF OIL CUTS
description: A senior Nigerian official has raised the prospect of reprisals against the United States over such issues as the Reagan Administration's policies on South-West Africa and a South African rugby tour of the United States organized by clubs in Los Angeles and New York.

title: Siegel Triumphs
description: Steve Siegel of Teaneck, who won the tournament in 1971, rallied to beat Tom Csipkay of Wyckoff, 6-3, 1-6, 6-4, in the final of the 18th annual Westfield Invitational today at the Westfield Tennis Club.

title: MAYOR OF PHILADELPHIA PONDERING A POLITICAL DEFEAT
description: Mayor William J. Green, a man who usually looks as if he had never had a sleepless night, got up at 5 A.M. the other day with some troubling thoughts, a friend says, and began to make some notes.

title: VILAS AND CLERC REACH FINAL
description: Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina moved into the final of the $200,000 Washington Star tennis tournament today with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over Stanislav Birner of Czechoslovakia.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JULY 27, 1981
description: International Palestinian guerrilla leaders censured a radical guerrilla faction that has refused to honor the shaky cease-fire along the Israeli border in southern Lebanon. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command was described in a broadcast statement by the Voice of Palestine radio as ''irresponsible'' and ''heedless of Lebanese and Palestinian blood.'' Except for three brief incidents of firing by the defiant faction, the cease-fire has not been violated. (Page A1, Column 6.) Philip C. Habib arrived in Washington and was expected to discuss with President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. the cease-fire he helped negotiate as the United States special envoy to the Middle East. Meanwhile, Senator Henry M. Jackson, senior Democratic member of the Armed Services Committee, said there was no question that the United States would resume delivery of the F-16 planes to Israel. (A6:3-6.)

title: VICTORY AT PENN CENTRAL
description: When the Penn Central Corporation last week announced an agreement in principle to acquire Colt Industries, it was another victory for Richard Dicker, Penn Central's 67-year-old chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Dicker, who has held those offices since 1978, following the transportation company's reorganization, is overseeing the transformation of the former Penn Central Transportation Company into an energy and technology company.

title: OUTDOORS: ELUSIVE NORTH CAROLINA TROUT
description: EDGEMONT, N.C. ALLOWING only two or three days for fishing unfamiliar waters at a poor time of year is like trying to woo a woman on a Ferris wheel. Both gambits are dubious.

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan is preparing a final effort to get his tax bill through Congress. Yesterday he entertained 15 Democratic Representatives at Camp David, and tonight he will address the nation on television. However the TV address, on the advice of Republican leaders in Congress, will make no mention of proposed cuts in Social Security benefits. (Page D1.)

title: Studies Planned On S.I. Oil Port
description: The Port Authority announced it has authorized environmental and engineering studies on a plan to develop a $170 million crude-oil handling facility on Staten Island.

title: DAYS INNS OFFICER AIMS AT BUSINESS TRAVELER
description: John Hunter, 37, has recently been appointed senior vice president, marketing, for Days Inns of America Inc., a 10-year-old company that has historically catered to the ''dollar-conscious Middle American traveler'' with inexpensive, no-frills motels on American interstate highways. Now Days Inns is building hotels downtown.

title: No Headline
description: George Vecsey A Quite Cr- usade

title: LAWYERS WILL PAY $50 FEES UNDER LAW SIGNED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey announced today that he had signed into law a bill requiring all lawyers in the state to pay a $50 registration fee every two years.

title: MAHAFFEY WINS BY 2 STROKES
description: John Mahaffey, in a three-way tie for the lead after three rounds, shot a four-under-par 67 and scored a two-shot victory today in the Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic.

title: Acaroid, $11.20, Triumphs
description: Acaroid, who has never lost on the grass, kept his record intact yesterday, beating the heavily favored De La Rose in the $87,300 Lexington Stakes for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park.

title: The Talk of Ossining
description: From his house on the bluff, the warden in years past could see sailboats fluttering along the broad Hudson River and, across the iridescent water, the Palisades cliffs.

title: DIRECTOR OF C.I.A. ASKING A HEARING TO ANSWER CRITICS
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, today asked the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence for a hearing ''as soon as possible'' to allow him to respond to questions raised about his judgment and business practices.

title: The Price of Cleaner Air
description: The Clean Air Act comes up for renewal this fall with its goal of healthy air for all Americans still unrealized. The act has reduced the number of hazardous days in urban areas and the average concentration of major pollutants. But some areas, like New York and Los Angeles, will find it difficult if not impossible to reduce pollutants to the levels decreed for 1982 and 1987.

title: Advertising; Bates Adds Atlanta's No.1 Shop
description: TED BATES WORLDWIDE, which already has five autonomous subsidiaries around the country, including the largest agency in Minneapolis, is about to acquire McDonald & Little, Atlanta's biggest shop.

title: 2 AT ESTEE LAUDER GET PRESIDENT POSTS
description: Estee Lauder Inc. has promoted two of its senior executive vice presidents to the newly-created position of presidents of their respective divisions.

title: Index; International
description: Limitation on whale hunting seen as victory for conservationists A3 As wedding nears, palace leaves nothing to choice A4 Around the World A5 Government/Politics House Democrats casting about for ways to punish defectors A10 Budget conferees narrow differ- ences in key areas A10 State trying to set up ''farmers' market'' in metropolitan area B3 Goldin urges tighter controls on long guns in New York City B4 General Around the Nation A8 Woman in Chicago called for help repeatedly before her death A8 Missouri Congressmen worried about state's redistricting A11 In Ossining, a village and a prison strive to get along B1 Appalachian Trail drawing more and more hikers B1 A kite flier gets a ticket from a po- lice helicopter pilot B2 New York State is preserving a marsh bordering the Hudson B2 Health/Science Fetus, a twin, undergoes surgery and both survive D8 Style Relationships: Analyzing the pangs of jealousy A13 The Livingstons: A Clan's Story A13 Royal weddings gifts: Extraordi- nary and ordinary A13 Obituaries William H. Nix, director of Met Opera Studio D9 Features/Notes Issue and Debate: Plea of in- sanity in criminal court A9 Notes on People A12 Going Out Guide C14 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Waltrip wins 500- mile race in disputed finish C3

title: MAYOR STARTS 2D CAMPAIGN ON SAFE TURF
description: As a campaigner, it turned out, Edward I. Koch, the candidate, was not much different from Edward I. Koch, the Mayor. There he was in the Rockaways yesterday, the collar of his longsleeved white shirt flapping in the firm breeze, the knot of people around him in bathing suits.

title: Racing Chiefs Summoned
description: Ogden Mills (Dinny) Phipps, board chairman of the New York Racing Association, and James P. Heffernan, N.Y.R.A. president, have been subpoenaed to testify today in State Supreme Court in Queens, where Larry Saumell, the jockey, seeks a permanent injunction to keep the association from barring him at New York tracks.

title: British Set Sept. 21 For Belize Independence
description: Belize, a self-governing Central American colony that is Britain's last American mainland possession, will gain full independence on Sept. 21, the Foreign Office announced today.

title: SOVIET IS SAID TO WAIT AND WATCH AS REAGAN'S POLICIES TAKE SHAPE
description: Diplomats from Eastern and Western Europe have concluded that, for the time being, Moscow has settled on a wait-and-see strategy toward the Reagan Administration rather than a stepping up the level of confrontation as Soviet officials were suggesting at the beginning of the year.

title: ROBERT P. KENNELLY
description: The Rev. Robert P. Kennelly, a Maryknoll missionary who spent 25 years in China, died Friday of a heart attack in Kona, Hawaii.

title: MAINE PORT MOVING TO REVERSE DECLINE
description: The wooden piers along the waterfront here are host mainly to small fishing boats and tourist craft. Business activity, for the most part, is moribund, although Portland is considered one of New England's best natural ports.

title: A FEEBLE CASE AGAINST CASEY
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The cease-fire was made with the P.L.O. There is no point in concealing this.

title: Youths Attack Police In New Liverpool Riot
description: Gangs of youths attacked policemen in Liverpool early today in a renewal of the street violence that plagued towns and cities across the country earlier this month.

title: TAX BILL VOTE TEST ANTICIPATED
description: President Reagan invited 15 House Democrats to Camp David to lunch today in an effort to win Democratic votes for the third major test of strength this year on fiscal issues between him and the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.

title: 'Worker Concern' Ends Long Strike
description: Workers have narrowly approved a contract settlement of their 12-week strike against the Okonite Company, a wire and cable concern that, on paper, is owned by the employees.

title: THE U.S. FAMILY
description: Public debate over abortions, the Equal Rights Amendment, divorce, out-of-wedlock births, and welfare has raised deep-seated concerns about the future of the American family. Almost all the ruminations on the current status and future of the family have tended to be extreme. Alarmists issue dire warnings that the family is disintegrating, while others respond with shouts of joy, welcoming the crumbling of the institution.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK WAYS OF PUNISHING DEFECTORS
description: Since they lost two critical budget votes on the House floor, some Democratic Congressmen have been casting about for ways to discipline party members who have regularly provided the Republican margin of victory in the current session.

title: FINISH DISPUTED
description: Who won? That depends on whose scoring you believe. Cale Yarborough drove into Victory Circle of Pocono International Raceway this afternoon and refused to budge while Darrell Waltrip was outside, demanding to have his car admitted.

title: BYRNE CRITICIZED ON BUDGET USE OF CASINO FUND
description: When the voters approved casino gambling in Atlantic City in 1976, the language of the referendum restricted the use of tax revenues from the casinos to reducing property taxes, rentals or utility bills paid by elderly residents and the disabled.

title: 'LINGUISTIC TRICKERY' IN THE PRO-LIFE CAMP
description: To The Editor: After remarking on ''the prostitution of truth and language by influential pro-abortion forces,'' Raymond Bannker (letter July 9) proceeds to say that ''innocent unborn babies are hunted out by scalpel and poison.''

title: NOT-SO-MALIGNANT
description: CONGLOMERATESTo the Editor:

title: DISMAY IN CANADA AS CURRENCY SAGS
description: The Canadian dollar has slumped to its lowest level in 50 years, and interest rates have soared to record highs as the pressures on the Canadian economy continue to mount in the face of high American interest rates.

title: ISSUE AND DEBATE last November; THE PLEA OF INSANITY AND ITS USE IN CRIMINAL CASES
description: The decades-old debate over whether insanity should remain a defense in criminal cases has flared again as a result of the attempt on President Reagan's life March 30 and other recent cases.

title: INVESTORS PREPARING FOR TREASURY OFFERING
description: Investors and traders in the credit markets are beginning to prepare for their second opportunity in three months to buy a large amount of new Treasury notes and bonds while yields are at or near record high levels.

title: GETTY AND SHELL RAISE PRICES IN ANSWER TO NEW YORK'S TRANSIT TAXES
description: Two more companies, Getty and Shell, have increased their gasoline prices in response to New York State's new transit-aid tax package. A rise of 2.7 cents a gallon for gasoline, diesel fuel and heating oil was announced by the Getty Refining and Marketing Company. The increase took effect Saturday. A Getty executive called the action ''a direct result'' of both the new 0.75-percent tax on oil-company gross receipts and the so-called unitary tax, which changes the formula for calculating oil-company state income taxes.

title: TOOL ORDERS ROSE 34.8% IN JUNE
description: Orders for machine tools, one of the key barometers of capital spending by American business, rose 34.8 percent in June from May, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.

title: Widespread Drug Sales Found Around Wall St.
description: Drugs are being sold openly in the Wall Street area during weekday business hours, according to a report by the State Division of Substance Abuse Services.

title: A KITE FLYING OVER BROOKLYN TANGLES WITH THE LAW
description: Larry Cuttitta was flying his nine-foot-wide red-white-and-blue kite in the balmy afternoon breezes high above Brooklyn yesterday when he got entangled in a legal battle with the New York City Police Department.

title: SOME TEAMS SEND PLAYERS THEIR SIDE
description: Red Smith Hot Franchises for Sale

title: CORPORATE BORROWINGS REMAIN LOW
description: Corporate finance officers continue to defer long-term borrowings while interest rates are at record high levels. This week's offerings could total less than $300 million, with the bulk of the borrowing accounted for by a $200 million issue of Aaa-rated Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company debentures due 2021.

title: News Analysis
description: When Mayor Koch announced that he would no longer let Harlem residents have any advantages over outsiders in buying city-owned property in their community, he not only stunned and angered some Harlem leaders, but he also took some of his own top aides by surprise. The remark came just as housing officials had agreed to, and the Board of Estimate was about to approve, a plan to give Harlem residents a three-to-one advantage in the lottery sale of 13 abandoned brownstones in the area.

title: F.B.I. Found No Conspiracy In Hinckley Case, Aide Says
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has concluded that John W. Hinckley Jr. acted alone in the shooting of President Reagan March 30, a spokesman for the bureau said today.

title: Pintor Keeps Title With a Knockout
description: Lupe Pintor of Mexico retained his World Boxing Council bantamweight crown today by stopping Jovito Rengifo of Venezuela in the eighth round at the Showboat Hotel Sports Pavilion.

title: Bridge: Rally by Texans Captures Grand National Team Title
description: Four players from Texas and one from Mexico won the Grand National Team title here in the early hours of this morning, capturing the final against New York by 36 international match points.

title: DEARIE ASSAILS JERSEY TRANSIT AID
description: Assemblyman John C. Dearie, a candidate for City Comptroller, yesterday attacked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's plans to contribute approximately $2.5 million toward running two upstate commuter lines whose costs had been primarily borne by the New Jersey Transportation Corporation.

title: AS WEDDING NEARS, PALACE LEAVES NOTHING TO CHANCE
description: It is about as certain as anything can be that the royal wedding procession Wednesday morning will set out from Buckingham Palace precisely on schedule at 10:22 - not a minute early, and not a minute late.

title: Air Traffic Union Says Pact Is Losing in Vote
description: Air traffic controllers are voting ''overwhelmingly'' to reject a tentative contract with the Federal Aviation Administration, according to samplings of the nearly completed tally, Marcia Feldman, press aide for the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization, said tonight.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a map that appeared Saturday showing alternate redistricting plans for Norfolk, Va., the legend was incorrect. The solid line on a north-south axis, dividing Norfolk's black voters into two small electoral parcels, shows the reapportionment plan adopted by the Virginia General Assembly and rejected by the Justice Department as having been drawn with ''discriminatory racial purpose.''

title: Carmen Ottilio Dead; New Jersey Contractor
description: Carmen Ottilio, a demolition contractor who was once accused of offering a $100,000 bribe to an agent of the Internal Revenue Service, died yesterday in Greater Paterson General Hospital in Wayne, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Totowa.

title: PFITZINGER CAPTURES MARATHON AT NATIONAL SPORTS FESTIVAL
description: Pete Pfitzinger, who was permitted into the field only yesterday after officials resolved a question about his eligibility, won the marathon at the National Sports Festival today in 2 hours 15 minutes 20 seconds.

title: COURTS MAY DRAW MISSOURI DISTRICTS
description: After legislative attempts to draw new Congressional district boundaries failed because of partisan, rural-urban and perhaps racial divisions, Missourians have turned to the Federal courts to solve the political questions that politicians did not solve.

title: Two Men Shot In Holdup Bid
description: Two men were shot during a struggle between an unarmed Greenwich Village store owner and one of four men who had tried to hold up the store, the police reported.

title: New Irish Plant
description: General Semiconductor Industries announced it would build a $7 million manufacturing plant in Macroon, Ireland.

title: Special Effort Wins Futurity
description: Special Effort took the lead at the start and went on to defeat Winkum by a length and a half in the $567,389 Rainbow Futurity for 2-year-old quarter horses at Ruidoso Downs.

title: THE THEATER: 'VILLAGER,' PORTRAIT OF HARDING
description: IT'S tricky when an author changes a comedy to a drama halfway through the play, and if he does, he ought to be awfully careful how he goes about it. ''Villager,'' the new play at the Lion Theater on Theater Row, starts as a lame-brained comedy, and then, intermission scarcely over, darkens its mood, flirts with melodrama and comes closer to being what the author, Ron McLarty, probably intended it to be in the first place. ''Villager'' is a play about the private lives of public people.

title: Market Place; Tender Offers: Some Nuances
description: WALL STREET sources acknowledge that the fight over Conoco Inc. is a replay of strategic patterns developed by McDermott Inc. in two prior offers - its successful fight for the Babcock & Wilcox Company in the summer of 1977 and the contest over Pullman Inc. in the summer of 1980.

title: Castro Blames the C.I.A.  For an Epidemic in Cuba
description: President Fidel Castro said tonight that he shared the ''profound suspicion'' of many Cubans that a series of disastrous crop blights and the current epidemic of dengue fever, which has killed 113 people, including 81 children, were deliberately introduced into Cuba by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: CAROL BETH RESNICK WED
description: At the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y., yesterday Carol Beth Resnick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Resnick of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married to Howard Steven Romanoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Romanoff of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Norton Shargel officiated. The couple are with Burlington Industries, she as a textile designer and he as a vice president of the Burlington Menswear division.

title: SENATOR JACKSON SEES DELIVERIES OF F-16'S SOON
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy, returned to Washington today as officials here considered how best to exploit a cease-fire in the Middle East that Mr. Habib had helped negotiate.

title: PAT BRADLEY WINS OPEN BY SHOT WITH RECORD 279
description: Pat Bradley, who had finished second 24 times in her professional career, won the United States Women's Open golf championship today with a record score of 279.

title: Steyn Triumphs In Tennis Final
description: Christo Steyn, a 19-year-old amateur from South Africa, gained his first victory in a professional tournament today in the $7,500 John Muir Southampton Tennis Classic final.

title: Conamor Winner In Larchmont Sail
description: Conamor, a new 39-foot sloop designed by Nelson Marek and skippered by Stephen Lieber of Mamaroneck won the grand prix division convincingly yesterday in the Larchmont Yacht Club's 83d annual Race Week.

title: THE LIVINGSTONS - A CLAN'S STORY
description: Nine-year-old Sarah Nelson of Houston, one of the younger sprouts on the family tree, wasn't particularly interested in its branches and entwined roots. She turned somersaults on the lawn, happily oblivious to the activity around her.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in SportsMonday on July 13 on a Federal inquiry into point-shaving, incorrectly identified the college attended by Rick Kuhn. Mr. Kuhn, a former basketball player, attended the Boyce campus of the Community College of Allegheny County, in Monroeville, Pa.

title: Walesa Enters Hospital For Tests and a Rest
description: Lech Walesa, the leader of the Solidarity trade union, entered a hospital today for medical tests and rest, a union spokesman said.

title: THE 2 GENERALS AT THE TABLE COMMAND WITH SIMILAR STYLE
description: THEY do not pitch or hit, they rarely step onto a diamond, they will never appear in a box score. But, in this lost summer of 1981, they are baseball's chief performers, and they are making more history than Pete Rose with his 3,630 hits and Gaylord Perry with his 294 victories pitched.

title: No Headline
description: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner QUESTION: A hit-and-run play is indicated with men on first and second and none out. The runners start moving on the pitch; the batter hits a pop fly, and the umpire signals that it is an infield fly. But the runners keep moving, with the man from first passing the man from second, who has stopped between second and third. The ball, without being touched by a fielder, hits the man from second, who still has not returned to his base. Is it a triple play?

title: INDIANA'S TURNER HAS SOME PARALYSIS
description: Landon Turner, a basketball star for Indiana University, the defending national collegiate champion, was in serious condition today with some paralysis in his hands and legs after an automobile accident yesterday, a hospital official said.

title: POEM BY THE LAUREATE
description: ''Let's all in love and friendship hither come Whilst the shrill treble calls to thundering Tom, And since bells are for modest recreation Let's rise and ring and fall to admiration.'' Those lines are taken from a ringer's rhyme Composed in Cornwall in the Georgian time From the high parish church of St. Endellion, Loyal to the monarch in the late rebellion, Loyal to King Charles the First and Charles the Second, And through the Georges to our Prince of Wales, A human, friendly line that never fails.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Security Bank elected Kevin G. Woelflein president, chief operating officer and a director of American Security Bank N.A., a subsidiary.

title: Billy Graham's Plea
description: Few men have raised as much money over the years as Billy Graham, but recent contributions to his Evangelistic Association have apparently not been keeping up with expenses.

title: The Bigger the Better
description: Cries of ''victory'' are resounding from the 45-and-over set. Senior players are energized by the recent news that the International Tennis Federation has refused to ban outsize racquets though setting some standards for racquet dimensions.

title: JUDGE BACKS DOWN IN FACE OF CHANGES IN PRESERVATION LAW
description: A Federal judge ruled last week that a new law made ''plain'' the Interior Department's authority to designate selected sites and buildings as landmarks for preservation.

title: ERICA AVA GREEN IS BRIDE OF BARRY KAPLAN, LAWYER
