description: The marriage of Erica Ava Green to Barry Martin Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Kaplan of New Hyde Park, L.I., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Michael Green, in Springfield, Mass. Rabbi Robert Neil Levine performed the ceremony.

title: AL JARREAU'S ELECTICISM
description: AL JARREAU may be the most technically gifted singer working in jazz-fusion today. With his multioctave range, he boasts a stylistical eclecticism that encompasses gospel, jazz, pop and African and Latin American idioms. Mr. Jarreau has won a large and loyal following by synthesizing these styles into a highly polished, uplifting jazz-pop approach.

title: U.S. WILL LIMIT AID FOR SAVINGS BANKS
description: Despite the huge losses that the nation's savings institutions have been reporting this year, the Reagan Administration has decided to limit its assistance to low-keyed, informal measures that protect depositors but leave the $800 billion industry to fend mostly for itself.

title: Washington Watch; Treasury View Of Thrift Units
description: WASHINGTON THE Treasury, on a tack 180 degrees from bank regulators, is downplaying the danger to thrift institutions from high interest rates, arguing that adequate backup already exists for just about any emergency - and that rates should be headed down pretty soon anyway.

title: Middle East Crossroads
description: Once again after an outbreak of bloodshed, a series of subtle changes in Middle East relationships has created new dangers and new opportunities.

title: NEW YORK' FEMALE TRAINERS: IT'S THREE FOR THE MONEY
description: SALLY BAILIE leaned back against the dusty wooden plank that stretches across the entrance to Barn 60 at Belmont Park. She looked down the long shed row at the stable workers who were finishing their morning tasks with the 17 horses she trains.

title: Ernie Holmes Held in Assault
description: Ernie Holmes, a member of the Pittsburgh Steelers' famed defensive line of the 1970's, has been arrested and charged with assaulting a barmaid.

title: No Headline
description: OIL SPILL: The Liberian tanker, Afran Zenith, ran aground near the port of Hamburg, West Germany, carrying about 77,000 tons of crude oil destined for refineries. Three hundred tons of oil leaked from ship covering banks of the River Elbe. The oil spill is drifting downstream to mouth of river toward North Sea.

title: INFLATION GIVES BIG PUSH TO ART IN MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY OIL booms are not normally a source of artistic inspiration, but when sudden economic growth brings inflation and when investors start looking to safeguard their profits, oil can translate into a very convincing stimulus to the creative process. That, at least, has been the case in Mexico. The art market has expanded as fast as the country's oil production has, and recognized painters and sculptors are now earning 3 to 10 times more for their works than just four years ago. And they are, needless to say, busy at work.

title: Foyt's Condition Good
description: A.J. Foyt won't be driving race cars for a while. Foyt, 46 years old, was listed in good condition today at University of Michigan Hospital in Ann Arbor after two hours of surgery early this morning to repair injuries he suffered in a crash during yesterday's first running of the Norton Michigan 500.

title: Hart of Cardinals Signs Contract
description: The veteran quarterback Jim Hart ended his holdout today and signed a one-year contract with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Ruth Alice Horowitz Becomes a Bride
description: Ruth Alice Horowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irvin M. Horowitz of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to David Phiroze Christensen, son of Dr. and Mrs. James R. Christensen of Rochester. Rabbi Frederick Dworkin performed the ceremony at the Horowitz home.

title: L.I. Mother Held In Attempt on Son
description: A 37-year-old woman who reportedly had a history of mental illness tried to set her 11-year-old son afire, the police said.

title: SOVIET, U.S. FIVES GAIN MEDALS ROUND
description: The United Stated and Soviet basketball teams advanced to the medals round of the World University Games today, and Jill Sterkel, an American swimmer, became the first American to win three gold medals.

title: In the Army Now
description: When vacation time rolls around, Leamon Hall, the former passing star at West Point, doesn't think twice about where to spend a big chunk of his 30 days off. Hall, an Army first lieutenant stationed at Fort Benning, Ga., packs a bag and heads for the Coast. Though a service commitment precludes his playing pro football until the 1983 season, Hall chooses to spend about three of his four weeks of annual leave working out in drills with the Dallas Cowboys, who signed him as a free agent last year.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt A MATTER OF DEGREE. Heat, Life, and Death. By Lucy Kavaler. 226 pages. Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: CLAUDIA R. KAWATA MARRIAED TO PETER ROBERT ROUX
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday Claudia Reimi Kawata, a senior product manager with the General Foods Corporation in White Plains, was married to Peter Robert Roux, a vice president with the Chase Manhattan Bank's project finance division. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Jones and the Rev. Joseph Lim, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Brother Defends Sister
description: The sign taped to a booth at the Denver airport by a group favoring nuclear energy was apparently intended as a knee slapper. ''Feed Jane Fonda to the Whales,'' it said, naming the actress who has been an outspoken oppenent of nuclear energy.

title: French Rivalry Adds Spice After 1-2 International Finish
description: Eugene Lefevre did the can-can early this morning, but not very well. He sipped champagne and basked in the momentary glory of his victory behind Ideal du Gazeau in the 23d Roosevelt International a few hours earlier.

title: INDIA'S NUCLEAR LIMIT
description: To the Editor:

title: PRINCE CHARLES HELPS ENGLAND DEFEAT SPAIN'S TEAM AT POLO
description: Prince Charles helped England to defeat Spain at polo this afternoon while tens of thousands of sightseers clogged the streets of central London along which the wedding processions of the Prince and Lady Diana Spencer will move on Wednesday.

title: Czyz Knocks Out Noggle in Seventh
description: Bobby Czyz knocked down Rick Noggle twice in the seventh round today and scored a technical knockout in a middleweight fight.

title: Pekingese Is Best At Elm City Show
description: The smallest dog in the ring won the biggest prize at the 75th show of the Elm City Kennel Club at the Bethany Airport today.

title: Judge Rules Out Mistrial for N.F.L.
description: The judge in the trial of the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the National Football League, who ruled that jurors must treat the league as a group of competitors, not partners, decided today that his ruling was no reason to declare a mistrial.

title: CHALLENGES FACING FOTOMAT
description: The Fotomat Corporation, whose blue and yellow kiosks are a familiar fixture in thousands of shopping centers nationwide, hardly needs more competition.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CARILLON SALUTE

title: Grumman Bus Cost May Be $50 Million
description: The Grumman Corporation said today that losses resulting from a national recall of 2,650 of its Flxible buses may amount to more than $50 million this year. Grumman already wrote off $7 million in last year's fourth quarter to cover a portion of the more than $15 million cost of reinforcing structural members that cracked in service.

title: A Close Call for Mr. Koch, and Some Swift Help
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he almost choked to death at a Chinatown restaurant Sunday night, but was saved by a dining companion who performed the Heimlich maneuver to dislodge a piece of food that had stuck in the mayor's throat.

title: State Park Office Gets a New Name
description: The New York State Office of Parks and Recreation has had its name changed.

title: SADAT DENOUNCES ISRAEL'S AIR STRIKE ON BEIRUT
description: President Anwar el-Sadat said today that Israel's air attacks on civilian targets in Lebanon were ''horrible'' incidents that obstructed the search for peace. He also said that Syrian troops based in Lebanon and Palestinian guerrillas had contributed to the latest round of killing.

title: Airport Personnel Confronted by a Didgeridoo
description: The grandmotherly looking woman looked innocent enough, but the stick she was carrying struck airport security personnel as distinctly out of character.

title: Growers Hopeful On California Fruit
description: Facing heavy odds, California fruit growers are hopeful that they can win their battle against the Mediterranean fruit fly and save the state's $15 billion agricultural industry.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON BLOCK GRANTS FOR HEALTH FUNDS
description: House and Senate conferees reached a tentative agreement today on using block grants to consolidate financing for several health care programs, but preserved separate appropriations for family planning.

title: SPORTING A BEARD
description: In recent seasons, Rosalind Elias, the Metropolitan Opera mezzo soprano, has spent considerable time wearing a luxuriant beard as Baba the Turk, the bearded lady of Stravinsky's ''The Rake's Progress.''

title: THE AGEE DECISION
description: .8,2ANN ARBOR, Mich. - There is no reason to shed tears for Philip Agee, the former Central Intelligence Agency officer now residing in Hamburg, whose passport revocation was recently upheld, 7-2, by the United States Supreme Court. For Mr. Agee had announced and carried out a campaign to expose undercover C.I.A. agents stationed abroad and ''to drive them out of the countries where they are operating.'' The Court observed that the the record reveals that Mr. Agee's public identifications ''have been followed by episodes of violence against the persons and organizations identified.''

title: Arlo Guthrie on Mend
description: Illness forced him to cancel weekend concerts in Los Angeles and Portland, Ore., but Arlo Guthrie, the folk singer, was out of the hospital yesterday after treatment for an inflamed pancreas.

title: CHEMICAL IN JERSEY FIRE SHIPPED UNDER U.S. RULES
description: Ethylene oxide, involved in the fire that caused the evacuation of areas near Newark International Airport yesterday because of fear of an explosion, is used in a wide variety of products.

title: New Chairman Named At a New York Bank
description: Frank Willie, 50, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Greater New York Savings Bank. Mr. Willie, a native New Yorker, is currently a partner in the New York and Washington law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft.

title: WARD STUDIES AN EARLY RETIREMENT PLAN
description: Montgomery Ward, the troubled retail subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation, is reportedly preparing to offer a program of widespread early retirements with incentives to redundant senior and middle-rank executives in an effort to sharply cut administrative costs.

title: ZIP Code Bill Goes to Floor
description: The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee today approved a bill requiring the new nine-digit ZIP code to be voluntary. The vote of 8 to 1 sent the measure to the floor, where it may languish until next year, according to the assistant Republican leader, Ted Stevens of Alaska.

title: Space Shuttle Testing Is Begun After Delays
description: A twice-postponed flight and systems rehearsal for the space shuttle Columbia began as scheduled at midnight last night, after wiring problems on the craft's huge mechanical arm were resolved.

title: Intoxicated Rats on a Treadmill
description: If the experience of some laboratory rats on a treadmill is any indication, the best way to learn how to function while intoxicated is to practice the function repeatedly while intoxicated. It may not be recommended for people driving cars, but this was the conclusion reached by a team of psychologists at the University of Washington in Seattle after experiments with rats dosed with ethanol.

title: Lawyer Walks Out At Murder Trial
description: The John Youmans murder trial was adjourned in Orange County Court after a judge's decision to allow testimony from four new prosecution witnesses sparked a walkout by the defense attorney.

title: Van Pelt to Get $1 Million Pact
description: After weeks of negotiations, Brad Van Pelt, the Giants' all-pro linebacker, and General Manager George Young agreed today on a five-year contract extension worth $1 million.

title: 36 Killed and 28 Hurt In Crash of Mexican Jet
description: An Aeromexico jetliner ran off a runway and burst into flames today while landing at Chihuahua in northern Mexico, killing at least 36 people and injuring 28, the authorities said.

title: LEGAL AID'S GOAL: KEEP CLIENT FREE
description: Each manila folder in the clutter on Brian T. Buchbinder's desk holds snippets of daily criminal life in the streets of New York City - someone stabbed, someone else pushed onto a subway track, thieves, pickpockets, con artists and the omnipresent peddlers of pills, marijuana and cocaine.

title: Two Killed in Glider Crash
description: A glider broke away from its tow plane and plunged into a river bank late yesterday, killing the pilot and passenger. The victims were identified as Alan Kevles, 35 years old, of Aspen, and Susan Tighe, 24, who was visiting the Colorado resort town from Barnesboro, N.J.

title: BBDO International Earnings Down 2%
description: BBDO International had a much prettier picture, not that the result was up, but it wasn't off much. Revenues for the second quarter were up 1 percent from the same period last year, to $44.6 million from $44 million, while net income was down only 2 percent, to $3.1 million, or $1.16 a share, from $3.17 million in 1980, or $1.18 a share, last year.

title: G.M. OFFERS AUTO BUYERS LOW-INTEREST FINANCING
description: The General Motors Corporation said today it would offer below-market interest rates to customers borrowing money to buy a G.M. car in an effort to perk up sluggish sales and to help clear large stocks of unsold cars before the 1982 models reach dealer showrooms.

title: MISTRIAL DECLARED IN MIAMI RIOT CASE
description: A mistrial was declared today in the retrial of a young black man charged with murdering a white motorist in riots in Miami in 1980.

title: No Headline
description: Representatives of professional, college and amateur hockey in the United States agreed today to seek ways for the National Hockey League to pay the National Collegiate Athletic Association, conferences or colleges when it drafts and signs their players.

title: No Headline
description: FIRES DESTROY 60,000 ACRES: Ranchers working Sunday near Oak City, Utah, to save a corral caught in the path of one of two major range fires in the state. The second fire consumed timber, grass and brush east of Clay Springs. The National Guard was called out to battle the blaze, which started Friday, set by lightning.

title: U.S. OIL LEASE SALE IN COAST'S WATERS BLOCKED IN COURT Conception and Morro Bay (p.B10)
description: A Federal judge today blocked the sale of oil drilling leases for more than 150,000 acres of California coastal waters. The judge ruled that the Reagan Administration had violated a 1972 Federal law in designating the area for development without first adequately consulting state authorities.

title: Hondurans Complain To El Salvador on Raid
description: The Government sent a complaint to El Salvador today over a violation of Honduran territory by Salvadoran forces on July 17.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Mel Gussow PLAYED OUT: The Jean Seberg Story. By David Richards. 386 pages. Random House. $13.95.

title: Thrillers; Movie of the Week
description: A horror-film fan who was first in line for both ''Blowout'' and ''Wolfen'' was awakened a few nights ago by what seemed to be a flashlight beamed at her eyelids. It was, instead, lightning.

title: REAGAN, IN SPEECH, ASKS TAX CUT HELP AND ATTACKS FOES
description: President Reagan, accusing the Democratic Congressional leadership of ''political fun and games,'' appealed tonight for support of his tax reduction program, which he termed ''the first real tax cut for everyone in almost 20 years.''

title: SOLDIERS SHOULDN'T SERVE AS DRUG-BUSTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: JOAN OF ARC REVISITED
description: Thomas De Quincey, in a highflown piece of rhetoric about Joan of Arc, declared that he could not find a Mozart or a Michelangelo among the female sex. But ''Sister Woman...'' he wrote, ''I acknowledge that you can do one thing as well as the best of us men - You can die grandly...'' The sight of a woman on the scaffold, he continued, eclipsed Luxor, or the Himalayas, or St. Peter's on Easter Day in grandeur.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: T HE boys with money to burn were burning it, one way or another, last week. One of them was Gene Pressman, the scion of the Barney's mini-empire. Another was Barry Schwartz, the 38-year-old president of Calvin Klein. In between, there was scattered sunshine and a few finds.

title: Sports of The Times; Walter Payton Fits in Chicago
description: THE best running back in pro football has signed the most lucrative contract in pro football, which is as it should be. Imagine how much Walter Payton would have received if open bidding were encouraged in the National Football League.

title: Huw Wheldon Is Given Morse Award
description: Sir Huw Wheldon, chairman of the London School of Economics and former chief executive officer of the British Broadcasting Corporation's television division, has received the Arthur D. Morse Fellowship Award in Communictions and Society from the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies.

title: China-Japan Trade Grows
description: Trade between China and Japan in the first six months of 1981 totaled $5.17 billion, up 29.3 percent from the level of a year earlier, the Japan External Trade Organization reported today. The new figure ranks second behind the record of $5.4 billion set in the last half of 1980.

title: CITY'S STREET-CLEANING EFFORT IS GETTING BETTER, KOCH SAYS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that citywide inspections showed ''sustained improvement'' in street cleaning over last year, and he suggested that an extra 450 street cleaners would soon make the city still cleaner.

title: Children
description: ''What are adults for?'' a man whose small son disappeared two years ago once asked. ''They're put on earth to take care of little children.''

title: Gaines Eager to Resume Job
description: Clark Gaines, the Jets' premier running back, is approaching the season with more tenacity than usual because he is coming back from a broken left leg that caused him to miss the final 11 games last season.

title: PARIS FALL COUTURE: OPULENCE ALL THE WAY
description: Never an egalitarian institution, the French couture surpassed itself in aristocratic opulence as its fall fashion openings got under way.

title: OPERA: PINE ORCHARD FESTIVAL
description: Along the roads near this small hamlet of the Northern Catskills with a winter population of 600, there are reminders that in this region Washington Irving's Rip Van Winkle supposedly slept - awakening after 20 years to a changed world.There's a Rip Van Winkle Campsite, a Rip Van Winkle Country Club, a Rip Van Winkle Hotel.

title: Republicans Back Gold's Aide As Brooklyn District Attorney
description: The Brooklyn Republican organization yesterday endorsed a Democrat, Norman J. Rosen, for District Attorney. Mr. Rosen, who now is executive assistant to the retiring District Attorney, Eugene Gold, was thus assured of a place on the ballot in November regardless of the outcome of a challenge for the Democratic nomination by Elizabeth Holtzman, the former United States Representative. ''Rosen is as good as Gold,'' said Alfred S. Pantaleone, the new Brooklyn Republican leader.

title: No Headline
description: Loan for Philippines MANILA, July 27 (Reuters) - The Bankers Trust Company of New York has been authorized to raise a $100 million 10-year loan for the central bank of the Philippines, officials of the central bank said today. The interest rate is to be 3/4 percentage point over the London interbank rate plus a management fee of 3/4 percentage point.

title: Tooth Impressions of Inmate Ordered in Slaying of Guard
description: A Dutchess County Court judge, ruling that the ''search for truth'' outweighed defense objections, today ordered that tooth impressions be taken from an inmate charged with killing a Green Haven prison guard, Donna Payant.

title: P.L.O. COMMANDER CALLS ISRAELI STRATEGY A FAILURE
description: The Palestinian guerrillas' top field commander today characterized Israeli military strategy over the last two weeks of fighting as ''a complete failure.''

title: Jersey Bill Affects Co-op Conversions
description: Elderly or disabled tenants who meet certain income requirements will be protected from eviction arising from condominium or cooperative conversions under legislation signed into law by Governor Byrne.

title: It Says Led Strikes
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda detained four trade union leaders and a businessman today, accusing them of instigating a series of wildcat strikes and planning to take over the Government.

title: TOP BRITISH JUDGE UNTIL 1980
description: Lord Widgery, former Lord Chief Justice, has died at the age of 70, his family announced today. They said he died at his home late Saturday. No cause of death was announced, but he had been reported to be in failing health since his retirement last year.

title: Occidental in Italian Venture
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, the Italian national energy corporation, announced the formation of a joint chemical and coal company, to be called Enoxy, that would be capitalized at $1.05 billion.

title: Advertising; Sambo's Switches Agencies
description: GEERS GROSS Advertising has become the new agency for the 1,400-outlet Sambo's Restaurants chain, which Robert Gross, the agency's chairman and chief executive, said should spend between $10 million and $15 million with the agency for advertising.

title: AN ALBANY 'MUST' ON HUMAN SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: Commodore Computer Account to Kornhauser
description: Kornhauser & Calene has emerged triumphant in the competition for the Commodore Computer Systems, the division of Commodore International Ltd., the country's third-largest seller of desk-top microcomputers, that could be spending more than $6 million for advertising.

title: THE DANCE: CARLA BLANK
description: IT'S a longstanding joke that dancers' brains are in their feet. Choreographers, however, can think too much sometimes, and that was a problem with the program of dances choreographed and performed by Carla Blank last Thursday at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation loft in SoHo.

title: EDWIN PHILIPS
description: Edwin Philips, an actor, died of cancer Sunday at the Cabrini Hospice.

title: Index; International
description: Threats alter life for Argentina's Nobel laureate A2 P.L.O. commander calls Israeli strategy a 'complete failure' A3 U.S. officials express optimism on Middle East truce A3 Sadat denounces Israeli air strike on Beirut A3 Japanese pleased at avoiding new obligations at Ottawa A4 Polish Government and union compromise on meat ration A4 Around the World A5 Behind the jubilation, a historic moment for Britain A6 The wedding day route: history all along the way A6 Old mingles with the new in sandy Nigerian city of Kano A10 British officials see no hope of re- solving hunger title: ERROR IN QUAKE FORECAST CONCEDED
description: A scientist has withdrawn a prediction that an earthquake more powerful than any felt on earth in this century would strike Peru and northern Chile in mid-August. He said he never meant for the prediction to be made public and would never again make such a forecast.

title: M-G-M's Holders Vote New Shares
description: Shareholders of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company approved a plan to increase the company's outstanding stock and sell about $100 million worth of the new shares to M-G-M's principal stockholder, financier Kirk Kerkorian.

title: Woman Dies in Fall Off Cliff
description: A 20-year-old Lodi, N.J., woman who had been drinking with a friend on the Palisades cliffs died today when she fell off a 125-foot precipice, the Palisades Parkway police said. The woman, Danielle Caurant, and Mark Mancini, 24, of New Milford, were drinking at the Rockefeller lookout on the Parkway in Bergen County when she either slipped or fell, the police said. Miss Caurant was pronounced dead at Englewood Hospital at 10:45 P.M.

title: BOEING OFF BY 9.5%; SINGER UP SHARPLY
description: The Boeing Company, the nation's leading builder of commercial jets and a major manufacturer of military aircraft, reported yesterday that lagging deliveries were an important factor in causing net income in the second quarter to drop 9.5 percent, as sales increased 14.9 percent.

title: Jury in N.F.L. Trial Given Three Issues
description: The judge presiding over the trial of the antitrust suit brought by the Oakland Raiders against the National Football League gave instructions today that appear to simplify the jury's job in the complex case. And an attorney for the plaintiffs began closing arguments by describing the league structure as ''lordships and fiefdoms.''

title: U.S., CANADA FILE PROTESTS ON RULINGS
description: The United States and Canada lodged protests at the World University Games today in a dispute involving swimming.

title: Young Finds Making Giants Is Not Easy
description: When the Giants selected Dave Young, the Purdue tight end, on the second round of last April's National Football League draft, many football people were shocked.

title: Sustaining the Right to Vote
description: These are critical days for the Voting Rights Act, even though the struggle for its renewal is not even half over. The House Judiciary Committee meets today to mark up a bill extending the 1965 law for another ten years. Given the chilly atmosphere in the Senate, the House is the more promising forum for early action on a strong bill. Much depends now on the legislative skill of diverse factions. The trick will be to meet civil rights needs with enough flexibility to attract the votes of moderates.

title: National Steel Net Soars
description: Despite the long coal strike and equipment failures at two mills, the National Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest steel producer, said today that its secondquarter net income rose sixfold from the same quarter last year.

title: MUSIC: VERDI'S REQUIEM
description: VERDI'S Requiem is a hardy work of genius that rarely fails to register an impact, no matter where or how it is performed. Certainly the New York Grand Opera's presentation of the Requiem on the Central Park Mall last Thursday night was far from ideal, but the basic qualities of the music were clearly discernible, and the overall effect was a powerful one.

title: FOXES TRACKED THROUGH THE NIGHT REVEAL A SURPRISING GROUP LIFE
description: hunting. He waits in his little blue van, one hand out the window aiming the antenna mounted on the roof. With the other, he adjusts the knobs of a radio receiver in his lap.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The end of armed attack which has been achieved could be a first, important step on the road to greater calm and security in the area.'' - Philip C. Habib, United States envoy to the Middle East. (A3:1.)

title: William V. Davis, 79; Pioneer Navy Aviator
description: Vice Adm.William V. Davis Jr. of the Navy, retired, a pioneer Navy aviator, died Saturday of cancer at the University of South Alabama Hospital in Mobile.

title: DETROIT'S CLOUDED CRYSTAL BALL
description: The product planners of the American Motors Corporation were droning through another meeting, describing the fuelefficient models on their drawing boards when Gerald Meyers, chairman, interrupted.

title: Andrew Field Plan Postponed by B.P.
description: The British Petroleum Company said it had postponed its plans to develop the Andrew oil field in the North Sea because proposed changes in Britain's tax laws would make the project economically marginal.

title: GRADUATE SCHOOLS' DECLINE LEADS TO WIDE CONCERN
description: GRADUATE education in the United States is caught in a war of attrition. Its sources of support are being drained by Federal budget cuts and reduced aid from foundations. In the humanities, its students are demoralized by the prospect of unemployment; in science and technology, its most promising talent is being gobbled up by industry without regard for the universities' continuing need for teachers and researchers. Such a depletion of the teaching pool would leave aging faculties whose members had made their contributions to fast-moving research fields a generation ago.

title: POLISH MINISTER AND UNION REACH COMPROMISE ON MEAT RATION CUT
description: The Polish radio said tonight that the independent labor union had reached a compromise accord with the Government over proposed reductions in meat rations.

title: N.& W. Profit Declines 56%
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway today reported a second-quarter profit of $26.2 million, or 80 cents a share, down 56 percent from $59 million, or $1.88 a share, a year before. Revenues fell 14 percent, to $351.2 million, from $406.2 million.

title: TESTS FAULTED FOR INABILITY TO MEASURE CREATIVITY
description: ROBERT, who is 6 years old, took a test last spring to see whether he qualified for a special program for gifted children. He scored only in the 80th percentile, but the examiner noticed that during the test he was dropping things, looking around the room and fidgeting with his shoes.

title: MOBIL LIFTS ITS OFFER FOR CONOCO
description: Moving to outbid Du Pont and Seagram in the multibillion-dollar battle for Conoco Inc., the Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it was increasing its cash offer for the nation's ninth-largest oil company to $105 a share for slightly more than half of Conoco's stock.

title: High Prison Aide Removed in Jersey
description: TRENTON (AP) - The highest-ranking correction officer at Trenton State Prison has been charged with ''neglect'' and removed from his post as chief deputy keeper at the state's only maximum-security prison.

title: Q. Why does soda bubble after a container of it is opened?
description: A. Soda water, like other carbonated beverages, contains carbon dioxide that has dissolved under pressure. When the pressure is released by opening the soda container, the liquid cannot hold as much carbon dioxide, so the excess bubbles out of the solution.

title: JAPANESE HIGHLY SATISFIED WITH OTTAWA PARLEY
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki returned over the weekend from the Ottawa meeting of the leading industrial democracies without any public comment on its results, but senior officials reflected a sense of deep satisfaction.

title: Providence Mayor Says He'll Dismiss Strikers
description: Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. threatened today to dismiss all 1,600 striking municipal workers and seek contempt of court orders against some employees.

title: POLLUTION CURBS' IMPACT ON THE ECONOMY CITED
description: Federal antipollution programs are adding four-tenths of a percentage point a year to the Consumer Price Index, according to a study released today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Saumell Ruling Is Put Off
description: State Supreme Court Justice Martin Rodell reserved decision yesterday on the motion by the jockey Larry Saumell to enjoin the New York Racing Association from barring him from its tracks.

title: KOCH SAYS LOTTERIES TO SELL CITY HOUSING ARE NOT RULED OUT
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had not completely ruled out future use of a preferential lottery in the disposing of city-owned property in Harlem.

title: Thai Premier to Quit Army
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda said today he was giving up his post as army commander in chief, apparently in a move to preserve military unity. General Prem told reporters he would retire from military office next month, when he reaches the age of 61.

title: G.T.E. Offers Medical System
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the nation's second-largest telephone company after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said that it would introduce a computerized data retrieval system to allow doctors to call up medical information on video terminals in their offices and hospitals.

title: A ROYAL OPPORTUNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUIS C. MIANO
description: Louis C. Miano, an industrial and commercial real-estate developer in the New York metropolitan area, died last Friday at his summer home in Amagansett, L.I. He was 71 years old and a resident of Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: U.S. ROAD CHIEF PLEDGES 90% AID TO THE WESTWAY
description: The Federal Highway Administrator said yesterday that the Reagan Administration was committed to financing 90 percent of the actual cost of building the entire Westway highway project, including most of the items that led to Mayor Koch's concern that there might be insufficient Federal funds.

title: Denver Arena Shows $115,949 Loss for '80
description: McNichols Sports Arena, home of the Colorado Rockies and the Denver Nuggets, has gone from a money-making operation two years ago to one that operates at or near a deficit today, a financial report shows.

title: CHEMICAL FIRE IN NEWARK RAIL CAR ROUTS HUNDREDS AND JAMS TRAFFIC
description: Hundreds of people were forced out of their places of work and traffic was backed up for miles on major roadways near Newark International Airport early this morning after a railroad tank car containing 26,000 gallons of a volatile toxic chemical caught fire at the Oak Island Conrail freight yards.

title: No Headline
description: United Nations officials in southern Lebanon said today that Palestinian guerrillas fired rockets and an artillery round at Lebanese Christian positions early today. They said that Lebanese Christian militiamen returned the fire.

title: Veteran of Senate Investigations to Aid Panels Inquiry on Casey
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Senator Barry Goldwater announced today that the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence had retained Fred D. Thompson as special counsel for what seems likely to be an extended examination of the financial dealings of William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Mines Official Sees No Threat From Old Fire That Surfaced
description: A 19-year-old mine fire that broke through to the earth's surface and is burning along a rocky cliffside poses no immediate threat to Centralia, a Federal official said today.

title: VETERAN OF SENATE INVESTIGATIONS TO AID PANEL'S INQUIRY ON CASEY
description: Senator Barry Goldwater announced today that the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence had retained Fred D. Thompson as special counsel for what seems likely to be an extended examination of the financial dealings of William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence.

title: YOUNG AUSCHWITZ VICTIM'S ART TO BE PUBLISHED
description: When the Nazis closed in on Berlin's Jewish community in 1939, Charlotte Saloman, a 21-year-old artist, fled to the home of her grandparents in Villefranche-sur-Mer, in the South of France. There, with a premonition of doom, she furiously began to paint the story of her life just as Anne Frank in Amsterdam had written intimately about herself in the famous diary. In late summer 1942, Miss Saloman was picked up and sent to Auschwitz, where she died the next year.

title: Uganda Troops Said to Kill 3
description: Ugandan soldiers bayoneted to death three civilians, including a Moslem priest, in retaliation for the murder of a local official of President Milton Obote's Uganda People's Congress, residents of Kisowola, a village 20 miles east of Kampala, reported today. They said that the three were killed Saturday.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Unidentified gunmen slightly wounded two American travelers on the Pan American Highway near the Honduran border yesterday, the United States Embassy said today. A spokesman identified them as Walter Alvarez and Willard Nenner. Both were reportedly treated and released.

title: TEXAS GOVERNOR SAYS COAST FRUIT TO BE INSPECTED
description: Gov. William Clements used emergency powers today to order inspection points set up to prevent California produce infested with the Mediterranean fruit fly from entering Texas.

title: Washington Post Net Rises
description: The Washington Post Company, parent of Newsweek magazine and The Washington Post newspaper, today reported that second-quarter income rose 3.2 percent on a 14 percent revenue gain over the same quarter last year.

title: Rates Prompt Senate Letter
description: In a letter released today, five conservative Democratic senators are urging President Reagan to convene a domestic ''economic summit'' to find ways of bringing down high interest rates before they cause ''irreparable damage to our economy.'' The senators told Mr. Reagan that any economic benefits flowing from his proposed tax cut would be offset by a continuation of high interest rates.

title: FEZZES AND GUCCI SHOES IN A SANDY NIGERIAN CITY
description: When the Emir of Kano travels these days, he does so, like anyone of substance in Nigeria, by limousine. The sound of the car's horns, residents say, resembles that of the clarions that once announced the arrival of his horse-borne, jeweled ancestors in centuries past.

title: Minister in Lisbon Quits, Imperiling the Cabinet
description: Portugal's influential Social Affairs Minister, Carlos Macedo, resigned today, raising a new threat to the continuation of the Government of Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao.

title: Oldfield Captures Shot-Put
description: It should have been one of Brian Oldfield's more satisfying moments. He had won the shot-put, after having been admitted to the National Sports Festival on a temporary court injunction, and he had beaten his two keenest rivals, Dave Laut and Michael Carter.

title: UNHERALDED SPORTS EXERT A PULL, TOO
description: SANTA CLARA$ Calif. - When the seven tug-of-war teams marched onto the field to began competition in the World Games immediately following the opening ceremonies at Buck Shaw Stadium last weekend, many of the 8,108 spectators marched out. What? Watch tug-of-war?

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amax Exploration Co., a subsidiary of Amax Inc., and the Hyundai Corp. of South Korea have agreed to form a 10-year joint venture to explore Korean molybdenite ores at a cost of $800 million. The companies are seeking Government approval for an initial 18-month exploration project.

title: Chicago Bridge Wins Contract
description: The Abu Dhabi Gas Liquefaction Company said it awarded a $320 million contract to Chicago Bridge Inc. to design and build seven gas storage tanks on Das Island, off the coast of Abu Dhabi.

title: Western Air Loss Widens
description: Western Airlines today posted a secondquarter loss of $8.4 million, compared with a $5.4 million loss in 1980's second quarter.

title: Ad Association Releases Member Income Data
description: You knew that last year wasn't a great year, right? If you'd like to put some flesh on the bones of that conjecture the American Association of Advertising Agencies can help you, because it has just released its annual study of member income.

title: RESORTS A MAGNET IN POPULATION SHIFTS
description: Those areas of the United States that have experienced the most rapid growth recently are mostly places providing outdoor recreation, a pleasant climate or natural beauty, according to a recent analysis of the 1980 census.

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan appealed in a television address for support of his tax reduction program and accused the Democratic Congressional leadership of ''political fun and games.'' (Page A1.) Democratic leaders denounced his plan as geared to the ''wealthy of America'' and predicted victory for their own bill on the House floor. Some liberal Democrats, however, object to provisions in both bills to give tax benefits to the oil industry and commodity traders. (A1.) Text of Mr. Reagan's message. (B6.) Text of Democrats' responses. (B7.)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Company has elected to its board Charles W. Duncan Jr., former Secretary of Energy.

title: No Headline
description: An obituary of William H. Nix in some copies of The Times yesterday was accompanied by an incorrect photograph. It showed William Nix, who figured in a 1968 campaign to help starving children in Africa.

title: A Spoilsman's Creed
description: Important United States Senators are demanding the resignations of two of President Reagan's Cabinet-level appointees - William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, and James G. Watt, Secretary of the Interior. But in both cases, the Senate itself bears much responsibility for the controversies.

title: THERAPIST USES POETRY AS GUIDE TO THE HIDDEN MIND
description: LITERATE man has always turned to poetry for truth. David Forrest turns to it for psychiatric truth. In particular, he has made an alliance with the poetry of E.E. Cummings.

title: LURE OF SHAKESPEARE ON COAST
description: SAN DIEGO THE peacocks from the San Diego Zoo - a ravine away -scream. The jets shriek overhead, and on a rough, open-air stage carved out of a canyon full of eucalyptus trees and wild berries, a rash and bullnecked King Lear, made more passionately headstrong by senility - preens as his courtiers applaud the declamatory flattery of his daughters.

title: BEHIND THE OUTPOURING OF JOY, A HISTORIC MOMENT FOR BRITAIN
description: On a shabby street in East London, a sudden silence came over the Crown Pub this afternoon, and the lunchtime crowd turned their rapt attention to a radio that was set upon the beer-splashed bar.

title: U.S. ISOLDE IN GERMANY
description: Johanna Meier's debut Saturday as Isolde in Wagner's ''Tristan and Isolde'' at the 70th Wagner Festival, the first performance of Isolde by an American-born soprano at Bayreuth, received mixed reviews from West German critics today.

title: Daimler Plant Set for Egypt
description: Daimler-Benz, West Germany's biggest truck maker, said today that it plans to build a plant in Egypt that will assemble medium and large trucks, all-terrain vehicles and buses.

title: G.M.'S EARNINGS REACH $515 MILLION
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today a profit of $515 million, or $1.72 a share, for the second quarter of this year, in contrast to a loss of $412 million in the comparable 1980 period.

title: LEASING BREAK IN TAX BILL
description: In the fine print of the Senate tax bill, the Reagan Adminstration has proposed sweeping but little-known changes in the $30-billion-ayear leasing industry. These changes are designed to give a financial lift to ailing industries - steel, autos and airlines - and to create billions of dollars of tax shelters for healthy industries.

title: DOW AT 945.87
description: With energy issues leading the way, the stock market moved higher yesterday in modest trading volume. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.13 points, to 945.87, thereby extending Friday's gain of 8.18 points.

title: EDITH SKINNER
description: Edith Skinner, a speech coach and consultant to Broadway actors, died in her sleep last Saturday in Milwaukee.

title: Jet Deliveries Linked to Truce
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that future deliveries of F-16 fighter-bombers to Israel would be linked to the continuation of the cease-fire in Lebanon and to negotiations toward a settlement in that region.

title: TRIAL LAWYERS TRADE TIPS AND PRACTICE PRESENCE
description: Trial lawyers, the showmen, scrappers and crap-shooters of American justice, are trading tips at a convention here about how to play to juries, trip up adversaries and get rich while doing good.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * N.C.A. Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 570,000 common shares, of which 210,000 shares are being sold by current shareholders, to be offered by a Hambrecht & Quist group.

title: DANCE: 'FACETS OF DESIRE,' BASED ON O'NEILL WORK
description: FOR its third weekend of dance, the Pepsico Summerfare '81 arts festival at the State University of New York's campus at Purchase offered ''Dramadance,'' a program described as dance based on dramatic themes. Only one of the dances, seen Saturday afternoon, fulfilled that premise. What did link them, however, was a general level of quality that made this one of the most dismal dance bills offered over the festival's two summers.

title: TORIES PROPOSE A JOB PROGRAM TO AID YOUTHS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced a package of emergency youth-unemployment measures today, in a response to the recent rioting and the defeat suffered by her Conservative Party in a parliamentary by-election.

title: Queens Man Is Found Guilty Of Killing 3 With Automobile
description: A Queens man was found guilty yesterday of killing a woman and her two daughters by running them down with his automobile. The man, 34-year-old Arthur Smith of 58-35 69th Avenue, in the Ridgewood section, was convicted of vehicular homicide in the deaths of Elfriede Rom, 41, and her daughters Heidi, 13, and Susanne, 9.

title: PHYSICIAN'S MOVE TO INDUSTRY MAY REFLECT WIDENING TREND
description: WHEN Dr. Charles A. Sanders, the director of the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, trained there as a cardiologist in the 1950's, his ambition was to become a leading teacher.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRITISH OFFICIALS SAY THEY HAVE LITTLE HOPE OF ENDING HUNGER STRIKES AT ULSTER PRISON
description: Two Irish Republican Army hunger strikers appeared to be approaching death tonight as British Government officials conceded that efforts to end the crisis had virtually collapsed.

title: F.T.C. Against Sale to Echlin
description: The Federal Trade Commission challenged the Echlin Manufacturing Company's acquisition of a part of the Borg-Warner Corporation, saying the deal may hurt competition in the sale of carburetor kits.

title: Westway, Still the Best Way
description: Perhaps, after a decade, Westway can now be built at last. Governor Carey and Mayor Koch have maneuvered toward agreement to proceed with the project; the alternatives look even less attractive than when they first entered the debate. But half a generation has grown up during the Westway wars. It has been misled by politics and paranoia and was never allowed to understand that Westway is much more than a road or job-creating enterprise. It is time to recall its promise.

title: Man Gets Life Sentence For Perjury in Slaying
description: A man convicted of perjury for his testimony about the slaying of a black youth found hanging in a tree was sentenced today to life in prison.

title: LONG-TERM RATES POST GAINS
description: Long-term interest rates moved higher yesterday, as many investors were reluctant to buy notes or bonds in advance of a heavy supply of new Treasury issues expected next week.

title: 16 Iranian Leftists Shot by Firing Squads
description: A leader of the leftist Moslem People's Mujahedeen guerrillas, Mohammed Riza Saadati, and 15 fellow members were shot by firing squads today in Teheran and other cities, the Teheran radio said.

title: U.S. IS 'OPTIMISTIC' ON MIDEAST TRUCE
description: United States officials are ''increasingly optimistic'' that the Middle East cease-fire announced Friday will not quickly break down and believe it is ''hardly surprising'' that there have been some initial small-scale violations, the spokesman for the State Department said today.

title: What About the Weather?
description: Many real estate promoters tout the ''equitable weather'' of their community, but Chesley J. Posey, professor emeritus of civil engineering at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, points out that the term is ambiguous.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday misstated the growth of the gross national product in the second quarter. In current dollars, the G.N.P. rose to an annual rate of $2,881 billion, from $2,853 billion in the first quarter. The ''real'' G.N.P., in uninflated constant dollars, declined to an annual rate of $1,509 billion, from $1,516 billion.

title: Court: Exxon Ransom Valid
description: A Manhattan State Supreme Court judge has ruled that the board of directors of the Exxon Corporation acted properly when it authorized the payment of a $14.2 million ransom to Argentine terrorists in 1974.

title: 6 OIL CONCERNS GAIN BUT ARCO NET SLIPS
description: Despite continuing weakness in the market for petroleum products, six of eight large oil companies that reported quarterly earnings yesterday registered increases over the comparable period a year earlier. But the largest company reporting, the Atlantic Richfield Company, posted a 13 percent decline, and American Petrofina Inc. slipped 39.3 percent.

title: PLAYERS SUPPORT BARGAINING UNIT
description: The shop stewards of all 26 teams in the big leagues met for more than five hours tonight and then unanimously supported their negotiators in the strike that has shut down the sport for 46 days.

title: NUCLEAR PLANTS' PROBLEMS SAID TO RISE
description: An antinuclear group said today that the nation's atomic power plants had reported 3,804 incidents of equipment problems, flaws in design and human errors in 1980.

title: PREFABRICATED JAIL READY FOR INMATES
description: It looks like the prefabricated buildings erected to house crewmen working in an oil field boomtown. But the neat, brown metal building with the bright orange door is a hastily assembled jail, built to help ease the overcrowding in the city's correctional system.

title: DEMOCRATS ZERO IN ON DISTRICT'S DISENCHANTMENT
description: BARRE, Pa., July 27 -John Wallace is a cloud on Ronald Reagan's horizon. Mr. Wallace, a 52-year-old machinist at a boiler factory, is one of many blue-collar workers who voted for Mr. Reagan last fall and enabled him to sweep Northeastern industrial states like Pennsylvania. But Mr. Wallace is increasingly unhappy with the President's policies, and he wants his Congressman to vote for the Democrats' tax bill when the issue comes before the House of Representatives on Wednesday.

title: Talking Business with Mertes of Continental Illinois; Automation In the Office
description: In the last four years, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, in Chicago, has pushed the frontiers of office automation in its professional ranks beyond the range of most businesses - including the computer companies that produce the equipment.

title: THREATS ALTER LIFE OF NOBEL LAUREATE IN ARGENTINA
description: Adolfo Perez Esquivel, the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize seven months ago, has been living ever since under repeated threats of violence.

title: I.B.M. To Adopt Global Standard
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it will adopt international data communications standards enabling its computers to communicate globally.

title: THE WEDDING DAY ROUTE: HISTORY ALL ALONG THE WAY
description: The four carriage processions that will carry the royal family on the wedding day will traverse a route laden with history. Three groups of coaches will leave from Buckingham Palace. The palace, which was built in 1703 by the Duke of Buckingham and bought by King George III in 1762, has been the ruler's home since Queen Victoria's time.

title: Queens Man Shoots Off Foot With Shotgun Hidden in Pants
description: A 44-year-old Queens man shot off his right foot and ankle with a shotgun concealed in his pants leg today while picking up a disputed paycheck from his employer, the Nassau County police said.

title: REAGAN, F.D.R. AND THE ARTS IN AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: COSTS AND SOCIAL CHANGES PROMOTE SHARED LIVING playing table tennis
description: Ed Thibodeau first noticed Laurel Fortin at work because she was circling the same newspaper classifieds he was: Ads for apartments in Marin County, regarded by many as the ultimate in California living.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL REAGAN'S TAX BILL
description: Democratic leaders denounced President Reagan's tax bill tonight as geared to the ''wealthy of America'' and predicted that they would defeat his proposal and enact their own tax package when the issue reaches the House floor Wednesday.

title: ECLIPSE OF SUN TO BE VIEWED BY MUCH OF WORLD
description: For three hours Friday, the shadow of the moon will sweep the earth in a path from the Black Sea across Soviet Central Asia, Siberia and the Pacific Ocean to a point north of Hawaii.

title: Morton Sale Suit
description: Morton-Norwich Products Inc. said it filed suit in a Delaware chancery court against Rhone-Poulenc of France and two of its officers, who are also directors of Morton-Norwich, in an effort to prevent the French company from selling its stake in Morton. The company said that Rhone-Poulenc's actions in connection with its previously announced intent to sell its 20.3 percent stake in Morton-Norwich violated a 1978 agreement between the two companies.

title: Heritage Finishes First
description: Don Wildman's Heritage beat M..S Keeler's Brassy across the finish line by 45 minutes today in the 57th Port Huron-to-Mackinac Island yacht race.

title: People
description: * Irene A. Hansen and William L. Sharfman have been elected senior vice presidents of Brouillard Communications, a division of the J. Walter Thompson Company.

title: Market Place; Price Outlook Is Gloomy
description: THE stock market, which is near its lowest ebb in over a year, has investors watching quotation machines for signs of disaster. Investors fear that the heavy selling of recent weeks could resume, and they are unenthusiastic about the possibility that stock prices may simply move indecisively for weeks.

title: JWT Group's Net Down 77.4% in Quarter
description: The JWT Group's financial performance for the second quarter, just released, was worse than the first. Gross revenues were up 21.8 percent to over $100 million from the $82.2 million in the same period last year.

title: U.S. POLICY INCREASES TRADE WITH CHINA
description: China has replaced the Soviet Union as the most active Communist trading partner of the United States under new policies linking political behavior with more favorable trade relations, President Reagan told Congress today.

title: Bonn Rejects Merger
description: The West German Federal Cartel Office said today that it rejected the proposed acquisition of more than 25 percent of Metallgesellschaft, the West German nonferrous metals and chemical company, by Veba, the petrochemicals and energy group that is West Germany's largest corporation in terms of sales. A Cartel Office spokesman said that after an informal examination of the proposed acquisition, the office expressed ''grave doubts'' whether the transaction could receive formal approval because of the extent to which certain market activities of both companies would benefit from the deal.

title: Tass Sees Japanese Buildup
description: Tass, the official Soviet press agency, said today that Japan had begun a new anti-Soviet campaign to justify plans to increase its military strength. It cited Japanese observance of ''a month for the return of the northern territories,'' referring to Tokyo's demands that Moscow relinquish a cluster of islands it occupied at the end of World War II. Japan claims the islands, in the Kuriles chain, but the Soviet Union has refused to negotiate.

title: 3 PERSONS ARE KILLED AS FLASH FLOOD HITS CANYON IN ARIZONA
description: Three persons were killed when a flood raced through a canyon recreation area yesterday afternoon, officials said, and at least five were still missing today.

title: BOATS ON MOON ESTATE STIR CONCERN IN TARRYTOWN
description: More than two dozen sport-fishing boats are parked on the spacious grounds of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, and their presence has left the town's residents wondering what the boats are doing here.

title: DR. FRANCES L. ILG, AUTHORITY AND WRITER ON CHILD BEHAVIOR
description: Dr. Frances L. Ilg, an authority on child behavior, died Sunday while on vacation at her family home in Manitowish Waters, Wis. She was 78 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Not Worth the Effort
description: One of the perils touring concert pianists face is discovering that the piano they are to play on is wanting. Alicia de Larrocha told yesterday about a particularly antique instrument she had to play Sunday night in a recital at the John Drew Theater in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Simple Cairo Service Marks Death of Shah
description: The family of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi today commemorated the first anniversary of his death with a simple ceremony at the Al-Rifai Mosque, where he is buried.

title: HYATT TRAGEDY RAISES QUESTIONS OF RESPONSIBILITY
description: The fall of two aerial walkways in the Hyatt Regency hotel here has raised questions with implications for the way major buildings are constructed in every city in the nation.

title: Former CBS Chief Settles on New Job
description: After he resigned last May as chief executive and president of CBS Inc., John D. Backe, 49 years old, sorted through hundreds of proposals before settling on the position of president of Tomorrow Entertainment, one of television's leading production companies.

title: WOLF TRAP: A CONCENTRATION OF TEEN-AGE BALLERINAS
description: Seemingly out of nowhere, but actually out of years of hard work in a ballet studio, a crop of teen-age ballerinas has shot up in various parts of the country.

title: Oil Policy Talks Held
description: Oil ministers from Libya, Nigeria, Algeria and Gabon met on Sunday to discuss forming a ''common front of resistance'' to worldwide pressure to cut their oil prices, the Libyan news service Jana reported yesterday.

title: Isn't a Primary News?
description: If the major league baseball season had not been postponed due to greed and intransigence, maybe no one would have noticed. The absence of a city primary campaign, that is. A good pennant race might have obscured the snowballing void that is our mayoral primary contest.

title: CHARLES AND LADY DIANA REHEARSE THE WEDDING
description: Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer rehearsed their vows tonight in the hush of St. Paul's Cathedral. Lady Diana, whose nerves have been frayed by the intense scrutiny to which she has been subjected in recent weeks, arrived at the cathedral by way of an underground car park. But after an hourlong practice ceremony, she and her fiance emerged hand-in-hand through the west door. She managed a quick smile for the crowd of several thousand people before jumping with Prince Charles into a waiting car.

title: CONVICTIONS THROWN OUT IN SAM GOODY TAPE CASE
description: A Federal judge yesterday threw out the convictions of Sam Goody Inc. and a vice president of the company on counterfeit-tape charges and accused the prosecution of misconduct.

title: U.S. Denies It Caused Dengue Fever in Cuba
description: The State Department today denied charges made last night by Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, linking the United States with outbreaks of fever and crop disease in his country.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 28, 1981
description: International Legislation to aid British youths in obtaining jobs was announced by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in response to the recent outbreak of rioting. The emergency bills, estimated to cost up to $1 billion next year, face almost certain approval in Parliament. (Page A1, Column 2.) With Britain's royal wedding just 36 hours away, Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer rehearsed their vows in St. Paul's Cathedral. The 300-year old church was sealed off by the police, and security specialists locked the doors and checked every nook and crevice of the vast edifice. (A6:1-2.)

title: STORM'S WAKE SLOWS RIDERS ON SUBWAY AND RAIL LINES
description: Thousands of subway and PATH riders found travel disrupted in the wake of a prolonged thunder and lightning storm that rattled windows and awakened many sleepers in New York City early yesterday morning.

title: Pennsylvania Bank Stake
description: Marine Midland Banks Inc. of New York and the Industrial Valley Bank and Trust Company of Philadelphia announced that Marine Midland plans to make an equity investment of up to $25 million in Industrial Valley. A definitive agreement is expected shortly, the two bank holding companies said yesterday.

title: VICTOR LESSER
description: Victor Lesser, a former textile executive in Manhattan, died Sunday after a brief illness at the Mount Sinai Medical Center.

title: Tribute to Lenny Bruce At Punch Line Monday
description: The Manhattan Punch Line Theater, 260 West 41st Street, will present a tribute to the late Lenny Bruce next Monday at 8 P.M. The evening will begin with a discussion about the comedian by a panel of journalists and comedians who knew him. The evening will include a screening of Fred Baker's 85-minute documentary ''Lenny Bruce Without Tears,'' featuring Bruce's appearances on ''The Steve Allen Show'' and an interview with Nat Hentoff.

title: GOLDIN DEBATES DEARIE IN BATTLE FOR NOMINATION
description: In their first debate of the Democratic primary campaign, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin and his opponent, Assemblyman John C. Dearie, agreed yesterday that the city was ''crumbling'' but they avoided pinning any responsibility on Mayor Koch.

title: Skating Title To Hamilton
description: Scott Hamilton, displaying the form that has brought him world and United States titles, easily won the gold medal in men's figure skating at the National Sports Festival tonight.

title: TV RULES CHANGES GAIN
description: Members of a House and Senate conference panel voted today to extend licensing periods for television stations to five years and to seven years for radio stations. The license period is now three years for both.

title: Mediator in Nurse Strike
description: A Federal mediator called both sides back for bargaining today in an effort to end a three-day-old strike by registered nurses that has crippled the Berkshire Medical Center, the largest hospital in the Berkshires.

title: Celanese Lifts Prices
description: The Celanese Fibers Marketing Company, a unit of the Celanese Corporation, said yesterday that it would increase prices by 10 cents a pound on heavy-denier polyester tire and industrial yarns, effective Aug. 31. It said the increase covers all type of products, 500-denier and above, and was caused by higher operating costs.

title: THE TEXT OF REAGAN'S SPEECH COMPARING THE DETAILS OF TAX CUT PROPOSALS
description: Following is the text of a speech on his tax-cutting program by President Reagan in Washington last night as recorded by The New York Times:

title: SIDNEY LIDZ
description: Sidney Lidz, an electronics engineer specializing in high-fidelity equipment, died of acute leukemia Saturday at his home in Middletown, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: Steel Output Down
description: Steel production fell to 2.301 million tons in the week ended July 25, a decrease of eight-tenths of a percentage point from the previous week's 2.319 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 77.8 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 78.4 percent in the previous week. Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 73.797 million tons, an increase of 14.1 percent from the 64.703 million tons in the previous year.

title: Chia Chou, a Pianist, Wins Competition
description: A 21-year-old Taiwanese-born Canadian citizen has won the Sydney International Piano Competition at the Sydney Opera House.

title: New President Named At Louis Harris Firm
description: Humphrey Taylor, 47, has been named president and chief operating officer of Louis Harris & Associates, a national research firm owned by the Gannett Corporation.

title: GOV. CAREY ISSUED NO RIOT FORECAST
description: To the Editor:

title: LOWER TAXI FARE PROPOSED TO AID NEWARK AIRPORT
description: To encourage more travelers to use Newark International Airport, Governor Byrne has proposed a system that would enable taxi fares from midtown New York to the New Jersey airport to be cut to $18 from the present $36.

title: DRUG SEEMS TO CONTROL SEVERITY OF
description: ILLNESS By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

title: Zia Leaves for Saudi Visit
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan left today for a three-day private visit to Saudi Arabia that could include talks with King Khalid on sales of United States arms to the two countries.

title: Chess: Seirawan and Kavalek Vie For Lead in Championship
description: Yasser Seirawan, a 20-year-old Seattle grandmaster, took the lead in the 12th round of the United States Championship in the Americana Hotel here with a 7 1/2-3 1/2 score.

title: No Headline
description: Kathy Arendsen pitched her third consecutive shutout at the National Sports Festival and kept the Raybestos Brakettes in contention in the women's softball competition today.

title: THE ULTIMATE WEDDING PUT-ON
description: Forget about those engraved glass bowls, silver platters and madeto-order beds. Prince Charles and Lady Diana have now been presented with a true accolade: Their larger-than-life royal heads, surrounded by hearts, horseshoes and candy kisses, currently reign on the fronts of matching cotton T-shirts, in such silkscreen shades as turquoise, yellow, pink and blue.

title: Bridge:; Chicago Experts Capture Lead in Life Master Pairs
description: Two experts from Chicago led the way into the second semifinal session of the Life Master Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here tonight. But among their closest pursuers were Edgar Kaplan of New York and Norman Kay of Narberth, Pa., long one of the world's finest partnerships and the winners of the Vanderbilt Cup in Detroit in March.

title: REAGAN DELAYING PROPOSALS FOR CLEAN AIR ACT
description: With key policy makers sharply divided over the way to proceed, President Reagan has been forced to defer sending to Congress his recommendations for changing the much-debated Clean Air Act.

title: Improvement Is Noted For Recipient of Heart
description: Blood coagulation problems afflicting a Dutch heart transplant recipient were reported to be under control today, and he let doctors know he was not in pain, although he was still listed in critical but slightly improved condition more than 36 hours after surgery.

title: RESPONSE BY DEMOCRATS TO PRESIDENT
description: Following are replies to President Reagan's tax speech by Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: POLICE OUTLOOK 'BLEAK' IN WESTCHESTER
description: Prospects for Westchester County's police department were described today as ''bleak'' unless steps were taken quickly to complete the merger of the County Sheriff's Department and the Parkway Police that voters approved two years ago.

title: Souvenirs Have More Than Sentimental Value
description: Sports stars do it, other celebrities do, too, so why not the Pope? That, apparently, is what Pope John Paul II wanted to know when he got a look at the Vatican's projected 1981 deficit of $25.6 million. To help close that financial gap the Vatican has now moved to cash in on the Pope's personal popularity by hiring Mark McCormack as the exclusive dealer for papal souvenirs during the Pope's visit to Britain next year.

title: Transactions; BASKETBALL PORTLAND (NBA) - Cut Brian Jack- son of Utah State and Mark Iavaroni of Virginia.; COLLEGE YALE - Named Christopher Morris as- sociate director of athletics.; FOOTBALL GIANTS (NFC) - Reached agreement with Brad Van Pelt, linebacker, on five- year extension of contract for $1 million.  Waived Kevin Huff, free-agent fullback from Hofstra, who left camp.  ATLANTA (NFC) - Waived Larry Fortner, quarterback, Anthony Anderson, running back, and Dexter Barry, offensive lineman.
description: lineman. Larry Tearry, free-agent offen- sive lineman, left camp. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Signed Tom Owen, reserve quarterback. ST.

title: THE PRESIDENT AS AN UNLIKELY DISCIPLE OF ANARCHIST KROPOTKIN
description: To the Editor:

title: KEEPING UP WITH BURGLAR ALARMS station
description: Just before the turn of the century, telegraph companies protected homes by installing electric call boxes that were connected by wire to their central offices. Customers could summon messengers, cabs, doctors and even policemen and firemen by means of telegraphic code.

title: Move It Now Triumphs As Belmont Meet Ends
description: Move It Now scored a narrow victory in the $53,200 Mount Vernon Stakes as the 72-day Belmont Park meeting ended before a crowd of 21,405 yesterday. The annual 24-day meeting at Saratoga opens tomorrow with reduced betting takeouts in effect.

title: INDIA SETS LIMITS ON RIGHT TO STRIKE
description: The Indian Government moved today to bar strikes in ''essential services,'' setting up the prospect of the most severe confrontations with labor unions since the period of authoritarian rule under Indira Gandhi in the mid-1970's.

title: THRILLERS; Landmarks
description: We also know a woman who's fond of taking visitors on a crimebuff's tour of New York. ''This,'' she'll say, pointing to a Greenwich Village house, ''is on the site of the mansion where Alexander Hamilton breathed his last.

title: Arkansas Prison Officials Begin Inmate Transfers
description: Gov. Frank White today ordered 15 state police officers and seven National Guardsmen to serve as security officers at the state prison's Wrightsville Unit so that more prisoners could be housed there.

title: A RECORD OUTFLOW FOR THRIFT UNITS
description: The nation's savings and loan associations reported a record savings loss in June, Federal regulators said today, marking an unprecedented fourth straight month during which savings withdrawals have exceeded deposits.

title: Israeli Estimate of Toll
description: The Israeli Government said today that the air strike on Beirut had killed at least a hundred Palestinian guerrillas, most of them members of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

title: CLERC DEFEATS VILAS IN FINAL
description: Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina, winning his second tournament in as many weeks, defeated his countryman, Guillermo Vilas, 7-5, 6-2, tonight in the $200,000 Washington Star International tennis championships.

title: Looking at the Bright Side in Rhode Island
description: It's too early to tell if Rhode Islanders can be persuaded to lift their heads and sing ''We're the biggest little state in the union, Rhode Island, Rhode Island.'' But if Gov. J. Joseph Garrahy has his way, the residents of the nation's smallest state will do just that.

title: BERRIGANS GET 3 YEARS IN PROTEST AT G.E. PALNT
description: Philip F. Berrigan and the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan were sentenced to three to 10 years in prison today for their roles in a break-in that was part of a nuclear protest at a plant of the General Electric Company.

title: 26 SUSPECTS ARE SEIZED IN GARMENT THEFT RING
description: Twenty-six persons were arrested yesterday and millions of dollars in stolen property was recovered as the police broke up what authorities described as a ''highly sophisticated'' organized-crime burglary operation preying upon the city's garment industry. Seven other persons were still being sought.

title: Borden Earnings Rise
description: Borden Inc., a diversified food and chemicals company, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter rose 1.5 percent to a record $40.2 million, or $1.37 a share, from $39.6 million, or $1.26 a share, and reflected a 1980 move to sell several units with low profit margins. Sales fell to $1.21 billion, from $1.28 billion a year ago, when Borden had more operating units.

title: Czechoslovak Dissident Gets Term of 7 1/2 Years
description: Rudolf Battek, a Czechoslovak dissident, was sentenced in Prague today to seven and a half years in prison for subversive activities, the Austrian radio said. He had already served 13 months in pretrial detention.

title: Transamerica Sells U.A. Unit
description: The Transamerica Corporation said that it completed the sale of its United Artists film unit to the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company for $380 million and will report an after-tax capital gain of about $150 million for the third quarter.

title: SIDEWALK TABLES GO QUICKLY IN A CRACKDOWN
description: The Department of Consumer Affairs began the strict enforcement of laws on unlicensed outdoor cafes yesterday. The move was an attempt to control at least one element of the increasing encroachment on sidewalk space by restaurant owners, florists, peddlers, fruit and vegetable stands, newsstands and others whose sprawling displays often force pedestrians to walk in the street.

title: OIL TAX ISSUE SPLITS REGIONS
description: Representative Dennis E. Eckart is a freshman Democrat representing Cleveland, a city that symbolizes the blight and decay now spreading across the nation's industrial heartland. As Congress approaches a key vote tomorrow on tax legislation, Mr. Eckart believes that both the Democratic and Republican bills make too many concessions to the oil industry.

title: Suspect in Rockland Murders Recaptured in Alabama Town
description: A suspect in the double murder of a Rockland County couple was recaptured today in Selma, Ala., three weeks after he escaped from the Rockland County jail by sawing through bars, the Rockland sherriff's office said.

title: Forest Fires in Portugal Force Villagers to Flee
description: The residents of entire villages were flown to safety by helicopters today as the worst forest fires in Portugal this century ravaged densely wooded areas.

title: Joe Namath, Actor
description: It was an evening of players at play at Hisae on East 58th Street on Monday, and Joe Namath, the unlikely star of the Jones Beach production of ''Damn Yankees,'' was the man of the moment.

title: I.T.&T. Settles Its Corning Suit
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has admitted infringing on the patents of Corning Glass Works in the manufacture of glass fibers, the two companies announced.

title: Fire Perils Georgia Island
description: ST. MARY'S, Ga., July 28 (AP) - A smoldering fire that burned 1,500 acres of northern Cumberland Island earlier this month has burst into flames again, threatening more of the island wilderness, officials said today.

title: Dome Mines Lifts Petroleum Stake
description: Dome Mines Ltd. said that it has raised its interest in Dome Petroleum Ltd. to 66.8 million shares, or 26.9 percent.

title: Adventists Weigh Loans To Bankrupt Developer
description: The national conference of the Seventhday Adventist Church said today that it was investigating loans made by several of its local units to a California developer who has filed for bankruptcy.

title: The Clean Plate Club
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: ''Encouraging (or Forcing) a Child to Eat'' (July 8) brought back many memories. It is a wonder my children even talk to me after the horrifying tales I told them when I was trying to make them eat.

title: After the Tax Spree
description: Ignore the shouting about taxes in the hot Washington air. What are now the President's proposals and the competing package from House Democrats are hardly distinguishable, and equally misguided.

title: Barbaro Questions Petitions of 2 Foes
description: Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro of Brooklyn has challenged the designating petitions of two of his competitors for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, Jim Smith and Mel Klenetsky.

title: Careers; The Rise Of Traffic Managers
description: A STRAIGHT line might not always be the shortest distance between two points, at least not for traffic managers. These are the men (and a scattering of women) who have the responsibility for shipping manufactured goods in the most efficient way - relating cost effectiveness and customer service.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: Recently in this space George Berkwitt expressed his perplexity at seeing a subway poster that said SAVE OHIO. ''Save Ohio?'' asked Mr. Berkwitt.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I shall, I think, spend half the time in tears.'' - Prince Charles. (A8:1.)

title: CASEY SUMMONED TO TESTIFY TODAY
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence announced today that it had called William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, to testify tomorrow in a closed session about his previous financial dealings and his management of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: DIRECTOR HAD WON 3 ACADEMY AWARDS
description: William Wyler, the movie director whose career began in 1929 and included such films as ''Ben Hur,'' ''Wuthering Heights'' and ''The Little Foxes,'' died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills. He had just returned from London, where he had been honored in a retrospective series by the British Film Institute. He was 79 years old.

title: SOCIAL SCIENTISTS FIGHT FOR GOVERNMENT FUNDS
description: Galvanized by what they see as an attack against them by the Reagan Administration, the nation's psychologists, sociologists, economists and other social scientists have mounted a sophisticated lobbying effort that has begun to change the way Washington views them.

title: DINING WHERE THE MAIN COURSE PERFORMS
description: day periods during their growth, and the restaurant that has gained fame for serving them has a hiding place of its own - the town of Goiana.

title: HOUSE TEST TODAY CALLED TOSS-UP
description: The Reagan White House and the Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives battled today for the votes that would assure victory tomorrow when the House chooses a tax bill.

title: N.F.L. Attorney Calls Antitrust Case 'Slim'
description: An attorney for the National Football League told jurors today that attorneys for the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission had submitted ''very slim, very questionable evidence'' to support their antitrust case against the league.

title: 2 More Victims Found In Arizona Flash Flood
description: Searchers discovered two more bodies today in a canyon recreation area, bringing to five the number of persons known killed when a flash flood raced through the campground over the weekend. At least three other persons were missing, and about 40 law-enforcement officers and civilian volunteers continued to search the area today.

title: Kennedy Center Names 5 to Be Given Honors
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has announced the recipients of the fourth Kennedy Center Honors for career achievement in the performing arts.

title: AN I.B.M. COMPUTER FOR SMALL BUSINESS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced its smallest computer yet. But it was not quite so small as expected.
