title: MAN, 71, IS ORDERED TO REPLY TO CHARGE OF SERVING THE NAZIS
description: An ailing 71-year-old man who says he worked for United States intelligence in World War II has been given until Aug. 10 to respond to charges that he was a Nazi SS captain who lied to gain United States citizenship, the authorities said today.

title: Senate Backs Heat Bill Credit
description: The Senate late tonight approved an amendment granting taxpayers up to $200 credit for their 1981 home heating bills.

title: BASIC COLANDERS AND THEIR USES
description: IHAVE been trying hard to think about my humbler tools lately, putting out of mind powerful machines and anything colored copper. Among the humblest - and to tell you the truth I never pay them any mind except when I force myself to -are my colanders.

title: STATE AND CITY OFFICIALS SAY JAILS CANNOT SAFELY HOLD NEW PRISONERS
description: City and state correction officials yesterday told a Federal judge who is considering how to ease the overcrowding of jails in New York City that neither of their systems could safely handle any more inmates.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: FRENCH chefs are taught at the beginning of their apprenticeship that subtlety in flavors is the heart and soul of great cooking. One flavor may be more pronounced than another in any given dish - the tarragon in lobster a l'americaine, for example - but no flavor should be overly stressed.

title: UNGARO'S STUNNING MIX OF COLORS AND PATTERNS
description: Emanuel Ungaro, after turning out one of the better ready-to-wear collections here four months ago, has surpassed himself with his couture clothes, which were shown here this morning. There were extended bursts of applause at his show and, at the end, bravos.

title: Giants Shift Rookie To a Key Position
description: On the first play of the Giants' 30-play controlled scrimmage this morning at nearby Briarcliff High School, Billy Taylor tried to slice off right guard.

title: PLAYERS ON COAST TO MEET
description: The baseball strike enters its 48th day today with Marvin Miller briefing a group of players in Los Angeles and the club owners meeting in New York, and with both sides hinting that their negotiations might be resumed tomorrow.

title: BEST BUYS
description: REASSURING words on the negligible local effect of the Mediterranean fruit fly are still coming from Hunts Point. According to a spokesman, because of the thorough inspection of all produce before shipment, the supply and quality of produce in area stores this week have not noticeably suffered.

title: 29 Die in Mexico Crash, Including 2 Americans
description: Airline officials said today that two Americans were among the 29 people killed when an Aeromexico DC-9 bound for Tijuana crashed and burst into flames while trying to land at Chihuahua airport in heavy wind and rain.

title: PORK- U.S. PRIME
description: How many Americans outside of Nebraska have ever heard of the ''O'Neill unit''? How many even inside Nebraska? How many Americans outside of Mississippi and Alabama have heard of Tennessee-Tombigbee? Or of a score or more of similar multi-billion dollar construction projects in the South and West that have no redeeming national social or economic value? They are, in reality, nothing more than major political payoffs that President Reagan's ''austerity'' budgetcutting has somehow missed.

title: NEW HOUSE MEMBERS SWORN IN
description: The House went to full strength for the first time in months today when the Republican winner of a special election, Joseph Smith of Philadelphia, was sworn in and said he would vote with the Democrats.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MUCH of the misery commonly associated with menopause is an outgrowth of society's negative image of this natural, inevitable time in a woman's life. ''The popular stereotype of the menopausal woman has been primarily negative: she is exhausted, irritable, unsexy, hard to live with, irrationally depressed, unwillingly suffering a 'change' that marks the end of her active (re)productive life,'' say the authors of ''Our Bodies, Ourselves'' (Boston Women's Health Book Collective, Simon & Schuster, $4.95). Such misconceptions can easily become selffulfilling prophecies and Second of two articles on the midlife crisis in men and women turn what might otherwise be a smooth adjustment into a tumultuous upheaval.

title: South African Squad To Face Protests Here
description: A group of political, religious and sports organizations announced today that it would attempt to stop a three-game September tour of the United States by a South African rugby team.

title: Another Abscam Verdict
description: Was the Government's ''sting'' operation - fictitious foreign millionaires offering real money to members of Congress and other officials - constitutional and legal? In a 136-page post-trial memorandum, Judge George Pratt, whose Federal court in Brooklyn handled most of the Abscam trials, answers the question with a ringing affirmative.

title: IN RIOT AREA, HARD TIMES SPOIL BRITAIN'S PARTY
description: Like many thousands of other shops all over Britain, the Bhikbro delicatessen here is decorated with two large pictures of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer, with a message of congratulations on their marriage tomorrow.

title: RENOVATION OF THE PRINCE GEORGE HOTEL ON E. 28TH ST.
description: Only four years ago the successful moderate-priced hotel appeared to be a vanishing species in Manhattan, succumbing to the decline in tourism during the hard economic times of the middle 1970's. For many such buildings, survival seemed to require conversion to housing.

title: DATA ON LAW FIRMS RAISE RACIAL ISSUE
description: Less than one-half of 1 percent of the partners in the nations' largest law firms are black, according to a recent study, and many lawyers and scholars blame racism, although representatives of the firms deny that.

title: Memorex Confirms Merger Discussions
description: The Memorex Corporation, confirming widespread speculation, said yesterday that it has been holding discussions with several unidentified partners over the past several months aimed at combining part or all of its assets with another company.

title: 3 ALLIES FOUND LAGGING ON OUTLAYS FOR MILITARY
description: The Defense Department has said that Japan, Canada and Denmark are not carrying fair shares of the burden of the common defense.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Brands Inc. has elected Arnold Henson senior vice president and general counsel.

title: ONE MAN'S FAVORITE LONG ISLAND MARKETS
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. ALTHOUGH eastern Long Island has long been celebrated for its potatoes and ducks, the area has also, thanks to an abundance of markets that have sprouted up over the last two decades, become an incomparable source of freshly harvested produce from the soil and oceans and lakes.

title: LEAGUE OF CITIES ASSAILS CABLE TV DEREGULATION
description: The National League of Cities, the nation's largest municipal association, threatened today to fight a comprehensive telecommunications deregulation bill because it would end the authority of cities to own cable systems or regulate local cable operators.

title: JETS' BLINKA ASKS TO BE TRADED
description: Stan Blinka, claiming that he is saddled with a long-term Jets contract that pays him less than half the going rate for linebackers, called an unusual news conference in his small dormitory room today to say, ''In order to seek what I think is fair, I'm asking to be traded.''

title: U.S. PRIEST IS SLAIN IN GUATEMALA
description: Unidentified gunmen today shot to death an American priest working in Guatemala, the United States Embassy said.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 29, 1981
description: International The resignation of an ambassador created a stir. The departure of Robert G. Neumann as Ambassador to Saudi Arabia was announced amid reports that his resignation had been forced after a dispute with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. Friends and critics of the foreign policy analyst said he had expressed criticism of statements made by Mr. Haig about Middle East policy and had said that Washington should ''crack down'' on Israel for its recent military actions. (Page A1, Columns 1-2. ) Emergency feed grain aid to Poland will be supplied by the United States. Warsaw was granted a $50 million loan to buy 350,000 metric tons of corn to feed livestock. (A3:1-3.)

title: Paine Webber Chief Adds Another Title
description: Donald B. Marron, the 47-year-old president and chief executive officer of Paine Webber Inc., was elected yesterday to the additional position of chairman. The move, which had been expected since Mr. Marron became chief executive last year, followed the retirement of James W. Davant, 63, who had been chairman for more than 10 years.

title: LITHOGRAPHS OF PICASSOS HIJACKED IN QUEENS
description: A truck carrying 600 lithographic reproductions of paintings by Pablo Picasso valued by the owner at $480,000 was hijacked by two gunmen yesterday afternoon when the driver stopped at a traffic light in Queens about a mile from the Queensboro Bridge, the police said.

title: Another Institute
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In reference to ''Coast Cooking School With No Secrets'' (July 15), the writer neglected to mention Johnson and Wales, a cooking school in Providence, R.I. Johnson and Wales offers an associate degree in culinary arts and is well-known. PHYLLIS JEANNE TAYLOR Willimantic, Conn.

title: NOMINEES SHOULDN'T PAY COURTESY CALLS ON SENATORS
description: They are graciously termed ''courtesy calls,'' but the practice of Presidential nominees' private visits with Senators before confirmation hearings corrupts the constitutional requirement that the Senate provide advice and consent on Presidential appointments.

title: The KaDeWe of Berlin
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Concerning your article ''For Berlin, a World of Food'' (June 24), I would like to bring to your attention that there was an error in the hours of the KaDeWe. By coincidence I went to Berlin after reading the article.

title: TURNING OUT AT BUCKINGHAM PALACE
description: Queen Elizabeth gave one of the biggest parties in the history of Buckingham Palace last night for 1,500 guests who ranged from members of the royal family to members of Prince Charles's favorite pop group, the Three Degrees. The ball, preceded by a dinner for 100, was in honor of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer, who will be married tomorrow.

title: LEGISLATOR PARLEY UPSET OVER GRANTS
description: Top officials of the National Conference of State Legislatures said today that Congress had modified President Reagan's block grants proposal so extensively that the new system of financing Federal programs would cause serious hardship to states and localities.

title: The Wedding, at a Proper Distance
description: Perhaps the most famous episode of ''Upstairs, Downstairs'' was the one in which Edward VII came to dinner at 165 Eaton Place. The crowd outside the Bellamys' cheered when he arrived; the servants peering from an upstairs landing held their breath.

title: Helicopter Hole Prompts Fears in Fly Spraying
description: Extra security was ordered around helicopters spraying pesticides over the populous Santa Clara Valley today after what looked like a bullet hole was found in the tail of one of the helicopters.

title: U.S., SOVIET TEAMS SET FOR FINAL IN BASKETBALL
description: The Soviet Union defeated Yugoslavia, 92-84, today to set up a match with the United States for the men's basketball championship at the World University Games.

title: HUNGER STRIKE STARTED BY 14 BASQUE INMATES
description: Fourteen Basque prisoners in the southern town of Cadiz began a hunger strike today to protest their transfer there from a Madrid jail, Justice Ministry sources said today.

title: Trainer Is Indicted On Charge of Perjury
description: The trainer Alex Fiore has been indicted on a charge of lying to the Nassau County grand jury that investigated charges that the jockey Larry Saumell illegally possessed an electric prod at Belmont Park. Nassau District Attorney Denis Dillon announced the indictment yesterday.

title: EX-AIDE SAYS SHERIFF HAD PROBLEMS IN JOB
description: A former deputy sheriff testified today that Thomas J. Delaney, who was suspended last February for alleged misconduct as the Westchester County Commissioner/ Sheriff, had ''moral problems with his position as a law-enforcement officer.''

title: MERGER
description: MUSINGSSeagram offers $73 a share for Conoco ... Conoco's management agrees to a takeover by Du Pont at $87.50 ... Mobil bids $90, Seagram's raises to $92, Mobil says $105 ... Sugar plums dance for the lawyers, arbitrageurs and investment bankers. But what can the rest of us make of it all?

title: THEATER: GERSHWINS' 'FUNNY FACE' AT GOODSPEED
description: EAST HADDAM, Conn. THINK of ''Funny Face,'' the George and Ira Gershwin musical at the Goodspeed Opera House, as the sunny side of F. Scott Fitzgerald; the girls are flappers and the boys are dancing fools. ''Funny Face'' has no real book, although it has an extraordinary amount of plot, and as a musical it exists mostly so that you can hear the score. When ''Funny Face'' was trying out in Wilmington, Del., in 1927, ''How Long Has This Been Going On?'' was dropped. There was nowhere to put it. When you cannot find a place for a song like that, you are dealing with a surfeit of riches.

title: Kroehler Family Sells Its Stake
description: The Kroehler Manufacturing Company, a maker of furniture, said that a group headed by Peter R. Harvey and Kenneth L. Kwiatt purchased about 37 percent of its common stock from the Kroehler family trust and certain related families for an undisclosed price.

title: Soft-Drink Suit Ending
description: A Federal Trade Commission judge today dismissed a 10-year-old suit against five soft-drink manufacturers charged with antitrust violations.

title: ABC's Profit Climbs 3.4%
description: The American Broadcasting Companies announced yesterday that its profit in the second quarter rose 3.4 percent. It thus became the only corporate parent of a broadcasting network to report a gain for the period.

title: Commodity Margins Cut
description: The New York Commodity Exchange Inc. yesterday reduced the margin requirements for speculative investments in gold, silver and copper, saying that volatility in the metals markets had lessened.

title: CBS Cable Sponsor
description: CBS Cable, the cultural network that will make its debut Oct. 12, has announced that its first advertiser is Kraft, which will sponsor a new monthly ''Kraft Music Hall.'' No money figure was mentioned for the five-year pact. The network, part of CBS, will have the potential of reaching over three million cable subscribers and will supply them with 12 hours of daily programming - a three-hour block repeated four times beginning at 7:30 A.M.

title: Jury to Investigate Death Before Missouri Crowd
description: A grand jury investigation will begin this weekend into the vigilante-style shooting death in Skidmore of a man whom the authorities considered to be a troublemaker.

title: HARLEM DANCERS OPEN IN LONDON AMID POMP
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem last night became the first black dance company to perform at the Royal Opera House. The occasion was attended by Nancy Reagan, who offered generous praise, and by London critics who delivered mixed reviews.

title: Elf Completes Texasgulf Bid
description: Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, a company two-thirds owned by the French Government, said that it has completed its $3 billion acquisition of Texasgulf Inc., a major American minerals concern and the world's biggest sulfur producer, despite a request from the United States Government to postpone the merger.

title: Dow Drops 6.47, to 939.40, on Rate Fears; Airline Issues Fall Sharply
description: A dispirited stock market lost ground yesterday after two advancing sessions. Its main nemesis was the fear of high interest rates, but the lack of a rally in bond prices this week put a particular damper upon the equity sector.

title: No Headline
description: The Cincinnati Reds said today that they would pay under protest the salary of Johnny Bench during the players' strike.

title: RAIL CAR WAS DUE TO BE MODIFIED
description: The railroad tank car that began spilling a volatile chemical that caught fire here yesterday had been scheduled to be modified to prevent the sort of puncture that apparently caused the leak, Federal officials said today.

title: Lucky, Comparatively Speaking, That Is
description: During intermission at a music festival in Kuhmo, Finland, on Monday night, Peter Cropper, first violinist with the Lindsay Quartet from Britain, was descending some stage stairs.

title: CAMBODIA'S FRIENDS IN HANOI
description: To the Editor:

title: THE COOLIDGE MODEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Anheuser-Busch Gains Control of Card Stadium
description: Anheuser-Busch Companies, owner of the St. Louis Cardinals baseball club, said today it had gained controlling interest in the company that owns Busch Stadium.

title: ABSENT WATER SECURITY CHIEF OF NEWARK IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: The Essex County Prosecutor's office has begun an investigation of possible fraud in connection with a former City Councilman.

title: SURVEY FINDS ANTI-SEMITISM IN U.S. HAS DECLINED SINCE 1964
description: Although anti-Semitism remains a serious social problem in the United States, prejudice against Jews has declined significantly over the past 17 years, according to a national public opinion survey conducted for the American Jewish Committee.

title: No Headline
description: Gabe Paul. president of the Cleveland Indians, said today that the baseball strike insurance has been of minimal help to his club.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 29, 1981; The Tax Debate
description: The Reagan Administration and the Democratic leadership of the House battled for votes on tax cut legislation, with both sides saying the outcome of today's vote was too close to call. (Page A1.)

title: HIGHER TOLL FEARED
description: At least 40 people were killed and 450 injured last night when a major earthquake struck a region of Iran devastated by an earthquake last month, the Teheran radio reported today.

title: Advertising; A Royal Wedding Promotion
description: DIFFERENT people will be watching the big wedding on television today for different reasons. Robert E. Launey's interest will be almost entirely commercial, because every time Lady Diana waves her right hand and shows off the sapphire and diamond engagement ring Prince Charles gave her, Mr. Launey will see it as advertising - pure advertising.

title: Oman Lowers Oil Price
description: Oman has lowered the price of its crude oil sold to Japanese customers by $3 a barrel, to $35.50, retroactive to July 1, an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The official said that Japanese refiners have not yet accepted the offer, but added that they would find it difficult to hold out for better terms, as the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group already has accepted the new price. Japanese concerns have been importing about 60,000 barrels of crude a day from Oman through direct deals.

title: SAVAGE CAPTURES GOLD MEDAL IN BOXING
description: Richard Savage of West Monroe, La., scored a 3-2 decision over Steve Cruz of Fort Worth tonight to win the boxing gold medal in the 119-pound division at the National Sports Festival.

title: U.S. GIVES POLAND A $50 MILLION LOAN TO BUY CORN
description: John R. Block, the Secretary of Agriculture, said today that funds had been found to provide Poland with 350,000 metric tons of corn to use as feed,

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MRS. LLOYD FOSTERS A TOUCH OF GRACE
description: When Chris Evert Lloyd gives a public accounting of her tennis accomplishments, she says that she hopes to be remembered for her unparalled success on clay courts and for her consistency.

title: A MANPOWER HURDLE TO SOVIET OIL OUTPUT
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPARING THE TWO TAX BILLS
description: The following table compares the principal provisions of the two tax bills that will come before the House of Representatives today. The Democratic bill was drafted by the Ways and Means Committee, where the Democrats hold a 23-to-12 edge. The Administration bill will be offered on the House floor as a substitute for the committee bill. The bill approved by the Senate Finance Committee and now before the Senate is similar to the Administration's substitute House bill in many respects. DEMOCRATIC BILL INDIVIDUAL INCOME TAXES Would reduce tax rates for 1981, 1982 and 1983. Democratic tax writers do not see much reason to reduce withholding taxes on Oct. 1 and might give 1981 tax relief in form of a 1982 refund after returns are filed. Democratic cuts in rates would average 10 percent in 1982, 16 percent in 1983 - but relative reductions would be greater below $50,000. The 70 percent maximum rate on investment income would be reduced to 60 percent in 1982, and 50 percent in 1983. A further round of rate cuts of about 5 percent would take effect Jan. 1, 1984, if the Administration's economic targets are met.

title: Economic Scene; The Gamble On Tax Cuts
description: THE moment of truth arrives in Congress today for the President's tax bill and that of his Democratic opponents. Or perhaps one should call it the moment of untruth. Both Republicans and Democrats are going to have trouble keeping a straight face hailing either bill as just what the nation needs at this juncture in economic history.

title: CONOCO MOVES MADE BY SEAGRAM AND F.T.C.
description: Conoco advanced by 1 3/4 points, to $90.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in the wake of an announcement by Joseph E. Seagram & Sons that next Saturday it would begin paying $92 a share for Conoco stock already sent in under its $4.1 billion cash tender offer.

title: HELLMAN ASSAILED AGAIN
description: An attack on Lillian Hellman in the spring edition of The Paris Review, accusing the writer of having passed off fiction for fact in a 12-year-old memoir, has reopened the controversy about Miss Hellman's role in the literary and political battles of the 1930's and 40's. The attack, by the novelist Martha Gellhorn, comes a little more than a year after Miss Hellman filed a defamation suit against Mary McCarthy, who called Miss Hellman a ''dishonest writer.''

title: U.S. DROPS LABELS FOR MEAT PLANTS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would discontinue Carter Administration policies that labeled meat and poultry plants as ''problem'' or ''chronic problem'' if inspections revealed repeated deficiencies.

title: MAJOR PROVISIONS OF THE BUDGET BILL AGREED TO BY SENATE AND HOUSE CONFEREES
description: Following are the major provisions of the budget bill that have been agreed to by House and Senate conferees.

title: Bridge: Australians in Contention For Life Master Pair Title
description: Two Australian experts were making a strong bid here tonight to become the first non-American pair to win the life master pair championship of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. Entering the final session, Paul Lavings and Bob Richman of Sydney were fourth in a field of 60 pairs, cut from an original entry of 548.

title: Chevron Pact On Oil Prices
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - An $82.5 million settlement, the secondlargest in a Federal oil pricing complaint, has been signed between Chevron U.S.A. Inc. and the Department of Energy, both sides said today.

title: Ruling on Paper Sale
description: The Bankers Trust Company said that it would continue selling commercial paper on behalf of its corporate clients despite a ruling yesterday by Federal District Judge Joyce Green in Washington that the paper comes under the Glass-Steagall Act, which prohibits bank underwriting of corporate securities. A Bankers Trust spokesman said no determination had been made that the bank was acting as an underwriter.

title: COAST PANEL POSTPONES ACTION TO SAVE CONDORS
description: The California Fish and Game Commission decided today to postpone action on an elaborate plan by the Federal Government to save the endangered California condor.

title: BEACONS BURN ACROSS A JOYFUL BRITAIN
description: Skyrockets spangled the sky over London with gold and silver and red and blue tonight while bonfires blazed on 101 hilltops across the kingdom in a joyous prelude to the wedding tomorrow of the Prince of Wales, the 32-year-old heir to the British throne, and Lady Diana Spencer.

title: BILTMORE IS EXPECTED TO BE RECONSTRUCTED INTO OFFICE BUILDING
description: The Biltmore Hotel will be stripped to its steel skeleton and reconstructed into a granite-clad office building that will become the New York City headquarters of the Bank of America, according to development sources familiar with the project.

title: STATEN ISLAND CALLED THE KEY IN HOUSE REDISTRICTING
description: A member of Congress from Brooklyn refused to pose for a picture with one of his fellow Representatives the other day, saying, ''I don't want anyone to start thinking of the two of us together - the thought shouldn't cross their minds.''

title: A SHARED EXPERIENCE IN GRIEF FOR A LOST CHILD
description: William Jacobson is a thin man whose collarbones show through his T-shirt and who smokes cigarettes without filters. He has a tattoo on one bicep that says ''Mother'' over a fat red heart, and six children.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE DISTORTION OF AMERICA. By Oscar Handlin. 154 pages. Atlantic-Lit- tle, Brown. $10.95.

title: MCA SETS SIGHTS ON FLORIDA
description: In 1976, MCA Inc.'s gruff chairman, Lew R. Wasserman, failed in his attempts to acquire Sea World, a theme park based in San Diego. And last year, his bid for Cedar Point, an Ohio amusement park, was rejected. So this year, MCA has announced that it will build its own entertainment complex in Florida, a $170 million Eastern copy of its highly successful Universal Studios Tour in California.

title: FAILED STRATEGIES IN THE MOVE TO FURTHER COLLEGE INTEGRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: A CONFLICT WITH HAIG IS REPORTED
description: The resignation of Robert G. Neumann as Ambassador to Saudi Arabia was announced today, amid widespread reports that his action had been forced after a dispute with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: CALIFORNIA AGREES TO TAKE OVER PROSECUTION OF SUSPECT IN STRANGLINGS
description: George Deukmejian, the Attorney General of California, agreed today to prosecute Angelo Buono, a 46-year-old automobile upholsterer, for the 10 Hillside Strangler murders.

title: U.S. Official Examines Hotel Disaster Evidence
description: A structural engineer for the National Bureau of Standards today examined an undamaged but disassembled aerial walkway and the debris of two others that collapsed July 17 at the Hyatt Regency hotel, killing 111 persons.

title: 2 NEW MEXICO GROUPS FIGHTING STATE'S PACT TO BURY NUCLEAR WASTES
description: New Mexico has signed an agreement with the Federal Energy Department allowing the department to proceed with its plans to bury nuclear wastes in the state. But two citizens' groups are still battling the Government in court to halt work on the project.

title: SARATOGA IS A BREED APART
description: Last weekend, it was vans full of horses. Today it was cars full of people who want to bet on them. They sped up the New York State Thruway to Albany, switched onto the Northway, and passed through towns such as Crescent, Halfmoon, Burnt Hills and Round Lake. By tomorrow morning, enough of the vans and cars will have turned off at exits 13 to 15, Saratoga Springs, to double the normal equine population from 600 to 1,200 and that of humans from 30,000 to 60,000.

title: MUSIC AND ROCKETS FOR 200,000
description: AT exactly three and a half minutes before the final notes of Tchaikovsky's ''1812 Overture'' float over the Great Lawn tonight in Central Park, where the New York Philharmonic opens its 17th season of free concerts under the stars (they hope), the assistant conductor, Larry Newland, speaking into his walkie-talkie, will cue ...

title: Live TV Coverage Set For Wedding Today
description: Channels 2, 4, 7, 11 and 13 are providing coverage of the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer. Live coverage from London begins at 4:30 A.M., New York time, on Channels 4 and 11, and at 5 A.M. on Channels 2 and 7.

title: MOON CHURCH TO MOVE BOATS FROM ITS ESTATE IN TARRYTOWN
description: The village of Tarrytown has ordered the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church to remove a fleet of fishing boats from the grounds of the church's estate here by next week, and the church has agreed to do so, village officials said today.

title: SHELL FLAT
description: The Standard Oil Company of California yesterday reported that its second-quarter net income rose by 15.1 percent, the Shell Oil Company said its earnings were ''essentially unchanged'' and the Sun Company announced a 20.6 percent increase.

title: HELP OUR BURNED-OUT TEEN-AGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tourism Agency Approved
description: The House today overwhelmingly approved the creation of a Travel and Tourism Administration to encourage foreigners to travel in the United States. Representative James D. Santini, Democrat of Nevada, said the American share of spending by foreign tourists, which is more than $100 billion a year, had dropped to 10 percent from 13 percent because there was ''no coordinated endeavor to recognize the importance of foreign tourism.''

title: EAST-WEST TALKS ADJOURN IN RANCOR
description: The 35-member Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe adjourned today in disagreement to start a summer recess.

title: 'CHAPLIN' MUSICAL PLANED FOR APRIL
description: AMUSICAL about Charlie Chaplin, called, forthrightly, ''Charlie Chaplin,'' will open on Broadway next April. Joe Layton is supposed to direct and choreograph, ''pending,'' he says, ''a conversation with Ray Stark.'' Mr. Layton, a ''hot'' director, whose most recent hit was ''Barnum,'' is also executive producer of the movie ''Annie.'' Mr. Stark, however, is the big, overall producer of ''Annie.'' ''Charlie Chaplin'' is to go into rehearsal in January, and try out in Boston or Washington. Mr. Layton must work out his schedule.

title: NUCLEAR SAFETY PIONEER
description: Dr. Stafford L. Warren, who was responsible for protecting participants in the development and testing of the first atomic bomb from radiation hazards, died Sunday at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif., of a heart attack. He was 85 years old.

title: WILLIAMS ADMITS ERRORS BUT DENIES HE'S CORRUPT
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. told a committee of his peers today that he had made ''mistakes and errors in judgment,'' but that he had ''never engaged in any illegal conduct and never corrupted my office.''

title: HUDSON'S BAY SET TO BUY AMOCO UNIT
description: The Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company of Calgary said it has agreed to buy a controlling interest in the Cyprus Anvil Mining Corporation of Vancouver for $212.4 million (Canadian) from the Amoco Minerals Company, a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).

title: New Law Allows Revocation Of Bail in Some Felony Cases; ALBANY, July 28 - Governor Carey today approved a bill permitting judges to revoke a defendant's bail if the defendant is accused of committing a violent felony while free on bail for a previous crime.
description: Mr. Carey noted that 12 percent of felony defendants are arrested while awaiting trial on a previous charge.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
description: Interest rates moved higher yesterday as securities dealers continued cutting prices and raising yields to levels that they hope will attract more investor demand next week when the Treasury sells an estimated $8 billion of notes and bonds.

title: PORTABLE MILL POISED TO DEFY ARCTIC CHILL
description: Quietly and slowly, with only gentle swirls marking the movement, a giant barge larger than a football field eased from its moorings in the St. Lawrence River to begin a 3,500-mile journey into business history.

title: MILAN USES RISOTTO AS DOWNTOWN LURE
description: When Italy's dynamic and well-to-do second city started a drive recently to bring new life to its downtown on weekends, the local boosters hit upon a surefire ploy to lure people there: risotto.

title: EDWIN WENDELL PAULEY SR., 78
description: Edwin Wendell Pauley Sr., an oil magnate who advised Presidents and organized the nation's first comprehensive petroleum policy 40 years ago, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 78 years old.

title: CASEY PLANNING TO SEEK CURBS ON EX-C.I.A. AGENTS
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, has ordered a review of C.I.A. contracts to develop what he called ''additional protections'' against the transfer of technology and information by former agents to such countries as Libya and the Soviet Union.

title: Reichhold Chemicals Founder Nears Birthday
description: Henry H. Reichhold, the founder, chairman of the executive committee and chief executive officer of Reichhold Chemicals Inc., will celebrate his 80th birthday on Friday by putting in a full eight-hour day. ''I feel pretty young and mentally up to date,'' he said yesterday when reached near his company's plant in Vienna.

title: Schlitz Approves Heileman Terms
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company, the nation's sixth-largest brewer, said that the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, the fourth-largest, has agreed to be acquired by Heileman in a previously announced $494 million transaction that would create the nation's third-largest brewery.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT NARROWS
description: The nation's trade deficit narrowed to $3.12 billion in June, the Commerce Department reported today, but Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said economic conditions portend ''a rough trade climate for the months to come.''

title: FOOTBALL FOOD: NOT JUST STEAK
description: Bryan Miller is a freelance writer. By BRYAN MILLER

title: NUCLEAR ENERGY EXPERT
description: John Lamarsh, head of the nuclear engineering department at the Polytechnic Institute of New York, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 53 years old.

title: NORTHERNERS IN DALLAS: A LESSON IN DETERMINATION
description: Mark Lee still believes he made the right choice in giving up his machinist's job in Toledo, Ohio, to head south. But some nights, after finishing a dinner of cold canned green beans and preparing to go to sleep on the floor of his 1974 Ford van, it is hard to keep the doubts from creeping in.

title: PEKING'S WOMEN IN FASHIONS, MEN IN UNDERSHIRTS
description: Daytime kissing in the parks has increased this summer. So have nighttime chess and card games under the street lights. With the usual bounty of watermelons and shortage of beer, people are scrutinizing the former and scrambling after the latter.

title: RAW FISH: HOW SAFE IS IT?
description: Recent warnings on the dangers of eating raw saltwater and freshwater fish because of parasites that can be transmitted to humans come at a time when an increasing number of Americans are developing tastes for uncooked fish specialties such as Japanese sushi and sashimi, South American ceviche, Dutch green herring, the lightly cured Scandinavian salmon called gravlax, and even for cooked fish that is very much underdone by traditional standards.

title: BEATING THE KILLER
description: WHILE his boss was suing the pants off the National League and his padded paladins were shaping up for a physical culture course in Santa Rosa, Calif., Tom Flores, coach of the champions of professional football, was in Oakland recently taking bows for whipping an opponent deadlier than the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Post Reportedly Considers Afternoon Edition in Capital
description: The Washington Post is considering publishing an afternoon newspaper if the Washington Star closes Aug. 7, according to a person who is in a position to know the newspaper's plans.

title: Market Place; Orange Co.  And Its Assets
description: WHEN fish and chips proved less successful than the Orange Company had hoped, the Lake Hamilton, Fla., enterprise focused its attention on citrus groves.

title: Verdict in Killings Of 2 on East Side
description: A 27-year-old Queens man was convicted of second-degree murder in the slayings last winter of Richard Kallman, a prominent art and antiques dealer, and Mr. Kallman's business associate.

title: Soviet Buys More U.S. Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 200,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery in 1981-82, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Record Syndication Of $28 Million Reported
description: A record $28 million syndication of the English champion Storm Bird has been arranged by Dr. William W. Lockridge, a Lexington veterinarian, The Lexington Leader reported today.

title: Officer Is Accused In Test of Integrity
description: A New York City police officer was arrested yesterday on charges of having stolen $1,100 from a detective posing as a helpless invalid who had just been robbed in his Greenwich Village apartment.

title: Boston Pops Conductor Ponders Return
description: As the Boston Pops Orchestra ended its season last night at Tanglewood in the Berkshires, the ''very hot question,'' as one official put it, was: Will John Williams return for a third year as director of the Pops?

title: COST OF UPSTATE ATOM PLANT PUT AT $5.6 BILLION BY FOES
description: A nuclear power plant under construction in upstate New York could ultimately cost $5.6 billion, a state consumer official said today. When the plant, Nine Mile Point 2, was begun in 1974, the cost of the project was estimated at $381.7 million.

title: TRUCE OR PEACE?
description: The present cease-fire in Lebanon is regarded here as little more than a temporary truce. It has provided a pause for reflection, but few officials pretend it will last unless it is followed by a major reappraisal and compromise of the political problem between the Mediterranean and the Indian Ocean.

title: Times Mirror Earnings Rise
description: The Times Mirror Company, owner of The Los Angeles Times and The Denver Post newspapers, said today that its second-quarter earnings rose to $38.5 million, or $1.13 a share, on revenues of $539.5 million.

title: AMAX SLIDES 32.6.%
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the country's largest steel producer, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1981 rose by 50.3 percent, while sales climbed 22.6 percent.

title: U.S. PUSHES SOVIET GAS ALTERNATIVE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States was continuing to urge its European allies to consider alternative energy sources, including American coal, before financing a 3,500-mile pipeline that would transport Siberian natural gas to Western Europe.

title: New Pact for Williams
description: The Philadelphia 76ers signed General Manager Pat Williams to a long-term contract today. The re-signing of Williams, who has been the 76ers' general manager since 1974, ended speculation that he might seek a new job after the team was purchased by Harold Katz from F. Eugene Dixon Jr.

title: ARIAS, 16, BEATS NASTASE ON TIE-BREAKER
description: Jimmy Arias, at 16 years old the youngest male tennis player to turn professional, defeated the veteran Ilie Nastase today in the first round of the $125,000 Mutual Benefit Life Open at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Index; International
description: In Peking, the women try fash- ions and the men, undershirts A2 East-West talks adjourn in disa- greement A3 Mrs. Thatcher blames I.R.A. for deaths of hunger strikers A3 Japanese military aides agree with U.S. on need for buildup A4 U.S. study says some allies aren't doing enough on defense A4 Around the World A5 Sadat chides U.S. for ''passivity'' toward Soviet in Mideast A6 For some Britons, a glittering oc- casion is spoiled by hard times A9 Marseilles killings give rise to political scandal in France A10 General Around the Nation A10 California agrees to prosecute strangler suspect A12 Berrigans get 3 to 10 years for nu- clear protest A12 Northerners in Dallas get lesson in determination A12 California postpones decision on saving condors A12 Ailing 71-year-old accused as wartime Nazi A13 A new survey finds anti-Semitism has declined in the U.S. A13 New Mexico groups protest plan to bury nuclear waste A14 House at full strength as Philadel- phia representative is sworn in A15 Study of black law firms stirs race dispute A20 The Unification Church will move its boats from Tarrytown B1 The cost of an upstate atomic power plant could be $5.6 billion B1 New York City begins crackdown on unlicensed outdoor cafes B1 26 arrested in multimillion-dollar garment center thefts B3 The Biltmore is to be recon- structed into office building B3 The Living Section Food Football food: Not just steak C1

title: SOUTHWESTERN FARE: A COOK WHO LIKES TO DO IT HIS WAY
description: WHEN John Sommers moved from Michigan to Albuquerque with his wife, Janet, in 1970 he felt he'd found the place where he would spend the rest of his life. The landscape - stretches of desert and mountain ranges struck by the brilliant southwestern light - appealed to the artist in him. The local cuisine - an unusual variety wedded to the green chili of Mexico - attracted the cook in him.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aloe Creme Laboratories Inc. and Scherer Laboratories Inc., of Dallas, Tex., said that Aloe shareholders approved a merger with Scherer pursuant to a stock exchange.

title: SADAT CHIDES U.S. FOR 'PASSIVITY' TOWARD SOVIET
description: President Anwar el-Sadat said last night that he was disturbed by the ''passivity'' of the United States towards Soviet moves in the Middle East and he again offered to provide Egyptian military facilities to the United States if they were needed.

title: Jackson Pessimistic
description: Reggie Jackson said today, ''If we're not on the field by the first week in August, there really isn't much hope for resuming the season.''

title: WINE TALK
description: AT its best, it is a big, intensely flavored red wine, one of the finest that Italy produces. It is called Barolo, and it comes from the Piedmont district in the northern part of the country, an area responsible for many of Italy's most renowned red wines.

title: Atico's New President Sees Growth in Oranges
description: Richard A. Krause, 53, has been named president of the Atico Financial Corporation, which has units in the mortgage banking, insurance and other industries. He succeeds Nathaniel B. Elkins, a 67-year-old lawyer and former president of the Federal Title and Insurance Company, who was appointed chairman and chief executive officer of the Miami-based company.

title: WEINBERGER IS PLANNING TIGHTER MILITARY CONTRACTS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he intended to tighten up on defense contracts by levying penalties for excessive costs and delays as part of an effort to stay within the Administration's plan for 7 percent annual growth in military spending.

title: Holzman Gets 2-Year Pact
description: Red Holzman ended speculation that he would step down as the Knicks' coach after next season when he signed a new two-year contract yesterday. The new pact covers the forthcoming season and 1982-83.

title: TV: TEXAN VISITS PEKING TO TEACH BALLET SKILLS
description: IN ''Pas de deux - a Dance of Two Countries: China and America,'' Ben Stevenson, artistic director of the Houston Ballet, visits China to teach Western dance techniques to students of the Peking Dance Academy. The film had been scheduled on WNET-TV last week, but at the last minute the station decided to repeat a program about baseball, evidently on the theory that the great American pastime was a hotter item than ballet. In any case, the dance film can be seen tonight at 10 o'clock on WLIW-TV.

title: BANNING OF PLUCKNETT CALLED UNFAIR BY PEERS
description: John Powell and Al Oerter, two of the most renowned discus throwers in the world, said they believe that Ben Plucknett was made a scapegoat when the International Amateur Athletic Federation recently barred him for life.

title: SECRET GROUP LINKED TO KILLING OF FRENCH DETECTIVE
description: The head of a secretive, right-wing counterterrorist group in France has been charged with complicity in the murder of a Marseilles detective.

title: MRS. THATCHER SAYS I.R.A. LEADERS ARE TO BLAME FOR DEATHS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, in a letter to four prominent American politicians, said that the responsibility for further deaths among Irish Republican Army hunger strikers ''rests firmly on the shoulders of those who are ordering these young men to commit suicide.''

title: Q & A
description: Q. I read that there is a French custom, after the main course of a meal, according to which diners consume a small bird literally down to the beak, while covering their heads with a cloth napkin. What is this dish and what are its origins?

title: CONFEREES DECIDE ON $37 BILLION TAX CUT IN FEDERAL BUDGET
description: A huge House-Senate conference moved tonight toward completion of more than $37 billion in budget cuts after ratifying changes in hundreds of programs in an effort to curtail Federal spending.

title: Italians Jail 74, Free 19 As Terrorist Trial Ends
description: A five-month trial of 94 men and women accused of belonging to the Front Line left-wing terrorist organization ended today with 75 convictions and 19 acquittals.

title: JAPANESE MILITARY OFFICIALS AGREE WITH U.S. ON NEED FOR MORE ARMS
description: The United States is not alone in its campaign to persuade Japan to increase its defense spending. The Japanese military establishment is entirely on the American side.

title: BILL AMENDS TAX PRIVACY LAW
description: The Senate, in an amendment to taxpayer privacy statutes, has approved legislation encouraging the Internal Revenue Service to share information with other law-enforcement agencies investigating nontax crimes.

title: News Analysis
description: For all the nationally televised debating over the rival Reagan and Democratic tax bills, winning seems to have overtaken substance as the primary objective of both sides in tomorrow's showdown vote in the House of Representatives.

title: SKIPPER IS ACCUSED IN SAILOR'S DEATH
description: The commander of the U.S.S. Ranger was accused of dereliction of duty today and four of the aircraft carrier's petty officers were charged with manslaughter in connection with a sailor's death, the Navy said.

title: Green Beret to Form Anti-Terrorist Concern
description: The Green Beret officer who was the ground commander in the illfated mission to rescue the American hostages in Iran last year plans to retire from the Army and form a company to help corporations fight terrorism.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Solar King said it would receive about $1.16 million from its successfully completed warrant exchange offer.

title: PARTNER IN FOX DEAL IDENTIFIED
description: A Netherlands Antilles company headed by Marc Rich, an oil trader and financier, and two others was identified yesterday as the silent partner of Marvin Davis, the Denver oil millionaire, in his recent $722 million purchase of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TALES FROM 3 CULTURES

title: CASSETTES NOW HAVE MATERIAL NOT AVAILABLE ON DISKS
description: THE proliferation of Sony Walkmans and similar compact, inexpensive cassette-player-and-earphones systems is combining with drastic changes in the contents and marketing of prerecorded music cassettes to challenge the dominance of the phonograph record.

title: BY ROYAL COMMAND
description: In the spring of 1953 I received a message from His Grace, the Duke of Norfolk, Earl Marshal of England, etc., etc., etc., stating that he had been commanded by Her Majesty, Queen Elizabeth II, etc., etc., etc., to invite my attendance at her Coronation at the Abbey at Westminster.

title: People
description: * Alan Jacobs has joined Doyle Dane Bernbach-New York as a senior vice president.

title: TENTATIVE AIR CONTROL PACT IS REJECTED BY 95% OF UNION
description: More than 95 percent of the members of the air traffic controllers union have voted against a tentative contract reached with the Government last month, a final count showed today. The union said it wanted to reopen negotiations immediately.

title: Technology; MORE EFFICIENT LIGHT BULBS
description: THE techniques used for making integrated circuits can also be used to change the ability of materials to absorb and emit light. That might have applications far afield from semiconductors. But can the phone company use that approach to develop a more energy-efficient light bulb?

title: Providence's Mayor Adamant As Strikers Demand Meeting
description: A parade of striking municipal workers blocked downtown traffic today, chanting demands for a meeting with Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr., as city officials acted to cut off the workers' benefits.

title: Business People; TRIANGLE PACIFIC FILLS PRESIDENTIAL VACANCY
description: Floyd Sherman, 41, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of the Triangle Pacific Corporation, a leading producer of kitchen and bathroom cabinets and hardwood flooring. The post had been vacant since the resignation in February of Robert Meltzer, 37. Mr. Meltzer's father, Abraham, 64, continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: THE NEGLECTED QUESTION
description: Over the last two years a number of American doctors have worked to bring home to people what the human consequences of nuclear war would be. A single bomb on a medium-sized city, they have pointed out, would kill hundreds of thousands and leave as many cruelly injured, without hope of care from the few surviving doctors.

title: DISPUTE ON SOCIAL SECURITY THREATENS TO REOPEN BUDGET CONFERENCE
description: House Democratic leaders threatened today to reopen a House-Senate conference that had just reached agreement on $36 billion in budget cuts in a bid to restore the $122-a-month Social Security minimum benefit that was eliminated in the budgetcutting package.

title: 'OUR PRAYER FOR CHARLES AND DIANA'
description: Following are excerpts from the sermon given today by the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, the Archbishop of Canterbury, at the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer:

title: U.S. RULE ON CONOCO AWAITED
description: The three-way takeover battle for Conoco Inc. shifted to Washington yesterday as Wall Street professionals watched for signals from the Department of Justice about its antitrust attitude toward the multibillion-dollar bids for Conoco by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the Mobil Corporation.

title: HEALTH NOMINEE DEBATE EASES
description: The ideological and procedural standoff that has for months blocked Senate confirmation of President Reagan's choice for Surgeon General of the United States, Dr. C. Everett Koop, a prominent foe of abortion, has been ended.

title: OWNERS, PLAYERS AGREE TO RESUME TALKS TODAY
description: Baseball's 26 club owners met for two hours yesterday and argued their strategy in the strike that has shut down the major leagues for seven weeks. But they took no votes on issues raised by a group of dissident owners, indicated no change in their position, and said only that they would resume bargaining ''in earnest'' with the players today.

title: TAX SHELTER INDICTMENTS
description: Two businessmen and a lawyer were indicted today in connection with the $38 million collapse of Investors Economic Systems, once highly successful in promoting real estate tax shelters. A 24-count indictment charged I.E.S.'s chief executive officer, Peter Bonastia, 43 years old, of North Caldwell, N.J.; and its executive vice president, Thomas C. Gaffney, 42, of Westfield, N.J., with conspiracy to commit securities and mail fraud, 16 counts of mail fraud and 7 tax violations. Robert Petrallia, 36, a lawyer, of Maplewood, N.J., was charged with conspiracy and 16 counts of mail fraud for allegedly drafting fraudulent promotional material. Mr. Bonastia said he would plead not guilty; attempts to reach his co-defendants were unsuccessful.

title: The Region; LAW GIVES COURT CURB ON PARENTS
description: Governor Carey signed a bill today that will allow the Family Court to terminate the rights of parents whose children are in foster care if the court finds that the parents have severely or repeatedly abused their children.

title: SAN FRANCISCO TACKLING 'DEN OF THIEVES' PROJECT
description: A number of times this summer young men from a high-rise public housing slum building within sight of City Hall have robbed foreign tourists of cameras, watches and money.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGE

title: ETHICS UNIT TO MAKE DECISION ON WILLIAMS CASE BY AUG.24
description: The Senate Select Committee on Ethics intends to decide by Aug. 24 if it will recommend the censure or expulsion of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. for his activities during the Abscam investigation, its chairman said today.

title: STORAGE BIDS FOR MEMOREX, WHICH IS 'INTERESTED'
description: The Storage Technology Corporation said yesterday that it had proposed to acquire the Memorex Corporation, the financially beleaguered manufacturer of data storage equipment and audio tapes. Kenneth Rowe, a spokesman for Memorex, said that while the offer had not yet been received in writing, ''the general response we want to convey is that we're interested.''

title: WATER POLLUTION WORST IN 34 AREAS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has listed the 34 areas of the country with the most polluted streams and rivers, waters so contaminated by toxic chemicals that they may require cleaning, beyond a specific legal requirement, to protect human health.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JULY 30, 1981; The Tax Vote
description: The House of Representatives approved the Administration's tax reduction bill by 238 to 195 in a decisive victory for President Reagan. The Senate overwhelmingly approved a similar bill earlier in the day. The bills provide for a 25 percent cut in individual income taxes over three years and several business tax reductions. (Page A1.) Congressmen said the President lobbied heavily to win their votes. (D21.)

title: AIDES SAY TOLL MAY BE 4,000
description: At least 700 people were killed in an earthquake in southeastern Iran, the second in that region in seven weeks, and the final death toll could be between 3,000 and 4,000, Iranian officials said today.

title: NEW DRUG SAID TO AID SUCCESS OF LIVER TRANSPLANTS
description: The odds of surviving liver transplants improve dramatically, at least in the short run, when patients are given an experimental new drug, researchers report. The medicine may also lead to much better transplant results with other organs, they say.

title: THE DRESS: SILK TAFFETA WITH SEQUINS AND PEARLS
description: For her long walk up the aisle that transformed her into a princess, Lady Diana Spencer, in the most romantic storybook tradition, wore a sequin-and-pearl-incrusted dress with a 25-foot train.

title: Gunmen Fire on Israeli Bus
description: Two armed Palestinian terrorists ambushed a bus at a kibbutz outside Jerusalem tonight and wounded four passengers, including a pregnant woman, in the first guerrilla attack since last week's cease-fire along the Israel-Lebanon border.

title: The City; SUBWAY CAR AWARD TO CITY AFFIRMED
description: A $72 million award that New York City and the Transit Authority won as damages for defective subway equipment was affirmed by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: LITTLE PROGRESS SEEN ON RATES
description: President Reagan's chief economic adviser acknowledged today that the Administration had made little progress in reducing high interest rates, but he said he was still convinced the rates would eventually fall if the Administration maintains its tight-money course.

title: HARVESTER TO CUT ILLINOIS WORK FORCE
description: The International Harvester Company said today that 1,250 employees at its East Moline plant - nearly one-third of the operation's workforce - will be laid off next month because of a seasonal decline in business for the financially ailing farm machinery maker.

title: CALENDAR: ANTIQUES AND VARIOUS CRAFTS
description: Shaker Museum Festival of Antiques and Art, Old Chatham, N.Y.

title: BID TO RAISE DEBT CEILING
description: Beryl Sprinkel, Undersecretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today that the Administration would ask Congress to raise the statutory debt limit in early September.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I placed a hot dish on my walnut coffee table and now there is a white ring on the finish. I have tried removing it by rubbing with furniture polish and several other ''home remedies,'' but none seem to be working. Other than having the table professionally refinished, do you have any other suggestions for restoring the finish? - Mrs. S.R., Ellenville, N.Y.

title: The City; MOTHER RELEASED IN NEGLECT CASE
description: Patricia Powers, the mother accused of removing her daughter, Jody, from New York Hospital, where the child was being treated for an eye injury and bruises, was ordered released from the psychiatric ward of Elmhurst Hospital in Queens.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES
description: PPG Industries Inc. said it has purchased the rest of Duplate Canada Inc. from Pilkington Brothers Ltd. for undisclosed terms. Previously, British-Based Pilkington had owned about one-third of Duplate and PPG two-thirds, PPG noted. Duplate, based in toronto, is a glass fabricating company with plants at Hawkesbury and Oshawa, Ontario, and owns a 66 percent interest in Smith and Stone Inc., a maker of electric devices, 49 percent of Fiberglas Canada Inc., and several small investment companies.

title: Index; International
description: Mixed-race group in Namibia seeks political allies A2 Haig delays push in Congress to sell Awacs to Saudis A3 Washington sets terms for uranium shipments to India A4 Aide's visit to Latin America to demonstrate France's interest A6 In Ulster, tears of joy and flags of mourning A10 Excerpts from wedding sermon by Archbishop of Canterbury A11 For expatriates, wedding lights up celebration far from London A11 Government/Politics U.S. lists 34 most-polluted streams A13 Detroit appears to overcome union resistance to rescue plan A14 Two House members announce voting rights compromise A14 Associates of former C.I.A. official sought in oil theft. A17 Senate panel to rule on Williams by Aug. 24 B2 Brigham leaving tomorrow as city's Budget Director B3 DelGiudice leaving as Carey's director of policy management B4 Inflation rate dropped sharply in New York in first half of '81 B8 Central Labor Council expected to endorse Barbaro for Mayor B9 General Tourist-conscious San Francisco worried about muggers A12 Budget would let Amtrak operate 85% of its routes A16 Ivy League colleges investigate $1,000 loans to 12 athletes B1 The City B2 Hundreds flee fire in 34th St. subway station B9 Washington Post denies rumor it may start a tabloid B11 The Home Section Home Living in the cathedral close at St. John the Divine C1

title: DELGUIDICE LEAVING HIS POST AS POLICY DIRECTOR FOR CAREY
description: Governor Carey's director of policy management, Michael J. DelGiudice, will be leaving the Carey administration in the fall.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly defined the maximum term of a lease under the Senate Finance Committee tax bill. The bill says terms of a lease cannot exceed a period equal to the Asset Depreciation Range midpoint life of the property.

title: SWISS FINANCING SOUGHT
description: Eldorado Nuclear Ltd. of Canada plans to float a $17 million bond issue in the Swiss capital market, through a consortium led by the Union Bank of Switzerland, banking sources said today. The proceeds will be used to expand Eldorado's mining properties.

title: MULTI-DIMENSIONAL ALTERNATIVE TO AN AMERICAN PEACE ACADEMY
description: To the Editor:

title: Hers
description: ONE isn't the loneliest number. Read the latest report on the 1980 census about the shrinking American household and face the future in your mirror. We have only ourselves to look forward to: by 1990, everyone in the United States will be living alone.

title: Business People; PACER DRILLING RECRUITS A LEADER
description: Thomas H. Hilton, 41, has joined Pacer Drilling Inc., a new contract drilling company, as its president. The Dallas-based concern, a subsidiary of Petrotech Inc., was started with $9 million in financing and is scheduled to begin operations early next month.

title: ARCO TO RECEIVE $950 MILLION LOAN
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced it had completed a transaction under which it will receive a $950 million loan from a nonprofit corporation set up by the Colorado School of Mines. The oil company said it received $400 million immediately, with the balance payable through January 1983.

title: RECORDS FALL AT SPA OPENING
description: Despite gray skies, a chilly drizzle and a track reduced to slop by thunderstorms yesterday, a record opening-day crowd of 24,455 turned out today to begin the 114th thoroughbred racing season at Saratoga Race Track.

title: BID TO DELAY A.T.&T. TRIAL DENIED
description: Leading officials from the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked a Federal judge today to recess an historic antitrust suit for 11 months, but the motion was promptly denied.

title: 1981 FORECAST FOR BUILDING CONTRACTS CUT
description: Reflecting the impact of high interest rates and monetary restraint on the building industry, the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company has cut in half its 1981 forecast for growth of construction contracting in the United States.

title: STEEL IMPORTS UP FOR HALF
description: Steel imports into the United States dipped slightly between May and June, but rose sharply in the first six months from the first half of 1980, an industry trade group reported today.

title: REAGAN'S 3-YEAR, 25% CUT IN TAX RATE VOTED BY WIDE MARGINS IN THE HOUSE AND SENATE
description: In a decisive victory for President Reagan, the House of Representatives today approved the Administration's tax cut bill.

title: TRIAL LAWYERS SEE GREATER ROLE IN PRODUCT SAFETY
description: Americans must depend on lawsuits, judges and juries, not government regulators, to protect them from hazardous products and chemicals, according to the trial lawyers who make their living bringing the lawsuits.

title: LABOR COUNCIL EXPECTED TO ENDORSE BARBARO
description: The New York City Central Labor Council is expected to announce formally today its endorsement of Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro, Mayor Koch's major Democratic opponent in the Sept. 10 primary.

title: Libya Opens New Office For Its Students in U.S.
description: The State Department said today that Libya had opened a new office to deal with Libyan student affairs in this country, but had been told that the new office must not perform any diplomatic functions.

title: TV: WEDDING COVERAGE DONE IN A REGAL MANNER
description: AFTER all was said and done -and a whale of a lot was said and done by American television - it was lovely. The royal wedding of Prince Charles to Lady Diana Spencer was one of those thoroughly efficient spectaculars for which the British are justifiably noted. Just about everything went off on cue, and everybody, including the massive street crowds, played their parts to perfection. One correspondent, ABC's Peter Jennings, aptly recalled Winston Churchill's description of a similarly grand occasion involving Queen Elizabeth II: ''A flash of color on the hard road we have to travel.''

title: SONG: DENNIS BROWN MIXES POP AND REGGAE
description: ALTHOUGH Dennis Brown, the Jamaican reggae singer who appeared at the Ritz on Sunday, has released 12 albums in his native country, it was only recently that he made his debut on a major American label. His album ''Foul Play'' is a smooth amalgam of American soul and Jamaican Reggae.

title: MOBIL OIL CANADA FINDS MORE OIL
description: Mobil Oil Canada Ltd. said it has discovered more oil at its Hebron well off the coast of Newfoundland, raising hopes of a large discovery.

title: ISRAELIS CLAIM SYRIAN MIG-25 IN CLASH
description: An air battle erupted over Lebanon today as Syrian jets scrambled to intercept Israeli reconnaissance planes. A Syrian MIG-25 was shot down, the Israeli military command reported.

title: IN ULSTER, JOY AND SORROW SIDE BY SIDE
description: Mary Ann Hammond, a 71-yearold Protestant, burst into tears as she watched on television as Prince Charles stepped down the aisle of St. Paul's Cathedral. ''Great day for the Ulster people,'' she said.

title: COSMOS CLINCH 4TH DIVISION TITLE IN ROW
description: The Cosmos clinched their fourth consecutive Eastern Division title in the North American Soccer League tonight with a 2-0 victory over the Portland Timbers at Giants Stadium.

title: THE PRESIDENT ATTAINS MASTERY AT THE CAPITOL
description: In 190 days President Reagan has not only wrought a dramatic conservative shift in the nation's economic policies and the role of the Federal Government in American life but has also swept to a political mastery of Congress not seen since Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: RISE IN RATE OF INFLATION SLOWING FOR NEW YORK METROPOLITAN AREA
description: Inflationary pressures eased substantially in the 18 counties of the greater New York-northeastern New Jersey area in the first half of 1981, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. But the job market was sluggish, with employment increases smaller than in recent years and unemployment somewhat higher than a year earlier.

title: CARLOS DALMAU, PSYCHIATRIST AND AN EX-COLLEGE DOCTOR
description: Dr. Carlos Dalmau, a practicing psychiatrist in New York City for 30 years, died Friday at his country home in Glen Gardner, N.J. Dr. Dalmau, who also was a resident of Manhattan, was 60 years old.

title: PROUD BRITISH 'HURRAH!' RESOUNDS IN LAGOS, TOO
description: The sky was low and dark and heavy with rain that came and left the Union Jack limp on the flagpole against a backdrop of palms. The awning that spread across the lawn from the veranda, like a marquee, got soggy, too, but not the spirit of Britons far from home.

title: Notes of Music; CULTIVATING YOUNG TALENT, 2 APPROACHES
description: THE cultivation of promising artists has always been more of a problem than cultivation of scholars; there are no generally accepted artistic standards. The Educational Testing Service, in Princeton, N.J., for example, has practically invented standardized testing of academic promise - giving high-school students, college students, law students, teachers and foreign students a series of alphabetically entitled exams such as the PSAT/ NMSQT, the SAT, the LSAT, the GRE, the GMAT, the NTE, the CLEP and the TOEFL. But it is only now entering the second full year of another sort of program, begun by the former president of the Educational Testing Service, William W. Turnbull. That program is the Arts Recognition and Talent Search - ARTS.

title: Robert Moses, in Time and Place
description: Robert Moses believed a government leader should satisfy people by his works, not assuage them by his words. He used his tongue to fight indolence and resistance to change, or simply people who got in his way. But he could also turn the weapon to a plowshare in preparing the ground for great projects, and with the innocent he was courtly.

title: MCI DEFENSE FOR MERGERS
description: Shareholders of the MCI Communications Corporation, after learning that the long-distance phone company set new records for revenue and income last year, today approved amendments to the corporate charter designed to stiffen the company's defenses against unfriendly takeovers.

title: Earnings; DART AND KRAFT CLIMBS; BANGOR AND PUNTA DOUBLES
description: Dart and Kraft Inc., a diversified food, chemicals and consumer products company, said yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1981 rose 15.5 percent, while sales advanced 16 percent.

title: RECITAL: ALICIA DE LARROCHA
description: ALICIA DE LARROCHA'S Mostly Mozart recital at Avery Fisher Hall Tuesday night showed how a thoughtful musician can transform relatively conventional repertory selections into an illuminating and entertaining program.

title: STARTING OVER IN A ONE-ROOM APARTMENT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leslie Aldridge Westoff is the author of several books, most recently ''Breaking Out of the Middle-Age Trap.'' By LESLIE ALDRIDGE WESTOFF

title: HE MIXES REGAL DIGNITY AND HUMOR
description: When Prince Charles was born on Nov. 14, 1948, jubilant crowds pressed close around the gates of Buckingham Palace all night long, singing ''For He's a Jolly Good Fellow,'' and the fountains in Trafalgar Square ran blue for the birth of a boy.

title: CONTINENTAL AIR POSTS A LOSS
description: Continental Airlines, locked in a battle to stop a takeover bid by Texas International Airlines, said today it posted a loss in the second quarter of $9 million, compared with a loss of $6.4 million in the similar 1980 period.

title: Indian Guilty of Rape-Murder Is Flogged in Arab Emirates
description: KHAIMA, United Arab Emirates, July 29 (Reuters) - Abdul Aziz Mohammed Bakr, an Indian sentenced by a religious court to flogging and death for the rape and murder of two little girls, received 70 lashes at a prison today.

title: 3 Tremors in Peru Cause Alarm but No Injuries
description: Three earth tremors shook different parts of Peru today, causing alarm but no damage or casualties, the National Geophysical Institute reported.

title: AMID SPLENDOR, CHARLES WEDS DIANA
description: In a blaze of martial and spiritual pageantry on a glorious summer morning, the Prince of Wales took as his wife today a shy and charming member of one of the kingdom's greatest families.

title: Court Backs Teen-Ager On Abortion Decision
description: The Massachusetts Appeals Court overruled a lower court's order that a 14-year-old must consult a parent before having an abortion, it was disclosed today.

title: JETS SINGING PRAISES OF ROOKIE MCNEIL
description: He celebrated a week with the Jets' veterans today, and Freeman McNeil continued to look good. A No. 1 draft choice - especially the running back chosen third in the entire draft - is supposed to stand out. But can he sing, too? His voice, he says, helped him through the week; in an unusual development the other night, the team revived its rookie show.Once it had been a staple of training camps: rookies got up on a stage, or on the mess hall table, and sang the old college fight song or whatever else came into their heads. It embarrassed some, though, and in the quickened pace of recent years it disappeared.

title: SAVIN ENDS OLIVETTI ACCORD
description: The Savin Corporation and the Olivetti Group, two companies that have had problems in gaining solid footholds in America's office automation business, said they have terminated a May 19 agreement in principle to combine their efforts in that market.

title: AFGHANS BATTLE ON
description: The Afghan people are more than holding their own in their struggle to regain freedom and national independence. They should not be abandoned by the West, which might be tempted to accept Kremlin terms for a cosmetic withdrawal of the Soviet troops in the hope of restoring the atmosphere of detente that was destroyed by the invasion.

title: Resignation of Envoy Surprises Staff in Jidda
description: United States Embassy officials in Saudi Arabia expressed surprise today over the resignation of Ambassador Robert G. Neumann, but there was no immediate official Saudi reaction, diplomats in Jidda said.

title: Market Place; A NEW TWIST: PUT BONDS
description: WALL STREET'S municipal bond community has developed a long-term bond that permits the holder to cash in years early at face value - a major plus in times of generally lower markets.

title: Advertising; FIAT MOTORS SHIFTS TO HANK FORSSBERG
description: Fiat Motors of North America, whose Fiat car unit sales were down 15.9 percent, to 18,425 cars, in the first half of the year, is planning a major change in direction. And as part of it, the auto producer has moved its advertising account from Benton & Bowles, where it has been since it left Carl Ally Inc., three years ago, and assigned it to Hank Forssberg, Inc., of Hackensack, N.J. Leading National Advertisers estimates that Fiat spent $12 million on advertising last year.

title: PLAN FOR DETROIT MAKING PROGRESS
description: Tiger Stadium has been empty since mid-June, but that does not mean there has not been a lot of hard ball played here this summer.

title: AIRLINES STATE MERGER ISSUES
description: Continental Air Lines said today its acquisition by Texas International Airlines would create a weak, debt-ridden carrier and would reduce air service, especially in the South Pacific areas now serviced by Continental.

title: DENG ALLY GETS MILITARY POST
description: Yang Shangkun, a political ally of Deng Xiaoping, China's principal leader, has been appointed secretary general of the Communist Party's military affairs commission, the Peking radio disclosed today. The commission controls China's armed forces, nearly four million strong. Mr. Yang succeeds Geng Biao, who was made Defense Minister earlier this year.

title: SHE CHARMS WITH AN EASY GRACE
description: When Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer posed for their engagement photograph on the steps of Buckingham Palace, she stood one step lower to make the Prince appear taller.

title: 2 PARK ADMINISTRATORS NAMED IN DECENTRALIZATION EXPERIMENT
description: Last winter, Diana Chapin, a professor and medievalist by training with a Ph.D. in Middle English from Cornell University, was named parks administrator for Queens. At the same time, Joseph M. Curran, who started his career 25 years ago as an assistant gardener in Tompkins Square Park, was named administrator for Staten Island.

title: EX-PLAYER AND 4 ARE INDICTED
description: A former Boston College basketball player and four other men were charged yesterday with conspiring to fix six basketball games during the 1978-79 season by shaving points.

title: Notes on People; DISPUTE WITH CBS-TV
description: What seemed clear yesterday was that the British actress Lynn Redgrave will be replaced on the CBS-TV weekly series ''House Calls.'' It was a matter of dispute as to whether she was dismissed from or walked out of the series.

title: KEY CURRENCY LEADER
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADIAN EXPORT CREDIT
description: The Canadian Export Development Corporation, a federal agency, has signed lines of credit totaling $135 million with four Yugoslav banks to finance Yugoslav purchases of Canadian goods, the trade ministry said today.

title: Boston Subway Fare Rises
description: The directors of the Boston area transit system's yesterday approved an increase in the basic subway fare, to 75 cents from 50 cents, beginning Saturday. The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority directors also voted to increase bus fares to 50 cents from 25 cents if the authority's advisory board of local officials accepts that plan.

title: Letter: On New Jersey's Treasure Preserving and Developing the Pinelands
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTECTING THE INDIVIDUAL IS THE HIGHEST LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: CLERC AND VILAS WIN OPENING VOLVO MATCHES
description: Jose Luis Clerc and Guillermo Vilas of Argentina scored opening-round victories today at the Volvo international tennis tournament.

title: Notes on People; RAY HEATHERTON TURNS TO POLITICS
description: For years he has been a tireless toastmaster at Republican dinners and an effective party fund-raiser, and now, at the age of 71, Ray Heatherton has decided to enter elective politics -as a Democrat.

title: JERSEY COURT BACKS GOVERNOR'S POCKET VETO POWERS
description: The State Supreme Court today narrowly upheld the New Jersey Governor's broad powers to kill legislation passed in the State Senate and Assembly.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Buildex Inc. is offering 17,000 units in Grant Industries Inc., each consisting of 100 common shares and 100 warrants to purchase common stock, at an initial price of $1,250 per unit, or a total price of $21.25 million, to be sold through a Prescott Ball & Turbin group.

title: Reagans 3-Year, 25% Cut in Tax Rate Voted by Wide Margins in the House and Senate
description: In a decisive victory for President Reagan, the House of Representatives today approved the Administration's tax cut bill.

title: MIXED-RACE NAMIBIAN GROUP SEEKS POLITICAL ALLIES
description: West Africa -They speak the Afrikaans language and, when they trekked into the arid vastness of South-West Africa in the 19th century to found their own republic, they were like numerous groups of seminomadic Afrikaners trying to win their own space in Africa.

title: Water to Donate, Not to Waste
description: Rain should gather in reservoirs, but New York's collects on subway tracks instead. The heavy storm that flooded the city's transit system Monday night dropped a stingy three-tenths of an inch on the Delaware and Catskill watersheds.

title: MARYLAND UNIVERSITY WINS EFFORT TO DENY A CHAIR TO A MARXIST
description: The president of the University of Maryland acted ''honestly and conscientiously'' when he decided not to appoint a Marxist scholar to a departmental chairmanship, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: SHARP PROFIT DROP AND SHAKE-UP JOLTS BRITAIN'S IMPERIAL
description: For decades, Britain's Imperial Group had the reputation of being a sound investment stock for widows, orphans and, more recently, pension funds. Although not a spectacular profit maker, Imps, as the tobacco and food conglomerate is known, could be counted on for a large dividend backed up by Imperial's majority share in the highly profitable British cigarette market.

title: ANGER OVER FOOD SPREADS IN POLAND
description: Wildcat strikes broke out here today to protest shortages of food and a 20 percent cut in the meat ration. Workers in this city, Poland's second largest, conducted their third protest march this week. In the Baltic port of Gdansk, members of the Solidarity union leadership met to discuss the spreading protests. ''I can't believe I'm in Poland,'' a Lodz woman said as she watched a procession of 53 trucks and heavy-duty vehicles lumber down Piotrkowska Street, blasting their horns and paralyzing the city center for three hours.

title: LEADING INDICATORS DROP 1.3%
description: An important gauge of future economic strength fell sharply in June for the second month in a row, but private and Government economists differed on whether the decline meant that a recession was on the way.

title: SUSPECT IS SLAIN IN CHASE
description: A food caterer shot and killed one of two men said to have been involved in a purse-snatching after chasing the suspects in his truck and on foot.
