The police quoted Robert Alexander Collins, 29 years old, as saying he had said he shot Ricky Leeburn Carney ''in self-defense'' after Mr. Carney fired a revolver at him. The case is to be referred to a grand jury for review.

title: Notes on People; BRINGING JAMES BRADY SOME HOMETOWN CHEER
description: The 22 schoolchildren who stood under a George Washington University Hospital window in Washington yesterday all wore blue T-shirts that said, ''Centralia, Ill. - Home of Jim Brady.''

title: USE OF GROUND BONE IS SUBJECT OF DEBATE
description: A consumer group said today that it would fight a proposal being considered by the Department of Agriculture to ease Federal regulations on the use of finely ground bone in hot dogs, salami and some other meat products.

title: MARINDUQUE LOAN
description: The Marinduque Mining and Industrial Corporation of the Philippines signed a $127.2 million short-term loan to finance oil imports with a group of international banks, Chemical Bank said as agent bank. The facility is guaranteed by the Development Bank of the Philippines and carries an interest rate of 7/8 percent over the Singapore Interbank offered rate.

title: TIRE CONCERNS TO LIFT PRICES
description: The nation's top tire makers announced yesterday that prices for replacement passenger and truck tires would rise between 3.5 percent and 5 percent in early August.

title: Home Beat; FOR ARTISTS WHO SHOP
description: IN 1964, Blair Brown and Lionel Spiro started a ''part-time'' business with $900. Last year they sold $21.6 million worth of art supplies and equipment.

title: TB Patient Leaves Hospital to Live Alone
description: Louis Semerano, a tuberculosis patient who was prevented from returning home by a court order two months ago because of fears that he was a menace to public health, has been given permission to leave a hospital and live by himself.

title: LIVING IN THE CATHEDRAL CLOSE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- David Lowe is a freelance writer and the author of ''Lost Chicago'' and ''Chicago Interiors.'' By DAVID LOWE

title: Country Gardener; WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH
description: Lawns Mid-August to early September is the key period for attention to lawns, new or old. Control disease and insect problems before any feeding or reseeding. Fungus diseases are rampant, particularly fusarium and pythium blights, rusts, leaf spots and anthracnose. Control with lawn fungicide applications according to label directions. Most chemicals must be watered immediately after application; check directions to be sure. Control lawn grubs, sod webworms and chinch bugs. Avoid use of weed control herbicides in hot, humid weather. For heavy thatch buildup, use mechanical dethatcher or slicing machine to aerate weakened turf, then apply fertilizer. Overseed thinned-out lawns with quality, not bargain, lawn seed. Seed or sod new lawns.

title: ALBERT E. DIEM
description: Albert E. Diem, vice president emeritus and former treasurer of the University of Bridgeport, died Monday at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital.

title: Advertising; People
description: * William B. Palmer has been elected a senior vice president, a director and creative director of Doremus & Company.

title: Sports of the Times; MATERNAL TOUCH IN TABLE TENNIS
description: OF the 2,600 amateur athletes at the National Sports Festival in Syracuse, only one carried significant extra weight around her waist. Being six and a half months pregnant did not stop Thomasina Burke from finishing near the middle of 16 female contestants. She was pleased to be scoring points against higher-ranked players, despite the equivalent of a bowling ball at the point where table tennis players need to bend and lunge.

title: No Headline
description: Angry motorists besiege a gasoline station in Beirut, Lebanon, where fuel is rationed because of recent Israeli raids. Man at center waves a pistol in the air. The shortage of fuel has led to at least five deaths at gasoline stations.

title: EXPERTS CITE WAYS THAT TV AFFECTS CHILDREN
description: Parents should be concerned about what their children watch on television and how much time they spend watching it, say psychologists and communications specialists.

title: RADICALLY NEW COURSE FOR U.S. FISCAL POLICY
description: Ronald Reagan's radical change in United States fiscal policy, aimed at cutting back the role of the Federal Government in the United States economy, has come to pass.

title: 6 More Yugoslavs Sentenced For Ethnic Rioting in Kosovo
description: Six more people in the southern region of Kosovo were sentenced today to prison for counterrevolutionary activity involving ethnic Albanian riots, officials said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 2 ACCUSERS OF EX-C.I.A. OFFICIAL HUNTED IN THEFT OF $3 MILLION
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is trying to find Samuel F. and Thomas McNell, brothers whose allegations led to the resignation of Max C. Hugel from a top post in the Central Intelligence Agency, on the suspicion that they improperly seized assets from the company one of them headed when they disappeared.

title: BANI-SADR SAYS HE'LL STAY IN PARIS UNTIL IRAN TAKES DEMOCRATIC PATH
description: The deposed President of Iran, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, was granted political asylum in France today after a dramatic night flight from Teheran in a hijacked Iranian plane.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL SOARS BY 80%
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the country's second-largest steel maker after the United States Steel Corporation, reported yesterday that higher steel product shipments helped net income in the second quarter of 1981 to soar 80 percent, as sales expanded 18.8 percent.

title: New Appeals Court Asked
description: Senator Howell Heflin, Democrat of Alabamna, said today that he would introduce legislation calling for a national court of appeals. Mr. Heflin said in a statement that such a would relieve the Supreme Court of some of its burdens and increase the national appellate capacity. He is a former Chief Justice of the Alabama Supreme Court.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JULY 30, 1981 International The wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer was held in a blaze of martial and spiritual pageantry. The 2,500 guests in St. Paul's Cathedral, the hundreds of thousands who watched along the processional route and the 700 million televison viewers around the world witnessed one of the great days in the history of the House of Windsor amid the sort of splendor that the world has all but forgotten. (Page A1, Columns 1-3.) Rousing choruses of ''Rule Britannia'' were sung by joyful Britons who saluted their troubled old land with tears, triumphant greetings and dancing in the streets in a sea of small Union Jacks. ''It's a great day to be British,'' remarked a retired factory worker, his voice breaking as the Prince and Princess of Wales waved to the joyous crowd from a balcony of Buckingham Palace. (A10:1-2.)

title: John Paul Said to Make Progress in Recovery
description: Pope John Paul II is making good progress in his recovery from a viral infection that developed after the attempt on his life last May and has regained a third of the weight lost after the attack, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Navy to Discharge Sailor Cleared in Lesbian Case
description: The Navy said today that it would discharge a sailor despite her acquittal by a three-member board that investigated allegations that she had had a lesbian affair with another sailor.

title: JURY IN RAIDERS TRIAL TO BEGIN DELIBERATIONS
description: The 55-day trial of the antitrust suit brought by the Oakland Raiders and Los Angeles Coliseum Commission against the National Football League and the city of Oakland went to a jury today, with the team's lawyers saying economic self-interest was the major issue before the panel.

title: MULTI-DIMENSIONAL ALTERNATIVE TO AN AMERICAN PEACE ACADEMY
description: To the Editor:

title: TO 'JERSEYIZE'
description: A new verb, ''to New Jerseyize,'' keeps surfacing in editorials and letters-to-the-editor in North Carolina newspapers, most often in a sentence like: ''Let's keep North Carolina from being New Jerseyized.'' This verb means ''to pollute,'' yet that customary word is not strong enough to convey the editorial writers' dread of oil refineries, poisonous chemical wastes, crippled cities like Newark, traffic jams, broken English, Atlantic City-style gambling, the Mafia.

title: AMTRAK SEES LIGHT IN ITS BUDGET LINE
description: As if emerging from a long tunnel, Amtrak can suddenly see sunnier prospects after an agreement by House and Senate conferees to authorize a subsidy of $735 million for the system in 1982 and $788 million in 1983.

title: AN OCEAN OF UNION JACKS AND CHANTING THRONGS ALONG PROCESSION ROUTE
description: Hundreds of thousands of joyful Britons, taking a welcome break from the strains of a difficult summer, lined the route of the royal wedding procession today to cheer their Prince and his bride.

title: Executive Changes
description: * Bank of New York has elected Richard P. Kiernan, Bruce E. Smith, George W. Van Der Ploeg and Mark Wolf vice presidents.

title: Home Improvement; ELECTRIC LAMPS TO KILL INSECTS IN YOUR YARD
description: THE introduction of improved models of electric insect-killing lanterns - coupled with the current awareness of the dangers of indiscriminate use of insecticide sprays - has caused a great many homeowners to consider buying electrified bug-zappers.

title: STOCKTON, AMID HARD TIMES, TRIES TO REGAIN FORM
description: When Dick Stockton was a child, crisscrossing the country on his way to a record 20 national junior tennis titles, he always carried an oversize suitcase so there would be room for a trophy.

title: City Gardener; WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH
description: Summer Flowers Flowering annuals that form side branches, such as petunias, verbena or ageratum, may now be overgrown and straggly. They will bloom again if you cut them back in August and feed with a water-soluble fertilizer high in phosphorous, the middle number on the package. Pest-infested plants can be sprayed with an insecticide on a cool day if a soapy water spray doesn't bring control. Plants not worth saving can be replaced with chrysanthemums or cool-weather vegetable crops. Bring gardening problems to the free plant clinic of the Cooperative Extension of Cornell University, held Mondays from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. in the south yard of Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

title: MAJOR PROVISIONS OF TWO BILLS COVER INDIVIDUALS, BUSINESSES
description: President Reagan's tax reduction bill, approved by the House of Representatives today over a version offered by the Democratic leadership, bears many similarities to that approved by the Senate.

title: SMALL-COLLEGE BACK IMPRESSES PERKINS
description: If Louis Jackson stays healthy, he has a good chance to make the Giants. Coach Ray Perkins said that today. Jackson knows it. But Jackson, a rookie running back from Cal Poly-San Luis Obispo, also knows that his ailing right hamstring muscle must mend soon or his chances will be endangered.

title: Going Out Guide
description: JAPAN'S 'LOVABLE TRAMP'

title: JAPANESE ARTIST WINNING BATTLE FOR HIS OWN STYLE
description: TOKYO MODERN Japanese painting in the Western style here is dominated by artists who still imitate the French Impressionists and Post-Impressionists of a century ago. Their work is taken seriously - the prices can be huge - and there's a great amateur tradition as well. On a pleasant weekend, people flood in with their easels to paint picturesque corners of the Imperial Palace, its moats and pines and stones.

title: Business People; KROEHLER REALIGNS TOP MANAGEMENT
description: A change in the management of the Kroehler Manufacturing Company has been announced, following the acquisition of the Kroehler family's 37 percent interest in the corporation by an investment group led by Peter B. Harvey and Kenneth L. Kwiatt. Kroehler, established in 1893, is one of the largest manufacturers of upholstered furniture.

title: PROVISOS ON URANIUM FOR INDIA
description: Washington has indicated that it will resume shipments of enriched uranium to India if New Delhi promises not to detonate a nuclear device or use spent fuel to make weapons, an Indian official said today.

title: POLISH MAHOGANY LIKE A PROFESSIONAL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: CITIES SERVICE FIGHTS MERGER
description: The Cities Service Company, the nation's 20th-largest oil concern, is arranging a $4 billion line of credit and will vigorously resist any merger attempts, Charles J. Waidelich, company president, said yesterday.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE FINDS CASEY FIT FOR C.I.A. JOB BUT PURSUES INQUIRY
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence announced today that it had found no basis for concluding that William J. Casey was unfit to serve as the Director of Central Intelligence. The judgment was unanimous.

title: SAINT LAURENT: SHORTER SKIRTS, BUBBLE SHAPES
description: The show, Yves Saint Laurent said after his fall couture opening - which coincided with the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer across the Channel - had a certain balance, he thought.

title: IVY LEAGUE CHECKING $1,000 LOANS TO 12 ATHLETES
description: Twelve athletes at three Ivy League colleges received loans of more than $1,000 apiece in possible violation of intercollegiate athletic rules, the Council of Ivy Group Presidents said yesterday.

title: REQUIEM FOR A LITTLE HOUSE ON 96TH STREET
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCORD REPORTED ON EXTENDING VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: Two key members of the House Judiciary Committee said today that they had reached tentative agreement on a compromise that would extend the Voting Rights Act indefinitely.

title: REAGAN DISPLAYS SKILL AT CRAFTING DEALS
description: Representative Glenn English represents a district in western Oklahoma that produces a vast amount of natural gas. Yesterday, Mr. English received a hand-written note from President Reagan, written on Camp David stationery, promising to veto any bill coming to his desk that would impose a special tax on the profits of natural gas producers.

title: FORD SETS LAYOFFS
description: The Ford Motor Company announced that 360 hourly workers will be laid off indefinitely next Monday at its English Avenue plant here.

title: FEDERAL AGENTS JOIN SEARCH FOR PICASSO REPRODUCTIONS
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have joined the search for 600 lithographic reproductions of paintings by Pablo Picasso that were taken from a truck hijacked in Queens on Tuesday.

title: Bridge; 17-YEAR-OLD STUDENT WINS IN LIFE MASTER PAIRS EVENT
description: In a stunning upset here last night, a 17-yearold high school student from Accord, N.Y., won the life master pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. The student, Steve Weinstein, thereby set a record as the youngest player to win a national title, breaking a record set by Kyle Larsen of San Francisco in l968 at the age of l8.

title: GREAT LAKES TEAM TAKES HOCKEY GOLD
description: Jay Wall's goal midway through the second period broke a 1-1 tie, and the undefeated Great Lakes team went on to a 5-2 victory over the Central squad tonight for the gold medal in hockey at the National Sports Festival.

title: Credit Markets; PRICES OF U.S. ISSUES DECLINE
description: Borrowing by the Treasury will accelerate between now and the end of the year, according to Treasury officials yesterday who announced plans to sell $8.5 billion of notes and bonds next week as the first step in raising $39 billion to $42 billion of cash by the end of the year.

title: 1980 CENSUS FINDS CHINESE SURPASSING JAPANESE AS NATION'S LARGEST ASIAN GROUP
description: The number of Chinese in the United States has grown so rapidly in recent years that they now total more than 800,000 and have surpassed the Japanese as the leading population of Asians in this country, according to 1980 census figures announced yesterday.

title: Books of the Times
description: DIVINE DANCER: A Biography of Ruth St. Denis. By Suzanne Shelton. 338 pages. Il- lustrated. Doubleday. $15.95.

title: JUDGE TELLS STATE TO ACCEPT IMMEDIATELY 530 PRISONERS NOW IN OVERCROWDED CITY JAILS
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered New York State to accept immediately 530 convicted felons housed in overcrowded city jails. And in the future, he said, the state must accept prisoners who have been sentenced to serve terms in state prison within 48 hours after transfer papers are completed.

title: CONNECTICUT UNVEILS PROPOSED LEGISLATIVE DISTRICTS
description: Proposed new state legislative districts that would slightly dilute urban strength while trying to minimize widespread political disruption in Connecticut were made public today.

title: 150 DEAD IN INDIAN FLOODING
description: Monsoon floods in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh have caused 150 deaths, destroyed or damaged more than 54,000 houses and inundated vast areas of farmland, the Press Trust of India news agency reported today. In Assam, in the northeast, about 2,000 people were made homeless by floods from the Brahmaputra River.

title: The Region; U.S. WILL CLEAN UP WASTES IN OSWEGO
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - The new Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency told a House subcommittee yesterday that an abandoned hazardous waste dump in Oswego, N.Y., would be the first site to be cleaned up with money from a new $1.6 billion fund.

title: FRENCH AIDE TO LEAVE TODAY FOR A VISIT TO LATIN AMERICA
description: France's Foreign Minister will leave Paris tomorrow for a weeklong visit to Mexico and Central America that diplomats here have called the first demonstration of France's new interest in third-world nations outside of its own French-speaking sphere.

title: I.B.M. AGREES TO DEDUCTIONS FOR THE BLACK UNITED FUND
description: I.B.M. has agreed to make payroll deductions for its employees who wish to contribute to the New York Black United Fund. The agreement is viewed by some philanthropic organizations as a major breakthrough for minority-group charities.

title: NATALIE G. SHORT
description: Natalie Guggenheim Short, heiress to the Guggenheim family copper fortune, died Monday at her home in Honolulu. Mrs. Short, who had lived in New York for many years, was 70 years old.

title: ROLL-CALL IN HOUSE
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 238 to 195 by which the House of Representatives today approved President Reagan's three-year, 25 percent tax-cutting plan, the decisive vote on the legislation. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the President's plan. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 48 Democrats and 190 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 194 Democrats and 1 Republican. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are no vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, no; Flippo, no; Nichols, yes; Shelby, yes. Republicans - Dickinson, yes; Edwards, yes; Smith yes.

title: SOUTH KOREA BUYS COAL
description: The Sun Eel Shipping Company of South Korea has agreed to buy more than 7 million metric tons of coal from the Usibelli coal mine over the next decade, a Usibelli spokesman said today. The value of the accord was not disclosed.

title: IMPORTS OF OIL AT 6-YEAR LOW
description: United States imports of crude oil fell last week to their lowest level in six years, the American Petroleum Industry reported yesterday.

title: MISSIONARY JAILED BY CHINESE
description: Bishop James Edward Walsh, a missionary priest who spent 12 years in a Chinese prison on a charge of spying and subversion, died yesterday of a heart ailment at the headquarters of the Maryknoll Fathers in Ossining, N.Y., where he lived. He was 90 years old.

title: U.S. DEFEATS SOVIET IN BASKETBALL FINAL
description: The United States defeated the Soviet Union, 93-87, today to win the gold medal in men's basketball, and an American swimmer, Jill Sterkel, tied the Rumanian gymnast Nadia Comaneci with five gold medals on the last day of the World University Games.

title: HAIG POSTPONES DRIVE FOR SALE OF AWACS TO SAUDIS
description: The State Department said today that it would postpone until September the submission to Congress of a proposal to sell Saudi Arabia a package of advanced military aircraft.

title: U.S.-CANADA TUNA TREATY
description: The United States and Canada formally signed a treaty today that ended a two-year dispute over tuna-fishing rights in the Pacific Ocean.

title: Advertising; Account
description: * Lane Drug Company, a division of People's Drug, to Fahlgren & Ferriss, Cincinnati.

title: U.S. and Canada Ratify Treaty on Tuna Fishing
description: Canada and the United States ratified a treaty on West Coast tuna fishing today, formally ending their dispute of two years ago.

title: BRIGHAM ENDING DUTIES AS CITY AIDE TOMORROW
description: James R. Brigham Jr., who had made it clear for some time that he wanted to leave municipal government, will finally get his way tomorrow when he officially steps down after three and a half years as New York City's Budget Director.

title: Advertising; IDEAL TOY'S SON OF RUBIK CUBE
description: THE Ideal Toy Corporation, which is being saved from further fiscal hurt by the puzzling, confounding Hungarian-born phenomenon known as Rubik's Cube, is going to try to repeat the success with a locally devised product called the Missing Link.

title: Trucks on a Reagan Curve
description: D.M. Bowman, a Maryland trucker, received permission from the Interstate Commerce Commission in April to haul building materials nationwide. But now the commission, newly dominated by the Reagan Administration's chairman, has reversed position. The Bowman concern, the commission said, never proved there was a market for its services. It will thus be licensed to haul only building supplies, for a single shipper.

title: The Region; WESTCHESTER VOTE ON UTILITY DELAYED
description: A deadline for legislative action that would have enabled Westchester County voters to accept or reject a proposed countywide public utility in the November election passed without action yesterday amid charges of political maneuvering. The proposed referendum might be completed in time for submission during village elections next March, according to one of its backers.

title: MOBIL'S NET UP CITIES SERVICE OFF
description: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest industrial company, yesterday reported that second-quarter earnings rose 2 percent, while the Cities Service Company announced a 15.5 percent decline.

title: Radiation Poisoning Kills A Former Radiographer
description: Douglas Crofut, 38 years old, an unemployed industrial radiographer, is believed by Federal officials to be the first American to die of radiation poisoning since the early days of experimentation with atomic bombs.

title: PRIVATE TEAMS HELP IN CARE OF ELDERLY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Liliane Droyan Kodner is a freelance writer. By LILIANE DROYAN KODNER

title: LIMITING CHILDREN'S TV HABITS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elin McCoy writes frequently on children and education. By ELIN McCOY

title: A G.&W. GROUP TO SELL ZINC UNIT
description: Gulf and Western Industries said that its natural resources group has agreed to sell certain assets of the New Jersey Zinc Company to a group of private investors that includes William E. Flaherty, executive vice president of the natural resources group.

title: CHICAGO SUBURBAN BUS LINES PLANNING A RETURN TO SERVICE
description: Two bus lines which suspended service two months ago because of the Chicago area's problems with transit funds will resume partial service to about 8,000 riders on Monday.

title: THE COUP DE GRASS
description: I am perfectly aware that there are many otherwise rational people who regard grass as merely a benign, even attractive ground cover, but I know better. Grass is going to kill me some day. It has already blighted my youth, attempted to geld me, and cost me the best job I ever had. Why should it stop now?

title: Gromyko Says Soviet Can't Ignore U.S. Plans
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said in an article published in New Delhi today that Moscow could not stay aloof from the Reagan Administration's plans to provide arms to China and Pakistan.

title: Advertising; INTERPUBLIC'S NET DROPS IN QUARTER
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday announced its secondquarter earnings. Revenues fell 1.1 percent, to $110 million from $111.2 million in the similar period last year, and net income fell 35.3 percent, to $5.8 million from $8.95 million.

title: MILL WORKERS GET BACK PAY
description: The first installment of about $5 million in back pay was mailed today to several hundred Southern textile workers who lost their jobs in a labor dispute dating to 1956.

title: WASHINGTON POST'S PUBLISHER DENIES PLAN FOR A NEW TABLOID
description: With eight days left before the planned closing of The Washington Star, there are no purchasers in sight for the 128-year-old daily and no definite plans for a replacement newspaper.

title: THE FEDERAL RESERVE IS TYING CREDIT TOO TIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's a great day to be British.'' -Geoffrey Tirson, a 72-year-old retired factory worker. (A10:1.)

title: Briefs
description: * Anaconda Industries, a unit of Atlantic Richfield Co., announced plans for an $89.5 million expansion of its production operations in Buffalo and Los Angeles.

title: CANADA ACTS TO CURB AMERICAN ACQUISITIONS
description: The Canadian Government reacted today to the dramatic weakening of its currency by moving to reduce ''substantially'' Canadian takeovers of American companies.

title: CALIFANO STUDIES DRUG PROGRAMS FOR USE BY STATE
description: Harry Moy, a 70-year-old man with a wide grin and thin white hair, sat with his cane at his side yesterday and summed up a lifetime of drug use. ''First opium, then heroin - then everything,'' he recalled.

title: Design Notebook; THE FIGHT TO SAVE AN 1840 VERMONT INN
description: HISTORIC WINDSOR Inc. is celebrating its 10th anniversary this year in the Vermont town from which it takes its name. The celebration is being held in Windsor House, an impressive Greek Revival structure built in 1840 as the finest inn on the route between Boston and Montreal.

title: Advertising; THE LATEST RUNDOWN OF ACCOUNT SWITCHING
description: Here are a few more bits and pieces along the account-switch trail: Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, will be doing the trade advertising for Knapp Communications' Architectural Digest and Bon Appetit magazines, formerly handled in-house.

title: CONCERT: CLEVELANDERS
description: FOR love of Mozart, listeners filled Avery Fisher Hall last Thursday evening and then overflowed onto its stage. They came to hear the Cleveland Quartet.

title: 7-FOOTER EWING GETS TALL TEST IN FESTIVAL
description: Michael Cage tried to intimidate Patrick Ewing, banging to the body, hooking legs for position and grabbing his arms. ''I wanted to test him,'' said Cage, a muscular 6-foot-9-inch, 225-pounder from San Diego State University who was among the leading rebounders in college basketball as a freshman last season. ''He didn't back off. We were banging in there pretty good, and both of us even got a double foul one time. But I like that in a player.

title: No Headline
description: HOME PARK: Jim Smith standing in the wreckage of his home, one of four mobile homes in Newport, Ohio, that were demolished Tuesday night by a storm that the National Weather Service called ''a probable tornado.'' The storm also damaged a number of homes in West Virginia.

title: ELF PROJECTS TEXASGULF GAINS
description: Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the French state-owned oil concern, said it expects earnings of its newly acquired United States subsidiary, Texasgulf Inc., to increase to $300 million in 1985, from $140 million last year. Elf Aquitaine directors told a news conference that Texasgulf revenues should reach $1 billion in 1985, compared with $600 million in 1980, while cash flow should rise to $400 million, from $140 million. Elf acquired Texasgulf for $2.8 billion cash in a complex transaction that involved a spin-off of Texasgulf's Canadian mineral holdings to the Canadian Government.

title: Critic's Notebook; WHY BUILDINGS GROW ON US
description: IF time heals wounds, it also heals a great deal of architecture: it is remarkable how much more benign many mediocre buildings seem 2, 3 or 10 years after their completion. For a long time, I thought that nothing could be worse than the ''XYZ'' buildings on the Avenue of the Americas, the massive Exxon, McGraw-Hill and Celanese skyscrapers that comprise the western expansion of Rockefeller Center, so named by their planners because of their nearly identical design. The three boxy towers are banal in the extreme, with huge and generally useless plazas dulling the street life in front and straight tops flattening out the skyline up above.

title: LACHEMANN PACT SEEN
description: Rene Lachemann, interim manager of the Seattle Mariners, will be hired on a permanent basis in 1982, it was reported today. According to The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, George Argyros, the owner, has already decided to rehire Lachemann, who replaced Maury Wills early in the season, and will work out the contract details early next month.

title: CONOCO BIDS INCREASE LOAD FOR WALL ST.
description: Donald Carter mans a shareholder hot line to explain Seagram's offer to Conoco shareholders. Nelson Schreiber oversees the printing of Du Pont's offers. Carl Ferenbach at Merrill Lynch consults with Mobil to outdo Conoco's other suitors. William Pelster culls through tomes of law to advise Conoco on its legal options. Through all of this, Gershon Kekst calms Conoco employees and wards off headhunters.

title: JAPAN AUTO EXPORTS OFF
description: Japanese car exports in June registered their first year-to-year decline in more than two years following curbs on shipments to major Western nations, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: ROBERT MOSES, MASTER BUILDER, IS DEAD AT 92
description: Robert Moses, who played a larger role in shaping the physical environment of New York State than any other figure in the 20th century, died early yesterday at West Islip, L.I. Mr. Moses, whose long list of public offices only begins to hint at his impact on both the city and state of New York, was 92 years old.

title: Helpful Hardware; FLEXIBLE LIGHTING
description: RIBBONLITE provides an unobtrusive, flexible way to illuminate small, hard-to-light places. Created by Willem Wirtz Associates, a garden lighting company, these small lights were originally made for cabinets holding objets d'art.

title: Commander Censured For Death on a Carrier
description: The commanding officer of the aircraft carrier Ranger was censured today as a result of an admiral's analysis of an inquiry into the treatment that led to a crewman's death.

title: SENATE VOTE
description: Following is the 89-11 roll call today by which the Senate approved President Reagan's three-year tax cut plan. Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr., a Virginia independent, who joins with Democrats on Senate procedural matters, is listed here among the Democrats.

title: FARM EQUIPMENT SALES PITCH
description: ''One of the most important buyer incentive programs that we or any other agricultural equipment dealer has ever offered.'' So proclaim the advertisements that International Harvester, the country's second-largest farm equipment maker, has been running recently in farm-oriented publications.

title: HUNDREDS IN STATION AT 34TH AND EIGHTH FLEE FIRE IN SUBWAY
description: Hundreds of people fled the subway station at Eighth Avenue and 34th Street yesterday morning after a fire broke out in the undercarriage of an IND train.

title: AIRLINES OFF IN SLOW MARKET
description: Airline issues continued to move down yesterday in the face of a possible strike by air traffic controllers, while stock prices over all posted a slight decline.

title: VIDEO SALES UP FOR JAPAN
description: Japan's production and exports of videotape recorders established records in June, while production and exports of color television sets also rose, the Electronics Industries Association of Japan reported today.

title: F.B.I. GETTING NEW HELP FROM ABSCAM INFORMER
description: A convicted swindler who was a key undercover agent in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam investigation into political corruption is working on another case for the agency, an F.B.I. spokesman said yesterday.

title: Philharmonic Is Playing 2 Free Concerts on L.I.
description: The New York Philharmonic, conducted by Edo de Waart, will give two free outdoor concerts of Berlioz, Tchaikovsky and Samuel Barber on Long Island this weekend.

title: WHEN AN ADOLESCENT IS LABELED A PRUDE
description: To the Editor:

title: East Side Italian and Vietnamese.
description: THE more attractive a restaurant is, the greater the promise of good food it holds out, for it is logical for diners to assume that an owner who spends a great deal of money and effort to create a beautiful dining room will be able to effect equally felicitous results in the kitchen. That such optimism can be somewhat misplaced is evident at the three-month-old Ristorante Felidia, on 58th Street between Second and Third Avenues, where the food is disappointingly inconsistent. Felidia, at No. 243, is not easy to find, despite its handsome stained-wood front framing a lavishly etched window, because neither the name on a small oval brass plate nor the building number is easily visible.

title: HELLER ACQUISITION
description: The Walter E. Heller International Corporation, one of the country's biggest financial concerns, said it has reached agreement with the French Government to acquire a 51 percent interest in Cofacredit S.A., a French export factoring company. Heller, which declined to disclose the cost of the transaction, noted that it was the first time that France's new Socialist Government, which is nationalizing many companies, had consented to sell a Governmentcontrolled firm to private interests.

title: N.B.A. ELIMINATES BONUS FREE THROWS
description: The National Basketball Association, in an effort to speed up games, announced yesterday that it has eliminated all bonus free throws as one of several rule changes for the 1981-82 season.

title: INDONESIAN COAL OUTPUT
description: Indonesia has set an annual production target of 10 million tons of coal by 1990, a fiftyfold increase over current output, the Mining and Energy Ministry said today. It said efforts to increase coal production were intended to meet the domestic demand for alternatives to oil, a major Indonesian export. Indonesia has huge potential coal deposits in central and south Kalimantan, in Borneo, in addition to the mines in south Sumatra.

title: FUNDS' ASSETS CONTINUE CLIMB
description: The assets of the nation's money funds climbed $2.2 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: SWIMMER, 47, CIRCLES MANHATTAN A 5TH TIME
description: At 10:10 A.M. yesterday, George Kauffmann, a 47-year-old Keansburg, N.J., tavern owner and father of 10 children, put on a yellow bathing cap and a pair of dark goggles and plunged into the East River at 89th Street to swim around Manhattan for the fifth consecutive year.

title: ROYAL NEWLYWEDS RELAX AT A PALATIAL HIDEAWAY
description: The bunting was still there on the morning after, but the tumult and shouting had died. No church bells pealed in London today, no horses' hoofs clattered on the pavements.

title: PRODUCTIVITY DECLINES, IMPLYING A SLOWDOWN
description: Productivity in American business declined at an annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, the Labor Department reported today. With the volatile factor of farming included, however, productivity increased at a 1.1 percent rate.

title: CASEY TELLS FEDERAL ETHICS AGENCY HE OMITTED THREE STOCK HOLDINGS
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, has notified a Federal ethics agency that he failed to disclose stock holdings in three corporations when he filed a personal financial disclosure statement in January.

title: Pistons Are Expected To Sign Thomas Today
description: The Detroit Pistons scheduled a news conference for tomorrow afternoon, presumably to announce the signing of Isiah Thomas, their first-round draft choice.

title: CABLE NETWORK FOR WEATHER
description: The latest entry in the cable network sweepstakes - a live, 24-hour, all-weather channel conceived by John Coleman, the meteorologist of ABC-TV's ''Good Morning America'' - was announced yesterday.

title: G.S.A. Chief Calls for Inquiry Into 2 Aides Fighting Waste
description: The head of the General Services Administration today asked the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency to ''clear the air'' by investigating ties between two top aides and a group that raised $175,000 to fight waste and fraud in Government.

title: A Field of 12 Horses Named for Whitney
description: A field of 12, including 11 stakes winners, was drawn this morning for Saturday's $150,000-added Whitney Handicap at Saratoga Race Track.

title: REP. GARCIA: ANYTHING FOR THE BRONX
description: Robert Garcia is half of what has become known around the halls of Congress as the ''odd couple'' and the liberal co-author of new legislation aimed at rescuing the nation's deteriorated urban areas.

title: SOUTHEAST ASIAN NATIONS' POSITION ON
description: CAMBODIATo the Editor:

title: AN OPERA CALLED 'BASTIEN' BY AN ARTFUL 12-YEAR-OLD
description: ''A remarkable pair of lovers,'' says the wizened shepherd Colas of the peasants Bastien and Bastienne in Mozart's short comic opera bearing their names. ''In sooth, innocence is found only in the country; in towns this is but a rarity.''

title: BONN BUDGET PLAN FOR THE MILITARY CUT IN REAL TERMS
description: The West German Cabinet today approved a rough outline for the 1982 budget that foresees a possible drop in military spending after inflation is accounted for. Chancellor Helmut Schmidt attributed the decline to the impact of high interest rates in the United States.

title: Todd Reaches Accord With Jets on Pact
description: Richard Todd, the Jets' quarterback and the only unsigned player on the club, reached an agreement today with the team president, Jim Kensil.

title: Work on the Space Shuttle Disrupted by a Fuel Spillage
description: A tiny amount of acid-like rocket fuel was accidentally spilled on the surface of the space shuttle Columbia today, slightly damaging some outer insulation and forcing a one-hour suspension of work.

title: Wanna Buy a Comet Picture?
description: Halley's Comet, one of the most famous objects in the solar system, will streak past the Earth again in 1986 and American scientists fear they won't have a space probe close by to watch it.

title: U.A.W. HALTS WAGE ACCORD
description: A 12 percent wage increase that the Chrysler Corporation had given to about 600 designers earlier this month to keep them from leaving for other companies was withdrawn today under pressure from the United Auto Workers union, Chrysler said today.

title: ALLIED SET TO BUY FISHER SCIENTIFIC
description: The Allied Corporation said today it has agreed to acquire the Fisher Scientific Company for $330 million as its first step in building a scientific health products business.

title: MODERN DANCE - ON THE BEACH AND UNDER THE
description: BRIDGE By JENNIFER DUNNING

title: Dismissed Worker Held In Killings of 2 at Plant
description: A machinist has been accused of fatally shooting two men at his former place of work after he was dismissed.

title: Friday; SHAKESPEARE IN THE PARK
description: Stagehands have been busy at Central Park's Delacorte Theater, clearing the deck from ''The Tempest'' and setting up for ''Henry IV, Part I,'' the latest serving of free Shakespeare in the park, which begins previews tonight at 8 P.M. and runs through Aug. 30. The production is directed by Des McAnuff and features Stephen Markle, Kenneth McMillan, Mandy Patinkin and John Vickery. For the first two weeks in August, there will be performances nightly except Wednesday; in the last two weeks there will performances nightly except Monday. Tickets are distributed on a first-come basis on the day of the performance, starting at 6:15 P.M. The Delacorte is near the park entrance at Central Park West and 81st Street. The box office number is 535-5630.

title: U.S. FISCAL COURSE A WORRY TO STATES
description: When President Reagan said today that his new economic package of tax and budget cuts was the ''first phase'' in an attempt to revitalize American federalism and return power to state governments, there were no great cries of joy among those attending the annual meeting here of the National Conference of State Legislatures.

title: Notes on People; KEESHAN RETURNING
description: Millions of very young fans and grown-up former fans will be happy to know that Bob Keeshan, television's ''Captain Kangaroo'' for the last 26 years, has returned home from Canada to continue his recuperation from a heart attack he suffered July 11.

title: TWO TIE FOR FIRST PLACE IN U.S. CHESS TOURNEY
description: Yasser Seirawan of Seattle and Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., tied for first place in the 15-player invitational United States Chess Championship here with 9-5 scores.

title: The City; QUEENS ASSAILANT KILLED IN LEAP
description: A 30-year-old man strangled an elderly woman in her apartment in Queens and then jumped out an eighth-floor window when officers arrived, the police said.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL TO MODERNIZE MILLS
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel producer after the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday announced a steel plant modernization program that will cost an estimated $750 million over the next five years. The modernization project is one of the largest in the company's history.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL GOES TO 2 NETWORKS
description: CBS Sports and ABC Sports agreed yesterday to pay $264 million over four years for the television rights to National Collegiate Athletic Association regular-season football games beginning with the 1982 season.

title: 55 Million Saw Wedding; The Associated Press
description: An estimated 55 million Americans saw some of the live television coverage of the royal wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer, ABC's research department estimated yesterday. However, a spokeman said complete audience figures, due later in the week, would be needed for a more precise calculation.

title: BUDGET OFFICE TIGHTENS RULES ON FEDERAL EMPLOYEES' TRAVEL
description: The Office of Management and Budget today announced tighter controls on travel by Federal employees. The office said that the controls could save more than $200 million.

title: U.S. and India Discuss Rift Over Nuclear Fuel
description: A high-level United States delegation met today with Indian officials to discuss the deadlocked issue of nuclear cooperation. Neither side seemed hopeful of a breakthrough.

title: MUSIC: NEWELL JENKINS LEADS WASHINGTON SQ. ORCHESTRA
description: THREATENING clouds persuaded Newell Jenkins and the Washington Square Music Festival Orchestra to move indoors Tuesday evening, and as a result this scheduled concert-in-the-park took place in the Judson Memorial Church, on the square. It was not an ideal ambience - the clammy heat affecting both players and audience and the high ceiling's reverberation factor effectively sabotaging most attempts at textural clarity.

title: The Evening Hours
description: YOU didn't have to be British to go to a lot of parties in New York this week, but it helped. The Britons, of course, were the most avid local celebrants of the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana. But many native New Yorkers also raised a Pimm's Cup or two in celebration of ''the wedding of the century.''

title: GENESIS, REWRITTEN
description: The Middle East memory bank is empty again. Just read the papers, watch the television. The new Book of Genesis begins with the raid on the Iraqi reactor and climaxes with the bombs over Beirut. The world is outraged and the world will not forget. The world has forgotten everything else, and if the American news media is representative, the world does not want any reminders. It is angry with Menachem Begin, it is impatient, it is at wit's end. And so history becomes intolerable. Still, history has its claims, does it not? And a memory bank is the only bank in history that needs a run on it to get back in business. So here are a few facts.

title: ARMCO PLANS SALE OF 2 STEEL PLANTS
description: Armco Inc., the nation's major specialty steels maker, confirmed reports that it is negotiating the sale of its two small mills in Sand Springs, Okla., and Marion, Ohio.

title: KAREN ROSE GOODKIND
description: Karen Rose Goodkind, a literary agent and personal manager, died of cancer Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Notes on People; VISITING LUMBERJACK
description: The two-time world champion chain sawer was in town yesterday, eyeing the trees in Central Park. Considering what happens when Roy Booth gets loose in the woods, it was a good thing he didn't have his chain saw with him.

title: NBC RAISES MULHOLLAND TO PRESIDENT
description: Robert E. Mulholland, a 20-year veteran of the National Broadcasting Company with a broad background in news, was named president and chief operating officer of NBC yesterday.

title: Foes of School Busing Lose Bid to Halt Senate Filibuster
description: Opponents of busing in school desegregation cases lost by one vote yesterday an effort to block a filibuster on a proposal to limit drastically court-ordered busing.

title: Briefs
description: * Armco Inc. said it plans to spend $18.5 million to upgrade and expand finishing facilities at its Ambridge, Pa., seamless tube plant.

title: The Region; PUBLIC SERVICE CO. RAISING ITS RATES
description: An adjustment in rates for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company based on the cost of energy is expected to cost its 1.6 million electric customers an average of $2.94 a month, beginning tomorrow.

title: Yankees Tired of Strike but Back Miller
description: A half-dozen Yankees had a reunion of sorts yesterday at Downing Stadium, where they discussed the 50-day strike while participating in a baseball clinic for children organized by the David M. Winfield Foundation.

title: GRES, MORI AND SPOOK END SHOWINGS
description: Alix Gres closed the fall couture showing season in the traditional way this afternoon. Models strolled through her salon on the Rue de la Paix while clients chatted about the parties they'd been to, the houses in the south of France they were going to and the price of clothes (steep already and climbing rapidly) they were going to buy.

title: IAN MARTIN
description: Ian Martin, an actor who appeared in seven Broadway shows and on 700 television programs, died of a heart ailment in Doctors Hospital last Saturday. He was 69 years old.

title: QUEENS MEDICAL GROUP KEEPS 5 CENTERS OPEN DESPITE STRIKE
description: The La Guardia Medical Group, an organization serving 150,000 people in Queens under the Health Insurance Plan, said yesterday that five of its nine centers were continuing to provide full medical services despite an employees' strike that will enter its third week today.

title: CHANGE IN LABEL ON A MEAT PRODUCT PROPOSED
description: A new proposal by the Reagan Administration to eliminate the words ''powdered bone'' from labels of meat containing small quantities of finely ground bone is aimed, in part, at making the product more acceptable to consumers, Agriculture Department officials said today.

title: Sound Advice on American Rights
description: Does opposition to Chicago's desegregation plan mean the Reagan Administration is getting soft on civil rights? Probably not. In a city where only 18 percent of the 463,000 public-school students are white, Chicago wanted to draw lines that would still leave some schools 70 percent white. It would have been difficult for any lawabiding administration to acquiesce in that arrangement.

title: Business People; GOLDBLATT BROS. SELECTS OFFICER IN RESTRUCTURING
description: William Hellman, 61, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Goldblatt Bros., a Chicago-based retail chain. As president, he succeeds Lionel Goldblatt, 52, who was named chairman and continues as chief executive officer.

title: ERA OF OPPORTUNITIES FOR SAVINGS & LOANS
description: To the Editor:

title: SALE BY CATERPILLAR TO SOVIET CLEARED
description: Despite objections from some Reagan Administration officials, the Caterpillar Tractor Company has received permission to sell 100 mechanical pipelayers to the Soviet Union.

title: A Dwindling Breed of Sports Fan
description: WHENEVER a strike shut down newspapers in New York, thousands of readers were lost. Some circulation was regained slowly, but many former subscribers continued along their uninformed way, settling for the superficial headline service of the news broadcasts.

title: SHARING THE ROYAL FUN AND THE SIGNIFICANCE
description: The happy smiles beamed across the world from London were the message. The pleasure of finery and pageantry as relief from the daily TV fare of smoking ruins and hate-filled faces was reason enough to applaud the royal wedding.

title: UNLIKELY HURDLE TO TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: To the Editor:

title: PANEL ACTS ON BIDS BY FOREIGNERS
description: The Senate today took its first action on proposed legislation, already moving through the House, to apply domestic borrowing ceilings to foreign investors when they are seeking control of American companies.

title: U.S. Leads by 5 Points In Admirals' Cup Races
description: The United States, West Germany and Italy held the first three places today after the second day of the 1981 Admirals' Cup, one of the world's premier yachting competitions.

title: ENTHUSIASM FOR THE TAX CUTS BUT INFLATION TEMPERS VIEW BY BUSINESS
description: Business leaders yesterday welcomed the passage of President Reagan's tax package with enthusiasm and excitement, describing it as essentially a ''revitalization'' of American capitalism.

title: Shields Is Cleared
description: Randy Shields has been cleared of wrongdoing on charges that he took a combination of pain-reducing drugs just before his April welterweight title fight against Thomas Hearns, the World Boxing Association champion. Shields has said he took an injection of cortisone, an anti-inflammation agent, and xylocaine, a local anesthestic, for a shoulder injury. He lost to Hearns on a 13th-round technical knockout and has not fought since the April 25 bout because of the injury, a torn rotator cuff.

title: No Nukes Heads Field In Rich Wilson Pace
description: No Nukes, driven by Ben Webster, drew the No. 2 post position today for the $1.7-million Woodrow Wilson Pace to be run Monday at the Meadowlands, and he was installed as the 9-5 morning-line favorite.

title: The Region; NEW YORK JOB RISE SLOWED IN JUNE
description: Payroll employment in New York State increased by 45,300 in June, nearly a third less than the average gain for the month during the last four years, the State Department of Labor reported.

title: ANGRY IRANIANS DEMAND PARIS RETURN 'CRIMINAL' BANI-SADR
description: Demonstrators chanting ''Death to Mitterrand!'' ringed the French Embassy in Teheran for three hours today, demanding that France extradite Iran's deposed President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr. There was no reaction from Paris.

title: 40 OUSTED FROM LIBYAN MISSION AFTER PROTEST
description: Forty people who identified themselves as Libyan students opposed to the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi took over offices of Libya's United Nations mission yesterday for three hours. They were arrested after six New York City police officers broke down a back door with a battering ram.

title: PEGGY LEE SINGS TONIGHT AND MANANA
description: PEGGY LEE is making a rare appearance at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., where she is performing tonight and tomorrow evening with Tony Bennett. As might be expected, her program includes some of her hit songs: ''Fever,'' ''Is That All There Is?,'' ''Why Don't You Do Right?'' and a little taste of @''Manana.''

title: CAINE AND STALLONE IN HUSTON'S 'VICTORY'
description: ''VICTORY,'' an adventure melodrama set mostly in a prisoner of war camp in Nazi Germany, represents the veteran director John Huston in an expansive and almost carefree mood. It's as if Mr. Huston, having just directed two of the most imaginative and difficult films in his long career, ''The Man Who Would Be King'' and ''Wise Blood,'' had decided to work on something more conventional and less demanding. (Not having seen ''Phobia,'' a horror film he made last year in Canada and that remains unreleased in New York, I suspect he considers that one simply as a timeout.)

title: SURGE OF VISITORS STRAINS THE NATIONAL PARKS
description: After a two-year slump in attendance caused by the soaring cost of gasoline and travel, Americans are flocking back to their national parks this summer in record numbers.

title: CARLA BLEY AND HER BAND IN VILLAGE
description: COLUMBIA RECORDS recently issued a curious album called ''Nick Mason's Fictitious Sports.'' Mr. Mason is the drummer for the popular rock group Pink Floyd, and nominally it was his solo album. But the music was written and arranged by the jazz composerCarla Bley and performed by her band, with Mr. Mason on drums and with two guest vocalists. It is boisterous music with quirky, off-beat lyrics. In ''I'm a Mineralist,'' Miss Bley confesses that just the thought of ironing gives me spasms of lust I creep up to old wrecked cars and lick off the rust I'm a mineralist. In ''Boo to You Too,'' she suggests a strategy for musicians who have to deal with hecklers in the audience: When they boo at me you know what

title: FEEBLE EXPOSE OF FARMERS' CHILD-LABOR ABUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Jets Said to Check Cuban MIG's Twice
description: United States Navy jets twice intercepted Cuban MIG-21 fighters on a course toward the aircraft carrier Independence in the last two weeks and in both instances the Sovietbuilt jets turned back, Navy sources said today.

title: MADCAP 'UNDER THE RAINBOW'
description: THE makers of ''Under the Rainbow'' have taken a strange idea and run with it, making it a good deal stranger. The year is 1938, ''The Wizard of Oz'' is about to be made, and a movie studio is auditioning Munchkins. So 150 midgets are holed up at the Culver City Hotel, preparing to don winged-monkey outfits and start swinging from the chandeliers. This would be plot enough for any movie, but it's about one-tenth of what goes on in ''Under the Rainbow,'' which has enough story angles to make your head spin.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't know who's happier about yesterday's events, me or Prince Charles.'' - President Reagan. (A8:5.)

title: MARRIED PEOPLE AND WIDOWS FOUND TO OUTLIVE WIDOWERS
description: Men, but not women, are much more likely to die within several years after the death of a spouse than are people who are still married, according to a study by Johns Hopkins University researchers. But remarriage appears to increase the widowed man's chances of living longer, the study says.

title: Transactions; COLLEGE
description: Named Clarence Shelmon a n assistant football coach. NEBRASKA - Named Kathy Hawkins w omen's tennis coach. FOOTBALL JETS (AFC) - Reached agreement w ith Richard Todd, quarterback, on series o f one-year contracts.

title: No Headline
description: Dan Schatzeder of the Detroit Tigers is upset about continuing reports that he is among baseball's dissident players regarding the strike.

title: ARCO TO CLOSE MORE STATIONS
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the nation's eighth-largest oil company, said it will begin closing its stations in Ohio and four other states as its dealers' leases expire and expects to be out of the market in those states within three years.

title: Notes on People; TV TURNS OFF ITS FATHER
description: The engineer often credited with being ''the father of television'' celebrated his 92d birthday yesterday and said that although he never dreamed TV would ever become so good from a technological standpoint, he seldom watches it because what appears on TV is ''awful.''

title: ARIAS TOPS JAMES, GAINS QUARTERFINAL
description: Sixteen-year-old Jimmy Arias finished a match that lasted 2 hours 5 minutes with a flourish tonight to advance to the quarterfinals of the $125,000 Mutual Benefit Life Open.

title: DIRTIEST BLOCKS GIVEN 'ROTTEN APPLES'
description: Lexington Avenue in front of the Citicorp Building looked spotless yesterday morning as the Association for a Better New York prepared to tour a ''litter disaster area'' a block south, between 52d and 53d Streets.

title: MGM HOTEL IN LAS VEGAS IS REOPENED
description: The MGM Grand Hotel reopened today eight months after much of it was severely damaged by an explosive, smoky fire that killed 85 persons, injured more than 700, and sent shock waves of apprehension among millions of other Americans who live and work in similar high-rise buildings.

title: TEXAS LIFE, CHAPIN FINALE AND THE POPS
description: ''EXCHANGE,'' a new PBS series of five documentaries by independent film makers, gets under way tonight at 9 on Channel 13 with ''The Third Coast,'' an impressionistic view of life in Texas, which was produced, filmed and edited by Alan and Susan Raymond. The same team was responsible for ''The Police Tapes'' and ''Bad Boys'' on public television and for ''To Die for Ireland'' on the ''ABC News Closeup'' series.

title: PLAN ON IMMIGRATION immigration policy; News Analysis
description: President Reagan's new immigration proposals would lead to three things: citizenship for several million foreigners now living in this country illegally, the admission of 100,000 Mexicans to this country over two years to work at jobs for which domestic labor is in short supply, and the first Federal law prohibiting the hiring of illegal aliens by all employers except for the very smallest concerns.

title: Market Place; THE CHALLENGE FACING KDT
description: KDT INDUSTRIES is attempting to restore a major acquisition to profitability. Some who are familiar with the company's past efforts at salvage expect another success, though KDT itself is ailing at present.

title: BRITISH SHIPBUILDERS
description: State-owned British Shipbuilders Ltd. said today that its loss for the year that ended March 31 narrowed to about $85 million, from about $225 million in the previous year. The military and civil shipbuilder said that sales for the year rose slightly, to about $1.8 billion, from $1.63 billion. It said that orders from both British and overseas companies insured that most of its large merchant yards would have work into 1983.

title: Neeskens Gets a Start
description: Johan Neeskens, the midfielder from the Netherlands who had been suspended by the Cosmos for 10 months, will start Sunday, Coach Hennes Weisweiler said yesterday. Neeskens last appeared in a North American Soccer League game Sept. 7, 1980.

title: TRIAL NEARS END IN HEROIN RING CASE
description: A jury in Manhattan heard summations yesterday in the trial of seven defendants accused of operating a major heroin ring and investing some of the profits in legitimate businesses with the help of a lawyer.

title: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES DOWN IN RALLY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell yesterday as the credit markets rebounded from the steep losses that followed the Treasury's announcement of its borrowing plans.

title: GREYHOUND NET UP 20%
description: The Greyhound Corporation, the diversified transportation, manufacturing and computer services concern, today reported a 20 percent rise in second-quarter earnings and said the gain ''bodes well for a new record year.''

title: House Would Prohibit Civil Service Abortions
description: The House voted today to bar three million Government workers and their dependents from using Federal health insurance to pay for abortions, except when the mother's life is endangered. The vote, 253 to 167, would bring Civil Service insurance in line with such Federal health insurance programs as Medicaid.

title: DC-9 CERTIFIED
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said that the Federal Aviation Administration has certified its DC-9 model 82 to enter commercial airline service.

title: BEHIND A TRACTOR WHEEL
description: Sometime before dawn, the wind rising, I was awakened by the cough of the tractor approaching the house. It went on coughing while I pulled on the clothes Agnes brought me - itchy underwear and socks, two heavy flannel shirts, coveralls still stiff from drying on the wash line, cold as ice.

title: SAVINGS RATE CEILINGS BEGIN 5-YEAR PHASE-OUT
description: Savings institutions and commercial banks have long complained about restrictions that they maintained hindered them in their competition with high-yielding money market funds. As of tomorrow, some of those restraints will be lifted.

title: HELPED CREATE GATEWAY PARK
description: Sheldon Pollack, an environmentalist who helped lead the effort to create the Gateway National Recreation Area, the first national park in an urban area, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack. Mr. Pollack, who lived in Manhattan, was 55 years old.

title: Index; International
description: Strains emerge in Nigeria's 21-month-old civilian regime A2 Gambia radio reports President is ousted while visiting Britain A2 Israel, startled by U.S. anger at raid, call truce good-will act A3 Haig says Soviet arms shipments to Cuba have risen sharply A3 Iranians demonstrate at French Embassy A3 India defends decision to buy foreign wheat A4 Around the World A5 Government/Politics Exhumation asked in case related to Hugel and C.I.A. A10 Casey says he omitted 3 stock holdings in report A11 Carey signs bill to aid people caring for parents at home B3 General Around the Nation A6 Five believed dead in blast at Utah explosives plant A6 Pennsylvania panel told of health insurance falsification A6 Fire Island property owners fight U.S. over condemnations B2 Summations heard in trial of seven on heroin-ring charges B3 ''Rotten Apple Awards'' made in midtown ''litter disaster area'' B7 Industry/Labor Medical group in Queens provid- ing services despite strike B16 Style The Evening Hours B5 Gres, Mori and Spook in Paris finale B5 A party given in the spirit of stylish young women B5 Obituaries James F. O'Neil, ex-publisher of American Legion Magazine B6 Sheldon Pollack, helped create Gateway Recreation Area B6 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Tours of biblical garden at St. John the Divine C12 Culinary Institute, dining adventure at Hyde Park, N.Y. C17 First music and dance festival at Bear Mountain C3 Modern dance on the beach and under the bridge C1

title: LOSING DEMOCRATS BREATHING EASIER
description: In a curious way, many Democrats were breathing a bit easier on Capitol Hill today. They suffered a smashing defeat yesterday on the tax issue but they rationalized that, in the long run, they might be better off this way.

title: JURY ACQUITS AN UPSTATE MAN IN SLAYING OF 2 HUNTERS IN '52
description: A jury acquitted a 53-year-old Newburgh man today of charges that he shot two hunters to death in the wooded hills of Orange County in 1952. The case had been reopened after a sister broke what she said was a 28-year vow of silence and testified against him.

title: Gretzky Asking Oilers To Renegotiate Pact
description: Gus Badali, agent for Wayne Gretky, has sent a proposal for a renegotiated contract to Peter Pocklington, the Edmonton Oilers' owner, outlining what he says is a fair salary for Gretzky, the National Hockey League's most valuable player.

title: Eruption Deaths Certified
description: Certificates of presumptive death have been issued for five persons who disappeared when Mount St. Helens erupted in May 1980.

title: Economic Scene; TAX PATTERNS: THE NEW LOOK
description: CONGRESS has given the President his smashing tax victory. The frenetic contest in the House of Representatives dramatized the importance of the tax bill, but the Reagan fiscal victory had already been secured no matter whose bill won. For the Democratic bill, had it passed, would have given the President almost everything he wanted.

title: THEATER: 'BODYBAGS AT THE INTAR'
description: TEE SARALEGUI'S ''Bodybags,'' which opened last night at the Intar Hispanic American Theater, is a confused and chaotic attempt at writing a drama about the emotionally debilitating peacetime effects of the Vietnam experience. The play makes points, seems to backtrack, then covers everything with excess detail. The dialogue is an admixture of the vernacular and verbiage.

title: MOBIL PLANS TO SELL GAS FIELD OUTPUT
description: The Mobil Corporation said it has reached an agreement to sell its 50 percent share of natural gas produced from the Beryl Field in the North Sea to the British Gas Corporation, the state-run gas utility.

title: AUTOPSY REQUESTED FOR BROTHER OF MEN WHO ACCUSED HUGEL
description: New York City's Chief Medical Examiner wrote the Queens District Attorney yesterday that he believed the body of Dennis McNell, the brother of two men whose charges of fraud forced the resignation of Max C. Hugel from the Central Intelligence Agency, should be exhumed for an autopsy.

title: DUPONT'S EDGE IN BID FOR CONOCO
description: The battle for Conoco Inc. is regarded by Wall Street professionals as a race down to the wire. But Du Pont emerged yesterday as the leading contender to win control of the oil company, based on the number of shares that have already been offered to the chemical group.

title: Insurance Bribery Case Almost Ready for Jury
description: Defense lawyers accused the Government of entrapment and depicted Joseph Hauser, an informer, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation as the real villains in summations today in a trial for bribery and conspiracy involving a fund for insurance company workers.

title: WHY GABRIEL ISAHAROV WAS MADE A U.S. CITIZEN
description: To the Editor:

title: 80TH BIRTHDAY PARTY FOR JEAN DUBUFFET AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: THE French painter, sculptor and polemicist Jean Dubuffet turns 80 today. As to what is being done about it in Paris I cannot say, but the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum has got its act together with splitsecond timing. Its birthday tribute opens this very morning and can be seen through Sept. 27.

title: BELL TRIAL TO GO ON, U.S. SAYS
description: The Justice Department, amid intense speculation today on its future course, announced that it would continue to press its antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, unless a bill is passed that addresses its monopoly concerns about the company's operations.

title: A.P., DOW IN QUOTRON DEAL
description: Dow Jones & Company, The Associated Press and Quotron Systems yesterday signed an agreement for the international marketing of Quotron's financial information service. The Quotron service will be marketed through A.P.-Dow Jones, a business and economic news and information group jointly operated by the two news organizations.

title: The summer in Europe.
description: sponsored exhibition in the Rheinhallen, just across the river from Cologne's imposing cathedral.

title: PHILHARMONIC: IN THE PARK
description: THE New York Philharmonic is obviously doing something right - or was on Wednesday night, at least. The orchestra opened its 17th season of free summer concerts on the Great Lawn of Central Park, and as such phenomena are measured nowadays the event was a walloping success. The night was not just mild, it was cool, and uncounted thousands of people - acres of them, most on the young side - had come prepared for a picnic night out. Long before the concert began, they had settled in for vacation festivities. In addition to food, wine, candles, balloons, blankets, banners and dogs, among other things, they had brought with them the relaxed high spirits more commonly associated with excursions to Jones Beach, Fire Island or the Hamptons than with symphonic concerts.

title: SIMMS SEES WAYS OF COACH'S WISDOM
description: Head coaches and quarterbacks have a special relationship, partly because they spend so much time together. The coach wants the quarterback to think like the coach, but they do not always agree on strategy.

title: Advertising; GILETTE INTRODUCING SILKIENCE MOISTURIZER
description: Gillette's personal care division, in hopes of taking a bite out of Oil of Olay's position in the skin-care market, will begin this fall putting $22.6 million in promotion behind a new product called Silkience Self-Adjusting Moisturizer.

title: RATE RISE FAILS TO HELP CANADIAN DOLLAR
description: The Bank of Canada allowed its discount rate to climb to another record level today -20.54 percent - in a vain effort to halt the slide of the Canadian dollar on the New York market.

title: PENNSYLVANIA UNIT TOLD OF HEALTH PLAN FALSITIES
description: Agents of the Pennsylvania Crime Commission testified today that a health insurance concern had collected more than $1.5 million from two union groups for services worth less than half that amount and had used fabricated figures to persuade the unions that they were getting a bargain.

title: BOXING PROMOTER INDICTED IN FRAUD
description: A Federal grand jury returned a 32-count felony indictment today against Harold J. Smith, the former boxing promoter, charging him with conspiring to defraud the Wells Fargo Bank of more than $21 million.

title: BEAR MOUNTAIN MUSIC FESTIVAL
description: A group of enterprising residents of the Hudson Valley have found a summer role for a nearby ski resort: the First Annual Bear Mountain Festival of World Music & Dance, or 45 acts from Leon Redbone and the James Cotton blues band through dancing, vaudeville, juggling and puppetry.

title: Salvadoran Businessmen Seek Government Shifts
description: Nine of El Salvador's business groups said today that they had formed a ''national unity pact'' to press for changes in the policies of President Jose Napoleon Duarte's Government.

title: WRISTON PONDERS IDEA OF A BANKLESS CITICORP
description: Surprising as it might seem, the management of Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, has been considering the idea of spinning off its major subsidiary, Citibank, an institution deeply rooted in the nation's financial history.

title: 'Usable Art' in Queens
description: A silver racing car and a painted set of furniture are among 48 pieces of ''Usable Art'' on view through Sept. 13 in a show of that title at the Queens Museum in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: L.I. MAN LOSES HIS CITIZENSHIP OVER NAZI TIES
description: A Federal judge yesterday revoked the citizenship of a 62-year-old Long Island man who he said had hidden his World War II role in Estonia as a concentration camp official and had participated in the execution of prisoners.

title: 5 MISSING IN BLAST AT EXPLOSIVES PLANT
description: Five persons were believed dead after a predawn blast turned an explosives manufacturing plant into a fireball today, leveling the concrete building where they were apparently working, officials said.

title: Trudeau Visiting Morocco
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada flew here today from London for a 24-hour official visit.

title: Justice Steven Extends Ban On Expulsion of Mexicans
description: Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens yesterday acted to allow thousands of Mexican immigrants to remain temporarily in the United States.

title: No Headline
description: Topics Barely Visible Water Cure

title: 3 Arraigned in Attack on Ray
description: Three prisoners were arraigned today for the stabbing of James Earl Ray, who is serving 99 years for the fatal shooting of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The three, accused of attacking Mr. Ray in a prison library June 4 while he was preparing an appeal for a new trial, are John W. Partee, Jerome N. Ransom, and Doc Walker. Mr. Ray required 70 stitches for 22 wounds.

title: OPERA: GLASS'S WORK ON YOUNG GANDHI
description: When Gandhi was searching for a name for his strategy of ''passive resistance'' in opposing the British oppression of Indians in South Africa, he chose ''Satyagraha'' - ''the Force which is born of Truth or Love or nonviolence.'' Philip Glass chose the same name as the title of his Sanskrit opera, which received its American premiere last night in Artpark's theater, retaining most of the cast heard nearly a year ago in the Rotterdam world premiere.

title: PACER TECHNOLOGY BUILDING SALES FAST WITH 'SUPER GLUES'
description: Frank Milo, the vice president of marketing and sales for tiny Pacer Technology and Resources Inc., enjoys recalling how he helped General Motors into a sticky situation.

title: Raider Jury Recesses
description: The jury in the antitrust trial of the Oakland Raiders versus the National Football League completed its second day of deliberations today without a verdict. After 55 days of testimony and lawyers' arguments, the main issue to be decided is whether the N.F.L. unreasonably restrained trade by keeping the Raiders from honoring an agreement to move to the Los Angeles Coliseum in 1980.

title: XEROX NET IS UP 7.5%
description: The Xerox Corporation reported a 7.5 percent rise in earnings for the second quarter on a 10.1 percent increase in revenues. The company said that its earnings in the first half were reduced substantially by currency exchange rates but that the decline was offset by a lower effective tax rate overseas.

title: THE DANCE: KAZUO OHNO
description: year-old pioneer of Japanese avant-garde dance, is now at LaMama E.T.C., appearing in two alternating, full-evening solos that mark his American debut. His performance on Wednesday of ''Admiring La Argentina'' never failed to fascinate, though probably not always as Mr. Ohno intended.

title: REAGAN'S STATEMENT ON IMMIGRATION
description: Following is the text of a statement by President Reagan today on immigration: Our nation is a nation of immigrants. More than any other country, our strength comes from our own immigrant heritage and our capacity to welcome those from other lands. No free and prosperous nation can by itself accommodate all those who seek a better life or flee persecution. We must share this responsibility with other countries.

title: SENATE ENDORSES U.N. STAND ON TERRORISM WITH HOSTAGES
description: The Senate voted today to endorse a United Nations call for tough measures against international terrorists who commit acts in which hostages are taken.

title: JAMES F. O'NEIL, 84, PUBLISHED MAGAZINE OF AMERICAN LEGION
description: James F. O'Neil, a past national commander of the American Legion and publisher of the American Legion Magazine for 28 years until his retirement in 1978, died Tuesday of a heart attack at New York Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: IMPERIAL'S TEXAS UNIT BEING SOLD
description: The Imperial Corporation of America, a multistate savings and loan association, said its directors have approved a plan to spin off to shareholders all stock in a Texas subsidiary, the Gibraltar Savings Association.

title: PITTSTON CITES LOSS
description: Nabisco Brands Inc., formed this month by the merger of Nabisco Inc. and Standard Brands Inc., reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1981 edged up 1.2 percent, while sales increased 7.7 percent.

title: NEW POLICE UNIT TO BATTLE DRUGS IN PUBLIC PLACES
description: Starting Monday, 100 police officers will be assigned to a new program to arrest those who sell or use narcotics on New York City's streets and in parks, playgrounds and schoolyards, the Police Commissioner said yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Wine Talk column in The Living Section on Wednesday listed an erroneous price provided by the Italian Trade Commission for one bottle mentioned. The price, for Conterno Barolo Riserva 1969, should have been $17.59.

title: Charlie Jenkins Faces a New Challenge
description: For some time after the death March 23 of James F. (Jumbo) Elliott, there was considerable speculation on this bucolic, suburban Philadelphia campus that Elliott, the almost-legendary Villanova University track coach, would be succeeded by his oldest son, James Jr.

title: News Analysis
description: Concern about the adverse impact of a prolonged inquiry on the morale and stability of the Central Intelligence Agency played a major role in the Senate Intelligence Committee's finding that William J. Casey is not unfit to continue as Director of Central Intelligence, according to committee members.

title: CONFLICTS EMERGING IN NIGERIA'S 21-MONTH CIVIL REGIME
description: A crowd went on a rampage here two weeks ago, burning down the state radio station, the assembly building and other institutions and setting fire to half the state's files. At least two people were killed, and the damage was estimated at $300 million.

title: HONDA WILL REPAIR FENDERS THAT RUSTED ON '75-'78 CARS
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced today that the American Honda Motor Company had agreed to repair the prematurely rusted fenders of 1975 to 1978 Honda automobiles or reimburse their owners.

title: France Suspends Work On Five Nuclear Plants
description: The French Government announced today that it had temporarily suspended work on five nuclear plants pending further debate on nuclear energy.

title: S.E.C. ACTS ON FILING METHODS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed major changes in the way the nation's 9,000 public companies register securities and report their financial activities to the Government.

title: Business People; WASHINGTON POST CO. PICKS A PRESIDENT
description: Richard D. Simmons, 46, a lawyer and vice chairman of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Washington Post Company, effective Sept.3. In addition to The Washington Post, the corporation owns two other newspapers, Newsweek magazine, four broadcasting stations and a 30 percent interest in The International Herald Tribune.

title: CULINARY SCHOOL DINING, A HYDE PARK ADVENTURE
description: YOUR waitress may get 10 demerits for spilling water as she pours it, and the student-captain may earn an A for the way he bones the fish, but whatever the grades turn out to be, lunch or dinner in the classroom restaurants of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., is bound to be an entertaining, revealing and generally satisfying experience. Formerly a Jesuit seminary, the handsome building that houses the classrooms and teaching kitchens is set in a rolling garden-park with pleasant walks and ample parking space.

title: BOTH PRICES AND TAXES INCREASED IN ZIMBABWE
