description: The Zimbabwe Government today increased prices of consumer goods and raised taxes across the board.

title: Energy Watch
The City; 4 HELD IN HOLDUPS OF 14 BRONX BANKS
description: Four Bronx men were arrested and accused of robbing at least 14 banks in the borough since mid-March. The Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed the arrests and said the four men would be arraigned on bank robbery charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: BIBLE IN BLOOM AT ST. JOHN THE DIVINE
description: When Adam and Eve realized they were naked, they covered their nakedness with fig leaves. Noah knew the flood waters had subsided when the dove returned to the ark with an olive leaf. Moses heard the Lord calling to him out of the burning bush, and Jesus spent the night before his crucifixion at the foot of the Mount of Olives.

title: Bridge: 151 Teams Dwindle to 64 In the Spingold Knockout
description: The Spingold Knockout Team Championship resumed here today at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals with 64 teams surviving from a field of 151.

title: Executives
description: * AMCA International, Hanover, N.H., has formed a new marine division and appointed Peter J. Gwyn the division's president.

title: FORD SALES ABROAD STABLE DURING HALF
description: The Ford Motor Company said its overseas affiliates sold 1,096,700 cars and trucks during the first six months of 1981, only 300 fewer vehicles than during the first half of 1980.

title: 65,000 CONRAIL COMMUTERS DELAYED BY A BLAZE IN BRONX
description: A three-alarm fire in the Bronx halted service on Conrail's Harlem and New Haven Divisions for more than an hour yesterday afternoon, delaying 65,000 commuters on the two lines though the homebound rush for up to 75 minutes.

title: CABARET: SHARON MCNIGHT ASSORTMENT
description: SHARON McNIGHT is a singer who is moving in an oddly assorted set of directions. Miss McNight, who was at the Duplex, 55 Grove Street, on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, is a jovial, semi-tough, bleached blonde with a heart-shaped face, a pink-and-white complexion and a voice that could penetrate the hubbub of any frontier saloon. Most of her songs are either country-and-western standards - ''Stand By Your Man,'' ''You Belong to Me'' -or songs of her own such as ''Bright Lights and Lonely Nights'' and ''Put a Nickel in the Juke Box and Bring Back Patti Page,'' that lend themselves to a countryand-western delivery.

title: SALLY KELLERMAN IN SONG AND GAGS
description: Sally Kellerman, the actress and singer who is appearing at Marty's through Aug. 8, has a musical career that's a history of pratfalls and false starts. So in her act at Marty's, she has turned her saga into an engaging mixture of music and self-effacing comedy, using such standards as ''Lush Life'' and ''He's Funny That Way'' to illustrate her autobiography.

title: Berrigans, 6 Others Granted Bail in Break-In Convictions
description: A three-judge State Superior Court panel granted bail today for the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, his brother, Philip, and six others.

title: GAMBIA RADIO SAYS PRESIDENT, IN BRITAIN, IS OUSTED
description: President Dawda Kairaba Jawara of the West African nation of Gambia was overthrown in a leftist coup today while he was visiting Britain for the royal wedding, Gambia radio reported.

title: A PRISON IS 'HOME' TO BABIES
description: Inmates of the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, the state's prison for women, had just returned to their rooms for a head count when a chorus of persistent cries rang out from down the corridor. Within minutes, regulations were eased to allow some of the women out of their rooms to quiet the disturbance.

title: PUBLISHING: CALLAS BOOK STIRS DISPUTE
description: AT least two music critics and the authors of two earlier biographies about Maria Callas, the tempestuous singer who died in 1977, have charged that parts of a recent best-selling biography, ''Maria Callas'' by Arianna Stassinopoulos, have been taken directly from those earlier biographies - a charge that Miss Stassinopoulos and her publisher, Simon & Schuster, vehemently deny.

title: A 'HARD WORKER' SET FOR CITY BUDGET CHALLENGE
description: Mayor Koch telephoned Alair Anne Townsend in Washington at 7:45 yesterday morning to tell her that he wanted her as his Budget Director.

title: PURCHASE OF WATER FROM OTHER SOURCES IS HALTED IN NEWARK
description: The city of Newark stopped purchasing water from outside suppliers today, a day after lifting restrictions on water consumption imposed when the pipeline serving the city was vandalized.

title: 'FRAGILE X' CHROMOSOME FOUND TO CAUSE RETARDATION IN BOYS
description: All male children who suffer from mental retardation of unknown cause should be tested for a condition known as ''fragile X,'' a scientist said at a genetics meeting here today. Mothers could then know whether any future sons might also be subject to the serious abnormality.

title: CAREY SIGNS BILL DESIGNED TO AID CARE FOR PARENTS
description: Governor Carey announced today that he had signed a bill designed to assist New Yorkers who take care of their elderly parents at home.

title: Advertising; E.S.P.N. DEVISES PLAN TO SHARE AD REVENUES
description: As an inducement to get those of its cable-system affiliates that don't use their service on an all-day basis, the management of the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network has evolved a plan to share its advertising revenues. Twice a year, beginning in January, it will pay operators 5 cents for each one of their certified subscriber households.

title: DOW ADVANCES 7.71 TO FINISH AT 945.11
description: The stock market greeted President Reagan's tax-bill victory in Congress with a moderate advance yesterday. For the first time in five sessions, volume exceeded 40 million shares. It expanded to 41.6 million shares from Wednesday's 37.6 million.

title: Hungarians make Stallone U.S. booster.
description: AFTER shooting ''Victory,'' which opens today, Sylvester Stallone came home from Hungary a flag waver. He says if everybody had to spend two weeks in a Communist country, ''patriotism in America would reach epidemic proportions.''

title: The Region; PRESERVE ON L.I. TO BE SPRAYED
description: The Federal Government has agreed to spray the 140-acre National Seatuck Wildlife Preserve in Islip, L.I., in an effort to rid the marshland of mosquitoes, according to the office of Representative Thomas J. Downey of Long Island.

title: POLISH FOOD SHORTAGE SPURS NEW UNREST
description: Demonstrations and strike calls increased in Poland today as the independent labor organization attempted to channel popular anger against food shortages and meat-ration cuts.

title: The City; WORKERS PROTEST AT CITY OFFICES
description: About 100 minority construction workers demonstrated outside the offices of the City Department of Housing Preservation and Development to protest the end of a minority hiring program.

title: CONRAIL IN BLACK FOR QUARTER
description: Conrail today reported net income of $13.8 million for the second quarter ended June 30 - only the second quarterly profit in the Government-chartered railroad's five-year existence. Conrail lost $48.3 million in the period last year.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, JULY 31, 1981; The Economy
description: Congressional leaders said the $36 billion budget-cut package would be completed this week. But House Democratic leaders threatened to stymie the bill if Republicans did not restore the $122-a-month minimum benefit for Social Security recipients. (Page A1.)

title: Business People; PRESIDENT NAMED BY MCGRAW-HILL
description: Joseph L. Dionne, 48 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of McGraw-Hill Inc. He succeeds Harold W. McGraw Jr., 63, who remains chairman and chief executive officer of the big New York publishing house.

title: Price of prints is on the rise.
description: PRINTS at auction commanded increasingly higher prices this season, especially for the works of Americans such as Edward Hopper and Thomas Hart Benton and Europeans such as Matisse and Picasso. Christie's total sales rose 19 percent to $2.8 million, from $1.9 million. But at Sotheby Park Bernet, after several seasons of dramatic increases in print sales, both the volume and sales total were off - the number of items presented for bidding was 4,300, a decrease of about 500, and the sales declined to to $9.7 million, a drop of almost $1 million. Before that, over a three-year period, sales had more than doubled annually, from $2.5 million in 1977-78 to $5.1 million in 1978-79 to $10.6 million last season.

title: NEW-HOME SALES DROP
description: Sales of new single-family homes plunged 17.2 percent in June, to the lowest level since the bottom of last year's recession, the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development reported yesterday.

title: Advertising; BBDO'S LARGEST ACQUISITION
description: LOCKE ADVERTISING, a 68-year-old Dallas-based ad agency with $122 million in billings, is about to become the largest acquisition of BBDO International, the world's eighth-largest agency.

title: Helen Keller story to continue in new play by Gibson.
description: THE gripping story of Helen Keller and her teacher, Annie Sullivan, which William Gibson dramatized in ''The Miracle Worker,'' will continue in Mr. Gibson's latest play, ''Monday After the Miracle.'' It will open on Broadway shortly after the first of the year. Arthur Penn, who staged the acclaimed 1959 Broadway production of ''The Miracle Worker,'' starring Anne Bancroft as Annie Sullivan and Pattie Duke as Helen Keller, will be the director. There is no cast yet, but Mr. Gibson met with Ellen Burstyn this week to discuss the Annie Sullivan role. The producers are Mr. Penn and Raymond Katz and Sandy Gallin, producers of the ''Donny and Marie'' television series.

title: The City; HEROIN SMUGGLER GIVEN 24 YEARS
description: The leader of a heroin smuggling ring was sentenced by a Federal judge in Brooklyn to 24 years for his drug-trafficking activities. The man, 24-year-old Craig Richard Clymore, of Laguna Hills, Calif., pleaded guilty on June 11. Mr. Clymore, who was a passenger on a Pakistani jetliner that was hijacked last March, could have gotten 30 years.

title: POTENTIAL TROUBLE SPOTS FOR SUMMER TRAFFIC
description: A. Palisades Interstate Parkway: Guide rail installation will cause intermittent lane closings just north of New York State Thruway. B.

title: OPERA: 'RAKE'S PROGRESS' AND SANTA FE MYSTIQUE
description: When John Crosby decided 25 years ago to plant an opera company here in the land of the yucca bush and the pinto bean, there could not have been many people in the music world who gave his horticultural efforts much of a chance. It seemed about as promising as setting out a rose garden in a crater of the moon. But his Santa Fe Opera has not only survived to celebrate its silver anniversary this season; it has also thrived to the point where it now serves as a standard of operatic quality in many respects for American companies of whatever magnitude of ambition or annual budget.

title: No Headline
description: Negotiators for baseball's players and club owners were said early this morning to be on the verge of settling their dispute and ending the seven-week-old strike.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks thar are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A Man Of Respect
description: After describing how he ran the California Assembly, Speaker Willie Brown of San Francisco was asked at a panel discussion at the National Conference of State Legislatures what he thought was Speaker Tip O'Neill's biggest problem in managing the House of Representatives.

title: F.C.C. BACKS CABLE DEAL
description: The Federal Communications Commission today approved the acquisition of the Teleprompter Corporation by the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, a $600 million deal involving the nation's No.2 cable operator.

title: ISRAELIS, STARTLED BY U.S. ANGER AT BEIRUT RAID, FEEL TRUCE SHOWS GOOD WILL
description: In the aftermath of Israel's air attack on Beirut and the strain it brought to Israeli-American relations, Government officials in Jerusalem are hoping that their adherence to the Lebanon cease-fire arrangement will be seen in Washington as a gesture of good will to American interests.

title: No Headline
description: Top-seeded Jimmy Connors, seeking to capture this event for the fourth time, beat unseeded Vince Van Patten, 6-0, 6-4, today in the second round of the $200,000 Volvo International tournament.

title: Notes on People; DEDICATION
description: To honor his Indian guru, Sri Chinmoy, Ashrita Furman, a stationery store manager in Queens, hoped to set a world record by embarking on a continuous 50-hour standing ovation.

title: HANCOCK'S 68 LEADS BY SHOT IN CANADA
description: Nineteen of the 20 leaders of the PGA Tour were in the field of 156 as the 72d Canadian Open began today, but few of them graced the leader boards.

title: Title Bout Set Sept. 25
description: The World Boxing Council light-heavyweight champion, Matthew Saad Muhammad, will defend his title Sept. 25 against Jerry Martin, the No. 3-ranked challenger. The site of the bout has not been selected, said the promoter, Murad Muhammad of Newark. Muhammad, 32-3-2 with 22 knockouts, has defended his title seven times since taking the crown from Marvin Johnson in 1979.

title: HAIG SAYS SOVIET ARMS SHIPMENTS TO CUBA HAVE INCREASED SHARPLY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., said today that Soviet arms shipments to Cuba had increased sharply in the last seven months. He added that there was ''solid evidence'' that some of the increased deliveries were being reshipped to Central America.

title: MARCELLA R. LAWLER
description: Marcella Rita Lawler, former professor of education at Teachers College of Columbia University, died Monday at her home in San Diego.

title: Chris-Craft Considering Buying Washington Star
description: Chris-Craft Industries of New York said tonight it was considering buying The Washington Star, but the purchase would reportedly be linked to approval by Congress of a special tax break for the company.

title: Notes on People; TOUGH BET TO WIN
description: Bob Hope lost a hat one year, and over the years so have Bing Crosby, Jack Dempsey and Johnny Carson. That, to be sure, puts this year's loser, Joe DeNardo, in good company, but Mr. DeNardo is supposed to be an expert.

title: About Real Estate; REAL ESTATE HEIR DEVELOPS LUXURY ON SUFFOLK FARM
description: At the age of 5, Stanley J. Harte Jr. spelled ''amortization'' correctly in a spelling bee. When he was challenged to explain the meaning, he obliged.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Alaska Airlines Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 1.5 million shares of common stock, to be sold by a Drexel Burnham Lambert group.

title: MITSUI AND IRAN CONCLUDE TALKS
description: Officials of Japan's huge Mitsui Industrial Group and the Iranian Government ended three days of talks in Teheran yesterday, unable to agree on a way to revive their troubled multimillion-dollar petrochemical complex at Bandar Khomeini in southern Iran.

title: German Rider Is First
description: Paul Schockemohle, West Germany's top rider, was a winner today as the Hickstead Nations Cup equestrian international meeting opened.

title: ABDUL-JABBAR SAID TO WANT TO PLAY HERE
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar has notified the Los Angeles Lakers that he would like to be traded immediately to either the New York Knicks or New Jersey Nets, according to a source close to the situation.

title: IRANIAN QUAKE LEFT 8,000 DEAD, U.N. AGENCY SAYS
description: An earthquake that struck southeastern Iran Tuesday evening killed at least 8,000 people, a spokesman for the Geneva-based United Nations Disaster Relief Agency said here today.

title: The City; DETECTIVE CHIEF IS DISCIPLINED
description: The commander of the Midtown South Precinct detective squad was transferred to a uniformed post in Brooklyn yesterday at a loss in salary for failing to exercise proper supervision, Police Department officials said.

title: DEMOCRATS TRY ANEW ON PENSIONS
description: President Reagan, exulting in his triumph yesterday when Congress approved his tax-cutting package, declared today that the United States now had ''an economic plan for her future'' that he hoped would lead to a further, historic reduction in the role and functions of the Federal Government.

title: Hunger Striker Lapses Into a Coma in Ulster
description: Kevin Lynch, a jailed Irish nationalist, lapsed into unconsciousness on the 69th day of a hunger strike today as he and seven other prisoners continued protest fasts for political status.

title: MOODY'S CUTS FORD UNIT'S RATING
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday lowered its rating on the Ford Motor Credit Company's commercial paper to P-2, its middle rating, from P-1, the highest.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Angola Reports Invasion, By South Africa Troops

title: Guild Hall Star Party
description: Guild Hall in East Hampton, L.I., is celebrating its 50th anniversary Sunday night at 8:30 with a revue called ''The Night of Stars.''

title: BLOCK GRANTS ARE A TRAP
description: With the exception of a few representatives of the country's large urban areas, the Reagan Adminstration's proposal to take dozens of specific Federal aid programs for social services, education, and health, and group them into a lump payment to states and localities as block grants has been warmly embraced by state, county, and municipal officials. It is easy to see why.

title: A PUBLISHING EXECUTIVE
description: Arnold D. Friedman, chairman and co-founder of Lebhar-Friedman Inc., publishers of business and trade newspapers, died Wednesday at his summer home in East Hampton, L.I. Mr. Friedman, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 81 years old.

title: The City; REGIONAL CHIEF NAMED BY H.U.D.
description: Joseph D. Monticciolo of Woodbury, L.I., a 43-year-old career civil servant, has been named regional administrator of the Department of Housing and Urban Development by Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr.

title: A PARTY GIVEN IN THE SPIRIT OF STYLISH YOUNG WOMEN
description: Oscar, Geoffrey and Calvin weren't there, but Tommy, Betsey and Lester were. It was a party for Saks Fifth Avenue's new fifth floor, which is aimed at the contemporary young woman, and the designers present weren't the usual household names but the ones who design for her.

title: Helsinki Rights, Soviet Wrongs
description: A circle has been cruelly closed in Moscow with the recent furtive trial of Feliks Serebrov. A 50-year-old factory worker, he is the last active member of a group that monitored the grotesque abuse of Soviet psychiatry for political purposes. Mr. Serebrov was charged with ''anti-Soviet agitation'' and now faces four years of hard labor and five more of internal exile. That brings to 47 the number of Helsinki monitors imprisoned by the Soviet Union. In Czechoslovakia, the most slavish of satellites, 16 monitors are in jail and 10 more await trial.

title: MRS. GANDHI UNDER FIRE FOR IMPORTING WHEAT
description: Despite claims of a record harvest, the Indian Government purchased foreign wheat for the first time in four years this month, buying a million and a half tons from private traders in the United States.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 31, 1981
description: International Reduced military spending by Bonn is likely under an outline for the next budget approved by the Cabinet. Military spending is to increase by 4.2 percent, but the inflation rate in West Germany is projected to be 5 to 6 percent. Thus, the real change could be a reduction of as much as 1.8 percent. The Government attributed the spending cuts to high interest rates in the United States. (Page A1, Column 1.) An earthquake that struck Iran Tuesday night killed at least 8,000 people, according to the United Nations Disaster Relief Agency. Ayatollah Khomeini, the revolutionary leader, termed the disaster in a southeastern province a ''test sent by God.'' (A3:2-5.)

title: A Little Secret
description: There we were, we panda fans, our eyes fixed on Washington's National Zoo and last spring's unfortunate menage a trois: Ling-Ling, Chia-Chia and Hsing-Hsing. We hoped for progeny; what we got was the spectacle of one female (L-L) being brutalized by one male (C-C) and ignored by the other (H-H).

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt FALSE WITNESS. By Dorothy Uhnak. 314 pages. Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: WHITE HOUSE ASKS A LAW TO BAR JOBS FOR ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: The Reagan Administration announced its long-awaited immigration policy today, asking Congress to outlaw the employment of illegal aliens and fine employers for violations, and suggesting an experimental program admitting ''guest workers'' from Mexico.

title: Indonesia in Katonah
description: The art of Indonesian textile weaving and dyeing is demonstrated in an exhibition of ritual garments from the late 19th century at the Katonah Gallery, 28 Bedford Road, Katonah, N.Y. Represented are 30 examples from the islands of Sulawesi, Sumatra, Flores, Roti, Java, Sumba, Savu and Timor, in addition to Malaysia and Indonesian Borneo.
